title: Bah, Humbug
description: To the Editor:

title: Chilean Military Vows to Try To Halt Trials of Journalists
description: Chile's military Government said Friday that it would seek to put a rapid end to the trials of about 40 journalists who face charges before military and other courts.

title: POSTINGS: 46 Stories on East 88th; High There, New Neighbor!
description: The apartment building that General Atlantic Realty is erecting on the former site of the Children's Aid Society will be tall. Not Twin Tower tall, not even Trump Tower tall, but its 46 stories will make it a giant for the southwest corner of the 88th Street-First Avenue intersection.

title: Busy Hands In Different Ways
description: Poor Mrs. Tilley (''Model's Success Is in Her Hands,'' Nov. 27).

title: Brown-Bagging It to Buckingham
description: MY INTENTION WAS TO become a great novelist, not a foreign correspondent, so naturally I never expected to end up in Westminster Abbey covering the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: FICTION
description: SNOWSTORMS IN A HOT CLIMATE. By Sarah Dunant. (Random House, $15.95.) First published in Great Britain, this psychological thriller travels well. While American readers may not find the settings - cramped, gritty New York City and the vast, sparkling California coast, among others - particularly exotic, they will find the writing refreshingly economical and astute. Witness, for example, this nice moment during a trans-Atlantic flight: ''On the aisle seat a corn-fed American in a checked jacket was already settled into a Mickey Spillane. He grunted as I squeezed past him. A man in tune with his fiction. There would be violence before I returned.'' The narrator, Marla, is a bored Oxford professor who travels to New York at the behest of her best friend, Elly. Upon her arrival, Marla learns that Elly has become hopelessly enmeshed in the affairs of an impossibly handsome, enigmatic cocaine dealer named Lenny, who's an amateur historian and is said to have killed a woman. As Marla tries to rescue Elly from an inevitable downfall, she finds that she too has become caught in a complex web of emotions: friendship, romance, curiosity, jealousy and revenge. Although it has its share of violence, ''Snowstorms in a Hot Climate'' is no Spillane; written from a feminist perspective, this first novel is intelligent and rarely predictable. But Ms. Dunant, a British television and radio producer and commentator, needs to fine-tune her fiction; she relies too heavily on secondhand storytelling to advance her plot. That's unfortunate, because the few scenes that do have ''live'' action - including a climax on a bridge high above a Scottish gorge - are truly breathtaking.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MIND. By Richard M. Restak. (Bantam, $29.95.) While philosophers throughout the ages have used logic to shed light on the conundrum of consciousness, an army of neuroscientists and cognitive psychologists around the world is now using far different tools to find out exactly what it is that makes us uniquely human.

title: Inwood Seeks Ban On Zoning Exceptions
description: LEAD: FOR the last few years, residents of Inwood have been trying to hold back spot zoning, which has been creeping along a residential strip near the Queens border in southwest Nassau County.

title: U.S. Bank Board Adds Nine More Troubled Savings and Loans to Its Pile of Bailouts
description: Closing out the year with a rapid-fire series of savings and loan bailouts, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced nine transactions today and late Friday that will require the Government to inject more than $5.8 billion of assistance over the next 10 years.

title: What's In, What's Out, What's What; People
description: Celebrities bewitch us with fantasies of glamour, wealth and fame. Their scandals tittilate; their excesses stupify. Who's in and who's out for the new year?

title:
What's In, What's Out, What's What;
Chow
description: LEAD: Cabbage and caviar are regaining their popularity now that there is a thaw in our relations with the Soviet Union. Only rarely do we eat the food of unfriendly nations.

title: THE ODDS ARE YOU'RE INNUMERATE
description: Innumeracy, the mathematical analogue of functional illiteracy, afflicts far too many literate people, even widely read and articulate men and women who might cringe if words such as ''imply'' and ''infer'' were confused. They generally react without a trace of embarrassment, however, to even the most egregious numerical solecisms. Once I was at a gathering of writers in which much was being made of the difference between ''continually'' and ''continuously.'' Later that evening, as we were watching the news (another measure of how enjoyable the occasion was), the television meteorologist announced that there was a 50 percent chance of rain for Saturday and a 50 percent chance for Sunday as well, and concluded that there was therefore a 100 percent chance of rain that weekend. I grant the mistake was not hilarious, but no one even smiled.

title: PINS Laws Don't Make Sense
description: In ''Letters to the Long Island Editor'' (Oct. 30), I read letters concerning the PINS laws. As I understand it, a child 16 or older cannot be forced to live at home or attend counseling or therapy program regardless of where or how the child is living. Yet, the parents of this child are financially responsible for it until said child reaches 21. The lobbying group Parents on the Move would like to see this ''independent'' age raised from 16 to 18 and the ''financially responsible'' age changed from 21 to 18.

title: I.B.M.'s New System Is Put to a Test
description: You have been a good customer at the bank for 10 years, and now you want to apply for a mortgage. There are forms galore. Taking pen in hand you scribble answers to questions about your credit history, questions that the bank has asked many times before. A half-hour later the loan officer shakes your hand and says you will get an answer in three to four weeks.

title: 40,2>Hispanic Groups Seek A Voice in Perth Amboy
description: NEARLY seven months after the shooting death of a Mexican immigrant and the wounding of his brother by an off-duty police detective here, a quiet revolution is taking place in this city of 42,000 people. Hispanic residents are beginning to organize and demand a voice in government, police affairs and even the naming of streets that is more in line with their numbers, which account for at least 40 percent of the population.

title: 'HERE I AM, BLACK AS YOU SEE ME'
description: BALM IN GILEAD Journey of a Healer. By Sara Lawrence Lightfoot. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: A Merloyd Lawrence Book/ Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: The Whitney Today: Fashionable to a Fault
description: In an art world ever more eager to share the glamour of rock music, the swagger of big business and the seasonal values of fashion, the new has become increasingly hard to resist. Among many contemporary artists, critics, collectors and dealers, there is an unending search for art that is of the moment, that partakes of the spirit of the age, that leads to the heart of the Zeitgeist. Some critics and collectors crave the new so badly that when they cannot find it they barely know what art to look at and speak about.

title: Potpourri
description: If there is one common thread that promises to run through this year's fashion, it is constantly increasing prices. Aside from that, the looks and directions will be diffuse. Here are just a few examples.

title: NONFICTION
description: UNDERCOVER: The Secret Lives of a Federal Agent. By Donald Goddard. (Times Books, $19.95.) Michael Levine was a big, tough, streetwise kid from the Bronx. With a penchant for settling arguments with his fists, he could easily have found a permanent home in one of New York's finer penal institutions. Instead, thanks to a brochure extolling the virtues of ''A Career in U.S. Treasury Law Enforcement,'' his life took a more positive turn. In ''Undercover,'' Donald Goddard - the author of ''Joey,'' a biography of the Mafia chieftain Joey Gallo - recounts the life Mr. Levine led as an agent for various Federal departments, including the Drug Enforcement Agency. With a chameleonlike talent for assuming various identities, Mr. Levine was able to rack up a very impressive arrest record throughout the pre-crack era of the 1960's and 70's. Using specific cases, Mr. Goddard weaves an exciting account of one agent's obsessive fight against drug traffickers. And wisely, he does not neglect the toll taken on the personal life of Michael Levine: a failed marriage and the drug dependency of his own brother. Mr. Goddard handles the various drug operations with clarity, which is not easy given the often intricate connections that mark these ''buy and bust'' operations. However, after a time the cumulative effect and sheer number of these tales are numbing, and it becomes frighteningly apparent that the fight against drugs, as we have been conducting it, is futile.

title: CRUSADER ON THE BEACH
description: In 1952, while my Marine Corps husband was stationed at Camp Lejeune, N.C., we stayed on Topsail Island while waiting for military housing (''Crusader on the Beach,'' by Barnard L. Collier, Dec. 4). The wait ended in September, about a week before the water of the sound met the water of the ocean in the middle of the island during a hurricane. Viewing the destruction that followed, we made a resolve never to own property on an ocean beach.

title: Going Home Again: But Where Is 'Home'?
description: MY parents moved to Long Island in the spring of 1960. With little deliberation, they rented a house in Commack.

title: A June Wedding for Susan Lierle And G. W. Birrell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Burton Lierle of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Buchanan Lierle, to G. William Birrell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Andrew Birrell of Greenwich, Conn., and Wilmington, N.C. The couple plan to wed in June.

title: Taking the Pulse of New American Architecture
description: In some ways Minneapolis at this moment may be the best place in which to ponder the essence of Los Angeles. No, it is not a matter of using sub-zero weather to instill a proper respect for palm trees and smog, but the fact that the Walker Art Center here, just two years after initiating a magnificent retrospective of the work of Los Angeles's pre-eminent architect, Frank Gehry, has now mounted an exhibition of the work of Franklin D. Israel, a young Los Angeles architect of unusual talent. And next spring the Walker plans to open a third exhibition that will relate closely to Los Angeles, a look at the work of Morphosis, a firm of young Los Angeles-based architects whose work exemplifies the city's current architectural impulses.

title: Jean Quinn Married to Dr. R. M. Alley
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Albany, Jean Quinn, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Brian O'Malley Quinn of Albany, was married yesterday to Dr. R. Maxwell Alley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Alley of Loudonville, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Tartaglia performed the ceremony.

title: When It Is Important to Be the First
description: ANY hobbyist can be a No. 1 collector, and today would be a good day to start planning. The reference, of course, is to the first stamps issued by each postal authority. Such a collection is a popular area and, with imagination, need not be expensive.

title:
FOCUS: PITTSFIELD, MASS.;
G.E. Building a House to Show Off Plastics' Potential
description: LEAD: As producers of plastics try to expand their role in construction and housing, one major manufacturer, the General Electric Company, is building a ''house of the future'' here to showcase its possibilities.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
At-Cost Custom Design to Clinch the Sale
description: LEAD: AT Carriage Townhomes, a development of 44 two- and three-bedroom town houses under construction in Elmont, Maxwell Krieger and his sons, Steven and Robert, are following a strategy that they had in mind when they bought the three-acre property six months ago.

title: Budd Has No Regrets
description: Although she said she would like to run again for Britain, Zola Budd, the world-class middle-distance runner, said she would never denounce apartheid despite pressure from opponents of the racial-separation laws of her native South Africa.

title: Donna Gresser Wed To James Harper Jr.
description: Donna Lee Gresser and James Lovett Harper Jr., 1983 graduates of Lawrence University, were married yesterday at Headquarters Plaza in Morristown, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi F. Dworkin and the Rev. James Harper, the father of the bridegroom, who is also the rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Bonita Springs, Fla.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
description: In the 1980's has anyone been able to carry such an average team to such a lofty accomplishment as Orel Hershiser did in '88? DAVID J. EDELSTEIN New York

title:
MUSIC;
Mintz to Open Orchestra's New Year
description: LEAD: THE renowned violinist Shlomo Mintz has been playing the violin for nearly 27 of his 31 years. He considers the process of performing ''a continual evolution.''

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Durham, N.C.; Adieu, Tobacco, Hello Drugs
description: THIS city, which has been looking for a new economic base since the tobacco industry began dying out some 20 years ago, seems to have struck gold.

title: In Alleys of Nablus, Yes to Talks, Yes to Resisting
description: Deep in the narrow, twisting stone alleys of the casbah, the local underground leader of the intifada, the Palestinian uprising, had little hesitation when asked what he thought of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recent moves to recognize Israel, renounce terrorism and begin talks with the United States.

title: Readers Speak Out on N.F.L. Parity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 3 Die in Explosion at Brazilian Diplomat's House
description: Three teen-agers were killed and another youth was critically injured today in a garage explosion at the home of a Brazilian Embassy employee, the police said.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Converting a Warehouse; Factory Outlet Plan in Chelsea Gives Way to Office
description: AFTER several years of trying to allay community opposition, a development team is abandoning efforts to turn a Manhattan warehouse on the Chelsea waterfront into an enormous factory-outlet shopping center - opting instead for 500,000 square feet of new office space.

title: 3 Held in Dispute Over Care for Jehovah's Witness
description: Three people were arrested Friday evening at a Suffolk County hospital when a group of Jehovah's Witnesses sought to prevent a critically ill member of their group from receiving a blood transfusion, the police said.

title:
ART;
Bold Ideas a Century Ago
description: LEAD: IN most art history texts, the Nabis rate a short entry or perhaps only a parenthetical mention. ''The Nabis and the Parisian Avant-Garde'' at the Zimmerli Museum at Rutgers University seeks to elevate their status and does a convincing job of it, as 180 drawings, prints and watercolors tell in depth about the revolutionary art movement that began in

title: THE ONE WHO CAN'T GET SICK
description: HIDDEN ILLNESS IN THE WHITE HOUSE By Kenneth R. Crispell and Carlos F. Gomez. Foreword by Birch Bayh. Illustrated. 267 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. $27.50.

title: Review/Opera; 'Fledermaus' in First Appearance of Met Season
description: When we confuse weight with significance, we cloud our judgment of comedy. By most thinking, for example, ''Parsifal'' must be greater art than ''Die Fledermaus'' because its themes of suffering and redemption sit more heavily on our consciousness. One must admit, moreover, that ''Die Fledermaus'' - which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night - is not serious at all.

title:
INVESTING;
Prospering As Others Struggle
description: LEAD: Restaurant companies face a difficult market. With shopping malls and roadside strips jammed with food outlets, competition has become ferocious. Though the McDonald's Corporation remains a powerhouse and a favorite of securities analysts, most other big national chains have struggled. Companies like the Pillsbury Company's Burger King unit and Wendy's International Inc.

title: Julian Sebastian Bell To Marry Justin Day
description: Justin Chappell Day, an associate director of the Industrial Bank of Japan International Ltd., and Julian Sebastian Bell, a manager of international stockbroking at SG Warburg & Company Ltd., both in London, are planning a spring wedding.

title: Elizabeth Barlow Marries Robert Dodge
description: Ann Elizabeth Barlow, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Stanley Barlow of Leonia, N.J., and Robert I. Dodge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Dodge 3d of McLean, Va., were married yesterday at the Palisades (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The bride's father performed the ceremony.

title: Keeping Up With Jones Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Through
description: 'I'm hoping that people will look back and say that in that difficult period, he got the ship through the storm. Maybe the captain got thrown overboard, but the ship got through.' - Paul T. Gentile, District Attorney of the Bronx, who has been in office only 14 months and is now yielding the job to Robert T. Johnson after a rancorous election campaign.

title: 'I FEEL HAPPY BECAUSE I AM A POET'
description: NICARAGUAN PEASANT POETRY FROM SOLENTINAME Translated by David Gullette. 211 pp. Albuquerque, N.M.: West End Press. Paper, $11.95.

title: Police Officer Is Slain Despite Protective Vest
description: A policeman was fatally shot through the armhole of his bulletproof vest as he tried to serve an arrest warrant, and the suspect was in critical condition today after a second shootout with the police.

title: Yousuf Karsh And the Art of Friendly Persuasion
description: It began with Winston Churchill's cigar.

title: Baseball Notebook; New Arbitration Crop Not Likely to Produce Bumper Salaries
description: A year ago the Dynamic Dozen watched their salaries soar toward the stratosphere on 24-carat dollar signs. They were young players eligible for salary arbitration for the first time, and the results of their foray were dramatic. Their collective incomes nearly tripled, climbing from $3,586,000 to $9,544,000.

title: Dear Old Golden Tour Days Don't Have to End
description: IF you are a graduate of a sizable college, you probably have been offered the chance to take a trip with academic overtones. Alumni tours are big business, often providing an opportunity to learn while you travel. But perhaps your fellow alumni aren't going where you want to go, or maybe their trip is focused on wildlife when you're more interested in archeology.

title: KNAVES IN THAILAND
description: THE PARADISE EATER By John Ralston Saul. 270 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company.

title: Leaky Reactor Pool Called Risky
description: A leaking pool of water containing highly radioactive fuel at the Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear plant could lead to a major accident, a consumer group has charged.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 18 listing placement agencies for nannies gave an incorrect telephone number for Kare for Kids in Hackensack. The agency's number is (201) 666-9539.

title: Bradshaw Mintener, 86; Helped Eisenhower in Presidential Race
description: Bradshaw Mintener, a Washington attorney and former Government official who helped in launching both Hubert H. Humphrey and Dwight D. Eisenhower into national politics, died of cancer yesterday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 86 years old and had lived in the capital since joining the Eisenhower Administration in 1954 as Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Contra Leaders Disagree on Peace Plan
description: Contra leaders, who have argued bitterly among themselves during the last year, are apparently about to split over a new peace offer that one faction is making to the Sandinista Government.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: If you are reading this, then it is probably already too late. You missed a good time. No, no. I'm not talking about last night. I expect you can recall a real good time last night. I'm talking about today, this morning, New Year's Day (National Recovery Day) - the finest morning of the year for being out and about.

title: Cuomo's Words, Shoreham Deeds
description: In attempting to ride roughshod over the New York State Legislature, Governor Cuomo and his ''court jesters'' demonstrate petulant, childish behavior when the Governor's judgment is found wanting.

title: Starting the New Year
description: Debuts at the Pierre

title: Vermont Official Urging Helmets for Skiers
description: Most of the skiing fatalities in Vermont in the last 10 years were due to head injuries and might have been prevented if the skiers had been wearing helmets, a state medical examiner says.

title: Bah, Humbug
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; How the Bills Came In From the Cold
description: At a Buffalo Bills practice not long ago, Jim Kelly tossed a pass to Ralph Wilson.

title: Jackets for the Slickest City Slickers
description: IN its latest wrinkle, the jeans jacket has dropped its good ol' boy image and gone and got itself all duded up in what might be called a bright lights, big city blue denim motif.

title: Many Metals Are Becoming Precious
description: WHEN the National Association of Business Economists reported recently that its members were pessimistic about near-term business growth and fearful that inflationary pressures were building, they confirmed something that the Quality Plumbing and Heating Company in St. Paul, Minn., had been feeling for months.

title: Coping With Egypt on Your Own
description: LEAD: EGYPT is alluring all right. Date palms, camels, the Nile and the pyramids, of course. Then there are the paintings, reliefs and monumental carvings in the tombs and temples of Pharaohs who believed in eternal life but weren't going to leave the conditions of their everlasting pleasure up to those who'd got to the next world first.

title: Sonic Youth's Chrome-Framed American Gothic
description: These aren't the most revolutionary times, and Sonic Youth, who recently released their seventh album, the double disk ''Daydream Nation'' (Enigma/Blast First 7 754003-1; all three formats), are deeply and self-consciously aware of that fact. Like other artists who have come to the realization that modernist ideas of esthetic rebellion are old-fashioned and ineffective, they've developed their own set of postures.

title: BLUES GIVE THEIR COACH A SPECIAL NIGHT
description: It was a special night for the St. Louis Blues' coach, Brian Sutter, and his players didn't want to spoil it.

title: Recalling The Needy Stirs Spirit Of Season
description: IT seems easy to feel happy during the Christmas and Hanukkah holidays. A tiny candle is lighted on a menorah and children eat chocolate coins by the handful. Christmas trees glitter and presents are placed under a tree with love. Everyone seems to be living the American dream. But I recall a week after Christmas when I realized that the dream may have missed some people during the holidays.

title:
What's In, What's Out, What's What;
Television
description: LEAD: This year is the 50th anniversary of television.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Owings Mills, Md.;
Offices on Rise In Town Center
description: LEAD: TWO brick office buildings nearing completion here have signaled a pick-up in office development in a new, rapidly growing town center.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: RESOLUTIONS? In 1989? One year before the 1990's? Eleven years before the 21st century? A dozen years before 2001? On the brink of a who-knows-what-kind of world awaits us out there, are people still making New Year's resolutions?

title:
What's In, What's Out, What's What;
Fashion
description: LEAD: The days of what's in and what's out in fashion are finally over. However, the only people not aware of this are those in the fashion press and clothing designers.

title: Correction
description: A caption today in the highlights section on page 40 of the Television section (distributed in the New York region) misstates the time and cable station for the movie ''Looking for Mr. Goodbar.'' It will be shown on Thursday on TBS at 10:35 P.M.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: REMEMBERING. By Wendell Berry. (North Point, $14.95.) The protagonist of this short novel by the poet and essayist Wendell Berry is Andrew Catlett, a Kentucky farmer and journalist who is undergoing a psychological and spiritual crisis. Speaking at an agricultural conference in the Midwest, he abandons his prepared speech and delivers an extemporaneous diatribe against the technology of contemporary farming; instead of returning home he flies to San Francisco, where he tries to sort out his anger, depression and self-doubt, deliberately plunging into ''the little hell of himself alone.

title: Not a Zero-Sum Game
description: Anything that responds to Palestinian feelings must be bad for Israel. That is the unstated premise of the new Israeli Government's condemnation of the American dialogue with the P.L.O. and of all that has followed. In other words, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is a zero-sum game, one in which any gain for one side must be an equal loss for the other.

title: Orchestras Are Playing to Their Future: Children
description: YEARS ago, many children learned about the symphony orchestra while squirming through an occasional Young People's Concert somewhere. Others were dragged to a Friday afternoon subscription concert, where the jangling of bracelets often drowned out the ringing of triangles. Either way, it was a nonparticipatory experience and often a boring one.

title: Violent Racism Attracts New Breed: Skinheads
description: There are four of them, and they dress in a manner best described as bristling: hair close-cropped, heavy boots with trousers bloused, black leather jackets and epaulets. They wear ties, and the look is neat, but a little Germanic, circa 1939. Two have earrings, but they say that is not part of the look, the skinhead look.

title: Pitching InTo Move A Library
description: SOME came because a clerk at the local supermarket had put a ''Help'' flier along with the groceries in their shopping bags. Some had read the sign on East Broad Street that carried the same message.

title: Yuli M. Daniel, a Russian Writer Tried as a Dissident, Is Dead at 63
description: Yuli M. Daniel, a Soviet dissident and satirist whose conviction in 1966 for publishing anti-Government writings abroad drew international attention, died at his home in Moscow on Friday after a stroke. He was 63 years old.

title: Chefs Hunt Up a Delicious Time in Chester
description: IN the small kitchen of the Restaurant du Village in Chester, meat juices sizzled on the stove, the air smelled of herbs, and several men were talking and laughing. And cooking.

title: Mother Is Seized in Attempt To Kill Her Children, 5 and 2
description: A Windham woman has been charged with trying to kill her two young sons in a series of incidents that took place last month, the police said.

title: Germans Accused of Helping Libya Build Nerve Gas Plant
description: The United States has concluded that a West German company played a central role in designing and constructing a huge chemical plant in Libya, a discovery that has prompted diplomatic protests to the highest levels of the Bonn Government, Administration officials say. The Administration says the plant is for producing chemical weapons, a charge denied by Libya.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Friday Night; RUTGERS STREAK ENDS IN ROUT BY LADY VOLS By IAN O'CONNOR
description: Only 10 minutes into the game with Tennessee, it was clear that the Rutgers women's basketball team was about to receive some harsh lessons it wouldn't soon forget.

title: Rona Pinkus Marries Joseph Forstadt
description: The marriage of Rona Lefkowitz Pinkus to Joseph Lawrence Forstadt took place last night at the couple's home in New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated.

title: Nintendo Fans
description: To the Editor:

title: After 40 Years, Let's Ratify U.N. Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCOCTING A FORMULA OF PAPER, TYPE AND COLORS
description: Whenever a magazine publisher and editor decide to redesign, they usually do it to keep a step ahead of the competition or to make a distinctive mark. ''One reason to redesign is when the raw materials you are using are old-fashioned,'' said Jan White, a communications design consultant based in Westport, Conn. ''Fashions in typography do change. Presentation techniques evolve. You have to stay abreast.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Americans seem to be rediscovering the Soviet Union and we are rediscovering America.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 11:1. ]

title: Irenee du Pont May Jr. Is Married To Lynn S. Ginter in Pennsylvani
description: The marriage of Lynn Shields Ginter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence U. Ginter of West Chester, Pa., to Irenee du Pont May Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. May of Greenville, Del., took place yesterday at the Cadet Chapel of the Valley Forge Military Academy in Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Dr. William D. Hess, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: 1988 Was, at Long Last, the Year of the U.N.  A String of Successes
description: Here are seven achievements of the United Nations in 1988: Afghanistan. After seven years of peace talks led by a United Nations mediator, the Soviet Union agreed on April 15 to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan by Feb. 15. But the Soviet Union and the United States have continued arming their allies in the civil war, and no political solution is in sight. Persian Gulf. On the basis of a Security Council plan, Iran and Iraq agreed to a cease-fire that went into effect Aug. 20 in their 10-year-old war. But talks aimed at achieving a final peace made little progress. Southwestern Africa. In December, South Africa, Angola and Cuba signed two agreements mediated by the United States providing for Namibian independence and a withdrawal of Cuban troops from Africa. The accord ended fighting among Angola, Cuba and South Africa, but not the Angolan civil war. Western Sahara. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar launched a peace initiative Aug. 30 to end the war for control of the Western Sahara fought by Morocco and the Algerian-backed Polisario guerrilla movement. Both sides have accepted the idea, but have not set a date for the vote. Last week, King Hassan II of Morocco agreed to meet with Polisario leaders for direct talks. Cyprus. Mr. Perez de Cuellar launched a peace initiative that secured the agreement on Aug. 24 of Greece and Turkey to hold new talks on unifying the island. The two countries have reported little progress, but the talks continue. Nobel Peace Prize. In September, the 10,000-member United Nations peacekeeping forces won the Nobel Peace Prize. Budget. On Dec. 21, the General Assembly unanimously approved a $1.76 billion budget for the years 1990 and 1991, a $22 million cut from the 1988-89 allocation. Officials said that the consensus, the first on the budget since the organization was founded in 1945, sent a message to the United States and other Western critics that the United Nations was cutting back.

title: Kathleen Daly to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. James C. Daly of Pleasantville, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Mary Daly to Joseph Alphonsus Emerson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emerson of Milton, Mass. Miss Daly, a graduate of Providence College, is studying for a master's degree in teaching at Simmons College. The future bridegroom is a lawyer with his father's law firm, Emerson & Emerson, in Milton. He graduated from Bowdoin College and the Suffolk University Law School. A July wedding is planned.

title: Medieval Festivals and Irving Berlin
description: THE tradition of serving boar as the first dish at feasts may stem from the Roman Empire. In Norman England ''the boar was the sovereign of the forests, a menace to man and a symbol of evil,'' said David Conrad of Connecticut Public Television. ''By the 12th century, the serving of the boar's head at Christmastide had become symbolic of the triumph of Christ over Satan.''

title: Planfor First Mall Divides a Town
description: SHOPPERS hunting for post-Christmas bargains are not the only ones obsessed with malls these days. A proposal to build a shopping mall on a 34-acre site in Hamden has been the subject of emotional debate among residents as local officials prepare to decide on its fate.

title: After Bills' Era of Mediocrity, Success Is Sweet for Smerlas
description: Years of frustration, second-class citizenship and a sense of anonymity will end for one of two teams today at Orchard Park, N.Y.

title: Two TV Veterans March Into the Late-Night Fray
description: Trailer 24, on the back lot of Paramount Studios, is an exciting place to work these days. The modular office block, headquarters of ''The Arsenio Hall Show,'' fairly vibrates with optimism: confident-looking executives navigate its stark corridors; lanky, black-sneakered comedy writers wisecrack happily as they shamble, in convoy, from production meeting to production meeting; the office walls of Marla Kell Brown, the show's producer, are papered on three sides with dozens of 5-by-7 index cards, each bearing the famous name - Barbara Walters, Clint Eastwood, Oprah Winfrey, etc. - of a prospective guest star.

title: Carousel Carvings on Parade
description: LEAD: A CROSS-EYED horse, a smiling pig and a hippocampus - a fanciful creature, part sea serpent, part horse - are just a few of the colorful menagerie of animals assembled for ''Carousel!'' at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle through Feb. 5.

title: Miss Egbert to Wed R. W. Brokaw 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cook Egbert of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Allison Huntting Egbert to Roberts Wyckoff Brokaw 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brokaw Jr. of Greenville, Del. The couple plan to marry next month.

title: Escape From M.I.T.
description: To the Editor:

title: Surviving the Holiday Spirit
description: MOST of us think there is something wrong with us if we don't have all the qualities espoused in the songs, television specials and advertisements of the holiday season.

title:
FOCUS: Construction Materials;
A 'House of Future' to Showcase Plastics
description: LEAD: AS producers of plastics try to expand their role in construction and housing, one major manufacturer, the General Electric Company, is building a ''house of the future'' here to showcase its possibilities.

title: Homeless Center Faces a Vote
description: NINE HUNDRED Upper East Side residents, during a bitter community board hearing last June, spent hours speaking, cheering and booing plans to open a drop-in center for homeless people in their neighborhood.

title: Singers Join in a Lament About Rising Pitch
description: Altitude may be a common metaphor for success, but not with opera singers. They are complaining with increasing stridency that international standards of pitch have broken disastrously free of their moorings and that the direction they are headed is up.

title: Health-Care Cures
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: HUDSON PARK;
When the Temperature Falls, Tough Habitues Take a Dip
description: LEAD: ROSE LEON went for a swim at Hudson Park the other day. The air and water temperature were the same: 43 degrees. It was, she explained, peeling off her parka, relatively balmy.

title: A FACE LIFT FOR A YOUNGER LOOKING SELF
description: When Anthea Disney, who is credited with the successful redesign of Us magazine, took over as editor of Self magazine in July, she planned a redesign. ''Self will be 10 years old in March 1989, and every year our reader grows up,'' said Ms. Disney.

title: U.S. TO HAVE ROLE IN SALES OF WATER
description: For most of the century the Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation has built dams for the arid West, but under a new policy, the bureau will be acting as a broker of water.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
description: The best performer in 1988 was Florence Griffith Joyner, for her three gold medals and a silver in the Seoul Olympics. MIKE WINFIELD Brooklyn

title: POSTINGS: Jersey Ski Homes; From Macs To Moguls
description: All that remains of the old apple orchard on Glenwood Road in Vernon Township stands around the sales office of the Pointe at Old Orchard Farm. Last fall the staff picked a few bushels and set them out for home shoppers to munch as they browsed.

title:
MONTCLAIR JOURNAL;
Fight to Save Ballfield Offers Lesson in Democracy
description: LEAD: IT is perhaps a sign of the times and the rapid disappearance of open space in New Jersey that residents here mounted an energetic, yearlong battle to save from development a ballfield measuring little more than an acre.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Reincarnating an 1871 Warehouse
description: LEAD: THE only warehouse designed by John McArthur Jr., the 19th-century architect who created this city's ornate City Hall, is scheduled to be reborn as part of an $11 million waterfront apartment development.

title: CRUSADER ON THE BEACH
description: I was sorry to read that Orrin Pilkey opposes the plan of the Army Corps of Engineers to save the homes on Dune Road in Westhampton Beach, L.I. His singularly financial analysis of the situation ignores the human element involved. My family, along with many others, owns a home beyond the erosion. It is currently inaccessible because of the shoreline damage. NANCY A. BUKAR Washington

title: Will Reagan's Luck Outlast Reagan?
description: Ronald Reagan, who knows something about scripts, is busily writing one of his own to guide future historians. They are likely to ignore it. His simplistic gloss does little justice to eight years full of contradiction and surprise.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: GAIL MELLOW;
'Gender Equity Isn't a Fluff Issue'
description: LEAD: SOME might believe that the issue of gender equality in education is a problem of the past, but a new report by the Connecticut Project for Equal Education Rights finds otherwise. The study, ''We Do More Than the Mandate: A Guide to Sex-Equity Activities in K-to-12 Education in Connecticut,'' lists 200 schools with courses or teaching methods that encourage gender equity.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Last-Minute Rush Of Bailout Deals
description: LEAD: A year-end rush of bailouts of savings and loan associations brought some new players into the industry. Ronald O. Perelman, the financier and chairman of Revlon Inc., led a group that will put up $315 million in a takeover of five insolvent Texas institutions with assets of $12.2 billion. The deal may prove to be the costliest ever for Federal regulators, who pledged up to $5.1 billion in assistance during the next 10 years.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. The threads on the outside filler pipe for my oil tank are worn out, so when the cover is put on it does not form a watertight seal. When it rains, water seeps in, causing the oil burner to fail. The oil company wants to put in a new pipe, but this is expensive. Is there a less expensive way to fix this?

title:
DANCE;
Kinetic Exuberance of Lubovitch
description: LEAD: THE Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will return to the state for the third time in less than a year with two performances on Jan. 9 and 10 at McCarter Theater in Princeton.

title: Long Island Interview: Ralph Donnelly; A Movie Impresario Assays Changing Tastes
description: RALPH DONNELLY of Merrick is considered one of the pre-eminent experts on the art and science of showing motion pictures. During the last 35 years he has booked films for some of the country's largest theater chains. He is the executive vice president of City Cinemas, which owns 14 movie houses in Manhattan, including Cinemas 1 and 2, the Paris Theater, the 68th Street Playhouse, the Festival Theater and the 86th Street East Twin.

title: As Neighborhood Sinks, Residents Wait to Leave
description: When hundreds of residents were told they would have to leave their houses in the Logan area of the city, the structures already posed a hazard: the row houses listed at angry angles, sidewalks were crumbled and the ground seemed no more steady than the nerves of the residents. It was a situation, city officials said, that could only get worse.

title: Days of Wine And Moses
description: To the Editor:

title: Diagnosis Confirmed
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Declines to Intervene In UMass Election Dispute
description: A judge has declined to become involved in a dispute over the election of a Communist as a student leader at the University of Massachusetts.

title: A Green-Eyed Poet
description: To the Editor:

title: Coptic Artistry And Tradition In Old Cairo
description: EGYPT, in the course of its nearly six thousand years of civilization, has seen cultures come and go: between the earliest Pharaohs and President Mubarak, that ancient land has supported many rulers and quite a number of religions. For the lover of the ancient world, the Nile valley is full of treasures; for those whose favorite period is that of the Roman emperors, there are the admirable Faiyum portraits; some of the best Muslim art and architecture anywhere is to be found in Cairo; but, squeezed in between are the Copts, a less well known, yet appealing culture and one that endures to this day.

title: Laurie K. Sutton To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Sutton of Southbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Kimball Sutton, to Michael Patrick O'Brien, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. O'Brien of Cos Cob, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: 1988 Was, at Long Last, the Year of the U.N.
description: THE United Nations enjoyed a spectacularly successful 1988, surprising its critics with its effectiveness as an international peacemaker. But with that success comes a new challenge for 1989: strengthening world confidence in the organization so it can keep up the momentum.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italy, North and South, in White Plains
description: LEAD: AT last the restaurant on the street level of the classy La Reserve Hotel has attracted an occupant almost worthy of its deep teal plush walls, peach upholstered chairs and luxurious appointments. Mulino's, open since last July, brings to the county some astonishingly fine versions of both northern and southern Italian dishes, but you won't get many of them on a Saturday night, when both food and service rated''Poor.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MITLA PASS. By Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) Almost two seconds after publication, Leon Uris's 10th novel leaped effortlessly onto the best-seller lists, which can be no surprise to the legion of his loyal fans. ''Mitla Pass'' is two stories in one - the impassioned tale of Gideon Zadok, who at a tender age announces his intention of becoming a Great Writer, and the turbulent history of his family in its tortuous journey from the shtetls of Russia to the cities of America.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. The threads on the outside filler pipe for my oil tank are worn out, so when the cover is put on it does not form a watertight seal. When it rains, water seeps in, causing the oil burner to fail. The oil company wants to put in a new pipe, but this is expensive. Is there a less expensive way to fix this?

title: Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
description: The best performers were Dave Winfield, Jose Canseco and Frank Viola. Also: Patrick Ewing, Darryl Strawberry and Mario Lemieux. ALPHONSE MAZZINA Union City, N.J.

title: Susanna N. Gioia,Design Assistant, To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Susanna Natalia Gioia to Anthony Giordano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Giordano Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J., has been made known by her parents, Iris Gioia and Emilio Gioia, both of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Crowded Train, A Glimpse of Knee, A Turn of Events
description: We are a society: an army over 200,000 strong sharing the daily commute from the suburbs to the city and back. Our customs and structure support one goal: perpetual motion. Although we see with blank eyes and speak volumes with our silence, we are the most intimate of strangers. We even know that sometimes the sight of a dimpled knee is more important than a seat on a crowded train.

title: All Eyes On Elusive Harris
description: This was a moment that all of West Virginia had waited for: the first quarter of the game against Penn State, a picture-postcard autumn afternoon in Morgantown, the Mountaineers moving into Nittany Lion territory, the ball on the 26-yard line, and Major Harris running the option.

title: SO WHAT HAPPENED?
description: More things get started than get finished, and thus the notion of process carries with it a whiff of uncertainty. Ambition, dreams, vision - these are great human motivations. But, of course, between motivation and achievement a lot can happen.

title: Deborah Lafer to Wed Dr. Howard I. Scher
description: Deborah Ann Lafer and Dr. Howard I. Scher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles I. Scher of New York, plan to marry in April, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fred S. Lafer of Wayne, N.J., have announced.

title: Praise Makers Seem to Be Calling the Tune
description: Concert program books are not ordinarily the place to look for objective evaluations of performers. By hallowed tradition, the sketches they contain are allowed to be effusive, as in this recent Carnegie Hall biographical blurb for a young violinist: ''Just as diamonds are forever, so are the art and appeal of Anne-Sophie Mutter.'' Before the reader can fully ponder the possibility that the publicist has overdosed on bromides, the prose rushes into the more perilous swamp of collegial endorsements: ''Hailed by Herbert von Karajan as one of the greatest violinists in the world . . . '' And, shortly after that: ''In the words of Mstislav Rostropovich, she is ' . . . a violinist who sets new standards of performance.' ''

title: THE NATION: Boom in Spy Craft; The Military Has A Fleet of Satellites In Line for Takeoff
description: NOW that the space program is back on track, the American military is looking to 1989 as the year that heralds its return to prominence in the heavens. Encouraged by last year's revitalization of the shuttle and the successful launching of a series of unmanned rockets, the Pentagon plans to greatly increase its arsenal of orbiting spacecraft and to pioneer a generation of powerful rockets. After a three-year hiatus in which military launching pads often sat idle, the Pentagon has scheduled 17 missions this year, the most since the early days of the space program.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-11

title: Spare Sparkle
description: Historical objects sparingly placed in cool, modern settings - that is the dominant direction for 1989. Off-whites and muted shades are de rigueur. So are antique fabrics, or new ones made to look old. This season's lighting fixtures and surface materials range from somber, industrial-sleek to those as colorful as confetti. Add to these a few well-chosen objects, like those shown here, and the result is a timely interior in good taste.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
description: Steffi Graf. Being in shape, staying healthy, playing at the top of your game, keeping mentally tough from the Australian Open in January to the French Open at the end of May is a season in most sports. But Graf still had Wimbledon, the United States Open and the Seoul Olympics to go. Graf's Grand Slam and Olympic gold medal is the best performance of 1988. ELIZABETH MAIO North Babylon, L.I.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
description: Kirk Gibson. He inspired a wounded team to win the World Series over the heavily favored Oakland Athletics. JOSH HOWLEY Short Hills, N.J.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GATHERING HOME. By Vicki Covington. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Set in Birmingham, Ala., in the early 1980's, Vicki Covington's first novel uses three concurrent stories to tell about the coming of age of a young girl named Whitney Gaines. The central one depicts Whitney's relationship with her adoptive parents, Cal (a liberal minister) and Mary Ellen, during Cal's unsuccessful campaign for Congress.

title: Europe's Old Colonies Are Getting Anxious as 1992 Nears
description: WESTERN EUROPE'S march toward a unified market by the end of 1992 is sending jitters through 66 former European colonies in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific.

title: C. R. Cachera to Wed Laura G. S. Farrand
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Farrand of Watch Hill, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Laura G. S. Farrand to Charles Rene Cachera, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jean-Paul Cachera of Paris. A May wedding is planned.

title: Loos's 'Blondes' Revived
description: FOR celebratory and commemorative purposes, the timing for the Coachlight Dinner Theater production of ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'' is just right. The new year marks the 40th anniversary of the Broadway musical version of Anita Loos's 1925 classic, which was first a straight play and film. And 1988 was the centenary of Ms. Loos's birth.

title: Ms. Conklin Wed To R. G. Nassau
description: The wedding of Alice Louise Conklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger E. Conklin of Kewanee, Ill., to Robert George Nassau, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul David Nassau of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Kewanee. The Rev. David Kniker performed the ceremony. The bride was attended by her sisters, Margaret A. Conklin, who is her twin, and Martha A. Conklin. Simon Cuttler and Peter Shimamoto were the best men.

title: Entering 1989, Utility's Woes Lead the List Of Concerns
description: THE two-decade struggle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which seemed to hit new heights last year, shows no sign of slowing in early 1989.

title: As A Tree Is Razed, Memories Are Plucked From Each Branch
description: THE Christmas tree stayed up until Jan. 12. It is my nostalgic duty to take it down each year and I postpone it always. It is so beautiful.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: OUT ON THE RIM, by Ross Thomas. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) This ''nimble international thriller'' about a terrorism expert named Booth Stallings and his dealings with Filipino guerrillas plotting against the Aquino Government is an ideal book to read on a long flight, Marilyn Stasio said here last year. It is filled with the ''kind of black humor that can keep you laughing even while the plane goes down.''

title: A Mission: Hospital Care For the Poor
description: A last-minute agreement by Governor Kean with Senate and Assembly leaders on a two-year extension of New Jersey's Uncompensated Care Trust Fund has averted a crisis for many inner-city hospitals. This trust fund helps pay the hospital bills of poor and uninsured people by spreading the cost among the 89 acute-care hospitals in the state through a surcharge on all hospital bills.

title: 3 Concerts Compete to Open New Year
description: HOW about a New Year's resolution that somebody devise a clearinghouse for cultural events? Of course, it is impossible to avoid all scheduling conflicts at the height of the season. But time and again one is forced to choose between programs simply because no one thought to present them on different days or even at different hours.

title: Parking Rules for Holidays in 1989
description: The New York City Transportation Department has issued its parking-rule changes for 1989. ALTERNATE-SIDE PARKING RULES SUSPENDED

title: Wary Walsh Runs Down His Checklist
description: Bill Walsh has made his list and checked everything twice, yet he still cannot escape the haunting feeling that maybe his San Francisco 49ers ought to try Plan B instead of A, or maybe even C or D or E. San Francisco (10-6) will play the Minnesota Vikings (11-5) on Sunday in Candlestick Park (4 P.M., Channel 2 in New York) in a National Conference playoff game.

title: Prospects; The Christmas Indicator
description: Consumer spending is an important indicator of future economic activity. While many analysts predicted a lackluster holiday selling season, consumers emptied their pocketbooks in the last 48 hours before Christmas, pushing holiday sales 5 percent to 6 percent beyond last year's levels. Four experts assess the future economic impact of strong consumer demand. Allen Sinai Chief economist, the Boston Company Economic Advisers Inc.

title: Review/Dance; Three Jazzy Offerings By the Ailey Company
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater made choreographic use of jazz in all three works it presented Friday night at the City Center Theater.

title: Sipping With Dignity At a London Oasis
description: AGATHA CHRISTIE, in ''At Bertram's Hotel,'' describes the hostelry of the title as dignified, unostentatious, and quietly expensive. That homage also aptly fits Brown's Hotel, the inspiration for Bertram's.

title: ACROSS THE BORDER AND WORLDS APART
description: LIMITS TO FRIENDSHIP The United States and Mexico. By Robert A. Pastor and Jorge G. Castaneda. 415 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: THE SOULS OF THE NEW MACHINES
description: MIND CHILDREN The Future of Robot and Human Intelligence. By Hans Moravec. Illustrated. 214 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $18.95.

title: '36 Fillette' Eyes The Teen-Age Temptress
description: If American movies tend to present coming of age primarily through young male protagonists, French films devote more attention to female puberty. Catherine Breillat's controversial ''36 Fillette,'' about a 14-year-old girl's troublesome rites of passage, is part of a tradition that includes Diane Kurys's ''Peppermint Soda,'' Jeanne Moreau's ''Adolescente,'' Roger Andrieux's ''Petite Sirene,'' Raphaelle Billetdoux's ''Femme-Enfant'' and Bertrand Blier's ''Beau Pere.''

title: Tamara Jaycox to Wed L. M. Kessler
description: Announcement has been made by Edward V. K. Jaycox and Victoria Holt Jaycox of Chevy Chase, Md., of the engagement of their daughter Tamara LaForge Jaycox to Lewis Maier Kessler, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kessler of Pittsburgh.

title: Eugene M. Gervasi, 51, Author of Nonfiction
description: Eugene Michael Gervasi, an author and former public relations director, died Friday at University Hospital in Richmond, after a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived in Richmond.

title: Afghans Await the Holy Warriors With Some Trepidation
description: ONLY weeks before time is scheduled to run out on Afghanistan's present agony, the first act of its next drama has not yet been written.

title: A REMINIST JOURNAL FINDS THAT LOOKS COUNT AFTER ALL
description: Redesigning a 16-year-old institution can be daunting. But that was the task facing Anne Summers, new editor of Ms. magazine, after Matilda Publications, an Australian company, acquired Ms. in February from its founders, Gloria Steinem and Patricia Carbine.

title: Qaddafi Denies Role In Sabotage of Plane
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said today that he believes that sabotage caused the explosion and crash of a Pan Am jet in Scotland, but he denied that either his country, Iran or Syria had a role in it.

title: Albany Backs Camera Use To Catch Traffic Violators
description: New York City has received approval to start a technological attack on people who ignore traffic lights, using computer-controlled cameras, below-pavement road sensors and a new traffic ticket that will chase scofflaw motorists home through the mail.

title: Beef Dispute: Stakes High In Trade War
description: As foreign trade goes, the loss of $130 million a year in exports is a minor matter. But beef industry executives and Federal agriculture officials say the stakes are far higher in a shrill trade dispute that has erupted with Europe over the presence of hormones in American beef.

title: Health-Care Cures
description: To the Editor:

title: DATABANK: January 1, 1989
DATA UPDATE: January 1, 1989
Who Was Dick Dudgeon?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Luck Helps a 'Poor' Slam
description: A DECADE ago China had a handful of bridge enthusiasts. Although the number is not known now, it is likely to be second only to the United States in terms of tournament players. A team event in Shanghai early this year attracted more than 700 teams and would have broken the world record for a single event if some players had not been excluded by lack of accommodation.

title: Thomas Lias, U.S. Official, 54
description: Thomas L. Lias, an official in three national administrations, died Thursday at his home here of complications that developed from a stroke he suffered three years ago. He was 54 years old.

title: Yachting; U.S. Trailing in Race for Cup
description: There is growing concern among American yachtsmen that the United States may be losing ground in its ability to defend the America's Cup.

title: When Pressure Forces Guilty Pleas
description: The decision of Drexel, Burnham, Lambert Inc. to pay $650 million in fines and restitution as part of an agreement to plead guilty to six counts of mail, wire and securities fraud demonstrates the coercive power of Federal prosecutors. Obviously, if one of the most powerful investment banking firms in America is forced to yield to pressures of prosecutorial power, the prospect for the preservation of the constitutional rights for less powerful citizens is not bright.

title: Bench Helps Louisville Rout Kentucky
description: Pervis Ellison scored 20 points to pace a balanced attack today as Louisville used its superior depth to beat Kentucky, 97-75.

title: BEST SELLERS LIST: January 1, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. Q (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 2 22 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 3 4 27 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 4 3 18 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride. 5 6 9 ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A man and his wife find themselves in a fantasy world. 6 5 7 DEAR MILI, by Wilhelm Grimm. (di Capua/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) A recently discovered tale by the 19th-century folklorist, illustrated by Maurice Sendak. 7 7 11 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and ''The Vampire Lestat.'' 8 8 11 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer. 9 11 12 FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A writer's struggles with his heritage and two loves reach a climax during the 1956 Sinai war. 11 10 15 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 12 13 2 SPY HOOK, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions.
