Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 1 7 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 3 3 37 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 4 8 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw- Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 5 7 11 SEVEN STORIES OF CHRISTMAS LOVE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack, $12.95.) The advocate of caring and love recalls experiences during holidays past. 6 5 11 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 7 6 7 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 8 8 4 CHRISTMAS IN AMERICA, edited by David Cohen. (Collins Publishers, $35.) An album of pictures taken by 100 photographers. 9 9 10 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 10 10 13 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) A profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 11 11 26 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 12 14 3 THE HOME PLANET, edited by Kevin W. Kelley. (Addison-Wesley, $39.95.) How the earth looks from outer space, shown in 150 photographs. 13 13 10 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican Presidential nominee. 14 12 12 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 15 15 9 PRESS ON! by Chuck Yeager and Charles Leerhsen. (Bantam, $17.95.) The legendary pilot on flying, the outdoors and his West Virginia roots. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 7 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 2 2 78 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 3 4 23 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. 4 3 4 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 5 11 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE BODY AND SOCIETY: Men, Women and Sexual Renunciation in Early Christianity, by Peter Brown. (Columbia University, $45.) A broad, deep and clear examination of the status of sexuality in the ancient world and among early Christians, and of the rich variety of opinion that preceded the far-from-predetermined triumph of virginity over marriage. THE MAN BEHIND THE IRON MASK, by John Noone. (St. Martin's, $35.) What and who lay behind modern Europe's most romantic rumor? Mr. Noone's spirited review of former theories concludes by proposing a resolution of his own. EUROPEANS, by Jane Kramer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) Solid essay-reports from The New Yorker, observing from the grass roots upward to show a Europe still unhomogenized. BERNARD FOY'S THIRD CASTLING, by Lars Gustafsson. (New Directions, $22.95.) An intelligent, tirelessly inventive novel within a novel within a novel, starring three Bernard Foys, one of whom may have committed a series of ghastly murders. SOR JUANA: Or, The Traps of Faith, by Octavio Paz. (Belknap/ Harvard University, $29.95.) Mexico's pre-eminent poet and essayist explores the world and work of Sor (Sister) Juana Ines de la Cruz, the 17th-century nun who was the last great poet of Spain's Golden Age and the first great poet of the New World. A SOR JUANA ANTHOLOGY, translated by Alan S. Trueblood. (Harvard University, $29.50.) A useful sampling of Sor Juana's writings: baroque, lyrical, amorous, religious, abundant. DANGER AND SURVIVAL: Choices About the Bomb in the First Fifty Years, by McGeorge Bundy. (Random House, $24.95.) A detailed, rigorously documented history and analysis of the political decisions in many countries that shaped the nuclear era.

title: Elizabeth P. Billings To Wed M. F. Sacca
description: Judge and Mrs. Franklin S. Billings Jr. of Woodstock, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Preudhomme Billings to Michael Francis Sacca, a son of Mrs. Gregory F. Sacca of Gloucester, Mass., and the late Mr. Sacca. A summer wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Volunteer Teddies
description: LEAD: Arthur Freed, chief of operations of the County Department of Public Works, keeps five teddy bears in his car at all times. If he pulls up to the scene of an accident and finds a child who needs comforting, he hands over one of the bears.

title: Miss Porter Is Planning A September Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. John H. Porter of Dublin, N.H., of the engagement of her daughter Patricia Stuart Porter to Gifford Combs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson G. Combs of Berkeley, Calif. The couple plan to marry in September.

title:
ART;
Ceramics Highlight Exhibition
description: LEAD: THIS year, 112 artists are participating in the annual Members Exhibition at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's gallery at Mills Pond House in St. James. It is one of the few nonjuried shows on the Island.

title: Admitted Westies Killer Who Informed Is Free
description: Francis (Mickey) Featherstone, an admitted killer who turned informer, has won his freedom, largely in return for testifying against his former associates in a violent gang called the Westies.

title: N.C. State Tops Iowa
description: Tyrone Jackson ran for two touchdowns as North Carolina State exploded for three quick second-period scores today, then held off Iowa for a 28-23 victory in the Peach Bowl, a game marred by 14 turnovers, 7 by each team.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
description: Florence Griffith Joyner. Her athletic accomplishments speak for themselves: 10.49 in the 100 meters and 21.34 in the 200 at the Seoul Olympics.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Spacious Kiss>

title: A Big Week
description: Last week's National Basketball Association player of the week and the league's seventh-leading scorer found a nice little break in the schedule. So Clyde Drexler, the Portland Trail Blazer guard, went back to New Orleans, the city where he was born, and on Friday married Gaynell Floyd, an attorney he met on a blind date last winter.

title: CRIME
description: ''A great many writers have been trying to steal him from me for fifteen years or more,'' Raymond Chandler noted, more than 30 years ago, about certain sticky-fingered admirers of his private-eye hero, Philip Marlowe. ''And they have never made it yet,'' he added.

title: Moving Beyond Patter and Persistence Photos of Tyrone Howze, a salesman for Nabisco Brands, checking inventory at a Michigan supermarket (NYT/Peter Yates); Gary Johnson, a sales representative for the Perceptron Corporation of Farmington Hills, Mich., with a computerized measuring system he sells (NYT/Peter Yates); Kristin Haser, who sells paper products for the Arnold Corporation in Pittsburgh, leaves a customer a holiday case of beer (NYT/Scott Goldsmith)
description: For years, it was mostly a matter of amiability, portability and motivation. But these days, the job of the ''traveling salesman'' is undergoing some subtle but important changes.

title: Why Rolls-Royce Loves Its Bentley Photos of Malcolm Hart, director of sales and marketing of Rolls Royce Motor Cars, with a Bentley Turbo R (NYT/Jonathan Player); working at the bottom of a car at the Crewe factory, which turns out Bentley and Rolls-Royce models; checking the hides (NYT); graph of number of Bentleys sold, 1970-1988* (*Estimate) (Source: Company reports)
description: The automotive accolades - ''hot,'' ''sporty,'' ''an incredible driving experience'' - are usually showered on the likes of Ferrari, Lamborghini and Porsche. But now, in auto magazines and among car enthusiasts, the praises are being heaped on a Bentley, long considered the stately first cousin of the Rolls-Royce, with the same behemoth proportions and bank-vault feel.

title: Readers Speak Out on N.F.L. Parity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A June Wedding For Ms. Jaroslow
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Davis Jaroslow to Marc Allen Lipsett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Lipsett of San Francisco, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Fred Jaroslow of Sands Point, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: In Switzerland, Wild Roses And an Elegy
description: Jan 2, 1917, was a sparkling cold winter day in Raron, a small Swiss town surrounded by snow-covered Alps in the Valais. On a rocky ledge high above the town in a churchyard a cluster of people gathered somberly around an open grave listening to one of the mourners recite: ''Of course, it is strange to inhabit the earth no longer,/to give up customs one barely had time to learn,/not to see roses and other promising things/in terms of a human future. . . .''

title: 4 Hurt in Jersey Plane Crash
description: Four people were injured, two critically, when the twin-engine plane they were flying in crashed today as the pilot tried to land at Somerset Airport, the police said.

title: Lesley Flood to Marry Robert H. Dial in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Flood of Bethesda, Md., of the engagment of their daughter Lesley Ann Flood to Robert Hastings Dial, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas A. Dial of Wyckoff, N.J. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Reserves of Canniness
description: BELLMAN AND TRUE Starring Bernard Hill (at center in photo), Kieran O'Brien, Richard Hope (right), Ken Bones (left). Directed by Richard Loncraine. 1987. Cannon. 121 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: THE WORLD: A Reminiscence: The Killing Fields; Could the Vietnamese Withdrawal Bring Back Cambodia's Nightmare?
description: A decade ago, Jan. 7, 1979, a group of moderate rebels in the Khmer Rouge, led by Heng Samrin and supported by Vietnamese troops, seized power in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, from the extreme left Khmer Rouge led by Pol Pot and Khieu Samphan.

title: CHINA POLICE SAID TO BEAT AFRICANS
description: Police officers attacked 140 foreign students with truncheons and cattle prods today in five hours of unrest near a house where the foreigners, mostly Africans, were isolated after a week of racial violence, witnesses said.

title: At European Airports, More Searching and More Questioning
description: Intensified airport security in European cities produced no major delays in flights to the United States yesterday, but travel was light on the final day of 1988 and the full effect of the measures was not expected to be felt until early in the new year.

title: Ever So Humble
description: A platter holding a tower of lobsters, shrimp, oysters and clams (called, appropriately, a shellfish extravaganza) and another bearing a flaming baked Alaska zipped through the renovated Rainbow Room in Manhattan. But that was last year. The restaurants born in 1989 - and the food served in them - will be decidedly more humble. Bistros, brasseries, Italian trattorias and American cafes will far outnumber the grand, formal restaurants. And roasted chicken, white beans with garlic, risotto, pasta of any shape, cassoulet, casseroles and duck confit will be more common than baked Alaska and seafood extravaganzas.

title: September Bridal For Ms. Mendley
description: The engagement of Diana Elizabeth Mendley to Lewis Steven Ingall has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mark Mendley of Bronxville, N.Y. Her fiance is a son of Dr. David Ingall of Highland Park, Ill., and the late Edith Roth Ingall, and a stepson of Carol Kreeger Ingall. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: In Washington Today, There's No Dodging The Tax Issue
description: ALTHOUGH President-elect Bush has repeated his ''no new taxes'' pledge so often and so categorically as to give pause to even confirmed cynics, the assumption among many Republicans and Democrats in Congress is that before 1990 he will find himself signing legislation that does in fact raise taxes.

title: IN THE WAKE OF THE LONE EAGLE
description: LEAD: CHASING THE GLORY Travels Across America. By Michael Parfit. Maps. 353 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $17.95.

title: In Britain, a Proliferation of Prosperos
description: ''The Tempest'' has always been one of Shakespeare's most popular plays. It also possesses a mythical power that seems to inspire other artists. As the Shakespearean scholar Anne Barton points out in the New Penguin edition, Mozart sketched out an opera based upon it, Hollywood plundered its story for a science fiction film (''The Silent Planet''), T.S. Eliot used fragments of it in ''The Waste Land'' and W. H. Auden wrote a long poem, ''The Sea and the Mirror,'' dwelling on the destinies of its principal characters.

title: Ethiopia Is Leaning Westward Again
description: WEARY of supporting Col. Mengistu Haile Meriam and his endless civil war, the Soviet Union is quietly encouraging Ethiopia to re-establish relations with its old ally, the United States. For a Government that prides itself on Marxist-Leninist purity, the rapprochement is bound to be difficult. So far, Ethiopia's gestures toward reconciliation have often come wrapped in socialist rhetoric, apparently intended to show that there is really no deviation from the revolutionary ideals that toppled Emperor Haile Selassie 15 years ago.

title: Recalling the Best of 1988
description: NINETEEN EIGHTY-EIGHT will be remembered as the year that Thai cooking found its way to Connecticut. While the number of Thai restaurants is still small, the cuisine brings a welcome spiciness and variety to the state's restaurant scene.

title: Farms Use Benefits to Lure Workers
description: Joe Wedge makes only $4 an hour, but the benefits are good. He gets a house, free heat, electricity, beef and all the milk his family can drink.

title: The Decor Is Just Fine, But After That?
description: NO. 16 Elm Street in Huntington Village is a familiar address to those who dine out frequently. First it was French, then seafood and now Italian: from Peche Mignon to Steve's Lighthouse to the present Villa Adriano.

title: New Yorkers, Indifferent to the Blind, Descend Into the Maelstrom
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: FAMILY: Family and Borghesia. Two Novellas. By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by Beryl Stockman. (Seaver Books/Holt, $15.95.) At the conclusion of ''Family,'' a character on his deathbed reviews his life and can recall nothing but a kind of exalted trivia, a ''whole pile of random detailed impressions, that were hazy, but light as a feather.'' These phrases offer a precis of Natalia Ginzburg's method, which consists of a similar piling-up of minutiae, paragraph upon paragraph, interrupted only by an occasional patch of dialogue. At first her style may seem monotonous, flat and maddeningly repetitive. But readers willing to surrender themselves to her peculiar rhythms will soon discover the urgency, and the feather-lightness, of a masterful writer. In the title novella, the author applies her literary pointillism to the deteriorating marriage of an architect, Carmine Donati. Bored and frustrated, Carmine is subject to the free-floating discontent that is typical of Ms. Ginzburg's characters. This same crucial indecision also affects Ilaria Boschivo, the aging widow at the center of ''Borghesia.'' At a friend's urging, Ilaria acquires a cat, which almost instantly dies. A trivial thing, she thinks - and yet, ''all of a sudden, she was discovering that even poor sorts of pain are acute and merciless, and quickly take their place in that immense, vague area of general unhappiness.'' Such small-scale heartbreaks, such poor sorts of pain, have dovetailed beautifully in Ms. Ginzburg's prose over the course of many decades; this scrupulous translation of the two novellas in ''Family,'' which were originally published in 1977, only confirms her position as one of Italy's best and most idiosyncratic writers.

title: Jersey Fears Another Year of Mud As It Awaits the Race for Governor
description: After the nasty political campaigns of 1988, is it possible for a dozen politicians running for Governor of New Jersey to stick to the issues and avoid slinging mud?

title: Tight Ship
description: Anyone who thinks New York City co-op boards are fussy might consider the case at the Viewpointe, an adults-only condominium complex in Margate, Fla. The Viewpointe board has set a deadline of Jan. 10 for Jamie Swartz, 9 years old, to leave the apartment owned by her father and stepmother, who took the girl in several months before her mother died of cancer. By neighbors' accounts, Jamie keeps quiet and minds her own business, but the board stood firm. ''I understand the perception this case has,'' said Douglas Neway, an attorney for the board. ''But the rule is 'no children.' '' The Swartzes, meanwhile, are trying to sell their apartment, although they are having a hard time, they say, because Viewpointe has acquired something of a bad reputation.

title: Sand Still Being Dug In Defiance Of an Edict
description: LEAD: DESPITE an order by the state's Department of Environmental Conservation to stop its activities, the Brookhaven Aggregates Company of Coram has continued to mine sand for 18 months at its 50-acre Coram site off Miller Place-Yaphank Road, near Whiskey Road.

title: Girl Gets O.K. To Play Basketball
description: AN 11 year-old's membership on the 78th precinct's bantam basketball team in Brooklyn was challenged in early November by an opposing team. The opposing team's coach did not want the 11-year-old in the game because she is a girl.

title: Venezuela Suspends Payments of Debt Principal
description: Venezuela, the fourth-biggest debtor in Latin America, announced today that it was suspending principal payments on nearly all of its $30.3 billion in foreign debt.

title: Dr. Nina M. Hill To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Dr. Nina Marie Hill to Walter Francis Raquet, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Raquet of Tequesta, Fla., has been made known by her parents, Ilda Kleiner of Delray Beach, Fla., and Peter Hill of New York. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: DOWNTOWN, WHERE THE ACTION WAS
description: UNION SQUARE By Meredith Tax. 437 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Tending Teen-Agers, 2d Time Around
description: WHEN my wife and I retired to Florida from Long Island 10 years ago, we reassured our married daughter who lives in Woodmere that we would always be there for her, just a phone call away, should she ever need us. A decade later she called in her marker.

title: 2d Investigation Touches Capital Mayor
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., already under investigation by the Justice Department for his visits to a hotel room occupied by a suspected drug dealer, faces still other problems from a separate investigation, this one by the Interior Department.

title: An Easy Approach To the New Catalogues
description: TIME off for a Happy New Year. A Bit of Everything

title:
What's In, What's Out, What's What;
Politics
description: LEAD: Real Washington insiders rely on the surreptitious circulation of intelligence estimates to prepare for next year's trends. The Company already knows that C.I.A. Director Webster is in, and that corporate serenity perhaps explains the subdued tone of this year's predictions.

title: Heritage Village Is Not Summer Camp
description: I READ with interest and considerable dismay the article on Heritage Village (''Where the Residents Are Busy Doing What They Want to Do,'' Nov. 20). The article describes a perpetual summer camp for adults in which play is the primary activity, almost as a reward for all those years working in the big, bad city.

title: The Processed Word
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Reincarnating an 1871 Warehouse
description: LEAD: THE only warehouse designed by John McArthur Jr., the 19th-century architect who created this city's ornate City Hall, is scheduled to be reborn as part of an $11 million waterfront apartment development.

title: Endings Can Really Finish a Movie
description: If you have friends and would like to keep them, try never to talk about movie endings. No greater breach of cinema-related etiquette exists, unless it's recommending a comedy by retelling its jokes. Endings are sacrosanct for obvious reasons, and also because a viewer's opinion of a film is usually formed long before the ending comes along. It's nice to think of an ending as both a surprise and a logical extension of what has preceded it.

title: Don't Insult Pilots With Weapons Screenings
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Mr. North Starring Anthony Edwards, Robert Mitchum, Lauren Bacall, Harry Dean Stanton, Anjelica Huston, Mary Stuart Masterson, Virginia Madsen, Tammy Grimes, David Warner, Christopher Durang. Directed by Danny Huston. 1988. Virgin Vision. 90 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. Rated PG. Has some mildly off-color language.

title: To the Editor:
description: Apropos of your symposium, please relay to Alice Adams that there does exist a female '' 'Quixote' enthusiast.'' I number ''Don Quixote'' among my favorite books. Since I too am an avid fan of Chekhov, please suggest to her that maybe if she read more than ''a page or two'' of Cervantes, she might change her mind. Tilting at windmills is, in fact, very close to going to Moscow. KAREN HOWARD EARLE New York

title: Unwrapping the New Year
description: It's easier to wrap up the old year than unwrap the new. Still, the difference between them is only some arbitrary celestial point in the zodiac, picked long ago by a committee of Babylonian astrologers. On the principle of continuity, the near future will look a lot like the recent past.

title: Hormone-Treated Beef Termed Generally Safe
description: Although the European Community has acted to ban imports of beef from cattle treated with growth-stimulating hormones, most experts in the United States insist that when the hormones are properly applied, the beef is safe to eat.

title: Shoreham Impasse: Suggested Solutions
description: As the new year begins, a solution to the Shoreham impasse seems likely to emerge from secret discussions among the Long Island Lighting Company and representatives of Governor Cuomo and Suffolk County. Before the parties sat down to negotiate under prodding from Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein, the Long Island Weekly asked several people for suggestions on ending the Shoreham problem. Their replies were compiled by Diane Ketcham, Ellen Mitchell and John Rather. Maurice Barbash Chairman, Citizens to Replace Lilco.

title: Dorsett Pleads Guilty
description: After originally being charged with drunken driving, Tony Dorsett of the Denver Broncos pleaded guilty Friday in Aurora, Colo., to a reduced charge of driving while impaired with alcohol. Geraldine Allan, an Arapahoe County judge, told Dorsett he could face up to 100 days in jail and a $500 fine. She ordered him to undergo an evaluation for alcoholism before his sentencing on Feb. 9. Dorsett's driver's license was automatically revoked for one year.

title: Stretching the Weekend: The Pre-Dawn Monday Commute
description: EVERY Sunday afternoon, at our weekend place in North Haven, just outside of Sag Harbor, my wife and I ask each other the same question. Should we return to Manhattan later that afternoon or leave early Monday morning? This question and the discussion surrounding it involves a variety of factors - the weather, our fatigue, and our adherence to a well-known principle of physics -that a body at rest tends to remain at rest.

title: Urban High Schools Step Up Recruiting of Students for Jobs Program
description: URBAN high schools throughout New Jersey are intensifying their efforts to recruit seniors for the first phase of a state-sponsored program that promises to place 10,000 high school graduates in full-time jobs in private industry by 1992.

title: Telling the Tales of Siena's Golden Age
description: ''Painting in Renaissance Siena: 1420-1500'' at the Metropolitan Museum is a glorious affair. Even in a season that has seen one great exhibition after another, worldwide, this one is a nonpareil. Moreover, the art that we see there is in the highest degree an unstandardized art - one that keeps us continually on the alert, thinking new thoughts, dreaming new dreams and on fire with speculation.

title: Deborah Faber Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack H. Faber of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Gail Faber, to Charles Michael Flock, a son of Mrs. Charles Flock of Garden City, L.I., and the late Mr. Flock. Miss Faber, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University, and her fiance, a principal of Cone Software in Upland, Pa., plan to marry in May. The future bride graduated from the Masters School and American University. Mr. Flock is an alumnus of Hofstra University, from which he also received an M.B.A.

title: For Grim Soviet Consumers, The New Year of Discontent
description: The Soviet Union is facing the brightest holiday on its calendar in the grimmest mood anyone can remember, primarily because of food and consumer-goods shortages that seem to grow more acute by the day.

title: Q and A
description: Rent Delinquency

title: UNIMAGINABLE CHAOS
description: THE COMING QUAKE Science and Trembling on the California Earthquake Frontier. By T. A. Heppenheimer. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: Jet Set Helps Bring a Business Boom To Argentina's First Family of Polo
description: It may be impolitic to recount this now, but there is a well-founded story that Prince Philip of Britain once expressed a willingness to trade the Falkland Islands to Argentina for two great polo players.

title: Taxing Spirits
description: To the Editor:

title: Revenue Bonds Proposed for Airport Terminal
description: UNDER a new proposal, construction of a passenger terminal and parking garage at the County Airport would be financed by airport profits, rather than by county taxpayers, through a nonprofit organization consisting of the County Executive and the Board of Legislators.

title: Life With 'The Boys Next Door': Dignity Despite Disabilities
description: TOM GRIFFIN'S comedy-drama, ''The Boys Next Door,'' at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, depicts life for the residents of a group home for the developmentally disabled.

title: How to Live With Looming Higher Interest Rates
description: AS rising interest rates gather momentum, many business executives would expect Connecticut's light manufacturing and service-oriented economy to slow down proportionately.

title:
What's In, What's Out, What's What;
Places
description: LEAD: During the Reagan Presidency, more millionaires were created than in all the preceding history of the United States. Now that George Bush's election has relieved them of the fear that the Democrats will take away their money, it's the right moment to let these lucky people in on the secret of where's in and where's out, just in case they're still living on the wrong side of the tracks.

title: THE NATION: Darman's Task; The Time Is Coming To Design a Budget And Freeze Flexibly
description: AS a Presidential candidate in 1980, George Bush deployed an economist friend, Paul W. MacAvoy, to ridicule Ronald Reagan's proposals for the economy as ''voodoo.'' Eight years later Mr. MacAvoy, the dean of the business school at the University of Rochester, calls Mr. Bush's proposed ''flexible freeze'' to balance the budget ''bunk-o'' - a combination of bunkum and bunco.

title: NONFICTION
description: REFLECTIONS ON THE WAY TO THE GALLOWS: Rebel Women in Prewar Japan. Translated and edited by Mikiso Hane. (University of California/Pantheon, $22.50.) In the Japan portrayed in this book, from the late 19th century up to World War II, young girls work 12-hour shifts in textile factories, poor farmers sell their daughters to brothels, police arrest anyone suspected of socialist sympathies and women are prohibited by law from participating in political activities. In ''Reflections on the Way to the Gallows,'' Mikiso Hane, a professor of history at Knox College, uses biographies and memoirs to tell the stories of 13 Japanese women who joined left-wing groups to fight these and other injustices and remained steadfast despite hunger, homelessness, torture and imprisonment. Details from their lives, not their political rhetoric, show clearly their intrepid spirits: impoverished Fukuda Hideko giving a precious 50 sen to a beggar woman; Kanno Sugako studying English mere days before her execution; imprisoned Yamashiro Tomoe delighting in the taste of pickled greens on a winter's day. Also intriguing is the contrast between these women's determination and loyalty to ideals and the hypocrisy and meanness of many of the men in their lives. The male comrades of both Kanno Sugako and Fukuda Hideko advocated the liberation of indentured prostitutes, yet shamelessly frequented brothels. After spending the night with her socialist lover, Kaneko Fumiko went hungry while he selfishly ate the breakfast delivered to his room; he offered her his leftovers only as an afterthought. Readers unfamiliar with Japanese names may be confused by the comings and goings in some of the memoirs, but the translations read smoothly. Mr. Hane's introduction provides good background on the status of women in prewar Japanese society.

title: U.N. Council Unable To Adopt Guidelines For a Namibia Force
description: The Security Council today failed to agree on guidelines for a peacekeeping force to supervise elections in Namibia. The deadlock was seen as a setback to hopes for a smooth transition to independence in the territory, also known as South-West Africa.

title: Ownership
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers. Their emotion and unity enabled Tommy Lasorda's underdogs to rise to new heights. DEBBIE WEISS New York

title: Dooley Gets Political Tip
description: If Georgia's head football coach Vince Dooley wants to run for governor, James Blanchard of Michigan is willing to be there to coach him.

title: Increasing Rapes on Campus Spur Colleges to Fight Back
description: College and university officials, concerned over an apparent steady increase in rapes on campuses, are strengthening campus security and reinforcing freshman orientation with programs on how to avert rape.

title: After 40 Years, Let's Ratify U.N. Bill of Rights; Draft Declaration
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Easy N Dirty Scores: Easy N Dirty edged Nostalgia's Star by a half-length yesterday to win the $80,550 Display Handicap at Aqueduct. Easy N Dirty, ridden by Jorge Velasquez and carrying 113 pounds, raced two and a quarter miles in 3:53 2/5 on the fast track for his second victory in 11 starts in 1988. Chaudennay finished third in the field of 10, three lengths behind Nostalgia's Star. Easy N Dirty earned $48,330 for his owner and trainer, Paulino Ortiz, and returned $26.80, $6 and $4 for $2 across the board.(AP) Speed Skating Blair Wins and Jansen Falls Again: Bonnie Blair, the Olympic gold medal winner, won both her races, but Dan Jansen, who fell in both his Olympic races, took a spill again Friday during the United States National Sprint speed skating championships in West Allis, Wis. Jansen fell with about 25 yards to go in the men's 500-meter race and slid across the finish line. He placed third in the race in 37.98 seconds. Nick Thometz won the 500 meters in 37.72 seconds followed by David Cruikshank in 37.83 seconds. Blair, the 500-meter gold medalist at the Winter Games in Calgary, won the 500 meters at the Wisconsin State Fair Park skating rink in 41.22 seconds and the 1,000 meters in 1:25.03. Her margin of victory was about two seconds in both races.(AP) Road Racing Atkinson First in Phoenix Event: Jeff Atkinson broke from the pack in the final 200 meters to win yesterday's fourth annual Fiesta Bowl Mile through the streets of uptown Phoenix. Atkinson, 24 years old, of Manhattan Beach, Calif., posted a winning time of 4:05.20. The defender, Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, was second at 4:05.6 while a former Arizona State University runner, Jeff Smith, finished third at 4:05.9. John Walker of New Zealand was fourth at 4:06.3 with the 1985 winner, Steve Scott, in fifth place at 4:07.7 and the 1986 winner, Ray Flynn of Ireland, in sixth at 4:09.9.(AP) Track and Field Young Takes Hurdles at West Point: Candy Young, a two-time winner of the N.C.A.A. indoor hurdles title while at Fairleigh Dickinson University in 1983 and 1984, won the 55-meter hurdles yesterday at the Manufacturers Hanover Holiday Trackfest at West Point, N.Y. Her time was 7.81 seconds. Young, who was competing for the Atoms T.C., beat Monifa Taylor, a senior at Truman High School in the Bronx, who was timed in 8.18 seconds in her first hurdles outing this season. Four former college standouts combined to win the women's 3,200-meter relay. Mary Ellen McGowan (Villanova), Pam Simmons (Hofstra), Joetta Clark (Tennessee), and Gail Bryant (Virginia) won the event in 9 minutes 12.48 seconds. In high school events, Rosalee Walters, a 14-year-old ninth-grader at Clifford Scott H.S. in East Orange, N.J., took the 600 meters in 1:43.99, and Caryn Landau, a 15-year-old 10th-grader from Grahamsville, N.Y., won the 1,500 meters in 5:02.69. Landau's sister Kate, a 12-year-old seventh-grader, was second in the 1,500 at 5:02.73, a New York State age record. Wrestling U.S. Defeats Soviet Team: Randy Lewis and Rico Chiapparelli won their matches in the final seconds Friday night as the United States beat the Soviet Union, 7-3, Fiesta Bowl Takedown One freestyle exhibition. It was the first time the United States has defeated the Soviet National team in 17 years of dual meet competition. The Soviets beat the Americans for the gold medal at last summer's Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. Lewis, a 1984 gold medalist at 143 pounds, flipped the current Olympic champion, Stepan Sarkisyan, with two seconds remaining in their match for a 6-5 triumph. Chiapparelli flipped Lukman Zhabrailov at the buzzer of their five-minute match in the 187-pound class for a 4-3 victory. Bill Scherr, the 1988 Olympic bronze medalist at 226.5 pounds, beat Aravat Sabeev by 2-0 and the silver medalist, Bruce Baumgartner, avenged his defeat last summer to the Olympic champion, David Gobedzhishvili, in the final match, 5-0.(AP) Hockey U.S.A. Selects Takes Final: Jim Sprenger and John Fritsche scored two goals each yesterday to spark the U.S.A. Selects to an 8-1 rout of Team Canada in the championship game of the Spengler Cup hockey tournament in Davos, Swizterland. Sprenger, a defenseman, opened the scoring at 6 minutes 59 seconds of the first period and added a short-handed goal in the second period. Fritsche added a goal in the first period and another in the third to help the team made up of Americans who play in Europe become the first United States winner in the 63-year history of the Swiss tournament. The other American scorers were Bob Crawford, Dave Silk, Rick Erdall and Mickey Krampotich. The United States goaltender, Dan Delianedis, who saved 39 shots in the final, was voted the tournament's most valuable player. Both the United States and Canada wound up the tournament with 3-1 records. (AP) Central Red Army 5, Bruins 4: Evgeny Davydov and Valery Zelepuhkin each had a goal and an assist in the first period as the touring Soviet Central Red Army built a 4-0 lead, then held off the Boston Bruins by 5-4 yesterday and raised their record against Wales Conference teams to 2-0-1. Davydov circled the net and scored on a backhander at 3:06, then set up Zelepuhkin's goal at 9:57. The loss was the Bruins' third in three games against visiting Soviet teams. They were beaten by 5-2 by the Red Army in 1976 and by 6-4 by Moscow Dynamo 10 years later.(AP)

title: NONFICTION
description: ASAD, THE SPHINX OF DAMASCUS: A Political Biography. By Moshe Ma'oz. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $19.95.) Moshe Ma'oz, a professor of modern Middle East history at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, has set out to write what he calls ''a political biography of an outstanding ruler of modern Syria,'' President Hafez al-Assad. However, as Mr. Ma'oz himself points out, this is no easy task for an Israeli. ''I have tried to remain as detached as I can,'' he writes, ''but without losing empathy for the study of Syria and Asad, with their interests and aspirations.'' What emerges in ''Asad, the Sphinx of Damascus'' is a thoughtful study, valuable for the wealth of detail and well-organized facts it presents about Mr. Assad (whose name can also be rendered, as it is in this book, Asad). It presents a full outline of his strengths and weaknesses, successes and failures; his legacy as a member of a minority sect in a land of feuding factions; his rise to power during the 1960's within the Syrian military and the Ba'ath party; his ambitions for a Greater Syria and leadership within the Arab world; his strategies for the conflicts with Israel and within Lebanon, and his harsh suppression of dissent at home. But it is clear that the material has been culled from a distance; the cited sources are, for the most part, works of history, published reports and other accounts available in Israel, the West and the Arabic press. Considering the relative dearth of material available on the subject, the book is useful as a guide to the forces that have produced Mr. Assad. Yet one hungers for what this author could not be expected to provide: the humanizing anecdote, the personal insight a biographer achieves when he becomes close to the subject himself.

title: Dolphin Dissection: Serious Subject

The title blithely implies that a friend (Flipper) was brutalized by our students via dissection. The tone gives reason to suspect that people may have been running about in a confused state of nausea, looking for relief. The principal did not disappear but, instead, was called away by an emergency (as evidenced by a buildingwide evacuation during the laboratory experience).

title: POSTINGS: Architectural Roots; 11 Hotels For Budapest

Imri Roth left his homeland in the 1880's and headed straight for Chicago. The Second City, Richard Roth explained, was preparing for a World's Fair. Only in 1897 did Imri - by then Emery - arrive in New York to establish, in 1902, Emery Roth & Sons, today one of the city's major firms.

title: Loose Ends
description: In the decade that he has been Mayor of Washington, Marion S. Barry Jr. has fought off reports of drug and alcohol abuse, always insisting that they were politically inspired. Last week, the Justice Department said it would investigate a visit the Mayor paid to an acquaintance suspected of selling drugs. On Dec. 22, two undercover detectives arrived at a Washington hotel to try to buy drugs from a former District of Columbia employee named Charles Lewis. At the same time, Mr. Barry came with his bodyguards to see Mr. Lewis. The undercover operation was called off, and after speaking to the Mayor, Mr. Lewis checked out the next day. ''At no time did I see any drugs, use any drugs or have any knowledge of any drugs,'' Mr. Barry said. If he is guilty of anything, he insisted, it is lack of judgment.

FICTION
description: LEAD: A CRAVING FOR WOMEN. By Sybil Claiborne. (Dutton, $17.95.) This occasionally witty first novel is dedicated to the author's writing group, and one suspects that its faults - an overabundance of fey jests, the lack of a purposeful structure - are traceable to the usual problems of literature by committee: it doesn't seem to develop so much as agglomerate.

title: Taking Stock of Investment Clubs
description: If one of your New Year's resolutions is to get back into the market, you might want to consider joining - or even starting - an investment club. Generally organized by 15 or so friends in the form of a partnership, the clubs offer a way to pool investment money and knowledge while at the same time lessening the anxiety level.

title: DESTINY UNCLUTTERED BY PRINCIPLES
description: THE FOUNDER Cecil Rhodes and the Pursuit of Power. By Robert I. Rotberg with the collaboration of Miles F. Shore. Illustrated. 800 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35.

title: Japan Slips in Smokestack America
description: Prospects for reviving the beleaguered National Steel Corporation seemed bright in 1984, when the Nippon Kokan K.K. Corporation acquired a 50 percent interest in the nation's sixth-largest steel producer. With deep pockets and technical prowess surpassing that of any American steel maker, NKK, Japan's No. 2 steel maker, seemed an ideal partner for a company that had been battered, along with others in the American industry, by cheap imports, falling steel prices and flagging demand.

title: Philcox Enjoys Blue-Ribbon Season
description: In the plethora of holiday bowl games, scores of players block and tackle on national television and some even can say, ''Hi, Mom,'' on camera. But others never get to play because someone else is better. They are the forgotten.

title: Health-Care Costs Rise and Workers Are Paying
description: EMPLOYERS throughout Connecticut will find the costs of employee health insurance going up as the New Year comes in, and they intend to have the workers bear part of the burden.

title: Hudson Valley - Second Home to Many
description: NORMAN ANDERSON is a bass baritone with the Metropolitan Opera who lived in Manhattan. Diane Perlmutter is a marketing consultant who lives in Manhattan on and off. Ralph Cardone is an official of the New York City Department of Correction who lives in Queens physically but not necessarily emotionally.

title: Miss Key Is Wed To an Art Dealer
description: Alexandra Lenoir Key, a daughter of David M. Key Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mrs. Charles R. Leonard Jr., was married yesterday to Eugene Ledogar Oakes Jr., the son of Mrs. Edward C. Rutherford of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Oakes. The Rev. Allan B. Ramirez performed the ceremony at the Brookville (L.I.) Reformed Church.

title: Legal Maneuvers Delay New Rules on Pesticides
description: New state regulations requiring public notice when pesticides are applied will not be enforced for the time being because of legal complications, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Some Dental Hygienists Seek Incentives
description: LINDA BAER has been a dental hygienist for 30 years, but she spends most of her time now selling advertising for a newspaper. According to Ms. Baer and other members of the Westchester Dental Hygienists' Association, a component of the American Dental Hygiene Asociation, the field of dental hygiene - which they love - lacks incentives.

title: Accessories for Fast Movers
description: LEAD: MOVADO, the watch corporation, introduced its fashion, office and travel accessories in early December in a new flagship boutique, at 625 Madison Avenue, near 59th Street.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 1, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 7 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. 3 2 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and-roll performers in tinselly southern California. 4 9 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 5 15 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 6 12 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 7 5 THE MASK, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.50.) The horrors that befall a couple after they adopt an attractive teen-ager. 8 5 SILVER ANGEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 2 5 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Bantam, $4.95.) The television star muses on life at 50. 3 6 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 4 2 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Warner, $5.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 5 29 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 6 32 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 7 271 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 3 2 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1989. (World Almanac/Pharos Books, $6.95.) Its 121st year. 4 5 SEPARATED AT BIRTH? by the editors of Spy. (Spy/Dolphin/Doubleday, $6.95.) Humorous juxtapositions of celebrities' pictures. 5 16 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons.
