The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: China Celebrates 10 Years Along the Capitalist Road
description: THE winter air was filled with rumors and anticipation in December 1978, as Communist Party leaders from across China gathered in the capital for a showdown. Yet almost no one could have imagined that this meeting would give birth to the sweeping economic and political upheaval that changed China and set the Communist world on its ear.

title: Police Switch to Baton
description: THE police force here is replacing its nightstick with a more sophisticated plastic baton, as part of what Deputy Chief Stephen A. Poloka calls ''an effort to build a new relationship with the community,'' after a summer of tension between residents and the police.

title: Twyla Tharp: Turning Sharp Corners
description: ''This year is an extraordinary set of circumstances. It's what I think of as a shakedown,'' says the choreographer Twyla Tharp, who for the first time in 23 years, is without a dance company that bears her name or her singular stamp. This past July, Ms. Tharp announced that she was disbanding the modern-dance troupe she began in 1965 and accepting the invitation of American Ballet Theater's artistic director Mikhail Baryshnikov to join A.B.T. as an artistic associate and resident choreographer, a billing she now shares with Sir Kenneth MacMillan.

title: A Holiday Seson Tradition: Counting Westchester's Birds
description: AS most of Westchester slumbered through a Monday holiday last week, Paul M. Saraceni stood on a frozen Hudson River bank gazing at the mass of seagulls soaring in the stiff breeze, the first rays of the sun glinting on their wings. Mr. Saraceni watched their ascent carefully, searching for any white wings or other unusual species. On this morning, there were none.

title: Readers Speak Out on N.F.L. Parity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Exploring Islamic Cairo
description: CAIRO comes at you like an assailant, or a persistent vendor of dubious wares. It teems and hustles, bursts with energy, oozes decay, collapses under its own frustrations. But it will not be denied. On the banks of the Nile, the impressions tumble, willy-nilly: noise and dust and the strangled calls of street hawkers; awesome sunsets, chaos, traffic, polluted air; the click of croquet mallets on the pampered lawns of the Gezira Sporting Club, a whisper of wind in its palms.

title: DRESSING DOWN
description: Relaxed formality, fashion's buzzword for the 1980's, was a phrase broad enough to encompass a multitude of trends. It covered the advent of the ''big suit,'' a wide-shouldered, loose-fitting hybrid of Italian and Yankee tailoring, as well as the return of the double-breasted jacket. But the final years of the decade that ushered in such hyper-refinements as brocade vests for daytime may have suffered from fashion overkill.

title: Loose Talk
description: The statement was mild and qualified, but when Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima of Nagasaki, Japan, suggested that Emperor Hirohito bears some responsibility for World War II, it brought editorials, petitions and death threats.

title: Regulations May Better Environment
description: Two new regulations intended to improve New York's environment will go into effect with the New Year.

title: It Takes Two to Weigh All Sides of Prokofiev
description: In one of history's ironies, Serge Prokofiev died on March 5, 1953, the same date as Stalin. The Soviet press, of course, played up the dictator's demise to the virtual exclusion of the composer's. Even in death, Stalin and his Bolshevik state cast a shadow over Prokofiev's career - as, indeed, they did over all Soviet composers' lives.

title: Who Came First? Dispute Over Priority
description: LEAD: THE Towns of Southold and Southampton have a lot in common. Both are on the eastern end of Long Island, the first part of their names is a direction on the compass and both claim to have been settled in 1640.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
Shopping Center For Chinatown
description: LEAD: A SHORTAGE of retail space has led to the leasing of more than 65 percent of the space in Chinatown's yet-unbuilt first shopping center. The foundation for the project - Chinatown Galleria, with a development cost estimated at $5.3 million - went in last November.

title: FICTION
description: PEACHTREE ROAD. By Anne Rivers Siddons. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) The prologue of ''Peachtree Road'' promises a sweeping chronicle of wealthy Atlanta gentry ruined by their privileged destinies, a formula for blueblood decay. The plot is jammed with incest, arson, suicide, gang rape - cardinal components of the great Southern saga. Sheppard Gibbs Bondurant 3d, the benumbed, reclusive son of an aristocratic Georgia family, narrates the tale, which spans some 40-odd years of life on Peachtree Road, the axis of Atlanta's exclusive Buckhead section. Baroque rituals precisely dictate the pattern of Buckhead's social fabric, and Shep devotes his life to protecting his beloved cousin Lucy from these censorious standards. At first Lucy appears to be the classic wild-child Southern spitfire, but as she ages she descends into alcoholic nymphomania. Shep doggedly follows her from one melodramatic exploit to the next as the civil rights movement and the rise of the New South churn in the background. Anne Rivers Siddons provides many loving descriptions of the Atlanta area and some finely tuned metaphors. However, aside from Shep and Lucy, the novel teems with peripheral figures who are brought forth almost in the style of a census. We learn about their cars and homes, and the ages of their children, but beyond that they remain bit players in a drama that sets out a string of carefully spaced mishaps. The premise of ''Peachtree Road'' is that the South's rigid code of behavior tragically destroys those who live by it, or near it. But it is an inadvertent tragedy that Ms. Siddons has wrought here in her fifth novel: the epic weight of her straining theme flattens her characters into stereotypes; their machinations do not, in the end, deserve the attention she has lavished on them.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ALICIA: My Story. By Alicia Appleman-Jurman. (Bantam, $18.95.) Alicia Appleman-Jurman's autobiography, ''Alicia,'' is so profoundly observed, and the life it records so remarkably lived, that no amount of prior immersion in the sad community of witnesses to the Holocaust can dull the reader to its heroine.

title: The Big Renouncement
description: DEEDS, NOT WORDS, are what count, we are repeatedly reminded. And Shakespeare's Hamlet, with his sighing dismissal of ''Words, words, words,'' gave the word >words a cast of inaction if not meaninglessness.

title: Mary Ann Knauss Is Wed To Rep. Hamilton Fish Jr.
description: The marriage of Mary Ann Tinklepaugh Knauss, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for intergovernmental affairs, to Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of Millbrook, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Philip's Episcopal Church-in-the-Highlands in Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Francis Hartley Geer and the Rev. Raymond Cunningham Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Lemieux's 5 Goals Set Penguin Mark B
description: The irrepressible Mario Lemieux of the Penguins displayed the abundance of his hockey talents again this afternoon in an 8-6 triumph over the Devils.

title: Business Leaders See Continued Growth
description: WHAT do Westchester business leaders see in store for the New Year? In contrast to the national uncertainty about the strength of the economy, Westchester observers are anticipating that this year the local business climate will favor economic growth in the county. There is concern, however, that the lack of affordable housing and of adequate public transportation and the shortages of entry-level workers may pose problems. Nine experts give their views: S. J. Schulman. president of the Westchester County Association, White Plains.

title: Choosing Cultural Life
description: A KIND of cultural brainstorming will take place in the county in the next two weeks as seven public meetings are held across Westchester to gather ideas for improving community cultural life.

title: NO ONE STAYS CLEAN IN WASHINGTON
description: JACK GANCE By Ward Just. 279 pp. Boston. A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: PAT SAJAK LATE NIGHT
description: Pat Sajak, whose new late-night talk show is scheduled to go up against Carson, says he will eschew Johnny Carson's introductory monologue to avoid the ''millisecond'' of ''panic'' he sees in Johnny's eyes after a failed joke (''The Good Fortune of Pat Sajak,'' by Diane K. Shah, Dec. 11). He says he will avoid David Letterman's ''stinging sarcasm'' because he cannot imagine insulting the executives of the parent company.

title: Newcomers to Region Donate To the Neediest Cases Fund
description: Michael and Mary Ann Bode, who moved to New York City in June from San Francisco, have made their first contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Keep Moviegoers Moving
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: S.I. Corporate Park; Culture Goes West
description: Four years ago, Everything Yogurt decided the cramped Wall Street area was no place for a growing frozen-confection franchise. It opted instead for the relatively open spaces of the east shore of Staten Island and renovated a former bank building in Port Richmond for its headquarters.

title: What's a Fair Price for Weakness?
description: One of the most interesting judgments a player is called upon to make is whether inducing a weakness in the opponent's pawn position is worth the lost tempo that the probe and retreat require. The conflict is between structure and time.

title: Second-Guessing Sophisticates
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Lenin: The Novel'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Fines Robertson Campaign $25,000 for Election Law Breach
description: Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign committee has agreed to pay $25,000 in fines for violations of Federal election law, the Federal Election Commission says.

title: Not Just Black vs. White
description: The stormy politics of South Africa since the emergency decrees of 1985 reaches most of us in single, incendiary images from news reports. Yet the reality of life under apartheid is far more complex than simple distinctions like black versus white, writes David C. Turnley, a photojournalist, in WHY ARE THEY WEEPING? South Africans Under Apartheid (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, Cloth, $35; Paper, $19.95). This beautiful but disturbing collection of more than 100 of Mr. Turnley's color photographs, with a superb accompanying essay by Alan Cowell, formerly the New York Times bureau chief in Johannesburg, is an unusual book. Mr. Turnley tries to provide a human context for recent political unrest. Not only does he record moments of joy, intimacy and grief within the tribal homelands and poor black townships; he also captures something of what it means to be a white Afrikaner living in a rural farming community or a rich urban suburb. And though he includes many dramatic images of the mass funerals and prayer vigils that have been the only vehicles for black activism since 1976, when the Government banned outdoor political gatherings, his most haunting photographs are those in which blacks and whites are pictured side by side as boss and worker, inextricably linked through economics, though hopelessly separated by Pretoria's racist politics. Mr. Cowell provides all the historical background these pictures need. He explores the politics behind the current state of emergency and writes interestingly of the violence at Crossroads, Capetown's most renowned squatter camp, and the inception and organizational strategy of the U.D.F., the coalition of anti-apartheid groups. Since the Pretoria Government's press restrictions in 1986, neither Mr. Cowell nor Mr. Turnley has been permitted to continue his coverage of South Africa, which is further proof of the power of their work.

title: In New Jersey, the State Tries to Rein In Local Sprawl
description: NEW JERSEY, the most densely populated state, is also one of the most fragmented. This is one reason why so much attention is being paid to the state's attempts to coordinate the activities of all 567 towns and cities and devise a comprehensive vision of the state's future.

title: Black-Eyed Peas For the New Year
description: A STAPLE of traditional Southern cooking, like grits and corn meal, black-eyed peas are heavily seasoned with myth and memories. This is one reason why many Southerners keep explaining their appeal to people who never asked. ''They're just so satisfying and good,'' a Kentuckian said, ''Each pea is like a tiny, juicy pork chop!'' He remembers childhood dinners always starting the same way: ''We sat down and somebody said, 'Pass the black-eyed peas.' ''

title: IT'S NOT OVER UNTIL THE SOPRANO DIES
description: OPERA, OR THE UNDOING OF WOMEN By Catherine Clement. Translated by Betsy Wing. 201 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $13.95.

title: The Miniatures Industry Grows - By Inches, Naturally
description: Maria Moll, a 36-year-old schoolteacher who lives in the Bronx, has a mighty generous boyfriend. For Christmas, he turned her loose in a store on Manhattan's Upper East Side with enough money to buy a bed, dresser, desk, mirror, table and sideboard, plants and plant stand, gilded bird cage, furniture for a baby's room, curtains, rugs, and assorted odds and ends, including a New York Mets pennant, perfume and a cheeseburger.

title: Faye Levin Is Engaged
description: Faye Deborah Levin, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Taub & Fasciana, and Dr. Harvey Mark Levin, a dentist in Washington, plan to be married in June. Dr. and Mrs. Norman L. Levin of Brooklyn have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Gertrude Levin of the Bronx and the late Harry Levin. The families are not related. Miss Levin graduated magna cum laude from Clark University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a J.D. from Boston University. Her fiance attended the Columbia University School of Pharmacy and graduated from the Howard University School of Dentistry.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The 1989 Bob Jones Award winner for distinguished sportsmanship, determined by the United States Golf Association, is Chi Chi Rodriguez, who won eight tournaments on the PGA Tour and is now a star on the senior tour. He started and still supports the Chi Chi Rodriguez Youth Foundation, a Florida center which helps abused and disadvantaged youths. . . . The Lafayette quarterback Frank Baur, the Eastern Kentucky running back Elroy Harris and the Connecticut wide receiver Glenn Antrum - the nation's leading passer, rusher and receiver - have been named to The Associated Press's Division I-AA all-America team. Also named were four members of the 1987 team: Sean Doctor, a tight end from Marshall; Glenell Sanders, a Louisiana Tech linebacker, and two defensive backs, Mark Seals of Boston University and Kevin Dent of Jackson State.(AP)

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Resolution No. 1: No More Lists
description: LEAD: IT may be said that the road to hell is paved with New Year's resolutions. Some folks never make them because they are naturally organized, disciplined, motivated and strong willed all year. Thank goodness I don't know any of them.

title: Venezuela Orders 20 Arrests In Killing of 14 Fishermen
description: A military court ordered the arrest of 20 members of a Government task force on Friday in the killing of 14 Venezuelan fishermen in October.

title: THE REGION: Licenses and Tests; The Making of the Principals In New York City Schools
description: PRINCIPALS are often remembered as models of stern rectitude who could hush an auditorium of caterwauling children with the slight elevation of an eyebrow.

title: 'Barnum' Review Missed the Point
description: Shame on Leah D. Frank's review of ''Barnum'' [ Dec. 11 ] , applying Broadway standards to denigrate it. Considering the limited resources of Theater Three - small theater, local talent - the production was almost seamlessly delightful. My wife and I saw it and enjoyed it immensely. Some of the acting, singing and dancing and stage business was so professional as we've seen anywhere, and carried along the story line, not just ''a loose confederation of scenes.'' Those young people should be encouraged to go on, not deflated. HAROLD GRILL Seaford

title: WRITES OF PASSAGE
description: SAFE AT LAST IN THE MIDDLE YEARS The Invention of the Midlife Progress Novel: Saul Bellow, Margaret Drabble, Anne Tyler, and John Updike. By Margaret Morganroth Gullette. 186 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $19.95.

title: About Cars; Some Leftovers That Bear Reheating
description: The holidays are a good time for leftovers, and 1988 has more than its share. Here are some of them, along with a helping of late-breaking notions.

title: Dragons, Tiny Treasures and Pasmore
description: IN New Haven, there is ferment on both sides of Chapel Street, with the Yale University Art Gallery host to two traveling exhibitions and the Yale Center for British Art the scene of a retrospective that will also travel. The magnum opus at the Art Gallery is ''In Pursuit of the Dragon: Traditions and Transitions in Ming Ceramics,'' which comes from the Idemitsu Museum of Arts in Tokyo.

title:
DINING OUT;
It's Worth the Search in Lambertville
description: LEAD: IT takes the perseverance of a pioneer to find Hamilton's Grill. The six-month-old restaurant, which is a block from the Delaware River, is tucked behind an antiques shop in an alley called the Porkyard, off a side street in the Hunterdon County town of Lambertville. Only a small sign with the restaurant's logo, a blue-and-white grid, at the corner of the alley gives a hint of the charming courtyard at the end.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Garden City $405,000 4 Birch Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old center-hall colonial; fireplace, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,900. Hempstead $220,000 21 Clark Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 55-year-old colonial; fireplace in living room, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,250. Levittown $146,000 39 Eden Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,800. Patchogue $126,000 6 Castle Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,700. Shoreham $175,000 80 North Country Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; fireplace, oak floors, den, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $1,800. Wading River $153,500 2 Cliff Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 5-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, beach rights; taxes $1,600. OTHER SALES Bloomfield, Conn. $164,900 20 Clover Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; new deck, open-floor plan, 88- by 159-foot lot; taxes $1,885. Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $450,000 Deertrack Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; fireplace, den, family room, solarium, 2.8 acres; taxes $7,926. South Orange, N.J. $175,000 356 Meadowbrook Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, enclosed porch, formal dining room; taxes $2,791.

title: Tea for Two (or More): A Sampling in London
description: IN London, one does not have tea. One does not merely drink tea. One takes tea, like one takes a holiday, or a calming constitutional, or a medicine that puts one's health to rights. English teatime is a social ritual, made fashionable in the 1840's, but it is a quiet and relaxing social ritual. As Michael Twomey, manager of the Palm Court of the Ritz Hotel in London, says, ''In the middle of the afternoon, when your batteries run down, it is a very nice thing to take tea.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
On the Abuses Of Grading Services
description: LEAD: THE rare coin market has benefited from the certification of coins by independent grading services. It has stabilized the market and given investors new confidence. But, in at least one area, certification has led to unfortunate abuses.

title: The Original Appeaser
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping the Elderly Keep Their Homes
description: LEAD: FINANCIAL arrangements that enable elderly homeowners to tap the equity in their increasingly valuable homes as a means of paying for the upkeep of the homes are gaining wider acceptance, say bank and public officials and advocates for the elderly.

title: Of Men, Women And Money
description: I would like to add a thought to the article on the complex subject of the impact of women's opportunities and attitudes in the workplace and academia during this century (''Now Is Not the Time to Put Women on Hold,'' Opinion page, Nov. 27).

title: '89 Tip-Off Foes Are Selected
description: The president of the Basketball Hall of Fame Tip-Off Classic says Villanova and Michigan will meet in the official opening game of the 1989 intercollegiate season.

title: Bless You, Marty
description: O.K., SO 1988 WASN'T PERFECT. We had a drought, a flood, a record-breaking heat wave. A hurricane, a forest fire and, in Bloomsburg, Pa., a roller coaster stalled midloop, suspending 20 riders upside down for more than an hour. Planes fell apart, people ate flowers, grilled tuna meat half raw. A large hole spread in the ozone layer, nightmares washed up on beaches and voracious pear thrips ate Vermont's sugar maples.

title: For Yuppies on Stage, a Time for Reflection
description: In the theater, as in life, people have been discovering that the fast track can be a treadmill. They are forced to confront what could be called the Yuppie Trauma: early success leading to young-life crisis. If you rise to the top of a profession before you are 30 - as stockbroker, movie producer, publisher, theater director - burnout may result when you are 30 something.

title: Why Call Them Artists?
description: To the Editor:

title: Poorhampton No More: Bridgehampton Is Upscale Now Too
description: WHEN I moved to Bridgehampton 25 years ago, it might as well have been called Poorhampton. Nearly every store on Main Street was vacant. Potato farmers were worried that their crop was worth less than the land on which it grew. Golden nematode disease impaired what potatoes they could grow. They were in hock to the local banks as they used their machinery as collateral to get through the winter.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Of Bowls, Bonuses and Big-Time Athletics
description: LEAD: This is college football at the climax of the 1988 season: Mobil Oil, Sea World and USF&G; pay off the teams and put their names on the holiday bowl games. Lou Holtz gets the opportunity to achieve fame in the Sunkist Fiesta. Barry Switzer plays for Florida Citrus, and Vince Dooley rides along with Mazda at the Gator.

title: Head Lice Infestation Found In Library of Congress Rooms
description: Officials at the Library of Congress have at least one problem in common with the lowliest elementary school librarian in the land - head lice.

title: Martha B. Weyl,Librarian, Weds E. W. Kenworthy
description: Martha B. Weyl of New York, a former librarian and bookbinder, was married yesterday to Edwin W. Kenworthy of Washington, a retired reporter for The New York Times. The ceremony took place at the Fifteenth Street Friends Meeting House in New York. The couple were attended by their children and grandchildren.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article in the Long Island Weekly today about the Shoreham nuclear power plant misidentifies John V. N. Klein. He is a former Suffolk County Executive.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Credit Card Widens Plan For Car Renters

title: Nintendo Fans
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Amiot, Employment Manager, To Wed Robert Stuart Hull in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Amiot Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Stephanie L'Abbe Amiot to Robert Stuart Hull, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd N. Hull of Greenwich. The couple plan a July wedding. Miss Amiot, a graduate of Denison University, received a master's degree in organizational psychology from Columbia University. She is the employment manager at Backer Spielvogel Bates, an advertising agency in New York. Her father, who is retired, was a partner in Ward Howell International, an executive research firm in New York. Her mother, Rebecca Amiot, is a teacher in the Greenwich public school system.

title: Elegant Showcase For Jamaican Crafts
description: SET well back from the bustling junction of Waterloo Road and Hope Road near the center of Kingston is the grande dame of Jamaican architecture, Devon House. The sprawling mansion, which resembles a classic 19th-century American plantation house, is surrounded by manicured lawns. Gravel paths lead visitors past formal gardens and fountains watched over by smiling cast-iron cherubs. Blue water hyacinths float in clear pools under a canopy of tall palms, and an allee of hibiscus leads to the wide veranda.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FAMILY SKIING SPOT

title: Marla Kirsh Plans Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. S. Martin Kirsh of Lyndhurst, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Marla Kirsh, to Dr. Brian David Gale, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. Gale of New Rochelle, N.Y. Ms. Kirsh is an associate at the New York office of the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue. Her fiance is a resident physician in nuclear medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University. They plan to marry in August.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. The threads on the outside filler pipe for my oil tank are worn out, so when the cover is put on it does not form a watertight seal. When it rains, water seeps in, causing the oil burner to fail. The oil company wants to put in a new pipe, but this is expensive. Is there a less expensive way to fix this?

title: Bears Roll Past Eagles as Fog Rolls In
description: To the 65,534 spectators at Soldier Field and the millions who watched the game on television, this is confirmation that the Bears soundly defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 20-12, today in either the Fog Bowl or the National Football League playoffs.

title:
What's In, What's Out, What's What;
Art
description: LEAD: In the art world, money is in; it always has been, of course, but not like this: $53 million for Van Gogh, $17 million for Jasper Johns, over $12 million for LeRoy Neiman - or was it Grandma Moses? The artist doesn't really matter; it's the money you hear about. Of course, nobody wants to look like a complete fool, and, as a result, we have these brand new art consultants.

title: Hello. Yes, It's Your Dial-a-Mom.
description: I watched them cut the umbilical cord when each of my three children was born. But the telephone cord - now that's a different story.

title: CLOSING OF BASES IS AN OPENING SHOT
description: If the independent commission on military bases has its way, the closing of bases it has just recommended will be only the beginning of a long process to close or consolidate many more bases.

title: 3-Year-Old Saves His Mother
description: A 3-year-old boy, using the telephone for the first time, saved his ill mother's life by calling the operator and asking her to reach his father at work.

title: Q and A
description: Low Countries

title: Troubles Ease in Paradise
description: LEAD: It has been a difficult year for Club Med Inc. But some analysts believe the worst may be behind the resort operator, which is incorporated in the Cayman Islands. Its stock, which reached a high of $32.25 on the New York Stock Exchange in 1986, now trades at about $13. But Bertrand F. Facon, an analyst at the First Boston

title: East End Divided Over Tuition Plan
description: LEAD: THE East End may be the site of a new high school one of these days, not because of overcrowding but because of a proposed 60 percent increase in tuition at East Hampton High School for those students who live outside the East Hampton School District.

title: Sophie Carpenter To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Sophie Carre Carpenter to Russell Frazier Speidel 2d, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Chapin Carpenter Jr. and Bowie Robertson Carpenter, both of Washington. A June 24 wedding is planned. Miss Carpenter, a graduate of the National Cathedral School in Washington, graduated from the University of Virginia, where she expects to receive a master's in May from the School of Education. Her father, who recently retired as a senior vice president of the Magazine Publishers of America, is a consultant to that trade organization in Washington. Her mother is the registrar at the National Cathedral School.

title: In Yonkers, the 'World Is Round'
description: THE world is coming apart in the Hudson River Museum, at Yonkers. Its fragmentation is the result, not of an explosion, but of the search by 22 artists for another angle on reality. The findings by these artists, called ''The World Is Round: Contemporary Panoramas,'' were organized for the museum by a guest curator, Marcia Clark, but they have only just arrived there, having spent the last year touring other galleries in the Northeast.

title: Pan Am Blast: An Inquiry in Hot Pursuit
description: In a dozen nations on both sides of the Atlantic, an intense and sophisticated investigation is under way into the downing of a Pan Am jumbo jet with 259 people aboard.

title:
GARDENING;
What Can Be Learned From Last Year
description: LEAD: LAST year was not the easiest for gardeners. Plagued by drought and heat, many gardens did not live up to expectations, and many gardeners were tempted to retreat to their air-conditioners.

title: Aluminum House Is Dismantled
description: ARCHITECTURE students on Long Island have completed dismantling and storing a three-story, five-room aluminum house. The house is being kept at the New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip until it can be reconstructed on the school's campus next spring.

title: Taking Solace In the Caring Of Strangers
description: When Susan Cohen learned that her only child, Theodora, had died on Pan Am Flight 103, she was so distraught that on the way to the airport she twice tried to throw herself from the car onto the highway.

title: Spain's Paradors: Inns With a Touch of History
description: SOMEWHERE between luxury hotels and bad boarding houses are the paradors of Spain, the Government-owned hotel system.

title: A School Offers a Model for Ulster Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Financiers Sense an Opportunity In the Savings Industry's Distress
description: Many of the nation's most troubled savings institutions are being rescued these days by many of the nation's savviest and most aggressive financiers, corporate executives and takeover experts.

title: INSIDE
description: Organizing Against Israel

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Which Teams Will Meet in the Super Bowl?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Vandalism Renews Fight on Shelter
description: With cold weather moving into the nation's capital, a long-simmering dispute between advocates for the homeless and the city's subway system has heated up.

title: Pondering Profits, Problems and the Future
description: As the new year begins, many of the old economic troubles remain - the budget and trade deficits, for instance. In addition, both the leading economic indicators and home sales are sharply down. Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman talked to 12 leaders in business and labor, who expressed concern, optimism and a commitment to work to solve national and business problems. Ted Turner Chairman, Turner Broadcasting System Inc.

title: Seeking Out The Surrealism in Balanchine Ballets
description: It's not easy to label George Balanchine. Because he used traditional ballet technique as the basis for his choreography, he is often called a classicist. Yet, his ability to adapt, develop or even distort traditional steps as he saw fit has also led him to be called a neo-classicist. However, recent revivals of two rarely performed ballets by Balanchine make it clear that those terms are insufficient to categorize him.

title: Citizen Reagan Won't Be a Retiree
description: His new neighbors will breathe a sigh of relief, his old friends will throw glittering parties, and the mashed-potato circuit will have a new star attraction.

title: At Least 51 Die As Party Vessel Capsizes Off Rio
description: At least 51 people drowned and another 30 to 40 were believed to be missing when a boat carrying party-goers to watch a New Year's fireworks display along Copacabana Beach sank at the entrance to the bay of Rio de Janeiro a few minutes before midnight Saturday.

title: Review/Music; The Philharmonic's Toast to Old and New Years
description: The New York Philharmonic closed its books on 1988 with a festive Pension Fund Benefit concert on New Year's Eve at Avery Fisher Hall. For the occasion, the orchestra was considerably enlarged and played under a canopy of colorful streamers, interlaced with microphone cables. The latter were used both for the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' broadcast, which piped the proceedings into living rooms across the country, and by CBS Records, which recorded the concert.

title: Wide Effect Seen From Trade Pact
description: Tariff cuts that took effect at midnight on Dec. 31 under a Canadian-American free trade agreement will bring cheaper ice skates and skateboards, fur coats and automobile parts to many Americans.

title: Thirty Years of Fidel Castro
description: Thirty years ago on New Year's Day, Cubans acclaimed Fidel Castro as the youthful liberator who felled the corrupt tyranny of Fulgencio Batista. Today the 62-year-old Mr. Castro himself resembles one of those crabbed caudillos in the novels of his Colombian friend, Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

title: Even in Fog, Finish the Game
description: EVER since the Buffalo Bills emerged as a Super Bowl contender, pro football people wondered what the weather would be like here on Jan. 1 for a playoff game. Surely zero degrees. Maybe snow. But yesterday turned up sunny and warm. At least sunny and warm for Buffalo at this time of year: 33 degrees at the kickoff with hardly any wind. And hardly any earmuffs.

title: Marci International Imports reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 13
Talk by Maurice Sendak Begins a Writers' Series
description: The author and illustrator Maurice Sendak is to be the opening-night speaker at the Hudson Park branch of the New York Public Library, 66 Leroy Street, on Jan. 12 at 6:30 P.M., when the library begins its fifth series of discussions titled Village Writers Meet Their Neighbors.

title: Bookstores Look to Instant Ordering
description: Customers who order an out-of-stock title from a bookstore would be well advised to settle down with another book while awaiting delivery -something on the order of ''War and Peace.'' While book publishing has modernized some production methods, the process of getting books from the warehouse remains mired in antiquity.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Babe Ruth hit 60 home runs for the Yankees in 1927 to set a major league mark, what was the National League record and who held it?

title: Two Alternatives to the Situp
description: THIS is a celebration of strong abdominal muscles and flat stomachs, but particularly strong lower backs. So try this test.

title: Memo Contradicts Government Reports On Uranium Leaks
description: Uranium emissions in 1961 at a federally owned processing plant were much greater than the Government has acknowldeged, a recently discovered memorandum shows.

title: Steinberg and Myerson Trials: 2 Cases Provoke Many Books
description: Publishers have already spent more than a million dollars on advances to authors writing about Manhattan's two most talked-about current courtroom dramas: the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg and the corruption trial that ended in the acquittal of Bess Myerson, a former Miss America and New York cultural commissioner. And there is no end in sight.

title: Outdoors: Fundamental Steps for Using Decoy Ducks
description: THERE is no one way to decoy ducks successfully, but knowledge of a few fundamentals will save you time and put more birds in your freezer.

title: Burnishing Detroit's Faded Image
description: The Motor City is trying to mount an auto show that will help it burnish its faded image as the car capital of the world.

title: Old Fashion Foods Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Nov 26
description: b-After a gain of $203,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Consul Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $70,000 for the latest 6 months and $160,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Fischbach Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $10,433,000 from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT The Canadian-American free trade agreement will bring cheaper ice skates and skateboards, fur coats and auto parts to many Americans. Canadians may find bargains in skis, furniture, computers and telephone handsets under the tariff cuts that took effect at midnight on Dec. 31. Duties are being reduced or eliminated in more than 8,000 categories - the start of a 10-year process that will end practically all trade barriers between the countries, freeing investment and strengthening ties. [ Page 29. ] Debt swaps are coming under fire in Latin countries. This method of reducing the region's payments - through conversion of debt into equity - is said to swell the money supply in countries already struggling with triple-digit inflation. Another complaint is that it expands foreign control of local economies without significantly increasing investment. [ 29. ] OPEC appeared ready to curb oil production under an agreement aimed at raising prices by cutting output nearly 20 percent. But experts said prices would probably stay below $15 a barrel because of high levels of supply. The accord, which would limit production of the 13 OPEC members to 18.5 million barrels a day for six months, took effect yesterday. [ 29. ] U.S. stock markets were again outperformed in 1988 by their counterparts abroad. Out of 20 countries, the United States ranked 12th when return is measured in dollar terms, outdone by Belgium, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Japan, France, Australia, Singapore/ Malaysia, Hong Kong, West Germany and Canada. [ 32. ] THE ECONOMY Superconductor patent battles now beginning could determine which organizations and even which nations control the rights to the new high-temperature materials that could revolutionize fields like computers and electricity generation. [ 1. ] Many American farmers appear to be prepared to fight on the issues of free trade that they see symbolized in a barrier the European Community has imposed against any American beef produced with the aid of growth hormones. [ 10. ] The new Banking Committee chairmen are a study in contrasts. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the 15-term Democrat from San Antonio, is the House eccentric, ardent populist and the first Hispanic person to be elected to Congress. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., a three-term Democrat from Michigan, with business training from Harvard, is deliberative and serious. [ 12. ] COMPANIES Airline profits in the United States are soaring to their highest level since the industry was deregulated 10 years ago. Behind the boom are higher air fares and modest growth in traffic. [ 29. ] Detroit is preparing an expanded auto show that it hopes will burnish its faded image as the international leader in car manufacturing. The show, which opens Saturday, will include the introduction of several new models by domestic and foreign makers. [ 29. ] San Diego officials oppose the bid by a utility company in Los Angeles to acquire San Diego Gas and Electric. [ 29. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS New varieties of video news releases worry some experts on journalism. Concerned about the quality and ethics of television news, they think this technique used to convey corporate views represents a dangerous blurring of news and advertising. Television. [ 33. ] A computerized ordering system for booksellers will go on line this spring, promising far greater speed and an end to much guesswork. Twenty-five major publishing houses have already agreed to participate in the system, called Pubnet. [ 33. ] A ''business magazine'' program begins today on public radio, with roughly 80 stations carrying the broadcast nationwide, making it the most widely distributed program of its kind. Called ''Marketplace,'' it will be distributed by American Public Radio. [ 33. ] TODAY'S COLUMN The Tax Reform Act of 1986 is harmful to the nation's economic health, some economists assert, because it encourages debt more than equity, a situation they say is particularly noticeable in regard to leveraged buyouts. Tax Watch. [ 30. ]

title: Youth Shot by Police Is a Hit-Run Suspect
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth, who the police later learned was a suspect in a fatal hit-and-run accident in June, was shot early yesterday morning by a police officer during a routine stop for a minor traffic violation, a police spokesman said.

title: Books of The Times; The Links and Rifts Between Fathers and Sons
description: First Acts A Memoir By B. L. Reid Illustrated. 243 pages. University of Georgia Press. $16.95. Spellbound Growing Up in God's Country By David McKain 257 pages. University of Georgia Press. $18.95.

title: The German Problem
description: Can it be that the ''good Germans'' are at it again - claiming to know nothing about the participation of some of their countrymen in a power-maniac's plans for his own Final Solution?

title: John Paul Issues a Plea for Minority Rights
description: Pope John Paul II today called on ''all men of good will'' to help build a world of peace and justice in 1989, and the Pope emphasized the need to defend the rights of members of minority groups.

title: Courageous Men
description: Vince Newsome of the Los Angeles Rams was Ed Block's kind of guy. Newsome has never whined or complained in the past two seasons, which were full of stress and strife for him. Now he is in a position to win the Ed Block Courage Award.

title: Computerland Court Ruling
description: A California appeals court has upheld a jury verdict granting a large minority stake in the Computerland Corporation to a group of investors.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Cagey Exuberance Wins Handicap: Cagey Exuberance, the favorite in the field of eight and carrying high weight of 121 pounds, rallied through the stretch yesterday to score a two-length victory in the $87,150 Interborough Handicap at Aqueduct. The triumph in the race for fillies and mares 3 years old and up was the third of the day for Richard Migliore, Cagey's Exuberance's jockey. Hedgeabout, carrying 114 pounds and Frank Lovato Jr., was the runner-up by a neck ahead of Sunshine Always, who carried 114 pounds with James Bruin. Hedgeabout was coupled in the wagering with Clever Power. Cagey Exuberance covered six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 2/5 and returned $3.80 for $2 to win.(AP) Ski Jumping Second Leg to Nykaenen: Matti Nykaenen of Finland won the second leg of the Four-Hill ski-jumping tour by soaring 109 and 102 meters yesterday in his two jumps at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, West Germany. Dieter Thoma of West Germany, who captured the first segment of the event in Oberstdorf two days earlier, managed only a fourth-place finish in the second leg.(AP) Tennis Czechoslovaks Capture Team Title: Czechoslovakia won the first Hopman Cup international team event yesterday with a 2-0 victory over Australia. Helena Sukova and Miloslav Mecir ensured the victory for Czechoslovakia by winning the mixed doubles against Pat Cash and Hana Mandlikova, 6-4, 6-2. The competition was held in Perth, Australia. Earlier, Sukova, who is ranked eighth in the world, beat Mandlikova, 6-4, 6-3, in the opening singles.(AP) Road Racing Oregonian Takes Midnight Run: Brad Hudson of Eugene, Ore., won the Moet/New York Road Runners Club New Year's Eve five-mile midnight run in 23 minutes 20 seconds. Jim McKeon, the defender from Short Hills, N.J., was second in 24:01. Anne Letko of Glen Gardner, N.J., repeated as the women's winner in 27:22. Letko, a student at Wake Forest University, finished 85 yards ahead of Ingr Schaurman of Richmond. Basketball Lady Vols Breeze: Debbie Scott led top-ranked Tennessee (10-1) with 14 points as the Lady Vols routed Western Michigan, 84-39, in Knoxville, Tenn. Western Michigan (4-5) was led by Ruthanne Wisniewski, who had 15 points.(AP)

title: Bancroft Convertible Fund Inc reports earnings for As of Oct 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The fund said it changed its fiscal year-end from March 31 to Oct. 31; year-ago results are not available.

title: Brazil's Economy Slows
description: The Brazilian economy, plagued by an inflation rate of more than 900 percent, showed hardly any growth this year. Brazil's gross domestic product rose only four-hundredths of 1 percent in 1988, the national statistics office said Friday in its first estimate for the year. The stagnant economy contrasted sharply with growth of 2.9 percent a year earlier and an 8 percent rise in 1986. Farming output grew by only six-hundredths of 1 percent in 1988 and industrial production fell by 2.23 percent, the institute said.

title: Val d'Isere Journal; On to Olympian Glory, but at Too Steep a Price?
description: When Jean-Claude Killy thinks about the year 1992, he doesn't have in mind the European Community's ambitious deadline for creating a frontier-free market of 320 million consumers.

title: Doors Open for Only Some Soviet Dissidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Calls the Deployment Of a Carrier Group 'Routine'
description: A 13-ship aircraft carrier battle group that left Norfolk, Va., on Friday for the Mediterranean was sent on a ''routine deployment,'' a Navy spokesman said today.

title: Review/Cabaret; June-Moon-Croon, in a Classical Way
description: What do the vintage hit songs ''Don't You Know?,'' ''Strange Music,'' ''Tonight We Love,'' ''There's No Tomorrow'' and ''Full Moon and Empty Arms'' share? All are pop songs that borrowed their melodies from themes by classical composers. In most cases, the pop lyrics attached to them were Broadway and Tin Pan Alley homilies that attempted to match the tunes' melodic sweep with vague greeting-card profundities evoking the moon, the stars and eternity.

title: Unimed Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
41 Minutes Into '89, City Records First Homicide
description: A 19-year-old Queens man who was killed in a dispute shortly after he left the raucous New Year's revelry in Times Square was the city's first homicide victim of 1989, the police said yesterday.

title: New Year's Resolution
description: LEAD: Well, I did it again, bringing in that infant Purity across the land, welcoming Innocence with gin in New York, waiting up to help Chicago, Denver, L.A., Fairbanks, Hon-olulu - and now the high school bands are alienating Dallas, and girls in gold and tangerine have lost all touch with Pasadena, and young men with muscles and missing teeth are dreaming of personal fouls, and it's all beginning again, just like those other Januaries in instant replay.

title: 20 Years Ago, Three Men Circled the Moon
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Wall Of Silence; Tompkins Goal Is Making Police Talk
description: Last week, nearly five months after New York City police officers called to Tompkins Square Park clubbed and kicked scores of bystanders, 400 officers and 40 sergeants who had been there that night stood accused of a new offense: stonewalling investigators from the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: Israel Expels 13 Palestinians Accused of Aiding Uprising
description: Thirteen Palestinians accused of leading the uprising in the occupied territories were deported to Lebanon today, and residents of the West Bank and Gaza Strip celebrated the 23d anniversary of the first attack against Israel by Yasir Arafat's Fatah guerrilla group.

title: Daniel Curley, Novelist And Story Writer, 70
description: Daniel Curley, a novelist and short story writer, died Friday night of injuries suffered when he was struck by a car while vacationing in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived in Urbana, Ill.

title: Infant Is Discarded With the Trash
description: A 23-year-old woman was charged with manslaughter after reportedly discarding her newborn infant with the trash sometime early last week, the Gloucester County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Dam Break Forces Evacuation
description: An earthen dike broke early today, forcing the evacuation of an estimated 1,500 people for several hours and closure of a major interstate highway, the authorities said.

title: OPEC Ready To Begin Output Limits
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries appeared ready to begin curbing oil production under an agreement that took effect today.

title: G.O.P. Leader Expects Tax Rise in Budget Bill
description: Representative Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, said today that a tax increase would probably be part of a bipartisan budget compromise in 1989 despite President-elect George Bush's pledge to oppose higher taxes.

title: Foreign Stock Gains Outpaced U.S. in 1988
description: The Bund and the Bourse. Tokyo and Madrid. Rome and Oslo. They are nowhere near Wall Street. But they are where Americans should be buying many of their stocks, a growing number of analysts say.

title: Irving Bank Deal Completed
description: The longest-lasting bank takeover finally came to an end Friday when the Irving Bank Corporation was legally merged into the Bank of New York Company.

title: Sinn Fein's Leader Criticizes I.R.A. on Killing of Civilians
description: Gerry Adams, leader of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, has criticized the I.R.A. for killing civilians in a string of botched attacks in 1988.

title: Canadian Rail Tunnel
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. said Friday that it had completed the longest railroad tunnel in North America as part of a $420 million ($500 million Canadian), four-year project to ease the gradient for westbound freight trains crossing the Canadian Rockies. A limited number of trains are using the 9.1-mile tunnel. The tunnel is expected to become fully operational next year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-8 An Israeli austerity plan to rescue the troubled economy was unveiled by Finance Minister Shimon Peres. It includes major budget reductions and would call for the layoff of thousands of Government employees. Page 1

title: Compumed Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $246,000 on the settlement of disputed claims.

title: India Says 2,000 Troops Will Leave Sri Lanka
description: India announced today that it would withdraw about 2,000 troops from Sri Lanka in the next few days, and officials said further troop reductions would follow.

title: H.W. Zancanata Dies; Rocket Builder Was 70
description: Harold W. Zancanata, a scientist who developed some of the first rockets for testing the atmosphere, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Florida Medical Center. He was 70 years old.

title: 10 PEOPLE KILLED IN MINNESOTA FIRE
description: A fire swept quickly through a house north of here today, killing eight children and the two adults who were baby-sitting for them, the authorities said.

title: Shut Military Units May Go to Homeless
description: Two hundred thirty housing units in 12 Connecticut communities used by off-base military personnel could be converted to homeless shelters under a 1987 Federal law.

title: Even if You Agree, Don't Honk Your Horn
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Watch; Buyout Incentives Of '86 Legislation
description: WHEN Congress holds hearings on leveraged buyouts later this month, the nation's tax laws are going to come under scrutiny to see whether tax incentives are being given to the wrong people. To certain academic economists, the answer is a clear yes.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Construction Spending Nov. Wednesday Factory Orders Nov. Thursday New-Car Sales Dec. Friday Unemployment Dec.

Pub Svc Nevada Pwr Houston Inds Pacific Ent WEDNESDAY Mercantile Stores Inc Rite Aid Corp THURSDAY Amax Inc James River Corp Va American Wtr Wks Inc Puget Sound Pwr & Lt General Pub Utils Sun Inc FRIDAY Health Care Ppty Invest Travelers Corp Lubys Cafeterias Inc U S West Inc Snap-On Tools Corp

title: Brown Wants to Lead Party He Once Spurned
description: Once hailed by some as the most inspired politician of his generation and disparaged by others as ''Governor Moonbeam,'' Edmund G. Brown Jr. is attempting a comeback by running for the unlikely post of chairman of the state Democratic Party.

title: Delmar Karlen, 76, N.Y.U. Law Professor
description: Delmar Karlen, a professor emeritus of the New York University School of Law and a former director of its Institute of Judicial Administration, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Williamsburg, Va. He was 76 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Long, Sad Year
description: The death of Steven Butler aboard Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland on Dec. 21 brought to six the number of Peace Corps volunteers who died in 1988. ''It has not been a good year,'' said a spokesman for the corps.

title: Top Avnet Executive Adds Chairman's Post
description: Avnet Inc., the nation's largest semiconductor distributor, has elected Leon Machiz chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds Anthony R. Hamilton, who died of cancer on Dec. 22.

title: Upstart Fiesta Bowl Growing Into the Biggest Party of All
description: EVERY year at about this time, the people who live and work in the Valley of the Sun heard about these great parties going on from coast to coast.

title: Debt-Equity Swaps Draw Latin Criticisms
description: As the incoming Bush administration prepares to take its promised new look at Latin America's foreign debt crisis, the one well-tried method of reducing the region's payments - through conversion of debt into equity - is coming under fire in several countries.

title: Crown Andersen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Couple Found Slain In Bedroom of Home
description: A couple were found dead last night in the master bedroom of their home in this affluent Westchester County village after a relative discovered a break-in at the residence, the police said.

title: Harding Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a gain of $315,000 from a cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Tennis Lessons Via Video
description: LEAD: LEARNING to play tennis from a videotape is not the kind of interactive experience that jumping around on the floor mimicking Jane Fonda is.

title: School, Police and Employee Groups Pool Money to Give to the Neediest
description: With the pressure of year-end exams, the Baruch College Coffee Klatchers did not have much time to think about giving, said Carol Robbins, director of Evening and Graduate Services.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Flash! No Failures!
description: Closing 1988 on a hopeful note, L. William Seidman announced Friday: ''The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is pleased to announce that no F.D.I.C.-insured banks failed this holiday week anywhere in the United States.''

title: Korea Surplus With U.S. Dips
description: The national trade surplus with the United States in the first 11 months of this year decreased to $7.61 billion, down $890 million from a year ago, the Korea Foreign Trade Association reported Friday. Under American pressure, Korea has eased import curbs and taken other steps in efforts to reduce the trade excess.

title: MSI Electronics reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Washington Talk: Congress; Banking Chairmen Show Sharp Contrast in Styles
description: One wears Kelly green sport jackets, the other pin-striped suits. One has decorated his office with political memorabilia dating back 30 years or more; the other prefers modern art. One held a two-hour press conference earlier this month, exhausting reporters. The other mostly speaks not for attribution Meet the new chairmen of the House and Senate Banking committees.

title: Overhauling School Decentralization
description: New York City's school decentralization law was born in the educational, political and racial crisis of 1968 that nearly tore the city apart. Issues of teacher accountability, union power and community control were dramatically contested in the streets. The resulting legislation was a rough political compromise, not a coherent educational vision.

title: Reviews/Television; Tantalizing Tidbits About 'Gone With the Wind'
description: As the narrator says in tonight's two-hour documentary beginning at 8 o'clock on cable's Turner Network Television - TNT, of course - the movie ''Gone With the Wind'' was ''a huge thing, crammed with excesses'' and its realization required ''blind faith and great good luck.'' Now, beginning 1989 and faced with a threatened sequel to the Margaret Mitchell novel, viewers have an opportunity to go back some 50 years and savor the rather astonishing story behind the enormous movie classic that the producer David O. Selznick built.

title: Leigh Ann Wilcoxson Weds
description: Leigh Ann Wilcoxson, the daughter of Nancy Stade of Salisbury, Md., was married there yesterday to Harlan Adam Eagle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Eagle of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Cantor Alvin Donald officiated at the Sheraton Salisbury. Mrs. Eagle, a graduate of Salisbury State University, is an exercise specialist at the Dorchester General Hospital in Cambridge, Md. Mr. Eagle, a graduate of the University of Maryland who received a master's degree in athletic training from Indiana University, is a physical education teacher at Mardela High School in Salisbury.

title: Swamped by Drug-Related Cases, Connecticut Frees Convicts Early
description: Overwhelmed by an increase in drug-related arrests, Connecticut prison officials are seeking to ease overcrowding by releasing scores of convicts early.

title: Camden Journal; In Struggles of the City, Children Are Casualties
description: Except for a couple blocks of downtown, Camden looks like a war zone, with block after block of burned buildings, collapsing buildings, half-gutted buildings, boarded-up buildings and a staggering succession of lots covered with rubble.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hole in the Story
description: Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, was reading a preliminary Federal report on the nation's forestry prospects for the next 50 years when he was struck by an ''inexplicable omission.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, headlines on the Outdoors and About Cars articles were transposed yesterday in some copies of the Sports section. Readers wishing copies of the corrected page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Teheran Finds War Was Easier to Make Than a Stable Peace
description: Five months after Iran embraced a cease-fire in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, the regime is struggling over how to rebuild its economy and recast its goal of ''war until victory'' to an ideology suited to peace.

title: New Scandal in French Art World Over Purchase of a Painting
description: In France's latest art controversy, a French court has ruled that the city of Strasbourg and its Museum of Decorative Arts defrauded a 73-year-old widow in the purchase of a 17th-century canvas, possibly done by Simon Vouet, the official court painter of Louis XIII.

title: New York Pedestrians Are on a Suicide Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Dead in Los Angeles After Holiday Gunfire
description: Gunshots fired on New Year's Eve struck police cars, knocked out electricity and left one man dead, and another man was killed by officers who said he had fired at an unmarked patrol car, the police said today.

title: The Thrift Approach
description: It has been 20 years since the Kansas City Royals began their baseball academy to discover and develop prospective players. The academy passed out of existence long ago, but its purpose has not left the mind of its original director, Syd Thrift.

title: Irvine Sensors Corp reports earnings for Year to Oct 2
We May Be Asking Too Much of Our Presidents; Keep Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korean Invites South to Get Together
description: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea invited his South Korean counterpart, Roh Tae Woo, and six other political and religious leaders to a political conference, the official North Korean press agency reported today.

title: BATTLES BEGINNING IN RACE TO PATENT SUPERCONDUCTORS
description: Patent battles now beginning could determine which organizations and even which nations control the rights to new high-temperature superconductors, materials that could revolutionize fields like computers and electricity generation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cardinal Technologies Inc., Los Angeles, a holding company, said Martin J. Salvin was named a director, increasing the board to five members.

title: San Diego Fights a Utility Takeover
description: Municipal leaders in San Diego are mobilizing to block what they view as a blow to the city's pride and pocketbook -the $2.5 billion takeover of their largest local corporation, the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.

title: New Owners and Chief For J.&W. Seligman
description: When Shearson American Express Inc. acquired the Lehman Brothers investment firm four years ago, William C. Morris did not stay with the firm. Instead of working for the newly acquired organization, the investment banker became a private investor.

title: INSIDE
description: 49ers and Bills Win The San Francisco 49ers routed Minnesota, 34-9, and advanced to the National Football Conference final.

title: It's a Rare Sport That Bush Doesn't Like
description: George Bush has taken some time out since the election for sedentary activities like picking a Cabinet and preparing a plan to govern. But mostly he has kept up a grueling schedule of shooting, casting, jogging, putting, pitching, lobbing, boating, diving and body surfing.

title: Bridge
description: An interesting way for players of intermediate strength to sharpen their bidding skills is provided by a new monthly venture called ''Mike's Newsletter.'' It is written by Mike Lawrence, a former world champion with the highest credentials. Subscriptions, addressed to him at 131 Alvaredo Road, Berkeley, Calif., are $30 for one year or $50 for two years.

title: Many Facing New Laws And Rules In New Year
description: Like resolutions, New Year's predictions tend to haunt those who make them. But some milestones can already be discerned in 1989 because of laws, rules or other government actions that will change the physical and social landscape in and around New York City.

title: B. Smith's Restaurant Has Marriage on Menu
description: G. Keith Alexander first met his wife, Sharrell, at a crowded midtown Manhattan restaurant. He was making a telephone call; she was sitting at the bar. Their eyes met. They married nine weeks later.

title: 49ers Swamp Vikings, 34-9; Bills Beat Oilers, 17-10; Kelly Leads Buffalo
description: This was how Jim Kelly remembered the way football should be played: you throw.

title: Chief Justice Urges Increase In Federal Judges' Salaries
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, warning that current salaries for Federal judges threaten the quality of the judiciary, today urged President Reagan and Congress to accept the substantial pay increases proposed last month by a special commission.

title: Clement A. Smith, 87, Professor of Pediatrics
description: Clement A. Smith, professor emeritus of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School and a past president of the American Pediatric Society, died Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87 years old. Dr. Smith conducted studies on the prevention of deaths of babies. He was a recipient of the Howland Award, the highest honor of the pediatric society, and a chair in pediatrics at the medical school was named for him.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
description: The year-ago 12 months' results included an after-tax charge of $229 million to cover cost over-runs at the Vogtle Nuclear Plant.

title: 49ers Swamp Vikings, 34-9; Bills Beat Oilers, 17-10; Rice, Montana, Craig All Excel
description: Jerry Rice had heard the sniping. He had listened to the comparisons of him and Anthony Carter, how he had produced a dazzling 23-touchdown season last year only to be shut out in the playoffs. Carter was the beauty in post-season play, Rice the beast.

title: Talks With Soviet Team
description: The spirit of negotiation promulgated under Mikhail Gorbachev was everywhere in evidence as the Soviet Union's top hockey team, Central Red Army, spent three days on Long Island last week as part of their seven-game Super Series. Coach Viktor Tikhonov, who arrived irritable and weary after a daylong trip from Quebec that started in a breakfast squabble with the National Hockey League translator, Anna Udovicic, initially waved off reporters with a terse ''nyet.'' Tikhonov had told Udovicic she should ''go back to the kitchen'' when luncheon plans for the team in Montreal were bungled. But after a catered dinner, he was all smiles again, and when again asked to meet with reporters, he shrugged and said ''O.K.''

title: Islanders Reflect a Positive Image
description: In defiance of a recent trend toward decrepitude, the Islanders have been victorious twice in the space of a week, and Saturday's 6-4 domination of the Washington Capitals suggests that their transformation from chumps to challengers may finally have taken place.

title: Holiday Today
description: Today is the legal holiday for New Year's Day. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No street cleanings or collection. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedules; Metro-North on holiday schedule; Long Island Rail Road on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Most closed; local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit buses on Saturday schedule, trains on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: The Video News Release: Let the Viewer Beware
description: WHEN the ''CBS Evening News With Dan Rather'' reported Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s settlement of Federal securities-law violations two weeks ago, it included a clip of Frederick H. Joseph, Drexel's chief executive, talking about how he felt about the agreement.

title: Critic's Notebook; Are Books Becoming Relics?
description: In her biography ''Private Demons: The Life of Shirley Jackson,'' Judy Oppenheimer describes how Miss Jackson and her husband, the critic and teacher Stanley Edgar Hyman, accumulated great quantities of books.

title: Lynn Sara Glickman Wed To Eli M. Moore, a Lawyer
description: Lynn Sara Glickman, a certified nurse-midwife at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, and Eli Max Moore, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, were married last evening at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. Rabbi Irwin Feldman, an uncle of the bridegroom, and Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald performed the ceremony.

title: Peru Plans to Seek Loans
description: Peru, which has taken a hard-line stance on its foreign debts, has announced that it plans to hold talks with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank about obtaining new loans from the international agencies.

title: Armenia Prints Warning to K.G.B.; Called Fake
description: An Armenian Communist Party newspaper has published what purports to be an anonymous ultimatum to the K.G.B., threatening to use American-made Stinger missiles in a campaign of ''mass terror'' if jailed Armenian nationalist leaders are not set free.

title: Bengals Eager to Move Along
description: The Cincinnati Bengals have already beaten the Buffalo Bills once this season. And the Bengals are 9-0 at home.

title: Ad Ban Might Help Cigarette Makers
description: Does advertising increase cigarette smoking? Representative Michael Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, thinks so, and is pressing for legislation to end tobacco promotion.

title: You Can Swing While You Swim
description: SWIMMING laps in a pool is a mainstay of many people's fitness regimen. But laps can be tedious.

title: S&L Deals: Did Taxpayers Lose?
description: Are all the latest costly savings and loan bailouts more costly to taxpayers and depositors than necessary? Federal regulators now face heavy criticism for a spate of year-end multibillion-dollar deals, in which private investors have agreed to take over bankrupt savings institutions.

title: Cuba's 30 Castro Years: Pluses, Minus the Gaiety
description: Thirty years ago today Cubans poured into the streets of Havana, cheering and honking car horns, to celebrate the collapse of a brutal dictatorship and the promise of a better way of life.

title: Correction
description: A listing in the Company News column in Business Day on Friday about Tiffany & Company misstated when the company most recently sold shares to the public. Tiffany, which was taken private in a leveraged buyout in October 1984, made a public offering of shares in May 1987.

title: Nicholas Calas, a Poet And Art Critic, Was 81
description: Nicholas Calas, an art critic and poet who directed attention in his writings to young artists and new art movements, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Reagan and Environment: To Many, a Stalemate
description: When President Reagan took office, environmentalists feared the worst from the man who once said trees cause pollution. They expected him to dismantle environmental regulation and give away public lands and resources.

title: Hospitals See (Relatively) Calm New Year
description: The ambulance was speeding toward St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan, carrying a 21-year-old college student who had been hit on the head as he stood in Times Square, the waning minutes of 1988 ticking away.

title: Shiite Rivals in Beirut Battle for Second Day
description: Rival Shiite Muslim militiamen today fought running street gun battles in southern Beirut for the second straight day, defying appeals from Shiite leaders to end months of violent confrontation.

title: Metro Matters; A Look Back At Some Stories Still Unfolding
description: Some matters that were subjects of this column in 1988 continued to unfold after they were first reported. Here's an update.

title: Lotto Prize to Be $26 Million
description: No one picked the six correct numbers in Saturday's Lotto drawing, making the first jackpot of 1989 worth $26 million, state Lottery Division officials said today. A division spokesman, George Yamin, said if someone picks the correct six numbers in Wednesday's drawing, the winner - or winners -will receive the fourth-highest Lotto jackpot in state history.

title: Maloney Absorbs Week Full of Pain
description: For Don Maloney, the week began and ended with broadsides, painful bookends to the most emotionally packed seven days of his life. The first changed his career; the second ruined much of the rest of his season. Maloney never saw either coming, and only in the last 24 hours have his vision and throat cleared enough for him to talk coherently about it all.

title: Red Eagle Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: We May Be Asking Too Much of Our Presidents; Civil Rights Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: The Super Bowl's Perfect 22
description: Many startling and dramatic events took place in 1988, but followers of the Super Bowl stock market theory got no surprises. It came through with flying colors for the 22d year in a row.

title: Moscow Curbs Exports of Scarce Goods
description: In the midst of the worst shortage of consumer goods in recent memory, the Soviet Government announced today that foreigners would soon be prevented from taking such scarce locally produced items as caviar, coffee, television sets, children's clothing, refrigerators or washing machines out of the country.

title: Tomczak Vows He'll Be Back
description: The Bears received good news today about Mike Tomczak, their starting quarterback. They learned that his shoulder injury was not as bad as expected, and they said he might play next Sunday.

title: Canada Television Deal
description: MacLean Hunter Ltd. said Friday that it had agreed to sell a television station in Hamilton, Ontario, to the Blackburn Group for about $57.4 million, or $68.5 million Canadian. MacLean Hunter said the station, CHCH-TV, had belonged to Selkirk Communications Ltd., which MacLean Hunter acquired earlier this month.

title: Tariffs Lifted By Venezuela
description: Venezuela on Friday sharply increased the import tariffs on about 500 consumer goods, including liquor and electronic items, to curb imports and stem a drain of foreign reserves.

title: Farmers' Trade Debate: To Fight or to Negotiate
description: On the brink of a trade war with Europe, America's farmers find themselves divided.

title: Conference Thrives by Cultivating Fans and Teams
description: When Dave Gavitt conceived the idea of an East Coast basketball league, his plan was to link teams in major media markets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I do not think an eye for an eye or a tooth for a tooth is ever valid. I can understand the anger. We feel the anger very deeply. The most important thing to do is to try to get the cooperation of all nations to track down these people so that they are brought to justice.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, on the crash of Pan Am Flight 103. [ 3:1. ]

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; In Memoriam
description: Honoring another victim of the Pan Am crash, the Criminal Division of the Justice Department has decided to dedicate its law library to a colleague who was aboard Flight 103.

title: Key Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included the loss from the company's discontinued leasing operation of $1,277,000.

title: A Test Of Polls In Light Of Bowls
description: Once the football teams from Notre Dame and West Virginia produce a result Monday afternoon, the 18th Fiesta Bowl will either demonstrate that polls and the bowl system can combine to produce a consensus national champion, or create another complex case of lobbying and haggling.

title: Public Radio Begins Business Program
description: A public-radio ''business magazine'' program begins today on roughly 80 stations nationwide, the most widely distributed entry in a growing field.

title: TV Notes
description: New Soap Opera

title: Craig Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company has changed its fiscal year to end Sept. 30 from June 30; full- year results are not available.

title: Review/Music; Solos and Duets
description: Marilyn Horne was the hostess for Carnegie Hall's concert party this New Year's Eve, and singing was the main course served - the only course, in fact, aside from the fluent and elegant accompanying of Martin Katz. Neil Rosenshein, Barbara Daniels, Hakan Hagegard and Barbara Bonney - all fresh from the Metropolitan Opera's ''Fledermaus'' the night before - were joined by Samuel Ramey and Miss Horne for a program of 22 well-known solos and duets.

title: A Writing Workshop
description: The director and lyricist Martin Charnin is to teach a five-session workshop, ''From Page to Stage: Lyric Writing and Directing for the Musical Theater,'' at 7:30 P.M. on consecutive Thursdays, beginning next week, at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. The fee is $85. Information: 996-1100.

title: The Phantom Old-Age Vote
description: Birthdays do not dictate the politics of American citizens. Nevertheless, when Congress and the President-elect Bush get around to attacking the Federal budget deficit, it's a safe bet they will be intimidated by all the usual assumptions about the elderly vote.

title: Israel, Hardly the Monaco of the Middle East
description: The recent definitions of Palestinian attitudes will not ''solve'' the Middle Eastern crisis or bring a negotiation with Israel into early view. But all attempts in Israel and the United States to portray them as worthless or fraudulent have incurred total failure. Moreover, it is absurd to suggest, as many of Israel's friends have, that the American decision to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization theatens Israel's very survival.

title: Portugal Raises Wages
description: Portugal, the poorest country in the European Community, raised the minimum wage for industrial workers on Friday by 10 percent, to 30,000 escudos, or $204, a month. The Government also said the minimum wage for agricultural workers would rise by 14.5 percent, to 28,400 escudos, or $193, a month.

title: We May Be Asking Too Much of Our Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurricanes Have Eyes On the Top
description: If the campaign works, Jimmy Johnson's next job might be in politics, working as a spin doctor for one of the candidates in the next Presidential campaign. The University of Miami football coach has apparently planted a seed of doubt about whether the winner of the Fiesta Bowl game on Monday in Tempe, Ariz., between unbeaten Notre Dame and West Virginia, should automatically be voted the No. 1 team in the country. And where there is doubt, however little, Johnson figures there is hope for the Hurricanes.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Vietnam, which is rolling back tight state control to revitalize its economy, said it would put some inefficient state enterprises into private hands next year to increase production and exports. Radio Hanoi said a National Assembly resolution on the economic plan for 1989 envisaged a 10 percent increase in industrial output, a 15 percent rise in the value of exports and a 6 percent rise in gross national product over 1988 levels.

title: At New York Nightclubs, It's In to Be Asian
description: LEAD: Asian chic has arrived in Manhattan's most popular and exclusive nightclubs and discotheques.
