There, Asians who live in New York, particularly the Japanese, are preferred customers, bringing cash and cachet. And in at least one club, they have been hired as hosts, waiters, waitresses and bartenders to project an image of style and sophistication.

title: ISRAEL PUTS FORTH AN AUSTERITY PLAN TO REVIVE ECONOMY
description: Finance Minister Shimon Peres unveiled a stringent austerity plan today to rescue Israel's troubled economy.

title: Two Old Rivals Meet in Pasadena
description: Bo Schembechler has mellowed so much that he is no longer impatient with silly questions. He even finds amusing ways to answer them.

title: Shift at Paper In Los Angeles
description: C. Shelby Coffey 3d became editor of The Los Angeles Times today, succeeding William F. Thomas, who retired after 17 years with the paper.

title: Georgia Wins Gator Bowl
description: Wayne Johnson threw three touchdown passes and Rodney Hampton ran for 109 yards and scored three times tonight as Georgia gave Coach Vince Dooley a 34-27 Gator Bowl victory over Michigan State in his final game.

title: From Tempe to Tampa to Your TV
description: Sunkist Fiesta Bowl Notre Dame (11-0) vs. W. Virginia (11-0) Kickoff 4:30 P.M., at Tempe, Ariz., NBC-TV. Ranking Notre Dame: A.P. 1, U.P.I. 1, Times 1. West Virginia: A.P. 3, U.P.I. 3, Times 6. Coaches Notre Dame: Lou Holtz. West Virginia: Don Nehlen. Probable payoff per school $3 million.

title: Reviews/Television; How Washington Works, as Seen From Inside
description: Like Hedrick Smith's knowing book from which it is derived, ''The Power Game'' is a shrewd observer's account of the movings and shakings of Washington's shakers and movers. Tonight's opening hour, on Channel 13 at 9 and Channel 49 at 8, deals with Congress, especially members who came in during the ''power earthquake'' of 1974, as anti-leadership, pro-reform insurgents. On the following three evenings, Mr. Smith, a former chief Washington correspondent and bureau chief for The New York Times and the series' host, takes on the Pentagon, the press and the Presidency.

title: Legalized Migrants Flock Home for Holidays
description: Santiago and Gloria Rodriguez have been married for eight years, but neither has ever met the other's parents, his in Mexico, hers in Guatemala. As immigrants living illegally in California, the couple dared not, until now, leave the United States for fear they might not ever be able to slip back across the border.

title: Honduran Drops His Threat To Boycott Summit Meeting
description: President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras has apparently removed the last obstacle to a meeting of Central American presidents set for Jan. 15-16 in El Salvador.

title: Thatcher Opposes Revenge for Bomb
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that no revenge should be taken for the bombing that destroyed a Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland with 259 people aboard.

title: Tibet Students Said to Hold Anti-Chinese Rally in Lhasa
description: Hundreds of Tibetan students demonstrated in Lhasa, demanding that the Chinese authorities respect their culture and stop carrying weapons, Western witnesses said today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Financial Officer Named President of Dean Foods
description: LEAD: The Dean Foods Company has named its chief financial officer, William D. Fischer, president and chief operating officer to fill the year-old void left by Howard M. Dean. Mr. Dean, the company's previous president, became chief executive officer in October 1987 and was elected chairman recently.

title: Wall St. Finds Life After Crash
description: Rebounding from the October 1987 stock market crash, the Dow Jones Industrial average climbed 11.8 percent last year to 2,168.57. Merger activity reached record levels and corporate profits soared. Articles on the outlook for the stock and bond markets, mergers and corporate profits begin on page D1, followed by full-year tables for the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq national market system.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Chesnokov Upset by Volkov: Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union upset Andrei Chesnokov, the top-seeded player, 6-3, 6-1, in the first round of the $123,400 South Australian Open in Adelaide yesterday. Mark Kratzmann of Australia upset second-seeded Darren Cahill of Australia, 7-6, 6-4.(AP) N.H.L. Capitals 8, Penguins 0: Bengt Gustafsson scored two of Washington's five goals over a 6-minute-56-second span in the second period yesterday and the Capitals, playing at home, ended a seven-game losing streak against Pittsburgh. Mario Lemieux, the league's leading scorer, was held pointless for the first time in his last 15 games.(AP) Bruins 8, Blues 7: The rookie center Craig Janney, in his first game back after eight games out with a groin injury, set up four goals to lead Boston at home. It was the first time the Bruins, who beat the Devils last Thursday, had put together consecutive victories since late November.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Women Clemson 69, Duke 55: Courtney Johnson scored 11 points to lead a balanced attack as Clemson upset Duke in the Atlantic Coast Conference opener for both schools. Clemson (7-2) held a 3-point lead at halftime, but pulled away in the second half. Sue Harnett led Duke (10-2) with 16 points and 12 rebounds. The Tigers made 56 percent of their shots from the field in the second half. (AP) Virginia 81, Bucknell 48: Dawn Staley scored 18 points and Tonya Cardoza had 16 as Virginia rolled over Bucknell last night. Virginia (8-2) held a 45-23 lead at halftime and was never challenged after that. Bucknell (4-4) was led by Christine Center with 13 points and 16 rebounds. (AP) Men N.C. State 83, Towson State 77: Rodney Monroe and Chucky Brown each scored 23 points last night to lead North Carolina State. The Wolfpack (7-1) struggled in the first half, trailing by as much as 32-25 with 6:08 left in the period. But it rallied to take a 46-38 lead at halftime. (AP) N.B.A. Suns 125, Bullets 122: Tom Chambers scored 12 of his 29 points in the fourth quarter, rallying Phoenix past Washington last night before a league season-low crowd of 3,729. The victory was the Suns' sixth in their last seven games, and their first in Landover, Md., since Jan. 26, 1985. (AP)

title: Capital Cities' Satellite Stake
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. has acquired a 14.3 percent stake in Satellite Music Network Inc., the Dallas-based company that pioneered the use of satellites to beam radio programming to AM stations nationwide. Last week, Satellite Music announced that Captial Cities had offered to buy the company for $5.40 a share, or a total purchase price of $48.38 million.

title: Hurricanes Try Harder and Rout Nebraska
description: The proclamation came shortly after the Orange Bowl game ended tonight and, like much of what Jimmy Johnson says, it was not intended to win friends or soothe anyone's feelings. The Miami coach felt his team had a point to prove against Nebraska and did so emphatically. Now, he was ready to boast. ''We might not be number one, but at this time we are the best football team in the country,'' Johnson said. ''I told the players after the game that I don't believe that I'd ever had a team that committed as much of themselves for the success of the team as this group has done.''

title: By Design; New Year, New Image
description: A few shifts in the way you put yourself together - hair, makeup and jewelry - can make a significant change in your appearance. Herewith, some suggestions for achieving a 1989 look, at least from the neck up.

title: A State Offers Working Poor Insurance Aid
description: In a pioneering program that is being closely watched in Congress, the state of Washington this week began providing medical insurance to working people who cannot afford it.

title: India-China Statement Angers Tibetan Exiles
description: A little-noticed paragraph recognizing Chinese sovereignty over Tibet in a statement signed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi on a recent trip to Beijing has aroused alarm and resentment among Tibetan exiles in India, a spokesman for the Dalai Lama said here today.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Partners & Shevack has created a print campaign for the American Jewish World Service.

title: Building a Dream, Floor by Rotting Floor
description: The six-story apartment building at 241 West 113th Street, just west of Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem, is the kind of abandoned ruin that marks all of New York City's poor neighborhoods.

title: Guggenheim Art Show Draws Crowds in Prague
description: An exhibition of modern art from the New York and Venice Guggenheim collections drew 121,000 visitors during its display at Prague's National Gallery.

title: Cleveland Group to Play Bartok String Quartets
description: The Cleveland Quartet is to play Bartok's String Quartets Nos. 3 and 6 and the composer's ''Contrasts'' on Jan. 19 at 8 P.M. in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The concert is the second in a series of three devoted to Bartok's complete string quartets and other chamber works; the last one is scheduled for March 30.

title: 'Junk Bond' King Waits Uneasily As Prosecutors Prepare Their Case
description: Although Michael R. Milken will remember 1988 as a year in which he spent more time with his lawyers than he cared to, 1989 could be worse.

title: Wall Street's Bonuses for '88 Favor Experts in Mergers and Acquisitions
description: It's year-end bonus time on Wall Street, and by all accounts 1988 was a very, very good year to be a mergers and acquisitions specialist at firms like Morgan Stanley, First Boston and Goldman, Sachs.

title: Cadwell's Help For Retarded
description: Cadwell Davis Partners handles the advertising for about half a dozen Johnson & Johnson products. J. & J. has long supported the Association of Retarded Citizens, which has 160,000 members and 1,300 chapters. So it was natural for Franchellie (Frankie) Cadwell and Herman A. Davis, the agency's president and chairman, to help the association create its first fully coordinated advertising campaign, including broadcast, outdoor and print ads.

title: U.S. Population in '88 Grew By 2.3 Million, Bureau Says
description: The population of the United States was 246.9 million as the New Year began, almost 2.3 million higher than a year ago, the Census Bureau said Sunday.

title: Interest Rates Seen Rising For 6 Months
description: As they peered into the new year from the relative safety of the one just past, credit market analysts seemed to have a remarkably clear view of what is likely to unfold over the next six months. What happens afterward is in considerable dispute.

title: Talking Business with Schwab, the discount broker; Hard Competition Seen for Brokers
description: Many stockbrokers will remember 1988 as a year they would like to forget. After the crash of October 1987, a steady stream of money from individual investors became only a trickle. Nearly every brokerage firm reported sharply lower profits, and many cut their staffs in an effort to compete in a tough new environment.

title: William Como, 63, A Longtime Editor Of Dance Magazine
description: William Como, the editor in chief of Dance Magazine, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: 'Computer Virus' Joins the Lexicon
description: The term ''computer virus'' spread into use like, well, a virus during 1988, but the outbreak came too late to make the latest editions of Merriam-Webster dictionaries.

title: Delayed NASA Missions Prepare for Takeoff
description: AFTER a decade in the doldrums, grounded by budget cuts and the space shuttle accident, planetary exploration by the United States is primed for a big leap forward this year.

title: Deals by Michael Foods
description: Michael Foods Inc. said it had acquired all the outstanding stock of Wisco Farm Cooperative Inc. and had agreed in principle to acquire certain assets of Microfresh Foods Inc. Terms of the deals were not disclosed.

title: L.I. Sniper Fires At a Policeman On a Bogus Call
description: A sniper fired at a Southampton Town police officer who was responding to what turned out to be a bogus report of a traffic accident here early Sunday morning, the police said today.

title: Williams's Late Drive Puts Clemson on Top
description: Rodney Williams, Clemson's quarterback, does not always look pretty, but today in the Citrus Bowl against Oklahoma he showed why his record does.

title: Emotional Talks Inspire 49ers In Their Quest to Be Champions
description: Talk is cheap? It would be difficult to convince the San Francisco 49ers of that, a polished team now one victory short of Super Bowl XXIII after a punishing 34-9 playoff victory over the Minnesota Vikings in Candlestick Park on Sunday.

title: Fatal Stabbing Of a Couple Is a Mystery
description: The Larchmont police said yesterday that they still had no suspects and no motive in the fatal stabbing of a couple whose bodies were found in their home on Sunday evening.

title: Telefonica Accord
description: Spain's state industrial holding group, Instituto Nacional de Industria, and Telefonica Nacional de Espana have agreed to pool their electronics and computer software interests under a wide-ranging agreement. Officials at Telefonica, in which the Government holds a stake of more than 30 percent, said the company's chairman, Luis Solana, signed a deal with Instituto's chairman, Jordi Mercader, that calls for detailed plans to be drawn up within three months.

title: Use of Jailhouse Informers Reviewed in Los Angeles
description: A jailhouse informer's recent disclosure that a prisoner can easily frame someone with bogus testimony has exploded into scandal for the nation's largest District Attorney's office.

title: British Pork Shift Offered
description: The Agriculture Department has offered to reduce import restrictions on shipments of British swine, pork and pork products to the United States.

title: Chinese Demand More By a Literary Legend
description: To Chinese readers, he is virtually a one-man literary movement, more a genre than an author, his 36 novels of chivalry and romance mesmerizing both Chinese peasants and foreign academics alike.

title: A Perfect Finish at 12-0 For Top-Ranked Notre Dame
description: From the day they gathered in South Bend, Ind., to begin their work in the August heat, the football players at the University of Notre Dame listened to the little man remind them of their shortcomings.

title: Eligibility Question
description: A British track official said yesterday that an inquiry into Zola Budd's eligibility for international competition would be reopened if the South African-born runner attempts to return to her adopted country.

title: Backlash on Takeovers Is Feared
description: It was the year of the big takeover. Even leaving out the still to be concluded RJR Nabisco buyout that saw one bidder raise the ante on another by several billion dollars, there was a record $266 billion in mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts completed in 1988.

title: Exotic Clam Colonies
description: Scientists repeatedly descending to 11,000 feet in the deep-diving submarine Alvin, have discovered a number of communities of six-inch clams and other creatures fed by organic seeps along a 30-mile stretch of the Monterey Canyon, 50 miles off Monterey Bay, Calif.

title: Bruins, Led by Aikman, Win 7th Bowl in a Row
description: Troy Aikman converted 12 of 20 third-down situations as the U.C.L.A. Bruins set a National Collegiate Athletic Association record with its seventh consecutive bowl triumph, a 17-3 victory over the Arkansas Razorbacks in the Cotton Bowl.

title: Carnegie Ushers Cross the Footlights for a Night
description: The sounds the ushers hear at Carnegie Hall are not always music to their ears. There are perennial irritants, like the whisperers. And the persistent coughers. And the candy-wrapper soloists. There are the latecomers who demand to be seated in the middle of a symphony movement. And yes, there are even the sports fanatics who wear earphones to performances during the World Series.

title: Atlanta Journal; Loss of Mail Jolts Tenants Into Action
description: For some time, residents of the Bankhead Courts public housing project here suffered in silence from the brisk, open and frequently violent drug trade in their midst. Then last month an innocent letter carrier found himself in the middle of a drug deal gone bad, and the Postal Service cut off the mail to the 500 apartments.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are in danger of chemical weapons becoming just another weapon of choice. We seek to raise the political costs of their use, and we hope that even countries accused of using chemical weapons will join in affirming support for the 1925 Protocol.'' - Roger G. Harrison, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State. [ A1:6. ]

title: A Higher Gas Tax Isn't Courage, but Arrogance
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgia Names Goff To Replace Dooley
description: Georgia has named Ray Goff, an assistant coach and former quarterback for the Bulldogs, to replace Vince Dooley as the football coach.

title: Cable-TV Systems Offer More and Charge More
description: Cable television systems are offering more channels to more viewers, but the price for watching is also going up.

title: Saudi-Texaco Joint Venture
description: Texaco Inc. and Saudi Arabia said they had closed their deal for a joint venture to refine and market petroleum in the United States.

title: Fetisov Tries Diplomacy in Quest to Join Devils
description: The Soviet Ambassador to the United States, Yuri V. Dubinin, has joined the saga of Vyacheslav Fetisov and his effort to play for the New Jersey Devils.

title: Budget Plight In the Wings In Albany
description: After less than a week's hiatus, lawmakers return to Albany today to start a legislative session that is expected to be dominated by the state's worsening financial plight.

title: Books of The Times; The Familiar Evils of Hong Kong, Then and Now
description: Hong Kong By Jan Morris Illustrated. 359 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: American Exchange Has Strong 4th Quarter
description: In choosing among America's three stock arenas, investors would have fared most successfully last year if they had placed their bets on the American Stock Exchange.

title: 27 Arrested at Nuclear Plant
description: Twenty-seven people were arrested on trespassing charges Saturday at a brief demonstration to protest the restarting of the Pilgrim nuclear plant nearly three years after it was closed for management and maintenance problems.Those arrested were among more than 125 demonstrators, the authorities said.On Friday, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission cleared the way for low-power testing of the 670-megawatt reactor.

title: The Flow of the Game Will Determine Pitino's Moves
description: The Knicks' starting lineup will remain unchanged tonight when they play the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden. The ''subtle'' changes that Coach Rick Pitino promised after Friday night's embarrassing loss to the Charlotte Hornets, an expansion team, will involve execution on offense and defense and perhaps the substitution pattern.

title: William Haber, Who Directed Aid To Jewish Refugees, Is Dead at 89
description: William Haber, an economist who helped Jewish refugees after World War II as an adviser to the United States armed forces and for 25 years after that as president of the American Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training Federation, died Friday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 89 years old. Dr. Haber, who was a professor emeritus of economics and former dean at the University of Michigan, died of pneumonia at his home, said Avi Feinglass, a spokesman for the federation.

title: Careers; Educating Managers In Hungary
description: BULGARIA last week stopped jamming radio programs broadcast from the West, a demonstration of openness. Hungary also moved in that direction with the announcement in November that an International Management Center had been opened in Budapest.

title: Discounting Not on Rise, Retailers Say
description: Post-Christmas shoppers facing a sea of signs in store windows advertising huge discounts off ''our already reduced prices'' might find it hard to believe, but many retailers say discounts since Christmas have been equal to or slightly below those of the corresponding period last year.

title: Drummond Rushes Past L.S.U.
description: Syracuse was almost perfect today. A clever offensive display and a steady defensive effort resulted in an easy victory over Louisiana State, 23-10, in the Hall of Fame Bowl before an announced crowd of 51,112.

title: Scientists Track Clues Linking a Bacterium To Stomach Disorders
description: NEW research has produced strong evidence that an S-shaped bacterium causes the common stomach disorder gastritis. And scientists say there is increasing though inconclusive evidence that the microbe is linked to many stomach and duodenal ulcers.

title: Fat-Cell Protein Is Implicated in Obesity
description: IN a major advance in the study of obesity, researchers have discovered that abnormally low levels of a protein produced by fat cells may be linked to the propensity to gain weight.

title: Working Woman
description: John Emmerling Inc. has added another member of the Time Inc. family to its client stable. Working Woman, a publication of the Working Woman/ McCall's Group (which is partly owned by Time), has retained the agency to create a trade campaign that will debut in mid-January. The magazine, which has a circulation rate base of 950,000, currently has no agency. The ads will run in Marketing and Media Decisions, Adweek and Advertising Age, and will focus on ''the growing strength of the executive woman,'' Mr. Emmerling said. The budget, he added, is $1 million.

title: Strike Cuts Iberia Flights
description: A 24-hour strike by mechanics of Iberia Air Lines forced the cancellation of 55 flights today, an Iberia spokesman said. The cancellations mostly affected flights to and from Madrid and Barcelona on the domestic carrier Aviaco, the spokesman said.

title: 'Chess' Cast to Perform In Carnegie Hall Benefit
description: Judy Kuhn, David Carroll, Philip Casnoff and other members of the original cast of ''Chess'' are to perform a concert version of the Broadway musical at Carnegie Hall on Monday at 7:30 P.M. The performance is a benefit for the Emergency Shelter Inc., which provides beds, job training and counseling for homeless teen-agers. Tickets are priced at $250 (which includes a party with the cast after the performance) or $50, and are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: O-T-C Stocks Rise 14%, But Trading Dwindles
description: After ending 1987 in turbulence, the over-the-counter market bounced back with strong growth in 1988. Some of the largest gains were posted by companies that were sold or put into play as takeover candidates.

title: A Higher Gas Tax Isn't Courage, but Arrogance; User Charges
description: To the Editor:

title: A Blueprint for Government Ethics
description: Michael Deaver leaves the White House and promptly begins to lobby his former colleagues. Scandal jars the Pentagon. Congress fails to limit corrupting honorarium payments. Special-interest money pours into lawmakers' personal and campaign bank accounts. Americans are being insulted by a political culture that places private gain ahead of public trust.

title: Sri Lanka President Sworn In
description: Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa, vowing to restore peace and prosperity to a country ravaged by ethnic strife, was installed today as the new President in this sacred Buddhist city. Mr. Premadasa succeeds J. R. Jayewardene, who retires from public life after nearly 50 years in politics.

title: No Big Airline Tie-Ups
description: Heavy new security measures at European airports last week produced no major passenger snarls at check-in counters or delays in flights to the United States over a long New Year's weekend of light but growing trans-Atlantic air traffic.

title: Sara Lee Sells Two Subsidiaries
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said it had sold its Lyon's Restaurant chain and the Peck Food Corporation to two separate buyers. Terms were not disclosed for either sale.

title: Lounge Wear for Cocooning
description: With the fire gone out of ready-to-wear clothes and consumers staying close to home, hearth and VCR, designers are making lingerie to suit the elegant Park Avenue hostess or the working woman trying to unwind.

title: Two Deal Makers Who Set Out Alone Find They Have Plenty of Company
description: When Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph Perella bolted from First Boston early in 1988 to begin their own firm, Wall Street drubbed the investment house's stock. By the market's account the two merger and acquisition specialists were worth at least $127.5 million, the value lost that day in the stock.

title: Testing a 'Mirror of Disease'
description: AN experiment in the Netherlands has called into question claims by many practitioners of ''alternative'' medicine that visible changes in the irises of patient's eyes can aid diagnosis of many different diseases.

title: Prelude to Mars: 5 Months in a Cave
description: An Italian researcher will spend five months - the time required to fly to Mars - in a cave here this year.

title: Shiite Militias Step Up Their Fight in Lebanon
description: Fighting between rival Shiite Muslim gunmen intensified today and spread from Beirut to southern Lebanon.

title: Florida St. Overcomes Mistakes
description: Sammie Smith rushed for 115 yards to lead an error-prone Florida State offense tonight as the Seminoles turned an early 13-0 lead into a 13-7 victory over Auburn in the Sugar Bowl.

title: Columbia Candidate
description: Gerry DiNardo, the offensive coordinator at the University of Colorado, confirmed yesterday that he had been interviewed for the head coaching job at Columbia. DiNardo, born and raised in New York, played at Notre Dame from 1972 to 1974.

title: What Gandhi and Bhutto Didn't Discuss: Kashmir
description: As the young Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan met for the first time Thursday, raising hopes for less bitter dealings between the two powers of the Indian subcontinent, a small motorcade drove up out of history with a cautionary message: Remember Kashmir.

title: Accounts
description: * Pacific Bell has retained Adland, San Francisco, to create advertising for the Asian-American market.

title: U.S. Turning to New Technologies to Clean Up Arms Plants
description: LEAD: FACED with one of the most costly environmental contamination problems ever, the Department of Energy is searching for new technologies to help it clean up toxic and radioactive wastes at its weapons installations.

title: Jazz Guard Injured
description: The Utah Jazz guard Bobby Hansen will be placed on the injured-reserve list again after fracturing bones in his cheek at a New Year's Eve party.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The economy grew in December at the highest rate in five months, partly because of a surge in export orders, according to the monthly report of purchasing managers. Production, new orders and export orders all surged. [ Page D1. ] The Federal Home Loan Bank Board put on a stunning display of its ability and willingness to strike deals last week. In five days, the agency arranged the sale of 34 troubled savings and loan companies with almost $62 billion in assets. It also agreed to spend $13.8 billion to cover losses at those associations. [ A1. ] After-Christmas discounting has been restrained, because many retailers had better-than-expected holiday sales. Inventory controls have also helped to avert big price cuts. [ D1. ] WALL STREET OUTLOOK The stock market turned in a remarkably strong performance in 1988, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 11.8 percent. Some professionals see bigger gains in 1989. [ D1. ] Corporations found investors generally unwilling to buy new issues. But mortgage- and asset-backed securities and foreign issues known as Yankee bonds rose in popularity. [ D5. ] A possible political backlash on takeover activity is feared by deal makers, who are wary of stirrings in Congress. [ D1. ] Analysts are unified in their view of what is likely to unfold in the credit markets during the next six months, with higher interest rates predicted. But what will happen later is a matter of considerable dispute. [ D1. ] Year-end bonuses will be especially generous for mergers and acquisitions specialists at some big firms. Most stock and bond traders have less to look forward to. [ D4. ] Companies involved in big takeovers are notably absent from the list of the year's top winners and losers on the Big Board. [ D10. ] The American Stock Exchange was the nation's strongest market, in general, in 1988. Its market-value index rose 17.5 percent. [ D12. ] The over-the-counter market grew strongly, with healthy gains by companies that were sold or put into play. [ D13. ] MARKETS The dollar varied little in currency trading in Frankfurt. Most markets were closed yesterday for the New Year's holiday. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL American meat exporters have found alternative markets for many products they normally sell to Europe. But the industry will not escape some harm from the European Community's ban on beef produced with growth hormones. Prices of organ meats are expected to decline in the U.S. as supplies increase. [ D1. ] COMPANIES A revamped Christian Science Monitor is being introduced today. The changes, which include fewer pages, color photography and less advertising, prompted the resignations in November of three top editors. [ D8. ] Florida officials have filed suit to halt $7 blood-cholesterol tests by a company, Heart Chek, in what could be a test case for a fledgling industry. [ A17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Charles Schwab expects a better year for brokers in 1989, but he concedes that strong competition may drive some firms out of business and lead to more acquisitions. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Corporate profits rose faster than predicted a year ago, but the outlook for 1989 is for more modest gains. Industries dependent on capital spending and exports are expected to perform the best, analysts say. Market Place. [ D5. ] Braniff named McKinney & Silver as its agency of record. Analysts expect the airline to reposition itself as a carrier for business people who travel to smaller cities. Advertising. [ D9. ]

title: Philadelphia Killer Critical After Tranquilizer Overdose
description: Gary Heidnik, who was convicted of murdering two of six women he abducted and kept shackled in the basement of his home in Philadelphia, took an overdose of anti-psychotic medicine he stockpiled in prison and was hospitalized in critical condition, his psychiatrist said today.

title: Quiet Day For Dollar
description: The dollar ended hardly changed in Frankfurt today with most world financial centers closed for the New Year's holiday.

title: Forget Bush's Lips
description: Happy New Year, folks! But don't bother to read George Bush's lips. No matter what he said in the campaign, Federal taxes went up on Jan. 1 for a lot of Americans - most brutally for those who are elderly and reasonably well off financially.

title: Perestroika, Without Western Subsidies
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's pledge to cut 500,000 Soviet troops and 10,000 tanks could signal the beginning of a new era in East-West relations. If the Soviets are serious about economic reform - and I believe they are -these cuts may be just the first installment in a large-scale reallocation of resources from the military to the civilian sector.

title: Depressed Woman Is Alive After Jump From the Verrazano
description: A 22-year-old Staten Island woman under treatment for depression jumped from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge early yesterday and survived a 230-foot plunge to the icy waters below.

title: Chess
description: The Soviet Union once again demonstrated its superiority in team competition by winning the 28th Olympiad in Thessaloniki, Greece, on Nov. 27 with a 40 1/2-15 1/2 score in the 14-round Swiss-system event. This was the 16th time out of its 17 appearances that the Soviet Union has won the gold medal.

title: Renault to Get Aid From French
description: The French Government has decided to proceed with a $2 billion capital injection for Renault S.A., the state-owned auto maker.

title: Danzig History Offers Little Help on Gaza
description: To the Editor:

title: Man, 88, Held in Slaying of 2
description: An 88-year-old man who had been feuding with the other residents at a cramped retirement home was accused today of killing two of them and injuring four others while they slept, the authorities said.

title: Bills' Shift From Running Leaves Game Plan in the Air
description: In studying for his master's degree in history at Harvard, Marv Levy learned George Santayana's dictum: ''Those who do not learn the lessons of history are doomed to the repetition of its mistakes.''

title: A Publishing Program That Has a Lot to Offer
description: PUBLISH-IT is a publishing program that, in the I.B.M.-compatible version I tried, seems to have everything anyone could want for producing professional-looking newsletters, brochures, advertisements, anything you would have gone to a printshop for, with a minimum of fuss.

title: BAKKERS ARE BACK IN NEW TV SHOW
description: Jim Bakker, the defrocked minister, and his wife, Tammy, were back on the air today with a new version of their religious talk show, two years to the day after a sex and money scandal forced him to shut down their popular PTL television program.

title: Getting Organized The Electronic Way
description: RESOLVED: That this year we are finally going to get organized.

title: Ghana, Once 'Hopeless,' Gets At Least the Look of Success
description: More than five years ago, when the World Bank decided to make the state-dominated economy here a model for free-market innovations in Africa, Ghana was in the grip of stagnation. Since then, Ghana has boasted Africa's highest consistent growth rate, an average of 6 percent a year since 1983.

title: In Spite of Crisis, New York Lacks Basic Services for AIDS Patients
description: After eight years as the epicenter of the AIDS epidemic, New York City still has no nursing homes for AIDS patients and only one modest residential center for them.

title: A Banker Who Changed the Rules
description: In an industry sometimes denigrated for its lack of boldness, J. Carter Bacot, chairman of the Bank of New York, stands out in 1988 as the banker who redefined the boundaries of what is acceptable.

title: Shaw Becomes a Hit In 2-Goal Performance
description: There were television lights, radio microphones and nonstop requests for interviews. David Shaw stood smiling in the middle of it all last night. For once this season, the public spotlight warmed Shaw more than it burned.

title: Michigan Gains Upset With a Big 2d Half
description: Maybe, just maybe, the big pendulum of football fortunes is finally swinging toward the Big Ten in its long, frustrating Rose Bowl wars with the Pacific-10 Conference.

title: China's Big Lurch Backward Theory Is Now Seen as Study in Pragmatism
description: Despite China's steps in recent months to restore central planning in some areas of its economy, there are growing signs that the country remains committed to developing more of a market economy.

title: 'How's He Doin'?'
description: Edward I. Koch, the Mayor of New York City, is not at all happy about the speech of the city's schoolchildren. Too often, he says, it is incorrect.

title: THE MEN BEHIND THE BIGGEST STORIES ON WALL STREET AND IN WASHINGTON: HENRY R. KRAVIS, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts; RJR Nabisco Deal A Triumphant Work For Master of Buyouts
description: The buyout specialist Henry R. Kravis began last year by donating $10 million to build the Henry R. Kravis wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and followed with $10 million for the Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: Labor Chief's Future
description: Although Lane Kirkland flatly denies it, there is growing speculation among labor leaders inside and outside the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s headquarters in Washington that he may soon step down.

title: James Chambers, 68, Former Orchestra Hornist
description: James Chambers, a teacher and scholar of the French horn who was the principal hornist of the New York Philharmonic for 23 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Cranberry, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: Proudly, a Soviet Dissident Is Buried
description: Yuli M. Daniel was buried and eulogized today in Moscow on a searing cold day, a day as cold as a prison camp. It was the sort of day, a man at the graveside observed, that Russia seems to reserve for the funerals of its bravest inmates.

title: 100,000 Burmese at Funeral Of an Independence Figure
description: More than 100,000 Burmese poured into the streets of Rangoon today to join a funeral procession for the widow of Aung San, who led the country to independence from Britain.

title: Market Place; Milder Rise Seen For 1989 Profits
description: WITH a lower dollar prompting stronger exports for many companies and years of restructurings in basic industries helping to cut costs, corporate profits in 1988 rose far more rapidly than expected when the year began.

title: Reports of Child Abuse Spur Gifts to Neediest Cases Fund
description: The recent tragic accounts of abused children have caused an outpouring of sympathy and contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Many donors have sent gifts in memory of Lisa Steinberg, the 6-year-old who was fatally beaten in Manhattan in 1987, and Jessica Cortez, 5, found dead with a broken neck in her apartment in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn last month.

title: Ruling Sought on Injuries
description: Paul Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals' founder, general manager and vice president, said yesterday he would ask the league's competition committee, of which he is a member, to look into the question of fake injuries after the season.

title: WASHINGTON TALK - Working Profile: Army Secretary John O. Marsh Jr.; Military Leader Wins High Ground, Quietly
description: John O. Marsh Jr. is the longest-serving Secretary of the Army in modern times and one of the few senior officials in the Defense Department to have served through the entire Reagan Administration. He may also be the least known.

title: Port Authority 'Growing' Own Electricians
description: Hours after the High School for the Humanities has adjourned its regular daily sessions in Manhattan, a band of young Port Authority employees squeezes their young adult frames into the small desk chairs. Clad still in their dusty boots and green work uniforms, they join a larger contingent of union-sponsored apprentices for two hours of lectures, quizzes and the occasional catnap.

title: Adams Examined
description: Michael Adams, the Denver Nuggets' No. 2 scorer and most prolific 3-point shooter, was scheduled to undergo a bone scan to determine the nature of a painful injury to his right foot that will keep him out of tonight's game at San Antonio.

title: Pretoria Ties Of Ford, G.M.
description: Michigan, home of the Big Three carmakers, will no longer invest state pension funds in two of the automobile companies because they have business ties to South Africa, state Treasurer Robert Bowman announced on Friday.

title: Bonn Sees No Proof Yet of Company's Role in Chemical-Arms Plant
description: As West European leaders skeptically weighed the Reagan Administration's accusation that Libya has a chemical weapons plant, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said today that preliminary investigations had uncovered no proof that a West German company had helped build it.

title: State Lotteries Have Something of the Shell Game About Them
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Tells P.L.O. That Any Clues On Bombing Would Be Welcomed
description: An American envoy told a Palestinian official in an informal meeting on Saturday that the United States would welcome any information the Palestine Liberation Organization might have about the Pan American bombing over Scotland, a White House spokesman said today.

title: A Higher Gas Tax Isn't Courage, but Arrogance; Trucks Should Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Loel Guinness, 82, R.A.F. Flier And a Socialite on 2 Continents
description: Loel Guinness, an heir of the banking branch of the Guinness family who was a Member of Parliament for 14 years and a socialite on two continents, died Saturday of heart disease at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 82 years old.

title: Regulator Tackles the Savings Crisis Because 'I Like a Challenge'
description: Before he assumed the chairmanship of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in July 1987, the question asked most frequently of M. Danny Wall was why he wanted the job.

title: Wellspring of Support for Mayor Barry
description: As ''Dump Barry'' signs went up on Capitol Hill, 3,000 of the faithful at a gospel revival in northeast Washington stretched out their hands to Marion S. Barry Jr., the besieged Mayor, in a prayer vigil being played out in the most loyal wards of this stunned and divided city.

title: Treasury Secretary Off to a Quiet Start, but Loud Issues, Including Taxes, Lie Ahead
description: Nicholas F. Brady has a machine to read quotes from the markets, and he uses it. He has a facsimile machine hooked up in his Washington apartment. He calls in assistants and deputy assistants to explain Treasury business, and they say he is a rigorous interrogator. ''He scrutinizes you,'' one said.

title: Rio Police Say Overcrowding Caused Party Vessel to Sink
description: The police today blamed overcrowding for the capsizing of a boat packed with revelers planning to watch a New Year's fireworks display off Copacabana Beach. At least 51 people died.

title: Knights Honor Reagan
description: The Sovereign Military Hospitaller Order of St. John of Jerusalem, of Rhodes and of Malta has decided to mark its 900th anniversary this month by presenting its Grand Cross of Merit Special Class to President Reagan.

title: How Easily Violence Comes Into the Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking On America's Team
description: It was hard enough taking on all the Subway Alumni and the Freeway Alumni and the Windy City Alumni and the Sunbelt Alumni.

title: CHANGES PLANNED IN ENTRANCE TEST USED BY COLLEGES
description: In its first major overhaul since it was created in 1959, a standardized college admission test taken by about one million high school juniors and seniors annually will be redesigned to emphasize a wider range of mathematical knowledge and more abstract reading skills.

title: AZT Can Damage the Liver, Doctors Say
description: AZT, the only drug approved for the treatment of AIDS, can on rare occasions damage the liver, a new report indicates.

title: Business Week's Move
description: Business Week magazine has named Ray Hoffman to replace S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman as its lead radio announcer. Mr. Hoffman was Business Week's No. 2 announcer. Mr. Ruderman last year pleaded guilty to trading stocks based on his advance knowledge of Business Week stories.

title: Cholesterol Testing for Shoppers Is Challenged
description: A company offering quick, cheap tests of blood cholesterol levels to shoppers says technology has outpaced state laws governing medical testing, but the state maintains the company's services do not have the proper licenses and has filed suit to enjoin the testing.

title: Fight Against Malaria
description: The parasite chiefly responsible for malaria has become increasingly resistant to chloroquine, a drug once regarded as a wonder cure for the disease. But a team of American scientists has discovered that chloroquine remains effective against the parasites if the drug is administered along with an antidepressant.

title: 67 DIE WHEN FERRY SINKS IN CARIBBEAN
description: A ferry overloaded with New Year's travelers sank off the Caribbean coast after it ran out of fuel, drowning 67 people, the authorities reported today. Fourteen were missing and 46 people survived.

title: Market for New Issues Fell Sharply in '88 Amid Investor Disenchantment
description: Although the economy and the performance of the stock market rebounded nicely from the October 1987 crash, corporations found investors unwilling to buy many new stock issues last year.

title: Subpoenas by North Expected
description: Three more Reagan Administration officials expect to receive subpoenas to appear as defense witnesses on behalf of Oliver L. North at his trial on conspiracy charges arising from the Iran-contra affair, an Administration spokesman said here today.

title: What's in a Japanese Name? For Many Women, Obscurity
description: Reiko Sekiguchi is the name she was given at birth, and that is how she is addressed at social gatherings and scholarly conferences, on research papers, even on letters from her husband.

title: Review/Television; Eudora Welty on Her Start as a Writer
description: Tonight at 9 on Channel 21 and at 10 on Channel 13, ''The American Experience'' on public television offers a documentary that was produced by Patchy Wheatley for the British Broadcasting Corporation. But ''Eudora Welty: One Writer's Beginnings'' is about a very American writer, a woman who has lived just about all of her nearly 80 years in the state-capital city of Jackson, Miss.

title: Treasury Bill Auction Set For Today
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Correction
description: A listing in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Friday about the Consolidated Natural Gas Company misidentified a new board member. He is Steven A. Minter.

title: A Higher Gas Tax Isn't Courage, but Arrogance; But Not Diesel Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: For Happy Memories, Have a Nice Day Today
description: WAS 1988 a good year for you?

title: Braniff Shifts Its Account To McKinney
description: PREPARING for its third major marketing realignment since emerging from bankruptcy five years ago, Braniff Inc. has named McKinney & Silver, a veteran of airline advertising, as its agency of record.

title: At Texas Border, Hopes For Sewers and Water
description: After years of inaction, Texas is trying to put together programs to address one of the nation's most wrenching public health problems: the tens of thousands of people living without running water or adequate sewage treatment along the border with Mexico.

title: PATTERNS
description: Seventh Avenue Blues

title: Rome Journal; How Is Marcus Aurelius? As Right as Acid Rain
description: They have made it more difficult to toss even one coin into the Trevi Fountain, let alone the Hollywood allotment of three.

title: Still Bullish, With Fingers Crossed
description: Fear hung over the stock market early last year as investors worried that the October 1987 crash would be followed by a 1930's-like depression and market decline. But the market turned in a remarkably strong performance, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 11.8 percent, ending the year at 2,168.57.

title: Our Towns; A Pair of Angels Who've Earned Their Wings
description: Kim Thornton is the youngest of seven children. The others looked out for her. They had to; their parents were alcoholics. When Kim was 8, her mother and father got bad. Her father sold the house for cash and announced he was driving them to Arizona.

title: Industry Sees New Markets After Europe Bans U.S. Beef
description: American meat-exporting companies say that they have already found alternative markets for many products they normally sell to Europe but that the industry will not escape some harm.

title:
WALL STREET OUTLOOK;
The Biggest Winners Were Not Big Names
description: LEAD: Multibillion-dollar takeovers and leveraged buyouts may have made the big business headlines in 1988, but the brand-name companies involved in those blockbuster deals, like Kraft Inc. and RJR Nabisco Inc., do not show up on the list of the year's biggest winners, in percentage terms, on the New York Stock

title: Monitor Introducing Redesigned Newspaper
description: The Christian Science Monitor will introduce a revamped daily newspaper today, with fewer pages, color photography and less advertising, after months of internal turmoil over the project.

title: Lost Boy Ate Spiders to Live
description: A 15-year-old boy who was lost in the Cleveland National Forest survived six days and bitter-cold nights by sleeping in hollow logs and eating snow and spiders, his mother said.

title: Iraq Said to Cut Oil Exports
description: Iraq has cut its oil exports by 90,000 barrels a day in accordance with its new OPEC production quota of 2.64 million barrels a day, the official Iraqi news agency said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Explaining Last Summer's Drought The 1988 drought was caused by cyclical changes in the tropical Pacific and had little to do with the greenhouse effect, new evidence indicates. With an improving understanding of the global climate system, scientists have linked cold waters off South America to storms and atmospheric disturbances that drove the jet stream northward, causing drought in North America. Science Times, page C1. Capital Mayor Supported Federal investigations of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. have failed to diminish his popularity among many in the city's black majority. Page A12. 2 Doctors Slain at Home A quiet, affluent Westchester County village is shocked by the stabbing and bludgeoning death of two of its residents. Page B1.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do the altitudes of timberlines vary from one mountain range to another? A. The treeline or timberline, the line on mountains and in polar regions beyond which trees will not grow, is mostly determined by temperature, according to researchers at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Trees need a long enough and warm enough summer to ripen seeds, produce new wood and form buds.

title: Cleanup After Harbor Blast
description: Workers cleared wreckage Sunday at a harbor where at least 50 yachts were destroyed in an explosion that set off a chain-reaction fire. The explosion Saturday night was aboard a pleasure boat moored at the Watergate Yachting Center.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's oldest bridge clubs, the Studenterforeningen Bridge Club in Copenhagen, marked its 60th birthday recently with an international pairs event. The diagramed deal won a Swedish player the prize for best-played hand, and the Swedish expert Sven-Olov Flodqvist suggests it would probably have won a prize for the best-bid hand, too, if such a prize had existed.

title: People
description: * Brian Anderson has been promoted to executive vice president and director of marketing at Marcoa DR Group, a direct-marketing company formed by the merger of BBDO Direct, the DR Group and Marcoa Direct.

title: Scientists Link '88 Drought to Natural Cycle in Tropical Pacific
description: LAST year's killing drought in the United States was caused by massive, naturally occurring climatic forces in the tropical Pacific Ocean and had little to do with global warming caused by the greenhouse effect, according to new evidence.

title: 2 Argentines Prepare American Jazz Revue
description: Is the revue dead? Not if Claudio Segovia and Hector Orezzoli, two Argentine producers who have brought new life to the genre, have anything to say about it.

title: Officially a Year Older, But Are They Better?
description: Did you remember, at the moment 1988 turned to 1989, to wish happy birthday to every racehorse in the Northern Hemisphere?

title: Panel Approves Evacuation Plan For Area Around Seabrook Plant
description: A Federal licensing panel has approved New Hampshire's evacuation plans for the Seabrook nuclear power plant, dismissing objections that the region could not be cleared fast enough to protect thousands of people in an accident.

title: This Country Needs a Third Political Party
description: LEAD: If there was one profound message from the Presidential election, it's that the old Democratic-Republican, tweedle-dee tweedle-dum, two-party system needs to be challenged. We need a new, third-party progressive political movement to represent the needs and interests of working people, minorities, the elderly, farmers, environmentalists, peace activists and all people who believe they are not represented by status quo politics.

title: Rain in Pennsylvania Found Most Acidic
description: RAIN at a monitoring station in central Pennsylvania registered the highest acid content of 131 sites in 46 states, according to a report by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: Addenda
description: * The American Advertising Federation has issued a call for nominations for its third annual Distinguished Advertising Educator Award. For information and nomination forms, call (202) 898-0089.

title: Wheat Offer Made to China
description: The United States Agriculture Department on Friday offered to subsidize sales of one million metric tons of wheat to China, the second such offer this month.

title: 5 Africans Say They Were Tortured by the Chinese
description: Five African students were tortured by the police in the eastern city of Nanjing, after a week of racial unrest in that city, an African diplomat today quoted the students as saying.

title: Financial Videos From Dollar Dry Dock
description: Look out MTV, Dollar Dry Dock Bank has come out with its own in-house videos. While the vignettes of financial advice may not rival Michael Jackson's hit singles, Borejko Leibler's subsidiary B Designed is banking that customers will use the three-minute shorts to learn more about the fundamentals of Wall Street.

title: Jersey Mayor Is Sworn For the Seventh Time
description: Mayor Thomas G. Dunn was sworn in today for the seventh time. It was also for the last time, he said.

title: Economy Is Bolstered By Exports
description: Fueled by an increase in exports, the nation's economy grew in December at its highest rate in five months, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, which is scheduled to be released today.

title: Phoebe H. Stein, 75, Health-Care Advocate
description: Phoebe Hockstader Stein, an advocate of health-care causes, died of lung cancer Sunday at Montefiore Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Persistent Recruiters
description: Less than a month before the Reagan Administration folds its tent, the personnel staff is still recruiting. One newcomer of note is John F. Cogan, who joined the Office of Management and Budget in October as a consultant and then became an unofficial special assistant to the director, Joseph R. Wright Jr. There was nothing to keep Mr. Wright from holding Mr. Cogan in that capacity through to Inauguration Day on Jan. 20, helping with the final Reagan budget to be submitted next Monday. Mr. Cogan could then return to the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford from which he has taken a leave as a senior fellow. Instead last week he received official appointment as deputy director.

title: Uniting the Enemies of Pol Pot
description: The United States and Vietnam now share an important goal - preventing Pol Pot and his killer Khmer Rouge forces from regaining power in Cambodia. But common action requires that Hanoi fully honor its promise to withdraw all Vietnamese forces from Cambodia. And as those withdrawals continue, the U.S., Vietnam, the Soviet Union and China all need to work together with the aim of disarming Pol Pot's troops and inserting an international force to save the Cambodian people.

title: Black Mayor and Council Are Elected in Divided Town
description: This racially divided town held its first locally supervised election since the 1930's today, re-electing the Mayor and voting in her all-black council slate.

title: Bank Board's Wild Week Of Round-the-Clock Deals
description: With a stunning display of its ability and willingness to strike deals and spend money, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board put on a show last week the like of which is seldom seen in Washington.

title: The Truth About Crime
description: A recent report from the American Bar Association contains a noteworthy confession: Criminal justice can't control crime. The A.B.A.'s appeal for more acceptance of that uncomfortable point deserves wide attention.

title: Economy's Captain Picks a Crucial Battle And Has Some Luck
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, emerged in 1988 as the interim captain of the American economy.

title: U.S. WILL PROPOSE WIDE U.N. POWERS ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The United States will soon propose giving additional powers to the Secretary General of the United Nations to investigate allegations of the use of chemical weapons anywhere in the world, Administration officials said today.

title: PERES IS ATTACKED ON AUSTERITY PLAN
description: Finance Minister Shimon Peres's austerity plan to shore up Israel's troubled economy is running into sharp opposition, particularly among members of his own Labor Party.

title: BKW Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Eddie Heywood, 73, Jazz Pianist, Arranger and Composer, Is Dead
description: Eddie Heywood, the pianist whose highly stylized arrangement of Cole Porter's ''Begin the Beguine'' made his sextet one of the most popular jazz groups of the 1940's, died Monday at his home in North Miami, Fla. He was 73 years old.

title: Possible Candidates For New York Mayor File for Public Funds
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch and four other potential mayoral candidates filed yesterday to participate in the city's new public campaign-financing program. But City Council President Andrew J. Stein said he would not participate, contending the $28 million plan is too costly to taxpayers.

title: Hewlett-Packard To Buy Hilco Stake
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would make a 25 percent investment in Hilco Technologies Inc. of St. Louis in exchange for an undisclosed amount of its stock. In addition, for three years, Hilco's software for manufacturing companies will run exclusively on Hewlett-Packard's hardware, and Hilco will become a reseller of the HP-9000 technical computer systems.

title: KEY RATES
Soviets Report Protests In Georgia in November
description: Nationalists in Soviet Georgia staged factory sit-ins, demonstrations and hunger strikes to protest constitutional changes that they fear could limit local sovereignty, Pravda said today.

title: Dollar, Off, Recovers a Bit On Report of U.S. Ship Move
description: The dollar opened the year's first trading day with a sharp decline and then rebounded some on a report that American Navy ships are being sent to the Mediterranean.

title: 'Radical Ideas' of Sociologists Gain New Respect
description: After years of adhering to the advice of psychologists, many educators are now turning to sociologists and their more radical prescriptions in the search for solutions to longstanding educational problems.

title: Course Is Revamped For New Jersey Race
description: The New Jersey Waterfront Marathon will have a revamped course this April that will start on the George Washington Bridge and end at Giants Stadium.

title: When Dividends Are Bad News
description: AMERICAN corporations are raising the dividends they pay to shareholders. Paradoxically, this may indicate that now is not a good time to buy stocks.

title: National Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents total data processing revenues.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Carolco Pictures Inc., Los Angeles, an independent movie maker, said it had paid $40 million for television syndication rights to 40 movies made by Hemdale Film Corp.

title: Waterhouse Investor Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Jehovah's Witness Wins Bid To Block More Transfusions
description: A Jehovah's Witness who was given a blood transfusion against her will won an appeal today that set aside the court order that allowed the transfusion, her lawyer said.

title: Super Rite Foods Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Nov 26
Arthur R. Gold, Professor, 53
description: Dr. Arthur Ralph Gold, a professor of English at Wellesley College in Massachusetts, died of cancer Saturday at Cambridge Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Jefferies Accuses GAF Of Carbide Stock Role
description: Boyd L. Jefferies, a crucial Government witness in several securities fraud cases, made his courtroom debut yesterday by accusing the GAF Corporation and one of its senior executives of asking him to manipulate the price of Union Carbide stock in the fall of 1986.

title: Collins Spurns Murdoch Bid
description: The Scottish publisher William Collins P.L.C. today rejected an increased takeover bid by Rupert Murdoch and sought a friendly deal with a French publisher instead.

title: Boy, a Bystander, Dies in a Police Shootout
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was killed last night when he was caught in the middle of a shootout between two police officers and a gunman, the police said.

title: Edwards Injured
description: Eddie (The Eagle) Edwards of Britain, the ski jumper who last February soared and dipped to international renown during the Winter Olympics at Calgary for his dogged competitive spirit despite extremely limited talent, yesterday broke a collarbone during a practice session in Innsbruck, Austria. Training for a World Cup event, Edwards lost control of his right ski in mid-air and tumbled several times after landing, suffering a head injury and skin abrasions as well as the broken collarbone. ''I have damaged myself,'' he said after being helped out of the snow and sent to a hospital. ''After I recover, I'll do that again.''(AP)

title: Reagan to Undergo Surgery For Finger Ailment Saturday
description: President Reagan will undergo minor surgery Saturday to correct a condition in his left hand that makes it impossible for him to straighten his ring finger, the White House said today.

title: Oakley and the Knicks Rebound in Overtime
description: The off-season trade for Charles Oakley never paid better dividends for the Knicks than last night. The power forward, acquired from the Chicago Bulls for Bill Cartwright, did what he does best: rebound.

title: Former Slaves Tell Of a Torn Country
description: Bullwhip Days The Slaves Remember Edited by James Mellon. 460 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $27.50.

title: Congress Opens Session In Spirit of Conciliation
description: With circumspection about the political fights to come, the 101st Congress opened today with pledges from the Democrats in command that they would work in a bipartisan spirit with both their new President and their old Republican rivals.

title: Bonn's Proliferation Policy
description: It should come as no surprise that a West German company has been accused of helping Libya build a plant to produce poison gas. If true, this is only the latest in a long line of irresponsible West German exports.

title: Dr. Irwin Lubowe, 83, Retired Dermatologist
description: Dr. Irwin Lubowe, a dermatologist specializing in disorders of the hair and scalp, died Monday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Oxford Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-Net loss

title: Comprehensive Care Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months included an after-tax gain on the sale of assets of about $900,000, or 8 cents a share. Corrected from Friday, Dec. 30, editions.

title: Woman Arrested in Newark In Cocaine Seizure at Airport
description: A woman was arrested this weekend for trying to smuggle $300,000 worth of cocaine onto a flight leaving Newark International Airport, a Port Authority spokesman said today.

title: Sterling Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net losses from discontinued operations of $2,088,000 and $8,022,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and after extraordinary gains of $1,979,000 and $4,815,000 for the same periods, respectively, from early retirement of debt. c-After an extraordinary gain of $360,000 from the early retirement of debt. There were no common share earnings for fiscal 1988 because the net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: NAVY OFFICIAL SAID TO HAVE GOT GIFTS
description: Federal investigators in the Pentagon procurement case believe that two consultants gave $1,000 gifts to a Navy official in a position to help the Hazeltine Corporation compete for a contract, a court affidavit made public today said.

title: Watching Steinberg
description: LEAD: Once the Joel Steinberg trial is over, will there be any serious argument left against televising trials?

title: Police Assault On Drugs Moves Into 3d Borough
description: New York City's new street-level assault on drug trafficking was expanded into a third borough yesterday with the deployment of a 117-member Tactical Narcotics Team in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Study Asserts 'Poison Pills' Do Not Raise Stock Prices
description: A new study challenges an earlier analysis compiled by Georgeson & Company that defended ''poison pills'' on the ground that companies adopting such takeover repellents outperform those that do not.

title: The Characters Are Real, the History Isn't
description: The Czar is baffled by his sister-in-law's taste in men. In an unusually down-to-earth moment from Roberto Pazzi's novel ''Searching for the Emperor,'' Czar Nicholas II wonders how Elizabeth could have chosen such an ''empty-headed and superficial'' lover. Her reason, which elevates imagination over sex appeal or love, points to the heart of the novel: ''Give me only a little of a man, a very little,'' she says. ''I'll make up the rest.''

title: Europeans to Offer Plan to Ease Trade Dispute With U.S.
description: The European Community will present a proposal to the United States this week that it hopes will ease a dispute over beef raised with growth hormones.

title: Great Wines of Jersey and Indianola
description: ''CHATEAUNEUF DU MAHWAH,'' the label announced. Mahwah? New Jersey? The wine was flavored by ''hunks of choice native white oak from Newark,'' the label explained. Food aficionados were given a hot tip: the wine ''is best enjoyed with tofu and mashed potato sandwiches.''

title: BOOK NOTES
description: Stalin With Warts

title: Digital Licenses Apollo's Software
description: Apollo Computer Inc., based in Chelmsford, Mass., said the Digital Equipment Corporation had licensed its network computing system and was evaluating it for use in future products. The system consists of software tools that allow the automatic distribution of parts of a single software application to multiple computers across a network.

title: S.E.C. Picks Computer Bid
description: After a delay of more than a two years, the Securities and Exchange Commission today awarded a $52 million contract to build its electronic data gathering, analysis and retrieval system, known as Edgar.

title: Article 563889 -- No Title
description: President Reagan's last budget is likely to show Government spending of about $10 billion a year to cope with the cost of salvaging hundreds of insolvent savings and loan institutions, according to White House officials.

title: Puerto Rico Governor Seeking Vote on Status
description: Gov. Rafael Hernandez-Colon has called for a plebiscite on Puerto Rico's political status.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Research Corp., Baltimore, a producer of high-technology weapon systems, named Gene J. Deporter to the new post of senior vice president of business development.

title: Shultz and Regan Subpoenaed by North
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, several of his aides and senior officials of the Defense Department and the Central Intelligence Agency have been subpoenaed as defense witnesses in the Iran-contra conspiracy trial of Oliver L. North, the agencies said today.

title: Mead and Toyota Fight Over Name
description: When the Toyota Motor Corporation decided to call its 1989 luxury-car line Lexus, the Mead Corporaton went to court. The name, Mead said, infringed on Lexis, the registered trademark for computerized information services provided by Mead Data Central Inc.

title: Equal Rights Proposal Is Revived in House
description: A group of 129 members of the House of Representatives reintroduced the proposed equal rights amendment to the Federal Constitution today and urged President-elect George Bush to support it.

title: Nets Win as Hornets Set An Attendance Record
description: Joe Barry Carroll and Roy Hinson scored 22 points each tonight as the Nets used a fourth-period spurt to defeat the Charlotte Hornets, 109-106.

title: A Top Receiver Seeks a Supreme Catch
description: Everything in pro football has come so fast and in such a flurry for Jerry Rice that, at first glance, he remains not only the game's consummate wide receiver, but also the happy, carefree youth he recalls being as he grew up in Crawford, Miss.

title: Construction Spending Rose 0.8% in November
description: Construction spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, reflecting an increase in work on homes and government projects that more than offset slower building of offices and shopping malls, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Lessons
description: Public schools in the United States have traditionally modeled themselves around prevailing fashions in industry.

title: Scimed Life Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Field Selling Pioneer Press To Sun-Times
description: The Chicago Sun-Times said today that it had agreed to buy Pioneer Press Inc., a suburban newspaper chain, from the Field Corporation for an undisclosed amount.

title: Topics of The Times; Not Bitter in New Hampshire
description: The Governor-elect of New Hampshire and the Mayor of Portsmouth, its largest city, deserve gold stars for enlightened reaction to news that a commission recommends closing Portsmouth's Pease Air Force Base. Pease is one of the largest installations on the Federal hit list, with 2,250 military personnel and 400 civilian employees.

title: Connecticut To Address Budget Gap
description: The Connecticut General Assembly will begin its 1989 session today, confronting not the opportunities of recent years but rather the limitations presented by a huge expected gap in the state budget.

title: Peru's Inflation Put at 1,722%
description: The Government says consumer prices rose 1,722 percent last year, the highest single-year mark in memory, and one economic forecasting concern predicts that they will rise at more than three times that rate this year.

title: Francis Van Bortel, 67, Advertising Executive
description: Francis J. Van Bortel, a former executive vice president of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, the advertising agency, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 67 years old.

title: Holtz Hails the No.1 Irish But Finds Flaws Amid Glory
description: The most optimistic ones among the followers of football at the University of Notre Dame had pictured their coach going onto the field not long after darkness fell upon the Arizona desert.

title: Christopher Andrewes, Virologist, Dies at 92
description: Sir Christopher Andrewes, a virologist who helped discover the influenza virus, died Saturday. He was 92 years old.

title: Ohio Mattress Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Barrett Resources Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $442,000. c-Net loss

title: Cuomo to Seek Rise in Grants For Welfare
description: Despite a state budget gap that he estimates at more than $2 billion, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to propose an increase in state welfare benefits in his State of the State address on Wednesday.

title: Washington Leans Away From Yanks
description: The chances appeared to be growing yesterday that Claudell Washington would not return to the Yankees, which would leave them without a left-handed hitting outfielder.

title: Why Not Help the Soviets Leave?
description: Moscow now gives every sign of resuming its troop withdrawals from Afghanistan in time to meet the treaty deadline of Feb. 15. Barbara Crossette of The Times reports that Soviet officials are being flown out of Kabul, a telltale sign that the end is near. That leaves the United States and Pakistan, chief supporters of the Afghan resistance for nine years, with the critical choice whether to abet or complicate the Soviet departure.

title: Radiant Technology Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $129,000 and $40,000 for the latest year and prior year, respectively.

title: The Nazi Time: Younger Jews Try to Comprehend
description: ''My parents never really spoke about it,'' Janet Greenberg, whose parents are both survivors, said as she walked through Yad Vashem, the Israeli memorial to the six million Jewish civilians who died at the hands of the Nazis in World War II.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the outlook for mergers and leveraged buyouts misidentified the company that recently put the credit ratings of Salomon Brothers and Shearson Lehman Hutton under review. It was Moody's Investors Service. In addition, a table with the article contained an incomplete list of the advisers to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in its acquisition of RJR Nabisco Inc. Merrill Lynch & Company was one of the advisers.

title: Dow Begins Year With 23.93 Decline
description: LEAD: Traders who were hoping that the stock market would get off on the right foot for 1989 were disappointed yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.93 points to close at 2,144.64.

title: New PGA Circuit Gives Hope to Young Players
description: The PGA Tour office, which conducts both the regular American pro golf circuit and the senior tour in this country, is to start another tour in 1990 that will serve as a proving ground for young golfers hoping to make the major pro golfing circuit.

title: Izvestia Opens Pages to 'Parasites'
description: ''French perfumes, French wines, the French striving for comfort have been well known to you for a long time,'' read the notice on page 5 of tonight's issue of Izvestia, the Soviet Government daily newspaper. ''Now you have the opportunity to get better acquainted with industrial France.''

title: Hextall Sparks 4-1 Victory for Flyers, Putting Damper on Islander Revival
description: The Islanders stormed the Flyers with 18 shots in the first period tonight and took a 1-0 lead, but they let up after that, and the Flyers, with strong goaltending by Ron Hextall, took control and emerged with a 4-1 victory.

title: Fountain Powerboat Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $11,000 for the latest year and $45,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: BIG SOVIET PULLOUT FROM AFGHANISTAN IS SEEN RESUMING
description: After suspending its troop withdrawal from Afghanistan two months ago, the Soviet Union now appears to be taking steps to carry out its original agreement to pull all its forces from the country by Feb. 15, Western diplomats said today. They said a major withdrawal seems to be planned as early as Jan. 15.

title: Rite Aid Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $47,059,000 and a gain of $3,712,000 from an accounting change.

title: About New York; An Experience? Sure. Timeless? Not in New York
description: Albert Boyars mailed out a news release just last September that said the ''New York Experience'' was ''timeless,'' like New York City itself. Here it is January and there is no longer an ''Experience'' to experience. The 55-minute sound and light blitzkreig closed Monday night, proof that timelessness and permanence are two different things in New York.

title: CBS Records to Buy Tree, Ending an Era in Nashville
description: Tree International Publishing, the last country music publisher to be both owned and operated in Nashville, is being sold to CBS Records for more than $30 million.

title:
EDUCATION;
New Movement Seeks to Replace Rivalry in Class With Team Spirit
description: LEAD: When Cathy Wilson teaches a spelling lesson to her third-grade class at the Ina E. Driscoll School in Wilton, Conn., she does not issue the usual warning that pupils keep their eyes on their own papers and their lips buttoned. She encourages them to talk and to help one another.

title: Chrysler Plans a 10-Cylinder Engine
description: The Chrysler Corporation confirmed today that it is developing a huge 10-cylinder engine that it hopes to place in a sports car by the early 1990's.

title: Elisabeth Hoffman Dietz, Professor, 80
description: Dr. Elisabeth Hoffmann Dietz, a retired professor of education at Brooklyn College, died of pnuemonia Monday at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta. She was 80 years old and lived in Sun City, Ariz.

title: Miami Coach Ignores Critics and Remains Successful
description: He has a cherubic face and perfectly coiffed hair, which give Jimmy Johnson a distinctive look, but have also made him a caricature among college football coaches. His slick style, outspoken manner and coaching philosophy win more adversaries than admirers. During the Orange Bowl game, for instance, Bob Trumpy, the NBC analyst who has made his own reputation by speaking his mind, called Johnson a used-car dealer who lobbies too much.

title: Blacks Keep Reins in Georgia Town
description: Black candidates won all six city offices Monday in this racially divided town, proving to many black residents that a victory by blacks last year in Keysville's first election since 1933 was not a fluke.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Swiss Wins 3d Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland posted her third World Cup slalom victory of the season, winning at Maribor, Yugoslavia, yesterday. She finished ahead of Monika Maierhofer of Austria and Tamara McKinney of the United States. It was Schneider's sixth World Cup victory over all this season. Schneider was timed for the two heats in 1 minute 22.65 seconds, finishing 1.16 seconds ahead of Maierhofer. McKinney, of Squaw Valley, Calif., was third in 1:24.14. Brigitte Gadient of Switzerland was fourth in 1:24.50, 50-hundredths of a second ahead of Christine von Gruenigen of Switzerland. Schneider's latest victory confirmed that she has reached the peak of her career as she prepares for the World Alpine Skiing Championships, which begin Jan. 29 in Vail, Colo. In the overall cup standings, she leads with 157 points, ahead of the runner-up, Ulrike Maier of Austria, who has 74. Another Austrian, Anita Wachter, is third, with 62 points.(AP) TENNIS Woodforde Gains: Mark Woodforde, the defending champion, scored a 6-4, 6-4 victory over the French hopeful Guillaume Raoux in the first round of the $123,400 South Australian Open in Adelaide.
