Sixth-seeded John Frawley of Australia fared worse than his compatriot, losing to a little-known Yugoslav, Goran Ivanisevic. Frawley bowed in three close sets to the 17-year-old, 7-5, 6-7, 6-4. West Germany's Patrick Kuhnen, seeded No. 7, was one of the few seeded players to survive the first round when he beat Olivier Delaitre of France, 2-6, 7-6, 6-2. The Soviet Union's Andrei Olhovskiy triumphed over Libor Nemecek of Czechoslovakia, 1-6, 6-3, 6-2. Roger Rasheed of Australia, in the tournament as a wild-card entry, defeated Sweden's Jan Apell, 6-3, 1-6, 6-3, and Peter Sampras of the United States beat Jeremy Bates of Britain, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Krishnan Upset: The top-seeded player and defending champion, Ramesh Krishnan of India, was eliminated, 6-4, 1-6, 6-3, by West Germany's Patrick Baur in the first round of the $145,000 BP New Zealand tennis championships in Wellington. Third-seeded Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands lost, 6-3, 6-4, to David Lewis of New Zealand. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Women Auburn 79, Appalachian State 50: Vickie Orr scored a season-high 23 points and also grabbed 14 rebounds to lead third-ranked Auburn.

title: In U.S. Produce, an Explosion of Exotica
description: LEAD: ''NEW American crops'' is a sobriquet being applied to produce that is rarely new or American. After all, only a handful of food plants cultivated in this country is native: sunflowers, cranberries, Jerusalem artichokes, pecans, blueberries, Concord grapes and the recently tamed wild rice. So ''New American'' refers to crops just now entering the North

title: Street Dramatist in India Slain Over Play
description: A leftist who was one of India's most popular street theater directors was beaten to death by thugs last weekend after he refused a politician's demand to stop a drama in support of an opposing candidate, witnesses said.

title: New Quake Hits Armenia
description: A new tremor rocked the earthquake-devastated Armenian city of Leninakan on Saturday, but it caused only minor damage to buildings, city relief authorities said today. The quake was one of a series of aftershocks that hit the area after a catastrophic earthquake on Dec. 7 that killed at least 25,000 people across Soviet Armenia, a spokesman said. The quake measured 7 on the 12-point Soviet scale, which is different from the more widely used Richter scale.

title: Review/Television; Agatha Christie Updated
description: Admirers of Joan Hickson's delicious Miss Marple in public television's ''Mystery!'' series know quite well that the British have a knack for bringing Agatha Christie to the screen. The American record, unfortunately, is spotty, particularly in a series of films made for CBS by Warner Brothers Television over the last several years. The latest, ''The Man in the Brown Suit,'' can be seen at 9 this evening. It is bottom-of-the-barrel time.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: DRIED salted cod has been associated with Spanish, Portuguese and French cooking for centuries. It was especially valuable before refrigeration because of its long shelf life. The cod, some of which measure up to six feet long, were usually salted aboard fishing vessels in large wooden barrels. Before cooking, the fillets were soaked in water to remove the salt and reconstitute the flesh.

title: Chief Executive Picked At Cyclops Industries
description: Cyclops Industries, a steelmaker in Pittsburgh, said yesterday that James F. Will had been named chief executive.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Slide
description: The credit markets began the new year on a sour note yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell sharply in light trading.

title: Holly Farms To Test Ruling
description: The Holly Farms Corporation, a poultry producer, said today that it would fight a court ruling won by its hostile suitor, Tyson Foods Inc., that blocks its friendly merger with the Conagra Corporaion.

title: In Modern Times, Shrinking Standards
description: REMEMBER when an acceptable substitute for a biscuit or cookie cutter was one end of an empty can of frozen orange juice? When the ingredient list made reference to a No. 2 can? When there was one size coffee can and it held a pound of coffee? It also held a loaf of bread, which is why so many recipes years ago called for a coffee can for bread baking.

title: Washington Talk: Electoral College; Bush Gets to Proclaim Own Election Victory
description: At precisely 1 P.M. on Wednesday, Vice President George Bush plans to enter the House of Representatives and, within 30 minutes, make a not very surprising announcement before a joint session of Congress.

title: Lemonade From a Greenish Tweed Lemon
description: To the Editor:

title: EATING WELL
description: Roast squab with port wine sauce; grilled chicken breast with white bean, fennel and escarole salad; braised salmon on a bed of barley and white rice: hardly Spartan dishes, yet they are part of a program for people who want to eat healthful but elegant food when they dine out.

title: Debt Issue in Mexico
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has called for unity behind his efforts to negotiate a reduction in Mexico's foreign debt servicing burden. ''Whoever doesn't contribute to the debt negotiations will really be attacking the unity of the nation, so necessary at this hour, and playing the game of our creditors,'' he said on Monday. Mr. Salinas said the Government would seek up to $7 billion in new foreign credits and a reduction in servicing payments on Mexico's $106 billion foreign debt when restructuring talks with creditor banks begin this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Stanley Works To Ammirati
description: The Stanley Works, the New Britain, Conn., manufacturer of home hardware products, has moved its $10 million to $12 million account from Della Femina, McNamee WCRS to Ammirati & Puris after a review that began in the fall.

title: BEI Holdings Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes tax credits of $1,395,000 for the latest year and $3,505,000 for 1987.

title: Way Cleared for Woman to Become Bishop
description: The first woman named to become a bishop in the Episcopal Church cleared a major obstacle to the position today when she received the necessary votes from church committees across the country.

title: Those Who Would Should
description: Democrats and Wall Street just won't leave George Bush alone on this tax thing. They want more taxes laid on, and they keep fretting at Mr. Bush to lay on with a will.

title: Panel Asks Strong U.S. Push To Develop Superconductors
description: A Presidential advisory panel has recommended that the Government organize a more aggressive national program to develop superconducting materials.

title: In Pittsburgh, Housing for Homeless Veterans Becomes a Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretoria 1988: A Year Many Lost a Voice
description: The Government restricted the political activity of 32 organizations in 1988, according to the Human Rights Commission, a private monitoring group based in Johannesburg.

title: The Pop Life
description: All the Rage

title: Holding On to Faith in the Face of the Reality of Evil
description: In May of 1987, while reporting on the Klaus Barbie trial, the novelist and short-story writer Hugh Nissenson spoke to a French Jesuit priest who had served in the Resistance in World War II. ''Our generation has experienced the truth about history,'' the priest said. ''Evil is real. The human condition hasn't changed since Adam and Eve. The world awaits its Redeemer. Nothing about the war - not even the murder of children - shakes my faith.''

title: Noll Retained
description: After several weeks filled with hints and rumors of a staff shakeup, the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday announced that four assistant coaches had been let go, the defensive coordinator had resigned and Coach Chuck Noll would stay with the Steelers until he retires. Dan Rooney, the Steeler president, said of Noll, ''I have much confidence in his ability to lead the team back to the top.'' The Steelers, who won four Super Bowls under Noll from 1975-80, have not qualified for the N.F.L. playoffs since 1984 and finished 5-11 in 1988. The coaches dismissed were Jed Hughes, linebackers; Hal Hunter, guards-center; Dennis Fitzgerald, special teams, and Walt Evans, conditioning and training. Tony Dungy, the linebackers coach, resigned.(AP)

title: Beyond 'Moosewood': Vegetarian Food for the Committed 80's
description: Mollie Katzen was 10 years old in 1960 when she discovered that spaghetti did not come out of a can. She was well into her teens before she ate fresh broccoli, cauliflower or asparagus. Her first foray into cooking was a mud pie, made with real mud at age 2, and her first professional job, at 16, was flipping hamburgers at a department-store grill.

title: Toys 'R' Us Names Two Vice Chairmen
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., operators of the toy and children's clothing chains, yesterday announced the appointment of two vice chairmen and the retirement of its president, and reported an increase in Christmas season sales that disappointed some analysts.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about plans to address Israel's economic problems rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from Finance Minister Shimon Peres. The quotation should have read, ''This is a directed and serious attempt to turn the economy toward growth, export, industry and economic independence''; he did not say ''dependence.''

title: Providence Goes to 11-0 By Trouncing St. John's
description: Unbeaten Providence College, led by Matt Palazzi's 19 points, overwhelmed St. John's, 98-69, in Big East play tonight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ciociola & Company Wins Remco Account
description: It's still looking a lot like Christmas at Ciociola & Company, which has won the $2 million to $5 million Remco Toys account, and at Bohbot Communications, which has been called on to handle media planning and buying for the $12 million Matchbox Toys USA account.

title: Kayser-Roth Names a New Chief
description: The new owners of the Wickes Companies have taken its Kayser-Roth Hosiery Group off the market and today named a new top officer from a rival hosiery maker.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Staying Green

title: How to Recognize Danger Signs of Depression; Enough Stigma
description: To the Editor:

title: Oliver L. Austin, 85, Ornithologist, Is Dead
description: Oliver L. Austin Jr., an ornithologist who wrote a definitive study, ''Birds of the World,'' in 1961 and who was curator emeritus of ornithology at the Florida Museum of Natural History, died Saturday at his retirement home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 85 years old and had lived for many years in Tuckahoe, N.Y., and in Wellfleet. Mass.

title: Unbeaten Seton Hall Defeats Georgetown
description: With each victory, Seton Hall's basketball program takes another step toward higher ground. And though the season is still young, the Pirates are savoring the view.

title: Playoff? What Playoff?
description: rrA group of early risers crowded in front of Lou Holtz yesterday morning to see if he had changed his mind on one of the burning issues of our time.

title: Double Murder In Westchester Puzzles Police
description: Clues to the savage slaying of a couple here continued to elude detectives today as troubled residents walked by the stone-and-stucco house to see where the murders had occurred.

title: Topics of The Times; And Read All Over
description: A careful editor, amused by the vagaries of the English language, has for years found the word ''misled'' a momentary puzzle because in her head she read ''MY-zuld.'' Then it dawned on her that the word ''read'' itself poses a problem: its tense can be understood only from context. That is, although the spelling of misled might mislead her into a mispronunciation, she is not likely to be misled into the wrong tense. But ''read'' is the spelling for past, present and future. It can be pronounced ''red'' or ''reed'' but is always spelled read. Some people say they'd rather be red than dead - or is it dead than red? In any case, lives there a writer with soul so dead who has not to himself once said, I'd rather be red than reed?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 A major Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan appears to be ready for as early as Jan. 15, Western diplomats said. At the same time, rebels announced an alliance for interim government. Page A1

title: Tokyo Route Award Won't Be Contested
description: The Department of Transportation said yesterday that it would comply with a court order awarding the coveted Seattle-to-Tokyo route to Continental Airlines. The department had previously argued that Continental was the least qualified of the three carriers seeking the route.

title: When Gloves Just Won't Do
description: MUFFS say as much about the times as they do about the temperature.

title: J. I. Case Predicts Higher Sales in '89
description: Sales of construction equipment will soften this year, but Tenneco Inc.'s troubled J. I. Case Company subsidiary predicted that its 1989 sales will increase in most categories. Case, which has endured major losses from its operations that make construction and farm equipment, believes its models ''will bear positive results in 1989 and beyond,'' said Stephen Scott, a company official.

title: American Standard
description: American Standard Inc., an equipment supplier to the construction industry, has sold its Steelcraft division to Masco Industries of Taylor, Mich., for more than $100 million. American Standard, based in New York, said it was using the proceeds to reduce debt. Steelcraft, based in Cincinnati, has annual sales of more than $100 million. It makes steel doors and other related products for commercial and residential markets.

title: Aileen Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss and after idle plant costs of $3,521,000 for both the 13 weeks and 52 weeks.

title: Adrian S. Lamb, Artist, 87
description: Adrian S. Lamb, an artist whose portraits hang in the White House, the Smithsonian Institution, Harvard Law School, the Pentagon and the United States Naval Academy, died of a heart attack in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital on Saturday. He was 87 years old and had homes in New Canaan, Conn., and Chappaquiddick, Mass.

title: About Real Estate; Office Building in Queens Rises After Long Delays
description: Nearly a decade after a developer first sought to build on the site of the defunct Kew Gardens Hospital near the Queens Borough Hall, the steel frame is in place for a 13-story office building.

title: Apogee Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
WINE TALK
description: THERE is a generation of wine drinkers out there convinced that zinfandel is white. The extraordinary success of white zinfandel over the last six years is one of those marketing phenomena that not even the most astute M.B.A. could have predicted. It's been good for the wine industry - and certainly for the zinfandel growers - and appears to have made a large number of consumers happy as well.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Views Mcorp Data
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the Wall Street investment house that has acquired RJR Nabisco Inc. for $24.88 billion, is examining the financial records of Mcorp to determine whether to bid for the troubled bank holding company.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: NOTHING is cozier on a cold evening than steaming mashed potatoes served with an ample main course - or eaten on their own from a bowl that warms the hands as the food soothes frazzled nerves.

title: Koch Contends He Is Scapegoat For Journalists
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday spent much of his first, formal City Hall press conference of the year testily complaining about the press.

title: U.S.-China Diplomat Quarrel Grows
description: A dispute between China and the United States about restrictions on diplomatic movements has grown into a case study in how negotiation strategies can go awry.

title: New Emergency-Room Rules Seen Going Unheeded in New York City
description: New state regulations intended to end overcrowding in emergency rooms in New York probably cannot be complied with, the heads of public and private New York City hospital agencies said yesterday.

title: Bomb Scares Slow or Disrupt Passenger Flights in Europe
description: Bomb threats forced unscheduled landings and flight delays at airports in Switzerland, Scandinavia and elsewhere, authorities said today.

title: The Deficit Commission: Still Needed
description: Barely 24 hours after President-elect Bush appointed two members to the budget deficit commission, President Reagan's budget office proclaimed that the plan Mr. Reagan will send Congress Monday will bring the books into balance in 1993. If that's right, if a balanced budget is already in the cards, why is a deficit commission needed?

title: China's Racial Unrest Spreads to Beijing Campus
description: China's racial unrest spread to Beijing today, with a march by Chinese students to protest what they said were assaults by African students on Chinese women.

title: Boy, 17, Critically Ill From Poisoned Yogurt
description: Federal health officials have found cyanide in a container of yogurt purchased in Camden, N.J., that was eaten by a youth who became critically ill yesterday in Trenton.

title: Tranzonic Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
How to Recognize Danger Signs of Depression; Italy and Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Archie Boe, Who Led Expansions At Allstate and Sears, Dies at 67
description: Archie R. Boe, a former president of Sears, Roebuck & Company and the Allstate Insurance Company, died of cancer Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 67 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Rates Are Mixed At Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.952 percent, down from 9.0393 percent last week and down for the second consecutive week.

title: Torture Called Routine For Turkish Prisoners
description: Amnesty International accused the Turkish authorities today of routinely torturing political detainees and said it had received reports of torture almost daily in the last two months.

title: Review/Television; 'Banking Basics,' Including a Pitfall
description: ''Banking Basics,'' tonight's opening hour of a three-part PBS series, ''Money in America: The Business of Banking,'' begins with an unusual credit. We are informed that the series was financed by the Wells Fargo bank ''in partial settlement of a class action proceeding involving overdrafts and returned checks.'' A group of consumers, it seems, had complained that Wells Fargo was overcharging on bounced checks. As part of an out-of-court settlement, the bank agreed to spend $1 million on teaching consumers how to handle their finances, including a public television series - and that is how ''Money in America'' came to be produced.

title: Oxidyne Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New 12% British Bond
description: The British Government today introduced a high-interest bond guaranteed to earn 12 percent a year over five years. National Savings, a Government savings plan, said the interest on its new ''capital bond'' is accumulated and paid out at redemption, so the value including interest of a $:100 bond held for five years would be $:176.24, or about $320 at today's currency exchange rates.

title: Review/Theater; Seeking a Lost Mother To Find a Lost Self
description: An adoptee searches for her natural mother in Sybille Pearson's ''Phantasie,'' but that search is less for a new parent than it is for clues to the character's buried self. Without knowledge of the circumstances of her birth or of her parentage, the woman (Diane Salinger) has had to fantasize possibilities. In her imaginative musings, she is everything from the child of a mother who was raped to the unacknowledged daughter of a Rothschild.

title: San Francisco Journal; Chronicling the Suffering He Shares
description: Tucked inside a recent issue of the student newspaper at San Francisco State University was a 64-page magazine called Helpers in the War on AIDS, a stark and moving collection of photographs and essays about people who care for the sick and the dying.

title: Economic Scene; The Bank Board's Costly Dilemma
description: HOW do you plug a $70 billion hole with a handful of small change? If you are the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, you use a little creative accounting and a lot of i.o.u.'s. Last week the board dealt away 34 bankrupt savings and loan associations, ending a year in which it committed the Government to $38 billion in bailouts.

title: Israeli Diamond Exports
description: Israel exported polished diamonds worth an all-time high of $2.46 billion in 1988, the Israel Diamond Exchange's president, Moshe Schnitzer, said today. Mr. Schnitzer said the figure, which compares with $2.06 billion last year, represented about a third of all Israeli industrial exports. He said the added value after the cost of rough stone imports was $600 million.

title: For 3 With Lyme Disease, Pain Without End
description: Because of Lyme disease, Claire Palermo walks with a cane now. At the age of 39, she says she sometimes feels like she is 82. In the last two years, she has seen 42 doctors, spent $30,000 on medical treatment, missed four and a half months of work and experienced a multitude of symptoms, from arthritis and heart palpitations to profound fatigue and depression.

title: Digital Optronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Los Angeles Galaxy Awaits a Brighter Star
description: You might think that Jimmy Carter's going home to Plains, Ga., or Harry Truman's going back to Independence, Mo., would be a much bigger deal than Ronald Reagan's coming home to Hollywood. After all, what high-profile celebrities had those small towns been exposed to? None, till they spawned Presidents. But Hollywood - no doubt about it - is full of stars. So who would think Ronald Reagan's return would be such a big deal? It is, however. The social aviary of Los Angeles is atwitter over the First Couple's homecoming ceremonies.

title: Soviet Travel Curb on Goods May Aim at East Bloc Allies
description: A Soviet regulation that will bar foreigners from taking caviar, television sets and refrigerators out of the country after Feb. 1 appears to be the latest shot in a growing trade war between the Soviet Union and some of its Eastern European economic allies over scarce consumer goods.

title: Clarcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Chicken Dinner, Both Humble and Noble
description: CHANGING a meal's status requires more than a change of name, but not much more. Roast chicken is still roast chicken whether you label it haute cuisine, bourgeois cuisine or country cooking; even calling it ''poulet roti'' will not transmogrify this simple bird. Move, however, from the kitchen to the dining room and from everyday dishes to fine china, then add an appetizer and dessert, and a family meal becomes a festive dinner for guests.

title: S. M. Milliken, 78, Lawyer and Adviser To Service Groups
description: Seth M. Milliken, a lawyer who spent his career as a pro bono adviser to nonprofit groups, primarily working on housing for the poor, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old. Mr. Milliken was on the board of the New York City Mission Society, where he founded a school tutorial program in East Harlem in 1964. He also founded a legal clinic to assist East Harlem residents with housing and social services.

title: Rare Wines Aid Meals-on-Wheels
description: A SINGLE large bottle of Taittinger Champagne holding the equivalent of 36 regular bottles - reportedly the largest Champagne bottle ever made - and a magnum of 1982 Chateau Mouton-Rothschild coupled with a lunch for four at the chateau are among hundreds of rare and unusual wines scheduled to be auctioned for charity in Manhattan on Jan. 15.

title: Again, Guatemala Is Cynical on Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Spectator Sport: Looking, Not Cooking
description: NINA KAMINER subscribes to three cooking magazines, regularly buys and reads new cookbooks, and has become addicted to watching cooking shows on television. ''My favorites are Madeleine, Jeff and Julia,'' she said, referring to Madeleine Kamman, Jeff Smith and Julia Child, whose shows are broadcast on public television.

title: GTE-A.T.&T. Joint Venture
description: The GTE Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that they had completed the formation of a joint-venture company to supply integrated services digital network and other advanced technology to GTE telephone companies.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 3 P.M.

title: Budd Speaks Out
description: Seeking to counter renewed criticism of her political views, Zola Budd said yesterday she did not support any ''political system that entrenches the superiority of one race over another'' or violates basic human rights. The former world cross-country champion issued one of her most explicit political statements in response to a controversy provoked by interviews she recently granted to British television networks. The remarks prompted critics to question whether she would be able to fulfill plans to return to Britain later this year and resume international competition. She returned home to South Africa last March, depressed by the relentless anti-apartheid campaigning against her, after living for four years in Britain to circumvent the international ban on South African participation in track and field.(AP)

title: Soviet Jews to Join World Congress
description: The way has been cleared to allow Soviet Jews formal representation in the World Jewish Congress, the executive director of the group said yesterday.

title: Dukakis Rules Out 4th Term as Governor
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, whose Democratic Presidential campaign ended in defeat in November, announced today that he would not seek re-election as Governor of Massachusetts in 1990.

title: Doctors' Group Acts to Aid Abused Women
description: The leading association of obstetricians and gynecologists today opened a campaign to help women who are victims of physical abuse, a problem that C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, said had become an ''overwhelming'' public health burden.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 2 More Advertisers To Use Comedians
description: Two more advertisers are joining the trend toward using comedians as spokesmen. Next week, Post Fruit & Fibre cereal, a product of General Foods, introduces ads featuring Harvey Korman and Tim Conway, co-stars of television's defunct ''The Carol Burnett Show'' and veterans of the stand-up comedy circuit of years past.

title: Bridge
description: In odd-numbered years, North America is entitled to send two teams to the world championships for the Bermuda Bowl. One of these is always from the United States, which has by far the biggest bridge population, and the other is from Canada, Bermuda or Mexico.

title: Saharan Rebels Leave For Talks in Morocco
description: A delegation representing the Polisario Front guerrillas left for Morocco tonight for its first talks with King Hassan II on ways to end the 13-year war in Western Sahara.

title: About Education
description: ''We made a commitment to go to the moon. Can't we make a commitment that no person will drop out of school and that all people will be able to read?''

title: Pepsico's Bottling Accord Off
description: Pepsico Inc.'s agreement to buy the General CinemaCorporation's soft-drink bottling business for $1.5 billion has been canceled because questions from the Federal Trade Commission prevented the deal's completion before the end of 1988, the two companies said yesterday.

title: PARLEY ON RIGHTS LIKELY IN MOSCOW
description: President Reagan has agreed to a Soviet proposal to hold a human rights conference in Moscow in 1991, Administration officials said today.

title: Tokyo Bank to Sell Chicago Operation
description: The world's largest bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd., said it was selling its Chicago operations to the First American Bank Corporation, a suburban bank holding company, to focus entirely on business banking. Terms were not disclosed. The deal includes assets of $35 million, including about 6,000 checking, savings and other accounts, and a retail loan portfolio of less than $5 million.

title: New Chips Offer the Promise Of Much Speedier Computers
description: Scientists have begun to combine two or more substances to create devices on computer chips that switch electronic signals hundreds of times faster than existing models.

title: Iceland Devaluation
description: Iceland devalued its currency, the crown, today for the fourth time in less than 12 months to ease the island's crippling financial problems, and the nation warned of more economic measures to come. The central bank said it was devaluing the currency by 4 percent against the dollar, bringing the rate to 48.08 crowns from 46.16.

title: Plan to Expand Church Media Reveals Christian Science Rift
description: Christian Science, a faith that has come to epitomize a quiet, disciplined spirituality, is being rent by discord provoked by the denomination's rapid expansion into radio and television broadcasting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology

title: U.S. Officials Predict Long Investigation of Capital's Mayor
description: Federal officials said today that their investigation of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. would take months to complete and would probably involve half a dozen or more investigative agencies.

title: Homeless New York Families to Get U.S. Rent Subsidies
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it would for the first time set aside Federal rent subsidies for homeless families as part of a plan to end the use of welfare hotels in New York City.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Big Surplus For Germany
description: West Germany reported its second-biggest monthly trade surplus on record today, and economists said the United States and others would probably renew their complaints that Bonn was doing too little to correct global trade imbalances.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Interested Observer
description: Michael J. Boskin, President-elect George Bush's choice to become chairman of the the Council of Economic Advisers, will be setting up shop at the council today, White House officials say. He will be an observer until the inauguration, while the current chairman, Beryl W. Sprinkel, completes his final chore of publishing President Reagan's Economic Report for 1989.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There comes a time when each of us has to ask himself if at the end of one's current term, it isn't time to pass the mantle of leadership to new hands. And I believe that by the end of 1990 that time will have come.'' - Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. [ A10:4. ]

title: B.P. to Sell Mining Unit To RTZ
description: The British Petroleum Company, the nation's largest concern, today announced plans to sell off its mining operations to the RTZ Corporation and to buy back much of the major stake in the oil company held by the Kuwaiti Government.

title: OPEC's New Friend: Us
description: Americans often fail to recognize how much the health of our high-cost oil producers depends upon the success of OPEC in limiting oil production. Indeed, Americans can get quite dewy-eyed thinking about the beauties of inexorable market forces - until, belatedly, they recognize that the marginal, high-cost producer who should be squeezed out in the quest for efficiency is us.

title: INSIDE
description: Dukakis Rules Out 4th Term

title: CSX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4 million for the quarter and income of $185 million for the year both from discontinued operations. c-Included income of $14 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and a gain of $59 million from discontinued operations in its energy segement, the year also included a loss of $294 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said 1988 earnings included a pre-tax special charge of $778 million taken in the second quarter relating to labor separations and certain litigation claims. The company also said during the 1988 fourth quarter, it repurchased 50.1 million common shares, 43.1 million under a ''Dutch Auction'' offer at $32 a share and 7 million in the open market at an average price of $30.88 a share. The company said its reported share earnings reflect these transactions.

title: Steinberg Mental Exam To Be Ordered by Judge
description: The judge in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that he would approve a prosecution request to order a psychiatric examination of Mr. Steinberg.

title: Sewer Money's Aroma Endures
description: Thomas Josefiak, the chairman of the Federal Election Commission, hotly denies charges that his agency ignored widespread fund-raising abuses in the 1988 Presidential race. Yet the commission remains curiously blase about the obvious corruption of public campaign financing.

title: QED Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a $575,000 non-cash writedown of the company's oil and gas properties resulting from lower oil and gas prices. c-Net income

title: A Former Energy Chief Is in Running for Post
description: President-elect George Bush has held talks with former Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger, who is under consideration for the same post, Bush aides said today.

title: Trials of Illness and Survival Inspire Donors to the Neediest
description: Matthew was born with respiratory problems that threatened to cut short his life, and he had to be rushed to a neonatal unit in Manhattan.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Maltese, Out of the Moonlight
description: Serphin Maltese, the newly elected State Senator from Queens, sets a positive example for other New York politicians: he has resigned as chairman of the state's Conservative Party.

title: Reagan Rules Out Oil Fee
description: President Reagan said today that he had decided against an oil import fee or other action to curb oil imports, but conceded that ''the free world will become increasingly dependent on oil supplies from potentially insecure sources.''

title: Missing Lynx Return to the Wild
description: Surrounded by snow and shrouded in secrecy, five lynx today began the final leg of a journey that started in the Yukon and will end somewhere deep in the Adirondack wilderness.

title: Stanford Selects Black as Head Coach
description: Dennis Green, the coach in charge of receivers for the San Francisco 49ers the last three years, yesterday was named head coach at Stanford University. In becoming the fourth black head coach among the nation's 104 N.C.A.A. Division I-A colleges, Green, who is 39 years old, replaces Jack Elway, who was dropped Dec. 5 after a 3-6-2 record in 1988 and four losing seasons in five. Green served as an assistant coach at Iowa, his alma mater, and Dayton before going to Stanford in 1977 and 1978, under Coach Bill Walsh. He moved to the 49ers in 1979 and then returned to Stanford in 1980 as offensive coordinator. Green served for five seasons as head coach at Northwestern, then returned to the 49ers and took charge of the receiving corps.(AP)

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; What's in a Name
description: The Bureau of Standards has just received a new name and an expanded mission.

title: Hawaii Tempest Over Burial Ground
description: The discovery of 900 skeletons at an ancient burial ground has led to a temporary halt in building an $80 million beachfront hotel on Maui island and to calls for changes in state laws that could slow Hawaii's construction frenzy.

title: Plant Grows Own Pesticide
description: Using biotechnology methods, a Maryland company has created an innovative corn plant that grows its own pesticide to combat the destructive corn borer.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Squelching a Rumor
description: Supreme Court Justices do not usually deign to respond publicly to what people say about them. But a report in Jan. 2 issue of Newsweek that Justice Byron R. White ''has told friends'' that he was thinking of retiring soon was apparently too much for the normally taciturn 71-year-old Justice.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Leber Katz Counts On Computers
description: FCB/LEBER KATZ PARTNERS celebrated its 35th birthday yesterday by peering into a crystal ball and seeing an apple.

title: Balboa Journal; Noriega's Comic Strip War: It's Deadly Serious
description: The cartoon cutouts on the manicured lawn here at first resemble the backdrop of a perverse miniature golf course: a gunslinger putting a bullet betwen Santa Claus's eyes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wells, Rich Resigns Cosmopolitan Magazine
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has resigned the Cosmopolitan account. The Hearst Magazines publication had put its account, worth less than $1 million annually, into a speculative review that the agency was not interested in participating in.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Baker Is Fined
description: Al (Bubba) Baker, a defensive end for the Minnesota Vikings, has been fined $10,000 by the N.F.L. for a late hit on Mike Tomczak, the Chicago Bears' quarterback, in the final game of the regular season, which the Vikings won, 28-27. Baker plans to appeal the judgment and has asked for a hearing before Commissioner Pete Rozelle. ''I'm really shocked and I'm pretty disappointed in the way it was handled because it wasn't intentional,'' said Baker, who lost $30,000 in fines and salary cuts this season. ''If he reviewed the film, he could see it wasn't flagrant.'' Earlier this season, Rozelle suspended Baker one game without pay (about $20,000) for poking Ron Heller of Philadelphia in an eye during a game Sept. 25.(AP)

title: Intervoice Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. Says Libya Moves Chemicals For Poison Gas Away From Plant
description: Administration officials said today that Libya had moved chemicals needed for the production of poison gas away from storage sites near a major chemical plant.

title: How to Recognize Danger Signs of Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the 1988 performance of stocks on the American Stock Exchange misidentified the eighth-biggest loser for the year. It is Energy Development Partners Ltd., a Denver-based partnership, not the Energy Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the Public Service Enterprise Group.

title: V.M.I. Names Shuck
description: Jim Shuck was named as Virginia Military Institute's head coach yesterday, saying the job with the Keydets would pose challenges similar to those he faced as Army's offensive coordinator. Shuck, 34, plans to use the wishbone offense, which has worked well for Army, as he takes over the job with a five-year, $52,000-a-year contract. The Keydets have had seven losing seasons in a row. (AP)

title: Richard Siegel, Teacher, 70
description: Richard Siegel, a retired English teacher, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: Westerners Can Avoid Soviet Customs Curb
description: New regulations barring foreigners from taking scarce consumer goods out of the Soviet Union after Feb. 1 will not apply to Westerners who buy caviar, vodka and other items and pay for them with dollars and other convertible currencies in special stores, a customs official said today.

title: Ditka Hasn't Decided Who Will Start for Bears
description: The injured Mike Tomczak and the now-healthy Jim McMahon alternated at quarterback today in the Bears' practice for the National Conference championship game Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers in Chicago. Coach Mike Ditka of the Bears said he would not decide until later in the week on which quarterback would start.

title: Reported Arafat Threat Is Grist for Israeli Debate
description: Right-wing Israeli politicians said today that reported death threats by Yasir Arafat against other Palestinians showed that the Palestine Liberation Organization was still a ''terrorist organization.''

title: Delicate And Bold Glasswork Designs
description: LEAD: A DECADE after its ''Glass America 1978'' exhibition, the Heller Gallery's ''Glass America 1989'' leaves no doubt that studio glass is alive and well. Forty-five glass artists are each represented by two or three pieces, affording a broad view of their most recent work.

title: Commuting: Have Mug, Will Travel
description: THE peripatetic nature of American society has spawned all sorts of strange creations, among them billboards, Winnebagos, Walkman radios and car telephones.

title: Strange Wants to Put His Successful Run Behind Him
description: The PGA Tour, one of the favorite multimillion-dollar toys of corporate America and corporate Japan, will begin its 42-tournament season Thursday when Curtis Strange, the United States Open champion, and a healthy Greg Norman tee off first in the MONY Tournament of Champions here at the LaCosta Country Club.

title: Best Products Fills Key Post
description: Norman S. Matthews, the former president of Federated Department Stores Inc., has been named vice chairman and a director of the Best Products Company, the catalogue-showroom chain in Richmond.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ashland Coal Inc., Huntington, W. Va., named Kenneth G. Woodring senior vice president, operations, and Raymond Smallwood president of its Hobet Mining Inc.

title: AFRICANS IN BEIJING BOYCOTT CLASSES
description: African students at a Beijing language institute began boycotting classes today to protest what they feel is racism in China, and interracial clashes were reported in another city after two weeks of racial unrest.

title: Giving Rises In 77th Drive For Neediest
description: Contributions to the 77th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are running ahead of the last appeal, and donors seem to be particularly alarmed by the desperate plight of the homeless.

title: Suffolk Woman Being Protected Is Shot to Death
description: A 34-year-old woman who obtained a protective court order after her former husband was accused of trying to murder her was shot to death on the front steps of her house here Tuesday night, the Suffolk County police said.

title: 16 Die in Philippines
description: A motor launch carrying more than 140 people sank in the central Philippines and at least 16 people were killed, the coast guard said today. Twelve people were reported missing. The vessel, the Jem II, sank Tuesday off Romblon Island, about 150 miles southeast of Manila, a coast guard officer said.

title: Rabbis Agree to Plan for Stores Near Graves
description: The Chicago Rabbinical Council, a group of Orthodox Jewish leaders, has reluctantly agreed to the construction of a shopping center on a plot of land bordered on three sides by a Jewish cemetery, a member of the council says.

title: Co-op Efforts Rewarded At D.M.B.&B.
description: WHEN he was a graduate student, Clay E. Stobaugh enticed a dozen colleagues to pose for an ''Eligible Bachelors of the Harvard Business School'' calendar, a project that netted him several thousand dollars. As director of co-operative advertising at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles for the last two and a half years, he has routinely lured dozens of companies to join in one ad, a procedure that has gained the agency about $10 million in revenues.

title: Celtics Surprised By Suns
description: The Phoenix Suns broke a nine-season Boston Garden losing streak tonight with a 106-104 victory over the Celtics.

title: Fire Shuts Down a Reactor
description: A fire in a turbine building at the Oconee Nuclear Station on Tuesday caused operators to shut down one of its three reactors, a utility spokeswoman said today. Workers were starting the plant's Unit 1 reactor, which had shut down automatically Monday, when an electrical breaker apparently caught fire, the station manager, Mike Tuckman, said. There was no nuclear material in the area of the fire, which was extinguished by a Duke Power Company fire crew. The two other reactors continued to operate, the company said.

title: Jersey Faces Shortfalls in Revenue, Kean Warns
description: Echoing concerns in neighboring states, Gov. Thomas H. Kean today disclosed growing shortfalls in the state's tax revenues and warned that New Jersey's next budget would be ''very tight.''

title: A Plant Almost Too Good to Be True
description: WITH much fanfare, several mail-order nurseries are introducing a new chrysanthemum in their 1989 catalogues, and all signs suggest that it is destined to become one of the most widely planted perennials in the United States in the next few years.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I own a two-family house that has baseboard hot-water heating. When the heat comes on the pipes knock, even though I have the system drained often. The banging is worse in the pipes going to the second floor. I was told that I would have to break walls open to correct this problem. Is there a simpler solution?

title: Power Supply Going Down In Argentina
description: It has become common sense in this metropolis of 11 million people not to enter an elevator within five minutes before or after 7 A.M., noon or 5 P.M.

title: Review/Comedy; Genial Student Of Anxieties And Foibles
description: Larry Miller is one of today's few younger comedians whose unswerving geniality and seamless delivery make him a possible contender to preside one day over the genteel living room tradition of which Johnny Carson remains king. A low-keyed, friendly observer of human foibles, Mr. Miller, who is appearing through Jan. 21 at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street), explores common anxieties in a way that soothes us with a sense of shared recognition.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Butterfly' by Prince

title: Lewenthal Memorial
description: A memorial service for the pianist Raymond Lewenthal is to be held on Monday at 3 P.M. at Green Auditorium, 40 West 68th Street. Mr. Lewenthal died of a heart attack on Nov. 21 at the age of 62. The service is open to the public.

title: Quaker Plans Ghirardelli Sale
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that it would sell its Ghirardelli chocolate business, based in San Leandro, Calif.

title: Nick Virgilio, 60, Poet Known for His Haiku
description: Nick Virgilio, a poet who specialized in haiku, died Tuesday at George Washington University Medical Center after a heart attack while taping an interview for the CBS television program ''Nightwatch.'' He was 60 years old and lived in Camden, N.J.

title: Up to $2 Million Is Missing From a Chicago Storage Site
description: As much as $2 million in coins owned by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago is missing from a suburban armored car company and the Federal Bureau of Investigation has entered the case, the authorities said today.

title: World Bank Raises Rates
description: The World Bank is raising interest rates for relatively prosperous developing countries to 7.65 percent annually, the first such increase since the bank began lending at variable rates in 1982, officials said today.

title: Ouster Of Milken Seen Near
description: Michael R. Milken, the head of the high-yield bond unit at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., will be removed from the firm and receive virtually none of his pay for last year as part of Drexel's settlement with the Government of charges of securities law violations, people familiar with the agreement said late yesterday.

title: Freddie Mac Offers Mortgage Issues
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, is offering $1 billion in mortgage participation certificates through a real estate mortgage conduit, with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as lead manager.

title: 2-Month-Old Baby Dies in a House Fire
description: A 2-month-old infant on Staten Island being watched by a baby sitter was killed last night when a fire broke out in the baby's bedroom, the police said.

title: East Dominates West in Race for Eclipse Awards
description: New York horses and horsemen were rewarded with a virtual sweep of thoroughbred racing's championship prizes.

title: Europe's Grand Plan for Web of Fast Trains
description: European nations are undertaking the world's most ambitious high-speed rail project, which will tie Europe closer together by allowing travelers to move across the Continent at speeds up to 186 miles an hour.

title: Books of The Times; Stalking a Boy Genius for the Codes
description: Daddy By Loup Durand Translated by J. Maxwell Brownjohn. 374 pages. Villard Books. $18.95.

title: Housing Repair Data Inflated, Goldin Says
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin asserted yesterday that the Koch administration had inflated the number of apartments it has renovated for homeless families by counting some renovations more than once.

title: FEW DATA FOUND IN CAPITAL INQUIRY
description: The inspector general of the Department of the Interior said tonight that his auditors had found few records in the Virgin Islands concerning consulting work there by District of Columbia officials, including Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. But the inspector general, James Richards, said in an interview that some of the records that had been uncovered about the 1988 consulting project on personnel and pay matters, including hotel and travel expenses, ''would raise your eyebrows.''

title: Yields Rise For Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, with the yield increases in C.D.'s concentrated in the six-month and one-year maturities.

title: Entremont Leaving Denver Symphony
description: Philippe Entremont, the French-born conductor and pianist, has announced his resignation as music director of the Denver Symphony, effective at the end of this season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL A high-speed European rail network that would sharply cut travel times is in the works. [ Page A1. ] THE ECONOMY The F.D.I.C. wants new powers to increase premiums on banks and to rein in high-risk lending. [ A1. ] President-elect Bush's strategy for the Federal budget has begun to take shape. [ A1. ] The U.S. has a smaller share than previously believed of world electronics production, two recent studies have found. [ D1. ] Orders for manufactured goods rose 0.3 percent in November, a report some economists said reflected continued growth. [ D11. ] COMPANIES Braniff will buy at least 50 Airbus aircraft and place many of them at its Kansas City hub in an aggressive expansion. [ D1. ] Testimony began in the Government's dispute with the Newhouse family over how much is owed in taxes from the estate of Samuel I. Newhouse. [ D1. ] A French bidder for William Collins stepped aside and Collins said it would open talks with Rupert Murdoch. [ D19. ] G.M. took the wraps off its long-awaited mini-van but angered Chevrolet dealers by saying they would have to share it with Pontiac and Oldsmobile. [ D5. ] The Customs Service reclassified imported utility vehicles and mini-vans as trucks. The sharply higher duty will raise prices. [ D5. ] Borden executives put into effect a takeover repellent under which the company's top 25 managers would resign. [ D2. ] Regina reported a loss of $16.8 million in the 15-month period its accountants said its earnings reports were inaccurate. [ D6. ] Quaker Oats will sell Ghirardelli chocolate, which it acquired in 1986 as part of its purchase of Golden Grain. [ D6. ] MARKETS Stocks rallied strongly, spurred by a stronger dollar and a late wave of program trading. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 33.04 points, to 2,177.68. [ D1. ] Michael R. Milken will be removed from Drexel and will get virtually none of his pay for last year as part of the firm's settlement with the U.S., people familiar with the agreement said. [ D1. ] Boyd L. Jefferies may have violated Federal election laws by concealing contributions made to members of Congress, lawyers in the GAF stock manipulation case said. Mr. Jefferies is the Government's main witness in a series of securities fraud cases. [ D19. ] The New York Merc moved toward electronic trading, as its governors discussed a link with the Chicago Merc. [ D2. ] The Chicago Merc told the S.E.C. that a new trading instrument proposed by the American Stock Exchange is illegal. [ D2. ] The prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in lackluster, apathetic trading. [ D15. ] The dollar advanced against most currencies in moderate trading, bolstered by tension in the Mediterranean. [ D16. ] Prices of copper futures rose sharply on supply worries rekindled by the apparent bombing of three locomotives in Peru. [ D16. ] Yields rose on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Are leveraged buyouts about to happen in banking? Probably not, banking experts say. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Sooner Federal Savings and Loan's stock has plunged to $4, from $17, and investors are crying foul. Market Place. [ D8. ] Clay E. Stobaugh specializes in co-op advertising as head of a new Darcy, Masius subsidiary. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: Mr. Cuomo's Priorities, and Their Price
description: Partway through his State of the State address Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, the Cuomo who can charm with a word and a nod, heard some applause greet his call for expanding social programs despite budget rigors, and digressed from his text. He clapped his hands, grinned and said: ''I'm pleased to hear the applause. Apparently somebody out there knows how they're going to do it.''

title: Ousted Panamanian Leader Offers to Talk With Noriega
description: Panama's ousted President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, has written to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega offering to negotiate an end to the nation's political crisis, according to a document obtained today.

title: Lorillard Appointment
description: Lorillard Inc., the manufacturer of Kent, True and Newport cigarettes, has appointed Lucy M. Giordano its director of media. Ms. Giordano, 40 years old, started at the company 21 years ago as the secretary to Bill Sands, the retiring media director whom she is succeeding. Lorillard, a subsidiary of the Loews Corporation, does its media planning and buying in-house, and handles media placement for the Loews hotels and its Bulova watches.

title: Recycling Is a Far Better Solution Than Navy Yard Incinerator
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Resumes Year-Round Cycle
description: The Governor's State of the State address has traditionally marked the start of a new political season. In years past, the event served as a sort of homecoming, with legislators who had not seen each other for months returning to slap backs and exchange stories in the manner of students coming back to school after a long summer recess.

title: Competition Cuts Price Of Gift-Wrap Books
description: ABOUT five years ago Joost Elffers, a Dutch book and graphic designer, had the idea of putting wrapping papers into book form. Paul Gottlieb, president of the Harry N. Abrams publishing company, was enthusiastic. ''It was a great concept,'' Mr. Gottlieb said. ''But Joost didn't really know how to do it.''

title:
Market Place;
The Sudden Drop At Sooner Federal
description: LEAD: EVEN in the risky world of oil-patch banking, the collapse of Sooner Federal's stock stands out. In two weeks the stock plunged from $17 to $4, and badly singed investors are crying foul.

title: Ms. Honors Portraits Series
description: The much-honored ''Portraits'' campaign created by Ogilvy & Mather for the American Express Company is adding another leaf to its laurel wreath: Ms. magazine's first annual ''Making A Difference'' advertising award.

title: Ward Approves Police Immunity In Melee at Park
description: Moving to counter criticism that the Civilian Complaint Review Board has not done all it could to expose police wrongdoing in Tompkins Square Park last August, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has authorized the panel's investigators to selectively reinterrogate officers, this time under grants of immunity from departmental charges.

title: Art Rush Dies at 81; Agent for Performers
description: Art Rush, a talent agent who represented such performers as Vladimir Horowitz, Orson Welles, Roy Rogers and Dale Evans, died of heart failure Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: Chief of Steinberg Ethics Investigation Quits
description: The chief counsel for the committee that disciplines lawyers in Manhattan announced Tuesday that he would resign, amid news reports that he mishandled charges of drug use and other misconduct against Joel B. Steinberg.

title: A Wall Street Boutique Names a Senior Partner
description: Ken Miller said he did not leave Merrill Lynch almost one year ago to create a one-man boutique. That is why he called his fledgling deal shop the Lodestar Group, to suggest his role as guiding light. ''If you name a firm after yourself, it doesn't help in getting additional personnel,'' Mr. Miller said.

title: Toxic Issue at Arsenal Stirs Furor in Colorado
description: Residents of a trailer park 10 miles northeast of here are at odds with state and Federal officials over the health risks of the cleanup of toxic waste at the nearby Rocky Mountain Arsenal.

title: Opening-Day Tradition
description: Tradition means a great deal on Capitol Hill. So does family. Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, has honored both on the first day of every new Congress since he first came to Washington in 1955.

title: BRIEFS
description: British Petroleum Co., London, will pay Kuwait a profit of about $700 million for 790 million shares of B.P. On Tuesday, when the deal was announced, estimates of Kuwait's profits on the sale were lower.

title: California Gala for Reagans Raises Money for a Drug Center
description: A glittering crowd rolled out a welcome wagon laden with caviar tonight for President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, at a black-tie party that was held to mark the couple's impending return to California and to raise a million dollars for a new center to combat drug abuse.

title: Bridge
description: There have long been connections between what are generally considered the three leading intellectual games of the Western world: bridge, chess and backgammon. A century and a half ago Deschapelles had a good claim to be considered the world's best at chess and the world's best at whist, bridge's forerunner. The Boston Chess Club turned into the headquarters of bridge in its area.

title: Now Soviet Armenia Begins to Rebuild
description: To the Editor:

title: Duties Raised on Vehicles
description: The United States Customs Service today reclassified an increasingly popular category of imported utility vehicles and mini-vans, making them subject to a 22.5 percent tariff.

title: Group Says Sloppy Labs Mislead Consumers on Radon Tests
description: A consumer group said today that results from over-the-counter kits to test for the presence of the carcinogen radon in the home may be misleading or false because of poor quality control at laboratories that analyze the results.

title: James Thompson, 85, Surgeon and Educator
description: Dr. James Edwin Thompson, an educator and retired surgeon, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Siesta Key, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: Test for the Attorney General
description: Dick Thornburgh faces one daunting internal problem as Attorney General, the same one that has tested his predecessors in the Justice Department for 30 years. That is the character of the F.B.I.

title: The State of 3 States
description: Money was on the minds of the gov-ernors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday. They warned their constituencies separately of budget constraints necessitated by spending that is outpacing revenues.

title: Regina Reports $16.8 Million Loss
description: The Regina Company, the financially troubled maker of vacuum cleaners, yesterday reported a loss of $16.8 million for the period in which inaccuracies were cited in its earnings by accountants.

title: Linens of Lively Prints
description: ALTHOUGH the pure white sheet has been considered the height of fashion by decorators for several years, two lines of designer sheets currently in the works are anything but.

title: River Phoenix Ranks Acting Below Animal Rights and Music
description: When River Phoenix learned he had just won the National Board of Review's award as best supporting actor of 1988 for his performance in ''Running on Empty,'' his first response was to ask what the society was.

title: Pay Raises Won't Improve Our Lawmakers; In the Public Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Senior U.S. Official Says Libyans Should Destroy Chemical Factory
description: As the United States prepares for a conference in Paris on chemical weapons, a senior Administration official said today that Libya should tear down a vast chemical plant.

title: Philip Tobin, 46, Former Tuckahoe Mayor
description: Philip D. Tobin, a labor lawyer who was twice elected mayor of the village of Tuckahoe in Westchester County, died of pneumonia Tuesday night at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan after a long battle with cancer. He was 46 years old and lived in Tuckahoe.

title: Proxy-Fight Plan Over Pennwalt Bid
description: In response to the rejection of its $785 million offer for the Pennwalt Corporation, Centaur Partners said that it would begin a hostile proxy fight to gain control of the Philadelphia-based chemical concern. Pennwalt rejected as inadequate a $100-a-share offer from Centaur.

title: 3 Dead After Taking of Hostages
description: A prison parolee demanding an airplane to Libya held about 20 people hostage in a restaurant Tuesday, killing one of them. The police fatally shot the suspect but also killed a hostage by accident, the authorities said today.

title: St. Paul's Architectural Time Capsule
description: ''YOU have traditional homes and Brave New World things, a fondness for Gropius and a Breueresque look,'' said Tom Martinson, referring to the conglomeration of styles in University Grove, a neighborhood of 102 homes built on the northwestern edge of St. Paul by University of Minnesota faculty members and administrators. ''To have these babies lined up and down the street is really something. After a while, it gets so screwy, it's pure Minnesota.''

title: John J. Faal, Professor And Administrator, 64
description: John J. Faal, a professor of economics and a former academic vice president at Suffolk County Community College, died of complications from acute leukemia yesterday at St. John's Hospital in Smithtown, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Commack, L.I.

title: Correction
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday, with an article about the outlook for interest rates, provided incorrect labels for several yield curves. A corrected table appears today on page D15.

title: Friendly French Offer for Collins Is Ended
description: The battle for control of William Collins P.L.C., the Scottish publisher, took a new turn today as a friendly French bidder stepped aside and Collins said it would open talks with Rupert Murdoch's News International P.L.C.

title: Practically a Native
description: The attractive flier, offering the upscale magazine European Travel & Life at half price, says for openers that it ''invites you to begin a lifelong love affair with the most magnificent place on earth'' - meaning Europe. The advertisement for the three-year-old publication displays color photographs of a formal castle garden, a baroque ballroom, a prancing fashion model, some fine china, a contemplative writer, and an unidentified couple in Bavarian leather knickers, with a seal-point Siamese cat, captioned: ''The People.''

title: Chief Executive Hired By American Hospital
description: Richard A. Gilleland, who has been in the hospital-products industry for 20 years, was named yesterday as chief executive of American Medical International Inc., one of the nation's largest hospital companies.

title: The Brash Bed: Today's Bold Design Statements
description: IN the 50's, people bought suites of furniture for the bedroom. In the 60's, the brave slept on water beds, and in the 70's the avant-garde chose platform beds to make a minimal design statement. Today, although four-poster and brass beds are still popular, the beds of choice are reinterpretations of antiques or one-of-a-kind designs.

title: Pitt Upsets Syracuse in Big East Opener
description: Sean Miller had 22 points tonight as Pitt handed Syracuse its first loss of the season, 81-76, in the Big East Conference opener for both schools.

title: Fast Play Is Not Fit Yet
description: Fast Play, the Seattle Slew colt who had been considered a leading prospect for the Kentucky Derby May 6, is unlikely to run in any of the Triple Crown races, his trainer said yesterday.

title: Study Islam, Khomeini Suggests to Gorbachev
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini told Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in a letter delivered today that Communism was dead and that he should study Islam.

title: Afghan Cadets Reportedly Riot in a Capital in Soviet Central Asia
description: A large group of Afghan cadets training at a Soviet police academy went on a rampage Tuesday in the Soviet Central Asian city of Tashkent, leaving an infant boy dead and several other people wounded, according to reports reaching Moscow tonight.

title: Trial Begins On Newhouse Tax Issue
description: Testimony began today in an attempt by the Government to win more than $600 million in taxes from the estate of Samuel I. Newhouse, who built one of the country's largest newspaper chains before his death in 1979.

title: Talking Deals; The Constraints On Bank Buyouts
description: JUST as Congress and business leaders are growing alarmed over the mounting levels of debt associated with leveraged buyouts, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout specialist, seems to be looking at a Texas bank as a possible acquisition target. Could it be that leveraged buyouts are about to happen in the banking industry, one of the most financially sensitive businesses in the country?

title: Knicks Stun Nets With 20-0 Explosion
description: The Knicks have had other superb comebacks this season, but tonight's bordered on miraculous.

title: Bennett of Bills Already Rated As One of the N.F.L.'s Best
description: On their first day together at Alabama, the new head coach, Ray Perkins, told the freshman Cornelius Bennett, ''You're going to be the next Lawrence Taylor.''

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Debate on Arafat

title: Next Flight of a Shuttle Moved Back Five Days
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today it would launch Discovery on the next space shuttle flight on Feb. 23, five days later than originally scheduled.

title: Close to Home
description: THE Christmas tree, kept till the day after New Year's, is finally gone, the ornaments are back in their boxes, and my major present, new earrings, has been worn thrice already. Now I am settling in for the long, slow trek through winter, for the low sun and the short days and the air that drops like iron into the lungs. There is worse. Winter, and January in particular, is when I ask myself where I went wrong.

title: Chilhood Memories
description: In ''Museum Memorializes Life in Tenements'' (Dec. 15, 1988), James Hirsch reported that the curators of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum had been unable to find anyone who had lived in its building at 97 Orchard Street in Manhattan. The article prompted this letter. To The Home Section:

title: Review/Television; Dinosaurs: Faster, Smarter, Warmer
description: The image of the dinosaur is being refurbished. Long considered just dumb, oversized lizards, the creatures that dominated earth for 140 million years are getting a better press. Revisionist paleontologists now hold that dinosaurs were warmblooded, quite energetic, not necessarily unintelligent and, in at least one species, caring of their young. ''The Great Dinosaur Hunt,'' on Channel 13 tonight at 10, introduces us to several of the major hunters and their theories.

title: Rangers Take Bows After Earning Tie
description: The opening by the Rangers last night prompted a collective review that would have made the critical reception of ''Legs Diamond'' seem quaint, even mildly encouraging. New York, having stumbled ineptly through 20 minutes of hockey, was thunderously booed by the Garden crowd.

title: CNN in Latin America
description: The Turner Broadcasting System said today that it would transmit the Cable News Network 24 hours a day to Latin America on the Pan American Satellite Corporation's international satellite. The agreement followed tests that began in November, TBS said. Turner's decision to use Pan American Satellite is a victory for the private company, based in Greenwich, Conn., and a defeat for Intelsat, the international consortium that operates most communications satellites.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Named Rick Lawes assistant public relations director. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS - Agreed to terms with Danny Cox, pitcher, on a one-year contract. BASKETBALL UTAH (NBA) - Waived Bart Kofoed, guard. COLLEGES CINCINNATI - Named Tim Murphy head football coach. FORDHAM - Announced that Fred Herzog, forward, will sit out the remainder of the season with a knee injury. MISSOURI - Named Tim Jamieson assistant baseball coach. PACE - Named Wilford Cintron head soccer coach. FOOTBALL GIANTS (NFC) - Announced the resignation of Len Fontes, defensive backfield coach. TUESDAY BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Named Phil Niekro roving minor-league pitching instructor. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Morris Madden and Willie Smith, pitchers. BASKETBALL ALBANY (CBA) - Signed Derrick Rowland, forward-guard. MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Placed Jeff Grayer, guard, on the injured list. Signed Andre Turner, guard, to a 10-day contract. PORTLAND (NBA) - Activated Kiki Vandeweghe, forward, from the injured list. Placed Rolando Ferreira, center, on the injured list. FOOTBALL NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE -Fined Al (Bubba) Baker, Minnesota defensive end, $10,000 for a late hit on Mike Tomczak, Chicago quarterback, in the final game of the regular season. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Dismissed Jed Hughes, linebackers coach; Hal Hunter, guards-center coach; Walt Evans, conditioning and training coach, and Dennis Fitzgerald, special teams coach. Announced the resignation of Tony Dungy, defensive coordinator. Announced that Chuck Noll, head coach, will return next season and has been given a lifetime contract with the team. HOCKEY DETROIT (NHL) - Traded Miroslav Frycer, left wing, to Edmonton for a 10th-round pick in the 1989 entry draft. Assigned Joe Murphy, center, to Adirondack of the American Hockey League.

title: Cuomo Plans A Major Effort To Fight Drugs
description: Calling drug abuse ''the single most ominous phenomenon of our times,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today outlined a major new effort to combat drugs in New York despite the state's tremendous financial problems.

title: Lyman C. Thunfors, 85, Retired Executive
description: Lyman C. Thunfors, a retired business executive, died of cancer Monday at his home in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 85 years old.

title: Chitchat During Pageant Is About Texas, Not Taxes
description: They were just a couple of guys from Texas, sitting around talking.

title: A 'Private' Collection Of Silver
description: SINCE the early 1970's the Italian industrialist Cleto Munari has been commissioning internationally famous architects and designers to produce silver objects. Although they were originally commissioned for his private collection, Mr. Munari began exhibiting these pieces in European galleries and museums, then hiring craftsmen in Vicenza to copy the originals and, finally, selling new editions of them.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: You Need Medical Advice at 3 A.M.? It May Be Only a Phone Call Away
description: It was 3 o'clock in the morning and a man, finally fed up with a throbbing, long-neglected bunion, decided it was time to do something. He called a telephone number, and a registered nurse, after telling him how to relieve the pain, gave him the name of a specialist he could arrange to see later that day.

title: Sharp to Griffin Bacal
description: Griffin Bacal has won the account for the Sharp Electronics Corporation of Mahwah, N.J., the American unit of the Sharp Corporation of Japan. The New Jersey operation, which makes consumer electronics and office automation products, has a budget for broadcast and print advertising of $12 million to $15 million. Griffin Bacal beat Korey, Kay & Partners, Brouillard Communications, Warwick Advertising and Stevens & Buchsbaum, which previously shared the account with Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Griffin Bacal is resigning the Commodore International Ltd. computer account because of the conflict with Sharp.

title: Bonn Finds No Libya Tie at Company
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said today that his Government had found no evidence yet to substantiate American assertions that a West German company had helped Libya build a chemical weapons plant, though it took the charges ''very seriously.''

title: TALKS BY DARMAN SHOW BUSH'S PLANS TO HANDLE BUDGET
description: President-elect George Bush's strategy for dealing with the Federal budget has begun to take shape, and Richard G. Darman, who has been given unchallenged authority to draft Mr. Bush's budget policy, is trying to sell it to Congress.

title: Debenture Offering From Fannie Mae
description: In its first financing of the new year, the Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, is offering $700 million in debentures due in 1994 through various securities dealers.

title: Busy Schedule Ahead For Fly-Fishermen
description: A daylong fly-fishing workshop sponsored by the Nutmeg, Mianus and Croton Watershed chapters of Trout Unlimited will be held at the Turn of River Middle School in Stamford, Conn., Jan. 14.

title: Some Travelers Switching Airlines
description: Concerned about the possibility of bombings, some travelers have begun to switch from United States airlines to foreign carriers for their flights to Europe.

title: U.S. Airports Told to Use Computer-Card Security Systems
description: In a sweeping new move to tighten security at United States airports, the Government yesterday ordered that computer card systems be installed at the busiest terminals by early 1991 to keep people who might threaten airline safety from reaching restricted areas.

title: Dartmouth Is Ordered To Reinstate 2 Editors
description: A state judge has ordered the reinstatement of two student journalists at Dartmouth College, saying their suspensions were tainted by bias against the off-campus conservative weekly for which they worked.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 18 about a decline in civility during 1988 misstated an affiliation and title of Dr. James R. Walker. He is assistant professor of communication at Memphis State University, not a professor at the University of Tennessee.

title: Reagan Schedules a Farewell
description: President Reagan will deliver a farewell address over television from the Oval Office at 9 P.M. on Jan. 11, the White House said today. The speech will be given nine days before Vice President Bush succeeds Mr. Reagan as President.

title: Pay Raises Won't Improve Our Lawmakers; With Our Deficit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Steinberg's Lawyer Predicts Conviction
description: The defense lawyer in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that his client ''probably would be found guilty'' in the death of Lisa Steinberg and that he would probably be sent to prison.

title: From Regan to Bush
description: President-elect George Bush is receiving a lot of advice these days, some of it unsolicited. Still, he might welcome the thoughts of Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's ousted chief of staff, in the form of a chapter added to the paperback edition of his 1987 memoir ''For the Record.''

title: Last-Minute Gifts Save a Vietnam Memorial
description: A forest planted by a Vietnam veteran in memory of Americans who died in the war was saved today when supporters raised enough money to stave off its sale by a bank.

title: Carlucci Backs Panel On Closing U.S. Bases
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci has approved a special commission's recommendation to close dozens of military bases around the country, setting the stage for a final debate on Capitol Hill, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This announcement shall be deemed a sufficient declaration of the persons elected President and Vice President of the United States.'' - George Bush, President of the Senate, after the reading of the final vote of the Electoral College. [ A1:2. ]

title: 'Poison Pill' Revamped At Borden
description: Executives of the Borden Company announced yesterday that they had put into effect a new type of takeover repellent that would result in the resignations of the company's top 25 managers if an acquirer took over the company at a price Borden's directors considered unfair.

title: Nightmare a Reality As Body of Mother Is Found in Freezer
description: A woman who had had nightmares about her mother's 1985 disappearance pried open a locked basement freezer and found the woman's battered body on Monday, the police said. The discovery led her father, a high school dean of students, to confess the slaying.

title: Illinois May End Premarital AIDS Testing
description: The nation's only law requiring premarital testing for AIDS may not be a law much longer, mainly because the overwhelming majority of those tested have shown no signs of the AIDS virus.

title: Thompson's Choice
description: Daley Thompson of Britain, the 1983 world decathlon champion and the 1980 and 1984 Olympic gold medalist in the event, says that Ben Johnson should be banned from international competition for life. Johnson was banned for two years after testing positive for steroid use following his victory in the 100-meter dash at the Seoul Olympics. In a magazine interview published yesterday, Thompson said: ''I hope the authorities make sure that Ben Johnson can never run again because of the damage he has done to the sport. I can't believe he could be back in two years. I think someone of his stature should be made an example of. Until we ban people for life, we are not taking the problem seriously enough. I think many of us don't have the best interests of the sport at heart - and that's indefensible because we are supposed to be the moral guardians of the sport.''
