In the interview with Athletics Today, a weekly track and field magazine published in Britain, Thompson also said that drugs and commercialism have so tainted track and field that he would not want his young daughter to enter the sport when she grows up.

title: 'Starlight Express' to Close
description: ''Starlight Express,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical with lyrics by Richard Stilgoe, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Gershwin Theater. Directed by Trevor Nunn, the show will have run for 761 regular performances and 22 previews.

title: East New York, Haunted By Crime, Fights for Its Life
description: The Brooklyn block where Norris Graham died is a bleak stretch of sidewalk that looks as if it is more for dying than living. Garbage and glass are everywhere, and someone has spray-painted ''Keep Out Killer Dog and Mother'' on a door.

title: Chicago Merc Is Opposing Amex Trading Instrument
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has recently argued to the Securities and Exchange Commission that a new type of trading instrument proposed by the American Stock Exchange cannot legally be traded.

title: European Flavors In SoHo
description: ''L'AQUITAINE is a little-known region in the south of France, but it's a name I've always liked,'' Carlos Fernandez Llamas said. So L'Aquitaine was the name Mr. Llamas chose when he opened a furniture gallery and interior design company last month in a converted factory space at 17 Greene Street between Canal and Grand Streets in SoHo.

title: Sahara Guerrillas Hold Talks For First Time With Hassan
description: Senior Polisario Front guerrillas conferred with King Hassan II on Wednesday in their first direct contact with the Moroccan monarch since the Western Sahara war began nearly 13 years ago.

title: CHEMICAL PLANT LINK DENIED
description: American warplanes today shot down two Libyan fighters that displayed ''clear hostile intent'' in international waters off the Libyan coast, the Administration said.

title: Wertheim Co-chairman Resigns to Form a Firm
description: Frederick A. Klingenstein has resigned as co-chairman of Wertheim Schroder & Company, the Wall Street investment firm, to form his own company specializing in investing for individuals and families with substantial assets - about $10 million or more.

title: Jazz Waives Kofoed
description: The Utah Jazz yesterday waived the second-year guard Bart Kofoed, following an incident in which a teammate, Bobby Hansen, sustained a broken cheekbone during a scuffle at a New Year's Eve party. ''There are many versions of the story,'' said the Jazz general manager, Dave Checketts. ''The fact is, a punch was thrown, and I don't see that the situation could ever be patched up again. There is a clause in his contract that requires him to act in good citizenship and good sportsmanship. For violation of that clause, we're going to terminate his contract because he struck one of his teammates and caused significant damage and damaged the team.'' Jim Farmer was signed to replace Hansen, also a guard, who is expected to be out four to six weeks.(AP)

title: Global Trading Network Near for New York Merc
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange is moving closer to the age of electronic trading, with its governors considering a plan to link their market with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange through a global computer network called Globex.

title: 14-Year-Old Bystander Is Killed In a Police Shootout in Brooklyn
description: A 14-year-old boy returning home from church services in Brooklyn was shot in the head and killed Tuesday night after he and his family were caught in crossfire between a policeman and a robbery suspect.

title: People
description: * Jennifer Clark has been promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor, at Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson.

title: New Data on the Pill Find Breast Cancer As a Possible Risk
description: An expert advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration will meet today to consider surprising new evidence that the use of oral contraceptives may increase the risk of breast cancer.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AVOIDING personal injury is the first consideration when using any tool. And with power tools, because accidents can be severe, this rule cannot be overemphasized.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Opera; Cultivating Young Singers in Jersey
description: The Opera/Music Theater Institute of New Jersey, a training organization for young singers directed by the longtime Metropolitan Opera bass Jerome Hines, presented its first full opera production, ''The Magic Flute,'' Saturday and Monday at Newark Symphony Hall. On the evidence of the second performance, the institute has succeeded in what must be the first step of any such group's mission: identification of talents worth developing.

title: Braniff's Checkered Past
description: May 1982 Braniff Airways Inc. files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, and the courts order the airline grounded. 1982-1983 The Pritzker family of Chicago, after gaining concessions from unions, buys Braniff. March 1984 Braniff resumes service with 30 Boeing 727 jets serving 25 cities. November 1984 Braniff restructures, reducing service and emphasizing low-cost long-haul flights. June 1988 BIA-COR Holdings, an investor group formed by Paine Webber Group, buys 64 percent of the carrier for about $100 million from a company controlled by the Pritzker family. William G. McGee, the former chairman and chief executive of Piedmont Aviation, is named to the top position at Braniff. July 1988 Braniff announces plans to buy 12 Fokker 100 jets and build a major hub at Kansas City, Mo. January 1989 The carrier says it plans to buy as many as 100 planes from Airbus Industrie in a deal valued at about $3.5 billion.

title: Florence Ryder, 88, Newspaper Publisher
description: Florence Ryder, chairman of the Times Journal Company, which publishes several weekly newspapers serving members of the armed forces worldwide and a number of suburban newspapers in the vicinity of Washington and San Diego, died in her sleep yesterday at her home in Washington. She was 88 years old. Mrs. Ryder, a native of Bedford, Ohio, was the widow of Melvin Ryder, who founded the Army Times Publishing Company in 1940. She was involved in the venture from its beginning and held several executive positions over the years. The publications now include Army Times, Navy Times, Air Force Times, Federal Times and Defense News, all weeklies, and the monthly magazine Military Market.

title: Ruth Moore, 80, Dies; Wrote About Science
description: Ruth Moore Garbe, a writer of books about science, died of cancer Monday at her brother's home in San Francisco. She was 80 years old lived in San Francisco.

title: Legionnaire's Shuts a School
description: Hunterdon Central Regional High School will be closed, at least for Thursday, because one janitor was confirmed to have and another is suspected of having Legionnaire's disease, a spokesman for the school said today.

title: Ball for Cleaner Air
description: On Inauguration Eve, two environmental groups will sponsor a ball to raise public awareness of air pollution and its effects, specifically how the atmosphere traps pollutants under the sun's heat, like a greenhouse, in a way that is some think will raise the Earth's temperature. The ball will be held in a greenhouse.

title: Raising Quality: Consumers Star
description: Deep down, what do people really want in a car door? That is not a trivial question for the Budd Company, which is using an increasingly popular Japanese quality control system to find the answer and make better doors as a result.

title: Baker's First Blunder
description: The Bush administration, three weeks before it takes office, has sent a signal of irresolution and hypocrisy in dealing with the Soviet Union.

title: Chrysler and Government Settle an Age Bias Case
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have tentatively settled an age discrimination suit filed by the commission in 1981 on behalf of 231 former salaried Chrysler employees.

title: U.S. EXPLAINS MOVE ON RIGHTS PARLEY
description: Hoping to bring a European security conference to an end before President Reagan leaves office, the Administration announced today that it would support a meeting on human rights in Moscow in 1991.

title: Correction
description: A chart on Tuesday about key yields for fixed-income securities in 1988 mislabeled several yield curves. This is a corrected version.

title: BAKER SAID TO PICK A KISSINGER MAN
description: James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State-designate, has offered the job of Deputy Secretary to Lawrence S. Eagleburger, colleagues of both men said today. Mr. Eagleburger is a career diplomat long associated with Henry A. Kissinger.

title: The Blooming Of Black Quarterbacks
description: The legend has it that when Robert Fulton was about to launch this invention of his, a boat that would supposedly run on steam, he was told it would never go. When it did, he was told it would never stop. History informs us that it did that, too.

title: Soviet Readers Finally Told Moscow Had Trotsky Slain
description: For the first time, a Soviet historian has told Soviet readers that the Kremlin was responsible for the slaying in exile of Leon Trotsky 48 years ago.

title: Cut Nuclear Weapons, Don't Add to Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Need Sheets for Your 707?
description: If you need extra-long twin sheets, dust ruffles for higher than normal beds or linens for irregularly shaped beds, E. Braun is one shop that can make them. This specialty linen house, on New York's Upper East Side, even makes extra-narrow sheets for mattresses like those on boats or railway cars.

title: Illusion and Reality on Stage: Earning a Living vs. Altruism
description: Paul Hecht's luck as an actor has certainly changed.

title: Charles M. Shapp, 82, Ex-New York Educator
description: Charles M. Shapp, a retired New York City school superintendent, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Marbella, Spain, where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: Jefferies's Campaign Giving Is Cited
description: Boyd L. Jefferies, the Government's main witness in a series of securities fraud cases, may have violated Federal election laws by concealing contributions made to members of Congress, lawyers involved in the stock manipulation case of the GAF Corporation said yesterday.

title: Nicaraguan Devaluation
description: Nicaragua devalued its currency by 54 percent today, the seventh drastic reduction in a year, and cut subsidies on transportation and military spending to combat an economic slump and soaring inflation. The central bank said in a statement that the cordoba was now fixed at 2,000 to the United States dollar, down from 920 to the dollar. President Daniel Ortega said Sunday that prices rose 21,742 percent in 1988, and he promised a severe new round of austerity. Some independent economists have warned that inflation could exceed 100,000 percent this year.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article headed ''Atlanta Journal'' on Tuesday about crime at the Bankhead Courts public housing project misidentified officers who kept watch over an all-night vigil by elected officials, ministers and students. They were police officers, not National Guardsmen.

title: Pay Raises Won't Improve Our Lawmakers; Obscene, Reprehensible
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Leaders, Reacting to Criticism, Agree to Vote on Rejecting a Raise
description: Senate leaders, responding to public criticism of the recommendation to increase Congressional pay by 50 percent, agreed today to schedule a vote within the next month on whether to reject the pay increase.

title: Mini-van Displayed By G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation took the wraps off its long-awaited plastic-body mini-van today, but the move was criticized by Chevrolet dealers who were angry at having to share the vehicle with Pontiac and Oldsmobile.

title: Accounts
description: * Progress Software Corp., Bedford, Mass., to Giardini/Russell Group, Watertown, Mass., with a $500,000 budget.

title: Events: Bee (Quilting) to Zebra (Carved)
description: Needle in Hand, Art Center of the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-996-1100.

title: Lauder Leaves New York City To Announce Run for Mayor
description: Ronald S. Lauder, former ambassador to Austria, traveled to Albany yesterday to announce that he was running for mayor of New York City.

title: Busch Shuts Plant Because of Oil Slick
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies suspended production at its biggest brewery because an oil slick working its way down the Mississippi River has slightly altered the taste of the water used in making beer. Company officials have not detected anything that would indicate a health hazard, Andrew J. Steinhubl, senior vice president of brewing, said.

title: Bank Regulator Asks for Powers To Raise Fees and Limit Lending
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed today to strengthen the deposit insurance system by giving it new powers to increase premiums on banks and to rein in high-risk lending.

title: Tracing the Roots
description: To The Home Section:

title: The War Against Chemical Warfare
description: The Reagan Administration is spending its final days militantly resisting the spread of chemical warfare. Whether part of a larger strategy or not, the shooting down of two Libyan fighter planes in the Mediterranean yesterday is likely to advance that high purpose.

title: Whalers Win in Overtime; Dineen Assists on 4 Goals
description: Brian Lawton scored at 3 minutes 19 seconds of overtime tonight, giving the Hartford Whalers a 5-4 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Hoare Govett Sets Cutback
description: The brokerage Security Pacific Hoare Govett announced today that it was getting out of the British and international bond markets and laying off 140 people.

title: Panel Seeks to Streamline F.D.A. for Cancer and AIDS Drugs
description: A new panel of experts hopes to find ways to streamline the bureaucracy of the Food and Drug Administration, its chairman said today.

title: In Blended Families, Rivalries Intensify
description: AT first, Christa and Shayne Johnson treated each other with the wariness of two hungry cats who suddenly have to share the same food bowl. Each was 8 years old and used to being the only child of a single parent. When those parents were married eight years ago, Shayne and his father moved in with Christa and her mother.

title: Braniff in Move to Buy 100 Planes
description: In an aggressive step toward modernizing and expanding its fleet, Braniff Inc. said today that it would buy as many as 100 airplanes from Airbus Industrie in a deal valued at roughly $3.5 billion.

title: 2 Studies Show Big Drops In U.S. Share of Electronics
description: Two recent studies conducted by Japanese and European organizations show that the United States' share of the world's electronics production has dropped far more dramatically than previously estimated, a United States trade group said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-15

title: Excerpts From Cuomo Address: Challenge of Difficult Times
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State address, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Mexicans Hoping for 'Salinastroika'
description: Some of the challenges facing Mikhail S. Gorbachev as he pursues glasnost and perestroika in the Soviet Union also confront Mexico's new President, and drawing parallels between the two has become an intellectual parlor game among Mexicans of various ideological persuasions and foreign diplomats here.

title: Atomic Cleanup Is Seen Costing U.S. $92 Billion
description: The Energy Department estimated today that it could cost $53 billion to $92 billion to clean up radioactive and chemical pollution at plants used to manufacture nuclear bombs and at other military and civilian installations under the department's control.

title: Rates Steady in Quiet Trading
description: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in lackluster, apathetic trading yesterday.

title: Metro Matters; A Time to Raise And a Time To Deny a Raise
description: What do Robert R. Kiley and the average welfare mother have in common?

title: I Beg Your Pardon
description: LEAD: Richard Nixon was granted a pre-trial pardon some 14 years ago, but President Reagan has decided not to give one to Oliver North and John Poindexter. Still the debate continues on the pardon issue. Would it be fair? Would it be proper? A look at pardons in another time may help us judge what is at stake.

title: Excerpts From O'Neill's Message to the General Assembly
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. William A. O'Neill's State of the State address to the Connecticut General Assembly:

title: Orders to U.S. Factories Rose by 0.3% in November
description: Orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods increased by a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in November, a report some economists said reflected continued but slower economic growth.

title: Giants' Assistant Turns In Resignation
description: The Giants announced yesterday that Len Fontes has resigned as the defensive backfield coach. It was the team's first coaching change since the Giants finished the season with a 10-6 mark and failed to make the playoffs for the second straight season. Neither Bill Parcells, the Giants' head coach, nor Fontes could immediately be reached for comment. Fontes, 50 years old, is the brother of the Detroit Lions' head coach, Wayne Fontes. Len Fontes was the defensive backfield coach since Parcells took over in 1983. This past season, the Giants' defense gave up 207.9 yards a game and 23 touchdown passes. It intercepted just 15 passes.

title: Cairo Journal; Finance and Islam Mix, Igniting a Mighty Scandal
description: When Effat Abbas Mohammed lost her life savings to Al Rayan, a huge Islamic investment fund, her story told much more than the sad failure of her ambition to make good and righteous money to help in raising four daughters. By now, hundreds of thousands of middle-class Egyptians may also have seen their modest wealth disappear in the hands of funds accused of dubious dealings.

title: Connecticut Session Opens With a Jolt
description: The often-staid Connecticut General Assembly began its 1989 session today in tumult, with the bitterly contested ouster of the powerful two-term Speaker overshadowing Gov. William A. O'Neill's warnings of fiscal constraint.

title: For Those Who Have Lost Sleep, The First Casualty Is Creativity
description: In a study with implications for the work performance of everyone from students and artists to hospital interns and pilots, a British researcher has found that loss of sleep sabotages creative faculties and the ability to deal with unfamiliar situations more rapidly than it impairs other mental abilities.

title: T. Herbert Shriver 2d, Investment Banker, 77
description: T. Herbert Shriver 2d, a retired investment banker, died Wednesday at his home in Towson, Md., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: 2 FROM FRENCH TVJ HELD IN BOMB HOAX
description: The New York bureau chief and a producer for a French television station, working on a report about airport security, were arrested yesterday and charged with trying to check three packages containing fake bombs through Kennedy International Airport, the Port Authority police said.

title: Part of Hollywood Past Dies in Closing of Hotel
description: A part of Hollywood died Tuesday as the last guests checked out of the 67-year-old Ambassador Hotel, the home of the Cocoanut Grove, one of the most famous nightclubs of the 1930's and 1940's.

title: U.S. DROPS CHARGES IN IRAN ARMS CASE
description: Federal prosecutors dropped all charges yesterday in a 1986 indictment charging a London lawyer, a retired Israeli general and nine other men with plotting to sell more than $2 billion in American-made weapons to Iran.

title: Fund Denial for Holocaust Course Is Upheld
description: Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos has said that he does not intend to reverse a decision denying money for a education program about the Holocaust, despite pleas from a group of Congressmen.

title: Lina Prokofiev, 91, Widow of the Composer
description: Lina Prokofiev, a singer and the wife of the Russian composer Sergei Prokofiev, died Tuesday in London. She was 91 years old and lived in London.

title: Anti-Cholesterol Move by Keebler
description: The Keebler Company, which sells more than $1 billion worth of cookies, crackers and other snack foods each year, said it would stop using tropical oils and animal fats in all its products. The company, a unit of United Biscuits (Holdings) P.L.C. of Britain, is the latest food manufacturer to respond to consumer concerns about the cholesterol problems associated with coconut oil, palm oil, palm kernel oil, lard and beef fat, all of which are high in saturated fat.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sukova Advances: Top-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia advanced to the third round of the $150,000 Danone Australian hard-court championship in Brisbane yesterday with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over unseeded Alexia Dechaume of France. Fifth-seeded Hana Mandlikova, a native of Czechoslovakia who is an Australian citizen, continued her recent poor form when she served 18 double faults during her 6-4, 6-4 loss to unseeded Catherine Tanvier of France. Ninth-seeded Brenda Schultz of the Netherlands complained about the heat after eliminating second-seeded Pascale Paradis of France, 7-5, 6-4. Australian Wendy Turnbull bowed to 11th-seeded Gretchen Magers of the United States, 6-0, 6-0, in 56 minutes. (AP) Ivanisevic in Quarterfinals: Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia reached the quarterfinals of the $123,400 South Australian Open in Adelaide with a straight-sets victory over Johan Anderson of Australia. The 17-year-old Ivanisevic, who made the main draw as a lucky losing qualifier, downed Anderson, 6-1, 6-7, 6-2.

title: Stocks Rally as Dow Rises 33.04, to 2,177.68
description: Stocks rallied strongly yesterday in a broad advance that market experts attributed to a stronger dollar and a late wave of program buying.

title: New and Classic Pipes, And Prompt Repairs
description: ''PIPE smokers are funny people,'' said Vince Nastri, president of the Barclay-Rex Pipe Shop, started by his grandfather in 1910, in the Wall Street area. ''They break their pipes, and it's like they've broken their legs. They have to have them fixed right away.''

title: Cyanide Yogurt Case Still Puzzles Officials
description: Investigators believe the cyanide poisoning of a teen-ager who ate tainted yogurt is an isolated incident, but they said yesterday that they were looking into a possibility that it might be linked to an unsolved product-tampering case two years ago.

title: Qaddafi Vows to 'Meet Challenge With Challenge'
description: Libya said today that the downing of two Libyan jet fighters by United States Navy planes was a premeditated attack, and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said that his nation would ''meet challenge with challenge.''

title: Lukas Foss to Leave Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: Lukas Foss, music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra since 1971, is to retire at the end of the 1989-90 season, orchestra officials announced yesterday.

title: Praise and Skepticism Greet the Drug Plan
description: Officials grappling with New York's huge drug problem welcomed proposals today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in his State of the State Message to combat drug abuse. But some officials criticized the Governor's program as thin on specifics and new initiatives.

title: Big Challenge Follows Big Victory
description: About three hours before game time Tuesday night, Seton Hall's team bus arrived at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Right then, the Pirates realized this wasn't an ordinary game.

title: Personal Health
description: Premenstrual syndrome, now widely known, discussed, diagnosed and even used as a legal defense, is still a biomedical mystery whose cause and proper treatment have yet to be established.

title: Thornburgh Meets On Trial of North
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra investigation, Lawrence E. Walsh, held an unusual private meeting today amid indications that Government concerns about national security were posing a threat to Mr. Walsh's prosecution of Oliver L. North.

title: Excerpts From Pentagon Briefing on Libyan Jets
description: Following are excerpts from the Pentagon briefing today on the downing of the two Libyan jets, including the opening statement by Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci and a question-and-answer session with Mr. Carlucci and Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff: Opening Statement

title: Tri-Cities Journal; Icy 'Miracle in the Desert' Is an Oasis of Cheer Amid the Gloom
description: Here in the desert of southeastern Washington State, home of the Hanford nuclear reservation, just about every piece of news lately has been bad.

title: Booking Guests for Talk Shows: A Hectic Hunt for Ever-Fresh Gab
description: Gail Evans has 9,000 telephone numbers. She has dozens of earthquake survivors, 15 people who say they've had afterlife experiences, 4 who insist they've seen Big Foot. She has the phone number of Cher's mother and the number of Rocky Graziano's upstairs neighbor. She has business numbers, home numbers, country home numbers, car phone numbers, airplane numbers and beeper numbers.

title: KEY RATES
Ex-Coach Complains
description: A week after being dismissed as the defensive coordinator for the Los Angeles Raiders, Charlie Sumner was quoted in yesterday's editions of The Los Angeles Times as saying that Coach Mike Shanahan had made him a ''fall guy.'' Shanahan, whose Raiders turned in a 7-9 record in his first year as head coach, dismissed Sumner and Willie Brown, another assistant, a few days after the Raiders were eliminated from playoff consideration. ''I really think I'm being made the fall guy and I think this was a set-up deal from the beginning,'' Sumner was quoted as saying. ''From the way it's turned out, I think this has been in Shanahan's mind from the beginning. I know one thing; he wasn't ready for the job.'' Shanahan, at 36 the league's youngest coach, responded by saying, ''I had a lot of respect for Charlie as a person and what he's accomplished in the profession. But I felt a change was necessary in the best interests of the organization.''(AP)

title: Stake Is Increased In Starrett Housing
description: The New York real estate developers Seymour and Paul Milstein have raised their stake in the Starrett Housing Corporation to 25 percent from 7 percent. Starrett, the New York-based construction company that built the Trump Tower and the Trump Plaza, received $60 million last year in connection with longstanding claims against Iran.

title: New Yorkers Braving the Chill of It All
description: Scarves were wrapped tightly, flags flapped snappily and cars hacked hoarsely as a wind-whipped front of frigid air bore down on the New York metropolitan region yesterday.

title: Campaign-Financing Law Is Amended
description: The New York City Council, after a committee meeting marked by shouts of anger and frustration, overwhelmingly approved a series of amendments to the city's new public campaign-financing law.

title: Murals, Monuments And Urban Decor
description: FOR the last 14 years, trompe l'oeil facades by the muralist Richard Haas have been decorating urban landscapes from Los Angeles and Milwaukee to Fort Worth and Cincinnati. In New York, many remember the cast-iron facade he created at 114 Prince Street and his re-creation of the old Times Tower in Times Square.

title: Building a Better Bird Cage
description: THESE days it seems even birds are deserving of historic houses. So believes Johanna Welty of Walnut Creek, Calif., who makes limited-edition bird cages in such styles as an Italian Regency dovecote and a Palladian aviary.

title: This House Needs Cleaning
description: LEAD: In the spring of 1789, when the first Congress was two months old, Fisher Ames, a Federalist representative from Massachusetts, wrote of his colleagues that while there were ''few shining geniuses . . . in time they will be found to improve.'' Ames is, to my knowledge, the first member of the House to suggest his colleagues have limitations and need improvement.

title: Good Riddance to the Welfare Hotels; At Least Help the Homeless Off the Street
description: ''I don't pray! Pray for what? I been prayin' all my life and I'm still here. When I came to this hotel, I still believed in God. I said: 'Maybe God can help us to survive.' I lost my faith. My hopes. And everything. Ain't nobody - no God, no Jesus - gonna help us in no way.''

title: Plan by Hoffmann
description: Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., an afiliate of the Swiss pharmaceutical concern F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, said it would build a $60 million plant in Freeport, Tex., to produce beta carotene, a nutritional supplement and food-coloring agent found naturally in carrots, broccoli, squash and other vegetables.

title: Castro Plays Down Differences With Soviets on Economic Change
description: Fidel Castro sought tonight to minimize differences between Cuba and the Soviet Union, but reaffirmed his refusal to adopt Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of economic liberalization to remedy his country's critical economic problems.

title: Not Getting Sympathy, Officials Hope for Raise
description: Since conservative Republicans have long preached the gospel of ''fiscal responsibility,'' one might expect virtually all of them to oppose the hefty pay increase recently proposed for Federal lawmakers, judges and executives. Not so. Every year, their complaint goes, the financial sacrifice of public service grows greater. They are tired of shopping at K Mart for their children's clothes and worrying about the price of parking. The cost of Washington life has turned a number of budgetary skinflints into spenders, at least on the pay issue.

title: Pay Raises Won't Improve Our Lawmakers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers Slug It Out In Tyson-Cayton Case
description: Beyond the battle to control the boxing future of Mike Tyson, a struggle that has pitted the heavyweight champion's manager, Bill Cayton, against Tyson and the promoter Don King, a small-scale skirmish is shaping up: one to influence public opinion.

title: Walesa Interview Published In Communist Party Weekly
description: Lech Walesa, interviewed by the Communist Party weekly Polityka for the first time since 1980, predicted that the authorities will have to reinstate his union one way or another.

title: Thatcher at Rites for Crash Victims
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher led several hundred mourners today at an emotional memorial service for the 270 people who were killed when Pan Am Flight 103 was blown apart by a bomb two weeks ago over the Scottish countryside.

title: Bush Seeks More Candidates For Post of Energy Secretary
description: Aides to Vice President George Bush said today that the President-elect had asked that additional candidates be proposed for the post of Energy Secretary.

title: Soviet Writers' Chief Quits
description: Georgi Markov, a defender of standard Communist values in the arts, retired Wednesday as chairman of the Soviet Writers' Union, the country's most important officially approved organization of authors. Mr. Markov, 77 years old, was one of the union's most powerful figures for almost 20 years, serving as its first secretary from 1971 to 1986 and then as its chairman. His successor was not immediately named. Mr. Markov succeeded in keeping the Writers' Union a relatively orthodox organization.

title: Jobless Rate Up in Germany
description: West Germany's unemployment rate rose in 1988 despite the nation's highest economic growth in this decade, data released today by the Federal Labor Office showed.

title: Review/City Ballet; After Mice And Toys, Balanchine
description: It could have been a Sunday in November. It wasn't. It was a Tuesday night. And it was this month: January. Nevertheless, by dancing ''Ballo Della Regina,'' ''Episodes'' and ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet'' at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet offered the three works by George Balanchine that it presented Sunday night, Nov. 27.

title: AFRICANS IN CHINA ARE FINALLY FREED
description: About 45 African students who had been held against their will by the authorities in the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing for the last 10 days were released today. Most plan to leave China as soon as possible.

title: His Number Is Up
description: Joseph Frank of Lafayette, Ind., made his mark in history today, which is his 26th birthday. According to the Selective Service System, he was the first 18-year-old to register for the draft eight years ago after Congress passed a law requiring young men to sign up within a month of their 18th birthday. Thus Mr. Frank is also the first to reach the end of his eligibility for conscription.

title: Questions Left Hanging; In Skillful Defense Strategy, North's Team Exploited Administration's Embarrassment
description: By dropping the most serious charges against Oliver L. North, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra case has left a host of questions that may never be answered.

title: For Christmas of '88, It's Adios and Ta-Ta
description: Three events will ring out the Christmas season this weekend: a parade and a concert drawing on Hispanic traditions, and a Boar's Head and Yule Log Festival recalling old England.

title: Shenyang Journal; A City That Undoes Mao Under His Steady Gaze
description: This drab, Dickensian city, where a statue of Mao presides over the snow-covered central square, is best known for its soot and industry.

title: Twist in North Case Isn't a Surprise in Congress
description: Members of the special Congressional committees that investigated the Iran-contra affair in 1987 said today that they were not surprised by the independent prosecutor's decision to seek dismissal of the conspiracy and theft charges against Oliver L. North.

title: Books of The Times; Art: The Immortal Substitute for Life
description: Utz By Bruce Chatwin 154 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: Koch Ends Support for River Projects
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch, anticipating election-year criticism of his development policies, has withdrawn his support for two large waterfront projects and says he will run ''on a campaign of balanced development.''

title: Grumman Offering Notes With Buyout Protections
description: The Grumman Corporation is offering $200 million of 10 3/8 percent notes due in 1999 at a price of par, or about 1.11 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Farm Credit Bank Cancels Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation said yesterday that it would not conduct its regularly scheduled offering on Jan. 23 because it and its borrowers have only a limited need now to raise cash in the debt market for medium- and long-term financing.

title: Discrimination Denied In AIDS-Drug Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Exemptions by the C.F.T.C.
description: In a policy retreat, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission today exempted from its regulatory jurisdiction certain financial instruments linked to the price of oil, gold and other commodities.

title: Tyson in Accident
description: Mike Tyson was in another car accident yesterday, when his 1988 Lincoln was hit by another car trying to get around a stalled vehicle in Las Vegas, Nev. No one was injured in the accident, which police described as a minor fender-bender that slightly damaged the door of Tyson's car. Tyson, a passenger, was on way to his doctor to be fitted for a mouthpiece. Tyson's friend, Rory Holloway, was the driver, and the promoter Don King was another passenger. The driver of the other car, Michael Credico, a waiter, was cited for making an illegal turn, a $100 fine. (AP)

title: Kinder, Gentler Lunch
description: A luncheon meeting Wednesday at the Capitol Hill Club brought together William K. Reilly, the President-elect's choice to head the Environmental Protection Agency, and Manuel Lujan Jr., his nominee to be Secretary of Interior. A Bush aide later characterized the luncheon as an augury of a ''kinder, gentler administration.''

title: U.S. ASKS SOVIET AID IN PRESSING LIBYA ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The United States is seeking Soviet cooperation in pressing Libya to cease operations at a chemical plant that Washington says will be used to make chemical weapons, American officials said today.

title: CARLUCCI APPROVES BASE-CLOSING PLAN
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci approved a plan today to close dozens of military bases around the country, calling it a ''unique opportunity'' to save money that had been endorsed by military leaders.

title: Confessions of a Lottoholic
description: LEAD: I used to be a slave to Lotto.

title: Manic Basketball and Making Waves in the Air
description: Molissa Fenley, Wendy Perron and Elizabeth Streb took choreographic chances Wednesday night in the first of two programs to be presented by Dance Chance at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Copeland Extends Bid for Church's
description: A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., the owner of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken, has extended its tender offer of $8 a share for Church's Fried Chicken Inc. to Feb. 7 by order of the United States District Court of the Eastern District of Louisiana, which is considering takeover-related litigation between the two companies. Copeland's hostile offer was to expire at midnight today.

title: Review/Piano; Kalichstein in Recital
description: Twenty years have passed since Joseph Kalichstein's New York debut, at which the Israeli-born pianist made a strong impression as a technician of heroic aspirations and a musician of serious intent. His subsequent capturing of the Leventritt Award further fueled that reputation and targeted him as one of his generation's most promising artists.

title: Vito Titone, Lawyer, 91
description: Vito Titone, a retired lawyer, died of heart failure Wednesday at his winter home in Hallandale, Fla. He was 91 years old and lived in Roslyn Heights, L.I., for the last year.

title: Virgin Islands Chief Discusses Inquiry
description: The Governor of the Virgin Islands said today that he regretted having named a former District of Columbia official to oversee a revision of the islands' personnel system. He said the official, Charles Lewis, who is at the center of an investigation of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington, ''wasn't producing anything.''

title: Conlan Planning To Rejoin Bills
description: Shane Conlan, a Pro Bowl linebacker sidelined for the last six weeks with a foot injury, practiced with the Buffalo Bills today and said he would start in the American Football Conference title game against the Cincinnati Bengals on Sunday.

title: India Hangs Two Sikhs Convicted In Assassination of Indira Gandhi
description: Two men convicted in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in October 1984 were hanged this morning, the Government announced.

title: U.S.-CUBA ENMITY MAY BE RELAXING
description: After three decades of mutual hostility, the United States and Cuba appear to be edging toward a wider range of contacts that some diplomats say may lead to somewhat improved relations.

title: 'African-American' for 'Black' Signals a Return
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says Tape Shows Missiles On a Libyan Jet
description: The United States said today that it had visual evidence indicating that two Libyan fighter planes were armed when they were shot down Wednesday by Navy fighters over the Mediterranean. It accused Libya of lying in asserting that the planes were unarmed reconnaissance aircraft.

title: What Next for a Mink-Coated 4-Year-Old?
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke Remains Unbeaten
description: Despite a lackluster offensive performance in the first half, top-ranked Duke led Davidson by 15 points, so Coach Mike Krzyzewski knew the Blue Devils' defense was effective.

title: 4 Illegal Asian Immigrants Are Believed to Have Drowned in River
description: As many as four illegal Asian immigrants, including a 7-year-old child, are believed to have drowned in the turbulent Niagara River this week while being smuggled into the United States on a flimsy inflatable raft.

title: The Newest Arrivals for the New Year
description: Aureole

title:
About Real Estate;
Modular Project Rises In Northern Dutchess
description: LEAD: Northern Dutchess County is out of commuting range of New York City, but the area's lower-cost housing is attracting buyers who work in White Plains and other outlying employment centers.

title: Steinberg May Face One Less Charge
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they were seriously considering dropping the first-degree manslaughter charge against Joel B. Steinberg on the ground that their case was primarily based on his ''depraved indifference'' to Lisa Steinberg's life and not on any intent to kill her.

title: Auctions
description: Cream of the Plum

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Woodforde in Quarterfinals: Mark Woodforde and Wally Masur of Australia and Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany scored straight-set victories yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the $123,400 South Australian Open in Adelaide. The fourth-seeded Woodforde defeated 18-year-old Andrei Cherkasov of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 7-6. The fifth-seeded Masur beat a countryman, Todd Woodbridge, 6-2, 6-1. Kuhnen, seeded seventh, breezed past Mark Koevermans of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-4, and unseeded Veli Paloheimo of Finland defeated Roger Rasheed of Australia, 6-1, 6-3, in other second-round action in the 32-player Nabisco Grand Prix event.(AP) BASKETBALL Cavaliers 103, Bulls 98: Cleveland won its 10th straight last night as Ron Harper scored 7 straight points to break a 90-90 tie late in the fourth quarter. The game was played in Richfield, Ohio. Cleveland, which improved its record to 23-5, extended its franchise record for consecutive victories in a season. It also matched the team record for consecutive victories set over two seasons (1977-78 and 1978-79). The Cavaliers' Craig Ehlo neutralized Chicago's Michael Jordan in the fourth quarter, limiting him to 2 points in the period until Jordan made a 3-point shot with 28 seconds to go. Jordan finished with 32 points, 20 of them in the first half. A dunk by the Bulls' Horace Grant tied the score for the 20th time at 90-90 with four minutes left. Harper then took control, making a scoop shot, a short jumper, a free throw and a fast-break layup off a steal to put Cleveland up by 97-90 with 1 minute 40 seconds to play. Jordan's 3-pointer got Chicago within 4 with 28 seconds left, but the Bulls could get no closer. Larry Nance led Cleveland with 24 points and Harper scored 20.(AP) Spurs 119, 76ers 104: Willie Anderson, a rookie, scored a career-high 36 points last night as San Antonio, playing at home, handed Philadelphia its fourth straight loss. Anderson, who hit 18 of 26 shots, scored 10 of his points in the first 5:22 of the third period. After Philadelphia moved ahead, 70-69, the Spurs scored 7 straight points, taking the lead for good at 76-70. Charles Barkley led Philadelphia with 23 points.(AP) HOCKEY North Stars 5, Flyers 3: Mark Habscheid scored the go-ahead goal on a power play with 4:46 remaining last night as Minnesota, ranked last in the National Hockey League on the power play, scored three times with the man advantage. The game was played in Bloomington, Minn. The North Stars entered the game with only 28 power-play goals in 190 opportunities for a league-low 14.7 percent success ratio. The Flyers, who came into the game with the league's top-ranked power play, were 0 for 6. Philadelphia had won 10 of its last 11 games, all with Ron Hextall in goal. But Hextall was victimized by two long and relatively weak shots in the third period, including Habscheid's game-winner. With Moe Mantha, a former North Star, in the penalty box and the score tied at 3-3, Habscheid took a pass from Neal Broten at the point and took a low, bouncing shot that eluded Hextall.(AP) Blues 5, Dynamo Riga 0: Tony Hrkac scored a goal and added two assists, leading St. Louis to the victory last night in St. Louis. It was the fourth loss in six games for the Soviet team. The shutout went to Pat Jablonski, who was called up for the game from the Blues' Peoria farm team in the International League. He had won only three games for Peoria this season and did not have a shutout. Riga's record dropped to 1-4-1 on its seven-game tour of the United States. The Soviet team closes out its series tomorrow night at Minnesota.(AP) College Boston College 7, Notre Dame 5: In Newton, Mass., Marty McInnis scored two goals and had two assists for the Eagles, who improved to 13-4. The Fighting Irish dropped to 4-19-2. McInnis's first goal came at 3:34 of the first period and Boston College never relinquished the lead. The Eagles were ahead, 4-1, at the end of the first period. (AP)

title: 2 Homeless Men Found Dead From Cold Weather
description: LEAD: Two homeless men froze to death yesterday, one in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx, as city and private shelters for the homeless were filled with men and women seeking warmth.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allstate Insurance Co., Northbrook, Ill., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co., named as executive vice presidents Louis G. Lower 2d and David E. McPherson. In addition, it named Myron J. Resnick senior vice president and treasurer.

title: Intermagnetics General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: Masanobu Ikemiya, a pianist and harpsichordist, is to play works by Brahms, C.P.E. Bach, Carl Nielsen and George Rochberg with members of the Bronx Arts Ensemble at Wave Hill, West 252d Street and Endependence Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Tickets are $10. Information: 549-3200.

title: KEY RATES
Bush Is Urged to Fight Threat of Global Warming
description: The National Academy of Sciences urged President-elect George Bush today to place the threat of a significant increase in global temperatures high on his agenda because ''the future welfare of human society'' is at risk.

title: Iranian Concern To Make Peugeots
description: Iran's biggest auto company, Iran Khodrow, has signed a contract with Peugeot S.A. of France to produce 500,000 cars in the next 10 years, the Iranian press agency reported today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Federal Express Corp, Memphis, an overnight delivery service, said it had acquired the home delivery service business of Littlewoods Organization P.L.C. of Britain. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Spielberg and Warner's Plan Cartoons
description: The director Steven Spielberg, a longtime lover of animated cartoons, is joining forces with Warner Brothers for a new television version of Warner's famous ''Merrie Melodies'' cartoons, to be called ''Tiny Tunes.''

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: The assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds decreased by $449.50 million, to $278.03 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 136 institutional funds increased by $588.4 million, to $72.41 billion. The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were up by $249.1 million, to $89.94 billion. The 91 broker-dealer funds decreased by $1.29 billion, to $115.67 billion, the institute said.

title: Dow Climbs To Highest Since Crash
description: Stocks rose broadly in heavier trading yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to the highest close since the October 1987 crash.

title: Agency Backs Medicare Cut at Teaching Hospitals
description: The General Accounting Office today supported a Reagan Administration proposal to sharply reduce the extra Government compensation to 1,100 teaching hospitals for Medicare patients.

title: Debt Crisis For Banks Said to End
description: Three leading bank regulators told Congress today that third world debts no longer posed a threat to this country's banking system.

title: Gansz Dismissed
description: Frank Gansz, whose teams won only eight games in his two seasons as coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, was dismissed yesterday by Carl Peterson, general manager and chief operating officer. Under Gansz, 50 years old, who had two years left on his contract, the Chiefs were 8-22-1. (AP)

title: In Tripoli, Business Is Almost as Usual
description: Shops were open, workers went to their jobs and commerce and business seemed normal here today. But a day after an aerial confrontation in which two Libyan fighter planes were shot down, there was anxiety over what the Americans might do next.

title: A New Arafat Veto by Violence?
description: Yasir Arafat should not be surprised that every word he utters, every statement made in his name is meticulously scrutinized. The world has so long associated the Palestine Liberation Organization he heads with terrorism that the credibility of his recent renunciation of this practice remains fragile at best.

title:
Market Place;
Growth Funds Post Biggest Gains
description: LEAD: In 1988, mutual fund investors who were willing to take risks generally did better than those who sought safety.

title: Steinberg's Lawyer Finds Sudden Fame, and Infamy
description: Ira D. London, Joel B. Steinberg's lawyer, tells the story himself. He goes into a fashionable Manhattan restaurant where he used to dine unknown but where he now gets a good table.

title: Mullen Becomes Rangers' Odd Man In
description: It wasn't much of a shot. In fact, it barely qualified as a pass. But for the Rangers, the puck that was launched without much speed or intent turned out to possess an unerring sense of direction.

title: John W. Brooks, 71, Retired Chief Of the Celanese Corp. of America
description: John Wood Brooks, a retired chief executive and chairman of the Celanese Corporation of America, died of heart failure Wednesday at his home in Bedford Hills, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday DAY FOR QUARTETS

title: U.S. Criticizes Bonn on Response To Charges on Chemical Company
description: Senior State Department officials said today that West Germany was not moving quickly enough to respond to American assertions that a German chemical company had helped Libya build a vast chemical plant.

title: 'African-American' for 'Black' Signals a Return; No Hyphens, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Beeba's Creations Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dining Out Guide: Italian
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Azzurro ** (Sept. 26, 1986), 1625 Second Avenue, at 84th Street (517-7068) - This little family-run Sicilian restaurant is expert at pastas and regional dishes. Among the freshly prepared appetizers are homemade mozzarella and grilled endive tied with scallion ribbons. Pastas excel at Azzurro; two choices are bucatini tossed with shreds of sardines and wild fennel, and penne with roasted eggplant and tomatoes. Other good dishes are grilled tuna Sicilian style and grilled chicken with fresh rosemary. Appetizers are $6 to $8.50, pastas $11 to $13.50, main courses $14 to $21. Open 5 to 11 P.M. Friday, 5 to midnight Saturday, 4 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Felidia ** (Sept. 16, 1988), 243 East 58th Street (758-1479) - On most evenings, this elegant two-story restaurant resonates with an affluent crowd of patrons with time for a leisurely dinner. A good starter might be a half order of one of the pastas -pasutice with shellfish or tortellacci filled with ricotta and Swiss chard. The kitchen also turns out good rustic entrees of osso buco, roasted pheasant, and veal chop Valdostana. At dinner, appetizers are $7 to $14, entrees $19 to $28. Open noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight Friday, 5 P.M. to midnight Saturday. Closed Sunday. Orsini's ** (Jan. 22, 1988), 26 East 63d Street (644-3700) - Orsini's menu and decor are classic and conservative. The spacious dining room has an opulent look, with banquettes and an impressive carved-wood ceiling. Familiar Italian dishes are prepared with flair: fresh salmon and green peppercorns are added to fettuccine in a light cream sauce; gnocchi are tossed in a pesto sauce with a crunch of pine nuts and thin green beans. Entree choices include grilled baby chicken with rosemary, Dover sole with pesto, and veal Orsini style. Entrees are $14 to $18 at lunch, $24.50 to $26.50 at dinner. Open noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M Friday, 6 P.M. to midnight Saturday. Closed Sunday. Rosemarie's * (Oct. 21, 1988), 145 Duane Street (285-2610) - Casual but romantic in atmosphere, Rosemarie's is an attraction for downtown fans of pasta and other favorite Italian dishes. Recommended are stracci (folded triangles of thin pasta) with chicken, artichoke hearts, snow peas and wild mushrooms; fried calamari rings (a special); roasted snapper with a saffron vinaigrette, and roast chicken with mashed potatoes. At dinner, appetizers are $6 to $7.75, entrees $13.50 to $22. Open 5:30 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. San Domenico *** (July 22, 1988), 240 Central Park South (265-5959) - This three-star offspring of a successful restaurant in Italy offers dishes from that country's distinctive regional repertory. Lavish attention has been paid to the decor. Terra cotta floor tiles were imported from Florence, artisans skilled in tinting and applying stucco to walls were sent from Rome. Some menu changes are being made while the restaurant is closed this week - it reopens Tuesday - but many recommended dishes will remain. Among them are pastas of garganelli (tiny pasta curls) with beluga caviar; seafood ravioli, and spaghetti alla chitarra. Entrees include lobster fricassee and Muscovy duck with olives. Lunch is prix fixe at $32.50; tasting dinner, $65. Dinner appetizers $16; pastas $21; seafood entrees $32.75; meat entrees $31.50. Open noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 5:30 to 11 P.M. Sunday. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: Charles J. Buesing, Executive, 79
description: Charles J. Buesing, a retired sales executive and longtime trustee of the American Cancer Society, died of emphysema Saturday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Indian River Shores, Fla., where he lived. He was 79.

title: Knicks' Run Against Nets Is Still Barely Believable
description: It lasted 7 minutes 4 seconds. It's hard to imagine unless you saw it. And it was a microcosm of the reason the Knicks (20-10) are a first-place team and why the Nets (13-18) remain far from the top.

title: Economic Scene; Recession in '89? Majority Doubt It
description: WHAT lies ahead for the economy in 1989?

title: Tarpley Suspended
description: The Dallas Mavericks forward Roy Tarpley, who went to drug counselors for help Wednesday, was suspended indefinitely without pay yesterday in line with the National Basketball Association's anti-drug agreement. The 24-year-old Tarpley returned to the active roster Dec. 13 after missing 14 games with torn cartilage in his left knee. He averaged 14.8 points and 10.6 rebounds. Tarpley sought substance-abuse counseling in June 1987. The following September Tarpley said he was treated for a problem that had been resolved. Under the N.B.A. drug policy, a player coming forward a second time, as Tarpley did, is suspended without pay during treatment but suffers no further penalty. (AP)

title: Cockpit Voices, Critical Moments
description: O.K., bodeys [ Libyan planes ] have jinked back at me again for the fifth time. They're on my nose now, inside of 20 miles.

title: Pop/Jazz; Recalling A Pop Artist And a Friend
description: ''Andy, it's me/Haven't seen you for a while/I wish I had talked to you more when you were alive,'' begins the elegiac lyric for ''Hello It's Me,'' one of 14 new songs written by John Cale and Lou Reed for their new musical suite, ''Songs for 'Drella.''

title: Correction
description: A brief article by Reuters in Business Day yesterday about the unemployment rate in West Germany described the change incorrectly. The rate fell to 8.7 percent in 1988, from 8.9 percent in 1987, but the total number of unemployed did rise.

title: Proposal on Automated Trading Systems
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for public comment a measure that would require increased regulation of private automated trading systems.

title: Big Bear Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Nov 26
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 15 percent stock dividend.

title: Bonus to U.S. From Clash: Intelligence
description: In shooting down two Libyan fighter planes, the Navy added to its knowledge of Libyan air defenses, information that would be useful if the Reagan Administration decided to attack what it says is a chemical weapons plant.

title: Military Bases Affected by Commission's Recommendations
description: Following is a list of 145 military installations affected by the recommendations of the Commission on Base Realignment and Closure. The numbers after each installation indicate a loss or gain of jobs and the amount of annual savings where any is expected. ALABAMA Alabama Ammunition Plant, closed, minus 1, $30,000. Coosa River Annex, closed, 0, $100,000. Anniston Army Depot, reorganized, 0. Redstone Arsenal, expanded, plus 31. ARKANSAS Eaker Air Force Base, expanded, plus 16. ARIZONA Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, reorganized, minus 506, $3.05 million. Fort Huachuca, minus 616. Navaho Depot, closed, minus 5. Yuma Proving Ground, reorganized, plus 277. CALIFORNIA Beale Air Force Base, reorganized, plus 781. George Air Force Base, closed, minus 5,358, $70.2 million. Hamilton Army Airfield, closed, minus 29, $150,000. Hunters Point Naval Station, reorganized, minus 4,225, $8 million. Long Beach Naval Station, reorganized, plus 461. March Air Force Base, reorganized, plus 3,420. Mather Air Force Base, closed, minus 3,000, $78.7 million. McClellan Air Force Base, reorganized, plus 231. Norton Air Force Base, closed, minus 6,653, $67.9 million. Presidio of San Francisco, including Letterman Army Medical Center, closed, minus 5,290, $74.08 million. Salton Sea Test Base, closed, 0. San Diego Naval Station, reorganized, plus 1,495. COLORADO Fort Carson, reorganized, plus 700. Lowry Air Force Base, reorganized, plus 386. Bennett Air National Guard Facility, closed, 0. Pueblo Army Depot, reorganized, minus 546, $15.45 million. title: Newhouse Head Testifies
description: Samuel I. Newhouse Jr. today lifted a small bit of the curtain that has kept from public view the inside workings of his family's vast newspaper, magazine and broadcast holdings.

title: Thorn-EMI Gets SBK for $337 Million
description: Thorn-EMI, the British conglomerate that owns Capitol Records, will buy SBK Entertainment World, the publisher of more than 250,000 songs, for $337 million, the highest amount ever paid for a music publisher.

title: Snow Falls in Iran's Desert
description: Snow has fallen on the desert regions of Khur and Biyabanak in eastern Iran for the first time in 50 years, the official Iranian press agency reported today. Officials said four inches of snow had fallen in the last 24 hours, forcing schools to close.

title: At the Movies
description: When you've got something old, something new, something borrowed and something blue, usually the topic is weddings. But this time it's movies - in particular, the outlook for movies early this new year.

title: Robert Coles, Ophthalmologist, Dies at 68
description: Dr. Robert S. Coles, an internationally known ophthalmologist and educator, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Trader's Plea Reveals New Front In Battle on Wall St. Corruption
description: Several Federal agencies have joined in a broad investigation of stock manipulation, using evidence that came to light as a result of the market crash of October 1987, officials reported yesterday.

title: American Recreation Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: b-Net income and includes a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $923,000. Year-ago quarter net is less than 1 cent a share. Year-ago periods' results are restated to include results of Right Start Catalog Inc., acquired in July 1988 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Reagan Supports 50% Raise for U.S. Officials
description: President Reagan decided today to recommend that members of Congress, Federal judges and top members of the executive branch get a 50 percent pay increase, the White House and Congressional officials said this evening.

title: Russian at U.N. Says Moscow Had Urged Restraint by the U.S.
description: The Soviet representative to the United Nations said today the Soviet Union had urged the United States to ''show restraint in the area'' before the aerial encounter in which two Libyan warplanes were shot down over the Mediterranean.

title: Review/Art; Four New Sculptors
description: Curtis Mitchell is one of many artists living in a raw warehouse area in Brooklyn, not far from the Brooklyn Bridge. One of his three untitled works in the ''Emerging Sculptors'' show at the Sculpture Center was inspired by a visit to Manhattan's glitzy Trump Tower. With its rectangular trunk shape, its marble facing and a carpet placed over it as carefully as a shroud, the sculpture suggests a fancy portable altar. But the carpet is pseudo-Oriental, the marble is veneer, and the black coating on top of the rug is prime New York City soot.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Signed Jim Eppard, first baseman-outfielder, to a one-year contract. CINCINNATI (NL) - Named Dave Bristol third-base coach. HOUSTON (NL) - Agreed to terms with Craig Reynolds, infielder, on a one-year contract. BASKETBALL NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSSCIATION - Fined Rick Pitino, Knicks coach, $3,000 for remaining near the playing area after being ejected from a game against the Chicago Bulls on Dec. 30. Suspended Roy Tarpley, Dallas Mavericks forward, indefinitely without pay for noncompliance with a follow-up drug program. INDIANA (NBA) - Named Dick Versace coach. FOOTBALL KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Dismissed Frank Gansz, coach. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed Nathan Wonsley, running back; Shaun Burdick, punter; Michel James, wide receiver; Bud Keyes, quarterback; Wendell Phillips, defensive back, and Peter Casperriello, tight end.

title: ESPN Will Pay $400 Million For Baseball-Game Rights
description: The ESPN cable network yesterday won the television rights to 175 major league baseball games a year for four years, beginning in the 1990 season, in a $400 million deal.

title: Arbitration for Thon
description: Dickie Thon, the San Diego shortstop who had demanded a trade, exercised another right yesterday by filing for salary arbitration. He was the only one of the 176 eligible players to file on the first day of the 12-day filing period. Under the trade demand, the Padres must trade Thon by March 15 or lose him as a free agent. In the meantime, he can have his salary determined by an arbitrator. Almost all of the eligible players are expected to wait until the final day, Jan. 16, to file for arbitration. Another eligible player, Steve Lyons, reached agreement with the Chicago White Sox, on a one-year contract for $325,000. Lyons earned $220,000 last season, during which he committed 25 errors in 128 games at third base.

title: Paul Brown Gives Bengals A Regimen
description: After the Cincinnati Bengals' switchboard operator plugged in the phone call, the voice that answered announced: ''Coach Brown's office.''

title: West Germans Try to Curb Dollar's Rally
description: The West German central bank intervened against a surging dollar yesterday, indicating its increasing displeasure with the dollar's growing strength.

title: Auto Sales in '88 Set 2d-Highest Mark Ever
description: The automobile industry enjoyed its second-best year ever in the United States in 1988, with sales of more than 15 million cars and trucks for an unprecedented fourth straight year.

title: Review/Art; Man Ray's Beginnings
description: As it was for many young American artists at the time, the Armory Show of 1913 was for Man Ray an event of singular significance. It put his mind ''in a turmoil,'' he recalled years later, ''the turmoil of a seed that has been planted in fertile ground, ready to break through.'' What Man Ray produced during the next eight years - beginning with the Cezanne-derived canvases he painted of scenes around his home in Ridgefield, N.J., and then in the photographs, collages and other Dada-inspired objects he created after moving to New York in 1915 - bears out the artist's memory.

title: Official to Quit To Weigh Race For Kean Post
description: Attorney General W. Cary Edwards announced today that he will quit his post in two weeks to contemplate whether to run for governor this year, a move that most politicians here consider likely.

title: Bilzerian Enters Plea of Not Guilty
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida financier who took over the Singer Company last year, pleaded not guilty yesterday to 12 counts of violating securities and tax laws, conspiracy and making false statements to the Government.

title: National Medical Plans To Spin Off Hillhaven
description: In its second significant restructuring in two years, National Medical Enterprises Inc. said today that it planned to spin off to shareholders one of its largest units, the Hillhaven Corporation, the nation's second-largest nursing home company.

title: Rail Police Resent Extra Burden of Homeless
description: Freezing weather and gusty winds have prompted many homeless people to seek shelter in New York City's transportation terminals, prompting complaints from the police at Pennsylvania Station that they are being forced to work overtime to keep the homeless moving.

title: Restaurants
description: Aureole

title: Reviews/Music; After 20 Years Onstage, a Debut For Jill O'Hara
description: After a 20-year career in musical theater that includes a role in the original production of ''Hair'' at the New York Public Theater in 1967 and a Tony nomination for her performance in ''Promises, Promises,'' Jill O'Hara is making her cabaret debut at Danny's Skylight Room in the Grand Sea Palace, 346 West 46th Street, with an adventurous range of material.

title: Hattie Rosenbaum, Manager for Famous In Music, Dies at 82
description: Hattie Clark Rosenbaum, a longtime vice president at Columbia Artists Management and one of the first women to attain a leading role in the concert-management profession, died of a brain tumor Dec. 24 at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. She was 82 years old.

title: President to Be Chief At Pratt & Lambert
description: Pratt & Lambert Inc., an old-line Buffalo-based coatings and adhesives company, said yesterday that its president, Joseph Castiglia, was taking on the added title of chief executive.

title: Washington Mayor Says He Took Drug Tests and Released Results
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today that he had been tested for drugs twice a year and had released the results.

title: Pacers Pick Versace In Third Change
description: In their third change of bench leadership while losing 23 of 29 games this season, the Indiana Pacers yesterday named Dick Versace, an assistant with the Detroit Pistons for three seasons, as their coach. The Pacers lost their first seven games under Jack Ramsay, dropped two more under the assistant coaches Mel Daniels and Dave Twardzik after Ramsay resigned, then won 6 of 20 games under George Irvine, vice president of basketball operations. Versace saw the Pacers break a nine-game losing streak with a 116-113 victory over Atlanta Wednesday night. ''I will not accept losing from this team or any team that I coach,'' said Versace, 48 years old, whose teams at Bradley had a 156-88 record over eight seasons before he joined the Pistons. (AP)

title: Equity Growth Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The 1987 results included T.A. & D.A. Troy Co. operations only for the 6 months from the date of acquisition in March 1987.

title: Reviews/Music; Pursuing The Research Of 'Bird' Songs
description: Charles McPherson's set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night was typically predictable, and typically brilliant. The alto saxophonist ripped through a handful of standards - ''Billie's Bounce,'' ''Cherokee,'' ''Easy to Love'' - as well as an original ballad. Solos followed one another logically, and Mr. McPherson played with the sort of muscular ease and wit usually found in athletes in their prime.

title: South African Insurgents Agree To Shut Their Bases, Angola Says
description: The African National Congress has agreed to close its military training bases here, Angola's President said today.

title: Energy Post Stumps Bush, With No Clear Candidate
description: President-elect George Bush's attempt to complete his Cabinet remained stalled today with no clear choice for Energy Secretary, senior Bush aides said.

title: Another Silicon Valley Tailspin
description: Wyse Technology, once a fast-growing maker of personal computers and computer terminals, said today that it would reduce its work force by 15 percent in response to steep drops in revenue. The company also announced that its president and chief operating officer, Phillip E. White, had left to join another company.

title: 'Misbehavin' ' to Close
description: ''Ain't Misbehavin','' a revival of the 1978 musical celebrating the music of Fats Waller, will close after the Sunday matinee on Jan. 15, at the Ambassador Theater. The show, which was directed by Richard Maltby Jr., will have had 8 previews and 176 regular performances.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MAI Details Drexel Link
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. today disclosed new details of its relationship with the embattled investment banking firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Raimondi Cancels
description: Ruggero Raimondi, the bass who was to sing in the ''Pavarotti Plus ... Plus!'' concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday at 8 P.M., has dropped out because of illness. Paul Plishka will take his place in the ensemble pieces requiring a bass. The performance is to be broadcast by the public television on ''Live from Lincoln Center'' and simulcast locally on WNCN radio (104.3 FM).

title: '88 Decline in U.S. Executions Defies Predictions
description: Fewer criminals were executed in the United States in 1988 than in any of the previous five years despite a 1987 Supreme Court decision that prompted predictions that the tide of executions would rise.

title: School Bus Driver in Drug Arrest
description: A school bus driver taking a 4-year-old girl home from nursery school in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday afternoon when he stopped the bus to buy crack, the police said.

title: SON OF 2 RECLUSES IS DISCOVERED DEAD
description: A 14-year-old boy has died of starvation and his parents and sister are under treatment for malnutrition in a case some people here link to the family's belief that God would take care of all their needs.

title: MGI Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said its gains from the sale of real estate investments in 1988 were $3,024,000, or 39 cents a share, with gains of $3,749,000, or 48 cents a share, in the prior year.

title: Recognition Spurns Prospect Group
description: Recognition Equipment Inc., the postal equipment company that has been indicted in a scandal involving Federal contracts, rejected an acquisition proposal from the Prospect Group, a New York-based investment group. Prospect, which has recently increased its ownership in Recognition, made a conditional proposal to buy the outstanding shares of Recognition for $12.75 a share in a Dec. 14 letter to the equipment company's board.

title: California's Deukmejian Says He Won't Seek a Third Term
description: Gov. George Deukmejian announced today that he would not seek a third term in 1990, saying that he wants to return to private life for ''new challenges.''

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Monday about books inspired by the Joel B. Steinberg and Bess Myerson trials described ''The Dark Side of 10th Street'' by Maury Terry incorrectly.

title: Drug Emporium Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Creative Star Is Joining Hill, Holliday
description: JOHN FERRELL, the creative prodigy whose demotion and subsequent departure from Young & Rubicam last fall stunned the advertising industry, is joining the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos as executive vice president and chief creative officer.

title: Oil Prices Stage a Rebound On Reports of Tight Supplies
description: Crude oil prices bounced back yesterday, reflecting reports of a possible squeeze in deliveries of North Sea oil in the London market and expectations that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other producers might agree to further steps to reduce output.

title: Sammie Smith Exits
description: Sammie Smith, the Florida State junior tailback whose 115 yards rushing made him the most valuable player in the 13-7 victory over Auburn in the Sugar Bowl, said yesterday that he would apply for the National Football League draft. Smith, whose freshman class will graduate this spring, was the Seminoles' leading rusher the last two seasons. His 1,230 yards in 1987 established the school's season rushing record, and his career total of 2,539 yards is the third highest. (AP)

title: The Right Goal
description: A Canute-like law commands the Federal budget deficit to stop at $100 billion in fiscal 1990. So a new President and a new Congress are about to take office hell-bent on reducing the deficit for that year by $27 billion to $41 billion, depending on whose economic estimates are accepted.

title: Is the Underclass Beyond Help?
description: LEAD: The word ''underclass'' has come into wide usage by the media, politicians and academics in the past five years. It refers to the isolated, mostly minority population of distressed crime-ridden inner city areas. There are two popular misconceptions about this underclass: that we could solve the problem with dispatch if we just had the will to do so, and that what we need is ''new ideas'' to bring this about.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Oracle Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Miller, Herman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: The latest 6-month results included net of $3,300,000, or 13 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Islanders Overcome Bruins With 5 Goals in Second Period
description: Brent Sutter, who normally suffers through his post-game analyses of Islander games this season, basked in this one and even allowed some nostalgia for shinier seasons to temper his recollections of tonight's 5-3 victory over the Bruins.

title: Panel Lines Up Some Glitter For Eve of the Inauguration
description: The co-chairmen of the committee mapping the activities surrounding President-elect George Bush's inauguration announced a number of plans today, including agreement by Bob Hope and Chuck Yeager to serve as grand marshals in the inaugural parade.

title: Toyota Wins Round in Court
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation today won a skirmish with the Mead Corporation over the use of the name Lexus for its new luxury car, and then displayed two models of the new, high-priced car line at the North American International Auto Show here. The United States Court of

title: Ex-Insider Who Elects To Remain on Outside
description: At a moment of political transition, when legions of potential officeholders are cajoling, conspiring or cudgeling their way toward the inner circles of power, former Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. shows every sign of digging in firmly on the outside.

title: Datamag Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
On-Line Software Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included for the year two non- recurring gains and two non-recurring expenses which, when combined, resulted in after-tax expense of $1,005,000, or $1,547,000 before tax benefit; the latest periods included extraordinary gains of $531,000 for the quarter and $1,841,000 for the 6 months, both after taxes. c-Net income and included an extraordinary gain, net of tax, of $154,000. Prior-year amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current presentation.

title: Keep Family Planning Free of Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: Healthcare Compare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Our Towns; Don't Build Here: The Fine Points Of Foot-Dragging
description: New Jersey's Mount Laurel housing plan is probably the most painless way to build low- and moderate-income housing in suburban America. Developed after 12 years of court battles, the state plan sets a quota of subsidized units for each suburb. But it doesn't cost the suburb a cent. The builder pays for it. And builders love it. They make more profit.

title: United Tote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $207,862 from an accounting change. c-Included an extraordinary gain of $45,515.

title: A Last Hurrah
description: The Washington establishment is preparing a last hurrah for George P. Shultz at the State Department Monday night. Among those expected to join in honoring the Secretary of State at cocktails and dinner are Henry A. Kissinger, William P. Rogers and Edmund S. Muskie, all of whom held the top Cabinet office, along with members of Congress, the diplomatic corps and such familiar foreign policy establishment figures as David Rockefeller, Sol M. Linowitz, Andrew J. Goodpaster and Paul H. Nitze.

title: Oklahoma Assails N.C.A.A. Immunity for Dykes
description: Hart Lee Dykes, the Oklahoma State wide receiver who could reportedly figure in probations handed to four college football programs by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, ''is making a mockery of the N.C.A.A. system'' by receiving immunity for his testimony, a University of Oklahoma official said today.

title: ReviewFilm; Love, and Discord, Between Sisters in Liverpool
description: Liverpool, 1944. The world is upside down, what with noisy, brawling, well-fed Yanks everywhere, throwing cigarettes and nylons around and acting as if they owned the place. The very proper Nellie (Joan Plowright) doesn't like it. Her thin lips permanently pursed, Nellie watches as giggly girls parade the streets, being pawed by American servicemen. ''Without shame or decency'' says Nellie, with pride in her own unchallenged rectitude.

title: Thanks From Armenia
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Acts to Lift a Hauler's License
