description: In the first major crackdown on violators of the state's costly year-old garbage-disposal rules, the Board of Public Utilities has voted to ban a hauler from operating in the state.

title: The Mahres Return, This Time as Pros
description: Professional ski racing lumbered along for about 20 years with only a few recognizable stars and little spectator interest. This season, that changed after Phil and Steve Mahre, the American Olympic medalists, joined the pro circuit.

title: Punitive Damages Strike at Intent to Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Producer of Pop Music Buys Stake in Chrysalis
description: David Geffen, a Los Angeles-based producer of films, pop music and Broadway theater, has expanded his holdings to Britain. Mr. Geffen, 45, has acquired an 8.4 percent stake in the Chrysalis Group, a financially troubled entertainment company.

title: Half a Billion for One Plane
description: The Pentagon's sophisticated new weapons are often criticized as gold-plated. Not the B-2, the Air Force's latest bomber. Forget plate: the aircraft costs nearly its weight in solid gold. Last month, on his final day as Secretary of the Air Force, Edward Aldridge said that each B-2 Stealth bomber will cost $516 million. That's nearly twice the staggering $280 million price tag of the B-1 bomber.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jazz at J's

title: On Stage
description: Newcomers In New Play

title: Can Courts Put a Price on the Enjoyment of Life?
description: When Emma McDougald entered the New York Infirmary 10 years ago to deliver her second child, she was a healthy 31-year-old who worked as a subway token clerk, managed her household and was planning to return to college.

title: Bengals' Wilson Arrested
description: Stanley Wilson, the Bengals' often-troubled running back who was suspended for the entire 1987 season for substance abuse, was arrested early this morning and charged with disorderly conduct.

title: Irvin Shapiro, 82, Distributor of Films By Foreign Directors
description: Irvin Shapiro, a film importer and distributor who introduced many notable foreign movies to the United States, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Sunday at his home in New York. He was 82 years old.

title: Europe Fires A New Shot In Trade War
description: The European Community said today that American walnuts and dried prunes, peaches, apricots and papayas would be subject to punitive tariffs if its trade dispute with the United States was not settled soon.

title: Mr. Stein's Strange Arithmetic
description: Andrew Stein, the New York City Council president, misleads the public about the true costs of his refusal to participate in the city's new public campaign financing system. He claims it will hold down the cost of an unpopular reform. In fact, it will trigger higher spending, while restoring the influence of wealthy donors.

title: Treasury Issues Continue to Dip
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped again in moderate trading yesterday as market participants awaited this morning's release of December employment data.

title: Undefeated Harvard Faces Tough Tests
description: With the holiday pause at an end, college hockey now jumps into an eight-week period that will determine which teams will go to the post-season tournaments.

title: F.D.A. Panel Finds No Need for Change In Taking of the Pill
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration said today that no changes in the use of birth control pills or in warning labels on the pills are warranted despite new evidence suggesting that use of the pill may increase the risk of breast cancer.

title: Airlines Ordered to Install Devices to Avert Collisions
description: All planes that carry more than 30 passengers must have collision-warning devices by the end of 1991, under a rule the Government issued yesterday.

title: Newest Arrivals for the New Year
description: IF cities had official mottos, ''What's new?'' might well be the most fitting phrase for the five boroughs of New York. Change is so permanent a feature of city life that one almost expects yesterday's parking lot to be tomorrow's skyscraper and the nondescript coffee shop one visited last month to become the fashionable restaurant or trendy discotheque that opens next week. As the new year begins, it seems a particularly good time to take stock of some of the most recent additions to this landscape-in-motion, and to list a few establishments that are to make their debuts in the coming weeks. Six of the many nightclubs, restaurants, shops, art galleries, performance spaces and other items added to the city's cultural inventory are shown here, and eight more appear on page C28. Hall of South American Peoples

title: Officer Removed Badge At Melee, Police Assert
description: A 32-year-old New York City police officer was suspended yesterday and ordered to face trial on a departmental charge that he removed his badge during a melee last summer at Tompkins Square Park.

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan Backs Pay Raise

title: The Singer Madonna Again Files for Divorce
description: The actor Sean Penn and Madonna, the singer, have separated and are planning to end their three-year marriage, a spokesman for Mr. Penn said today.

title: Samuel T. Carter 3d, Author, Is Dead at 84
description: Samuel T. Carter 3d, a radio and television writer who retired to write on American history, died of cancer Dec. 28 at the Ponperaug Woods Health Center in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived in Heritage Village.

title: Fur Vault Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net income

title: The lonely view from the bench for the new judge who must undergo a rite of passage
description: The new judge, clad in a T-shirt and shorts, walked past a couple of lawyers at a local health club. Only a few years ago, he knew, both of his one-time bar brethren would have ignored him. ''Good evening, your Honor,'' said one, thinking he was leaving. In fact, the judge was only going to the Nautilus machine, and when he emerged a few minutes later he passed them again. ''Good evening, your Honor,'' the lawyer unctuously repeated.

title: 9 Are Convicted of Extortion On Restaurant Inspections
description: Six New York City health inspectors and three restaurant consultants were convicted yesterday of extorting thousands of dollars from restaurant owners by threatening to cite them for violations or close them.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums AFRICAN AMERICAN FESTIVAL, a program of music and colorful costumes by the Universal Language Ensemble, 1 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street. Tickets: children and the elderly, $2.50; others, $5. Information: 777-3240. ''PINOCCHIO,'' a musical comedy presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1 and 2:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''THE ALL AMERICAN BUG SHOW,'' a program of mime, dance and fantasy by Annie Hickman, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic and comedy show, with audience participation, presented by Brian McGovern and Imam, 2 P.M. Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Braniff's purchase of aircraft from Airbus Industrie described a transaction involving Pan American World Airways incorrectly. Airbus and International Aero Engines paid $115 million, plus the return of Pan Am's deposit, for the right to assign the order and options to Braniff.

title: 'Xanadu/The Millions'
description: Storytelling, music and dance will be combined in ''Xanadu/The Millions,'' presented by Mark Taylor and Friends tonight through Sunday at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. Suggested by the story of Marco Polo, the multi-media piece was choreographed by Mr. Taylor to a score for percussion and amplified cello, composed and played at each performance by Elise Tobin. The spoken text for the dance is taken from ''Invisible Cities,'' a novel by Italo Calvino. Performances are at 9 P.M. Admission is $8; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations and information: 477-5288.

title: S.E.C. Review on Lawyer
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission decided yesterday to review the decision of a Federal administrative law judge in the case against George C. Kern Jr., a prominent takeover lawyer.

title: Rev. Charles T. Fritsch, A Biblical Scholar, 76
description: The Rev. Dr. Charles T. Fritsch, a biblical scholar and former professor of Old Testament literature at Princeton Theological Seminary, died Monday at his home in Jamesburg, N.J., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Lindsay Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Man Executed in Missouri for Killing Waitress
description: A convicted killer was put to death by injection early today for the murder of a tavern waitress, becoming the first Missouri inmate executed since 1965.

title: Lockheed Contract
description: The Navy awarded the Lockheed Corporation a $52 million contract to build two prototypes of a new submarine-hunting patrol plane, indicating that the project cleared an internal Pentagon review. In October, after a spirited competition, the Navy selected Lockheed to develop a modernized version of its P-3C Orion antisubmarine airplane. But at the time the Navy said it would not award a contract for full-scale development until ''after formal review of the program by the Department of Defense.''

title: FOR STALIN PURGES, YET MORE CRITICISM
description: The Communist Party called today for the mass rehabilitation of Soviet citizens convicted by the summary courts that carried out Stalin's purges.

title: Allwaste Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TV Weekend; U.S.-Soviet Relations
description: ''The Eagle and the Bear,'' a 26-part weekly series on the cold war that begins at 8 tonight on the Arts & Entertainment cable network, is chronologically jumpy. The first episode starts, reasonably, with the end of World War II and of the United States-Soviet wartime alliance. In the second episode, we are in Korea a couple of years later. So far, logic prevails. But then, in episode 3, we are carried ahead to Berlin in 1961, and a week later to Grenada in 1983. Subsequent half-hours play hopscotch, returning to Berlin and Korea and visiting Cuba in time for the missile crisis of 1961, Greece during its civil war in the 1940's and Afghanistan in 1979.

title: Israeli Civilian Killed in the West Bank
description: An Israeli man was found killed in the West Bank on Thursday night, and Jewish settlers tried to raid nearby Arab villages in revenge, Israel radio said. But troops ejected the settlers and blocked roads into Arab areas.

title: Judge Rules Economic Panel Can't Hold Meetings in Secret
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the National Economic Commission, a blue-ribbon panel on cutting the budget deficit, may not conduct its deliberations in secret.

title: Strong December Sales Reported by Retailers
description: The nation's largest retailers yesterday reported strong December sales, registering an average gain of 10 percent above the previous Christmas season.

title: New Flaws Are Discovered at Nuclear Arms Plant
description: Engineers working to repair reactors at the nation's most important nuclear weapons plant encountered more potentially serious structural weaknesses today that could cause further delay in producing tritium, a vital ingredient of atomic weapons.

title: Review/Film; A Hunger for Wisdom
description: ''36 Fillette'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4. The film, which is in French with English subtitles, opens today at Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: 3 States Cope With Slump In Revenues
description: Already in this very young year, the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have warned that they may be forced to cut services and freeze spending because tax revenues are falling short, even as their states' economies remain strong.

title: Review/Art; The Possibilities of Line at the Nolan Gallery
description: Given that line is the primary vehicle of drawing, a trip to the David Nolan Gallery, by whatever means available, is in order. On view is an exhibition that traces the evolution of an eccentric linear drawing style in the work of Rudi Troger, born in 1929 and a teacher at the Academy of Fine Arts in Munich, and two of his students, Erwin Pfrang and Franz Gunzel. Born in 1951 and 1956, respectively. Mr. Pfrang and Mr. Gunzel remain, as their art attests, close friends.

title: TCBY Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
National Medical Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Cocaine Blamed in Bus Deaths
description: A bus accident last May that killed three people and injured 19 others was caused by the bus driver, Louis Taylor, 45 years old, who was high on cocaine, according to Dutchess County prosecutors. Mr. Taylor is charged with manslaughter in the deaths of the victims, who were mentally handicapped adults. ''In a nutshell, this guy got high on coke and drove like a maniac,'' said Howard Lewis, a prosecutor.

title: John Tower Has Malignant Polyp Removed
description: John G. Tower, who has been chosen by George Bush to be Secretary of Defense, had a malignant polyp removed from his rectum last week in Dallas, a hospital spokeswoman said today.

title: Armenians Raise a Glass to All Those Who Cared
description: Normally on this day, Christmas Eve on the Armenian Church calendar, the Arutunyan family would have invited friends and relatives for a joyous feast and exchange of gifts. And the next day they would have gone to the cemetery to remember the dead.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Philip D. Tobin, a labor lawyer and former Mayor of Tuckahoe, N.Y., omitted the identity of a principal client. Mr. Tobin was counsel for the Newspaper Guild of New York.

title: Lojack Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about Ira D. London, the lawyer for Joel B. Steinberg, misidentified a New York University law professor who commented on legal ethics. He is Stephen Gillers, not Villers.

title: Review/Art; Esthetics of Comfort
description: He was ''Coddy'' to her. She was ''Pussy'' to him. They were friends, colleagues, collaborators. Between them, they had an immense influence on the way certain people wanted to live. In New York, in Boston, in Newport, R.I., in the Berkshires and on Long Island, their ideas were law, more or less, for those who did not blanch at the tab.

title: Magee Shows He Belongs In Champions' Tourney
description: Andrew Magee admits that he was intimidated by the big-name players while spending the last four years earning his spurs on the PGA Tour. He remembers the first time he played with Jack Nicklaus when he was a rookie.

title: Florida Schedules Still in Conflict
description: Last year, the Florida Legislature thought it had come up with a clever settlement to the endless war among the Miami area's three throughbred tracks over prime winter racing dates.

title: Paris Broker Stake To Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation has agreed to take a 49 percent stake in Didier Philippe S.A., a French stockbroker. Didier Philippe said in a statement that the bank would not take any role in running the brokerage and that its current directors would retain control.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 The United States wants Soviet help in pressing Libya to cease operations at a chemical plant that Washington says will be used to make chemical weapons, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. Page A1

title: Bird Return Nears
description: Larry Bird's recovery from surgery on his heels last Nov. 19 is ahead of schedule and he will probably return to the lineup before March 1, the Boston Celtics' team physician, Dr. Arnold Scheller, said yesterday. ''There's no buildup of scar tissue, but right now we've got to work on getting the strength back in his calf muscles,'' Scheller said. ''He still will need two to three weeks of practice, so we want to take it nice and easy.'' (AP)

title: A Correction
description: An article on Wednesday incompletely identified a West German company allegedly involved in illegal shipments of nuclear materials to third world countries. The company is Alfred Hempel KG GmbH & Company of Dusseldorf, not the F. W. Hempel Company Inc., also of Dusseldorf.

title: Grafton Journal; Library's Name Brings Talk of Anti-Semitism
description: Wintertime in this quiet town frequently finds children gliding uneventfully on ice skates across the frozen Milwaukee River while their parents keep warm over coffee cups in local diners, often hashing over the latest high school basketball game. Residents acknowledge that news that makes headlines here might seem mundane to those in the big cities - news of a new library, perhaps.

title: Clash Off Libya Arouses Concern in Europe
description: The downing of two Libyan jet fighters has sharpened concerns among America's Western European allies that the Reagan Administration could be preparing for a military strike against a Libyan chemical plant.

title: TV Weekend; Harold Prince's 'Butterfly'
description: Harold Prince has collected a record 16 Tony Awards for his stage productions over the years, most recently for ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' Somewhat less well known is his work in opera. He staged, for instance, Carlisle Floyd's ''Willie Stark'' for the Houston Grand Opera. And on tap are ''Don Giovanni'' for the New York City Opera and ''Faust'' for the Metropolitan Opera. A representative sample of his opera work can be seen on this evening's ''Great Performances,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock. It's Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' which Mr. Prince directed for the Lyric Opera of Chicago.

title: Bishop Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Fiscal 1988 loss included $2,040,000 of non-recurring repositioning costs recognized in the third quarter, which resulted from management's programs designed to reverse operating loss trends and return the company to profitability.

title: DISCLOSURE OF SECRETS FEARED
description: The independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case today moved to dismiss the main criminal charges against Oliver L. North, saying concern over the use of secret Government documents as evidence made a trial on those charges impossible.

title: Roosevelt I. Landmarks Are New York History
description: To the Editor:

title: This Is the Team That Embry Built
description: No joke. The Cleveland Cavaliers, once the comic relief of the National Basketball Association, now have the best record in the league.

title: Correction
description: An obituary yesterday about a professor of economics and former academic vice president at Suffolk County Community College in New York misidentified him. The professor, who died on Wednesday, was John J. Saal, not Faal.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Smoking on the Premises

title: Iran-Contra Events Span the Reagan Era
description: Aug. 4, 1981 Maj. Oliver L. North of the Marine Corps is assigned to duty at the White House with the National Security Council. December 1981 President Reagan signs a ''finding'' authorizing a covert Central Intelligence Agency operation to support the Nicaraguan rebels, or contras. December 1982 The first Boland amendment becomes law barring use of Federal money to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua. Various versions of the amendment are in effect until October 1986. Spring 1983 North is assigned by N.S.C. superiors as the White House link to the contras. February 1985 Using a series of dummy corporations in Switzerland and elsewhere, North, now a lieutenant colonel, and two associates, Richard V. Secord and Albert Hakim, make the first of six purchases of arms for the contras. Money comes from a secret $24 million contribution by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. North and his associates eventually spend $16.5 million for military aid for the contras. Hakim, Secord and a third associate, Thomas C. Clines, will retain for themselves $4.4 million in commissions. Summer 1985 Press accounts link North to a private network supplying military aid to the contras. North suggests to his N.S.C. superior, Robert C. McFarlane, that he rewrite secret White House documents to conceal his role in the contra aid effort. McFarlane rejects the suggestion, but later tells Congress that North ''did not solicit funds or other support for military or paramilitary activities.'' Early July 1985 Israeli Government officials tell McFarlane that Iran wishes to open a ''political discourse'' with the United States, an overture that soon leads to the first shipment of American arms to Iran and the release of an American hostage. July 1985 Secord agrees to begin an airlift operation to supply the contras. Nov. 19, 1985 North is drafted by McFarlane to handle logistics for a second shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. He turns to Secord, telling him in a letter that his ''discrete'' assistance is again required ''in support of our national interest.'' The North-Secord-Hakim network ferrying arms to the contras assumes a role as the agent for future secret shipments of American arms to Iran. April 4, 1986 In a memorandum, North outlines a plan to have $12 million in profits from the Iran arms sales diverted to the contras. The memo is prepared for John M. Poindexter, who has succeeded McFarlane as NSC adviser, to relay to the President. Poindexter later testifies that he never showed the memo to the President. May 25, 1986 McFarlane, North and other American officials fly to Teheran, carrying spare parts for Iran's Hawk antiaircraft missiles. They spend four days meeting with Iranian officials, unsuccessfuly trying to win the release of all the American hostages. Aug. 6, 1986 North meets with 11 members of the House Intelligence Committee and denies raising money for the contras or offering them military advice. Later North testifies that he lied in this session. Oct. 5, 1986 A cargo plane carrying arms to the contras, part of the North-Secord resupply operation, is shot down over Nicaragua. Three crewmen are killed and a fourth is captured. Nov. 3-6, 1986 Press accounts say the United States sent arms to Iran. Nov. 12-19, 1986 North and other White House officials prepare increasingly inaccurate chronologies of events in the Iran affair. Nov. 21, 1986 North is told that Justice Department officials will inspect his files the next day, and he begins shredding documents. Nov. 22, 1986 Justice Department officials discover in North's office an April 1986 memo to the President that mentions the diversion of Iran-arms sale money to the contras. Nov. 23, 1986 North meets privately with McFarlane and assures him that the diversion of arms money was approved by the White House. North meets with Attorney General Meese and tells him there was a diversion of funds. Nov. 24, 1986 Meese goes to the White House and tells the President of the diversion. Nov. 25, 1986 Meese announces the diversion of money from the Iran arms sales to the contras. President announces Poindexter's resignation and North's dismissal. July 7, 1987 Under a grant of limited immunity, North begins six days of televised testimony before the Congressional committees investigating the affair. He says he has no idea if the President had any knowledge of the diversion of funds to the contras. He also says that William Casey approved the diversion and that the arms sales were originally intended as an exchange for the hostages. Jan. 19, 1988 The Supreme Court upholds the prosecutorial power of Lawrence M. Walsh, the special prosecutor, in the Iran-contra criminal inquiry. March 16, 1988 North, Poindexter, Secord and Hakim are indicted on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by illegally providing the contras with funds from the sale of American weapons to Iran. March 18, 1988 North resigns from the Marine Corps and says he might subpoena ''the highest-ranking officials of our Government'' to defend himself against criminal charges. June 8, 1988 Judge orders that North and his three co-defendants be tried separately. Nov. 21, 1988 Judge says he will grant North's lawyers ''wide latitude'' to cross-examine Government witnesses about ''involvement in sensitive matters.'' Nov. 30, 1988 White House announces that it intends to stop the release of secret documents North wants to use in his defense. Dec. 1, 1988 President rules out a pardon for North, but says the White House has a ''duty'' to withhold certain classified documents. Dec. 12, 1988 Judge rejects bulk of the defense's demand to use 30,000 pages of secret documents as evidence. Gives defense attorneys until Jan. 3 to select 300 classified documents for public disclosure in the trial. Dec. 21, 1988 Judge sets Jan. 31, as date of North's trial. Dec. 30, 1988 Reagan and Vice President Bush are subpoenaed to testify as defense witnesses. Jan. 5, 1989 Walsh asks the court to dismiss the two main charges against North because of the problems over the use of classified documents.

title: Israel Approves $550 Million in Budget Cuts
description: A proposal by Finance Minister Shimon Peres to reduce the Israeli Government budget by $550 million was approved tonight by the Israeli Cabinet.

title: Intermetrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included tax benefits of $180,000 for the quarter and $655,000 for the 9 months. c-Included tax benefits of $228,000 and $550,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Costco Wholesale Corp reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 20
description: b-Included a net gain of $1,160,000 on retirement of subordinated debentures and a tax loss carryforward of $771,000.

title: Dexter Masters, 80, British Editor; Warned of Perils of Atomic Age
description: Dexter Masters, a writer and an editor, died of bronchial pneumonia at St. John's Hospice in Springfield, Ill., yesterday. He was 80 years old and lived in Totnes, England.

title: Nichols Research reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $700 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities.

title: Applied Power Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a $450,000 tax credit. The latest quarter included $1,700,000 pre-tax allowance for one- time costs associated with redirecting manufacturing and warehousing operations. It also included a $2,400,000 pre-tax gain on the sale of land near Tokyo.

title: Audiovisual Madrigal
description: ''Salt 40,'' a work about 40 years of conflict in Israel, by Kei Okada, is to be perfomred at Franklin Furnace, 112 Franklin Street, tonight at 8:30. Mr. Okada, a Japanese composer living in New York, has described the piece as an audiovisual madrigal. It is also to be performed tomorrow evening at 8:30. Tickets are $8. Information: 925-4671.

title: Oliver North: Still Accountable
description: Oliver North, the man at the heart of the Iran-contra affair, has cut the heart out of the criminal case against him. The special Federal prosecutor, after struggling to reconcile the needs of national security with the demands of a public trial, has decided that he must drop the major conspiracy and theft charges against the former National Security Council staff officer. It's a heavy loss for justice, denying the public a test of whether Iran-contra was a criminal conspiracy, as well as reckless and duplicitous.

title: Bonn Clears Company of Libyan Role
description: Government investigators said today that they had found no evidence of illegal exports by a West German chemical company that Washington has accused of helping build a chemical weapons plant in Libya.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Society, relatives and those close to the victims await the full rehabilitation of all innocently repressed and the perpetuation of their memory.'' - Soviet party declaration on victims of Stalin's purges. [ A6:2. ]

title: Reviews/Dance; Exploring the Boundaries Of Frivolity and Ferocity
description: The New York City Ballet presented a program that probed extremes of light and darkness on Wednesday at the New York State Theater.

title: '1992' Architect To Advise Firm
description: Lord Cockfield, who stepped down today as vice president of the European Community, will become a consultant and special adviser on European affairs to Peat Marwick McLintock & Company, Britain's largest firm of accountants and management consultants.

title: Pan Am Crash Inspires Gifts to the Neediest
description: In memory of the victims of the explosion of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland, Fred Halden of Teaneck, N.J., sent $25 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Seeing Double at Adolfo: Never Too Much of a Good Thing
description: Adolfo's spring and summer clothes, shown yesterday, looked both slicker and softer than usual as the designer continued his long-term hommage to Chanel.

title: INDICTMENT IS SEEN IN PENTAGON CASE
description: A Federal grand jury in Virginia is expected to announce on Friday the first indictment in a broad investigation of accusations of bribery and fraud involving Pentagon officials, the Justice Department said today.

title: Man Charged in Death Of a 14-Year-Old Boy
description: A Brooklyn man was charged with homicide yesterday in the death of a 14-year-old student, Jeffrey Vilain, who was caught in the middle of a gun battle between a police officer and a suspected robber in the East Flatbush section.

title: Highway's Demise: Nightmare for Drivers
description: The rusting, rotting remains of a portion of the West Side Highway are about to get the burial they have so long deserved. Starting in March, a 14-block stretch of the viaduct, moribund for years, will be torn down and hauled away.

title: 'He's Got a Missile Off,' Followed by 'Good Kill'
description: A Navy cockpit tape of the confrontation between American and Libyan jet fighters offers only flashes of video images, but provides in sound the drama of American aviators unexpectedly caught up in combat.

title: Meadowlands to Open
description: Harness racing will return to the Meadowlands at 7:30 tonight as a 194-night meeting opens at the track in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Into the Woods
description: With Congress in recess until Jan. 20, it is junket time again and one of the more unusual journeys will take five Senators and two Representatives into a tropical rain forest next week.

title: Critics Say New York Can Do More on Child Abuse
description: Child-abuse experts, reacting to Mayor Edward I. Koch's statement that his administration could not have prevented most child-abuse and neglect deaths last year, say New York City could do a far more effective job of protecting children.

title: Sikes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
White Supremacist Guilty
description: A Federal jury today found a white supremacist guilty of conspiring to violate a family's civil rights. The defendant, Gary Skillman, 24 years old, was convicted of of using force and the threat of force to intimidate the family and of burning a cross outside the family's home in Orange County. The crimes carry a maximum sentence of 21 years.

title: Jefferies Says He Destroyed Notes on Trades
description: Boyd L. Jefferies, an important Government witness in several securities fraud cases, testified yesterday that shortly before entering a plea-bargaining agreement in 1987 he destroyed many of his notes about his trading patterns and discussions with clients.

title: Less Is Still Enough For Depleted Bears
description: In 1985, the Chicago Bears steamrollered the opposition almost every week en route to an impressive victory in Super Bowl XX. Now a Bears team with less firepower, less talent and many more injuries is struggling and usually winning.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Other Dirty Dozen

title: New Director at Photography Museum
description: The International Museum of Photography at George Eastman House in Rochester announced yesterday that James Enyeart will become its director on April 15. He succeeds Robert A. Mayer, whose resignation was made public Wednesday.

title: Soviets Curbing Private Businesses
description: The Soviet Government has sent a wave of alarm through the growing private business sector with sweeping new limits on a range of private businesses, including medical care, publishing, film making, video salons, schools, concert booking and the manufacture of religious artifacts.

title: Global Trade System Gains
description: As expected, the governors of the New York Mercantile Exchange voted late Wednesday night to join Globex, an electronic futures trading system developed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters Ltd. The system is designed to afford traders around the globe access to both markets after their normal trading hours.

title: The Arafat Murder Threat
description: Consider the following sequence of events.

title: Enron Subsidiary In L.I. Gas Accord
description: Enron Gas Marketing Inc., a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation, signed a 15-year $150 million agreement to supply natural gas to a co-generation plant to be constructed in Uniondale, L.I., as part of the Nassau District Energy System, which supplies power on Long Island.

title: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
John E. Lawe, 69, the President Of the Transport Union, Is Dead
description: John E. Lawe, president of the Transport Workers Union of America since 1985 and before that president of Local 100, which represents New York City's subway and bus employees, died of complications from cancer of the esophagus yesterday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 69 years old.

title: U.N. HEARS DEFENSE IN DOWNING OF JETS
description: The United States presented photographs of what it said were armed Libyan fighter planes to the Security Council today in support of its contention that American pilots acted in self defense in shooting down the Libyan planes.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about budget problems facing New York, New Jersey and Connecticut characterized Connecticut's response incorrectly.

title: Northwest Air Turns the Corner
description: When a Northwest Airlines flight arrived late here recently, a passenger who missed his ride home asked the carrier to reimburse him for the $6 taxi ride. Ron Dahm, a customer service supervisor, approved the request on the spot.

title: Man Found Dead in His Car Was Wanted in L.I. Killing
description: A man being sought on charges of killing his former wife - who had obtained a protective order against him - was found shot to death this afternoon at a rest stop on the Long Island Expressway, the authorities said. He had apparently committed suicide.

title: Satellite's Nuclear Risks Discounted
description: The space agency said today that the risk of a nuclear accident will be only slight when it launches an interplanetary satellite carrying a plutonium power plant later this year from the space shuttle Atlantis.

title: Home Banking By Computer Hasn't Made Paper Obsolete
description: Despite the continuing optimism of some bankers, banking at home with a personal computer has not come anywhere near its potential.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet's Answer to 'Unanswered Question'
description: ''The Unanswered Question,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Thursday at the New York State Theater, has been a prickly addition to the company's repertory. The piece, created by Eliot Feld for City Ballet's American Music Festival last spring, demands dramatic presence rather than virtuoso dancing from its performers.

title: Inmates Interview Author About Dr. King
description: In Unit C-73 on Rikers Island during the noon hour yesterday, one of the first questions the inmates asked Taylor Branch was: What prompted you, a white man, to write a book about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.?

title: Lilly Industrial Coatings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The latest periods' share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August 1988.

title: Consumer Complaints on Airlines At the Lowest Level in Four Years
description: The number of consumer complaints against airlines in the United States fell in December to the lowest level in four years, the Department of Transportation said Thursday.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Dow Up 3.75 for Third Straight Gain
description: LEAD: Stock prices rose yesterday for the third straight session, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at a new post-crash high after toying with 2,200.

title: Greece Scrutinized Extradition Request
description: To the Editor:

title: A Leader Who Took Japan to War, to Surrender, and Finally to Peace
description: Emperor Hirohito reigned over not one Japan, but three: a Japan consumed with militarism almost from the time he took over the Chrysanthemum Throne, a Japan that lay in ruins at the end of World War II and seemed destined for years of occupation and dependency, and finally a Japan that, from the shambles of defeat, achieved in peacetime global economic power.

title: Bonn Seems To Reverse Dollar View
description: The dollar surged again yesterday, powered by an apparent change of stance by the West German central bank that left some currency traders wondering what was going on.

title: Chip Industry Is Planning A Health Study at Factories
description: The nation's semiconductor industry said today that it would begin a comprehensive health study of its workers to determine whether working in a computer chip factory is hazardous.

title: Soviets Dispute U.S. Assertion On Libya Plant
description: The Soviet Union implied today that the United States had no proof for its assertion that Libya had built a chemical weapons plant.

title: Attendants Forced Cancellation of Flight
description: Flight attendants at Newark International Airport forced United Air Lines to cancel a Los Angeles-bound flight on Tuesday night when they learned of a sabotage threat shortly before the 198 passengers boarded.

title: A Soviet Official Issues A Vow on Afghanistan
description: The Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister promised today that Soviet troops would be out of Afghanistan by Feb. 15, an Afghan guerrilla leader said after meeting with him.

title: Liability Cap in Crash May Not Apply to All
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Health System's Problems Resist Quick or Inexpensive Solutions
description: New York City's health-care system is in the midst of a crisis for which few quick, inexpensive or painless remedies are available.

title: MBS Textbook Exchange reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
It's Bad Enough Without Bashing Calcutta
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Method to Repair Teeth Offers Less Discomfort
description: Howard Cohen, an orthodontist in Woodmere, L.I., has invented a way to repair chipped and broken teeth more easily and with less discomfort to the patient.

title: About New York; Along Avenue J, Cowpokes Bust Bucking Broncos
description: Molded fiberglass dinosaurs and baby-sized spaceships with convertible tops still gently toss juvenile riders for 25 cents a turn along the old shopping district of Avenue J in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Difficult Issues Emerge On Canada-U.S. Trade
description: When Gary Timmerman returned from a shopping trip to Chicago he became an example of the misconceptions and disappointments that have sprung up since the free trade agreement between the United Sates and Canada took effect last weekend.

title: Dukakis Delivers Fiery Speech
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis inspired liberal followers and irked conservative critics with a suprisingly fiery State of the State Speech Thursday night. Mr. Dukakis lashed out at his opponents as ''gutless wonders'' and said ''baloney'' to those who accuse the state of overspending. Republican leaders and conservative Democrats said they found some of the Governor's remarks bitter and even tasteless. Most agreed that Mr. Dukakis was signaling his determination to push for new taxes to make up a shortage oin the state's budget.

title: Queens and Brooklyn Give Subway Improvements Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabot Medical Corp. reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $103,000 resulting from the retiring of a promissory note at a discount.

title: Westerbeke Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Television; 'Cops' Camera Shows the Real Thing
description: You want to be a star? Join the police force. At least that seems to be the message Fox Broadcasting is delivering as the Rupert Murdoch organization pounces mercilessly on ''reality'' programming.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: '88 Jobless Rates in New York And Jersey Drop to '69 Level
description: Unemployment rates rose slightly in New York State and New Jersey last month, but the annual rates for the two states dropped to levels not matched in 19 years, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: CVN Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Polaroid Stock Plan Upheld; Setback for Shamrock Seen
description: The Delaware Chancery Court today determined that the Polaroid Corporation's employee stock ownership plan was valid, a ruling that appears to be a setback to Roy E. Disney's takeover bid for the film and camera company.

title: Collapse of North Case: Back to Basics
description: Beneath the weighty invocations of national security, the complex requirements of the Classified Information Procedures Act and the exalted titles of those whose fortunes were to some degree at stake, the case against Oliver L. North foundered this week on one of the simplest, most basic propositions of the American legal system: that a person accused of breaking the law has the right to the evidence necessary to defend himself fully and in public.

title: Wayward Bus Trip in Libya Avoids Factory
description: Several dozen journalists boarded two buses here this morning for what they thought would be a trip to the chemical plant that is the center of a dispute between Libya and the United States.

title: Contractor Disciplines 17
description: The Sundstrand Corporation, the military contractor that agreed to pay a record $115 million fine last October for defrauding the Government, has taken disciplinary action against 17 employees as a result of the case.

title: Thomas Holmes, Psychiatrist, 70
description: Dr. Thomas Holmes, a psychiatrist who helped create a stress scale of such events as marriage and work troubles, died Dec. 24 of a stroke. He was 70 years old.

title: Review/Music; Distilling the Erotic in Weill
description: Among modern theater composers, Kurt Weill has proved to be the one with whom rock-era performers identify the most readily. The skewed bluesiness of his music, along with the cynicism of his collaborators' lyrics - not only those of Bertolt Brecht but also those of Alan Jay Lerner and Ogden Nash - lend the songs a perennial contemporaneity.

title: Correction
description: The headline yesterday on an obituary of Dexter Masters, a writer and editor, misstated his nationality. He lived in England but was an American.

title: Cold Days Inspire Aid To Neediest
description: As winter sets in with blustery winds, freezing temperatures, ice and snow, many people's thoughts turn to the needy, who are particularly vulnerable at this time of year.

title: John B. Newman, Professor, 71
description: Dr. John B. Newman, a retired professor of speech at Queens College and an expert in semantics, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Whitestone, Queens. He was 71 years old.

title: Chemical Arms: Third World Trend
description: Libya's reported attempt to join the chemical weapons club is the latest example of a trend in the Middle East and Asia that appears to have tripled the number of countries possessing such weapons in the last decade.

title: Washington's Lesson for Washington
description: Should all Americans have health insurance? Yes; in the richest nation in the world, the question shouldn't be if, but how to finance decent universal coverage fairly and efficiently.

title: A City Where Apartheid Shows Its Gentler Face
description: A semblance of normal life has returned to obscure some of the political tensions of this scenic coastal city, part of an area damaged by the social engineering of apartheid and nearly a decade of sporadic civil unrest.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Women Auburn 67, Tennessee 59: Carolyn Jones and Vickie Orr each scored 18 points as third-ranked Auburn put itself in position to take over the No. 1 spot with a victory over top-ranked Tennessee (11-1) last night in Auburn, Ala. The Lady Tigers improved to 13-0 and should move to the top in next week's poll since No. 2 Louisiana Tech also lost this week, falling to Colorado, 61-60, on Tuesday.(AP) Clemson 69, Maryland 67: Ramona O'Neal stole a pass and scored with 12 seconds left as Clemson upset No. 5 Maryland in an Atlantic Coast Conference game in Clemson, S.C. O'Neal, who led the Tigers with 17 points and had 4 steals and 10 assists, stole the ball and missed from about two feet. But she grabbed the rebound and put the ball in. Maryland (8-2) had a chance to tie the game but Deanna Tate missed the first shot of a one-and-one and Clemson rebounded the ball as time expired.(AP) Iowa 82, Michigan 42: Robin Christian scored 16 points without missing a shot as No. 6 Iowa (9-2) beat Michigan (6-5) in the Big Ten Conference opener for both teams. Christian made 7 of 7 shots from the field and was 2-for-2 from the free-throw line.(AP) SKIING First American Winner: Mike Holland won the fourth event in the four-hill ski jumping tournament yesterday in Bischofshofen, Austria, becoming the first American winner in the competition's 37-year history. The 27-year-old from Norwich, Vt., and former world record-holder had jumps of 111 and 107 meters for 218.5 points. He was only the second United States jumper to win a World Cup event. The first was Jeff Hastings at Lake Placid, N.Y., in 1983. Risto Laakkonen of Finland won the overall title, although he did not win a single event. With 841 points, he beat Jens Weissflog of East Germany and the three-time Olympic gold medalist, Matti Nykaenen, who had 838.5 points each. In March 1985, Holland briefly held the world record with a jump of 186 meters. The mark was broken by Nykaenen. (AP) N.B.A. Pacers 123, Clippers 88: Chuck Person scored 28 points last night as Indiana crushed visiting Los Angeles and gave Dick Versace a victory in his N.B.A. coaching debut. It was only the seventh victory in 30 games this season for the Pacers, who Thursday announced the hiring of Versace, a former Detroit assistant, to succeed the interim coach, George Irvine.(AP) Celtics 115, Hornets 92: Danny Ainge scored 25 points as Boston handed Charlotte its 10th consecutive road loss. The Celtics, beaten in two previous starts at Boston Garden, improved their home record to 11-6.(AP) Pistons 111, Hawks 88: Bill Laimbeer broke out of a six-game slump and keyed a second-quarter surge as Detroit defeated visiting Atlanta, giving Chuck Daly his 300th victory as Detroit's coach. With 7:55 remaining in the second quarter, Laimbeer and Atlanta's Dominique Wilkins got into a shoving match under the Hawks' basket and both drew a technical foul. When order was restored, the Pistons, who led by 34-28 at the time, went on a 20-12 run to forge a 54-40 halftime lead. Laimbeer scored 7 of his 11 second-quarter points after the fracas.(AP) Jazz 106, Bulls 92: Karl Malone scored 10 of his 22 second-half points during a decisive 16-4 third-quarter run and Thurl Bailey came off the bench to score 33 points as Utah held off Chicago in Chicago. Bailey, who scored 20 points in the first half and Malone, who finished with 30, helped the Jazz win for only the fifth time on the road. The Bulls' Michael Jordan finished with 27 points.(AP) Suns 120, Mavericks 111: Tom Chambers scored 31 points, Armon Gilliam had 26 and Mark West added 24 plus 15 rebounds as streaking Phoenix won its 10th straight home game. Phoenix, 13-2 on its home floor this season, went ahead to stay at 24-22 on Gilliam's jumper with 3:29 remaining in the first quarter. Kevin Johnson finished with 16 points and a career-high 18 assists, one shy of Gail Goodrich's club record set in 1969.(AP) Bucks 128, Bullets 121: Ricky Pierce scored 4 of his 29 points in the second overtime to lead Milwaukee to the victory at Baltimore Arena. The game, the Bullets' first regular-season game in the Baltimore Arena since 1973, drew a crowd of 6,429.(AP) N.H.L. Canucks 2, Red Wings 2: In Detroit, Tony Tanti scored his 15th goal of the season with 2:06 remaining in the third period last night, giving Vancouver the tie. Tanti took a pass from Jim Sandlak inside the Detroit blue line and beat the Red Wings' goaltender, Greg Stefan, with a slap shot from 35 feet.(AP) Capitals 3, Maple Leafs 0: Mike Millar, a rookie, scored his second goal in two games and Pete Peeters earned his second shutout in three starts as Washington won at home. Millar took a pass in the right circle from Kevin Hatcher and blasted a slap shot over the shoulder of the Toronto goalie, Allan Bester, for a power-play goal with 7:09 left in the first period, giving Washington a 1-0 lead.(AP) Jets 4, Kings 4: Dale Hawerchuk's power-play goal with 3:08 to play in regulation gave Winnipeg the tie at home. The Jets trailed by 4-2 heading into the third period, but Paul Fenton's second goal of the game closed the gap to 4-3 with 5:13 to play.(AP)

title: Social Security Reserves
description: To the Editor:

title: Arnault Purchases Lift LVMH Stock
description: The stock price of LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton soared to a record high on the Paris stock exchange. Company sources said the French financier Bernard Arnault, a large stockholder, has been buying additional shares of LVMH, which controls some of France's best-known luxury brands, in recent days.

title: Bonn Asks U.S. for Evidence of Libya Connection
description: The West German Government renewed its demands today that the United States supply evidence to support assertions that a German chemical company was involved in the contruction of a chemical plant in Libya. Bonn complained that it was being victimized by a ''media campaign'' in the United States.

title: Mark Producing Sells Its Assets
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said it and a Japanese partner had agreed to acquire the exploration and production assets of Mark Producing Inc. for about $245 million in cash. Mark Producing, a Houston-based company, has extensive natural gas and oil properties in the Gulf of Mexico. The deal includes proven and probable reserves of 190 billion cubic feet of natural gas and five million barrels of oil.

title: MIXING INVESTMENTS
description: The beginning of the new year is a perfect time to establish or review personal investment portfolios. Economic conditions should be an important part of any guide to what kind of investments to make. For instance, a weak or slowing economy favors bonds. Not everyone's financial needs are alike, and portfolios should vary - some are geared to increasing personal wealth and favor stock investments. Others lean toward generating future income and call for a larger share of debt securities, like bonds, treasury securities and certificates of deposit. Brokerage firms can tailor portfolios for the individual. Here are some model portfolios suggested by a few brokerage houses to thier clients for the first quarter of the new year. Brokerage House Stocks Debt Cash Securities Dean Witter Reynolds 71% 25% 4% Gruntal & Company 60 30 10 Merrill Lynch 45 45 10 Paine Webber 14 35 51

title: De Rose Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stamp of Honor
description: LEAD: Not everybody feels the same way about Robert Sprague. Some say he's a squealer and a troublemaker who bites the hand that feeds him. But the American Association for the Advancement of Science thinks he's a hero.

title: But Does Ice Cream Go With Romance?
description: How does an ice cream manufacturer draw attention to new flavors in the dead of winter? Well, Haagen-Dazs's strategy this week was to release results of a poll that explored attitudes toward romance at the same time it announced its new flavors: deep chocolate, deep chocolate fudge and deep chocolate peanut butter.

title: Suit to Block Housing Is Dismissed by Judge
description: A State Supreme Court justice today dismissed a lawsuit by opponents of a proposed housing project for the homeless in the town of Greenburgh.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES PENSION CHANGES
description: The Cuomo administration wants to lower the state's contributions to the pension fund for state workers to save New York hundreds of millions of dollars and help close its huge budget gap without major tax increases.

title: Strong Dollar Helps Treasury Bonds Gain
description: The market in long-term Treasury bonds was buoyed yesterday by a stronger dollar, which influenced investors and traders more than the Government's report of higher employment in December. Shorter-term Treasury maturities were narrowly mixed.

title: Review/Music; A Guitarist From Italy
description: Piero Bonaguri, a guitarist from Italy who made his New York debut on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, is a talented interpreter, if not the most adventurous programmer. Most of the music he offered was from the tried-and-true core of his instrument's literature, including guitar works by Sor, Torroba and Villa-Lobos, and transcriptions of pieces by Frescobaldi and Albeniz.

title: Hearing for Scurry
description: Rod Scurry faces a preliminary hearing April 4 on charges of possession and use of cocaine. The court date was set for the free-agent pitcher during a brief appearance Thursday in Reno Justice Court. He remains free on $6,000 bail. The 32-year-old left-hander was arrested Dec. 22 and charged with buying $40 worth of crack from a police informant. (AP)

title: First Natl Bancorp (Gainesille, Ga.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nancy Vaiti Is the Bride Of Stephen J. Zielinski Jr.
description: Nancy Whitehead Vaiti, a daughter of Edward Whitehead of West Allenhurst, N.J., and the late Eleanor Whitehead, was married yesterday to Stephen J. Zielinski Jr., a son of Rose Zielinski of Trenton and the late Mr. Zielinski. Judge Alvin Y. Milberg, the assignment judge of the New Jersey Superior Court, officiated at the Monmouth County Court in Freehold.

title: Marcos Out of Hospital
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines has been released from a hospital and is resting at home after spending a week in the hospital for treatment of congestive heart failure, an aide said.

title: Strickland Vs. Pitino Vs. Bianchi
description: The Knicks' rookie guard, Rod Strickland, who can dazzle, flung up a cuckoo shot in traffic that flew over the hoop. This was on Tuesday night against the Celtics at Madison Square Garden.

title: Madonna and Sean Penn To End Their Marriage
description: Madonna has filed for divorce to end her turbulent three-year marriage to the actor Sean Penn, a spokesman for her record label said.

title: Winfield Group Suing Steinbrenner Again
description: The stormy relationship between Dave Winfield and George Steinbrenner yesterday produced a new round of thunder and lightning over an old matter: the owner's failure to make payments to the David M. Winfield Foundation.

title: Implants Rejected, Girl Dies
description: A 3-year-old girl who had received a transplant of five organs died today, and experts said the girl's swift decline showed that the procedure for replacing the digestive system was still in its infancy.

title: Bush Aides Say Tower Will Still Be Nominated
description: Aides to President-elect George Bush said today that John G. Tower would still be nominated to be Secretary of Defense, despite Mr. Tower's surgery last week to remove a cancerous polyp from his rectum.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the conviction of nine people in a New York City restaurant inspection scandal misstated the charges. Each defendant was convicted of extortion, but the number of counts varied among defendants.

title: House Plan to Assure a Raise: Prevent Floor Vote
description: The House leadership has a plan to make sure that top Government officials, including members of Congress, get a proposed 50 percent raise. The leaders plan to send any measure to reject the raise to a committee and bottle it up there, top strategists said today.

title: Time for Reckoning Arrives for Hembrick
description: The Olympic T-shirt he wears is a souvenir, but it is also a sad reminder of what should have been the highlight of Anthony Hembrick's amateur boxing career.

title: Southwestern Public Service Co. reports earnings for 12mo to Nov 30
Derby Preps In Florida
description: More than a dozen newly turned 3-year-olds will contest the Florida season's first two prep races for the Triple Crown this weekend.

title: Jobless Rate Down for 5th Year in a Row
description: The Labor Department said today that unemployment fell in 1988 for the fifth year in a row, to a yearly average of 5.4 percent.

title: Patents; Aluminum Mulch Said To Spur Plant Growth
description: The Transmet Corporation, recently spun off from the Battelle Memorial Institute in Columbus, Ohio, has developed an aluminum flake mulch that reflects sunlight and is said to increase the growth rate and yield of garden plants.

title: An Opera Based on O'Neill
description: An opera based on the Eugene O'Neill play ''Desire Under the Elms'' is to have its premiere on Wednesday at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, to benefit the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. The work, composed by Edward Thomas with a libretto by Joe Masteroff, will be performed by the New York Opera Repertory Theater, with Judy Kaye starring. Tickets, priced at $150, include a champagne supper after the performance. The Repertory Theater and the National Music Theater Network will also share in the proceeds. Information: 581-7907.

title: Ottoman Archive: Painful Look Into Turkish-Armenian Past
description: After 74 years and countless recriminations, Turkey plans to reopen the archival records on one of the more grisly episodes of this century: the mass deaths of Armenians at the hands of the Ottoman Turks during World War I. For decades, Armenians have maintained that as many as 1.5 million of their countrymen were murdered or were allowed to die of starvation and exposure in a deliberate Turkish attempt at genocide begun in the spring of 1915.

title: TOP REAGAN AIDES KNEW NORTH CASE FACED COLLAPSE
description: The six senior Reagan Administration officials who decided to prohibit the use of certain classified evidence in the trial of Oliver L. North were advised in advance by the prosecutor that their action could cripple his case, Government sources familiar with the decision said today.

title: GOVERNOR IN WEST RULES OUT '90 RACE
description: Gov. George Deukmejian, with a simple announcement Thursday, has made California government and politics more lively and interesting than it has been since he took office in 1983.

title: Japan's Emperor: A Mortal Man
description: When the American military high command in Tokyo in 1945 suggested that Emperor Hirohito renounce his divinity, the Emperor was bemused. ''I have never considered myself a god,'' he said, ''nor have I attempted to arrogate to myself the powers of a divine being.''

title: U.S. Warns Salvador on Rights Cases
description: The recent collapse of a key human rights case and the failure to make progress in another have prompted renewed political controversy here and warnings that United States aid to this country could be cut.

title: Honeywell Bull to Cut Work Force by 15%
description: Honeywell Bull Inc. said today that it would reduce its American work force by 15 percent, or 1,600 employees, in the next two months to make itself more competitive.

title: Michael J. Napolitano, Radiologist, 59
description: Dr. Michael J. Napolitano, chairman of the radiology department of the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens, died Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after a short illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Son Kills Mother Over Crack Money, Police Say
description: A Bronx teen-ager with no history of disciplinary trouble stabbed his mother to death Tuesday after she refused to give him money to pay a crack dealer, the police said yesterday. After the killing, the youth rearranged his mother's body to make it look as if she had been raped and robbed, they said.

title: Bengals Accused of Pulling a Fast One  No-Huddle, Hurry-Up Offense Angers Opponents
description: It is fiendish, the better mousetrap. It might be unethical if not illegal.

title: Ex-Chiefs of Haas Penalized In Stock-Manipulation Case
description: More details of the Government's investigation of stock market manipulation were disclosed yesterday, as charges of regulatory violations were brought by the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Browns Meet Carson
description: Coach Joe Walton said yesterday that the Jets' defensive coordinator, Bud Carson, met with Cleveland Browns officials Wednesday to discuss the head coaching job left vacant when Marty Schottenheimer resigned last week. Walton said he had told Carson he did not want him to leave the Jets, but gave him permission to be interviewed for the job.

title: George M. L. La Branche, Stock Trader, 89
description: George M. L. La Branche, founder of La Branche & Company, a Manhattan stock trading concern, died of pneumonia Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Injury to Maggie Smith Leads to 'Lettice' Delay
description: Maggie Smith broke a shoulder while riding a bicycle on vacation in November and the accident has forced the postponement until next season of ''Lettice and Lovage,'' the Peter Shaffer play in which she was scheduled to star on Broadway this spring.

title: Queens and Brooklyn Give Subway Improvements Bronx Cheer; Too Much Tooting
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudbury Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net income The company said in the latest quarter it incurred non-recurring charges of $1.1 million related to executive management changes and $2.9 million in costs related to long-term contracts.

title: Corrections
description: The Weather Report last Sunday through Thursday carried miscalculated times for the rise of the sun, the moon, Saturn, Mars, Venus and Jupiter for those dates. Corrected listings appear today on page 46.

title: Home Seizures In Drug Raids Imperil Many
description: LEAD: In the 11 months since the Federal Government began seizing properties in an accelerated program of weekly drug raids in New York City, almost 100 apartment buildings and other residences have been barricaded or bulldozed, caches of weapons confiscated, and crack dens smashed.

title: Cracks Mar the Facade of Bhutto's Pakistan; To Protect Minorities
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Romance' to Close
description: ''Romance Romance,'' a four-character musical by Keith Herrmann, with book and lyrics by Barry Harman, will close after tomorrow's performance at the Helen Hayes Theater. The musical will have played 289 regular performances and 10 previews.

title: Chase Manhattan Cuts London Unit
description: Chase Manhattan Equities, the British brokerage subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, said it would withdraw from some London share trading operations and eliminate 135 jobs here. Chase said the trading volume and profits were too small, so it would withdraw from making markets in British equities.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Correction
description: An article on Thursday about the opening of the Connecticut General Assembly misstated the vote to elect Richard J. Balducci as Speaker of the House. It was 94 to 57 for Mr. Balducci; he was supported by all 63 Republicans and 31 dissident members of the 88-member Democratic majority.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Weather Report last Sunday through Thursday carried miscalculated times for the rise of the sun, the moon, Saturn, Mars, Venus and Jupiter for those dates. The correct times appear below: $ Date *2*Saturn *2*Moon *2*Sun rise set rise set rise set 1 6:57 16:14 1:13 11:56 7:20 16:39 2 6:53 16:10 2:16 12:21 7:20 16:40 3 6:50 16:07 3:22 12:51 7:20 16:41 4 6:46 16:04 4:30 13:30 7:20 16:42 5 6:43 16:00 5:37 14:18 7:20 16:43 Date *2*Venus *2*Mars *2*Jupiter rise set rise set rise set 1 5:40 15:03 11:53 0:59 13:38 4:01 2 5:42 15:04 11:50 0:58 13:34 3:57 3 5:44 15:04 11:47 0:57 13:30 3:53 4 5:46 15:05 11:44 0:55 13:26 3:48 5 5:48 15:06 11:42 0:54 13:21 3:44

title: PENTAGON FRAUD: INDICTMENT AND GUILTY PLEAS
description: The companies and some of those involved in the Government's investigation of fraud in weapons procurement. HAZELTINE CORPORATION: A Greenlawn, L.I., manufacturer of military electronic systems.In 1986, the company, which also has plants in Massachusetts, was bought by the Emerson Electric Company of St. Louis. In 1988, Hazeltine had sales of about $158 million, 2.4 percent of Emerson's $6.7 billion in revenues. TELEDYNE INDUSTRIES, a subsidiary of Teledyne Inc. of Los Angeles, is a major manufacturer of airplane engines, making half the general aviation piston engines in the United States. The company also makes airframe structures, robot and remote control aircraft, spacecraft and drone systems. Its sales for the nine months ended Sept. 30 were $2.56 billion, up from $2.41 billion for the 1987 period. Net income amounted to $293.6 million compared to $218.4 million the year before. Stuart E. Berlin: The only Government employee indicted, he headed the ship systems engineering branch of the Naval Air Systems Command from October 1986 until he was reassigned by the Pentagon last June. A Navy procurement specialist, he faces charges of accepting bribes in exchange for providing classified information. Court documents say Berlin provided information to Teledyne and Hazeltine. William L. Parkin: An Alexandria, Va., consultant, he worked in the Navy's Joint Cruise Missile Project from 1977 to 1983. According to court papers released earlier, he was hired by Hazeltine to get inside information from the Pentagon that would allow the company to compete for a $15.9 million contract for battlefield equipment. The indictments said Teledyne agreed to pay the Parkin firm $160,000 to obtain information. Fred H. Lackner: A Woodland Hills, Calif., consultant, he worked for several aerospace companies, including a Northrop Corporation electronics unit in Hawthorne, Calif., the Stromberg Carlson Corporation in Winter Park, Fla., then a unit of the General Dynamics Corporation and later a division of the United Technologies Corporation, and the systems development unit of the Unisys Corporation. The indictment said Mr. Lackner and Mr. Berlin struck an agreement that Mr. Berlin would help Teledyne win a contract in exchange for money. Joseph Colarusso: A former senior vice president of Hazeltine who worked at the Greenlawn office, he joined the company in 1959 and was appointed senior vice president in 1984. He resigned last month. He pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to defraud the Government and commit wire fraud. Charles Furciniti: A former marketing representative of Hazeltine who held the title of vice president, he worked for the company for 20 years, resigning last May to take a post with another company. Like Mr. Colarusso, he pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the Government and commit wire fraud. Michael Savaides: A Washington-based lobbyist for Teledyne, the Government said he had a financial relationship with Mr. Parkin. Affadavits showed that Mr. Parkin, Mr. Berlin and Mr. Savaides had planned at one time to divide $150,000 from Teledyne. Source: Associated Press

title: INSIDE
description: Oklahoma State Punished

title: McMahon Named Starter
description: Jim McMahon, who publicly lobbied to start the National Conference championship game, was given the job today by Coach Mike Ditka.

title: Arvia MacKaye Ege, A Poet, Is Dead at 86
description: Arvia MacKaye Ege, a poet and a founder of the Rudolph Steiner Educational and Farming Association, died Wednesday at her home in Hillsdale, N.Y. She was 86 years old.

title: Nozzles for Cutting Pollution Arrive at Jersey Gas Stations
description: This week was the first that New Jersey's largest gasoline stations were required to do their part to reduce air pollution by using pump nozzles designed to trap gasoline vapors.

title: Toyota Will Build Trucks In California if G.M. Agrees
description: The General Motors Corporation is close to concluding an agreement that would allow the Toyota Motor Corporation to build 100,000 trucks a year in Fremont, Calif., G.M.'s chief executive, Roger B. Smith, said today.

title: Digital Communications Asociates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $12.6 million incurred in connection with the acquisition of Digital Transmission Systems Inc. on Dec. 22, for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: Missouri Puts Killer to Death In Tavern Waitress's Slaying
description: A convicted killer was put to death by injection early today for the murder of a tavern waitress, becoming the first Missouri inmate to be executed since 1965.

title: Devils' Top Line Enjoys Its Reunion
description: The Devils are a much better team when Mark Johnson is flanked by John MacLean and Patrik Sundstrom, the team's top two scorers.

title: Senior Tee Rule Nearly Drives Palmer Off Course
description: While a strong, cold wind zipped over the LaCosta Country Club course in the second round of the MONY Tournament of Champions today, Arnold Palmer was very warm from the second hole on. Actually he was hot under the collar. Palmer admitted later that he almost walked off the course after he learned that he hit from the wrong teeing ground on No. 2.

title: Murdoch Wins Control of Collins
description: Rupert Murdoch's News International P.L.C. won control today of William Collins P.L.C., ending a two-month struggle by the major British book publisher to resist a takeover by Mr. Murdoch.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7

title: Cracks Mar the Facade of Bhutto's Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Attacks Policy That Keeps Aliens in Texas
description: Attorneys representing aliens from Central America filed suit here today in an attempt to overturn a new Government immigration policy that has left hundreds of aliens stranded and homeless in one of the nation's poorest areas.

title: 30% MORE FOR AIDS IN REAGAN BUDGET
description: The Reagan Administration will send to Congress on Monday a $424.4 billion budget for health and human services that will include a 30 percent increase in spending on AIDS but restrain the growth of Medicare and Medicaid.

title: 2 South African Black Policemen Die in Township Grenade Attack
description: Two policemen were killed and 30 were wounded Thursday night when suspected guerrillas threw four grenades onto a police parade ground in a black township near here, the police said today.

title: 16 More Polish Sailors Jump a Ship in Boston
description: Sixteen Polish sailors fled a fishing trawler in Boston Harbor Thursday, joining 30 of their countrymen who jumped ship last week and applied for political asylum in the United States.

title: Intertrans Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Anglo Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $26,749,000. c-Net loss

title: May Sets Mergers For Goldwaters
description: The May Department Stores Company said it would merge the five Phoenix stores of its Goldwaters division into its Robinson's department store chain, based in Los Angeles, effective Feb. 26. Two other Goldwaters stores will be operated by two other May divisions, and two in Tucson, Ariz., will be sold to other retailers.

title: Shareen Blair Brysac Weds Karl E. Meyer
description: The marriage of Shareen Blair Brysac, the daughter of Fred E. Blair of Paris, Tex., and Denver, and the late Margaret Blair, to Karl E. Meyer, the son of Dorothy Meyer of New York and the late Ernest L. Meyer, took place yesterday in New York. Judge Albert A. Blinder of the Court of Claims performed the ceremony in his chambers at 2 World Trade Center.

title: Harvest Drops in China
description: China reported today that its 1988 grain harvest fell for the fourth straight year, calling into question the ability of the nation to feed its billion people. The official China Daily attributed the shortfall to one of the worst droughts in China's history and to ''lack of motivation'' by peasants to plant more grain. The State Statistical Bureau said 393.79 million tons of rice, corn, wheat and other grains were harvested last year, down from 1987's 402.98 million tons and only slightly higher than harvests in 1985 and 1986. China produced a record 407 million tons of grain in 1984 but has been unable to match that figure since.

title: New York School Board Faulted For the Disarray of Local Districts
description: The New York City Board of Education has failed to prevent the local decentralized school districts from mismanaging their budgets, ignoring ethical standards and often placing politics ahead of educational concerns, education officials, union leaders and representatives of community watchdog groups say.

title: Tokyo Takes News Solemnly, but in Stride
description: With customary attention to decorum and detail, and with flashes of spontaneity, Tokyo awoke this morning to witness the first ascension of an Emperor since 1926, and to mourn the only monarch most Japanese have ever known.

title: Less Mystery in Car Rentals
description: Drivers should find it easier to shop for the lowest rental-car rates this year, and many customers will be able to disregard the industry's puzzling and expensive insurance options, thanks to some new laws, guidelines and credit-card services.

title: Earth Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Coach Relieved
description: Mike Pollio, the coach of the Virginia Commonwealth basketball team, said yesterday he felt a sense of relief to learn that the death last Monday night of Michael Brown, one of Pollio's players, was not drug-related.

title: Capt. Crab Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: The company said included in earnings for fiscal year 1987 was approximately $550,000 of franchise and other fee income.

title: Oklahoma St. Is Placed On Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today banned the Oklahoma State football team from bowl and television appearances as part of a four-year probation for recruiting violations. The N.C.A.A. warned that future infractions could result in the ''death penalty,'' which would shut down the program.

title: President Enters a Hospital For Surgery on Hand Today
description: President Reagan was admitted this evening to the Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where he will undergo minor surgery on his left hand Saturday for a condition that has caused a curvature of his ring finger.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Beverly Enterprises Inc., Pasadena, Calif., agreed to sell 20 nursing homes in Massachusetts to GHM Inc., East Hartford, Conn., for $47.25 million.

title: Florida Faces Loss
description: A disclosure by Vernon Maxwell, a rookie with the San Antonio Spurs, that he accepted payments from agents while playing for the University of Florida, could cost the university more than $600,000 in forfeited revenues from National Collegiate Athletic Association tournaments of 1987 and 1988, The St. Petersburg Times reported Thursday.

title: Bush Calls Walsh's Motion 'the Proper Suggestion'
description: President-elect George Bush said today that he thought the independent Iran-contra prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, ''did the right thing'' Thursday in moving to dismiss the two main charges against Oliver L. North. But the Senate Democratic leader called for more information on the move.

title: Patents; 3 New Drugs Backed for AIDS Study
description: Three new drugs that promoters say could help in the fight against AIDS were granted patents this week. The granting of a patent does not mean the drugs are necessarily safe or effective treatments for the disease, merely that they meet the Patent Office's criteria of being original and non-obvious. In each drug's case, the developers said that evidence of effectiveness was still far from proved.

title: Starving Family Refused to Buy Food, Police Say
description: A starving family had more than $3,600 in cash and in bank accounts but refused to spend it for food because they believed the money ''belonged to God,'' according to a police affidavit made public today.

title: Bruce Failing Sr., 70, Advertising Executive
description: Bruce F. Failing Sr., an advertising executive, died of a heart attack Thursday at the Albany Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: A Witness Says Nussbaum Hit And Flung Lisa
description: A defense witness in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg testified yesterday that she saw Hedda Nussbaum fling Lisa Steinberg aside in a fit of rage and then slap her on the side of her neck in 1983 when the child was less than 2 years old.

title: Life Magazine Photos
description: ''Life: Through the 60's,'' an exhibition of 200 photographs from the archives of Life magazine is to be on view at the International Center for Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, from March 17 to May 14. The photographs run from the late 1950's to the early 70's, and the subjects include the civil-rights movement, the Vietnam War, the Peace Corps and the Kennedy Administration. Information: 860-1777.

title: Cancer Experts See A Need for Caution On Use of Birth Pill
description: Several leading experts in breast cancer said yesterday that they believed new data linking oral contraceptives and breast cancer were so troubling that some women should be discouraged from taking birth control pills.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 8.

title: PROTESTS FOLLOW HANGING OF 2 SIKHS
