description: Stores and schools in predominantly Sikh areas were closed today to protest the hanging of two Sikhs for the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Hirohito Death Closes Markets
description: Japan's stock, commodity and bond markets did not open today after the announcement that Emperor Hirohito had died.

title: Inscrutable Occidental Mentality
description: For days warlike sounds have issued from Washington about the need for a ''surgical strike'' to ''take out'' that troublesome chemical plant in Libya. This fast-food and medical jargon harks back to Vietnam days when it was used to describe what our air forces were up to, which was bombing with a ferocity somewhat less destructive than nuclear assault.

title: Review/Music; Philharmonic Strings Are Given the Stage
description: In mid-December, Zubin Mehta gave nearly all the string players of the New York Philharmonic a week off. This past week, he has given the winds and brass a rest. Such planning may mostly have to do with union contracts, mandating a certain amount of time off per musician. But the programming made sense artistically as well: the December concert was very good, and this week's is better yet.

title: Chief Rival Abandons Effort To Oust Los Angeles Mayor
description: City Councilman Zev Yaroslavsky, the only significant challenger to Mayor Tom Bradley, dropped out of the mayoral race today, saying he was discouraged by a poll indicating he had little chance of winning the election April 11.

title: For Harper & Row, the Deal Insures Closer Cooperation
description: Now that Rupert Murdoch has won control of William Collins, Harper & Row will be able to integrate more closely its publishing and distribution in Britain and Canada, where the two companies have often gone their separate ways.

title: FIRST INDICTMENT RETURNED BY JURY IN PENTAGON FRAUD
description: A Federal grand jury returned its first indictment today against a military contractor, a Pentagon official and five other people in the two-year investigation of fraud and bribery in military weapons procurement. Another contractor and two of its former executives pleaded guilty in a Federal court to similar charges growing out of the investigation.

title: Manning Injures Knee Ligament
description: Danny Manning of the Los Angeles Clippers, the No. 1 pick in the National Basketball Association draft last summer, has knee ligament damage and will not be with the Clippers when they play the Knicks tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden. The severity of the injury will be determined next week. If a complete tear is found, reconstructive surgery could require up to a year of rehabilitation.

title: Capital's Mayor Balks at Drug Inquiries
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., under Federal investigation for a December visit to a man suspected of being a drug dealer, declined today to make public the results of 10 drug tests that he has said he took over the past five years.

title: KEY RATES
Accords by Banks Advance Nabisco Deal
description: The $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company moved nearer to completion yesterday after a few dozen of the world's largest banks agreed to lend in the vicinity of $10 billion for the deal.

title: The Missing Conscience Of the 20th Century
description: Tours of the Black Clock By Steve Erickson 320 pages. Poseidon. $18.95.

title: Altex Industries reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Bridge
description: If the players competing in the Winter Regional Swiss Team Championship in Manhattan three weeks ago had been asked by Santa Claus what they wanted for Christmas, a likely answer would have been a doubled part-score, making game, with the help of some mis-defense.

title: New Boston Arena
description: An agreement for the owners of the 60-year-old Boston Garden to build a new arena, which could be ready by the fall of 1992, was announced yesterday by Mayor Raymond Flynn.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD:;
Coping: With Hi-Fi Changes
description: LEAD: New kinds of hi-fi equipment arise and elbow each other aside faster and faster. In the '80s alone, stereo systems have had to accommodate compact disk players, surround sound and audio feeds from such video gear as televisions, videocassette recorders and videodisk players.

title: Snowstorm Wreaks Mischief on Most Roadways
description: A wet white rag was thrown in the faces and under the feet of New York region residents yesterday, as the first snowfall of the year dropped three to five inches from southeastern New Jersey to the tip of Long Island.

title: Queens and Brooklyn Give Subway Improvements Bronx Cheer; Isolated in Sea Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: BP America Sets New Brand Name
description: BP America Inc., the United States unit of the British Petroleum Company, said it would replace the various brand names under which its gasoline stations operate with a single brand name. The company refused to disclose the new name or say whether the name chosen for the American market would also apply to B.P.'s European operations.

title: The Twelve Charges That Still Face North
description: Oliver L. North faces 12 charges in addition to the two major counts that the prosecution in the Iran-Contra case is seeking to dismiss.

title: Your Money; A Need to Gauge One's Cash Flow
description: Sometime in the next three months most taxpayers will be sorting through their 1988 financial records to get the information they or their tax preparers need to file returns. A key to really getting finances under control is to do the job as soon as possible and as thoroughly as possible, by preparing an entire cash-flow statement that shows all expenditures as well as income and deductions.

title: No Strickland Problem for Pitino
description: The Rod Strickland situation appears to be one of the few thorns these days for the Knicks, who head into their game against Cleveland today with a 20-10 record and their best start in 16 seasons. And it's a perplexity that is not likely to go away.

title: Donald P. Wright, Lawyer, 48
description: Donald P. Wright, a vice president and general counsel at the Harris Corporation, the electronics and communciations company, died of a heart attack Thursday at Holmes Regional Hospital in Melbourne, Fla. He was 48 years old and lived in Indialantic, Fla.

title: Hirohito, 124th Emperor of Japan, Is Dead at 87
description: Emperor Hirohito, the last of the World War II leaders and Japan's longest-reigning monarch, died today at the Imperial Palace. He was 87 years old.

title: Andersen's Chief Will Step Down
description: In an unexpected move, Arthur Andersen & Company said today that Duane R. Kullberg would relinquish the title of term was scheduled to expire.

title: U.S. SPURNS SAUDIS ON LIBYA MEDIATION
description: Less than two weeks before two Navy fighter planes shot down two Libyan jets over the Mediterranean, the Reagan Administration rejected an offer by Saudi Arabia to mediate between the United States and Libya, State Department officials and Arab diplomats said today.

title: A Bill Without Money
description: The hue and cry over the deplorable conditions of New York City's schools has produced, in record time, a new, if revolutionary, authority: the New York City School Construction Authority. Now provided with first-class leadership, it has the powers to press school projects to prompt completion. But a will and a way won't suffice if projects are not assigned and funds not allocated. The city's leaders must provide, for the first time, sufficient money to build the schools we need or they must declare that they are unwilling or unable to so do.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 7, 1989
description: Economy

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Autoclave Engineers reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $554,000 gain on the sale of real estate. The year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to give effect to the 10 percent stock dividend issued on May 16, 1988.

title: Why Soviet Foreign Policy Went Sour
description: LEAD: For many years, and especially during those known conventionally as the ''era of stagnation,'' diplomats in the East and West carried on an endless and protracted argument about what must come first -confidence-building, as they said, or arms reductions, as we said. This discussion led to one result: inaction.

title: Eagleburger Is Named for No. 2 Post at State Dept.
description: President-elect George Bush today selected a number of prominent political associates and Government figures to serve as State Department officials and United States ambassadors.

title: Review/Music; 4 Saxophones on an Unaccompanied Romp
description: Though jazz has regularly used instrumental combinations that defy convention, the 1980's have seen a real increase in the popularity of oddly outfitted groups. The 29th Street Saxophone Quartet, which played at Visiones on Thursday night, made it clear why the practice has become so popular: without the interference of a rhythm section, its four saxophones are immensely sensual and capture an archtypical jazz sound. And like other groups without rhythm sections, it often draws a listener into the creative process by implying, and letting the audience imagine, bass lines and drum parts.

title: F.A.A. Plans Changes In Rivets on Older 727's
description: Expanding its campaign to assure the safety of aging airliners, the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday proposed a rule calling for intensive inspections for fuselage cracks in older Boeing 727's.

title: Alfred Julien, Lawyer, Dies at 78
description: Alfred S. Julien, a New York trial lawyer who was founder and senior partner in the law firm of Julien & Schlesinger, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 78 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Despite the concerted efforts of medical treatment, finally today His Majesty passed away from a tumor in the duodenum.'' - Shoichi Fujimori, grand steward of the Imperial Household Agency. [ 1:1. ]

title: A Bigger Sea Around Us
description: With a Christmas week stroke of a pen, President Reagan bestowed on the United States a breathtaking gift: 185,000 square miles of new territory. That's the biggest acquisition since the purchase in 1867 of Alaska's 586,000 square miles. The President extended the country's territorial waters from 3 to 12 miles, pursuant to a United Nations convention that has been denounced by his own Administration as a leftist plot. The world indeed turns in wondrous ways.

title: GUIDE
description: YALE'S WINTERFEST Elizabeth Egloff's ''Phaedra and Hippolytus,'' Anthony Giardina's ''The Beach,'' Anne Commire's ''Starting Monday'' and Douglas Wright's ''Interrogating the Nude'' are four new plays to be performed as works-in-progress during the ninth annual Winterfest at the Yale Repertory Theater, at York and Chapel Streets in New Haven.

title: CORRECTION
description: The video column on Dec. 25 incorrectly described the kind of machine on which tapes recorded in Super-VHS can be played. Such tapes cannot be played on standard VHS machines. However, tapes recorded in standard VHS can be played on Super-VHS machines.

title: HERO IN A RAGGED KILT
description: BONNIE PRINCE CHARLIE A Biography. By Carolly Erickson. Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Shelters for Homeless Ordered
description: Homeless residents of the capital and their advocates won a victory today when a judge ruled that the city must be prepared to open new shelters within three days in neighborhoods where existing shelters fill to capacity for two consecutive nights.

title: Ann Reynolds Engaged To Robert deButts Jr.
description: The engagement of Ann Elizabeth Reynolds, a producer for ''Good Morning America'' on ABC-TV, and Robert Edward Lee deButts Jr., an associate in the New York law firm of Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Telfer Barkley Reynolds of Los Angeles.

title: Employers Assay Ban on Polygraphs
description: AS Westchester retailers tabulate the profits from a successful holiday season, they fear they are losing ground against a common enemy, the thieving employee. On Dec. 27 polygraph testing, one of the means retailers in the state have used to determine the honesty of employees, was banned under the Employee Polygraph Protection Act of 1988.

title: The High Costs of Dumping Going Higher)
description: IT'S becoming more and more expensive to get rid of something nobody wants: garbage. Many garbage haulers say they are considering raising their prices 20 percent or more this year, as towns charge more at disposal centers to cover their own costs and as recycling requirements make handling garbage more complicated and expensive.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Title Search
description: A mile or two south of Pauillac, the famous wine town in the Bordeaux region of France, lies the renowned Chateau Pichon-Longueville, founded in the 17th century by Jacques de Pichon, Baron de Longueville and first President of the Bordeaux Parlement. The present, 19th-century neo-Gothic chateau, with its narrow black spires jutting up out of the vineyards, is along the Bordeaux road.

title: With Feet, Happy Is Better Than Dainty
description: I AM not suited to capitulation. It is not in my stubborn nature, nor was it in my lexicon until the question of sneakers arose. Up to that point sneakers (grimy, disreputable, gargantuan) were a way of life for my grandsons, and they could have them, I decided.

title: Art Brut
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''In Europe, Tracing the Art of the Outsider'' (Travel, Nov. 20): Those who would like to learn more should read ''Art Brut'' by Michel Thevoz, the curator of the Art Brut Museum in Lausanne.

title: Q and A
description: Tax Abatement for Condo

title: Campus Rites: The Job Interview
description: LEAD: BEFORE SHE stepped into her first on-campus recruitment interview, Tiffany Osterhout, a senior at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., went to 10 stores in search of the perfect interview outfit (a conservative gray striped suit). She put as much time into researching the company, the accounting and consulting firm Arthur Andersen & Company, as she did preparing for a midterm.

title: Brian L. Peters Weds Maria Teresa de Ona
description: At St. Hugh's Roman Catholic Church in Coconut Grove, Fla., Maria Teresa de Ona, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan de Dios de Ona of Coral Gables, Fla., was married yesterday to Brian Lawrence Peters, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Peters of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. Cristobal Figuero performed the ceremony. Martha Isabel de Ona was maid of honor for her sister. The best man was Robert Papp.

title: Church Groups Plan Houses for Homeless
description: LEAD: RELIGIOUS groups in the county, which have provided temporary shelter, soup kitchens and counseling services to the growing number of homeless people, are seeking to play a more significant role in meeting the need for more affordable housing.

title: TALKING: Estate Taxes; Easing Federal Liability
description: THE surge in property values in the last few years has thrust hundreds of families into a position where Federal estate taxes are likely to be due at the time of death. Those taxes may turn out to be particularly steep if, in addition to a principal residence, there is a vacation home or investment property, such as a condominium, which may have skyrocketed in value, too.

title: Jazz and Russian Dance in Stamford
description: AS the concert season struggles to awaken after its holiday nap, Stamford leads the way with Russian dances, jazz duets, a recital by an eminent pianist and an adventure in cabaret pops.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Chickens See Red, And It's Soothing

title: A Visit to the Late, Great City Of New York
description: WHEN people ask me where I come from, my answer is always New York City. It doesn't matter that when I was 6 years old other people controlled my life and moved me ''out to Long Island.'' The umbilical cord was stretched; it was never cut. I use any excuse to visit the city - a parade, a show, a walk in Central Park on an autumn afternoon. Occasionally my company sends me there on business.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Teams Will Meet in the Super Bowl?
description: The San Francisco 49ers may be the league's most dominant team after scoring 34 points against Minnesota's top-ranked defense. Against the N.F.C. Central Division champion Chicago Bears, San Francisco will win by attacking with a dominant offensive line to control Mike Singletary, allowing Joe Montana adequate pass protection.

title: Melding Design and Disability
description: THE EXTERIOR of a school can be deceptive. From the outside, two public schools, the Frederick J. Gaenslen School in Milwaukee, Wis., and the Mercer Junior-Senior High School in Trenton, N.J., look like any other new schools. They are both low-slung, modern brown brick structures. The American flag flies in front of the canopied entrances. School buses park outside.

title: A Par Contest For Junior Players
description: EUROPEANS have long been energetic in promoting bridge for young players. Several countries across the Atlantic, notably the Netherlands and Sweden, teach bridge in schools. Britain has an annual event contested by about 70 school teams.

title: Elisabeth Ostrow To Wed a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Ostrow of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Sara Ostrow, to Andrew Victor Buchsbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Buchsbaum of Englewood, N.J. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: New Zealand
description: To the Editor: Because I have tramped up and down the Abel Tasman National Park coastal track on New Zealand's South Island, I was delighted to see the article on that splendid part of the world (Travel, Nov. 20). But one small stone was left unturned.

title: Silver Spoons for Victorian Yuppies
description: American silver of the 1890's - exotic, exuberant and hefty - has come into its own in the 1980's. Museums mount major exhibitions, scholars write historical books and collectors - many in their 20's and 30's - from coast to coast seek punch bowls one word? Mike two pn and pitchers from the gaslight era in auctions and antiques shops.

title: Disparity in Costs For Education
description: I'm responding to the article ''Mount Sinai Vote Due On High School Plan'' [ Oct. 30 ] .

title:
DINING OUT;
In Thornwood, Hunan Fare Arrives
description: LEAD: UP-COUNTY diners interested in what is for the most part carefully prepared Hunan cooking should take note of the recent opening of Hunan Ritz. It replaces the short-lived China Boat in the middle of the Rose Hill Shopping Center. Those familiar with the pink and white linens, dramatic black chairs and the gentle fountain of the former occupant will find them intact.

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor: In the Nov. 20 Travel section there was a letter from Pilar Vico, director of public relations of the Spanish Tourist Office, regarding your article on the Dollar Abroad (Travel, Oct. 9).

title: FICTION
description: FROM THE REMINISCENCES OF PRIVATE IVANOV: And Other Stories. By Vsevolod Garshin. Translated by Peter Henry, Liv Tudge, Donald Rayfield and Philip Taylor. (Dufour Editions, Cloth, $27.50; Paper, $13.95.) For a few years in the mid-1880's, the eyes of the Russian literary world turned to Vsevolod Garshin. Dostoyevsky and Turgenev were dead, Tolstoy had given up writing and Chekhov was just beginning. Garshin seemed to be the rising star. But his suicide in 1888 at the age of 33, after only a decade of writing that produced a handful of stories, cut short those expectations and relegated Garshin to obscurity outside Russia. Nevertheless, as this ably translated collection proves, Garshin was a powerful, innovative writer of unusually broad stylistic range. He wrote lyrical children's fables as well as brutally realistic war stories. And while Garshin borrowed from his more famous predecessors, particularly Dostoyevsky and Tolstoy, he did so with original results. For example, in ''The Signal,'' which tells of two peasant railroad workers oppressed by poverty and corrupt officials, he challenged Tolstoy's view of the Russian peasant as a wise, Christlike figure. Garshin also showed a surprisingly modern insight into human psychology. His stories are full of the senseless, bloody horror of war, the dehumanizing effects of poverty and disease, the innate cruelty of life. And his heroes face a timeless dilemma: they are tortured by the suffering they see all around them, frustrated by their inability to do anything about it, yet morally unable to ignore it.

title: Jill R. Vanacore Planning to Wed Richard G. Reid
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Vanacore of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Roberta Vanacore to Richard Gerveys Reid, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Reid of Brooklyn Heights and Quogue, L.I. The couple plan a May 6 wedding.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Akihito; New Symbol for New Japan
description: In the closing days of World War II, as much of Japan lay in ruins, an 11-year-old boy was living and studying in Nikko, a quiet town in the mountains safe from the American B-29 Superfortresses that were bombing Tokyo nightly.

title: Exercise Pays Off
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Perfect Pop From Tiffany - Seriously
description: Seriousness has hit pop music big. Whether in the high-mindedness of Tracy Chapman or the industrial, mass-produced ditties of Tiffany, seriousness is the flavor of the day.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A CALL TO CIVIC SERVICE: National Service for Country and Community. By Charles C. Moskos. (Twentieth Century Fund/Free Press, $22.95.) For centuries, Rio Grande farmers have communally cleaned the irrigation ditches each spring, to bring water to the farms of New Mexico. In other states throughout the country, Job Corps volunteers work in conservation projects and learn job skills.

title: Jean Dexheimer To Wed in April
description: Jean K. Dexheimer, an associate at the law firm of Davis Hoxie Faithfull & Hapgood in New York, and Paul M. Dudek, an associate at the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, plan to marry in April.

title: Garment Unions Sue To Ban Work in Home
description: Unions and clothing industry groups have filed a suit to block new Government regulations that would allow work at home in five industries, ending a 40-year ban.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Where Should Baby Sleep?
description: LEAD: NO SEEEP! NO SEEEP!'' such is the sad wail of my 20-month-old daughter, amid lullabies in her father's arms, just before she sinks into the state she has been protesting against so loudly. My son, now 7, was similar; at 3 he used to explain patiently to babysitters, ''It takes me a long time to go to sleep.

title: Deer Hunting On Fire Island
description: While a propensity for violence is a variable that many of us harbor in some degree, I cannot countenance the licensing of those who hunt with bows and arrows, ''Hunting of Deer Begins,'' (Dec. 18, 1988).

title: Giants End Up In Proper Place
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Theater in the State: A 'Coming of Age'
description: NO sooner had the new year begun when three of the state's 15 professional theaters got down to the business of opening their next plays - all on the same night. And within a month, three more productions will reinforce the new year's theater blitz in New Jersey.

title: Yugoslav Backer of Changes Reported in Line for Premier
description: Ante Markovic, a strong supporter of market-oriented liberalization and a leader of the republic of Croatia, is the leading candidate to become Yugoslavia's new Prime Minister, Yugoslav newspapers said today.

title: Teen-Agers and AIDS: Protection, Yes, but How?
description: AT first glance, two bills in the State Legislature to require that family life education programs, and materials circulated by the State Board of Education, shall stress abstinence from sexual activity until marriage as the ''only completely reliable means of preventing the sexual transmission of AIDS'' and of avoiding pregnancy are deceptively appealing.

title: A Family Affair with Bikes
description: ON most Tuesday evenings, children do their homework or settle down in front of television sets. But not at the Maguire home in New Canaan.

title: THE REGION: To San Juan; Koch Leads the Pack in Pursuit Of Hispanic Voters
description: NO ONE can say New York City lacked for standardbearers at last week's inauguration of Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico. Mayor Edward I. Koch was there. So were the Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, and the Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, all of whom are contemplating their chances of replacing Mr. Koch in this year's mayoral election.

title: Protest in San Salvador
description: Troops used tear gas and fired shots in the air to break up a group of women protesting the compulsory draft of young men in poor neighborhoods, witnesses said. Reynaldo Blanco, head of the independent El Salvador Human Rights Commission, said 20 people were detained at the demonstration Friday outside the barracks of the 1st Infantry Brigade.

title: 'Army' Alert
description: To the Editor:

title: Providence Rallies to 12-0
description: Carlton Screen made two free throws with 11 seconds left to give undefeated Providence an 80-78 victory today over Connecticut in the Big East.

title: Alternatives to Incinerators are Sought
description: LEAD: IN an effort to halt the construction of garbage-burning incinerators in New Jersey, a bill has been introduced calling for a moratorium on the issuance of permits for the incinerators.

title: For North, the Road Ahead Seems in Some Ways Harder
description: Oliver L. North faces a long and in some ways more arduous legal battle on 12 remaining criminal counts against him now that national security concerns appear to have scuttled the two most serious charges, officials close to the case say.

title: Flights Seek Clues to Atlantic Storms
description: After more than two years of planning, scientists have begun flights in specially equipped weather airplanes into the centers of fierce, unpredictable northeaster storms spawned in the Atlantic Ocean.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A New Era Begins for Commemorative Coins
description: LEAD: THE 1980's have witnessed a renaissance in United States commemorative coinage. Eleven new commemoratives have been issued since 1982, when the series resumed after a hiatus of nearly three decades and four more have been approved for issuance this year and next year.

title: China's Burst of Rage: A Show of Racism, And of Something More
description: 'WE'RE tired of being second-class citizens,'' declared a large poster erected illegally last week by Chinese students at the Beijing Languages Institute. In a sense, that seemed to be what China's racial unrest of the last two weeks has been about.

title: THE WORLD: Talks in Paris; Can Words Stem a Flow Of Chemical Weapons?
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S call in September for an international conference to discourage the use of chemical weapons seemed like a straightforward idea. In December, a top State Department official said the conference would be ''an exercise in high rhetoric'' to revive a global taboo broken by the use of poison gas in the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Ocean-Crash Recorder Found
description: The voice recorder from a South African airliner that crashed into the Indian Ocean 14 months ago was recovered Friday and appears to be in good condition, Cecil Margo, a senior South African investigator, said. All 160 people aboard were killed when the South African Airways Boeing 747 crashed as it approached Mauritius on a flight from Taipei to Johannesburg in November 1987. Radio exchanges and an examination of wreckage recovered earlier suggest that an in-flight fire may have disabled the plane, the flight crew or both.

title: American Jews Stand Firmly to the Left
description: DESPITE the sociological rule that economic success usually leads to conservatism, American Jews remain distinctly liberal in their social and political outlook, as even the disappointed conservatives among them concede.

title: At a Breast Exam, Perfection Is Where You Find It
description: I HAVE reached middle age, my children are grown and gone, I am a grandmother and I have perfect breasts. I'm not the one who thinks so. Today someone who saw me topless described them that way, someone who sees women's breasts every day - the mammography technician.

title: When Explosive Energy Drives Home a Point
description: Now you see it, now you don't. That could be said about the movement in many works by contemporary choreographers who send dancers hurtling through space. Images often flash by so rapidly that one may not be sure how to interpret them. Ambiguity may even be part of a dance's point. Yet, when employed skillfully, speed can convey its own message.

title: N. Carolina Upset by Iowa On Free Throw by Marble
description: Roy Marble's free throw with 11 seconds to play capped a 23-point performance, and Iowa beat North Carolina, 98-97, today.

title: The Battle to Save the Banks
description: The silent run was accelerating at the First RepublicBank Corporation's offices in Texas - silent because retail customers were not lining up on the streets. This run was being fueled by large institutions, including other banks, racing to electronically withdraw uninsured deposits. Alarm bells went off around Washington, as the nation's top bank regulators met in an emergency session. As the relatively new special assistant to L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, I found myself at that meeting - positioned to view and participate in the Government's response to the developing crisis.

title: Don't You Believe the Deficit Isn't a Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Average, We All Would Like the Good Life
description: TRYING to deal with the midlife crisis everyone says I am in, at my age, 47, I am baffled by my ordinariness. I felt by this time that there would be something more - I felt I was better, or at least different, than the rest.

title: The Nuclear Arms Industry's Ills, Step by Step
description: Among the problems that will be considered in coming weeks by the 101st Congress is how to pay the enormous costs of repairing and cleaning up the nation's crippled nuclear weapons production system. Last spring, the United States lost its remaining means of producing tritium and plutonium, essential ingredients of nuclear warheads, when the last reactors at the aging Savannah River Plant in South Carolina were shut down. Although plutonium lasts tens of thousands of years and stockpiles are said to be high, tritium steadily decays into helium, resulting in automatic, unilateral disarmament. It has been estimated that restarting the plant will cost $350 million; replacing it will cost 10 times as much and take at least 10 years.

title: Colombia Says It Has Begun Peace Talks With Guerrillas
description: The Government of President Virgilio Barco Vargas opened peace talks Friday with leftist guerrillas, Government officials said.

title:
ART;
Private Zeal on Public Display
description: LEAD: THE urge to gather and display objects that we treasure seems to be a fundamental human trait. For private individuals, collecting may be a pastime or a passion; for museums, it is their raison d'etre.

title: A GUIDEBOOK TO THE NEW MIRACLES
description: SCIENCE AND THE UNBORN Choosing Human Futures. By Clifford Grobstein. Illustrated. 207 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

title: Elizabeth Koontz, 69, Dies; Led Teachers' Union
description: Elizabeth Duncan Koontz, the first black president of the National Education Association and director of the Women's Bureau in President Nixon's Department of Labor, died Friday after a heart attack at her home in Salisbury, N.C. She was 69 years old.

title: The CD Revolution Is Here 20 Years Ahead of Schedule
description: Five years ago, in a Blithely prophetic mood, this column predicted that it would take about 25 years for the newly introduced CD to supplant the firmly entrenched LP record. Now it turns out that this prophecy erred on the side of caution by roughly 400 percent.

title: A Texas-Size Bet in Advertising
description: The commercial opens with a shot of the actor Randy Quaid slouched in his rather messy apartment, holding a beer and a very large sandwich. He is complaining in a folksy way about a party he recently attended. ''They didn't even serve beer,'' he grouses. ''I oughta throw a real party - Texas style. I'll stock that refrigerator full of Miller Lite and any Texan who wants one - come on over.'' Like others in the series, the television spot closes with Mr. Quaid promising to get back to viewers with more details about the upcoming bash.

title: Planning Ahead
description: Michael S. Dukakis, who spent much of 1988 in an unsuccessful bid to cut short his third term as Governor of Massachusetts by becoming President, announced last week that he will not seek a fourth term. Mr. Dukakis noted that he will have served for 12 years when his current term ends in 1990, and said that it would then be time to ''pass the mantle of leadership to new hands.'' There was speculation that Mr. Dukakis was making early preparation for a 1992 Presidential run, and at least one Democratic political consultant said the Governor had ''started to plant the seeds'' for such a campaign. But Dukakis aides insisted that it was too early to speculate, and the 55-year-old Governor offered only vague hints at his plans, saying, ''Public policy and public service is what I'm all about.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Quick Fiction

title: Playing It Straight
description: Perhaps it is a measure of how East-West relations have changed. Vyacheslav Fetisov, a Red Army hockey player who would like to play for the New Jersey Devils, has made no perilous dash for freedom, but is behaving like any pro athlete seeking to be traded. While his team has been playing a series of exhibition matches against American teams - the last one is set for tomorrow in Buffalo - Fetisov has bantered with reporters, wheedled his coach, and even discussed the matter with the Soviet Ambassador to the United States. There is no question that the Devils want the Russian star - his team beat them 5-0 - but the Soviets seem reluctant. Asked last week if something could be worked out, Fetisov's coach said, ''It's possible for him to stay here, but not now.''

title: Big Stanley Wins Tropical
description: Big Stanley, the quickest 2-year-old sprinter in Florida last year, carried his speed a mile and an eighth today to win the $166,950 Tropical Park Derby by 1 3/4 lengths at Calder Race Course.

title: Reagan's Budget Gives Bush Some Room to Negotiate
description: President Reagan will submit a final budget Monday that largely suits George Bush's priorities but still leaves the President-elect opportunity to put his own stamp on the Government.

title: The Super Baby Burnout Syndrome
description: PARENTS HAVE LONG appreciated the Picasso-like brilliance of their own children's first finger-painting. But never before have they paid so much attention to the amateur-quality strokes of the child next door.

title: The Everlasting Autodidact
description: MY HIGH SCHOOL classmates completed four years of college last June, a date at which I too had completed four years of study. Their graduation was greeted by presents, parties and diplomas. Mine never occurred. What studies and studies and never graduates? The answer can be found in one word: autodidact. It can be used to describe anyone who is self-taught, and the self-taught are almost anyone.

title: Tasteful to Tasteless With a Flick of the Dial
description: What's it to be: gentility or barbarity? Television can give you either, as long as a demand is detected. On tonight's Masterpiece Theater presentation, ''A Wreath of Roses,'' we can find British actors bringing a familiar measure of good taste and, yes, exquisite manners to a violence-tinged tale of loneliness. Then, in the barbarity sweepstakes, some of the extremes have reached a point that must give pause to students of contemporary civilization. Submitted for evidence is ''The Diceman Cometh,'' a Home Box Office ''On Location'' comedy special that had its debut New Year's Eve and will be rattling around the HBO schedule for a couple more weeks. The star is Andrew ''Dice'' Clay, a former Brooklynite who has parlayed street-corner lewdness into a presumably profitable gig. The pay-cable service is carefully promising that the program will never be shown earlier than midnight. As one executive murmurs: ''Put the children away for this one.'' Masterpiece Theater is undergoing some basic changes this season. There will be more ''one-shot'' dramas, presented in a single evening instead of being stretched into a mini-series. And there will be fewer pieces done in period costumes. Coming up in a few weeks, on Feb. 12, for example, is Alan Bennett's ''Bed Among the Lentils,'' taken from a series of six monologues he wrote for the BBC under the umbrella title of ''Talking Heads.'' The ''Lentils'' play is about a woman describing her very unfulfilling marriage to a much-beloved vicar of the Church of England. The exercise is a touch strained, but it gives the enormously gifted Maggie Smith an opportunity to deliver the most brilliant performance you are likely to see this year.

title: They Talk a Lot, but at Least They're Trying
description: ''In a way, they're pretty touching. They all talked so much. Like they'd seen this movie and wanted to be in it.'' That's Sam, the 16-year-old son of Jake and Catherine, explaining his parents to the audience in Susan Miller's new play, ''For Dear Life,'' which opens Tuesday at the Public Theater.

title: 'Essence of North Carolina' Leaves Office at 89
description: Thaddeus Armie Eure, the nation's longest-serving state official, has ended a 52-year career as North Carolina's Secretary of State.

title: Eilat
description: To the Editor: If I wanted to boost tourism in Redneck City and was able to finagle a Travel section story on this hot spot, would you print the boast that my resort has no Jewish community? Would you run a promotion that implies ''Jew-Free Vacation!''? I hope not. And I would have hoped that you would not have done so on Dec. 11 in reference to the lack of Arabs in Eilat, Israel (''Eilat has no Arab community . . . a fact the city's boosters like to point out'').

title: For Food Pantry Volunteers, All Is Not Peaches and Cream
description: ''HEY, lady, what number are you at?'' The young man tries to peek over my shoulder at the stack of numbered cards I'm holding. I tell him the number, he sighs noisily.

title: Exploring the Heart of Old Rabat
description: THE Kasbah des Oudaia in Rabat stands as it has for centuries, aloof atop the cliffs overlooking the Atlantic and the Bou Regreg River, keeping watch over the mouth of the river, the inland plain and the little boats ferrying people to Sale, Rabat's gleaming white sister city on the right bank of the river. Gauzy light, particular to the North African Atlantic coast, warms the air gently, but effectively, as the morning advances, and the streets of the medina - the old city wrapped around the base of the casbah - begin to empty around midday.

title: Sifting Through Bushels of Beethoven
description: Beethoven remains the center of our musical, or at least our classical-musical, or at least our orchestral, life. No better proof of that can be found than in the bins of our record stores, where a seemingly unstoppable flow of new Beethoven symphony recordings gushes forth every month.

title: Reagan, Qaddafi and the Death Cloud
description: TWO weeks before leaving office, the Reagan Administration was again tangling with the man America loves to hate - Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya. As they have done in the past, the Western European allies last week were sitting on the sidelines, wringing their hands and wondering whether the other shoe would drop.

title: Tap-Dancing Teachers: This Is Education?
description: In an age when people have lost faith in the quality of education, when pupils are at risk and receiving less instruction within the classroom, how could the Port Jefferson Board and principals allow teachers to spend time tap dancing for parents, a district conference and for the entire school LLong Island Journal, Nov. 27, 1988 ] ? Since when is a soft-shoe performance more important than education? The energy and emotions applied to this extravaganza should have been applied to lessons. What are they trying to prove?

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The heady days of pre-October 19 gave birth to this case. It is probably one of 1,000 tragedies from that day.'' Kalman Gallop, lawyer for Stanley Aslanian Jr., former Wall Street executive who agreed to plead guilty to stock fraud.

title: How an Era Empowered Students
description: WHERE ONCE decisions about college life were made by administrators and faculty, the 60's changed all that. Today student representatives sit on panels and committees alongside faculty and officials. Where once students were seen and heard only in the classroom context, the 60's empowered them. Now their counsel is institutionalized, in an effort to avoid potential conflicts.

title: Christmas: 'Mistreated And Misinterpreted'
description: I'm a Christian and the Christmas described in ''Christmas Is Not My Holiday'' [ Westchester Opinion, Dec. 11 ] is not my holiday either. Like so many Christian and Jewish brethren, Christmas has been misinterpreted and mistreated for decades.

title: John W. Kjorlien Is the Bridegroom Of Ms. Kowalski
description: The marriage of Suzanne Celia Kowalski, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon John Kowalski of Captiva Island, Fla., and Woodstock, Vt., to John Walker Kjorlien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence John Kjorlien of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Osterville, Mass., took place yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Kevin Royal performed the ceremony. Elizabeth Buck King was the matron of honor, and James Edward Kjorlien was his brother's best man.

title: Moss Dismissed
description: Coaches who take over teams that have been in recent trouble with the National Collegiate Athletic Association are forever complaining that they are being unfairly punished for transgressions committed by others when the N.C.A.A. imposes sanctions on their programs long after the infractions were committed. Often, they note, by the time the N.C.A.A. acts against a program, the coaches who actually committed the violations are at other schools and escape punishment altogether.

title: CONSUMER RATES
MRS. THATCHER'S CHILDREN
description: I did enjoy Malcolm Bradbury's piece about Mrs. Thatcher's children, who are raking it in all over the new-look, designer Britain. For one thing, it's always nice to read about oneself. For another, Mr. Bradbury's assertions weren't too far off the mark.

title: Baseball Fans Should Strike, Too
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Reagan Budget: $1.15 Trillion
description: When President Reagan submits the final budget of his Presidency Monday, it will be the first in which both spending and revenue exceed $1 trillion.

title: Grief and Apathy as Expatriates Mourn Hirohito
description: Despite the absence of black bunting and other outward signs that Japan's Emperor had just died, Japanese residents running errands in the slushy cold of this village today related a sense of loss, however muted by the thousands of miles separating them from Japan.

title: Review/Dance; Lindsay Fischer Stars as Balanchine's 'Apollo'
description: A talented young dancer became a noble god on Friday night at the New York State Theater when Lindsay Fischer of the New York City Ballet gave his first performance in the title role of George Balanchine's ''Apollo.''

title: Residential Resales

title: Question Of the Week; Which Teams Will Meet in the Super Bowl?
description: Since the Giants are out of it, I really don't care. Anyway, I think the Cincinnati Bengals and the Chicago Bears will meet in the Super Bowl. It will be a great matchup between the Boomer and Jim (Taco Bell) McMahon. ADAM KRAMER Madison, Conn.

title:
ART;
Ephemeral Pairing of Granite and Steel
description: LEAD: THE hefty sculptures of John Van Alstine that currently fill the main exhibition space at the Jersey City Museum might constitute an ode to New Jersey. Though there is nothing of the woodlands here, the pieces are typically made of combinations of granite and steel - an incongruous pairing in sculpture indeed.

title: A Musician in the Process Of Inventing Himself
description: With his moviestar good looks, sultry New Orleans drawl and conviction that the jazz musician should be an entertainer as well as an instrumentalist, Harry Connick Jr. may have what it takes to inject the world of traditional jazz with a shot of Hollywood glamour.

title: 3 Killed and One Is Injured in Connecticut Crash
description: Three men were killed and a fourth was critically injured when their car slammed into the back of a tractor-trailer in Farmington, Conn., late Friday night, the state police reported.

title: A NEW BREED AT THE BARRICADES
description: SOPHISTICATED REBELS The Political Culture of European Dissent, 1968-1987. By H. Stuart Hughes. 172 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: 'MR. STOCK MARKET': Li Yining; Selling China on a 'Public' Privatization
description: Some economists dream of writing textbooks, others of having equations named for them. Li Yining is more ambitious: He dreams of changing China.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 8, 1989
Walter Cronkite: Speaking His Mind Instead of Just News
description: Walter Cronkite had always been more comfortable delivering the news than making it. But something was gnawing at him, and when the opportunity arose one evening not long after George Bush was elected President, Mr. Cronkite made a speech in defense of liberal values that surprised people more than he could have imagined.

title: Clearwater Coffee House Organized
description: AN unusual folk-singing revival will get under way in northern Westchester next Saturday evening when the folk singer Pete Seeger performs at the opening of the Walkabout Clearwater Coffee House at the Harvey School Hall in Katonah. Organizers of the monthly nonprofit coffee house say they hope the audience will sing in the chorus and help with the environmental-action programs of Walkabout Clearwater, a nonprofit environmental organization chartered by the Poughkeepsie-based Clearwater Inc. and devoted to the same environmental-action program as its sponsor.

title: Class Ranking Falling From Favor
description: LEAD: A GROWING number of Westchester's public and non-public high schools are doing away with class ranking, as administrators, parents and students conclude that the practice only increases competition among already pressured college-bound students.

title: Trash Cans: Orange Sentinels of Brave New World
description: IF it's orange, it must be Wednesday. Like soldiers they line both sides of the street as far as the eye can see. Each week the bright-orange trash cans of Smithtown's recycling program stand neatly at curbside.

title: Pentagon Mapping Action in Fraud Investigation
description: Pentagon lawyers, spending this weekend sorting through new disclosures in the investigation of military contracting, expect soon to announce steps against companies, consultants and Government officials involved in the case.

title: A Smoker's Advice
description: To Legislators I am angered that the County Board of Legislators is considering a bill that would ban smoking in public places and workplaces in the county.

title: Jill Caryn Norman, a Lawyer, Marries Sami Hisham Fouad in Massachusetts
description: Jill Caryn Norman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Norman of Concord, Mass., was married there yesterday to Sami Hisham Fouad, the son of Dr. and Mrs. A. A. Fouad of Ames, Iowa. Naomi Cherny, a Justice of the Peace of Lexington, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Concord Academy Chapel.

title:
Peapack-Gladstone Journal;
Tax Break for Moroccan King Is Drawing Notice
description: LEAD: A TAX cut fit for a king hasn't gone unnoticed in this small, affluent borough.

title: Cheers for the Lower Half
description: AS president of the New Jersey chapter of the National Association of the Lower Half and one of the founders of the organization, I want to express our organization's concern and annoyance over the criticism and harassments directed toward Dan Quayle for his scholastic record.

title: Canadians Fight Again, in Two Languages
description: THE struggle over language in Canada has roots that go back to the 17th-century, when England and France first locked horns over the vast hinterland of North America. For the past 20 years, the legacy has been a bitter battle over the right of English and French minorities in various parts of the country to the full use of their languages.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Louisville, Ky.;
Overbuilt? Build On!
description: LEAD: IN the face of what has been an overbuilt rental market in the East End suburbs, the Paragon Group of Dallas and Carney Development Company of Louisville are doing what few others will try in 1989 - building more apartments.

title:
GARDENING;
Some Plants Will Grow, Sun or Not
description: LEAD: GARDENING jargon is bandied about more often than it is explained. This certainly is the case with terms used to describe the kinds of natural light available for growing house plants, such as bright light, diffused sun, partial shade and reflected light.

title: Age-Old Scottish Treat: Oatcakes
description: ''OATCAKES are a delicate relish when eaten warm with ale,'' wrote Robert Burns in the late 18th century. His fellow countrymen may have agreed with that sentiment but they also ate theirs with eggs, cheese and cod. Most Scots, in fact, considered oatcakes to be their daily bread and by 1929, when F. Marion McNeill penned ''The Scots Kitchen,'' she wrote, ''Oatcakes are especially good with herrings, sardines, cheese, curds, buttermilk, broth, and kail; or spread with butter and marmalade to complete the breakfast.''

title: Barbers Say 1984 Law Makes It Difficult to Do Their Business
description: LEAD: FOR years Richard Spataro has offered a full line of services for male and female customers at his small shop in this Monmouth County community. But Mr. Spataro says a 1984 state law intended to upgrade the barber industry may actually drive him out of business.

title: Bread and Butter Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Planning for the Inevitable Rainy Day
description: As is usually the case, many people ushered in the new year resolving to put their affairs in order. One good place to begin, experts say, is to work out a system to deal with accidents, serious illness or other emergencies.

title: Moscow's Afghan Envoy Looks to Political Solution
description: Moscow's special envoy to Afghanistan said today that the solution to the Afghan conflict lay in the political and not in the military realm.

title: Part of the Family
description: BUNDLE up and prune; lack of leaves reveals tree/shrub scaffolding, which makes it easier to do some judicious cutting; this is also a good time to prune overgrown conifers and hollies. Cut off the Christmas tree branches and place them over perennials to protect early growth in spring. Do not overfeed or overwater house plants now because most of them are in a resting or dormant period. A Heritage Plant

title: London
description: To the Editor: I would like to embellish on the ''Where to Eat'' section of ''What's Doing in London'' (Travel, Nov. 27).

title: In Defense of Celibidache
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PARIS - MINISkIRTS OF THE MIND
description: Around the display tables of university bookstores, ''the latest fashion from Paris'' does not refer to the length of skirts. It refers to a series of startling ideas and images out of the French mind. In paraphrase: That truth is castrating and humanism oppressive. That the ego is infinitely dissolvable. That a person is made up of syllables and life is really a run-on sentence that only death can bring to an end. That nihilism is the only defensible philosophy for modern times. That May 1968 says it all. So beware. Don't be misled by that academic vernacular spoken on college campuses. When some stylish student reproves ''Oh, that went out a year ago,'' it is not Pierre Cardin she has on her mind. What she has on her mind is some form of French-spoken consciousness. An author: Sartre, Levi-Strauss, Piaget, Barthes, Lacan, Foucault, Derrida, Kristeva. A text : ''Being and Nothingness,'' ''The Order of Things,'' ''Of Grammatology.'' A movement: existentialism, structuralism, deconstructionism. A Gaulish mantra: semiology, post-modern feminism, intertextuality, the arbitrariness of the sign. A meditation: on negation, on impiety, on the void.

title: Pretoria Held to Create Namibia Rebel Group
description: A Namibian opposition leader has asserted that South Africa is creating a rebel Namibian group similar to groups aided in the past by South Africa in Mozambique and in Angola.

title: Sikhs Kill 14 Hindus After Executions in India
description: Sikh militants shot to death 14 Hindus today in two attacks in the northern Indian state of Punjab, apparently seeking to avenge the hanging of two Sikhs convicted in the 1984 assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title:
ART;
In Hartford, Contrasts Between the Regular and the Free Flow
description: LEAD: AT 100 Pearl Street in the thick of downtown Hartford is a brand-new office building, which, like so many complexes in urban areas, has agreed to make some of its ground floor space a public amenity. In this case, an ample lobby area has been put in the care of the Connecticut Gallery whose home, in contrast, is in bucolic surroundings in nearby

title:
Long Island Interview: Spencer Ross;
Helping Businesses Expand International Trade
description: LEAD: THE Trade Development Consortium, a Long Island-based foreign trade incubator, is looking for a selected number of Island businesses to explore affordable exporting with the help of experts.

title: Howard Beach Victim Convicted in a Shooting
description: Timothy Grimes, one of the victims of the Howard Beach racial violence, has been convicted of malicious wounding for shooting his brother in the face.

title: 'A POWERFUL LOT OF TRIBULATIONS'
description: LEAD: BULLWHIP DAYS The Slaves Remember. Edited by James Mellon. Illustrated. 460 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $27.50.

title: Editors' Note
description: The main article in the Business section on Dec. 25 discussed the possibility of renewed regulation on Wall Street, spurred by Drexel Burnham Lambert's decision to plead guilty to fraud. The article said critics of deregulation would probably paint the Drexel case as only the latest example of Wall Street's being out of control; it listed other disputed behavior, some illegal and some not.

title: Football Is Levy's Obsession
description: In his loafers, cable-knit sweater and chinos, Marv Levy looks like a middle-aged poet.

title: BONN TO REVIEW AMERICAN EVIDENCE ON LIBYAN PLANT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced steps today to convince West Germany that a Libyan plant that the United States says is intended to produce chemical weapons was built with German help.

title: Review/Music; 2 Quintets In Return Engagement
description: Weill Recital Hall is regularly visited by ensembles from universities across the country; that is one of the traditional ways for faculties to declare themselves to the larger musical community. Not many of them, though, are assisted in their programs by one of New York's best-known chamber groups. This was the unusual privilege of the Missouri Arts Quintet in its visit Friday night, when the New York Woodwind Quintet joined the program after intermission for Samuel Baron's transcription for double wind quintet of the Mendelssohn Octet for strings.

title: For High Schools, a Look at the Future
description: LEAD: SIX New Rochelle High School students spent a recent afternoon discussing red and white blood cells and different types of cancers. Instead of reading from a science textbook in a classroom at the high school, the juniors and seniors learned first-hand about the topic in a two-hour, after-school session at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center.

title: THE NATION: Barry's City; The Mayor's Troubles Turn Washingtonians To Local Business
description: ''One of these days this will be a great city, if nothing happens to it.'' - Henry Adams, 1877.

title: HE NEARLY GOT AWAY - IT WAS A SATURDAY
description: FAMILY OF SPIES Inside the John Walker Spy Ring. By Pete Earley. 385 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house. Do you have any ideas before we put on a new coat of stain?

title: Who Knew What Will Remain Unknown
description: PERHAPS more than a whimper, but there certainly wasn't much of a bang when the main thrust of the Government's case against Oliver L. North collapsed last week.

title: ROLE IN DRUG WAR FOR NATIONAL GUARD
description: Select National Guard forces, including helicopter units and military police detachments, will be used increasingly this year in anti-drug activities. Defense Department officials hope one result will be to ease public pressure on the Air Force, Army and Navy to fight drugs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will do everything in our power to prevent German nationals, citizens of the Federal Republic of Germany and German companies from cooperating in a foreign country in the production of chemical weapons.'' - Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. [ 1:6. ]

title: Navy Officer Wed To Miss Morford
description: At St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington, Charlotte Weeks Morford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Morford of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to Lieut. Comdr. Steven Anthony Fillipow, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Fillipow of Long Beach, Calif. The Rev. William McDonald Tully performed the ceremony. Katherine Jean Hoving was the maid of honor, and Lieut. Peter Woodbury Dunn Morford, U.S.N., the bride's brother, was the best man.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house. Do you have any ideas before we put on a new coat of stain?

title: A Clash Of Proud, Big Egos In N.F.C.
description: Rarely in any sport do two teams clash who have egos larger than the field boundaries on which they will play, who display confidence that oozes and overflows from owner down to equipment manager and who have the players to back any boast no matter how boisterous, no matter how brash.

title: Enlisting a List to Keep a Community's Charm Unusullied
description: AT the turn of the century, summertime crowds of New Yorkers came by train to vacation in the seaside village of Stony Creek and the nearby Thimble Islands. The New Yorkers who now come to Stony Creek hope to buy part of it. Although the state's real estate market as a whole has cooled, Stony Creek, on Long Island Sound, remains a hot property.

title: 12 Arabs Wounded in Uprising
description: Israeli troops shot and wounded 12 Palestinian demonstrators today, and there were conflicting reports over responsibility for the overnight killing of a West Bank village leader.

title: Migratory Birds
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentine, Aiming to Please, Runs as a Peron for the 90's
description: Carlos Saul Menem is known as a pleasant fellow who can't say no and as a man who likes to be photographed with showgirls and belly dancers.

title: Jersey Buys Computer to Match Fingerprints
description: A system to match fingerprints in a few hours is to be introduced this year, New Jersey officials said this week. The $12.2 million Automated Fingerprint Identification System can compare prints from a crime scene with the 1.9 million in the state's file at the rate of 9,000 a minute, officials said.

title: Mink Coat Serves To Bare Cold Facts
description: A MINK coat as both lure and coverup is the peg on which the British sex farce ''Not Now Darling'' hangs.

title: Nothing to Laugh About
description: To the Editor:

title: A Seasoned Broadcast Producer Turns to Cable
description: ''A producer's lifeblood is access to air time,'' said Av Westin, ''whether it is on a network station, on cable or on a cassette for which someone makes his own air time.''

title: Hoyas Trounce Miami
description: Alonzo Mourning scored 15 of his season-high 26 points in the decisive first half as Georgetown snapped Miami's five-game winning streak with a 112-79 victory today.

title: Q and A
description: Turks and Caicos

title: From Collaboration, a Strange Beauty Emerged
description: A curious intimacy exists between artists in a collaboration. A distant closeness.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINIONSaluting the LEgacy ofthe Constitution State
description: LEAD: THIS week the people of Connecticut will celebrate the reason we are called the Constitution State.

title: Anne Rittenberry To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Giles Rittenberry of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Boughton Rittenberry to Walter M. Steppacher 4th, the son of Mr. Steppacher 3d and Margery D. Steppacher, both of Poughkeepsie. A May wedding is planned.

title: Luke Baione, 67, a Banking Executive, Dies
description: Luke A. Baione, the former chairman of Crossland Savings Bank, the nation's 11th-largest savings institution, died of cancer Friday at his home in Staten Island. He was 67 years old.

title: Evelyn M. Day Becomes Bride Of David Lasry
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Evelyn Morris Day, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney D. Day 3d of New York and Bryn Mawr, was married yesterday to David Paul Lasry, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James E. Lasry of La Jolla, Calif. The Very Rev. Arnold E. Mintz performed the ceremony.

title: The Name of the Game
description: OVER the holidays I devised a great new party game, called ''Pass the Point and Shoot.'' The rules are simple. After spinning the camera on a table to see who goes first, you turn on its self timer and begin passing it around the table, to your left.

title: The Trade War Keeps Simmering
description: The new-year trade war between the United States and Europe got off to a halting start. The European Community, led by Jacques Delors of France, did impose its Jan. 1 ban on meat from animals treated with growth hormones. Washington, which says the ban is trade protectionism and not a health measure, did apply its 100 percent retaliatory tariff on $100 million worth of European food imports. But both sides agreed that they wanted to seek a settlement and that these sanctions would not apply to products that were shipped before Jan. 1. The Europeans say unless there is a settlement soon, they will put tariffs on about $100 million worth of American walnuts and a variety of dried and other fruits.

title: Harking to The Muse Of Music
description: There may be many composers who made a major mark in other fields than music, though the only ones who occur to me are Charles Ives (insurance), Paul Bowles (fiction) and Arnold Schoenberg (painting). Turn the coin the other way, however, and the situation changes: famous people from every sector of the nonmusical world seem impelled to dabble in composition. Does writing music really appear that easy from the outside?

title: Cyanide Said Found In Teen-ager's Home
description: Cyanide has been found in the home of a teen-ager who lapsed into a coma after eating yogurt tainted with the poisonous substance, a newspaper reported today.

title: Kay M. Larholt Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Larholt of London of the engagement of their daughter Kay Marice Larholt to Neill Eric Silverman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Silverman of Livingston, N.J. Miss Larholt, a doctoral candidate in biostatistics at the Harvard University School of Public Health, graduated from Ben Gurion University in Beersheba, Israel. Her fiance, a senior associate at the Boston law firm of Perkins, Smith, Arata & Howard, graduated magna cum laude form Dartmouth College and cum laude from the Cornell University Law School.

title: Philippine Troops Rout Muslims Who Seized a Military Garrison
description: Troops backed by combat helicopters stormed a military garrison today held by Muslim gunmen and ended a three-day standoff in which at least 17 people were reportedly killed.

title: N.C.A.A. Director to Continue Plans for Playing by the Rules
description: In his first major speech as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's executive director last January, Dick Schultz told a convention audience that intercollegiate athletics, in attaining unprecedented popularity and riches, had lost a measure of its integrity.

title: Defining Factors On Exercising
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: John Ehrman Plans To Wed Ms. Parsont
description: The engagement of Diane Marie Parsont to John Ehrman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Ehrman of East Sandwich, Mass., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Elinor S. Parsont of Port Chester, N.Y., and Robert E. Parsont of New Rochelle, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: Writer vs. Robot
description: LAST WEEK I RECEIVED a 'Grammatik III' word-processing program,'' writes Gertrude M. Webb of Waltham, Mass., ''and have been using it to analyze my own written work. I thought it might be fun to 'Grammatik-ize' a few paragraphs of your column. I'm passing the robot's comments along to you. Enjoy.''

title: The World of Hamilton High
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Plants That Overcame the Summer of '88
description: LEAD: HEAT and drought took a heavy toll last summer in gardens. With watering restrictions in many areas, some plants faded away. But there were some plants that not only survived, but also thrived.

title: A Job For the Holidays: The Other Side of the Counter
description: IN my newly independent circumstances, the salary from my full-time job barely covers my expenses - expenses being all those boring necessities like food, shelter, car maintenance and panty hose. So to make a little extra cash for the holidays, I pounded the pavement one day in November asking local shopkeepers if they needed Christmas help on Saturdays through the season. The ''educational'' (expensive) toy store called me the next week, and I took the job.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Shopping Centers; A Green Light for a South Bronx Venture
description: YES, Gigi, they really are going to build a shopping mall and movie theaters on 161st Street in the South Bronx.

title: Book on Valvano Brings a Denial
description: Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State basketball coach and athletic director, said he was never interviewed for a book scheduled for publication next month that, according to a published report, accuses him of running a corrupt basketball program on its jacket.

title: Rangers Pick Islanders To Pieces
description: After the game, the Rangers spoke of togetherness, the Islanders of disintegration.

title: Doctor's Practice is Playing Jazz Bass
description: LEAD: DR. LYN CHRISTIE is a general practitioner, although the only practicing he does these days is on his bass. Yet the same sense of duty to the community that informed his medical career now forms his musical inspiration.

title:
ART;
Faces of Nepal: Portrait Photographer in a Far Land
description: LEAD: FEW things make us as conscious of the years passing by as portrait photography. But, of course, this art form also has the potential to give much more than documentary evidence of appearances at a given moment.

title: Deborah Wickenden, Writer, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. James W. Wickenden of Belle Mead, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Wickenden to Lieut. James Arthur Crisfield, U.S.A.F., a son of James P. Crisfield of Youngstown, N.Y., and Lucile Stafford Proctor of Princeton, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Changes and Uncertainty in the Theater Season
description: ACCORDING to the theater calendar, the beginning of the year corresponds to the middle of the season. By January, one can be certain that theater schedules will have changed since the first announcements of September. Some shows have been postponed or canceled; others have been switched to different time slots.

title: No Need For Decay
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rebuttal To Cablevision
description: Cablevision has been running recent TV commercials portraying ''the man on the street'' in an interview situation. A woman claims she is not a sports fan, so why should she be expected to pay an increased rate if MSG (the Madison Square Garden network) was incorporated into the basic service? Furthermore, why should someone who is not a Ranger or Knick fan have to pay for someone else's pleasure? This has been Cablevision's appeal to the consumer's pocketbook. Its depth is superficial at best and deserves some convincing rebuttal.

title: Where the Trout Reside, and Why Where the Trout Are Hiding, and Why
description: If you begin to peruse Tom Rosenbauer's ''Reading Trout Streams'' (Nick Lyons Books, $17.95) this winter, you'll spend less time flailing dead water when the fifth month's soft breezes are upon us.

title: State's Public Works Show: More than Just Buildings
description: PEDESTRIANS strolling through the West Rock Tunnel of the Merritt Parkway in New Haven on the day of its dedication, the stones of Bulkeley Bridge in Hartford being set by hand, and even a worker loitering by a portable latrine as construction of the Hartford Armory went on all around him - such sights as these tracing the history of Connecticut's public buildings, highways and bridges are displayed in a new exhibit at the Connecticut Museum of History.

title: Remorse From Dan Michel to James Joyce
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Warehouses; In a Tenant's Market, Bigger Is Considered Better
description: ALTHOUGH warehouse space tends to be tediously stable as a real estate investment in the metropolitan New York area, good fortune in 1988 was skewed sharply in favor of developers specializing in huge suburban warehouse complexes.

title: Pope Calls a Conference of African Bishops
description: Pope John Paul II has called a special synod of bishops on the role of the church in Africa, where Roman Catholicism is spreading faster than anywhere else.

title: Of Dorms and Roommates
description: WHEN Boston University moved last fall to prohibit students from having overnight visitors in their dormitories, some students were outraged but most of their parents were relieved. Spurred by the case of a parent irate because her daughter's roommate had a boyfriend sharing her room for two months, the university's president, John R. Silber, announced housing rules that enable only immediate family members to spend a night.

title: Nassau Museum: Disruptive Changes
description: I recently attended the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art, and, as in past visits, came away with an enjoyable and nourishing art experience. I am saddened to learn that the kind of exhibits and programs my family has come to expect may soon end.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THE yuppie baby boomers who are now gentrifying Jersey City in areas like Hamilton Park and Van Vorst Park know ''the Boss'' as the Jersey rock star Bruce Springsteen.

title: Style Meets Comfort
description: SHOE buying for women is often a compromise between fashion and comfort. But now the U.S. Shoe Company, which came out with a specialized walking show for women in 1987, has a walking pump. The Easy Spirit Dress pump has features that promise a high comfort quotient. The shoes have a wide toe box, contoured heel support, a flexible sole, breathable fabric lining, and two layers of a shock foam. They come in full and half sizes from 4 to 12 and widths from AAAA to EE. They are available in 11 colors in leather, and black patent leather. Priced from $70 to $80, the pump are sold in department stores across the nation, including Macy's Northeast, Jordan Marsh, Nordstrom's and Woodward & Lothrop, and Red Cross and Cobbie shoe shops.

title: FILM VIEW: 'Mississippi Burning': Generating Heat or Light?; Taking Risks to Illuminate a Painful Time in America
description: ''Mississippi Burning'' is now on trial. It's just 21 years and three months since the climax of the case that inspired the movie, when a group of white supremacists were put into the dock and charged with violating the civil rights of three young voter-registration workers. The means being murder, the violations were permanent. The film, a fictionalized investigation into that case, is being treated with everything from seriously reasoned outrage to the sort of lazy contempt one hears expressed at cocktail parties: Hollywood is Hollywood so what can you expect?

title: Voicing a Conviction
description: In what appeared to be a display of something other than dazzling legal footwork, Ira D. London, the defense attorney in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg, said last week that his client would probably be found guilty and be sent to prison. Some legal experts called the remarks inappropriate and improper, and said they suspected that Mr. London was using the press to tell jurors something he could not say in his courtroom defense of Mr. Steinberg, who is charged with the beating death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg. Some lawyers said that Mr. London's words - he said, ''The best thing we can hope for is a verdict of criminally negligent homicide'' -could have the effect of persuading jurors even before they get the case that they could consider charges less serious than second-degree murder.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: WHEEL OF THE WINDS (Tor, $18.95) is M. J. Engh's second novel. Her first, ''Arslan,'' which was published in 1976 and reissued in 1987, is a disturbing fantasy about different kinds of power - political, moral, personal. In it the United States is taken over, with hardly a shot fired, by a charismatic Central Asian adventurer named General Arslan.

title:
The Road to Industrial Rebirth;
Down With Bureaucrats
description: LEAD: A Pentagon official is creating a stir with a very unofficial briefing. In his audience-participation talks, Tom Amlie, an Air Force technical systems specialist, takes his largely military audiences through a history of weapons innovations since the Civil War. He asks his listeners to vote on whether each innovation significantly improved fighting capabilities and whether it was preferred by the Defense (or War) Department.

title: INSIDE
description: Gorbachev Assails Skeptics

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Chamber Urges End to Rent Regulation
description: LEAD: A LEADING Westchester business group says that the county can resolve a major part of its affordable-housing problems by ending rent control.

title: 'A POWERFUL LOT OF TRIBULATIONS'
description: LEAD: WITHIN THE PLANTATION HOUSEHOLD Black and White Women of the Old South. By Elizabeth Fox-Genovese. Illustrated. 544 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $34.95. Paper, $12.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Plants That Overcame the Summer of '88
description: LEAD: HEAT and drought took a heavy toll last summer in gardens. With watering restrictions in many areas, some plants faded away. But there were some plants that not only survived, but also thrived.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE FACTS AND FICTIONS OF MINNA PRATT By Patricia MacLachlan. 136 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. (Ages 8 to 12

title: Skiers Aid The Battle On Cancer
description: WHILE traversing a snowy trail on Hamburg Mountain here five years ago, Paul Kattermann of Frankford Township, an avid skier, caught up to the 12 participants in the first Ski-a-thon benefit for the American Cancer Society and its Sussex County chapter.

title: Argentina
description: To the Editor: The Argentina Tourist Information Office listed in your article on Argentina (Travel, Oct. 2) is a travel agency, not a government office. The official Argentina Tourist Office in the United States is the Argentina National Tourist Office, 12 West 56th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; 212-603-0443. MIGUEL LOPEZ LECUBE New York, N.Y.

title: In the Boston Writers' Room, Few Distractions and Low Rent
description: In a room just down the hall from the State Secretary of Transportation's office and a few floors down from the headquarters for Boston's subway, Paul Tucker spends most of his days writing a book about Claude Monet's paintings of the 1890's.

title: A Town of Crystal And Old Artistry Near Florence
description: EVERYONE has heard of Venetian glass, but not even most Florentines, a mere 30 miles away, are aware of the crystal from Colle di Val d'Elsa, although 90 percent of Italy's crystal is made in this little hilltop town. More famous in Dante's time than it is today, the scene of a decisive battle between Ghibellines and Guelphs, the poetic-sounding Colle di Val d'Elsa (literally the Hill in the Valley of the River Elsa), off the busy superstrada on the way to Siena, is also the birthplace of Arnolfo di Cambio, the greatest architect of his time, who designed Florence's Cathedral.

title: Down to Size
description: I HAVE MOSTLY BLAND recollections of the professors in my seven years of higher education. Two I recall vividly, because -though it was not their intention - they terrified me.

title:
GARDENING;
Plants That Overcame the Summer of '88
description: LEAD: HEAT and drought took a heavy toll last summer in gardens. With watering restrictions in many areas, some plants faded away. But there were some plants that not only survived, but also thrived.

title: Press Won't Chuck That Woodchuck Story
description: How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?

title: Pension Profits
description: To the Editor:
