title: 'Virus' Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Concur on Raise, Especially in New York
description: To Judge James L. Oakes, a good illustration of why Federal judges deserve pay raises is what happens to their clerks when they join law firms.

title: Dispute Over Halpin Policy
description: DIFFERENCES in the interpretation of Suffolk County's policy of arrests in domestic violence have arisen since the recent murder of Elizabeth Croff by her estranged husband, William Croff, and his suicide.

title: GORBACHEV ASSAILS ECONOMIC SKEPTICS
description: The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, sounding unusually beleaguered and defensive, has lashed out at critics and supporters alike for losing faith in his economic program, and hinted more strongly that his initiatives have encountered high-level resistance.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house. Do you have any ideas before we put on a new coat of stain?

title: The Prado Shakes Off the Dust of Centuries
description: At least two prime ministers, the directors of several of the world's most illustrious museums and even Britain's Prince Charles are reported to have courted him, so when Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza finally signed an agreement a few weeks ago lending to the Prado for 10 years a major portion of his multibillion-dollar art collection, it seemed as though Spain had triumphed over formidable suitors.

title: Stock Manipulation
description: 'Mr. Sherwin called and asked me in summary and in substance: If they wanted to have Union Carbide close for a specific price for several days, could that be done? And I said, ''Yes.'' And Mr. Sherwin said, ''We'll make up any losses.'' . . . . In substance he said do you think you can close Union Carbide at 22 today, and I said, ''Sure, I think so.'' ' - Boyd L. Jefferies, former head of the brokerage firm Jefferies & Company, testifying in the securities fraud trial of James T. Sherwin, the vice chairman of the GAF Corporation.

title: A March Bridal For Ann Guthrie
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Mahlon G. Guthrie of Washington of the engagement of her daughter Ann Joyce Guthrie to Mark Kelsall Hingston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Hingston of Needham, Mass. The couple plan to marry in March.

title: Director's Post Empty Again at Hudson River Museum
description: AFTER serving a year and a half, Thomas S. Holman has resigned his post as director of the Hudson River Museum, museum officials and Mr. Holman confirmed last week. The 35-five-year old Mr. Holman, the fifth director in this decade, signed a letter of resignation on Monday.

title: Reviewing West Point's Honor Code
description: Twin studies of the West Point honor system, one by graduating cadets and the other by outside experts, are likely to produce changes later this year in the way the code of conduct is applied.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger. By Stephen King. (Plume/New American Library, Paper, $10.95.) He wears two guns as he pursues a mysterious man in black across ''the apotheosis of all deserts.'' But before you think of Clint Eastwood, you should know that he earned those guns in combat, armed only with a hawk, with his larger, older, presumably stronger teacher; that his land is called New Canaan, and that his name is Roland.

title: Classroom to Dias: Teacher of the Year
description: ALTHOUGH she begins her official reign as Connecticut Teacher of the Year for 1989 this month, in some ways Carol R. Virostek feels she has held the title for much, much longer.

title: Kimberly Bush Is Married to Jose Lopez-Castillo
description: At the Mystic Congregational Church in Mystic, Conn., Kimberly Earl Bush, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Bush Jr. of Noank, Conn., was married yesterday to Jose Miguel Lopez-Castillo, a son of Graciela Castillo del Valle of Mexico City and Miguel Lopez Somera of Topilejo, Mexico. The Rev. Peter B. Grandy performed the ceremony.

title: Sports of The Tims; Make Way for the Other Pros
description: For a change of pace, we will not have to worry today which football teams are ''clean'' or ''not clean.'' Did the Chicago Bears give a sports car to that mastodon as a bonus for enrolling at Halas U.? Tsk, tsk.

title: Lucy Garry Engaged To William Flinn 3d
description: Lucy Anne Garry and William Flinn 3d, a son of Elizabeth Folk Flinn and Michael de Vlaming Flinn, both of Greenwich, Conn., plan to marry in June, Miss Garry's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jay Garry of Atlanta, have announced.

title: New Opera and Old Wines
description: Music at Cathedral

title:
THEATER;
How One Tiny Theater Snared Harold Pinter
description: LEAD: Last Spring Harold Pinter sent Lauren Bacall down to Manhattan's East 13th Street to take a look at CSC Repertory's production of his play ''The Birthday Party.'' Her report so intrigued the playwright that when visiting New York in November he arranged to see the small, 180-seat theater and meet CSC's 29-year-old artistic director, Carey

title: The Cotswolds
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a bicycle trip through the Cotswolds and was interested to read Bruce Boucher's ''Stones of Wiltshire'' (Travel, Nov. 13) in which he describes the abbey at Malmesbury. I had spent part of an afternoon in this town while on the way to Bath.

title: The Financial-Aid Numbers Game
description: SWEATY PALMS. Rapid pulse. Muscle spasms. All symptoms of families anticipating those tuition and expense bills that will start arriving the moment their child starts his college career. But parents needn't resign themselves to elevated blood pressure or a four-year liquidity crisis; all they need do is learn - before their child applies to college - what financing is available at each one, and how it is parceled out.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Middletown, R.I.;
Sealed Bids Aid Condo Project
description: LEAD: A CHANCE to make sealed bids for purchases has increased interest in a new condominium project in this seaside town as the real-estate market has softened, the developers say.

title: Valarie King Is Engaged
description: Valarie King and Douglas P. Thoren, a son of Carol McKenna of Hoboken, N.J., and Donald P. Thoren of Mount Kemble Lake, N.J., plan to marry in August, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold King of Ridgefield, N.J., have announced. Ms. King, a graduate of Douglass College at Rutgers University, is studying for a Ph.D. in sociology at the University of Pennsylvania. Her fiance, a cum laude graduate of Seton Hall University, is an assistant professor of psychology at Rutgers and a candidate for a Ph.D. in psychology there.

title:
FOCUS: Boston;
From Navy Yard to a New Neighborhood
description: LEAD: ONE of the city's newest neighborhoods - with new and renovated housing, office and retail space, public parks, landing docks and private marinas - is emerging on the site of the former Charlestown Naval Shipyard on Boston Harbor.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ODYSSEY: Pepsi to Apple . . . A Journey of Adventure, Ideas, and the Future, by John Sculley with John A. Byrne. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) Having taken on Coke with the ''Pepsi Generation,'' John Sculley left his job as president of the soft-drink company to enforce some discipline at Apple Computer, where he eventually replaced the legendary Steven Jobs. This book ''is an intriguing account of one of the decade's most celebrated corporate crises,'' John Taylor said here in 1987. THE WESTERN LANDS, by William S. Burroughs. (Penguin, $7.95.) In the last book of a trilogy that began in 1981 with ''Cities of the Red Night,'' an old writer named William Seward Hall enlists the characters in his fiction to help him navigate through the netherworld to the Western Lands, the Egyptian name for Paradise. ''Mr. Burroughs has gone his own outrageous way and literary fashion has gone virtually in the opposite direction,'' Jonathan Baumbach said in The Book Review last year. ''The genius of this trilogy and of Mr. Burroughs's best work in general is that it sets itself virtually impossible tasks, springs from private obsession, makes little or no concession to the reader, offers us a vision that is viscerally unpleasant and often repellent, and still manages to work.'' DEBUTANTE, by Gioia Diliberto. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) With the help of the gossip columnists, a 17-year-old debutante named Brenda Frazier became such a sensation in 1938 that an orchid was named after her. ''There is something voyeuristic'' about this story of her eventual decline, John Gross said in The Times in 1987. But the author ''shows commendable skill in piecing together the whole sad story.'' THE MELTING POT: And Other Subversive Stories, by Lynne Sharon Schwartz. (Penguin, $7.95.) History shadows many of these stories, and in one of them memories of the Holocaust invade suburbia as a woman and her husband try to exterminate a colony of bees. ''Lynne Sharon Schwartz writes cleanly and with compassion,'' Perri Klass said here in 1987. PAST TENSE. Diaries: Volume One, by Jean Cocteau. Translated by Richard Howard. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $8.95.) In the first installment of the journal he kept during the last 13 years of his life, the film maker, artist and writer Jean Cocteau describes encounters with Colette, Matisse, Picasso, Jean Genet and Somerset Maugham. But it is most valuable, The Times's John Gross said in 1987, for its ''acute'' observations on Marcel Proust. THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD, by Iris Murdoch. (Penguin, $8.95.) Several lapsed revolutionaries from Oxford decide to bankroll their old friend David Crimond, who is writing a utopian tract. Last year our reviewer, Charles Newman, called this novel ''a triumphal celebration of literacy as a social bond.'' LEBANON'S PREDICAMENT, by Samir Khalaf. (Columbia University, $14.50.) A Lebanese sociologist tries to understand why his country fell apart. In 1987, Thomas L. Friedman said here that the book is ''suffused with the passion and insight of a true Beiruti trying to explain to himself and to the world why he can't go home anymore - why and how it happened that his house may still be standing, but the spirit that once inhabited his neighborhood . . . has scattered to the winds.'' TRICKS: An 87th Precinct Novel, by Ed McBain. (Avon, $3.95.) Trick-or-treaters are killing liquor store owners in the 39th installment of this series. In 1987 our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, compared this novel to ''expertly manufactured . . . literary furniture.'' But ''it's all done very professionally, and the writing races along.'' IN WHOSE INTEREST? International Banking and American Foreign Policy, by Benjamin J. Cohen. (Yale University, $12.95.) Bankers and diplomats have long enjoyed a symbiotic relationship, but what is good for international finance is not always good for the commonweal, Benjamin J. Cohen argues. Mr. Cohen has written ''a rich and engrossing analysis,'' Edward L. Morse said in The Book Review in 1986. LULLABY AND GOOD NIGHT, by Vincent T. Bugliosi with William Stadiem. (Signet/New American Library, $4.95.) Drawing on a sex scandal that made headlines in New York in the 1920's, two lawyers have written a novel about a woman who takes revenge on the political machine that framed her as a prostitute. Last year our reviewer, David Black, said the authors ''have attempted a moral complexity that is often missing in novels based on criminal cases. . . . It is an ambitious entertainment that strives to see a city - and an era - whole.'' CHAMBERET: Recollections From an Ordinary Childhood, by Claude Morhange-Begue. Translated by Austryn Wainhouse. (Marlboro, $9.) One day in 1944, when the author was 7 years old, the Nazis came and took her mother to Auschwitz. This memoir is ''heartbreaking,'' Marianne Veron said in The Book Review last year. Claude Morhange-Begue ''evokes the child's perception of the surface of life, the colors of the seasons and the loveliness of little things, but also her terror of the underlying drama that went unexplained.'' THE MURDER OF MIRANDA, by Margaret Millar. (International Polygonics, $4.95.) When a rich widow disappears along with the head lifeguard at a Palm Springs beach club, a young Hispanic lawyer named Tom Aragon is called to solve the case. In 1979 our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, said Margaret Millar ''is justly celebrated for her mastery. . . . She is a virtuoso.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Westwood
description: LEAD: EVEN before the Hackensack and New York Railroad rattled through in 1869, Westwood was a commercial center for the younger suburbs in north-central New Jersey. A huddle of stores on its main street and grist and lumber mills along the Pascack and Musquapsink Brooks, which flowed through it, served residents and businesses.

title: Two Counties Join in Sludge Disposal Plan
description: Westchester and Nassau Counties have agreed to team up to find alternatives to dumping sludge in the Atlantic Ocean, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said this week.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Reagan in 'Good Spirits' After Hand Surgery
description: President Reagan was termed in ''good spirits'' after minor surgery today to correct a condition that had caused a curvature of the ring finger on his left hand. A White House spokesman said Mr. Reagan remained awake throughout the operation and chatted about horses with his doctors.

title: Don't You Believe the Deficit Isn't a Problem; Late Conversions
description: To the Editor:

title: Video Olympics Test Fitness of the Young
description: LEN SAUNDERS grabbed a microphone, and the 250 elementary school students gathered in the gymnasium of the Valley View School grew silent. Mr. Saunders told them that most of their peers in the country did not know how to exercise and that he expected them to be exceptions.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 8, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 8 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 2 23 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent in the Soviet Union. 3 3 28 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 4 5 10 ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A man and his wife find themselves in a fantasy world where the possibilities of their pasts still exist. 5 4 19 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride to the North Pole and the magical events that follow. 6 6 8 DEAR MILI, by Wilhelm Grimm. (di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) A recently discovered tale by the 19th-century folklorist, illustrated by Maurice Sendak. 7 7 12 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and ''The Vampire Lestat.'' 8 8 12 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer from Philadelphia. 9 9 13 FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Colonel Qazi, an ''international terrorist,'' plots to steal American nuclear weapons. 10 13 23 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary New York. 11 11 16 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 12 10 10 MITLA PASS, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A writer's struggles with his heritage and two loves reach a climax during the 1956 Sinai war. 13 12 3 SPY HOOK, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $18.95.) The agent Bernard Samson on the trail of a financial scam within the British secret service. 14 15 33 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 15 20 TILL WE MEET AGAIN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $19.95.) The exploits of a woman and her two daughters from pre-World War I Paris to present-day Los Angeles. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 10 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 2 8 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 3 3 38 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 4 9 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 5 8 5 CHRISTMAS IN AMERICA, edited by David Cohen. (Collins Publishers, $35.) An album of pictures taken by 100 photographers. 6 7 8 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 7 5 12 SEVEN STORIES OF CHRISTMAS LOVE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack, $12.95.) The advocate of caring and love recalls experiences during holidays past. 8 6 12 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 9 10 14 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) A profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 10 11 27 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 11 12 4 THE HOME PLANET, edited by Kevin W. Kelley. (Addison-Wesley, $39.95.) How the earth looks from outer space, shown in 150 photographs. 12 9 11 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 13 13 11 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican Presidential nominee. 14 14 13 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 15 15 10 PRESS ON! by Chuck Yeager and Charles Leerhsen. (Bantam, $17.95.) The legendary pilot on flying, the outdoors and his West Virginia roots. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 8 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 2 3 24 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. 3 2 79 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 4 14 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur who deals in life insurance and investments. 5 5 12 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) JACK GANCE, by Ward Just. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) A Chicago boy rises through the Washington ranks to become a senator in this realistic novel of daily lives and moral choices among politicians and other Government inhabitants. OPERA, OR THE UNDOING OF WOMEN, by Catherine Clement. (University of Minnesota, Cloth, $35; Paper, $13.95.) A provocative and original examination, by a prominent French philosopher and cultural critic, of an art form in which women rarely win. THE FOUNDER: Cecil Rhodes and the Pursuit of Power, by Robert I. Rotberg with the collaboration of Miles F. Shore. (Oxford University, $35.) A richly detailed narrative history of the astonishing career that started South Africa on its current course. AMERICAN APPETITES, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $18.95.) Ms. Oates's 19th accomplished novel concerns a distinguished demographer on whose upmarket milieu a cloud descends when he kills his wife in self-defense. THE PARADISE EATER, by John Ralston Saul. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Mr. Saul's nihilistic hero, an import-export deal maker, slogs without hope through a consistently fascinating, voluptuously described environment of venality in Bangkok. THE BODY AND SOCIETY: Men, Women and Sexual Renunciation in Early Christianity, by Peter Brown. (Columbia University, $45.) An examination of sexuality in the ancient world and among early Christians, and of the wide variety of opinion that preceded the far-from-predetermined triumph of virginity over marriage. THE MAN BEHIND THE IRON MASK, by John Noone. (St. Martin's, $35.) What and who lay behind modern Europe's most romantic rumor? Mr. Noone's spirited review of former theories concludes by proposing a resolution of his own.

title: MORE DEMAND FOR THOSE WHO MAKE WATER FLOW
description: In 1985 and 1986, record high water in the Great Lakes washed away and flooded streets. In 1988, a dry, hot summer was followed by a quick return to substantially lower levels that left harbors too shallow for ships to navigate. The extreme fluctuations in water levels have created a nearly continuous debate among engineers and planners over the success - or lack of it - of current methods to regulate the water's rise and fall.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: New York Bans Waivers on Auto Rentals

title: Who Gets Credit For an Innovation?
description: WHO should get the credit for a brilliant idea - the thinker who conceived it or the player who first actually put it on the board?

title: Maria Lanari Married To John Foy, a Writer
description: Maria Jose Britto Pereira Lanari, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roberto Lanari of Rio de Janeiro, was married there yesterday to John FitzGerald Foy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. W. Foy of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Adilson performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Brejal Chapel.

title: It's a French-Inspired Find in Peapack LBy VALERIE SINCLAIR
description: SEVERAL years ago, a mini-phenomenon called bagel chips hit the stores. The idea originated with Jim Burns, Gary Ricker and Rene Reist, who were at that time owners of the Cheese Store in Bernardsville. Originally, the chips were a means of making use of bagels that would otherwise be thrown out.

title: PUBLIC AID THAT GOES WHERE DEVELOPERS FEAR TO TREAD
description: For many of the Great Lakes region's downtowns, which have been hurt by the move to the suburbs as well as by a persistent industrial image, waterfront redevelopment is considered risky at best - especially since private developers have generally preferred more populated cities and warmer climates.

title: AIDS on the Job: Businesses Fight Fears and Prejudices
description: ALTHOUGH the rising number of AIDS cases on Long Island has prompted concern among businesses, its impact in the workplace is hard to gauge because of the continuing stigma attached to AIDS and the reluctance of most affected employees to admit that they have the dreaded virus.

title: Led by Malone, Hawks Top Nets
description: Moses Malone scored 12 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter tonight, leading the Atlanta Hawks to a 103-93 victory over the Nets.

title: Latin America's Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Mary O'Connor To Be Married in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. O'Connor of Convent Station, N.J., and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Mary O'Connor to Michael V. McKay, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McKay of Hempstead, L.I. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

title: Urban Woes Add to Burdens of Legislators
description: THE stereotype of Connecticut as wealthy, content and pastoral persists despite growing evidence to the contrary. There are crime, drugs, overcrowded prisons and stagnant areas of dire poverty - all largely products of the state's big cities, a realm far removed from the Connecticut of Currier & Ives.

title: To Call Battle of the Little Bighorn an Ambush Distorts History
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Men Are Killed In Separate Incidents
description: Three people were killed Saturday in different drug-related incidents in New York City, the police said.

title: MANHATTAN GETS SECURITY NETWORK
description: A security network that puts 39 buildings in radio contact with police dispatchers began operating on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on Thursday, and organizers hope the program will spread to other buildings in the area and to other parts of New York City.

title: How Israel's Economic Revival Ran Out of Steam
description: AT the turn of the century, the creed of the founders of modern Israel was Labor Zionism. Steeped in European socialism and a belief in hard outdoor work, and determined to escape pogroms and shtetls, they sought not only a new country, but a new Jewish people.

title: Ambivalence Over Pill Grows With Risk Data
description: Ever since birth control pills were first marketed in the United States in 1960, many doctors and women have found themselves torn between enthusiasm for the liberating contraceptive and fears about possible dangers from long-term use.

title: Completing A Dream
description: From a farm on Long Island to Notre Dame to the Red Sox to baseball immortality in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Steinberg Case PromptsRise in Abuse Reports
description: THE death of Lisa Steinberg and the trial of her adoptive father led to an increase in reports of child abuse on Long Island during 1988, although authorities think that the incidence of abuse has probably not risen.

title: FLOURISHES
description: Do not underestimate the power of a beauty statement. When a number of women suddenly lop off their long hair, it may be more than just a collective whim. Short hair tends to be popular when women are battling societal restrictions. Right now, the feminine flourishes in fashion may be giving way to a more subdued, simplified look. That goes for makeup, too.

title: U.N.'s Angola Mission to Take Cuba at Its Word
description: When the long-awaited withdrawal of Cuba's 50,000-man military force starts here Tuesday, verification promises to be limited to a friendly United Nations officer standing dockside with a clipboard.

title: Americans Abroad
description: STORMY MONDAY Starring Melanie Griffith, Tommy Lee Jones (in photo, left), Sting (in photo), Sean Bean. Directed by Mike Figgis. 1988. Paramount Home Video. 92 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. Rated R.

title: Getting Your Family Onto the Slopes: A Primer
description: REMEMBER that crazy weekend in Vermont years ago when you first went skiing? You had a memorable time, even if you did crash into another skier and nearly fell off the lift. You were more daring in those days, but you didn't take up the sport. You're married now, have responsibilities, including a child or two, but you keep toying with the idea of getting the family on the slopes, schussing down trails together, relaxing in a lodge. How does the mature beginner (or re-beginner) set about getting it together?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Middletown, R.I.;
Sealed Bids Aid Condo Project
description: LEAD: A CHANCE to make sealed bids for purchases has increased interest in a new condominium project in this seaside town as the real-estate market has softened, the developers say.

title: Disaster Strikes and Red Cross is There
description: LEAD: DECEMBER may have been the busiest month for the many people preparing for holiday festivities, but it was also the busiest month of 1988 for the Red Cross disaster action team in Westchester. For the victims the team helped, it was the cruelest month - their homes were destroyed and their holiday gifts were left charred and soggy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Schneider Posts Eighth Cup Victory: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, skiing through a driving rain, captured her eighth straight World Cup victory and fourth giant slalom of the season yesterday in Schwarzenberg, Austria. She had the best time in both heats for a winning total of 2 minutes 16.75 seconds. On Friday, Schneider broke the record of six consecutive victories in Alpine skiing, held by Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden and Alberto Tomba of Italy.(AP) Soccer Coventry City Upset in Cup Play: Sutton United, a team of semiprofessional part-timers, stunned Coventry City, 2-1, yesterday and knocked the English League First Division team out of the F.A. Cup. Coventry, which won the cup two seasons ago, is fifth in the First Division. Matthew Hanlon of Sutton broke a 1-1 tie after 58 minutes of play.(AP) Tennis Kuhnen Moves Into Final: Seventh-seeded Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany outlasted unseeded Veli Paloheimo of Finland last night to advance to the final of the South Australian Open in Adelaide. Kuhnen took 2 hours 5 minutes to beat Paloheimo, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. He will face the defending champion, Mark Woodforde of Australia, in the final. The fourth-seeded Woodforde gained the final with a 6-2, 7-5 victory over unseeded Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union. (AP) Sukova to Play for Title: Top-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia and a Dutch teen-ager, ninth-seeded Brenda Schultz, won semifinal matches yesterday to advance in the Australian women's hardcourt championships in Brisbane. Sukova routed third-seeded Patty Fendick of the United States, 6-2, 6-4. The 16-year-old Schultz, the Wimbledon junior champion, defeated an unseeded Australian, Jenny Byrne, 6-1, 2-6, 6-4. (AP) Track and Field Triple Winner: Tamika Francis of Malverne (L.I.) High School won three events yesterday at a track meet in the Army Field House in West Point, N.Y. Francis took the girl's long-jump at 16 feet 1 1/4 inches, the 200-meter dash in 26.39 seconds and the 55-meter hurdles in 8.58. Meet Mark for Goddard: Cheri Goddard of Saratoga Springs (N.Y.) High School, the national leader this season in the girls' 1,500 meters (4:34.5) and one mile (4:57.1), posted another victory yesterday in the Dartmouth Interscholastic meet in Hanover, N.H. She won the two-mile run in 10:32.24, a meet record. Neil Butler of St. Raphael's Academy in Providence, R.I., earned a spot in the Millrose Invitation High School Mile Feb. 3 when he won that event in 4:13.01. His twin brother, Andrew, was third in 4:13.76. Horse Racing Lord of the Night Wins: Lord of the Night, ridden by Herb McCauley, took the lead after entering the stretch yesterday and went on to post a one-length victory in the $86,850 Aqueduct Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Its Acedemic was runner-up, 4 3/4 lengths ahead of True and Blue. King's Swan, the favorite, failed to mount a serious challenge and wound up last, behind Lyphard's Ridge

title: Schaus to Retire
description: As coach he watched the Mountaineers' basketball team make it all the way to the final game of the 1959 N.C.A.A. tournament, and as athletic director he watched the Mountaineer football team win national recogition with an 11-0 regular-season record and a game, if losing, effort against No. 1 Notre Dame in the 1989 Fiesta Bowl. Now Fred Schaus, who also coached the Los Angeles Lakers, has decided he has had enough excitement at West Virginia. He announced he will retire as athletic director on his 64th birthday, June 30, to spend more time with his family. (AP)

title: Stopping Child Abuse Before It Happens
description: The screams began sometime after dinner: a teen-ager and his father were having a quarrel that could be heard through the wall of a neighbor's apartment in a luxury building on East 87th Street in Manhattan. Suddenly the neighbor heard a banging. Apparently the father was bashing his son's head against the bathroom wall.

title: POSTINGS: 'Miracle' in Manhattan; Basement Multiplex
description: Joseph Saleh called the Broadway basement where he is creating Manhattan's newest downtown moviehouse ''a miracle.'' Here was cheap space - less than $20 a square foot - where zoning permits a cinema. It even seemed to have been built with the multiplex in mind: big at 20,000 square feet - ''like a football field'' - and tall with 26-foot ceilings. The basement of the Cable Building at 611 Broadway and Houston Street was actually made for the cable cars parked there until 1912. Last month, Mr. Saleh, president of Angelika Films, an independent film producer and distributor, began to turn it into a six-screen, 1,200-seat complex.

title: The Swiss School Nonpareil
description: ITS TUITION compares with that of the best American universities. The people who run it are so determined that students get their money's worth that anyone absent without leave for more than 20 hours is automatically expelled. A four-year veteran of military life found it ''in some ways tougher than the Marine Corps.''

title: Steve Wolf's Big Test
description: It is not surprising that United Airlines was the only major carrier to support deregulation when debates heated up in the late 1970's. The free-for-all competition created by deregulation, United figured, would enable it to consolidate its position as the undisputed king of the skies.

title: In Switzerland, Train Stations Are for Eating
description: T. S. Eliot created a character who . . . pulled her stockings off With a frightful cry of ''Hauptbahnhof!''

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Union City Grapples With Development
description: LEAD: THREE years ago the development pressures that had changed the face of much of Hudson County finally reached Union City. But many of its 54,913 people are worried about the impact of development on the community, where land is scarce, streets are packed and services are limited.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: OPERA IN DENVILLE

title: Bringing the Television Image Into Focus
description: What Dolby is to sound, Faroudja is to video. Hard to pronounce and remember, the name isn't likely to become a household word. Besides, unlike Ray Dolby - the inventor who made audio cassettes capable of high fidelity and likes to see his name emblazoned on every product based on his patents - Yves Faroudja prefers to stay in the background. Yet his work, carried on quietly at his private laboratory in Sunnyvale, Calif., may prove a turning point in the history of television and video.

title: Winfield Answered
description: Stung by a suit filed by Dave Winfield, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, said yesterday that he has been making payments to the David M. Winfield Foundation, but to an escrow account rather than directly to the outfielder's foundation.

title: FANFARE FOR THE COMMON COMPLAINTS
description: THE COMPANY OF CRITICS Social Criticism and Political Commitment in the Twentieth Century. By Michael Walzer. 260 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Teams Will Meet in the Super Bowl?
description: This is the year of the AnimalL the Chicago Bears and Buffalo Bills.

title: In Darkest Winter, Many Cold, Few Frozen
description: LEAD: THE sanest way to spend an East Coast winter, some say, is to turn dormant and emerge sleek and fresh in the spring. But on hard-working, hard-traveling Long Island, where hibernation is a seasonal style that few can afford, life hurtles on, with only the snow to slow the pace.

title: 'Goodbye' for Some, 'Ciao' for Others
description: I READ somewhere that yuppies are taking leave of one another these days with the word ''ciao.'' I have never been able to bring myself to say ''ciao.'' But I would like to. I roll it around in my mind. ''Ciao.'' Even better, ''Ciao, baby.''

title: For Small-Scale Entertaining, Simple but Not Ordinary
description: AFTER the holidays, when the memory of exhausting large-scale entertaining has finally receded, it is pleasant to have a few friends around for a quiet dinner. The following is a meal for four to six that is somewhat out of the ordinary yet simple enough to prepare just before your guests arrive.

title: Richard W. Murray Wed To Miss Taylor, Executive
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Katherine Vinton Taylor, the daughter of Mrs. William F. Taylor of Asheville, N.C., and the late Nita Montague Taylor, was married yesterday to Richard Walter Murray, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Murray of Hamburg, N.Y. The Rev. Jane P. Henderson performed the ceremony.

title: Student Gains in Fight To Bar Pregame Prayer
description: One day four years ago, when Kevin Douglas Jager was a freshman saxophonist in the marching band at Douglas County High School in suburban Douglasville, he complained to his father about the reciting of prayers before the school's home football games. Doug Jager - everyone calls him by his middle name - is an agnostic, as is his father, William, who persuaded him to take his concerns to the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Beastly To Beckett?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Past Examined
description: IT IS NOT OFTEN that a social historian gets to watch social history march past his own window. But that was Prof. Leon F. Litwack's rare opportunity when the Free Speech Movement erupted at the University of California campus in Berkeley in 1964. With what he calls a ''certain kind of exhilaration,'' the historian watched as his students succeeded where his older generation of social activists had failed. He watched as Mario Savio exhorted his fellow students to challenge the authorities, to ''put your bodies on the gears and upon the wheels, upon the levers, upon all the apparatus, and you've got to make it stop.''

title: Ms. Ballon Is Married
description: At the Harmonie Club in New York, Hilary Meg Ballon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ballon of New York, was married last evening to Orin Stuart Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Kramer of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Ely Pilchik performed the ceremony.

title: KING ARTHUR IN TORONTO
description: THE LYRE OF ORPHEUS By Robertson Davies. 472 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Hembrick Wins, but Is Hurt
description: He waited nearly four months for redemption, but Anthony Hembrick could not have known that there would be a price to pay for the victory he so craved.

title: Action in Insurance Stocks
description: Investors began the new year preoccupied with the possibility of more corporate takeovers. And by the second trading day they had zeroed in on insurance stocks. On Wednesday the stocks of Capital Holding, Monarch Capital and USLife shot up after investors learned of a report in an Asian newspaper that Nippon Life, a Japanese insurance company, was interested in buying an American insurance concern.

title: Turtle Bay Tour
description: Adventure on a Shoestring is to conduct a walking tour of the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan at 3 P.M. today. The fee is $5; for meeting place, call 265-2663.

title: Haitians Detained in Florida After Rescue From Sailboat
description: Ninety-four Haitians were rescued Friday after their 30-foot wooden sailboat ran onto rocks off the Florida Keys. Most of the Haitians have been detained until a judge decides whether they should be deported, the authorities said.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Teams Will Meet in the Super Bowl?
description: Super Bowl prognosis: Bengals 24, Bears 10.

title: Klaus Column: Help in the Kitchen
description: My usual reaction to one of Barbara Klaus's articles is, ''Thank the household gods! I am not alone,'' and her piece on holiday cooking [ ''What It All Boils Down To,'' Long Island Sound, Dec. 4 ] evoked that consoling shock of recognition. I wonder if she is familiar with a further complication.

title: Even While Money Is Short, Cuomo Has Big Plans for It
description: THE State of the State address has often given New York's governors an opportunity to map their course for the coming year. But Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's speech last week was a disappointment to anyone looking for clear directions.

title: ONLY IRISH NEED APPLY
description: RAINBOW'S END Irish-Americans and the Dilemmas of Urban Machine Politics, 1840-1985. By Steven P. Erie. 345 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press.

title: THE CASE FOR BURNING
description: It is high time that the National Park Service's decision not to combat Yellowstone's lightning-caused fires was defended. The public's misguided furor over the natural calamity was fueled by election-year politics, local business interests and ignorance.

title: Miss Weingarten Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Weingarten of New York and New Milford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Joy Weingarten, to Scott Ryan Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Singer of Huntingdon Valley, Pa.

title: Pro-Iranian Terror Groups Targeting Saudi Envoys
description: Newly formed underground organizations believed linked to Iran say they have mounted a campaign of terror against Saudi diplomats abroad.

title: Alison Cumming Riker, a Teacher, Marries Lieut. Steven Paul Friedel
description: Alison Cumming Riker, a daughter of Mrs. Gordon Potter of Rumson, N.J., and the late William I. Riker, was married in Rumson yesterday to Lieut. Steven Paul Friedel of the Army, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Theodore Friedel of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church.

title: Talk and Pictures Combined Make the Most Efective TV News
description: To the Editor:

title: Temple Site Roils Great Neck
description: LEAD: LEGALLY, it is a question of ''a delicate balance'' between the religious rights of the congregants of a proposed house of worship, and the benefits its availability can offer the community, as opposed to the adverse impact that the building might have upon the character of the neighborhood.

title: FICTION
description: THE SANDS OF TIME. By Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Being Sidney Sheldon means never having to say you're writing. In his 10th book, ''The Sands of Time,'' Mr. Sheldon appears to have produced a literary version of painting by numbers. The story follows the fortunes of four nuns from an intensely austere Spanish convent as they wander through scenery that seems to have been imported from ''For Whom the Bell Tolls'' - in the company of some fugitive Basque nationalists. All are hunted by a secret police chief, Colonel Acoca, who is described, seemingly on every third page, as ''a giant with a scarred face.'' Each of the nuns bears a Terrible Secret. One is a certifiable, jilted-in-love crazy person; another has been raped at 14 by her mother's Moorish lover; the third, Heaven help us, is a genuine Missing American Industrial Heiress; and the fourth is a distinctly earthy woman on the lam from the Italian police. The Basque leader is ''six feet tall, with a strong, intelligent face, a muscular body, and brooding dark eyes.'' The other characters are paper dolls. The style is reminiscent of a syrupy 1950's magazine, enlivened by ''the lubricious creak of bedsprings,'' to say nothing of a pastoral co-ed nude rubdown with dry leaves. This would all be good, picaresque fun if it weren't so exploitative of women in general and nuns in particular. Each wimple is wrapped around a featherhead, and the contemplative life of the convent is brutalized with graphic descriptions of self-flagellation. To make things worse, the wanderings around Spain read like a strange collaboration between Barbara Cartland and Ernest Hemingway.

title: Wanda A Helped By Neediest
description: The story of Wanda A., the battered woman who is now beginning a new life with her 7-year-old daughter in Harlem, has inspired many contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. An account of her struggle was published by The Times early last month.

title:
MUSIC;
Youth Orchestras At Carnegie Hall
description: LEAD: THE first New Jersey Youth Orchestra Festival, which will be held Saturday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall in New York, has aroused a good deal of excitement among New Jersey musicians and music educators. The concert, involving three youth orchestras, will be the product of the combined efforts of 279 young musicians and three conductors.

title: Quick Peek, From Afar, at Libyan Plant
description: Libyan officials took journalists to this town today and drove them past a disputed chemical plant, but then refused to allow a visit to the grounds of the complex.

title: A Lap of Luxury for Elderly Cats
description: LEAD: When the doors of the Last Post, a glass-walled compound overlooking the Housatonic River in Falls Village, swing open, there are cats everywhere.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SEX AND SUBTERFUGE: Women Writers to 1850. By Eva Figes. (Persea Books, Paper,$10.95.) Despite social constraints and limited education, women in early 19th-century England began writing serious novels and in so doing radically altered the genre. So claims the novelist and critic Eva Figes in ''Sex and Subterfuge: Women Writers to 1850,'' a lively and articulate study of major and minor writers including Jane Austen, the Brontes, Fanny Burney and Maria Edgewood.

title: THE CASE FOR BURNING
description: Peter Matthiessen's article on the Yellowstone fires was a thoughtful piece and goes further than anything else I've read to convince me that this disaster probably couldn't have been avoided, that change is part of the natural order of things and that life in all the beauty of Yellowstone will go on (''Our National Parks: The Case for Burning,'' Dec. 11). I am a native of Montana, and have visited the park every summer for 40 years. My grandfather was one of the builders of the Old Faithful Inn.

title: The Caribbean Connection
description: ''THE Great White Fleet'' conjures up visions of a vast medieval force, invaders perhaps, or explorers, or profiteers. In some ways the Great White Fleet, which crisscrossed the Caribbean for more than 50 years, was all of these things.

title: A Book Lover's Los Angeles
description: THE poet John Ciardi once looked at the false-fronted electronic dream factory of Southern California and wrote, ''The only possible mistake is in trying to perceive depth there.'' Anyone who thinks that Los Angeles is a shallow, post-literate wasteland might be surprised to learn that it ranks second to New York in book sales, according to a United States Department of Commerce survey. Its public libraries hold more volumes than Chicago's, according to Rand McNally's ''Places Rated Almanac'' (1985). And despite the dominance of national chains, about 100 of the 300 book sellers are specialists.

title: Glamour and Fantasy and the Return of Dance
description: JUST over a year ago, the demise of social dance was reported in the newspaper. Apparently, in the age of health clubs and videocassette recorders, neither the physically fit nor the couch potato seemed inclined to cha-cha into the night. But it is now clear that this particular obituary notice was greatly exaggerated.

title: Bringing Superconductivity Down to Earth
description: WHEN the new high-temperature superconductors were discovered two years ago, they inspired visions of revolutionary products -trains that float above their tracks, supercomputers the size of grapefruits and perfectly efficient electric power lines.

title: GOD'S INNER-CITY GO-BETWEEN
description: LEAD: MIZ LIL & THE CHRONICLES OF GRACE By Walter Wangerin Jr. 192 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: Oaxaca, Poised on the Edge of a Boom
description: ESSENTIALLY, foreign travelers are drawn to Mexico for any of four reasons: beaches, pre-Columbian ruins, Spanish colonial architecture or traditional handicrafts. It is ironic, then, that one of the few regions that contains all these attractions, and much more, within its borders is one that is neglected by most visitors from abroad. Rising from the shores of the Pacific Ocean to enfold verdant mountain valleys and isolated villages, the southern state of Oaxaca is a world in and of itself, immersed in a glorious past but about to open, as never before, to the world around it.

title: M. O. Hill Wed To Ms. Peterson
description: Elizabeth Ann Peterson and Michael Oliver Hill, both lawyers at the Department of Justice in Washington, were married yesterday at the Washington Cathedral. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by Canon Charles S. Martin.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A NEW EUROPE In 1992 twelve European nations will lift all restrictions on their citizens' ability to live and work in each others' countries. ''There will really be a united European nation,'' said Henry Gordan, moderator of a forum called ''Is World Federalism Inevitable?'' scheduled from 3 to 5:30 P.M. today in Wainwright House, at 260 Stuyvesant Avenue in Rye.

title: Latin America's Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: Footing That College Bill
description: NEARLY everybody seems to be getting into the act of making it easier for future generations of students to afford the rapidly rising college costs, which have more than doubled in the last decade.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SKIING CLINICS Weather or not, cross-country skiing comes in for some scrutiny today, when Long Island's state parks start their annual series of free weekly clinics devoted to that most amiable pastime.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Teams Will Meet in the Super Bowl?
description: The San Francisco 49ers will see through the fog of Chicago, while no one at the game will see what is going on, and everyone will say how great it was to be there.

title: Deer Problem At Chemical Plant
description: THE E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company plant in Deepwater, N.J., knows how to make chemicals. But controlling the chemistry of rapidly reproducing deer has the company stumped.

title: China Assails Foreign Reports on Racial Strife
description: China today sharply criticized what it described as fabrications in foreign news reports about recent racial incidents in several Chinese cities.

title: Vermonters Battle Mall's Developer
description: Ben A. Frank has the air of a man under siege.

title: EVERYTHING HAPPENS IN THE MAID'S ROOM
description: THE PASSION ACCORDING TO G.H. By Clarice Lispector. Translated by Ronald W. Sousa. 174 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: In Praise Of Knight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LUCIAN FREUD: THE UNBLINKING EYE
description: Marina Warner's article ''Lucian Freud: The Unblinking Eye'' (Dec. 4), full of compelling facts and rumors about Lucian Freud's personal life, is surely interesting, but what is important is to see and experience the intensity, depth and mastery of his work; there is no other painter like him. Only a self-portrait by Rembrandt or Van Gogh comes close to the profundity and honesty of Freud's ''Reflection.'' One is convinced that there is real blood flowing beneath the clotted-cream surfaces of Freud's portraits of nudes.

title: Memorial for Founder of Legal Services
description: LEAD: THOSE who knew him well say the late Myron S. Isaacs worked round the clock - as a lawyer and as a volunteer for organizations and committees devoted to criminal justice and civil liberties.

title: Taking a Scalpel to Health Costs
description: There is a general practitioner in Florida who, while he may not realize it, is being watched from Connecticut. Those monitoring his performance do not like what they see.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: PHILIP AND THE OTHERS. By Cees Nooteboom. Translated by Adrienne Dixon. (Louisiana State University, $14.95.) Originally published in 1954, the Dutch novelist and poet Cees Nooteboom's first novel, ''Philip and the Others,'' has now appeared in an elegant English translation by Adrienne Dixon. The first-person narrative traces a young man's search for family, identity and love, as expressed in a surrealist mesh of mirror images, recurring themes and rituals.

title: Social Studies: A Bit of Background
description: ''The schools ain't what they used to be, and never was.'' - Will Rogers.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: North Adams, Mass.;
description: LEAD: SEVERAL moderate-income families will become homeowners for a $2,000 down-payment and carrying charges of $345 a month in a cooperative being developed in an old hillside building overlooking this northwest Massachusetts city.

title: NONFICTION
description: IMELDA: Steel Butterfly of the Philippines. By Katherine Ellison. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Katherine Ellison is part of the Pulitzer Prize-winning San Jose Mercury News team that in 1985 traced the money of Ferdinand E. Marcos, then President of the Philippines, around the globe. In ''Imelda,'' she is on the track of bigger game - the soul of the country as well as of her subject, Imelda Marcos, the President's wife, his political equal and - but for the explosion of long-simmering revulsion with their staggering corruption - his potential successor. In a story that sometimes, unfortunately, reads like a cross between a script for ''Dallas'' and a psychohistory of a Pacific Rim Evita, Ms. Ellison takes us from Imelda Romualdez's adolescence on the island of Leyte and her days in postwar Manila through her transformation from a college beauty queen to full political partner in a ''conjugal dictatorship.'' In Ms. Ellison's view, Imelda Marcos's drive to be rich and worldly and her sensitivity to insult, real or imagined, mirrors a national nostalgia for colonial times and rage at the developed world that made the Philippines, for a decade at least, a sucker for the surreal romance she spun with her Cultural Center, her Western jet-set associates and her good works for the many poor, who were growing only poorer during the Marcos regime. The First Lady's rage at Corazon Aquino in the presidential campaign that led to the Marcoses' exile was as much personal as political, Ms. Ellison opines: in ''a matriarchal society overtly ruled by men,'' Mrs. Aquino, a member of ''the landed wealthy class that Imelda had always felt snubbed by . . . was winning power seemingly without effort.''

title: In Search Of Popular Culture
description: EVEN IN THE late 1960's, when relevance was a campus battle cry, Ray B. Browne's intellectual wanderings seemed radical. With a doctorate in American literature from the University of California at Los Angeles and a scholarly book on Herman Melville under his belt, he yearned to publish a journal on romance novels and rock music. His idea was that such slices of popular culture - anything excluded by folk and American studies' scholars as too contemporary - would revolutionize education. Like many other ideas that arose from the 60's, the quest became a grass-roots movement that continues to evolve.

title: THE UNSPEAKALBE LIFE OF A CHILD
description: W Or The Memory of Childhood. By Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. 164 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $16.95.

title: Chamber Orchestra To Make Debut Jan. 25
description: Malcolm Bilson is to lead the On Original Instruments Chamber Orchestra in its debut performance, Jan. 25 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The core group of string quartet, flute, oboe, horn and bassoon will be expanded to 19 members for the program of Haydn's Violin Concerto in C - with Stanley Ritchie as soloist - and Symphony No. 49 (''La Passione'') and Mozart's Piano Concerto in B flat and Variations on ''Come un agnello.'' Tickets: $15. Information: 362-8719. On Jan. 23 at 8 P.M., also at Merkin Hall, Mr. Ritchie and the instrument makers Jacques Francais and Sam Zygmuntowicz will give a lecture on great violin makers of the 18th century, and will demonstrate techniques used in making an instrument.

title: Ilene Kantrowitz Engaged
description: The engagement of Ilene Kantrowitz to Elliot Avrum Reinfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Reinfeld of North Plainfield, N.J., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Kantrowitz of Beverly Hills, Calif. The couple plan to marry in August. The future bride is an elementary-school teacher in Pasadena, Calif. Her fiance is the director of marketing at Monterey Canyon Apparel in Los Angeles.

title: Ditka's New Lease on Life Is Less Taxing
description: The house specialty at Mike Ditka's Restaurant in Chicago is pork chops, not because the chef likes them but because the owner likes them.

title: DATA BANK: January 8, 1989
Musings On Moses
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. THATCHER'S CHILDREN
description: Malcolm Bradbury's look at British yuppies bothered me for the same reasons that Mrs. Thatcher's policies, and those of her ideological soul mates on this side of the Atlantic, do (''Mrs. Thatcher's Children,'' Dec. 11). Mr. Bradbury describes those who benefit from her policies: ''they're smart, they're snappy, they're clever, they're clean.''

title: THE INCREDIBLE STUFF
description: COUNTDOWN An Autobiography. By Frank Borman with Robert J. Serling. Illustrated. 448 pp. New York: Silver Arrow Books/ William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Saturday Outing in San Angel
description: A SATURDAY morning in San Angel begins, as do most days here, with the clanging of one of the bells in the tower of the Church of San Jacinto. The church was constructed in the late 16th century by Franciscan monks and although much of it has been rebuilt, the bells have a heavy, tired sound - as though they have been ringing for too many years.

title: New York's Campaign Finance Law: Limits and Loopholes
description: The first public financing of political campaigns in New York State went into effect in New York City last week. It provides for the partial financing of primary and general-election races for municipal offices, similar to the national financing of Presidential candidates.

title:
ART;
Two Print Shows Examine Technique and Conceptualism
description: LEAD: TWO current print exhibitions are at opposite poles. One displays an arsenal of up-to-the-minute printmaking techniques and is at the offices of Tyler Graphics Ltd. in Mount Kisco. The second is long on Conceptualism and is at Elizabeth Galasso Fine Art Leasing in Ossining.

title: The Road to Industrial Rebirth; Make Allies Share Defense
description: The 101st Congress will likely challenge the Bush administration to spend less overseas to defend our allies and more to defend our own economic future. The alternative is to witness a continued erosion not only in commercial competitiveness but in our military-industrial base as well.

title: TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
description: WHEN GEORGE BUSH TAKES THE oath of office later this month, all Americans will share a moment of celebration, offering our new President prayers and good wishes as he takes on the most demanding job in the free world. But for Democrats it is also a time to reflect - to ask why a decisive majority of American voters have lost confidence in our ability to govern from the White House.

title: 2 Held as Leaders of Scheme Defrauding Metals Investors
description: A man and a woman with homes in the New York metropolitan area have been arrested in Florida and charged as the organizers of a scheme in which more than 2,000 people across the country were cheated out of $21 million that they believed had been invested in precious metals, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Support Voiced For the Boycott
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Multiple Listing Coming to Manhattan
description: AN upheaval, bitter and factional, is reshaping the way apartments are bought and sold in Manhattan, forcing brokers to abandon traditional strategies in a marketplace lurching toward the future.

title: Innocent Tenant Evictions Cause Koch to Assail Policy
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday called a Federal program that evicts innocent tenants from buildings seized in drug raids ''nuts'' and proposed that New York City oversee such buildings so occupants not charged with crimes can stay.

title: A Little Coffee To the Rescue
description: WHEN I FIRST began teaching, I was invited to a workshop for new faculty. Like most people who teach at universities, I had spent a long time learning what to teach, but none learning how to teach it. Somehow, my university seemed to hope, a weekend spent with experienced members of its faculty would make up for that.

title: POSTINGS: Confidence in Greenwich; Mansions on Spec
description: In a soft market, smart money builds lavishly. That seems to be the lesson to be learned in Connecticut. While most of Fairfield County is enduring a residential sales slump, Greenwich is enjoying something of boomlet in mansion-building. Signaling the confidence builders have in the high end of the housing market, four large homes rising near one another there are all being built on a speculative basis.

title: INVOVLING CHILDREN IN CREATIVE PROCESS
description: ''IT'S my favorite project,'' said Adina Salmansohn-Affelt, who has been involved with many kinds of community endeavors through the years. Her most recent efforts, however, have led to the establishment of the Hudson School of Creative Arts. Opened last September in south Yonkers, the school's stated purpose is to teach music, art and dance to students who would not otherwise be able to afford lessons.

title: The Scramble For Black Professors
description: THREE YEARS AGO, Mylon Winn was a professor of political science at the University of Alabama with no particular plans to leave. Then he received a letter from Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, saying that the school was seeking to hire more minority-group faculty members. Today Mr. Winn, who is black, makes his home in Ohio.

title: Talk and Pictures Combined Make the Most Efective TV News; What We Can't See
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Ministry to Homeless is Losing Its Home
description: The Rev. James W. Parrott raised his eyes to the dingy ceiling, blessed the dozens of homeless people huddled around tables waiting for their only hot meal of the day and prayed for a ''miracle on Broad Street.''

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Week in Review last Sunday listing successes of the United Nations in 1988 incorrectly described the participants in negotiations on the unification of Cyprus. The talks are between the leaders of the Greek and Turkish communities on the island.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A;
What It's Like to Be Homeless
description: LEAD: The number of homeless people in New Jersey is estimated by New Jersey Right to Housing, an advocacy group, at 30,000 to 35,000. A more precise figure is hard to come by because people drift into and out of homelessness.

title: P.L.O. Gains Embassies in 3 More Countries
description: China, Jordan and Qatar announced today that they will upgrade missions of the Palestine Liberation Organization in their capitals to embassies in recognition of the Palestinian parliament's declaration of an independent state.

title: Laurie Edelman Weds T. A. Kyzivat
description: Laurie Beth Edelman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerry Edelman of White Plains and Tolland, Mass., was married last evening to Thomas Anthony Kyzivat, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Kyzivat of White Plains. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center in White Plains.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Mountain View, Calif.;
A High Rise for Silicon Valley
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION begins this month on the 12-story office component of the Stanford Business Center, a mixed-use development in this Silicon Valley community 30 miles south of San Francisco.

title: The Black Ascent In Union Politics
description: IN the early 1960's, the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. provoked an angry outcry from some labor leaders when it urged them to open their ranks to black workers. It was not until 1964, some 15 years after the armed forces began to integrate and a decade after the Supreme Court ordered desegregation of public schools, that the last labor federation affiliate removed the ''whites only'' clause in its constitution and bylaws.

title: Naturalissimo
description: ''I'VE ALWAYS BEEN INFLUENCED by landscape,'' says Kenneth Frazelle, a 33-year-old composer who lives in Winston-Salem, N.C. And though such a sentiment borders on a romantic cliche, it would appear that for Frazelle, the hills are alive with the sound of music. His impromptu, crayon-and-pencil representations of the musical ideas he derives from the outdoors initiate his compositions. At left, he's making sketches for ''Blue Ridge Airs II,'' a work-in-progress for flute and orchestra commissioned by the flutist Paula Robison.

title: Four Day Trips From Mexico City
description: IF you are visiting Mexico City and want to escape the bustle and noise for a day, there are several places not far from the capital that can be reached within two hours by car, for a picnic, a hike or a quiet day in the countryside.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Recess, an Endangered Playtime
description: LEAD: RECESS used to be every child's favorite subject in school.

title: A TAKEOVER PLAY IN MUTUAL FUNDS
description: TAKEOVER specialists searching for companies with undervalued assets are increasingly noticing a type of publicly owned companynot typically thought of as takeover play: closed-end stock funds. Indeed, as corporate acquisitions remove more equity from the stock market, investment professionals believe that acquirers will become increasingly interested in closed-end funds, especially those whose shares sell at sharp discounts to their net asset value. The net asset value is the market value of the securities held in the fund minus liabilities, divided by the number of fund shares outstanding.

title: Finding Your Routes
description: IT was a curious thing to read some time ago that the Soviets have purposely been printing inaccurate maps of their motherland for years in order to bamboozle nosy foreigners. What amazed me most was the realization that I have never gotten a bum steer from an American road map.

title: Hungary's History
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: The petite woman is skiing swiftly down a slope somewhere in New England. Faster and faster she goes, when suddenly, to her horror, she is in midair and heading over a cliff. She cries for help; the words that tumble from her lips are spoken in a Boston accent. That really terrifies he and with that, Dr. Ruth Westheimer wakes up, happy to realize that it was all a dream.

title: Why an Austerity Plan Is Unraveling in Hartford
description: FOR weeks, Gov. William A. O'Neill had prepared voters and legislators alike for a year of budget cuts, higher taxes and difficult political compromises, all of which, he said, would be needed to solve Connecticut's worsening fiscal plight. Then, only minutes before he was to open the five-month session of the General Assembly with his State of the State address on Wednesday, the problems became even worse.

title: Student Engaged To Jane E. Veron
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Veron of White Plains of the engagement of their daughter Jane Elizabeth Veron to Andrew Todd Feldstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Feldstein of Flagstaff, Ariz. The couple plan an August wedding.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title: Forecast For the 21st Century
description: TODAY'S FIRST-GRADERS will be college freshmen when the 21st century begins a dozen years from now. Computers will be ubiquitous, creating and, at the same time, helping to meet a staggering challenge for students.

title: Seton Hall Thrashed For First Defeat
description: Seton Hall never receives a warm welcome here. And tonight, the Pirates got another cold slap in the face.

title: Dentists: AIDS Gear Raises Fees
description: PEOPLE going to the dentist may pay higher fees this year, because dentists are raising their fees to pay for protection against the AIDS virus.

title: HUNT FOR PAN AM BOMBER: NEW SHAPES AND SHADOWS
description: The bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 does not bear the trademark of any one terrorist group, and so investigators are speculating that it was carried out either by a new coalition of terrorists or by a radical group demonstrating previously unknown capabilities.

title: Burke's Return Benefits Devils
description: The return of Sean Burke in goal inspired the Devils to post their second consecutive victory, a 5-2 decision tonight over the Detroit Red Wings. It was the first time in almost a month that they won two in a row.

title: Hannah Fryshdorf, Researcher, 68
description: Hannah Fryshdorf, the assistant executive director of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research in Manhattan, died of cancer Friday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 68 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Slow Market Helps the First-Time Buyer
description: LEAD: THREE days after Christmas, Edwin Hutzler and his wife, Kelly Anne, became homeowners for the first time. The 42-year-old, two-bedroom ranch in Patchogue for which they paid $99,500 is only 1,000 square feet in size but is in good condition and the 75- by 150-foot lot will permit an addition.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Going for It All (and It's a Lot) in Golf
description: LEAD: It is somewhat voguish for us vaunted insiders to cavil about the snowballing prosperity of the PGA Tour, which teed off its 1989 season this week at a luxuriant spa in southern California.

title: Feeding Bagels To Barracudas In Caneel Bay
description: THERE'S something unnerving about having a four-foot stingray nuzzle against you while you're floating flat on your face, or offering a five-foot barracuda a bite of a bagel. You learn later that a barracuda doesn't particularly like bagels, though it might be tempted by lox. A stringray likes both, and will pester you for a handout.

title: The French and Saratoga
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Isn't It a Waste?'
description: The vision of a nonracial South Africa was raised just 77 years ago - on Jan. 8, 1912 - by the new African National Congress. Today blacks are still denied political and other rights; the A.N.C. is banned, its leaders imprisoned, dead or in exile. But its president, Oliver Tambo, is optimistic.

title: Arias Asks Delay in Central America Meeting
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica has asked that the summit meeting of Central American Presidents scheduled for Jan. 15 to 16 be postponed.

title:
The View From: The White Plains Fire Department;
A Dangerous Job Measured in Seconds
description: LEAD: DON'T look for constant drama in the White Plains Fire Department. Yes, the alarms ring and men are dispatched within seconds. Yes, they put out fires - sometimes big ones - and lay their lives on the line. But with the characteristic bravado of many men in high-risk professions, these firefighters tend to shrug and say, Scared?

title: Reviews/Music; Songs of Love, With a Latin Flavor
description: Danny Rivera, one of Puerto Rico's leading pop singers, declaimed ardent love songs Friday night at Carnegie Hall. He was performing a benefit concert for the literacy program of the National Puerto Rican Forum, an organization that works to improve employment opportunities for the economically disadvantaged.

title: Kate Bonanno, a Designer, Is Married to Ian P. Turner
description: Kate Bonanno, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bonanno of Demarest and Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to Ian P. Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Turner of Brisbane, Australia. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Jones Holds On For 2-Stroke Lead
description: Steve Jones, winner of the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am last winter, took a two-shot lead today into the final round of the MONY Tournament of Champions at La Costa Country Club when Chip Beck slumped badly at the end of the third round.

title: Waste Plans: A Tale of 2 Counties
description: LEAD: AS the director of the Sussex County Board of Chosen Freeholders, Michael J. LaRose, sees it, the garbage disposal situation in the northwest corner of New Jersey is a tale of two counties in which ''one opts for an environmentally safe solution and the other rushes to the most hazardous.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 'No Beer Here'

title: WHAT DRIVES THE PISTONS
description: FOR A BASKETBALL FAN, A VISIT TO the preseason training camp of any National Basketball Association team is instructive and perhaps a little deflating.

title: Walsh Proves He Can Handle Criticism as Well as Plaudits
description: Bill Walsh is 8-4 in playoff games, 100-63 in his 10th season as the San Francisco 49ers' coach. He has won two Super Bowls, six National Conference West divisional titles and has coached the 49ers to their sixth consecutive playoff appearance.

title: CHINA'S BEST AMERICAN FRIEND
description: LEAD: EDGAR SNOW A Biography. By John Maxwell Hamilton. Illustrated. 343 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $25.

title: U.S. Plan to Save Thrifts: Pay Now, Maybe Later
description: A WEEK after the Federal Home Loan Bank Board struck a blizzard of year-end deals for sick savings and loan associations, many industry experts are asking, ''What hath the Government wrought?''

title: Yes, We Have No Actuality
description: LEAD: I am really embarrassed. The whole country probably knows about the toll free number at the White House to get the latest important news, but I just found out about it last week. Until then, I had to rely on the newspapers and the broadcast media for up-to-the-minute information from our capital, even though I realized that I was getting it second hand.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: PETER J. NESBITT;
Polishing a Tarnished Image at Playland
description: LEAD: FOR more than 50 years, Playland, the county-owned amusement park in Rye, has been a place area residents visited during the summer to go on the rides or swim and in the winter to ice skate. The park's image was of a place for wholesome family fun.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
MAKE ROOM FOR DADA
description: LEAD: ''The 'problem' of Man Ray,'' Neil Baldwin writes in this first full-scale biography of the artist by an American writer, ''begins with the matter that . . . his eclecticism [flouts] the ground rules of art history.'' Mr. Baldwin, a poet and the author of a biography of William Carlos Williams, writes that MAN RAY: American Artist (Clarkson N.

title: SHOW-OFFS
description: The highly decorative and accessorized bathing suits shown on these pages are mostly for making a splash. Suits strictly for swimming, however, are still primarily maillots.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Dec. 25 about abortions performed solely because of the sex of the fetus attributed remarks by Dr. Michael A. Roth to Dr. Lawrence D. Platt. Dr. Platt does not perform abortions. It was Dr. Roth who said that doctors who decline to perform abortions for sex selection but perform abortions for other reasons ''are selectively picking out who they want to do them on and who not,'' and added, ''I haven't turned anybody down.''

title: Learning Service With a Smile
description: STUDENTS and ducks shamble about the palm-lined campus of Florida International University on a bright Miami day, the former to classes and the latter to nearby ponds. Despite the sprinkling of people wearing chefs' uniforms, the ducks are unconcerned. Students at the F.I.U. School of Hospitality Management have little time to flambe anything with cherry sauce; they are too busy with classes in hospitality information systems, hospitality law and physical-plant management. Hotel school, as it turns out, isn't for ex-hockey players anymore.

title: To the Reagans: Happy Trails
description: Now that Ronnie and Nancy are about to pack their Vuittons and ride off into the sunset - hey! they're headed in the opposite direction, away from the Sturm und Drang of Long Island's infamous Shoreham, that is - the parting shot is that it's now O.K. to license and open all nuclear stops.

title: FILM: 'Mississippi Burning': Generating Heat or Light?; Cinematic Segregation In a Story About Civil Rights
description: What ''Mississippi Burning'' intends is clear from a scene disturbingly like one in ''A World Apart,'' a film set against the black struggle with apartheid in South Africa. In the closing scenes of ''A World Apart,'' the camera's eye comes in on a crowd of blacks assembled to bury one of their own murdered by the South African security police - and settles on two whites in that assembly.

title: Remorse From Dan Michel to James Joyce
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Jim McMahon and Politics
description: In this city where Mayor Daley remains as revered as George Halas, where politics inspires as much devotion as the Bears, the pro football politicians had it all figured out. They knew why Mike Tomczak, despite a damaged left shoulder, and not Jim McMahon would be the Bears' starting quarterback today in the National Conference championship game. To the pro football politicians, it was as obvious as Lake Michigan itself. Mike McCaskey, the Bears' president, and Mike Ditka, the coach, were hoping to win the Super Bowl without McMahon so they could:

title: City Ties Its Future To Hotel
description: LEAD: ALMOST four years after the project was announced, construction has begun on the Ocean Place Hilton, a luxury hotel that has been touted as the hub of the city's oceanfront redevelopment effort.

title: WE ARE THE STORIES WE TELL
description: LEAD: WRITING A WOMAN'S LIFE By Carolyn G. Heilbrun 144 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $14.95.

title: Prospects; The Superconductor Race
description: Last week a Presidential panel released a report calling for a more vigorous national effort to develop superconducting materials.
