The report said the United States was falling behind Japan in commercializing this new technology. It recommended increased Government funding for research and establishing research consortia comprised of Government laboratories, industry and university researchers. Four experts explain the significance of this report. Robert Dynes Director of the chemical physics research laboratory, A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Teams Will Meet in the Super Bowl?
description: The Jets and the Giants, right? ROBERT E. SWEENEY Brooklyn

title: STREETSCAPES: Woodycrest Children's Home; A New Life - and Mission - for a Bronx Residence
description: IT IS a wreck, still elegant in parts, but definitely a wreck. Now the vacant, vandalized Woodycrest, a home for neglected children built in the Bronx in 1902 by the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless, seems on the road to repair, if not restoration.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Business Forum page last week by K. Graham Walker, president of the Dexter Corporation, dropped a phrase from a sentence about the company's goals. It should have read: ''My goals for Dexter are very clear - to renew the growth of earnings on a sustainable basis to equal at least two times the growth of real gross national product plus two percentage points.''

title: Fenner Turning Pro
description: He's certainly had his share of problems since leading the Atlantic Coast Conference in rushing with 1,250 yards as a freshman in 1986, but now Derrick Fenner says he's going to turn pro. After losing his scholarship to Gardner-Webb College because of academic deficiencies, Fenner, a transfer student who has not played in two years, said he had decided to waive his last years of collegiate eligibility and apply for the April draft. Since his last game in 1986, Fenner spent 44 days in jail on a murder charge that was eventually dropped, pleaded guilty last year to possession of cocaine and drew three years' probation, and was slightly wounded in the chest in a shooting last month.(AP)

title: Rachel Heyman Becomes a Bride
description: Rachel Claire Heyman and Daniel Baruch Lidawer were married last evening at the Palmer House in Chicago by Rabbi Marc Berkson, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Bowing to Pressure
description: After 20 years as head of the Italian track and field federation, Primo Nebiolo has decided to step down in the wake of a series of scandals. The 64-year-old industrialist, who also serves as president of the international track and field federation, has been criticized because of the scandals, which included the fixing of the men's long jump results at the 1987 world championships in Rome. There was no word on his future with the international group, which elected him to a new four-year term last month, but according to a spokesman for the national governing body, Nebiolo's resignation will take effect Feb. 8.

title: Preservation Plan For Nassau Gains
description: LEAD: NASSAU COUNTY and New York State's plan to preserve 88 pristine acres in Old Westbury has taken an important step with the sale by Mrs. Margaret Boergner, owner of the land, to the Nature Conservancy for $7 million.

title: Richard Goldwater, 70, Ex-Assemblyman
description: Richard M. Goldwater, a Manhattan lawyer and former New York State Assemblyman, died of complications of pneumonia Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Two Trillion Dollars Is Missing; Why Is U.S. Prosperity Eroding? It's No Mystery.
description: ITEM: In 1966, when the prototypical American man turned 50, he had enjoyed a 31 percent increase in income over 10 years. For his present-day counterpart, the increase has been only 10 percent.

title: THOSE GIANT CHEESE GRATERS IN THE SKY
description: THE CITY THAT NEVER WAS Two Hundred Years of Fantastic and Fascinating Plans That Might Have Changed the Face of New York City. By Rebecca Read Shanor. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Viking. $35.

title: A Substitute for Hospital Surgery
description: LEAD: A 5-year-old man from Douglaston walked into the Nassau Center for Ambulatory Surgery in Garden City the other day, and two hours later walked out eating a doughnut.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted. A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside. It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it. This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house. Do you have any ideas before we put on a new coat of stain?

title: Colorful, Wooly and Warm
description: IN these bundle-up days, even city slickers who see trees only at Christmas have discovered the cozy woolen woodsman's coat. This colorful old American favorite is getting a lot of exposure, thanks largely to guess who? Right you are: it's that noted lumberjack (and occasional designer) Ralph Lauren.

title: Pacific Oil Spill Renews Fears of Offshore Drilling
description: When Olympic National Park rangers reached the wild stretch of Pacific shore here a few days ago after hiking through the rain forest, they found a scene from their worst nightmares.

title: Matchup Of a New Order In A.F.C.
description: The Bengals and the Buffalo Bills, representing the New Order of American Conference teams, meet in the A.F.C. championship game at Riverfront Stadium Sunday.

title: Anne Kingsbury to Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. Kingsbury of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter Anne Howard Kingsbury to L. Eric Andrews, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Andrews Jr. of Fairfield, Conn. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Their Race Problem, and Ours
description: The anti-African student riots of the last two weeks have opened a new window on China and the view isn't pretty: black students under attack . . . beaten by police . . . detained incommunicado . . . shocked on the genitals with cattle prods. The Chinese attitude toward blacks seems unapologetically racist.

title: Autodidact
description: To the Editor:

title: Donna Kaloust Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kaloust of Gloucester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Donna Louise Kaloust to Dr. Robert Christopher Hedgepath, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Hedgepath of Wilmington, Del. An August wedding is planned.

title: Military Figure With Contras Slain Near Honduran Capital
description: A military leader of the Nicaraguan rebels was assassinated by gunmen in Honduras today, a rebel spokesman said.

title: St. John's Triumphs On Free Throws
description: One after another, the Redmen stepped to the foul line against Villanova. And one after another, the balls dropped neatly through the basket. The parade was unending, the results nearly unvarying.

title:
GARDENING;
Plants That Overcame the Summer of '88
description: LEAD: HEAT and drought took a heavy toll last summer in gardens. With watering restrictions in many areas, some plants faded away. But there were some plants that not only survived, but also thrived.

title: SWIM IN LAKE ERIE, SEE STORMS IN DULUTH
description: The Great Lakes have only recently been recognized for their potential to trigger fresh business development. After all, it was only 20 years ago that Lake Erie, which had been suffocating from a lack of oxygen, was declared ecologically dead. The problems with water quality in the Great Lakes are far from solved. But the improving quality has resulted in projects that would have seemed implausible just a decade ago.

title: More Than an Artistic Director
description: Within big performing arts institutions - where musicians' careers are made and unmade, audiences influenced and creative agendas set - power not only descends from its highest officials but swirls sideways around those just below them.

title: An Early Jump On Admissions
description: THE FIRST signs are in that it's going to be a particularly anxious season for high school seniors seeking admissions to the nation's most selective colleges.

title: HOW FOTO JOE WON THE WAR
description: THE EIGHT CORNERS OF THE WORLD By Gordon Weaver. 382 pp. Chelsea, Vt.: Chelsea Green Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: Cavaliers Trip Up Weary Knicks
description: It was payback time today for the Cleveland Cavaliers, who tied a National Basketball Association record by blocking 21 shots as they defeated the Knicks.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Howell $165,000 8 Admirals Row 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; w/w carpeting, eat-in-kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $2,864. Middletown $336,000 189 Ueland Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; fireplace, deck, family room; taxes $4,643. Millburn $260,000 10 Berkeley Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; porch, 2-car garage, fireplace, hardwood floors; taxes $3,099. Mountainside $240,000 311 Indian Trail 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; full basement, eat-in-kitchen, new windows; taxes $2,452. Orange $239,000 184 Austen Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split level; 2-car garage, dining room, finished basement; taxes $4,892. Ringwood $172,500 1 Woodland Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; sun room, patio, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,738. OTHER AREAS Plainville, Conn. $126,000 296 Cooke Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 57-year-old bungalow, fenced yard, 2-car detached garage; taxes $1,183. New Rochelle, N.Y. $300,000 909 Webster Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 54-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, den, accessory apartment; taxes $3,600. Massapequa, L.I. $242,000 12 Cambridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; dining room, den, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $5,000.

title:
FOOD;
TAKING TEA
description: LEAD: Afternoon tea conjures up images of people sipping Earl Grey with their pinkies outstretched and nibbling doll-size sandwiches. In these visions, conversation never rises above a polite hum. But I've been fond of holding afternoon teas on winter Sundays for more hedonistic reasons. It's cozy and relaxing for guests.

title: POSTINGS: Change in Westhampton; Sexton's Shrinking
description: Last summer in Westhampton Beach, Sexton's was the same store it had been for 22 years. But no sooner did the season end in October than the department store began to change. By the time summer residents and vacationers start to return to the Long Island resort in April, Sexton's will be only one of 14 stores and professional offices operating out of the four connected buildings it once filled. From an 11,500-square-foot full-line department store, Sexton's will become a 2,000-square-foot shop specializing in linens and wicker furniture. The remaining space will be sold as condominiums for $170,000 to $465,000.

title: The Whitney Paradox: To Add Is To Subtract
description: The temptation is to tell the story like a morality play. Marcel Breuer's gray-granite Whitney Museum of Art, for two decades a Modernist fixture on Madison Avenue, is challenged by the upstarts of post-Modernism in the form of a design for a massive addition by Michael Graves. The addition would not so much expand the Breuer building as overwhelm it by merging it into a post-Modern collage. And so in their fury the troops of modern architecture rally in defense, attacking Michael Graves as the plunderer of one of the 20th century's great works of architecture. The Whitney retreats, asking Mr. Graves to produce a scaled-down version of his design. When that mollifies the furies only slightly, the Whitney sends him back to the drawing board and, hallelujah, Mr. Graves produces a third design, this one considerably more deferential to the Breuer building.

title: When Buyers Shop for Reliability
description: When a personal computer fails at a large company, the worker usually places a frantic call to the technical support office. The technician comes to the desk and either fixes the problem or swaps the machine for a backup. The failure is annoying but rarely catastrophic. In most businesses, however, there is no in-house technical support, no backup machine or spare-parts inventory. If a PC fails, the victim can be in limbo for hours, or weeks.

title: Arts Groups Court the County's Older Residents
description: THE county's older residents have become a serious focus of interest for many of the area's cultural organizations. Theatrical and musical groups, as well as museums, are going beyond the standard discounted tickets for the elderly to seek new ways to attract them.

title: Rise in Attendance Is Seen
description: When auto racing finally discovered what other sports leagues already knew - that fans have an insatiable appetite for statistics - all sorts of performance barometers were created, from total laps led to fastest pit stops. But one statistic from each race is usually known only to the promoter and the Internal Revenue Service: total attendance.

title: A 'New Olivier' Is Taking On Henry V on the Screen
description: Any exciting young British actor is almost inevitably dubbed ''the new Olivier.'' But in the case of 27-year-old Kenneth Branagh, the comparison is unavoidable.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Miami
description: Four hundred and fifty years separate two conquerors who came to Miami in search of gold: Juan Ponce de Leon in the early 1500's and Don Johnson in the early 1980's. Ponce de Leon never struck gold. Don Johnson did, with his TV show ''Miami Vice.''

title: Catherine Gallaher, Banker, Weds W. A. Mulligan
description: Catherine Mary Gallaher, the daughter of Frank Dixon Gallaher of New York and the late Catherine Antoinette Gallaher, was married yesterday to William Anthony Mulligan, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bernard Mulligan of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Robert J. Verigni performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: Reviews/Music; Newcomers in Met Opera's 'Figaro'
description: Casts seem to be shifting more rapidly in the later years of the James Levine regime at the Metropolitan Opera than they did earlier on, and the four newcomers to Wednesday's cast of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' served to underscore that instability.

title: RIVER BLINDNESS: CONQUERING AN ANCIENT SCOURGE
description: ON THIS BRIGHT NOVEMBER morning the mood is anything but gloomy in Sikoroni, Mali, a mud-hut village of the vast West African savanna. The summer rains were generous for the first time in years, and today 10-foot sorghum stalks are bowed by heavy heads of grain. True to protocol, the chief of this village of 400 has called in the elders to exchange ceremonial words with arriving visitors. As boys run to fetch them, we wait to the quotidian music of rural Africa: the ancient booming cadence of women pounding grain, the laughs and cries of children and the discordant crows of wandering roosters. The women's extravagant cotton prints are welcome flares of color against the drab landscape.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: POETRY READING

title: For Many Nicaraguans, the Future Lies Elsewhere
description: TIMES are good at the Garcia Agency, which occupies a dim storefront near a busy Managua intersection. Three years ago, the owners, caught up in the economic crisis that has enveloped Nicaragua, stopped selling clothes and other merchandise. They have gone into a far more lucrative business, perhaps the only business in the country that is truly booming: They arrange trips for Nicaraguans who want to abandon their homeland and make a new start abroad.

title: A Florida Show-and-Tell: Guns
description: IN A LETHAL version of Show and Tell, pupils are increasingly bringing guns to elementary school and accidentally maiming or killing classmates. While school districts nationwide grasp for solutions, officials in Dade County, Florida, unanimously approved the nation's first comprehensive ''gun awareness'' program.

title: Finding New Life at the Water's Edge
description: A smokestack economy, polluted lake water and icy winters are tough negative images to fight. But after suffering years of national derision, civic leaders in such Great Lakes cities as Cleveland, Buffalo and Detroit are turning to idled industrial waterfronts to bring back residents and attract new visitors.

title: FORMALITIES, IMPLOSIONS AND SOMNAMBULISMS
description: LEAD: EVENING WIND By Robert Mezey. 79 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $18.50. Paper, $10.95. GLASSWORKS By David Wojahn. 67 pp. Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95. DREAMS BY NO ONE'S DAUGHTER By Leslie Ullman.

title: In the Russian Motherland, Fascination Now With Those Who Chose Exile
description: The writer Andrei D. Sinyavsky likes to say that he resides in Paris but lives in Russia, a spiritual home built of literature, fellow emigres and surprisingly joyful memories of nearly six years in a Soviet prison camp.

title: Wanted in Westchester: A Golf Club for Japanese Buyers
description: LEAD: WANTED: One Westchester country club. Japanese investors looking to buy an existing club. Money no object.

title: Review/Concert; Access Chamber Group In Lesser-Known Music
description: The Access Chamber Ensemble is a group of young freelancers who describe their mission as ''the exploration of new or obscure music.''

title: Dazzling Display For Eiffel Tower
description: AS the Eiffel Tower Management Company prepared to mark the centenary of its Paris attraction this year, it envisioned a display so dazzling that the entire world would notice it. Space art, it was called. One proposal under study last summer was for a ring of light made of 100 silvery plastic spheres, each six feet in diameter, connected by tubing into a circle 15 miles in diameter. Orbiting the earth at an altitude of 480 miles, the ring would appear as big as the moon and as bright as 100 of the brightest stars.

title: Fighting Dirty Air And Motorists' Ire
description: WHEN Colorado proposed in 1987 to be the first state to mandate the use of high-oxygen gasoline to cut carbon-monoxide pollution, surveys showed that most of the affected motorists were angry or worried.

title: Judges Who Decide Social Security Claims Say Agency Goads Them to Deny Benefits
description: Many of the judges who decide claims for Government disability and health insurance charge that they are being harassed by the Social Security Administration in an effort to reduce costs.

title: NONFICTION
description: FABLES FOR THE NUCLEAR AGE. By Alan Neidle. Illustrations by Jeff Leedy. (Paragon House, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $9.95.) Behemoths, butterflies and other creatures populate ''Fables for the Nuclear Age,'' canny political parables that take up where Aesop and Orwell left off. As animals scheme to shift the balance of power, they imitate Homo sapiens' diplomatic strategies more apt to escalate problems than to solve them. For example, an uneasy alliance of paranoid sharks and sanctimonious turtles collapses when shark spies expose promiscuity among the turtles (a species respected for its monogamy), paving the way for blackmail. The sharks' denial of spying is categorical, under the cynical reasoning that ''if you assert anything strongly enough, half the fish in the ocean will believe you.'' In another tale, rival monkeys negotiate limits to the stockpiling of coconut-cannonballs behind masks that express cliches -Astonishment-and-Indignation, More-in-Sorrow-Than-in-Anger and Limits-to-Our-Patience - and stall progress. The anthology ends in an eerie evolutionary tale. A dinosaur, taunted by propaganda about his tiny brain, asks God for his peers' respect for his mind, not just his tread. He is reincarnated as an atomic scientist - great mind, weak body - who makes the earth shudder. The author, Alan Neidle, earned his skepticism as an official with the State Department and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency from 1957 to 1981, participating in international negotiations to curb nuclear weapons. All-too-human expressions - shrewd, gullible, stubborn - are deftly rendered in Jeff Leedy's sketches.

title: In Hot Pursuit of Mentor Photos of Mentor's chief executive, Thomas H. Bruggere, with the package deal: Software by Mentor Graphics, running on Apollo hardware (NYT/Brian Drake); the chassis of an Apollo workstation, which uses Mentor's software system.
description: ExecutiveS of the Mentor Graphics Corporation, whose revenues far exceed those of their next-biggest rival, like to describe their competition in the computer-aided engineering industry as ''vanquished.'' But now, the forces that turned Mentor into the industry's No. 1 company may be working against it.

title: Pursuing the Tears - and Laughter - in Parenting
description: Infertility is not exactly a funny subject, but the cast now making a film that tackles this problem is striving for laughs as well as tears.

title: Efforts for Children Called Inadequate
description: As Governor Mario M. Cuomo's Decade of the Child enters its second year, doctors, advocates for children and some government officials say that the quality of life for poor children in the state is deteriorating quickly and that Albany's efforts are not keeping pace with the problem.

title: Special Today; Education Life/Section 4A
description: The scholastic legacy of the 60's, its scholars and multimedia courses.

title: Jody Ann Hocart Engaged To Marry Gregory James
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hocart of Essex Fells, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jody Ann Hocart to Gregory Michael James, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John James of Glen Rock, N.J., and Fairfield, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

title:
FOCUS: Boston;
From Navy Yard to a New Neighborhood
description: LEAD: ONE of the city's newest neighborhoods - with new and renovated housing, office and retail space, public parks, landing docks and private marinas - is emerging on the site of the former Charlestown Naval Shipyard on Boston Harbor.

title: FICTION
description: VELOCITY. By Kristin McCloy. (Random House, $16.95.) The night after her mother's funeral, Ellie, the heroine of Kristin McCloy's first novel, has a dream: she's riding in a car with her mother; neither is wearing her seat belt. They go faster and faster, until. . . . The very next night, Ellie meets Jesse, a long-haired, half-Cherokee biker who lives down the road. She asks him if she can have a ride on his motorcycle. When he asks her where she wants to go, she says, ''I don't care, I just want to go fast.'' She does. Every bit of common sense and friendly advice to the contrary, once Ellie's had a taste of what it's like to sleep with Jesse, that's it. She can't stay away, and she won't. She gets up in the middle of the night, goes to his door, begs to be let in. She lies to her father and to her boyfriend to guard this affair. In the end, she's like a desperate animal, stalking Jesse wherever he goes. Though Ms. McCloy can reach the level of poetry when she's writing of Jesse and Ellie's lovemaking, by the end of the novel the reader is left wondering about the cause of Ellie's uncontrollable desire. After 250 pages, you're certain it can't be Jesse. He's a petty criminal, selfish, barely literate and, ultimately, boring. Ms. McCloy makes an effort to explain things by introducing Ellie's discovery of her mother's infidelity, thus linking the destinies of the two women. But this seems contrived. Though there is fire in ''Velocity,'' clearly something is missing.

title: NONFICTION
description: IT ONLY HURTS WHEN I LAUGH. By Stan Freberg. (Times Books, $19.95.) America's self-styled ''gray-flanneled kamikaze pilot,'' Stan Freberg wields the stiletto of satire against the smug and self-satisfied in popular culture and advertising. Mr. Freberg was the mad prophet of the airwaves, performing on radio, television and records his hilarious sendups of everything from ''Dragnet'' to the overcommercialization of Christmas. An independent taking on Madison Avenue, Mr. Freberg has always made his ad work intentionally provocative: the nine out of ten doctors who prefer Chun King chow mein (all but one of the doctors Chinese); a radio mini-musical for Butter-Nut coffee called ''Omaha!''; the campaign for Contadina tomato paste that asked, ''Who put eight great tomatoes in that little bitty can?'' Mr. Freberg's goal was radical when he began in the 1950's, but standard procedure today: advertising that ''was actually something you would wish to hear as opposed to turning it off.'' So it is surprising that someone as iconoclastic and unorthodox as Mr. Freberg would write such a conventional autobiography. ''It Only Hurts When I Laugh'' is straightforward, almost matter-of-fact, without his characteristic verve and bite. Too often, devices familiar to memoirs intrude: ''Little did I realize when I was growing up . . .,'' frequent references to famous folks who are fans. Take note: this is a first volume, covering Mr. Freberg's life and career until 1963; his further adventures are being saved for the next book. To his credit, Mr. Freberg acknowledges this in the preface, and it becomes a kind of running gag. Yet it might have been better to put all of his great material into one not so little bitty book than to ask the many Freberg aficionados to come back for seconds.

title: AT END OF AN ERA, PRAYERS IN TOKYO
description: On this last day of the era called Showa, or Enlightened Peace, this nation cried, prayed, skied, shopped and had its hair done.

title: Washington Mayor Defended
description: A man who is the central figure in a pair of Federal investigations of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. is quoted as denying that he used drugs with the Mayor and defended his role in a joint personnel venture between the governments of the District of Columbia and the Virgin Islands.

title: As Farm States Become Less Rural, Politics Also Changes
description: IT will be another year before census takers fan out among the small towns and big cities, taking America's decennial head count. Among politicians in Iowa and other farm states, where tens of thousands of people have abandoned small towns and family farms over the past decade, the 1990 census is approaching with the tread of doom.

title: 'Colds Can Really Occur Year Round'
description: AS the cold and flu season gets under way, Dr. Matthew L. Cartter, a medical epidemiologist with the preventable diseases division of the state's Department of Health Services, can expect to get busy sorting and analyzing reports of influenza in the state.

title: Ex-Football Player Finds New Goal With an Urban Ministry in Baltimore
description: The Door officially opened just before Christmas, and about 175 adults and children from an East Baltimore neighborhood were warmly greeted by the bearded, 260-pound figure of the Rev. Joe Ehrmann.

title: Distinctive Chinese in Westport
description: THE discovery of a Chinese restaurant with a style of its own is an auspicious way to welcome the New Year. Tiger Bowl, on the Post Road in Westport near the Fairfield line, boasts a chef and owner from Shanghai.

title: 17 Reported Hanged in Iran Anti-Drug Campaign
description: Seventeen drug smugglers were hanged in Teheran and other Iranian cities during a nationwide anti-narcotics campaign in which 1,000 people were arrested and scores were killed in shootouts, official Iranian reports said today.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FROM A DISTANT PLACE. By Don Carpenter. (North Point, $17.95.) Jackie Jeminovski, divorced and 45 years old, lives comfortably in Marin County, Calif. Because she has a lovely house, drives an expensive car and pays attention to her appearance, everyone assumes she's an independent woman of some means.

title: Rebuild America by Rebuilding Labor
description: A dangerous, virtually unquestioned assumption has taken hold of American management - that the best way to be competitive is to cut people, wages and salaries. This assumption has led to the trade deficits that are bankrupting America, and it is making our nation dependent on foreign powers for all manner of capital, products and - increasingly - technology. Yet this assumption is indefensible. Consider: In manufacturing, direct labor averages only 10 percent of costs, but draws 75 percent of cost-cutting efforts. This means 90 percent of true costs, such as technology, capital, inventory turnover and embedded waste, are barely touched.

title: Resourcefulness In the Domain Of the Forgotten
description: Somewhere between impressionism and post-Impressionism on the one hand and Fauvism and Cubism on the other, there is a niche that has no one name. What was done between 1888 and 1900 by the young Pierre Bonnard, the young Edouard Vuillard and their colleagues in the brotherhood known as the Nabis is difficult to identify in any existing major museum. This is not because it is unknown, but because it ranged from large-scale easel paintings and murals to theater programs, theater decors long vanished, original prints, book jackets and book bindings, designs for fans and lamp shades, posters and caricatures, illustrated books, political and social polemics, and designs for stained glass and furniture. By calling themselves the Nabis, after the Hebrew word for prophet, the artists in question made a specific claim for themselves. But the prophetic element in their work is only a part of its attraction for us. And the taste for it, once formed, is omnivorous.

title: POSTINGS: Just Off Central Park; Rocky Road for Townhouses
description: If everything went right for Townhouses on the Park, one-half block from Central Park West, all 77 of its two- and three-bedroom apartments with balconies and gardens would have sold for only $63,000 and $73,000. But just about everything went wrong for the community development corporation that started building the project eight years ago with Federal and city aid. Instead, 38 of the apartments are now for sale at from twice to three times their expected price: ranging from $145,000 to $265,000.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Best Boy Directed by Ira Wohl. 1979. Today Home Entertainment. 111 minutes. $59.95. Not rated.

title: Interior Dept. Acts to Speed Sales Of Public Lands for Development
description: In the last days of the Reagan Administration, the Interior Department is taking a series of steps to accelerate or simplify the transfer of public lands and public sources of energy to private entrepreneurs.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Altoona, Pa.;
Expressways Stir Things Up
description: LEAD: THE coming of two expressways in the last five years to this previously isolated old railroad town has expanded its retail marketing area and helped spur commercial real estate construction.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ALEXANDRE DUMAS: Genius of Life. By Claude Schopp. Translated by A. J. Koch. (Franklin Watts, $27.50.) Claude Schopp's richly detailed and highly colored biography of Alexandre Dumas, originally published in France in 1986 and sparklingly translated by A. J. Koch, presents the writer now known almost solely for ''The Three Musketeers'' and ''The Count of Monte Cristo'' as a beloved, vainglorious, tireless citizen of 19th-century France, whose part in such upheavals as the Revolution of 1832 was remarkably similar to the heroic doings in his romances.

title: Curtain Staying Down
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Inside Out
description: SITTING IN a movie theater a few years ago, Todd Gitlin had another of his frequent out-of-culture experiences. He was watching the movie ''The Big Chill,'' about a group of college friends who had abandoned their 1960's political and social commitment in favor of 1980's affluence and personal striving. ''Everyone around me was loving it,'' he said of the film, ''and I was just hating it!''

title: Repairing Veneer on Woodwork
description: Veneer is usually a thin layer of attractive woodthat is glued in the surface of thicker, less attractive wood to enhance its appearance.

title: Duke Player Stars In the Hula Bowl
description: Anthony Dilweg of Duke passed for three touchdowns to Michigan State's Andre Rison today as the East beat the West, 21-10, in the Hula Bowl.

title: Music Teacher's View of Holiday Music
description: As a public-school music educator for the last 23 years, I have had to deal with the issue of holiday music in a variety of school settings. The article ''Schools Strive for Seasonal Balance'' [ Dec. 18 ] was interesting but failed to point out one obvious solution to the dilemma. Simply make the issue a non-issue by remembering that the primary function of the music teacher is to teach music and to provide positive musical experiences to all students.

title: Kimberly K. McDermott Is Married To Miles D. N. Esty, a Law Student
description: Kimberly Kavanaugh McDermott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. McDermott of Hamburg Cove, Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Miles David Newman Esty, a son of Susan Esty of New York and St. John, V.I., and the late William C. Esty 4th. The Rev. Andrew E. Fiddler performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church-on-the-Green in New Haven.

title: Chinese Modern With Old Favorites
description: THE age-old debate continues. French or Chinese? Which is the world's premier cuisine? Residents of St. James don't have to choose; they have it all. Lotus East, an exceptional Chinese restaurant, recently opened approximately 500 crispy duck lengths from Mirabelle, one of Long Island's great French restaurants.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 8, 1989
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 8 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. 3 10 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 4 3 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and-roll performers in tinselly southern California. 5 16 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 6 13 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 7 24 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 8 2 LOVE SONGS, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.50.) Horrors await a pop singer when she returns to her hometown in Maine. 9 6 THE MASK, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.50.) The terrors that befall a couple after they adopt an attractive teen-ager. 10 10 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 11 2 THE SILK VENDETTA, by Victoria Holt. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A young woman's choice of one of two brothers as her husband creates a storm in a wealthy European dynasty. 12 2 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Penguin, $4.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 13 97 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 14 6 SILVER ANGEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A kidnapped Englishwoman finds romance in a pasha's harem. 15 1 WINTER, by Len Deighton. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The experiences of a Berlin family, from Kaiser Wilhelm to Adolf Hitler. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 11 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $6.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat that adopted and soon owned him. 2 6 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Bantam, $4.95.) The television star muses on life at 50. 3 7 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 4 3 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Warner, $5.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 5 30 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates life's stages, from birth to coming-of-age to marriage to aging and death. 6 272 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 7 4 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.) A ''new science'' that makes it possible to see order and patterns in what appears to be erratic and formless. 8 33 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 9 * 2 LIFE SMILES BACK, by Philip B. Kunhardt Jr. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Photographs from Life magazine. 10 21 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race's struggle for identity, seen through many centuries of mythology. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 11 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY 3, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $10.95.) A selection of cartoons from three previously published collections. 2 15 THE ESSENTIAL CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 3 3 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1989. (World Almanac/Pharos Books, $6.95.) Its 121st year. 4 6 SEPARATED AT BIRTH? by the editors of Spy. (Spy/Dolphin/Doubleday, $6.95.) Juxtapositions of celebrities' pictures; humor. 5 17 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Armchair Travel
description: To the Editor: Since insensitive tourists create a disproportionate amount of ill will for the traveling population, I am grateful for Arthur A. Witkin's advocacy of armchair travel (Letters, Nov. 20).

title: Garbage In . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Hirohito's Death Puts Focus on New Identity
description: The death of Emperor Hirohito may crystallize a national pride, self-confidence and search for Japanese values under way long before he took ill.

title: Implications of RICO Verdict
description: LEAD: THE significance of a Federal jury verdict that last month found the Long Island Lighting Company and a former company president guilty of racketeering was slowly dawning across Long Island as the New Year began.

title: Wyche Provides Example Of the Merits of Hard Work
description: The reminder can be found on an orange and black sign near the top of a building being constructed downtown. Or on the radio stations that play thematic groups of songs. And certainly, early this afternoon, the message will be sent in the stadium on the banks of the Ohio River:

title: BUCKAROO POETS: WHOOP-EE-TI-YI-YO, GIT ALONG, LITTLE DOGGEREL
description: I can ride the wildest bronco in the wild and woolly West, I can rake him, I can break him, let him do his level best. I can handle any cattle ever wore a coat of hair, And I've had a lively tussle with a tarnal grizzly bear. I can rope and throw a longhorn of the wildest Texas brand, And at Injun disagreements I can take a leading hand. But I finally met my master, and he really made me squeal, When the boys got me astraddle of that gol-darned wheel. . . .''

title: Baseball Notebook; Mattingly Is Still Top Hitter Despite Off Year, Study Says
description: A statistical study determined last off season that for the previous four seasons Don Mattingly easily was the best player in the universe.

title: Reigning Over the Bridal Trade
description: LEAD: IT'S love that makes the world go round, but perhaps no one knows it better than Bill Heaton. As president of Bridal Expos Inc., he reigns over what he describes as the largest traveling bridal show in the world, now ''playing'' to 22 cities across the country.

title: On Broadway, Spectacles Raise the Stakes
description: ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's $8 million megamusical, has been a consistent sellout since its opening last January, taking in more than $28 million at the box office. But it is not expected to reimburse its investors fully until the end of April - more than 15 months into its run.

title: Video Games On the Rebound
description: THOUGH the crazed days of Pac-Man and Space Invaders may be over, student-union directors and students say a new generation of video games is flourishing on campus.

title: Susan Urdang Married To Jeremy A. Berman
description: The marriage of Susan L. Urdang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Urdang of New Rochelle, N.Y., to Jeremy A. Berman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simeon M. Berman of Brooklyn, took place yesterday at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Alvin Poplack performed the ceremony.

title: Israeli-Appointed Palestinian Is Wounded
description: An Israeli-appointed Palestinian official in the West Bank was stabbed by masked youths early this morning in the second such attack in two days.

title: TV Notes
description: CBS Late-Night Show

title: Contra Military Commander Is Assassinated in Honduras
description: A Nicaraguan rebel military commander was killed by gunmen on Saturday, the police said today.

title: Beijing Journal; Freshest Nuance in China's Art Is (Blush) Nudes
description: In the 10 years since China opened up to the world, most Chinese encountered enough Coca-Cola, television, disco dancing and sunglasses to make them blase about most exotic imports from the Occident - until Beijing opened an exhibition of nude art.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Symington Tribute
description: A memorial service will be held Tuesday at the National Cathedral for W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force in the Truman Administration and a Democratic Senator from Missouri for 24 years. He died Dec. 14 at 87. On hand will be his son, James W. Symington, a former Missouri Congressman; Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina; Clark Clifford, a former Secretary of Defense, and David C. Acheson, a former Treasury official.

title: Industry Partners Disagree On Favoring of Chain Stores
description: IT is virtually impossible to be around booksellers or publishers very long without realizing that they generally respect each other, taking considerable pride in their roles as disseminators of the written word.

title: Tokyo Stocks Set Record
description: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in early trading today, while share prices set a record on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in the first day of trading after Emperor Hirohito's death early Saturday.

title: Sports World Specials; Sluggers' Signatures
description: Ask a fan where to find the greatest array of sports figures assembled in one place this month and the guess would probably be the Super Bowl. The guess would be wrong. No star or stars will shine brighter than the collection of sluggers who will sign autographs at Tropworld Casino and Entertainment Resort in Atlantic City next weekend.

title: At Least 37 Die in British Plane Crash
description: At least 37 people were killed and about 75 others were injured Sunday when a British domestic airliner crashed near a major highway in central England while trying to make an emergency landing, the police said.

title: On Being Heard
description: ''I will not equivocate,'' cried a passionate journalist a century ago, ''. . . and I will be heard!''

title: Ladbroke Buys Race Track
description: Ladbroke Group P.L.C. said its United States Racing division had acquired for $41 million the Golden Gate Fields race track near San Francisco, a leading thoroughbred track and one of two big satellite-betting operations in Northern California.

title: Topics of The Times; The Snooker Boom
description: In Manhattan, new emporiums where the public can play pool and billiards are opening faster than the city's massage parlors closed. These establishments are equipped with pocketless tables on which the congnoscenti play three-cushion billiards, and 6-by-12-foot snooker tables that look as big as polo fields next to standard American 4-by-8-foot pool tables.

title: Outdoors: Boats for Everyone
description: BILLED as the oldest affair of its kind in the world, the 79th New York National Boat Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan opens Saturday and continues through Jan. 22.

title: A.C.L.U. Accuses Louisiana Of Neglecting Foster Children
description: Hundreds of children in Louisiana's foster care program have been neglected by the system intended to protect them, the American Civil Liberties Union contends in a report to be issued this week.

title: Topics of The Times; Beauty on a Bike
description: The Palisades Interstate Park Commission governs one of the region's loveliest roads. It runs along the base of the Palisades from just north of the George Washington Bridge to Alpine, N.J., offering intimate Hudson River views and access to marinas and picnic grounds. The road, however, is barely two lanes wide and full of curves, and despite repeated requests from bicycling groups, the commission considers it unsafe for simultaneous use by autos and bikes. The commission limits bicycles to a few morning hours on weekends between April and November.

title: Two Shiite Militias Battle Fiercely Near Sidon
description: Rival Shiite Muslim militiamen fought their fiercest battles in a year of confrontation in southern Lebanon today, and the police said 28 people were killed and 51 wounded.

title: Fitness; New Sophistication On Using Muscle
description: BACK in 1981, when Priscilla Clarkson was a new faculty member at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst and the ink was still wet on her Ph.D. diploma, she was fascinated with studying exercise and its relationship to muscle strength and fatigue.

title: Wright Steers a Bold Course Into Stormy Issues
description: In the basement of the Capitol an investigation of Representative Jim Wright grinds toward its conclusion. Around him, allies advise a cautious, let-George-do-it-first approach in discussing the budget deficit with the new President. But anyone expecting a weakened or wary Speaker finds that Mr. Wright is not easily derailed.

title: Hoping Students Without Homes Will Say, 'Here!'
description: Only one parent, Luis Santiago, was waiting in the bitter cold outside the Prince George Hotel in Manhattan the other afternoon when the first yellow school bus rumbled down East 28th Street.

title: Queens Woman Charged With killing Mother
description: A Queens woman described by the police and neighbors as chronically mentally ill was charged with arson and murder yesterday after her elderly mother died Saturday night in a fire that tore through their apartment.

title: Rozelle's Snap Decision Forces Bengals to Adapt Special to The New York Times
description: In the end, it was hitting, tackling and running that won for the Bengals today and sent them on their way to Super Bowl XXIII.

title: Rangaire's Head Ousted By Its British Investor
description: A foreign investor has shaken things up at the Rangaire Corporation in Cleburne, Tex.

title: Books of The Times; True McGinniss Story of Greed, Lust and Murder
description: Blind Faith By Joe McGinniss Illustrated. 381 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: New Battle Erupts for LVMH Moet
description: A new battle has erupted for control of the world's largest luxury-goods company, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, and many analysts say all the jockeying could produce a stalemate rather than a clear winner.

title: Triangle-Pechiney Insider Inquiry Widens
description: An insider-trading investigation involving the acquisition of Triangle Industries by Pechiney S.A., the French aluminum company, grew last week when investigators linked a friend of President Francois Mitterrand, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and several stockbrokers in France and Luxembourg to the affair.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the disciplinary actions taken by the National Association of Securities Dealers in a stock-manipulation case incorrectly described the findings and sanctions against Eugene K. Laff, the former chairman of the Haas Securities Corporation. The association concluded that Mr. Laff had failed to adequately supervise Haas's former president, Stanley Aslanian Jr., who has pleaded guilty to stock-manipulation charges. Because of an editing error, the article failed to report that Mr. Laff consented to the findings without admitting or denying guilt. In addition to other sanctions, Mr. Laff was suspended for two years from associating with any member firm of the N.A.S.D. in a supervisory capacity.

title: Attorney General Says Walsh Not Pressured on North Case
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that the Reagan Administration did not try to thwart Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case, from pursuing any avenue of inquiry in the matter.

title: Woods Leads Bengals Past Bills
description: In an American Conference championship game devoid of newfangled offensive gimmicks, the Bengals chugged along on the old-fashioned running of Ickey Woods today to beat the Buffalo Bills and advance to Super Bowl XXIII.

title: In Patrick, the Last Are First
description: A glance at the National Hockey League standings now, about midway through the season, shows that the two Patrick Division teams that missed the Stanley Cup playoffs last season are now among the top five in the league.

title: Results Plus
description: Skiing Schneider Wins Again: Vreni Schneider continued her string of successes yesterday, winning a World Cup women's slalom in Mellau, Austria, for her third triumph in three days and her ninth of the season. Tamara McKinney of Squaw Valley, Calif., who led after the first heat, straddled a gate in the second run and was disqualified. With McKinney out, Schneider, who clocked 53.78 seconds in the first heat for third place, danced and darted through the gates and produced the best time in the second run, 52.34, for a total of 1:46.12. Mateja Svet of Yugoslavia was second at 1:46.40. Schneider has 232 World Cup points, with Ulrike Maier of Austria second with 118. (AP) Hangl Surprises: Martin Hangl of Switzerland overshadowed the stars of the men's World Cup circuit, winning a super-G race for his third career triumph. Hangl, 26, made up time on the lower part of the 2,000-meter Fatschas run in Laax, Switzerland, and produced a winning time of 1:16.14. Hans Enn of Austria finished second in 1:16.48.(AP) Tennis Sukova Ends Slump: Helena Sukova ended an 18-month spell without a tournament victory by beating Brenda Schultz of the Netherlands, 7-6, 7-6, in the final of the Danone Australian women's hardcourt championship in Brisbane yesterday. Sukova, ranked eighth in the world, was the top-seeded player in the tournament, which she won in 1984. Schultz, the Wimbledon junior champion, was seeded ninth. Schultz had set points in both sets, but although she hit the ball with tremendous power she lacked Sukova's composure on the crucial points.(AP) Nordic Skiing Kempf Takes Combined: Hippolyt Kempf of Switzerland won a World Cup Nordic combined competition at Schonach, West Germany, and took over the lead in World Cup standing. Andrei Dundukov of the Soviet Union finished second in the combined event, followed by Trond Elden of Norway. Kempf's victory came after he posted the best time in the cross-country competition, after finishing fourth in the jumping event Saturday. (AP) Road Racing Anastasio Wins: Robert Anastasio of Warren Street Athletic Club, a former Cornell star, pulled away in the stretch to win the New York Road Runners Club's five-mile run in 24 minutes 59 seconds at Central Park yesterday. The club's opening race of the season drew a field of 2,010 in a steady rain. Paul Mascali of the New York Athletic Club trailed by 10 yards in 25:02. Gordon Bloch of the Atalanta Track Club, runner-up last year, earned the women's title in 28:15. Horse Racing Third Straight for High Brite: High Brite, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., scored his third straight stakes victory yesterday, outlasting Vinnie the Viper by a nose in the $85,200 Paumonok Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. It was 5 1/2 lengths farther back to Scottish Monk. Fire Plug and Never Forgotten completed the order of finish. High Brite, carrying highweight of 124 pounds, went six furlongs on the fast track in 1:09 1/5 to earn $51,120 for Joseph Allen. High Brite returned $3.60, $3.20 and $2.20 for $2 across the board. Vinnie the Viper paid $4.80 and $2.60, and Scottish Monk was $2.60 to show. (AP) Dog Show First for Clumber Spaniel: Ch. Raycroft Sheriff, a Clumber spaniel, was named best in a field of 993 yesterday at the American Spaniel Club's specialty in the Meadowlands Hilton Hotel in Secaucus, N.J. It was the first time a representative of the breed had taken the top award since the American Spaniel Club began awarding best in show in 1921. Bear, as the 6-year-old orange and white dog is called by his owners, George and Dorothy O'Neil, was imported from England in 1985. The Clumber is the heaviest of the spaniel family, the breed being named after Clumber Park, the estate of the Duke of Newcastle. There are only 800 Clumbers in the United States.

title: Schultz Urges Hiring Change
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association opened its 83d convention today with the executive director reaffirming the healthy condition of intercollegiate athletics and urging members to create more executive-level opportunities for women and members of ethnic minorities.

title: Stung by Cable Audience Claims, Networks Retaliate
description: For years, the cable television industry has gone around to advertisers mocking the major television networks and vigorously promoting the marvels of cable. The networks have listened, shrugged and said nothing. No more. Tired of losing viewers and advertising dollars to cable, CBS and ABC have in recent weeks unleashed a get-tough strategy. They have been calling on ad agencies and key national advertisers with elaborate presentations skewering the cable industry. The Television Bureau of Advertising, a trade group for television stations, has sent brochures with similar messages to its members. NBC, though it discusses cable along with other issues in chats with advertisers, has not put together a specific road show on the topic. CBS Uses a Fable

title: Salvador Rebels' Drive on Mayors Is Bringing Chaos to Rural Areas
description: In a major blow to United States policy in this country, municipal government has collapsed in many rural areas.

title: Schoolchildren Raise Money for the Neediest
description: A group of second graders at Public School 221 in Little Neck, Queens, raised $360 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They did it by selling toys, games and books to other classes in the school.

title: Japanese Flick on Their TV's and Glimpse Well-Hidden History
description: The nation awoke to a new imperial epoch on Sunday, the Heisei era of Achieving Peace. But along with the celebrations came stark black-and-white images of Japanese soldiers invading Manchuria, assassinating prime ministers, bombing Pearl Harbor and hoisting the Rising Sun flag next to Nazi swastikas.

title: Koch Seeks Taxes on Co-ops For Increased Child Services
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch's budget proposal for the next fiscal year, which is expected to call for service cuts and tax increases, will include $60 million in additional spending on child-abuse programs and education.

title: Sara Lee Accounts
description: In preparation for 1992, when European trade barriers will be eliminated, the Douwe Egberts/Sara Lee Corporation, a European subsidiary of the American consumer-products giant, has consolidated its advertising, currently at 30 local agencies, in B.B.D.O. Europe, HDM and Saatchi & Saatchi. A B.B.D.O. spokesman said that agency would double its billings, to about $30 million. Representatives of the other agencies were unsure about their assignments or budget.

title: An Infant Suffocates In Bed With Her Father
description: A 4-month-old infant apparently suffocated while sleeping with her father early yesterday, the police said.

title: SOVIETS TO START TRIMMING ARSENAL OF CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it would start to destroy its stocks of chemical weapons.

title: Poison Reported Found In 17-Year-Old's Home
description: Cyanide was found in the home of a teen-ager who lapsed into a coma after eating yogurt tainted with the poison, a newspaper reported this weekend.

title: In War Against Corrosion, Costly Byproduct Is Waste
description: There have been times in recent months when Harry De Soi wasn't sure if waste handlers would accept the toxic heavy metals left over from his electroplating business in Franklinville, N.J. Mr. De Soi had visions of being fined by the Government and being labeled a polluter, as have so many other people in his business.

title: Saatchi Gets Ski Job
description: Last week Saatchi & Saatchi, New York was given the North American ad account of Salomon, a French manufacturer of ski equipment and accessories. The budget will be $7 to $10 million. Last month, Saatchi's London office received Salomon's European account. The former North American agency-of-record is John Creel Advertising.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''And should anyone say to us that we waited too long before stopping the production of chemical weapons and imposing other prohibitions on them, we would say: yes we did wait too long.'' - Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union. [ A8:2. ]

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Seals' Lion
description: Bob Kerrey's Vietnam War buddies attended his inauguration as Governor of Nebraska in 1983 and they watched last Tuesday as Mr. Kerrey, a Democrat, was sworn as the junior Senator from Nebraska.

title: Short-Term Rate Rise Expected
description: New evidence of economic strength makes further increases in short-term interest rates likely over the next month to six weeks, credit market analysts predicted.

title: Reviews/Dance; 'Raymond,' a Portrait Of Isadora's Brother
description: The best came last on Friday evening at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, where the Mary Anthony Dance Theater Foundation presented work by Bertram Ross and Nai-Ni Chen. Nothing in the program quite measured up to Mr. Ross's ''Raymond,'' the bittersweet portrait of Isadora Duncan's addlepated brother, which closed the program. But then the solo, in which Mr. Ross speaks the actual words of Raymond Duncan as he strides, whirls and cajoles, is inspired work. It draws from Mr. Ross, a noted former member of the Martha Graham Dance Company who became an actor and cabaret singer, a level of sustained characterization that ends in a moment of searingly poignant revelation.

title: Crack and Gunfire Come to a Quiet Place
description: On the elm-lined streets of Washington's Fourth Ward, where residents live in neat brick houses and dutifully tend their azaleas, many people now hurry indoors and dare not stroll the way they used to.

title: Trade Show's Hottest Item: The TV Set
description: The hottest product at this year's Consumer Electronics Show is one of the oldest - the television set. So strong has the demand been for television sets around the world that there is now a growing shortage.

title: How Many Young Lives Is a Basilica Worth?; John the Divine Largest
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; 'Twist of Fate' Concludes
description: The unlikely is commonplace in television movies and dramas. Even the Hallmark Hall of Fame recently offered Anthony Hopkins as a Frenchman who is arrested by the Nazis during World War II, gives away his possessions to save his life, and then returns after the war to be a servant in his own chateau, completely unrecognized by anyone in the village. But of course ''The Tenth Man,'' based on a Graham Greene story, was something of a parable, taking for granted an enormous suspension of disbelief. It is when the unlikely takes a giant leap into the preposterous that television can be truly stunning. Consider ''Twist of Fate,'' a four-hour production on NBC, the second half of which can be seen tonight at 9.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday, based on information from The Associated Press, misidentified the men with Emperor Akihito of Japan. From the right were Akihito; Crown Prince Hiro; Akihito's brother, Prince Hitachi, and a cousin, Prince Tomohito.

title: D.M.B.&B. Acquires Penchina
description: PENCHINA, SELKOWITZ INC., a tiny New York agency known for its work for Burroughs computers, was acquired on Friday by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the $2.5 billion advertising giant. Executives of the agency will receive an undisclosed amount of cash and stock in D.M.B.&B., and a percentage of their agency's profits.

title: Horse Racing; Gulfstream Opens And Halrose Wins
description: Halrose benefited from a scorching early pace to beat Jabotinsky by a long neck and win the $57,950 Spectacular Bid Stakes today before a record opening-day crowd of 26,517 at Gulfstream Park.

title: Islanders Fall to Blackhawks
description: After the game, Randy Wood sat ruminatively in a locker-room corner tonight and held an ice pack to his left knee as all around him his teammates used words like ''disaster'' and ''awful'' to describe themselves and their losing ways.

title: Proud Bears Face the Facts
description: After teams lose important football games, their players are often stunned or angry or sullen or tight-lipped. After the San Francisco 49ers soundly defeated the Bears, 28-3, today to advance to the Super Bowl, most of the Bears were calm and contained.

title: Mississippi Town Won't Get Film
description: The owner of this town's only theater said today that she would not show the film ''Mississippi Burning,'' a fictionalized account of the deaths here 25 years ago of three civil rights workers.

title: Market Place; The High Price Of Manipulation
description: IT is a back alley of Wall Street that normally gets little attention from the press or prosecutors, involving small companies and stocks that shoot into the stratosphere, only to fall back to the ground. But although the companies are small, the losses for investors can be very large. Sometimes, the losers are also the owners of family businesses that have been acquired by high-flying companies.

title: Fitness; Start Slowly and Use Common Sense
description: Dr. Priscilla Clarkson of the University of Massachusetts believes that exercise should not damage muscles so much that negative effects outweigh the benefits. She makes the following suggestions for recreational athletes:

title: Business and the Law; U.S. Judge's Role In Wall St. Cases
description: THE Federal judge presiding at the GAF Corporation stock-manipulation trial, Mary Johnson Lowe, is expected to decide this week whether to declare a mistrial because of charges of prosecutorial misconduct.

title: Israel's Presence in Moscow To Be Expanded, Arens Says
description: The Soviet Union will upgrade Israel's consular delegation in Moscow and allow Israeli diplomats to conduct political talks there, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said today.

title: Group Said to Be Studying Offer to Buy G.E. of Britain
description: A consortium of international companies is working on a possible bid for the General Electric Company of Britain, a London investment house said this weekend, prompting calls for Government intervention.

title: Women Meet, Ideology in Back Row
description: Though they cheered for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, more than 1,100 women representing 61 organizations focused more on trade deficits, job training, child care and other economic issues at a national conference this weekend.

title: The Ant and the Grasshopper; Why Is U.S. Prosperity Eroding? Japan's Lessons.
description: Japan and America are engaged in a furious struggle of which many Americans seem scarcely aware, a struggle that neither has to lose.

title: Sports World Specials; Different Kind of Net
description: Ever since Ivan Lendl left to play several tournaments in Australia a few weeks ago, he has had his secretary, Diane Nagy, send him daily messages about the doings of the Hartford Whalers of the National Hockey League.

title: At Hardee's, Fast Food and Trends
description: As Gary Langstaff explains it, his primary professional task is to understand precisely the role of the hamburger, the french fry, the seafood salad and the soda in society.

title: When Courts Take Charge Of the Unborn
description: Last spring, Brenda Vaughan, a 29-year-old Washington woman, pleaded guilty to forging about $700 worth of checks. It was her first offense and one that would normally have brought probation. But because Ms. Vaughan was pregnant and tests showed she had used cocaine, the judge sent her to jail until the date the baby was due, saying he wanted to protect her fetus from drug abuse.

title: Jean Willes, Actress, 65
description: Jean Willes, an actress who appeared in films like ''Elmer Gantry'' and television series like ''Perry Mason'' and ''Bonanza'' in her 30-year career, died of liver failure Tuesday. She was 65 years old.

title: Clippers, Minus Manning, Fall to Knicks
description: The Los Angeles Clippers lost another road game last night. They were thrashed by the Knicks, 134-100, at Madison Square Garden in a game that served as a morale builder for Johnny Newman and Gerald Wilkins, who had been in shooting slumps. The 34-point margin was the largest this season for the Knicks, who brought their record to 21-11.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY President-elect Bush's economic team is preparing proposals to encourage businesses to concentrate more on productivity and growth and less on quick profits, Treasury officials say. The new administration hopes to confront problems like the decline of savings rates, the relative erosion of America's standard of living and lackluster investment in long-term growth. [ Page A1. ] Job security replaced wage increases as the top goal of many labor unions during the 1980's. But the unions have had little success in winning employment guarantees. [ A1. ] The Export-Import Bank has decided to suspend new lending as a result of Federal budget tightening. [ D1. ] Television sets are in short supply, with demand strong around the world. As a result, consumers may face price increases and reduced supplies of the cheapest sets, say executives attending the electronics industry's annual show in Las Vegas, Nev. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT An international consortium is working on a possible offer for Britain's General Electric Company, a London investment house said. British officials immediately called for Government intervention against such a bid, which could exceed $10.6 billion. [ D1. ] Venezuela's President-elect is urging a unified Latin American approach to the debt crisis. Carlos Andres Perez has undertaken a diplomatic initiative, holding discussions with two presidents and planning talks with other leaders in the region. [ D8. ] A French insider-trading inquiry has grown. Under scrutiny are purchases of Triangle Industries shares just before the U.S. concern was acquired by Pechiney, a state-owned company. [ D8. ] COMPANIES The bankrupt McLean Industries may be acquired by investors led by Paul S. Levy, who is seeking to buy Allegheny International. McLean's tax breaks could be invaluable if the company is wedded to a potentially profitable concern like Allegheny. [ D1. ] Pacific Resources agreed to merge with a subsidiary of Broken Hill Proprietary of Australia. Pacific Resources stockholders would receive $19 a share from the $395 million deal. [ D1. ] A battle has erupted for LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton. There is speculation that Bernard Arnault, the company's largest shareholder, is seeking to obtain a blocking minority. [ D8. ] Digital will introduce a range of work stations and personal computers with competitive prices. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS CBS and ABC are fighting back against cable TV with elaborate presentations aimed at holding onto advertisers' dollars. [ D6. ] The Chicago Sun-Times appears to be on firmer financial footing than it was just a few months ago. It has agreed to buy a second newspaper chain in the Chicago suburbs. [ D6. ] Nissan says its unusual ''Road to Rio'' ads helped to improve sales of its Pathfinder by 25 percent last fall. The six-part series chronicles a 6,700-mile trip from Chicago to Brazil. [ D6. ] Booksellers and publishers are sharply divided over F.T.C. complaints that six publishers illegally discriminated against independent bookstores in favor of large chains. Publishing. [ D6. ] D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has acquired Penchina, Selkowitz, known for its Burroughs computer ads. Advertising. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Further increases in short-term rates seem likely, analysts say, based on signs of economic strength. But some experts are not sure the Fed has tightened credit. Credit Markets. [ D5. ] Recent cases have illustrated how easy stock manipulation can be. Although the companies involved may be small, the losses for investors can be very large. Market Place. [ D4. ] Lawyers have criticized the judge in the GAF trial for her actions in previous cases. Business and the Law. [ D2. ]

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Once again this past season, the two Canadian major league teams, Montreal and Toronto, failed to have a pitcher win 20 games. Have the Expos or Blue Jays ever had a 20-game winner?

title: Cardinal of Detroit Orders 30 Parishes In the City to Close
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit today ordered 30 parishes in this city to close in the coming months and gave 25 others a year to improve their status or suffer the same fate.

title: Armenian Benefit
description: The Osipov Balalaika Orchestra, returning to the United States for the first time in 12 years, will present a benefit for Armenian earthquake relief at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 25 at 8 P.M. The Osipov, directed by Nikolai Kalinin, will be joined by the dancers and singers of the Babkina Folk Ensemble and two Bolshoi Opera soloists, Galina Borisova and Vladimir Malchenko. Tickets are $35 to $10 at the Carnegie Hall Box Office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: New Loans Suspended By Agency
description: The Export-Import Bank, a Government agency making below-market-value loans to buyers of American exports, has decided to suspend new lending operations as a result of the Reagan Administration's budget squeeze, bank officials said.

title: Digital Will Introduce PC's and Work Stations
description: In a move certain to increase the competition in the fastest-growing portion of the computer industry, the Digital Equipment Corporation will introduce tomorrow a range of aggressively priced work stations and personal computers.

title: Review/Dance; Mazowsze, From Poland
description: There is nothing quite like Mazowsze. The Polish folk ensemble began its American tour - the fourth since its founding in 1948 - with a typically rich and heartwarming performance on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: New Ampad Campaign By Partners & Shevack
description: Partners & Shevack is focusing on consumers' inability to distinguish between brands of memo pads in its first campaign for a new client, Ampad. In trade ads for the paper-pad manufacturer based in Dayton, Ohio, the agency eschews serious discussions of rips and runs in favor of whimsy.

title: Fort Dix's Neighbors Need to Plan
description: The partial closing of Fort Dix could pose more problems for southern New Jersey communitiesthan the total closing of other bases will pose elsewhere. But that's no reason for Congress to scuttle the base-closing plan. Instead, all affected areas need to make a quick start, with Federal help, on plans for future development.

title: Big East; Not Surprisingly, Surprises Abound
description: So far, the only predictable thing about the Big East has been its unpredictability.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Sports World Specials column of SportsMonday on Jan. 2 about the Ed Block Courage Award misstated the reason Tom Baldwin of the New York Jets was nominated for the award. He was nominated because of his fight against alcoholism.

title: 'Who Is a Jew' Remains A Volatile Issue in U.S.
description: The explosive issue of ''who is a Jew'' has been removed from the immediate political agenda in Jerusalem, but in the United States the debate continues to alter the relations of Jews with Israel and each other fundamentally, many American Jews say.

title: Chief of Canon U.S.A. Is Returning to Japan
description: Fujio Mitarai, who helped to make Canon cameras and business machines leading sellers in the United States, is going back to the parent company in Japan after 23 years -an unusually long stay here for a Japanese executive.

title: Budget Tug of War Is About to Begin
description: It begins officially Monday - the collision of political wills, national priorities, parochial interests and slippery arithmetic otherwise known as the budget process.

title: Job Security a Mirage for Unions Despite Wage Concessions of 80's
description: Job security replaced wage increases in the 1980's as the top contract goal of many American labor unions. But with the decade almost over, the unions have had precious little success in winning employment guarantees.

title: How Many Young Lives Is a Basilica Worth?; Third World Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: South Florida Journal; Will Car-Country Folks Be Steered to the Train?
description: That symbol of the Northern suburbs, the commuter rail line, has come to South Florida. But getting the track and the trains was easy. Now comes the hard part: getting people to ride it.

title: Burmese, Still Under Military, Settle Into a Sullen Waiting
description: Nearly four months after a spontaneous popular uprising against 26 years of eccentric military autocracy was crushed by the armed forces, the people of Burma have settled into a sullen and angry watchfulness made worse by economic hardship and continued repression. Promised elections seem ever more remote.

title: The Problem of Control in Child Custody
description: To the Editor:

title: Why They, Not Jean Harris, Received Clemency
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Said to Arrest Armenian Dissidents
description: Authorities in the Armenian capital of Yerevan have arrested a dozen more Armenian protest leaders in the latest crackdown on nationalist dissent in the republic, a Yerevan resident said tonight.

title: Long, Turbulent Run Of '42d Street' Arrives at Its Finale
description: David Merrick's long-running ''42d Street'' closed on 44th Street yesterday afternoon at the St. James Theater after 3,486 performances, and with it an era in Broadway musical history may have come to an end.

title: Sports of The Times; Ickey Shuffles To Miami
description: FORTUNATELY for the Bengals and the stern muse of the dance, Ickey Woods, the rookie with the wacky hoofs, saved his best choreography for the playing field yesterday afternoon in the American Conference championship game.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Consumer Credit Nov. Tuesday Wholesale Trade Nov. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Producer Prices Dec. Retail Sales Dec.

title: Review/Cabaret; Tony Bennett Opens A Club Near the Stars
description: Tony Bennett, as much as any other pop singer of his generation, symbolizes continuity in a city where it often seems nothing was meant to last. His mixture of streetwise toughness, starry-eyed romanticism and punchy sincerity also gives musical expression to a time-honored image of New York as a place where you have only to scratch someone's hardened surface to discover an unexpected reservoir of integrity, loyalty and decency.

title: Reagan Leaves Hospital
description: President Reagan returned to the White House today, a day after undergoing surgery on his left hand. Mr. Reagan waved his bandaged hand upon leaving the Walter Reed Army Medical Center here, where the operation, to correct a curvature in the ring finger of his left hand, was performed. He was not wearing a sling, although reports before the operation said he would have to wear one. He is expected to resume a full schedule of activity this week, his next-to-last as President.

title: How Many Young Lives Is a Basilica Worth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Singer and Friends Make Music to Help Music
description: One cold afternoon last week, the Swedish baritone Hakan Hagegard emptied the living room of the West Side apartment where he is staying and hauled in two enormous packing trunks. The trunks contained pieces of a scale model of the Hakan Hagegard Music Center, a rehearsal space, recording studio and artists' retreat the singer hopes to build in Brunskog, Sweden - a project for which Mr. Hagegard, Mstislav Rostropovich, Judith Blegen and several other singers, instrumentalists and ensembles are giving a benefit concert at Alice Tully Hall, tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: ON YOUR OWN;
description: Like so much of yachting, sailboarding is a seasonal sport. Or so it was until the advent of the mechanical windsurfer.

title: Doctor Is Beaten to Death in Her Bellevue Office
description: A doctor who had gone to work on her day off Saturday was found yesterday beaten to death in her office at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; Montana Was Never Better
description: IN the warmth of the 49ers' locker room, Guy McIntyre, their offensive right guard, was smiling as he pulled his white ''62'' jersey over his shoulder pads.''Not against the Bears,'' he was saying to two teammates. ''Not in the frigid cold.''

title: Bus Companies in Brooklyn Are Investigated for Bribery
description: More than a dozen private school and passenger bus companies in Brooklyn are under investigation for offering bribes to an undercover inspector to overlook possible safety violations, law-enforcement officials say.

title: How Many Young Lives Is a Basilica Worth?; Bitter and Sweet Money
description: To the Editor:

title: New, Mellower Qaddafi Now on Display in Libya
description: Another day, another demonstration to show support for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, against assertions that he is building a plant to produce chemical weapons.

title: Review/Music; Trumpet Avant-Gardist
