description: Two composers who are also performers - Ben Neill, a trumpeter, and David First, a guitarist - led their own ensembles in some of their recent works at La Galleria at La Mama on Saturday evening.

title: Correction
description: Because of editing errors, a report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Friday misstated the date and purpose of a trip to Latin America by some members of Congress. They are to study third-world debt issues and to examine results of large-scale clearing of the Amazonian rain forest in Brazil. The first of two groups left Washington on Thursday.

title: A Guide to Winter Excursions
description: These organizations can provide information about outdoor workshops, outings and lectures.

title: Police Guard AIDS Home For Toddlers
description: A 16-month-old boy has become the newest resident of a Brooklyn block, but his reception by most of his neighbors has been as frigid as the recent weather. The child has AIDS.

title: 'Unbearable Lightness' Gets Film Prize
description: ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' the film version of the novel by Milan Kundera, was voted the best film of 1988 yesterday by the National Society of Film Critics, a 39-member group that includes critics from New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and other cities. Philip Kaufman was voted best director for his work on that film.

title: Nathan G. Finkelstein, 73, Dies; Chairman of Beauty Salon Chain
description: Nathan G. Finkelstein, the chairman of the board of Glemby International, which operates more than 1,600 beauty salons around the world, died of lung cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Off
description: The Canadian unemployment rate fell to 7.6 percent in December from 7.8 percent in November, mainly because of increased job opportunities for men over 25 years old, the Government agency Statistics Canada reported Friday. In December 1987, the seasonlly adjusted unemployment rate was 8.1 percent. The agency said employment among men rose by 20,000 for the month but was virtually unchanged among women.

title: Ruth and Thornton And 'Our Town'
description: LEAD: In 1937, Ruth Gordon and the producer-director Jed Harris were planning a production of Henrik Ibsen's classic play ''A Doll's House,'' in which Ruth would play the leading role. They commissioned the redoubtable Clifford Odets to prepare a new English language version - a good idea suggested by Thornton Wilder.

title: Bridge
description: For the last five years, tournament players in the New York area have known what to expect when they read the names ''Bergen-Cohen'' on the opposing convention card. Marty Bergen and Larry Cohen, armed with a full arsenal of bidding theory and sharp card play, have won a string of titles at every level.

title: Treasury Bill and Note Auctions This Week
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction $7 billion of seven-year notes, followed on Thursday by the regular monthly sale of one-year bills.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Broken Hill to Acquire Pacific Resources
description: Pacific Resources Inc., an oil refiner and marketer, has agreed to merge with a subsidiary of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the largest public company in Australia, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Ketchum Fills Creative Post
description: In two weeks, Ketchum Advertising/New York will welcome Liz Nickles Murray to the new post of executive vice president/executive creative director.

title: Golf; Chip Shots Help Jones, Barber Win
description: On a day when chipping into the cup from off the greens became commonplace, Steve Jones used a chip shot to help him win the MONY Tournament of Champions by three strokes over David Frost and Jay Haas.

title: New College Freshmen Sho Shifts in Attitudes
description: A survey of members of the college class of 1992 shows that more are smoking, that they may be losing interest in business careers and that they overwhelmingly favor mandatory testing for AIDS and drugs.

title: Prepare for a Wintry Day in the Woods
description: SPORTS like skiing, hiking, snowshoeing, climbing and snowmobiling can turn cold and snow into a bounty of winter fun. But you have to know when to be cautious. Park trails and mountainsides are a lure for day trips and weekend excursions. The risks are small if you go well prepared. If you dress properly, take along the right food and recognize the signs of hypothermia and frostbite, you have little to fear and much to gain. The solitude of a snowy woodland in winter is one of life's best discoveries.

title: B.S.B. Buys Agencies In Norway and Sweden
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates has cemented its dominant position in Europe's ''Nordic region'' with its agreement to acquire four agencies in Norway and Sweden from Scan Partner, a marketing communications company based in Oslo.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INSIDE
description: Doctor Slain at Bellevue A pathologist who was five months pregnant was found in her hospital office, beaten to death and possibly raped, the police said. Page B1. Budget Battle to Begin The annual budget battle on Capitol Hill begins today, and President Reagan's proposal is likely to be the first casualty. House Speaker Jim Wright, for one, is charting a bold course for the new Congress. Page B6. '42d Street' Bows Out After 3,486 shows in 8 years, the award-winning musical gave its last Broadway performance. Page C11.

title: BUSH AIDES STUDY IDEAS TO REDIRECT GOALS OF BUSINESS
description: President-elect George Bush's economic policy makers are preparing proposals to encourage American businesses to concentrate more on productivity and growth and less on quick profits, Mr. Bush's advisers in the Treasury Department report.

title: Attention, Students: Never Mind Bush's G's
description: To the Editor:

title: China Orders American Out
description: An American and a Canadian have been ordered out of China because they were working for a United States-based dissident organization, the official New China News Agency said today. Huang Wencheng, an American citizen, and Huang Han, Canadian, were accused of carrying out ''illegal activities'' for the New York-based Chinese Alliance for Democracy since they arrived in China as tourists, it said.

title: Venezuelan Seeks Unity On Latin Debt
description: Even before taking office on Feb. 2, Carlos Andres Perez, the President-elect of Venezuela, has begun trying to forge a more unified Latin American approach to the region's foreign debt problem.

title: Family Rises Using Fraud On Medicaid
description: Sheldon Weinberg owned a modest dress shop in Brooklyn before he and his sons branched off into Medicaid ventures. Their new business quickly brought them the lavish trappings of success: six-figure incomes, a yacht, a $100,000 Rolls-Royce, apartments in Trump Tower, a butler, a maid and a $2.5 million home in Florida.

title: Perks for Peres Aggrieve an Austerity-Minded Israel
description: A political storm was gathering today over reports that Finance Minister Shimon Peres's austerity budget is less austere than it first appeared.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Swiss economic growth in 1989 and a more restrictive monetary policy could combine to push interest rates higher, the Swiss National Bank said. In its latest quarterly report, the bank reiterated its projection that real gross domestic product growth would be 2 percent this year, with inflation between 2 percent and 3 percent. The National Bank has announced a money supply growth target of 2 percent, using the fourth quarter of 1988 as the base.

title: An Actor Stands In As Writer
description: ''In the Heat of the Night'' has emerged as one of the few hits of the new television season, and its success can be attributed at least in part to the active role taken by the series' star, Carroll O'Connor.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, a publishing company, named Robert Baker to the newly created post of chief operating officer and executive vice president.

title: Review/Opera; Bronx Company in Smetana's Rustic 'Secret'
description: ''Tajemstvi'' (''The Secret''), the next-to-last of Bedrich Smetana's eight operas, was composed under the strain of deteriorating health, financial troubles and progressive deafness. ''I'm afraid my music is not cheerful enough,'' he wrote to his librettist in 1877, ''but when I see only poverty and misery ahead of me all enthusiasm for my work goes.''

title: Readings From 'Kitty'
description: Kitty Carlisle Hart, the chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, will read selections from her autobiography, ''Kitty,'' as well as from Moss Hart's autobiography, ''Act One,'' and other works, on Jan. 19 at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 50th Street. The reading will take place from 12:30 to 1:30 P.M.; admission is free.

title: Passenger Bobsleds at Lake Placid
description: DID you know that you can experience one of winter sport's ultimate fantasies, taking a turn down the Olympic bobsled course at Lake Placid, N.Y.?

title: Unusual Ad Campaign Improves Nissan Sales
description: In an effort to reach the sophisticated buyer who is hard to impress with lists of extras, the Nissan Motor Company is relying on an unusual advertising campaign for one of its newest lines.

title: 2 Macmillan Units Are Sold
description: The Maxwell Communication Corporation said on Friday that it had sold Macmillan Inc.'s Intertec publishing unit and certain assets of its Webb Publishing Company for $171 million. The purchaser, the Intertec

title: David Deutsch Wins Buick Dealers' Group
description: After a five-way review, the 120 Greater Pittsburgh Buick Dealers group tapped David Deutsch Associates as its agency.

title: Hormones and Trade Wars
description: LEAD: Hormones can be dangerous. Imprudently used, they could ruin our lives and infest the Olympics. But -would you believe -they can even start trade wars. When the European Community's ban on hormone-fed beef went into effect Jan. 1, we imposed retaliatory tariffs, thus firing the opening shots of what may turn into a battle, perhaps a war, before the dust settles.

title: Ejection Helps Put Bills Out
description: This was not the first time Tim McGee and Derrick Burroughs had met. Just the most significant.

title: The Mideast, Bush's First Test
description: The Bush administration's first real foreign policy test is likely to come in the Mideast.

title: Sun-Times Deal is Called Sign of Gains
description: The Chicago Sun-Times's agreement to acquire a second major suburban newspaper chain is a sign that the daily is on a firmer financial footing than it appeared to be a few months ago, despite a continuing decline in circulation, industry analysts say.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 9, 1989: MONDAY Carolina Freight Corp West Inc TUESDAY AAR Corp Ohio Mattress Co Diversified Ener Minn Unifirst Corp Learonal Inc Weyerhaeuser Co WEDNESDAY Bard C R Inc Walgreen Co Holly Farms Corp Woolworth F W Co Pacificorp THURSDAY Colgate Palmolive Co Pillsbury Co Ford Mtr Co Rubbermaid Inc Hartmarx Corp FRIDAY Flowers Inds Inc New York St Elec & Gas

title: Review/Television; A School Success Story
description: Channel 9 is showing a rerun tonight. But it's the kind of program that cannot be repeated too often.

title: New Prosecutor Vows to Battle Drugs at School
description: The new Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, said yesterday that he would estabish a policy of seeking a minimum one-year sentence for people convicted of dealing drugs within one block of a school.

title: ARABS LINK CURBS ON GAS AND A-ARMS
description: Iraq and other Arab nations said today that a call for a comprehensive ban on chemical weapons should be linked to a similar stand on nuclear weapons in light of Israel's reported possession of nuclear arms.

title: Reviews/Dance; The Lewitzky Company in Three Recent Works
description: Bella Lewitzky is always meticulous in her choreographic craftsmanship, and there are no sloppy movers in her Lewitzky Dance Company. That was apparent this afternoon when the Los Angeles-based group presented three recently choreographed works in the Zellerbach Theater of the Annenberg Center at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Washington Talk: Civil Service; Many Reaganites Now Find the Capital Is a Nice Place to Work
description: More than eight years ago Ronald Reagan ran against the Federal establishment in his Presidential campaign, arguing that government was the source of the nation's ills, not the solution.

title: Argentine Inflation
description: Argentina said Friday that its 1988 inflation rate was 387.7 percent, the highest since 672.2 percent in 1985, when President Raul Alfonsin's Government began the austral anti-inflation plan.

title: Correction
description: An obituary headline in some editions on Friday about one of the first women to become a leader in concert management misidentified her. She was Hattie Clark Rosenbaum.

title: Cubans Leaving Angola Look Back in Fondness
description: With her brown hair in a ponytail and heart-shaped earrings in her ears, 19-year-old Vivian Hernandez Caballero of the Cuban women's antiaircraft battery is already preparing for a long-awaited reunion this week with her boyfriend in Havana.

title: Super Rematch: 49ers and Bengals Going to Miami
description: At first, it was a quick death for the Chicago Bears. They blinked, and swoosh, there went Jerry Rice blazing past them into the end zone. Then it became a slow death for the Bears. A 13-play drive here, a 12-play drive there, one consuming nearly six minutes and the other almost seven minutes of the final half, each ending with the San Francisco 49ers in the end zone.

title: J. H. Weitzman Wed To Ms. Lowenbraun
description: Leslie Lowenbraun, an associate at the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, and Jeffrey H. Weitzman, an associate at the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells, were married in New York yesterday at the Union League Club by Rabbi Donald R. Gerber.

title: Sports World Specials; Ranger Memories
description: ''Tradition on Ice'' might be one of the most stirring hockey videos ever made. It's a 60-minute, 62-year retrospective that includes rare and dramatic early footage of Ranger action, interviews with Ranger stars from Murray Murdoch to Phil Esposito, and an almost nonstop narrative gush by David Perry.

title: Charity Schools Teach No Lesson for Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Scotland Investigates Report Of a Mix-Up in Crash Bodies
description: The police said today that they were investigating a claim that the family of an American student killed in the crash of Pan Am Flight 103 was given the wrong body.

title: McLean Deal Seen Linked To Allegheny
description: An investor group led by Paul S. Levy, one of two contenders to buy Allegheny International Inc., is well on its way to acquiring control of another company operating in bankruptcy, McLean Industries. Although the two companies do not seem to realize it, their destinies could be intertwined.

title: N.J. Transit Losing Hearts, and Fares, of Riders
description: After steadily improving a nearly bankrupt system of trains and buses through most of the 1980's, N.J. Transit is losing riders, revenue and some of its hard-earned reputation in what some commuters say is a rerun of the bad old days.

title: Angolan Sanctuary Closing to Rebels
description: After 13 years in Angola, two foreign armies are packing their bags here this week.

title: Books of The Times; In the English Gulag
description: Incline Our Hearts By A. N. Wilson 250 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: Car Export Limits Kept By Japanese
description: Despite strong opposition in Japan, the Japanese Government has told American trade officials that its restraints on automobile exports to the United States will be maintained for another year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Ad Hoc Marketing Resources, New York, has agreed to create a campaign for New York City to decrease the number of non-emergency calls made to the city's 911 emergency telephone services.

title: Feasts on Cotton Plant May Be Over for Pest
description: TO a caterpillar, a growing cotton plant is a natural invitation to dine and farmers pay the multimillion-dollar check. But now, genetic engineers have developed a cotton plant that is naturally poisonous to the pests.

title: Swedish Stock Market
description: The Stockholm stock exchange closed at an all-time high today despite a 15 percent tax on 1989 company profits. which the Government announced Dec. 31. The general index finished at 1,002.99 after climbing 1.57 percent for the day.

title: Child-Abuse Cases Overwhelm Agency
description: Despite strides toward improvement in the last two years, the agency charged with protecting New York City's children from abuse and neglect continues to be overwhelmed by its task, according to present and former officials, caseworkers and other experts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; FM Business Acquires Computer Decisions
description: FM Business Publications, the new trade-publishing company, can lay claim to having a growing stable of publications. The company has acquired Computer Decisions magazine, a 20-year-old publication aimed at corporate management information systems managers.

title: New Wind for the Panting Giant; Tasks for America: Compete, Save, Stimulate, Persist
description: Twenty years ago, America's economy was the envy of friends and enemies, an engine of progress leading the world in virtually every branch of technology and generating the world's highest living standard. Today it is a panting giant, increasingly on the defensive in global competition for markets and economic influence.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Ad for Project To Aid the Homeless
description: The throbbing beat of a Brian Eno composition lends insistence to the message of the Manhattan Bowery Project: ''No matter how many times you look away, turn away, walk away, the homeless are still there.''

title: In China, Racism Serves Needs of Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Ingram Begins Bid For Micro D Shares
description: Ingram Industries, a privately held Nashville-based company, began a tender offer for all outstanding shares of Micro D Inc. at $12.50 a share in cash. Ingram, which operates inland marine transportation and distibutes books, videotapes and microcomputer products, already owns about 59 percent of Micro D, a Santa Ana, Calif., distributor of microcomputer software, hardware and accessories.

title: JUDGE WANTS U.S. TO JUSTIFY STAND ON NORTH CHARGES
description: The Federal judge in the Iran-contra inquiry today declined to dismiss two of the main criminal charges against Oliver L. North until the Attorney General certifies that classified evidence in the case cannot be disclosed without damaging the nation's security.

title: Datavision Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest fiscal year included a total of $6 million in non-recurring charges in connection with a restructuring and increases in reserves for potentially uncollectable receivables.

title: Closed Talks Bring GAF Trial to Halt
description: The GAF stock manipulation trial was delayed again yesterday, as lawyers for the Government and the defendants tried in closed meetings at the Federal Court House in lower Manhattan to resolve a mistrial motion filed last week.

title: Donors to the Neediest Cases List AIDS as a Major Concern
description: ''How does one determine who the truly needy are?'' asks Arlene Solomon of Manhattan. She notes that there are so many categories to choose from and mentions these: the homeless, battered women and children, people suffering from AIDS and animals abused in many ways.

title: Total System Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Crownamerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: b-Included after-tax gains of $349,000, or 33 cents a share, from the sale of Crownamerica's U.K. subsidiary and $415,000, or 39 cents a share, in subsequent exchange gains on the proceeds of that sale and other foreign exchange gains. c-Included a net gain of $500,000, or 44 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change; $152,000, or 13 cents a share, in exchange gains from the two overseas operations, and the U.K. subsidiary contributed $183,000, or 16 cents a share, in net income in this first quarter.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adia S.A., Zurich, the world's No. 2 temporary employment agency, expressed interest in buying ''substantial portions'' of Blue Arrow P.L.C., also an employment concern.

title: Court Orders Guardian For Poisoned Jerseyan
description: A New Jersey judge yesterday ordered that a legal guardian be appointed for a Haddonfield teen-ager who has been comatose since eating yogurt tainted with cyanide last week.

title: Patterns
description: Cold Comfort for Furs

title: Oliver North's Rights
description: Oliver North will probably not be tried on the most serious offenses alleged against him, and that's too bad. Substantial charges remain, however, and it's reassuring that he benefits from constitutional and legal ''technicalities'' of the kind he tried to subordinate to ''patriotism'' during his Congressional testimony in 1987.

title: Mourning Fails to Slow Japan's Economy
description: No sooner did Emperor Hirohito fall gravely ill than Japan starting projecting the economic cost of an imperial mourning and succession period. Economists calculated that the country's ever expanding gross national product would be noticeably hurt by days of lost work, as the world's second-largest economy officially closed down.

title: Lebanese Flee a Battle of Shiite Rivals
description: Thousands of villagers fled their homes today as fierce fighting between rival Shiite Muslim militiamen continued in a district in southern Lebanon.

title: Some Daughters of Modern Dance Prepare Series
description: Modern dance was formed by women like Loie Fuller, Isadora Duncan and Martha Graham, and although there has been more balance lately between the sexes, it remains a bastion of strong, inventive female choreographers.

title: Write-Off Is Set by Corning
description: Corning Glass Works announced yesterday that it would take a one-time after-tax charge of about $84 million to its 1988 earnings for its estimated liability on future medical benefits for its current retirees.

title: Woman, 59, Is Found Slain In Upper Manhattan Home
description: A 59-year-old resident of a high-rise apartment building in upper Manhattan, who had not been seen for a week, was found slain in her home yesterday, the police said.

title: Sudan Rebels Say They Are Victims of Poison Gas
description: A spokesman for the Sudanese rebels said today that Libyan forces supporting the Khartoum Government had used chemical weapons against them in the Sudan in the last six months. American officials said they had been investigating the charges.

title: Reagan's Final Budget Leaves Bush Tough Decisions - and Some Favors
description: President Reagan has left his protege George Bush with a budget that could make it hard to start a new Presidency but one that also does him a few favors.

title: Setback for Fed Jurisdiction
description: The Federal Reserve Board suffered a setback Friday in its attempt to extend its regulatory reach over banking subsidiaries and state-chartered banks seeking to expand into such areas as insurance and real estate investing.

title: Pernod Is Allowed To Sell Coca-Cola
description: A Paris court has ruled that Pernod-Ricard S.A. would temporarily be allowed to continue to produce and sell canned drinks of the Coca-Cola Company in France, Pernod said. An appeals court said on Friday that Pernod could continue its activities in canned Coca-Cola products pending a final decision in the case, Pernod said.

title: U.S. Says an Iraqi Had Role in Libyan Plant
description: Administration officials said today that an Iraqi civil engineer who operates several companies in Switzerland and elsewhere in Europe played a central role in the construction of the Libyan chemical plant.

title: Critics Award Goes to Book On Dr. King
description: ''Parting the Waters'' (Simon & Schuster), Taylor Branch's detailed account of the rise of the American civil-rights movement, yesterday won the National Book Critics Circle award for general nonfiction.

title: Healthvest reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Montclair Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Prior-year share earnings are not available because the bank was not a capital stock savings bank throughout the period. The bank said the 1988 quarterly and annual earnings are after $109,000 and $358,000 charges, respectively, for the costs associated with the proposed First Fidelity Bancorp affiliation, which was terminated on Dec. 30, 1988.

title: The Conquest of Terrorism
description: One day perhaps the West will summon the moral and political courage to face the truth about terrorism. On that day, the conquest of terrorism will begin - but not until that day.

title: Where Big Macs Grow
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacific Resources Head Calls Deal 'Imaginative'
description: For Robert G. Reed 3d, the chairman, president and chief executive of Pacific Resources Inc., the proposed acquisition of his Hawaii-based company by a large Australian crude producer is a ''win-win deal for everybody.''

title: Cranston Williams, 93; Led Publishers Group
description: Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association for 21 years before his retirement in 1960, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Lynchburg, Va. He was 93 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Firstbank of Illinois Co., Springfield, named as chief financial officer Chris R. Zettek. He replaces Mark H. Ferguson, who was elected president and chief operating officer last year.

title: Equity Bank reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $142,000 from a tax loss carryforward. Comparable year-ago figures are not available because the bank began operating in August 1987. The bank said in the four-month period ended Dec. 31, 1987, it reported a loss of $335,000.

title: Careers; A Good Year Is Seen for Managers
description: MANAGEMENT recruiting and outplacement firms count on another good year for hiring, and cite new trends to reinforce that view.

title: Biotechnology Collaboration
description: California Biotechnology Inc. and Genentech Inc. said today that they had agreed to collaborate on developing therapeutic uses of human lung surfactant. Surfactant, a mixture of proteins and fats produced in late pregnancy, enables an infant's lungs to remain expanded after exhaling.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Saceanu Upsets Chesnokov: Christian Saceanu of West Germany upset second-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in the $350,000 New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia. Olivier Delaitre, a French-born resident of Belgium, surprised Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-2, 6-4. In the women's draw, 10th-seeded Nicole Provis of Australia downed Hester Witvoet of the Netherlands, 6-3, 7-6.(AP) N.B.A. SuperSonics 105, Cavaliers 103: Derrick McKey's rebound and dunk with five seconds left last night snapped Cleveland's 11-game winning streak. Seattle, which has won five straight games and 11 in a row at home, scored the final 6 points. Dale Ellis scored on a dunk with 48 seconds left, and McKey tied the game with two free throws at the 28-second mark. Cleveland ran the clock down to nine seconds and took a timeout, but on the inbounds pass, John Williams threw the ball out of bounds. Sedale Threatt took a 20-foot jump shot with eight seconds remaining and McKey, who scored a career-high 32 points, was there for the rebound. The Cavaliers' injured point guard, Mark Price, did not play. (AP) Celtics 119, Clippers 84: Jim Paxson sparked a 34-8 surge in the last part of the first half as Boston broke open a close game. The Clippers closed a 28-22 deficit after one quarter to 33-32 on Benoit Benjamin's dunk with 7:49 left in the second. But Ron Grandison's layup with 7:29 to go began the run that gave Boston a 67-40 halftime lead. The Celtics were led by Robert Parish with 25 points.(AP) 76ers 121, Mavericks 103: Ron Ander-son scored 8 of his 23 points during a 26-10 second-quarter run that broke up a tight game in Dallas. The game was tied at 31-31 with 10:10 left in the first half when the 76ers exploded, building a 57-41 lead with 3:06 remaining in the period on Hersey Hawkins' 3-pointer.(AP) HOCKEY Red Wings 3, Canadiens 2: Dave Barr's goal early in the third period last night snapped a 2-2 tie and the Red Wings, playing at home, ended Montreal's nine-game winning streak.(AP) Maple Leafs 3, Canucks 0: Ed Olczyk's 23d and 24th goals of the season and the goaltending of Allan Bester sparked Toronto to the victory at home.(AP) Sabres 6, Central Red Army 5: Ken Preistlay scored at 2:20 of overtime to give Buffalo the victory at home. The Red Army finished its seven-game N.H.L. tour with a 4-2-1 record.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Women South Carolina 85, S. Mississippi 80: Schonna Banner scored 28 points and Lisa Diaz triggered a 9-4 run in the final 3:23 to lead No. 17 South Carolina in the Metro Conference game. The Gamecocks are 9-0 over all and and 2-0 in the conference. Southern Mississippi is 6-2 and 0-2.(AP)

title: Robeson Industries Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on the sale of its Mineola, N.Y., building of $1,050,596. c-Net loss Sales represent net sales.

title: BARRY THREATENED WITH RECALL DRIVE
description: Mitch Snyder, the leader of the drive to get shelter and care for the homeless in Washington, warned Mayor Marion S.Barry Jr. today that he might face a citizens' effort to remove him from office if the quality of government in the city did not improve.

title: Price Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 18
Arias Postpones Latin Summit
description: Costa Rica today announced the indefinite postponement of a Central American summit meeting that was scheduled for Jan. 15 and 16.

title: Temco Service Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Bush Will Swear On the 1789 Bible
description: Mr. Bush will take the oath Jan. 20 on the Bible used by George Washington in 1789. The Bible, from the St. John's Masonic Lodge in New York, is the King James Version printed in 1767 in London. After Washington was sworn by Robert Livingston, chancellor of New York State, the Bible was given to St. John's Masonic Lodge.

title: Belfast Daily To Be Sold
description: The News Letter, the Belfast daily that says it is the world's oldest surviving English-language newspaper, is to be sold, it was announced today.

title: Koch Affirmative-Action Program Used for Patronage, Panel Is Told
description: A job-referral program set up in City Hall for affirmative action was used instead to dispense patronage on behalf of top political leaders throughout New York City, current and former Koch administration officials told an investigating state panel yesterday.

title: The New Couple On the Block
description: Would you like to buy Dan and Marilyn Quayle a showerhead? A washer-dryer set? Spring for some historic molding for the family room? The Quayles are accepting contributions from friends to raise up to $150,000 for renovations to their new official residence.

title: Plane-Device Merger Set
description: Two Massachusetts companies that are the leading rivals in the fledgling business of providing airplane security devices announced Friday that they were merging.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Act III Publishing has acquired the assets of Mix Publications, which includes Mix, the recording industry magazine; Electronic Musician magazine; Mix Bookshelf, a catalogue of technical resources for musicians, and the annual Mix Technical Excellence and Creativity Awards program.

title: United Stationers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Defenseman Snaps Late Tie as Devils Win Third in a Row
description: Joe Cirella banged in the rebound and the Garden groaned last night. For the Rangers, the sound was as foreign as it was audible. They had manufactured a lot in the third period this season - thrills, comebacks, defensive stands - and the Garden had been their most rewarding workplace.

title: War and Finger-Pointing; Odds of Progress at Poison Gas Conference Are Dimmed Amid a Welter of Accusations
description: A conference of 145 nations summoned to galvanize world opinion against chemical weapons has partly proved to be an exercise in moral ambiguity, since none of its key participants can claim spotless records. Fingers of accusation wag in many directions.

title: Helene Curtis Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-ago figures are restated.

title: Discovery of Rare Stars
description: The world's most powerful radiotelescope has pierced dense clouds of cosmic dust and gas to reveal scores of very young stars in much greater profusion than ever found before, astronomers at the University of Wisconsin have reported.

title: On Campus in Japan, Taking Stock
description: Amid the familiar, the reassuring and the everyday, the students who will help shape the era of a new Emperor pondered today whether it will really mean a new Japan.

title: Sausalito Journal; Cholesterol Battle Is a Cause Many Take to Heart
description: At a sunny Sunday brunch on the terrace of the Alta Mira Hotel here, W. Patrick Holt dug into what could be called the restaurant's Cholesterol Special: steak, fried eggs and french fries.

title: Joy Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: The latest periods included non- recurring gains of $3.6 million for the quarter and $5.8 million for the 9 months. The prior year's results included $7.4 million of income generated by businesses held for sale that was not matched in the current year.

title: Libya Says It Can Make Chemical Arms if Others Do
description: Libya today implicitly asserted its right to make chemical weapons as long as other nations have similar devices.

title: Holly's Board Sets Auction
description: Instead of appealing a Delaware Chancery Court ruling on its efforts to avoid being acquired by Tyson Foods Inc., the board of the Holly Farms Corporation will put the chicken-producing company up for auction for the shareholders' benefit.

title: Templeton Foreign Fund reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets. During the 12 months, dividends of 62 cents and capital gains of $1.16 were paid out.

title: 18 Start in 'Workfare' in Westchester
description: Fifteen men and three women began working today for their welfare benefits, as Westchester County initiated a ''workfare'' program that officials said could save taxpayers $2 million a year in relief costs in this city alone.

title: Softer Tone at U.N. on Libya Incident
description: A softening of a proposed resolution on the downing of two Libyan jets by United States planes over the Mediterranean last week was reported by diplomats today as the Security Council ended its third day of debate on the incident.

title: Two Reagan Mortgages on the Future
description: President Reagan's final budget completes a transforming chapter in American fiscal history. With eight years of deficits that will have tripled the national debt, this President, who wants a constitutional amendment to forbid all deficits, has made huge deficits acceptable. Thanks to him, balancing the books in future years will be harder than ever.

title: Suburban Homelessness Is a Problem With an Illegal Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Budget Would Allocate Funds for Big Domestic Programs
description: President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1 advocates ending 82 Government programs, cutting spending on farm programs by nearly 19 percent and trimming the growth in Medicare and Medicaid by about $5 billion.

title: Amid the Rustle of Finery, Fashion Celebrates Its Own
description: American fashion was seeing red last night, but nobody was the least bit upset. The annual gala awards dinner of the Council of Fashion Designers of America at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was more than a glittering occasion for the industry to celebrate its own. It was also a last hurrah for Nancy Reagan, who appeared in a red satin dress by Oscar de la Renta to receive the council's lifetime achievement award.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wells, Rich, Greene Adds Outsider on I.B.M.
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has brought in an outsider to help it run the International Business Machines account, which the agency won last summer. David Sklaver, who managed several food accounts along with the account of NEC, an I.B.M. competitor, at DDB Needham, is joining W.R.G. as an executive vice president and group head for the technology company's account.

title: Washington Talk: State Department; For Diplomats, Time To Read the Tea Leaves
description: When James A. Baker 3d and a coterie of aides began turning up in the State Department cafeteria line a few weeks ago, they sparked intense speculation within a bureaucracy trained to read intentions into seemingly minuscule nuances of behavior.

title: Canonie Environmental Servces reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chiat/Day In Accord To Buy Mojo
description: CHIAT/DAY, the Los Angeles-based agency whose West Coast unconventionality helped Apple Computer take on I.B.M. and Nynex sell Yellow Pages, announced late yesterday that it had entered into an agreement in principle to purchase Mojo MDA Group Ltd., the Australian ad agency that made ''G'day, mate'' part of the American vernacular.

title: Review/Television; Robert Moses' Vision: Boon and Bane
description: To his admirers, he was the greatest builder of all time, who transformed New York from a 19th- to a 20th-century city and paved the way for urban developers throughout America. To his critics, he was a prodigious destroyer of neighborhoods, who cared less for flesh and blood than for steel and concrete. All could agree that Robert Moses, the subject of tonight's episode of ''The American Experience,'' was a bulldozer of a man, who left behind a contentious legacy of accomplishment and bitterness. The profile can be seen at 10 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channels 21 and 49.

title: Kenneth McMillan, 56, Actor In Numerous Stage and Film Roles
description: Kenneth McMillan, the prolific charactor actor with a burly policeman's demeanor who won critical praise for his often lovable performances, died of liver disease Sunday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 56 years old and lived in Studio City, Calif.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Rule on 'Dial-a-Porn' Law
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a new Federal law banning sexually explicit telephone message services violates the First Amendment right to freedom of speech.

title: John William Bainton, Executive, 63
description: John William Bainton, an engineering executive, died of melanoma Thursday at Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 63 years old and had homes in Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, and in Amagansett, L.I.

title: Dollar Rises Against Mark But Loses Ground to the Yen
description: The dollar rose sharply against the West German mark yesterday and then retreated somewhat in the face of modest dollar sales by the Federal Reserve and several European central banks and comments from the president of the Bundesbank.

title: Military Request Includes Tempting Targets
description: The $315.2 billion President Reagan requested today for the military, already singled out by budget cutters, includes several tempting targets, especially the program to develop an antimissile defense system.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Alvin H. Schechter has been named chairman and chief executive and Jonathan J. Prinz has been named president of Schechter Design Group, a recently acquired subsidiary of the Omnicom Group.

title: Bridge
description: A useful book for the experienced player is one that tests him with miscellaneous play and defense problems. This genre, common in England, is rather rare on this side of the Atlantic. Helping to fill the gap is ''Spingold Challenge,'' in which the reader, by a set of curious chances, finds himself in the final of a national knockout team championship and plays 64 difficult deals. The author is Allan Falk, the Commissioner of the Court of Appeals in Lansing, Mich. His book is available for $11.95, including postage, from Granovetter Books, 18 Village View Bluff, Ballston Lake, N.Y. 12019.

title: Templeton Income Fund reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: During the 12 months, dividends totaled about 72 cents and capital gains of 12 cents were paid out. Assets represent net assets.

title: Dr. Milton J. Brothers, Diabetes Specialist, 62
description: Dr. Milton J. Brothers, an internist who specialized in the treatment of diabetes, died of bladder cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 62 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Research Stirs Conflict By Suggesting Heredity Plays a Role in Inhibition
description: A RADICAL new theory from respected researchers about Tourette syndrome and its genetic nature has aroused an extraordinary amount of emotion in the normally staid field of medical genetics. The theory has been condemned by some geneticists, while others say they want to keep an open mind on an intriquing proposition.

title: Master Plan Seeks $15 Billion for Schools
description: New York City school officials yesterday urged Mayor Edward I. Koch to provide $15 billion to rebuild and modernize New York's dilapidated school system by the end of the century.

title: Performance of Mass Is Act of Affirmation For Soviet Composer
description: The surprise in Moscow today is to find over and over that almost nothing is impossible anymore. And so as 1988 ended, there was the composer Rodion K. Shchedrin sitting nervously in the sixth row of the Moscow Conservatory, for the premiere of his latest work, a Slavonic Mass called ''The Sealed Angel'' after a 19th-century Russian parable by the writer Nikolai Leskov.

title: Bonds Track Dollar's Vicissitudes
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in moderately active trading yesterday, as dealers spent the session reacting to the dollar's twists and turns on the foreign exchange markets.

title: Our Towns; Open Any Door: You Can't Tell An Owner Is Poor
description: If you really, really try hard, you might be able to tell which are the subsidized low- and moderate-income condominiums at the new Society Hill complex here, and which are the $140,000 market-priced units. ''Sometimes I can tell which people - I think I can,'' said Petra Catogge, who lives in a subsidized unit. ''Not by looks, not by clothes, just sort of woman's intuition.''

title: Compromise On Allegheny Is Expected
description: The two rival suitors for Allegheny International Inc. have worked out a compromise that would allow them to carve up the bankrupt consumer products company, people familiar with both sides said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Yellow Spots Gets Job For Southwestern Bell
description: Yellow Spots Inc., the company that sees value in unused space in the nation's Yellow Pages directories, has become the exclusive marketer of filler space for Southwestern Bell Media's blond books.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Move Over Madison
description: Many are the perks that come with the Presidency. To wit, George Bush, as a former member of the House Ways and Means Committee, now gets to have his picture hung in the committee's gallery of former members who went on to win the White House.

title: New Swap Plan By Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced the introduction of a weighted-average-coupon adjustable-rate mortgage guarantor program. Under the program, Freddie Mac will swap its weighted-average-coupon adjustable-rate mortgage participation certificates for a like amount of adjustable-rate mortgages issued by lenders. The certificates represent an interest in those same mortgages.

title: Lifecore Biomedical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Business and Health; The Effort to Curb Caesarean Rate
description: EMPLOYERS and insurers have been fighting an uphill battle to get expectant mothers and their doctors to think twice before a baby is delivered by Caesarean section.

title: Epsilon Data Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Keeper Of the Tennis Court
description: Marvin Bush has bagged one of the most powerful jobs in the new administration. He'll be keeper of the White House tennis court.

title: Hi-Shear Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said the second quarter and 6 months earnings declines were attributable primarily to pre-tax operating losses of $1,775,000 and $2,475,000, respectively, from the company's space and defense systems operation and lower revenue and earnings at its aerospace fastening systems operations.

title: N.C. State Encourages Investigation by N.C.A.A.
description: Bruce R. Poulton, the chancellor of North Carolina State University, and Jim Valvano, the school's basketball coach and athletic director, today sent a letter to Richard R. Schultz, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, in which they invited an investigation into the university's basketball program.

title: Marines Are Faulted in Death
description: The Marine Commandant, Gen. Alfred M. Gray, today accepted a report concluding that there was a ''total breakdown'' in accountability procedures in a unit that left an enlisted man to die in the California desert during a training exercise in August.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 China was urged to end state ownership of industry in a bold proposal for change made by three influential Chinese economists with close ties to the Government. Page A1

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Central Federal Savings, Mineola, L.I., to Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK, with a $2 million budget.

title: Blasius Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $175,000 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter and a tax credit of $150,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after gains from repurchase of notes of $257,000 and $344,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said net earnings for the latest 6-month period included net gains from sales of marketable securities of $3,991,000 and writedowns of marketable securities of $428,000. On Nov. 29, 1988, Blasius stockholders approved the changing of the company's name from Blasius Industries to Lexington Precision Corporation. The company anticipates that the name change will be effective on or before Jan. 31, 1989, and will be listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: A Consortium Will Acquire Cooke's Cable TV Systems
description: A consortium of cable operators said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the cable systems owned by Jack Kent Cooke, which have a total of 700,000 subscribers. No price was disclosed.

title: Banponce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stake in Unit Is Acquired By Memorex
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had signed an agreement with Memorex Telex N.V. to form a joint venture in which each company would own half of National Advanced Systems, formerly National's wholly owned subsidiary, which distributes mainframe computers and peripheral equipment manufactured by Hitachi Ltd. in Japan.

title: Reagan Is Doing 'Quite Well' After Surgery on Left Hand
description: President Reagan is ''recovering quite well'' from surgery to correct a curvature of the fourth finger of the left hand, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today.

title: Hear the Voice of the Endangered Farmers; Environmental Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Templeton Global Fund reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets. During the 12 months, dividends of 77 cents and capital gains of $3.52 were paid out. On Dec. 7, 1988, Templeton Global I split 5-for-1. On Dec. 16, 1988, Templeton Global II shares were exchanged for shares of Templeton Global I, creating the Templeton Global Fund. During the 12 months, Templeton Global II paid dividends of about 27 cents and capital gains of about 38 cents a share.

title: Noxell Replaces Rabbits In Tests of Cosmetics
description: THE Noxell Corporation, maker of Noxzema skin creams and Cover Girl cosmetics, has decided to screen new cosmetics and skin care products for safety by applying them to tissue cultures in laboratory dishes instead of injecting them into the eyes of rabbits.

title: Sallie Mae Prices $450 Million Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday priced a $450 million issue of floating-rate notes due on July 13, 1989, through a group of various securities dealers. Sallie Mae is a federally chartered stockholder-owned corporation that has financed about 4 in 10 of all guaranteed student loans outstanding today, Offered at a price of par, the notes are yielding a variable rate equal to 55-hundredths of a percentage point more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill auction rate. Interest on the floating-rate notes, payable at maturity, will be adjusted the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction.

title: Quake Felt in Las Vegas
description: A mild earthquake was felt in the Las Vegas area Sunday night, but the authorities received no reports of serious damage or injury. The tremor, centered 10 miles northeast of Las Vegas, came at 9:08 P.M. and measured 3.2 to 3.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion and energy released, according to the United States Geological Survey. Earlier Sunday, two earthquakes were reported southeast of Adak in the Aleutian Islands and registered 5.6 and 4.8 on the Richter scale. Neither was felt at Adak, the nearest populated area.

title: Article 168089 -- No Title
description: A 37-year-old Nigerian-born graduate student who has not seen his wife since 1980 - and who has never seen his 7-year-old daughter - was the sole winner of last week's $26 million Lotto drawing, state lottery officials announced yesterday.

title: Savings Industry's Costly Fraud
description: Federal regulators examining documentation for thousands of multimillion-dollar loans now in default at insolvent savings institutions are finding that fraud was more widespread than had been thought.

title: Unihorn China Venture
description: Chinese software developers will write programs for overseas customers in a joint venture with an American company. Unihorn Inc., a San Francisco-based subsidiary of Unison Inc., has joined with the Chinese Aerospace Ministry and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation, which sells satellite-launching services, in a venture that will develop and package software for international markets.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Devil and Bruin Draw Suspensions
description: Coach Terry O'Reilly of the Boston Bruins was suspended by the National Hockey League for four games and Jim Korn, a Devils' forward, was banned for three games yesterday in connection with their fight Dec. 29 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The league also fined each club $5,000, O'Relly $1,000 and Korn $500 for their fight in the runway under the stands at the end of Boston's 6-2 victory. The fight erupted when O'Reilly made a remark to Korn, who pushed O'Reilly against the wall. The coach of the Bruins then punched Korn.

title: Harold H. Goldberg Jr., Realtor, 62
description: Harold H. Goldberg Jr., a realtor who headed the American Jewish Committee in New Jersey, died yesterday at his home in Short Hills, N.J., after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Interco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $10,203,000 for the quarter and $22,034,000 for the 9 months. c-After income of $1,603,000 for the quarter and $10,115,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The company's net from continuing operations in the latest third quarter included pre-tax charges of $35.8 million, which included interest charges of $21.8 million, primarily related to the accrual of interest on subordinated debentures, and restructuring costs and expenses.

title: Correction
description: The Music View column in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday gave an incorrect date for a piano recital by Dmitry Rachmanov at Merkin Concert Hall in New York. It is tonight at 8, not tomorrow.

title: Curfew Back At the Parks In New York
description: New York City reimposed the late-night curfew at virtually all of its parks and playgrounds yesterday and planned to provide vans to take the homeless people now sleeping in them to shelters.

title: The Facts on the Fax
description: TODAY is National Fax Day.

title: Where's the 'Beef'? Here
description: LEAD: On a cold January day, with ice on the windows and the wind working up a rage, nothing raises the spirits and whets the appetite like visions of a bread-dunking, savory, steaming stew - the French navarin of lamb: generous cubes cut from the leg, braised in a delicious elixir of a touch of sherry, garlic, tomato, white wine and beef broth, with aromatic tiny onions, baby carrots and lima beans, the lamb so juicy and tender it can almost be cut with a sharp glance.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Appeals on Bases
description: Many Congressional protests against plans to close military bases so far seem to have been perfunctory objections lodged for the sake of appearances before constituents.

title: Scientists Link Some Breast Cancer to Loss of Protective Gene
description: NEW evidence linking some breast cancers to loss of a protective ''anti-oncogene'' has strengthened the theory that loss of such genes is a major factor in the complex process by which many human cancers arise.

title: United Insurance Co of Amerca reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net gains on sales of investments of $3.4 million and $50.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net gains on sales of investments of $48.5 million and $67.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago fourth quarter and full- year results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for certain life insurance products. The company said the accounting change decreased its 1988 net income by $2.6 million, which included a cumulative effect for prior years of $1.9 million. The company is based in Chicago and is an affiliate of Teledyne Inc.

title: Rescue Promissory Notes Under Fire
description: With savings and loan rescues coming under greater Congressional scrutiny, the $18 billion of promissory notes issued by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to help sell off insolvent institutions have become a pawn in a fierce political debate.

title: Cuomo Explores Borrowing to Close New York Budget Gap
description: Governor Mario M. Cuomo said today that the state would probably have to borrow ''somewhere in the range of a couple of hundred million dollars'' to close its budget gap for the current fiscal year.

title: Gresham Isn't Father Of Gresham's Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Rig Count Falls Again
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs fell by 36, to 872, last week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. It was the second consecutive decline. The count dropped by 32 the week before. A year ago, the number of working rigs totaled 1,102. The count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; On Their Own
description: The entire White House staff was asked by President Reagan in November to submit resignations effective ''at the pleasure of the President.'' So some staff members have set out on their own rather than hold out hope for a post in the Bush administration.

title: Bizarre Explosions
description: A team of American astronomers believes it has found evidence of a bizarre double supernova explosion -the explosion of a very massive star inside the blast debris of an earlier and similar explosion.

title: Correction
description: A report yesterday about the marriage of Leslie Lowenbraun and Jeffrey H. Weitzman misstated the bridegroom's occupation. He is a partner, not an associate, in the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells.

title: G.E. of Britain Vows to Fight Possible Offer of $12 Billion
description: Britain's largest manufacturing concern, the General Electric Company, vowed today to fight a takeover bid estimated at $12 billion that an international consortium is apparently trying to put together.

title: Chess
description: For the first time since the beginning of women's international team play in 1957, the Soviet squad had to yield the championship to Hungary in the 1988 Olympiad, which ended Nov. 27 in Thessaloniki, Greece. The sensational Hungarian women racked up a score of 33-9 to capture the gold medal.

title: OPEC Sets Strategy Talks With Other Oil Producers
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other oil-producing nations will meet on Jan. 26 in London to discuss ways to cooperate in an attempt to stabilize the world oil market, the Secretary General of OPEC said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Not even the Israelis have massacred so many Shiites.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Friday about Dr. Robert S. Coles, a New York City ophthalmologist, included erroneous dates given by Lenox Hill Hospital for some events in his career. He retired in January 1988 as director of ophthalmology at the hospital and was a member of its medical staff until his death last Wednesday.

title: Gulfstream Remembers Rocky Start
description: Fifty winters ago, Sonja Henie, the Olympic skating champion, cut a ceremonial green-and-white ribbon and racing began at Gulfstream Park.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Busy Week For Ellis Verdi
description: It is a busy week for Ellis Verdi & Partners.

title: HOCKEY: Law and Order Bring Success; Police Training Comes In Handy for Canadiens Coach
description: In the curious nomenclature of professional hockey, the ''policeman'' is often the player who breaks the rules, the toughest guy on the roster, the one who protects weaker teammates and keeps foes in line with a timely stick poked in the ribs or a meaningful glove shoved in the face.

title: Market Place; Money Managers Beat Market in '88
description: Institutional money management firms did something unusual last year: as a group, they outperformed the stock market, a feat they have accomplished only twice in the last six years. The value of the average money manager's stock portfolio climbed 17.8 percent in 1988, according to C.D.A. Investment Technologies. For the same period, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 16.4 percent.

title: Unisys Plans Job Cuts
description: The Unisys Corporation said Friday that it would cut 450 jobs from its Computer Systems division in St. Paul and Eagan, Minn., through layoffs and attrition. The information services company, which is based in Blue Bell, Pa., said about half of the jobs affected are salaried. Unisys employs 10,800 people in Minnesota.

title: 28 More Bushes For White House
description: Besides the 100 or so members of the sprawling Bush clan taking over the Jefferson Hotel near the White House for the inaugural festivities, 28 Bushes will be camping out at the White House. ''We have family members coming we didn't even know we had,'' joked Mr. Bush's brother Jonathan. ''We're talking about cousins of a grandfather's second wife and that sort of thing. We're reaching way out there.

title: Export Scheme Charges
description: The president of a Belgian company and three Dutch businessmen were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges that they tried to ship high-technology equipment to Eastern bloc countries. Marcel Sanders, the president of the the Belgium Trading Company was arrested on Dec. 22 after trying to complete arrangements for an illegal shipment of American-made equipment to Bulgaria, the Government said. Franciscus Govaerts, of the Netherlands, was arrested in Boston two weeks earlier when he completed similar plans, the Government said. Also indicted in the purported scheme were Roger Von Alpen and Goris Christian Grandia, both of Amsterdam.

title: In Accessories, the Mood Is Softer
description: When fashion follows a classic route, as it is doing for this spring, the extras make a difference. Accessories can set a woman apart from the crowd and establish her personal style. She can be as classic as a triple strand of pearls or as exotic as an armload of jangling charm bracelets.

title: More Black Rhinos Found in Kenya
description: Kenya's population of black rhinoceroses, prized by poachers for their unusual horns, is on the increase, the minister of tourism and wildlife said in an interview published in the Sunday Nation, a newspaper.

title: In Beijing, a Bold New Proposal: End State Ownership of Industry
description: In a bold proposal for change, three influential Chinese economists with close ties to the Government have called for China to abandon state ownership of industry.

title: Nelson Is Said to Have a Recurrence of Cancer
description: Karl Nelson, who missed the Giants' 1987 season because of Hodgkin's disease but played this season, has a recurrence of the cancer, sources close to the team said yesterday.

title: Review/Television; A Lesson for Young Viewers
description: ''Hope it wakes up a few of the dead brain cells in this town,'' says the high school student as he and a friend prepare to distribute, surreptitiously, their underground paper called Hatchet Job. Most of the brain cells do respond, with fury. Before the incident is over, the young journalists are involved in a court case, represented by an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer. Such is the promising plot of today's ''Schoolbreak Special'' on CBS at 4 P.M. ''Words to Live By'' was written by Rick Doehring and directed by Bradley D. Wigor. It is still another ''based on a true story'' television drama.

title: Default Case Jury Let Go
description: The 17-member jury for the huge securities fraud trial involving the Washington Public Power Supply System's $2.25 billion bond default was formally dismissed today.

title: Certron Corp reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $11,000 for the latest year and $120,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said at Oct. 31, 1988, it had sufficient tax loss and investment tax credit carryforward to eliminate $50,000 of federal taxes. Due to a corporate equity adjustment during 1982, $39,000 of this benefit has been credited to additional paid-in capital and $11,000 as an extraordinary item. The company also said at Oct. 31, 1987, it had sufficient tax loss carryforward to eliminate federal taxes. Due to the corporate equity adjustment, $126,000 of this benefit has been credited to additional paid-in capital and $120,000 as an extraordinary item.

title: Dukakis to Sit Out The Inaugural Ball
description: Michael Dukakis will not be dancing at George Bush's Inaugural Ball. Massachusetts's state office has sent the Democratic Governor's tickets back to the Presidential Inaugural Committee. ''He's got other things in the works up here,'' said James R. Dorsey, a Dukakis spokesman in Boston.

title: Institute Plans to Revive 100-Inch Telescope
description: THE historic 100-inch telescope on Mount Wilson, Calif., which closed down in 1985 despite its standing as one of the largest astronomical instruments in the world, appears to have gained a new lease on life.

title: Reagan, North and the Truth
description: LEAD: The idea that a dismissal of conspiracy and theft charges against Oliver L. North would mean that President Reagan's true role in the Iran-contra affair will never be disclosed is naive and represents an exaggerated notion of what new facts a trial could produce.

title: Marchi, After 16 Years, Loses Post On Finance Panel in Senate Shifts
description: New York City lost a key ally on the Senate Finance Committee today and Long Island legislators gained new leverage in the first major realignment of the State Senate leadership since 1973.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Soviets Open Pre-1917 Files
description: The Central State Archive has opened 500,000 secret files on such subjects as the Russian Orthodox Church and the White Guards' opposition to the Bolshevik Revolution, the press agency Tass reported today. Records on organizations liquidated during the 1920's and 30s, at the height of the Stalinist repression, are being declassified, it said. Specialists may now view documents of the czarist secret police, jails and courts, Tass said.

title: Steinbrenner Files a Suit On Winfield Foundation
description: George Steinbrenner, sued last week by Dave Winfield for his failure to make some $450,000 in payments to the Yankee outfielder's charitable foundation, filed his own lawsuit yesterday in an attempt to remove Winfield as head of the New Jersey-based organization.

title: U.S. Pilots Got Caution Warning
description: The Navy pilots who downed two Libyan fighters last week received orders moments beforehand to act with caution and fire only in self-defense, the Pentagon said today. The pilots had not received orders to fire at will. A Pentagon spokesman, Daniel Howard, said the cautionary advice means that ''weapons are to be fired in self defense. That is precisely what the gentleman did.''

title: REAGAN EMBRACES OPTIMISTIC GOALS IN HIS LAST BUDGET
description: Eleven days before he is scheduled to leave office, President Reagan today proposed a $1.15 trillion budget for the fiscal year 1990 that he said would meet the deficit ceiling of Congress's budget-balancing law, significantly increase spending on the military and some other programs and avoid new taxes.

title: Pioneering Studies Find Surprisingly High Rate Of Mental Ills in Young
description: AS many as one in five children suffer from psychiatric problems serious enough to impair their lives in some way, according to the surprising findings of several new surveys of the mental health of children.

title: Spitak Journal; Towns Can Be Rebuilt; How About Broken Lives?
description: In the towns that suffered the worst damage in the Armenian earthquake last month, survivors are turning their thoughts toward an uncertain future.

title: Ruling on N.F.L.
description: A Federal judge yesterday denied a request by National Football League owners for permission to continue to hold the college draft through 1992, but declined to rule on its legality. District Judge David Doty said that until the N.F.L. Management Council, which represents the owners, and the N.F.L. Players Association reach a bargaining impasse on the issue, the owners ''are exempt from antitrust provisions up until the expiration of the agreement.'' Doty ruled last June that there was an impasse in free-agency bargaining. There has not been a request from the union to find an impasse in bargaining over the college draft. The last collective bargaining agreement expired in 1987, and the players union said it may seek an injunction to prevent the 1989 draft.(AP)

title: Ojeda's Recovery
description: Bob Ojeda, who nearly severed the tip off a finger of his pitching hand with an electric hedge clipper in an accident on Sept. 21, says he is recovering nicely from the career-threatening injury. The Mets' left-hander, who has begun pitching from the mound at a high school field in his hometown of Visalia, Calif., reported he was not hampered even though he has lost feeling in the tip of the middle finger on his left hand. ''There really is, legitimately, no difference in the way I'm throwing now and the way I used to throw,'' he said. ''I feel great.''(AP)

title: Cox to buy Texas Papers
description: The Herald Publishing Company, corporate owner of The Daily Sentinel and The Sunday Sentinel, announced last week that it had agreed to sell the Nacogdoches newspapers to Cox Enterprises Inc. No price was disclosed. Cox publishes 17 daily newspapers, including 6 in Texas. The transaction includes not only the Sentinels but also Ad Extra and The Garrison News.

title: Park Electrochemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Revived Air Express Picks Chief Executive
description: The Air Express International Corporation, an air-freight company that has been turned around in the last three years, yesterday announced the appointment of a new chief executive, Guenter Rohrmann.

title: Israelis Wound 23, Arabs Say
description: Israeli troops shot and wounded 23 Palestinians during clashes today, Arab reports said, as a general strike closed down the occupied territories.

title: Robert Pomeroy, 86, An Ex-Legislator, Dies
description: Robert Watson Pomeroy, a former New York State legislator, died of heart failure on Jan. 4 at his home in Millbrook, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: Templeton Growth Fund reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: During the 12 months, dividends of 73 cents and capital gains of 48 cents were paid out. Assets represent net assets.

title: Jungle Fever Is Contagious In Cincinnati
description: It is the kind of greeting that makes you consider reaching for your blunderbuss.

title: Times Co. Agrees to Sell Cable Unit for $420 Million
description: In the largest sale under a Government program of tax breaks that is intended to increase ownership of broadcast properties by members of minority groups, The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its cable television system for $420 million in cash.

title: Decor Corp reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 26
Walgreen Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the latest quarter sales figure no longer reflects food service sales, since it sold its 91 Wag's restaurants to Marriott Corp. in August.

title: Effect of Abortion on Women Is Discounted
description: No conclusive evidence exists on how abortions affect a woman's mental or physical health, C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, told President Reagan in a report today.

title: Richard Barr, 71, Stage Producer And Theater League Head, Dies
description: Richard Barr, the president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, died of liver failure yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Barr, who as a producer brought to the stage the works of Edward Albee, Samuel Beckett and many other playwrights, was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: After the N.F.L. Huddles, Bengals Won't Have To
description: The Cincinnati Bengals can continue doing what they did to get to the Super Bowl.

title: Excerpts From the Final Budget Message by President Reagan to Congress
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's budget message today to Congress: EIGHT YEARS OF ACCOMPLISHMENT Working together, we have accomplished much over the last eight years. The Economy

title: Argonaut Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Aftet a loss of $800,000 for the quarter and a gain of $29 million for the year, both on sales of investments. c-Included gains on sales of investments of $75.9 million and $105.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Dow, Up by 5.17, Reaches a 15-Month High
description: LEAD: The stock market posted its fourth straight gain yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average reached its highest level in 15 months, rising 5.17 points to close at 2,199.46.

title: Constance Chilton, Educator, 85
description: Constance Chilton, a former director of the Elizabeth Morrow School in Englewood, N.J., died after a long illness on Dec. 28 at Englewood Hospital. She was 85 and lived in Englewood.

title: Judge Halts Rule Stranding Aliens in Rio Grande Valley
description: A Federal district judge in Brownsville today issued a temporary restraining order suspending a new immigration policy that has left hundreds of Central American aliens stranded and homeless in the Rio Grande Valley.

title: Yastrzemski and Bench Voted to baseball Hall
description: The two favorites, Johnny Bench and Carl Yastrzemski, were swept into baseball's Hall of Fame last night, both gaining admission in their first year of eligibility and both becoming near-unanimous choices.

title: Hear the Voice of the Endangered Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bug Lover Explores Nature's Subtle Chemistry
description: THOMAS EISNER had barely reached school age when he was smitten by a ''disease'' he calls biophilia - love of living things, especially the more than billion billion creatures with six or eight legs that crawl, swim and flit through nearly every conceivable habitat on earth.

title: Templeton World Fund reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: During the 12 months, dividends of 98 cents and capital gains of 38 cents were paid out. Assets represent net assets.

title: Global Income Plus Fund Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Assets represent total net assets. The company said the for the period from Sept. 1, 1988 (commencement of investment operations) through Oct. 31 (its 1988 fiscal year-end) earnings from net investment income were $2,701,779, or 11 cents a share. Net realized and unrealized gains were $2,897,855, or 12 cents a share. The company also said that at Sept. 2 net assets were equal to $9.27 a share, based on 21,010,753 shares outstanding. A total net asset figure at Sept. 2 was not immediately available.

title: Herbert A. Seltzer, Administrator, 82
description: Rabbi Herbert A. Seltzer, a retired administrator of a geriatrics center, died Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: Submarine Contract To General Dynamics
description: The Navy today awarded the General Dynamics Corporation a $726 million contract to build the first Seawolf attack submarine, a new class designed to hunt Soviet missile and attack subs.

title: Hewlett-Packard's New Work Station
description: Broadening its technical computer line at the low end, the Hewlett-Packard Company introduced the HP 9000 Model 340 SRX work station, which it said is the first 3-D graphics work station priced under $15,000. Hewlett-Packard also announced big price cuts on several related products.

title: GTE Reorganizes Into Six Units
description: The GTE Corporation, which operates the largest independent phone network in the United States, reorganized into six operating units and eliminated a layer of management in the process. GTE has been restructuring since March, selling various businesses and announcing big job cuts.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Speechwriting Bork
description: Robert H. Bork Jr., son of the former Federal judge and Supreme Court nominee, has become a speechwriter for Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire.

title: Tutors for Disk Jockeys
description: WHEN you need to learn anything about using computers, no book or series of lectures can substitute for putting your fingers on the keyboard and making things happen on the screen. Here are some software packages to help guide your fingers.

title: Consumer Debt Rose $4.5 Billion in November
description: Americans took out $4.5 billion more in consumer debt in November than they paid off, as consumers increased purchases for the holiday season.

title: Jersey's Annual Report Previews Kean Address
description: At a time when New Jersey faces growing fiscal woes, Gov. Thomas H. Kean released today a summary of his proposed initiatives for 1989, including programs designed to create low- and moderate-income housing, and a bond issue that would preserve open lands in this, the nation's most densely populated state.

title: Bears Only Human In Losing to the 49ers
description: Last week, Mike Singletary, the Bears' wonderful middle linebacker, was asked what his team would have to do to play a perfect game against the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Soviets Designate a U.S. Dealer for Their Artists
description: Thousands of contemporary Soviet artists are to be offered the chance to sell their works at art galleries around the United States as a result of a joint venture agreement signed yesterday between the Soviet Ministry of Culture, the Union of Soviet Artists and a New York art dealer who will act as wholesaler of the works.

title: Free Cello Recital
description: The cellist Sharon Robinson is to give a free recital on Thursday at 8 P.M. at Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, to open the Pro Musicis 20th-anniversary season. The program will be a Marcello Adagio, Beethoven's Sonata in C, Chopin's Polonaise Brillante, Rachmaninoff's Sonata, Opus 19, and Ned Rorem's ''After Reading Shakespeare.'' Information: 355-6105.

title: Pentagon Expected To Bar Some Figures In the Fraud Inquiry
description: Defense Department officials said today that the Pentagon is expected to move on Tuesday against several companies, consultants and Government employees, including a former assistant Navy secretary, implicated in the Federal procurement fraud investigation.

title: William Powers, 81, A Rhode Island Judge
description: William E. Powers, the victim of an accident that left him blind, who become a Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court and the state's Attorney General, died Saturday at the Wayland Health Center in Providence. He was 81 years old.

title: Tyson Seeks Purse
description: In a deposition yesterday, Mike Tyson said he still has not been paid all the $21 million he said was promised to fight Michael Spinks nearly seven months ago.

title: Bush Urges His Aides to Hire Minority Talent
description: President-elect George Bush told his personnel recruiters today that he had gained a firm political mandate in the 1988 election and that his administration must seek to carry out that mandate with groups often ''overlooked'' by Republicans: the disabled, blacks, Asian-Americans and Hispanic people.

title: U.S. Turns to Giant Blimp for Defense of the Nation's Shores
description: A QUARTER century after the United States Navy consigned its last dirigible airship to the scrap heap of antiquated weaponry, a gigantic new blimp is taking shape to defend America against cruise missiles, drug smugglers and a host of other modern threats.

title: Santa Monica Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Measles Kills
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Gets $105 Million I.R.S. Waiver
