description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. was given some crucial financial relief yesterday when the Internal Revenue Service granted a waiver that enables the carrier to postpone paying $105 million into its employee pension fund that was due in September.

title: Teledyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gains of $21.3 million and $121.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively, on the sale of investments, and also includes equity in net income of investees of $10.9 million and $39.6 million for the same periods, respectively. c-Included pretax gains on the sale of investments of $123.4 million and $171.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, on the sale of investments, and also includes equity in net income of investees of $11.1 million and $36.7 million for the same periods, respectively.

title: Vagrant Held In Slaying Of Pathologist
description: A vagrant who had been living secretly on the 22d floor of the Bellevue Hospital Center was arrested and charged yesterday with the murder, rape and robbery of a pregnant doctor who was attacked as she worked alone in her office Saturday afternoon.

title: Guidry's Agent Tells Mets He's Interested
description: Ron Guidry made a bid yesterday to remain in New York. His agent, Reggie Ringuet, called the Mets to find out if they had any interest in him as a relief pitcher. Guidry spoke with Pat Gillick, general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, who apparently do have some interest in him as a reliever. ''Basically, I couldn't give him an answer at this point,'' said Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' vice president for baseball operations. ''The only interest we might have would be as a leadup man in the bullpen. He's a veteran pitcher who certainly knows how to pitch. The problem is would he get enough work to make it worthwhile. It's something we have to think about.'' Gillick did not make Guidry an offer but talked to him about his left shoulder and his thoughts on relieving. ''He really didn't comment one way or another,'' Gillick said. ''I think if he had his druthers, he'd rather be a starting pitcher.'' In having his agent call the Mets, though, Guidry was indicating a willingness to relieve because he knows the Mets don't need a starter. The left-hander, who is a free agent after having pitched for the Yankees for 13 years, likes the idea of staying in New York. No movement is expected in the next week in Guidry's effort to find a job because he and Ringuet are leaving tomorrow for a week of skiing in Colorado.

title: Seitel Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KEY RATES
SAKHAROV TOOK UP ENCLAVE'S STATUS
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, explored the possibility of direct rule from Moscow of an ethnic Armenian region in Azerbaijan when he visited the territory last month, according to an Armenian journalist who accompanied him there.

title: TI Selling Units
description: TI Group P.L.C. said it had agreed to sell three of its United States plastics subsidiaries for $86 million to the Fluorocarbon Company of Laguna Niguel, Calif. The three companies - Dixon Industries, CHR Industries and Bunnell Plastics - are subsidiaries of the Bundy Corporation, which TI acquired in April. The decision to sell the companies was announced in October. The sale is expected to be completed later this month.

title: Syracuse Upset Again as Villanova Tiumphs
description: Kenny Wilson scored 20 points tonight to lead Villanova to a 75-73 victory over No. 4 Syracuse. It was the Orangemen's second Big East Conference loss in a week.

title: Guilty Pleas Close Case Against 10 Klan Members
description: Four members of the Ku Klux Klan pleaded guilty today just before their trial was scheduled to begin on Federal charges of conspiring to attack civil rights marchers in Decatur, Ala., in May 1979.

title: 75-Footers to Replace 12-Meters and Offshoots
description: Moving to restore stability to an America's Cup tarnished by discord, international challengers have reached agreement on a new class of boat as well as race courses, dates and format for the next sailing competition.

title: Both Engines Apparently Failed On Airliner in Crash in England
description: As the death toll rose to at least 44 in the crash of a British airliner in central England, Government investigators tried today to determine why both engines apparently failed on a three-month-old Boeing 737 jet.

title: By Design: Winter Camouflage
description: It's that time of year - gray skies, gray moods, and you feel a head cold coming on. There are positive steps you can take to brighten your wardrobe and your mood.

title: Scientists Find Lasting Damage From Oil Spill
description: IN the first comprehensive ecological study of oil spills in tropical waters, scientists have found that, contrary to widely held assumptions, the damage to coral reefs is not only immediate and severe but also can leave the organisms vulnerable to devastating disease and blight for years to come.

title: Leo H. Barry, Lawyer, 71
description: Leo H. Barry, a lawyer, died Sunday at New York University Medical Center as the result of a stroke early last month. He was 71 years old and lived in Astoria, Queens.

title: INSIDE
description: Abortion Case on Agenda The Supreme Court will rule on a law limiting abortion access. Page B5.

title: Male Duck's Timidity Around Flashy Rivals May Threaten Species
description: THE American black duck, whose numbers have shrunk by 60 percent in the last 30 years, may be on the road to extinction because males of the species are too timid to win females away from the flashier and more assertive mallard drake, a study by Canadian scientists suggests.

title: Review/Architecture; The Healing Murals of Richard Haas
description: Richard Haas has, in all but name, become an architect. He has not gone to school and got a degree, but no matter: Mr. Haas's art, which has long taken architecture as its theme, has now expanded to the point where it plays as much of a role in the cityscape as many real buildings.

title: New Age of Gerrymandering: Political Magic by Computer?
description: When state legislators gather a year after the 1990 census to begin redrawing the nation's election boundaries, a profusion of new computer technology will make it possible for any political hack to be a political hacker.

title: TALKS BROKEN OFF BY AFGHAN REBELS
description: Afghan guerrilla leaders refused today to resume direct talks with Soviet representatives, accusing Moscow of playing political games to obtain a place in a postwar government for members of the Kabul Government.

title: Settlement by Rocky Mount
description: The Rocky Mount Undergarment Company and two of its principals today settled Federal civil charges that the company's 1985 annual report was deliberately falsified to increase reported net income.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Argument On Law Limiting Abortion Access
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a Missouri law intended to limit access to abortions. The case offers the Court a vehicle for reconsidering its abortion precedents, a step urged by both Missouri and the Reagan Administration, but the brief order issued today gave no indication whether the Court would take that opportunity.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Is it true that spare batteries last longer if they are kept in the refrigerator? A. It was probably true in the past, but consumers probably could not tell a difference now because of changes in the way batteries are made, battery manufacturers say.

title: Colorado Prime reports earnings for Year to Oct 28
ATI Pharmaceuticals Inc reports earnings for 12mo to Oct 1
description: b-Included extraordinary income of $106,111 and $3,464,708 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively. The company was formerly ATI Inc.

title: Steinberg Defense Disputes Account of Child's Death
description: Disputing the prosecution's theory of how Lisa Steinberg was killed, a medical expert for the defense testified yesterday that the child was shaken, then thrown against a hard surface, causing the head injury that killed her.

title: Chinese Dissident Freed From Jail, but Restricted
description: A campaigner for democracy who had studied in the United States was released from a Chinese prison today. But a Government official said he would not be able to return to America for at least a year.

title: U.S. Opposed to 2 Westinghouse Ventures
description: The Justice Department, which has taken few antitrust actions during the Reagan Administration, said yesterday that it would seek to block two proposed joint ventures between the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and ABB Asea Brown Boveri, a Swiss industrial equipment manufacturer, unless the deals are modified to eliminate features that the department says are anti-competitive.

title: Briton Links Ties With Iran To Movement on Hostages
description: British officials told Iran today that relations could not improve without progress on freeing British hostages believed to be held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon.

title: Review/Music; Some Basics and a Tribute
description: Michael Morgan, a 31-year-old assistant conductor of the Chicago Symphony, led the New York Philharmonic in 1986 and began conducting at the New York City Opera this season. This weekend, he made his debut with the Brooklyn Philharmonic at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and at the last of his three performances, on Sunday afternoon, he not only left a strong impression of his own talents but had the orchestra sounding like a world-class ensemble as well.

title: From Russia, With Love for U.S. Goods
description: In Brooklyn, Queens, New Jersey and on Long Island, wherever Russian is spoken these days around New York, you can hear variations on amused laments about the ''vacuum cleaners,'' one of the latest phenomena spawned by a changing Soviet Union.

title: The Barber Of Pennsylvania Ave.
description: Bush staff members are already scheming how to get prime office space in the White House. One plot is to move the White House barber shop, where 67-year-old Milton Pitts snipped the manes of the last four Presidents.

title: DCNY Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bill Terry, a .400 Hitter for the Giants, Dies at 90
description: Bill Terry, the Hall of Famer who was the last player to bat .400 in the National League, died yesterday in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 90 years old, and had been in failing health for several months.

title: Pacific Gas Sets $200 Million Offer
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company is offering to the public $200 million of first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 2022 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which made the winning bid on the competitive issue.

title: GTech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,405,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,693,000 and $3,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said certain reclassifications have been made to the 1987 amounts to conform with the 1988 classifications. The latest periods' results were improved by the addition of a non-recurring net profit of $2,673,000 from the sale of the company's entire investment in Intervoice Inc.

title: MGM-UA Communications Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $3 million from the sale of the company's headquarters building. The loss realized in the latest first quarter resulted primarily from increased writedowns on theatrical releases and projects in development, as well as increased interest expense.

title: Kean Urges Ending 'No Fault' Car Insurance
description: Reflecting the growing rage of car owners over soaring insurance premiums, Gov. Thomas H. Kean today proposed scrapping New Jersey's 16-year-old system of ''no fault'' automobile insurance, an experiment originally intended to save drivers money.

title: Books of The Times; Grappling With a Changed Life and Language
description: Lost in Translation By Eva Hoffman 280 pages. E. P. Dutton. $18.95

title: Correction
description: An article on Monday about criticism of Finance Minister Shimon Peres over reports of a special account for the Finance Minister in the Israeli budget misstated the size of the account. It is said to be equivalent to one-tenth of 1 percent of the overall budget reductions recommended by Mr. Peres, not 10 percent.

title: Rumblings Rise Anew On Status Of Capital
description: Is the capital of the free world, a.k.a., the District of Columbia, free and democratic itself?

title: Lessons
description: Americans admire competition in most areas of national life. Why not then build it into public education?

title: REAGAN ADVISERS BLAME U.S. POLICY FOR SAVINGS CRISIS
description: In their final annual report, President Reagan's economists today blamed Government regulatory policies for the savings and loan crisis and said the public would have to pay for much of the cure.

title: K Mart Loses Court Fight
description: The K Mart Corporation, the discount retailer, breached its contract with a wholesaler clothing buyer and must pay $73 million in damages, a Federal jury decided today.

title: The Outcasts Challenge The Famers
description: Reserve Doubleday Field for the night of the Baseball Hall of Fame induction next summer. Don't worry about turning on the lights. We can play this one from memory.

title: Washington Federal Savings & Loan Assn Seattle reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Giants Sued for Bias in Coach Hiring
description: Lance Hamilton, the former Penn State linebacker, has filed a suit charging the Giants and the National Football League with racial discrimination. He contended in a suit filed yesterday in State Superior Court in Hackensack, N.J., that the Giants had reneged on a promised offer of a coaching job because he is black.

title: Conston Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net income

title: Rostropovich to Conduct Premiere Of Unpublished Shostakovich Work
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet expatriate cellist and conductor of the National Symphony, will present the world premiere of an unpublished and unperformed satirical cantata by Dmitri Shostakovich tomorrow night in Washington. The National Symphony is to play the same all-Shostakovich program Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

title: Panel Spawned By Corruption
description: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity was appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on April 15, 1987, as a response to unfolding corruption scandals on both the state and municipal levels.

title: Gulf & Western Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Revenue represents total revenue. The year-ago quarter's net income and share earnings have been restated to reflect an adjustment to the method of allocating the company's annual amortization of plate costs among the quarterly periods. This adjustment had no effect on the full year results. The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 2, 1988.

title: Adobe Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said share earnings figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Nov. 15. The company also said its 1988 results reflect the acceptance of the postscript interpreter in computer printing and publishing, and the acceptance of its applications software products.

title: 50,000 in Yugoslavia Press For Ouster of Area's Leaders
description: More than 50,000 people demonstrated today in the southern Yugoslav city of Titograd to press their demand for the resignation of the Communist authorities in the republic of Montenegro, but the leaders refused to yield.

title: Student Loan Marketing Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Newspaper Ads Up
description: Spending on newspaper advertising for the first three quarters of last year totaled $22.68 billion, an increase of 5.9 percent over the comparable period in 1987, according to preliminary estimates from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. National spending rose by 2.5 percent, to $2.66 billion, while retail advertising climbed by 3.5 percent, to $11.08 billion, and classified increased by 6.8 percent, to $3.01 billion.

title: Record at Burson
description: Burson-Marsteller, the public relations unit of Young & Rubicam, said yesterday that its 1988 revenues totaled a record $148.7 million. The revenues increased 17.6 percent over those of 1987.

title: John F. Hennessy, 60, Construction Engineer
description: John Francis Hennessy, a consulting engineer who supervised the design of major buildings in New York City and Washington, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Pop Life
description: Multi-faceted Diamond

title: House Unit Is Critical Of Bank Board's Deals
description: In the first formal inquiry into the savings industry's problems by the new Congress, members of the House Banking Committee assailed regulators today for their flurry of December transactions that rid the industry of 75 insolvent savings and loan institutions at a cost of $16.7 billion.

title: Review/Film; 'Kupalo,' Ukrainian Folk Tale
description: For a couple of minutes at the start of ''The Eve of Ivan Kupalo,'' you can tell what is happening. An old man in a boat is admiring a young woman -''my black-eyed daughter'' - on shore. But when a young man appears and embraces her, the father jumps into the water and gets into a clownish splashing match with him. After that, Yuri Ilyenko's movie, drawn from some Gogol stories and Ukrainian folk tales, turns into a surrealistic show that is not designed to make much sense to anybody this side of the Ukraine.

title: Penguins Gang Up on Islanders
description: Tonight was only a relatively triumphant return for the flu-plagued Brent Sutter, who had two goals, because Mario Lemieux went one better by scoring his fifth hat trick of the season and 17th of his career. For the Islanders, merely playing better isn't close to being good enough.

title: G.M. Layoffs at Buick
description: About 100 workers of the General Motors Corporation's Buick division will be laid off as the auto maker cuts production of its Reatta luxury two-seat car, a company spokesman said Monday. Larry Gustin said production levels at the Reatta Craft Center in Lansing, Mich., would be cut Feb. 13, from 56 to 42 cars a day. There are now about 780 employees at the plant, which produces only the Reatta.

title: Jackson as African-American
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is here, telling leaders at the conference of the African-American Institute what they want to hear from the U.S.

title: Of Time, Tradition, And Mozzarella
description: LEAD: EVERY morning at 7, Anthony Russo begins making mozzarella, as he has for 15 years and as his father did before him. Six times a day, he plunges his bare hands into a basin of hot water and milk curd and tosses out ball after ball of mozzarella. His kitchen, the size of a closet, is tucked behind shelves of Italian olive oil and canisters of dried porcini mushrooms in his shop, Russo and Son Dairy Products, at 344 East 11th

title: More Revlon to Tarlow
description: Tarlow Advertising, which received a portion of Revlon Inc.'s Almay account several weeks ago, said yesterday that it had picked up the rest from its former agency, Korey, Kay & Partners. Revlon spent $9.36 million advertising the Almay line during the first nine months of 1988, according to Leading National Advertisers.

title: William J. McDonald, A Catholic Bishop, 83
description: The Most Rev. William J. McDonald, a nationally known cleric who served as Auxiliary Bishop of the San Francisco Archdiocese for 12 years before his retirement, died of a heart attack Saturday. He was 83 years old, Bishop McDonald, a native of Ireland, was president of the International Federation of Catholic Universities from 1960 to 1963 and editor of the Catholic Encyclopedia. He served as Auxiliary Bishop in the Washington Archdiocese from 1964 to 1967, when he was transferred to San Francisco. He retired in 1979.

title: Using Force Against Libya?
description: LEAD: The diplomatic crisis brought on by the prospect of an American military strike against the Libyan plant suspected of making chemical weapons raises once again the critical issue of force and its justification. The crisis also raises the broader issue of international order and the responsibility the world's premier power bears in the maintenance of order.

title: 'Black and Blue' Postpones Opening
description: ''Black and Blue,'' the jazz-and-blues revue that was to open Sunday at the Minskoff Theater, has postponed its official opening until Jan. 22 or 26, Marilyn LeVine, the show's press agent, said yesterday. The postponement was caused by the illness of one of the show's stars, Ruth Brown, who suffered an angina attack last Friday, complicated by pneumonia, Ms. LeVine said.

title: Excerpts From Address by Kean
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of Gov. Thomas H. Kean's State of the State address to the New Jersey Legislature:

title: France Delays Visa Changes
description: A French Government spokesman says that plans to cancel the visa requirement for American visitors are still under negotiation and that France is seeking a reciprocal move by the United States.

title: Review/Music; Pavarotti and Guests In a Program of Arias
description: Luciano Pavarotti presided over a gala concert of opera excerpts at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, bringing with him eight colleagues - four sopranos, a tenor, two baritones and a bass - as well as the New York City Opera Orchestra. The concert, offered under the title ''Pavarotti Plus,'' was televised as part of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series.

title: People
description: * John J. Fraser has been named senior vice president, management supervisor of Lintas: New York, part of the Lintas: Worldwide network.

title: U.S. Report Raises Estimate of Smoking Toll
description: Twenty-five years after the Surgeon General of the United States jolted the nation with the first official warning of the health perils of cigarettes, a Federal report has concluded that smoking has caused more death and disease than previously believed.

title: Dream of White Christmas Is Now Family's Nightmare
description: Carlos Fajardo is sick of snow. Just last month, it was all he wanted.

title: Article 373689 -- No Title
description: The Walt Disney Company's chairman, Michael Eisner, earned $40.2 million in 1988, mainly in profits from a stock-option plan, company proxy material disclosed.

title: Wine Talk
description: HOW much does anyone really know about wine? There are sports fans who know every statistic, every player and every rule but who cannot throw a ball. There are wine fans who know all the labels and all the vintages but who cannot tell hearty Burgundy from rare old Bordeaux.

title: Batus to Close Units in Europe
description: All six European buying offices for Batus Inc., the American arm of B.A.T. Industries, will be closed about April 1, retailing executives in New York said. The offices buy apparel and home furnishings lines for Batus's American retail subsidiaries, including Saks Fifth Avenue in New York, Marshall Field in Chicago and J. B.Ivey in Charlotte, N.C.

title: No-Huddle Rule Wasn't An Easy Snap for Esiason
description: Confused about the no-huddle, quick-snap penalty ruling for the American Conference championship game last Sunday?

title: Favor Fading, Premier Faces Turkish Vote
description: A chance decision not to sit down one day last June may have saved the life of Prime Minister Turgut Ozal of Turkey and preserved political stability in his country.

title: BONN WILL TIGHTEN CURB ON EXPORTS OF DEADLY GOODS
description: Under considerable American pressure, the West German Cabinet agreed today to tighter controls on the export of nuclear and chemical materials and technology and stiffer penalties for violators.

title: Father Flees Court in Case On Medicaid
description: On the day of his sentencing for participating in a $16 million Medicaid fraud, Sheldon Weinberg failed to show up in a Brooklyn court yesterday and was declared a fugitive from justice.

title: Imre President Seeking New Product Exposure
description: Paul W. Self, named this week as president and chief operating officer of Imre Inc., a biomedical company in Seattle, said he had been hired to push the company's therapeutic products out of the research stage and into national markets, a feat he accomplished at two other medical equipment companies.

title: Cunningham Selected As Top N.F.L. Player
description: Randall Cunningham, who directed the Philadelphia Eagles to their first playoff berth since 1981, yesterday was named winner of the Bert Bell Trophy as the National Football League player of the year. Cunningham won by a 3-1 margin on first-place votes in balloting by Maxwell Football Club members, Pro Football Writers Association members, the Philadelphia news media and all 28 N.F.L. teams. Cunningham, a four-year veteran, completed 301 of 560 passes for 3,808 yards, all Eagle single-season records, and was the National Conference's 11th-leading rusher, with a team-leading 624 yards. (AP)

title: Moody's Reduces Rating On Outstanding Sears Debt
description: Moody's Investors Service has reduced the debt rating for more than $5 billion in outstanding debt issued by Sears, Roebuck & Company and of Sears Roebuck Acceptance and Sears Overseas Finance.

title: About New York; From Underclass Come the Pros Of Produce
description: This is a tale about New Yorkers who don't have much, the people who have come to be called the underclass. It is equally a story about economic change, the importance of knowledge, the reality that a new generation has better things to do than follow in dad's footsteps and - most important - why you may have less trouble finding a decent tomato at the supermarket.

title: CB&T Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said prior year results included a pre-tax gain of about $7.3 million from the sale of a mortgage banking subsidiary. Prior year results also included a $5 million addition to loan loss reserves.

title: Cooperation From Birth
description: To The Living Section:

title: Suns Beginning to See the Light
description: Two occurrences best highlight the five-year fall and resurgence of the Phoenix Suns. The decline began in June 1983 with the trade of Dennis Johnson to the Celtics for Rick Robey. The trade considerably strengthened Boston and proved disastrous for the Suns. Phoenix has finished at or below the .500 mark ever since and has missed the playoffs the last four seasons.

title: Canada to Open Drugs Hearings
description: Federal Hearings into the use of drugs in amateur athletics prompted by the Olympic scandal involving the Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson start Wednesday.

title: Aliens Flee Border Area While Rules Are Lifted
description: Chaos and confusion swept this border city today as hundreds of Central American refugees tried to get out of town and find shelter with relatives or friends by Thursday morning. That is when a Federal judge will review an immigration policy that could keep them here for weeks or even months.

title: Microcom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $462,000.

title: G.O.P. TO PAY BILL OF QUAYLE HOLIDAY
description: The Republican National Committee will pay about $15,000 in costs related to Dan Quayle's requirements as Vice President-elect during his family's Christmas skiing vacation in Colorado, Mr. Quayle's press spokesman said tonight.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Shipyard's Success Reopens Wounds From Bitter Strike
description: These should be heady days here in submarine country, where the sleek gray war machines are a decorative motif on everything from diners to monuments.

title: Urban School District For Indians Is Urged
description: The Minnesota Legislature should start the nation's first urban school district run by American Indians to focus on the special educational needs of native American children, a group of educators has recommended.

title: Jackson Talks Resume
description: After a hiatus of almost two months, the Knicks resumed negotiations yesterday on a new contract for Mark Jackson, their star second-year guard. Al Bianchi, the club's general manager, and Don Cronson, Jackson's agent, met for about an hour in Bianchi's office at Madison Square Garden. Bianchi said he had given Cronson an opportunity to make a counterproposal to the Knick offer that Bianchi had called ''final'' at the previous session on Nov. 18.

title: Koop's Stand on Abortion's Effect Surprises Friends and Foes Alike
description: Once again Dr. C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, has confounded the White House and Congress, liberals and conservatives. This time he told President Reagan in a letter Monday that, after extensive study, he could not conclude one way or another that abortions were harmful to women.

title: Kentucky Sale Plan Is Upheld as Legal
description: Kentucky's plan to become the first state to sell bonds to Japanese investors in Tokyo's financial markets was upheld today by state Attorney General Fred Cowan despite the objections of state legislators.

title: Soviets Say Afghan Deadline Is in Danger
description: A top Soviet diplomat warned today that there is ''serious danger'' that his country will not meet the Feb. 15 deadline for withdrawing its last troops from Afghanistan.

title: Rumors Rise On Takeover Of Ogilvy
description: IS Ogilvy in play? Once upon a time, it was assumed that advertising agencies could not be subjects of hostile takeovers. Then a British knight named Martin S. Sorrell stuck a lance through the JWT Group, the parent of the venerable J. Walter Thompson, and demolished that fairy tale.

title: Hi-Shear Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said the second quarter and 6-month earnings declines were attributable primarily to pre-tax operating losses of $1,775,000 and $2,475,000, respectively, from the company's space and defense systems operation and lower revenue and earnings at its aerospace fastening systems operations. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Topics of The Times; Red Stars
description: Mikhail Gorbachev, a Pisces, has the stars pulling for him, according to the first horoscope published in a Soviet Communist newspaper. The signs promise a harmony between earth and sky, the astrologer Eremei Parnov writes in Moskovskaya Pravda. Thus a whole universe opens for Kremlinologists.

title: City University Has a Proud Academic Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Staples to Keep a Dieter Out of the Deli
description: THIS year's New Year's resolution was not to make any resolutions I didn't think I would keep.

title: Children's Book Awards For Writers and Illustrators
description: Paul Fleischman has won the 1989 John Newbery Medal for his book ''Joyful Noise: Poems for Two Voices'' (Charlotte Zolotow/Harper & Row). The award is given annually for the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children. The books honored have been published the previous year. Mr. Fleischman's father, Sid, won the award in 1987 for ''The Whipping Boy.''

title: Data on Champion Is Given to Several
description: Champion Products Inc. agreed to let Walsh Greenwood & Company and other parties review its confidential financial data. Walsh Greenwood, a New York investment firm, has offered $55 a share, or $220 million, for the company, but Champion, a Rochester-based maker of athletic wear, rejected the bid as inadequate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY President Reagan's economists blamed regulatory policies for the savings and loan crisis and said the public would have to pay for much of the cure. [ Page A1. ] Members of Congress assailed regulators for December transactions, which rid the industry of 75 insolvent institutions at a cost of $16.7 billion. [ D5. ] The Supreme Court backed state taxation of long-distance phone calls and data transmission by upholding a 5 percent excise tax that Illinois imposed in 1985. [ A1. ] Rudolph W. Giuliani will resign as United States Attorney in Manhattan after five and a half years. He said he had not decided whether to run for Mayor of New York. [ A1. ] The Navy has begun actions against more than a dozen people and companies involved in the Pentagon fraud inquiry. [ A12. ] MARKETS A mistrial was declared in the GAF stock manipulation case, in a major embarrassment for Federal prosecutors. The ruling came after accusations of prosecutorial misconduct. [ D1. ] Stock prices retreated after four days of gains, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.25 points, to 2,193.21. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury bonds were generally higher in erratic trading. [ D14. ] The dollar finished higher against most currencies despite what dealers described as light dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve. [ D15. ] Cocoa futures prices dropped sharply amid arbitrage selling and rumors of heavy exports by the Ivory Coast. [ D15. ] INTERNATIONAL OPEC has succeeded in propping up prices but still faces obstacles in achieving its target range of $18 to $20 a barrel. [ D1. ] The U.S. warned the European Community's meat exporters that they could face a ban on $500 million of meat shipments unless their inspections meet U.S. standards. [ D2. ] Japan confirmed that it will extend its ''voluntary'' restraints on automobile exports for a year. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Harris Trust and Savings will pay $14 million in back pay to minority and female employees as part of a record settlement of Federal charges of sex and racial discrimination. [ A1. ] Eastern Airlines and its machinists are near a showdown in their long contract dispute. [ D1. ] Unilever is negotiating with Faberge, seeking its cosmetics, fragrances and toiletries divisions. [ D1. ] A compromise plan for Allegheny International has provoked a backlash among the company's advisers and shareholders. [ D4. ] Digital Equipment introduced eight desktop computers and outlined a new software strategy. [ D4. ] Pan Am will sell its profitable World Services, which provides security, maintenance and other services. [ D4. ] TECHNOLOGY Richard M. Stallman is obsessed. The computer programmer longs for those good old days when programming was a communal activity, with secrets freely shared. [ D1. ] More efficient cores for transformers seem likely to emerge since a longstanding problem has been solved. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Most economists still think deficits count, and most Americans still agree. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The stock market is not so healthy as the Dow Jones industrial average would seem to indicate. Market Place. [ D8. ] Is Ogilvy in play? Wall Street is abuzz, and the stock price has been jumping. Advertising. [ D16. ]

title: Plane Engine Shut Down Before Crash, British Say
description: Investigators said today that an engine on a British airliner was inexplicably shut down before the plane crash landed in central England on Sunday night, killing 44 people.

title: Chicago Milwaukee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $3,130,000 and $10,917,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax benefits of $1,704,000 for the quarter and $18,410,000 for the year. The company said proceeds of $67.9 million from the sale of two suburban commuter rail lines on Sept. 4, 1987 are included in revenue for 1987. Income for 1987 was increased by $28.9 million as a result of the sale.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: HUNTING for the unmarked brick building on an obscure stretch of West Huron Street that houses Wild Game Incorporated is almost as difficult as hunting the wild things sold there. It is worth it, however, because this six-year-old business sells a wide variety of game birds, big game, wild mushrooms and other exotic foods to retail customers at the same price as it does to restaurants.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were generally higher in erratic trading yesterday.

title: Correction
description: An article on Friday about Ira D. London, the lawyer for Joel B. Steinberg, misidentified the lawyer who referred Mr. Steinberg to Mr. London. He is Robert Kalina, not Galima.

title: Atlanta Official Fined on Gun
description: Atlanta City Councilman Hosea Williams, who was arrested in March for trying to carry a .38-caliber pistol past security at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport, was fined $1,000 Monday after pleading no contest to carrying a concealed weapon and carrying a pistol without a permit, misdemeanor charges. Mr. Williams has already paid a $1,000 civil fine.

title: Police Begin Releasing Files On 1969 Raid on a Gay Bar
description: Complying with a court order, the New York City Police Department began turning over confidential files yesterday that it had compiled in connection with a 1969 police raid on a gay bar called the Stonewall in Greenwich Village.

title: Stephen Csoka, Painter, 92
description: Stephen Csoka, a Hungarian-born realist painter who taught art in New York for four decades, died Thursday at his home in Kings Park, L.I. He was 92 years old.

title: General Cinema Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $4,855,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,034,000 for the quarter and $17,100,000 for the year. In the latest quarter, the consolidation of Neiman Marcus Group results accounted for $9.8 million, or 13 cents a share, of the earnings decline. In fiscal 1988, Neiman Marcus Group contributed $14.2 million, or 19 cents a share, to General Cinema's net income. The latest quarter and year included after-tax gains of $5 million and $33.3 million, respectively, from the sale of securities, compared with similar gains of $17.4 million for the year-ago quarter and $26.1 million for the year. Revenue for the latest quarter and year included $273.8 million and $1,223,200,000, respectively, from Neiman Marcus Group.

title: KEY RATES
Barton Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest year's results included the acquisitions of R&G Supply Co., Duke Lubrication and Consulting Inc., and the Sentinel Manufacturing Co. The R&G and Duke acquisitions were accounted for as a pooling of interest, so the company's operations have been restated to reflect the companies' combined operations. The Sentinel acquisition was accounted for as a purchase, and the results are included as of Aug. 10.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Kings 106, Lakers 97: The Los Angeles Lakers lost their eighth straight road game, tying a club record, as La Salle Thompson had 23 points and 11 rebounds to lead Sacramento. The last time the Lakers lost eight consecutive road games was 13 years ago. Thompson also had four blocks for the Kings. Kenny Smith had 19 points and 14 assists, while Harold Pressley scored 17 for Sacramento, which has the worst record in the Pacific Division at 8-21. Magic Johnson and James Worthy each had 22 points for the division-leading Lakers, who are 22-12. Johnson also had 12 assists. It was the Kings' fifth straight home triumph, but only their second victory against the Lakers in the teams' last 31 meetings. After Rodney McCray's fast-break layup gave the Kings a 70-58 lead, the Lakers pulled within 4 points, at 75-71, at the end of the third period, outscoring Sacramento 7-0 in the final two minutes. But Sacramento regained its 12-point margin on a jump shot by Ed Pinckney, giving the Kings a 91-79 lead with 6 minutes 49 seconds to play.(AP) Bulls 104, Hawks 101: Michael Jordan scored 48 points, including 14 in the final 7 minutes 18 seconds when Chicago erased a 14-point deficit in Atlanta. Jordan's two free throws with 22 seconds remaining completed the scoring, and the Hawks missed three 3-point shots in the final 20 seconds, one each by Dominique Wilkins, Moses Malone and Dudley Bradley.(AP) Utah 92, Miami 88: Jim Farmer and Mark Eaton each hit two free throws in the final 25 seconds as visiting Utah withstood a Miami comeback. Karl Malone scored 29 points to lead the Jazz. Rony Seikaly had 30 points and Jon Sundvold added 28 for the Heat. (AP) Bullets 120, Nuggets 117: John Williams sank a layup with 18 seconds remaining and Jeff Malone hit two free throws with five seconds left to give Washington the victory in Landover, Md. A last-second attempt by Walter Davis to tie the score was blocked from behind by Charles A. Jones, who had a career-high 16 rebounds. Bernard King led the Bullets with 33 points and Williams had 25 points.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 3, North Stars 2: Derrick Smith and Rich Tocchet scored 47 seconds apart in the third period, leading Philadelphia past visiting Minnesota. Smith, returning after a two-game absence because of a hip pointer, scored the game-winning goal while sprawled in the crease. He pushed the puck into the open net at 7:22 of the third period after a shot by Terry Carkner pulled the North Star goalie, Jon Casey out of position. Tocchet scored his 23d goal to give the Flyers a 2-2 tie when he converted a wrist shot between Casey's pads at 6:35. Brian MacLellan tipped in a shot from Marc Habscheid from the point on a power play at 8:12 of the first period to give the North Stars a 1-0 lead. Neil Broten beat Ron Hextall in the slot just 22 seconds into the second period for the North Stars' second power-play goal. Tim Kerr, returning from a five-game shoulder injury, scored his 28th goal on a power play. He tapped in Gord Murphy's shot from the blue line with 8:14 left in the second period.(AP) Capitals 4, Nordiques 4: Kevin Hatcher and Dave Christian scored third-period goals as visiting Washington rebounded from a two-goal deficit to gain the tie with Quebec. Hatcher got his 10th of the season on a scramble in the goalmouth at 10:03 of the third period. Christian scored the tying goal, his 19th, from the left circle with 5:35 remaining in the third. Mike Ridley and Mike Gartner scored the other goals for Washington. Michel Goulet, Marc Fortier, Peter Stastny and Trevor Stienburg scored for Quebec, which has not won in seven games.(AP) ALPINE SKIING Nierlich Wins Giant Slalom: Rudi Nierlich of Austria clung to a first-heat lead yesterday to win a World Cup giant slalom in Kirchberg, Austria, besting Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland and Alberto Tomba of Italy. Nierlich led by just 24-hundredths of a second after the first heat, but skied strongly on the second run, clocking 1 minute 24 seconds for a total of 2:44.72. Zurbriggen, the World Cup overall leader, was second in 2:45.10, and Tomba, who made a costly mistake at the end of the first run, finished third in 2:45.26 (AP) TENNIS Shriver Gains, but Leconte Is Upset Pam Shriver, returning to tournament play after a five-week break, easily won her opening match of the $350,000 New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia, yesterday. But Henri Leconte of France, seeded No. 1 in the men's field, was upset in his first-round match on the second day of the weeklong tournament. Shriver, the defending champion but seeded second behind Martina Navratilova, scored a 6-1, 6-4 victory over an Australian teen-ager, Jo-Anne Faull. In other women's matches, Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia beat Liz Smylie of Australia, 6-2, 6-1, in a second-round match and Hana Mandlikova of Australia downed Jo Durie of Britain, 3-6, 7-5, 7-6. Three seeded women were beaten. Eighth-seeded Pascale Paradis of France lost, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2 to Amy Frazier, a 17-year-old American. Dinky Van Rensburg of South Africa beat 12th-seeded Brenda Schultz of the Netherlands 6-2, 7-5, and Etsuko Inoue of Japan downed Nicole Provis of Australia, the 10th-seeded player, 6-4, 6-4. Leconte, ranked ninth in the world, was, like Shriver, returning after a rest, but found the heat and Peter Lundgren of Sweden too much, losing 6-4, 6-3 in a first-round match. Fifth-seeded Darren Cahill of Australia bowed, 6-3, 4-6, 6-1 to Carl Uwe Steeb of West Germany.(AP) Mansdorf Advances: Top-seeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel powered into the second round of the $145,000 New Zealand Open, beating Menno Oosting of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-4. Second-seeded Ramesh Krishnan of India also moved into the second round with a 6-1, 7-6, victory over Michael Kures of the United States.(AP)

title: Lady Tech Star Wins
description: Teresa Weatherspoon, a guard on the Louisiana Tech basketball team and a starter on the Olympic gold medal team, was named collegiate woman athlete of the year last night and received the Honda-Broderick Award in San Francisco.(AP)

title: Southwest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: M.H. Stone, Acclaimed Mathematician, Dies at 85
description: Marshall Harvey Stone, a prodigious and influential American mathematician, died Monday in Madras, India, apparently of a stroke. Dr. Stone, who was 85 years old, had gone to India to attend a music festival.

title: First American Tennesse Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge-off of $31.3 million in problem loans and an increase of $31.4 million in loan loss reserves. c-Net income

title: Gordon Jewelry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,218,337 from the sale of real estate. c-Net loss

title: 8 Desktop Computers Introduced by Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced eight desktop computers today and outlined a new software strategy that company executives said would give the company an advantage by allowing its different models to be coupled more closely.

title: Chemical Weapons Parley Labors On
description: As the international conference on chemical weapons neared an end here, diplomats worked late tonight in an effort to fashion a statement reinforcing the ban on the use of such weapons in war.

title: Journalists Donate to Neediest
description: For the second year in a row, Dan Rather has chosen to honor colleagues at CBS News by making gifts in their names to the Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Corporal Punishment In Schools Must End
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue-Chip Job Recruits With Short-Term Goals
description: Betrayed only by the evident newness of their dark suits and the slight flush in their cheeks, several dozen college seniors sat in a Bankers Trust conference room last week looking exactly like the bankers and executives they want to be.

title: Rhoden Goes To Astros For Three From Minors
description: The Yankees sent Rick Rhoden to the Houston Astros for three minor league players yesterday, accomplishing their goal of trading one of their veteran high-priced starting pitchers.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: GEORGE BUSH'S hankering for barbecued pork ribs preceded his Presidential bid. In Houston it is common knowledge that he will drop in at Otto's, a sprawling barbecue, but the President-elect's taste in restaurants in the nation's capital is not as well known.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, received an order for four A310-300 jets from Pan American World Airways. The value of Pan Am's order was estimated at $240 million.

title: 'Romance' Extends Run
description: ''Romance Romance,'' a musical that was to have closed last Sunday, is extending its run at the Helen Hayes Theater, the show's producers have announced. The four-character musical was written by Keith Herrmann with book and lyrics by Barry Harman.

title: Stocks End Down 6.25 After Piercing 2,200
description: Stock prices retreated broadly yesterday after four days of gains, but the decline was modest. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 6.25 points lower, at 2,193.21, after once again piercing 2,200 in early trading.

title: Bush to Attend Hirohito Rites
description: President-elect George Bush will lead a United States delegation at the funeral of Emperor Hirohito of Japan on Feb. 24, a Bush aide said today. Mr. Bush is to be inaugurated on Jan. 20, and the trip to Japan is likely to be Mr. Bush's first visit abroad as President.

title: Retail Sales Up In New York
description: A number of the largest New York retailers had their best sales gains of the year in December, averaging increases of 7.2 percent in the city and 7.1 percent in the metropolitan area from the year before, a spot-check found yesterday.

title: 100 Approved for Soviet Legislature
description: The Communist Party's Central Committee today approved a list of 100 candidates submitted by the ruling Politburo for the 100 seats that the party will fill in the new Soviet legislature.

title: Arbitration for Joyner
description: Wally Joyner, the California Angels first baseman, filed for salary arbitration yesterday. Three players who were eligible to file yesterday agreed to one-year contracts: Mike Fitzgerald with the Montreal Expos, Ken Howell with the Philadelphia Phillies and Pat Clements with the Padres. Players can file through Monday. (AP)

title: Chefs Search for the Perfect Version
description: RISOTTO is causing quite a stir in restaurants these days. As diners become more knowledgeable about this versatile northern Italian staple, chefs are responding with an ever-increasing variety of preparations. The accompanying recipes are a testament to the dish's versatility.

title: Why Not a Methadone Clone for Cocaine?
description: Nothing would help the medical and public health communities fight substance abuse more than a chemical treatment that works against cocaine addiction much as methadone works against heroin.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Giuliani Departs
description: Some prosecutors are quietly efficient. Rudolph Giuliani, who now announces that he's quitting this month, is loudly so. In five years as United States Attorney in Manhattan, he raised the visibility of an office long known for effectiveness and professionalism. He recognized an important part of his job: tell the public what you're doing.

title: Review/Television; Smoking: From Flirtation to Peril
description: ''Smoking: Everything You and Your Family Need to Know,'' on Home Box Office tonight at 10:30, marks the 25th anniversary of the Surgeon General's report linking cigarette smoking and lung cancer. Nothing good has been discovered about smoking in the interim.

title: FORMER NAVY MAN IS CHARGED AS SPY
description: A former Navy technician was arrested today on charges of trying to sell secret information on antisubmarine warfare to the Soviet Union. Federal investigators said he was seeking revenge because the Navy had discharged him for indecent exposure.

title: Pentagon Moves Against Figures Cited in Inquiry
description: The Navy has initiated actions against more than a dozen individuals and companies involved in the Federal inquiry into military procurement fraud, including the suspension without pay of a Navy employee who was indicted in the case last week, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Probation Dept. Had Lost Track of Suspect in Bellevue Slaying
description: The man charged in the murder of a pregnant pathologist at Bellevue Hospital Center was on probation for stealing a refrigerator in Brooklyn four years ago, and probation officials lost track of him last April, according to police and Probation Department records.

title: Soviet Pullout in Hungary Soon
description: The Hungarian Communist Party leader was quoted today as saying the Soviet Union would begin withdrawing troops from Hungary ''within weeks.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Franc on the Cabernet Front
description: ALTHOUGH cabernet sauvignon is the dominant red grape in California, trend-spotters predict that it will be challenged by varietal wine made from another family member - cabernet franc.

title: U.N. Resolution on Dogfight Softened Again
description: A proposed resolution on the downing of two Libyan jet fighters by United States planes over the Mediterranean last week was softened further today as the Security Council debate on the confrontation continued.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council

title: Prosecutor Ends Inquiry on Leak In Brawley Case
description: The New York State special prosecutor for the criminal-justice system said yesterday that he had ended his inquiry into the disclosure to The New York Times of secret grand jury material in the Tawana Brawley case.

title: Judge Rules Mistrial in GAF Case
description: In a serious embarrassment to Federal prosecutors in New York, a judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the GAF stock manipulation case, the first prosecution based on information from the insider-trading scandals of 1986.

title: Eating Well
description: IT seems as if everyone is talking or writing about nutrition these days. Even if you seldom follow the subject, you might be surprised at the amount of information you have absorbed subliminally.

title: What the Deadbeat Asks of the U.N.
description: Hardly a week passes without the United States devising yet another task for the no-longer-scorned United Nations. The most recent proposal is to give the Secretary General power to probe charges of chemical weapons use. That's a sensible idea, and the larger policy change is surely welcome. What's baffling, even shaming, is that these ideas are unblushingly promoted by the U.N.'s most incorrigible deadbeat; the U.S. is $402 million behind in its dues.

title: 2 Groups Discuss Offers for G.E.C.
description: Two international groups are talking about bidding for Britain's huge General Electric Company, industry sources said. One is headed by General Electric of the United States, which is not linked in any way with G.E.C., and the other by G.E.C.'s chief British rival, Plessey P.L.C.

title: Accounts
description: * Murry's, Forestville, Md., formerly Murry's Steaks Inc., an East Coast chain of grocery stores specializing in meat products, to Weitzman/Dym/ Livingston, with a $2.5 million budget.

title: Haas Hopes to Start Fast Again
description: Jay Haas does not know why some players get off to a fast start on the PGA Tour swing through the West. But he accepts the fact that some do just that and that he is one of them. He won the $1 million Bob Hope Chrysler Classic last year, finished second in the San Diego Open and sixth in the Los Angeles Open, before the PGA Tour moved East.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in the Transition Watch column yesterday about the Bible that will be used in George Bush's inauguration misstated the date the Bible was given to St. John's Masonic Lodge in New York. It was in 1770, not after George Washington's inauguration in 1789.

title: Filippo Berio Oil to Lempert
description: After a four-month review of 20 agencies, Salov North America, the American and Canadian arm of a family-run olive oil company in Lucca, Italy, has awarded its advertising budget for Filippo Berio brand oil to the Lempert Company, Belleville, N.J. The annual budget totals seven figures.

title: When Is Rice High Art? When It's Risotto
description: NOW that Americans have assimilated pasta and no longer blanch at spending $15 for a plate of noodles, they are starting to embrace another emblem of Italy: risotto.

title: Nevada Scholarships Stem Student Exodus
description: On a campus where basketball players are recruited with a religious zeal, Nevada's brightest students are getting a second look, thanks to a university president who resolved to stop this state's ''brain drain.''

title: Counter-Inaugurations
description: The counter-culture lives, also in the context of the Presidential inauguration festivities that are to take place next week.

title: Food Notes
description: The Way to Win

title: Donald Voorhees, 85, Conductor Who Led 'Bell Telephone Hour'
description: Donald Voorhees, for 28 years the conductor and musical director of the ''Bell Telephone Hour,'' one of the most popular musical programs in broadcasting history, died of pneumonia yesterday at Tomlin Memorial Hospital in Cape May Court House, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in Stone Harbor, N.J.

title: Texas Instruments Plans Plant in Italy
description: Texas Instruments said it would build a $250 million semiconductor fabrication plant in Avezzano, Italy, about 65 miles east of Rome, to supply the European semiconductor market. The plant will begin production of integrated circuit wafers, including dynamic random-access memory chips, in late 1990. The new operation is expected to employ about 500 when it reaches full production in 1991.

title: Head of Framatome Is Out to Diversify
description: Jean-Claude Leny heads a huge French industrial enterprise with a problem. Its principal product, nuclear reactors, is no longer in demand.

title: Mayor Is a Mad Driver
description: Mayor Charles Luken of Cincinnati, whose Bengals will play the San Francisco 49ers in the Super Bowl Jan. 22, was chagrined the other day when he realized that a city street on which he had once lived and which he still uses to drive his children to school is named Montana Avenue.

title: Thou Shalt Not Mess With the Global Environment; Hot Summers in 1990's
description: To the Editor:

title: Mistrial in GAF Stock Case
description: In an embarrassment for Federal prosecutors, a mistrial was declared in the GAF stock manipulation case and a new trial ordered. Page D1.

title: Evans Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Market Place; Warning Signs For Stock Prices
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average is trading at its highest levels since the 1987 crash, to a chorus of disbelief. Contrarians can take comfort in just how much doubt there is, but in the meantime there are signs that the stock market is not nearly so healthy as the Dow would seem to indicate.

title: No Headline
description: THE goods, so to speak, were on the table, and 50 high-school and college students were bidding fiercely for the job attributes that would satisfy them most. ''How much for intellectual status?'' It starts at $50 and is quickly bid up to $650. ''What about working alone?'' Sold, to the young lady in the front row for $450. ''Here's community. How much for community?'' No takers at any price.

title: Unilever Seeks Units Of Faberge
description: The Unilever Group, one of the world's largest consumer products manufacturers, is negotiating to buy the cosmetics, fragrances and toiletries divisions of Faberge Inc., Daniel J. Manella, the chairman of Faberge, said yesterday.

title: Review/Television; Late-Night Chitchat Additions: Pat Sajak and Arsenio Hall
description: One show is affably low-key, in the mode of Johnny Carson and easy-listening radio.

title: Personal Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $69,000.

title: With a Microwave Oven, Relief From Constant Stirring
description: THE very notion of cooking risotto in a microwave oven may seem as close to culinary blasphemy as one can get. In reality, however, it is one of the most alluring recipes in the microwave cooking repertory. Risotto cooked this way is not cooked more quickly than the traditional stove-top version, but the quality is excellent and the cook is liberated from the endless standing and stirring.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: EVEN those who have little knowledge of Russian cuisine recognize the term stroganoff (or stroganov). This popular winter dish has a French connection going back to the 19th century. Aristocratic Russians of the time had a strong commercial and cultural connection with France, and many upper-class Russians employed French cooks, who were always looking for ways to give French dishes a Russian twist.

title: High Court Says A State Can Tax Interstate Calls
description: The Supreme Court today opened the door to more aggressive state taxation of long-distance telephone calls and data transmission through phone networks.

title: A Champion Prosecutor Faces Politics of Nuance
description: With crime and drugs topping the list of worries of New York City voters, a popular prosecutor who made his name fighting organized crime, municipal corruption and insider trading, would from the start be a formidable candidate for political office.

title: National Community Bank of New Jersey reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Costs of Special Education
description: Schools spent $3,555 extra for each of the 4.4 million handicapped children receiving some form of special education in the 1985-86 academic year, according to a study prepared for the Government.

title: Nets Alter Lineup Again
description: The Nets, who have lost three of their last four games, are making two lineup changes for their game tonight at Philadelphia.

title: Silicon Valley Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 share earnnings have been restated to reflect stock dividends paid in 1988.

title: Geodynamics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
Tyco Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The results of Mueller Co. and Atcor Inc. have been included since the dates of their acquisitions on Sept. 30, 1988 and Aug. 10, 1987, respectively.

title: A New Way to Save Electricity
description: Electrical transformers, which reduce high voltages on power lines to levels useful in homes and businesses, are inefficient devices. Their metal cores must be magnetized and demagnetized dozens of times each second, which wastes electricity. But amorphous metals, in which the atoms are arrayed radomly rather than in tight rows, are much more efficient as transformer cores because they are more easily magnetized and demagnetized.

title: WPP Buys Donahue
description: The WPP Group has acquired for an undisclosed sum Donahue & Associates Advertising, a firm that specializes in employment recruitment advertising. Donahue, which has $20 million in billings, will be merged into Thompson Recruitment Advertising, a Los Angeles-based unit of J. Walter Thompson, whose billings exceed $130 million. The new Thompson Recruitment division will serve New York, New Jersey, southern Connecticut and central and southern Florida.

title: Cuba Pulls 450 Soldiers Out of Angola
description: Thirteen years after a Cuban force came to Angola, 450 Cuban soldiers left here today, marking the start of a Cuban military withdrawal scheduled to be complete by mid-1991.

title: Mark IV Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included net gains of $1,306,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter from the sale of securities, and $9,930,000, or 92 cents a share, for the 9 months from the sale of securities and assets. c-Included a net gain of $1,256,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of Baird Corp.'s common stock. The latest third quarter included two months of the results of Dayco and Blackstone, two divisions of the recently acquired Armtek Corp. Mark IV said it intends to sell Armtek's copolymer division, therefore, its results are not included in its latest third quarter. The results also included Cetec Corp.'s results from July 1, 1988, Conrac's results from May 1, 1987, and Eagle Signal Control's results from June 1, 1987.

title: Interim U.S. Attorney: 'Street Smart' and Fair
description: Benito Romano brings to the job of interim United States Attorney ''street smarts,'' a fervent intolerance for corruption and a sense of fairness that comes from growing up poor in the South Bronx, his friends and colleagues say.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AFTER a brunch of beef sausages, fried chicken, macaroni salad and Tater Tots, the 114 members of the Corsi Senior Center on East 116th Street in East Harlem donned party hats, decided who should have which noisemakers and strolled - some with canes, some with walkers - from the center's dining room into the lounge. There, Dom Giglio's two-piece band (horn and keyboard) was already getting the guests into a New Year's Eve party mood with a swinging version of ''Memories'' followed by several tunes with a Latin beat.

title: High Court Eases Appeals On Curb on Access to Counsel
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a conviction must be set aside whenever a trial judge has interfered with a criminal defendant's constitutional right to the assistance of counsel.

title: Mexico Inflation Down
description: A wage and price freeze reduced inflation last year to 51.7 percent, down two-thirds from the 1987 rate, Mexico's central bank said on Monday. The Bank of Mexico noted that consumer prices rose by 159.2 percent in 1987. Last Feb. 29, the Government froze the peso's exchange rate against the dollar.

title: Arum Makes Big Plans
description: Predicting that 1989 would be ''the year of the middleweights,'' Bob Arum announced yesterday that he planned to promote a series of middleweights bouts that would unify the title. And if everything works the way the president of Top Rank Inc. believes it will, the series will lead to a fight that might gross more than $30 million.

title: Herbert Morrison, 83, Hindenburg Reporter
description: Herbert Morrison, who 52 years ago broadcast an emotional description of the crash of the Hindenburg, died early today at a nursing home here. He was 83 years old.

title: Giuliani Resigns as U.S. Attorney; Still Undecided on a Mayoral Bid
description: Completing a term marked by unusual accomplishment, publicity and controversy, Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would resign as United States Attorney in Manhattan.

title: Blacks Fined in Protest on Confederate Flag
description: A district judge today convicted the head of the Alabama National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Thomas Reed, as well as 13 black legislators on a misdemeanor trespassing charge in their protest against the Confederate battle flag flying atop the state Capitol.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 9.0437 percent, up from 8.952 percent last week and the first increase in three weeks.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Wider Fines
description: The head of the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Federal agency would ask Congress to pass legislation allowing the S.E.C. to seek monetary penalties for all civil violations of the Federal securities laws. At present, the S.E.C. can seek monetary penalties only for civil charges of insider trading.

title: Criticare Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chicago Bank to Pay $14 Million In Resolving Discrimination Case
description: A large Chicago bank has agreed to pay $14 million in back pay to women and minority employees as part of a record settlement of Federal charges of sexual and racial discrimination.

title: Diasonics Settles With Ex-chairman
description: Diasonics Inc. has reached a settlement with its former chairman, Albert S. Waxman, under which Mr. Waxman agreed to end his battle to seek control of the Milpitas, Calif., medical equipment manufacturer. Mr. Waxman and his partner, the New York financial services concern Integrated Resources Inc., had offered to buy Diasonics for $3.12 a share, or $206 million.

title: Lillian Vernon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: The company said it terminated its S corporation tax status in August 1987. Accordingly, no provision for income taxes was made for the first 6 months of fiscal 1988; results reflected a pro-forma tax provision for comparative purposes.

title: New O'Horgan Musical Has 2 Previews Canceled
description: Preview performances of ''Senator Joe,'' a new musical composed and directed by Tom O'Horgan, were canceled Sunday and last night at the Neil Simon Theater. The show had begun previews Saturday night. A Jan. 19 opening has been announced.

title: Changes in '91 Tourney Upheld
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association came out on top tonight in a dispute with the nation's two historically black Division I athletic conferences, the Mid-Eastern Athletic and the Southwestern Athletic.

title: Thou Shalt Not Mess With the Global Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: India's Claims on China
description: To the Editor:

title: Chiron and Ortho Win Test Approval
description: The Chiron Corporation and Ortho Diagnostic Systems, a division of Johnson & Johnson, said that the Food and Drug Administration had approved Ortho's genetically engineered hepatitis B antibody test. The test, the first of a series being developed collaboratively by Chiron and Ortho, uses a recombinant antigen developed by Chiron. It will be used to detect the presence of hepatitis B antibodies in human blood and plasma. The worldwide screening market for hepatitis B is estimated at more than $40 million.

title: Carnegie Plans Centennial
description: Carnegie Hall officials announced preliminary plans yesterday for the hall's centennial season in 1990-91, highlighted by a commissioning program to link 10 composers with 10 performers and ensembles.

title: Universal Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Swearing In Quayle
description: It is not the law, but it is tradition that the President is sworn into office by the Chief Justice, who, until 1977, also customarily swore in the Vice President.

title: California's 6-Year Boom May Be Over
description: California's six-year economic boom, which strengthened the state's image as a land of boundless opportunity, may be coming to an end.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Climax Molybdenum Co., Greenwich, Conn., a division of Climax Metals Co., which is owned by Amax Inc., named James E. Gorman to the new post of president.

title: Pilots Scarce, Airlines See 30-Year-Olds as Captains
description: Airline executives, concerned about an imminent world shortage of pilots, are taking steps that will place younger and less experienced fliers in command of airliners.

title: Boom Ends As Minorities In the Region Lag Behind
description: The metropolitan region's six-year economic boom has ended but without any progress in drawing a large part of the population into the mainstream workforce.

title: Eastern and Machinists Near a Showdown
description: A showdown appears to be drawing closer between Eastern Air Lines Inc. and its largest union, the machinists. And the National Mediation Board is moving nearer to deciding whether to declare an impasse in negotiations that have dragged on for 15 months.

title: Andersen Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Omaha Journal; Goal Is New Theater in an Old Market
description: Dick Mueller is fighting for his professional life and for the life of his theater, which has long been a centerpiece of the Old Market section of downtown Omaha, a section known as the local Greenwich Village.

title: Telecrafter Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
We Can Teach Growth by Deficit Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Nation's Table
description: TOSTADA chips and hot sauce could well be the national dish of Texas. So, it's not surprising that Texans hold strong opinions - with little consensus - about the perfect salsa. Recently, some serious contenders have been produced by ambitious home cooks, like the former Austin radio talk-show host Patrick J. Timpone.

title: Correction
description: An article on Monday about the Federal budget process misidentified the broadcast on which Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine appeared Sunday. It was ''Meet the Press'' on NBC.

title: Bridge
description: The first tournament of the year, for players in the New York metropolitan region is the Tristate Regional beginning today at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: CASTRO SCORNING GORBACHEV MODEL
description: For the last six months Fidel Castro has been kicking up a storm of protest about changes taking place in the Soviet Union, his closest ally and the source of enormous economic support that has been crucial to Cuba's survival.

title: International Paper Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Mayor Koch's Basement
description: Edward Koch has always curled a mayoral lip at the concept of old-fashioned patronage, conceding its political value but boastfully banning it. Now come allegations that his administration not only ran a patronage system but did so under the guise of an affirmative action job-referral service, the Mayor's Talent Bank.

title: Nelson Remains Optimistic; Giants' Tackle Begins Treatment for Cancer Recurrence
description: Karl Nelson confirmed today that his cancer had returned.

title: Marine's Death in Training Becomes a Harsh Lesson for Corps
description: The Commandant of the Marine Corps, clearly angered over the death of a lance corporal who was abandoned in the California desert while on a training exercise, has turned an investigation into possible negligence into a sharp lesson for leaders of the corps.

title: Rangoon Journal; A Daughter of Burma, but Can She Be a Symbol?
description: In the six days between the death and the Jan. 2 funeral of Daw Khin Kyi, the widow of the founder of Burmese independence, more than 20,000 people flocked to her house and garden off University Avenue, near Inya Lake. They came to show reverence and respect, but also resistance, for Daw Khin Kyi's daughter, Aung San Suu Kyi, has become the foremost symbol of Burma's hopes for democracy.

title: Time for Mr. Mosbacher to Come Clean
description: Robert Mosbacher, who served as George Bush's chief campaign fund-raiser, now reaps his reward; he is the President-elect's choice to be Secretary of Commerce. But before he is confirmed he needs to take care of some unfinished business: clearing the air about the millions he raised in so-called ''soft-money'' campaign contributions.

title: Winfield v. Steinbrenner: Charges Are Intensifying
description: The mud-slinging that has been a part of the George Steinbrenner-Dave Winfield relationship intensified yesterday in the wake of the latest round of lawsuits by each side.

title: INSIDE
description: Surgeon General's Surprise

title: Allegheny Plan Spurs Opposition
description: A compromise plan that two rival suitors for Allegheny International Inc. have reached to avert a bidding war has provoked a backlash among the company's advisers and shareholders.

title: Tyson Becomes Punchy On the Subject of Money
description: Mike Tyson is a closed-circuit attraction once again, but this time he is playing to a far smaller audience than the one that last June paid millions to watch him knock out Michael Spinks.

title: Even Presidents Taste Frustration; N.C.A.A. Slow to Change
description: When Dr. Peter Likins volunteered to become a charter member of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Presidents' Commission, he was, by his own admission, ''an impetuous, young college president,'' who wanted the commission to charge in like the cavalry and install new controls over intercollegiate athletics.

title: What a Jim Dandy Ending
description: In Washington George Bush was being a swell guy again. ''What a swell guy!'' everybody was saying.

title: Cyril A. Zebot, Professor, 74
description: Cyril A. Zebot, a retired professor of economics at Georgetown University and a Slovenian nationalist who vigorously opposed the postwar Communist regime in Yugoslavia, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Washington. He was 74 years old. Professor Zebot, a graduate of the University of Ljubljana, came to the United States in 1947 and taught at Duquesne University before joining the Georgetown faculty in 1958. He retired in 1978 but continued to write and lecture until his final illness.

title: Steinberg Lawyer Quiet On Psychiatric Exam
description: A defense lawyer in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg refused to disclose last night whether the defendant would submit to a psychiatric examination ordered by the court, but officials in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said, ''we're assuming he has agreed'' and have scheduled the examination for 2 P.M. today.

title: British List Bill On Steroid Use
description: A bill that would impose a criminal penalty on anyone caught taking or supplying anabolic steroids without a prescription was introduced in the House of Commons today.

title: Review/Theater; Hanging On to All the Right Attitudes Articulately
description: The relentlessly right-thinking and ferociously articulate characters in Susan Miller's new play, ''For Dear Life,'' are the kind of people who can't contemplate the change of seasons without anticipating nuclear winter. They can't pour a glass of milk without crying over the snapshot of a missing child on the carton. They can't go to the bathroom without worrying about the depletion of the ozone layer.

title: Economic Scene; Back to Basics On the Deficit
description: IT'S budget season, and once again those pesky skeptics are asking the embarrassing questions. If deficits really matter, why has America enjoyed six straight years of prosperity? How can Japan, that rising economic sun, live with a debt that has grown faster than America's and represents a larger fraction of national income?

title: Astronomers Miss the Mark On Rays by 340 Light-Years
description: An intense source of gamma radiation long believed to be at the center of the Milky Way actually lies at least 340 light-years from the true nucleus of Earth's galaxy, a balloon-borne telescope has revealed.

title: Push Is On for Overhaul Of Vocational Training
description: Floyd Fowles, an electronics teacher, has tacked up signs on his classroom walls carrying a simple, direct message: ''Think.''

title: Pentagon Defends Tactics of Pilots Off Libya
description: Vigorously defending the American fighter crews that shot down two Libyan warplanes last week, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that the Navy fliers may have waited too long before launching their missiles.

title: For Asians in U.S., Hidden Strife
description: LEAD: With its new shelter for battered Asian women, the San Francisco Bay Area joins New York City and Los Angeles in recognizing a problem that has long been hidden among the rapidly growing Asian communities of the United States: the presence of domestic violence.

title: End of Jersey's No-Fault System Would Surprise Few Auto Insurers
description: The proposal by Gov. Thomas H. Kean that New Jersey abandon its no-fault system for automobile insurance is unlikely to be viewed as a decisive blow to the no-fault concept in insurance circles. The New Jersey version of no-fault has long been regarded as so weak as to be no-fault in name only.

title: Leader of Mexican Oil Workers' Union Arrested
description: A leader of the Mexican oil workers' union was arrested on weapons charges today, setting off a walkout by refinery workers and a confrontation between the Government and the country's most powerful labor group.

title: Book Notes
description: Winners in Print

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Japan Confirms Extension of Its Car Quotas
