description: The Japanese Government confirmed today that it would continue its ''voluntary'' restraints on automobile exports for another year.

title: Loss at U.P.I. Of $16 Million
description: United Press International said today that it had lost $16 million in 1988 and would lay off about 40 employees.

title: Independent Bank Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Dance; Journey to Strange Lands
description: The dancers never left Performance Space 122 on Sunday evening. Nevertheless, they visited many strange lands in ''Xanadu/The Millions,'' which Mark Taylor choreographed for his company, Mark Taylor and Friends.

title: Israelis Say They Killed 8 Guerrillas in Lebanon
description: Israeli troops killed eight guerrillas over the weekend north of the buffer strip in southern Lebanon that Israel calls its security zone, the army said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Bank board deals which privatize profit, while socializing risk, amount to nothing less than a societal decision to allow those with potentially large tax liabilities - that is, the rich -to get richer.'' - Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. [ D5:1. ]

title: Holly Farms to Set New Bid Deadline
description: The Holly Farms Corporation, the Memphis chicken producer, said its two suitors, Tyson Foods Inc. of Springdale, Ark., and Conagra Inc. of Omaha, would not be required to have their best proposals to acquire the company ready for Wednesday's board meeting.

title: Wall St. to the Bronx: the Prosecutor's Unfinished Work
description: The resignation of Rudolph W. Giuliani as the United States Attorney in Manhattan came as a number of major cases were unresolved or about to go to trial. These are among the defendants in the cases: Michael R. Milken Mr. Milken, the head of the high-yield, or junk bond, unit of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has been at the center of a two-year investigation of Wall Street. Mr. Milken, who received a letter late last year from the United States Attorney indicating that he was the target of a criminal investigation, is expected to be charged along with other Drexel employees with many securities law violations. The GAF Corporation GAF and a top executive have been charged with criminal manipulation of stock in transactions involving its ownership of stock in the Union Carbide Corporation. Yesterday, a Federal judge declared a mistrial in the GAF case, charging ''prosecutorial misconduct.'' Paul Bilzerian Mr. Bilzerian, the Florida takeover specialist who is the chairman of the Singer Corporation, was charged last month with securities fraud. The case is scheduled to begin trial in May. Princeton/Newport Partners Five principals of Princeton/Newport, a New Jersey investment firm, were charged along with a former trader from Drexel with conspiring to create fraudulent tax losses through phony stock trades. The firm was not charged but it collapsed last month. Trial is to begin in June. Wigton, Tabor, Freeman The case against Richard Wigton and Timothy L. Tabor of Kidder, Peabody & Company, and Robert M. Freeman of Goldman, Sachs & Company is perhaps Mr. Giuliani's greatest defeat in the securities field. The three men were charged with a host of violations of the Federal securities laws. The Government was forced to drop all charges in 1987, however, after the three pleaded not guilty and prosecutors were unprepared to go forward with their cases. At the time, Mr. Giuliani vowed to bring broader indictments. He has not done so. Teamsters A lawsuit filed by Mr. Giuliani last summer said local executives of the union had Mafia ties. The trial is to begin Feb. 27. Wedtech One remaining trial, a civil suit on racketeering charges, is that of E. Robert Wallach, a friend and personal lawyer of Edwin Meese 3d, and two financial consultants, R. Kent London and W. Franklyn Chinn. The case has yet to go to trial. Robert Garcia Representative Robert Garcia, Democrat of the Bronx; his wife, Jane Lee Garcia, and a lawyer, Ralph Vallone Jr., were indicted on charges involving an alleged bribery-extortion scheme to obtain $185,000 from the Wedtech Corporation. The trial is scheduled for June 1. The Marcoses Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, were charged with racketeering involving allegations of fraud and embezzlement concerning Manhattan real-estate deals. Mrs. Marcos pleaded not guilty and is free on bail. Mr. Marcos, said to be too ill to travel, has not been arraigned yet. The Helmsleys Harry and Leona Helmsley and two officers of the Helmsley Corporation were indicted last April on 47 counts of conspiracy, extortion and tax evasion. Last month, a Federal appeals court denied for the second time a motion for dismissal. The trial is to begin April 24.

title: One Man's Fight for Free Software
description: Richard M. Stallman is a computer programmer obsessed with a mission. He wants to bring back the good old days when programming was a communal activity and those toiling at the craft freely shared their ideas - and their source code, the internal instructions that tell the computer what to do.

title: U.S. Warns Europeans Of Possible Ban on Meat
description: Escalating a trade conflict with the European Community, the United States has warned the community's meat-exporting nations that they could face a ban on $500 million of meat shipments unless they can prove that their inspection standards are being maintained.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Traded Rick Rhoden, pitcher, to Houston for John Fishel, outfielder, and Pedro DeLeon and Mike Hook, pitchers. Assigned Hook and DeLeon to Albany of the Eastern League. MONTREAL (NL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Fitzgerald, catcher, on a one-year contract. OAKLAND (AL) - Agreed to terms with Matt Young, pitcher, on a one-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Agreed to terms with Ken Howell, pitcher, on a one-year contract. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Agreed to terms with Pat Clements, pitcher, on a one-year contract. TORONTO (AL) - Named Paul Beeston president and chief operating officer. BASKETBALL ALBANY (CBA) - Signed Lowes Moore, guard. Traded the rights to Jeff Cook, center, to Cedar Rapids for the rights to Dirk Minniefield, guard. COLLEGES CARNEGIE-MELLON - Named John H. Harvey director of athletics and physical education, effective March 1. GEORGIA - Named Frank Orgel linebackers coach. KANSAS STATE - Named Tom Grogan assistant football coach. WASHINGTON STATE - Named Sonny Lubick defensive coordinator. FOOTBALL DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Pete Mandley, wide receiver, and Harvey Salem, offensive tackle, to multiyear contracts. HOCKEY BUFFALO (NHL) - Sent Mike Donnelly and Scott Metcalfe, left wings, to Rochester of the American Hockey League. VANCOUVER (NHL) - Reassigned Jay Mazur, center, to Milwaukee of the International Hockey League.

title: OPEC Pact Lifts Oil Prices, But $18-$20 Goal Is Elusive
description: Six weeks after reaching an agreement to cut its oil production by four million barrels a day, or about 20 percent, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has succeeded in propping up prices. But it still faces obstacles in achieving its target range of $18 to $20 a barrel.

title: E-Z-EM Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Volt Information Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included a gain of $5,355,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle for income taxes. c-After an extraordinary charge of $3,165,000 related to the early redemption of debentures.

title: DMI Furniture Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
River Forest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; A No-Frills Hotel Rises In Manhattan
description: FOR more than two years, Journey's End Motels, a fast-growing chain based in Belleville, Ontario, has been trying to bring its no-frills concept to Manhattan. Until recently the company's efforts to build in New York City have been thwarted by the high cost of land in acceptable locations.

title: Frisch's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 11
At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: CONVENTIONAL wisdom has it that serious restaurants cannot succeed in downtown Atlanta south of the hotels, but Steve Nygren, president of Peasant Restaurants, is not worried.

title: Fuller, H B Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Rink New York Fixed All by Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Riggs National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and that is attributable to special provisions of $53.5 million which the company made in 1987 in connection with problem country loans. The special provisions of $53.5 million contributed to reduced earnings in 1987.

title: Coping With Twins
description: To The Living Section:

title: Redmen's Fortune Turns for The Better
description: Contrary to the assortment of twists and turns that have lurked along the path to victory for teams in the Big East Conference this season, something straight and narrow transpired last night before a sellout 6,008 fans at Alumni Hall: St. John's defeated Connecticut, 71-63.

title: Koch Doubts There is Patronage In Program for Affirmative Action
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he did not believe an affirmative action program he established more than five years ago had been turned into an operation that systematically dispensed patronage jobs on behalf of top political leaders.

title: Bush, Wooing Educators, Urges Choice in Schools
description: In one of his first major appearances since the election before a constituency he ardently wooed, President-elect George Bush told educators today that parents should be able to choose the best public schools in their neighborhoods, not necessarily the ones nearest their homes.

title: States Could Provide the Housing for Congress; Their Market Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Employers Match Donations, Multiplying Gifts to Neediest
description: Thomas Clemmons of Pawling, N.Y., sent $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ''to help provide aid to the homeless and hungry of New York City.'' His gift was made under the matching-gifts program offered by his employer, The Reader's Digest Foundation of Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Scientists Find How Allergic Reaction Works
description: Scientists have discovered the structure of a substance that is a key to allergic reactions, and they expect to use the knowledge soon in searching for new treatments for these widespread and varied forms of illness.

title: Metro Matters; Mau-Mauing Flak Catchers On the East Side
description: The presidency of the 70-year-old East Sixties Property Owners Association has never been a hotly contested job, and the reluctant incumbent shuns the suggestion that his civic activism might be perceived as the incarnation of preservationist chic.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertisign; New Publisher Named For Endless Vacation
description: Robert F. Young has been named publisher of Endless Vacation, another step in the travel magazine's effort to make itself a significant consumer publication. Mr. Young, who is 54, was the founding publisher of Good Food, which Rupert Murdoch recently bought and closed. Before that, he spent 13 years at The New Yorker.

title: Market Place; Realty Concern's Rapid Collapse
description: IT may be a record for speed. In just 201 days, the Residential Resources Mortgage Investment Corporation went from being an initial public offering to a Chapter 11 case in bankruptcy court.

title: Tultex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
Ex-Professor Criticizes N.C. State
description: A controversy started by the jacket cover of a forthcoming book charging wrongdoing within the North Carolina State basketball program intensified yesterday when a retired professor at the school said that grades had been changed to maintain the eligibility of Chris Washburn, one of the school's former star players.

title: Library Cat Is Out, and So Is Library
description: The local library's eviction of Muffin, a cat that had lived there for seven years, may cost it as much as $30,000.

title: River Forest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DSC Settles S.E.C. Action
description: The DSC Communications Corporation and a senior company official settled Federal disciplinary proceedings on Tuesday. The Securities and Exchange Commission contended that the company had misstated its net income on certain financial statements in 1984 and 1985.

title: City National Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said per share earnings included non-recurring income equal to 8 cents a share and 22 cents a share for the latest year and 1987, respectively. Per share earnings reflected a 20 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 17.

title: Tyson Says He Signed More Than One King Pact
description: Mike Tyson, in a deposition he gave in his suit to break his managerial contract with Bill Cayton, has said he signed more than one contract with Don King over the past year.

title: Falcon Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Movie Buffs Find a Trove on Cable
description: Howard Mandelbaum, the owner of Photofest, a Manhattan movie-photo archive, says the unthinkable has happened - he's become a slave to his video recorder. Meryl Mintzer, an administrative assistant, says she no longer has time to shop, let alone clean her apartment. Bill Dworkin, the vice president of sales at Rizzoli Publishing, confides that what he really likes to do these days and nights is stay at home in front of his television.

title: Too Long at the Fair
description: Silky Sullivan, the race horse, used to thrill his fans with a come-from-behind rush in the homestretch - sometimes.

title: Quayle Takes Bush Vice Presidency as Model
description: For more than eight weeks, Dan Quayle has prepared for the Vice Presidency by meeting with foreign policy and domestic specialists, shaping a staff largely made up of Republican moderates, and remaining - as George Bush was to Ronald Reagan - as discreet and deferential as possible.

title: 2 KOCH AIDES DENY PATRONAGE IN JOBS
description: Contradicting earlier witnesses before a state investigating committee, two Koch administration officials who supervised a job referral program in the basement of City Hall denied steadfastly yesterday that the program was used for political patronage.

title: Immucor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $142,386 for the quarter and $249,081 for the 6 months.

title: Seat Belt Study Assesses Savings in Medical Costs and Injuries
description: A pioneering study by researchers at the University of Illinois has quantified the value of seat belts in preventing injuries in motor vehicle accidents.

title: Hovnanian Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a gain of $2,583,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. The company said year-ago results are restated to consolidate wholly owned finance and mortgage banking subsidiaries previously reported on the equity method.

title: EA Engineering, Science & Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CLOSE TO HOME
description: MY rituals are few but faithfully observed, which means that one Sunday every January will find me in a large and floridly decorated roadhouse called the Venus de Milo Lounge, strolling through aisles of junk, not-quite-junk and several gems. The gems are hard to spot, but I know they're there. So do most of my fellow prowlers: we are primed to pounce.

title: Self-Chilling Can Fraud
description: The mastermind of a $2.4 million fraud involving claims of a self-chilling beverage container was sentenced to 12 years in prison today.

title: Perry Gets Settlement
description: Gaylord Perry, the star pitcher who retired in 1983, and his family accepted a $1 million settlement yesterday for a lawsuit involving his wife's death in a car wreck. The agreement came as attorneys were preparing for closing arguments following two days of testimony in Bartow, Fla. Perry's wife, Blanche, died after an accident near Lake Wales, Fla., in September 1987. She was 48 years old. A car driven by Mrs. Perry, of Gaffney, S.C., collided with one that Harold Arnold of Winter Haven allegedly drove through a stop sign. (AP)

title: Review/Theater; Certain Friendly Skies
description: In ''Skin - a State of Being'' (at La Mama Annex), Ping Chong takes his audience aloft into a cloudland of airy activities. As cumulus images drift by in the background, offstage voices of polite flight attendants settle us into our seats, preparing travelers for an armchair theatrical adventure. A real airline should be so soothing and accommodating. Ping Chong Airways is not about to overbook or to fly in an endless holding pattern.

title: Barnett Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. and Allies Veto U.N. Move on Libyan Planes
description: A resolution that deplored the downing of two Libyan fighter planes by American fighters over the Mediterranean last week was vetoed in the Security Council tonight by the United States, Britain and France.

title: Knowledge Is Power
description: Turn down a dusty dirt road, go a mile or two past small cornfields and round peasant huts, and you come to a group of brick buildings set about with shade trees. At the gate a sign says Kawere School, and another: Knowledge Is Power.

title: Newmil Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
States Could Provide the Housing for Congress; Buy Them Apartments
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Let That Anger Out, It's Good for You
description: To the Editor:

title: Digital Solutions Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Poll Finds Blacks and Whites 'Worlds Apart'
description: A national survey has found that blacks and whites are ''worlds apart'' in their perception of race relations, with large majorities of whites believing that blacks are treated equally in America and similarly large majorities of blacks disagreeing.

title: A Texas Park For Opryland
description: Opryland USA Inc. and the insurance company USAA said this week that they planned to develop a musical theme park here that would resemble one in Nashville. Opryland's president, E. W. Wendell, said that no cost or starting date for construction had been determined but that he hoped to have details worked out by the end of the first quarter.

title: Talking Deals; Film Processing's Latest Name
description: QUALEX INC., the result of the recent merger of the photo-processing labs of the Eastman Kodak Company and Fuqua Industries, knows the value of a good name. And in this case that name is Kodalux, the new name for the processing that used to be done by Kodak.

title: CVB Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Electronic Sales Up
description: American factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products rose by more than 8.7 percent, to $242 billion, last year.

title: Holmgren Is a Coach After His Players' Hearts
description: The night he found out he wasn't a Flyer anymore, a devastating tidbit of news that came to him from his car radio, Paul Holmgren drove the car into a ditch. His body, already battered from eight years as a Flyer henchman, wasn't hurt, but his pride was, and at that moment the ditch seemed like the place to be.

title: Karl Geiringer, 89, Musicologist And Composers' Biographer, Dies
description: Karl Geiringer, a leading figure in musicology since the 1930's, died Tuesday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif., from complications arising from a fall. He was 89 years old and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: HEI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
U.S. Is Said to Agree To East-West Meeting
description: The United States has agreed to convene a major East-West economic conference in Bonn early next year. The meeting could lead to expansion of trade and financial relations between Washington and Moscow, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Westchester Poll to Assess Racial Attitudes
description: Westchester residents will be polled on their attitudes about race relations and housing on Jan. 25 at an ''electronic'' town meeting at the County Center in White Plains.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ALEXANDRA LOGUE was the sort of finicky eater who drives parents to distraction. At 1 year of age she wouldn't touch anything except bread and milk. Fifteen years later she couldn't stand such teen-age staples as spaghetti or Coke. She still refuses to eat fish.

title: Sheldahl Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
Restoring Old Pianos To Historic Dimensions
description: KALMAN DETRICH says he repairs pianos inside and out. ''Most people get involved with one part or another,'' he said. ''But in order to do a good job, you should do both in the same place.''

title: Part of Chrysler Legacy To Be Sold at Sotheby's
description: Art from the collection of Walter P. Chrysler Jr. - Old Master and 19th-century paintings by Bernardo Bellotto, Lucas Cranach, Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres and Theodore Gericault, and Art Nouveau glass by Tiffany and Galle - is to be sold by Sotheby's in June.

title: Sandata Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DeKalb Genetics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
MGM/UA Television Names New President
description: LEAD: Lynn E. Loring was named president of the MGM/UA Communications Company's restructured television division, one of Hollywood's most successful production outlets. Ms. Loring, who joined the company as a television programming and production executive in 1985, thus becomes one of the entertainment industry's highest-ranking women.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we forget what we did, we won't know who we are. I am warning of an eradication of the American memory that could result, ultimately, in an erosion of the American spirit.'' - President Reagan. [ A1:3. ]

title: Books of The Times; Through a Dark Boyhood to a Place in the Sun
description: This Boy's Life A Memoir By Tobias Wolff 288 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Steinberg Has Mental Exam; Answers Are Called 'Evasive'
description: Joel B. Steinberg submitted to a three-hour examination by a prosecution-appointed psychiatrist yesterday to determine his mental condition on Nov. 1, 1987, when the prosecution says he beat 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg to death.

title: Yields Rise For Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday.

title: Racially Mixed Couple Attacked In Bias Incident on Midtown Street
description: A real-estate broker and his wife walking with their infant daughter were attacked in midtown Manhattan Monday afternoon by a knife-wielding black man who resented that the couple was racially mixed, the police said last night.

title: Irving Officer Gets New Post
description: The Bank of New York Company announced yesterday that Samuel F. Chevalier, 55 years old, had been appointed a vice chairman of both the bank and the holding company. Mr. Chevalier is the president of the Irving Bank Corporation and a vice chairman of its banking subsidiary. The Bank of New York acquired Irving in December, after a yearlong takeover battle.

title: Ralston Purina
description: The Ralston Purina Company accepted about 5,525,000 shares of its common stock for payment at $84 a share in accordance with its previously announced tender offer. Based on an early count, the human and pet food products group said about 5,538,000 shares had been tendered at or below $84 a share. Ralston Purina's offer expired Tuesday night. The company offered to repurchase up to 5 million shares of its common stock in a ''Dutch auction'' but has chosen to increase the number of shares purchased as permitted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: NBSC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Raden Haji Harsoyo, U.N. Commander, 63
description: Gen. Maj. Raden Haji Harsoyo, former commander of the Indonesian contingent of United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Vietnam War, died of heart disease Tuesday. He was 63 years old.

title: Peoples Heritage Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Columbia Pictures Entertainent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $5,225,000 for the quarter and $13,100,000 for the 9 months. c-Included a gain of $5,912,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said income per common share is pro forma for the periods from Oct. 1, 1987 to Dec. 17, 1987 and from April 1, 1987 to Dec. 17, 1987. Operating results of Tri-Star Pictures Inc. are included only for the latest 3 months and 9 months. The company's fiscal year-end is the last day of February. For comparative purposes, the year-ago periods from Oct. 1, 1987 to Dec. 17, 1987 and from April 1, 1987 to Dec. 17, 1987 are presented.

title: A Marketing Specialist Leads Funk & Wagnalls
description: Edward A. Volkwein, having made the marketing switch from Ragu spaghetti sauce to Prince tennis racquets already in his career, doesn't mind his latest leap - to Funk & Wagnalls encyclopedias.

title: Transcript of Reagan's Farewell Address to American People
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech to the nation last night from the White House, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Convention Tightens Scholarship Eligibility
description: In a turn of events that could dramatically affect the ability of certain high school athletes to attend college, Division I delegates to the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today approved a proposal that will prevent incoming freshmen who do not meet prescribed academic standards from receiving athletic scholarships.

title: Safety Rules Proposed for the Handling of Blood
description: The Labor Department, responding to concern among health care workers about AIDS and other blood-borne diseases, has proposed regulations requiring that all blood and body fluids be handled as if they were infected.

title: 90 Feared Dead in Pakistan On Boat Carrying Mourners
description: A river boat crowded with funeral mourners and goats broke apart and capsized after hitting an obstruction, and 90 people were missing and feared dead, newspapers said today.

title: Article 597089 -- No Title
description: The Ford Motor Credit Corporation is offering $250 million of 10-year notes through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Where's the 'Mona Lisa'? Just Follow the Map
description: LESLIE SMOLAN and Kenneth Carbone have worked together since 1977, but they consider their victory in the competition for the visitor information and sign system at the Louvre a plum, one of their best assignments to date.

title: Lazare Kaplan International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss Sales represent gross sales.

title: Bush Will Name Retired Admiral As Energy Chief, Filling Cabinet
description: President-elect George Bush has decided to name a retired admiral, James D. Watkins, as Energy Secretary, filling the last Cabinet position, officials on Mr. Bush's staff said tonight.

title: Carolinian Ordered Extradited
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has ordered the extradition of a Tuscarora Indian who fled kidnapping charges in North Carolina and sought haven at an Indian reservation in New York, a spokeswoman for the Governor said Tuesday.

title: California Utility In Bond Offering
description: The Southern California Edison Company, a subsidiary of SCEcorp, is offering $150 million of first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 2020 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc., which made the winning bid in competition yesterday.

title: RICO Shouldn't Be Used to Clog Federal Courts With Civil Suits
description: To the Editor:

title: Need for High-Tech Consortiums Stressed
description: Executives in several high-tech industries and some academics and Government officials say that if the United States is to remain competitive, it must begin forming a large number of cooperative research and development consortiums. The joint research efforts would substantially alter traditional relationships among business, universities and the Government.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The floors in our bathrooms are covered with small hexagonal tiles that I feel look old-fashioned. I would like to re-cover these floors with a vinyl or with some other type of tile. Can I apply the new floor covering directly on top of the old tiles, or must they all be removed first? A.As long as the old tiles are still bonding firmly you can apply a new floor covering directly over them. You can put down either a vinyl or ceramic tile, depending on preference and on the type of adhesive you use (check with your dealer on this). Chances are you will have to fill in the grout joints and level out the old floor first, especially if you are going to put down vinyl.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pacers 127, Celtics 108: Indiana beat Boston at Boston Garden last night for the first time in 18 regular-season games since April 2, 1978. Chuck Person scored 29 points and Rik Smits had 21 as the Pacers gained their first victory in 16 road games this season. It was the fourth consecutive victory for the Pacers, including three straight under Dick Versace, their new coach. In extending their longest winning streak of the season, which began after Indiana broke a nine-game losing streak earlier this month, the Pacers opened a 30-22 lead as Smits scored 10 points and Person 7 in the first quarter. Smits, a 7-foot-4-inch rookie center from Marist College, scored 7 more points and Person added 9 in the second quarter as the Pacers increased their advantage to 60-43 at halftime.(AP) Bulls 106, Hornets 101: Michael Jordan scored 22 of his 24 points in the second half to lead Chicago last night in Charlotte. Jordan scored 15 points in the third quarter as the Bulls expanded a 49-48 halftime lead. After two free throws by Rex Chapman cut the Bulls' lead to 69-68, Chicago went on an 11-4 run, with Jordan giving the Bulls an 80-72 lead after the third quarter. Despite making only six field goals in the quarter, the Bulls hit 14 of 16 free throws to hold off Charlotte.(AP) N.H.L. Capitals 3, Maple Leafs 2: John Druce scored twice last night in Toronto as Washington gained its second victory in six days over the Maple Leafs. Washington, unbeaten in six games, moved back into first place in the Patrick Division with 53 points, 2 more than the idle Pittsburgh Penguins. The Capitals outshot the Maple Leafs, 34-30. It was the ninth consecutive game in which Toronto had been outshot.(AP) HORSE RACING Migliore Wins 3 Straight: Richard Migliore rode his third straight winner when he guided Barbara W. Turner's Pok Ta Pok to a 1 1/2-length victory in the feature race yesterday at Aqueduct. Broadway Bonanza, who led into the stretch, was runner-up in the field of nine, 2 1/2 lengths ahead of Chicot County. Pok Ta Pok earned $14,400 and returned $3.20, $2.60 and $2.40 for $2 across the board. It was the third victory in nine career starts for the 4-year-old colt by Full Pocket and Tiy.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Auburn 77, Mississippi State 35: Carolyn Jones scored 17 points and top-ranked Auburn scored the first 17 points of the second half last night as the Lady Tigers (14-0, 2-0) rolled to the Southeastern Conference victory. The game was the conference opener for Mississippi State, which fell to 8-7 over all.(AP) Mississippi 90, Memphis State 59: Phyliss Stafford scored 15 points and had 7 rebounds last night to lead undefeated and third-ranked Mississippi at home. The victory improved Mississippi's record to 13-0. Memphis State fell to 5-6.(AP) TENNIS Cash Beats McEnroe: Pat Cash of Australia defeated John McEnroe, 7-6, 6-4, in the opening exhibition match of the round-robin Rio International Challenge yesterday in Adelaide, Australia. Cash was erratic, serving 9 aces while committing 11 double faults. The Australian took the first set in a tie breaker, 7-5, after a comeback following McEnroe's service break in the opening game.(AP) Navratilova Advances: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova moved into the third round of the New South Wales Open championships yesterday with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Andrea Temesvari of Hungary. Pam Shriver, the defending champion who is seeded second, was the first player to make the quarterfinals with a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Etsuko Inoue of Japan. Hana Mandlikova, seeded ninth, beat Nathalie Herreman of France, 6-3, 6-3, and Terry Phelps of the United States, seeded 16th, beat Rafaella Reggi of Italy, seeded sixth, 6-3, 7-5. An American teen-ager, Mary Joe Fernandez, seeded fourth, defeated Belinda Cordwell of New Zealand, 6-3, 6-0. Other winners in second-round matches were Patty Fendick, Dinky Van Rensburg and Judith Wiesner. Winners in second-round men's play were Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa, Libor Nemecek of Czechoslovakia and Olivier Delaitre of France.(AP)

title: States Could Provide the Housing for Congress; What of Rank and File?
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar: Japanese Lacquered Carvings
description: Kamakurabori, Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street; 212-832-1155.

title: Reagan, in Farewell, Warns Against Loss of Spirit
description: President Reagan said goodbye to the American people tonight as his 96 months in office neared an end, warning them that the revival in patriotism he helped to foster ''won't count for much and it won't last'' unless they learn more about their country's history and ideals.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Smoky Response
description: In the time-honored tradition of bureacratic documents, a spade is never a spade but rather a hand-manipulated tool for displacing and removing earth and other materials.

title: Bridge
description: Half a century ago a young New York bridge expert was embarking on a brilliant career that was to bring him a string of national titles, three near-misses in world championships and the reputation of being the greatest bidding innovator of all time.

title: Ransburg Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,250,000. c-Net income d-Included gains of $96,000 and $205,000 from tax credits for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $21,109,000. The company said the losses in the latest quarter and year included unusual charges of $9,494,000 for costs associated with consolidating two facilities of a West German subsidiary and writing down its assets; settling two lawsuits; tender offer expenses and writedown of investment securities to market value. The fiscal 1988 loss also included an $800,000 reserve to cover costs related to the disposal of Satomat-Globe Asia.

title: Gene Accord For Cetus
description: The Cetus Corporation and Hoffman-La Roche Inc. said they had agreed to collaborate on the development and commercialization of in-vitro human diagnostic products based on Cetus's Geneamp polymerase chain reaction technology.

title: SafeCard Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Walker Street Unable to Get Data
description: Walker Street Associates L.P. disclosed that it had been rebuffed in an attempt to examine confidential financial information of National Intergroup Inc. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Walker Street said it had met on Tuesday with the management of National Intergroup but the two sides ''were not able to reach any agreement or understanding and do not plan to meet any further,''

title: Suspect Freed Without Bail In Bronx Assault on Teacher
description: A Bronx judge yesterday released without bail a man indicted for attacking a teacher in a crowded school hallway last month. The teachers union strongly criticized the action.

title: Allegheny Spurns Compromise Plan
description: The board of Allegheny International Inc. voted late yesterday to reject a compromise plan of reorganization that was supported by the company's creditors. The plan would have allowed Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. to buy Allegheny in exchange for selling its profitable patio furniture and outdoor grill units to an investor group led by Paul S. Levy.

title: Jose Bustamante, 94; Peruvian President Ousted in '48 Coup
description: Former president Jose Luis Bustamante y Rivero, who was ousted in a 1948 military coup and later became president of the International Court of Justice, died Wednesday, a hospital spokesman said. He was 94.

title: Drought Leaves Nets High and Dry
description: The Nets used their new starting lineup tonight, featuring Chris Morris at forward and Dennis Hopson at guard. They overcame a 15-point deficit and got a career-high 20 points from Morris.

title: WestPoint Pepperell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: b-Included a gain of $6,299,000 from the sale of discontinued operations and a charge of $7,865,000 from the cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting for income taxes. The latest first-quarter results included special charges of $17 million, or $10.5 million after taxes. In addition, a $3 million reserve was established to cover related expenses from the company's announced intention to move certain apparel support functions from Troy, N.Y., to locations in the South. The special charges also included $3 million in expenses incurred to date related to the unsolicited tender offer by Farley Inc. Sales for the latest quarter included those of J.P. Stevens, which was acquired in May 1988.

title: A City Without Sirens: Quiet Views of Gotham
description: TWO new books - ''Frontier New York'' (Hudson Hills Press), top, and ''Urban Wilderness: Nature in New York City'' (Earth Environmental Group), above - offer fascinating, silent views of a city often thought of as boisterous, crowded and noisy.

title: Leaders of a Republic In Yugoslavia Resign
description: Government and Communist Party leaders in the republic of Montenegro resigned today in the face of widespread protests over the economy and abuse of power.

title: Demand Strong for 7-Year Notes
description: Credit market participants were very active bidders at yesterday's auction of new seven-year Treasury notes, but showed little interest in secondary issues of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Bush's Shell Game
description: President-elect Bush has earned extra brownie points as an ''environmentalist'' for naming a well-regarded professional to head the badly crippled Environmental Protection Agency.

title: More U.S. War Dead Pledged
description: The Vietnamese Government will give more remains of Americans missing in action to a United States team arriving Thursday, and joint excavations of crash sites will be conducted, an official said today. ''I think there will be quite a number,'' said Nguyen Can, acting director of the office dealing with the servicemen missing in action from the Vietnam War. Mr. Can said his Government is allowing American teams to roam the country, interviewing witnesses and officials in regions where planes are believed to have gone down.

title: Pepperell Appeals Ruling on Defense
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. asked an appeals court today to reinstate the textile company's ''poison pill'' defense as it tries to fend off an unsolicited $1.4 billion tender offer from Farley Inc.

title: Ballet Theater Plans 50th-Anniversary Gala
description: American Ballet Theater plans to celebrate its 50th anniversary with extended United States and international tours, a retrospective of the company's repertory, a ''Dance in America'' program for public television, and a touring exhibition of Ballet Theater memorabilia.

title: Mary Field Twombly, Teacher, 79
description: Mary Field Twombly, a former member of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee, which monitored patient care for the United Hospital Fund, died of Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at the Duncaster retirement community in Bloomfield, Conn., where she lived. She was 79 years old.

title: Memorial for Wien
description: A memorial for Lawrence A. Wien, the lawyer, real-estate investor and philanthropist who died Dec. 10, will be held tomorrow in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University at 2 P.M. Tributes will be offered by officials of Columbia, Brandeis University, the New York City Opera and Lincoln Center. Mr. Wien, who was 83 years old, was a major benefactor of the institutions.

title: 110 degrees Heats Kills Baby; Mother Is Charged
description: A 10-month-old boy died after the temperature in the Bronx apartment where he was sleeping reached 110 degrees, the police said yesterday. His mother, who had turned on a gas heater and then left the child unattended for about 12 hours, was charged with manslaughter.

title: Aspin Asks Long-Term Budget for Strategic Arms
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said today that to save taxpayers money and yet make military outlays more effective, all strategic weapons should be put on long-term budgets and their funds should be collectively frozen for 10 years.

title: SBE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Triton Lifts Stake In Fuqua to 9.9%
description: Triton Group Ltd., moving toward its goal of obtaining control of Fuqua Industries, increased its stake to 9.9 percent by exercising an option for 1.3 million shares owned by the Georgia company's founding chairman and largest shareholder, J. B. Fuqua, for $36 a share. Fuqua's stock rose $1.75 to close at $32 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Seton Hall Struggles Before Defeating Iona
description: The emotional reconstruction of the Seton Hall basketball team was supposed to begin with tonight's game with Iona. The Pirates figured to rout the Gaels and heal some of the wounds left from their embarrassing 90-66 loss to Syracuse last Saturday night.

title: Nuclear Plant Decision Is Limited
description: Experts on utility regulation said the Supreme Court's decision that utilities do not have a constitutional right to bill customers for the costs of unfinished plants had limited applicability to the scores of nuclear plants abandoned around the country.

title: A Student Calls for Harder Schools
description: A task force on youth held its first meeting here Tuesday and got a bit of a lecture from a high-school sophomore.

title: New Look for a Famed Hotel
description: The landmark Sheraton Palace Hotel, a home away from home for several Presidents and armies of celebrities since 1875, has closed for the first time since the great earthquake of 1906 for a $60 million, 18-month renovation.

title: Knicks' Long-Range Shooters Are on Target
description: The Bomb Squad is the name the Knicks' 3-point shooters have given themselves. The squad, made up of Mark Jackson, Gerald Wilkins, Trent Tucker, Rod Strickland and Johnny Newman, had been slumping lately.

title: Kollmorgen Will Get Offer From Vernitron
description: The Vernitron Corporation said yesterday that it would make a tender offer today for the Kollmorgen Corporation for $23 a share in cash, or about $294 million.

title: SHIITE WAR SPLITS SYRIANS AND IRAN
description: Bitter fighting between Shiite Muslim factions in Lebanon appears to have strained a decade-old alliance between Syria and Iran as a Teheran newspaper today waged a scathing attack against Damascus.

title: Replacing Giuliani: A Familiar List
description: Otto G. Obermaier, a top defense lawyer in New York, emerged yesterday as the leading candidate to succeed the United States Attorney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, people close to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said.

title: Winfield Case Likely to Center on Payment Dispute
description: If George Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield eventually meet in court to resolve questions regarding their contributions to the Yankee outfielder's charitable foundation, the case will likely focus on each person's obligations to meet his financial promises and on alleged misuse of funds by Winfield, not on allegations of loans from Winfield to a gambler.

title: TV Notes
description: Bilateral Dramas ''American Playhouse,'' which begins its eighth season on the Public Broadcasting Service next month, has agreed to co-produce two feature films with Soviet film makers this year. The films are to be released first in Soviet and American theaters, probably in 1990, and are to be shown on the PBS series at a later date, the executive producer of the series, Lindsay Law, said yesterday.

title: U.S. Suspends Teledyne Unit
description: The Defense Department said yesterday that it had suspended Teledyne Electronics, a division of Teledyne Inc., from doing work on Government contracts because the company was implicated in the Federal procurement fraud investigation.

title: Reagan's Economic Critics: Wrong
description: Everyone knows that the Reagan Administration's economic forecasts are always too optimistic, and this year is no exception, the pundits assure us. Real growth in 1989 of 3.5 percent? Inflation at only 3.7 percent? Go on, they scoff.

title: Banks Ask for Backing For Third World Loans
description: An organization representing 186 banks in 40 countries today called for changes in third world debt strategy, asking in particular for governments of creditor countries to guarantee bank lending to debtor nations.

title: Review/Piano; A Premiere for a Rarity: A Pasternak Sonata
description: Dmitry Rachmanov is a Soviet emigre pianist who has plenty of interesting musical ideas and a technique that is sizable, if not always foolproof. On Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, he played a recital of Russian music that included the American premiere of a recently discovered sonata by the author Boris Pasternak.

title: Stage Set for Congressional Battle With Elderly on Tax for Medicare
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee today all but ruled out changes in the new health insurance law covering catastrophic costs of major illness, setting the stage for a battle with groups protesting the surtax that older people must pay to finance it.

title: Arrest of Oil Union Chief in Mexico Sets Off Strike
description: Striking oil workers disrupted production throughout Mexico today, protesting the dramatic arrest of their longtime union leader. But their strike did not spread and there were signs that the bold step by the Government might pass without embroiling it in a national labor crisis.

title: The Hammer That Threw Bill Cosby
description: With the rubbery face that has turned Dr. Cliff Huxtable into a household name, Bill Cosby stared at his visitors.

title: U.S. Savings Official Quits
description: The president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, Kan., Kermit Mowbray, took early retirement last week, bank board officials said today.

title: Drexel Said To Pursue Shad for Job
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is negotiating with John S. R. Shad, seeking to persuade the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission to join the firm as chairman, people with knowledge of the talks said yesterday.

title: Fed Proposes Loan Rules
description: The Federal Reserve Board today proposed new rules requiring lenders to provide home equity loan borrowers with more information about the cost of such loans.

title: SFE Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $683,000. Sales represent net sales.

title: INSIDE
description: Birth Control Choices:

title: Where Farm Animals Are Living Antiques
description: AT Firestone Farm, a re-creation of a 19th-century sheep farm in Dearborn, Mich., the curators want everything to look as it did in 1882: the guides' costumes, the farming tools, the outbuildings. But finding old-fashioned sheep is not as easy as it sounds.

title: Save the Next Jessica Cortez
description: Who's to blame for the death of Jessica Cortez, an apparent victim of child abuse? Her mother and a companion have been indicted for second-degree murder. What remains a mystery is whether New York City agencies could have done more to protect the child. The mystery endures because of a state law requiring confidentiality. In this case, the law appears to do more harm than good.

title: U.S. Halts Navy Maneuvers That Libya Calls Provocative
description: The United States has canceled plans for naval fighters to hold aerial maneuvers near Libya next week, American diplomats said today.

title: Labor Backing Jackson Aide
description: Ronald H. Brown, a Washington lawyer who was the Rev. Jesse Jackson's convention manager, received a major boost today in his campaign to be chairman of the Democratic Party when he was endorsed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Bonn Relents Somewhat on U.S. Charges
description: West German officials indicated today that they were no longer ruling out that a German chemical company may have taken part in the outfitting of a Libyan plant that Washington says is intended for the manufacture of chemical weapons.

title: Bids for G.E.C. Put in Doubt
description: A possible hostile takeover bid for the General Electric Company, Britain's biggest manufacturing company, was put in doubt today.

title: London Journal; To Barricades! Bureaucrats Fault French Cuisine
description: For the last week a headline-grabbing confrontation has been unfolding in a London court that pits French gastronomy against British bureaucracy.

title: States Could Provide the Housing for Congress; Average Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: A Glance Outdoors Gives the Lie to 'the Dead of Winter'
description: THE conventional wisdom about a garden in winter, except in states like California and Florida, is that it is dead, or at best asleep. There is little to do in the garden and not much to see, unless you count the activity at the bird feeder.

title: More Icons of the 80's
description: To The Home Section:

title: Anti-Sandinistas Say U.S. Should End Embargo
description: Leaders of the political opposition in Nicaragua are virtually unanimous in urging the United States to end its four-year-old trade embargo against the Sandinista Government.

title: Bronx Kindergartner Shows Up With Loaded Gun
description: A 5-year-old kindergartner took a loaded .25-caliber pistol to school yesterday, and on orders from his teacher, handed it over, barrel first, as hundreds of pupils ate sandwiches, milk and cookies in a crowded cafeteria in the Bronx, officials said.

title: Canada Pork Imports Inquiry
description: The United States International Trade Commission said today that it was undertaking an investigation to determine whether imports of pork from Canada have injured United States producers.

title: Shadow of Talent Bank May Fall on Koch's Bid
description: The documents sat in an old file cabinet in Nydia Padilla-Barham's basement. She had been told to remove them from her office in the Mayor's Talent Bank in 1986, she told the State Commission on Government Integrity, but not to throw them out at City Hall.

title: Special Agency for Air Traffic Urged by Transportation Chief
description: Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley today proposed restructuring his department in a way that could lead to the establishment of a semiprivate organization to control the nation's air traffic.

title: City of Freeways Plants An Idea to Help Nature
description: If any city has a moral obligation to do something about global warming, this is it. And so today the city of angels and internal combustion took action.

title: Trip for His Workers Is a Dying Man's Gift
description: Francis Sennott, a business executive who died in October, left his employees something to remember him by: They are going to Hawaii next month.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Shoe-Town, a 250-store retail chain, to Solin Associates, with a budget exceeding $3.5 million.

title: Orion Pictures reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Prime Files Motion Against MAI Basic
description: Prime Computer Inc., which is facing a hostile $1.3 billion bid from MAI Basic Four Inc., filed a court motion contending that MAI Basic violated Federal Reserve Board margin requirements in arranging financing on its $20-a-share tender offer.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Tuesday, about Ellis Verdi & Partners, now called Follis & Verdi, misstated the budget of the account of the Financial Services Corporation of New York. It ranges from $100,000 to $200,000.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: St. Augustine Beach Journal; Even in a Sanctuary, the Birds Can Outstay Their Welcome
description: It was duck against woman, woman against duck, a desperate struggle best left to the police report, No. 88-241099-7-B, for description:

title: Starting Over, Once More With Style
description: THE piercing blue eyes in the 1964 portrait by Richard Avedon are clearly the same. So are the fair hair with the ruler-straight part and the meticulous bespoke clothing. With his feet up on a small English tray table in front of an 18th-century Venetian painted desk he has had since he was 22 years old, J. Allen Murphy, smoking one cigarette after another, looks relaxed and perfectly at home.

title: Among Europeans, Less Skepticism
description: As the international conference on chemical weapons adjourned, the Reagan Administration appeared today to have made considerable progress in convincing its Western European allies of its assertion that Libya is building a chemical-weapons plant.

title: Suffolk Video-Terminal Law Takes Effect Today
description: Despite a legal challenge, a landmark law that requires work breaks and special training for many operators of video display terminals in Suffolk County will go into effect today.

title: Precision Standard reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the latest quarter sales increase is due mostly to the September 1988 acquisition of Hayes International. The company said its latest quarter net income figure is attributable to the company's decision to write off non-recurring costs related to the acquisition.

title: Ogrin Lets Tournament Score Speak for Itself
description: The First Amendment to the Constitution does not really come into play for the golfers on the PGA Tour. Many pros, including such players as Mac O'Grady, J. C. Snead and David Graham, have paid the price for speaking their minds or writing what they believe. The going rate has been $1,000 or more in fines.

title: ROUND OF SELLING ENDS DOLLAR RALLY
description: A new, coordinated round of dollar selling by central banks, led by the Federal Reserve and the West German Bundesbank, stopped a new year's rally in the dollar yesterday.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about an imminent shortage of airline pilots misstated the number of flight hours required for an air transport pilot's license. It is 1,500.

title: Review/Television; Fighting for the Country That Seizes One's Family
description: ''The Color of Honor'' tells the story of the Japanese-American men who served in the United States Armed Forces in World War II, while other Americans of Japanese descent, including some of the soldiers' families, were being held in Government internment camps. The 90-minute documentary, at 9 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, is a tribute to the ''terrible choices and redeeming courage'' of people who were treated shamefully by their country.

title: Review/Television; 'Reality' Rears Its Head in New Shows
description: In an unusually busy week for new series and formats, ''reality'' programs and public-affairs projects have been competing for attention with the celebrity-laden talk shows. In syndication, ''Inside Edition'' -being locally broadcast weeknights at 7:30 on Channel 4 - is still another electronic tabloid exercise, this one featuring David Frost as anchor. And on Channel 13, ''The 11th Hour,'' presented nightly at 11 with Robert Lipsyte as host, is trying to provide metropolitan-area viewers with perspective on everything from crack and crumbling tenements to art and architecture.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A New Start In Direct Marketing
description: TOSS a marketing dollar in the air these days and the breeze is likely to waft it away from large advertising agencies and toward small sales-promotion companies or Yellow Pages specialists.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: APPLYING fresh paint to walls and ceilings is one of the most common home-improvement projects that amateurs undertake. The experience is often marred by dismay at the mess created and sometimes even with the results. But thorough preparation of rooms and surfaces to be painted can usually prevent both disappointments.

title: Lord & Taylor to Bolster Presence in New Jersey
description: Lord & Taylor, the New York-based fashion chain that has been expanding rapidly around the nation in recent years, will soon have a stronger presence in New Jersey.

title: Shopping for the 'Right' Summer Camp
description: WHEN Barbara Wagner was shipped off to summer camp as a 10-year-old, she hated it so much that her parents had to whisk her back home before the end of the session.

title: British Order Inspections
description: Britain's Civil Aviation Authority today ordered British airlines to increase inspections on engines similar to those on the Boeing 737-400 aircraft that crashed Sunday and said the inspections would continue until the precise cause of the accident was determined.

title: Penny Wise, Tax Foolish
description: There's a lot of wishful thinking in every Presidential budget, and even more when the President is about to leave office. Now President Reagan proposes that the Internal Revenue Service charge a fee for the phone-in tax help it currently provides free. The I.R.S. could save time and expense by ditching the plan after Mr. Reagan leaves town.

title: Designcraft Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago 9 months included a gain of $1,990,000 on the sale of the company's New York City office building. The shares have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend distributed in September 1987.

title: HEALTH: Birth Control; For Those Concerned With Pill's Risk, a Look at the Choices
description: With new studies hinting that birth control pills may be linked to an increased risk of breast cancer, many women and doctors are taking a closer look than ever at contraceptive choices, weighing the risks and benefits of the various methods.

title: 'Black and Blue' Sets Date
description: ''Black and Blue,'' the jazz-and-blues revue at the Minskoff Theater, has rescheduled its opening for Jan. 26. The opening was delayed from Jan. 15 because of the illness of one of its stars, Ruth Brown. Previews are continuing in her absence. Until Ms. Brown returns, some of her material will be performed by Dakota Staton.

title: When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. Calvet armchair by the Catalan architect Antoni Gaudi dates from 1904. B. Ceccotti armchair, 1988, is by Roberto Lazzeroni and Allessandro Celleno, two Italian designers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; B.S.B.W. Names Backer President
description: William M. Backer, the author of ''It's the real thing'' for Coca-Cola and the mastermind of the ''Tastes great/less filling'' campaign for Miller Lite beer, has been elected president and worldwide creative director of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide.

title: Circon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Manning to Miss Season Because of Knee Injury
description: The Los Angeles Clippers' worst fears about Danny Manning's injured right knee were realized yesterday. ''I am 95 percent cerain that the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee is torn,'' said Dr. Tony Daly, the team physician, after studying computer-enhanced X-rays. ''The degree to which it is torn will have to be determined through diagnostic arthroscopic surgery.'' Reconstructive surgery on the knee could sideline Manning, the league's No. 1 draft choice, for the rest of the season and possibly longer. Manning was injured last Wednesday at Milwaukee. The 22-year-old forward said he ''heard a snap'' when he landed stiff-legged after making a layup. ''He will come back from this injury,'' Daly said last night. ''Realistically, the general rule is one year, but it's all generalized. Will he be 100 percent? That's open to question. Maybe he'll be at about 90 percent when he comes back, but 90 percent of Danny Manning is a lot better than 100 percent of most N.B.A. players. His age is greatly in his favor, but he still will lose some of the explosiveness in his right leg, some of his quickness and his cutting ability.'' (AP)

title: Rockwell Ends Bid To Buy Eaton Unit
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it had ended negotiations about purchasing a troubled Eaton Corporation unit that makes electronic jamming equipment for Rockwell's B-1B bomber.

title: 4 Customs Workers Are Among 14 Held In Drug Crackdown
description: Federal agents yesterday arrested 14 people, four of them Customs Service employees, in a crackdown on drug trafficking at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Merrill Lynch Names Official
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said this week that it had named Christopher Reeves, formerly deputy chairman of Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., as chairman of its Merrill Lynch Europe and Middle East unit. The appointment was made last month. Mr. Reeves resigned from

title: U.S. RAISES QUOTA OF SOVIET REFUGEES BY CUTTING ASIANS'
description: President Reagan has decided to increase the number of Soviet refugees who can come to the United States this year by 39 percent, to a total of 25,000, and will offset the change by reducing the number of places reserved for Southeast Asian refugees, Administration officials said today.

title: Automotive Industries reports earnings for Year to Oct 1
description: b-After a income tax benefit of $879,000. The company said comparable figures for fiscal 1987 are not available; the 1987 figures only include results from Dec. 18, 1986 (the company's date of incorporation) through Oct. 3, 1987. The company reported net income of $224,087, or 17 cents a share, during that period, on revenue of $31,085,225. The shares outstanding totaled 1,338,794.

title: Incentives Extended By Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company extended its buyer-incentive programs today and offered some through low-rate financing and cash rebates.

title: Canadiens Tough to Beat at Home, but Devils Try
description: The Devils and the Canadiens played hockey tonight the way it should be, fast end-to-end action with no fights, crisp and accurate passing and inspired goaltending from both teams.

title: Diamond Trade Spurts
description: Belgium's diamond trade, the world's largest, reported a 27 percent gain in business last year, to 461.5 billion francs ($12.5 billion), the industry said on Tuesday. The country's diamond sales rose 25 percent, to 229.6 billion francs ($6.2 billion), while imports climbed 30 percent, to 231.9 billion francs ($6.3 billion).

title: Jorge Bolet Cancels
description: Because of illness, Jorge Bolet has canceled a piano recital on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. He is to be replaced by John Browning. A Carnegie Hall appearance by Mr. Bolet, scheduled for Wednesday at 8 P.M., has been rescheduled for April 16 at 8 P.M. Brooklyn Center information: (718) 434-1900. Carnegie Hall information: 247-7800.

title: Two Pipelines Get Approval
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission gave initial approval today to two pipeline projects that developers hope will bring Canadian natural gas to the Northeast by 1991. In a unanimous vote, the

title: Now, the Hard Part on Poison Gas
description: Ridding the world of chemical weapons, George Bush declared in his campaign for the White House, would be a topmost priority of his Presidency. With two very small steps this week in Paris and in Bonn, the Reagan Administration has pushed matters along. It's now up to Mr. Bush to overcome the still- substantial obstacles to a new and tougher treaty banning the scourge of chemical war.

title: Nu Horizons Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Washington Talk: Diplomacy; What Makes Washington Tick? Ask a Canadian
description: When Allan E. Gotlieb arrived here seven years ago as Ambassador from Canada, he labored under some misconceptions. Among them, he recalled, was the impression that there was a single point of power in Washington: the Presidency. He soon learned that a diplomat must also pay a great deal of attention to Congress.

title: Hungary Eases Dissent Curbs
description: Hungary paved the way for political opposition to the Communist authorities today when Parliament voted to allow independent parties and public demonstrations.

title: Sensible Modesty in New Jersey
description: Gov. Thomas Kean's final New Jersey State of the State Message this week was notable mainly for its modesty, both for the few initiatives proposed and for the demands they would place on the budget. The modesty is a tribute to the Governor's sense of political realism and the prospect of growing revenue shortfalls.

title: German Growth in '88 Is Put at 3.4%, Exceeding Forecasts
description: The West German economy defied the gloomy forecasts of a year ago to post its strongest growth since 1979, according to provisional figures on 1988 performance released today by the Federal Statistics Office.

title: P.&G. Plans to Add $1 Billion To Its Employee Stock Plan
description: In the largest action of its kind to date, the Procter & Gamble Company announced yesterday that it would add $1 billion to its employee stock ownership plan in a move that will provide substantial tax benefits and offer a shield against a hostile takeover.

title: As a City's Wealth Grows, So Does Its Drug Problem
description: Some big-city problems have infiltrated this compact community of 45,000 people on the banks of the Connecticut River. Caught in a local eddy of the nationwide flood of cocaine, the Middletown police last year saw the number of drug arrests climb to 227, more than double the previous year's total.

title: National Mercantile Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflected 10 percent stock dividend paid in August.

title: Continental to Buy 6 Eastern Planes
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it was planning to sell six of its A300 airplanes to Continental Airlines for $170 million to provide cash for its operations. The carrier, which has been losing money and traffic in recent months, said the transaction would not reduce the size of its fleet because the planes have been on lease to Continental since mid-1987.

title: Household to Quit Manufacturing
description: In a major restructuring, Household International Inc. said today that it would leave the manufacturing business and return to its roots - providing financial services to individuals and small businesses.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Lofty View of a Pole
description: What, one may well ask, do public television, hot air balloons and Tadeusz Andrzej Bonawentura Kosciuszko have in common?

title: Green to Reassign 348 Headquarters Workers
description: Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green yesterday presented the latest phase of his plan to reduce the size of the central Board of Education staff, reassigning 348 employees to local districts.

title: Stock Units Are Opposed
description: A representative of some of the nation's leading institutional investors has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to reject a New York Stock Exchange proposal that would allow companies listed on the Big Board to break their stock into a package of new securities that have come to be known as ''unbundled stock units.''

title: Battleground Of Mexicans; President Takes Aim At the Unions' Power
description: With the dramatic arrest Tuesday of the powerful leader of Mexico's Oil Workers' Union, the long-simmering feud between President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and the country's restless labor unions has erupted into virtual open warfare.

title: Israel Court Rebuffs Army Censor
description: The High Court has overturned an Israeli military censor's ban for the first time, allowing the publication of criticism of the head of the Mossad intelligence agency.

title: After 9 Months of Delays, U.S. Tries 3 for Sedition
description: Nine months after lawyers began jury selection, opening arguments have begun in the trial of avowed revolutionaries that has already cost the Government millions of dollars.

title: With a Firm Hand, Warping Can Be Fixed
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH some woods are more stable than others, most tend to warp unless braced from the start. For example, a table top secured to its base might not warp, while its leaves might.

title: Review/Dance; Women With Whimsy
description: Womanworks, a two-week modern-dance series devoted to female choreographers, got under way Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater with two experimental troupes. The first was Sally Silvers and Performers. The second was Yoshiko Chuma/The School of Hard Knocks, which incorporated some of Miss Chuma's recent students from the Netherlands.

title: Sri Lanka's New President To End State of Emergency''
description: President Ranasinghe Premadasa of Sri Lanka promised today that the five-and-a-half-year-long state of emergency would be lifted at midnight, providing for the release of hundreds of political prisoners, a Government spokesman said.

title: Jersey Is Moving Cautiously Against Accused Polluter
description: New Jersey authorities are moving cautiously against a barge company accused of dumping ''mind-boggling'' amounts of hazardous wastes into New Jersey and New York waterways, for fear of driving the company, a major disposer of sewage sludge for the metropolitan region, out of business.

title: U.S. ORDERS CHECKS ON 300 JETLINERS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration instructed United States airlines tonight to inspect 300 Boeing aircraft within 72 hours to make sure that their engine warning systems and monitoring circuits are not flawed.

title: Soviets Seen Retiring Warsaw Pact Chief
description: The Soviet leadership has decided to replace Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, the Warsaw Pact military commander in chief, as part of a shake-up tied to cutbacks in the armed forces, Soviet and Western officials say.

title: Scientists Find A Fault in Earth At Atomic Plant
description: A previously unknown fault in the ancient rock layers beneath the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina has been detected and mapped by geologists, the Energy Department announced today.

title: Tale of a Soviet Cap and a Missing Flight Recorder
description: First the flight recorder from an American missile was missing. Then a few empty vodka bottles and a Soviet sailor's cap turned up on a remote South Pacific beach where there were not supposed to be any Russian seamen.

title: Rights Group Criticizes U.S. Over Refugees in Indochina
description: A human rights group has asserted in a report on Indochinese refugees that United States immigration and screening procedures are unfair. It also criticized Thailand, along with Malaysia and Hong Kong, for trying to shift the burden of asylum elsewhere through harsh policies toward refugees.

title: Chip Orders Behind Sales
description: After a small rise in November, the semiconductor industry's leading indicator dropped in December, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported increased sales but decreased orders, a trade group reported Tuesday.

title: Hubco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year results included a non- recurring after-tax gain of $400,157, or 10 cents per share, from the sale of an office and an after-tax loss on the sale of securities of $143,773. The 1987 per share earnings results reflected a 5 percent stock dividend paid Nov. 18, 1988.

title: 'The Heidi Chronicles' Moving to Broadway
description: ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' the Wendy Wasserstein play featuring Joan Allen that is now at Playwrights Horizons, is to move to the Plymouth Theater on Broadway next month. It will finish its run - the rest of which is sold out - at Playwrights Horizons on Feb. 19 and begin performances at the Plymouth on Feb. 28.

title: Independent Bank Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Principal, Not Partner
description: With one lawyer for every 22 residents, the District of Columbia may have the highest density for the profession in the United States.

title: Hickory Dickory Dine
description: ''IT'S called Restaurant 10-10,'' explained Jean-Pierre Heim, ''because that's always the time when photographers take pictures of clocks and watches.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. Berkeley Heights, N.J., said its microelectronics unit planned to make a new version of its 32-bit floating-point semiconductor that would cut the chip's cost by 65 percent.

title: Dispute Seen as Threat to Arms Talks
description: A last-minute dispute between Greece and Turkey threatens the completion of an East-West agreement that would open the way to new talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe, State Department officials said today.

title: John Allston Sargent, Executive, 79
description: John Allston Sargent, a retired executive and former chief financial officer of the General Dynamics Corporation, died of a stroke Monday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 79 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; New Winds on Trade
description: In what promises to be a somewhat quieter year for trade legislation, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, is taking over as chairman of the Trade Subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee from Senator Spark M. Matsunaga, Democrat of Hawaii.

title: Latshaw Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
PARIS CONFERENCE CONDEMNS THE USE OF CHEMICAL ARMS
description: Diplomats from more than 140 nations today condemned the use of chemical weapons and called for a stepped-up effort to complete a treaty banning the development, production and possession of such weapons.

title: Quiet Figure in the Dispute Over Koch's Talent Bank
description: He is the quiet man with the dark eyebrows who stands with a knowing smile in the back of the room at his boss's news conferences, or who buttonholes officials intently in the corridors of City Hall. He has endured more than a few public putdowns from his patron, yet remains his friend and adviser, even when his advice goes unheeded.

title: Bills' Star Investigated
description: Bruce Smith, the Buffalo Bills' All-Pro defensive end, was followed for three weeks in November by private investigators hired by the Bills because of concerns about drug abuse, according to a published report. The Buffalo News, citing police sources, reported Tuesday that the Bills had off-duty detectives follow Smith and watch his home. The detectives, it was said, were hired after Smith was suspended for the first four games of the 1988 season for a violation of the National Football League's substance-abuse policy. The Bills' general manager, Bill Polian, denied the report, saying the Bills did not have anyone follow Smith or any other player. Late Tuesday, Hamburg's police chief confirmed that some of his detectives had been hired by the Bills to follow Smith. ''It wasn't our idea,'' said Mathew Czerwiec, the chief. ''It was the Bills organization that wanted this done.'' (AP)

title: A Debt Swap To Aid Nature
description: The American Express Company has completed the largest private ''debt for nature'' swap to date in conjunction with the Nature Conservancy, a Washington-based land conservation group. Such a swap supports conservation at the same time that it enables a nation to reduce its foreign debt and a bank to get troubled loans off its books permanently.

title: Security for Connecticut Bills
description: Bill boxes outfitted with combination locks to foil would-be thieves at the new Legislative Office Building here work so well that they even keep out their owners.

title: Council Is an Issue in Chicago Mayoral Race
description: Not for the first time, a group of civic and business leaders complained here this week that the Chicago City Council was a bloated and wasteful body interested in government mainly for the spoils it offers.

title: Rising Rents Threaten Theater Companies
description: A study prepared by an association of Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway nonprofit theaters in New York City has found that rising rents are endangering the theaters' future and could force many of them to leave the city.

title: Hearing Is Set In GAF Trial
description: A Federal appeals court is scheduled to hold a hearing this morning to decide whether to halt the criminal stock manipulation trial of the GAF Corporation and a senior executive.

title: Chrysler May Raise Capital Spending
description: The Chrysler Corporation is considering raising its capital spending goal for the next five years to $14.1 billion to pay for new and redesigned products, the trade publication Metalworking News said today. Chrysler officials were not immediately available for comment on the report.

title: Israeli Jets Raid Bases in Lebanon
description: Israeli planes tonight bombed bases of the Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal, the police said.

title: China Buys More Wheat
description: Private exporters have sold an additional 360,000 metric tons of United States wheat to China at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday. Melvin E. Sims, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat was part of one million tons authorized for China on Dec. 30 under the Export Enhancement Program. Under the arrangement, exporters can sell designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices to meet foreign competition. Exporters then collect free Government surpluses of grain as subsidies.

title: McCormick & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included gains on the sales of property of $900,000, or 4 cents a share, for the latest year and $3.8 million, or 16 cents a share, for 1987. The latest year also included a gain of $6.4 million from the cumulative effect on prior years of accounting change for deferred tax liability.

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $12,216,000. c-Included loss from discontinued operations of $4,405,000 and a gain of $3,353,000 from an accounting change.

title: Amtech Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $94,000 and $193,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $32,000 for the quarter and $127,000 for the year. The company said results are adjusted to reflect a 1-for-20 reverse stock split in April 1988.

title: Tubs of Sawdust and Enzymes To Soothe Flagging Spirits
