description: LEAD: NO longer content to soak in hot tubs, seekers of rejuvenation here claim to have found an elixir in a hot, fermenting concoction of sawdust, rice bran and enzyme powder in which they steep neck-deep for up to 20 minutes at a time.

title: In Uruguay, Immunity Repeal Has Wide Support
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Surgeon General Rebukes Tobacco Industry Over Combative Ads
description: C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, criticized the tobacco industry today for advertisements in many newspapers that maintain that smokers are a put-upon group and that ''enough is enough!''

title: Adtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Smuggling Pop LP's Out of the U.S.S.R., Thanks to McCartney
description: Not long ago, music fans in the Soviet Union had to search the black market for European and American pop recordings and pay exorbitant prices for them. But now, for once, the tables have been turned.

title: Laker Road Is Paved With Losses
description: The headline in the Los Angeles Times read: ''Lakers' Road Streak Reaches 8 in Sacramento.''

title: Lloyd's Stand On Liability
description: Lloyd's of London, which prides itself on having never failed to settle an insurance claim, said today that it would maintain its policy of unlimited liability.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alexander's Inc., the department store chain, elected Leon Peck executive vice president, finance, succeeding William H. Pavony, who left the company. It also named Brian M. Kurtz senior vice president and controller.

title: Personal Health
description: Chances are that as soon as wisdom teeth begin struggling to emerge, a dentist will recommend that they come out. But should they?

title: Calvin DeWitt Jr., 94, Brigadier General
description: Brig. Gen. Calvin DeWitt Jr., a career Army officer who commanded the New York Port of Embarcation after World War II, died Tuesday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 94 years old.

title: Suspect in Slaying Was Treated at Bellevue
description: The homeless man charged in the murder of a pregnant doctor at Bellevue Hospital Center was hospitalized there for nine days last month after he told doctors that he had swallowed rat poison in an attempt to kill himself, according to officials familiar with his case records.

title: Kimball Pleads Guilty In a Surprise Decision
description: As testimony began today in his drunken-driving manslaughter trial, Bruce Kimball, the 1984 Olympic diver, switched his plea to guilty, admitting that he drove into a crowd of teen-agers last summer, killing two and injuring four others.

title: Volt Information Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included a gain of $5,355,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle for income taxes. c-After an extraordinary charge of $3,165,000 related to the early redemption of debentures.

title: Bush Pledges Angola Rebel Aid
description: President-elect George Bush has written to Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader, offering ''all appropriate and effective assistance'' during the Bush Administration.

title: RSI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago figures are restated.

title: Heldor Industries reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,024,000 and a $970,000 extraordinary credit from the settlement of its business interruption insurance claim which arose from the spa plant fire in 1986.

title: Soviets Say Foreigners Will Need AIDS Certificates
description: The Soviet Government said today that it would require foreigners planning to stay here for longer than three months to present a certificate showing they do not carry the AIDS virus, starting Feb. 1.

title: N.F.L. Plan Announced
description: National Football League owners yesterday approved unanimously a free-agency plan the league will put into effect Feb. 1 unless an agreement is negotiated with the players' union. The original plan allowed the 10 playoff teams to protect 40 players, the next 10 teams to protect 42 and the 8 teams with the worst records to protect 44. John Jones, a spokesman for the Management Council, said he did not think the numbers in the revised plan would change much and estimated that the 28 N.F.L. teams average 59 players per team. Management and the union have operated without a labor agreement since Aug. 31, 1987. ''We fully expected them to make this announcement today,'' said Dick Berthelsen, general counsel for the N.F.L. Players Association. Under the plan, teams can protect a certain number of players, but those above the limit would be free to negotiate with any N.F.L. team between Feb. 1 and April 1. (AP)

title: States Could Provide the Housing for Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Circles Take Fresh Look At Proposals on Health Insurance
description: In another sign of growing concern about the financing of health care, The New England Journal of Medicine has published two alternative plans for universal health insurance. One plan was proposed by a nationwide group of physicians and the other by an economist at Stanford University.

title: South Africa Moves to Curb 3 More Journals
description: The South African Government signaled its intention today to suspend three anti-apartheid publications under censorship laws.

title: Investment Firm Started
description: Peter R. Fink, who resigned as president and chief executive of the R. P. Scherer Corporation in November after losing a proxy fight against his estranged wife and other heirs of the company founder who want to sell, said Tuesday that he had started his own investment company. The Quantum Corporation, of which Mr. Fink is president, may make an offer to buy Scherer, a gelatin capsule manufacturer, Mr. Fink said. But he added that Quantum was not established specifically to buy Scherer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15 More Russians can come to the U.S., President Reagan has decided. This 39 percent increase will be offset by reducing the number of places reserved for Southeast Asian refugees. Page A1

title: KEY RATES
Jole Veneziani, Designer, 87
description: Jole Veneziani, an Italian clothing designer, died Tuesday at her home in Milan. She was 87 years old.

title: Sound Warehouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
More Punished in Marine's Death
description: The Marine Corps punished more officers today for abandoning a 19-year old lance corporal in the California desert, where he died last summer.

title: High Court Rejects Charges by Utilities For Unused Plants
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution does not guarantee utility companies the right to recover the costs of uncompleted or abandoned power plants.

title: American Nursery Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Text of the Declaration From the Paris Conference on Chemical Weapons
description: Following is the official text of the declaration issued today at the end of the international conference on chemical weapons:

title: Angry Drivers Win Victory, of Sorts
description: The suggestion by Gov. Thomas H. Kean on Tuesday that New Jersey scrap its no-fault insurance system marked a victory of sorts for a guerrilla campaign of angry motorists who have struck fear into the hearts of politicians here in an election year.

title: Review/Music; From a Popularity Contest
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center handed over the stage of Alice Tully Hall this weekend to its resident string quartet, the Emerson, for a program that included two works from the society's Subscribers' Choice list of 20 chamber favorites, and the world premiere of Richard Danielpour's Piano Quintet.

title: Dow Closes Above 2,200, Rising 13.22
description: LEAD: After dancing around it for several sessions, the Dow Jones industrial average finally closed above the 2,200 level yesterday, reaching another post-crash high.

title: Single Mothers: Making It Their Way
description: LEAD: THIS television season has been filled with images of single professional women thinking about having children on their own: Melissa, the spiky-haired photographer of ''Thirtysomething,'' considered it. So did Murphy, the egotistical television journalist of ''Murphy Brown.'' J. C., the successful executive of ''Baby Boom,'' has been raising a child on her own, and it looks pretty much of a snap.

title: Article 765189 -- No Title
description: The parents of a boy struck and killed by a teen-age driver who had attended an ''all you can drink'' graduation party will receive $600,000 in settlement of their lawsuit against the couple who were hosts of the affair.

title: Powerful Chip Due From Intel
description: The Intel Corporation is preparing to provide details of an extremely powerful new chip for the microprocessor business.

title: 1% OF EMPLOYEES TESTED FOR DRUGS
description: Despite intense publicity about the magnitude of the nation's drug problem, less than 1 percent of the nation's workers were subjected to drug tests by their employers from the summer of 1987 to the summer of 1988, the Labor Department said today.

title: Review/Music; 44th Street Boogie-Woogie
description: Harry Connick Jr., a 21-year-old singer and pianist from New Orleans, brought an aura of backroom honky-tonk to the normally staid Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, on Tuesday evening as he opened a four-week engagement there.

title: Jesse Jackson Gains Backers
description: Five African leaders support the movement by some American blacks to call themselves African-American, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today at the end of a 16-day tour of Africa.

title: Review/Music; Happy Sounds, Dissonantly
description: The Americas Society, which pro-motes cultural interchange between hemispheres, offered an evening of music by the Mexican-American composer Max Lifchitz at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening. Mr. Lifchitz, who holds academic posts in Albany and New York City, writes a busy, rhythmically active, upbeat-sounding kind of music in a dissonant idiom.

title: Regan Agrees To a Shift On Pensions
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Comptroller have agreed on a plan to help New York State close its budget gap by lowering the state's contribution to its pension fund by about $600 milllion over the next year.

title: Westerbeke Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Fine-Tuning for First Nationwide
description: The First Nationwide Financial Corporation's name has long been more an expression of its desire to expand than a reflection of its actual operations.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; They Also Serve
description: There was an unusual ceremony Wednesday honoring a Foreign Service wife, Emily Vest. She was given a ''tribute of appreciation'' and a plaque by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who said of her four decades of service to the country, ''You have represented America with distinction.''

title: Vermont Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings were adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend to be paid Jan. 25.

title: Michael V. Forrestal Dies at 61; A Lawyer and Ex-U.S. Official
description: Michael V. Forrestal, an international lawyer and former Government official who frequently served as an intermediary seeking to improve relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, died of a ruptured aneurysm Wednesday. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Finalists at Columbia
description: Walt Hameline, caoch at Wagner, and Ray Tellier, coach at Rochester, are the finalists to succeed Larry McElreavy as head football coach at Columbia, several sources told The Associated Press yesterday. Hameline, who led Wagner to the Division III title in 1987, and Tellier each declined comment except to say he wanted the job. Al Paul, Columbia's athletic director, wouldn't comment on the search. (AP)

title: NERVE GAS SCHEME STOPPED IN JERSEY
description: A Short Hills businessman was arrested today by Customs Service agents and charged with participating in a conspiracy to buy and export 125 tons of an illegal nerve gas for $5 million.

title: Facing a Big Job With Limited Tools
description: President-elect Bush's choice for Secretary of Energy is being asked to lead one of the most complex and expensive environmental and rebuilding programs in history with only a fraction of the financial resources experts have said are needed to complete the work.

title: Last Mob at Maxwell's Plum Bids on Glass and Menagerie
description: Jennifer Carter returned yesterday to the restaurant where, way back in 1976, she met the man she married. This time she did not get what she wanted.

title: Coin Savers Help the Neediest
description: Elizabeth Kellerman of Douglaston, Queens, has embarked on a personal mission to keep the Little Neck Bay shorefront free of litter, going out daily to pick up cast-off cans and bottles. Then as a double good deed, she sent the refunds on the cans and bottles, amounting to $100, to The New York Time Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Met-Coil Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Art and Conscience Mix In King Observances
description: There are some who argue that art and politics do not mix well, and some who insist that art unsupported by a political conscience is meaningless. But there have always been statesmen whose principles have inspired not only those artists who see their work as part of a social force, but also those who prefer to think of art in more abstract ways.

title: Review/Film; 'Sucka,' a Sendup
description: A decade and a half after their heyday, the grand old men of the blaxploitation genre can be heard complaining about their bunions in ''I'm Gonna Git You Sucka,'' a cheerful and gag-filled (though not terribly sharp-toothed) sendup that actually owes less to blaxploitation than to the anything-goes humor of the ''Airplane!'' school. However, the film assembles enough shiny suits, swaggering tough guys and choice bits of early-70's memorabilia to recall the form in all its glory. The plot is even set in motion by a death that the police term ''a case of just too many gold chains.''

title: A Smetana Opera
description: The Bronx Opera Company is presenting Bedrich Smetana's ''Secret'' at the Hunter College Playhouse, 68th Street at Lexington Avenue, tonight at 8. The principals include Lori Phillips, a soprano; Lori-Carol Brown, a mezzo-soprano; John Vergilii, a tenor, and Mark Johnson, a baritone. Michael Spierman, the company's artistic director, will conduct. The opera will also be performed tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $11 to $13. Information: 787-1356.

title: Electro Rent Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Luciano Berio Speaks of Virtuosos and Strings
description: For 30 years Luciano Berio has cultivated, alongside his ambitious and once-controversial works for the stage and concert hall, a special genre of solo music that he calls the ''sequenza'' (sequence). Each one is a short but substantial unaccompanied virtuoso work, theatrical and full of contrast, usually exploiting unconventional playing techniques.

title: Review/Film; In a Wet And Scary Place
description: Even the fish lack personality in ''Deepstar Six,'' a film that makes the exotic undersea world not much more interesting than the average bedroom closet. ''Deepstar Six'' is supposed to take place six miles beneath the ocean's surface, but in fact it unfolds on a drab, colorless command-module movie set where the blinking lights on the control panels don't even blink very well.

title: Marietta Names Head Of Its Space Venture
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday named Edward M. Browne to lead its commercial space venture.

title: Housing Street People Better, Cheaper
description: Shelter number 1 offers hundreds of beds on the noisy, open floor of an armory. Privacy is impossible and there are too few security guards to assure personal safety. The most fragile homeless street people, the mentally ill, shrink from such a place.

title: Bear Stearns Has Record Profits in Quarter
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that the quarter just ended was the most profitable in its history and announced that it planned to buy back 4 million of its shares outstanding.

title: McDonald's Notes Total $100 Million
description: The McDonald's Corporation is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent notes due in 1999 at 99.575 to yield 9.817 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Town & Country Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Excerpts From News Session by Bush, Watkins and Bennett
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President-elect George Bush's news conference with Adm. James D. Watkins and William J. Bennett in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News: OPENING STATEMENTS George Bush

title: Marine Officer Charged in Death
description: The Marine Corps said today that an officer had been formally charged in the case of a lance corporal who was abandoned and died in the California desert last summer and that technicalities had been cleared away so that courts-martial of two sergeants could proceed.

title: Drexel Talking to Shad on Chairman's Job
description: In addition to trying to persuade John S. R. Shad, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to become its chairman, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is trying to recruit another former S.E.C. chairman as a director.

title: Hinson and Nets Miss Their Big Shot
description: There were 18 seconds remaining in tonight's game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Nets trailed the Boston Celtics by a point. And Roy Hinson, New Jersey's forward, had the ball exactly where he wanted it: 12 feet from the basket in the lane.

title: Whittle Chief Executive Announces Resignation
description: Nicholas Glover, president and chief executive of Whittle Communications, announced his resignation yesterday after five years at the Knoxville, Tenn., publishing partnership he helped to build. Time Inc. bought a 50 percent interest in the company last month for $185 million, with provisions to increase its stake over the next five years.

title: No Headline
description: Alain Chevalier resigned today as chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the apparent loser in a bitter board-room power struggle with Bernard Arnault, the largest shareholder.

title: Utah Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bomb Suspect's Driver Says He Was Informer
description: A man who has acknowledged driving an animal-rights advocate armed with a bomb to the headquarters of the United States Surgical Corporation last November now says he was a paid informer cooperating with the company and the police.

title: Bellevue Slaying: Gaps in Mental Care
description: The arrest of a homeless man with a history of psychiatric illness in the murder of a pregnant doctor at Bellevue Hospital Center reflects a failure by New York City and State agencies to concentrate mental-health services on the most seriously ill, mental health care experts say.

title: BB&T Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sorg Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $58,000 and $145,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Canadiens Top Bruins
description: Stephane Richer scored one goal and assisted on two others tonight as the Montreal Canadiens continued their domination of Boston with a 5-3 victory over the Bruins.

title: Brazil High-Speed Train
description: Brazil has announced plans to introduce Latin America's first high-speed train. The train, which will exceed 132 miles an hour, will reduce the travel time between the country's two main cities, Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, to two hours, the authorities said. The cities are 280 miles apart.

title: KEY RATES
What's Cooking in Park Slope; Strolling Seventh Avenue With Food in Mind
description: As the gentrification of Park Slope in Brooklyn continues, its major commercial artery, Seventh Avenue, is experiencing dramatic change. Small ethnic groceries and storefront service businesses are fast giving way to specialty grocers, upscale carryouts, wine shops, bars and trendy restaurants - from bagels to brioche, so to speak.

title: TV Production Unit Set Up
description: The Republic Pictures Corporation and United Artists Communications Inc. have formed a joint venture to develop and produce television programs and have committed $60 million in the next five years to support it.

title: Angola Says Rebels Still Hold Border in Southeast
description: Five months after South Africa and Angola agreed to jointly patrol Namibia's border, a 300-mile gap remains under the control of Angolan rebels supplied by South Africa, an Angolan Army officer asserted here today.

title: Liberty National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
At the MoviesLawrence Van Gelder
description: Writing Movies Not content with a formidable reputation as a novelist and short-story writer, Joyce Carol Oates is off on what she calls ''a delightful excursion into another dimension.''

title: Books of The Times; Bob Shacochis's Stories of Dreamers Who Are Seeking a New World
description: The Next New World By Bob Shacochis 209 pages. Crown Publishers. $16.95.

title: First Federal of Michigan reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $972,000, net of tax, from the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss d-After extraordinary losses of $7,961,000 for the quarter and $3,224,000 for the year.

title: Miami Upsets Kansas on Foul Shot With 2 Seconds to Play
description: Joel Warren made a foul shot with two seconds remaining for his only point of the game tonight and Miami upset No. 16 Kansas, 87-86, ending the Jayhawks' 11-game winning streak.

title: Pity the Serfs at Our Medieval Universities
description: Universities glory in the study of feudalism, but where they truly excel is in the practice of it.

title: Seeking Audiences Unafraid to Laugh
description: ''VOLTAIRE once said that God is a comedian; it's just that His audience is afraid to laugh,'' said Steve Kaplan, the artistic director of Manhattan Punch Line Theater.

title: First Illinois Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Silicon Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amity Bank, Woodbridge, Conn., which is owned by Amity Bancorp, New Haven, said Joseph V. Ciaburri had been elected president and chief executive of both the bank and the parent company.

title: More Comedy USA
description: Funny men tell no jokes in the new 64-page directory of comedians just published by Barry Weintraub. Instead, their names lie on the page, waiting to be plucked by casting directors and promotions organizers. Mr. Weintraub is a 28-year-old entrepreneur whose previous ventures include Comedy USA, a semiannual magazine distributed at some 300 comedy clubs around the nation, and Comedy USA Newswire, a trade journal. His latest publication lists 640 comedians available for commercials, promotions and shows, as well as the firms representing them. Mr. Weintraub's company, Comedy USA Productions, is at 915 Broadway, Suite 1100, New York, N.Y. 10010.

title: Knicks Turn Up Defense And Roll Past Hornets
description: In the same way the Hornets have awakened fans in Charlotte, N.C., to becoming a part of the National Basketball Association, they put the crowd to sleep in the second half last night at Madison Square Garden in a 106-89 loss to the Knicks.

title: Meridian National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $117,000, or 3 cents a share. The latest periods' results included those of National Metal Conversion Co., a 50 percent owned partnership that began operations in December 1987.

title: What to See and Hear
description: The Brooklyn Museum is presenting these exhibitions, talks and concerts, all free with the suggested admission of $3 for adults, $1.50 for students and $1 for the elderly. The museum, at 200 Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue, is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily except Tuesday. Information: (718) 638-5000. Today GALLERY TALK. ''American Landscape Paintings.'' Dorothea Basile, museum educator, Brooklyn Museum. A 45-minute tour of American galleries. Meet in the grand lobby, first floor, 3 P.M. Tomorrow ''ARTY FACTS.'' Arts and crafts workshop for children 4 to 12 and accompanying adults. Meet in grand lobby, 11 A.M. GALLERY TALK. ''Courbet Reconsidered.'' Martha Usdin, museum educator. A retrospective. Meet in grand lobby, 2 P.M. ''WHAT'S UP?'' Arts and crafts workshops for children 6 to 12. Meet in grand lobby, 2 P.M. CONCERT. Honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Eleo Pomare Dance Company with Pam Patrick. West African folk music and dance. In the court, third floor, 2 P.M. Sunday ''WHAT'S UP?'' Arts and crafts workshop for children 6 to 12. Meet in grand lobby, 2 P.M. GALLERY TALK. ''Courbet Reconsidered.'' Sloan Seiden of the Graduate Center, City University of New York. A retrospective. Meet in grand lobby, 2 P.M. CONCERT. Honoring Dr. King. The Heavenly Tones, African-American gospel music; the Gospelettes, all-female gospel group, and the Diane Jacobowitz Dance Theater in ''Steps of Silence.'' In the court, third floor, 2 P.M. Continuing Exhibitions ''COURBET RECONSIDERED.'' European galleries, fifth floor. Through Monday. INSTALLATION BY THE SCULPTOR MARTIN PURYEAR. Grand lobby. Through Feb. 13. ''IMAGES ON STONE: PETROGLYPHS OF THE SOUTHWEST.'' First floor. Through March 13. ''NINETEENTH-CENTURY FRENCH WATERCOLORS AND DRAWINGS.'' Second floor. Through Feb. 20. ''A CENTURY OF FRENCH PAINTING'' (19th century). First floor. Through March 6. ''ENGLISH GLASS: SELECTIONS FROM THE LEICKE COLLECTION.'' Fourth floor. Through June 18. ''LACQUER - A PANORAMA OF ASIAN DECORATIVE ARTS.'' Second floor. Through June 14.

title: OSHA Investigators Charging West Point With 156 Violations
description: Federal investigators have cited the United States Military Academy at West Point for 156 violations that have threatened the health and safety of many of the academy's civilian workers, officials said today.

title: Holly Farms Sets Deadline for Bids
description: The Holly Farms Corporation said it had given its two potential buyers, Tyson Foods Inc. and Conagra Inc., until next Wednesday to submit their best and final offers for the company. The Memphis-based chicken producer said its board would meet then to consider the proposals and to determine which is the most attractive for Holly Farms' shareholders.

title: Murray Industries Supports Proposal
description: Murray Industries, the parent of the Murray Chris-Craft Boat Companies, said it had tentatively approved an offer from Genmar Industries to buy a substantial part of the boat maker's assets. Terms were not disclosed. The offer is subject to court and regulatory approval and any higher or better offer, said Mary Glass, a Chris-Craft spokeswoman.

title: Marshall & Ilsley reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Violin; Webern Pieces By Rony Rogoff
description: Certain aspects of Rony Rogoff's violin playing at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday evening were unusual and satisfying. In a recital of Mozart, Beethoven, Webern and Franck, Mr. Rogoff fought shy of the muscle-bound, cutting tone that is favored by many of his colleagues, shaped his lines with sensitivity, and thoughtfully matched his tone and vibrato to the expressive purpose of the phrase at hand.

title: Time for Truce Talks in U.S.-Europe Beef War; What They Want
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; Conclave in herringbone ponders lofty and mundane in legal education's muddled mission.
description: Speaking to a packed house of his peers, James Boyd White of the University of Michigan talked of Shakespearean sonnets, Burmese art and the evolution of the Gothic arch. And Dante, Gertrude Stein and Jaroslav Pelikan. And Picasso's ''Guernica,'' Mont St. Michel and the cathedral of Chartres.

title: Touring the Brooklyn Museum: An Art Explorer's Selection
description: Doubtless it is from professional deformation that this critic has, every so often, an irresistible dream. He is in a city unknown to him. On the top of a hill, there is an enormous house. He walks up to it. The door opens to his touch. He gets inside. Before him is an encyclopedia for the eye. The art of all times and all places is documented there, together with human nature in all complexities. What is on offer is nothing less than the world in epitome.

title: Kentucky Utilities Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net for 1987 was reduced by a one-time charge associated with writeoff of $5.9 million for the company's cancelled Hancock generating project.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds increased by $4.36 billion, to $282.4 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 137 institutional funds rose by $519.2 million, to $72.94 billion. The assets of the 225 general-purpose funds were up by $239.5 million, to $90.17 billion. The 91 broker-dealer funds increased by $3.61 billion, to $119.28 billion, the institute said.

title: Sudan Train on Rebuilt Track Takes Food to Starving Town
description: Railway workers, rebuilding track as they went, crossed 175 miles of Sudan's civil war zone to reach the starving town of Awiel with 30 carloads of cornmeal, the Government reported today.

title: First Commerce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge Said to Back Popeye's on Offer
description: A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., the owners of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken fast-food restaurants, said a Federal judge in Louisiana had ruled that the company could proceed with its $8-a-share offer for Church's Fried Chicken Inc. The ruling reverses a preliminary decision made against Popeye's last week.

title: Nomura Cuts Staff in U.S.
description: Nomura Securities International, the American affiliate of the world's largest securities firm, is again trimming its United States staff, particularly in the equities securities area.

title: Green Helps Out
description: The uniforms of the Thomas Jefferson High School basketball team were stolen a few weeks ago. When Sidney Green, the Knick forward who was a basketball star at the Brooklyn school 10 years ago, learned of the problem, he ordered a new set of 15 uniforms, costing about $2,500. He will present the new outfits to the team today before the school's home game against Wingate High School.

title: William Chaison, 44, Dancer and Teacher
description: William Chaison, a dancer and choreographer and associate professor of physical education at Kean College in Union, N.J., died last Friday at Doctor's Hospital in New York City. He was 44 years old.

title: Review/Film; Kevin Kline On the Trail Of a Killer
description: ''The January Man'' is well titled. It's a big-budget mainstream production that, in spite of its first-rate writer, director and cast, manages to fail in just about every department. It couldn't have stood up to the competition from the slightly less bad films released in December.

title: SEABROOK'S OWNER GETS TAKEOVER BID
description: New England's largest utility yesterday offered to buy the nonnuclear assets of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the first utility to file for bankruptcy protection since the Depression.

title: Time for Truce Talks in U.S.-Europe Beef War; The 1880-91 Pork War
description: To the Editor:

title: State Antitrust Laws Regulate Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Small-Town Feeling on Brooklyn's Gold Coast
description: Park Slope has a large collection of Victorian town houses, one of America's greatest urban parks and a grand arch unlike any this side of the Arc de Triomphe. But perhaps the most notable hallmark of this central Brooklyn community is that, in many ways, it feels like a small, friendly college town.

title: Reported AIDS Cases Increase in Connecticut
description: Reported cases of AIDS in the state's three biggest cities were up last year, with the largest increase in Bridgeport, the state's Department of Health Services reported.

title: Planters Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chemical Net Rose 25.7% in 4th Quarter
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation, one of the nation's largest banking companies, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 25.7 percent, bolstered by the receipt of past-due loan interest from Brazil.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Power Agency's Revenue Bonds
description: The Northern Municipal Power Agency, based in Minnesota, is tentatively offering a total of $302.8 million of electric-system revenue bonds to raise new money and retire previously issued debt in advance, with a maximum yield of 7.60 percent for an issue due in 2016.

title: Southeast Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest and year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the Dec. 30, 1988 acquisition by Southeast of its wholly owned subsidiary, First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Jacksonville, which was accounted for on a pooling of interests basis. The year-ago net included $77 million in after-tax special provisions for credit losses relating to loans to less developed countries.

title: ReadiCare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ICE HARVESTING, a demonstration by the Philip Whitney family from Fitchberg, Mass., and the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center farm staff, who will be cutting the ice and removing it from the lake, using antique tools. Duke and Diamond, the farm's oxen, will move the cakes of ice, 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the center, 39 Scofieldtown Road. Admission: children and the elderly, $2; others, $4, or maximum per car, $10. Information: (203) 322-1646. ''RUMPLESTILTSKIN,'' a musical comedy presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1 P.M. Sunday, and ''Peter Pan Meets the Wicked Wizard,'' 2:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. BOB SCHNEIDER AND HIS RAINBOW KIDS, a 45-minute concert by Mr. Schneider, a troupe of children and the 92d Street Y Music Chorus, 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, for ages 3 to 6, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $8 and $12. Reservations: 996-1100. THE KALEIDOSCOPE DANCERS, a program at 7:30 tonight during Friday Night Free Fun, at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Building M, Livingston. Information: (718) 273-2060. ''PUPPETS, PUPPETS, PUPPETS,'' a comedy program by Bob Conrad, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, at the Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic and comedy show, with audience participation, presented by Brian McGovern and Imam 2 P.M. Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE TRICKSTERS,'' a new play about the shy dragon who lives in Central Park, and a funny zookeeper, written by Miranda McDermott and performed by child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. Saturdays at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations: 734-5195. ''THE THREE LITTLE PIGS,'' a play by the Little People's Theater Company, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, and ''Humpty Dumpty Falls in Love,'' 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 765-9540.

title: Jazz India Group
description: Badal Roy, a tabla drummer, will lead his group Jazz India tonight at 8 at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street. Admission is $10. Information: 206-1050.

title: Opus Computer Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included a $262,830 gain from the sale of the company's Irish subsidiary. c-Net loss and included a loss from the company's former Irish subsidiary of $417,800.

title: In Brazil, an Isolated Leader Struggles to Be Heard
description: In a somber mood some weeks ago, President Jose Sarney threw out the dark prediction that Brazil is ''marching toward totalitarianism'' as a result of leftist gains in recent municipal elections.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Vietnamese Classics Nguyen Dinh Nghia, Uris Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art (206-1050). Nguyen Dinh Nghia is a master of the sao, a Vietnamese bamboo flute. Along with his family - two daughters and a son, who double as his band - he'll play transcriptions of classical European music on Vietnamese ethnic instruments. He'll also play the spare, delicate music of the central highlands of Vietnam, full of eerie wavering guttural notes. The show is on Sunday at 2:30 P.M.; tickets are $10. Trio, Trio, Trio

title: Soviets Say Car Bomb Blasted an Afghan City
description: A car bomb exploded in the western Afghan city of Herat, killing or wounding 20 people, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Tokyo Funeral Forces Choice By Old Foes
description: Emperor Hirohito's death is forcing Japan's trading partners to decide which Japan looms larger, the wartime aggressor of the past or the economic giant of the present.

title: Retirement at McCann
description: John J. McNamara announced his retirement yesterday as president and chief operating officer of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, but not his retirement from the larger world. His first book, ''Advertising Agency Management,'' will be published this summer. What is more, Mr. McNamara, 54, is running for mayor of Pelham Manor, N.Y. His political fate will be decided in early March.

title: Gen. John Knight Waters, 82; Fought in World War II and Korea
description: Gen. John Knight Waters of the Army, retired, a highly decorated veteran of World War II, died of heart failure Monday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 82 years old and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: Soviet-Israeli Diplomacy Is Winner in a Court Test
description: Zvi Sherf stood on the sidelines of the basketball court at the Central Army Sports Club here and could not quite believe what he was seeing.

title: U.S. and Japan End Dispute On Development of Fighter
description: Japanese and American officials said today that the two countries had resolved a dispute over the exchange of military technology that had threatened cooperation on a new fighter plane for the Japanese Air Force.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections and street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Electronics Units Study TV Venture
description: Sixteen American electronics companies, including several leading computer companies, are actively looking at banding together to get the United States into the emerging high definition television business.

title: Ford Raises Dividend By 25%
description: The cash-flush Ford Motor Company raised its quarterly dividend 25 percent today, which made Ford's dividend yield comparable to the yield of the General Motors Corporation's common stock.

title: Emigrant Bids for Greater New York
description: In the latest example of pressures to consolidate the savings bank industry, the Emigrant Savings Bank made a $200 million unsolicited offer yesterday to acquire the Greater New York Savings Bank.

title: Economic Scene; The Budget Gap: Failed Forecasts
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has delivered his farewell address and his final budget. His one great regret, he said, was ''the deficit.'' But the least surprising thing about his final budget is that it shows the deficit declining well within Gramm-Rudman-Hollings targets: to $98.6 billion in 1990, $66.8 billion in 1991, $32.2 billion in 1992, and then swinging above the balanced-budget line to surpluses of $2.4 billion in 1993 and $33.4 billion in 1994.

title: U.S.-Greek Talks Recess
description: Greek and American officials ended another round of talks on United States military bases today without making much headway toward a new agreement, a Greek Government spokesman said. A spokeswoman for the American Embassy declined to comment on the three-day talks, the first round since a five-year operating agreement for the four installations expired Dec. 20.

title: U.S. Sees a Possibility Libya Will Return Body of Airman
description: Libya has indicated it will return the remains of an Air Force officer killed in the 1986 American air raid on Libya, United States officials said today.

title: Bush Completes His Choices for Cabinet
description: President-elect George Bush completed the selection of his Cabinet today and challenged its designated members to ''think big'' about the budget deficit, the narcotics crisis and other issues.

title: Intech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 9
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August 1988.

title: Peru Rebels Kill 9 Policemen
description: Left-wing rebels killed nine policemen Wednesday, raising the toll to 33 this month in a surge of violence as Peru's army retreats from the countryside. Guerrillas of the Shining Path group shot dead five policemen and two civilians who had been traveling on a bus near the port city of Huacho in central Peru, and attacked a power station near the central city of Huaras and shot dead four policemen.

title: How Opium Became Burma's Cash Crop
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Piano; Pogorelich, Dapper but Otherwise Recognizable
description: Ivo Pogorelich has cleaned up his act a bit, sartorially speaking. The Yugoslavian pianist, who made his annual recital appearance at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, used to look like a romantic punk. This year, he was coifed and conventional in attire, although his slack posture and wan appearance still bespoke the matinee idol.

title: Racial Differences Found in Care Heart Patients Obtain at Hospitals
description: A team of researchers has found one of the strongest indications so far of racial differences in the kind of medical care Americans receive. The researchers at Harvard University found that a significantly higher proportion of white people admitted to Massachusetts hospitals with heart problems undergo coronary bypass operations and cardiac catheterizations than do blacks.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Deal 36
description: They may not displace baseball cards, but among political junkies ''Iran-Contra Scandal Trading Cards'' are gaining popularity. Eclipse Enterprises of Forestville, Calif., has sold nearly 10,000 decks.

title: Dow Closes at 2,222.32, a Post-Crash High
description: LEAD: Stock prices surged again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 15.89 points, to close at 2,222.32, another post-crash high.

title: SHAMIR IS JEERED AT SETTLERS' RITES
description: Angry Jewish settlers shouted down Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today at a memorial service for two Israelis killed in the occupied West Bank as settlers staged an unprecedented general strike.

title: First Empire State reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The earnings from banking business for the latest fourth quarter were hurt by a $2.8 million loss on sales of bank investment securities and a one- time charge of $1.8 million in connection with restructuring.

title: Home Savings & Loan Assn Inc of Duram, North Carolina reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Arrivals: Hustlers Vying With the Skycaps at Kennedy
description: In the year since self-service baggage carts were introduced at Kennedy International Airport, hundreds of free-wheeling hustlers who retrieve the wagons for their 25-cent return fee have taken to cruising the terminals, stealing baggage from the carts and fleecing passengers with a host of confidence schemes.

title: Airlines Begin Checking Jets' Engine Circuits
description: Airlines began an urgent safety inspection of Boeing 737's around the country today, but as the work progressed no flaws were reported in the wiring of engine monitoring and fire alarm systems.

title: Concept 90 Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Strikes Wane at Mexico Oil Sites; Union Leader Faces New Charges
description: After two days of labor disruptions, Mexico's sprawling oil refineries appeared today to be returning to normal operations even as new charges were brought against the leader of the nation's oil workers.

title: In First Year, Tunisia Chief Makes Strides
description: The smiling pictures of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, next to those of President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia, were still fresh on building walls weeks after the Libyan leader's third visit of 1988.

title: Grade-Change Denial
description: The former North Carolina State basketball player Chris Washburn said yesterday that his grades were not changed while he was playing for the Wolfpack, disputing the allegations of a former department head at the school. Speaking in an article in yesterday's Atlanta Constitution, Washburn said, ''If they changed some grades, why didn't they change enough to get me a diploma instead of just playing basketball for two seasons?'' Washburn, now under suspension from the Atlanta Hawks for violating the National Basketball Association's substance-abuse policy, left N.C. State in 1986, after his sophomore year, to turn professional. The changing of grades was one of the allegations contained on the jacket of a forthcoming book on the university's basketball program. On Wednesday, Richard A Lauffer, the retired chairman of the physical-education department at N.C. State, said Washburn's grades were changed to maintain the player's eligibility.(AP)

title: Accelerator Is Proposed for Making Bomb Material
description: The Department of Energy could use a linear accelerator to produce tritium for nuclear weapons, a process that would be cheaper and safer and would produce less radioactive waste than a reactor, according to an unreleased Department of Energy study.

title: Entronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Swing for Dancing
description: Spanky Davis, a trumpeter, and the Jimmy Ryan All-Stars will play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society on Sunday at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090). Doors open at 7 P.M., with music beginning at 8; tickets are $8, $4 for the elderly.

title: 7 Killed in Fires in the Bronx and Manhattan
description: LEAD: Arson is believed responsible for two fires in which seven people died and 18 firefighters were injured yesterday in in the Bronx and Manhattan.

title: Review/Art; Image Manipulation
description: Barbara Kruger's latest exhibition at the Mary Boone Gallery includes a lenticular photograph depicting five apparently healthy babies who, when seen from one angle, disappear behind block letters spelling out phrases like ''feed me,'' ''hug me,'' ''need me.'' Viewed from another angle, the faces reappear above the words ''psychotic,'' ''neurotic,'' ''schizophrenic,'' ''hysterical'' and ''paranoid.''

title: Kinard Makes Pro Bowl
description: Terry Kinard, the Giants' free safety, was chosen yesterday to play in the Pro Bowl game Jan. 29 in Honolulu. Each coach is allowed to add one ''need player,'' and the Bears' Mike Ditka, who will coach the National conference, picked Kinard.

title: On Nicaraguan Range, Assault Rifles for Hire
description: There are signs that civil conflict in Nicaragua may be ending after six years, but those who feel nostalgic for the crack of rifle fire can indulge themselves just 15 miles from the capital. Here anyone with cash can legally rent a rifle or a submachine gun for target practice.

title: Peru Rebels Blamed in Death Of Jersey City Mayor's Wife
description: A New Jersey mayor's wife who died in a rail crash Dec. 1 in Peru was probably the victim of sabotage by leftist guerrillas, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Drug Nominee Vows He'll Kick the Habit
description: In accepting his new assignment to coordinate the Federal attack on drug abuse, William J. Bennett promised today to give up a drug habit of his own: cigarette smoking.

title: BELGIAN CHARGED IN ILLICIT SHIPMENT FOR LIBYAN PLANT
description: The expanding search for participants in the building of a suspect Libyan chemical plant produced its first arrest today - that of a Belgian shipping agent charged with disguising a shipment of German goods - while the West German Government officially acknowledged ''indications'' that German companies had been involved in the Libyan project.

title: Review/Art; Straitened Landscapes Of a Post-Modern Era
description: Suddenly there is a spate of landscape shows in New York. Several have a post-modern feeling to them, which is surprising since post-modern landscape painting has almost seemed like a contradiction in terms: post-modernism has a lot more to do with sitting around theorizing about ''nature'' than setting hand and foot to earth and stone. The landscapes on display are less answers than questions, but the questions are important, and they expose some of the nerve ends of contemporary American art.

title: Dukakis Seeks $730 Million In New Massachusetts Taxes
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis tonight proposed tax increases for Massachusetts residents that would raise about $730 million in the next 18 months to head off budget deficits.

title: 6 Found Alive in Armenia 35 Days After Quake
description: Six men were found alive Wednesday after 35 days in the basement of a nine-story apartment building that collapsed in the earthquake in Armenia, official Soviet news accounts said today.

title: Clemente Brings S.E.C. Into Battle With Suitor
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today found its name bandied about in the middle of a takeover battle.

title: Thomas Will Return
description: The Penn State tailback Blair Thomas, a third-team all-America selection in 1987 who was sidelined by a knee injury last season, announced yesterday that he would return for his final season. Thomas ran for 1,414 yards on 268 carries in 1987. (AP)

title: 'At the Chelsea' Festival Looks at Hotel's History
description: ''At the Chelsea,'' a festival of performance art, music and theater based on the Chelsea Hotel's history, is being presented through Feb. 5 in three rooms of the hotel at 222 West 23d Street. Among the artists who have created and are to perform works during the festival in tribute to the hotel are David Van Tieghem with Tina Dudek, Penny Arcade, John Kelly, Frank Maya, Squat Theater and Ann Carlson.

title: Spinal Osteoporosis Reported Halted by New Drug Therapy
description: Texas researchers reported evidence today that a new treatment halts the progress of spinal osteoporosis and reverses bone loss. The disease, which can cause a curved spine and stooped posture, afflicts millions of people, primarily elderly women.

title: Dollar Steady On Threat of Intervention
description: The threat of further, coordinated central bank intervention held the dollar relatively steady yesterday.

title: Canandaigua Wine reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,031,364 from an accounting change.

title: Space Shuttle Will Not Carry Civilians on Its Future Flights
description: The space agency, scarred by the explosion of the Challenger in which a teacher was killed, announced today that it will no longer carry civilians on the space shuttle.

title: Capital's Man in Congress Is Subject of F.B.I. Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is seeking to determine whether Walter Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's Delegate to Congress, broke Federal law by employing the son of a Congressional colleague at a time when records show the son had sworn he was living in Illinois.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Tariff Trouble
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, apparently influenced by complaints from Suzuki and other Japanese automobile manufacturers, is reviewing a decision by the Customs Service last week that set sharply higher duties on imported multipurpose vehicles like vans.

title: Sergeant's War Story: The Shame of the Whites
description: When Bruce Moore-King was fighting for the Rhodesian Army more than a decade ago, he thought the war was a brave and noble affair.

title: On Stage
description: 'American' on Broadway Wouldn't it be nice if the year continued with news like this? And the news is that a show called ''An American in Paris'' (yes, it is the ''American in Paris'' you're thinking of) will, if everything goes as planned, be on Broadway sometime next year.

title: Mayor Seeks Panel Records On Job Bank
description: Reacting to a possible scandal in his own office, Mayor Edward I. Koch asked a state investigating commission yesterday to turn over to him its files on the how a City Hall agency handled job referrals from Democratic politicians. The agency was supposed to place minorities and women in city jobs.

title: Ogilvy Adopts A 'Poison Pill'
description: The Ogilvy Group announced yesterday that its board had adopted a shareholder rights plan intended to deter a hostile takeover.

title: Hawaii Company Seeking Property
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc., a Hawaiian land, shipping and agriculture company, said it was seeking to buy $100 million worth of property in the Western United States in the next six months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are at war. Drugs are a terrifying, insidious enemy.'' - George Bush. [ D17:1. ]

title: International Paper Seeks French Concern
description: The International Paper Company said today that it planned to begin a takeover bid for Europe's largest paper maker.

title: Cherry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DOCUMENTS FILED ON NORTH CHARGES
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today filed a sealed statement in Federal District Court buttressing the request by the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case to drop the main criminal charges against Oliver L. North, Government officials said.

title: Valentin Glushko, 80, Rocket Pioneer For Soviet Program
description: Valentin P. Glushko, who in the 1930's pioneered the development of Soviet liquid-fueled rockets, then played a prominent but secret role in Russia's postwar space program, has died at the age of 80, the Soviet press agency Tass announced yesterday.

title: Rangers Find Tactics for Lemieux Hard to Compute
description: Michel Bergeron lugged his brand-new computer, a gift from his superiors in the organization, into his office before practice today. Bergeron, the coach of the Rangers, was pleased but realistic about the present.

title: Green Tree Acceptance Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 net includes an accounting change gain of $7,212,000, or 45 cents a share.

title: Unifirst Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Central Jersey Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Square Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of real property of $313,000, or 27 cents a share.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: ALPINE SKIING Figini Leads Swiss Sweep: Michaela Figini, the defending World Cup champion, led the Swiss to a sweep of three of the top four places in a World Cup downhill race yesterday at the new Tschuggen course on Mount Eiger in Grindelwald, Switzerland. Figini was timed in 1 minute 55.82 seconds down the tough, bumpy course. Figini was a half-second ahead of her teammate Beatrice Gafner, while Carole Merle of France was third, .74 behind Figini. Maria Walliser of Switzerland was fourth. Figini, who also won the season's opening downhill at Val d'Isere, France, moved to the top of the World Cup downhill standing with 65 points. Walliser is in second place with 42 points. (AP) TENNIS McEnroe and Lendl Advance: John McEnroe and Ivam Lendl scored straight-set victories yesterday in the Rio International exhibition tournament in Adelaide, Australia. McEnroe upset Mats Wilander of Sweden, the No. 1-ranked player in the world, 6-4, 6-3. Lendl scored a 6-4, 7-6 triumph over Mark Woodeforde of Australia.(AP) Victory for Krickstein: Aaron Krickstein and Mary Joe Fernandez of the United States advanced, but Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia was upset yesterday in the $350,000 New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia. Krickstein, seeded third and ranked 14th in the world, advanced to the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 6-4 second-round victory over another American, Joey Rive. Fernandez reached the quarterfinals with a 6-7, 6-2, 6-1 victory over Gretchen Magers in a third-round match. But Sukova, seeded third behind Martina Navratilova and the defending champion, Pam Shriver, lost, 6-3, 6-0, to Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden. (AP) SOCCER United States 5, Brazil 3: The United States beat Brazil yesterday and advanced to a semifinal matchup with the Netherlands in the World Indoor Soccer Championship in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The United States, the only team to go 3-0 in the second round, has won five games in a row since tying Australia in its opener. The Americans will face the Netherlands in the second semifinal tomorrow after Brazil plays Belgium. The winners will meet Sunday for the championship.(AP) N.B.A. Bullets 106, Heat 100: Bernard King and Jeff Malone scored 32 points each for Washington and Steve Colter scored 11 points in the fourth quarter to rally the Bullets, who have won six of their last eight home games. Malone made four free throws in the final 13 seconds to seal the victory.(AP) Rockets 116, Trail Blazers 106: Akeem Olajuwon scored 32 points, including six straight baskets in the closing minutes in Houston. Olajuwon, who grabbed 16 rebounds, scored 12 points in the fourth quarter. Mike Woodson scored 22 points for Houston.(AP) Jazz 115, Spurs 91: John Stockton had 26 points, 16 assists and 6 steals for Utah, which was playing at home. Frank Brickowski scored 16 points to lead the Spurs, who lost their third straight game. Utah's lead reached 81-51 midway through the third quarter before the Spurs reeled off 17 straight points, but San Antonio got no closer than 13 points after that.(AP) SuperSonics 130, Mavericks 95: Dale Ellis scored 36 points as Seattle gained its 12th consecutive home victory. It was the Mavericks' sixth loss in a row. Ellis ignited a 21-5 Seattle run during a six-minute span in the third quarter as Seattle turned a 14-point lead into an 88-58 advantage. Seattle had 36 assists, 9 by Nate McMillan. The SuperSonics' center, Alton Lister, had a season-high 17 rebounds. Detlef Schrempf led Dallas with 24 points.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Georgia 82, South Carolina 73: Tammye Jenkins led a balanced scoring attack for Georgia with 19 points as the sixth-ranked Bulldogs (12-2) beat No. 16 South Carolina (9-1) last night in Columbia, S.C. The Gamecocks were one victory short of matching the school record for consecutive victories to start a season.(AP)

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Schneider Sings Weill Helen Schneider, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). Over the last five years, Helen Schneider has grown into a cabaret performer of exceptional breadth and theatrical command. In her new show, devoted to the songs of Kurt Weill, Ms. Schneider dives fearlessly into the tempestuous emotional world of the songs, rather than taking the ironic distance that an older generation of Weill interpreters used to adopt. She is especially adept at revealing the deep erotic currents in songs like ''Stranger Here Myself'' and ''My Ship.'' Shows are at 9 and 11 tonight and tomorrow. There is a $15 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. Daugherty and Field

title: Pro-Israel Lobbyists Face Charge on Election Role
description: Former United States officials filed a complaint today against an influential pro-Israel lobbying group and 53 political action committees, charging they had violated Federal election laws.

title: Boston Acoustics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
To Our Readers
description: Because of computer problems at The Associated Press, today's Options on Futures table does not include figures for sales and open interest.

title: Sorrow and Grace Mix As Pathologist Is Buried
description: Dr. Kathryn Hinnant and the son she was carrying were buried today beneath a stand of loblolly pines far from the Bellevue Hospital office in which she was killed five days ago.

title: About Real Estate; In Rockaway, a Project on the Shore
description: As a seagull traced lazy circles overhead and a wintry wind blew spray in from the Atlantic Ocean, Charles Reis, a Manhattan developer, walked around a litter-strewn vacant lot near 99th Street on the Rockaway peninsula - the former site of the Rockaway Playland - and talked of his plans for 309 stucco and clapboard year-round town houses and apartments.

title: Elcor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher yesterday, touched off at first by a technical short-covering rally that later turned in to broad-based buying.

Diner's Journal
description: Aunt Sonia Aunt Sonia is not a matronly relative who loves to cook. It's a down-home, no-frills restaurant in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn - named for the nearby Ansonia Clock Building - that turns out some engaging fare at budget prices. The chef and co-owner, Michael Schrieber, is a self-taught cook who took over a bric-a-brac shop in a landmark building two and a half years ago and with his partner, Wayne Perez, turned it into a spare but pleasant neighborhood spot.

title: PRETORIA MINERS FEUD WITH OWNERS
description: Fifteen months after South Africa's longest and costliest mine strike ended, residual bitterness over mine violence and working conditions has erupted in a war of words between the Anglo American Corporation and the black miners' union.

title: Ithaca Coach Honored
description: Jim Butterfield, the football coach at Ithaca College, was selected yesterday as the Kodak Division II coach of the year by the American Football Coaches Association at its convention in Nashville. Butterfield, 164-59-1 in 22 years at Ithaca, coached the Bombers to a 13-1 record and the N.C.A.A. Division III national championship this season. Don Nehlen, who led West Virginia to the first perfect regular season in its 96-year football history, was named coach of the year by the American Football Coaches Association.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved the Delta Government Options Corporation yesterday as the first registered clearing organization for over-the-counter options on Treasury securities.

The latest quarter reflected the acquisitions of PGL Industries in June, and Bergall Corp. and Careco Inc. in August. Results also include the operations of the Old Staff Builders Inc. from its acquisition in May 1987.

description: The British maker of jellybabies, a popular gelatin candy, has vowed to fight a hostile takeover offer of $:63 million, about $112 million, from the Swedish company Procordia A.B. Bev Stokes, the chief executive of Bassett Foods P.L.C., said the offer by Procordia, Sweden's 10th-largest business, badly undervalued the company.

Moscow Puts Disputed Region Under Direct Rule
description: In an attempt to defuse the violent ethnic dispute that has brought virtual martial law to the republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan, the Soviet Government decided today to put a disputed territory under direct rule from Moscow, an Armenian journalist said.

description: International A2-17

title: Family Dollar Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Moscow's Warning and Washington's Silence
description: And now let's take a look at one of the more interesting Soviet statements of the New Era. It is important in itself but mostly because Washington acts as if it had never been made and somehow will go away, which it won't. The statement: ''There is a serious danger that things may develop in such a way that the Soviet Union might not be able, within the nearest future, to do what we have in principle decided to do.''

title: Sri Lankan Authorities Begin Releasing Political Detainees
description: The Government released more than 200 political prisoners today after the new President, Ranasinghe Premadasa, lifted a state of emergency in this ethnically troubled land, the military said.

title: U.S. Report Shows Decline in Air Crash Fatalities
description: Accidents involving United States commercial air carriers and private airplanes killed 875 people in 1988, the lowest number this decade, Government figures indicate.

title: Poles to Cut Coal Export
description: The Government expects to reduce coal exports to almost nothing by the year 2000 because of rising domestic demand and increasing costs of extraction, the Industry Minister, Mieczyslaw Wilczek, said on Wednesday. Poland, the world's fifth-largest coal exporter, will instead try to increase exports of other products, Mr. Wilczek said. He said it was not economically feasible to increase extraction from the current level of 190 million tons annually.

title: Automobile Protection reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $50,937.

title: 21% Southmark Stake for Sale
description: The top officers of the Southmark Corporation, Gene E. Phillips and William S. Friedman, are trying to sell their 21.7 percent stake in the ailing real estate and financial services concern, the company said today. According to a Securities and

title: Tyson Visits Givens in Canada, and Controversy Again Tags Along
description: A television station in Vancouver, British Columbia, was considering yesterday whether to file charges against Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, after a scuffle in a hotel lobby on Wednesday involving Tyson, a television cameraman and a still photographer.

title: Battle for Plessey Is Put on Hold
description: The British Government and the European Commission called a temporary halt today to one of the biggest and most significant takeover battles ever seen in Europe.

title: Chemical Weapons, Cloudy Thinking
description: Inconsistencies of United States chemical weapons policy lie exposed by the unhappy conjunction of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's big new poison gas factory with Secretary of State George P. Shultz's cautious avoidance of specifics in his address to the Paris chemical weapons conference that ended Wednesday.

title: McGirt's Hooks Halt DeLeon In Six
description: Buddy McGirt, the former International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champion, stopped Manuel DeLeon last night at 29 seconds of the sixth round at the Felt Forum.

title: Bush Inaugural Will Signal Open, Accessible President
description: President-elect George Bush's five-day inaugural gala is being packaged down to the last waltz to suggest an administration that will be more open and more engaged than President Reagan's.

title: Nussbaum Seen By a Witness As Competent
description: The defense in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg tried to portray Hedda Nussbaum to the jury yesterday as having been a mentally competent, functional woman immediately after the death of Lisa Steinberg and not the helpless, incoherent victim who the prosecution said was incapable of saving the life of the 6-year-old child.

title: New Housing Down by 5.6%
description: Completions of new homes and apartment buildings in the nation declined by 5.6 percent in November from October, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.42 million units, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Dining Out Guide: Near Galleries and Museums
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. The Gibbon

title: Review/Opera; Premiere Of 'Desire,' Based On O'Neill
description: ''Desire Under the Elms,'' an opera by Edward Thomas, was composed in 1978 and has been performed in several workshop productions since then. The work's official world premiere, however, was on Monday evening, when the New York Opera Repertory Theater performed it at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. The performances are to be repeated tonight at 8 o'clock and on Sunday at 3.

title: INSIDE
description: Brazil's Power Vacuum

title: WASHINGTON TALK: State Department; Wordsmiths of the Mideast Move
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced that the United States was opening a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, he drew on a large amount of preparatory work by a small group of policy advisers at the State Department.

title: Dionex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BEATING IN PANAMA PROTESTED BY U.S.
description: The United States has strongly protested the severe beating and threatened killing of an American sailor by Panama's Defense Forces, Pentagon officials said today. The Panamanian Government has acknowledged that the incident occurred, but made no apology.

title: TV Weekend; An Ex-Steelworker Loose at England's Controls
description: Just when the label liberal is deemed to be a liability in mainstream circles, along comes British television with a riveting, walloping, unapologetic celebration of left-of-center politics. ''A Very British Coup'' is certain to knock a good many Reagan-Thatcher noses out of joint, but the production is so remarkably good - it won the 1988 International Emmy for Best Drama - that pouting would merely be pointless.

title: For All the Talk of New Faces, the Cabinet Shapes Up as a Group of Government Pros
description: Michael S. Dukakis promised a campaign about competence, not ideology. George Bush, who beat him, today completed the selection of a Cabinet that might be described with the same words.

title: Review/Film; A British Cause Celebre
description: Bill Douglas's ''Comrades,'' opening today at the Public, is an elaborately misconceived three-hour movie that apparently means to be both a meditation on the heritage of cinema and a tribute to the ''Tolpuddle martyrs,'' six farm laborers who became early heroes of England's labor movement.

title: Basque Separatist Leader Is Seized in France
description: The French police have arrested a leader of the Spanish Basque independence movement, dealing a heavy blow to the group and underscoring increased antiterrorist cooperation between France and Spain.

title: Israeli Jets Raid Base Of Palestinian Group
description: Israeli Air Force jets attacked a base in southern Lebanon today that belongs to the hard-line Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal. It was the second day of air raids.

title: National Bancorp of Alaska reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Cyclical Stocks Seem Depressed
description: THE United States economy is in the seventh year of expansion, and nothing lasts forever.

title: Johnny Coles's Trumpet
description: Johnny Coles, a trumpeter, is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Birdland, 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street (749-2228). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Cold Brown Fields
description: The meadow beneath my window is brown and the mountains beyond are more nearly gray with mist than white with snow. Is this merely a momentary setback for skiers - or a harbinger, in the middle of a cold Vermont winter, of another damaging drought next summer?

title: Assessing the Johnson Debacle
description: The specter of the sprinter Ben Johnson and his Olympic fiasco hung over a hearing room this week as Canada's judicial inquiry into drug use by athletes began taking testimony in an attempt to get to the bottom of the country's worst sporting embarrassment.

title: King Musical Celebrations: Where and When
description: Many schools, libraries and churches have scheduled events to honor the 60th anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (Although the actual birthday is Jan. 15, it will be observed on Jan. 16 this year.) Here is a sampling. GOSPEL AND SPIRITUALS, Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, Brooklyn College, junction of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Flatbush. Tomorrow, 8 P.M.: Grassroots Gospel Festival, with Clarence Fountain and the Original Blind Boys of Alabama, Sister Sadie and the Famous Biblettes, the Brooklyn Skyways and the Rev. Timothy Wright, and the choir of Washington Temple Church of God in Christ. Tickets: $20, $15, $12 and $10. Sunday, 3 P.M.: the Harlem Spiritual Ensemble. Tickets: $12 and $9. Information: (718) 434-2222. LADY LEGENDS IN JAZZ, Harlem School of the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, at 141st Street. More than 100 historic photographs, posed and candid, of great female jazz artists of six decades. Admission is free. Hours: tomorrow: 3 to 6 P.M.; Sunday and Monday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: 926-4100. CONCERT, The cantata ''I Have a Dream'' and ''Five Langston Hughes Songs,'' by the composer Elie Siegmeister. Harlem School of the Arts (see above), Sunday, 3 P.M. Admission is free. The program will be broadcast on WQXR radio (1560 AM; 96.3 FM) Monday at 7 P.M. Information: 926-4100. GOSPEL CONCERT AND COMMUNITY CONVOCATION, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Tomorrow, 8 P.M.: Gospel with Phoebe Snow, Twinkie Clark of the Clark Sisters, Butch Heyward and Devotion, Kecia Lewis-Evans, the Inspirational Choir of Morning Star Baptist Church, and the Voices of Victory of Allen A.M.E. Church. Tickets: $15 and $10. Sunday, 3:30 P.M.: ''Living the Dream,'' a convocation, with the New York Boys' Choir, students from the Harlem School of the Arts, and the St. Luke's A.M.E. Youth Choir. Admission is free. Information: 662-2133. DANCE, GOSPEL AND SOUL, Third-floor court of the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway in the Crown Heights section. All events are free with the suggested museum entrance donation: $3 for adults, $1.50 for students and $1 for the elderly. Tomorrow, 2 P.M.: Eleo Pomare Dance Company and Pam Patrick (Pam Pam), a West African folk performer. Sunday, 2 P.M.: the Heavenly Tones, an a cappella gospel quartet; the Gospelettes; the Diane Jacobowitz Dance Theater. Monday, 2 P.M.: David Peaston, singer; the Rod Rodgers Dance Company; the Orient Express, sitar and synthesizer players. Information: (718) 783-3077. ''DREAM'' CONCERTS, Three performances of ''Scenes From the Life of a Martyr,'' by Dr. Undine Smith Moore, Brahms's ''Schicksalslied'' and Verdi's ''Te Deum'' and ''Stabat Mater,'' performed by the Saintpaulia Symphony and Voices Saintpaulia, a 120-voice choir. Tomorrow, 8 P.M., the Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street. Tickets: $25, $17.50 and $12.50; information: 307-7171. Sunday, 8 P.M., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place in the Fort Greene section. Tickets: $25, $17.50 and $12.50; information: 307-7171. Monday, 8 P.M., Carnegie Hall. Tickets: $30, $25, $20, $15 and $10; information: 247-7800. ODETTA, Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue, Bedford Park, the Bronx. Sunday, 3 P.M. The folk singer and the Mafata Dance Company in ''Tell It to the Lord,'' a piece using Dr. King's words and music by Lionel Richie. Admission is free, but seating is limited and tickets must be picked up in advance. Information: 960-8833. BIOGRAPHER, BRUNCH AND POETRY, The 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. Sunday, 11 A.M.: the writer Arnold Rampersad will discuss his biography of Langston Hughes, and a brunch will be served afterward. Admission: $13. Monday, 8 P.M.: The actors Ruby Dee and Paul Winfield will read poems by Countee Cullen and Hughes. Admission: $8. Information: 996-1100. CHAMBER MUSIC AND JAZZ, Brooklyn Botanic Garden auditorium, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights section. Sunday, 3 P.M. The Brooklyn Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble and the bassist Larry Ridley with the Jazz Legacy Ensemble. Admission: $3 for adults; $2 for children and the elderly; free for members. Information: (718) 622-4433. MUSICAL FOR CHILDREN, Staten Island Children's Museum, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Building M, at Snug Harbor in Livingston. Monday, 2 P.M.: ''Dream Alive,'' a program of songs and stories about the achievements of noted black Americans. Admission: $2. Information: (718) 273-2060. JUILLIARD CONCERT, Paul Recital Hall at the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street. Tuesday, 6 P.M. Students from the music, dance and drama departments will perform ''I Have a Dream,'' a new work by the composer Robert Convery; ''Oh Freedom,'' a work for seven dancers set to the spiritual of the same title, by Robert Wright; a dance work set to a South African anthem; and a reading of excerpts from Coretta Scott King's book ''Words of Martin Luther King.'' Admission is free; no tickets are required. Information: 874-7515.

title: Amsouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cruising to Louisville
description: For Shug McGaughey and Easy Goer, these are the sweetest and easiest days of winter.

title: Principal Says A Local Group Forced Him Out
description: A Brooklyn elementary school principal who has been involved in a bitter community dispute was transferred yesterday to the District 16 office.

title: Our Towns; Creating Castles At a Discount For Playgrounds
description: No one at Fairmount Elementary School had ever met a celebrity architect before. And what a celebrity. Robert Leathers has built 450 playgrounds all over America. (How do you get a job like that, they wanted to know. Might as well be eating ice cream for a living.) At each school he mobilizes hundreds of children and parent volunteers, showing them how to construct a playground in practically no time for a fraction of the normal cost. He's even been featured on Mr. Rogers.

title: Correction
description: A picture in Business Day on Wednesday with a Business People report about Jean-Claude Leny, chairman and chief executive of Framatome & Company, was published in error through a misidentification by the Camera Press agency.

title: First Financial Savings Assn Pennsylvania reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chemical Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods' nets included the recognition of the receipt of about $161 million, net of withholding taxes, of past-due interest on Brazilian loans for the period from Feb. 20, 1987 to Sept. 30, 1988.
