The latest year's net included pre- tax gains of $53.8 million on settlement of a portion of the company's pension obligations and $41.3 million on the sale and closure of certain non- strategic businesses. The year-ago periods' nets included a pre-tax gain of $126.4 million on the settlement of a portion of Chemical's pension obligations and a gain of $25.6 million from the sale of Chemical's factoring business. The 1987 year loss also reflected the $1.1 billion special addition to the allowance for loan losses made in June 1987 for loans to countries engaged in debt rescheduling, as well as a $135 million restructuring charge recorded in the third quarter of that year. The bank's consolidated loan loss provisions for the latest periods were $81.1 million for the fourth quarter and $363.7 million for the year, compared with year-ago quarter of $108.2 million and $1,492,000,000 for 1987. The 1987 amount reflected the $1.1 billion special addition to the allowance for loans related to debt rescheduling countries. Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. merged with Chemical Banking on May 1, 1987. Its operations are included in Chemical's full year 1988 results, but in 1987 only from the merger date.

title: Bear Stearns Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year results are restated to conform to current fiscal year presentation. The company said the results for the latest second quarter reflected strong performances in the principal transaction and investment banking activities of the firm.

title: Knight-Ridder to Sell 2 Daily Papers
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. announced plans today to sell two of its daily newspapers - The Star-News in Pasadena, Calif., and The Post-Tribune in Gary, Ind.

title: Now, Novels Are Turning Promotional
description: IT'S not as if Proust had traded his madeleines for pumpernickel in return for a payment from Pepperidge Farm, but Beth Ann Herman has raised hackles by putting her novel's protagonist in a Maserati.

title: Review/Concert; 83 Minutes of Bruckner
description: Klaus Tennstedt and the Philadelphia Orchestra devoted their entire program Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall to Bruckner's Symphony No. 8 in C minor. That meant the concert, without intermission, began at 8:05 and ended two minutes before 9:30. But it would seem unlikely that anyone in the nearly full auditorium felt cheated of their customary two-hour concert span. Bruckner's Eighth is so massive and world-embracing, to use the sort of terminology favored by Bruckner and his fellow fervent Wagnerians, that to pair it with almost anything else would court Germanic redundancy.

title: Oil Prices End Unchanged After Day of Wild Swings
description: Domestic crude oil prices closed unchanged yesterday after a day of wild price swings caused by heavy selling at the opening of the New York Mercantile Exchange and fresh buying late in the session.

title: 2d Daughter for Nelson
description: Karl Nelson, the Giants' offensive tackle, has become a father for the second time. His wife, Heidi, gave birth yesterday to a daughter, Lindsay Rae, at the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. The Nelsons also have a daughter named Brittany, who will be 3 years old in March. Nelson began chemotherapy treatment Tuesday after a recurrence of Hodgkin's disease, a cancer of the lymph-node tissue. The illness sidelined him for the 1987 season.

title: Student Takes Gun to School; Another Is Caught With Fake
description: A 16-year-old student was arrested yesterday at his high school in Manhattan and charged with carrying a loaded .38-caliber revolver, and, in a separate incident, a 15-year-old student in the Bronx was charged with menacing a teacher with a fake gun, the police said.

title: Despite Revisions, Few Blacks Passed Police Sergeant Test
description: Despite the involvement of minority officers in helping to prepare a new promotion examination for the New York City Police Department, 94.7 percent of the latest group of officers promoted to sergeant are non-Hispanic whites.

title: Experimental Ulcer Drug Held Superior to Current Mainstay
description: Researchers have found that a new ulcer drug is superior to one of the mainstays of ulcer treatment because it promotes healing and relieves symptoms more quickly.

title: Review/Art; For Keith Sonnier, Two Shows 20 Years Apart
description: Keith Sonnier then and now is the subject of a pair of exhibitions in SoHo. One at Barbara Gladstone Gallery, the other at Leo Castelli, they focus, respectively, on the artist's early and current work.

title: Chip Shots Put Bryant In Front In Classic
description: During the final round of the MONY Tournament of Champions last Sunday, four golfers chipped into holes a total of five times. In each case, the successful chip shot involved a player finishing first or tied for second in the regular and senior divisions.

title: Correction
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about a sedition trial in Springfield, Mass., cited the defendants' previous convictions incorrectly. Two defendants, Raymond Luc Levasseur and Richard Williams, have been convicted on bombing charges; they have not been convicted of bank robbery. Another, Patricia H. Gros Levasseur, has no convictions on bombing or bank robbery charges.

title: Reporter's Notebook; The Traffic Is Romantic On the Road in Mandalay
description: Even under martial law, love will find a way.

title: Communications Transmision Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said results for the second quarter and 6 months reflected its 42.2 percent interest as of Nov. 30 in the operations of ALC Communications Corp. on a consolidation basis.

title: Crazy Eddie Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $48,226,000 from an exchange offer related to Crazy Eddie's convertible subordinated debentures. c-Net loss d-After tax credits of $16,261,000 for the quarter and $26,465,000 for the 9 months.

title: Nikos Psacharopoulos, 60, Co-Founder of Theater
description: Nikos Psacharopoulos, artistic executive director and a co-founder of the Williamstown Theater Festival more than 30 years ago, died yesterday in the Virgin Islands. Mr. Psacharopoulos, who lived in New York and was 60 years old, had colon cancer and was vacationing on St. John Island after surgery, a festival spokesman said.

title: G.M.'s Dispute Over Hughes
description: The General Motors Corporation has made only two major strategic acquisitions in recent history, and both have proved troublesome. Its $2.5 billion purchase of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in 1984 led to an embarrassing public dispute with the E.D.S. founder, H. Ross Perot. Now G.M. is embroiled in a potentially costly wrangle over its 1986 purchase of the Hughes Aircraft Company.

title: Aouita Will Challenge O'Sullivan Indoors
description: Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, who has lost only two indoor races in the last three years, both to his countryman Eamonn Coghlan, will get a stiff test again this winter, even though Coughlan is retired. Said Aouita of Morocco, who holds world records outdoors at 1,500, 2,000 and 5,000 meters and ran the second-fastest mile in history, 3:46.76, will compete against O'Sullivan in three American indoor meets: the 3,000-meter run in the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden, the 5,000 meters at a meet at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., and the mile run at the Vitalis-Meadowlands Invitation meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. ''He's here for records,'' O'Sullivan said yesterday at a news conference in Manhattan. ''He likes to beat people. He likes to crush people. I don't mind; the feeling is reciprocal.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adolph Coors Co., Golden, Colo., reported record beer sales in the fiscal year 1988 of 16.5 million barrels, a 5.6 percent increase over the previous year.

title: Richard Davis Quintet
description: Richard Davis, a bassist, is leading a quintet - with Cecil Bridgewater on trumpet, Ricky Ford on tenor saxophone, Sir Roland Hanna on piano and Freddie Waits on drums - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., with a $12 cover and $6 minimum.

title: Murder Suspect Flees Rikers Unnoticed
description: A man awaiting a second trial on murder charges left Rikers Island last month after an accomplice falsified jail records to make him eligible for bail, a spokeswoman for the City Corrections Department said last night.

title: Southern National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chicago Journal
description: Cathy Barrett's children hadn't been born when she wrote a letter to WGN-TV nine years ago, requesting tickets to ''The Bozo Show.'

title: Review/Dance; Balanchine and Robbins, by the City Ballet
description: That the New York City Ballet is blessed with talent was evident Tuesday night at the New York State Theater when the company danced works by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins that enabled many dancers to appear in major roles.

title: Time for Truce Talks in U.S.-Europe Beef War
description: To the Editor:

title: Allegheny Plans to Sell Key Units to Rival
description: Allegheny International Inc. disclosed yesterday that its 13 directors had unanimously approved a plan of reorganization that involves selling the company's prized Sunbeam and Oster appliance units to one of its largest competitors, the Black & Decker Corporation, for about $260 million.

title: Review/Theater; Turgenev, With License And Without Reverence
description: Brian Friel labeled his recent adaptation of the novel ''Fathers and Sons'' ''after Turgenev'' to indicate that he had taken certain artistic liberties with the original. In his version, ''Nothing Sacred'' (at Hartford Stage), the Canadian playwright George F. Walker has assumed artistic license.

title: Ehrlich Pleads Guilty to Charges of Bribery
description: Bernard Ehrlich, a former New York National Guard general, pleaded guilty yesterday to state charges that he accepted a bribe to get the Guard to buy the same hand-held computer that the Citisource Company sold to the New York City Parking Violations Bureau.

title: Showing Beats Telling in Many Courtroom Cases
description: In the lobby area of Elizabeth Browning's office here is an illustration simple enough for a school child to understand.

title: It's Business as Usual for Undaunted Capital Mayor
description: The Mayor, as usual, is running a good half hour late.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES New England's largest utility offered to buy the nonnuclear assets of Public Service of New Hampshire, the first utility to file for bankruptcy protection since the Depression. But the deal would not resolve the principal roadblock to opening the Seabrook nuclear plant, the issue of emergency evacuation planning. [ Page A1. ] Allegheny International proposed to sell Sunbeam and Oster to Black & Decker for $260 million as part of a larger reorganization plan to emerge from Chapter 11 protection. [ D1. ] Drexel Burnham Lambert is seeking to recruit two former chairmen of the S.E.C., John S. R. Shad as its chairman and Roderick M. Hills as a director. [ D6. ] Ford raised its quarterly dividend 25 percent, making the dividend yield comparable to that of G.M.'s common stock. Analysts were divided over whether G.M. would raise its dividend. [ D4. ] Emigrant Savings Bank offered to buy Greater New York Savings Bank for $200 million. Greater New York rejected the offer, which analysts said was far too low. [ D3. ] Clemente Global Growth Fund drew the S.E.C. into its fight against a hostile takeover by a group that includes T. Boone Pickens 3d, the son of the corporate raider. [ D2. ] Chemical Banking's fourth-quarter earnings rose 25.7 percent, bolstered by interest payments from Brazil and by the performance of its Texas Commerce unit. [ D3. ] Bear Stearns had its most profitable quarter ever and announced plans to buy back four million shares. [ D3. ] Sixteen American electronics companies are actively looking at banding together to compete in high-definition TV. [ D2. ] International Paper plans to begin a bid for Aussedat Rey, Europe's leading paper maker. [ D4. ] Knight-Ridder plans to sell two daily newspapers, in Pasadena, Calif., and Gary, Ind. [ D5. ] Southmark's two top officers are trying to sell their 21.7 percent stake in the ailing company. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL Britain and the European Commission put on hold one of the biggest corporate takeover battles ever seen in Europe. The decisions affected the hostile bid for Plessey by General Electric of Britain and Siemens of West Germany. [ D1. ] Alain Chevalier resigned as chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the apparent loser in a struggle with Bernard Arnault, the largest shareholder. Mr. Arnault is likely to be named chairman today. [ D1. ] Japan and the U.S. resolved a dispute over the exchange of military technology that had threatened cooperation on a new fighter plane for the Japanese Air Force. [ D1. ] MARKETS The dollar was held relatively steady by the threat of further coordinated central bank intervention. No dollar selling in the open market was reported. [ D1. ] Stock prices surged again, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 15.89, to close at 2,222.32, another post-crash high. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher as a technical short-covering rally turned into broad-based buying. [ D12. ] Domestic crude oil prices fluctuated wildly before closing unchanged on the New York Mercantile Exchange. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The President foresees a vanishing deficit in his final budget, but skepticism is in order. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Stocks of companies that suffer in a recession continue to sell at levels that appear cheap. Market Place. [ D6. ] A new novel mentions lots of brand names, in return for promotional considerations. Advertising. [ D5. ]

title: Giuliani Finds His Is the Head Now Hunted
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, undoubtedly the nation's best known United States Attorney, is not the only one now contemplating his future. So are some of the major law firms in New York.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Sues The Times Over Real-Estate Advertising
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the New York Open Housing Center, an organization that advocates fair housing, sued The New York Times yesterday, asserting that The Times carries racially discriminatory housing advertisements.

title: Inauguration With a Mission
description: The five-day inaugural gala has been packed with symbols carefully planned to convey the tone of the Bush administration. Page D28.

title: Nominee for 'Drug Czar' Has Tough-Talking Past
description: William J. Bennett, President-elect George Bush's choice to coordinate the Federal Government's battle against illegal drugs, has always spoken bluntly when he felt strongly about something, and the drug problem in the United States is something he feels strongly about.

title: Restaurants
description: La Boite en Bois Just a few years ago, when someone seeking restaurant advice asked me what to look for around Lincoln Center, my response was ''a cab.'' I was only half joking, for pickings in the neighborhood were lean. Cafe Luxembourg was always a solid choice, but it is difficult to reserve on short notice. The appearance of La Boite en Bois in mid-1985 added a charming option for those who sought something a little more tranquil. Both are still going strong amid much needed competition.

title: Mayoral Credibility and the Talent Bank
description: Six years ago Mayor Koch did something naive or sloppy, or more likely disingenuous. He established a job-referral service that he said was designed to ''attract women and members of minority groups to city service.''

title: N.C.A.A. Is Called Biased After Change on Scholarships
description: Until Wednesday's final session, it seemed as if the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 83d convention would be remembered more for the beauty of the host city than for what happened inside the convention hall.

title: G.M.'s Saturn Unit
description: The Saturn Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it would hire 1,000 people and spend $1 billion on capital equipment this year to prepare for the introduction of its cars by the fall of 1990, as planned. The company now employs 500 people at its complex in Spring Hill, Tenn., where buildings are still being completed.

title: For Schultz, Bad News Is No News
description: Dick Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, has either had a vision or his standards are lower than the grade-point averages of some college athletes. There is no logical explanation for Schultz's rose-colored state-of-the-N.C.A.A. address to the convention in San Francisco earlier this week, in light of the almost daily revelations of scandals in big-time college sports.

title: U.S. Honed Tactics Used Against Libyan Jets
description: The American fighter crews that shot down two Libyan warplanes last week used tactics developed through mock combat exercises that include missions against Soviet-built warplanes that have been obtained by Western intelligence agencies, a Pentagon official said today.

title: Freedom Man, Mocked
description: On Wednesday night President Reagan recounted the story of an Indochinese refugee calling from his crammed and leaky boat to a crewman on the carrier Midway: ''Hello, American sailor -Hello, Freedom Man.'' Yet his Administration proposes to make room for more Soviet refugees mostly by lowering the quota for Southeast Asians.

title: U.N. Seeks Procedural Shifts For Poison Gas Investigations
description: To improve compliance with a 1925 ban on chemical and germ warfare, the United Nations is preparing a code of conduct to govern investigations into reported violations, officials say.

title: Auctions
description: From a Master's Hand

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY McPARTLAND PLAYS

title: Unitel Video Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included equity in earnings of 50 percent-owned affiliate of $71,000 for the latest quarter, and equity in loss of 50 percent-owned affiliate of $18,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Andrea Roschelle, Lawyer, And Howard Leader Wed
description: Andrea Leslie Roschelle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Roschelle of New York, was married at the Stanhope Hotel in New York last evening to Howard Leader, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Leader of Scottsdale, Ariz. Judge Joel Blumenthal of the Criminal Court in Queens, performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Film; Science Fiction in Jordan
description: ''Friendship's Death'' was shown as part of the 1988 New Directors/New Films festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 25. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street.

title: Judge Drops Counts Against Ex-Police Chief
description: A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a 32-count indictment accusing the former chief of Metro-North's railroad police of conducting illegal background checks on job applicants and people who had sued the railroad.

title: Nellcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
A Family Of Gospel Singers
description: A gospel family reunion should raise the rafters tomorrow night at Greenwich House. Martha Bass, a traditional gospel singer who was a soloist with the Ward Singers in their heyday, will share the stage with her two children: Fontella Bass, best known for the 1965 soul hit ''Rescue Me,'' and David Peaston, whose electrifying high tenor has won him top prizes and national television appearances at Apollo Theater talent shows.

title: Punjab Militants Said to Kill 36
description: Sikhs waging a separatist war in Punjab killed 36 people, hanging 4 in revenge for the executions of two Sikhs convicted in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, the police said today.

title: Thomas Brennan, 81, Trade Group Official
description: Thomas M. Brennan, an official of the National Association of Manufacturers for 28 years before his retirement in 1965, died of cancer on Tuesday at his winter home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 81 years old and also had a home in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Recycling Plant for Rockland
description: The Rockland County Executive, John T. Grant, is proposing a $3 million bond issue to plan and design a countywide recycling plant. He said he would submit the proposal to the County Legislature at the end of the month, along with legislation on the management of recycling in the county. The proposals are part of his plan to develop a countywide recycling program by 1990. He announced the plans at a news conference Wednesday.

title: Import Vehicle Duties Studied
description: The Treasury Department has taken under advisement a Customs Service decision to classify imported sport-utility vehicles like the Suzuki Samurai and most small vans as trucks, subjecting them to duties 10 times higher than those for cars, a spokesman for the agency said Thursday night.

title: Soviet Press Casts Doubt on Quake Survivor Story
description: Soviet press agencies and television cast doubt tonight on reports that six survivors were found Wednesday under the rubble of an apartment building that collapsed in the Armenian earthquake 35 days earlier. But the news organizations did not retract the reports.

title: Thompson to Leave Bench in Protest on Scholarships
description: John Thompson, the Georgetown University basketball coach, said today he would leave the bench at the start of Saturday night's Big East game with Boston College as a protest against a new scholarship regulation approved this week by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. He called the regulation ''discriminatory.''

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan View of Racism

title: Reagan Vows to Continue Battle on Abortion
description: One week before he leaves office, President Reagan declared that he will never ''leave the battle'' to reshape Federal policy on abortion and welfare reform, two issues that have emerged as political litmus tests for conservatives in the Reagan years.

title: Israel Uses New Bullet Against Arabs
description: Israeli forces in recent weeks have been using a new type of bullet against Palestinian protesters in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Palestinians and Israelis say.

title: Lotus Shipments
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said it had started shipping its new microcomputer and mainframe software that will allow Lotus 1-2-3 and Symphony software users to gain access to mainframe data. The company said the new software, Application Connection Release 5.0, was priced at $40,000 without volume discounts.

title: U.S. Sees Gains in Effort to Stop West German Aid to Libya Chemical Plant
description: Administration officials say the American campaign to stop Libya from acquiring expertise and materials from West German and other European companies for its vast chemical plant has succeeded, at least temporarily.

title: Jerome P. Dean Jr. Weds Marcela Davison Aviles
description: At St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Tucson, Ariz., Marcela Consuelo Davison Aviles, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Beatty Davison of Tucson, was married last evening to Jerome Paul Dean Jr., the son of Mr. Dean of Falmouth, Mass., and Mary Jane Dean of Gold River, Calif., Msgr. Arsenio Carillo performed the ceremony.

title: The Teen-Agers Goetz Shot: 4 Years Marked by Struggle
description: At first, Troy Canty enjoyed the attention that engulfed him after he and three other teen-agers had been shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in an IRT subway car, Mr. Canty's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Patents; Preventing a Car From Rolling Over
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation received a patent this week for a computer-controlled system that anticipates the likelihood of a car to roll over and tries to prevent it.

title: KEY NORTH COUNTS DISMISSED BY COURT
description: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell today dismissed the main criminal charges against Oliver L. North in the Iran-contra case, saying he was ''totally powerless'' to try the two charges without classified documents the Reagan Administration had ordered withheld.

title: Goetz Is Given One-Year Term On Gun Charge
description: An unrepentant Bernhard H. Goetz was sentenced yesterday to one year in jail for possessing an unlicensed gun when he shot four men he thought were going to rob him on an IRT train on Dec. 22, 1984.

title: Venality So Bald It's Now Intolerable
description: In a country where, the saying goes, only ''prostitutes, blacks and the poor'' end up in jail, Brazilians have long shrugged cynically at corruption scandals involving top officials and prominent businessmen, and even at killings carried out by police officers and soldiers.

title: Central Banks' Action Drops Rates
description: Interest rates continued to plunge yesterday, largely because of coordinated actions by the Federal Reserve and other central banks to reduce the dollar's value.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Insurance Addiction
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo would raid the state insurance fund to balance New York State's budget, in deficit by $2.04 billion. This reckless proposal raises serious questions about his understanding of both budgeting and insurance.

title: All-Star Jazz Reunion
description: Art Farmer on fluegelhorn, Clifford Jordan on tenor saxophone, the singer Chris Connor and many other musicians will perform at J's All-Star Jazz Reunion at 6 and 9 P.M. tomorrow. J's is on the second floor at 2581 Broadway, above 98th Street; admission is $15, with a two-drink minimum. Information: 666-3600.

title: Verplank Leads Hope By Two
description: Scott Verplank just didn't feel comfortable on the PGA Tour. For the first year or two, he struggled on the circuit. That was ''just a feeling'' he said, even though he was the rookie in 1986 who everybody thought would be the next big star.

title: Correction
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Thursday and its headline, about Gen. Maj. Raden Haji Harsoyo of Indonesia, incorrectly described a peacekeeping unit in which he was an officer. He was deputy commander of an Indonesian contingent in Vietnam created under the Paris peace accords of 1973; the operation was not affiliated with the United Nations.

title: Bridge; Post-mortem arguments tend to dominate partnerships after every duplicate event.
description: After every duplicate event, almost every partnership tends to be embroiled in post-mortem arguments: ''Why did you bid this?'' Or ''Why did you play that?'' The maximum dispute potential comes from mixed-pair events, since more than a third of the participants are combinations of husbands and wives who drive home together and can bicker, if they choose, far into the night.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Quits Times Suit
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday suspended its involvement in a lawsuit charging The New York Times with publishing racially discriminatory housing advertisements.

title: Justice Dept. Removes 21 in Budget Cutback
description: Budget worries have left 21 employees of the Justice Department's press and legislative affairs offices looking for work this week.

title: (A Pop Quiz) Leveraged Buyouts Are: Good for U. S. Business
description: Somewhere, in the midst of the public clamor about leveraged buyouts, a small but persistent voice is trying to be heard. If we listen carefully, we will hear some things that may surprise us: that disassembling inefficient conglomerates can be good for American business, that when managers own equity in their corporations they perform better and that LBO's can help make industry more competitive.

title: New Order on Aircraft Wiring
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today issued its second order in two days for checks of possible miswiring of aircraft emergency systems, requiring inspection of all Boeing 757 airliners.

title: Bush Begins Fishing Trip
description: His Cabinet was finally set, but President-elect George Bush had one more announcement to make as he landed here today for a weekend of angling for tarpon and bonefish.

title: A Third Career for Admiral Watkins
description: James D. Watkins, the retired admiral chosen by President-elect Bush to be Energy Secretary, faces one of the harder tasks of any cabinet member. He must clean up the appalling mess at the nation's nuclear bomb factories, modernize the aging plants to avert unilateral nuclear disarmament and persuade a deficit-ridden Government to pay the $81 billion bill.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Nations Seek Banks' Help For 3d World
description: Citing social and political tensions in impoverished Latin America, the United States and other major industrial nations are trying to induce their commercial banks to lend the countries much more and to absorb some losses on loans they have already made, American officials and officials of other leading governments said.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of a Spanish Basque separatist leader in France referred incorrectly in some copies to the period in which a conservative Parliament and Cabinet shared power with President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist. It was March 1986 to May 1988.

title: Followers of Many Religions Contribute to Neediest Fund
description: Bishop G. P. Mellick Belshaw of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey has sent $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: New York Housing Policy Should Solve, Not Worsen, Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Nichols, Journalist, 60
description: Peter Nichols, for 30 years the Rome correspondent of The Times of London, died Wednesday of a brain hemorrhage in Bracciano, Italy, where he lived. He was 60 years old.

title: Reviews/Pop; A Bassist Plays Free Jazz With Design
description: Reggie Workman's music swirls around melodies like undersea currents around a reef. Mr. Workman played bass with John Coltrane and other 1960's innovators and has collaborated often during the 1980's with the choreographer Maya Milenovic. He brings a sense of dramatic, sometimes cinematic narrative to free jazz. The music is anything but a uniform sprawl of improvisation.

title: New Limits Imposed On 376 Substances Found in Workplace
description: The Labor Department today broadened its regulation of toxic and hazardous substances in the workplace, putting new limits on such substances as grain dust and gasoline fumes while strengthening existing limits on others.

title: John Unterecker, 66, A Poet and Biographer
description: John Eugene Unterecker, a poet, biographer and educator, died after heart surgery Monday at Straub Hospital in Honolulu. He was 66 years old and lived in Hawaii.

title: Computer-Imaging and a Satellite To Aid Search for Pan Am Dead
description: An international group of scientists is planning to use satellite photography and other sophisticated computer-imaging techniques to aid searchers still looking for the remains of 28 passengers in the widely scattered wreckage of a Pan Am Boeing 747 in Scotland.

title: Board of Estimate Approves Twin Towers for First Ave.
description: The New York City Board of Estimate, in a pre-dawn vote yesterday, approved zoning changes to allow construction of a twin-tower condominium, hotel and shopping complex on First Avenue at 60th Street, overshadowing the Queensboro Bridge.

title: Woman, 18, Is Shot to Death At a McDonald's in Brooklyn
description: A man sprayed the inside of a McDonald's restaurant with gunfire last night in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, fatally wounding an 18-year-old woman, the police said.

title: Crossword Is a True Anglo-American Creation; Social Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Returns Body of Pilot in '86 Raid
description: Libya today returned the body of a United States Air Force officer who was killed in the bombing raid on Tripoli in 1986.

title: Coping: With Financial Planning
description: Like sports records, New Year's resolutions often seem made to be broken. Perhaps it is because they tend to be made in haste or because the carrying-through must start just when post-holiday letdown comes face to face with January.

title: Michael N. Katzoff, Principal, 79
description: Michael M. Katzoff, a retired principal at the High School of Fashion Industries, died of heart failure Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: BONN SAYS IT KNEW OF A GERMAN ROLE IN A LIBYAN PLANT
description: West Germany said today that its intelligence services had warned of possible participation by German companies in a suspect Libyan chemical plant almost a month before President Reagan told Chancellor Helmut Kohl of similar concern.

title: Patents; Device to Help Mothers Store Breast Milk
description: John Hauk, an inventor in Oakland, Calif., won patent approval for Lactote, a device to help working mothers store breast milk while they are on the job.

title: Miami, Saying It's Overburdened, Tells Nicaraguans to Stay Away
description: After three decades of welcoming Hispanic immigrants with open arms, officials here said today that Miami could not cope with the latest wave of Nicaraguans and had no jobs or housing for them.

title: Review/Opera; 5 New Singers Instead of 7 In the Cast of 8 for 'Aida'
description: In the steadily shifting panoply that counts as casting coherence at the Metropolitan Opera these days, Thursday night's performance of ''Aida'' included five singers and a conductor who did not perform the opera at the opening night of this new production five weeks ago. It would have been a nearly clean sweep - an entirely different cast apart from Paul Plishka's Ramfis - except that two original cast members, Leona Litchell in the title role and John Gilmore as the Messenger, substituted for Aprile Millo and Charles Anthony, who were both indisposed.

title: Quayle Trip May Be in Store
description: Dan Quayle's first trip out of the country as Vice President is likely to be to Caracas, Venezuela, for the inauguration of Carlos Andres Perez as president on Feb. 2, an aide to President-elect George Bush said Thursday.

title: Times Appoints 2 in Photos and Design
description: Appointments of a picture editor and a deputy design director at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the paper's executive editor.

title: U.S. Urges 2 Steps on Measles
description: A decade after predicting that measles was on the verge of eradication, Federal health officials have proposed two new steps to try to wipe out the persistent disease.

title: Dow Adds 3.75, to 2,226.07, in Slow Trading
description: Stock prices gained slightly yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average inched up to yet another post-crash high.

title: Cuomo-Regan Pension Pact: How They Agreed to Changes in the System
description: When Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Comptroller announced a plan this week to save the state hundreds of millions of dollars in pension costs, the announcement raised questions about whether the state's pension fund could be manipulated to yield savings.

title: From Shop to Lab to Farm, Animal Rights Battle Is Felt
description: Irwin Roberts, whose Roberts Furs has been at the same downtown location here for 30 years, has taken to having customers who buy fur coats escorted out a back entrance by a security guard.

title: 'Disposable' Diapers
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Die at French Ski Resort
description: Seven technicians testing a cable car at a ski resort in southeastern France were killed today when it broke loose and plunged 200 yards into the snow, police said. The new cable car was being installed at the Alpe d'Huez resort.

title: Patents; Four-Wheel Steering, For Stability
description: The Honda Motor Company this week received the first of what appears to be a series of patents for its system of four-wheel steering in automobiles. The company introduced its first four-wheel steering system last year, as an option in the Prelude, and the new patent sheds considerable light on how it works.

title: Mexican Oil Prices
description: Mexican oil prices rose an average of more than $2 a barrel in December in the wake of the new OPEC quota agreement, Pemex, the Government oil monopoly, said. The price of light Isthmus crude in the Americas was $13.93 a barrel in December, up from $11.62 in November, Petroleos Mexicanos said late Thursday. The heavy Maya grade sold for $10.52 a barrel, up from $9.21 a month earlier, and the extra-light Olmeca for $15.24, up from $12.90.

title: Art for Religious Rituals
description: ''On the Sacred in Art: Receptacles of Spirit,'' an exhibition of work by six artists, will be on view at the Rotunda Gallery in the Brooklyn War Memorial, Cadman Plaza West and Orange Street, through Feb. 11. Many of the works, from a variety of traditions, are used in specific religious rituals. Hours: Tuesday through Friday, noon to 5 P.M., and Saturday, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: 718-875-4031.

title: Crossword Is a True Anglo-American Creation; Better After 40
description: To the Editor:

title: Crossword Is a True Anglo-American Creation; Puzzling Confession
description: To the Editor:

title: Rochester Coach Appears In Line for Columbia Job
description: There were indications yesterday that Ray Tellier, the head coach at the University of Rochester, would be appointed the next football coach at Columbia University. But Al Paul, the Columbia athletic director, and Tellier refused to confirm that a choice had been made.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Saturday about the Pentagon procurement case described Stuart Berlin, a defendant in the case, incorrectly in some copies. He continues to work for the Defense Department.

title: Chang Is Selected For U.S. Davis Team
description: Michael Chang, the 1988 rookie of the year in men's tennis, will join Andre Agassi, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso on the United States Davis Cup team, which will meet Paraguay in Fort Myers, Fla., Feb. 3-5.

title: Keeping A Medical History On Hand
description: As the winter vacation season reaches its peak, travelers are packing their clothes, sports equipment and, in more and more cases, their medical records.

title: Rockland Jury Hears Evidence In Murder Trial
description: A Rockland County jury began hearing evidence today in the murder trial of 18-year-old Alonzo Williams, who shot his mother five times after, he said, she had sexually abused him since he was 6 years old.

title: String Band Festival
description: The 1989 String Band Festival, at 8:30 and 11:30 tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880), will include the Nashville Bluegrass Band, Major Conte and the Canebrake Rattlers, Pat Cannon's Foot and Fiddle Dance Company and the Wretched Refuse String Band. Tickets are $13.

title: Sooner Lineman Shot
description: Prosecutors in Norman, Okla., have charged Jerry Parks, a starting cornerback for Oklahoma, with shooting with intent to injure after a teammate was wounded during an argument in an athletes' dormitory early yesterday morning.

title: Ban Disappears, and a New Hotel Appears
description: The developer Harry Macklowe, who illegally tore down four buildings in Manhattan in 1985, has started building a hotel on the site two years before he was supposed to because the New York City Council - apparently unknowingly - removed a ban on the construction.

title: Pepsico in New Deal With General Cinema
description: The sale of the General Cinema Corporation's soft-drink bottler to Pepsico Inc. is on again, but at a higher price of $1.75 billion, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Student Had Gun, Police Say
description: A 16-year-old student at a Roman Catholic diocesan high school in Manhattan was arrested yesterday after he brought an unloaded .38-caliber revolver to school and hid it in his locker, the police said. They said five cartridges were found in his pockets. The student, Anthony Reyes, of 220 East 102d Street in Manhattan, brought the revolver to Immaculata High School, at 317 East 33d Street, yesterday morning the police said. He was charged with criminal possession of a weapon.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 West German intelligence warned its government of possible involvement by German companies in a disputed Libyan chemical plant almost a month before President Reagan expressed similar concern. Page 1 Israelis have been using a new bullet against Palestinian protesters. Although meant to be nonlethal, the bullet is killing and injuring protesters at an increased rate. 4 Israeli soldiers fired on Arabs in the West Bank, killing two 4 In listing an anti-apartheid group, the African National Congress, as a terrorist organization, a Pentagon report has touched off a furor in South Africa. The State Department repudiated the characterization. 3 Washington's campaign to stop Libya from gaining Western expertise to operate its chemical plant has succeeded, at least temporarily, Administration officials said. 5 Body of U.S. Air Force officer is returned by Libya 5 The search for passenger bodies in the wreckage of a Pan Am Boeing 747 in Scotland will be aided by satellite photography and other sophisticated computer imaging techniques. 2 Soviet press agencies cast doubt on reports that six men were found alive Wednesday under a building that collapsed in the Armenian earthquake 35 days earlier. But the agencies did not retract the reports. 3 A decision to allow more refugees from the Soviet Union into the United States at the expense of Southeast Asians has upset Thailand, Malaysia and other countries where Vietnamese boat people seek asylum. 3 Greek and Turkish fighter planes confronted one another over the Aegean sea, prompting Greece to put its armed forces on limited alert and contributing to a deterioration in the countries' relations. 2 Political liberaliztion in Turkey, including the lifting of emergency rules in Istanbul a few weeks ago, has led to increasingly free-wheeling Turkish newspapers and the testing of old taboos for the first time in years. 2 Rio journal: A venality finally so bald that it's intolerable 4 National 6-8, 26 Producer prices rose by 0.4 percent in December and by 4 percent for all of 1988, the largest annual increasesince 1981, the Labor Department said, indicating that inflationary pressures are growing. 1 The nation's retail sales rose 6.7 percent last year from 1987 to a record $1.61 trillion, the biggest year-to-year gain since 1984, the Commerce Department reported. 44 Miami can't take more immigrants, its officials said, marking a turning point for a city that for three decades has welcomed Hispanic aliens with open arms. That turning point has resulted in part from a wave of Nicaraguans now arriving in Miami after a Federal court ruling this week. 1 The key charges against Oliver North were dismissed by the Federal judge who said he was ''totally powerless'' to try those charges without classified documents - ordered witheld by the White House - as evidence. 1 Rules on toxic and hazardous matter in the workplace were broadened by the Labor Department, which put new limits on substances like gasoline fumes. Labor and consumer called the rules inadequate. 1 Animal rights groups are growing in influence, their recent achievements indicate. Targets of the groups say that radicals are taking control of the movement, and they point to an increase in violent acts. 1 Rights leaders exaggerate racism in America to keep their cause alive, President Reagan said. Mr. Reagan's comments drew immediate criticism from the civil rights groups that have regularly clashed with him. 8 Reagan vows to continue battle on abortion 8

title: Midseason Clash for Powerhouses
description: The game of the season comes up today in Canton, N.Y., where Harvard plays St. Lawrence. Both teams are expected to be undefeated after games last night against lesser opponents, and a midseason clash such as this one between two major unbeaten teams is rare.

title: U.S. Expatriate Held by Costa Rica as a Spy
description: An American expatriate rancher living in Costa Rica has been arrested on charges of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency and links with arms and drug smugglers and with the Nicaraguan rebels, a justice official said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Florida has suffered enough.

title: About New York; Locksmith Binds The Wounds Of a Fearful City
description: Miguel Martinez enters apartments and the darkest corners of people's deepest fears, fixes their locks and leaves them feeling they might survive in this city for one more day.

title: Sadler's Wells Ballet to Quit London Next Year
description: Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet, the sister company and touring wing of the Royal Ballet, is leaving London in August of next year to make its home in Birmingham, England's second-largest city.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a book written by a former soldier in the Rhodesian Army misidentified the publisher of Baobab Books. He is Hugh Lewin, not Lewan.

title: Crossword Is a True Anglo-American Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; An Implantable Device Checks Blood Pressure
description: Data Sciences Inc. of St. Paul won patent approval this week for an implantable device that monitors blood pressure.

title: CAMPEAU'S OPTIMISTIC SCENARIOS
description: Robert Campeau sits animatedly in his office on the 20th floor of the Federated/Allied Stores headquarters building here and shuffles his scenarios.

title: Intervention Fails to Halt Dollar Rise
description: The dollar surged again yesterday, overcoming a round of coordinated central bank intervention led by the Federal Reserve with repeated dollar selling.

title: Bareheaded Motorcyclists Pressed Anew to Cove Up
description: While Gary Busey, the actor, recovers from head injuries caused by a motorcycle accident last month, legislators in several states are drawing attention to his case as they revive attempts to require motorcyclists to wear safety helmets. The well-publicized accident has also given lawmakers and safety experts an opportunity to promote the use of helmets in many other recreational sports, like bicycling, skiing, skateboarding and roller-skating.

title: 2 Palestinians Dead, 17 Hurt in Army Clashes
description: Israeli soldiers opened fire on Arabs in the West Bank city of Hebron today after a confrontation with Jewish settlers, Israeli radio and Arab reports said. Two Palestinians died and 17 were wounded in separate clashes.

title: Review/Ballet; A Many-Faceted Revival of 'Jewels'
description: ''Jewels,'' a three-act plotless work that George Balanchine created in 1967, has always had a special place in the New York City Ballet's repertory, and on Thursday night it was presented as part of a special occasion.

title: 'Black Book' Tells Tale of Jobs and Politics
description: The highest-paying jobs allocated through Mayor Edward I. Koch's Talent Bank - an office set up in part to promote the hiring of black and Hispanic applicants - went overwhelmingly to whites, a review of city records shows.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 14, 1989
description: Economy

title: Draw in Australia
description: The defending champions, Mats Wilander and Steffi Graf, were matched against relatively easy first-round opponents yesterday for the $1.5 million Australian Open Championships, the year's first Grand Slam tournament. Wilander, ranked No. 1 in the world and seeded first, will open against a fellow Swede, Tobias Svantesson, who is ranked 95th in the world.

title: Burning Memories, Mississippi 1964
description: As I watched ''Mississippi Burning,'' a new film about civil rights unrest in the South in 1964, I found myself remembering. I recalled the lost moral universe relegated to the background of the film.

title: Argentine Inflation Curb
description: The Argentine Government and industry leaders have agreed to extend until the end of June the anti-inflation package announced Aug. 3. Economy Ministry officials said today that rises in the price of a wide range of goods and public-sector tariffs would continue to be limited to 4 percent monthly. The austral, Argentina's currency, will continue to be devalued at a similar rate.

title: Yugoslavia Ad Came From Nazi Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: PROODUCER PRICES UP 0.4% IN MONTH AND 4% FOR 1988
description: In a report signaling that inflationary pressures are still growing, the Labor Department said yesterday that producer prices rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in December.

title: U.S. Report Stirs Furor in South Africa
description: A Pentagon report listing an anti-apartheid group, the African National Congress, as a terrorist organization has touched off a furor in South Africa, and the State Department today repudiated that characterization.

title: Air Incident Worsens Greek-Turkish Ties
description: Units of the Greek armed forces in the eastern Aegean have been put on limited alert after a confrontation between Greek and Turkish fighter planes, a Greek Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: James E. Hurtubise, Race-Car Driver, 56
description: James E. Hurtubise, a race-car driver who once held the average qualifying speed record for the Indianapolis 500, died Jan. 6 after suffering a heart attack near his home in Port Arthur, Tex. He was 56 years old.

title: Bid for Tidewater
description: Tidewater Inc. said it had received an unsolicited letter from a group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis-based investor, offering $9.50 a share in cash to acquire the company. Tidewater, which operates vessels for the offshore oil and gas industry, has almost 22.5 million shares outstanding, giving the offer a prospective total value of about $213 million. Tidewater's shares closed today at $7.50, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Tidewater, which said it would consider the offer in due course, added that the letter indicated that the Jacobs group had not yet arranged financing.

title: KEY RATES
Koch Proposes Higher Taxes In 9-Point Plan
description: The Koch administration proposed a list of tax increases yesterday intended to help balance New York City's budget without conflicting with Albany's efforts to fill a much larger hole in the state's spending plan.

title: Reviews/Pop; Singer of Songs With a Political Edge
description: Chris Cochrane, who played at A-Mica (324 East Ninth Street) on Sunday, performed two different types of music. Mr. Cochrane, a guitarist and co-leader of the group No Safety, sang several songs that referred to regular songwriting conventions. And he played industrial, metallic soundscapes that fit into the Lower East Side improvising tradition.

title: Susan Parmenter Wed in Scarsdale
description: Susan Jane Parmenter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Parmenter of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Brian Scott Walters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Walters of Chatham, Ontario, were married yesterday in Scarsdale. The Rev. Robert S. MacLennan performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less.

title: Review/Music; Shakespeare and a Cellist
description: The Pro Musicis Foundation, which presents young musicians in concert and requires that they also perform in prisons, hospitals and shelters, is celebrating its 20th annivesary with a series of five free concerts at Florence Gould Hall. The first was offered by Sharon Robinson, the cellist, on Thursday evening.

title: William Michelson, 74, Ex-Union Leader
description: William Michelson, a former president of the United Storeworkers Union, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Phillies Sign Samuel
description: Juan Samuel, a second baseman turned outfielder, has agreed to a two-year, $2.8 million guaranteed contract, the Philadelphia Phillies announced yesterday. Samuel, 28 years old, who is moving from second base to the outfield this year, batted .243 in 157 games with 12 homers, 67 runs batted in and a club-high 33 stolen bases.(AP)

title: Redmen Seek 3d in Row
description: St. John's will seek its third consecutive victory in the Big East Conference today when it is host to Syracuse, ranked fourth in the latest Associated Press poll, at 2 P.M. at Madison Square Garden.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Shriver Upset: In the $350,000 New South Wales Open Championships in Sydney, Australia, yesterday Top-seeded Martina Navratilova beat Patty Fendick, 6-1, 6-1, and Pam Shriver, seeded second, was beaten by 16th-seeded Terry Phelps, 6-3, 6-3. In men's action, Aaron Krickstein, seeded third, beat Carl Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 2-6, 6-3, 6-3.(AP) Edberg Wins: Stefan Edberg beat Ivan Lendl, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in the Rio International Challenge in Adelaide, Australia. (AP) GOLF Strange Leads: Curtis Strange kept his composure through a midafternoon tropical storm and went on to shoot a two-under-par 70 yesterday to move into a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the $525,000 Daikyo Palm Meadows Cup tournament at Melbourne, Australia.(AP) ALPINE SKIING Swiss Streaking: The defending overall champion, Michela Figini, won her second World Cup downhill in less than 24 hours yesterday at Grindelwald, Switzerland and gave the Swiss women's team its 13th victory in 14 races this season.(AP) N.B.A. 76ers 114, Hawks 101: Charles Barkley had 23 points and 19 rebounds and Hersey Hawkins scored 21 points last night as Philadelphia won its fourth straight game.(AP) Bucks 107, Heat 101: Ricky Pierce scored 23 points, including 16 in the pivotal third quarter as Milwaukee handed Miami its 10th straight loss.(AP) Bulls 104, Nuggets 99: Michael Jordan had 38 points, 12 rebounds and 11 assists for his seventh career triple double to lead Chicago to its third straight victory.(AP) Pistons 119, Bullets 103: Adrian Dantley made 17 of 21 foul shots and finished with 35 points to power Detroit.(AP) Suns 111, Kings 90: Eddie Johnson scored 16 of his 32 points in the third quarter and Armon Gilliam pulled down a career-high 21 rebounds as Phoenix, at home, won for the 12th time in its last 13 games. (AP) Lakers 116, Cavaliers 95: Magic Johnson scored 26 points and handed off 11 assists as Los Angeles, playing at home, swamped Cleveland. The victory kept the Lakers perfect at the Forum, running their record to 14-0 as they remained the league's only unbeaten team at home. The Lakers are 9-12 on the road. The Cavaliers are 25-7 over all. Los Angeles played outstanding defense, getting fast breaks off turnovers and defensive rebounds, and took command of the game in the first half. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 5, Oilers 3: John Druce, Dale Hunter and Mike Millar scored second-period goals last night as Washington extended its unbeaten streak to nine games. The victory was Washington's sixth straight over the Oilers at the Capital Centre.(AP) HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL St. Anthony 68, Tolentine 50: St. Anthony of Jersey City easily overcame St. Nicholas of Tolentine of the Bronx, the defending national champion, in a game at Fordham's Rose Hill gymnasium last night. Terry Dehere, a 6-foot-3-inch senior, led the Friars with 19 points. Doug Adams, a 5-11 junior, who had averaged 3 points a game, led Tolentine with 19 points. Tolentine lost for the fifth time in its last 14 games, while the Friars won their 30th straight over two seasons.

title: Shearson to Take Write-Off Of $105.5 Million for the Year
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it would take $105.5 million in pretax write-offs this year to reflect a decline in value on nearly $150 million of stock and bonds it owns in Mcorp, one of the biggest financially troubled banking companies in Texas.

title: William Chaison, 44, Dancer and Teacher
description: William Chaison, a dancer and choreographer and associate professor of physical education at Kean College in Union, N.J., died last Friday at Doctor's Hospital in New York City. He was 44 years old.

title: Cardinal and Reagan
description: President Reagan is to be interviewed during his stay in New York this weekend by John Cardinal O'Connor. Mr. Reagan is in New York to receive an award from the Knights of Malta. The interview is to be shown on ''Face to Face With John Cardinal O'Connor'' on Channel 2 at 7:30 A.M. Sunday. Cardinal O'Connor is expected to speak with the President about religious issues during Mr. Reagan's tenure and how his beliefs influenced his leadership.

title: S.R.O. Inspection Ends in Arrest
description: The manager of a single-room-occupancy hotel in midtown Manhattan was arrested yesterday after a building inspector found evidence that the hotel was being renovated without a permit.

title: Crossword Is a True Anglo-American Creation; Practical Pens
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Sells Stake In Liberty All-Star
description: An investment group led by the Continental Casualty Company, a unit of the CNA Financial Corporation, has sold its entire 5.8 percent stake in Liberty All-Star Equity Fund. The sale by the Continental group is a blow to certain of the mutual fund's shareholders, who are planning a shareholder vote to convert Liberty All-Star Equity Fund from a closed-end fund, with a fixed number of shares, to an open-end fund.

title: Correction
description: A headline in some editions yesterday on the obituary of John Knight Waters, a retired Army general, misstated a position he held at the United States Military Academy. He was commandant of cadets, not Superintendent of the Academy.

title: New Chairman and Panel Are Named at Moet Vuitton
description: As expected, Bernard Arnault, the 39-year-old French financier, was elected chairman today of the world's largest luxury- goods group, LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, and a new executive committee was formed that for the first time includes no representative of the Moet-Hennessy faction.

title: General Electric and G.E.C. Set Joint Deals
description: The General Electric Company and the General Electric Company P.L.C., Britain's largest manufacturing concern, yesterday announced an agreement to create joint ventures in consumer products, medical equipment and electrical distribution equipment. The companies, which are not related, will also cooperate in the gas turbine business.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Allegheny Gets An Extension
description: The Federal Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh granted Allegheny International a three-week extension yesterday to file the plan of reorganization that its directors had approved unanimously on Wednesday. That plan, backed by the company's shareholders, involves selling Allegheny's Sunbeam and Oster appliance units to a rival, Black & Decker, for about $260 million.

title: Review/Concert; Soviet Emigre Conducts Prokofiev Sixth Symphony
description: Felix Kruglikov, who immigrated to this country from the Soviet Union in 1979 and became assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic in 1984, led a stirring account of Prokofiev's chilling, historically important Symphony No. 6 on Friday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. The concert was part of a subscription series that will continue tonight at 8 and Tuesday at 7:30 P.M.

title: Quayle Says He'll Play Important Role for Bush
description: One week before taking office, Vice President-elect Dan Quayle is undertaking a public campaign to present himself as a leading player in the Bush administration who will actively seek to reshape the image of the Republican Party.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Saving Indoor Plants
description: Pots of gardenias, geraniums, African violets and ficus sit serenely near the window. But look again. When the heat is on, insects multiply indoors. These minute nuisances often live their lives undetected until leaves turn yellow or drop, or the plant fails to thrive. An arsenal of chemical weapons is not necessary to get the insects under control. If the measures suggested here do not work, use a nontoxic house-plant spray. Isolate each plant before it is treated. Indoors, sprays to use are the synthetic pyrethrins or the soap-based products packaged by Safer Inc. Pest Plants Treatment Spider mites Azaleas, ivy Give plants a shower or use a hand mister daily. Mealybugs Gardenias, Wipe backs of leaves and axils jade, with cotton swabs dipped poinsettias, in alcohol. Repeat every few ficus, days to kill nymphs. cactuses, African violets Scale Citrus, palms, Flick off the black or white camellias specks that adhere to stems, or scrub off with a soft toothbrush and lukewarm water. White flies Lantanas, Use sticky traps, available geraniums where housewares are sold. Replace every few days until flies disappear.

title: Vehicle Sales Up Slow 5.7%; Light Trucks a Bright Spot
description: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks opened the year at a sluggish pace that analysts said reflected the last-minute efforts of several companies to bolster their 1988 results.

title: 2 Teamsters Convicted in Payroll-Padding Scheme
description: After deliberating 16 hours over three days, a Federal jury today convicted two top officials of the Ohio teamsters' union of racketeering and embezzlement.

title: British Computer Users Have an Unlucky 13th
description: A computer virus struck personal computers in Britain today, wiping out program files and causing problems for businesses, a computer expert said.

title: California Moves to Bolster Teaching of Evolution
description: The California Board of Education today unanimously adopted a policy intended to strengthen the teaching of evolution in California schools and in textbooks purchased by the state.

title: Fernandez Eyes Arbiter
description: Sid Fernandez, the left-handed pitcher, filed for salary arbitration yesterday.

title: Rushdie Novel Brings Bomb Threats
description: Several anonymous bomb threats by telephone have been directed against the New York publisher of Salman Rushdie's new novel, ''The Satanic Verses,'' and thousands of threatening letters have been sent to the publishing house. The book, which has been banned in India, Pakistan, South Africa, Egypt and other countries with many Muslims, is regarded as blasphemous by fundamentalist Muslim groups.

title: The Coach Has a Head Of Wild Curls
description: It's late, 1 or 2 o'clock in the morning, and the man of the house taps the woman of the house on the shoulder. She stirs in bed. ''Huh?'' she says foggily. ''Sweetheart,'' he says in typically dulcet tones for that hour, ''can you do me a favor?''

title: Sheets Paved With Gold?
description: Always the last to know what's going on, I discovered just two days ago that it is now possible to spend $540 for a bedsheet and that people are actually doing so.

title: Disciplining Pentagon Suppliers
description: The suspension this week of two large companies in the arms industry from doing business with the Federal Government has overshadowed a far more prevalent trend, a steady increase in the number of small companies being banned from dealing with the military.

title: Reagan Hints Rights Leaders Exaggerate Racism to Preserve Cause
description: President Reagan has suggested in a television interview that some civil rights leaders exaggerate the degree of racism in America to keep their cause alive and to maintain their own prominence.

title: Tenneco Unit Sale
description: Tenneco Inc., the Houston-based diversified industrial corporation, said it had reached a definitive agreement to sell its Louisiana Intrastate Gas Corporation unit and related assets. Terms were not disclosed. The company is being acquired by a new corporation formed by Wasserstein Perella Partners, Gale L. Galloway and others. The sale, which is expected to close in the first quarter of this year, substantially completes the sale of Tenneco's oil and gas businesses. The company received about $7.5 billion from the sales.

title: Asia Upset Over U.S. Quota Cuts
description: Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong and other countries where Vietnamese boat people seek asylum are upset with President Reagan's decision to increase the number of Soviet refugees allowed into the United States at the expense of Southeast Asians, Thai officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Custom-Made Dress for Next First Lady
description: Arnold Scaasi said yesterday that Barbara Bush would select one of his made-to-order dresses to wear to the parties in Washington Friday night after her husband's inauguration. The designer, who completed the fitting on several evening dresses Thursday, is not sure which she will select. In addition to the long dresses, he made a number of daytime outfits in silk and in wool.

title: Crossword Is a True Anglo-American Creation; Ultimate Put-Down
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of an Honest Congress
description: To his credit, President Reagan is putting his last days in office to good use indeed by joining the campaign for sizable salary increases for members of Congress and other Federal officials. He also endorses a ban on members collecting speaking fees. Citizens interested in enhancing the appearance and reality of ethical behavior in Washington will cheer both steps.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections. No street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Promise to Prominence: Crossing the Distance
description: A long practice session was nearing its close in the gymnasium of Elizabeth High School, and Ben Candelino had seen enough. For two hours, Candelino, the basketball coach at Elizabeth, had watched the most gifted player in New Jersey jog up and down the court, lumber through drills and allow smaller players to score and rebound inside without fear.

title: Bell Atlantic Unit Gets U.S. Contract
description: The United States General Services Administration awarded a contract that it estimated would be worth between $221.3 million and $282.1 million for replacing parts of the Federal Government's telephone systems in the Washington area with a digital system. The contract was awarded to the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company, a unit of the Bell Atlantic Corporation.

title: Houston's Schools Offer Rest to Troubled Young
description: The Houston Independent School District opened gymnasium doors Thursday night to schoolchildren who had no other place to sleep, and eight children 5 to 18 years of age spent the night.

title: Chip Maker Posts Loss
description: Advanced Micro Devices, a semiconductor manufacturer, said today that it lost $34.1 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. Sales in the quarter were $248.1 million, down 5.5 percent from $262.5 in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: The Steinberg Defense Rests Without Calling Defendant
description: The defense rested yesterday in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg without introducing an insanity defense and without calling the defendant to the witness stand.

title: Mets-Padres Trade
description: In a trade of minor leaguers, the Mets have traded Rich Rodriguez, a pitcher, to the San Diego Padres for Brad Pounders, a first baseman. Pounders, 25 years old, hit .279 in 110 games for Class AAA Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League last season. He had 14 home runs and drove in 74 runs. Rodriguez, 25, a left-hander, was 2-7 with six saves and a 2.87 earned run average in 47 games with the Class AA Jackson Mets of the Texas League.(AP)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Biotechnica International Inc., Cambridge, Mass.,a genetic engineering concern, signed a letter of intent to acquire the plant business of Molecular Genetics Inc., Minnetonka, Minn., for $4.1 million.

title: Human Rights in China: The Aggrieved Cry Out
description: Seeds of Fire Chinese Voices of Conscience Edited by Geremie Barme and John Minford Illustrated. 491 pages. Hill & Wang. $25.

title: Islanders End Losing Streak As Hrudey Makes 40 Saves
description: All the Islanders, young and old, responded favorably tonight to Coach Al Arbour's promise to emphasize youth against the Devils.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Dec. 23 about Representative Manuel Lujan Jr., who has been selected as Interior Secretary, discussed his background, his record in Congress and the response to his selection. In describing Mr. Lujan's family, the article noted that he is a Roman Catholic.

title: Kimball May Shift Plea
description: Bruce Kimball, the former Olympic diver, may be allowed to change his guilty plea in a drunken-driving manslaughter case to safeguard insurance money for victims and their families, his attorney said yesterday.

title: Royal Little, Pioneer in Forming Of Conglomerates, Is Dead at 92
description: Royal Little, the shrewd Rhode Island entrepreneur who is widely regarded as the inventor of the modern conglomerate, the highly diversified breed of corporation that became the rage on Wall Street in the late 1960's, died Thursday night at his home in Nassau in the Bahamas. He was 92 years old and also had a house in Narragansett, R.I.

title: Protecting Skin in Winter
description: Moisturizers soothe dry skin and protect it from low temperatures and high winds. With winter here in earnest, the question is: which products work best?

title: Review/Revue; Songs of 60's That Retain Their Bite
description: More than two decades after many of them were written, the songs of Tom Lehrer still feel remarkably contemporary. Writing about politics and culture in a relatively optimistic time, Mr. Lehrer distilled a snobbish, cold-blooded misanthropy that went sharply against the cultural grain.

title: Andrew Jackson, 81, Retired Vice Admiral
description: Andrew McBurney Jackson Jr., a retired vice admiral of the Navy who also served as vice chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at a nursing home in Edgewater, Md. He was 81 years old and lived in Annapolis.

title: Traffic Controllers and U.S. Reach Tentative Agreement
description: Air traffic controllers have negotiated the first labor agreement with the Federal Government since 1981, when a strike led to the mass dismissal of controllers and the abolition of their union.

title: N.C.A.A. to Look at North Carolina State
description: Bruce Poulton, the chancellor of North Carolina State, said today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association would investigate allegations of grade-fixing at the school.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: Hartsburg Retires
description: Craig Hartsburg, a 10-year veteran with the Minnesota North Stars and the team's captain for the last six seasons, retired yesterday, citing injuries.(AP)

title:
BIG WHEELS, BIG DEALS;
(A Pop Quiz) Leveraged Buyouts Are: 'A blight on the land'
description: LEAD: Leveraged buyouts are a blight on the land. They are risky, ill-conceived and - perhaps most objectionable from an investment point of view -popular. In America, nowadays, everyone is on the same side of the financial boat, and that is the side of debt.

title: Blue Arrow Chief Executive Replaced by Man He Ousted
description: The board of Blue Arrow P.L.C., the world's largest employment agency, ousted Tony Berry as chief executive today and replaced him with a man he had dismissed last month.

title: Kean Fights Gym Rule, And It's Fitness vs. Flab
description: Pity the poor New Jersey nerd. For a moment this week, it seemed that the calculator-toting legions and others who dread the prospect of another high school gymnasium class appeared to have a gained a powerful ally in Gov. Thomas H. Kean.

title:
Your Money;
Depositor Losses At Failed Banks
description: LEAD: Despite the record number of failures of banks and savings institutions in the last few years, most savers feel secure, knowing that their money is protected by Federal deposit insurance. But what many fail to realize is that they could face an unexpected loss of interest income if an institution fails before they are able to withdraw their deposits and invest them elsewhere.

title: Turks Enjoy More Freedom but Torture Continues
description: Turkish newspapers are increasingly free-wheeling and unafraid to challenge Prime Minister Turgut Ozal. Old taboos are being broken, or at least tested for the first time in years: there is public debate on whether to legalize a Communist party, to give more latitude to Islamic fundamentalists, to abolish the death penalty and to expand cultural rights for the country's large Kurdish minority.

title: Winfield Says He'll Block Trade
description: Dave Winfield's latest feud with George Steinbrenner has begun to produce a modicum of trade interest around baseball, but the Yankee outfielder yesterday repeated his pronouncement of the past: No trade.

title: Gordon Wright, 85, Riding Team Founder
description: Gordon Wright, a noted horseman and riding instructor who helped establish the United States Equestrian Team after World War II, died Jan. 5 at a nursing home in Tryon, N.C. He was 85 years old and had lived at Wright Way Farm outside nearby Landrum, S.C.

title: Adjust Deficit Figures To Show Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: The Quayles (& Co.) on Vacation
description: Considering all the flap about his family's recent Colorado ski vacation, Vice President-elect Dan Quayle may regret he ever took the trip. Yet he did nothing wrong in asking the Republican National Committee to pick up a portion of the cost.

title: BENEFICIEARIES OF THE TALENT BANK
description: Highest-paid city workers hired through the Mayor's Talent Bank, a job-referral program operated out of the basement of City Hall, according to a list taken home in a shopping bag by Nydia Padilla-Barham, the program's former director. List covers period between 1981 and July, 1985. Salary is as reported in that list. ''Street'' as a referral indicates job recipient sent resume on his own. Codes for race: (W) White, (B) Black, (H) Hispanic, (U) Unknown.$ M 06,07,18,03,04,25,23 SALARY NAME SEX RACE POSITION/CITY AGENCY REFERRED BY $45,000 Brooke Trent F W Assistant Commis. Nathan Leventhal, General Services! former Dep. Mayor 44,756 Eugene Gurshung M W Manager, Trans. Donald Manes, former Queens Borough Pres. 44,756 Michael Cipriani M U Manager, Trans.
