title: Retail Sales Rose by 0.2% In December
description: Nationwide retail sales ended 1988 with a whimper.

title: New York, Because of Spills, To Cover Its Garbage Barges
description: New York City, while sharply disputing the state's assertion that large amounts of garbage fly off the barges that travel to the city landfill on Staten Island, will begin placing covers over the barges next Tuesday.

title: Jewish Group Is Optimistic After India Visit
description: An American Jewish delegation has ended a visit to India, saying it is hopeful that the time is right to upgrade relations between India and Israel and end Indian discrimination against Israelis.

title: Limits on Help for Libya
description: American officials say that they have blocked West German and other European help for Libya's chemical plant, at least for now, but that they are still concerned about West German technology exports. Page 5.

title: Blacks' Charities Struggle To Meet Cosby Challenge
description: When Bill Cosby gave $20 million to Spelman College in Atlanta, the largest individual donation ever made to a black college, he made it clear that he intended the money not just as a gift but as a challenge to other black Americans to support black colleges.

title:
DINING OUT;
Two Settings in One Armonk Spot
description: LEAD: ANNOUNCEMENTS of new ownership prompted a willing revisit to one of the prettiest eating places in the county. Little has changed at Covington. The downstairs dining room, in particular, offers one of the most amiable surroundings we know of - a 19th-century public house transplanted from London, with gleaming etched glass and rich dark paneling intact.

title: A Tourist Lost En Route To the Screen
description: ''It's no accident that the critics agree,'' says an ad on behalf of ''The Accidental Tourist,'' going on to tout the fact that the film was voted 1988's best by the New York Film Critics' Circle. Even in the world of movie promotions, where exaggeration is a way of life, this amounts to a monumental whopper. The critics most certainly did not agree, which is how this nondescript dark-horse candidate managed - quite accidentally - to emerge a winner. Last year produced so few real favorites that the critics' votes were scattered far and wide; otherwise, an indifferent choice like ''The Accidental Tourist'' would never have stood a chance.

title: In Search Of Opals in South Australia
description: IN mid-August, in the small Outback town of Coober Pedy, South Australia, thieves broke into the home of an opal buyer and removed a safe containing about $750,000 in stones and cash. The local police began their investigation assuming that the valuables were still in the safe, that the safe was still in or around Coober Pedy, and that their task was hopeless.

title: Accord Reached on Homeless Plan
description: LEAD: IN a major step for WestHELP, the Common Council agreed informally last week to a plan that links operation of the city's largest homeless hotel with the nonprofit group's year-old proposal to build housing for homeless families in White Plains.

title: Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: Of course college sports can play by the rules. It is just a question of whether or not universities want to, and if they're willing to risk being caught by the sometimes-alert N.C.A.A. SARA BENNETT Great Neck, L.I.

title: Canoe Trip Leads to a River's Adoption
description: ONE spring morning last year, Bob Walters decided to commute between Pleasantville and Yonkers by canoe instead of by car. For the environmental leader, the choice of a route less traveled - the Saw Mill River - and his successful navigation of it, ''made all the difference,'' as the poet Robert Frost once observed about such decisions.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: WHO WROTE THE BIBLE? by Richard Elliott Friedman. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Most scholars have come to believe that the first five books of the Bible traditionally attributed to Moses were actually the work of several ghostwriters. But who were these people? ''If you have ever thought biblical scholarship as dry as dust, then join detective Friedman as he tracks down his four elusive authors,'' our reviewer, Robert Davidson, wrote in 1987.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: COLD TALES. By Virgilio Pinera. Translated by Mark Schafer. (Eridanos/Rizzoli International, Cloth, $24; Paper, $15.) Virgilio Pinera, the Cuban novelist, poet and critic who died in 1979, created a world governed by a geometry of loathing and an algebra of emotional entrapment. His elegantly precise stories, presented here for the first time in English in a generally felicitous translation by Mark Schafer, echo Kafka, Borges and Poe, and evoke the architectural visions of Piranesi and the grotesques of Bosch.

title: Evacuation Fears Unfounded
description: Re: ''To the Reagans: Happy Trails'' [ Letters, Jan. 8 ] . Those who read the papers and watch TV know that evacuation around a nuclear power plant in the event of emergency is required only for those within a 10-mile limit of the plant. Physicists are confident only two miles is necessary because of the improved safety of our U.S. plants.

title: 2 Palestinian Girls Die of Israeli Gun Wounds
description: Two Palestinian girls died today of head wounds from Israeli gunfire, bringing to four the number of Palestinian teen-agers who have been killed in the last 36 hours.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Code Red: Alarm in Progress
description: LEAD: IF Romeo courted Juliet today, he'd haul his ladder over to her window, fling it open and set off her parents' burglar alarm.

title: Sea Coral Used as Bone Substitute in Dentistry
description: LEAD: THANKS to a bone substitute made from sea coral, Cecilia Quinlan of Fort Lee has a stronger front tooth.

title: A WAKE IN CHARLOTTE
description: THE ANNA PAPERS By Ellen Gilchrist. 277 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: Window on a Memory
description: KENNEDY Starring Martin Sheen (in photo), Blair Brown (in photo), Vincent Gardenia, E. G. Marshall, Geraldine Fitzgerald, J. R. Dusenberry (in photo). Directed by Jim Goddard. 1983. Prism Entertainment. 278 minutes. $79.95. Not rated.

title: Franchise Brokers
description: To the Editor:

title: Tennis
description: Navratilova Eliminates Mandlikova: Martina Navratilova advanced yesterday to the final of the New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia. Navratilova, a three-time winner of the tournament, scored her 25th victory in 32 matches against Hana Mandlikova, winning, 6-3, 6-2. Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden also moved into today's final with a 5-7, 6-3, 7-6 victory over Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y.(AP) Mansdorf and Krishnan in Final: Amos Mansdorf of Israel and Ramesh Krishnan of India will meet in a repeat of last year's final of the New Zealand Open when the tournament is decided today in Auckland. Mansdorf, the defending champion, overcame the powerful serve-and-volley game of Roger Smith of the Bahamas to win his semifinal by 6-3, 6-2 yesterday. Krishnan beat Richey Reneberg of the United States, 7-6, 6-3.(AP) Skiing Mahrer Wins Downhill: Daniel Mahrer of Switzerland won the World Cup downhill yesterday at Kitzbuehel, Austria, edging Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg and preventing him from scoring successive victories. With the Hahnenkamm course harder and faster than it was the previous day when Girardelli won, Mahrer was timed in 1 minute 58.42 seconds, beating Girardelli by seven-hundredths of a second. Peter Wirnsberger of Austria was third in 1:58.67. The race was held up for 20 minutes after Brian Stemmle of Canada, the 24th starter, suffered a cracked pelvis when he crashed coming out of the Steilhang curve and tumbled 110 yards. Stemmle, who also suffered cuts and internal injuries, underwent surgery later in the afternoon in Innsbruck. (AP) Track and Field Charles Leads Wingate to Victory: Junior Charles ran his anchor leg in 1 minute 56.1 seconds to give Wingate of Brooklyn victory yesterday in the 3,200-meter event at the Martin Luther King Relays in Draddy Gym at Manhattan College. The meet was limited to New York City public high schools. Wingate was clocked in 8:06.6, with Prospect Heights, also of Brooklyn, a close second in 8:06.8. Preceding Charles on the winning relay were Mike Williams (2:04.1), Trevor Walker (2:04.7) and Errol Thomas (2:01.7). Wingate, with Charles running a 50.3 final leg, finished first in the 1,600-meter relay but was disqualified for an infraction. Boys and Girls High was declared the winner in 3:25.0. Bubka Captures Pole Vault: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union, the Olympic pole vault champion, won the third ''Gold Pole'' indoor event yesterday with a vault of 18 feet 8 1/4 inches in Barcelona, Spain.(AP) Horse Racing Rose's Cantina Triumphs: Rose's Cantina, ridden by Eddie Maple and coupled in the wagering with Bristlin' Belle as the Carl Icahn-owned entry, posted a 5 1/4-length victory in the $91,200 Affectionately Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Tops in Taps was the runner-up in the field of 10, a nose ahead of the favorite, Thirty Eight Go Go. The victory was the seventh in 28 career starts for the winner, who went a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:42 4/5 to earn $54,720. The Icahn entry returned $11.20, $5.20 and $3 for $2 across the board. (AP) Women's Basketball Louisiana Tech 79, Texas Tech 57: Nora Lewis, a senior forward, scored 15 points in the second half yesterday and fourth-ranked Louisiana Tech pulled away in the final 10 minutes en route to the victory in Lubbock, Tex. Lewis, who finished with 19 points, scored 12 of them as the Lady Techsters (12-2) outscored the Red Raiders (7-7) by 28-8 down the stretch. Venus Lacy, a junior center, added 8 points during the run.(AP) Georgia 83, Vanderbilt 62: Carla Green, a senior guard, scored 19 points as sixth-ranked Georgia jumped to a 16-5 lead and rolled to an 83-62 Southeastern Conference victory in Athens, Ga. Sherelle Warren added 18 points for the Lady Bulldogs (13-2 over all, 2-0 in the conference). Wendy Scholtens, the center for Vanderbilt (12-4, 0-2) and the S.E.C.'s leading scorer, scored 33 points. She also made 9 of 10 free throws and set a National Collegiate Athletic Association women's record of 44 consecutive foul shots before missing late in the game. The previous record was 40 set by Kristin Smith of Arizona in 1987.(AP) High School Basketball St. Anthony 65, Xaverian 37: Undefeated St. Anthony (13-0), ranked No. 1 in the nation, had no trouble with Xaverian of Brooklyn last night at Dickinson High School in Jersey City. Jerry Walker and Terry Dehere scored 13 points apiece, and Bob Hurley Jr. had 11 for the Friars, who cruised to their 31st straight victory. Xaverian dropped to 10-3. N.H.L. Sabres 1, Nordiques 1: Marc Fortier scored with less than three minutes remaining in the third period to give Quebec the tie at home last night. The Nordiques were applying pressure and buzzing around the Sabres' goal when Michel Goulet picked up a loose puck and let go a quick backhand toward Darren Puppa, the Buffalo goaltender. Puppa made the initial save but Fortier picked up the rebound and banged it home at 17:03 for his 10th goal of the year at 17:03. It was the ninth straight game without a victory for Quebec.(AP) Bruins 5, Red Wings 5: Ken Linseman's goal midway through the third period lifted Boston into a tie at Detroit yesterday, despite two goals and three assists by the Red Wings' Steve Yzerman.(AP) Canadiens 5, Maple Leafs 3: Russ Courtnall made a successful return to Maple Leaf Gardens last night, scoring twice to lead Montreal to the victory. The Canadiens have lost only once in 13 games. Courtnall was making his first appearance in Toronto since the Nov. 7 trade that sent him to Montreal for John Kordic.(AP) Soccer U.S. Loses to the Netherlands: The Netherlands edged the United States, 2-1, and Brazil beat Belgium in a penalty shootout yesterday to reach the final of the first indoor soccer world championship at Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Brazil and Belgium were tied at 1-1 after regulation play and at 3-3 at the end of extra time before Brazil won the shootout, 4-3. The Netherlands got both goals from Vic Hermans. Jim Gabarra scored the American goal. The Dutch were tentative at first, unable to cope with the United States' early checking. But when the United States failed to get any momentum of its own going, the home side pushed ahead.(AP)

title: POSTINGS: The Last Apartments?; Plan B For Madison
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission will decide whether to allow the construction of what could be the last apartment house on upper Madison Avenue. As the public hearing on Jan. 24 approaches, its developer is stressing one point: Not one brownstone will be harmed.

title: Let's Give the Analysts A Real Big Hand
description: IF you fancy yourself as an analyst, cover the East-West hands shown in the diagram and prepare for work. If you do not, look at all four hands and prepare for an unusual challenge that is as puzzling as the Chinese carved ivory spheres with a series of concentric layers.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Theater View column on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today appears with a sentence omitted. The sentence should have read, ''An old poster behind a refreshment stand at the Royal Shakespeare's present London base reawakened my memory of Mr. Hall's restoration of another Broadway failure, Edward Albee's 'All Over,' with Peggy Ashcroft and Angela Lansbury, at the Aldwych Theater in 1972.''

title: Granato's 3d Goal Gives Rangers a Tie
description: Tony Granato, a towel draped around his stiffening neck, stood in the Ranger locker room and ran a hand softly across his face, assessing the afternoon's damage. There was a nasty gash under his right eye and a red welt covering his forehead, and his ears had the look of cauliflower.

title: WHEN IN DOUBT, DUEL
description: ROMANTIC AFFINITIES Portraits From an Age, 1780-1830. By Rupert Christiansen. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Agents Arrest Five in an Attempt to Sell Explosive
description: More than 300 pounds of a powerful plastic explosive stolen from a mine were seized in a raid by Federal agents posing as buyers for the material, the authorities said today.

title: College Testing Is A Hard Habit To Break
description: STANDARDIZED college admissions tests have often been criticized as inaccurate and biased against women and members of minority groups. But many critics of the tests admit that they are fighting a losing battle.

title: Casino Funds To Aid Projects In Urban Areas
description: AS soon as the ground thaws enough in the spring, construction is to begin to transform a blighted block of Monticello Avenue here into modern apartments and shops. The $2.9-million project will be the first investment of casino funds in urban redevelopment in northern New Jersey.

title: Another View On the AIDS Risk
description: The Dec. 18 article ''Link Between AIDS and Drug Abuse Is Studied in State'' is insensitive and misleading. It contains racist, classist and sexist overtones, and muddies important points about AIDS transmission and prevention.

title: Schubert and Schumann From Three Masters
description: Schubert and Schumann have been getting a workout by some of the biggest pianistic guns in the contemporary arsenal. The most ambitious undertaking is a two-disk excursion into the last three Schubert sonatas, the three Klavierstueck and the C minor Allegretto played by Maurizio Pollini (Deutsche Grammophon 419 229-2). On a single disk Murray Perahia plays the big A major Sonata by Schubert, along with Schumann's G minor Sonata (CBS MK 44569). There is a performance of Schumann's ''Carnaval'' by Vladimir Ashkenazy, along with the same composer's ''Humoresque'' and the first two ''Novelletes'' (London 421 010-2). Having finished recording all the works of Chopin, Mr. Ashkenazy is now embarked on a Schumann project.

title: After Two Oaths, Lowey is 'Ready to Roll'
description: HER Capitol Hill office is in disarray; her computers are not programmed, and she is still in the process of hiring most of her staff. But Nita M. Lowey, the new Representive from Westchester County's 20th District, said she was ready to take on the United States Congress.

title: Memphis Blacks Charge Calendar Slurs Dr. King
description: On the eve of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, black residents of the city where he was slain are reeling over a McDonald's promotional calendar that labeled the holiday ''National Nothing Day.''

title: On a Vacation
description: VACATIONS, I've found, serve two purposes. They let us shed the woes and cares we've been carrying with us for months. They give us a chance to point ourselves in a new direction.

title: Elizabeth Emmons to Wed Ames Colt
description: Mr. and Mrs. George B. Emmons 3d of South Salem, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Harley Emmons to Ames Borden Colt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard B. Colt Jr. of Little Compton, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Stuart Kensinger, Angela E. Webb, Exchange Vows
description: Angela Ellis Webb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gaynor Webb of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stuart Roben Kensinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kensinger of Houston. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Resolutions: For 1989, Clean Up Long Island Sound
description: AS a resident of the North Shore of Long Island, I promise in 1989 to work for the protection of Long Island Sound. I know the water in the Sound is seriously polluted in many areas. This pollution is from people, boats and industry. I know that oxygen levels have been dangerously low during the past two years; that copper, PCB's and other heavy metals threaten our fishing industry.

title: What Do You Tell Children About Terrorism?
description: THE question came directly and clearly, in that way of asking questions that only children possess. It came at breakfast in between orange juice and oatmeal. I should have expected it and kept a more careful watch. ''What is terrorism?'' my 6-year-old daughter asked.

title: A Debate Heats Up: Is It News or Entertainment?
description: After years of dancing around the edge of sensationalism, television leaped enthusiastically into the pit last year with the kind of journalism many newspapers have practiced for a hundred years or more. The half-dozen or so new shows and the old ones that remade themselves on a sex-and-mayhem model proved so successful that they have spawned a multibillion-dollar industry: reality-based television.

title: 4-Year Status Urged For Medgar Evers To Stabilize College
description: Medgar Evers College, a two-year community college in central Brooklyn with a long history of administrative problems, should be turned into a four-year institution to give it greater stability and status, an independent consulting firm has recommended.

title: Four on the Outside
description: Carlos and Bermaida Fajardo, who struggled for years to get to the United States from Cuba - he arrived in 1984, she in 1986 - find themselves outside the land of opportunity again. Mr. and Mrs. Fajardo, who live in Miami, wanted their two children to have a white Christmas, so they drove north to see snow - all the way to Niagara Falls. But after a brief stop on the Canadian side, they found they could not get back into the United States.

title: THE CONNOISSEUR AS SURVIVOR
description: UTZ By Bruce Chatwin. 154 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: An Encore For Instrument Sales
description: Twelve-year-old Robert Camp takes private saxophone lessons at New York City's Collegiate School, where he is a seventh grader. He says he likes the kind of music - jazz, rock, pop - that can be played on the alto sax he is renting.

title: Moscow Chief Who Fought Party Seeking to Run for Soviet Congress
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick populist who has won a huge following by waging political war within the Soviet leadership, today offered to quit his high-ranking job in the Construction Ministry to accept a popular draft as candidate for a new National Congress of Deputies.

title: Will Success Spoil the Double Cheese With Anchovies?
description: There are times when Stephen J. Zelepos wonders if things have got out of hand.

title: A Living Definition Of Acting
description: What Irish actor can boast a longer and more impressive bio than Ray McAnally? None, surely. He's appeared in over 250 theater productions, 150 television dramas and a score of movies. Back home on Dublin stages, he's played Macbeth and Arthur Miller's Willy Loman and heroes and non-heroes galore. Over the water in London, he's been George in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and Bernard Shaw in Hugh Whitemore's recent ''Best of Friends.'' He was a conscience-stricken Cardinal in the film ''The Mission'' and the aging conman Rick Pym in the television adaptation of John le Carre's tale ''A Perfect Spy.''

title: Frozen Pipes
description: FREEZING winter weather brings with it the threat of frozen plumbing. To minimize the risk, most household water pipes are deliberately situated away from unheated areas.

title: THE BOGSAT METHOD
description: Helene von Damm's description of how Ronald Reagan formed his Cabinet read like a Doonesbury comic strip (''Out of the Kitchen, Into the Cabinet,'' Nov. 27). In my headhunter days, we called it the Bogsat method - a Bunch of Guys Seated Around a Table, peddling those they knew best to the leader of the free world. ''What about . . .?'' ''Someone threw out . . .'' ''Someone mentioned. . . .''

title: Storm Calls Make Prime Time on Radio
description: LEAD: IT'S the wee hours of the morning and the season's first serious snowstorm is on it way. As the first flakes fall, staff members at Westchester County's five radio stations prepare to answer an onslaught of calls with information they must relay quickly to their listeners.

title: Important Chores For the Season
description: WHEN studying catalogues from nurseries and seed houses, don't get lost in colorful pictures; look for unusual and challenging introductions to make this year a particularly rewarding one in horicultural expertise. Keep bird feeders stocked with fresh supplies of their favorite seeds; provide water daily, if an outdoor heater is available so the water does not freeze. Continue pruning, especially overgrown trees and shrubs to make them suit the home's landscape. Strawberries

title: Shin Hee Chung Weds F. A. Packer 3d
description: Shin Hee Chung, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Yohan Hun Doo Chung of Seoul, South Korea, was married in New York yesterday to Francis Avery Packer 3d, the son of Comdr. and Mrs. Packer Jr. of Summit, N.J. The Rev. William E. Starr, an Episcopal priest, and the bride's father, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Meaning Is in the Ears of the Beholder
description: Pop musicians and their advisers slave to make themselves clear. They agonize over lyrics, try dozens of takes on solos, mix and remix arrangements, scrutinize album packages, fiddle with advertisements and re-edit videos according to private combinations of game plan and instinct. At some point in the project, they'll try to think like a casual listener, a radio program director or a longtime fan, all in attempts to guarantee that their initial inspiration comes through just the way they planned it.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Asbestos; Cleanup Worries Tenants Renting Out Surplus Space
description: TWO years after New York City began enforcing cleanup procedures for asbestos, owners of office buildings are adjusting to the financial and legal burdens, but many tenants with surplus space are finding themselves in costly predicaments.

title: Cut Down by The Hairdresser
description: ONCE I TRIED TO find a hairdresser less expensive than the one I usually use. Calling in August, I got an appointment in late October. My hair grew. Ends split. Eventually I drove the two hours from my home to Manhattan.

title: Easy Go
description: 'A lot of money got put into people's pockets and they've rat-holed it somewhere. Some of it is in artwork, fancy homes, fancy airplanes and Rolls-Royces. Some of it went to Rolex watches, lizard shoes, hunting parties and yachts.' - H. Joe Selby, former chief regulator for the Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas, discussing abuses in some savings and loan associations in Texas.

title: Budget Battles in Co-ops and Condos
description: THIS is the time of year when co-op boards of directors and condominium owners associations send out their annual budgets. For many, the statements will carry the message of assessments and higher monthly charges, provoking another round in the long and abrasive debates among New York's resident owners that turn on the question, ''What kind of building do we want, anyway?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington;
A Mix of Uses In the West End
description: LEAD: A 240,000-SQUARE-FOOT office and residential building is under construction in the West End, an area between Georgetown and downtown where several hotels have been built in recent years.

title: Akiyama to Conduct New Orchestra
description: AS music director of orchestras in Syracuse and Tokyo, Kazuyoshi Akiyama commutes regularly between both cities, but next weekend the man Paul Dunkel has called ''the greatest Japanese conductor in the world today'' adds Purchase to his itinerary, becoming the first guest maestro in the six-year history of Mr. Dunkel's New Orchestra of Westchester.

title: Patience and Then the Classical Clobbering
description: THE classical prescription for winning was to more or less slowly outmaneuver the opponent by trenchant positional play and, when all was in readiness, to strike with the decisive combination.

title: Group of New Yorkers Face a Proposed Move
description: The Koch administration has offered a plan to force many residents of middle-income subsidized housing into smaller apartments, and many of the residents are bitterly opposed to the program.

title: SOUND
description: Henry Ford didn't believe in giving his customers much of a choice. When he launched his famous Model A in the l920's, he thought that painting the cars in different colors was wasteful. ''They can have any color they want,'' he declared, ''as long as it's black.''

title: Instant Snapshots for Your TV Screen
description: For the consumer who has everything, a new toy will soon be beckoning. It is the electronic still video camera, a device that looks like a bulky 35-millimeter camera but captures images on electronic sensors instead of film. The images are then stored on built-in magnetic disks that can be played back with a machine connected to a TV. The result is an instant version of the snapshot on the TV screen.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture. However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years. The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone. I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent. However, I feel that acetone is too toxic. Is there some other way to clean without sanding the furniture down to the raw wood, and after it is clean should I use the same oil?

title: Maine Rejects Plan to Import Electric Power From Canada
description: The Maine Public Utilities Commission has refused to allow the state's largest utility to buy electrical power from Canada, a plan that would have required laying a 140-mile power line.

title: The Bottom Line of Sponsoring Sports
description: FOR corporations, sports-sponsorship programs are effective and prestigious sales tools. For fund raisers, they are a fine source of financial benefit. For sports-marketing companies, which bring the parties together, they have become a big industry.

title: Study Links Male Unemployment And Single Mothers in Chicago
description: Researchers at the University of Chicago say a new social survey of low-income inner-city residents here offers evidence of a strong correlation between unemployment among men and the growing number of children who are being reared by single mothers.

title: Bellevue Board Members Seek Official's Resignation
description: In a bitter dispute over the creation of a program to train emergency-room doctors at Bellevue Hospital, the hospital's community board has called for the resignation of its longtime chief of medicine, Dr. Saul J. Farber.

title: A Regular Guy Goes to the White House
description: GEORGE BUSH insists that nothing is going to stop him - not rain, nor sleet, nor Secret Service, nor press corps - if he decides to leave the White House and run down to the local deli to buy some bagels. ''I've got to do this,'' he says ominously. His ''read-my-cream-cheese'' tone of voice signifies something important about the Bush Presidency.

title: Day of the Insider: Members of the Bush Club
description: WITH the choices of James D. Watkins, a retired admiral, to be Energy Secretary, and William J. Bennett, President Reagan's former Education Secretary, to fill the job of ''drug czar'' that Congress created last year, George Bush last week put the finishing touches on his Cabinet and his group of top advisers - a close circle that is dominated by that elite group of professional operatives known as Washington insiders.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Proposals for Punishment; The Case of the Criminal Corporation
description: THE criminal justice system has never really known how to punish corporations. If convicted of a crime, a company cannot be handcuffed and thrown into prison. The usual answer is a fine, and in most cases the amount assessed is little more than pocket change to a big company.

title: THE CZARS NEVER HAD IS SO GOOD
description: In 1770, eight years after she became Empress of Russia, Catherine the Great established the workshops that would lavishly and permanently furnish the imperial palaces. Catherine's move gave birth to the Russian furniture industry - and the Russian style. Antoine Cheneviere, a Swiss-born London antiques dealer specializing in Russian furniture, has written RUSSIAN FURNITURE: The Golden Age 1780-1840 (Vendome Press, $65), the first major book outside of the Soviet Union on the style as it evolved over a 60-year period. Compared to the French, German and Italian furnishings that inspired the artisans who worked in St. Petersburg and Moscow, the Russian furniture they produced was frequently weightier, bolder in scale, more elaborately carved, richer in detail and more exquisitely crafted. Mr. Cheneviere explains how this style developed and discusses its designers and artisans, including the man who may have been Russia's Chippendale - Andrei Nikiforovich Voronikhin. Most of the illustrations are of major examples of the gilded, malachite-veneered, crystal, bronze, steel and carved wood chairs, tables, desks and chests in Russian museums. Many of these, especially the elegant steel furniture from the town of Tula and the tables, desks and chests veneered in malachite, jasper, porphyry and lazulite are breathtaking - a far cry from anything produced in Europe.

title: A Down-to-Earth Tenant For an Exclusive Address
description: With a laugh, Barbara Bush acknowledges that she now views herself as a role model for many American women.

title: New Medicare Act Benefits the Aged, but They'll Foot the Bill
description: LEAD: MEDICAL care for Long Island's increasingly elderly population will cost a lot more this year, as the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act becomes effective.

title:
INVESTING;
A Tax Shelter for the Not-So-Rich
description: LEAD: Investing in low-income housing may not seem to be the shortest path to wealth. But a growing number of limited partnerships are entering the field, betting they can produce aftertax returns of 15 percent or more.

title:
GARDENING;
Keeping the Welcome Mat Out for Birds
description: LEAD: SONGBIRDS that do not migrate may be falling on hard times when their sources of weeds are snow-covered. Setting up a feeder can take an important role in insuring the birds' survival.

title: Fictitious Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE IN GLEIWITZ WAS NEVER NORMAL
description: EARTH AND FIRE By Horst Bienek. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 257 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: FUGITIVE CHILDHOODS
description: LOST IN TRANSLATION A Life in a New Language By Eva Hoffman. 280 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: At Long Last, dBase IV Arrives
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation has finally completed dBASE IV version 1.0, the latest revision of the most popular data base program for personal computers. It offers a number of improvements over dBASE III-Plus and adds features that will make it attractive to the two million dBASE users. And beginners will find it less intimidating than previous versions.

title: 'The January Man' Dossier: The Force Is With It
description: As law enforcement officers go, the New York City Police have never had a reputation for being particularly conformist. And Nick Starkey, the shaggy, mustachioed protagonist of ''The January Man,'' an offbeat political melodrama that opened Friday, is hardly your average Gotham police officer. Not by a long shot.

title: Experts on Deficit Defend the 1986 Tax Changes
description: Is the 1986 overhauling of the Federal tax code raising havoc with the budget?

title: Woman Is Killed by a Train
description: A 33-year-old woman was struck and killed Friday night by a Long Island Rail Road train as she walked along the tracks, the police said today. The woman, Teresa Bustos, of 26A Town Path in Glen Cove, was walking on the tracks between Glen Street station and Seacliff station at 7 P.M. Friday when she was struck by a westbound express train, said a police spokesman, Officer Frank Messana.

title:
Neptune Township;
Residents Try to Save a Farm Dating to 1832
description: LEAD: THE traffic on Route 33 whizzes by the green and white farmhouse that sits on a gentle slope facing the highway. Many motorists may not even notice it. However, controversy has erupted over the future of the farm, started in 1832 by descendants of one of Monmouth County's founding families, and township officials and the local historical society have joined forces in an effort to save it from demolition.

title: Dede Desrochers to Marry Bradford McLane in April
description: Dorothy M. Desrochers, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Desrochers of Baltimore, and Bradford L. McLane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. McLane of New Canaan, Conn., plan to marry in April.

title:
THE WORLD: Western Sahara;
Why Morocco And Algeria Are Tired of Their War
description: LEAD: EFFORTS to end the 13-year war over the Western Sahara seem to be gaining ground, in large part because Morocco and Algeria appear tired of it. For them, domestic problems have only worsened because of the conflict.

title: Quayle's Schuss Fund
description: LEAD: This time the press has gone too far.

title: A 212-Mile Trek in the High Sierra
description: LEAD: The John Muir Trail, say the guidebooks, extends 211.9 miles through California's high country on a line more or less parallel with the Nevada border, from Yosemite at the northern end and south to Mount Whitney - at 14,495 feet the highest peak in the Lower 48.

title:
GARDENING;
Keeping the Welcome Mat Out for Birds
description: LEAD: SONGBIRDS that do not migrate may be falling on hard times when their sources of weeds are snow-covered. Setting up a feeder can take an important role in insuring the birds' survival.

title: Jackson Calls Reagan Woeful on Civil Rights
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today condemned Ronald Reagan's record on civil rights and said the President had failed to meet black leaders in his years in the White House, according to an interview broadcast today.

title: A SLOW SELL FOR A TECHNOLOGY WITH A HIGH MYSTIQUE
description: Until recently, electronic still photography manufacturers had been chasing after the business and professional sector because of its specialized needs and ample budgets. Now they are turning their attention to the average consumer.

title: NEW YORK WIDENS BILINGUAL STUDIES
description: A broadened policy of bilingual education in New York's public schools to meet the anticipated needs of a growing population of students with limited skills in English has been announced by the state's Commissioner of Education, Thomas Sobol.

title: Man Convicted in Cow Deaths
description: A Bethel man on Wednesday was convicted of cruelty to animals for letting his cows starve to death and will spend nine days in prison, a court spokeswoman said Thursday. The man, David Townsend, 46 years old, who is now a truck driver, had farmed for 20 years before the discovery of dead and dying cows drove him out of business. Mr. Townsend's lawyer, Charles Buttery, told the Vermont District Court jury that his client may have mismanaged the farm, but said other causes of death for the animals were not considered.

title: IRONING OUT THE WRINKLES
description: An article about a municipal building getting a face lift appeared in The New York Times on the same day that Melvin Konner's Body and Mind article ''Mortality'' did (Dec. 4). I doubt whether anyone would object to the ravages of time, weather and pollution being effaced from the building; one would rejoice, rather, that the landmark was being restored to its former splendor. So it is with the human face. Why not, after four or five decades, iron out the wrinkles that heredity, joy, sorrow, weather, etc. have put there? CARRIE LEE New York, N.Y.

title:
FOCUS: Nashua, N.H.;
Impact Fees: Fair Sharing or 'Blackmail'?
description: LEAD: THIS city of 80,000 helped itself and other fast-growing communities in the state by getting a developer to agree to pay $18 million for public improvements in exchange for zoning permission to build a large residential and commercial project.

title: Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: A resounding yes!

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Montrealer Run Due to Resume This Year

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: ISSUES AND ANSWERS By BILLY PACKER; Billy Packer is the principal college basketball analyst for CBS Sports. As a player, he led Wake Forest to the Final Four in 1962, and was an assistant coach there from 1965 to 1970.
description: Despite the serious issues considered at the just-concluded National Collegiate Athletic Association convention and the recent controversy involving Jim Valvano and North Carolina State, I think the status of collegiate basketball has never been better. The quality of coaching, the new rules that have dramatically improved the style and flow of the game, the incredible individual talent and the dozens of teams that can realistically set their sights on the national championship all combine to enhance the already grand expectations for the 1990's.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Criticizing the Critic

title: Beuys and Warhol Still Set the Tone - Even After Death
description: The two ubiquitous artists of the late 1980's are Joseph Beuys and Andy Warhol. Beuys was featured in last year's inaugural exhibition of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles and given prime place in the 1987 Documenta, whose theme was social and political art. Warhol had a museum and gallery show in New York City last fall. A Warhol retrospective will open at the Museum of Modern Art next month. Their current prominence is so widely recognized that the sculptor Jannis Kounellis was recently asked matter-of-factly in the December issue of View, a photojournal of art: ''Do you agree with those who define Beuys and Warhol as the two poles around which the history of postwar art turns?''

title: Racing Panel Ignores Facts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TWO LIVES ON HOLD
description: I can empathize with the anguish and frustration experienced by William and Joan Squadron. My husband waited eight anxiety-ridden months for a desperately needed heart transplant, which he was lucky enough to receive last August. He, like Joan, was running out of time, and we will be eternally grateful to an anonymous family in Cleveland, who offered John the gift of life in the midst of their grief.

title: Seeing Red
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Pledge Continued Aid to Afghan Leaders
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, visiting Kabul, pledged continued ''all-around assistance'' to Afghanistan's beleaguered Government, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: The Appointment Book Rules: A Life Down in Black and White
description: THE voice coming from my answering machine was brusque, the message explicit.

title: Shelley R. Berson To Wed in April
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Berson of Pomona, N.Y., and Peru, Vt., have announced the egagement of their daughter, Dr. Shelley Rose Berson, to Jack Weinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Weinstein of Monsey, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: A 'Pinafore' Sails In On a Fresh Breeze
description: What is the British theater coming to? A current hit at London's National Theater dares to have Queen Elizabeth II represented on the stage. And the New Sadler's Wells Opera production of ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' that sails into the City Center on Tuesday features a Sir Joseph Porter done as ''a wicked takeoff of our own dear Prince of Wales,'' as the critic for the Sunday Daily Telegraph wrote. The actor responsible for this royal parody is Nickolas Grace, best known here for his foppish Anthony Blanche in television's ''Brideshead Revisited.''

title: BUSH AIDES PLAN REVIEW OF POLICY TOWARD RUSSIANS
description: The Bush Administration is preparing for a broad review of policy toward the Soviet Union that could lead to a reassessment of American positions on the full range of East-West issues.

title: One on the Run
description: This family fraud made the Medicaid mills of the 1970's look like small potatoes. Sheldon Weinberg and his sons, Jay and Ronald, were sentenced to prison last week for stealing $16 million over seven years; essentially, they billed Medicaid for twice as much service as they actually provided to poor patients at the Brooklyn clinics they owned. Before they were indicted in 1987, the Weinbergs led a lavish life of yachts, fine cars and adjacent apartments in Trump Tower. But family ties have their limits. On Wednesday, after lawyers for each unsuccessfully sought to win leniency by blaming another of the men, both sons were in jail. But Mr. Weinberg, 64 years old, had disappeared and was declared a fugitive.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 15, 1989
Reviews/Dance; Isolation of Traveler and Artist in Work by Gross
description: One of the most interesting aspects of the Womanworks festival at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, is the chance it offers to see in a formal proscenium setting many pieces that have been performed primarily in small loft theaters and other alternative spaces. A case in point is the work of Sally Gross, whose dances were performed on Thursday at the Joyce.

title: Teddy Bears On Police Beats
description: AFTER hearing that a handful of other police departments in the country had found teddy bears valuable assistants on the beat, the Dade County Police in metropolitan Miami decided to recruit their own.

title: Lincoln Center Theater: Act II; Flowers In the Desert
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen Christian to Marry Charles Francis Morgan Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Glenn W. Christian of Independence, Ohio, have made known the engagement of Mr. Christian's daughter Kathleen Estelle Christian to Charles Francis Morgan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Time for Cuddling Is Now
description: LENNY, my 3-year-old son, cries out:

title: Surgery for Manning
description: A year ago he was on his way to leading his Univerity of Kansas team to the national championship and being voted the college player of the year. Yesterday, Danny Manning, the No. 1 draft pick in the National Basketball Association last summer, underwent reconstructive knee surgery in Inglewood, Calif., and will be in rehabilitation for up to a year.

WITHIN THE PLANTATION HOUSEHOLD: Black and White Women of the Old South, by Elizabeth Fox-Genovese. (University of North Carolina, Cloth, $34.95; Paper, $12.95.) A diligent historian concludes that class and race were so ideologically decisive that black and white women had little in common. THE PASSION ACCORDING TO G.H., by Clarice Lispector. (University of Minnesota, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $8.95.) Existentialism and structuralism, the great modern heavies, inform this fascinating, entertaining philosophical novel, first published in Brazil in 1964 by a wizard who is, alas, now dead. SOPHISTICATED REBELS: The Political Culture of European Dissent, 1968-1987, by H. Stuart Hughes. (Harvard University, $20.) W: Or, the Memory of Childhood, by Georges Perec. (Godine, $16.95.) A terrifying short fantasy that mixes memories of childhood in Nazi-occupied France with the confabulations of a clever adolescent; originally published in France in 1975. JACK GANCE, by Ward Just. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) A Chicago boy rises to become a senator in this realistic novel of daily lives and moral choices in Washington.

title: Too Many Bugs In Replay System
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Making the Past Into a Workable Present
description: LEAD: ''AND this is the wine cellar,'' James O'Grady told the young couple, potential buyers of the two-bedroom co-op, lifting up a trapdoor in the pine floor of the living room to reveal a steel ladder.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: In Monet's Gardens TERE are few opportunites to paint what the great masters painted. After all, most of what the great masters painted has long since departed. But Ora Lerman, a professor of art at Suffolk Community College in Selden, recently had the opportunity to step back in time. She spent six months painting Monet's gardens in Monet's gardens.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: A WORLD-CLASS NATION;
America Needs an Investment Strategy
description: LEAD: There are no examples of a nation borrowing and consuming its way to a higher living standard. It therefore follows that our present policy of borrowing massive amounts from abroad for consumption rather than investment is imprudent. But instead of a policy of austerity to cut this foreign borrowing, we must begin to invest our way out of debt with what we call ''investment economics.

title: TALKING: Age Limits; New Law Troubles Condos
description: WHEN Congress modified the Fair Housing Act last September to insure that families with children would no longer face discrimination in buying or renting a home, it included a provision intended to exclude retirement and ''adult only'' communities.

title: Marjorie Curran Wed To Dr. Thomas Ptak
description: Marjorie Ann Curran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Curran of Ashland, Mass., was married yesterday in Framingham, Mass., to Dr. Thomas Ptak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Ptak of Fitchburg, Mass. The Rev. William H. McLaughlin performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Plots That Balzac Would Have Savored
description: The days before christmas were made lively to some and hideous to others by the emergence - thanks primarily to the investigations of a provincial examining magistrate with a flair for publicity - of a truly French scandal. It ran the gamut of society from the former keeper of a dubious bar in Toulon to one of the most flamboyant trial lawyers of the day. Money was at the bottom of it, but there was talk, among much else, of an ailing old woman starved to death in a dark room way off in the Provencal countryside. At least one of the persons involved was already in jail, and others seemed to be headed the same way.

title: Article Led to Punishment, Child-Abuse Workers Assert
description: A New York City child-protection caseworker and her supervisor who talked publicly last week about problems in their agency, are being punished by their superiors, officials of their union have said.

title: State's Skiing Booms as Vermont's Lags
description: CONNECTICUT ski resorts are collectively off to one of their best starts ever, largely because of an early-season dearth of natural snow in Vermont, a colder-than-normal December, relatively cheaper lift tickets and continuing expansion.

title: Shadow On the Future
description: In many ways Zimbabwe is the success story of black Africa. Food production is booming. The country's foreign debt is low. Visitors arriving here from elsewhere in Africa, or from abroad, remark on the prosperity in this capital city.

title: In Defense of Adam Smith
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest, in Old Age
description: Medical science and improved nutrition prolong life, but don't necessarily ease the burdens of age. Social welfare advances of recent years have greatly relieved the economic torments faced by many older Americans, but even so many elderly Americans still live in poverty. That is why The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund puts special emphasis on help for the aged.

title: The Hearty Breads Of Portugal's Hearths
description: DESPITE attempts to introduce modern, refined bread, the Portuguese by and large prefer the old-fashioned country kind, loaves that are big and rough and the color of earth, with crisp crust and a moist interior.

title: Review/Music; Two Composers' Odes to St. Cecilia
description: Music becomes a little self-conscious when called upon to describe itself, whether in Mozart's ''Impresario'' and the whole tribe of parody operas about how funny opera supposedly is or in the family of rhapsodies and apostrophes to which the odes to St. Cecilia by Purcell and Handel belong. The two most substantial of those composers' Cecilian offerings - Purcell's ''Hail, Bright Cecilia'' of 1692, with words by Nicholas Brady, and Handel's 1739 ode to verses by Dryden - were sung by Musica Sacra under Richard Westenburg, with an orchestra of period instruments, at Alice Tully Hall Friday night.

title: KOOP CHALLENGED ON ABORTION DATA
description: Many experts in reproductive health and psychology challenge the contention of Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, that scientific data on the health effects of abortion are inconclusive.

title: THE AMBIGUOUS YASIR ARAFAT
description: In her article, Marie Colvin writes, ''After 1967, when the Arabs lost the last inch of Palestine. . . .'' Our modern definition of Palestine is derived from the British Mandate on Palestine, which defines an area including Jordan and Israel as ''Palestine.'' Although it may hardly satisfy the Arabs on the West Bank, who want an independent state, the fact remains that there is an Arab Palestine - it is called Jordan. PETER ROGOVIN New York, N.Y.

title: Review/Dance; New Leads, New Look In Balanchine 'Apollo'
description: ''Apollo,'' which George Balanchine choreographed in 1928 to Stravinsky's ballet score ''Apollon Musagete,'' refers to Greek mythology but has also acquired a mythical aura of its own. A virtually all-new cast in a seminal Balanchine work, then, is a major event at the New York City Ballet.

title: SENDING PHOTOS IN A FLASH OVER TELEPHONE LINES
description: When Senator Edward M. Kennedy posed with his nephew, John F. Kennedy Jr., at the podium at last summer's Democratic National Convention in Atlanta, a photographer from USA Today snapped a picture of the scene at 9:07 P.M. Twenty-one minutes later, editors in the newspaper's home office in Roslyn, Va., had the resulting photo in hand and were preparing color separations from it for the front page of the next day's edition, which had a 10 P.M. deadline.

title: Just Another Quick Fix?
description: On the eve of the Presidential inauguration, members of the incoming Bush administration are reviving an old complaint about American businessmen: they concentrate too much on earning fast profits, sometimes wrecking their companies in the process.

title: Andrid's Revenge
description: WITNESS A WORD with its meaning being stretched.

title: Comedian's Forte: Scenes, Not Jokes
description: ON the ''Tonight'' show one night last month, the comedian Larry Miller was describing a Thanksgiving family dinner that ''starts out great, with the kids in polo shirts chasing puppy dogs through piles of leaves,'' until animosities surface.

title: Why Analysts Like Pittston
description: LEAD: Although the Pittston Company faces a possible strike by the United Mine Workers union this month and although the diversified coal company's stock is trading on the New York Stock Exchange at about $18, near its 52-week high of $18.50, several analysts are recommending buying it. ''The company could hit a home run this year,'' said Marc D.

title: A Lesson of Sorts in Italian Geography
description: IN Italy, La Sila is a lovely mountain in Calabria. On Long Island, it's an Italian restaurant on a quiet street in Inwood. A taste of La Sila's food is an instant lesson in Italian geography. Robust red sauces all point to a restaurant whose heart and soul are near that mountain in the south of Italy.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: ROMAN ART

title: Parents Should Teach A Love of Books
description: WHAT is wrong with today's children? They just don't seem to be reading anything and, what is worse, they don't seem to have any desire to.

title: Early Works by Escher in Norwalk
description: MAURITS CORNELIS ESCHER probably had himself in mind when, in a 1957 essay, he compared the graphic artist to ''a blackbird singing at the top of a tree.'' Unlike the painter or sculptor, said Escher, the printmaker ''repeats his song over and over again, and it is complete in each print that he makes.''

title: Bolshoi to Tour in U.S.
description: The Bolshoi Ballet is to tour the United States in the summer of 1990 under an agreement by Classical Artists International and the James Nederlander Organization. The itinerary will be announced later.

title: A DEATH IN LENINGRAD
description: STALIN AND THE KIROV MURDER By Robert Conquest. 164 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95.

title: Trade and Credits With Soviet Union Are Near
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: EXPRESSIONISM AT YALE The Yale Art Gallery has gleaned ''Expressionist Prints: From Nolde to Kokoschka'' from its substantial collection of German and Austrian graphics by artists working in Dresden, Munich, Berlin and Vienna from the turn of the century to the 30's.

title: Law Career Is Rejected For Job Racing Turtles
description: LEAD: WHAT is someone who started out to be a lawyer doing racing turtles for a living?

title: Brazil Raises Prices Ahead of Devaluation
description: Brazil authorized large price increases today, a day before the announcement of a new anti-inflation plan that officials said would include a devaluation of the country's currency.

title: Gleanings From Catalogues
description: THE gardener's candy store is open. Seed and nursery catalogues are arriving in the mail and the winter ritual is beginning.

title: The Chill Joys of Sailboarading the Sound
description: WHEN the wind is blowing over 20 knots, Wayne DeVingo, a hair stylist at Guy Sasson in Stamford, stops cutting hair and starts windsurfing. It has been arranged with the shop that when the wind is up, Mr. DeVingo can get out.

title: German Press and Foes Attack Kohl Over Libya
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under strong attack from the political opposition and the press today over his Government's disclosure that it had known since October of potential West German involvment in the construction of a suspect Libyan chemical factory.

title: A JACKPOT IS STOPPED
description: Pro golfers can make as much money as corporate sponsors are willing to put up in prizes. That has been the theme of the PGA Tour under Commissioner Deane Beman: money, money, money.

title: In Mourning, Japan Reopens a Debate From Another Era
description: EVEN in the aftermath of his death, the world is not sure which Emperor Hirohito to remember: the warrior on a white horse or the kindly old marine biologist who saw his nation transformed into an economic superpower.

title: What Hirohito Meant to a Boy of 5 Whose Father Went to War
description: To the Editor:

title: Maine Rabbi's Specialty Is Helping Counselors
description: When a Protestant minister in Maine became overwhelmed by personal problems, he sought help not from a psychiatrist but from a rabbi.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture. However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years. The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone. I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent. However, I feel that acetone is too toxic. Is there some other way to clean without sanding the furniture down to the raw wood, and after it is clean should I use the same oil?

title: 'THE MAYOR WHO DIDN'T WANT TO KNOW'
description: CITY FOR SALE Ed Koch and the Betrayal of New York. By Jack Newfield and Wayne Barrett. Illustrated. 466 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: State Is Lauded On Reform Of Welfare
description: NEW JERSEY'S Reach program, which gives welfare recipients training and helps them find jobs, was developed along with similar national welfare reform. But in the end, New Jersey got ahead of the Federal Government and helped guide the national effort.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Q and A
description: Mexican Trains

title: STREETSCAPES: Rhinelander Industrial School; A $1.9 Million Effort to Rectify The Alteration of an 1891 Relic
description: THE typical restoration story reads like a honeymoon, with a rosy aura of press releases, civic awards and back-patting. But the story of the Children's Aid Society's old Rhinelander Industrial School at 350 East 88th Street is more like a tale of child abuse.

title: All-World Tour
description: The way Arnold Palmer sees it, if professional golf is to continue to prosper and expand there will have to be an end to the tugs-o'-war among rival national tours, including the separate United States, European and Japanese circuits. What is needed, he says, is the creation of one super all-world tour.

title: St. John's Rallies to Upset Syracuse
description: In only 1 minute 12 seconds yesterday, the physical difference between St. John's and Syracuse was drastically reduced.

title: Abortion: The Justices' Ambiguous Move
description: THE Supreme Court's intentions for the abortion case it accepted last week are mysterious even as the case becomes the latest lightning rod for the never-ending debate about abortion rights.

title: THE AMBIGUOUS YASIR ARAFAT
description: Marie Colvin tells us that Yasir Arafat has ''launched a campaign to convince the world - and Washington in particular - that there is now a new, moderate, realistic P.L.O.''

title: ETHICAL QUESTIONS THAT ARISE WHEN IT'S EASY TO DOCTOR IMAGES
description: Want a photograph of Alf, the lovable TV space alien, presiding at your company's board of directors meeting? Or how about the Eiffel Tower in the middle of the Manhattan skyline? Such doctored photographs have always been possible, of course, through tedious cut-and-paste operations. But the advent of still video photography, in which images can be stored in digital form in computers and manipulated on the screen, enables users to arrange tricks - or, more typically, to improve existing photos - at the touch of a button.

title:
ART;
Mixing the Archaic With the Modern
description: LEAD: A STRAIN of wickedness exists in both Emilio Cruz and China Marks, who currently have separate shows of recent works at the Robeson Center Gallery of Rutgers University. But just as some young people today say that something is ''bad'' when they find it very good, the wickedness in these two artists' works does keep the viewer's eyes open and makes him pay attention.

title: Pirates Solve Problems and UConn
description: Whenever Seton Hall faced a problem tonight, someone solved it.

title: Miss Greenwald To Marry in May
description: Jill Greenwald and Jonathan Roy Liebman, a son of Muriel Liebman of Hartsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Theodore Liebman, plan to marry in May, the the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James H. Greenwald of Olympia Fields, Ill., have announced.

title: Shortchanging Internees
description: When President Reagan signed the authorization for reparations payments to 60,000 Japanese-Americans last Aug. 10, he said that ''no payment can make up for those lost years'' when the Government held them in internment camps during World War II. Next year's budget provides virtually that - no payment.

title: Ms. Freeman, an Engineer, Is Engaged to Peter Roth
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harvey I. Freeman of New York of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Brooke Freeman to Peter Robert Roth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Roth of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Lincoln Center Theater: Act II; Remember The 'Failures'
description: To the Editor:

title: Child-Care Resource: Au Pair Program
description: The Dec. 18 article ''Nannies Are Striving to Upgrade Status'' was informative, underscoring the importance of having qualified caregivers in the home. However, the article overlooked a resource that addresses the child-care needs of the family and is affordable and legal.

title: Scientists Favor Opening Shoreham
description: The article ''Shoreham Impasse: Suggested Solutions'' (Jan. 1, 1989) failed to include comments from people representing the views of a majority of Long Island's scientists, engineers and physicians. Having participated with many of my colleagues in the analysis of numerous Shoreham issues, I believe that the following conclusions represent the prevailing professional opinion of this group.

title: Ellen R. Dickman Becomes a Bride
description: Ellen R. Dickman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin L. Dickman of New York, was married in New York last evening to Steven Koch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koch, also of New York. Rabbi Jacqueline Koch Ellenson, a cousin of the bridegroom, and Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated at the Rainbow Room.

title: PRESIDENTS: THE POWER AND THE MEDIOCRITY
description: James Bryce and Harold Laski, household names in another era - at least in certain intellectual circles - appear to have receded into that decent obscurity reserved for those whose major works, still in print, are rarely read. In a world of thermonuclear weapons and booming new industries, of innovative and complex communications systems and news media held to be immensely influential, with vastly expanded public bureaucracies expending money in amounts once never conceived of, books published in 1888 and 1940, purporting to treat what is putatively the most powerful position in the world, the American Presidency, can only be thought old-fashioned. It is a curious fact, however, that those who continue to write (or think) about the office - and their number is legion, particularly in the United States - do so generally in the tradition of either Bryce or Laski, whether they know it or not. What is even more curious, perhaps, is that while both have become part of our political discourse, the substantial differences between them are largely ignored. Yet they are immensely significant, particularly today.

title: POSTINGS: Downtown Ecletic; Hands-Off Condo
description: Hard by the Manhattan entrance to the Holland Tunnel are new headquarters for Local 28 of the Sheet Metal Workers International Association and the Community Literacy Research Project, a new outlet for a Washington art gallery and new homes for an insurance company and a jewelry manufacturer - all in one building. The eclectic mix results from the unusual traits of 500 Greenwich Street.

title:
THE REGION: Voters' Decision;
California Revolt Is Stalled in Court
description: LEAD: LIKE the taxpayers' revolt sparked 10 years ago by Proposition 13, the approval in November of California's Proposition 103 may have been the forerunner of a wider uprising against soaring automobile insurance costs.

title: A Shifting African Mood
description: The library of the American Cultural Center here is dedicated to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. At the conclusion of the African-American Institute's conference this weekend, a memorial ceremony was held at the center to honor Dr. King.

title: Getting an Early Start for Camp
description: LEAD: IT is in the midst of January's usually frigid weather that parents should begin to consider and look at summer camps for their children, experts in the field say.

title: Laura A. Zavatto to Marry
description: Laura Anne Zavatto and Paul D. Dewsnap, the son of Frank E. Dewsnap of Boston and the late Anne C. Dewsnap, plan to marry in September, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Zavatto of Shelter Island, L.I., have announced. Ms. Zavatto, a graduate of Adelphi University and Teachers College of Columbia Univesity, is a physical education teacher at the Hewitt School in New York. The future bridegroom, a graduate of Columbia, is the president of Donaldson Associates, a marketing services company in New York.

title: Body of Pilot in Libya Raid Is Flown Home From Rome
description: After a brief, silent ceremony at Rome's military airport, the body of an American pilot downed over Libya in 1986 was put on a United States Air Force plane today for the final journey home.

title: West End Risks and Rewards
description: An expatriate American freind of mine who has devoted five years to voracious London theatergoing is thinking of moving home to New York. I asked him what he would miss most about the theater in London and wasn't surprised when he failed to answer ''musicals on roller skates.'' But I was wrong to assume that he would rhapsodize about ''the classics'' or the Royal Shakespeare Company or the National Theater. ''I'm beginning to worry that there can be too much Shakespeare,'' he said, referring to the five not altogether distinguished productions of ''The Tempest'' he'd already seen this year. ''What I'll really miss most,'' he said, ''is Vanessa Redgrave. I've seen her give a half-dozen performances that I'll never forget.'' Miss Redgrave is giving one of those performances right now in a West End revival of Tennessee Williams's ''Orpheus Descending.'' Will homebound Americans ever see it? One can hardly assume so; Miss Redgrave, whose vocal support for the Palestine Liberation Organization is repugnant to many, has been conspicuously absent from our stages since the Boston Symphony Orchestra canceled her engagement as a narrator for Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex'' in 1982. In the meantime, Americans are missing the creative prime of the greatest actress in the English-speaking theater.

title: On a Stage, Making Music, For the First Time
description: THE phone call comes on a Friday afternoon while I am at the home of friends, playing oboe with fellow music lovers. On the line is a student conductor from a local college orchestra. Would I like to play second oboe in the Prokofiev Symphony No. 6? The concert is in a few weeks.

title: John Duncan Engaged To Heather Hawkins
description: Announcement has been made by Gaynell L. Hawkins and Walter E. Hawkins Jr., both of Shreveport, La., of the engagement of their daughter Heather Covell Hawkins to John Bruce Duncan, a son of J. Bruce Duncan of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Leila H. Duncan. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Getting Used to the Far Side of 50
description: AS I watch the plumbing in my 35-year-old house get rusty and I realize I'm getting the same way, I wonder what the future holds for me. At 50-plus (where did the time go?), when I squander my energies on a cleaning spree or on preparing fancy meals for 10, I find myself footsore, short-winded, exhausted.

title: Is Bush Prepared to Imagine the Future?
description: NOT since Dwight D. Eisenhower has an incoming President had more foreign policy experience than George Bush. As chief United States representative at the United Nations, as American liaison officer in Beijing, as Director of Central Intelligence and finally as Vice President, he has served a long, varied and testing apprenticeship.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A Proposal for Honoring Martin Luther King Jr.
description: LEAD: MANY forms of tribute are being paid today to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on what would have been his 60th birthday. Some believe one of the tributes should be a five-cent United States coin bearing his image.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture. However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years. The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone. I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent. However, I feel that acetone is too toxic. Is there some other way to clean without sanding the furniture down to the raw wood, and after it is clean should I use the same oil?

title: Playing a 'Fun Music' for Inaugural Ball
description: LEAD: TO Edward I. Metz, an investment banker, no amount of leverage is too much - as long as he's applying it to his piano keys.

title: High-Tick
description: MOST CENTURIES, IN ORDER TO compensate for the accumulated irregularities of measured time, the calendar skips a leap year Feb. 29. There are watches complex enough to adjust for this. However, at the turn of every fourth century (the year 2000 is one), the one leap year day must be reinstated, compensating for a slightly out-of-whack compensation. Soon - thank goodness -there will be a watch that accounts for this, too.

title: Judge Rejects Boat Searches
description: A Superior Court justice in Maine has ruled that game warderns' searches of boaters along the Saco River last summer were unconstitutional. Game wardens conducting the searches cited rowdy and potentially dangerous behavior by some boaters. But Justice Donald Alexander said there was ''no significant connection'' between the behavior the wardens sought to stop and the charges that were subsequently filed. Many charges involved fishing without a license, marijuana possession and not having enough life jackets.

title: Spain, Losing Backward Image, Booms as It Lures Foreign Money
description: With Europe's fastest economic growth rate and foreign investment that has tripled in five years, Spain is turning into the continent's Sun Belt.

title: Correction
description: A listing of Caribbean housekeeping accommodations on Dec. 11 included an erroneous report from the Cayman Islands Tourist Board about the status of the Driftwood Village apartments on Grand Cayman Island after Hurricane Gilbert. The resort remained open despite storm damage.

title: Pitching Is More Than Statistics
description: The Sports Editor:

title: Tne Courage of Dr. King: Challenging The Legacies of Other Black Leaders
description: WHEN references are made to the courage of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. we may think of his willingness to challenge the system of segregation or his denunciation of our Government's involvement in the Vietnam War or his determination to continue his nonviolent protests despite persistent death threats, or all of these.

title: Professors' Tax Break Phasing Out at Brown
description: A tax break for Brown University professors that dates to the days of King George III is being phased out but still gives 32 faculty members a discount on their property taxes, officials say.

title: Selling Grain
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Working Girl' in Reagan Country
description: LEAD: They've done it again.

title: Rough Week for Valvano and North Carolina St.
description: Considering all that happened the previous week, it was perversely appropriate that the long-scheduled kickoff dinner for a North Carolina State fund-raising drive fell on Friday the 13th.

title:
>New Jersey Q & A: James E. Trecker;
Bringing World Cup Soccer to the U.S.
description: LEAD: FOR the first time in the 59-year history of the World Cup soccer tournament, the United States will be the host country of the competition. James E. Trecker, 43 years old, of Oradell had a major role in arranging for the World Cup to be played in the United States in the summer of 1994.

title: The Drug Czar's First Battle
description: The newly appointed Federal ''drug czar'' sits at his desk, putting the finishing touches on a new strategy to stop traffic in addictive substances that can threaten health and life itself. Satisfied with his work, he leans back and lights up a cigarette.

title: FICTION
description: RICOCHET. By Ovid Demaris. (Scribners, $17.95.) Frank Conti is not your average bank loan officer. True, he does have an M.B.A., an upscale wife and a nice house in the suburbs, but he also has a very heavy enemy in Tony Allio, leader of the Atlantic City mob, who has hated him since they were in high school together in south Philadelphia. Frank, it seems, had humiliated Tony way back then, and nobody - repeat, nobody - humiliates this guy and gets away with it. Tony, deciding it is finally payback time, sets in motion a scheme to bring Frank to his knees by taking advantage of his wife's addiction to gambling. Tony's goons get her deep into debt, drug her, then kidnap the poor woman and hide her away in a pimp's apartment. Why kidnap her if they already have enough of her markers to break Frank's will, force him to steal money from his own bank and destroy his life? For the same reason they kill Frank's father, a tough but honest cop, and beat to death an old woman who just happens to get in their way: to make them despicable low-lifes who deserve what they get. And they get a lot before Frank finally crushes them into smears of grease. How is an M.B.A. banker able to take on such evil thugs? Hey, he knows karate. Plus he's one of those violence-haunted veterans of Vietnam, a former Green Beret who can . . . well, you know what they can do. Ovid Demaris, a crime novelist and former journalist, has written a novel full of bad dialogue, logical inconsistencies and cardboard cutouts. The one thing ''Ricochet'' does have is a fast pace, but not fast enough to allow the reader to suspend disbelief. It would have to move at twice the speed of sound for that.

title: Lincoln Center Theater: Act II; All Hope Abandoned?
description: To the Editor:

title: Freighters
description: To the Editor: The Dec. 18 Q & A included a California couple's request for sources of information on freighter travel. Besides the two publications suggested, freighter information of a different nature is available from the Freighter Travel Club of America (Post Office Box 12693, Salem, Ore. 97302).

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually today, will be observed tomorrow. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections.

title: Hoping Selfishness Goes Out of Style
description: I RECENTLY watched Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life'' for the eighth time. As always, I was emotionally uplifted by the story, which paints good and evil in broad strokes, letting the former prevail. But I was also saddened, for the movie highlighted a major failing of too many of my contemporaries - their need to measure success in terms of material wealth.

title: THE STEINBERG TRIAL: SCENES FROM A TRAGEDY
description: AT 2 O'CLOCK, WE turn on Channel 2. There is a close-up of a crying woman. A man, off-camera, is saying: ''You did what?''

title: THE PLAZA SUITE
description: Perhaps no hotel in the world has as remarkable a past or as controversial a future as the Plaza. Since the architect Henry J. Hardenbergh completed the French Renaissance-style structure in 1907, it has been the spot where gray-haired dowagers demurely sip tea in the Palm Court and giggling debutantes twirl through the Grand Ballroom until dawn. The Plaza was also the home of Eloise, the fictional 6-year-old, who spent her days pouring water down mail chutes, asking valets to clean and press her sneakers and calling room service to order one roast-beef bone, one raisin, seven spoons ''and charge it please.''

title: Lincoln Center Theater: Act II; The Judgment Is Premature
description: To the Editor:

title: January Light: A Rosy Blush From a Distant Sun
description: THERE is very little I like about winter except the light on a clear day. Winter light on a clear day has special qualities: oblique rays and a rosy blush around the horizon.

title: Accord at Vienna Conference
description: NATO and the Warsaw Pact announced an agreement clearing the way for conventional-arms talks and a human rights declaration. Page 4.

title: Revving It Up In Leather Coats
description: THE leather coat has frequently been cast in the role of bad boy; you know, the back-talking punk who's never going to amount to anything unless he changes his tune.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My mail tells me a lot of fat, white-haired, wrinkled ladies are tickled pink.'' - Barbara Bush. [ 1:1. ]

title: Fellow Owners Keep Close Eye On Steinbrenner
description: Usually, it's George Steinbrenner who is the scrutinizer. He scrutinizes his manager, he scrutinizes his pitching coach, he scrutinizes his players, he scrutinizes his general manager, not to mention everyone else who works for him. Now, however, the Yankees' owner has become the scrutinized.

title: ...AND THEY LIVED HEARTLESSLY EVER AFTER
description: THE NOTEBOOK By Agota Kristof. Translated by Alan Sheridan. 183 pp. New York: Grove Press. $15.95.

title: WHAT MADE HIM A HERO
description: EDWARD R. MURROW An American Original. By Joseph E. Persico. Illustrated. 562 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $24.95.

title: A Moderately Priced Newcomer
description: IT looks as though Danbury and Stamford are racing to see which city can open the most restaurants in the shortest space of time. Every time diners turn around, a new restaurant has emerged. For quality at moderate prices, however, the edge at this moment would go to Danbury.

title: L.I. Radio: Two Markets
description: The article regarding Long Island radio [ ''Radio Redux: Frequencies Are in Demand,'' Dec. 25 ] was interesting but made a common mistake, namely, that Long Island radio is one market. It is not. It is two. Nassau and western Suffolk is one and Long Island's East End is the other. While Arbitron does not measure them separately, Birch Research does.
