In the two surveys conducted, East End listening habits were divided as follows: East End stations 42 percent; Connecticut 27 percent; Nassau and western Suffolk 16 percent, and New York City 15 percent.

title: Insurance Chief Seeks H.M.O. Controls
description: LEAD: WITH 18 of the state's 23 health maintenance organizations posting losses for the first nine months of last year, the State Commissioner of Insurance has called for strict new controls on the organizations to insure their viability and to protect their members.

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Pete Fornatale;
20 Years of Rock 'n' Roll Radio
description: LEAD: FM radio has undergone many changes since the late 1960's. Among them has been the decline in on-air personalities who prepare their shows thematically.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HOME MOVIE. By Ellen Akins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Joey Taylor, the 14-year-old protagonist of this vividly written, authoritative first novel, is a young girl who starts out as ''a little brat doing her expert rendering of a little brat.'' As it happens, Joey has every reason to be bitter: her father has died after an undisclosed illness; her mother's whereabouts she can only guess from a string of postcards.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Environmental Worry Over Ferry

title: Image in Film Worries Mississippians
description: To many Mississippians, the first public screenings of ''Mississippi Burning'' here Friday revived painful memories of the state's violent past and raised concern that the movie would negate the progressive image the state has been trying to project nationally.

title: SCENES FROM A SEEDY COMMUNE
description: THE WOMAN WHO WAS GOD By Francis King. 296 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Burma Becomes a Test Case in Human-Rights Politics
description: BURMA'S new military leaders paid dearly for their brutal crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in September. Not only were they shunned diplomatically, but nearly all the country's foreign aid - including $300 million from the Japanese, $100 million from the West Germans and $12 million from the United States - was suspended. The effect was to cut off 90 percent of Burma's foreign exchange.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SANDINISTAS: The Party and the Revolution. By Dennis Gilbert. (Blackwell, $24.95.) Although a truce in the war has, at least temporarily, removed Nicaragua from the headlines, the subject of ''Sandinistas'' remains controversial. Dennis Gilbert, who teaches sociology at Cornell University, takes as his focus the ruling Nicaraguan party - the FSLN, for Sandinista National Liberation Front.

title: Lisa F. Fairburn, Student, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. David H. Fairburn of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Lisa Farnsworth Fairburn to Todd Rhoads Clark,the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. William Clark Jr. of Harvard, Mass. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: HACKER FOR HIRE: Peter Goldis; Looking for the Loopholes
description: Peter Goldis spent most of mid-December in Holland, breaking into the Amsterdam computer of a major international financial services firm. Earlier in the fall, he did the same thing at corporations in Detroit, Chicago and Los Angeles. This month, he has an assignment in Phoenix.

title: Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: College football and basketball should take their cue from college baseball, about which we rarely hear news of rule-breaking. The N.F.L. and N.B.A. should establish minor leagues. They should recruit high schoolers and make no bones about what is already obvious. A student could enter college to get an education, and yet not eliminate himself from the pro ranks (e.g., Ron Darling).

title: Urban Crime Begins to Alarm the Spaniards
description: Crime in general, and street crime in Madrid and other big cities in particular, has begun to alarm residents and Government officials concerned about the country's image.

title: THE GUIDE
description: HAMPTON IN MONTCLAIR Lionel Hampton, a giant of jazz who has performed with virtually all the other jazz greats, will appear with his orchestra Saturday night in Montclair.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
A Mix of Uses In the West End
description: LEAD: A 240,000-SQUARE-FOOT office and residential building is under construction in the West End, an area between Georgetown and downtown where several hotels have been built in recent years.

title: South African Writer, Though Freed, Is Gagged
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects; A High-Flying Dollar
description: Since the beginning of the year the dollar has been surprisingly strong. To bring down its value, central banks in Europe and Japan sold dollars on Wednesday and Friday. But despite a high level of intervention into the currency markets, the dollar continued its rise, closing out the week in Europe at 126.65 yen and 1.8275 West German marks to the dollar. Three traders and an economist speculate on the dollar's future. John W. Baker First vice president and chief trader, Bank Julius Baer & Company.

title: N.C.A.A. Rule Called Result of Self-Interest
description: For the last two decades, college athletes, black athletes in particular, have been pawns in a game designed to keep intercollegiate athletics, primarily football and basketball, on a prosperous course.

title: Origins of Imperial Line
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Katmandu
description: Katmandu, capital of a kingdom closed to all but a few official foreigners until 1951, has done a lot of catching up, particularly in the last decade. While much of the country remains medievally rural, steeped in social traditions, religious customs and even superstitions established by centuries of practice, the outside world has made inroads all over Nepal, especially in the capital.

title: A Case of Xenodochiophobia
description: IT'S a jawbreaker of a word: xenodochiophobia.

title: Staging Joyce, in His Own Words
description: ON the impact of James Joyce, a writer once commented: ''He made it impossible to be unaware of word choices.'' Another said, ''I don't think there's a writer alive who's escaped his influence.''

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: EDWARD E. DOWDY;
Pursuing Fairness and Equity on the Job
description: LEAD: THE county government is one of Westchester's largest employers - with a work force of about 7,000 people. To insure that opportunities for both entry-level and managerial jobs are given fairly - regardless of race, gender, age or religion - the government has an affirmative action officer. It is his job to enforce and monitor the county's affirmative action policy and deal with discrimination complaints from employees.

title: Thompson Walks and So Do Hoyas
description: Cynics might suggest that John Thompson chose the perfect time and place for his protest.

title:
GARDENING;
Keeping the Welcome Mat Out for Birds
description: LEAD: SONGBIRDS that do not migrate may be falling on hard times when their sources of weeds are snow-covered. Setting up a feeder can take an important role in insuring the birds' survival.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Dec. 31 MANHATTAN Chelsea $117,000 100 West 15th Street 470-sq.-ft. prewar co-op studio; 14-ft. ceilings, sleeping loft over kitchen; maintenance $404, 55% tax-deductible (Broker: Delson-Ginsberg Real Estate) Madison Square Area $1.25 million 5 East 22d Street (Madison Green) 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 3,000-sq.-ft. postwar penthouse condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, den, 2 powder rooms, fireplace, 2 kitchens, balcony, 4 exposures; common charge $1,006, taxes $2,472 (Broker: Wells & Gay) SoHo $50,000 150-152 Sullivan Street 250-sq.-ft. prewar co-op studio; separate kitchen, high ceilings, hardwood floors, renovated bath; maintenance $205, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Buchbinder & Warren) Upper West Side $260,000 315 West 99th Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $638, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: B.J. Gottesman) Upper West Side $180,000 300 Riverside Drive (102d St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, renovated kitchen and bath; maintenance $411, 33% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) BRONX Allerton Avenue Area $185,000 911 Burke Avenue 2-family, attached brick house; 3 bedrooms, dining room, large kitchen in primary duplex unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath in each; 16- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,150 (Broker: Sterling Realty) Wakefield $200,000 3310 Seymour Avenue 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, kitchen dinette in each unit; finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,350 (Broker: Cancro Realty) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights $206,000 2 Grace Court 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining room, windowed, large kitchen, parquet floors; maintenance $832, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Markgraf Group) Kensington $57,500 207 Ocean Parkway 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining foyer, new windows, hardwood floors; maintenance $278, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Elise Franco Brown) Midwood $265,000 2814 Bedford Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached center-hall colonial; dining room, large kitchen, den, fireplace, finished basement, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,173 (Broker: Dwork & Korn) QUEENS Fresh Meadows $218,000 53-14 196th Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, attached brick colonial; dining room, finished basement, rear patio, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) Rego Park $76,000 97-07 63d Road (Park City 3 & 4) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining area, windowed kitchen, double terrace, remodeled kitchen; maintenance $323, 58% tax-deductible (Broker: Elm Management) STATEN ISLAND New Dorp $163,000 4 Beacon Place 3-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, semiattached, frame house; dining area, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,233 (Broker: Schlott Realtors) St. George $285,000 204 Richmond Terrace 2-family, detached Victorian; 3 bedrooms, 2 baths in primary unit; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath in other; dining room, large kitchen, fireplace in each; 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,500 (Broker: Otto Vitale Real Estate)

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TEMPTATIONS. By Otis Williams with Patricia Romanowski. (Putnam, $17.95.) Otis Williams, the founder of the Motown singing group the Temptations, offers a unique perspective on the group's history, but the Tempts were best known for their soaring five-part harmonies and those other voices are sorely missed.

title: Man Dies as Car Hits a Midtown Work Site
description: A Queens man was killed early yesterday and two other men were seriously injured when a car crashed into trucks being used by workers removing a snowflake decoration from above a midtown Manhattan intersection, a police spokesman said.

title: THE REGION: The State's Rates; In Massachusetts, It's the Drivers' Turn
description: ONLY in Massachusetts and Texas are automobile insurance rates set by state government. In Massachusetts, the public control was meant to reduce differences in premiums between cities and suburbs, but the result has been a continuing wrangle over rates between the state and insurance companies.

title: The Strategy and Tactics Of Mothering a Sportsman
description: ANYONE who has ever raised a boy knows that gym class is a metaphor for life. Here in the sports arena of junior athletics, the boys are separated from the men, wimps are weeded out from winners and coach is a deity second only to the Highest Power. I should know. I'm a sports mother, dedicated to the care and feeding of the next lean, mean money machines: two young athletes in the making.

title: Reagan Gives Final Goodbye, Ending Eight Years on Radio
description: President Reagan, saying ''Saturdays will never seem the same,'' delivered his final weekly radio talk to the nation today, thanking the American people for the chance to lead them in pursuit of ''the American saga.''

title: A Modest Proposal On the Homeless
description: This year my Christmas spirit did not make it well into the New Year. It exploded into thousands of angry fragments on Christmas morning, when I read the article, ''Taxes Will Rise by Average of 9 Percent for Homeowners.'' To tell someone, whose tax burden is already approaching five figures, that his liability will be upped another big notch so as to pay $150-per-night hotel bills for the ''underprivileged'' is enough to create total outrage. It is not ameliorated by hearing that Social Services Commissioner John J. Allen is ''seeking alternatives.'' What in blue blazes have you been doing so far?

title: September Songs From Two Seasoned Stars
description: Ever since Walter Huston introduced ''September Song'' in the 1938 Broadway musical ''Knickerbocker Holiday,'' Kurt Weill and Maxwell Anderson's solemn meditation on aging has marked an unofficial rite of passage for pre-rock male singers seeking certification as pop interpreters. Of course, this great song in which an older person reflects on the follies of youth and the shortness of life should not be restricted to men. And on their new albums, Lena Horne and Julie Wilson prove that, with minor editing, a lyric haloed in avuncular pipe smoke can be just as powerful when voiced by a woman. Moreover, the fact that both Miss Horne and Miss Wilson are over 60 and still exude a commanding, statuesque glamour lends their renditions an extra tug of poignancy.

title: Judge Faulted in Departure of Discipline-Panel Aides
description: Members of the committee that disciplines lawyers in Manhattan have charged that the court that supervises it improperly forced the committee's top two staff lawyers to resign.

title: Agreement Clears Way for New East-West Talks
description: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators in Vienna announced an agreement today that cleared the way for the start of new negotiations on reducing conventional armed forces in Europe and for a major East-West document on human rights and economic cooperation.

title: Role Models and Robbins
description: Big Brothers' Helpers

title: Daniel Barenboim Is Dismissed as Chief Of New Paris Opera
description: Daniel Barenboim, the artistic and music director of the new Opera de la Bastille, was dismissed on Friday in a dispute over duties and salary.

title: Richard Goode
description: The pianist Richard Goode will play works by Beethoven, Schubert, Chopin and Debussy at Alice Tully Hall today at 3 P.M. Tickets are $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Downtown Brooklyn; Another Big Rental Hits the Co-op Road
description: A CO-OP conversion is under way at a large development called University Towers in downtown Brooklyn that has much to say about housing conditions in New York City and the role of conversions in improving them.

title: The 'Lost' Private Steps Forward
description: FROM the hundreds of soldiers who marched along the Champs Elysees in August 1944, one more has stepped forward to identify himself on the 1945 stamp that honored the United States Army. The soldier is Alfred G. Gilbert, who has retired from the dressmaking industry in New York City and lives in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. In 1945 he was a private first class, A company, 3d Battalion, 110th regiment, 28th infantry division. Although Mr. Gilbert claims a place assigned to another, his case is convincing.

title: Paine and Chadwick Return to Favor
description: Fashion can catch us up in the excitement of the moment, lending a surge of energy to contemporary artworks. But fashion can be cruel, too, and nowhere is it crueler than in the consignment of once-honorable, once-popular composers to oblivion.

title: Four Artists at Gallery Shows
description: THIS has not been one of Westchester's glittering art seasons and, viewed from the halfway point, it offers little promise of improvement. Apart from the Neuberger's artists' books show (closing today), most of the action for county residents has been at nearby museums in the Bronx, specifically at the Lehman College Art Gallery, whose 1960's exhibition has just closed, and at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, where the massive roundup of Hispanic artists remains through Jan. 29.

title: What Phones Must Provide To Customers
description: LEAD: FOR those who view the new privately owned pay telephones as the one-armed bandits of communications, the State Public Service Commission assures the public that the machines should not have to show three cherries to complete a call.

title: In Debt to Dante
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y.U. Plan Is Undeterred by a Fire
description: A fire that swept through a historic town house in Greenwich Village this month will not stop plans to convert it into a New York University center for Greek studies, the people in charge of the project say.

title: Stefanie Block Wed To Evan Jared Reed
description: Stefanie Pam Block, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Jay Block of Miami, was married there last evening to Evan Jared Reed, a son of Heidi A. Hyman of Danbury, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla., and Ary Reed of Bethel, Conn. Rabbi Herbert M. Baumgard performed the ceremony at the Kings Bay Country Club.

title: G.M. Executive Is Expected To Get No. 2 Pentagon Job
description: Donald J. Atwood Jr., vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation, is expected to be named to the No. 2 post at the Pentagon, officials involved in the transition to a new administration said today.

title: IT'S YOUR MOVE, CHARLEMAGNE
description: THE EIGHT By Katherine Neville. 550 pp. New York: Ballantine Books. $18.95.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title: Moonlight on Judea
description: As the bright, full early evening moon cast its glow on the Judean Desert, turning the Dead Sea beyond an unexpected pink, my reverie was broken by the sound of my stepson munching on his cucumber sandwich. A loud ''shhhhh'' punctuated the still air.

title: In Election Year, Tax Rises at Issue
description: REAL-ESTATE taxes have increased dramatically in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the extent of the rise not only has become a political issue but also is likely to be contentious through the local elections this year.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: MATILDA By Roald Dahl. Illustrated by Quentin Blake. 240 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Q and A
description: Unmarried Shareholders?

title: Of Pigs and Hot-Dog Trees
description: BIG TOP PEE-WEE Starring Pee-wee Herman (in photo), Penelope Ann Miller, Kris Kristofferson, Valeria Golino, Wayne White, Susan Tyrrell. Directed by Randal Kleiser. 1988. Paramount Home Video. 86 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG - though even its strongest double-entendres are harmless.

title: With Rival Coaches, Playbook's the Thing
description: Super Bowl XXIII next Sunday showcases head coaches who, offensively speaking, are wild and crazy and fast friends. Both are coaches who gleefuly tinker with offenses like locksmiths in a maze of doors.

title: Zaire Seeks Another Country To Offer Idi Amin New Exile
description: Zaire began looking today for a home for Idi Amin, the deposed Ugandan dictator who slipped out of exile in Saudi Arabia last week and is now without a country.

title: John Norris, 85, Led Alcoholics Anonymous
description: Dr. John L. Norris, a former chairman of Alcoholics Anonymous, died of complications from pneumonia Friday in New London Hospital in New Hampshire. He was 85 years old and lived in New London.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Can Winfield and Steinbrenner Find Peace?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Flight Delays
description: To the Editor: In her ''Abroad but Aground'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 6) Betsy Wade defines the flight delay problem well but does not point out that the most common example is not the long international flight but rather the everyday short-haul domestic flight.

title: Heidi H. Wasch to Marry Robert Leversee in June
description: The engagement of Heidi Helm Wasch to Robert Owen Leversee, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack H. Leversee of Bellevue, Wash., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William K. Wasch of Middletown, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: 'Fiddler': Endearing Classic
description: A FRIEND of mine says that she can see ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' as many times as it is produced, regardless of the quality of the production. She never tires of it.

title: CREATED BY THEIR ENEMIES
description: THE CONSTRUCTION OF HOMOSEXUALITY By David F. Greenberg. 635 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $29.95.

title: Correction
description: A front-page contents listing on Dec. 18 for an article about Rio de Janeiro characterized the city incorrectly. The capital of Brazil is Brasilia.

title: Harriet T. Huber Weds a Physician
description: At the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y., Harriet Therese Huber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Huber of Fond du Lac, Wis., was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas L. Tuttle, the son of Mrs. Ernest Harold Tuttle of Bronxville and the late Mr. Tuttle. The Rev. Richard J. Lichti performed the ceremony. Mary Ann Von Eichhorn was the maid of honor. Dr. Peter Williams, a cousin of the bridegroom, was the best man.

title:
ART;
Inner Concepts, Outer Forms
description: LEAD: BY choosing ''Inner and Outer Concepts'' as an exhibition title, the B. J. Spoke Gallery in Sea Cliff has found a way to encourage additional readings. It may be that the focus works well here because the exhibition is small enough for intellectual speculation to be appealing; there are 25 examples by 12 members of this artist-run cooperative.

title: POSTINGS: New Chairman; A Problem of Perception
description: On Thursday, the 93d annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of New York will be presided over by its 43d chairman. The new year brought Burton P. Resnick to the helm of the city's largest realty trade group. He succeeds Jerry I. Speyer and will serve a three-year term. The biggest problem facing the board, he said, is the ''perception of the real estate industry in the eyes of the city.''

title: Review/Music; Organ Recital By German
description: The centerpiece of Hans Uwe Hielscher's organ recital last Sunday afternoon at St. Bartholomew's Church was a big four-movement sonata by the French Romantic composer Alexandre Guilmant. Guilmant's name and some of his work are known to organists - he was a notable teacher, of Nadia Boulanger among others -but his music rarely turns up in recitals. Mr. Hielscher, who is organist of the Marktkirche in Wiesbaden, West Germany, has written a book on the composer and championed his music; on Sunday's evidence it would be rewarding to hear more.

title: Rosemarie Connors to Wed
description: The engagement of Rosemarie Patricia Connors to Vincent Gerard McCallion, a son of Rosetta McCallion of New York and the late Vincent McCallion, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Connors of Brooklyn. Miss Connors, a graduate of Fordham University, is the director of research in Mayor Edward I. Koch's press office. The future bridegroom, a trading assistant in the municipal bonds department at Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith in New York, graduated from Baruch College of the City University of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: THE AMBIGUOUS YASIR ARAFAT
description: Marie Colvin's article ''The Ambiguous Yasir Arafat'' (Dec. 18), is accompanied by a large picture of Mr. Arafat addressing the Palestine National Council in Algiers. It was at this conference that he renounced terrorism. In the picture, Mr. Arafat is wearing army fatigues and has a large gun in a holster at his right side.

title: Julia W. Pierson Is Married to Michael Mombello
description: Julia Welles Pierson, a daughter of Mrs. John Jay Pierson of St. Paul and Gulf Stream, Fla., and the late Mr. Pierson, was married yesterday to Michael Edward Mombello, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gary Mombello of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Richard Lampert and the Rev. Thomas Mitchell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist in St. Paul.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Madison
description: WHEN Mary Scranton was born in 1872, family homesteads along Route 1, Madison's Main Street, extended for almost a mile, down to Long Island Sound. ''Each house had a farmyard and access to the water for fishing,'' said her daughter, Charlotte Evarts, the town historian. ''Everybody had to be self-sufficient.'' Since then the farmers, shipwrights, millers and ax-makers who had lived in Madison from the mid-1600's until the beginning of this century have been replaced by bankers, doctors, lawyers, business executives and Yale professors. But Madison's appearance has changed little.

title: A NATION DIVIDED
description: MUBASHIR HASAN, who was Finance Minister in Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's Government during the early 1970's, was serving tea at his house in Lahore. We were joined by the editor of an Urdu-language newspaper and a businessman, both old members of Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, the P.P.P. I asked what they thought of the present leader of the party and now Prime Minister, Bhutto's daughter, Benazir.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: About Cars; A Cadillac Long on Luxury
description: My friend McCutcheon was wallowing in richness, breathing in the aroma of new leather. ''One thing you got to say,'' he said, ''this thing is luxurious.''

title: Home Plan Saves Land for Refuge
description: LEAD: THE Congleton Farm has been subdivided for development, but that might not be apparent to passers-by, since almost 90 percent of the land has been left untouched.

title: PROGRAM HELPING YOUNGER REFUGEES
description: When Ila Roy asked a group of 8-year-old Central American immigrants to draw a scene from their lives, she got some surprising results.

title: Downtown, Downplayed
description: Gentrification, a New England woman complains, is not exactly the word for what's happening to her town. Cute is more like it.

title: Miss Weiler To Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Eileen C. Weiler of New York and Sun Valley, Idaho, of the engagement of her daughter, Pamela Brooke Weiler, to Douglas Keane Grayson, the son of Dr. Isabel T. Whitehill-Grayson and Dr. Bernard N. Grayson of Brooklyn. Miss Weiler, the daughter also of the late Henry Weiler, and her fiance plan to marry in June.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hancock, Mass.;
Resort Condos, By Jiminy
description: LEAD: THE Jiminy Peak resort here has started work on Mountainside, a new vacation condominium project that will have 94 units in two complexes: one at the base of the 2,400-foot mountain and one higher up the slope.

title: Opening a New Era in Garbage Disposal
description: LEAD: MECHANICAL claws, like those of some giant, metallic bird of prey, are tearing into mounds of garbage inside the just-completed Babylon resource-recovery plant, the first of a new generation of at least seven garbage-burning incinerators projected for Long Island.

title: A&W: Prospering By Avoiding The Big Boys A&W Avoids the Big Boys
description: There are lots of things that tiny A&W Brands Inc. just cannot do. It cannot hype its sales and brand awareness by getting McDonald's or Burger King to serve its root beer; a contract with the A&W restaurant chain prohibits the soft drink maker from selling to any other fountain operation.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Melvin Bolton's first novel, ''The Softener,'' was published about three years ago, and it was respectfully greeted. It is nice to report that the British author's second book, THE TESTING (Gollancz/David & Charles, $19.95), carries on the good work.

title: Linda Gracia Married To Bruce J. Ruzinsky
description: At Congregation Brith Shalom in Bellaire, Tex., Linda Eloina Gracia, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnoldo Gracia of Houston, was married last evening to Bruce Jay Ruzinsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Ruzinsky of Old Tappan, N.J. Rabbis Andre Ungar and Shaul Osadchey, assisted by Cantor David Propis, performed the ceremony.

title: 'Famous for 15 Minutes'
description: To the Editor:

title: He'll Take Seattle (The Rain's Good For Business)
description: When Daniel Sullivan, a veteran director of New York and California theatrical productions, moved to the Pacific Northwest nearly 10 years ago he was asked at a party about his private passions. ''Do you ski?'' the guest queried Mr. Sullivan. ''No.'' ''Do you like to climb mountains?'' ''No.'' ''Do you own a boat?'' Again, Mr. Sullivan shook his head. The partygoer looked puzzled, and asked one more question: ''Then what are you doing in Seattle?''

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Branford, Conn. $275,000 21 Wilford Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old frame house; Long Island Sound views, cobblestone fireplace, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,373. Guilford, Conn. $193,500 98 Valley Shore Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; lake rights, finished basement, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,861. Madison, Conn. $220,000 46 Acorn Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; glassed porch, new roof, 1 acre; taxes $2,735. Hartsdale, N.Y. $565,000 32 Clubway 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; breakfast room, paneled library, playroom, porch; taxes $6,862. Scarsdale, N.Y. $500,000 21 Herkimer Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 51-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, family room, playroom, study; taxes $7,366. Yonkers, N.Y. $188,888 59 St. John's Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 56-year-old Tudor; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, dining room; taxes $2,400. OTHER AREAS Hauppauge, L.I. $190,000 22 Saturn Boulevard 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; dining room, den, basement; taxes $3,800. Levittown, L.I. $159,000 118 Gun Lane 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; family room, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Springfield, N.J. $277,500 16 Laurel Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old split-level; sun room, deck, 1-car garage, den; taxes $3,716.

title: Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: Of course they can play strictly by the rules, just as soon as they decide that education is more important than athletics, even for athletes. BERNARD LIEBMAN Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: CONNECTICUT Q & A: Caroline A. Dinegar; 'Terrorism Is a Crime Against Humanity'
description: The end of 1986 brought the reality of terrorism home to many people in Connecticut. First, the planting of a bonmb in a Norwalk pharmaceutical company, U.S. Surgical, allegedly by animal rights activist, indicated that terrorism can and does happen in one's backyard. With the bombing in December of Pan American's Flight 103, in which several Connecticut residents were killed, terrorism again hit home, and this time a lot harder.

title: Kathleen Scully to Wed J. L. Weinstock in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Brian J. Scully of Villanova, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Ann Scully to James L. Weinstock, the son of Mrs. John R. Shattuck of Cumberland Foreside, Me., and Harold B. Weinstock of New York. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Patricia McBride: Ballerina Plus
description: LEAD: In January 1959, George Balanchine, the New York City Ballet's founding choreographer, took a 16-year-old Teaneck, N. J., girl into his company. Balanchine cast Patricia McBride in the fourth movement of his ''Symphony in C'' and thereby launched the longest, most consistently successful career of any woman in the troupe's history.

title: India Studying 'Accidental' Deaths of Hindu Wives
description: All over India, where Hindu wives traditionally burned on their husbands' funeral pyres, brides in recent years have been dying in their husband's homes in fires that were called ''accidents'' until women's organizations began to demand an official accounting.

title: Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: No! The pressure to win: too great. The money involved: too much. The coaches' situation: too desperate. And a kid with talent: too vulnerable. MACK MORGAN New York

title: Take It Easy! You're Going on Vacation
description: A VACATION is - or should be - a time of relaxation, a time to put aside the daily routine and avoid petty annoyances. In short, a time to escape from stress. But vacation travel is fraught with situations that bring on stress: getting stuck in traffic on the way to the airport, waiting in line to check in, sitting on the runway wondering when the plane will take off, arriving at a hotel only to be told you have no reservation. Or, saving all year for what you hope will be the trip of a lifetime, then worrying whether or not your expectations will be dashed; going off to confront unfamiliar currencies, languages and ways of life and fearing you will suffer homesickness; encountering crowds at tourist sites; fighting lines at box offices.

title: Multiple Transplants Put Off
description: Doctors at the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh have stopped performing multiple-organ abdominal transplants until they can find a better way of keeping the body from rejecting the organs.

title: Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: As long as academically unprepared students are accepted at colleges, college will be a business - a big business! So let's stop pretending and get rid of the myth about halls of learning.

title: New Exhibit Examines South America's Tribes
description: Just past the stuffed bird displays and behind the Aztec statues, a new exhibition on South American tribes will open this Friday at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Church Seeks Bigger Home as Ethiopians Flock to Its Doors
description: In the late 1960's a small group of American and West Indian blacks, caught up in the move to regain their lost African heritage, established Holy Trinity Ethiopian Orthodox Church in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx.

title: Soviets Say Armenian Invented Ordeal in Quake
description: Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that Aikaz Akopyan and his sister had ''apparently'' invented an account of his rescue last week after being trapped 35 days with five companions beneath the rubble of the Armenian earthquake.

title: Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
description: The N.C.A.A., like OPEC, is a cartel, and any economist will confirm that cartel members gain a competitive advantage by cheating on their fellow members. Since no big-time coach willingly yields or fails to pursue an edge, cheating naturally inheres in big-time college sport. It is one more way our major universities teach their students the futility of fairness and the wisdom of greed. JOHN SWINTON State College, Pa.

title: CAUTION AT THE FED
description: ALAN GREENSPAN, CHAIRMAN OF THE FEDERAL Reserve Board, comes quickly across the office from his big, mahogany-brown desk, and greets his visitor with a nod and a gentle handshake. A friend of his says that Greenspan looks like Woody Allen, and there is a resemblance. But the thick, horn-rimmed glasses are gone; Greenspan has switched to thinner frames. And he does not have Allen's startled expression; his is deadpan, with just a hint of good humor.

title: When Accountants Function as Brokers
description: Millions of Americans will soon be knocking on their accountants' doors, an annual rite as the tax-filing deadline nears. Besides seeking the obligatory help in cutting their tax bills, many clients will ask the accountants to go one step further and provide broad financial assistance and investment advice.

title: Review/Theater; The Fleshpots of Dublin, In 'Ulysses in Nighttown'
description: If evocative language were the cornerstone of compelling drama, ''Ulysses in Nighttown,'' Marjorie Barkentin's dramatization of the Walpurgisnacht episode from Joyce's ''Ulysses'' might qualify as a modern classic. Faithful to the letter of Joyce's prose, the play - a mosaic of scenes connected by a narrator - follows Leopold Bloom and Stephen Dedalus on a June evening in 1904 into the fleshpots of Dublin where they find themselves in a phantasmagoric brothel.

title: Hoping to Salvage Desert Rail Depot
description: THERE is something about a ghost railroad stati, , ananding forlorn vigil in a lonely town, that grabs many city dwellers.

title: Giving to Neediest to Honor Many Who Cared
description: To honor the late Edward Torpey, superintendent for the buildings at 1604 and 1606 First Avenue in Manhattan, the landlord and tenants sent a gift of $200 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: PUTTING A LID ON THE MELTING POT
description: THE PARTY OF FEAR From Nativist Movements to the New Right in American History. By David H. Bennett. 509 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $29.95.

title: Burlesque, Gospel and Gershwin
description: FROM Baroque to burlesque, from gospel to Gershwin, from song to symphony, the Connecticut music scene has definitely returned to its pre-holiday level of activity.

title: Knicks' 3-Point Shots Hit The Spot
description: It was a first-half laugher at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: PERU'S TWIN CRISES RAISE COUP RUMORS
description: With President Alan Garcia seemingly overwhelmed by the challenges posed by wild inflation and mounting terrorism, Peru has been shaken over the last two weeks by intense rumors of an imminent military coup.

title: Trip Insurance
description: To the Editor: I would like to warn Times readers about the amounts paid to a traveler who buys trip cancellation insurance. The round-trip fare to Milan, for example, varies from as little as $400 to a high of about $660. T.W.A. advertises round trip to Rome, which is farther, at $546. These are restricted fares and are nonrefundable, noncancelable. But even at the high figures, one-way fares should run $330, $350, even as high as $400, which is the low round-trip fare.

title: One on the Fence
description: After five and a half years as the very visible United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani announced last week that he was leaving the job, touching off speculation that he would run for Mayor of New York.

title: Ms. Bingham Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Bingham of New York and Argyle, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Bingham to Jeffrey R. Perry, a son of Beverly Perry of New York and the late Jay H. Perry. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Making It in Hartford as a Homesteader
description: WHEN the Rev. Julio Colon, a pastor at Hartford's Christian Pentecostal Church, took a second job as a state prison chaplain, his increased income cost him his Federal subsidy on his apartment and his rent soared from $476 to $966. Such increases are applied to hasten the turnover of apartments to needier families.

title: Catherine Amdur Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Allen Amdur of Allenhurst, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Richardson Amdur, to Scot McCauley Small, a son of Karna Small of Washington and Francis M. Small Jr. of Aptos, Calif. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: General Hospital, New York City Style
description: THE public long imagined the general hospital, that sturdy device of television serials, to be a bustling but orderly fortress where hourlong crises arose only to be struck down through the efficient wonders of science.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bala Cynwyd, Pa.;
Offices Hugging The Main Line
description: LEAD: A $75 MILLION, nine-story office building has begun to rise in this affluent Philadelphia suburb of 10,000 residents that has long been the area's strongest office market.

title: Just a 'Watchword'
description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh Herbs at Hand No Matter What the Season
description: AS more companies go into the business of growing herbs hydroponically, various fresh herbs are now available all year. A few sprigs of fresh thyme, rosemary or tarragon can be found in many produce markets, sealed in plastic. In winter they usually cost $1.25 to $2 a package.

title: Outdoor Trips for the Active
description: Adventure travel is not for watchers but for doers. For some travelers, simply leaving the tour bus behind and striking out on an independent itinerary is adventure enough. For others, the destination is the adventure - China before it had Western-style tourist facilities certainly qualified, but fewer travelers would categorize it that way today.

title: Museum's Role in 'Billy Bishop'
description: LEAD: AT first glance, cooperation between Long Island Stage and the Cradle of Aviation Museum might seem a bit odd. After all, what could a theater company and a repository for vintage airplanes have in common?

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WOMEN, ART, AND POWER: And Other Essays. By Linda Nochlin. (Harper & Row. $22.50.) When Linda Nochlin's essay ''Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?'' was published in 1971, it set forth a pioneering agenda for a feminist history of art. The answer to the question of her essay, Ms. Nochlin argued, lies not in pondering women's innate genius, but in probing the social and institutional conditions that constrained them.

title: Canoeing Among Alligators
description: Six canoes slipped through the dark bayou waters under a full moon. But where was the moonlight? Not over our left shoulders, where it should have been, beaming into the narrow stream that wandered through a patch of Louisiana wetlands. That early autumn night all celestial rays were blocked by thick clouds just blown in from the Gulf of Mexico. Paddling in the bow of canoe No. 3, I peered ahead dubiously. I could see only broad outlines: trees and some suspicious-looking shapes on top of the water. A log? An alligator waiting for dinner - or waiting for us? Or was it a clump of lavender and pale green water hyacinths, beautiful but a menace to navigation.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CHILDREN OF CHINA: Voices From Recent Years. By Ann-ping Chin. (Knopf, $22.95.) In ''Children of China,'' the Chinese-American scholar Ann-ping Chin offers an intimate chronicle of contemporary China as told by its children. She interviewed more than 100 young people, ages 6 to 19, and elicited candid accounts of everyday life as well as provocative reflections on family relationships, education, morality, politics and the future.

title: TWO LIVES ON HOLD
description: William Squadron's story of his wife's agonizing wait for a suitable heart-lung organ transplant surely emphasizes the critical need for donors (''Two Lives on Hold,'' Dec. 18). One can only hope that thousands will respond by making the decision to become donors. In signing up with a human-parts bank, it is also helpful for the donor to inform his physician and lawyer, as well as next-of-kin.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Diverse Program By 5 Choreographers
description: Soundance, a repertory company that features dances in a variety of styles, was enterprising enough to present works by five choreographers on Thursday night at the Dia Dance Foundation. But its laudable intentions did not produce equally laudable results.

title: The Trials And Errors Of Boyd Jefferies
description: Boyd L. Jefferies puffed nervously on a Benson & Hedges cigarette while pacing the hallway of a Federal courthouse early last week. With anxiety clouding his tanned and deeply lined face, he could not conceal his unease over the prospect of another day of vigorous questioning by Arthur L. Liman, a lawyer for the GAF Corporation.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MADENSKY SQUARE. By Eva Ibbotson. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) Eva Ibbotson's second novel, '' Magic Flutes,'' won the 1983 Romantic Novelists Association award for the best romantic novel published that year in England. Her third, ''A Company of Swans,'' was equally and conventionally romantic. With her fourth novel, ''Madensky Square,'' she has fine-tuned - and perhaps even enlarged - the genre.

title: Trade and Credits With Soviet Union Are Near; Everybody's Business
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Businessman for Pentagon

title: New Charges Are Traded in Playland Case
description: THE ousted director of the Playland Amusement Park in Rye, indicted for having used park employees to assist in Republican Party mailings, has responded by accusing the District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, of conduct ''virtually identical'' to that attributed to the director.

title: Harbingers of Spring Enliven January
description: ALFRED KRAUTTER begins to ''think spring'' in January. While the rest of us burrow in for the worst of winter, Mr. Krautter, owner of the Sprainbrook Nursey in Scarsdale, envisions the bouquets of May.

title: 3 Goals Don't Do the Trick
description: Coach Al Arbour did a slow burn tonight behind the Islander bench in the first period, the one that wound up costing his team the game.

title: Calcavecchia Leads By Two Strokes
description: Mark Calcavecchia would prefer playing golf in wide-open spaces. It better suits his game, with those gigantic drives. He won the Honda Classic two years ago with an 8-iron shot from way out in left field to reach a green after a wild drive.

title: A Return to the Wooden Bridge
description: A New 60-foot bridge in Middletown represents a step back in time, both in technology and price, but transportation planners hope that it also offers a glimpse of the future.

title: Kate J. Horning To Wed in June
description: Kate James Horning and Mark Spencer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Spencer of Annapolis, Md., plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Horning of Fairfield, Conn., have announced.

title: Diana Pietraszewski Becomes a Bride
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Diana Beth Pietraszewski, a daughter of Mrs. Frank P. Pietraszewski of Simsbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Pietraszewski, was married yesterday to Edward Frederick Wagner Jr., the son of Mr. Wagner of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Columbus, Ohio, and the late Margaret Wagner. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony. Valerie Anne Pietraszewski was her sister's matron of honor, and Anthony John Hamilton was the best man.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE CHINAMAN PACIFIC & FRISCO R.R. CO. By Frank Chin. (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) The stories in Frank Chin's first collection, mostly set in Oakland, Calif., use fantasy, obscenity, slapstick and acute introspection to describe the frenzied search for identity of a Chinese-American artist known as Dirigible.

title: THE NATION: Governing in the 'Feel-Good Era'; What Congress Really Does Between Elections
description: AMERICANS will watch on their television sets this week the grand ceremony of inauguration, when those chosen by politics are invested as the leaders of Government. As he takes the oath of office Friday as the 41st President, George Herbert Walker Bush will be surrounded on the steps of the Capitol by the members of the 101st Congress. But the political process that has brought them to this high place, many of these politicians will know, has done little to prepare the public, or steel these officials, for the work that Government now must do.

title: Ray Morehart, Yankee With Ruth, Dies at 89
description: Ray Morehart, a reserve infielder on the 1927 New York Yankees, died at home Friday. He was 89 years old.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A LOVING ANALYST
description: THE CLINICAL DIARY OF SANDOR FERENCZI Edited by Judith Dupont. Translated by Michael Balint and Nicola Zardy Jackson. 227 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: Brecht and Weill Meet the 'Cinema Man' Weill and Brecht Go On the Screen
description: On a vast lot of former farm land outside Budapest, corn growing had given way to film making and a grimly realistic vision of the lower depths of Dickensian London had risen.

title:
GARDENING;
Keeping the Welcome Mat Out for Birds
description: LEAD: SONGBIRDS that do not migrate may be falling on hard times when their sources of weeds are snow-covered. Setting up a feeder can take an important role in insuring the birds' survival.

title: Flight 103 Explosive Didn't Need Sophisticated Trigger Device
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture. However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years. The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone. I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent. However, I feel that acetone is too toxic. Is there some other way to clean without sanding the furniture down to the raw wood, and after it is clean should I use the same oil?

title: The Layered Look Was Pioneered By Laquerware
description: Lacquering, an ancient craft combining exotic imagery, exquisite detailing and satiny finishes, has transformed a stunning variety of ordinary and esoteric objects over many centuries. The proof is seen in a selection of delightfully dissimilar works assembled in the exhibition ''Lacquer - A Panorama of Asian Decorative Arts,'' at the Brooklyn Museum, through June 14.

title: A Vicious Circle Keeps Latin America in Debt
description: IMAGINE a family that suddenly finds it can no longer keep up payments on its $80,000 mortgage and falls $6,000 behind.

title: U.S. RELINQUISHES ALABAMA PRISONS
description: Alabama's state prisons are back in state hands, more than 16 years after a Federal judge cited them for ''barbarous'' and ''shocking'' treatment of inmates and 13 years after he took control of the entire system.

title: Lincoln Center Theater: Act II; A Particular Grail
description: To the Editor:

title: Lexanne Johnson to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Stanley E. Johnson of Philadelphia and Siasconset, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Lexanne Johnson to Christopher Cunningham Abbott, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Abbott Jr. of Manchester, Mass. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Rebel Hunters in Namibia Train for Less Violent Times as Ordinary Police
description: The police counterinsurgency teams that have ruthlessly hunted down guerrillas from the South-West Africa People's Organization are being retrained for a more mundane role in anticipation of Namibia's independence.

title: Thriving with Turgenev
description: WHILE one might wonder just what it is about ''Fathers and Sons'' that has drawn one playwright after another - all of different nationalities - to dramatizing Ivan Turgenev's 1862 Russian novel, it is clear that George F. Walker's version is the popular play of the regional theater season.

title: George Bush's New World
description: Has any new President ever been dealt a stronger hand in foreign affairs than George Bush? Consider the opportunities for progress, some of which senior officials in the new administration say they are already looking into.

title: BRINGING BACK THE ECSTASY
description: LEAD: THE COMING OF THE COSMIC CHRIST The Healing of Mother Earth and the Birth of a Global Renaissance. By Matthew Fox. 278 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. Paper, $14.95.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Thin Blue Line Featuring the principals in the case and, in re-enactments, Adam Goldfine, Derek Horton, Ron Thornhill, Marianne Leone, Amanda Caprio and Michael Nicoll. Directed by Errol Morris. 1988. HBO Video. 101 minutes. $89.99. Not rated.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WOMAN WHO WAS NOT ALL THERE. By Paula Sharp. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) Paula Sharp's first novel tells the story of Marjorie LeBlanc, a nurse struggling to rear her four children with the emotional support of several unconventional female friends - but without any help from her prosperous ex-husband.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LABOR PAINS. By Kate Klimo. (Crown, $17.95.) Popular novelists have seldom been able to resist the story of a group of women and how they grow. In ''Labor Pains'' by Kate Klimo, who co-wrote the novel ''Golden Triple Time,'' five New Yorkers grow literally - they meet in a Lamaze class. There's Carleen, the fortyish publishing executive who beats her long-time infertility; Louise, the mother of three and the wife of a food mogul whose libido is as vast as his gourmet empire and whose dislike for his unborn child (little does he know it's triplets) surpasses both; Mary

title: From a Master Scarf-Maker
description: SCARFS are making a strong fashion statement this year, so an exhibition opening Tuesday at the Hermes boutique at 11 East 57th Street is a timely one. Called ''A Scarf Is Born,'' the show will include demonstrations of scarf-making as well as a display of 100 framed scarfs chosen from the 900 designs in the company archives in Paris.

title: Ruth Ann Brophy Wed to Executive
description: Ruth Ann Brophy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles George Brophy of Southport, Conn., was married at the Southport Congregational Church yesterday to Frederick Chorlton Mitchell 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Jr. of Newark, Del. The Rev. Loring Sabine Ensign performed the ceremony.

title:
The View From: The Saturday Night Specialty Show;
Savoring the Legends of Rock 'n Roll
description: LEAD: ''DON'T touch that dial!'' Freddie Cannon's voice, recorded back in 1966, boomed through the control room at WZFM 107.1 on your FM band. ''We're just on that station. I'm going to make another dedication.'' And another and another and another. Saturday nights, 7 o'clock to midnight, the station, on Bedford Road here, broadcasts hits from the 1950's and 1960's, most of them requested by listeners.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: AIRLINE DEREGULATION;
For Better Service, Rebuild the System
description: LEAD: Civil aviation has built industries, created millions of jobs, aided American competitiveness and helped corporations manage their operations. Small wonder some economists believe civil aviation accounts for as much as 10 percent of the gross national product.

title: Tight Money Slows Drive to Integrate
description: JUST over a year ago, Education Commissioner Gerald N. Tirozzi denounced what he called an ''educationally, morally and legally wrong'' condition in the state's public schools: racial segregation. And he said the local school districts could correct the imbalance on their own, or be forced to.

title: Thompson Keeps the Faith
description: We were at somebody's 40th birthday party the other night, mourning the 60's. My friend said he missed the time when people took a stand if they thought something was unjust.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ANOTHER LOOK AT CALLAS Twenty-six years ago George Jellinek, the noted musicologist and host of WQXR's nationally syndicated program The Vocal Scene, wrote a book about Maria Callas titled ''Callas: Portrait of a Prima Donna.''

title: Holli Gunther and Alan H. Roth Marry in Boston
description: Holli Georgia Gunther, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gunther of Arlington, Vt., and Alan Harry Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Roth of Patchogue, L.I., were married last night at the Parker House in Boston. Justice of the Peace Vivian T. Burns of Woburn, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: To Create the Ideal Employee, Bridge the Generations
description: IF you were asked to create a workplace Frankenstein as a paradigm for the ideal employee, where would you begin? When observing co-workers, have you noticed that certain glaring behavioral differences often follow patterns related to age?

title: Comings and Goings
description: She won two gold medals at the 1988 Olympics and now Jackie Joyner-Kersee has her sights set on a world record. She will try to break the indoor mark for the 55-meter hurdles at the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Feb. 3. . . . James (The Heat) Kinchen and Chris Tiozzo of France will fight a 10-round super-middleweight bout in Paris March 10 under the aegis of the Houston Boxing Association.

title: Ticket Lottery At Meadowlands
description: The Meadowlands has issued rules for the lottery drawing to obtain tickets to the Eastern Regional collegiate basketball tournament there March 24 and 26.

title: Mexican Union Chief Is King To the Oil Workers at Home
description: In this drab industrial city on the Gulf Coast, the main supermarkets are owned by the Mexican oil workers union. So is the only funeral home and so are some of the auto repair shops and gasoline stations.

title: MADAME AMBASSADOR AND THE BOSS'S WIFE
description: AT REAGAN'S SIDE By Helene von Damm. Illustrated. 341 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: THE ROOT OF ALL SPORTS: $$$$
description: When that ol' devil auditor comes to mark against your name, He marks not if you won or lost but how much you banked from fame.

title: IT'S A SMALL WORLD
description: Angel Antonio Sanchez-Cabanas turns away from the glare of Madrid's midday sun and leans his frame against a wall, the better to show off his garb. He wears a snug-fitting toreador-style jacket, a black ribbon tie - the sort of thing that Zorro might have fancied - and a Mexican belt with a hand-tooled silver buckle. He mates this all-Latin composite with American khaki trousers and a pair of fancy snakeskin cowboy boots, a present from a friend in Oklahoma.

title: Ready-Made Alibi
description: Coaches are forever dreaming up excuses to account for a poor record, but Jes Hutson, the coach of the Thiel College basketball team in Greenville, Pa., outside Pittsburgh, has a ready one to explain why the Tomcats have lost 9 of their first 10 games this season: a shortage of players. It seems that a combination of injuries, fouls and academic problems has left the Tomcat ranks so depleted that they have twice finished games with just four players on the floor.

title: Making a Subtle Difference
description: On Friday night, the San Francisco 49ers' special teams got together for a Gutbuster Dinner. The entertainment for the 25 players and their wives and dates was a video of the special-teams season, the good parts and the funny. Lynn Stiles, the special-teams coach, picked up the check.

title: THE REGION: Kean's Frustration; Compromise On Insurance Isn't Working In New Jersey
description: NEW JERSEY'S Insurance Commissioner, Kenneth D. Merin, once suggested that the chief reason for the state's high automobile insurance rates was that it had more people and cars per square mile than any other state, ''and they keep bumping into each other.''

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: IF there are two overworked words in the English language at the moment, they must be ''kinder'' and ''gentler.'' Since President-elect George Bush chose them to convey his vision of the country and the future, they have filled newspaper columns and airwaves, have been sprinkled in countless conversations, have jumped out of advertisements and commercials and have been used in almost every context, with a grand disregard for accuracy.

title: Who George Bush Is, And Is Not
description: When Mr. Bush moves into the Oval Office, he will put aside the isolated majesty that Mr. Reagan brought to the Presidency and slip into something more comfortable.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Dr. Greenspan is administering the medicine the economy needs. The unintended side effect is that the dollar gets too strong.'' Neal M. Soss, chief economist, First Boston Corporation.

title: With Aquino Popular, the Philippine Rebels Tread Tricky Political Waters
description: When the founder of the Communist New People's Army, Bernabe Buscayno, began talking about shifting to a peaceful political struggle a couple of years ago, he set off a furious debate within the top echelons of the party that still has not been resolved.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: AT first, there was just the barest hint of a sound - the sort of noise that exerts enough leverage to bring heads up, then leaves them hanging. ''Must be the wind,'' I hypothesized, surrendering to the lure of that timeless red herring.

title: POSTINGS: Near Spring Lake; Basic Colonial
description: The 65 houses of Old Mill Estates in Wall Township, N.J., will look so much like those from the 1790's that, if not for their obvious newness, they would seem straight out of the 1970's. Their architect, Tom Schauvette, said that while the Colonial style, marked by shutters, shingles and simplicity, remains as popular in the 80's as in the 70's, such houses today usually are dressed up. ''Everyone now is doing a Colonial base with more contemporary flairs,'' he said. But the Old Mill developers bought their plans from a set compiled over 10 years by Mr. Schauvette's concern, the Washington Group of Morristown, and left them alone, even keeping the central hallway, which has verged on extinction.

title: Sampling New Terrain At Vail
description: FOR a quarter of a century Vail has been one of America's big-league ski resorts. Now Vail is twice the area it was a year ago. That's not just a figure of speech. Vail this season has opened the China Bowl Expansion, a shorthand reference to the opening of four bowls (large, deep expanses of terrain mostly free of trees) on the back of the mountain - China, Teacup, Siberia and Mongolia - all made accessible by two new lifts. That doubles Vail's skiable terrain to 3,787 acres served by lifts. The spread is six times the size of Aspen Mountain, its traditional rival; more extensive than Colorado's Breckenridge, Copper Mountain, Arapahoe Basin and Keystone combined. And that doesn't include the 800 acres at Beaver Creek, 10 miles to the west and skiable on the same lift ticket.

title: HOW TO WIN A COIN TOSS
description: LEAD: INNUMERACY Mathematical Illiteracy and Its Consequences. By John Allen Paulos. 135 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $16.95.

title: The Anti-Patronage Mayor Finds He Has Explaining to Do
description: IN 1977, Edward I. Koch, who had made a career out of battling the political bosses, met with one of the biggest of the bosses, Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Demo-cratic leader, to win Mr. Esposito's blessings in the New York mayoral primary runoff against Mario M. Cuomo. Mr. Koch and Mr. Esposito agreed that Mr. Esposito would work for Mr. Koch but would keep quiet about it.

title: For Moiseyev, Change Is Afoot
description: To hear Igor Moiseyev tell it, Americans still insist inexplicably on seeing the same rosy-cheeked Russian maidens they remember from his theatricalized folk dances of more than 30 years ago. But times are not the same since the Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow made its wildly acclaimed United States debut in 1958. Change, in fact, is very much on the mind of the famed Soviet choreographer, who celebrates his 83d birthday on Saturday.

title: Bush Is Urged to Give Priority To Fighting Adult Illiteracy
description: Backed by Barbara Bush, a research group on education policy has urged the incoming Presidential administration to give adult illiteracy a high priority.

title: Danbury Medal Maker Celebrates New Presidents
description: Donald A. Schwartz, the president of the Medallic Art Company, was fidgeting. With just days left before Inauguration Day, everything in his production room was at a virtual standstill while workers were taking inventory.

title: Flight 103 Explosive Didn't Need Sophisticated Trigger Device; Send Bags Separately
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerry Lee Lewis Can Still Stir Things Up
description: It's a sunny, sweater-weather winter afternoon, and as Jerry Lee Lewis's ''High School Confidential'' blasts from an eight-foot-high tower of speakers, the actor Dennis Quaid, playing the wild and legendary rocker, bounces up the steps of a Memphis elementary school to grab Winona Ryder, who portrays Lewis's 13-year-old bride, Myra, in the film ''Great Balls of Fire!''

title: The Best Books of the Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Cesar Pelli Seeks the Perfect Skyscraper
description: Cesar Pelli has struggled, perhaps more earnestly than any other commercial architect, with the problem of making a skyscraper form suitable for our time. An architect whose initial fame came from his attempts to use glass to make patterned and colorful facades (Mr. Pelli did Museum Tower in New York and Four Leaf Towers in Houston, among others), his quest clearly has been to find a way to make buildings that are richer than the austere Mies van der Rohe knockoffs of the 1960's and 1970's, yet avoid the literal cribbing from history and the somewhat precious use of details that are so often part of post-Modernism. Yet over the years Mr. Pelli's skyscrapers have become more evocative of the towers of the past, as if he realized that the abstract direction in which his glass towers were taking him was too limiting.

title: Professional-izing
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Golf, and 'the Course Is Mine'
description: THE lazy days of summer are gone. The Mets have left Shea and the Great Pumpkin is memory. The earth is cold. Boy, am I glad.

title: Independent Pay Phones on Rise LBy DAVID WINZELBERG
description: LOCAL independent pay-telephone companies have reached out and touched upon a new multimillion-dollar industry, creating big changes in phone booths, while leaving many customers calling for help.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Allendale $339,000 87 Homewood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Tudor; deck, brick patio, beamed ceiling in living room; taxes $4,560. Hanover Township $404,000 16 Forest Way 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; family room, c/a, deck, landscaped; taxes $3,721. Millburn $290,000 116-118 Cypress Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, c/a, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,761. Springfield $277,500 16 Laurel Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old split-level; sun room, deck, 1-car garage, den; taxes $3,716. Toms River $156,250 18 Lynn Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; 2-car garage, patio, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,422. West Milford $184,900 20 Shore Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old lakefront ranch; fireplace, new kitchen, private dock; taxes $2,665. OTHER AREAS Yonkers, N.Y. $188,888 59 St. John's Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 56-year-old Tudor; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, dining room; taxes $2,400. Madison, Conn. $220,000 46 Acorn Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; glassed porch, new roof, 1 acre; taxes $2,735. Uniondale, L.I. $200,000 1293 Birch Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; den, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800.

title: The Camera Lens as Two-Edged Sword
description: Except in rare and wonderful moments like Edward R. Murrow's 1960 documentary ''Harvest of Shame,'' television traditionally follows rather than leads when it comes to social movements. It is, of necessity and leaning, a cautious medium, licensed by the Government and influenced by the seesaw rhythms of public policy and piety. In the 1960's, television was chastised as a vast wasteland by the Federal Communications Commission. In the 1980's, the same F.C.C. treats the medium more like an unregulated for-profit industry than a public asset designed to operate in the public interest.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Developers Home In on Small Airports
description: LEAD: A DWINDLING supply of developable land, rising property values, growth pressures and the financial problems of airport operators have made New Jersey's small airports prime development candidates.

title: Thurber's Law
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: A BURNS BIRTHDAY Did you know that Robert Burns, the great Scottish poet, was born in January - Jan. 25, 1759, to be exact?

title: When a Doctor Is Worth a Tax
description: IT WAS at the time a big step for Fort Cobb, Okla., population 722.

title: Vermont Case May Upset Transplant Policy
description: Varian D. Schmokel won her court case but died before she ever knew it.

title: Armenian Church Plans Mass for Quake Victims
description: LEAD: MEMBERS of the Armenian Church hold a ''requium mass 40 days after someone's death,'' Father Karekin Kasparian of the St. James Armenian Church in Purchase said. Today is the 40th day after the earthquake that devastated Armenia, and at St. James a candlelight service will be held for the victims.

title: WINTER WARMTH
description: The descent of winter on the garden and the produce market colors everything green, brown and ivory. People shopping wear looks of resignation. They may fill their baskets with bright red tomatoes or strawberries, knowing that lively color disguises something that tastes more like styrofoam than food.

title: Baton Poised at Last in New Haven
description: MICHAEL PALMER'S debut as music director of the New Haven Symphony, delayed since Nov. 15 because of a musicians' strike, will be Jan. 24 in Woolsey Hall.

title: Immigrant's Daughter Takes Talent to India
description: When Leela Raja was growing up in an affluent suburb of Philadelphia, her classmates thought of her Indian face and clothes not as exotic or interesting, but only as different - and that put a distance between her and them.

title: Political Notes; Hearings on Koch Patronage: a Matter of Timing
description: The timing of last week's headline-making hearings into Koch administration patronage could be highly significant - and certainly intriguing.

title:
MUSIC;
A Met Double Bill of Disturbing Intensity
description: LEAD: Bela Bartok's ''Bluebeard's Castle'' and Arnold Schoenberg's ''Erwartung'' are regarded by many as pivotal scores in the 20th-century operatic literature; but while recordings of these one-act works are readily available, they are rarely heard in the opera house. The Metropolitan Opera is rectifying the situation with a double bill that opens tomorrow at 8 P.M.

title: A Hazard at Home: Air Pollution
description: HE person next door to you could be living in a home that is environmentally safe, but, depending on ventilation and chemical use within your household, you may be living in an environment that's hazardous to your health.

title: Lawyer's Words Cause Shock
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Providence Shocked By Villanova, 76-67
description: Rick Barnes, the first-year coach at Providence, took his first loss of the season the same way he did the news the Friars were ranked No. 20 last Monday, in stride.

title: INDUSTRY HOPING FOR AN ENCORE OF '88
description: The baby boom generation embraced the marine industry last year as never before. Industry officials say the union produced record sales and a period unmatched in boating history.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

title: AIDS Scare Leaves a Supplier With a Glut of Latex Gloves
description: Months after concern over the spread of the AIDS virus caused a shortage of rubber gloves, a New Britain-based medical supplier is stuck with millions of them.

title: The Missing Millions: Where Are They?
description: The article on the increase in county taxes for 1989 [ ''Taxes Will Rise by Average of 9 Percent for Homeowners,'' Dec. 25 ] quoted the official explanation - rising corrections and homeless requirements. The first increase by $13.4 million, the second by $13.1 million. But the total budget rose from $847 million in 1988 to $930 million for 1989, a jump of $83 million. This leaves $56.5 million not explained by the increases for corrections and homeless housing.

title:
MUSIC;
Clarinet Quartet Focuses on the Young
description: LEAD: THREE workshop-concerts at the Echelon Mall in Voorhees will focus on educating young listeners in an informal setting. A clarinet quartet from the Haddonfield Symphony will show that music is ''a living art,'' said Daniel Dorff, a member of the ensemble and spokesman for the quartet, which he formed this season.

title: THE WORLD: A Vicious Circle Keeps Latin America in Debt; Where the Burden Is Heaviest
Jennifer Conlin To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Conlin of Ann Arbor, Mich., Harbor Springs, Mich., and Red Hook, V.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Anne Conlin to Daniel Hirsch Rivkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Rivkin of New York and Westport, Conn. Miss Conlin and her fiance, graduates of the University of Michigan, plan to marry in June.

title: DARWIN MEETS THE KAWESKAR
description: WHO WILL REMEMBER THE PEOPLE . . . By Jean Raspail. Translated by Jeremy Leggatt. 213 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $18.95.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Scottsdale, Ariz.; Reservation Shopping
description: SCOTTSDALE PAVILIONS, a 600,000-square-foot shopping center, is scheduled to open in March on the Salt River Indian Reservation just outside this city of 126,000 residents. It will be the country's largest private commercial development on Indian land.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Hollywood, Fla.;
Luxury Rentals For the Elderly
description: LEAD: A MAJOR expansion is under way here in a rental development for the well-to-do elderly that is providing another example of how builders are trying to fashion different types of living facilities for a growing market.

title:
FOCUS: NASHUA, N.H.;
Impact Fees: 'Blackmail' or a Fair Sharing of Costs?
description: LEAD: This city of 80,000 helped itself and other fast-growing communities in the state by getting a developer to agree to pay $18 million for public improvements in exchange for zoning permission to build a large residential and commercial project.

title: Shot-Putter Wins Despite Incident
description: Randy Barnes, a 1988 Olympic silver medalist, overcame the loss of sleep following an early morning confrontation with an Arkansas gunman and recorded the second-best American indoor shot-put today.

title: Lakers Rookie's Search for Solace
description: THE basketball court has long been a sanctuary for David Rivers. Whether it is a shiny wooden floor in a famous arena, or bent rims on a glass-strewn playground, all he needs is a basketball to control the action.

title: When Swans Cry
description: To the Editor:

title: Why History Will Honor Mr. Reagan
description: As a new President comes into office, it is commonplace to express hope for the future. But even a cynic would have to acknowledge an extraordinary combination of events, at the end of the Reagan Administration, that offer the world more hope for peace and freedom than at any time in decades. It is crucial that we understand how we reached this point.

title: First Lady Hopes for Unglamorous Legacy
description: Despite ''terrible press'' over such matters as her fondness for designer gowns and expensive china, Nancy Reagan hopes that history will remember her for her efforts to solve America's social problems, the First Lady said in an interview made public today.

title: Lincoln Center Theater: Act II; Artistic Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: The Homey Carpets Of County Cork
description: IRELAND has its rains and winds; it also has some of their most effective antidotes. Irish civilization at its best puts sufficient warmth inside the home to counter the deepest chills or damp. The heat of a good peat fire penetrates; steaming tea and fresh wholemeal scones brace one against the elements. Hearty stews inject well-being with their blend of earthy potatoes, smoky bacon and pungent lamb. Similarly, Macroom carpets combine rich elements with a balanced mix that buoys the soul. Nubbly yarns play against flat ones, vibrant crimsons and foamy greens against muted whites. Underfoot these rugs divert and soothe.

title: Oklahoma Shooting
description: The shooting of one Oklahoma football player by another was an accident after a series of arguments ''about stupid stuff,'' according to a third Sooner player who said he witnessed the incident early Friday morning. Rod Fisher, a halfback, told The Daily Oklahoman that he was present when Jerry Parks, a freshman, shot Zarek Peters, a third-year lineman, during a scuffle in Peters's dorm room. Peters was reported in serious but stable condition yesterday with a bullet wound of the left chest.

title: Outdoors; Guide to Fishing in Faraway Places
description: Since late last fall, I have been sliding certain brochures and letters into a manila folder which bears the legend ''faraway places.''

title: 685 ARE ARRESTED OPPOSING ABORTION
description: The police arrested 685 abortion opponents yesterday demonstrating outside Manhattan abortion clinics for the second consecutive day. Many of the protesters had stopped traffic, blocked sidewalks and, in once case, chained themselves together, the police said.

title: RUSSIANS DISCLOSE SATELLITES CARRY NEW REACTOR TYPE
description: Soviet scientists have disclosed that they have launched satellites carrying an advanced new class of nuclear reactor that is the most efficient, long-lived and powerful ever to orbit the earth.

title: NETS HIT IN CLUTCH TO DEFEAT PACERS
description: Roy Hinson scored 10 of his 23 points in the fourth quarter, including four free throws in the final two minutes, to lead the New Jersey Nets to a 106-97 victory tonight over the Indiana Pacers.

title: The Dollar Shows Its Buoyancy
description: The dollar kept bouncing up despite coordinated efforts by central banks to wrestle it down. The gains were especially strong against the West German mark. The dollar has risen more than 3 percent against the mark this year. On Friday, the dollar reached three-month highs, trading above 1.84 marks in Europe before falling when the central banks began selling dollars in their fourth intervention of the week. A principal reason the dollar is attractive is American interest rates, which are higher than in many other countries and, thus, cause investors to buy dollars to invest in American debt securities. Worldwide corporate demand for dollars was also said to be heavy. Central banks were trying to cap the rise because a stronger dollar hurts efforts to cut America's trade deficit. *

title: SUMMARY JUDGMENT
description: IN BROAD DAYLIGHT By Harry N. MacLean. 342 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95

title: Common Denominator Is Millions
description: If the nuns at Our Savior elementary school in the Bronx could see Sheelah Ryan now: being toasted with champagne on the deck of the yacht Trump Princess, talking about the hundred marriage proposals she has turned down, counting her millions.

title: Man Held in Student's Slaying
description: A Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday and charged in the inadvertent shooting death of an 18-year-old Brooklyn College student in a McDonald's restaurant in the Flatbush section, the police said. They said the gunman had been aiming at another person.
