title: Elizabeth C. Pille to Marry William Georges in April
description: Announcement has been made by Eugenie Compton French of Hamden, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Compton Pille, to William Theodore Georges, the son of Theodore William Georges of Colts Neck, N.J., and the late Rhoda Brounstein Georges. An April wedding is planned.

title: Seeking Facts On Back Pain
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: A SOVIET ODYSSEY. By Suzanne Rosenberg. (Oxford University, $19.95.) As a child in the Ukraine, Suzanne Rosenberg would be awakened by the gunfire of the Russian civil war. But she spent her formative teens in Montreal, where she was taken by her mother at the urging of their Canadian relatives. Consequently, when mother and daughter went back to the Soviet Union in 1931 to be at the forefront, as they saw it, of the struggle for a new world, she perceived the events that followed through an unusual double vision - as a Russian uplifted by the ideals of the Revolution and as a product of a Canadian education, with its bedrock of liberal beliefs. The result in ''A Soviet Odyssey'' is an extraordinary personal memoir of the Stalin years. What comes through in this harrowing account - Ms. Rosenberg, her mother and her stepfather were all sent to prison camps on trumped-up charges, and only she survived, to find her way back to Canada - is the sheer madness of the terror that Stalin loosed upon the land. It was as if one man's paranoia at the center of power brought out the sickies everywhere, and drove millions - needlessly, mindlessly, purposelessly - to their deaths.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: AIRLINE DEREGULATION;
Less Congestion Requires Higher Fees
description: LEAD: Public discontent with airline deregulation has grown so great that Congress is reportedly considering re-regulating the industry. Has airline deregulation created results that are socially desirable? Providing a definitive answer about the benefits and costs of deregulation is extremely difficult because the issue has become so poltically charged.

title: The Lost Voice
description: AT 6 O'CLOCK ON A FRIDAY night, Dr. Robert F. Ward waits for his last patient of the day. She rushes into his office at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, in Manhattan, and croaks a greeting. The patient is a singer who goes on stage in two hours - and she has laryngitis. Dr. Ward asks her to stick out her tongue; he grasps it with a piece of cotton gauze. Carefully, he guides a curved metal syringe down her throat, to just above her vocal cords. Watching with a mirror and a light strapped to his head, he places drops of the chemical epinephrine, the human hormone that charges up the body in the grip of trauma or excitement or fear, onto her inflamed, irritated vocal cords. She coughs, then thanks him - in a normal voice.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian and Americanized French Fare
description: LEAD: After the clamor and excess of the holidays, it's comforting to come across an intimate little restaurant serving pleasing dishes that don't also cost an arm and a leg.

title: Cartoon Museum Gets New Director
description: LEAD: BARBARA M. Hammond was the person Mort Walker wanted to be director of the Museum of Cartoon Art here.

title: Dr. Mark Lowitt Planning to Wed Dr. Nancy Ryan
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. William A. Ryan of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Dr. Nancy Lyn Ryan to Dr. Mark Harris Lowitt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Lowitt of Sarasota, Fla.

title: No Clues in African Jet Crash
description: A voice recorder salvaged from the Indian Ocean has failed to explain the cause of an airliner crash in which 160 people died, officials said today. The South African Airways Boeing 747 crashed en route to Johannesburg in November 1987.

title: Paige A. Gilbert Engaged To Wed Daniel Goldfarb
description: A June wedding is planned by Paige Alison Gilbert and Daniel Jon Goldfarb, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Gilbert of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Goldfarb is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin F. Goldfarb of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Hanoi Aide in Beijing; Cambodia Talks Seen
description: A high-ranking Vietnamese official arrived here tonight for talks apparently aimed at settling the conflict in Cambodia.

title: SUPER BOWL: Sports of The Times; Back to Miami 'Super' Theater
description: IN the days before Super Bowl V in Miami, Duane Thomas, then a rookie running back who had not yet decided to distance himself from the news media, was sitting on the grass at Fort Lauderdale Stadium where the Dallas Cowboys were practicing.

title: Rangers Come Back On 5 Goals
description: For the Rangers, silliness seemed the order of the day.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; D.M.B.&B. Purchase
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has acquired the Connecticut Consulting Group, a 10-year-old marketing planning and promotion services company in Wilton, Conn. Terms were not disclosed. D.M.B.& B. said it planned to merge the firm into Ted Colangelo Associates, its Greenwich, Conn.-based subsidiary specializing in marketing and corporate communications, including sales promotion, package design and direct marketing. The new company, which will have $120 million in billings and more than 100 employees, will operate under D.M.B.&B.'s Diversified Communications Companies division.

title: Myth of Amazon Rubber Seeds Debunked
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; The Classical, Back and (Next Time) Forth
description: The Classical Quartet, which generally plays music from the Mozart-Haydn era suggested by its name, is branching out somewhat this season. Saturday evening at St. Michael's Church (Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street), the group investigated Baroque territory already familiar to most period-instrument players - including, no doubt, this foursome, since all are active with other early-music ensembles. They will play Beethoven and Schubert in the same hall next Saturday.

title: Changes in Libya Embargo
description: The Reagan Administration is likely to allow five American oil companies to resume doing business in Libya, U.S. officials said. Page A7.

title: CFM Sells 49.5% Stake
description: CFM Associates, the limited partnership that publishes Corporate Finance magazine said last week that it had sold a 49.5 percent stake to Verlagsruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck G.m.b.H., one of West Germany's largest publishing companies. Terms were not disclosed. Holtzbrinck, based in Stuttgart, publishes Handelsblatt, a daily business newspaper, and Wertschaftswoche, a business weekly. In the United States, it owns Scientific American magazine and Henry Holt & Company.

title: A Latin AIDS Meeting Opens Its Ears to What Was Once Unmentionable
description: When experts gathered here recently for a widely publicized conference on AIDS in Latin America, they used words and notions about people's sex lives that must have startled the more conservative corners of the continent.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Key Goal Of Four A's: Friends
description: JOHN E. O'TOOLE'S office at the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York is a picture of calm. Only two weeks on the job, and already the paintings are hung and the thick stack of welcoming letters are out of sight and almost answered. The scene comforts, as might be expected from the copywriter who once wrote, ''To make sales, advertising has to make friends.''

title: Inmates Find Ways to Lock Anger Inside
description: For the last six weeks, 15 prison inmates have assembled daily in a classroom here to consider the harm they have caused others, including the strangers they have assaulted, robbed or raped and the family members they have abused, stigmatized or left abandoned.

title: SUPER BOWL: Rice Overcomes Pain; Bengals Turn Tables; Their Receivers Are Paid to Hit
description: ''IT'S amazing,'' said the hard-driving coach of the Bengals' receivers, Bruce Coslet, ''what a player will do for $5.''

title: Plessey Seeks to End G.E.C. Venture
description: Plessey P.L.C., a British electronics group, said today that it had begun efforts to win control of a $3.2 billion telecommunications unit it owns jointly with the General Electric Company of Britain.

title: Crime Victims Fought Back
description: Almost three-quarters of the victims of violent crimes who survived to tell about it say they made some effort to protect themselves, and most believe their resistance was worthwhile, a Federal survey shows.

title: Sylvia Meagher, 67, Former Health Official
description: Sylvia Meagher, a writer and retired senior liaison officer of the World Health Organization at the United Nations, died of complications from the flu Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Prague Police Crush Rally for a 1960's Martyr
description: Policemen used riot sticks, dogs and water cannon today to crush a rally commemorating the death 20 years ago of a student who set himself afire to protest the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

title: BOMB PLANT FLAWS KNOWN TO DU PONT AND U.S. FOR YEARS
description: Energy Department managers in South Carolina and the operator of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant there were intimately aware of critical structural flaws and deficiencies in management and maintenance years before three reactors were shut down for safety.

title: Snowboarding for Beginners
description: Lowell Hart, head of snowboarding instruction at Stowe, Vt., and Suzi Rueck, supervisor of snowboarding at Stratton, Vt., offer these suggestions for getting started.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone Produces 'Sunkist K.I.D.S.'
description: Sunkist Growers Inc. will next month introduce ads in Sports Illustrated for Kids magazine heralding its new television series for children on ESPN, ''The Sunkist K.I.D.S.'' Left unstated in the advertisements, which are scheduled to appear throughout 1989 in the new Time Inc. publication, is that they are by Foote, Cone & Belding. So is the production of the television show. So was the concept of honoring kids in the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl parade. So, indeed, was the very idea of linking Sunkist's orange products to children.

title: Brazil Acts To Fight Inflation
description: The Brazilian Government announced an indefinite freeze today on prices and wages and a devaluation of about 17 percent as part of a new anti-inflation plan.

title: Morris Klein Married To Naomi S. Freeman
description: Naomi Sue Freeman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Freeman of Millburn, N.J., and Morris Klein, the son of Mae Klein of Pittsburgh and the late Abraham Klein, were married yesterday at the Small Jewish Museum in Washington by Rabbi Max Ticktin.

title: Deep Cut Is Reported In Soviet-Cuba Trade
description: The Soviet Union reduced its trade with Cuba by 12 percent in the first quarter of 1988, according to documents of the Cuban National Bank made available here.

title: Reporter's Notebook; An Angler in Paradise, All That and No More
description: Fishing report, Friday, Jan. 13: The Vice President caught a 13-pound bonefish, using 8-pound line with spin-casting gear.

title: New Princeton/Newport Indictment Seen
description: Additional charges will be brought against the top officers of a defunct New Jersey investment partnership who were indicted last summer on charges of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy, lawyers in the case said yesterday.

title: The Royal Shakespeare Thinks Busy And Better
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company has announced plans for its biggest Shakespeare year ever, with a schedule that is to include productions of 14 of Shakespeare's plays and a new policy intended to attract more leading actors by offering shorter contracts.

title: Soviet Aide Ends Kabul Visit, Signaling Pullout By Feb. 15
description: As a two-day visit to Kabul by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, ended today, there were clear indications that all Soviet troops would be out of the country by Feb. 15 despite continuing fighting between guerrillas and Afghan Government forces around the capital.

title: Caesars Ruling for Trump
description: The Federal Trade Commission has given the developer Donald J. Trump permission to buy more shares of Caesars World Inc. stock.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Lowe Marschalk's Spot For Regina Vinegar
description: Skinny women waltzing down a fashion-show runway clad in lettuce and potato salad may not be the average viewer's idea of a classy commercial, but sophistication was what Lowe Marschalk had in mind when it created its first-ever television spot for Regina Wine Vinegar. Andrew Langer, the agency's creative director, said the model was its campaign for Grey Poupon mustard, like Regina, an RJR Nabisco brand.

title: SENATORS EXAMINE BAKER ON TUESDAY
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, meeting on Tuesday to consider the nomination of James A. Baker 3d as Secretary of State, is preparing an examination dominated by questions on changes under way in the Soviet Union, according to a committee briefing paper.

title: Research Hints at Link Between Patient's Attitude and Progress of AIDS
description: Tentative evidence suggests that the mental attitudes of AIDS patients may affect the progress of their disease, scientists from five research institutions reported today.

title: Boston Co. Net Is Overstated
description: The Boston Company's profits for the first three quarters of 1988 were overstated by $30 million, more than twice as high as preliminary estimates, officials with the investment firm said. Shearson Lehman Hutton

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Trotsky is no longer the evil spirit of Russian history. He's simply a political leader who held rather unacceptable views in many ways.'' - Adam B. Ulam, professor of government at Harvard, on emerging new views of Leon Trotsky. [ A3:4. ]

title: Perestroika Enters Finland, a Bit Bumpily
description: Perestroika has rippled through Finland, the Western nation with the longest and most extensive trading relationship with the Soviet Union, causing almost as much turmoil and uncertainty in board rooms and government offices as the restructuring has brought on the other side of the border.

title: New Yorkers Are Still Willing to Help the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Named by Texaco For Canadian Oil Unit
description: Philip J. Cram will be carrying the flag of Texaco Inc. in Canada after the oil company sells its 78 percent interest in Texaco Canada Inc.

title: Rights Advocate Maintains Police Beat Him in a 'Sting' He Arranged
description: A civil rights advocate, who arranged a sting operation to prove local police harass blacks, said today that an officer beat him and pushed his head through a window in a routine traffic stop.

title: Helping to Sell a Book by Its Cover
description: The cover conference at Berkley Books was under way for only a few minutes when someone raised the question: Should the cover on the paperback edition of the suspense novel ''Smoke and Mirrors'' actually depict a mirror?

title: James Davidson, 48, Founder of Bus Service
description: James A. Davidson, the founder and board chairman of the Hampton Jitney, a bus service between eastern Long Island and Manhattan, died of complications from AIDS yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and had homes in Water Mill, L.I., and Cocoanut Grove, Fla.

title: Miami Diagrams Its Big Play
description: SHORTLY after arriving in Miami this week, each of the 90,000 visitors expected for Super Bowl XXIII at Joe Robbie Stadium next Sunday will receive an original piece of artwork: the medium is crayon, the artists nearly 100,000 students in the Dade County elementary school system.

title: For Roundabout, Changes at the Top
description: The Roundabout Theater Company will announce today the appointment of Todd Haimes as its producing director, effective at the end of the 1989-90 season. Mr. Haimes, who is 32 years old, has been the company's managing director since 1983.

title: Plan to End Busing in Boston Runs Into Black Opposition
description: All four black members of the Boston School Committee oppose a plan to end 15 years of court-ordered school busing, saying the plan will not work unless the city commits more money to it.

title: Carol Levinson Is Bride Of H. Richmond Fisher
description: Carol Levinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Lowenthal of Phoenix, was married there yesterday to H. Richmond Fisher, a son of Ann T. Fisher of Marblehead, Mass., and the late Capt. Benjamin H. Fisher, U.S.N.R. Judge Alice Wright of the Phoenix Municipal Court performed the ceremony at the Phoenix Country Club.

title: Yonkers Blaze Kills 7 People Inside a House
description: Seven people were killed and eight others were injured here early today when a fire swept through a boarding house on the bluffs overlooking the Hudson River.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Phantom' Mini-Series For years, Arthur Kopit wanted to write a musical based on the Gaston Leroux novel ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' The playwright had even collaborated on an adaptation with Maury Yeston, a composer with whom he had created the Broadway musical ''Nine.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 15,1989: MONDAY Cent and South West Corp Republic Gypsum Co Southern Co TUESDAY Centerior Energy Corp Honeywell Inc ICM PPTY Invs Inc Security Pac Corp Smucker JM co Southern Ind Gas & Elec Co TECO Energy Inc WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Co Barnett Bks Inc Cincinnati Gas & Elec Co Clorox Co Columbia Gas Sys Inc Dun & Bradstreet Corp Gencorp Inc Midwest Energy Co Mortgage & Rlty TR St Joseph Lt & Pwr Co Texas Inds Inc Tokheim Corp WPL Hldgs Inc THURSDAY Automatic Data Process Bearings Inc Delaware Claire's Stores Inc First Wis Corp Lomas Finl Corp PPG Inds Inc Ralston Purina Co Standard Fed Bk Troy Mich >FRIDAY Aluminum Co Amer Communications Satellite Mellon Bk Corp Twin Disc Inc SUNDAY Williams Cos Inc

title: Shanghai Journal; At the Cutting Edge of China's New Journalism
description: In a country where the boundaries of debate are real but ill-defined, a weekly newspaper here is renowned as perhaps the best surveyor of the changing frontiers of intellectual tolerance in China today.

title: King William Journal; Last Stand Nears for Tiny Indian Tribe's Identity
description: For many tribal members, being a Pamunkey Indian these days is as much a state of mind as anything.

title: Man Sought in 7 Sex Attacks in Subways
description: A slightly built young man who apparently has detailed knowledge of New York City's subway system and its cars may be responsible for at least seven sexual attacks since September, the Transit Police said yesterday.

title: Sports World Specials; Dream Management
description: There have been fantasy camps where those who dream of playing major league baseball can rub elbows with real former major leaguers.

title: Poland's Party to Meet; Solidarity Will Be a Topic
description: The Polish Communist Party begins a two-day conference on Monday that may lead to renewed contacts between the Government and the banned Solidarity trade union.

title: Big East; Thompson's Protest Intensifies Debate
description: When Georgetown's coach, John Thompson, walked off the court Saturday night before a game with Boston College, he added another dimension to the increasingly complex debate over Proposal 42.

title: Diet Coke's Ad Gives Super Bowl a New Look
description: Introducing a new dimension to the cola wars, the Coca-Cola Company has been distributing 20 million 3-D glasses to retailers all over the country, including Walgreen, CVS and other chains in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: New Yorkers Are Still Willing to Help the Blind; Discrimination at State
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprise Star Among the Bells
description: At the time of the breakup of the Bell System, few would have picked Cincinnati Bell Inc. to emerge as a star performer. But it has done just that.

title: U.S. May Ease Curbs on Oil Companies in Libya
description: President Reagan is expected this week to lift some prohibitions on American oil companies doing business in Libya to prevent theirlosing their assets in the country, Administration officials said today.

title:
SUPER BOWL;
49ers Have More Weapons, but Must Stop Bengals' Runners
description: LEAD: THE Super Bowl result could be a blowout for San Francisco because the 49ers have more big-play players -Craig, Montana, Rice - on offense than Cincinnati does on defense.

title: Ski Wear Goes Solar
description: Solar energy is used to heat some houses, and now the same technology is being used to produce warmth in ski wear.

title: The New Trotsky: No Longer a Devil
description: As they continue exposing Stalin's repressions and trying to correct the many distortions of official history, historians and journalists here have begun to sketch a clearer picture of a complex figure whose role in setting up Soviet power was blotted out for 60 years: Leon Trotsky.

title: Edward Barber, 72, A Retired Executive of Steamship Lines
description: LEAD: Edward John (Ted) Barber, the retired chairman of Barber Steamship Lines Inc., died of an intestinal illness yesterday at Shand's Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in John's Island, Fla., and Quogue, L.I.

title: A Tough Sale for Knight-Ridder's TV Stations
description: Just a decade ago, media companies especially wanted to own network-affiliated television stations. The seemingly inevitable increases in advertiser spending, predictable cash flows and loyal audiences made owning a network affiliate a sure-fire investment.

title: A Day Off Is Not the Dream, Disciple of King Says
description: From a Manhattan pulpit where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. often preached his vision of a nation free of prejudice and violence, a disciple of the slain civil rights leader warned yesterday that the dream ''is at risk of being derailed'' by well-meaning but misguided people.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Earle Palmer Brown
description: The Earle Palmer Brown Companies of Bethesda, Md., has agreed to acquire Ensslin & Hall, an agency in Tampa, Fla., that has $20 million in billings and 27 employees. No terms were disclosed. The acquisition raises E.P.B.'s total billings past $300 million annually. Ensslin & Hall's major clients include GTE Mobilnet and The St. Petersburg Times.

title: COMPUTER DEPICTS THOUGHT PROCESS
description: Scientists at Johns Hopkins University, using electrodes connected to a monkey's brain, say they have produced a computer image of the brain as it thinks.

title: Nippon Phone Releasing Data
description: Japan's dominant phone company, under pressure from the Government, said Friday that it would disclose market information that would help its new long-distance competitors plan their strategies. The Nippon Telegraph and

title: Economic Collapse and Noriega Rule Producing Hopelessness in Panama
description: In a country whose bedrock was the unshakable conviction that tomorrow could only be better, hopelessness has grown until it now appears to define the national mood.

title: Sculptor and Patron Clash Over Piece
description: A sculpture depicting a contemporary creche of a homeless family huddled on a steam grate is the centerpiece of a legal battle over whether the creator or the patron of a commissioned work of art owns the copyright for it, and thus sometimes lucrative licensing and reproduction rights.

title: Robert Lekachman Is Dead at 68; Teacher and Writer of Economics
description: Robert Lekachman, a teacher of economics whose maverick views often set him apart from mainstream economists, died of cancer of the liver Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Dispute Over Building Ban City Council members challenged Mayor Koch's account of public disclosure of a change in a law that benefited a developer. Page B1. 7 Die in Yonkers Fire In the city's worst fire in years, seven people were killed and eight injured when flames swept through a boarding house. Page B1. The New Trotsky He has not been restored to official favor, but Leon Trotsky's reputation is benefiting from the Soviet leadership's anti-Stalin campaign. Page A3.

title: Chinese Prison Emphasizes Rehabilitation
description: To the Editor:

title: The Poor People's Campaign of 1989
description: ''Many white Americans of good will have never connected bigotry with economic exploitation. They have deplored prejudice but tolerated or ignored economic injustice. But the Negro knows that these two evils have a malignant kinship.''

title: Bengals Try A Different Approach DTLrrMIAMI, Jan. 15 -
description: Determined that the Bengals will neither wilt nor freeze up in Super Bowl XXIII, as their Bengal predecessors did seven years ago, Coach Sam Wyche put them through a 1-hour-45-minute practice in the 78-degree weather soon after they arrived today from Cincinnati.

title: Denver Program Curbs Teen-Agers' Pregnancy
description: Each week about a dozen teen-age girls, some with babies in their arms, come to La Mariposa Health Station here to pick up $7 each, a dollar a day for not becoming pregnant again.

title: Stop the Todeskramer
description: What did they know and when did they know it? This question about an official ''cover-up'' of illegal acts, familiar to America's Watergate fans, is now being asked by a belatedly aroused free press in West Germany.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Goya Foods Inc. to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, with a budget in the $3 million to $5 million range.

title: Six Traders Suspended
description: The Chicago Board of Trade has fined and suspended six traders linked to a scheme in which a colleague of theirs had donned a wig and used fake identification to gain access to privileged information.

title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets
description: LEAD: Minutes before the start of the New York Knicks game Saturday night, Alex Sumner stood outside Madison Square Garden, desperate.

title: Books of The Times; Shaping the Reality of AIDS Through Language
description: AIDS and Its Metaphors By Susan Sontag 95 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Downing the MIG's: A Pilot's View
description: LEAD: For some it's easy, reading the morning paper, to claim the Navy pilots who shot down the two Libyan MIG-23's were trigger-happy, that they should have held their fire until the Libyan pilots' motives were more apparent. It's easy, if you haven't the slightest familiarity with the realities of air-to-air combat.

title: ARAFAT'S FACTION IS SAID TO AVOID GUERRILLA ACTIONS
description: The army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Dan Shomron, has told a parliamentary committee that Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization has not planned or carried out any guerrilla acts in more than two months.

title: Miss Swartz, Lawyer, Weds Dr. Peter G. Hill
description: The wedding of Barbara Jill Swartz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Swartz of Teaneck, N.J., to Dr. Peter Gary Hill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hill of Rego Park, Queens, took place yesterday at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Bernard Cohen performed the ceremony.

title: Funds Are Lacking, Cancer Is Gaining
description: LEAD: The impressive gains made over the last few years in the battle against cancer are at risk. Simply put, there is not enough money to do the research work necessary to find the elusive cure.

title: Market Place; Broker's Big Role In Chase Medical
description: WHAT happens when more than 100 percent of the publicly owned shares of a company are held by customers of one brokerage house?

title: Complicated Task of Writing Blurbs
description: Paperback publishers rely heavily on freelancers to write the copy for the covers of paperback books. ''Some are aspiring writers, some moonlight while they work as editorial assistants in publishing houses, but some do it full time,'' said Natalee Rosenstein, the Berkley Publishing Group's executive copy chief, who herself started as a freelance copy writer.

title: Speech Teachers and Class in Basics Vanishing From Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Two players who have won five national titles between them, Warren Rosner and Ron Gerard of White Plains, captured the Superflighted Pairs title at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y., Saturday.

title: The Talk Of the Connecticut Legislature; A Dry Spell in Hartford Amid Tokens of Plenty
description: Officially, it's called ''The Travelator.'' Unofficially, it's ''The Ogle-eer,'' 250 feet of mechanized moving sidewalk named for a Connecticut state official, David B. Ogle, who envisioned legislators and lobbyists gliding smoothly through the newly expanded state-capitol complex and said, why not.

title: Review/Theater; Macho Memories
description: ''Guys like to fight - it's like petting but it's hard and very fast,'' observes John O'Keefe in ''Shimmer,'' a rivetingly kinetic solo performance piece in which he remembers his troubled adolescence in Iowa in the mid-1950's.

title: Koch Disputed On a Benefit To Developer
description: City Council members, civic leaders and lawyers who represent poor New Yorkers yesterday challenged the Koch administration's assertion that there had been public disclosure and debate over a change in city law that benefited the developer Harry Macklowe.

title: Article 657489 -- No Title
description: Most New Yorkers would not read the state budget if you paid them. But now the Cuomo administration wants interested citizens to buy the weighty volume, which runs about 700 pages, instead of receiving it free.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market. The regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, normally held on Mondays, will take place tomorrow. The Treasury cash market is closed today for the observance of Martin Luther King Day.

title: Sharpton and 5 Other People Arrested at a Sit-In in Hotel
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton and five other protesters were arrested last night after they staged a sit-in at the Helmsley Palace Hotel, a police spokesman said.

title: Chinese Prison Emphasizes Rehabilitation; Release Wei Jingsheng
description: To the Editor:

title: Major Hispanic Museum Lies Low and Likes It
description: In a city teeming with vibrant cultural institutions, the Hispanic Society of America has chosen to go its own anachronistic way. A magnificent cache of Spanish art and literature far from the busy museum-gallery scene of mid-Manhattan, it draws only 10,000 visitors a year, and its administration likes it that way.

title: Connecticut's Chickens, Home to Roost
description: Connecticut is looking for $882 million in state spending cuts and tax increases to close next year's prospective budget deficit. That's close to 15 percent of its budget - a big gap for any government. State officials like to blame the difficulty of predicting revenues, particularly in the wake of Federal tax reform. They would be more credible if they accepted some blame themselves.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Fonda Eases Up in Life and on Tape
description: LEAD: ''IN the old days I was very driven,''

title: Revere Copper Products
description: Revere Copper Products Inc. has been purchased by an internal management group led by M. Brian O'Shaughnessy, the company's president, in a $61 million transaction. The purchase includes the Rome plant, which employs 550 people, as well as Revere Copper Products' plant in New Bedford, Mass., where 180 people work, Mr. O'Shaughnessy said Friday. Mr. O'Shaughnessy's group bought the company from independent investors who owned about 75 percent of the concern. Mr. O'Shaughnessy already controlled 25 percent.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Leconte Is Upset: Hard-serving Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden upset sixth-seeded Henri Leconte of France, 6-4, 6-3, 6-2, Monday in the first round of the Australian Open at Melbourne. Gunnarsson needed only 87 minutes to eliminate Leconte from the first Grand Slam event of the year. Tobias Svantesson of Sweden took No. 1 Mats Wilander to five sets before losing, 6-3, 2-6, 7-5, 5-7, 6-3. (AP) Navratilova Triumphs: Winners of the $350,000 New South Wales Open at Sydney were Martina Navratilova, who defeated Catarina Linqvist of Sweden, 6-2, 6-4, and Aaron Krickstein, who beat Andrei Cherkosov of the Soviet Union, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) N.B.A. Bucks 120, Pistons 112: Terry Cummings scored 26 points as the host Milwaukee rallied with a 13-2 fourth-quarter run yesterday for its sixth consecutive victory.(AP) Bulls 110, Celtics 104: Michael Jordan scored 42 points as Chicago won its fourth consecutive game and Boston fell to 4-11 on the road.(AP) 76ers 116, Hornets 109: Charles Barkley scored 24 points, leading visiting Philadelphia over Charlotte.(AP) Lakers 116, Clippers 95: Byron Scott scored 28 points as the Lakers extended the Clippers' losing streak to nine games and ended a eight-game road losing streak. (AP) Mavericks 111, Trail Blazers 108: Derek Harper's steal and layup with 17 seconds remaining helped Dallas, playing at home, end a seven-game losing streak.(AP) Heat 118, Pacers 117: Rory Sparrow scored 20 points, including four foul shots in the final 19 seconds of double-overtime, and Miami (4-31), playing at home, rallied from a 29-point deficit to beat Indiana and end a 10-game losing streak. (AP) Horse Racing Wee Stark Wins by a Neck: Wee Stark, ridden by Richard Migliore, won by a neck in the $87,450 Montauk Stakes for New York-bred 3-year-olds at Aqueduct yesterday. Wee Stark went a mile and a sixteenth on the sloppy track in 1:45 3/5 to record his third victory in nine career starts. He earned $52,470 for James Riccio and returned $13.40, $6.80 and $4.60 for $2 across the board.(AP) Skiing Bittner Takes Slalom: Armin Bittner of West Germany won a men's slalom in Kitzbuehel, Austria, while Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg took the overall World Cup lead yesterday. Bittner upset Alberto Tomba of Italy with a total time of 1 minute 45.09 seconds. Girardelli completed a weekend in which he collected 82 points in four events and overtook Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland. (AP) Fifth Victory in Row for Schneider: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland won her fifth consecutive slalom race and posted her 10th victory of the season yesterday. Schneider, eighth after the first heat in Grindelwald, Switzerland, gained more than a second in the second heat and finished with a total time of 1 minute 22.87 seconds. Tamara McKinney of Squaw Valley, Calif., finished runner-up, with a total time of 1:23.75. (AP) Soccer Brazil 2, the Netherlands 1: Brazil beat the Netherlands yesterday to win the first FIFA indoor soccer championship, in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The United States finished third after defeating Belgium, 3-2, in overtime.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 4, Capitals 3: Glen Wesley scored his second goal of the game with 55 seconds left yesterday as Boston ended Washington's home unbeaten streak at 11 games. (AP) Red Wings 8, Flyers 4: Paul MacLean scored two goals and Steve Yzerman added a goal and three assists as Detroit snapped Philadelphia's eight-game home winning streak.(AP) Sabres 3, Flames 2: Jacques Cloutier made 36 saves, many of them spectacular, to lead Buffalo at home. The victory extended Buffalo's undefeated streak to four games.(AP)

title: French Leaders Act to Ease Damage of Insider Scandals
description: As a storm of insider trading allegations, some of them touching French Finance Ministry officials, continued to grow in intensity, President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Michel Rocard moved last week to try to contain the damage to their Government.

title: Trade Arbitration Plan
description: The European Community has given a cool response to a proposal made by a group of United States Congressmen to set up a bilateral panel to arbitrate trade disputes between the United States and the community. A spokesman for the European Community's External Relations Commissioner, Frans Andriessen, said Friday that the community was more interested in strengthening the procedures of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based international trade body.

title: Taking On the Slopes (Sideways)
description: TWO years ago, a skier riding sideways on a single, wide snub-nosed ski was a rare sight. Most conventional skiers dismissed it as a fad. Today, between 200,000 and 250,000 people are climbing onto snowboards and swiveling downhill, according to the North American Snowboard Association, the sport's governing body.

title: Truth About Auto Insurance
description: Like their counterparts in California, New Jersey drivers are fed up with soaring auto insurance bills and won't let state officials rest until they've done something about it. Even so, Governor Kean's latest proposal to placate angry drivers is a non-starter, at best puckish and at worst irresponsible.

title: Outdoors: Pursuit of Cottontail Leads to Lessons of Childhood
description: THE cottontail rabbit is the most sought-after small-game animal in this country.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None

title: Steve Jones Wins Playoff With a Birdie
description: Steve Jones, given a reprieve when Paul Azinger bogeyed the final hole, sank a 4-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole today to win the 30th annual Bob Hope-Chrysler Classic and remain the only winner on the 1989 PGA Tour. This victory in a three-way playoff against Azinger and the Scot, Sandy Lyle, came a week after Jones won the MONY Tournament of Champions at La Costa Country Club in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: Metro Matters; A Little Tin Box With Feerick As Its Pandora
description: Q. Whereabouts at home in the house did you keep this money that you had saved? A. In the safe. Q. But a little box in a big safe? A. In a big box in a big safe.

title: Indications Look Better for Bonds
description: Credit market conditions could well stabilize or perhaps even improve a bit more during the next few weeks, buttressed by strong technical factors and interest rates that hover close to or above 9 percent across the maturity spectrum.

title: Seoul Planning '89 Surplus Cut
description: South Korea plans to cut its trade surplus with the United States by $2 billion in 1989 to help ease pressure from Washington to revalue the won, economic planning officials said last week.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has an athlete ever played in both the World Series and the Super Bowl during his career?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; A Season the Networks Would Rather Not Repeat
description: FIVE months after Hollywood returned to work at the end of a paralyzing strike against producers by the Writers Guild of America, the three networks are assessing the costs and the consequences of the strike - particularly its impact on viewer habits and on revenue.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 'Kids of Summer'
description: Looking beyond the cold winter days toward June are Good Housekeeping and Sesame Street Magazine's ''Parents Guide.'' Together, they are preparing a special section called ''Kids of Summer,'' a 48-page section scheduled to appear in both magazines in June. The YMCA plans to distribute some 250,000 reprints of the issue to its 1,200 branches across the nation. Half of the publication will be made up of stories on summertime activities and safety; the other half will be ads - but not for ''violent toys'' or ''heavily-sugared'' food products. The sponsors project an audience of more than 25 million.

title: Shifts Studied For Financial Regulators
description: The Treasury Department is considering whether to abolish the Federal Home Loan Bank Board as part of a sweeping overhaul of financial services regulation in the Bush administration, a top banking regulator said last week.

title: NatWest Halting Role In Treasury Securities
description: A United States subsidiary of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. will end operations as a primary dealer of United States Treasury securities, the bank announced Friday, a little more than three months after the unit had gained approval to be a dealer from the Federal Reserve Board.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Report

title: Tax Watch; Asbestos Work: Deductible or Not?
description: IN the next few years American businesses will face significant costs for removing asbestos from plants and office buildings, and a key question will be whether those costs can be treated like repairs and deducted for tax purposes immediately or whether they must be capitalized.

title:
SUPER BOWL;
For Cincinnati, It All Starts With That Huge Offensive Line
description: LEAD: WHEN you look at the Cincinnati Bengals, the first thing that jumps out at you is the offensive line. As I told our players, it's like facing the Great Wall of China.

title: Sports World Specials; Grateful on the Bench
description: Sometimes David King catches himself sulking on the end of the Boston University bench. Those are the times King reminds himself just how good he has it. Those are the times King remembers that he's young, he's a member of a major college basketball team and he's receiving a free college education.

title: Award to Architects
description: Cesar Pelli & Associates, a Connecticut architectural firm, is to receive the 1989 Architectural Firm Award from the American Institute of Architects in May at its National Convention in St. Louis, the institute has announced. The award is given annually to a firm that ''has consistently produced distinguished architecture for at least 10 years.''

title: Angst and Anger in Bonn; U.S. Disclosures on Libyan Chemical Plant Raise Hackles and Questions About NATO
description: In the two weeks since West German companies were accused of helping to outfit a suspect chemical plant in Libya, West German officials have gone from a petulant defensiveness to the surprising admission that they knew all about it long before the Americans told them of their concerns.

title: Soviet Militiamen Are Posing As Afghans, Insurgents Say
description: Guerrilla organizations fighting the Kabul Government say that Moscow has sent Soviet militiamen with Afghan identity cards into several Afghan provinces recently.

title: Neediest-Cases Donors Say Gifts Are Late but Still Timely
description: With the Christmas rush over, Alfred Chappy Morris of Manhattan sent his annual contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, saying, ''I know it is never too late to help those in need.'' He donated $250.

title: SUPER BOWL: Rice Overcomes Pain; Bengals Turn Tables
description: THREE months later, the reminders are still being transmitted from Jerry Rice's left ankle. Rice's season goes on, longer than any of his three previous years with the San Francisco 49ers. His contribution has met the personal standards that his record-setting 1987 season established.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; An Everyday Exercise In Remaining Young
description: THE distance down Highway 513 from Joe Lizzi's driveway to the crossroads at the United Methodist Church and back in this tiny community in rural Hunterdon County is 4.6 miles. Lizzi, who is 60 years old, has measured it carefully.

title: New Yorkers Are Still Willing to Help the Blind; Worse in London
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Says Ending Abortion Will Mean U.S. Is 'Civilized'
description: President Reagan said in a television interview broadcast today that he does not believe the United States will be ''completely civilized'' until it stops abortion.

title: In New York, Parents Lack Say in Schools
description: When New York City's elementary and junior high schools were given greater autonomy 19 years ago, parents were supposed to gain direct control over their children's schooling through the local school boards that took over much of the central administration's responsibility.

title: Study Faults New York City's Public-School Health Project for Adolescents
description: A four-year-old Health Department program to provide adolescents in New York City public schools with medical counseling and referrals to doctors is plagued with staff shortages and other problems and should be refocused into schools of greatest need, a private study has found.

title: The Biggest Wheel
description: In Milltown, N.J., in 1940, Edward W. Bradley was chosen by his eighth-grade teacher to deliver Special Delivery letters around town for the local postmaster. The only requirements were to get a bicycle and to report to the Post Office every morning at 6:30 sharp. Mr. Bradley recalled delivering hundreds of letters, receiving about 8 cents for each of them.

title: A Nation Kicks a Habit
description: The 1989 Surgeon General's report calls it ''phenomenal,'' and it surely is. Nearly half of all living adults who ever smoked have quit. In doing so they have kicked a habit responsible for more than one out of every six American deaths. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop warns, however, that progress has to continue and accelerate or the health impact of smoking will remain into the 21st century.

title: Bush Enlists Economic Agnostics Who Share Belief in What Works
description: President-elect George Bush's economic policy appointees are ideological agnostics who call themselves results-oriented, and they are. But Mr. Bush has yet to present them with a detailed map for reaching his goal of budget reduction and continued prosperity.

title: Review/Television; 'Big Bird in Japan'
description: Looking for new programming directions, the Children's Television Workshop has fallen back once more on the good graces of Big Bird. Several years ago there was the special called ''Big Bird in China,'' produced, directed and written by Jon Stone. Tonight at 8 on Channel 21 and tomorrow at 7 P.M. on Channel 13 there is ''Big Bird in Japan,'' written and directed by Mr. Stone and produced by Sonia Rosario. The underwriters are the Sony Corporation and the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association. There is more than one way, obviously, to skin a public-television budget.

title: Cathay's Fate Is Tied to Hong Kong
description: Decades ago this crossroads in the Orient made a fortune for a handful of shipowners. Now Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. is betting billions of dollars in new planes that the territory will do the same for an airline.

title: On Dr. King's Birthday: One Nation, Divisible
description: LEAD: In death, as in life, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has been plastered over thickly with labels: Christian martyr, dreamer, Communist, the black Moses, De Lawd, national hero, womanizer and saint, among others. A multiplicity of names carries great meaning.

title: Reviews/Music; New Piano Music and Old
description: Although Sarah Rothenberg's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night was a conscious effort to blend new music with old, attention and curiosity turned naturally to the former. Bruce Adolphe's ''. . . And Time Future Contained in Time Past . . .'' is a piece made whole by its scrupulous and intelligent economy. Recurrent ideas - above all a three-note repetition - form both satisfying resting places and interesting points of departure. Mr. Adolphe's piece also continues a current obsession among American composers with titles containing dots.

title: Review/Television; AIDS and Hemophilia
description: Once again prime-time television entertainment is approaching the subject of AIDS through the case of a hemophiliac youth infected through a transfusion of tainted blood. The vast majority of AIDS patients are homosexuals and drug addicts, but television apparently is not ready to explore these groups with any degree of compassion. Innocent youngsters trapped by circumstances beyond their control provide far easier dramatic hooks for uplift exercises.

title: Lincoln Upset by Hayes
description: Cardinal Hayes High School of the Bronx upset Lincoln of Brooklyn yesterday, 77-75, in the second game of the Martin Luther King Classic at St. Francis College in Brooklyn. Lincoln's defeat was its first of the season by a New York City school.

title: Micheline Keating, Novelist, 85
description: Micheline Keating, a novelist and reporter, died Friday in a nursing home in Tucson, Ariz. She was believed to be about 85 years old.

title: College Basketball; Pitt Overpowers Oklahoma
description: Maybe Pitt should stick with top 10 opponents. Just ask the Oklahoma coach, Billy Tubbs.

title: At Least 70 Die as 2 Trains Collide in Bangladesh
description: An express train carrying pilgrims to a Muslim festival crashed head-on into a mail train near here today, killing at least 110 people in Bangladesh's worst railroad accident, officials said.

title: At the Top: Economic Policy
description: ALAN GREENSPAN: Chairman, Federal Reserve Board Could be the spoiler . . . A solid Republican with ties to Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker going back to the Ford Administration when Mr. Greenspan was the President's resident economist . . . 62 years old . . . Born and reared in New York . . . Graduated from New York University with highest honors . . . Ran economic consulting firm in New York . . . Headed commission that overhauled Social Security system in 1983 . . . Former professional jazz clarinetist . . . all work at Fed, lunching at desk while scanning data to detect inflation. CARLA A. HILLS: U.S. Trade Representative From wealthy California building supply family . . . 55 years old . . . Graduate of Stanford and Yale Law, where she was 12th in a class of 167 . . . Has a bad knee at moment, but in an administration of strong tennis players, the former West Coast Women's Collegiate champion could be seeded No. 1 . . . Practiced antitrust law in Los Angeles and Washington . . . Links with the Bush-Baker team date to jobs as an assistant Attorney General and as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in Ford Administration. NICHOLAS F. BRADY: Secretary of the Treasury Treasury Secretary since August 1988 . . . Very wealthy, from inheritances and earnings as chairman of Dillon Read investment banking firm . . . Sold the firm in 1986 for $157 million . . . Friendship with Mr. Bush dates to childhood summers in Kennebunkport . . . Worked for Mr. Bush in unsuccessful 1980 campaign for Republican nomination . . . 58 years old . . . Attended Yale and Harvard Business School . . . Filled unexpired Senate term in 1982, representing New Jersey . . . Led study of October 1987 stock market collapse. RICHARD G. DARMAN: Budget Director Mentors were Elliot Richardson and James A. Baker 3d . . . Fled to research outfit when Mr. Nixon dismissed Mr. Richardson during Watergate scandals . . . 45 years old . . . Reared in Woonsocket, R.I., and Boston suburbs . . . Scion of textile family . . . Graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Business School . . . White House legislative strategist in first Reagan term, Deputy Treasury Secretary in second . . . Prickly and thin-skinned sometimes, self-deprecating and whimsical at others . . . Writes own, often pun-larded speeches. MICHAEL J. BOSKIN: Chief Economic Adviser 43 years old . . . Born in New York City, raised in Los Angeles in family of modest circumstances . . . Went to University of California at Berkeley, receiving three degrees and awards as top economics student . . . Rose through ranks at Stanford economics department to professorship 11 years ago . . . Became leading expert on national debt and Social Security . . . Another diehard tennis player . . . Works out with Stanford varsity . . . Mild-mannered, even-tempered, new to political gamesmanship . . . Moderate conservative. CHARLES H. DALLARA: Asst. Secy. for Int'l. Affairs A key member of second-tier network that gets things done . . . 40 years old . . . Joined Treasury at age 28 in the Ford Administration . . . Spotted and promoted by James A. Baker 3d . . . Later, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady made him a point man on major issues . . . Graduated from the University of South Carolina and has three degrees from the Fletcher School of diplomacy at Tufts . . . Served as officer in the Navy . . . Married, two children . . .Since 1988, Assistant Secretary for policy development.

title: Knicks Get Set For Road
description: During a wait at an airport earlier this season, Rick Pitino got into a discussion over whether the Knicks might win 50 games this season, a number that appears within their reach.

title: Markets Open Today
description: Banks and Government offices will be closed Monday to observe Martin Luther King Day. The stock markets will be open, and there will be foreign exchange trading.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Jan Bell Marketing Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a supplier of jewelry and other products to wholesale membership clubs and other retailers, named Lee A. Mills to the newly established post of executive vice president-corporate planning and general counsel.

title: 15,000 Foes of Sandinistas March in Nicaragua
description: A crowd of 15,000 chanting, cheering protesters marched through Managua today to dramatize their grievances against the Nicaraguan Government in the broadest collection of opposition groups since the Sandinista Front took power in 1979.

title: Tired of Cooling Their Heels, the Republicans Turn Up the Heat
description: After 34 years out of power, a stint of minority status unbroken since cars had fins, Republicans in the House of Representatives have had it. In the face of a muscular Democratic majority of 259-to-174, signs of a new Republican scrappiness abound.

title: Review/Dance; Woetzel and Hlinka in a Balanchine Pas de Deux
description: The New York City Ballet is offering a cascade of debuts this season. On Saturday afternoon, Damian Woetzel, one of the company's most promising young male dancers, was seen for the first time in George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux'' at the New York State Theater.

title: Sports World Specials; Can't Count on Figures
description: The man who compiled these statistics doesn't put much faith in his own figures. But for the record, attendance at college football games declined a bit last season, providing further evidence that the proliferation of televised games may be keeping some fans at home on fall Saturdays.

title: Retail Group Loses Leader
description: Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company, abruptly resigned last week as chairman of the National Retail Merchants Association just before the group began its annual convention in New York.

title: Reviews/Music; Aki Takahashi, Pianist
description: Composers of the world seem to have found each other in the last generation, and their elaborate efforts to homogenize once-distant cultures, to find meeting grounds for once-irreconcilable music styles, are ending up in programs like Aki Takahashi's piano recital at the Asia Society late Saturday afternoon.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Casino as a Movie Setting and Metaphor
description: Casinos are delivering payoffs in three recent buddy movies. In ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' Michael Caine and Steve Martin compete for the fortune of a reputed soap heiress, Glenne Headly, at a Riviera roulette table. In ''Things Change,'' Joe Mantegna, a Mafia underling, takes Don Ameche on an outing to Atlantic City, where the old fellow is allowed to make a seeming killing before the mob boss decides to really kill him. And in ''Rain Man,'' Tom Cruise wins a bundle in Las Vegas with the help of the computerlike memory of his brother, an autistic whiz played by Dustin Hoffman.

title: Opera Plan Falls Apart in France With Dismissal of Artistic Director
description: One of the most ambitious postwar plans for opera on an international level has exploded with the ouster of Daniel Barenboim as artistic director of the new Bastille Opera of Paris.

title: Turkish Economy at a Turning Point
description: As 1988 drew to a close, Turkey's Prime Minister Turgut Ozal received an unusual, and unwelcome, package in the mail: Five men from the western city of Denizli had sent him the belts to their trousers.

title: New Specialist Sees A Big Board Openness
description: A subsidiary of the ABD Securities Corporation has become a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange - a rarity for a foreign-owned firm.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Yasir Arafat's wing of the P.L.O. has not planned or carried out any guerrilla acts in more than two months, the Israeli Army Chief of Staff has disclosed, drawing criticism from Prime Minister Shamir. Page A1

title: Martin Luther King Day
description: NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections. No street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed.

title: Burke and Devils Blank Oilers
description: With Sean Burke playing brilliantly in goal, the Devils handed the Edmonton Oilers a 1-0 defeat today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Reagan Raising a Possibility Of Pardoning Patricia Hearst
description: President Reagan raised the possibility today that before he leaves office Friday he would pardon Patricia Hearst Shaw, the newspaper heir, for her conviction in a 1974 bank robbery.

title: Work Station Market To Get Its First Clones
description: A Colorado start-up company backed by a Japanese electronics giant will introduce on Monday a line of computers it says is fully compatible with a popular work station sold by Sun Microsystems Inc., the leader in the engineering work station business.

title: Engine Fire Forces Jet to Land
description: An American Airlines jet bound for Dallas with 91 people aboard returned to Baltimore-Washington International Airport shortly after takeoff today when an engine caught fire. An airline spokeswoman said a part on the left engine of the McDonnell-Douglas MD80, Flight 201, apparently came loose and a compressor stalled, prompting the pilot to shut the engine. The cause of the fire was not known, she said.

title: A Minority of None
description: For most of the last eight years, said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, ''there has been no bipartisanship'' in any area of foreign policy from strategic planning to state dinners. He said ''Democrats are almost never invited'' to the dinners, ''which was not the case in the past.''

title: Cuomo May Juggle Auto Fees to Aid Budget
description: To raise quick cash to pare the state's budget deficit, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to propose that some motorists be required this year to register their automobiles for two years rather than one.

title: Optek Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $150,893 and $360,433 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $207,000 and $518,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company noted that the 1988 fourth quarter is the first full quarter of combined operations since the acquisition of TRW Inc.'s Optoelectronics division in July.

title: Hunt Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Britain Agrees to Review the Case Of 4 Convicted of Bombings in '75
description: The Court of Appeal will review the case of four accused guerrillas who were convicted in 1975 of the bombings of English bars, the British Government announced today. Seven people were killed in the bombings.

title: First Indiana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mayfair Super Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
New York Police Checking For Lieutenants' Test Fraud
description: The New York City Police Department is investigating allegations of impropriety and cheating by a small number of officers during a recent examination for promotion to lieutenant, police spokesmen said yesterday.

title: Scientific Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss Latest-quarter share earnings are less than 1 cent a share.

title: Dow Falls by 1.43 Amid Sluggish Trading
description: LEAD: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday in thin trading resulting from the closing of the credit markets and many banks for Martin Luther King Day. Several takeover situations, however, enlivened Wall Street.

title: American Medical Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $33,900,000 charge for the repurchase of debt, and a $50,700,000 gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. Year-ago first quarter included operations for 36 hospitals sold to Epic Healthcare on Sept. 30, 1988. The company said the latest first quarter's pre-tax income included $13 million in additional malpractice insurance provisions and $11 million in lease buyout costs.

title: Schulman, A Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Science Watch: Group Sets Up Pension For 'Retired' Chimps
description: A BIOMEDICAL foundation in San Antonio has established a pension plan for chimpanzees infected with the AIDS and hepatitis viruses so the animals can ''retire'' once their usefulness in research experiments is over.

title: First Team Sports reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Fries Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
An Ad Guy. Did a Book. Hard-Boiled
description: HE was sitting in a corner of a Second Avenue seafood joint with a red no-smoking sign hanging behind the nape of his neck. His name was Patterson - James Patterson. He wrote ads. Worked for a guy named Thompson. He said he'd written a book.

title: 'The Pulse' of the 49ers' Defense
description: The permanently furrowed brow and the infrequent smiles provide signs that being the keeper of the standard is no simple job. In Ronnie Lott's early years as a defensive back for the San Francisco 49ers, the more ambitious expectations of the organization were being put in place and the most important responsibilities belonged to others.

title: Here's to Haggis, but Only for Scots
description: THE British Medical Journal, a weekly publication famous for its science but little known for whimsy, has broken new ground in both fields.

title: Jackson and the Garden Are Too Much for Spurs
description: After yet another victory at home, the Knicks now take to the road, where few National Basketball Association teams win conistently.

title: Burlington Northern Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $44,417,000 and $57,048,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a charge of $108,500,000 from the settlement of an antitrust litigation for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Included net from discontinued operations of $63,317,000 for the quarter and $231,200,000 for the year. The company said results for Burlington Resources Inc., which was spun off on Dec. 31, 1988, are reported as discontinued operations. The 1988 amount included a $43 million industrial land sale to Glacier Park Co., a subsidiary of the company's former Burlington Resources Inc. subsidiary.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Zander Pulls Off Upset: Richard Zander, an American-born West German who almost quit last year because of a back injury, upset the Soviet favorite, Aleksandr Fadeev, to win the men's compulsories at the European championships yesterday in Birmingham, England. Zander, who was born in Portland, Ore., and grew up in Los Angeles, gained top marks in both figures with a superb display of technical skating and swept into the lead on the first day of the tournament. Fadeev, aiming for his fourth European title in nine years, was in second place after the second of the compulsory exercises, which count for 20 percent of the total score.(AP) N.H.L. Maple Leafs 5, Whalers 3: Rick Lanz scored his first goal of the season midway through the second period to help Toronto win at home last night. The Whalers had rallied to 3-2 in the second period on a pair of power-play goals 34 seconds apart by Kevin Dineen when Lanz scored the game-winner at 9 minutes 19 seconds on a slapshot from the top of the left faceoff circle. (AP) Blackhawks 2, Oilers 2: Craig MacTavish's goal with 49 seconds left in the third period gave struggling Edmonton a tie in Chicago. MacTavish's 11th goal came after goalie Ed Belfour had stopped Jimmy Carson's 10-foot blast. The Oilers had pulled their goalie, Grant Fuhr, with 1:13 left in regulation for the extra skater. In the overtime period, Chicago's Steve Larmer put the puck in the net with 1:25 left but the play was ruled off sides.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Tennessee 79, Mississippi State 54: Bridgette Gordon scored 19 points and grabbed 13 rebounds to lift the Tennessee Lady Vols to victory last night. Tennessee improved to 14-1 over all and 2-1 in the Southeastern Conference while Mississippi State is 8-9 and 0-2. The Vols received a boost from Sheila Frost's 17 points. Top scorers for Mississippi State were Shirley Walker and Sophie Ratliff with 14 points each.(AP) Georgia 96, Clemson 75: Stacey Ford scored 17 points to lead five players in double figures as Georgia overpowered Clemson last night in Athens, Ga. The Lady Bulldogs (14-2) led, 55-30, at halftime. Tammye Jenkins added 15 points for the winners; Adrienne Shuler scored 14, Sherelle Warren 13 and Kim Berry 12. Michelle Bryant led Clemson (8-6) with 16 points.(AP) Maryland 84, Wake Forest 68: Vicky Bullett scored 25 points as Maryland rallied for an Atlantic Coast Conference victory. Bullett scored 10 points in a six-minute span as the Terrapins came back from a 43-34 deficit to take a 54-46 lead with 12 minutes left. Deanna Tate added 17 points for the Terrapins, 11-2 and 3-1 in the A.C.C. Alice Neal scored 13 points to lead Wake Forest (11-5, 2-2).(AP) SQUASH Sanchez Wins at Greenwich: Mario Sanchez of Mexico City, captured the $20,000 Rolex Greenwich Open Men's Championship yesterday, defeating Kenton Jernigan of Cambridge, Mass., 15-12, 15-12, 15-14, at the Field Club in Greenwich, Conn. In the $3,500 Women's Final, Demer Holleran of Princeton, N.J., defeated Karen Kelso of Denver, 15-10, 15-10, 15-6.

title: Diners Stabbed, Waiter Held
description: A waiter angered by the small tip left by two customers was arrested after he allegedly attacked them with a knife, the police said today. Guang Da Shen,19 years old, of Brooklyn, was charged with two-counts of assault after the incident Saturday night outside the Dragon House Restaurant. Louis Pabian, 59, of Trumbull, was stabbed in the abdomen, and his son, Neil, 24, of Bridgeport, was cut in the hand, They had left a $2 or $3 tip on a bill of less than $50, the police said.

title: Investments By Taiwan
description: Businessmen from Taiwan more than doubled their investments overseas in 1988, to a record $219 million from $103 million in 1987, the Investment Commission said today.

title: Dow's Rise Draws Small Buyers
description: LEAD: Some of the small investors who went into hibernation after the stock market crash in October 1987 may be stirring in the heat of a new year's rally on Wall Street.

title: Northeast Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included tax credits of $3,644,000 for the quarter and $8,395,000 for the 9 months. The latest third quarter included a one-time charge of $4.6 million from a provision reflecting the decline in the present value of expected future cash flows of certain collateralized mortgage obligation residuals. The per share earnings are after preferred dividend payments.

title: Saudis Block Idi Amin's Return
description: Idi Amin, the deposed Ugandan dictator, is unwelcome at his home-in-exile in Saudi Arabia, Arab diplomats said today.

title: Bank Chief to Leave South Africa, Joining Growing Flight of Liberals
description: The chief executive of South Africa's largest commercial bank has decided to leave the country for a post in Europe, the bank announced today.

title: Associated Natural Gas Corp reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: The company went public on Sept. 29, 1988.

title: Germantown Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transition Watch; Lee Atwater And His Orchestra
description: A highlight of the inaugural festivities is a lineup of rhythm and blues stars Saturday night at Constitution Hall in a rocking concert that the new President and his family plan to attend.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The Soviet Union's grain harvest fell 40 million tons short of the 235-million-ton target, a Soviet official said. That would be the worst harvest in three years and a bit less than had been anticipated. [ Page A1. ] Grain and soybean prices plunged, despite the news from Moscow and U.S. reports of sharply lower harvests. [ D15. ] The chief executive of South Africa's largest commercial bank decided to leave for a post in Europe. Christopher J. W. Ball, managing director of First National Bank, is one of the country's most prominent liberal business executives. He joins a growing group of executives who have left the country. [ A1. ] India will lease civilian airliners from Moscow and may buy some as well, moving away from its dependence on Western aircraft manufacturers. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Coastal is seeking to acquire Texas Eastern, a leading Northeastern supplier, in a cash tender offer of $42 a share, or about $2.6 billion. Coastal owns the nation's third-largest natural gas pipeline; its offer reflects the scramble to obtain pipeline capacity in the Northeast. [ D1. ] Grand Met put its team in place at Burger King, naming Barry J. Gibbons chief executive and Ian A. Martin chairman. [ D1. ] More banking companies reported sharp improvements in earnings, in part a reflection of two years of overdue interest payments that were finally received from Brazil. [ D4. ] National Semiconductor will cut its work force by 5 percent, eliminating about 2,000 jobs worldwide. [ D5. ] Shamrock Holdings agreed to buy Sound Warehouse for $25.65 a share, or $132.5 million. [ D4. ] Damon agreed to be acquired by Nomad Partners in a deal valued at more than $250 million. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY A top regulator of the Texas insurance industry resigned, saying the state kowtowed to insurance companies. The state Attorney General warned that insurers could face a rash of failures similar to those of banks and savings institutions in Texas. [ D1. ] Predictions that 1989 will bring improved apparel sales but a slowdown in big-ticket durable goods opened the convention of the National Retail Merchants Association. [ D5. ] MARKETS The dollar rose sharply in Europe and held its gains in light holiday trading in New York. The strong demand for the dollar carried over from last week. [ D14. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose marginally in light trading in Europe. [ D13. ] Stock prices closed mixed in thin trading resulting from the closing of the credit markets and many banks for Martin Luther King Day. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at 2,224.64, off 1.43 points. [ D6. ] Prices of oil futures surged to their highest levels since November 1987, bolstered by market speculation that OPEC would be able to keep a cap on its output. [ D14. ] Trading in Chase Medical Group shares was suspended by the S.E.C. amid a widening investigation into how customers of one brokerage came to control the public float in the stock. [ D3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Michael Peters is making U.S. acquisitions. His company believes design is an international language. Talking Business. [ D2. ] It makes no sense that the Super Bowl should be used as a market forecaster, but it is. Market Place. [ D6. ] James Patterson, writer of a hard-boiled mystery, is chairman of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: TRey Wilson, 40, Dies; A Stage and Film Actor
description: Trey Wilson, a stage and film actor, died yesterday at New York Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 40 years old and lived in New York.

title: Reviews/Music: Paying Tribute to Dr. King
description: Two anniversaries coincided on Sunday - Elie Siegmeister's 80th birthday and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s 60th.

title: Times Machinists Threaten Strike
description: Nearly two years after its contract expired, a union representing 72 machinists at The New York Times said yesterday that it would strike the newspaper on Friday unless a new labor agreement was reached by then.

title: At the Top: Foreign Policy
description: ROBERT M. GATES: Deputy National Security Adviser A 45-year-old Kansan who has spent two decades at Central Intelligence Agency, where he is deputy director . . . Georgetown University Ph.D. in Russian and Soviet history . . . Served at National Security Council . . . At C.I.A., did not have a direct hand in covert operations or clandestine intelligence-gathering . . . Lost chance to be Director of Central Intelligence when President Reagan withdrew nomination rather than face contentious confirmation hearings over what he knew about role of William J. Casey in Iran-contra affair. LAWRENCE S. EAGLEBURGER: Deputy Sec'y of State A 58-year-old Washington insider who graduated from the University of Wisconsin, with bachelor's and master's degrees . . . Served in the Army . . . Spent 27 years in foreign service, culminating in senior jobs at the State Department, Pentagon and the National Security Council . . . Also was Ambassador to Yugoslavia during the Carter Administration . . . In recent years, worked as president of Kissinger Associates Inc. with his close associate in government, Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State. BRENT SCOWCROFT: National Security Adviser A West Point graduate who holds a doctorate from Columbia in international relations . . . Born in Utah 63 years ago . . . A retired Air Force lieutenant general . . . A former Russian history professor at West Point . . . Served as military attache in Yugoslavia . . . A trusted aide in Henry A. Kissinger's National Security Council . . . Was national security adviser to President Ford . . . A member of the Presidential commission that investigated the Iran-contra affair . . . Vice chairman of Kissinger Associates since 1982. JAMES A. BAKER 3d: Secretary of State A 58-year-old Texan who is heir to a family fortune dating to the 1860's . . . Classics major at Princeton who took law degree at University of Texas . . . Ex-marine . . . Entered politics in 1970 by working for the Senate campaign of George Bush . . . Opposed nomination of Ronald Reagan while serving as Gerald Ford's campaign manager in 1976 and as Mr. Bush's campaign manager in 1980 . . . First exposure to foreign leaders came as Mr. Reagan's chief of staff . . . At Treasury, formulated plan to relieve third-world debt crisis. >WILLIAM H. WEBSTER: Director of Central Intelligence A Federal judge in Missouri who came to Washington in 1978 . . . Degrees from Amherst College and Washington University Law School in his native St. Louis . . . Prospered in Missouri legal circuits . . . Became Federal judge . . . Picked by President Carter as Director of Federal Bureau of Investigation, where he helped restore its damaged reputation . . . Took top C.I.A. job in 1987 during Iran-contra affair . . . Survived lobbying of President-elect George Bush by some agency veterans to have him replaced . . . 64 years old. JOHN G. TOWER: Secretary of Defense Born 63 years ago in Houston . . . Graduate of Southwestern University in Georgetown, Tex., with master's degree from Southern Methodist University . . . Served in Navy in World War II . . . Assistant professor of political science at Midwestern State University in Texas . . . Ran unsuccessfully for Senate against Lyndon B. Johnson in 1960 . . . Ran again and won, becoming first Republican Senator from Texas since Reconstruction . . . Chairman of Senate Armed Services Committee, later a strategic arms negotiator.

title: U.S. Issues Rise in Light European Trading
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose marginally in very light trading in Europe yesterday.

title: Octel Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $599,000 and $840,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: National City Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods included loan loss provisions that reduced net income for the quarter by $35.7 million, or 59 cents per share, and by $76.1 million, or $1.25 per share, for the year.

title: In Chemical Maker's Town, Germans Silently Disbelieve
description: Even in its hometown of Lahr, Imhausen-Chemie was hardly a household name before Jan. 1, when the company was publicly accused of having helped Libya build a poison-gas plant.

title: Transition Watch; Added Starter: Jesse Jackson
description: The Bush transition headquarters received an unexpected phone call yesterday morning. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who had not spoken too kindly of Mr. Bush in the Presidential campaign, said he was planning to come to the inauguration. It was, Mr. Jackson said, not a Republican event but an event for the republic.

title: Ford Plant Switch
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would switch production of its Sierra model from Britain to Belgium as part of its strategy to prepare for a single European market at the end of 1992. The gradual production switch is likely to eliminate 500 jobs in Britain and create 2,000 jobs in Belgium, Ford said. It said it would eliminate the jobs through attrition.

title: Claims From Fires In Yellowstone Area Total $1.1 Million
description: Damage claims totaling $1.1 million have been filed against the Federal Government as a result of the fires in Yellowstone National Park and surrounding forests last summer, United States Forest Service officials say.

title: National Micronetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: b-After tax benefits of $228,000 for the quarter and $560,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after a gain of $31,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months; the quarter also included a tax loss of $53,000.

title: Castle Energy reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,672,319 from a bank debt settlement.

title: Global Warming: Experts Ponder Bewildering Feedback Effects
description: Scientists studying the greenhouse effect are struggling to understand a host of bewildering interactions among air, water and plants that could hasten the potentially disastrous global warming, postpone its effects or, they worry, produce unexpected, rapid change in the Earth's climate.

title: Slamming The Door
