description: No doubt some sports fans will condemn John Thompson, Georgetown University's basketball coach, for walking out of a game to protest a new rule that slams the door on college opportunity for underprivileged athletes.

title: Meese Is Reportedly Denounced In Report by Justice Department
description: The Justice Department has written a stinging report concluding that Edwin Meese 3d engaged in ''conduct which should not be tolerated of any Government employee, especially not the Attorney General,'' according to The Washington Post.

title: Mitsubishi Metal
description: The Mitsubishi Metal Corporation said it would build a $250 million copper smelter in Texas City. The plant will employ about 250 people and generate an estimated $5 million annual payroll, the company said. The plant is expected to be in full operation in 1991 and will produce about 150,000 metric tons of copper a year.

title: Sandy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and after a $17,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Cancer Fears Throw Spotlight on Estrogen
description: THE more researchers study estrogen, the female sex hormone, the more they find themselves dancing around points and counterpoints.

title: CK Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company's quarterly earnings reflected its purchase of First State Savings and Loan Association of Gastonia, S.C. on Oct. 31, 1988 and the two months' operation of the consolidated companies.

title: Texcel International reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The fiscal 1988 loss is after a gain of $435,691 on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Independent Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRC Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jordan Gets Honor
description: For leading the Chicago Bulls to victories and averaging 39 points, Michael Jordan was named as N.B.A. Player of the Week yesterday.(AP)

title: Broader CBS Ad Campaign
description: Languishing in third place among the television networks, CBS is about to send its advertising to a new frontier: consumer magazines. Next month the network begins ''program specific'' advertising in New York magazine, Vanity Fair, Esquire, New York Woman and L.A. Style, as well as in several advertising and broadcast trade journals.

title: Cable Company Drops CVN Bid
description: Tele-Communications Inc., one of the nation's largest cable-television concerns, said it had withdrawn its offer to buy the CVN Companies for $14 a share in cash and a $4 note. The offer, made in November, had been valued at about $313 million. Tele-Communications, based in Denver, said it had withdrawn the offer because CVN's stock price on Friday, $18.50 a share, exceeded its bid. After the announcement, CVN's stock fell in over-the-counter trading by $2.875, or 15.5 percent, to $15.625.

title: FEWER BLACK MEN ON U.S. CAMPUSES
description: In the last decade, the number of black men enrolled in higher education has declined, even though the overall minority presence in the college population has increased, says a study by the American Council on Higher Education.

title: Congressmen Urge Bush to Delay Sales of California Water Rights
description: A bipartisan group of Congressmen is urging President-elect George Bush to delay an Interior Department sale of water rights in California because the department had declined to analyze the environmental consequences.

title: Nigeria Opens To Investment
description: Wide areas of Nigeria's manufacturing industry are being opened to full foreign ownership, the nation's President, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, announced this weekend. The country's Enterprises

title: Managua Journal; As Sandinistas' Old Foe Exits, New Ones Line Up
description: Having survived the contra insurgency and outlasted President Reagan, a powerful enemy, the Sandinista leaders of Nicaragua find themselves facing adversaries perhaps even more formidable.

title: Atlantic Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter's share earnings is less than one cent a share.

title: Johnson Products reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $606,000 for the latest quarter and $15,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FASHION: By Design; Looking Ahead: Post-Red
description: Chartreuse may have been the shade of the season last spring, but red is certainly this winter's bell ringer. Red hats, scarves, sweaters, suits, coats are seen scurrying about Manhattan.

title: Sexual Response Is Studied in Rats
description: SEXUAL climax in both male and female laboratory rats can be produced by stimulation of a particular area of the urethra, scientists at Northwestern University Medical School have discovered.

title: Books of The Times: Chess and the Future Overlay the Fate of a Nation
description: Hence By Brad Leithauser 320 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. In Brad Leithauser's ambitious new novel, the year is 1993 and Americans are suffering from ''millennial neuroses.'' Trends already in evidence in our own day have accelerated. Changes in the weather heighten everyone's worst environmental fears, and the nation's desperate craving for some kind of order or faith is exploited by evangelists who preach apocalyptic doctrines of blood and sacrifice on television. Small towns have fallen on hard times as industry and jobs have fled, giant conglomerates now control everything from research centers to hotels, and everywhere technology is threatening to overwhelm the accomplishments of man.

title: Thompson Says He Might Persist in Boycott
description: John Thompson, the head basketball coach at Georgetown University, said yesterday that he might continue his boycott of National Collegiate Athletic Association-santioned games until ''something concrete'' is done to reverse a recently passed N.C.A.A. action that he feels negatively affects black athletes.

title: Rangers Hit the Road Fueled by Big Rally
description: The locker room felt electrically charged, although the sensation had nothing to do with the television wires and radio microphones that snaked across the floor.

title: Dollar Up Steeply in Europe; Trading Light in New York
description: The dollar rose sharply in Europe yesterday and held its gains in light holiday trading in New York.

title: Wall to Wall Sound & Video Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and included for the 9 months a gain of $712,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: At This School A Commitment To a City's Poor
description: There aren't many Catholics at St. Patrick Catholic Elementary School. ''More Baptists than anything else,'' said Sister Maeve McDermott, the principal. All 500 children are black; 80 are Catholic.

title: Troops in West Bank Kill Teen-Age Arab; A Gaza Youth Dies
description: A Palestinian teen-ager was shot to death by Israeli soldiers in the occupied West Bank today, while another Arab youth died of gunshot wounds sustained in a demonstration in the Gaza Strip this week, Palestinians and the army said.

title: New York City Can Do Better Than Spend on Political Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynicism and Mistrust Tied to Early Death
description: Angry, cynical people are five times as likely to die under 50 as people who are calm and trusting, a psychiatrist has found.

title: Man Pushed Through Glass Alleges Police Racism
description: A black civil rights advocate charged today that a police officer who pushed him through a store window in a weekend incident broadcast on national television used violence as a first resort and without justification.

title: Review/Dance: Variety in Womanworks
description: The third program of the current Womanworks dance festival at the Joyce Theater is a mixed bag. Nonetheless, Beverly Blossom, Maedee Dupres and the entry billed as Annabelle Gamson/Dance Solos in one fell swoop offer the wild swings of humor and vision that single-troupe performances rarely provide.

title: Imperial Judges? No, Decent Prisons
description: For two decades and more, state prison systems have been under siege. Overcrowded and underfunded, they have bulged with inmates whose only schooling has been in further violence and crime. The failure to provide humane and safe custody for inmates has, in turn, provoked the wrath of the Federal courts and, in some cases, actual judicial supervision.

title: Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $326,500.

title: NEW WIRE FAULTS FOUND ON 2 JETS
description: Two more Boeing 757 jetliners have been found with crossed wires leading to cargo hold fire extinguishers, bringing to five the number of planes found with wiring problems since compulsory checks began on Friday, The Times of London reported today.

title: Westin Hotels President Begins Expansion Plan
description: In September, Lawrence B. Magnan, who had been at Westin Hotels and Resorts for 23 years and was a prime candidate for the president post, was ''disappointed'' when an outsider was hired instead. But late last week, Mr. Magnan, who is 44, was named president after the newcomer, Helmut Hoermann, resigned abruptly, citing personal reasons.

title: Experimental Technology 'Maps' Joints for Surgical Precision
description: EMPLOYING technology similar to that used for creating topographical maps of the earth's surface, a researcher has developed a new way of examining the internal functions of human joints such as the knee, shoulder and wrist.

title: Quirk of Geography Turns Town to Homeless Capital
description: First there was the village of Elmsford, circa 1910. Then came the highways, three of them, criss-crossing its single square mile. Then they built the motels, five of them, providing roadside rest for the weary traveler.

title: Central & South West Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and year included non-recurring positive items. Earnings for the latest quarter were lower because of the cost of starting up the South Texas project without deferred accounting treatment or increased rates.

title: U.N. Council Agrees to Cut Namibia Peace Force
description: The Security Council agreed in principle today to cut the size and cost of the peacekeeping force it will send to Namibia this spring to oversee preparations for the territory's independence. But diplomats cautioned that it was unclear whether the vote had really ended a three-week dispute between the five permanent members of the Council and third world nations.

title: International Minerals & Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax income from discontinued operations of $8.4 million, or 35 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. c-Included tax credits of $9.4 million for the quarter and $17.9 million for the 6 months. This year's results reflected approximately 38 percent ownership of IMC Fertilizer Group Inc., compared with 100 percent ownership last year.

title: Reagan Cites Regret on Regan
description: President Reagan wanted his former chief of staff Donald T. Regan out of the White House for some time before Mr. Regan was ousted, Mr. Reagan said tonight in a nationally broadcast interview.

title: Punishment for Plane Bomb Is Necessary
description: To the Editor:

title: Damon Agrees To Nomad Bid
description: The Damon Corporation ended its seven-month struggle for independence today and agreed to be acquired by Nomad Partners L.P. in a deal valuing the chemical laboratory company at more than $250 million. Under the agreement, Damon's shareholders will receive $26 a share in cash and 50 percent of the proceeds from the sale of Damon's 61 percent stake in Damon Biotech Inc.

title: Fifth Third Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Commerce Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Insurance Plan For Nissan Dealers
description: The Nissan Motor Company's American subsidiary said it would help to finance an insurance company to be owned and operated by its dealers, the first such arrangement in the auto industry.

title: Spreadsheet Rivalry Heats Up
description: Personal computer users, get ready for the spreadsheet wars.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Conservative Edge
description: Conservatives may purport to hate government, but conservative political appointees in the Reagan Administration are being advised how to become permanent Federal employees as the Bush administration prepares to take office.

title: Some Burmese Student Protesters Disappear While in Army Custody
description: Some student demonstrators have disappeared or died in custody since the Burmese Army suppressed demonstrations for democracy on Sept. 18, while the army has forced thousands of people to serve as porters and ''human minesweepers'' in battles against ethnic insurgents, diplomats and Burmese say.

title: Computer Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Illinois Central Stake Is Acquired
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said it had bought an 8 percent stake in the Illinois Central Transportation Company, a major rail hauler of grain between Chicago and the Gulf of Mexico. Archer, a grain processor based in Decatur, Ill., said its stake was an investment, not a takeover move.

title: George J. Aspland, 73, Ex-Judge in New York
description: George J. Aspland, a Suffolk County prosecutor who became a State Supreme Court justice, died after a heart attack on Sunday at his retirement home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and also had a home in Babylon, L.I.

title: Champion Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
INSIDE
description: India's Russian Planes India is leasing civilian airliners from the Soviet Union in a move away from its reliance on Western manufacturers. Page D1. Protecting the Protected Most New York communities do not have the wherewithal to assure the safety of victims of domestic violence, experts say. Page B1. High-Level Korean Meeting North Korea accepted South Korea's plan for a meeting of Prime Ministers, the highest level of contacts since the Korean War. Page A3. Tactics in the Poverty War The head of public housing in Omaha wins praise for efforts to get children to school and, eventually, to get people out of public housing. Page A20.

title: Chase Medical Trading Is Suspended by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in the shares of Chase Medical Group Inc. yesterday amid a widening investigation into how customers of one brokerage firm came to control more than 100 percent of the public float in the stock.

title: Bangladesh Toll Rises to 135
description: The official death toll from Bangladesh's worst train disaster rose to 135 today. More than 1,000 people were injured when two crowded trains crashed head-on Sudnay at Pubail, 15 miles from Dhaka.

title: Israel Sets Demands on Taba
description: Israel's inner Cabinet agreed today to demand free access for Israelis to the Taba Red Sea resort and joint ownership of a hotel complex there in exchange for returning the disputed area to Egypt, Cabinet officials said. Israeli, Egyptian and American negotiators will meet Thursday at the luxury hotel at the center of the seven-year border dispute.

title: Letter Indicates More Links Between Gas-Plant Builders
description: Der Spiegel, the West German news magazine, published a letter today that established further links between Imhausen-Chemie, the company accused of involvement in construction of a suspect Libyan chemical plant, and I.B.I. Engineering, the principal contractor for the plant.

title: General Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Sea to Sea, North and South, King Is Honored
description: From Brooklyn, where Mayor Edward I. Koch recalled how he went to Mississippi in 1964 as a young lawyer defending civil rights workers, to Los Angeles, where golfers teed off in a tournament benefiting the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, Americans honored the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. yesterday.

title: Bank of Granite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.O.P. ROLE GROWS IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Liston B. Ramsey, a New Deal Democrat from deep in the Appalachian Mountains, accumulated political power the old-fashioned way, but has lost it in the state's new two-party politics.

title: In Heartbeat, Predictability Is Worse Than Chaos
description: A perfectly regular heartbeat is more likely to presage sudden death than good health, scientists reported at a symposium here.

title: Marcos in Honolulu Hospital
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former President of the Philippines, was in guarded condition with pneumonia after entering St. Francis Medical Center for the third time in little more than a month, a hospital spokeswoman said. Mr. Marcos, 71 years old, who is also suffering from bronchial asthma, returned to the hospital yesterday afternoon, said a nursing supervisor, Cindy Miller.

title: Banctec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $711,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Brazil Warns About Debt
description: Finance Minister Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega said today that Brazil might again suspend interest payments on its foreign debt if its foreign reserves fell to a critical level.

title: Bhutto Faces New Election Test in 2 Key Regions
description: With a tumultuous national election only two months behind her, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is facing another round of voting on Jan. 28 that will test her party's strength in the country's most important province, Punjab.

title: 'Smokeless' Tobacco Linked to Oral Lesions
description: Nearly half of a group of professional baseball players who used snuff or chewing tobacco regularly had lesions in their mouths, researchers said today.

title: Carson of Jets Among Coaching Candidates for Browns
description: Bud Carson, the Jets' defensive coordinator, emerged today as one of four finalists for the Cleveland Browns' head-coaching job.

title: Shamrock to Acquire Sound Warehouse
description: In a move to expand its foothold in the fast-growing music and video retail business, Shamrock Holdings Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Dallas-based Sound Warehouse Inc. for $25.65 a share, or $132.5 million.

title: Cuomo Delays Esplanade Plan For the Hudson
description: Citing delays by New York City, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today suspended planning on an esplanade to run along the old West Side Highway, but said that planning on the replacement road would continue.

title: Paine Webber's London Curbs
description: Paine Webber Inc. said today that it was pulling out of the Eurobond business and that 22 London traders would lose their jobs.

title: Cellcom Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $371,086 from discontinued operations.

title: South Carolina National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transition Watch; . . And Now, in the Other League . . . Transition Watch
description: The Democrats acknowledge that they're down, but not out.

title: Coastal Bid For Texas Eastern
description: The Coastal Corporation, a Houston-based energy company that owns the nation's third-largest natural gas pipeline, said today that it was seeking to acquire the Texas Eastern Corporation, a leading Northeastern supplier, in a cash tender offer worth $42 a share, or about $2.6 billion.

title: First Union Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: First Union said its loan loss provision for 1988 was $61 million, a decrease of $21 million for the 1987 amount. The 1987 total included a $25 million provision for Latin American exposure. First Union eliminated all Latin American loan exposure in the first quarter of 1988.

title: Cubans May Stay in Canada
description: A Cuban who unwittingly deported himself and his family from the United States on a sightseeing trip nearly a month ago said today that the family may be forced to seek refugee status in Canada.

title: First Federal of Western Pennsylvania reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year per share earnings was not available because the company converted to stock form in mid- 1987.

title: FASHION: Patterns; Risks and Hard Work
description: Pacing the new optimistic mood in the fashion industry is the Limited, a trendy specialty retailer that has reported solid sales increases since November. After a dismal period, from the end of 1987 through fall 1988, when sales were sluggish and earnings were down for three consecutive quarters, the company reported reassuring sales gains of 14 percent in November and 28 percent in December. For the first quarter of 1988, Wall Street analysts are forecasting a 90 percent rise in the publicly traded company's earnings per share. How did they do it?

title: A Killing Silence in the Sudan
description: Don't make waves, say State Department officials when asked about a horrifying famine that last year claimed as many as a quarter-million lives in the southern Sudan. Making a fuss, they say, will only undercut an elected, moderate, useful regime in Khartoum. Trust us, they add, to send the right stern signal to the Moslem-led Government in the North beset by a rebellion in the non-Moslem South.

title: Weldotron reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Careers; Improving Morale of Employees
description: COMMUNICATING with employees is becoming important to top management, says Kathryn L. Troy, a senior research associate who wrote a report published this week by the Conference Board.

title: Jersey in Uproar Over Fees at Counties' Garbage Transfer Stations
description: One year after New Jersey closed two regional landfills and forced six counties to ship their garbage out of state, disposal costs have doubled and tripled, and charges of price gouging, windfall profits and illegal monopolies are flying.

title: Lendl Rolls in First Round of the Australian Open
description: Second-seeded Ivan Lendl, playing against an outclassed opponent, overpowered Alexander Mronz of West Germany, 6-0, 6-1, 6-3, today in the first round of the Australian Open championships.

title: Scientists Pursuing Idea Of Tritium Accelerator
description: More than half a century after a particle accelerator was used to discover tritium, scientists met in New Mexico today trying to prove that a much larger accelerator could affordably provide the gas in amounts needed for nuclear warheads.

title: International Research & Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in September 1988.

title: Northern Telecom Selects a New Chief
description: Paul G. Stern, former president of the Unisys Corporation, will join Northern Telecom Ltd. as vice chairman and chief executive on March 1, the company announced yesterday.

title: Automatic Data Processing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sterling A. Brown, 87, Poet and Educator, is Dead
description: Sterling A. Brown, a poet and former professor of literature who helped to establish Afro-American literary criticism and who taught many of the nation's black scholars and writers, died of leukemia on Jan. 13 at the Heritage Health Care Center in Takoma Park, Md. He was 87 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Private Brands reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
The Pill: What's a Woman to Do?
description: American women fear breast cancer, and with reason: one in ten can expect to get it someday, and it will kill 30 percent of those that do. Now comes evidence that using birth control pills might increase the risk. What's a woman to do?

title: Jonesport Journal; On a Lobster Tie Line to the Nation
description: While fishermen in hip boots drag crates of lobsters out of an icy bay in this eastern Maine town on the Atlantic, slickly produced advertisements are beamed by satellite to hundreds of cable television stations, promising that the lobsters will arrive, alive, anywhere in the country in 24 hours.

title: Hornets Win as Tripucka Scores 40
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 40 points, including 9 in overtime today, as the Charlotte Hornets beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 127-122, to snap an 11-game road losing streak.

title: CPAC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
134 Request Arbitration
description: Some of the highest-priced names in baseball - led by Orel Hershiser, Dwight Gooden, Roger Clemens and Jose Canseco - were among the 134 players who filed letters for salary arbitration by the noon deadline yesterday.

title: New National Coach
description: The United States Soccer Federation yesterday announced the appointment of a full-time coach for the national team. He is Bob Gansler, a staff coach with the federation since 1975 and the head coach soccer coach at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee since 1984. Gansler replaces Lothar Osiander, who had coached the United States national team on a part-time basis since 1986, including in the 1988 Olympics. Gansler, who had been the coach of the national under-20 team, will assume his new duties this month.(AP)

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Matter of Continuity
description: Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci, along with other Cabinet officers of the Reagan Administration, will leave office Friday, not on Feb. 1 as Mr. Carlucci had previously said. Deputy Secretary William Howard Taft 4th will become Acting Secretary until the new Secretary is sworn in.

title: Personnel Moves At Bozell, Jacobs
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt made several significant personnel moves yesterday, naming Gary Davis president and chief operating officer at Poppe Tyson, its $95 million business-to-business subsidiary, and appointing Josephine A. Cummings executive vice president and executive creative director of its Chicago office.

title: First Wachovia Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income for year-ago periods was reduced by $18.2 million, or 33 cents a share, in the quarter, because of a special after-tax loan loss provision, and $38.2 million, or 70 cents a share, in the year, because of the special loan loss provision, net of an $8.9 million equity security gain. The company said its provision for loan losses in the latest periods were $16.3 million for the quarter and $61.3 million for the year, compared with same year-ago periods of $49.7 million and $149.6 million, respectively.

title: Chess
description: The Belgrade International Open Tournament, sponsored by the Grandmasters Association and Yugoslav Airlines, ended in a six-way tie for first place on Dec. 13. Five Soviets, the grandmasters Mikhail Gurevich, Lev Psakhis, Evgeny Pigusov and Lev Polugayevsky and the international master Igor Naumkin, and the Yugoslav grandmaster Krunoslav Hulak all scored 7-2 and were awarded an $8,833 share each of the prize fund.

title: International Dairy Queen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Chase Manhattan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter and full year earnings included $217 million after taxes of cash collections of interest payments received on medium- and long-term cross-border extensions of credit to borrowers in Brazil, of which $35 million and $117 million, both after taxes, were applicable to the quarter and full year, respectively, and $30 million and $100 million, both after taxes, were applicable to the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. Partially offsetting the impact of these interest payments was the placement in non-accrual status, beginning in the third quarter of 1988, of certain loans to borrowers in Argentina, which reduced latest quarter earnings by $13 million after taxes and $31 million after taxes for the year. Chase incurred a $40 million after- tax restructuring charge in the latest quarter and the utilization of $60 million of available income tax benefits. The net for 1988 also included an after-tax gain of $103 million from a modification of the company's major pension plan and the purchase of annuity contracts substantially in settlement of Chase's pension plan obligation; a $61 million after-tax gain from the sale of Interactive Data Corp., a former unit; a $59 million after-tax gain from the sale of a Paris branch office building and the use of $215 million of income tax benefits and the previously mentioned United Kingdom restructuring charge. The results for the year-ago quarter included a $39 million after-tax gain from the sale of real estate in Japan. The 1987 year included a $1.6 billion special addition to the reserve for possible credit losses related to refinancing countries; the utilization of $150 million in income tax benefits; an $88 million after-tax pension plan settlement gain; a $39 million after-tax gain from the sale of reale estate in Japan; a $9 million after-tax gain from the sales of a subsidiary in the Netherlands and a minority interest in an affiliate in Belgium, and a special network restructuring charge of $33 million after taxes.

title: Candor Is Seen as Best Weapon to Disarm Critics
description: On the afternoon of the day that two United States Navy F-14's shot down a pair of Libyan fighters over the Mediterranean, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr. called in his top aides to assess the situation, including the publicity surrounding the episode.

title: Afrikaner Paper Urges Talks With Mandela
description: South Africa's major Afrikaans-language daily newspaper, Beeld, called on the Government today to hold talks with the outlawed African National Congress, the main exiled guerrilla group fighting to end white rule.

title: McDonnell Order
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said China Eastern Airlines had agreed to buy five MD-11 jetliners in an order valued at more than $500 million. The MD-11 is a long-range, wide-bodied jet that is slightly smaller than the jumbo Boeing 747. Its main competitor is the Airbus A340, produced by the European consortium Airbus Industrie. Neither Airbus nor McDonnell Douglas have their planes in service yet.

title: KEY RATES
Six in OPEC Have 70% of Oil
description: Six members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries now have 70.5 percent of the world's proven oil reserves, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: Bush Says the Dream of Dr. King Will Be a Vision for His Tenure
description: Signaling a greater responsiveness to black Americans than many blacks perceived in the Reagan Administration, George Bush said today that he would make it his mission as President to aggressively pursue Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream of equality.

title: Texas Insurance Regulator Quits, Calling System Lax
description: A high-ranking regulator of the Texas insurance industry says he will resign because the state continues to be ineffective in disciplining a growing number of troubled companies.

title: In Bonn, Echoes of Kaiser Wilhelm
description: West German intelligence knew about the ''Libyan connection'' as early as 1987 and told Bonn so repeatedly. Presumably, President Reagan and the Secretary of State, George P. Shultz, tried to be good allies when they discreetly informed the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl; the point was not to compromise the Federal Republic but to allow Mr. Kohl to move against Imhausen-Chemie and other poison-gas mongers on his own.

title: Seton Hall Uses Defense to Thwart Villanova
description: Villanova played its third consecutive Big East game on the road tonight, and looked like a team in need of a rest. The only problem for the Wildcats was that their rest seemed to start before their game against Seton Hall ended.

title: Langer Biomechanics Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A Clash Erupts Between Scientific Subculture
description: THIS fall, in what has become a case study in the sociology of science, William A. Goddard 3d, a chemist at the California Institute of Technology predicted that the new copper oxide superconductors would never work at room temperature. With astonishing precision, he calculated that the highest possible threshold temperature was 54.7 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Bryn Mawr Bank Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Flowers Industries reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 17
description: b-Included a gain of $1,757,000 from a change in tax accounting.

title: Funny Meant Money at the Movies in 1988
description: Comedy was king in 1988, winning the top six places at the United States and Canadian box offices in a record-breaking year for Hollywood. Since nobody wants to break up a winning hand, the movies scheduled for this year will be heavy on comedy as well.

title: Belgian-Zairian Links Eroding
description: Relations between Belgium and Zaire, its former colony, have fallen to a new low with Zaire's announcement last weekend that the African country was scrapping cooperation agreements and suspending payments on the part of its $7 billion debt owed in Belgium.

title: S.I. Tech Plays Host to Soviets
description: Students at Staten Island Technical High School, where Russian is the only - and, thus, required - foreign language, are being given an unusual chance to practice their language skills. Their classmates for the next month will include visiting Soviet students.

title: The Doctor's World: Many, Like Reagan, Find Bent Finger a Bother
description: DUPUYTREN'S contracture, the deforming hand ailment for which President Reagan had surgery a little more than a week ago, is a common inherited condition that tends to be more nuisance than painful.

title: Shigeharu Matsumoto, Japanese Internationalist, 89
description: Shigeharu Matsumoto, a founder of the International House of Japan, died of a stroke last Tuesday in Tokyo, where he lived. He was 89 years old.

title: Key Tronic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 17
35 Nations Issue East-West Accord Assuring a Broad Range of Rights
description: Thirty-five nations today made public a new East-West agreement that includes commitments for the protection of human rights, including freedom of association, religion, travel and emigration.

title: Standard Shares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Learonal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Shelton Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Home Intensive Care reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Share earnings results have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1987.

title: Hoechst Celanese
description: The Hoechst Celanese Corporation, the American subsidiary of Hoechst A.G. of West Germany, said it would offer to acquire all the shares of Celanese Canada Inc. that it does not own in a deal valued at $210 million (Canadian), or about $175 million (United States). Hoechst Celanese owns about 56.2 percent of Celanese Canada and is offering to buy each of the remaining shares for $35 (Canadian), or about $29 (United States).

title: Personal Computers: New Fax Machines: Getting More for Less
description: THE fax (short for facsimile) allows users to send and receive exact copies of documents anywhere in the world, or just across town, in minutes for much less than the cost of overnight mail.

title: A.T.&T. Is Quiet On G.E.C. Reports
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which will hold its regularly scheduled board meeting tomorrow, declined to comment yesterday on widespread reports that it might join the Plessey Company in a hostile takeover bid for the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain. The Financial Times reported that A.T.&T. was expected to confirm its participation in a bid for G.E.C. this week after weekend negotiations with the British investment firm of Lazard Brothers.

title: UST Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Science Watch: Tank-Destroying Robot
description: Researchers at the Sandia National Laboratories have developed a robot that, under remote control, can spot and destroy enemy vehicles, including tanks. But in doing so, it destroys itself.

title: Electrosound Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $351,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and included a gain of $193,000 from a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $252,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month periods included a charge of $4,384,000, for the company's remaining investment in Memory-Tech, its compact disk joint venture with Mitsubishi Corp., based on the company's decision to dispose of its interest.

title: Market Place; Predicting Victor In the Super Bowl
description: IT makes sense that changes in the discount rate should affect the stock market, and it is widely believed on Wall Street that they do. It makes no sense that the result of the Super Bowl should be useful as a market forecaster, but it too is widely followed.

title: First Chicago Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and were due to additional reserve action related to troubled country debtors.

title: Yonkers Fire Toll at 8; Violations Found
description: The death toll from the city's worst fire in 23 years rose to eight today, and the city's Fire Commissioner said the building where it occurred Sunday had been illegally converted into a rooming house and was in violation of the fire code.

title: Ex-Ulster Policeman Killed
description: Two gunmen killed a former reserve policeman with Northern Ireland's Royal Ulster Constabulary, the police said today. Harry Keyes, 25 years old, was shot Sunday evening as he was backing out of the driveway of a friend's house in Ballintra in western Ireland, they said.

title: A Real Estate Primer
description: LEAD: Looking for your ''starter home'' in the current impenetrable housing market?

title: TV Festival Beginning
description: The New York World Television Festival begins today at the Museum of Broadcasting with a drama inspired by the fiction of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel laureate, and it ends next month with a 20th-anniversary salute to ''Monty Python's Flying Circus.'' Just what kind of a festival is this anyway?

title: Todd-AO Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Alexander Hahn Postwar Investigator, 92
description: Alexander Hahn, who headed a mission after World War II that sought to locate and return Hungarian property taken by the Nazis, died of arterial sclerosis on Dec. 29 at the Forest Hills Nursing Home in Queens. He was 92 years old.

title: Pennview Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its first quarter income decrease was primarily due to an accounting change which resulted in the deferral of $85,000 of loan fee income.

title: Burlington Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net for 1988 is after a net charge of $143 million relating to the company's natural gas properties. The company said there are no common share earnings for the 1987 periods because Burlington Resources did not become a public company until July 7, 1988.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax gains from the disposition of assets of $1.9 million and $3.3 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago results are pro forma because the company went public in February 1988.

title: Upon the Aral Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: LSB Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cotto in Accord
description: The Seattle Mariners reached agreement on a contract for the coming season with Henry Cotto, the outfielder, bringing their number of signed contracts to six. Cotto, 28, hit .259 with 8 home runs, 33 runs batted in and 27 stolen bases in 133 games for Seattle. . . . The California Angels signed Bill Schroeder, a catcher, and Tony Armas, an oufielder, for 1989. Schroeder, acquired from Milwaukee during the off season, signed for $375,000, a slight raise of his 1988 salary. Armas signed for $425,000, the same amount he earned last year, after he had filed for arbitration earlier in the day.(AP)

title: Search for a Nugget
description: The Denver Nuggets, third in the National Basketball Association's Midwest Divison, are considering a trade for an aggressive forward, Pete Babcock, president of the team, said yesterday. He said repeated injuries had created the ''most unstable situation'' he has encountered during a 14-year career in the National Basketball Association, the last four years with the Nuggets. At various times this season, the Denver injury list has included Fat Lever, Michael Adams, Jay Vincent, Blair Rasmussen, Calvin Natt, Bill Hanzlik and Elston Turner.(AP)

title: A Tough Decision: Quitting Talent Bank Post
description: Disillusioned as she was after two years in the New York City government, Nydia Padilla-Barham nonetheless found it difficult to quit her $32,000-a-year job as director of the Mayor's Talent Bank.

title: Bank of New Hampshire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect the acquisition of Suncook Bank in February 1988.

title: Accounts
description: * 3M Company's Do-It-Yourself business unit, St. Paul, a maker of remodeling and auto products, to Martin/ Williams, Minneapolis, with a budget of $3 million.

title: Reviews/Television: New England Tragedy
description: With Judy Crichton as executive producer, ''The American Experience'' closes out its sturdy first season on public television tonight - on Channel 21 at 9 and Channel 13 at 10 -with still another first-rate documentary exploring the nation's past. ''Sins of Our Mothers'' was produced by David Hoffman and written and directed by Matthew Collins. Here is a subject, centered around rural New England life in the 1800's, that has little or no pictorial documentation. Yet as David McCullough, the series host, points out in a brief introduction: ''It's amazing how many telling details of long-lost lives can still be recovered.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ball Corp., Muncie, Ind., said it was the low bidder on a one-year, $23.1 million contract to supply copper-plated zinc penny blanks to Government Mints in Philadelphia, Denver and San Francisco.

title: Homestake, Bond in Deal
description: The Homestake Mining Company announced today that it would invest more than $117 million (Australian), or $99 million (United States), to join Alan Bond, the Australian businessman, in his dream of a ''super-pit'' gold mine.

title: First Citizens Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: To the Editor:

title: Designating the Driver
description: It's not clear to what extent television molds social behavior. But on the assumption that it does, the Harvard Alcohol Project and the television industry have been trying to combat drunken driving by promoting the designated driver concept. Both partners deserve credit for the effort.

title: Whittle to Test School TV Plan
description: Whittle Communications said yesterday that it was preparing to test Channel One, a daily television news program to be shown in six schools across the country.

title: Damon Biotech reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Latin Debt Crisis Seen as Threat To Continent's New Democracies
description: A nonpartisan panel of 60 prominent private citizens in the Western Hemisphere warned today that the debt crisis gripping Latin America could lead to a political crisis and a return to authoritarian rule on the continent.

title: WORK IS FALTERING ON U.S. REPOSITORY FOR ATOMIC WASTE
description: For the first time since the development of atomic weapons, Government bomb makers are trying to build a nuclear project under civilian safety rules, and they are faltering badly.

title: Europe Inquiry On Asian Tapes
description: The European Community's Executive Commission said today that it had begun an inquiry into imports of audio cassette tapes from Asia that are said to be for sale in the 12-nation trade bloc at below market prices.

title: Peoples Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Family Violence: Protection Improves but Not Prevention
description: Police and court protection for victims of family violence in the New York City metropolitan region has improved sharply in the last five years, social workers and law-enforcement officials say, but most counties still lack comprehensive and coordinated programs to prevent the abuse and help the victims.

title: Get Serious About Escalating Medical Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Reply On Meat
description: The European Community will investigate Washington's recently expressed concerns that European meat sold in the United States is not adequately inspected, a senior trade official said today.

title: Bengals Hope Defense Will Stay Offensive
description: They are more noted for shouting ''Woo! Woo!'' and rotating their hips as part of the Ickey Shuffle, than for stopping passes. On a team that leads the league in scoring and yardage, who notices if the secondary plays well? Or poorly? It takes an average of more than 28 points a game to beat the Bengals' offense, which has six of the eight Cincinnati players who are going to the Pro Bowl.

title: India Turning To Soviets For Airliners
description: India has signed a deal to lease civilian airliners from the Soviet Union to handle its increased domestic and international traffic and to offset a series of air mishaps that have depleted its fleet.

title: Barenboim Refuses To Accept Dismissal
description: Daniel Barenboim, the Israeli conductor and pianist dismissed as musical and artistic director of the new opera house in Paris in a scandal of operatic dimensions, said today that his dismissal should come from President Francois Mitterrand.

title: First Commercial Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bank of New England Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods included special provisions of $90 million for the quarter and $197 million for the year, both for loans to countries that were refinancing their debt.

title: Olympians Join Meet
description: The Olympic medalists Diane Dixon and Andrew Valmon, along with the former 800-meter world record-holder Rick Wohlhuter, have entered the Millrose Games Feb. 3 at Madison Square Garden, meet officials announced yesterday.

title: Profits Up At Hanover And Chase
description: More banking companies yesterday reported sharp improvements in earnings, in part a reflection of two years worth of overdue interest payments that were finally received from Brazil.

title: Rowan Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $24.4 million from the physical loss of an offshore drilling unit. c-Net loss Prior-year results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Gain in Apparel but Lag In Durables Sales Seen
description: Predictions that 1989 will see an improvement in apparel sales but a slowdown in sales of big-ticket household durables opened the annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association yesterday at the New York Hilton and Sheraton Center hotels in New York.

title: Bridge
description: Two major team titles were decided Sunday when the Tristate Regional Championships concluded in Port Chester, N.Y. The Knockout Team Championship was captured by Neil and Juanita Chambers, Gene and Roslyn Weiss and Norb Kremer, all, Schenectady, N.Y., and Alan Sontag, Manhattan. Victory in the Swiss Teams went to Phillip Martin, Manhattan, Debbie Zuckerberg, Flushing, Queens, Joel Friedberg, Scarsdale, N.Y., and Ethan Stein, Irvington, N.Y.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: NBD said its 1987 net was reduced by $32.4 million, or 69 cents per share, as the result of a special $54 million provision for possible credit losses on Latin American loans. The company said the provision for possible credit losses in 1988 was $46 million, compared with $115.1 million ($61.1 million excluding the special provision for Latin American loans) in 1987. Results reflected the acquisition on Dec. 31, 1987, of State National Corp. and the Aug. 31, 1988 acquisition of Charter Bank Group.

title: Morton Thiokol Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q&A
description: Q.Why do flocks of birds fly up and wheel in the sky before landing on trees around sunset? A.They may be leaving an avian ''cocktail party'' or arranging themselves into groups for the night, ornithologists suggest.

title: U.N. ACTS TO SPUR IRAN-IRAQ TALKS
description: Five months after Iran and Iraq agreed to a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is to send an envoy to the region next week to inject new life into stalled peace negotiations there.

title: Zero Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months included results of Air Cargo Equipment Corp. for the month of December.

title: Peripherals: Predicament Of Computer And Owner As Orphans
description: MOST owners of personal computers use them for one job or a limited range of tasks and couldn't care less about how they operate otherwise. Excerpts from a letter from one such user follow:

title: Brother James Vaughan, 81, Ex-Iona Dean
description: Brother James H. Vaughan of the Christian Brothers order, a former dean of Iona College, died of a heart attack on Friday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Oradell, N.J.

title: Secom General reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Transition Watch; All Is Not Quiet On the West Front Transition Watch
description: On the West Front of the Capitol, framed against the dazzling prospect of the Mall and the Washington Monument, workers were installing the rostrum and the bulletproof shield that will surround it for the swearing-in of the 41st President. The mood seemed frenetic. ''The very first thing we did this morning was make a checklist of what could be forgotten - who's bringing the Bush bibles, who's bringing the Quayle bibles,'' said Michael F. Ruehling, executive director of the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies.

title: SOVIETS' HARVEST WORST IN 3 YEARS
description: The Soviet Union's grain harvest last year fell 40 million tons short of the target of 235 million tons, according to preliminary estimates, a Soviet offical said today.

title: National Semiconductor To Cut Work Force 5%
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it would reduce its worldwide work force by approximately 2,000, or about 5 percent of the total of 39,000. In connection with this action, National said it would record a one-time restructuring charge in the third quarter of its 1989 fiscal year.

title: Compuscan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a loss of $9,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. Latest quarter included a non- recurring charge of $275,000 from the termination of the company's former chairman and a provision of $100,000 relating to the pending merger with Enercon Data Corp. The company said prior year second quarter and 6 months revenues included about $1,762,000 and $3,334,000, respectively, relating to Compuscan's former formsreader and field service operations which were sold in January 1988.

title: Job Concern Is Reacquired
description: Barry Nathanson, president of Richards Consultants, has reacquired the management recruiting firm that he sold to British-based Blue Arrow P.L.C., the world's largest employment agency, in May 1987.

title: On Ice, the Old Guard and the Avant-Garde
description: In narrow knitted trousers or tights, in oversized ski sweaters that either celebrate or parody classic patterns and motifs, in wonderfully goofy hats for women and, for children, those gloves called Freezy Freakies - New York looks nice on ice.

title: The Unsinkable Kissinger Bobs Back
description: Looming behind the Bush cabinet is the improbable but inescapable figure of Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Koreas Agree to Hold High-Level Talks
description: North Korea agreed today to a South Korean proposal for the highest-level political and military talks since the Korean War.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He lived a hero's life. He dreamed a hero's dreams. And he left a hero's indelible mark on the mind and imagination of a great nation.'' - George Bush, on Martin Luther King Jr. [ A1:3. ]

title: The Famous Join in Aiding the Neediest Cases
description: What do John McEnroe, Peter Falk, E. L. Doctorow and Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. have in common? Like many people whose names don't make headlines they are concerned about the alarming increase in the ranks of the poor of New York City and have sent contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: King's Role in Selma Recalled as 3 Blacks Take Seats on Panel
description: A few blocks from the bridge where a national voting rights law was born in violence 24 years ago, three black men took an oath of office today to end 112 years of white domination of the government of Dallas County.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the marketing role of book covers reversed the identities of two men. Ed Breslin, editor in chief of Berkley Publishing Group, was on the left; Roger Cooper, publisher, was at the center.

title: Solitec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $47,000 for income tax reduction from utilization of loss carryforwards for the year and 3 months, and included an extraordinary credit of $77,000 for gain on debt restructuring for the year.

title: Hudson PCB Removal Stalled Again
description: Removal of PCB's from the Hudson River, delayed for more than a decade, has been stalled once again by a state panel's rejection of a plan to bury soil dredged from the river on an upstate dairy farm.

title: Hasidic Rabbi in Manhattan Is Missing After Sunday Walk
description: A 66-year-old Hasidic rabbi, leader of a small Orthodox congregation he founded on the Upper East Side 11 years ago, has been missing since Sunday, the police said yesterday. They asked for the public's help finding him.

title: Reviews/Music: Shostakovich Premiere
description: Mstislav Rostropovich had planned to conduct the National Symphony Orchestra in Haydn's Sixth and Shostakovich's Seventh symphonies on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. But early last week he announced that in place of the Haydn, he would offer the premiere of a previously unknown Shostakovich cantata in which the composer parodied Stalin's decrees about the nature of music.

title: Thompson's Walk Raises Broader Issue
description: IN the swirl of John Thompson's protest, and John Chaney's cries of N.C.A.A. racism, and the move spearheaded by Vince Dooley and the Southeastern Conference folks to push through Proposition 42, the essential function of the university, and the responsibility of the student himself, seem to have got lost.

title: JAMAICA ELECTION SET FOR FEBRUARY
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga of Jamaica, who has been trailing in political polls, has announced that national elections will be held on Feb. 9, ending months of speculation in the Caribbean nation.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sterling Capital Corp reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets, and net assets and assets per share are after a dividend of 23 cents, to be paid Jan. 18 to shareholders of record Dec. 29.

title: Grain and Soybean Prices Tumble
description: Grain and soybean prices plunged yesterday, despite Government crop reports detailing sharply lower harvests caused by the drought last summer and the Soviet Union's announcement that its grain harvest had come up short as well.

title: Omaha's Housing Chief Strives to Lead the Way to Better Lives
description: When Jack F. Kemp was chosen to be the next Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, he promised a war against poverty, but many people say that war has already begun right here.

title: Fatal Shooting By Miami Police Sets Off a Melee
description: A crowd in a predominantly black section of the city threw stones and bottles at police officers and journalists and set fire to cars Monday night after officers shot and killed a black man who was fleeing the police on a motorcycle.

title: Bear, Stearns Appointments
description: Bear, Stearns & Company yesterday announced the formation of a new public finance group to focus on New York State and named Edward M. Bopp and Robert Steingut as co-heads.

title: Talking Business with Peters of the Michael Peters Group; Design Held Vital To Sales Abroad
description: The Michael Peters Group P.L.C., a rapidly growing British design company, is beginning to make acquisitions in the United States.

title: Bush Selections Signal Focus on Foreign Policy
description: New Presidents have usually lodged their closest confidants in politically sensitive domestic jobs, notably that of Attorney General.

title: Gains Toward Cambodia Settlement Are Seen
description: Diplomats and Thai officials say the necessary elements for a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia are rapidly coming together.

title: Scientists Race to Explain How the New Superconductors Work
description: IN the quest to find superconductors that work at higher and higher temperatures, scientists have been frustrated by the fact that they really don't know what in the name of physics is going on. There was little reason to expect that the new materials, which are not metals but ceramics, would conduct electricity at all, much less that they would do so without losing any energy to resistance.

description: Jerry Rice, generally regarded as the top receiver in the National Football League, suffered an injury to his right ankle in today's 49ers' practice and was listed as only 50-50 to be able to play in Super Bowl XXIII on Sunday.

title: Spearhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Merciless Texas Justice
description: One reason Texas leads the nation in executions is the peculiar way Texas law makes it hard for juries to grant mercy. The case of a convicted rape-murderer, Johnny Penry, argued before the Supreme Court last week, exposes the law's unfairness and forces the justices, who have upheld the law in principle, to confront its operation.

title: Speaker's Ladders for Moscow
description: It is official now - the representatives of 35 nations including the United States have agreed to gather in Moscow in 1991 to talk about the struggle for human rights around the world.

An Ex-Belgian Premier Is Believed Kidnapped
description: A former Prime Minister believed to have been kidnapped, possibly by a terrorist group, was threatened before he disappeared, Prime Minister Wilfried Martens said today.

title: JARUZELSKI WARY ABOUT SOLIDARITY
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said today that ''agreement of all the nation's constructive groups'' was indispensable for social and economic change. But his words fell short of an expected proposal that the banned Solidarity union be made legal again.

title: 'Ecstasy' Drug Tied to Brain Damage
description: The amphetamine derivative known as ''ecstasy'' may have long-term damaging effects on the brain, a Stanford University researcher says.

Imre Cholnoky, Developer, 68
description: Imre Cholnoky, founder and president of Sinjon Inc., a real-estate development corporation, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 68 years old and also had homes in Stratton Mountain, Vt., and Scottsdale, Ariz.

description: Following are excerpts from the final document of the Vienna meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Taking part in the conference were the Soviet Union, the United States, Canada and all European nations except Albania. Condemning Terrorism

title: 4.9% G.M. Loans
description: The General Motors Corporation, following the lead of the Ford Motor Company, said it would offer 4.9 percent financing on some compact pickup trucks. G.M. said the 4.9 percent rate is available on two-year loans for 1988 and 1989 S/T-15 pickups. Also available are rates ranging from 6.9 percent on three-year loans to 9.9 percent on five-year loans. Buyers can also receive rebates of $500 to $750.

title: Drug Foes See Big Mac As a Threat
description: LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation, which spends millions of dollars each year refining its wholesome image, is fighting off hundreds of complaints from Upper West Side residents who fear that a planned fast-food restaurant would encourage drug-dealing in their neighborhood.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Echo or Tocsin?
description: When Joseph I. Lieberman beat Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in Connecticut's Senate elections, Republican reaction in Washington was generally sanguine. Mr. Weicker, a very liberal Republican who was sometimes bellicose in advocating his positions, had been a thorn in the side of the Reagan Administration. Mr. Lieberman, by contrast, ran as a fairly conservative Democrat and is considered easy to get along with.

title: Kraft Sets Layoffs
description: Kraft Inc., the newly acquired subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies, said it would eliminate about 250 of its 2,800 Chicago-area employees in the next two months. Kraft is making the reductions as part of its plan to cut back after its $13 billion acquisition last month.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airlease Management Services Inc., San Mateo, Calif., the general partner of Airlease Ltd., said Douglas C. Kay had resigned as president to pursue other business interests. He will be replaced by Gary P. Stern, an executive vice president of U.S. Leasing International Inc., which founded the partnership.

description: Choosing its own executives to head the Burger King Corporation, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. today named Barry J. Gibbons as chief executive and Ian A. Martin as chairman of the troubled restaurant chain, effective immediately.

title: Giving Miami the News in Both of Its Languages
description: The Miami Herald became the oldest daily newspaper in town when The Miami News, a 92-year-old afternoon paper, died of circulation problems and neglect last month. But the demise of The News, its only English-language competitor, promises to have little effect on The Herald, which long ago won the battle for readers and advertisers, at least those who spoke its tongue.

Transition Watch; Bush's Plans For His Big Day
description: On Inauguration Day, this Friday, George Bush plans to wake up before 6 A.M., watch the morning news programs until 6:30, ''play with grandkids, pray, go to the White House, go to Capitol Hill, get sworn in,'' reports Sheila Tate, the spokeswoman for the transition to his Presidency.

title: Syncor International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Latest-quarter share earnings were less than 1 cent a share.

Of the $146 million in past due interest received from Brazil, a total of $81 million was related to the 1987 year. The year-ago quarter's net is after a net restructuring charge of $48 million, and the loss for 1987 if after the $1.7 billion addition to the reserve for possible credit losses.

title: New York Banks on Winter Season
description: The soul of thoroughbred racing has moved south and west for the season, taking up winter quarters amid the cool San Gabriel Mountains towering over Santa Anita in California and the royal palms swaying at Gulfstream Park in Florida. But in New York the game goes on, and on and on, at Aqueduct Race Track, where the winter winds whip in from Jamaica Bay and the horses race on a little inner track packed with salt.

title: Passport Travel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: British Sales Decline
description: Britain's retail sales fell by a tenth of a percent in December from November, the Government reported today. Retail sales had fallen six-tenths of a percent in November. But retail sales were up 5.2 percent on a year-to-year basis in December, the Department of Trade and Industry said.

description: The latest periods' results included the operations of Mushroom King Inc. from its acquisition on Oct. 1, 1987. The year-ago periods' losses included strike-related costs and expenses of $254,000 and $2,592,000, respectively.

title: United Cable Television Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $5,108,000 from repurchase of debentures.

title: Rice to Announce Goldsmith as Coach
description: Fred Goldsmith, the new Rice football coach, said yesterday that he is facing the most challenging job in college football. Goldsmith will be introduced today as Rice's head coach. He replaces Jerry Berndt, who resigned Dec. 28 to accept the head coaching job at Temple. The Owls finished last season 0-11 and have the nation's longest losing streak of 18 losses. ''It's probably the biggest challenge in college football at this time,'' Goldsmith said as he arrived in Houston. Bobby May, the associated athletic director at Rice, is expected to assume the duties of athletic director. Berndt held both titles at Rice. The search committee wanted a coach familiar with Texas and with Rice's high academic standards. ''One of the keys to Rice football is to really hone in on recruiting in the state of Texas,'' Goldsmith said, ''and to have people on the staff that know the state of Texas.'' Before his service with Arkansas, last season's Southwest Conference champion, Goldsmith was head coach at Slippery Rock in Pennsylvania in 1981.

title: Buying Is Seen In UAL Shares
description: Saul P. Steinberg has accumulated nearly a million shares, or close to 5 percent, of the UAL Corporation, an individual close to the Manhattan billionaire said yesterday. UAL owns United Airlines, the biggest carrier in the country.

title: Nuclear Data reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,000 for the quarter and $760,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $225,000 for the quarter and $226,000 for the 9 months.

title: Correction
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about protests against a new N.C.A.A. rule misstated the effective date. It is Aug. 1, 1990, not 1991.

title: Conner Saves the Night for Nets
description: The Nets were on their way to another debacle tonight. They lost an 18-point lead in the second half. Their offense collapsed in the fourth quarter. They were struggling against the San Antonio Spurs (10-26), a team the Nets shouldn't lose to at home.

title: ITT Financial 10-Year Notes
description: The ITT Financial Corporation priced a $100 million offering of 10-year notes through a syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Warning From Tokyo on Trade and Dollar
description: A senior official of Japan's powerful Finance Ministry warned today that a widening trade surplus with the United States would not be improved by further declines in the dollar, suggesting that the Bush administration will have to take a markedly different approach to equalizing trade between the countries.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-President of Sears To Head Savings Unit
description: LEAD: Richard M. Jones, who retired last year as president of Sears, Roebuck & Company, has been named chairman, chief executive and president of Guaranty Federal Savings Bank, one of the Texas savings units created under the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's rescue plan for the industry.

title: BAKER ASSERTS U.S. SHOULD NOT 'RUSH' IN AIDING MOSCOW
description: Secretary of State-designate James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States has an interest in seeing Mikhail S. Gorbachev succeed in his attempts to bring changes to the Soviet system, but should avoid ''a headlong rush'' to provide Moscow with loans and credits.

title: Let Mediation Board Do Its Job at Eastern Air; Impact on Florida
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than 200 Arrested in Miami In 2d Night of Racial Disturbances
description: The police used force to clear the streets last night as blacks burned automobiles and threw bottles in the Overtown section for the second night and violence spread to another black neighborhood.

title: New Liszt Concerto Discovered
description: A Chicago musicologist has quietly completed work on a discovery that will make a lot of noise: a hitherto unheard piano concerto by the piano's thundering master, Franz Liszt.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Matisse Misfit Is Placed
description: Thanks to the Art Institute of Chicago, and above all to its director, James N. Wood, one of the more disappointing aspects of the recent improvement in Soviet-American relations has been laid to rest. . For the first time ever, Soviet authorities on 20th-century art sat down with their American equivalents and talked freely, easily, incisively and before an invited public for hour after hour.

title: Cooking Classes Come to the Family
description: PEOPLE who make a living in the food business certainly have an obligation to teach their children how to cook. Right? Well, I tried. Heaven knows I tried. After both of my children, who are five years apart in age, had gone through the licking-the-bowl-and-the-eggbeater stage and had shown an interest in how to make the stuff that was clinging to both bowl and beater, I was happy to instruct. After all, they seemed eager to learn. And, I reasoned, these would be what I call ''survival skills'' of a sort: my children would not starve for want of a can opener. Moreover, I would end up with cheap, reliable labor: willing hands to take on some of the easier chores in the kitchen like cutting, peeling and chopping.

title: International Paper Offer Is Approved
description: The directors of Aussedat Rey S.A., one of France's largest paper companies, approved a $320 million acquisition offer from the International Paper Company. International Paper, the world's largest paper maker, offered $107 a share for all of the French company's stock. The bid was announced last week, but no price was disclosed.

title: Kissinger Relays Bush's Ideas On Relations to Gorbachev
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met Mikhail S. Gorbachev today and relayed some ideas about Soviet-American relations from President-elect George Bush, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Review/Theater; A Fictional Bert Lahr In Crisis
description: A famous clown named Max Luck is in Florida rehearsing a role in an avant-garde tragicomedy (very much like ''Waiting for Godot''), and his insecurity in the play sends him into a swirl of memories about his early days in vaudeville. For many years, he and his partner, Maxie (later his first wife), had been struggling troupers. As Max began to be successful on his own, Maxie was overcome by mental illness. Eventually she was institutionalized, leaving her celebrated husband with feelings of remorse and guilt.

title: Helen of Troy reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Aristech Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $23,700,000 from an accounting change. The company said the 1988 net from operations is after a gain of $21,900,000 from an accounting change related to the sale of inventories at a Houston plant.

title: Indiana National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter and year reflected the addition of $11 million and $34 million, respectively, of provisions for foreign loan losses.

title: Dow Off by 10; Transport Average Climbs
description: Despite a strong day for airline stocks that sent the Dow Jones transport average to a post-recovery high, the stock market closed lower yesterday on moderately higher volume. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10 points, to 2,214.64, The transport index climbed 7.78, to 1,004.38, its highest level since Oct. 14, 1987, when it closed at 1,011.59.

title: Hospital Neglected to Notify Family of a Man Who Died
description: The body of an 81-year-old man who died in a Queens hospital nine days after he was in a car accident was sent to the morgue for burial in a common grave because his relatives were not called, City Council President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.

title: Archer-Daniels-Midland Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Correction
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Lotus Development Corporation misstated the circumstances under which Mitchell Kapor, its founder and chairman, left the company. Mr. Kapor said he left in July 1986 because he was unhappy with his work. He did not start another company until late 1987.

title: Scribner: Down to The Last Syllable
description: LEAD: On Jan. 22, the Scribner Book Store will close its doors forever. The late Prof. Henry-Russell Hitchcock called this architectural rival to Grand Central Terminal ''the grandest interior space that had been created in New York.'' Today, the store is threatened with subdivision and dismemberment. Only quick and decisive action by the New York City Landmarks Preservation

title: Let Mediation Board Do Its Job at Eastern Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; Premiere of Guitar Piece
description: At a glance, the program Eliot Fisk played at his Alice Tully Hall guitar recital on Sunday evening seemed weighted toward the familiar, with a new work by Luciano Berio wedged in among pieces by Sor, Scarlatti, Bach, Paganini and Barrios.

title: 18 Accused of Commodity Fraud
description: Eighteen former employees of the First Commodity Corporation of Boston have been charged with defrauding more than 2,600 customers of more than $40 million.

title: Reviews/Music; Uchida in Piano Recital
description: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida established her reputation as a superb Mozartean with a series of sonata and concerto recordings, and although she has expressed a desire to devote more time to other composers, she will be playing all the sonatas during Mostly Mozart's complete-works survey.

title: Vienna Spring, Prague Winter
description: Only an hour after pledging in Vienna to ''respect the right of their citizens to contribute to the promotion of human rights and fundamental freedom,'' Czechoslovakia used dogs, clubs and water cannon to deny that right.

title: Molex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' nets included net charges of $6.5 million from the settlement of a lawsuit and the company's Japanese expansion program.

title: Rules on Tranquilizer Prescriptions Don't Harm Confidentiality; Bottleneck in Refills
description: To the Editor:

title: Petoskey Journal; One Victim Fights a Rare Disorder
description: Nancy Whitmore Sando's muscles began slowly turning to bone when she was 5 years old. Now at 29, she is almost completely paralyzed, the victim of an extremely rare genetic disorder, Fibrodisplasia ossificans progressiva.

title:
Market Place;
Tidewater Bid: Focus on Drilling
description: LEAD: A RECENT takeover bid for Tidewater Inc. has investors taking a closer look at other oil drilling service companies.

title: Tellier Named Coach Of Columbia Football
description: Ray Tellier Jr., who was the head coach at Rochester for the last five seasons, was appointed yesterday as the new Columbia football coach.

title: Jim Bakker Pleads Not Guilty Of Misusing PTL's Millions
description: Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL television ministry, pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of diverting millions of dollars in donations from his followers and using the money to support his lavish style of life.

title: L.F. Rothschild Withdraws As a Key Treasury Dealer
description: L.F. Rothschild & Company said yesterday that it had withdrawn as a primary dealer in United States Treasury securities. It cited difficult business conditions and questionable short-term prospects.

title: Heico Bid Raised By Investor Group
description: A Miami-based investment group has raised its offer to acquire the Heico Corporation to $23 a share, or $48.1 million, from its previous price of $21 a share. In a letter to Heico's board dated Jan. 16, which was contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group's leader, Laurans A. Mendelson, said he was ''prepared to meet with Heico immediately, in good faith, to negotiate the purchase of the entire company.''

title: From Shepherds, A Pasta Legacy
description: TO an American in Rome, seeking the city's past in monuments and museums is a perfectly logical pursuit. Yet statues and portraits are silent. To learn of the glory that was and is Rome, one most go to its neighborhoods. Among other things, the fortunate visitor will find an ancient cuisine passed down through Roman families.

title: Insider-Trading Inquiry Reported in Paris
description: The Commission on Operations of the Bourse, the French equivalent of the Securities and Exchange Commission, refused to comment today on reports that two prominent Lebanese businessmen were being investigated in connection with insider trading in the takeover of Triangle Industries by Pechiney S.A., the French aluminum company.

title: A NAMIBIAN GROUP OPPOSES U.N. CUTS
description: The head of the South-West Africa People's Organization called on the United Nations today not to cut back on its plans for a Namibian peacekeeping force.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Devils' Power Play Is No Advantage
description: Marc Fortier, Gaetan Duchesne and Jeff Jackson each scored short-handed goals tonight to help the Quebec Nordiques beat the Devils, 7-4.

title: The New Voodoo, Made Fairer
description: Commendably, President-elect Bush wants to stretch the dismally short investment horizons of American business. Not at all commendably, he thinks that cutting the tax on capital gains is a sensible way to do that. He urged that new form of voodoo economics during the campaign, and it is now said to be high on a list of contemplated fixes.

title: Federal Pay Increase Is Given Little Support
description: Only one American in seven favors the proposed 50 percent pay increase for members of Congress, Federal judges and high officials of the executive branch, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about bank earnings misstated the closing price of the stock of the Chase Manhattan Corporation. It closed at $30.875, up 62.5 cents.

title: Pitt Rallies to Beat Boston College, 73-64
description: Bobby Martin scored 17 points and Jason Matthews added 16 to lead Pitt to a 73-64 Big East victory over Boston College tonight.

title: Triad SystemsQtr to Dec 31 reports earnings for 1988
description: b-Included 20 cents a share from property sale and accounting of nonrecurruing costs.

title: KEY RATES
How the Balloting Went
description: The results of two ballots on Proposition 42, an amendment to the N.C.A.A. bylaw popularly known as Proposition 48. Proposition 42 would tighten academic requirements for an athletic scholarship. The first vote was Jan. 10, with the proposition being defeated by 159-151. On a second vote, on Jan. 11, the proposition was passed, 163-154. Each school and each conference has one vote. title: Girl, 11, Raped on Way to Brooklyn School
description: An 11-year-old Brooklyn girl was raped while on her way to school yesterday morning, the police said.
