title: Czarist Bond Talks Going On
description: The State Department has disclosed that United States and Soviet officials have started talks on the repayment of bonds issued by the czarist Government of Russia but repudiated after the Soviet revolution of 1917.

title: 'Darkness' Was in Our Vision
description: The statue of Dr. David Livingstone gazes out across the falls, a roaring curtain of water more than a mile wide that is truly one of the world's wonders. He was, as a signboard explains, ''the first European to see the falls, which he named in honor of Queen Victoria.''

title: Apple Computer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Real Estate; Hovnanian's Big Project In Jersey
description: OVER the last three decades K. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., a development company based in Red Bank, N.J., has become a leading home builder by putting up no-frills housing. The company's low prices have drawn buyers willing to camp out overnight for the chance to purchase.

title: International Multifoods Names Chief Executive
description: The International Multifoods Corporation, a Minneapolis-based company that has become a major food distributor, has named Anthony Luiso chairman and chief executive.

title: Toys 'R' Us Head Honored; Some Retailers Don't Attend
description: A number of major retailing executives did not attend a luncheon yesterday honoring Charles Y. Lazarus, chairman and founder of Toys ''R'' Us and Kids ''R'' Us, who was honored as ''boys' wear retailer of the year.''

title: Burke Gets All-Star Spot
description: Sean Burke, the 21-year-old goaltender for the Devils, has been voted the starting spot on the Wales Conference team for the National Hockey League All-Star Game Feb. 7 in Edmonton, Alberta. He is the first rookie to be named a starter since the fans began selecting the starting team four years ago.

title: Walsh Keeps Future A Continuing Mystery
description: Faced with an indication that he has planned to resign as coach of the San Francisco 49ers after Super Bowl XXIII Sunday, Bill Walsh repeated today that he would not make that decision until after the game.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE other day, Gloria Ross was late for an appointment at a company on the Avenue of the Americas. She holds herself blameless for being tardy and in defense she offers this explanation:

title: MNC Financial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Monsanto Is Nearer Sale of Unit to Germans
description: An inter-agency Government task force has tentatively approved the Monsanto Company's plan to sell its semiconductor subsidiary to one of the largest chemical companies in West Germany, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Rights Panel Sees Decline in U.S. Enforcement
description: A private commission today reported a ''dramatic decline'' in civil rights enforcement by the Federal Government under the Reagan Administration and urged that President-elect George Bush appoint a Cabinet-level group ''to deal with the causes and results of bigotry and prejudice.''

title: Wells Fargo & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Both year-ago periods' results included the effects of special additions to the allowance for loan losses and related tax benefits in connection with loans to developing countries. Excluding the effects of the additions, the year-ago quarter's per share and net income would have been $2.05 and $116.6 million, respectively, and for the year, $6.69 per share and $382.6 million in net income.

title: Making Over an Image With an Expert's Help
description: IN the movie ''Working Girl,'' Melanie Griffith plays a character named Tess McGill, an ambitious Staten Island secretary who wears dangling earrings. She encounters Katharine Parker (Sigourney Weaver), an impeccably groomed executive with an unfortunate tendency to quote Coco Chanel. Like many professionals, Tess needs to upgrade her image. Katharine suggests - in a saccharine tone - ''You might want to rethink the jewelry.''

title: Farley Expects Shift by Pepperell
description: The chairman of Farley Industries said he believed that West Point-Pepperell Inc.'s executives would change their hostile stance toward Farley's $48-a-share offer before a special shareholders meeting on Feb. 25.

title: TV Stations Subpoenaed
description: Three network-affiliated television stations in the Roanoke, Va., area have been subpoenaed in a Justice Department inquiry into price-fixing of advertising rates, Government officials and station executives said today.

title: MCI to Slash Service Prices
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it was dropping the prices for its electronic mail service, beginning Feb. 1.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SWEET red peppers make an excellent base for all kinds of delicious low-fat sauces. I recently prepared a splendid but easy weeknight dinner using trimmed, boneless loin of pork and a quick red-pepper sauce.

title: Dancing At the Bottom
description: I once went to an Inaugural Ball.

title: Zitel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $48,000 and $110,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Irish vs. Virginia In Kickoff Classic
description: Notre Dame, which wound up its undefeated 1988 season by beating West Virginia in the Fiesta Bowl, will begin the college football season against Virginia in the Kickoff Classic in Giants Stadium on Aug. 31.

title: Yugoslav Head Faults Strife Among Officials
description: The Yugoslav head of state has declared that conflicts among the country's regional leaderships are preventing Yugoslavia from dealing with its grave problems.

title: Apple Profits Are Up 16%; Prices Cut
description: Apple Computer Inc. today reported a 16 percent gain in net income on a 35 percent growth in revenues for its first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 30. The company also announced selected price cuts for expensive products, effectively rolling back part of the unusual price rises it made in September.

title: German Inquiry Begun on Aid to Libyan Air Force
description: The Munich prosecutor's office announced today that it had opened an investigation into a Bavarian company that has reportedly been helping Libya develop a capacity for midair refueling.

title: Book Notes
description: New From Saul Bellow

title: Putting Data at Your Fingertips
description: Stephen A. Rondel stood amid a small crowd with a strange contraption in his hand, speaking slowly into a microphone. ''I would like . . . to go . . . to the . . . airport,'' he said in a monotone voice. Then, he added, ''Translate.''

title: Why Spelling Machines Sometimes Flunk
description: The makers of electronic spelling checkers say their machines can find the proper spelling even if the user spells the word wrong. ''Type NABOR and in seconds the Spell-Checker locates NEIGHBOR,'' boasts the brochure for the Texas Instruments product.

title: Brazil Payments Aid Citicorp Net
description: Bolstered by payments of past-due interest on loans to Brazil, Citicorp, the nation's largest bank, reported a strong gain in fourth-quarter earnings.

title: Gerald G. Probst, 65, Chairman Of Sperry at Time of Big Merger
description: Gerald G. Probst, former chairman of the Sperry Corporation and a longtime executive in the computer and military systems industries, died at his home in Salt Lake City last Sunday. He was 65 years old.

title: Time-Life Book Club
description: Time-Life Books (Europe) Inc. agreed on Monday to purchase Books for Children, Britain's largest hard-cover book club for children, from Independent Television Publications. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions in Business Day yesterday with an article about the National Retail Merchants Association were reversed in some editions.

title: Arafat and Arab Mayor: Threat or a Distortion?
description: On New Year's Day, Yasir Arafat was reported to have told a meeting of Palestinians in Saudi Arabia that any Palestinian who opposed the uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip ''exposes himself to the bullets of his own people.''

title: United Jersey Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grubb & Ellis Realty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Teachers College Is Pondering New Challenges
description: The centennial party is over at Teachers College at Columbia University, and, as it wakes to the realities of its second century, the school continues to reflect the strains of the profession for which it is named.

title: Whoop Whoop Whoop Whoop
description: LEAD: I once read a science fiction novel about a man who ceased to sleep. He was a mutation, I think, or maybe he was bitten by a radioactive bat. You'll have to excuse me if I seem a bit confused. I haven't been getting much sleep lately. (Have I already said that?) Maybe it was a movie dubbed from the Japanese: ''The Man Who Did Not Sleep vs.

title: Firstfed America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an $855,000 gain on the sale of Firstfed's Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. participating preferred stock.

title: Justice Dept. Assails Meese
description: The Justice Department's ethics office said yesterday that if Edwin Meese 3d were still Attorney General he should be subjected to Presidential discipline.

title: Bengals' Blockers Are Moving Ahead
description: They are the team within a team, one of the most honored units in the National Football League.

title: IRAQ SAID TO STUDY BIOLOGICAL ARMS
description: Iraq is developing biological weapons, including arms that can spread typhoid, cholera and anthrax, Government officials said tonight.

title: Saudi Oil Production
description: Saudi Arabia's oil output averaged 4.35 million barrels a day in the first two weeks of January, slightly below its newly assigned OPEC quota of 4.52 million barrels, Persian Gulf oil sources said today.

title: Fetisov Leaves Team In Dispute With Coach
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, the star defenseman, and Igor Larionov, a center, have resigned from the Central Red Army team in a dispute with their coach, Viktor Tikhonov, who is also the coach of the Soviet national hockey team. In an interview in Moskovsky Komsomolets yesterday, a Moscow youth daily, Fetisov cited a series of grievances against Tikhonov who, he said, made life with the club intolerable. Fetisov said he was determined to get out while there was still a future for him in the game and hoped to take up an invitation to play for the New Jersey Devils. John McMullen, the owner of the Devils, said last night he did not know anything new about the Fetisov situation. ''No question a commitment was made for the player to come,'' he said. ''But he did not defect, and that is to his credit.'' Fetisov recently participated in a Red Army team tour against N.H.L. teams.(Reuters)

title: Park Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Molinari Fights A Federal Post For Goodman
description: In a move symptomatic of the deep divisions within the New York Republican Party, Representative Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island said yesterday that he was actively opposing the possible appointment of another leading city Republican, State Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan, as Federal General Services administrator.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES CUTS IN SPENDING AND RISES IN FEES
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a state budget today that would increase a wide array of fees and taxes, ranging from marriage license fees to taxes on tires, while cutting spending for many major state programs, including Medicaid and higher education.

title: MGM/UA Weighing Sale Of Its United Artists Studio
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company said today that it was considering a restructuring plan in which its United Artists film and television studio would be sold.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN which we rummage through a couple of new wine newsletters and pass on a tragic tale from a wine-store O. Henry.

title: A 45-Dish Banquet For 110 Hunters
description: THE dinner began with woodcock breasts in brandy sauce and ended, 44 dishes later, with chocolate truffles. ''If anybody's still hungry after this, you can go get a pizza,'' said Mark Avondoglio, one of the hosts, to the 110 guests, many of them hunters and fishermen.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Flattered but . . .
description: It was one of those Washington dilemmas: Daniel Schnur, a Bush campaign worker for 18 months until last November's victory, had received tickets to a Presidential inaugural ball, but his girlfriend was so involved in the inaugural activities that she could not go as his date.

title: It's a Disgrace! Moscow's Warmest January in 100 Years
description: Add winter to the list of current items in deficit in Moscow. With chickens and soap disappearing from store shelves and service stations empty of gasoline, Muscovites are finding that even cold weather is hard to come by.

title: Bridge
description: If you watch a declarer win the first trick and then see him start to think, you can safely assume he is not an expert. Even if the play to the first trick seems obvious, it pays to plan before touching a card. Sometimes a little cogitation will result in a different play at the first trick.

title: Security Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After additional provisions for developing country debt of $350 million for the quarter and $908 million for the year.

title: Israel Orders Harsher Tactics in Palestinian Revolt
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin announced tough new measures today against Palestinians accused of throwing stones in the occupied territories.

title: Intel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB 94, consolidation of majority-owned subsidiaries, and FASB 96, accounting for income taxes.

title: Capital Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Georgetown Is Pressing Its Case
description: In the aftermath of a continuing protest by the school's basketball coach, Georgetown University officials have conducted an intense campaign throughout the National Collegiate Athletic Association to overturn a measure that could keep prospective student-athletes out of college.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: NBD said its 1987 net was reduced by $32.4 million, or 69 cents per share, as the result of a special $54 million provision for possible credit losses on Latin American loans. The company said the provision for possible credit losses in 1988 was $46 million, compared with $115.1 million ($61.1 million excluding the special provision for Latin American loans) in 1987. Results reflected the acquisition on Dec. 31, 1987, of State National Corp. and the Aug. 31, 1988 acquisition of Charter Bank Group. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Avery International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: In Senate Forum: All Hail, Baker!
description: They had obviously gathered, these eminent Senators, not to bury James A. Baker 3d under a heap of hostile questions but to praise him, and the compliments flowed back and forth all day long.

title: An Honor for Payton
description: Walter Payton, who rushed for more yards in his career than any other professional football player, was named the winner of the Dapper Dan Club's fifth annual Farewell to Sport Award yesterday. The honor goes to a retiring athlete who exemplifies competitive excellence and service to the community. Payton, who retired from the Chicago Bears after the 1987 season with 16,726 yards gained rushing, will receive the award at the Dapper Dan dinner in Pittsburgh Feb. 4.(AP)

title: Islanders' Hard Work Pays Off
description: For a change, the Islanders did what they were told and devoted 60 minutes of their evening to a game that requires a solid hour of their time but doesn't often get it.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Presidency; Army of Cartoonists Begins Hunt for Fodder
description: Jules Feiffer draws him as a prep schooler in short pants; Bill Mauldin sees him as a scolding headmaster; Gary Trudeau renders him like Tinkerbell, a tiny point of light, the rest invisible.

title: Cross Recalls Some Other 49ers
description: He comes from a time when the future of the coach of the San Francisco 49ers was not a subject of national attention, because there would be a new one soon enough. Randy Cross does not have to be told about the days when the most loyal of the 49er faithful did not come close to filling Candlestick Park, when the Super Bowl was an event to watch and not a place to work.

title: Panel of Scientists Fears Global Race In Biological Arms
description: Military use of biotechnology threatens to create a biological arms race that will disrupt recent efforts at international arms control, a panel of scientists said today.

title: Makers of 'Jones' Sequel Offer Teasers and Tidbits
description: Because they face a summer full of sequels to successful movies, Steven Spielberg and George Lucas have thrown off the mantle of secrecy behind which they hide their forthcoming films until the last possible moment.

title: Northern Trust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included losses from provisions for loan losses in less developed countries of $60 million for the quarter and $151 million for the year.

title: Tender Offer for Actmedia
description: The Heritage Media Corporation, a Dallas-based broadcasting company, announced a cash tender offer yesterday for up to 6.4 million shares of Actmedia Inc. as a first step toward a friendly merger.

title: 2 Lawyers for Brawley Fight Disbarment Move
description: Facing disciplinary proceedings for their roles in the Tawana Brawley case, C. Vernon Mason and Alton H. Maddox Jr., Miss Brawley's lawyers, are battling before two committees to avoid censure, suspension or disbarment.

title: Stage II Apparel reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago periods included the results of the apparel division of Sportsotron Inc. since its acquisition effective Aug. 1, 1987.

title: Probation Agency Faces a Double Burden
description: The murder of Dr. Kathryn Hinnant this month has once again cast a harsh light on the Probation Department, the New York City agency that was responsible for the activities and whereabouts of the 23-year-old man accused in her death.

title: William Redfield, 94, Ex-Grocery Executive
description: William F. Redfield, a retired grocery executive and former president of the Hills Brothers Company, died Monday at his home in Montclair, N.J., after a long illness. He was 94 years old.

title: Toronto-Dominion $150 Million Issue
description: The New York branch of the Toronto-Dominion Bank offered $150 milllion of 10-year subordinated notes.

title: EATING WELL
description: AFTER a dinner at your favorite restaurant in which nearly every dish is served with a sauce enriched with cream, butter or both, you may find it difficult to believe that the chef has heard of the dangers of cholesterol.

title: 51 Killed in Sri Lanka As Train Smashes Bus
description: At least 51 people, including 35 schoolgirls, were killed today when a train slammed into a crowded bus in southern Sri Lanka, police officers and hospital officials said.

title: Intertan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,225,000 for the quarter and $1,431,000 for the 6 months.

title: Steinberg Jury Will Consider All Four Charges of Homicide
description: The jury will be able to consider all the homicide charges against Joel B. Steinberg, including second-degree murder, first- and second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, when it gets the case against him Monday.

title: Correction
description: The Patents column in Business Day on Saturday misidentified the inventor of a device to help store breast milk for working mothers. He is David Hauk.

title: Paul Sheatsley, 72; Pioneer and Leader In Opinion Research
description: Paul Baker Sheatsley, a retired research director who was a well-known authority in public opinion polling, died of emphysema Sunday at Little Company of Mary Hospital in Chicago. He was 72 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: New Jersey Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
First Pennsylvania Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Rockwell International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring favorable tax adjustment of $50.2 million, or 18 cents a share.

title: Donors to the Neediest Cases Express Concern for the Aged
description: ''There are so many different groups that need help, but the aged and infirm are surely among the most deserving,'' wrote a couple, asking to remain anonymous. Natives of New York City, now living in Scarsdale, they sent $200 to help the elderly.

title: Hunt Pressed for Belgian Ex-Prime Minister
description: The Belgian authorities investigated presumed terrorist organizations today in their search for former Prime Minister Paul Vanden Boeynants, who disappeared from his home here Saturday night.

title: About Education
description: ''Schools are often ugly, shoddy, and dirty. McDonald's Hamburgers Inc. spends millions of dollars redecorating their establishments to sell their products; yet, teachers are supposed to sell poetry, geography and the miracles of mathematics in environments that are often very unappealing, if not downright filthy. I currently teach in a room that has never been painted since it was built over 20 years ago.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Serious Ethics Breaches by Meese Are Found in Justice Dept. Study
description: The Justice Department said today that Edwin Meese 3d violated government ethics codes so seriously when he was Attorney General that if he were still in office he should be subjected to Presidential discipline.

title: Paramount to Buy Option For Control of TV Stations
description: Another movie company moved yesterday to enter television broadcasting, as Paramount Pictures agreed to acquire the right to buy control of TVX Broadcast Group, a troubled operator of independent stations, from Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: 40 Banks Said to Back Deal for RJR Nabisco
description: Commercial banks proved to be willing lenders for the $24.88 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: Mr. Meese's Disgrace
description: The difference between escaping indictment and vindication has long eluded Edwin Meese. He claimed vindication when one special prosecutor failed to indict him, thus clearing the way for his confirmation as Attorney General. He claimed vindication again last summer when another special prosecutor declined to file criminal charges. Now the Justice Department's own ethical watchdog, the respected Office of Professional Responsibility, reasserts the critical distinction. Concluding its 61-page review of an independent counsel's report, that office says:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about self-service baggage carts at Kennedy International Airport misstated the salaries of skycaps who also help carry passengers' luggage. They earn $19,000 a year plus tips, not $14,000.

title: Listing Is Won In Yellow Pages By Gay Groups
description: Beginning with its 1989-90 editions, the Nynex Yellow Pages will be reorganized to include a previously unpublished listing: gay and lesbian services.

title: EDUCATION;
description: Saul P. Steinberg, chairman and chief executive officer of Reliance Group Holdings, has pledged $25 million to the University of Pennsylvania, the largest single donation ever for the school, university officials announced yesterday.

title: Steel Output Capacity Rising
description: The nation's ability to produce steel will increase this year after declining for seven years, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Monday.

title: Review/Theater; 3 Tales Play Against One Another In a Farce From Everett Quinton
description: ''What in the gay hell?'' asks a startled Everett Quinton upon opening his apartment door during the early moments of the new Ridiculous Theatrical Company production, ''A Tale of Two Cities.'' In true Dickensian fashion, Mr. Quinton, playing the role of an aspiring transvestite club performer, has just discovered that he is the recipient of an abandoned baby in a milk crate. The infant is sobbing; the new adoptive father takes it personally. ''He's a straight baby,'' Mr. Quinton concludes. ''But we can co-exist. I know it can be done.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Treads Inc., Atlanta, a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co. that services the aviation industry, appointed Albert K. DeRosa president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Garland T. Duke, who is retiring.

title: Mariners Sign Davis
description: Alvin Davis agreed to a three-year, $4.45 million contract with the Seattle Mariners yesterday. Shawon Dunston, Zane Smith, John Cerutti, Neil Allen and Al Nipper agreed to one-year contracts. Davis, who made $922,500 in 1988, will get $1.25 million in 1989, $1.425 million in 1990 and $1.725 million in 1991. He batted .295 last season with 18 homers and 69 r.b.i. Dunston and the Chicago Cubs agreed to $550,000, almost double his 1988 salary of $232,500. Nipper agreed with the Cubs to $410,000, a $13,000 raise. Allen, a free agent released by the Yankees, signed with Cleveland for $325,000. Smith and the Atlanta Braves agreed to $450,000, the same salary he made last year. Cerutti and the Toronto Blue Jays agreed to $417,000, a raise of $187,000.(AP)

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $160 million for the quarter and year. c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter and year included $436 million, after tax, representing nearly two years of Brazilian interest payments taken into earnings in the fourth quarter, after finalization of new loan agreements. It said results also included a reduction of earnings of about $14 million for the fourth quarter and $36 million for the year, from placing $800 million out of $1.4 billion of Argentine outstandings on a cash basis. The latest quarter also included a $41 million loss from the phase-out of the mobile home and some auto lending businesses. Other closing of restructuring costs of $42 million for the fourth quarter and $60 million for the year also are included.

title: Confusion Renewed Over Pill and Risks
description: CONCERNED and confused, sometimes angry or, by now, numb to bad news about breast cancer: that is how gynecologists are describing patients' reactions to three recently released studies linking prolonged exposure to the estrogen in oral contraceptives with increased risk of breast cancer.

title: Cambodia Must Unite
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Bad Debts Grow

title: Citizens & Southern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year net was reduced by 43 cents by two unusual events in the second quarter, a $15 million special provision for Latin American debt and a $27.6 million lawsuit settlement.

title: U.S. Note and Bond Prices Slip
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped modestly in light trading yesterday, as market participants awaited this morning's release of the latest figures on the United States trade deficit.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Better to Receive?
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd has a suggestion for colleagues who say they oppose the 50 percent pay increase recommended by a Federal commission: Give it back.

title: Review/Opera; Jessye Norman in a 20th-Century Double Bill
description: Both of the works on the double bill that had its Metropolitan Opera premiere on Monday evening, Bartok's ''Bluebeard's Castle'' and Schoenberg's ''Erwartung,'' were composed at a volatile time when the ideas of Freud and such Expressionist painters as Kandinsky were setting out a radical new agenda for 20th-century social and artistic thought. Schoenberg's monodrama, as he termed his emotionally searing one-act piece, appeared in 1911, the very year of Kandinsky's landmark canvas ''The Blue Rider.'' The age of Angst had been born.

title: Jordan Surge Paces Bulls
description: Michael Jordan, held to 11 points for three quarters, erupted for 11 fourth-period points and dished off 13 assists tonight to help lead the Chicago Bulls to a 103-96 triumph over the Indiana Pacers.

title: Excerpts From Cuomo's Budget Message: Cuts in Aid and Other Programs ALBANY, Jan. 17 -
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget message to the Legislature: SOCIAL JUSTICE Substance Abuse And Alcoholism

title: Garrison Makes Comeback And Moves to Third Round
description: Sixth-seeded Zina Garrison came back in the final set to beat Sandra Wasserman of Belgium, 7-6, 4-6, 6-4, today and advance to the third round of the Australian Open tennis championships.

title: Trade Parley Falls Through
description: In a bid to defuse trade tensions, United States and European Community officials tried last week to set up a secret meeting in Bermuda, European diplomats and American officials said today. But no meeting was held because of scheduling conflicts.

title: Arab Countries Try To Help Lebanese Solve Political Crisis
description: Arab governments have begun an initiative to help Lebanon solve a political crisis that has left the country without a president and split between rival Muslim and Christian interim administrations.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Koch Rebuffed in Bid for Inquiry Data
description: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity yesterday refused to provide Mayor Edward I. Koch with confidential information gathered during its investigation of the Mayor's Talent Bank.

title: Pioneer-Standard Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Rules on Tranquilizer Prescriptions Don't Harm Confidentiality
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Inventories Rose 0.4% in November
description: Business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November and sales rose at the same pace, the Government said today in a report that analysts said bodes well for the nation's economy.

title: Education Chief Blocks Move To Suspend a Board Member
description: The state Commissioner of Education, Thomas Sobol, yesterday blocked a move by the city Board of Education for the immediate suspension of former City Councilman Robert Rodriguez from membership of Community School Board 4 pending the outcome of removal proceedings.

title: Vacatons Spa Resorts reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Carl M. Spero, Executive, 86
description: Carl M. Spero, retired president of the Spero-Whitelaw Company, Manhattan insurance brokers, died of pneumonia on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Accord in Death of Girl Who Made Peace Trip
description: The mother of Samantha Smith, a Maine schoolgirl who visited the Soviet Union on a peace mission at the invitation of the Soviet head of state, has settled a $50 million lawsuit she filed after the girl and her father died in a plane crash, a lawyer said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Soviet Pair Leading: Maryna Klimova and Sergei Ponomarenko emerged yesterday from the four-year shadow of Natalya Bestemyanova and Andrei Bukin to take the early lead in the ice dance competition at the European figure skating championships in Birmingham, England. Klimova and Ponomarenko have never won a major event, having been runners-up in eight previous world, Olympic and European championship appearances. But the Soviet pair got off to a perfect start in their quest for gold as they led a Soviet sweep of the first three placings in the compulsories. Maya Usova and Aleksandr Zhulin were in second place with Natalya Annenko and Genrikh Sretenski third. Klara Engi and Attila Toth of Hungary placed fourth, ahead of the leading Western pair, Sharon Jones and Paul Ashkam of Britain. With the compulsories counting for only 20 percent of the total mark, Klimova and Ponomarenko still had a long way to go. The original set pattern takes place tomorrow and the free dance Friday.(AP) SKIING Girardelli Wins Giant Slalom: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg posted the best times in both heats to win a giant slalom race in Adelboden, Switzerland, and widen his overall lead in the World Cup standing. The 25-year-old native of Austria, who was World Cup champion in 1985 and 1986, survived a near fall in the first heat as the No. 10 starter and rallied to dominate the race in a combined 2 minutes 31.84 seconds. The big surprise, however, was the second-place finish for 22-year-old Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway, who joined the circuit only last season. He was timed in 2:32.49. Alberto Tomba of Italy was third. Girardelli raised his overall World Cup point total this season to 219, with Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland trailing him at 183. Tomba, who does not compete in downhill races, is third with 113 points.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Louisiana Tech 88, Austin 54: Venus Lacy scored a career-high 36 points and grabbed 14 rebounds to lead Louisiana Tech, ranked No. 3, past 17th-ranked Stephen F. Austin. Louisiana Tech (13-2), playing at home, was in front by only 38-29 by halftime, but steadily increased its margin. Nora Lewis added 14 points and 10 rebounds for Tech. Portia Hill paced Stephen F. Austin (11-2) with 24 points and 13 rebounds.The Lady Techsters finished with a 50-31 rebound advantage.(AP) Texas 95, Texas Tech 49: Vicki Hall, a freshman, led four Longhorns scoring in double figures as Texas handed Texas Tech the worst Southwest Conference defeat it has ever suffered. Clarissa Davis, the nation's third-leading scorer, hit all of her 13 points in the first 7 minutes as Texas, playing at home, took a 34-6 lead. Texas, ranked No. 11, improved its record to 9-4 and 5-0 in the conference. Texas Tech dropped to 7-8 and 1-3. Hall led all scorers with 15 points.(AP)

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
G. Heileman Brewing Gets a New President
description: LEAD: Murray S. Cutbush, 43, an associate director of the Bond Corporation, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the G. Heileman Brewing Company. He will succeed Russell G. Cleary, 55, Heileman's chairman, president and chief executive since 1971, who said Monday that he would retire.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Ruling Upholds California Redistricting
description: Ending a decade-long legal battle over Congressional redistricting in California, the Supreme Court ruled today that the district lines drawn after the 1980 Census did not amount to unconstitutionally partisan gerrymandering.

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: ITALIANS LECTURE IRANIAN ON RIGHTS
description: Iran's Prime Minister met today with Italian leaders and with Pope John Paul II, receiving pledges of aid to rebuild the Iranian economy but also hearing calls for human rights improvements and for swift prisoner-of-war exchanges.

title: Can a Champagne Redeem de Sade?
description: A LINE of three Champagnes named for the Marquis de Sade was introduced in Paris yesterday by a descendant seeking to rehabilitate his ancestor's name. Each wine is a brut - that is, dry.

title: L. Reyner Samet, Lawyer, 83
description: L. Reyner Samet, a New York divorce lawyer for 50 years whose clients included Colleen Dewhurst, Lee Remick, Barbara Walters and Roy Scheider, died of heart failure Monday in Marina del Rey, Calif., while on vacation. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cuomo Education Budget Draws Wide Criticism
description: Governor Mario M. Cuomo's proposed $11.3 billion budget for education, if adopted by the Legislature, would mean faculty layoffs, program cuts and dramatic increases in local property taxes across the state, education officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Citizen Watch Leaving Levine
description: After six years, Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has lost one of its showcase accounts, the Citizen Watch Company of America, to Young & Rubicam and HDM.

title: Chamber Music Society Sets New-Season Plans
description: Fred Sherry, the cellist who will become the artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in the fall, announced plans for his first season at the society's helm at a news conference yesterday.

title: Sen. Gordon Allott, 83, Pushed for Water Projects
description: Former United States Senator Gordon Allott, who during 18 years in the Senate helped push through water projects instrumental to the economic development of Colorado and Arizona, died of cancer today. He was 82 years old and lived most of his life in Englewood.

title: Peoples Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Dublin Journal; Fair Is City but Foul Is Air When Smog Creeps In
description: The smog creeps menacingly through doors and windows here. It attacks throats and lungs. It sometimes invades Dublin to such a degree that night appears to fall by midday.

title: 2 Executives Leave Salomon
description: Two senior executives have resigned from Salomon Brothers Inc., the securities firm has announced.

title: Lessons
description: Most societies have some sort of rite of passage from childhood to adulthood. The aborigine in Australia send adolescents into the wilderness on a ''walkabout.'' German noblemen prove their maturity by acquiring dueling scars.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Washington is quiet now except for the background hum of knives being sharpened.'' - Robert Lichter, a political scientist. [ A15:2. ]

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chevrolet and Pontiac, two units of General Motors Corp., Detroit, said they would offer 4.9 percent financing on selected models.

title: Birmingham Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Defaults Up On Debts Owed U.S.
description: Delinquent debts that farmers, students, veterans and taxpayers owe the Federal Government have more than doubled in the Reagan years despite stepped-up efforts to curb it, the White House is expected to report later this week.

title: Hillenbrand Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about foreign reaction to Emperor Hirohito's death misidentified a South Korean official who visited the Japanese Embassy in Seoul to sign a book of condolences.

title: Lloyd Bentsen Sr., 95, the Father Of Texas Senator, Killed in Crash
description: Lloyd Bentsen Sr., the millionaire rancher whose son. Lloyd Jr., was the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee in 1988, was killed early this morning in a traffic accident in Edinburg, Tex. He was 95 years old.

title: Mayors Hopeful on Homeless
description: The nation's mayors expressed guarded optimism today that the problems of homelessness and hunger in the cities had finally stabilized.

title: Review/Theater; Medieval Mystery Plays, As Performed to Music
description: Handed down through centuries, the Medieval Mystery Plays are a native folk art in England, France and Germany. There are so many cycles and so many directorial interpretations of Bible stories that one always looks for a fresh perspective. This, unfortunately, is not forthcoming in ''Genesis: Music and Miracles from the Medieval Mystery Plays,'' an unimaginative storybook version of biblical highlights that opened last night at the Public Theater.

title: RECOMMENDED FEES AND FINE CHANGES
description: Some increases from the budget proposed yesterday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo

title: The Big Cleanup Push Will Take Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Luggage Holder in Pan Am Bombing Found
description: The police investigating the explosion that destroyed a Pan Am Boeing 747 over Scotland last month said today that they had identified the luggage container in which the bomb was placed.

title: An Executive Director Is Chosen at Bellevue
description: The executive director of the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst was named the executive director of the Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Damon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included costs of $1,874,000 related to the company's defense against an unsolicited tender offer. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $234,837. The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect Damon Biotech Inc., a majority owned unit, as a discontinued operation.

title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road
description: A man riding in a car that was pulled over for speeding on the New Jersey Turnpike was killed today while struggling with a state trooper over a gun.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Agreed to terms with Zane Smith, pitcher, on a one-year contract. CHICAGO (NL) - Agreed to terms with Shawon Dunston, shortstop, and Al Nipper, pitcher, on one-year contracts. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Signed Claudell Washington, outfielder, to a three-year contract. CLEVELAND (AL) - Agreed to terms with Neil Allen, pitcher, on a one-year contract. METS (NL) - Agreed to terms with Edwin Nunez, pitcher, on a one-year contract. MINNESOTA (AL) - Traded Gary Borg, outfielder, to Milwaukee for Gerry Barragan, shortstop. SEATTLE (AL) - Agreed to terms with Alvin Davis, first baseman, on a three-year contract. TORONTO (AL) - Agreed to terms with John Cerutti, on a one-year contract. COLLEGES COLUMBIA - Named Ray Tellier head football coach. OTTOWA - Named David Dallas head football coach. RICE - Named Fred Goldsmith head football coach. SOUTHWESTERN LOUISIANA - Announced the resignation of Dave Culley, assistant football coach, to become offensive coordinator at Texas-El Paso. FOOTBALL PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Named Jon Kolb, special teams coach, the team's conditioning and strength coordinator. HOCKEY ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Sent Glen Featherstone, defenseman, to Peoria of the International League.

title: Lavish Inauguration Nearly Ready
description: In the Pentagon, a two-star general commands a legion of 8,500 military people for temporary duty as planners, parade marshals and chauffeurs. On a street corner near the White House, Alfonso Benjamin Hayden Dixon holds sway over a set of commemorative buttons that he hawks to passing tourists.

title: How to Obtain State Budget
description: Copies of the 1990 New York State Budget, which run about 700 pages, are bing sold to the public for the first time. The cost to the state is $20 per copy, but they will be sold for $10 each, and 3,000 copies are available. Legislators, libraries and journalists will still receive free copies. To obtain a copy, send $10 to Paul Fisk, Budget Services Unit, Room 117, State Capitol, Albany, N.Y., 12224.

title: Bush's Domestic Policy Team Is All Set, but Not the Agenda
description: George Bush ascends to the Oval Office this Friday having made a broad set of domestic policy promises: to clean up the environment, fight drug abuse, improve education and make day care more affordable for the poor.

title: Oren C. Herwitz, Lawyer, 81
description: Oren C. Herwitz, a retired lawyer and a former New York City official, died of cancer Monday at his home on Treasure Island, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: Reagan's Final Rating Is Best Of Any President Since 40's
description: As President Reagan prepares to leave office this week, two-thirds of the American people approve his performance over the last eight years, the highest rating given any President at the end of his term since World War II.

title: Marriott in Venture With Soviet Airline
description: The Soviet airline Aeroflot and the Marriott Corporation announced a venture to supply about 10,000 meals a day to Aeroflot passengers. The catering operation would be the first in the Soviet Union to involve a Western concern, the companies said.

title: For TV, a Festival of Glowing Images
description: George Bush's inauguration will be a festival of glowing television images aimed at bringing him the final step out of Ronald Reagan's shadow and burnishing away the remaining political scars from an election campaign dominated by harsh television commercials.

title: Nunez Agrees to Terms
description: The Mets reduced their salary-arbitration list to eight yesterday when they reached agreement on a 1989 contract with Edwin Nunez, a relief pitcher, who was purchased from the Seattle Mariners last July. The terms were not disclosed, but Nunez was believed to have signed for one year for a slight raise over the $310,000 he earned last season. Nunez, a 25-year-old right-hander, pitched only 14 innings in 10 games for the Mets, then tore the ligaments in his right thumb in a fall on Sept. 17 and underwent surgery three days later.

title: A Macklowe Cloud Over New York
description: The saga of Harry Macklowe's midtown Manhattan hotel, a melodrama complete with dangerous dead-of-night intrigue, has turned into an indictment of New York City government.

title: Federal National Mortgage Association reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a non-recurring credit of $135 million relating to the retroactive implementation in 1987 of a new accounting standard for both the quarter and year. Without the credit, net would have been $60 million, or 75 cents a share, for the quarter and $242 million, or $2.98 a share, for the year. The company said the earnings for 1988 reflect a tax rate of 34 percent compared with 40 percent in 1987.

title: Books of The Times; American Suburbs and How and Why They Grew
description: Borderland Origins of the American Suburb, 1820-1939 By John R. Stilgoe Illustrated. 353 pages. Yale University Press. $35.

title: Metro Datelines; Bird and 10 Snakes Stolen From 2 Shops
description: Ten snakes, two iguanas and a $1,400 cockatoo have been stolen from two pet shops in Nassau County, the police said yesterday. It was not known if the two thefts were related.

title: Five Children Killed As Gunman Attacks A California School
description: A young drifter dressed in military fatigues opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle at children playing outside and others inside an elementary school today. Five children between 6 and 9 years old, all of them refugees from Southeast Asia, were killed and more than 30 people were wounded, about half of them critically, before the gunman shot himself to death.

title:
EDUCATION;
Students Succeed With Lectins and Craters
description: LEAD: New York City continued its imposing dominance of the prestigious Westinghouse science prizes, placing more than a third of the semi-finalists selected.

title: Economic Scene; Saving Energy: The Big Chill
description: IMAGINE a technical fix that would conserve two billion barrels of oil, eliminate the need to build 14 Shoreham-sized power plants, slow the carbon dioxide buildup in the atmosphere - and still save consumers tens of billions of dollars.

title: King World Productions Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Equimark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year included a special net gain of $5,028,000, or 50 cents a share. The company realized a gain of $24,215,000 from the sale of its credit card portfolio and $1,878,000 from the receipt of previously unaccrued interest payments from Brazilian debtors. The above gains were partially offset by an increase in the provision for possible loan losses of $11,336,000; expenses of $2,616,000 to adjust non-performing real estate properties to net realizable values and to provide for the cost of a recent litigation settlement; a charge for $2,229,000 to reflect the expected reduction in the future yield and cash flow of an investment hedge; costs of $2.2 million related to the repurchase of Equimark stock, and other costs of $2,684,000. Equimark said its provision for possible loan losses, exclusive of items related to the special net gain, was $26,090,000 in 1988, compared to $20,864,000 in 1987.

title: Strains Among the Children of Privilege
description: EVEN now, almost three months after the accident, there are straggly bouquets of flowers at the base of the big coral tree at 11th Street and San Vicente Boulevard in Santa Monica. The tree has become the unofficial tombstone of the four teen-agers who died when their speeding car plowed into it the night of Oct. 28 and exploded in flames.

title: Drought Alert Is Declared In Echo of '85
description: New York City and Westchester County jointly declared a ''drought watch'' yesterday, and the Delaware River Basin Commission, from which New York City receives about half its water, went a step further by declaring a ''drought warning.''

title: Review/Dance; Isadora Duncan's Legacy
description: One of the most amazing theatrical illusions is spontaneity. Isadora Duncan, the great pioneer of modern dance, must have known how to create it, for she so enthralled audiences that many assumed her choreography was improvised. But the dances by Duncan preserved by her disciples after her death in 1927 are as precise in form as they are eloquent in content.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Lincoln's Inaugural Feast The menu for Abraham Lincoln's inaugural luncheon in 1861 consisted of mock turtle soup, corned beef and cabbage, parsley potatoes, blackberry pie and coffee. It was held at the Willard Hotel across from the White House.

title: Excerpts From Baker's Testimony Before Senate Committee
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by James A. Baker 3d, the nominee for Secretary of State, at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The testimony was recorded by The New York Times, through the facilities of C-Span, and by the Federal News Service. OPENING STATEMENT

title: Yanks Lose Washington To 3-Year Angels Deal
description: In the midst of a feud between the owner and the star right fielder, the Yankees lost their center fielder yesterday when Claudell Washington signed as a free agent with the California Angels and nearly doubled his annual pay with a three-year contract for $2.625 million.

title: Budget Plan Burdens New York City, Its Officials Say
description: New York City officials, citing the new burdens they would shoulder for education and medical care, said today that Governor Mario M. Cuomo had underestimated how onerous his proposed budget would be to the city. They vowed to lobby for major changes in the budget.

title: McTear Pleads Guilty
description: Houston McTear, a former record-holder in the 100-yard dash when world records were recognized in that event, pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of selling cocaine and will be sentenced in Santa Monica (Calif.) Superior Court Jan. 31. McTear was arrested by the Santa Monica police last fall and charged with selling cocaine in a park. McTear, who was clocked in 9.0 seconds for the 100 in 1975, plans to begin a track comeback when he competes in the Sunkist Invitational Friday at the Sports Arena in Santa Monica, Calif.(AP)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 The Secretary of State-designate, James Baker 3d, said that the United States has an interest in seeing Mikhail Gorbachev succeed, but should avoid ''a headlong rush'' to provide loans and credits. Page A1

title: In U.S., Slim Expectations
description: The American public strongly supports United States talks with Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization, but entertains little hope that either the P.L.O. or Israel will make the real concessions needed to achieve peace in the Middle East, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Magazine And Retailer Join Forces
description: THE nation's largest women's magazine, Family Circle, and the second-largest retail chain, K Mart, have joined with a popular taste maker in a multimillion-dollar program to enhance the retailer's image through advertising and editorial coverage.

title: Rockwell's Trial Is Delayed
description: The start of the Rockwell International Corporation's trial on charges of overbilling the Air Force on a navigation-satellite contract was delayed today after the company and Federal prosecutors apparently made progress in negotiating an out-of-court settlement.

title: Icahn Raises Texaco Stake
description: Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that he owned 40.47 million shares of Texaco Inc., or 16.6 percent. The New York financier had previously reported a stake of 16.2 percent.

title: Metro Datelines; Two Armed Robbers Killed by a Grocer
description: Two holdup men were shot to death by a grocer during an attempted robbery of a store in the High Bridge section of the Bronx last night, the police said.

title: Soviet Pullout Is Said to Be Brisk As Afghan Deadline Gets Nearer
description: Soviet troops have been leaving Afghanistan by the hundreds in daily airlifts from Kabul, the Afghan capital, Western diplomats said here today.

title: RPM Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Craft House Corp. in March 1988.

title: Polish Party Eases Stance on Solidarity
description: Poland's Communist Party approved a complex plan early today that if accepted would lead to the legalization of the outlawed Solidarity labor union. But it contained conditions that senior Solidarity advisers have said make it virtually impossible to accept.

title: Morgan, J P & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1987 included a $875 million second quarter provision for credit losses. The provision for credit losses for the latest periods totaled $100 million for the quarter and $200 million for the year, compared with year-ago periods of $30 million for the quarter and $960 million for 1987.

title: Columbia Fellows to Include Soviets
description: Columbia University will establish a graduate fellowship program next fall in American and international studies with students from the United States, the Soviet Union and four other countries, school officials say.

title: About New York; In This Corner, Wearing Heels And a Tiara . . .
description: People have been hitting each other and calling it sport for 3,500 years. For what seemed clear and sufficent reason, boxing has been a male preserve.

title: Nova Scotia Yield at 9.51%
description: The Province of Nova Scotia priced $200 million worth of long-term bonds yesterday through a syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Shultz Accuses East Bloc on Rights
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz asserted today that some countries in Eastern Europe, especially Czechoslovakia and Rumania, were abusing human rights even as they signed a major international agreement promising to respect such rights.

title: Smith Barney Will Re-enter Risk Arbitrage Deals Feb. 1
description: Smith Barney Inc., the big securities firm owned by the Primerica Corporation, will announce today that it plans to re-enter the risk arbitrage business on Feb. 1, Frank Zarb, the company's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Australian Dollar Offering by Unisys
description: The Unisys Financial Corporation priced a $75 million (Australian) note offering.

title: The Pop Life
description: Tallying the Hits ''My image is that I have no image except that of an everyday person,'' Debbie Gibson said the other day. ''When I first signed with Atlantic Records, the people I was working with said I had to have one. They thought I should look older. But I asked why. I pointed out that guys in the business don't have to have an image, and that's one reason why they get taken more seriously. Look at Billy Joel.''

title: Lennar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Maxtor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Gramm-Rudman, With Half a Heart
description: A new administration is about to take power in Washington and, as it does, world financial markets join a chorus of domestic experts in warning us that we have to deal with our huge Federal budget deficits.

title: Triton Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $6,594,000 from the redemption of 13.5 percent notes due 1994. The company said oil-reserve values resulted in $10.8 million and $14.3 million in non-cash writedowns of capitalized costs for its fiscal 1989 second quarter and 6-month results, respectively.

title: A Bengal Remembers Overtown
description: Eddie Brown went back to his old neighborhoods on Monday but they looked closed, in more ways than one.

title: Intel's Net Down in Quarter
description: The Intel Corporation, a leading maker of computer chips, reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings had dropped 10.2 percent from a year ago. The company cited a decline in demand for its 80386 microprocessor, reflecting inventory buildup by personal computer manufacturers.

title: Review/Television; Diary of a Rain Forest and Its People
description: Phil Agland lived with the Baka in their tiny villge deep in a rain forest in southeastern Cameroon while making ''Baka: People of the Forest,'' and it shows. His close-in view of the day-to-day lives of the seminomadic Pygmy tribe awakens thoughts of our common humanity. The appealing National Geographic documentary can be seen at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 and 8 P.M. on Channels 21, 31 and 49.

title: First, You Break 4,800 Eggs
description: THE guests at one of the inaugural balls this week can have their 12-foot high cake, but they can't eat it, too.

title: A Salute to Pan Am Staff Following Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Hugh D. McCandless, 81, Ex-Rector of Church
description: The Rev. Dr. Hugh Douglas McCandless, rector emeritus of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany at York Avenue and 74th Street in Manhattan, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: A Salute to Pan Am Staff Following Crash; Christmas in Lockerbie
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Tie and Brown Betty: The Fun Begins
description: FIFTEEN security guards took their posts in the main hall of Union Station in Washington last night, awaiting this morning's commuters and Amtrak riders and keeping an eye on 5,400 pieces of china, 18,000 pieces of silverware and 6,300 pieces of glassware. Their tour of duty, which began at about 11 P.M., should end shortly before the arrival of the first dinner guests tonight.

title: At the Top: Domestic Policy
description: ROGER B. PORTER: Assistant to the President for Economic and Domestic Policy

title: Standard Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
For Now, No Changes in Prescribing Methods
description: DOCTORS at most family-planning groups and student health clinics surveyed said they did not plan to change guidelines for prescribing contraceptive pills in the wake of three new studies linking the pills with increased risks of breast cancer.

title: John Loder, 90, British Actor
description: John Loder, an actor whose tenure of more than 30 years in British and American movies was credited largely to his good looks and his imposing physique, has died in England. He was 90 years old and had homes in London and Buenos Aires.

title: Smith, A O Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,000,000 from an accounting change.

title: Community Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Close to Home
description: NOW that the Holland Hotel is finally closed there aren't so many of them around Times Square: the big-bellied girls in their makeshift maternity clothes. But they're elsewhere in the city, as many as there ever were, so young sometimes I wonder whatever drove them to sex. Surely not lust; it must have been a rite of passage. When I was their age my rite of passage was a tube of Tangee lipstick, bought out of an allowance of 75 cents a week and more contemplated than used.

title: Capital Mayor Is Subpoenaed In Federal Grand Jury Inquiry
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Mayor's conduct and a city contract with the Virgin Islands, an assistant to the Mayor indicated tonight.

title: Sterling Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $34,800 and $68,600 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Results for the prior year were restated to include discontinued operations and to reflect an accounting change.

title: Reagan in Retrospect, on 'Frontline'
description: ''Frontline'' bids farewell to the Reagan era tonight with a 90-minute exploration of ''The Real Life of Ronald Reagan.'' The title hints at a theme of Garry Wills's narration -that Mr. Reagan's own view of his career and the world often owed more to memories of the movies he played in or watched than to reality. The point is made early with a clip of the famous scene from ''Knute Rockne -All American'' in which Ronald Reagan, the actor, delivers his ''win this one for the Gipper'' line. And there is Ronald Reagan, the President, delivering it again at a rally.

title: Meridian Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cherokee Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss included net non-recurring pre-tax expenses of $1,915,000. The latest 6 months included non- recurring expenses of $4,309,000, related to the pending acquisition of the company by Green Acquisition Co. and the settlement of certain litigation and employment agreements, and a gain from the settlement of a fire insurance claim of $1,756,000.

title: American Capital Manageent & Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
International Business Mahines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Cost and expenses for the latest periods included a $270 million pre- tax charge in the fourth quarter and a pre-tax charge of $870 million in the year for estimated costs of consolidations and also earnings before income taxes included a $220 million payment for the same periods from Fujitsu to I.B.M. for a paid-up license and interest as a result of arbitration between the two companies. The latest year also included a net credit of $315 million, or 53 cents a share, taken in the first quarter, and representing the effects of Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No. 96., accounting for income tax purposes.

title: After Shooting, Horror but Few Answers
description: They fled the killing fields of Cambodia to bring up their children in the peaceful, fertile fields of the San Joaquin Valley of California. But today the thousands of Southeast Asian refugees who have settled here could only wonder in horror why a young American would walk into a schoolyard and open fire with an assault rifle.

title: US Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year included a gain from an accounting change of $8,834,000, or 22 cents a share.

title: RLC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from operations to be spun off of $430,000, or 2 cents a share, and $968,000, or 6 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively; the year-ago period also included a tax credit of $9,125,000.

title: Problems on Shuttle Resolved
description: Engineers have resolved the tile and engine problems of the last space shuttle flight, and the launching of the next shuttle has been set for Feb. 23, the Kennedy Space Center director said today. Forrest S. McCartney said damage to tiles on the shuttle Atlantis on its secret mission last month was caused by insulation that hit the shuttle in liftoff. The turbopump problems were unique to Atlantis's turbopump.

title: Irving Boroff, 80, Ex-Head of Special School
description: Irving M. Boroff, a retired New York school principal who devised innovative programs to deal with disruptive and other problem pupils, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: NEW FLAWS FOUND ON MISSILE SHIELD
description: A panel of the National Research Council said yesterday that proposed energy sources to power weapons for the Pentagon's space-based system to defend against missiles were ''unacceptably large,'' making them impracticable to launch into orbit.

title: Australian Trade Gain
description: Australia's broadest measure of trade improved in December, when the current account deficit fell to $941 million (Australian), or $809 million (United States), from $1.54 billion (Australian) in November, the Government said today. The current account measures trade in goods and services and is the nation's broadest measure of trade. It was the first time in six months that the deficit had dropped below $1 billion (Australian).

title: Yanks to Stay With Own Center Fielders
description: Despite the loss of Claudell Washington to the California Angels, despite the feud between George Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield and despite a lot of things in a time of tumult, the Yankees insisted yesterday that they were planning no wild forays into the trading market and would instead find a center fielder within their own ranks.

title: Two Receive Awards For Bush Campaign
description: Frankenberry, Laughlin & Constable, a Milwaukee ad agency, shared the top prize with Roger Ailes, President-elect George Bush's political media consultant, at the American Association of Political Consultants' Pollie Awards dinner in Washington last night.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN a furnace unexpectedly stops working or fails to start, there are several safe, simple procedures you can try before calling for professional service. Naturally, do not hesitate to call for service if you feel uncertain about how to proceed or if you suspect danger.

title: IPM Inc reports earnings for
State-O-Maine Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Kohl Attacked in Parliament on Libya Chemical Issue
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under sharp personal attack in Parliament today for his handling of the Libyan chemicals affair, while a senior aide to Mr. Kohl called the spread of chemical weapons to irresponsible governments a ''nightmare'' that must be stopped.

title: Chameleon on Plaid
description: Tergiversators, equivocationists and circumlocutionaries were filled with a warm (if ambivalent) glow this week as a world-class double-talker, nominated for Secretary of State, made monkeys out of the members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: National Convenience Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the 6 months was after a gain of $6,531,000 from an accounting change.

title: Reed Loses Temper As Nets Lose Game
description: So often, Willis Reed suffers silently on the Nets' bench, keeping his composure while watching another chance for victory slip away.

title: Fido, Captured in Paint
description: WHAT do Lady Emma Hamilton, Emily the pug and Otto and his mother have in common? All are cats or dogs that have had their portraits painted by Mimi Vang Olsen.

title: A 'Chilling Effect' On New Products
description: Slotting allowances - the practice among retailers of forcing vendors to pay for shelf space - is having a ''chilling effect'' on product introductions, a recent issue of Gorman's New Product News reported.

title: Raise for Galarraga
description: Andres Galarraga tripled his salary yesterday and Bobby Bonilla, Joe Hesketh, Wes Gardner and Kevin Mitchell doubled their paychecks. Galarraga and the Montreal Expos agreed to a one-year contract for $865,000, an increase from the $240,000 he made in 1988. Bonilla and the Pittsburgh Pirates agreed to a one-year contract for $730,000, a $485,000 raise. Hesketh and the Montreal Expos settled at $417,000, a $226,000 raise, while Gardner and the Boston Red Sox settled at $265,000, a $148,000 raise. Mitchell and the San Francisco Giants agreed at $535,000, a raise of $297,500. Bob Brenly, a free-agent catcher-infielder, signed a one-year contract worth $450,000 with the Toronto Blue Jays. (AP)

title: Zurn Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Western Customers, Chinese Tame Hot Colors
description: FOR East to meet West, sometimes only a change of palette is necessary.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bonnie Doon Inc., Stamford, Conn., a maker of women's and children's hosiery, named Martin B. Kramer president and chief executive.

title: Intermec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Both year-ago periods are restated to include the financial position and results of operations of Intermec- Southwest, acquired during the quarter ended June 30, 1988, and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: The Events on Inuaguration Day
description: All times are Eastern. 11:30 A.M. Swearing-in ceremony begins. 1:30 P.M. Inaugural parade. 8 P.M. Inaugural balls. Television Coverage ABC: 10:30 A.M. to 1 P.M., 2 to 3 P.M., on '20/20' at 10 P.M. and on 'Nightline' at 11:30 P.M. CBS: 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 2 to 4 P.M. NBC: 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 11:30 P.M. to midnight. CNN: 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. C-SPAN: 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M., 2 to 2:30 P.M. and starting at 9 P.M.

title: Digital Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Music; The Voices In Honor Of Dr. King
description: Symphony Saintpaulia and its associated choirs, the Voices Saintpaulia, made their Carnegie Hall debuts Monday night in a tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Saintpaulia is the African violet, and violet is one of the colors that leapt to mind as the rainbow richness of the choir's sound unfolded.

title: Fleet/Norstar Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for both 1988 and 1987 included Indian Head Banks Inc., Nashua, N.H., which was acquired by Fleet/Norstar on Dec. 21, 1988, while 1987 also reflected non-recurring charges recorded in the second and fourth quarters.

title: Chrysler Unit Set for Aircraft
description: The Chrysler Technologies Corporation, the smallest of the three operating units of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that it had established a subsidiary for the modification of military aircraft that would combine complementary units of its two other subsidiaries.

title: Carlucci Urges Growth in Military Spending
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci made a final appeal to Congress today for resuming the growth in military spending that was halted late in the Reagan Administration. He said that the Soviet Union still was a threat and that national security could be impaired if military budgets were cut or frozen.

title: Geodyne Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents total revenue.

title: Federal Judge Acting to Settle Lilco Suit Case
description: The Federal judge presiding over the racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company has intensified pressure on the representatives of the utility, its customers and Suffolk County to fashion a settlement that could lead to the closing of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Reviews/Television; When a Teen-Ager Takes a Stand
description: This afternoon's ''Taking a Stand'' should be considered required viewing for Ronald Reagan. Last week, the President wondered aloud if some civil-rights activists haven't been exaggerating the degree of racial prejudice in this country. The recent turmoil in Yonkers alone should have been enough to give him pause.

title: CCB Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.6 million from an accounting change.

title: Students Are Recalled With Sobs and Silences
description: In the arena where Syracuse University has celebrated its greatest victories with deafening roars, there were muffled sobs and eerie silences today as more than 10,000 people gathered to share an excruciating loss. Four weeks after 35 Syracuse students were killed aboard Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, today's grief was new and raw, as the families of the dead students exchanged snapshots of the children they had lost.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: How to Fix the Molding On Wooden Furniture
description: LEAD: Molding is the ornamental wood pattern found along a face of a piece of furniture. Because it rarely interferes with furniture's function, molding, like veneer, is seldom repaired on its own. But there are a few small repairs, easily done at home, that could be the ounce of prevention staving off the pound of cure.

title: Fidelity Savings Association reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said there is no per share information presented for year- ago period, as the association converted from mutual to stock ownership in July 1988, and had no shares of common stock issued and outstanding prior to that date.

title: Polaroid-Kodak Trial Is Delayed
description: The trial that will determine whether the Eastman Kodak Company will have to pay the Polaroid Corporation as much as $1 billion for violating Polaroid's instant-photography patents was postponed Tuesday until at least April 17. The trial had been scheduled to begin Tuesday in Boston, but all parties agreed to a postponement after a meeting with United States District Judge A. David Mazzone, a Kodak spokesman said. The case was delayed because Kodak is appealing rulings that it infringed the patents.

title: On the Agenda, Parting and Partying
description: Outside 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, workers were completing the stands for the inaugural parade on Friday. Inside the White House, a Marine Band played ''Auld Lang Syne'' in the East Room as Nancy Reagan cried and Ronald Reagan blinked back tears.

title: Suspended 5 'Down Here On Business'
description: rrFrom a dock on Biscayne Bay, the United States Customs speedboats roar off to chase the cocaine smugglers. On Miami Avenue, a store sign, apparently in descending order of importance, blares: ''Lotto, Checks Cashed, Guns and Ammo, Hardware.'' Along Interstate 95 through downtown, blue flares and blue lights atop police cars block ramps near the Overtown area, seething from the fatal shooting Monday night of a speeding motorcyclist by a policeman.

title: Rangers Are Glad to Win Big One Against the Blackhawks
description: Tony Granato had just put the puck past Ed Belfour of the Blackhawks to secure a 6-4 triumph for the Rangers and complete the third hat trick of his wondrous rookie season. Suddenly, a lone hat floated out of the stands and over the end boards.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Most of the time my toilet flushes fine, but occasionally the water swirls around and won't flush completely. In fact, sometimes the water keeps rising until it almost reaches the rim of the bowl. The ballcock inside the tank is adjusted properly and the flapper valve is working fine. There is no leakage. I have used a chemical drain-cleaner and have tried cleaning out the holes under the rim. Any suggestions?

title: South African Leader Has 'Mild Stroke'
description: President P. W. Botha, South Africa's leader for the last 10 years, suffered a ''mild stroke'' early today, a presidential spokesman said.

title: Pacific Gas Has Big Loss
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported today that it lost $487.1 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Lawyer Says 'Dying' Marcos Is Unfit for Trial
description: A lawyer for Ferdinand E. Marcos said yesterday that the former Philippine President's health had deteriorated so severely that he could not be arraigned on criminal charges and might be physically incapable of withstanding a trial.

title: Laclede Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,618,000 from an accounting change for the quarter and year. The year-ago periods also included total charges of $1,329,000 for the quarter and $2,329,000 for the year from certain payroll accruals and costs associated with a special retirement incentive. The year-earlier share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split that was effective in October.

title: Researchers Make Clotting Protein
description: A clotting protein made through genetic engineering appears promising for people with the bleeding disease hemophilia and would be more certainly free of contaminating viruses than current treatments, researchers say.

title: Two Trials Sought In Death of Jessica
description: The lawyer for Abigail Cortez asked yesterday for separate trials for Mrs. Cortez and Adrian Lopez, both of whom are charged in the death of 5-year-old Jessica Cortez.

title: Dollar Up In Spite of Trade Data
description: The dollar surged yesterday, ignoring the negative economic news in the widening trade deficit and another round of central bank intervention.

title: Accounts
description: * Orangina USA, a soft-drink maker whose parent is Austin Nichols & Co., a subsidiary of Pernod-Ricard S.A., Paris, to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, with a budget of more than $2 million.

title: KEY RATES
The Palestinian Menace Has Been Exaggerated; Limitless Demands
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day to Celebrate
description: About 289,000 Federal employees have three reasons to celebrate this week: the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, President-elect Bush's inauguration and, because of the first two, a three-day work week.

title: Promotion at Lintas
description: In an effort to coordinate its European operations, Lintas: Worldwide has appointed Ingo Zuberbier chairman of Lintas: Europe and head of its newly formed European Executive Group. Mr. Zuberbier, who will continue as chairman of Lintas: Germany, will be responsible for the agency's 57 media and marketing operations in 16 countries.

title: Neighborhood Grants to Combat Drugs
description: To help make citizens the first line of defense in New York City's fight against drugs, a nonprofit organization will award grants to neighborhood groups with solid anti-drug programs.

title: Compromise on Leadership Reached by Retailers Group
description: After a four-day convention marked by opposition between large retail members and small ones, the directors of the National Retail Merchants Association moved to smooth things over yesterday by appointing a small-store merchant as its new chairman and a big-store chief executive as first vice chairman.

title: Georgetown Journal; Coach's Private Battle On Night of Big Game
description: John Thompson is more than a basketball coach at Georgetown University. He is a symbol.

title: American Franchise Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HWC Distribution Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York State budget misstated the total spending proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for the coming fiscal year. It is $46.6 billion, not $46.4 billion.

title: Wave of Growth Planned at South Street Seaport
description: The South Street Seaport would take a big step northward, with the transformation of two gritty old waterfront blocks into a fancy new stretch of shops, offices and apartments, under an agreement announced yesterday between New York City and two private developers.

title: Officials Fear Shift of Taxes From Albany
