description: One day after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo made public his $46.6 billion state spending plan, many state lawmakers and local government officials said that if the plan were enacted, New Yorkers would be spared increases in their state taxes only to see them show up on their local tax bills.

title: First Virginia Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Cabaret; Hildegarde, Still Kinetic
description: ''The Incomparable Hildegarde,'' as this singer from Milwaukee has been billed for many years, is now, at the age of 83, not only beyond comparison but is seemingly unquenchable. In the new cabaret room Rainbow and Stars, on the 65th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, she is singing, playing piano, bouncing around the tiny stage and expending enough energy to exhaust someone half her age.

title: Judge Extends Order That U.S. Protect Dolphins
description: A Federal district judge has extended his order for American tuna fishing boats to carry Government observers to see that efforts are made to prevent the killing of dolphins that become caught in the boats' nets.

title: Chemical Weapons Talks Facing Tough Hurdles
description: Although a powerful international spotlight has been trained on them, negotiations here to ban the production, stockpiling and use of chemical weapons face formidable hurdles before delegates can complete a draft treaty, diplomats and specialists say.

title: Steel Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Tennessee National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods included charges of $7,888,000 for the quarter and $15,509,000 for the year on loan loss provisions for lesser developed countries loans, and gains of $401,000, or 2 cents a share, and $4,959,000, or 32 cents a share, for the same periods, respectively, for partial settlement of pension plan liabilities. The year also included a gain of $1,439,000, or 8 cents a share, for a tax recovery.

title: Bribes and Babies
description: ''Boys don't like it too much when you have to take your baby on dates.'' It sounds like a line from a TV situation comedy. In fact it comes from real life, from a Denver 17-year-old named Rita Lafoya, and the situation she describes is nothing to laugh at. Miss Lafoya is the mother of a 20-month-old boy, which is hard, she says, ''because most of my freedom is gone.''

title: U.S. to End Protection Of 6 Kuwaiti Tankers
description: In a sign of the continuing reduction of tensions in the Persian Gulf, the United States has decided to phase out its naval protection of 6 out of 11 Kuwaiti tankers that have flown the American flag since mid-1987, State Department officials said today.

title: Jacobs Engineering Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Excerpts From Interview With Reagan, Looking Back on His Presidency
description: Following are excerpts of an interview with President Reagan in the White House today by print journalists: The Hostage Situation

title: S.E.C.-Drexel Negotiations Are Said to Be at Impasse
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. are at an impasse over how to settle the charges of securities law violations against the firm, a person directly involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Collagen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $56,000 for the quarter and $241,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss The latest 6 months' net from operations included a one-time payment of $1 million from Bristol-Myers Co. during the first quarter.

title: At Library, a Room for the Homeless
description: WHEN the new public library in Haverhill, Mass., opens in 1992, it will include a room designed specifically for homeless people. The 60,000-square-foot library is part of a civic center, shown above, being designed by Mark Mitchell Associates of Hanover, N.H. Haverhill is in the northeastern part of the state.

title: UST Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United Jersey Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Calendar: Antiques On View
description: Nine Days of Antiques, Seventh Avenue Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; 212-665-5250.

title: Reservation's Taxes May End Detours for Cheap Gas
description: Each day hundreds of people stop briefly just inside the reservation here near the shore of Lake Erie. Most are truck drivers or cigarette smokers looking for bargains.

title: Valley National Phoenix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The net is after credit losses of $103.9 million in 1988 and $154.9 million in 1987. The allowance for credit losses at the end of 1988 was $178.8 million, compared with $195.1 million in 1987.

title: Miami Mayor Apologizes to Police For Actions at Scene of Disorder
description: Mayor Xavier Suarez said today that he regretted his handling of an incident that helped touch off race-related violence that continued this evening for a third night, and he issued a public apology to the police.

title: Parker Hannifin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1987 have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Gull Inc.

title: Central Bancshares of the South reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for 1987 and 1988 are restated to reflect a change in accounting for loan fees and origination costs in accordance with FAS No. 91.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Coastal Corporation's offer to buy the Texas Eastern Gas Corporation misstated terms of a deal between two other natural-gas companies. The Transco Energy Corporation has agreed to acquire the Texas Gas Transmission Company from the CSX Corporation.

title: At the Top: Congressional Movers
description: SAM NUNN: Chairman, Senate Armed Services Committee A 50-year-old native of the small south Georgia town of Perry who has spent 16 years in the Senate building an imposing reputation on national security issues . . . Often mentioned as a Presidential candidate . . . Graduate of Georgia Tech, with law degree from Emory University . . . Played critical role in ratification of Soviet-American treaty banning nuclear missiles of intermediate and shorter range; found loopholes, demanded and received Soviet clarifications, in dramatic demonstration of bipartisan power . . . Married, two children. DAN ROSTENKOWSKI: Chairman, House Ways and Means Committee A 61-year-old Chicagoan who stands at the center of any debate over new taxes . . . A 30-year veteran of the House with the safest of seats . . . Lifelong resident of Chicago's 32d Ward . . . Son of a Chicago alderman . . . Served in both houses of Illinois Legislature . . . Became Ways and Means chairman in 1981 . . . His shepherding of tax revision legislation in 1986 considered a Congressional masterwork . . . A golfer, a social animal, a storyteller and a brilliant deal maker . . . Married for 37 years, with four grown daughters. LLOYD BENTSEN: Chairman, Senate Finance Committee A 67-year-old Texan who returns to the Senate with enormous national recognition after his performance as running mate of Michael S. Dukakis . . . Some friends say it's still unclear how he will use his new clout, but he will play critical role on any new taxes . . . Will hold hearings early this year on the use of borrowed money to finance mergers and acquisitions . . . Patrician son of a wealthy landowner in the Rio Grande Valley . . . Graduate of the University of Texas . . . A decorated pilot in World War II . . . Married, three children. JIM WRIGHT: Speaker of the House A 66-year-old Texan whose first two-year term as Speaker was marked by major legislation but continuing controversy over ethics charges against him . . . Report by House ethics committee expected in a month . . . Native of Fort Worth . . . Educated in Texas public schools and at Weatherford College and University of Texas . . . Has been in the House 34 years . . . Noted for his old-fashioned speaking style . . . A student of history eager to leave a legislative legacy akin to that of Sam Rayburn, a personal hero . . . Married, four children. GEORGE J. MITCHELL: Senate Majority Leader A 55-year-old native of Maine who was handily elected Democratic leader in November . . . Rose to national prominence during Congressional hearings two years ago on Iran-contra affair . . . A former Federal judge and former Federal prosecutor . . . Educated at Bowdoin College and Georgetown University Law Center . . . Started political life as an aide to Senator Edmund S. Muskie . . . Appointed to the Senate to replace him when Mr. Muskie became Secretary of State, and elected twice subsequently . . . Divorced, one child. BOB DOLE: Senate Minority Leader A 65-year-old Kansan who became Republican leader in November 1984 . . . Former chairman of Senate Finance Committee . . . Gerald Ford's running mate in 1976, when his sharp-edged style drew criticism . . . A ''new'' Bob Dole ran for President in 1980 and again in 1988, but campaigns were plagued by organizational problems . . . Severely wounded while leading an assault on a German machine gun nest in Italy in 1945 . . . Married to Elizabeth Hanford Dole, President-elect George Bush's choice for Secretary of Labor.

title: Kimberly-Clark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Developer Drops Plan For Philadelphia Mall
description: A developer is abandoning his $120 million Penn's Landing mall and office project along the Delaware River about three months before its scheduled groundbreaking, calling it ''an expensive mistake.''

title: F.D.A. Backs Warner Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it had approved the Warner-Lambert Company's anti-cholesterol drug, Lopid, for use in reducing the risk of coronary heart disease.

title: Holiday Glow Won't Go Away
description: Christmas decorations still glow each night in downtown Delano because the Chamber of Commerce does not have the money to store them and pay for insurance. The lights have been plugged into city light poles since mid-November, so they turn on automatically every evening. ''It's very embarrassing to me,'' the chamber manager, Dorothy Knight, said Monday. ''It's bad for the image of the community.''

title: Continental Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The net income for 1988 included approximately $55 million in net after- tax gains from corporate restructuring, including $11 million from funds released from reserves after Continental's decision to leavemass-market retail banking and certain foreign operations. The latest periods' results also reflected $65 million in interest collections from Brazil and about $36 million of that was interest earned before 1988. This was partly offset by a $19 million reduction in interest revenue from the $271 million in Argentine loans placed on a non-performing basis in 1988. Continental said prior year earnings would have been $189.5 million, including $63.2 million for the fourth quarter, except for an unusual credit loss provision for loans to less developed countries of $700 million for the year and $200 million for the fourth quarter, and a $99 million provision in the 1987 fourth quarter and year for customer receivables.

title: Weapon Used by Deranged Man Is Easy to Buy
description: The Soviet-designed military assault rifle that a deranged man used to kill five schoolchildren in California and wound 30 others can be purchased as easily as an ordinary rifle or shotgun, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Lotus to Offer PC Software
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said yesterday that it would introduce a new kind of utility software designed to help personal computer users organize and retrieve information stored in computer files, including spreadsheets, word processing documents and data base files.

title: Jefferson Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacific Western Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: It's Israel's Move
description: For all his double-talk, Yasir Arafat has done enough in recent weeks - including apparently halting terror operations - to put the burden of the next move on Israel. That's clearly the private sentiment among many people in Congress and incoming Bush administration officials.

title: Bengals' Krumrie Carries the Load
description: Most football players train by lifting weights. Tim Krumrie lifts an anvil.

title: Southtrust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Homework Reminders Given By Phone
description: A PROFESSOR of education at Vanderbilt University has come up with a way for schools to increase communication between busy parents and teachers through the use of telephone-answering machines.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rally
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds staged a rally in active trading yesterday, bolstered by the dollar, which rose despite a trade report that showed the merchandise trade deficit widening substantially in November.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the MCI Communications Corporation misstated some of the company's price reductions. The cost of sending electronic messages and domestic facsimile documents has been reduced as much as 75 percent. Under one plan, the cost of sending an electronic message will be 25 cents for each of the first 40 messages of no more than 7,500 characters.

title: Manning on Mend
description: Danny Manning, the Los Angeles Clippers rookie forward, was released from Centinela Hospital in Inglewood, Calif., yesterday, four days after undergoing reconstructive surgery on his right knee. Manning will undergo a rehabilitation program at the Kerlan-Jobe Orthopedic Clinic for the next 9 to 12 months, the Clippers' general manager, Elgin Baylor, said. (AP)

title: Bridge
description: Every beginner is taught to select a four-four major suit fit rather than play in no-trump. There are rare exceptions, and it is possible to have hands with a five-four fit on which no-trump is preferable. But eschew a five-five major suit fit? Never.

title: Amid Uneasiness, Super Bowl Visitors Stream In
description: The visitors at the airport arrived bearing golf clubs, tennis racquets and caps with Bengals and 49ers logos. They had reservations at hotels, but only limited reservations about coming to the Super Bowl at a time of civil disturbances.

title: St. John's Holds On to Edge Rutgers
description: St. John's ran up leads of 10 points against Rutgers twice during tonight's second game of a doubleheader at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and held on to win by 62-61 before a crowd of 6,691.

title: Moscow Journal; Prying Where It Counts: Into the Soviet Census
description: In a high-rise apartment complex in the Proletarsky district of Moscow, a census-taker handed a 75-year-old woman a card listing sources of income. After an awkward moment, the woman admitted she could not read it.

title: Caution Urged Over AIDS Partners
description: The health authorities should use caution in notifying the sexual partners of people infected with the AIDS virus, officials from 20 countries have concluded.

description: President-elect George Bush today announced his intention to nominate a New York pharmaceutical executive, Bruce S. Gelb, as director of the United States Information Agency, which oversees the Voice of America and international cultural programs.

title: Review/Ballet; A Debut With 'Jewels'
description: Thanks to some polished dancing by the New York City Ballet, George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' glowed on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater when a new cast took over many of the principal roles in the three-act spectacle.

title: Many Species Are Still Threatened Despite Law, U.S. Agency Reports
description: The Federal program that is supposed to protect threatened plants and animals is fraught with problems, the General Accounting Office reported today, and a third of the 500 species listed as in peril continue to fade toward extinction.

title: Republic New York Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for 1987 included losses of $83.8 million on lesser developed country (LDC) debt, a special loan loss provision for LDC's of $110 million and an extraordinary loss, net of tax benefit, on the early extinguishment of long-term debt of $15.9 million. The provision for loan losses declined from $140 million in 1987 to $41.5 million in 1988. In 1987 special provisions for loan losses of $110 million were provided, compared with $25 million in 1988. The corporation's normal loan loss provision declined from $30 million in 1987 to $16.5 million in 1988.

title: ATWATER ELECTED CHAIRMAN OF G.O.P.
description: Lee Atwater, who enhanced his street-fighter reputation as Vice President George Bush's campaign manager, today was elected chairman of the Republican National Committee and immediately sounded the battle cry for the party's next big challenge: Congressional redistricting.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section yesterday about breast cancer misstated the affiliation of Dr. Selig Strax. He is medical director of the Guttman Breast Diagnostic Institute.

title: James W. Cooper, 84, Retired Bar Official
description: James Wayne Cooper, a retired lawyer and former president of the Connecticut Bar Association, died of cardiac arrest Monday at his home in Woodbridge, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Pilgrim's Pride Stock Soars
description: The share price of the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation soared $1.50 today, to close at $7.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Circulation Power Play By Magazine
description: IN New York, they say, money is power. In Washington, they add, power is power, a tautology that perhaps explains why poorly paid Senate aides are nevertheless feared.

title: Cross Says He Is Going to Retire
description: Randy Cross, the offensive lineman who has been with the San Francisco 49ers longer than Coach Bill Walsh, announced his retirement today. ''I can think of no better way to end a career,'' Cross said. ''It's the way you dream of ending your career.''

title: RABIN AT CENTER OF ISRAELI STORM
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin walked out of a stormy debate in Parliament today after opposition members heckled him about increased bloodshed in the occupied territories and demanded that he resign.

title: Market Place; More Visibility On O-T-C Orders
description: IF the purpose of a marketplace is to bring together buyers and sellers, the over-the-counter market in stocks has long had a weakness: It is completely possible for a prospective buyer and a prospective seller to be willing to trade at the same price, and for neither to be able to make the trade.

title: Papers Unsealed in RJR Nabisco Suit
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, one of the bondholders of RJR Nabisco that sued the company after its management began a leveraged buyout offer, concluded in confidential studies conducted in 1985 that all of the corporations in which it held bonds were open to such bids.

description: Scott Williams sparked the inside game, scoring 22 points to lead the 13th-ranked North Carolina to a stunning 91-71 upset of top-ranked Duke in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: How Khomeini Made Gorbachev See Red
description: The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, flushed when Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini told him Communism was an outdated relic, an Iranian cleric said today.

title: George Bush: In Search of A Mission
description: Candidate Bush turned out to be a surprise. President Bush may be a bigger one.

description: Toronto's claim to one of the best records on race relations of any major North American city has been shaken in the last week by scenes of anger and recrimination between the city's blacks and its overwhelmingly white police force.

description: At least 32 people were killed and 41 injured when a passenger train hit a crowded bus in northeastern China, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: When Chest Pains Have Nothing to Do With a Heart Attack
description: Severe, crushing pain in the chest is often a warning of an imminent heart attack, but in tens of thousands of people this frightening symptom has nothing to do with heart disease, scientists have concluded on the basis of new studies.

title: Life's Basic Problems Are Still Top Concern In the Nursing Homes
description: A new study indicates that residents of nursing homes are much more concerned about the daily problems of institutional living than with the loftier issues of death and dying that ethicists thought would be uppermost in their minds.

A Catalyst Among the Avant-Garde
description: LEAD: EXCEPT to a knowing few, Frederick Kiesler remains a shadowy figure in the history of modern architecture and design. Building very little, Mr. Kiesler, an architect, painter and sculptor, distinguished himself through a series of conceptual projects and exhibition designs executed primarily from 1923 to 1950.

title: Club Med Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Esquire Campaign
description: Esquire magazine has a new trade campaign that begins Monday and is about as far removed from advertising as it can get. The magazine is running three editorial pages, without any ad copy or sales chatter at all, in Adweek. It will continue the campaign through February. W. Randall Jones, Esquire's publisher, called it ''a subtle sell.'' A subtle way of telling its ad agency that it's unhappy with its work? Not at all, said Mr. Jones -the idea came from Kirshenbaum & Bond, Esquire's agency of record.

title: Ebb and Flow of Time and Tastes Reshape Kennedy's Grand Vision
description: In 1961, in what is now a legendary trip in the annals of urban planning as well as American politics, John F. Kennedy rode down Pennsylvania Avenue in his inaugural parade and was so appalled at the tawdry state of the boulevard connecting the Capitol to the White House that he set in motion plans to revive it.

title: Record for World Steel
description: World output of crude steel rose to an all-time high of 780 million metric tons last year as demand boomed in leading non-Communist industrialized countries and developing nations opened new plants. The International Iron and Steel Institute said today that the figure was up 6 percent from 1987's level. The data are provisional and include output estimates for 14 nations. Developing countries recorded the biggest increase of any group, raising their output by 10.2 percent, to a record 96.6 million metric tons. Non-Communist industrialized nations increased production by 8.8 percent, to 487.6 million tons.

title: Say Again, Please
description: The Pentagon is known for being hooked on acronyms, abbreviations and jargon, but the members of the press who cover the Department of Defense are not immune to the affliction. At a recent briefing on the new military budget, a reporter sought this information:

title: India Lets Israeli Consulate Expand Diplomatic Activities
description: India said today that it had agreed to allow the Israeli Consulate in Bombay to expand its activities and represent the interests of a small group of Jewish families in the southern state of Kerala, where Jews have been living for more than a thousand years.

title: Gasoline Demand and Oil Price Rise
description: The price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil climbed to $19.26 a barrel yesterday, its highest level since November 1987. The 31-cent increase in the spot contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange was spurred in large part by sharply higher gasoline prices.

title: Ernie Blake, Ski Resort Owner, 75

title: Hershiser Complains
description: He may be a sentimental hero to Dodger fans, but the way Orel Hershiser sees it, to the Dodger management he is just another business asset that may be getting too expensive to keep. The pitcher, who was named as the most valuable player in both the National League playoffs and the World Series, told a Los Angeles radio station that although he wanted to remain with the Dodgers he had become so disenchanted with negotiations for a new contract that he was beginning to think of becoming a free agent after next season and moving to a new team. ''If we sign a one-year deal, that's definitely an option in the future,'' he said. Unable to come to terms on a multiyear pact, Hershiser, who made $1.1 million last season, filed for salary arbitration and is to exchange salary figures with the Dodgers today. The Dodgers have not been commenting publicly on the talks, but, as Hershiser pointed out, the team has not hesitated to lose such popular stars as Steve Garvey and Steve Sax rather than meet their salary demands. ''Business is business,'' Hershiser said. ''We really start to find out that the sentimentality of baseball isn't always there.'' (AP)

title: Southmark's 2 Top Officers Step Down
description: The Southmark Corporation said today that its two top officers and major shareholders, Gene E. Phillips and William S. Friedman, had resigned from the ailing real estate and financial services company and several affiliates.

title: Review/Operetta; 'H.M.S. Pinafore' Sails In
description: The English Savoyard tradition is undergoing a sea change, with London companies being reorganized, and hallowed, not to say creaky, performance styles being rethought. Yet judging from the cheerful but rather becalmed production of ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' by the New Sadler's Wells Opera, which opened Tuesday night at the City Center for a 12-day run, a little more flair would still be welcome.

title: Life at the Top: Even the Weather Is Different
description: ''YOU'RE the top! You're the Colosseum,'' the song lyric goes. But the Colosseum stands only 160 feet tall, and the forgotten-but-not-gone New York Coliseum is a mere 102. With apartment buildings climbing 50, 60 and even 70 stories, the top is closer to the clouds than the Romans or Cole Porter ever dreamed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Federal Reserve said it would allow banking companies to raise money for corporations in the bond market. The decision breaks down part of the wall that has separated banking and the securities business since 1933 - the Glass-Steagall Act. [ Page A1. ] The nation's trade deficit widened substantially in November, to $12.5 billion, as exports declined and imports surged to the second-highest level on record, the Commerce Department reported. Administration officials and private economists called the increase a serious disappointment. [ A1. ] Japan reported that its trade surplus rose in December to $9.65 billion, a record. [ D26. ] U.S. industry operated at its highest rate in nine years last month, the Federal Reserve reported, but analysts said the modest growth should allay fears that inflation is rising. [ D26. ] COMPANIES Kidder, Peabody will shortly announce a major reorganization that includes the appointment of a new chief executive, Wall Street analysts and executives said. Speculation on a new chief centered on a 41-year-old executive vice president of G.E. Capital. [ D1. ] The S.E.C. and Drexel Burnham Lambert are at an impasse over how to settle the charges of securities law violations against the firm, a person directly involved in the case said. The stumbling block is over the issue of moving its junk bond unit. [ D1. ] I.B.M. reported that its fourth-quarter net income rose 12.4 percent from a year earlier, below some analysts' expectations. [ D2. ] The sale of Eastern Airlines' shuttle was tentatively approved by the Transportation Department, a gain for Donald Trump. [ D2. ] A claim against RJR Nabisco is likely to be damaged by papers unsealed in court in the lawsuit filed by two life insurers. [ D5. ] Rockwell International agreed to plead guilty to charges of overbilling the Air Force on a navigation-satellite contract. [ D8. ] The National Retail Merchants Association appointed a small-store merchant and a big-store executive to two top posts. [ D26. ] Panasonic has agreed to return as much as $16 million to consumers to settle charges of price-fixing. [ A1. ] Two top officers of Southmark resigned from the ailing real estate and financial services company and some of its affiliates. [ D5. ] Two brewers are merging North American operations: Molson and Carling O'Keefe, both makers of popular Canadian beers. [ D5. ] MARKETS The dollar surged, ignoring both the negative economic news in the widening United States trade deficit and another round of central bank intervention. In late trading, the dollar was at a three-month high against the mark and the Japanese yen. [ D1. ] The Reagan Administration and President-elect Bush are unconcerned about the rise of the dollar in recent weeks, including a new spurt today, a senior Treasury official indicated. [ D20. ] The price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil climbed to $19.26 a barrel, its highest level since November 1987. The 31-cent increase came in part from sharply higher gasoline prices. [ D1. ] The Dow jumped 24.11 points, to 2,238.75, another post-crash high. The spurt was attributed to a rising dollar and a report that the November trade deficit was much higher than expected. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasuries rallied in active trading, bolstered by the dollar. Credit Markets. [ D18. ] Yields rose on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A group led by William Zeckendorf Jr. rented 90 percent of a new office tower and residential complex in midtown Manhattan by offering incentives to attract tenants. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The over-the-counter market is making a change tomorrow in the way it matches buyers and sellers. Market Place. [ D10. ]

description: * Cop Shot (Citizens Outraged at Police Being Shot) is receiving $500,000 in bus shelter ad space provided by Gannett Transit to advertise its award program.

title: Stone & Webster Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $8,577,000, or $1.13 a share, from sale of investment securities. Revenue represented gross earnings, and the gross earnings for the latest year included $12,585,000 from the sale of investment securities.

title: GBC Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter included $243,000 writedown of data processing equipment.

title: Jones Goes for 3d Straight
description: Steve Jones, who says he is not nervous about it, can become the first man in 11 years to win three consecutive tournaments on the PGA Tour. All he has to do is beat 143 other tour pros in the Phoenix Open, which begins Thursday and ends Sunday at the Tournament Players Club of Scottsdale. No one has been able to put together three consecutive tour victories since Gary Player won the Masters, the Tournament of Champions and the Houston Open in the spring of 1978.

title: Stoneridge Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represented operating revenue.

title: Grocer Is Charged In Killing of Robbers
description: The owner of a small grocery store in the Bronx was charged yesterday with a misdemeanor weapons violation after he fired at three armed men who were trying to hold up his store, killing two of them, the police said.

title: Arco Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Angola Strife Rages Around Phantom City
description: Onlookers in this besieged highland city craned their necks today as a Soviet cargo jet climbed in a steep spiral, spewing burning white flares from its underbelly.

title: Apple Offers New Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. introduced the Macintosh SE/30 today, a new computer that packs much of the power of the top-of-the-line Macintosh IIX into the smaller housing of the original Macintosh.

title: 2 V.M.I. Cadets Seized in Big Holdup
description: Two cadets at Virginia Military Institute and a father of one of the cadets were arrested yesterday by Federal agents and charged in the armed robbery of $4.5 million from an armored car in Clifton, N.J., last month.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD DISPUTED SYSTEM OF U.S. SENTENCING
description: The Supreme Court, ending a year of turmoil in the lower Federal courts, today upheld the new Federal system for sentencing convicted criminals.

title: U.S. Says It Has Tape of Arafat Threat
description: Despite denials that Yasir Arafat had made any threats, the State Department said today that it had a tape recording by the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman made on New Year's Day that amounted to a threat to moderate Arabs and strayed from Mr. Arafat's commitment to renounce terrorism.

title: Julian L. Greifer, Sociologist,87
description: Julian L. Greifer, a former social worker who was a professor emeritus of sociology at Temple University, died of internal bleeding Saturday at Arlington Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 87 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: First National Cincinnati Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Loss of Subsidy May Ground A Little-Used Georgia Flight
description: A dozen times a week, Flight 3323's engines crank into a throbbing whine and lift an 18-passenger turboprop out of one of the nation's busiest airports into one of air travel's loneliest routes.

title: Not Quite a Maze, Perhaps, but Amazing Nonetheless
description: IT doesn't matter that neither design is a bona fide medieval maze or an authentic Renaissance parterre. But hidden among the bricks and concrete of Manhattan, two carefully composed boxwood gardens aspire to emulate these historical forms. Despite limited space, the city folk who created them enjoy an elegant year-round pattern of green.

title: Advanced Marketing Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Estonia Votes to Make Its Language Official
description: The legislature of Estonia approved a law today giving Estonian precedence over Russian as the official language of the republic.

title: A.T.&T.-Dialcom
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Dialcom Inc. said that they had established the first commercial link between two domestic electronic mail services employing a new international standard designed to simplify computer-to-computer communications. The new standard, known as X.400, is a set of guidelines specifying the format, delivery and receipt of electronic messages recommended by an international standards body. As part of the agreement, the companies said that Federal Government users of A.T.&T. electronic mail as part of the FTS-2000 telecommunications contract would gain access to a series of Dialcom computer data bases.

title: Security Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
And Now a Few Words From President's Critics
description: ''We made a difference,'' President Reagan said in his farewell address last week, describing a nation ''more prosperous, more secure and happier than it was eight years ago.'' They are words that the President has repeated, with slight variation but with consistent enthusiasm, in a final round of interviews that have focused on the Reagan legacy.

title: Nissan Establishes U.S. Finance Unit
description: The Nissan Motor Company of Japan said it had established a financial subsidiary in New York that would complement those in London and Tokyo. The unit will give the auto maker 24-hour access to global financial markets.

title: Vanzetti Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Court Settles Insider Case
description: Two foreign nationals who were employed by the Upjohn Company today settled Federal civil charges that they had illegally traded Upjohn stock options while in possession of inside information that the Canadian Government had approved the company's anti-baldness medicine, Rogaine, for marketing in the fall of 1986.

title: First Peoples Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,123,000 and $5,293,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain related to a legal settlement of $2,312,000. c-Included tax credits of $1,015,000 for the quarter and $4,130,000 for the year. The company said 1987 fourth quarter and full year results are restated for an accounting change.

title: Excerpts From Baker's Testimony to Senate Foreign Relations Committee
description: Following are excerpts from testimony today by Secretary of State-designate James A. Baker 3d at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as recorded by the Federal News Service: Latin American Policy RICHARD G. LUGAR. How do you intend to take charge in the Latin American situation, or how are you going to manage, really, in the next two or three weeks, in which a good bit may happen? A. Well, I think, until Friday, Senator Lugar, the problem will continue to be managed by the outgoing Administration. If I am confirmed by this committee and by the Senate, I will, of course, be able to address - to give it some attention as of the date of that confirmation by the full Senate. There are people who are in the Department who are not - who will remain in the Department and who have been dealing with these problems for a considerable period of time and will be available to continue to deal with them during that transition period of whatever it is, five or six days. I don't know, under our system, what I can do in that period, if that's the gist of your question. Q. I'm afraid that things are drifting, and I don't really see, in the Department right now, the ability to handle any of this. And I'm -and this must be of some disturbance to your - A. Well, as you know, Senator, it is disturbing to me. As you know from my private visits with you and the other members of the committee, I don't see an issue coming at us any quicker than this one. I think it's going to be right on our doorstep when we take office. That's what I have said in my private visits with you, and that's why I think it's so extraordinarily important that we get together, as a Legislative and Executive Branch, on what our policy ought to be down there - get a unified policy and start implementing it, because these problems are not going to go away without it, and they're going to multiply. Middle East Peace NANCY LANDON KASSEBAUM. I just got back from a trip to the Middle East. . . . As often as I heard in the countries we visited that their support for an international peace conference and some type of comprehensive solution, I also was struck with really how far apart all the major players on what they really expect from the peace conference. . . . Are we not raising expectations too high about an event that may be just then argued as far as the shape of the table? And is it better to be seeking, perhaps, some smaller steps that could lend support, then, for the grander agenda? A. . . . So I think that we should pursue whatever avenues there are that could help us find a way to peace in the Middle East, as I just indicated to Senator Simon, but I think we ought to all be realistic about the prospects for achieving a breakthrough. I don't, you know, there is no more intractable problem facing us; there has been no more intractable foreign policy facing us for a long time. That doesn't mean that we - the difficulty of the task does not - should not deter us from making the effort. Human Rights Conference Q. Going on to another question, were you involved in the recent decision that we go along with a human rights in Moscow in 1991? And what's your opinion of this development? A. Well, contrary to published press reports, Senator Kassebaum, I was not involved in the decision. . . . I've had some reservations in watching the issue develop, even during the campaign, about the wisdom of holding a human-rights conference in Moscow, but having said that, I have to say to you that I am impressed by the changes which are taking place in the Soviet Union and what Secretary Shultz and the President have achieved there.

title: Review/Pop; A Keyboardist Steps Out Into The Foreground
description: Rod Williams, the keyboardist who performed with his group at the Knitting Factory on Monday night, is one of the many musicians in New York who toil in the background, but shouldn't. With other people - he is the regular keyboardist for the singer Cassandra Wilson - he is an empathetic accompanist, stabbing away at chords when needed, adding lush solos on cue.

title: When the Search Is an End in Itself
description: LEAD: WHILE people of her generation were trying to find themselves, Marilyn Greene was trying to find other people. A self-taught private investigator in Schenectady, N.Y., Mrs. Greene has spent 20 years defying the traditional roles of wife and mother by redefining a modern male stereotype: the hard-boiled, hard-drinking detective.

title: National Lampoon Board Expanded
description: Matty Simmons, the chairman of National Lampoon Inc., has agreed to expand the company's board to seven seats from four and to add as directors the actor Tim Matheson, who played Otter in ''Animal House''; David Grodnik, a motion picture and television producer, and an Omaha investor, Alan S. Parsow. The three investors control 21.3 percent of National Lampoon's 1.5 million shares.

title: Chips & Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bio-Logic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Fadeyev in Lead: Aleksandr Fadeyev, the former world champion from the Soviet Union, took the lead yesterday after the original program of the men's competition at the European championships in Birmingham, England. With a routine that included some interesting arm-shaking and body-wiggling choreography with a difficult triple axel-double toe-loop combination, Fadeyev moved ahead of the figure leader, Richard Zander. The West German dropped to sixth after making several mistakes in his program. With 1.4 factored placings, Fadeyev is in a commanding position to retain his European title. Entering the free-skating final tomorrow, Grzegorz Filipowski of Poland is second and Petr Barna of Czechoslovakia third. (AP) HORSE RACING Its Acedemic Wins: Its Acedemic staged a strong late run to score a 1 1/4-length victory in the $41,000 Dark Crystal Purse for 4-year-olds and up yesterday at Aqueduct. The winner, ridden by Diane Nelson, reached the wire comfortably ahead of Turning for Home. It was 1 3/4 lengths farther back to Worryation. The victory was the first in two starts this year for Its Acedemic, the favorite in a field of seven. He went one mile, 70 yards on a fast track in 1:41, earning $24,600 for Marcus Vogel.Its Acedemic returned $5.60, $3.20 and $2.20 for $2 across the board. Turning for Home paid $6.80 and $3.40. Worryation returned $2.20 to show. (AP) BASKETBALL 76ers 115, Celtics 104The host 76ers fell behind by 12-0 before rallying as Ron Anderson scored a career-high 36 points, including 17 in the final period. The Celtics led, 83-80, at the start of the fourth quarter but Philadelphia scored the first 7 points in an 11-2 surge and took a 91-85 lead with 9 minutes 11 second left. The Celtics cut their deficit to 3 points five times, the last at 102-99 with three minutes remaining. The Sixers then outscored Boston, 8-2, with the help of two field goals and two free throws from Anderson. Charles Barkley, who played despite an ailing back, scored 23 points and Mike Gminski 18 for Philadelphia. Kevin McHale led the Celtics with 31, Reggie Lewis had 22 and Robert Parish 20. Philadelphia committed only five turnovers, low in the National Basketball Association this season.(AP) Bucks 118, Hornets 106Terry Cummings scored 26 points and Ricky Pierce made five consecutive baskets to open the fourth quarter for the Bucks in Milwaukee. The victory was the Bucks' seventh in eight games and their third without a loss against the Hornets. The Hornets made 15 of 21 shots for 71.4 percent in the first quarter and led by 11 points.(AP) HOCKEY Canadiens 3, Whalers 1: Mike McPhee and Guy Carbonneau scored third-period goals to lead Montreal to victory last night. Peter Svoboda added an empty-netter as the Canadiens stretched their unbeaten streak at home to 17 games. Montreal's last loss at the Forum was to Pittsburgh on Oct. 29. Joel Quenneville gave the Whalers the lead just 83 seconds into the game, but McPhee tied it with his 16th goal at 4:22 of the third period by completing a two-on-one play with Claude Lemieux. Carbonneau notched the winner at 11:00, getting away a soft shot that eluded the goaltender, Peter Sidorkiewicz.(AP) Oilers 9, Jets 4:Mark Messier had two goals and two assists as the Oilers snapped a four-game winless streak. The Oiler goaltender Grant Fuhr was carried from the ice on a stretcher after a collision with Winnipeg's Andrew McBain. Dr. Wayne Hildahl of the Jets said Fuhr was taken to hospital and released with a strained neck. Fuhr was conscious, talking, and could move his hand, Hildahl said.(AP) North Stars 3, Sabres 3: A freak bounce off the boards gave Buffalo's Ray Sheppard a goal in the third period and the Sabres the tie. Sheppard found himself alone in front of an open net on the power play when a clearing pass ricocheted wildly off the boards behind the net. The winger tapped the puck into the net at 14:37 of the third period for the game's final goal.(AP)

title: AIDS Treatment Is Found Effective in Monkeys
description: An experimental substance that is thought to prevent the AIDS virus from infecting cells has dramatically suppressed AIDS-like viral infections in monkeys.

title: Dow Gains 24.11; Rising Dollar Helps
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average reached another post-crash high.

title: Bounties and Vans: Jersey Copes With Labor Shortage
description: For Keith J. Esmark, general manager of the Holiday Inn here, dealing with the lowest unemployment rate in the metropolitan region means doing everything from paying bounties for new workers to bringing in employees from as far away as Staten Island and Easton, Pa. At times, short of staff, he has even had to cook breakfast for guests.

title: Metro Matters; Now Hear This! Or Is the Honking Too Loud?
description: ''Come Blow Your Horn'' is the name of a Neil Simon comedy, but in New York City it might as well be an invitation.

title: Corrections
description: A list in Sports Pages yesterday, showing schools' and conferences' votes in two ballots on Proposition 42 at the N.C.A.A. convention, misstated or omitted some votes. The University of New Mexico voted no on the first ballot and yes on the second; it did not vote yes twice. The Southwestern Athletic Conference voted no, not yes, on both ballots. The Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference voted yes twice; the Association of Mid-Continent Universities Conference and Winthrop College voted no on both ballots.

title: Lund Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Russell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Integrated Device Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Talking Deals; How Zeckendorf Filled a Tower
description: WHERE crowds once roared at the previous Madison Square Garden, between 49th and 50th Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues, workers are putting the finishing touches on an office tower and residential complex that pushes the midtown cluster of high-rises and white-collar workers into a neighborhood best known for pornography and cheap bars.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Hit a Record Last Month
description: Amid growing concern over its trade gap with the United States and Europe, Japanese officials reported today that the country's trade surplus had widened in December to $9.65 billion, a record monthly imbalance.

title: US Trust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted. The company said latest quarter and year results reflected the impact of the company's share repurchase program, partly offset by the sale of 450,000 shares of stock to the company's newly formed employee stock ownership plan.

title: Yields Rise For Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds all rose for the week ended yesterday.

title: Sherwood Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and included a $1,580,491 after-tax gain on the early extinguishment of debt. Results for 1987 included the proceeds of a key-man, life insurance policy in the amount of $5,851,643 and $86,246 for the 6-month and 3-month periods, respectively.

title: Mayors Voice Hope for the Cities With Bush Assuming Presidency
description: The nation's mayors said today that they were looking with hope to President-elect George Bush after an eight-year fiscal drought under the Reagan Administration.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Widens Sharply As Imports Soar
description: The nation's trade deficit widened substantially in November, to $12.5 billion, as exports fell and imports surged to their second-highest level, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Industry Operated at a 9-Year High in December
description: Industry in the United States operated at its highest rate in nine years last month, the Government reported today, but analysts said the modest growth should allay fears that inflation is rising.

title: First Interstate Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $27 million extraordinary credit. c-Included $180.4 million provided for loan losses at First Interstate Bank of Texas, together with $33.7 million of expenses associated with foreclosed properties. d-Net loss The latest quarter net from operations included net of $25.8 million from interest recognized on Brazilian non-performing loans. The 1988 results also included a $150 million million charge for a mark-to- market adjustment in connection with the accelerated disposal of an additional $400 million in low-quality assets through a subsidiary specializing in real estate loan workout. First Interstate said it provided $119.9 million for possible loan losses in the latest fourth quarter, bringing the total for the year to $589.7 million. In 1987 the provision for loan losses was $243.3 million for the quarter and $1.25 billion for the year.

title: Old Stone Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a $16,177,000 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Results for the prior year have been restated to reflect the adoption of a change in accounting for income taxes. The company said the restatement reduced its 1987 earnings from $14.2 million to a loss of $7.7 million on a restated basis.

title: Reynolds Metals Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains totaling $14.7 million and $18.8 million, mostly from tax credits, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Power Behind the Pen: The Book Agent's Rise
description: At a Simon & Schuster party at Tavern on the Green recently, Laurence J. Kirshbaum, the president of Warner Books, surveyed the crowd of several hundred publishers, editors, authors and literary agents. ''You can tell who the agents are,'' he said. ''They're the ones with all the money.''

title: Gardens Born of the Imagination
description: FLOWERS do not grow and grass is markedly absent at ''Theatergarden Bestiarium,'' a show at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Wang Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Bishops Say Vietnam Eases Religious Curbs
description: The Government of Vietnam has significantly reduced, though not eliminated, repressive policies toward religion, a delegation of American Roman Catholic Bishops said this week.

title: Crown Crafts reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included insurance gains of $315,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $666,000, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend payable Feb. 6, to stockholders of record Jan. 19.

title: When Amateurs Are Professionals
description: It's no secret that many athletes who play big-time college sports are essentially mercenaries hired to win championships and fill stadiums. From time to time the N.C.A.A. makes a fuss about minimum academic standards. But this is hypocritical nibbling around a larger truth: athletes rarely get a solid education because that's not why they're there. So why not drop pretenses - and move to a system of open professionalism?

title: U.S. Again Reports Libyan Role in Terrorism
description: The United States asserted today that Libya continues to support terrorism around the world and is using foreign surrogates to strike Western targets.

title: First Maryland Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for the latest quarter included one-time expenses of about $5.3 million associated with the offer by Allied Irish Banks Plc. to purchase the shares of First Maryland that Allied did not already own.

title: Ryan's Family Steak House reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United Vermont Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The prior quarter and year included a one-time charge of $779,000 to the bank's loan loss reserve and a write- down of securities of $325,000.

title: A Garden Tied In Knots
description: FOR centuries, gardeners have taken pleasure in creating patterned landscapes. Among the earliest, believed to have come from pagan rituals and Greek mythology, are mazes or labyrinths: networks of paths through which it is difficult to find a way.

title: King Says He Signed 2 Contracts with Tyson
description: While making a deposition in Mike Tyson's suit to void the contract of his manager, Bill Cayton, Don King was glum in the morning, loquacious in the afternoon and thunderingly irate at the close of the proceedings.

title: Boston Questions 11 Firefighters On Claim to Be Part of a Minority
description: City officials have questioned the assertions of 11 firefighters that they are members of minority groups and thus are qualified for preferential treatment in hiring and promotions, according to a city report released Tuesday night.

title: A Top Officer Is Named At American Savings
description: The Robert M. Bass Group has hired Robert T. Barnum from the First Nationwide Bank to be the chief financial officer for its American Savings Bank of Stockton, Calif.

title: Review/Photography; An Evans Show, 50 Years Later
description: Fifty years after the publication of his ''American Photographs'' and 14 years after his death, Walker Evans (1903-1975) remains a beacon for contemporary photographers. Unlike the other modernist masters who photographed in the 1930's - Alfred Stieglitz, Paul Strand and Ansel Adams among them - Evans seems relevant to our post-industrial, post-modern age. This is paradoxical, since he photographed precisely those elements of American life most vulnerable to the wages of time: clapboard houses, tin-sheathed garages, automobiles and billboards.

title: Kings Road Chief Out
description: Kings Road Entertainment Inc., a small film maker that has been unprofitable since going public in 1986, said Tuesday that its chairman and chief executive, Stephen J. Friedman, had been dismissed. The company said a management restructuring was planned. Kings Road has made about 20 films, including ''Slapshot,'' ''All of Me,'' and ''Enemy Mine.'' In the six months ended Oct. 31, the company had losses of $2.1 million on $14.8 million in revenue.

title: Personal Health
description: Perhaps you remember as a child having a mouthful of food that you absolutely hated and couldn't begin to swallow. Or perhaps you had a throat so sore and swollen that even water had trouble getting through. Now, try to imagine having a more serious variation of the problem, perhaps all the time, every day, every time you try to eat or drink.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Wes Gardner, pitcher, to a one-year contract. DETROIT (AL) - Agreed to terms with Chris Brown, third baseman, on a one-year contract. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Tim Stoddard, pitcher, to a minor league contract. Invited Stoddard, Dan Firova and Tom Magrann, catchers, to their training camp. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Agreed to terms with Jerry Don Gleaton, pitcher, on a one-year contract. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Andres Galarraga, first baseman, and Joe Hesketh, pitcher, to one-year contracts. OAKLAND (AL) - Agreed to terms with Ron Hassey, catcher, on a one-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Agreed to terms with Bobby Bonilla, third baseman, on a one-year contract. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Bob Brenly, catcher, to a one-year contract. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Agreed to terms with Kevin Mitchell, third baseman, on a one-year contract. COLLEGES AUSTIN PEAY - Suspended Tommy Brown, forward, from the basketball team for the rest of the season. CALIFORNIA-DAVIS - Named Jim Sochor athletic director and Bob Foster head football coach. CINCINNATI - Named John Lovett defensive coordinator; Bill Sheridan outside linebackers coach; Ted Daisher defensive line coach; Russ Burns wide receivers coach, and John Harbaugh tight ends coach and recruiting coordinator. Retained Bruce Ivory, running backs coach, and Lou West, secondary coach. TOLEDO - Named Frank Kurth assistant football coach. WILLIAM JEWELL - Named Hugh Williams head soccer coach. FOOTBALL DETROIT (NFC) - Named Woody Widenhofer defensive coordinator and Frank Gansz special teams coach. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Announced the retirement of Randy Cross, center, effective after the Super Bowl.

title: American Home Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Illinois Town Suffers With Stockton
description: More than 70 parents accompanied their children to the Hubbard Woods Elementary School in this Chicago suburb today, where reading and arithmetic lessons gave way to discussions about random violence against children.

title: 2 Accused in Scheme To Sell F-14 Parts
description: Two Long Island businessmen were arrested at a Suffolk County airport yesterday on charges of selling parts for the F-14 Tomcat fighter jet to an undercover Federal agent posing as an arms dealer for Iran, Federal officials said.

title: Apartment Project To Be Scaled Down
description: The developers planning Brighton by the Sea, a Brooklyn apartment project on the site of the Brighton Beach Baths, have withdrawn an application they submitted last year to the City Planning Commission, officials said yesterday. A spokesman for the developers said they planned to seek permission for a scaled-down version of the project.

title: Passing the Blame
description: If at first you don't succeed, blame the assistant coaches. That seems to be the operative philosophy of the Los Angeles Raiders' first-year head coach, Mike Shanahan, and the team's owner, Al Davis. When the Raiders finished the season with a 7-9 record and failed to make the playoffs, Shanahan, a former Denver assistant who took over the Raiders last season, dismissed the team's defensive coordinator, Charlie Sumner, and another assistant, Willie Brown. Now another Raider assistant has been dismissed. According to The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Nick Nicolau, the coach of the wide receivers, was told last Friday that he would not be back with the team next season. The 56-year-old Nicolau spent seven seasons with the Broncos before he left with Shanahan last March to join the Raiders. (AP)

title: FEDERAL RESERVE ACTS TO LET BANKS INTO BOND TRADING
description: Breaching a wall that has separated banking and the securities business for more than 50 years, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that it would allow banking companies to raise money for corporations in the bond market.

title: Bessemer Securities Acts to Get Aggressive
description: The Bessemer Securities Corporation, a staid Wall Street investment firm owned by the Phipps family, said yesterday that it planned to get more aggressive and hired a new president and chief executive, Ward W. Woods Jr., as a first step.

title: Gretzky Places Third In Balloting by Fans
description: It was no surprise that Wayne Gretzky made the Campbell Conference team for the National Hockey League All-Star Game when results of fan balloting were announced yesterday. The surprise was that he finished third in the voting. From the record 1,151,321 votes cast by the fans, who selected the starting team for the fourth consecutive year, Gretzky's Los Angeles teammate, Luc Robitaille, a left wing, finished first over all with 279,202 votes. Gretzky's former Edmonton teammate, Grant Fuhr, a goaltender, was runner-up with 272,181 votes. Gretzky, who was obtained by the Kings in a preseason trade with the Oilers, was the top vote-getter at center with 270,988 votes. Three Kings, including Steve Duchesne, a defenseman, and three Oilers, including Jari Kurri, a right wing, and Kevin Lowe, a defenseman, were voted to the starting Campbell Conference team for the game against the Wales Conference Feb. 7 in Edmonton, Alberta.(AP)

title: Cost of Reagan Reign Far Exceeds Benefits; Breaking the Jinx
description: To the Editor:

title: Trinity Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Metro Tel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Neediest Gain From Art Sale And Lottery
description: The New York Graphic Society of Greenwich, Conn., donated $1,000 from its second ''Help the Homeless'' art sale to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Review/Theater; In Pirandello, a Game Too Convincing for Enrico
description: As a philosophical comedy, Pirandello's ''Enrico IV'' (at the Roundabout Theater Company) deals with the limits of logic and the possibilities of artifice. In keeping with other Pirandello plays, it encapsulates a truth within an illusion.

title: Bancorp Hawaii Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $12,705,000 from the sale of the bank's Waikiki building.

title: Knicks Covet Mullin
description: Chris Mullin in a Knick uniform has always been a family dream. It may be a Knick dream, too. Ever since Mullin left St. John's University, where he was the 1985 college player of the year and then the Warriors' top draft choice, several attempts - some of them real - have been made to make him a Knick.

title: Network Equipment Technoloies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $559,000 for the quarter and $3,155,000 for the 9 months.

title: Lights! Action! Inauguration Is Under Way
description: President-elect George Bush opened a five-day celebration of his inauguration tonight, saying he wants Americans to do more for one another than they have done before and dramatizing the idea with a fireworks display of several thousand points of light across the sky.

title: George R. Tweed, 86; Eluded Foe on Guam
description: George R. Tweed, a World War II Navy radioman who eluded Japanese forces on the Pacific island of Guam for 31 months, died Monday in an automobile accident in Northern California. He was 86 years old.

title: Ohio Edison Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Bancorp of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,282,000 from an accounting change.

title: Business as Usual
description: Despite disturbances in Miami, fans, players and the N.F.L. are trying to keep Super Bowl preparations as normal as possible. Page A18.

title: Berlin Wall Aids Peace, East Bloc Powers Assert
description: The Soviet Union and East Germany today rejected Western calls for the destruction of the Berlin wall, saying it must stay in place for the time being.

title: ARCO Offering
description: ARCO said it expected to receive up to $1.38 billion in proceeds from its 40-million-share initial public offering of the Lyondell Petrochemical Company, which was priced today at $30 a share. As part of the offering proposal, Lyondell paid ARCO a $500 million dividend on Tuesday. The stock will be offered for sale beginning Thursday through the offering's underwriters, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc. The offering ends next Wednesday. The per share price of Lyondell stock is at the low end of an initial price range estimated by Los Angeles-based ARCO in November when the spinoff was proposed. Rising demand for commodity petrochemicals has increased prices throughout last year and raised Lyondell's earnings nearly fivefold in the first nine months of 1988.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Technology Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Kidder, Peabody Reorganization Expected
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company will shortly announce a major reorganization that includes the appointment of a new chief executive, Wall Street analysts and executives said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Amanda Acquisition Corp., Burlington, Mass., a subsidiary of High Voltage Engineering Corp., said it had extended its $35-a-share offer for Universal Foods Corp. to Feb. 1 from Jan. 17.

title: Killing of a Child: How the System Failed
description: A little more than two years ago, welfare investigators portrayed the home of Abigail Cortez as a ''warm and nurturing environment.'' On Dec. 14, 1988, her 5-year-old daughter, Jessica, was dead of a broken neck, and Mrs. Cortez and her companion, Adrian Lopez, were charged with murder.

title: The Fast-Food Market's New Lure
description: Fast-food marketing experts, always trying to shrink the time and distance between a man and his meal, are rapidly discovering a new competitive wrinkle.

title: INSIDE
description: Baker Says Central America Is Most Pressing Issue

title: Texas Eastern, Coastal to Meet
description: The Coastal Corporation, which has bid $2.6 billion for the Texas Eastern Corporation, said that a meeting between officials of the two companies has been arranged for this weekend. Coastal said it owns about 4 percent of Texas Eastern's outstanding common stock on a fully diluted basis.

title: TCF Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $2,338,000 and $9,009,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and included losses from the reversal of a tax credit of $1,245,000 and $4,128,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Latin Issues Pressing Bush, Baker Says
description: James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State-designate, said today that several Latin American issues, including the March elections in El Salvador, troubled relations with Nicaragua and the difficult state of dealings with Panama, would require the Bush Administration's immediate attention.

title: Roberts and 49ers Become Stronger
description: It would not be fair to say that Larry Roberts was being pushed around a season ago. He was in his second season as a defensive end with the San Francisco 49ers, primarily responsible for an outside rush in passing situations, when injuries suddenly necessitated a new role and created extenuating circumstances.

title: Building Dreams With Toy Blocks
description: NORMAN BROSTERMAN does not consider himself a toy collector. ''These things are much more than toys,'' he said, referring to the 265 sets of children's architectural building blocks that crowd the closets of his Upper West Side apartment. ''They represent the whole history of architecture. You have to wonder which architects played with which ones when they were kids.''

title: Comerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Check of Ski Lifts Is Ordered After Cracks Appear in Chairs
description: State officials have ordered nine ski resorts to inspect ski lifts immediately after cracks were found in a chairlift.

title: Linear Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After tax credits of $791,000 for the quarter and $1,506,000 for the 6 months.

title: Water Meters Gain Urgency During Drought
description: With New York City and the metropolitan region facing the prospect of its third drought in a decade, progress on the city's plan to install water meters in every home - and to charge customers based on their consumption - has taken on new importance.

title: Ties Are In, Tees Are Out
description: The Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has voted down a proposal to establish a tie-breaker for football.

title: As the Congress Will Make Clear, It Isn't Only the President Who Governs
description: For all the early sniping about George Bush's lack of a mandate, Congressional leaders are not spoiling for a fight with the new President. Indeed, Washington has become a peaceable kingdom in recent weeks, with earnest pledges of bipartisan cooperation from every corner.

title: Rockwell to Plead Guilty to Overbilling Air Force
description: The Rockwell International Corporation today agreed to plead guilty to charges of overbilling the Air Force on a navigation-satellite contract.

title: In Capital, Patriotic Napery
description: AT dinners last night in Washington celebrating George Bush's inauguration, the guests may not have noticed the tablecloths, but officials at Waverly Fabrics in New York surely did: the company produced the fabric.

title: E. B. Simmons Sr., 86, Dentist for 50 Years
description: Dr. Everett B. Simmons Sr., a dentist for 50 years, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan and had practiced in East Orange, N.J.

title: Treasury Official Says Bush Is Unfazed by Dollar's Gains
description: A senior Treasury official indicated today that the Reagan Administration and President-elect George Bush are unconcerned about the rise of the dollar in recent weeks, including a new spurt today.

title: Books of The Times; The Many Faces of a Colorful Intelligence Agent
description: Edward Lansdale The Unquiet American By Cecil B. Currey Illustrated. 430 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $24.95.

title: Hibernia Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Kitchens and Baths With Flair
description: FOR a show at the Art et Industrie gallery in SoHo, James Hong reinvented two objects that architects and decorators buy from catalogues: the cooktop and the bathroom sink.

title: Panasonic to Return $16 Million to Consumers
description: In a major price-fixing settlement, the Panasonic Company has agreed to return as much as $16 million to consumers to end charges by New York State that it threatened retailers with a loss of supply unless Panasonic products were sold at prices dictated by the company.

title: Jaruzelski Said He'd Quit If Party Rejected His Gesture to Solidarity
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski and other Polish leaders threatened to resign to force the adoption of a resolution opening the way for legalization of the Solidarity trade union, a Government press agency report said late Wednesday.

title: Huntington Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In London, a Showcase for Italian Design
description: The richly colored metaphysical paintings of Giorgio de Chirico fill an entire gallery in the new exhibition ''Italian Art in the 20th Century,'' which opened Saturday at the Royal Academy of Art here.

title: TAIWAN IS SEEKING NEW TIES ABROAD
description: Despite strenuous objections from Beijing, Taiwan will begin a diplomatic offensive aimed at broadening relations with other countries, Taiwan's Foreign Minister said today.

title: EDUCATION PLEDGE RENEWED BY BUSH
description: President-elect George Bush, seeking to put a distinctive stamp on his Presidency, reinforced his campaign pledge today to make education a top priority of his Administration.

title: Shift by Rockport
description: The Rockport Company, which is based in Marlboro, Mass., and is a subsidiary of Reebok International Ltd., has temporarily returned to Chiat/Day after a yearlong relationship with Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey & Schmetterer. Creative differences led to the divorce. Chiat/ Day handled Rockport's advertising for about a year, until January 1988.

title: Temtex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $221,000.

title: First Eastern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter and full year results are restated to reflect the company's merger with Peoples First National Bank and Trust Co.

title: PRISONS' DIRECTOR IS SLAIN IN OREGON
description: The director of Oregon's prison system was found stabbed to death today on the grounds outside the headquarters of the Department of Corrections here.

title: Elmore Jackson, 78, Quaker Mideast Envoy
description: Elmore Jackson, a Quaker official who attempted a secret diplomatic mission aimed at achieving a political settlement between Egypt and Israel in 1955, died of Parkinson's disease Tuesday in Newtown, Pa., where he lived. He was 78 years old.

title: Jostens Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $40,185,000 for the quarter and $42,183,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Selfix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Imperial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corestates Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Molson and Carling To Merge Operations
description: Brewers of two of Canada's most popular beers, Molson and Carling O'Keefe, are merging their North American operations to reach for a bigger share of the United States beer market.

title: Yonkers Regains Many Fiscal Powers
description: The State Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday restored much of Yonkers's spending authority, convinced that many restrictions imposed during a crisis over a court-ordered housing desegregation plan were no longer required.

title: Gencorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $8 million and $12 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $3 million from an accounting change. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $238 million for the quarter and $457 million for the year. The company said in the year-ago fourth quarter net from continuing operations is after a $12 million pre- tax provision for environmental cleanup costs and an $8 million pre- tax provision for restructuring and unusual items. Fiscal 1987 net from continuing operations is after a $52 million pretax provision for restructuring and unusual items.

title: U.S. Agency Sets Wetland Protection Policy
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, in a step with potentially far-reaching conservation consequences, today announced a new policy of preventing any net loss of the nation's remaining wetlands.

title: Apple Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $3,351,000 for the quarter and $8,366,000 for the year.

title: Sunair Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
An Angolan Proposal
description: The President of Angola, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, has called for a cease-fire in his Government's long war with the Unita rebel movement.

title: Bank South Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Exchange Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $2,043,000 from an accounting change. c-Included tax credits of $574,000 for the quarter and $3,345,000 for the year.

title: Hoyas Top Providence
description: Georgetown, playing its second consecutive game without Coach John Thompson, beat Providence, 80-77, tonight. Charles Smith scored 35 points, including a go-ahead basket with 5 seconds left.

title: Anna Sokolow Choreographs Lessons in Sorrow
description: Anna Sokolow has steadfastly moved to her own drummer. A leading American modern-dance choreographer, she has had a long and influential career teaching young dancers and actors how to make every moment count emotionally. And her dances have addressed the alienation of modern life with memorable intensity.

title: Tandy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transplanting Genes Is Approved To Study Cancer Cells in Humans
description: The Federal Government yesterday approved the first federally sanctioned attempt to transplant foreign genes into humans.

title: At the Show Without a Ticket
description: Not everyone is celebrating in Washington today. Hundreds of frustrated out-of-towners are spending their first hours in town in the cavernous Convention Center, standing in long lines and sitting in abject resignation in the Error Resolution Area.

title: Skiing Risks Include Mismanaged Slopes
description: To the Editor:

title: Clippers Dismiss Shue And Name Don Casey
description: The Los Angeles Clippers dismissed Coach Gene Shue yesterday and named Don Casey, an assistant who was a former coach at Temple, as interim coach. Shue has the most victories of any active National Basketball Association coach, with 784. The Clippers lost their 11th consecutive game Wednesday night, to the Los Angeles Lakers.(AP)

title: Excerpts From Warsaw Plan To Discuss Legalizing Unions
description: Following are excerpts from the Communist Party resolution calling for talks leading to legalization of new trade unions, as translated by the official P.A.P. press agency:

title: Balkan Parley in Albania
description: For the first time since World War II, Albania is the host of a meeting of Deputy Foreign Ministers from the six Balkan countries, Bulgaria, Romania, Yugoslavia, Turkey, Greece and Albania. The three-day conference in Albania is seen a strong indication that the country is emerging from a long self-imposed isolation.

title: Los Angeles Station Sold
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation, an Irving, Tex., radio station operator, said today that it had paid $55 million for the Los Angeles classical music station KFAC. Louise Haifetz paid $33.5 million in 1986 for the FM station, along with its AM sister station, which was sold separately last summer for $8.7 million. While radio stations typically sell for 10 times cash flow, the price for KFAC amounts to 22 times its cash flow of $2.5 million annually.

title: Kenny Burrell
description: The guitarist Kenny Burrell leads his Jazz Guitar Band tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1,432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and $10 admission at the bar.

title: Nuclear Industry Faulted
description: A study of the American nuclear power industry found it had one of the worst performance records in the industrialized world, and management weaknesses are probably at fault, a group of nuclear engineering experts said this week. The best nuclear plants in the United States are as good as any in the world, they said. But pressurized water reactors at troubled plants were out of action so frequently that they operated over all at only about 60 percent of their energy capacity, the experts said. The capacity-usage figures for pressurized water reactors were 80 percent or above in West Germany and Switzerland and above 60 percent in Japan, Sweden and France, the other countries studied. Britain, which uses a different technology, was excluded from the study, which covered the period from 1975 to 1984. The study is to be published today in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Technology Review magazine.

title: Auctions
description: A Suite With a Past
