title: Fed Selling Ends Rally In Dollar
description: A bruising round of central bank intervention and an increase in interest rates in Europe stopped the dollar rally yesterday, but some traders said they still expected the dollar to move higher.

title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate
description: The 24-year-old man who opened fire on children in a schoolyard here Tuesday was a troubled loner full of hate who could not keep a job and had alcohol and drug problems, according to the portrait that is emerging from investigators and family members.

title: Review/Dance; A Cavalier and a Hoofer
description: Almost every balletgoer knows that George Balanchine loved to choreograph for women. But it should not be forgotten that he also created interesting parts for men. In one of the two works by Balanchine that the New York City Ballet offered Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, the male dancer was a noble cavalier; in the other, the male star was a hoofer.

title: On Stage
description: No Dandy, Mandy

title: Knicks Stall Again on the Road
description: The Knicks were in trouble early tonight with Patrick Ewing in foul trouble and on the bench in the first quarter. The Knick center tried to bring his team back, scoring 34 of his 38 points in the final three quarters, but it was not enough.

title: Housing Construction Hit 6-Year Low in 1988
description: Housing construction fell by 2.2 percent in December, ending a year in which residential building activity dropped to its lowest level in six years, the Government reported today.

title: Pentagon, Not Social Security, Made the Deficit; Middle-Income Targets
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Image, Woods Has Serious Side
description: The first time Sam Wyche met Ickey Woods, the Bengals' coach couldn't help noticing the rookie was wearing a ponytail.

title: Times and Machinists Reach Tentative Pact
description: The New York Times and the union representing its 72 machinists reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a six-year extension of a labor contract that expired nearly two years ago. The accord averted a strike that had been set for 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Nine Hostages Sadden Reagan
description: President Reagan, whose obsession to gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon prompted the failed arms-for-hostages initiative with Iran, is saddened that he will leave office with nine Americans still captive.

title: For a Third Party
description: To the Editor:

title: Optimistic Mood Greets 41st President
description: Americans begin the Bush administration in a buoyant mood, optimistic about the country and the new President and especially satisfied with their own lives, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: COMMODITY HUBS
description: Figures are for 1988. CHICAGO BOARD OF TRADE

title: With 8 Hands and 25 Strings, a Quartet Makes Music
description: The classic guitar, with its gentle voice and its ability to play contrapuntal music, is usually regarded as a solitary instrument - the province of the soloist. But throughout the instrument's modern history, guitarists have teamed up as duets, trios and even, if more rarely, quartets, in order to take on music that makes demands greater than two hands and six strings can negotiate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * American Capital Management and Research, Houston, a provider of financial services, to EBW Advertising, with a $2 million budget.

title: Washington's Mayor Is Questioned by Grand Jury
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. went before a Federal grand jury today, asserting as he entered the closed hearing that he had done no wrong and was not the target of the jury's investigation into allegations of drug dealing and misuse of government funds.

title: Charging Riot Policemen Beat Protesters in Prague Square
description: Policemen swinging riot sticks stormed into a crowd of more than 2,000 demonstrators in Prague's central square today, pinning many to the ground and beating them severely.

title: Reviews/Film; Writer's Block, by Law
description: ''Memoirs of Prison'' was shown as part of the 1984 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 10, 1984. The film, in Portuguese with English subtitles, opens today at the Public, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Digital Equipment Net Falls 15%; Sun and Microsoft Gain
description: Even though it posted an earnings decline of 15 percent, the Digital Equipment Corporation fared well on Wall Street yesterday because those second-quarter results were 25 to 30 cents a share better than analysts had expected.

title: For Better or for Worse, The Bushes Trade Tales
description: In a conjugal dustup in a television interview, President-elect George Bush and his wife, Barbara, have exchanged gibes about her weight and his dancing.

title: New Chief Executive For Fuqua Industries
description: J.B. Fuqua, the man who built Fuqua Industries, has stepped down as chief executive, and the post has been given to Lawrence P. Klamon, Fuqua's president and chief operating officer, the company announced yesterday.

title: Guilty Plea by Rockwell
description: The Rockwell International Corporation pleaded guilty today to two significant counts in an indictment that charged one of the nation's 10 largest military contractors with conspiring to defraud the Air Force.

title: Everett Quinton's Life After Ludlam
description: Everett Quinton is sitting in the front row of the Charles Ludlam Theater thinking about the last two years.

title: Disclosure Step By Comptroller
description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates national banks, said on Wednesday that it would start disclosing more to the public about its enforcement actions against banks.

title: The Inaugural Sewer
description: George Bush's lavish Inaugural festivities carry a lavish price tag. By the time the five-day extravaganza ends, a record $30 million will have been spent - about eight times the tab for Jimmy Carter's 1977 Inauguration.

title: Reagan's Housing Chief Says Never Mind to His Critics
description: On Friday, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. ends his tenure as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and as the only person to have served in President Reagan's Cabinet for the full eight years.

title: INSIDE
description: Steinbrenner Wins Pardon

title: George, Do It Yourself
description: Every time a politician runs for President the real message is the same: Just put me into that Oval Office and I will show you that I can get things done and that I can make changes. Count on me.

title: For the Record
description: Diversity in Hiring From remarks Jan. 6 by Prof. Alan Freeman of the State University of New York at Buffalo at the convention of the American Association of Law Schools in New Orleans. Professor Freeman spoke on behalf of 300 colleagues who had signed a petition calling for the appointment of an independent commission to promote ''diversity in hiring'' in law schools.

title: Northeast Utilities
description: Lawyers for shareholders and creditors of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire Tuesday dismissed a $2 billion offer for the company by Northeast Utilities as too low. Howard Berman, a lawyer representing Public Service's 100,000 shareholders, said they would urge the company's board to reject Northeast Utilities' plan ''as totally unsatisfactory.'' Northeast Utilities offered last week to buy Public Service's assets aside from the utility's share of the Seabrook nuclear power plant for $1.2 billion.

title: At the Movies
description: Partners in a Venture

title: 4 Visit Nelson Mandela At Guarded Bungalow
description: Four jailed black nationalist colleagues of Nelson Mandela visited him at the prison farm bungalow where he is confined two days before Christmas, a lawyer for one of the prisoners has said.

title: Writers Reading
description: As part of the fourth season of the New York Voices readers series of public readings by writers who live in or write about New York, Meg Wolitzer, whoe most recent novel is ''This Is Your Life,'' is to read from her works this afternoon at 12:15 at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza. Thulani Daivs, a poet and staff writer for The Village voice who wrote the libretto for the opera ''X, the Life and times of malcolm X'' and Mark Richard, a writer and photographer, are to read next Friday at the smae time and place. Free. Information: 269-0320.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about next season's plans at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center misidentified the composer of a work it has commissioned. The work, a String Sextet that is to have its premiere, is by Charles Wuorinen, not Milton Babbitt.

title: Birthdays and Engagements Inspire Gifts to the Neediest
description: After lengthy discussions about what to buy each other for their first wedding anniversary, Leslie J. Lane and Alan H. Vorchheimer of Manhattan decided to celebrate the occasion with a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: For Bush, 40,000 Points of Maglites
description: If President Bush follows his plan to use the phrase ''thousand points of light'' in his address to those attending the inaugural balls Friday night, 40,000 points will shine.

title: Capital's Day of Waiting and Nostalgia
description: President-elect George Bush, suggesting he would take a cautious approach in the first weeks of his administration, said today that he would not rush to reach an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Tom Russell Band
description: Tom Russell is to lead his country band tomorrow at 11 P.M. at Delta 88, 332 Eighth Avenue, at 26th Street (924-3499). There is a $5 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Sharyn Williamson has been promoted to executive vice president/planning and operations at Eisner & Associates, Baltimore.

title: Pop (as in Populism) Go the Festivities
description: With the Beach Boys at the Lincoln Memorial, a mariachi band at the Kennedy Center, rhythm-and-blues at the Washington Convention Center and country music everywhere, the entertainment for the inaugural festivities adds up to the capital's most populist cultural event since the heyday of Jimmy Carter.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $2.2 billion, to $284.59 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 137 institutional funds increased by $998.2 million, to $73.93 billion. The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $2.9 million, to $90.17 billion. The 91 broker-dealer funds rose by $1.21 billion, to $120.48 billion, the institute said.

title: Soviets Buy Pushkin Love Letters
description: Thirteen letters written by Aleksandr Pushkin were handed over to a Soviet official at a ceremony in a Geneva hotel Wednesday night. The letters once belonged to a member of the Czar's family and later to Sergei Diaghilev.

title: Homeless Have Moved From Hotels for Years
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pepsi to Show Ad in Russian
description: ''Noise! Noise! You call that music?'' a father trying to read a newspaper says to his son, who is bopping to music blasting in the living room. The dialogue is in Russian, with English subtitles. A can of Pepsi is on top of a shortwave radio.

title: Dismissed Coach Sues
description: Gary Moss, who was dismissed as the Sam Houston State coach after the National Collegiate Athletic Association issued sanctions against him, has filed a lawsuit against school officials and others, including Dick Schultz, the N.C.A.A. executive director. In the suit filed Wednesday in Huntsville, Tex., Moss said his constitutional rights were violated because a hearing on his dismissal was not held. In his second season at Sam Houston State, Moss was dismissed Jan. 7 after the N.C.A.A. penalized him for violations it said he committed when he was the coach at West Texas State. It was the first time penalties were levied against a coach no longer at a school. In the suit, Moss asked State District Judge Bill McAdams for a restraining order reinstating Moss's salary and other benefits as the Sam Houston State coach. He also requested that school officials not name a replacement. (AP)

title: Anglicizing Yiddish Theater
description: Is Lillian Lux, the Brooklyn-born star of Yiddish stage, bringing to her native heath new wine in old bottles or old wine in new bottles? The question, which arises in connection with her presentation of a musical, ''Oy, Is This a Rebbitzin!,'' by the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, may not have an answer. It may not even need one.

title: Reviews/Film; Substitute Soldiering
description: ''Field of Honor'' was shown as part of the 1988 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 18. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room, Seventh Avenue at 57th Street.

title: Review/Dance; More of Womanworks
description: The emphasis was on long, continuous strands of motion on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, where the Womanworks festival presented Risa Jaroslow and Dancers and the Monica Levy Performance Group. There was also some fine dancing by the two companies. But there the similarities ended.

title: Islanders Keep Kings And Gretzky in Check
description: Another frightening opponent, another Islander victory. The modest two-game string of success is enough, said Pat LaFontaine, to make the Islanders believe they can make a habit of winning once again.

title: Top-Ranking Executive Quits Posts at Invitron
description: The Invitron Company, a biotechnology company involved in cell culture manufacture, has announced the resignation of its president and chief executive, Charles V. Benton.

title: On Bush's Team, Key Word in Assistant to the President Will Be 'Assistant'
description: President-elect Bush has installed a White House staff of seasoned, but relatively unknown senior aides. Its mission is to stay that way. While the aides will have the same lofty-sounding ranks as their predecessors, they have been told in no uncertain terms that the important word in a title like assistant to the President, is assistant, not President.

title: Report Looks to Hudson for New York City's Water
description: To meet its expanding needs, the New York City water-supply system will likely have to begin to take up to 300 million gallons of water a day from the Hudson River, a state report says. The report also says that Long Island will probably need to be connected to the city's system soon to prevent depletion of its ground-water acquifers.

title: Reviewers Urged to Doubt A Book on the Binghams
description: A letter signed with the names of four members of the Bingham publishing family of Louisville, Ky., has been sent to book reviewers with documents to try to support what it calls misstatements in ''Passion and Prejudice'' by Sallie Bingham. The book is to be published by Alfred A. Knopf on Feb. 3.

title: Penny Stock Fraud Case
description: Three Federal enforcement agencies announced a 36-count indictment on Wednesday, charging 10 individuals with criminal conspiracy and securities fraud in the trading of Protecto Industries. Protecto is a so-called penny stock - one that is thinly traded and for which little information is available.

title: Arabs Blacklist Hotel Chain Owner
description: Arab officials organizing the economic boycott of Israel blacklisted the British-based owners of the Hilton International hotel chain. An official at the Damascus-based Arab Bureau for the Boycott of Israel said the Ladbroke Group, which owns Hilton, was blacklisted on Saturday. He said that under boycott rules all subsidiaries of a blacklisted group or company were included in the ban.

title: Review/Music; The Influences on a Trio
description: Despite the enormous differences in their sensibilities, the young pianist Geri Allen and the veteran bassist Charlie Haden, the two main soloists in a trio that performed at the Knitting Factory on Friday night, made extraordinary music for a packed house.

title: Frose Keeps the Ranger Goal And His Mouth Shut Tight
description: Bob Froese does not complain or despair. He plays only occasionally, but keeps his mouth closed. The Rangers, from management to minor leaguers, admire his unfailing stoicism. What they appreciate even more, though, is that when he does play, he gives them no reason to complain.

title: Review/Cabaret; Of Young Adulthood
description: The finest songs of Richard Maltby Jr. and David Shire, the collaborative team best known for the 1977 cabaret revue ''Starting Here, Starting Now'' and the 1983 Broadway show ''Baby,'' communicate something rarely found in theater music nowadays: a rich sweeping sense of lives being lived and people changing over time.

title: Warsaw Issues A Call for Talks On New Unions
description: Poland's leaders today published the long-awaited text of the Communist Party resolution calling for talks leading to legalization of new unions, including Solidarity, which was banned more than six years ago.

title: U.S. Files More Charges On Princeton/Newport
description: Government prosecutors brought additional charges yesterday against the top officers of a disbanded New Jersey investment partnership and one other person who had been indicted last summer on charges of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy.

title: Books of The Times; The Ecstasies and Agonies Of the Neurotic Life
description: Intimacy By Susan Chace 161 pages. Random House. $14.95.

title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense
description: The lawyer representing William Lozano, the city police officer whose fatal shooting of a black motorcyclist on Monday set off three days of racial violence here, said today that the officer acted in self-defense when the 500-pound vehicle came roaring toward him.

title: Restaurants
description: One-shtick restaurants, like one-shtick comedians, can be amusing for a while, but their routines soon wear thin. That was my impression after repeated visits to Trattoria dell'Arte, a restaurant designed by Milton Glaser with an anatomical theme that is about as subtle as Pee-wee Herman.

title: McCaw, Boston Globe Owner Set Changes
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular telephone operator, and Affiliated Publications Inc., owner of The Boston Globe and specialty magazines, yesterday announced plans for separate but related financial transactions that change the structures of both companies.

title: Chrysler and G.M. Expand Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation expanded low-interest incentives by offering financing as low as 4.9 percent on some of their small cars and light trucks. The Ford Motor Company started the latest wave of low-interest incentives last week by offering 4.9 percent interest on some of its small cars.

title: G.O.P. Shows Fun Side, Mostly in Formal Wear
description: Republicans in tuxedos and long dresses are roaming everywhere about Washington this week. So much so that at a ''Cabaret Night'' for the conservative wing of the party, Oliver L. North, no longer a marine, outshone other partygoers by wearing his medals on his dinner jacket.

title: Limited Supply Of 3D Glasses
description: As this Sunday's Super Bowl approaches, millions of Americans are scrambling to find tinted cardboard glasses they can use to watch a three-dimensional commercial and halftime show sponsored by the Coca-Cola Company.

title: Bush Offering a Special Mix: Ivy League and Pork Rinds
description: If Ronald Reagan represents the apotheosis of cowboy values, symbolizing the enduring American myths of self-help, self-sufficiency and self-confidence, George Bush embodies the patrician ideal of responsibility begotten by privilege: an equally American tradition reaching back through the many Presidents more at home in mansions than log cabins, from Washington of Mount Vernon to Jefferson of Monticello to Roosevelt of Hyde Park.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase 2.4% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday reported that short interest on the Big Board rose 2.4 percent in the four-week period ended last Friday.

title: Getty Trust And Chinese
description: China and the Getty Conservation Institute today announced a joint effort to preserve two of China's largest and most significant cultural sites, where statues and paintings dating from the fourth century are decaying from harsh weather, pollution and damage by earthquakes.

title: THE 41st PRESIDENT: Expectations for the Bush Years
description: The Mood is Generally Optimistic

title: Spoleto U.S.A. Announces '89 Season
description: New productions of operas by Mozart and Bellini and a world premiere by Laurie Anderson are to be part of the 13th Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., May 26 to June 11.

title: Drug Watch Hot Line
description: There is a new hot line here that has nothing to do with impending confrontations with the Soviet Union. If you are calling 1-800-333-6988 it relates to the Washington metropolitan area's drug wars.

title: Retail Prices Up 0.3% for Month
description: Prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December, contained by a sharp drop for gasoline. For 1988 prices rose 4.4 percent, the same as in 1987.

title: Dow Inches Up 0.36 to Finish at 2,239.11
description: The stock market continued its peak-and-valley pattern yesterday, managing to eke out another post-crash high on the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising
description: A Campaign For Research On Animals

title: 6-Year-Old Boy Who Had Knife Is on Suspension
description: A first grader was suspended Wednesday for carrying a knife into the same Bronx elementary school where a 5-year-old student was found with a loaded pistol last week.

title: Fairchild Rejects Offer by Carlyle
description: Fairchild Industries, the military electronics contractor, rejected an unsolicited $264 million takeover bid by the Carlyle Group, an investment partnership in Washington. A statement issued by the company read in part, ''The proposed conditional cash purchase of $15.50 a share of common stock was financially inadequate and not in the best interests of Fairchild and all its stockholders.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: San Francisco Journal; Chilling Answer to Life After Death
description: Everyone knows that you can't take it with you. But if members of the American Cryonics Society Inc. have their way, they are going to come back and get it.

title: Shamrock Lifts Bid for Polaroid
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc. said today that it would raise its offer for the Polaroid Corporation by $3, to $45 a share, and begin a proxy fight for control of the company's board. The revised offer is worth $3.1 billion.

title: A Strained Welfare Unit, Another Child Dead
description: In the latest example of New York City's inability to track troubled families, a Bronx woman whose 10-month-old boy suffocated last week was supposed to be contacted by city caseworkers once a month but had not been visited since last April.

title: Miami's Vice: Living in Illusion
description: LEAD: This week's riots in Liberty City and Overtown once again have reminded Miamians that theirs is a real city with real problems. After the cocaine cowboys in the late 70's, the Mariel boatlift of the early 80's and recent arrival of tens of thousands of destitute refugees from Nicaragua, it may seem peculiar that Miamians could still view themselves as living in a tropical paradise conveniently located within the continental United

title: Hoyt S. Haddock, 81, a Maritime Unionist
description: Hoyt S. Haddock, a retired maritime union official who was a former president of the United Seamen's Service, died Tuesday at his home in Towson, Md., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: James Marshutz, Advertising Executive, 66
description: James Marshutz, an advertising executive and television producer, died of cancer Jan. 12 at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: Palestinian Is Killed In Protests in Gaza; Many Are Wounded
description: A Palestinian in the occupied Gaza Strip was killed by soldiers today and dozens of others were wounded during widespread violent protests against the army's harsh new measures to quell the Palestinian uprising.

title: Bogus Police Sought In Thruway Incident
description: The state police said yesterday that they were looking for two men who posed as police officers to pull a driver off the New England Thruway on New Year's Day and for the ''good Samaritan'' who may have saved her from harm.

title: Koop Foresees 50 Different Laws If Abortion Ruling Is Overturned
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, who opposes abortion, said today that if the Supreme Court returned control of abortion to the states, ''we'll have 50 problems instead of one.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary article and headline yesterday about a former executive vice president of the Atlantic Refining Company misidentified him. He was Harry G. Schad, not Shad.

title: To Flop Or Not To Flop?
description: WHEN the world pauses for the Super Bowl on Sunday, there may be no giddy spectacle of players writhing on the ground, trying to remember which knee to clutch, the way the Seattle Seahawks did three weeks ago, trying to evoke a free timeout.

title: A.T.P. Announces 1990 Schedule
description: The Association of Tennis Professionals unveiled its inaugural tour yesterday, a 77-event schedule for 1990 that includes new tournaments in China and the Soviet Union while omitting several major American events that had been fixtures of the tour operated by the Men's Tennis Council.

title: Neo-Classicism Sweeps Armory Show
description: WINGED horses, gilded eagles and an impressive gathering of Roman goddesses reign in Neo-Classical splendor among the urns, columns and obelisks spread throughout the Winter Antiques Show, opening today in previews and tomorrow to the public for a nine-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: John D. Hickerson, 91; Foreign Service Officer
description: John D. Hickerson, a former Ambassador and chairman of the group that established NATO, died of cancer Wednesday in Maryland at Bethesda Retirement and Nursing Center. He was 91 years old and lived in Washington.

title: 3 Banks Post Rise In Profits
description: Several more banks reported record quarterly earnings yesterday as they benefited from interest payments from Brazil that had been overdue since the beginning of 1987. Even excluding that unusual item, however, banks continued to show progress in controlling expenses and in generating additional fee income.

title: Life's Nightmare Continues For a Howard Beach Victim
description: Timothy Grimes's life had been deeply troubled even before he was a victim of violence two years ago in Howard Beach, Queens. Since then his problems have worsened.

title: G.E. Unit Executive Named As Kidder, Peabody Chief
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation, a financial subsidiary of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that Michael A. Carpenter, an executive vice president, had been named president and chief executive of its Kidder, Peabody Group.

title: Review/Music; Four Conducting Contestants Show Their Stuff
description: Four nervous but assured conductors, all Americans under 35 years of age, took their turns on the podium at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Each led the American Symphony Orchestra in bits of Beethoven's ''Egmont'' overture as well as Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' and Mozart's ''Jupiter'' symphonies; each accompanied an aria by Leonard Bernstein and rehearsed a difficult stretch of Aaron Copland's Orchestral Variations. Four older conductors, an orchestra executive and a critic listened attentively, and at the end of it all George Hanson was the 1989 winner of the Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition.

title: Corrections
description: The Lessons column on the Education page on Dec. 7, about Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, described Richard M. Nixon's 1968 campaign remarks about the Vietnam War incorrectly. Mr. Nixon pledged to end the war if elected President.

title: Tyson Sweetens Holly Farms Bid
description: The Holly Farms Corporation received a sweetened bid of $63.50 a share in cash from Tyson Foods Inc., the Springdale, Ark., chicken producer that made the original offer for Holly Farms in October. Holly Farms, based in Memphis, said its board was considering the latest bid by Tyson. Tyson's previous bid for Holly Farms was $60 a share in cash.

title: Hispanic Partnership Formed to Buy TV Stations
description: Hoping to take advantage of tax incentives available to television station owners who sell to minority buyers, Herman Badillo, Geraldo Rivera and three other Hispanic partners yesterday announced the formation of a partnership to acquire and manage stations in various markets around the country.

title: PRETORIA INSTALLS ACTING PRESIDENT
description: A senior member of the South African Cabinet was sworn in as Acting President today, 34 hours after President P. W. Botha suffered a mild stroke.

title: BUSH AIDE INSISTS ON NO TAX RISES, EVEN IN DISGUISE
description: Richard G. Darman, the chief architect of President-elect George Bush's budget policies, told Congress today that the new administration opposed all measures the public might perceive as tax increases and would not disguise tax proposals in euphemistic terms.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Advanced Micro Devices Inc. misstated its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1987. The company earned $262.5 million.

title: N.C.A.A. Presidents Urge Delay on Proposition 42
description: The presidents of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and of the organization's Presidents' Commission said today that they would recommend postponing the enactment of Proposition 42, the controversial proposal to tighten scholarship eligibility requirements for prospective freshman athletes.

title: Heading Off 'Junk Fax' At the Wire
description: Don't fax me, I'll fax you: Under a bill proposed in the Connecticut General Assembly, that would be the official message here to businesses, direct marketers and others who send unsolicited advertisements - ''junk fax'' - over the telephone wires.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''NO PROBLEM,'' #10 new vignettes by the Paper Bag Players, who romp and dance their way through ''The Great Mummy Robbery'' and ''The Paper Bag Rag'' as well as other numbers, to the music of Donald Ashwander and the direction of Judith Martin, who also wrote the material, 2 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, through Feb. 26, at the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway. Admission: $10. Reservations: 864-5400. ''FREEDOM TRAIN,'' a musical about Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad, with the book by Marvin Gordon and music arranged by Garrett Morris and Ron Burton, presented by Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. Saturday and Sunday, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Reservations: 677-5959. ''RUMPLESTILTSKIN,'' a musical comedy presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1 P.M. and 2:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''ADVENTURES OF A BOY AND HIS DOG IN OUTER SPACE,'' a comedy by the Mum Puppet Theater, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, at the Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic-and-comedy show, with audience participation, presented by George Schindler and Imam 2 P.M. Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472. ''THE BEAST,'' a musical by Tom Oliver, with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Rose That Refused to Bloom,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677.

title: Group Urges Doctors to Fight Malnutrition in AIDS Patients
description: Aggressive efforts to improve nutrition, including intravenous feeding and other medical intervention when necessary, could greatly improve the quality of life and possibly extend the lives of AIDS patients, a study group said today.

title: Inflation Slows in New York Area
description: Consumer prices in the metropolitan New York area rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, finishing the year with an inflation rate that was markedly lower than that in 1987, the Labor Department's regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: San Jose Boycott
description: Ten members of San Jose State's team who demanded the dismissal of Coach Bill Berry were replaced by eight walk-ons for the game last night at Fullerton State. Four replacements, who joined the four remaining members of the team, are football players, including the tailback Johnny Johnson. Only one walk-on, 6-foot-9-inch Craig McPherson, a transfer from Santa Clara, has college experience. Berry held an open tryout Wednesday night after a delegation of players met with Randy Hoffman, the athletic director, complained of abuse by Berry and said 10 of the 14 regular players would not play again until the coach quit or was dismissed. The school said Berry, in his 10th season as coach, will remain at least through the end of the season. The boycotting players' scholarship status will be determined in the next week, said a university spokeswoman, Karen Rosenzweig. San Jose State (5-11) lost its last five games and is 1-6 in the Big West Conference. Berry's overall record is 142-132.(AP)

title: African Bishops Urge Peace
description: Roman Catholic bishops from nine southern African nations appealed today to governments and guerrillas in the region to make peace. The letter, written after three years of research and approved by Pope John Paul II when he visited Zimbabwe in September, was published her by the Inter-Regional Meeting of Bishops of Southern Africa.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Radio-Print Campaign For the Sisters of Mercy Radio-Print Campaign For the Sisters of Mercy
description: ''You won't find her program for success inside a computer,'' one print ad says. Another says, ''Her promotion to vice president meant picking up a sponge and a mop.'' These are among the four print ads and a 60-second radio spot promoting the Sisters of Mercy, a Roman Catholic order that has received a grant for the project from the Catholic Communications Campaign.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * An anti-crack radio campaign, featuring the 1950's hit song ''Yakety Yak,'' with new lyrics recorded by the original group, the Coasters, has been produced by Mark & Jeff's Jingle Company, San Francisco, and financed by Foote, Cone & Belding/ San Francisco, for the Partnership for a Drug Free America.

title: Owner of Canadian Air Will Acquire Wardair
description: In a move that will reduce competition in domestic air travel in Canada to only two significant carriers, the PWA Corporation announced today that it planned to acquire all outstanding shares in Wardair Inc. of Toronto.

title: Irish Player Dies
description: Bob Satterfield, a Notre Dame player, collapsed at a nightclub and died yesterday, a few hours after returning with his teammates from a White House visit, school officials said. A preliminary autopsy indicated that Satterfield, 22 years old, suffered a seizure followed by cardiac arrest, said the Notre Dame sports-information director, John Heisler. Test results showed no alcohol or drugs in Satterfield's blood at the time of his death, Heisler said. The results did not indicate what caused the seizure. Satterfield, of Los Angeles, died at 3 A.M. at Pawating Hospital in Niles, Mich., after collapsing at O'Tay's Nite Club in Niles, about five miles north of the campus in South Bend, Ind., Heisler said. Notre Dame finished 12-0 and No. 1 in the final polls after defeating West Virginia in the Fiesta Bowl. The Irsh met with President Reagan at the Rose Garden. (AP)

title: F.B.I. SAID TO STUDY CHICAGO CHEATING IN FUTURES TRADES
description: Officials of Chicago's commodities exchanges acknowledged today that Federal investigators were looking into trading activities to determine whether investors had been defrauded.

title: Exit the Music Man
description: Already the spotlight is turning away. In a few more hours, President Reagan will snap off a parting salute and be gone. Come noon, it will be George Bush's day, city and Government. But there will be time to think about all that. For the moment, Ronald Reagan is still President and he remains, to the end, both amazing and comfortable; it's a fit time to contemplate why.

title: Our Towns; Pulling America To the Twistless, Droopless Blind
description: Homeowners don't know it, but they're about to have a new consumer need developed. The typical suburbanite thought he was doing great a few years ago when he got rid of the heavy venetian blinds with the fat slats and bought those skinny wonders, thin-slatted aluminum mini-blinds. Forget it. America does not stand still. You are about to feel a need for a horizontal window blind made of fabric. ''You'll notice it next month,'' said George Shouldis, window coverings president of Hunter Douglas.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have just a slight sense that Bush may turn out to be more of a tribune of the people than he chose to suggest in the campaign. We may find noblesse oblige replacing greed as the White House style.'' - Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. [ A11:3. ]

title: Top Official of Israeli Labor Party Quits
description: Uzi Baram resigned as Secretary General of the Labor Party today, formalizing a split in the party's ranks that may create new leaders for Labor in the months ahead.

title: Giuliani Says Efforts on Drug Abuse Are Wanting
description: In a speech that could serve as a mayoral campaign theme, United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani declared yesterday that the Federal, state and local governments have not done enough to combat drug abuse and addiction. But he conceded that the problem could not be solved, only reduced.

title: Buyout Curbs Draw Concern
description: Congress should move cautiously on proposals to restrict leveraged buyouts for fear of stifling economic growth, the House Ways and Means Committee chairman said today.

title: Nabisco to Shed South Africa Units
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York investment firm that recently won control of RJR Nabisco Inc. with a record $24.88 billion bid, said yesterday that it would sell Nabisco's South African operations.

title: Link of Smoking and Heart Disease Reported
description: Heart disease patients who smoke are three times more likely to have chest pains and restricted blood flow to their hearts than those who do not, researchers say in a new study.

title: U.S.S.R. Says It Will Withdraw More Nuclear Arms From Europe
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union announced today that Soviet troops leaving Eastern Europe under a previously announced reduction would take their battlefield nuclear weapons with them.

title: Sounds Around Town; Specialty Singing
description: Stephanie Nakasian and Hod O'Brien, Chez Beauvais, 852 10th Avenue, at 56th Street (581-6340). Hod O'Brien started out in the 1950's as a be-bop pianist influenced by Bud Powell. He has since developed a very different style, one closer to the rumbling, swaggering lines of Dave McKenna. In recent years, he has been teamed with Miss Nakasian, a singer who spent two years in Jon Hendricks's vocal group singing the ''trumpet'' parts Mr. Hendricks wrote for Annie Ross when she was the high voice in the trio of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross. The solo specialties of Mr. O'Brien and Miss Nakasian give their programs unusual variety and, when they join forces in duets, a provocative combination of virtuosic scat singing and dark, driving rhythm. They can be heard at 9 and 11 tonight and tomorrow. There is a $7 cover charge and an $8 minimum. JOHN S. WILSON Wild at the Algonquin

title: Pension Fund Acts
description: The Merchant Navy Officers Pension Fund said it planned to sell from time to time its 6.9 percent stake in First Union Real Estate Equity and Mortgage Investments, a real estate investment trust in Cleveland. The Merchant Navy fund, which provides pensions for retired officers of the British Merchant Navy, controls 1.24 million First Union shares. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Merchant Navy said it had sold 150,000 First Union shares last week for prices ranging from $18 to $18.25 a share. The British pension fund gave no reason for the decision to sell the shares. First Union's shares slipped 37.5 cents today, to $19.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Tokyo Journal; A Fear of Cancer Means No Telling
description: The biggest conspiracy of silence in recent Japanese medical history started sometime in late 1987, in a secret meeting at the University of Tokyo.

title: At the Top: The Senior Aide Corps
description: JOHN H. SUNUNU: White House Chief of Staff A 49-year-old engineer retiring as Governor of New Hampshire . . . Credited with helping Mr. Bush to victory in the New Hampshire primary . . . became increasingly a key player in the campaign, taking on the role of chief critic of the Democratic nominee, Michael S. Dukakis . . . politically conservative . . . regarded as hard-charging, blunt and decisive . . . worked with Congress as Governor but lacks significant Washington experience . . . born in Havana and received bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees at M.I.T. . . . married, eight children. C. BOYDEN GRAY: Counsel to the President A 44-year-old, soft-spoken lawyer . . . long-time confidant to Mr. Bush . . . shares a wealthy background and many of Mr. Bush's interests . . . has been Mr. Bush's legal counsel since 1981, working out of the spotlight . . . he is active in the fields of regulatory revision and ethics . . . formerly associated with the prominent Washington law firm Wilmer, Cutler and Pickering . . . 1964 graduate of Harvard, magna cum laude . . . law degree, first in his class at the University of North Carolina . . . clerked for Chief Justice Earl Warren . . . married, one child. GEORGE W. BUSH: Adviser to the President At 42, the President's eldest son . . . Behind-the-scenes adviser to his father . . . left the oil business last May to work full-time on the Presidential campaign, visiting more than 30 states . . . Strong interest in politics . . . was narrowly defeated in 1978 for Congress seat from Texas' 19th District . . . Lives in Texas and is considering a campaign for governor . . . Offers advice to Mr. Bush on a range of issues, including appointments . . . graduate of Yale . . . master of business administration degree at Harvard . . . married, two daughters. FREDERICK D. McCLURE: Chief Congress lobbyist At 34 years old, long associated with former Senator John G. Tower of Texas . . . returning to government from executive post for Texas Air Corporation . . . no role in the Bush Presidential campaign . . . Mr. Tower's support may make Mr. McClure the highest black official in the new White House . . . special assistant to President Reagan for legislative affairs . . . Associate Deputy Attorney General . . . Tower legislative director . . . Graduate of Texas A & M, summa cum laude, law degree from Baylor University in 1981 . . . married, two children. DAVID F. DEMAREST: Communications Director A 37-year-old New Jersey native who was Mr. Bush's communications director in the Presidential campaign . . . Reagan Administration post in public and intergovernmental affairs . . . Entered government working for Bill Brock . . . Followed him to Labor Department . . . Jersey Republican political strategist in the late 1970's, participating in seven Congressional campaigns . . . Field coordinator for local election campaign division of the Republican National Committee . . . received bachelor's degree from Upsala College in 1973 . . . married, one daughter. CHARLES G. UNTERMEYER: Ass't for Personnel A 42-year-old Texan who worked for Mr. Bush in his 1966 Congressional campaign . . . Executive assistant when Mr. Bush became Vice President . . . has Mr. Bush's trust, evident in this appointment . . . expected to help in filling political posts in the new administration . . . Former reporter for The Houston Chronicle, he insists on speaking on the record . . . Congressman, 1977 to 1981 . . . left Mr. Bush's staff in 1983 to become Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Navy . . . born in New Jersey, reared in Texas . . . honors graduate of Harvard . . . single.

title: White House Ordered To Save Message Files
description: A Federal district judge issued a restraining order tonight that bars the Government from destroying computer files containing interoffice messages sent by Reagan Administration officials on the White House computer.

title: Dining Out Guide: Tropical Settings
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Caribe Diner's Journal (March 14, 1986), 117 Perry Street (255-9191) - A jungle of palms thrives at Caribe, an informal Greenwich Village restaurant with flamingo-pink walls and wicker furniture. Accompanied by reggae, the food is a mix of specialties from several Caribbean islands and includesthe Jamaican national dish, ackee and salt fish. On the menu are black bean soup, jerked chicken (chicken baked with West Indian spices), braised oxtail that comes with fried plantain and rice and beans, and spiced and baked whole red snapper. Appetizers are $2.50 to $3.95, entrees $6.95 to $9.95. Open 4 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday, 4 to 11 P.M. Sunday. Claire ** (Sept. 23, 1988), 156 Seventh Avenue, near 20th Street (255-1955) -Claire in Chelsea has a twin establishment in Key West; the New York outpost takes the chill off winter with tropical flower arrangements and palms, ceiling fans and latticework. This seafood house has a Thai chef, accounting for the distinctive and spicy preparations. Recommended starters include the conch chowder, and crayfish and rock shrimp in garlic and lemon. Cayenne-spiked crab cakes are served with a cilantro sauce. Other entrees are Key West grouper, tilefish with fresh basil, and grilled mahi-mahi with stir-fried vegetables. Appetizers are $5.95 to $8.95, entrees $11 to $22. Lunch from noon to 4 P.M., limited menu 4 to 5:30 P.M., dinner 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Friday to Sunday. Indochine ** (Nov. 25, 1988), 430 Lafayette Street (505-5111) - This still-trendy, still-noisy downtown restaurant serves a mix of Vietnamese and Cambodian cuisines. Southeast Asia of an earlier age is evoked by the palm fronds and banana leaves hand painted on white walls. The kitchen is skilled in deep-frying, as demonstrated by Vietnamese spring rolls. Other good dishes for starters or main courses are the steamed shrimp salad with mint and lemongrass; fish steamed in banana leaf, and spicy beef salad with lemongrass and shallots. Appetizers are $5.50 to $11.50, main courses $10.50 to $16.50. Dinner 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Friday to Sunday. Jezebel ** (Aug. 28, 1987), 630 Ninth Avenue, at 45th Street (582-1045) - Jezebel's dining room is dressed in palms, piano shawls and wicker. Overhead fans gently stir the lacy fabric draped over the ceiling pipes. All that's missing is a veranda. This restaurant, a short walk from Broadway theaters, is noteworthy for authentic soul food. Start with good corn bread or baking-powder biscuits, the smothered garlic shrimp, rib bits, or she-crab soup. Main-course portions are large and include peppery fried chicken, roast chicken with waffles, and Carolina shrimp creole. Appetizers are $5.75 to $6.75, entrees $15.75 to $21.75. Dinner at 6, 7, 9 and 9:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday. No reservations required after 10 P.M.; food served until 11:45. Closed Sunday. Manhattan Island * (Sept. 11, 1987), 482 West 43d Street (967-0533) - Manhattan Island's two informal dining rooms, with a view of a swimming pool, have a leafy tropical theme. White-framed fan windows are hung on walls covered with palm-printed paper, and in warmer months, patrons can dine on the outdoor terrace. Coconut fried shrimp and corn chowder are two appetizers on the current menu. Among the other dishes are plump crab cakes with cole slaw, paillard of chicken sandwich, grilled rib-eye steak, and chicken hash in a bubbling casserole. Appetizers are $3.50 to $7, entrees $8 to $17. Open noon to 9 P.M. Friday to Sunday; brunch noon to 4 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: Windborne Dollars
description: As might have been expected, when a bumbling bank robber dropped the $2,900 he had just stolen from Redlands Federal Savings on Tuesday, passersby quickly gathered to grab what was blowing in the wind. What they caught they returned to the bank. All but $20 was turned in, said Sgt. Dan Castellini. He said the the missing $20 bill probably blew away before anyone could grab it. The robber got away.

title: Show and a Concert of William and Mary
description: The exhibition ''The Age of William III and Mary II; Power; Politics and Patronage, 1688-1702'' continues through Jan. 28 at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street. For the first time on display outside the archives of the House of Lords, is the Declaration of Rights, which effectively established parliamentary rule in Britain and is considered the most important document in English history after Magna Carta. Free. Hours: Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The exhibition will be closed tomorrow. A concert of music from the period of William and Mary, ''Sweeter Than Roses,'' is to be presented by the Folger consort of Washington tonight at 7 at the Club. Tickets: $8.50.

title: Diner's Journal; Gage & Tollner
description: Gage & Tollner, the 110-year-old landmark Brooklyn restaurant operated by the Dewey family since 1919, was sold late last year to a partnership headed by Peter Aschkenasy, a Manhattan restaurateur who has vowed to keep its 19th-century character, including its faded tin ceiling, burnished wood walls and period chandeliers. In an attempt to revitalize the food, he has hired Edna Lewis, a veteran cook and the author of three books on Southern cuisine. Mrs. Lewis was a co-owner of Cafe Nicholson in the 1940's.

title: Murray Chris-Craft Will End Business
description: Murray Chris-Craft Inc. will close next Friday, ending a 50-year presence as a manufacturer of pleasure boats. Chris-Craft's debt-ridden parent company, Murray Industries of Bradenton, Fla., made the announcement Wednesday to the 70 workers at the Holland Township plant, which employed about 600 workers as recently as 1983.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Big B Inc., Birmingham, Ala., a drugstore chain, said it would acquire Reed Drug Co., a unit of Peoples Drug Stores Inc., Alexandria, Va., for about $50 million.

title: Prices of Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Treasury note and bond prices closed narrowly mixed yesterday as the fixed-income securities markets were again dominated by the gyrations in the dollar. Dealers said that moves by several European countries to raise domestic interest rates were ignored by the bond market, as were several economic reports that would usually be considered positive for the market.

title: Reviews/Art; An Antic Hymn to a Never-Elegant New York
description: As George McNeil gets older, his work gets younger. The new paintings by this nearly 81-year-old artist step out of his disco series, but they are even more topsy-turvy, even more antic. They are a hymn to New York City, composed by someone for whom Manhattan has the packed, labyrinthine concentration of medieval Celtic manuscripts.

title: Study Ties Race and New York City Pay Disparities
description: Although the number of black and Hispanic workers in New York City government has increased, whites continue to hold a disproportionate share of the highest-paying jobs, a study by the Community Service Society has found.

title: Death-Plot Fugitive Seeking to Return
description: A fugitive convicted in 1968 of plotting to murder two civil rights leaders, Roy Wilkins and Whitney M. Young Jr., has made overtures to return to New York, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Vasconcelos and Band
description: Nana Vasconcelos and his Brazilian-funk band Bush Dancers are to perform tonight at midnight at B#2, 157 Hudson Street (966-5881). Tickets are $15; doors open at 10 P.M..

title: Irving Resnick, Gambling Figure, 72
description: Irving (Ash) Resnick, a gambling figure credited with bringing high rollers to the Las Vegas Strip, died Wednesday after a long bout with cancer. He was 72 years old.

title: Title Bid Is 3d For Jones in '89
description: Steve Jones's attempt to win a third consecutive PGA Tour event got off to a fair start today in the first round of the Phoenix Open as he shot three-under-par 68.

title: European Units Acquired by UPS
description: United Parcel Service announced the acquisition of seven transport companies, which it said would strengthen its operations in Europe and the Pacific. The acquisitions, whose terms were not disclosed, will also facilitate the company's expansion into the Middle East and Africa, it said.

title: Atlanta Transit Authority Sets $143.6 Million Offering
description: The Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority is offering $143.6 million in sales tax revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of about 7.437 percent for an issue due in 2010, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: On Eve, Everything's Coming Up Relatives
description: Like hundreds of his brothers, sisters, aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews and cousins, George Bush Jr. was scrambling through the traffic-choked streets of Washington today, rushing from event to event to event.

title: Rebel Camp on Thai Border Captured by Burmese Troops
description: Burmese Government troops backed by mortars captured a major rebel camp near the Thai-Burmese frontier, sending 600 civilians of the Karen ethnic group fleeing to Thailand, Thai officials said today.

title: Annette Krebs, 72; Led a Literacy Project
description: Annette Krebs, a former director of the adult literacy project of the Massachusetts Council for Public Schools, died of Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at her home in Newton, Mass. She was 72 years old.

title:
About Real Estate;
Queens Firehouse to Be Converted
description: LEAD: During its 40 years as a firehouse, the building at 89-56 162d Street in Jamaica, Queens, was known as ''the big house'' because of its size. The building, which occupies a 95-foot-by-73-foot site just north of Jamaica Avenue, was home to a ladder company and three engine companies, and served as a battalion headquarters until it was closed in 1965.

title: TV Weekend; The Woman Who Loved Melba Toast
description: A couple of long shows are on tap this weekend. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, ''Great Performances'' begins the four-part ''Melba,'' a weekly mini-series that tells more than you probably care to know about the legendary soprano from Australia. And Sunday at 9 P.M., NBC is offering the first half of a four-hour television movie adapted from the David Morrell thriller ''Brotherhood of the Rose.'' The conclusion can be seen Monday. Nellie Melba (1861-1931) is played in this Amalgamated Global production by Linda Cropper, who lip-syncs when necessary to the pleasingly delicate voice of Yvonne Kenny. Unlike the breezy 1953 British movie starring Patrice Munsel as the diva, this biography, written by Roger McDonald and directed by Rodney Fisher, takes Nellie very seriously.

title: Sounds Around Town; DUELING DECIBELS
description: Blind Idiot God, B.A.L.L., Reverb Mofos and Rude Buddha at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052). Rough, brute-force rock -pounding drums, distorted guitars, disheveled vocals - takes the stage tomorrow at CBGB. Blind Idiot God, at 11:30 P.M., plays bruising instrumentals that embrace dub reggae, hard-rock and Stravinsky; B.A.L.L., at 12:30 A.M., plays grinding, lumbering, sometimes off-handedly funny songs; the Reverb Mofos, at about 1:30 A.M., bash away like a latter-day Steppenwolf. Rude Buddha opens at 10:30 P.M. Earplugs are essential. Admission is $7. JON PARELES Sun Ra's Outer Spaces

title: Brooklyn Man Held In Rape of Girl, 11
description: A maintenance worker at a Brooklyn day-care center was arrested Wednesday and charged with the rape of an 11-year-old girl, the police said.

title: D'Amato Urges Defense Lawyer For U.S. Attorney
description: Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato will ask the Justice Department to name Otto G. Obermaier, a top defense lawyer in New York, to be the next United States Attorney in Manhattan, a spokeswoman for the Senator confirmed last night.

title: Carlos Carrillo, Psychiatrist, 64
description: Dr. Carlos Carrillo, a psychiatrist and physician, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Administration Lauds Own Homeless Efforts
description: A White House report made available today lauded Federal efforts to combat homelessness, but concluded that state, local and private groups bear most of the responsibility for addressing the problem.

title: KEY RATES
Steinberg Lawyers Say Nussbaum Killed Lisa
description: Defense lawyers said yesterday that it was a jealous and deceitful Hedda Nussbaum who murdered Lisa Steinberg, not Joel B. Steinberg, who is accused of beating the 6-year-old child to death.

title: Japan to Be No. 1 Giver of Foreign Aid
description: The Japanese Government today made public a budget for 1989 that will, for the first time, make it the world's largest donor and lender of foreign aid.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Agreed to terms with Mark Thurmond, pitcher, on a one-year contract. CLEVELAND (AL) - Agreed to terms with Brook Jacoby, third baseman, on a two-year contract. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Agreed to terms with Ray Searage, pitcher, on a one-year contract. MONTREAL (NL) - Agreed to terms with Pascual Perez, pitcher, on a one-year contract and with Kevin Gross, pitcher, on a two-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NL) -Signed Don Carman, pitcher, to a one-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Agreed to terms with Rafael Belliard, shortstop, on a one-year contract. HOCKEY N.H.L. - Named Ron Hoggarth referee and Ron Asselstine and Wayne Bonney linesmen for the All-Star Game. HARTFORD (NHL) - Announced that Marc Laforge, defenseman, would report to Indianapolis of the International Hockey League. DEVILS (NHL) - Recalled Craig Billington, goaltender, from Utica of the American Hockey League. WINNIPEG (NHL) - Traded Alain Chevrier, goalie, to Chicago for future considerations. Recalled Brad Berry, defenseman, from Moncton of the American Hockey League.

title: Lawyer for striking air traffic controllers won back 60 jobs but suffered personal loss
description: More than 11,000 air traffic controllers lost their jobs in their ill-fated strike of 1981. Jack Solerwitz, the lawyer who represented many of them, arguably lost even more.

title: Micro D Takes Ingram Offer
description: Micro D Inc., a distributor of microcomputer hardware, software and books, said today that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by Ingram Industries for $14.75 a share in cash. Ingram, a privately held company based in Nashville, already owns about 59 percent of Micro D, of Santa Ana, Calif. Ingram began a tender offer

title: Dr. Michael B. Shimkin, 76, Dies; Helped Link Smoking and Cancer
description: Dr. Michael B. Shimkin, a researcher who helped establish the link between smoking and lung cancer, died of a stroke Monday at the Medical Center of the University of California at San Diego. He was 76 years old and lived in LaJolla.

title: Ohio Doctor Offers to Quit
description: A gynecologist who faces charges from the State Medical Board that he performed unnecessary surgery on women has offered to surrender his certificate to practice medicine, his lawyer, Earl Moore, said Tuesday. Dr. James C. Burt asserted that the genital surgery would enhance sexual responsiveness. But it caused sexual dysfunction, infection and the need for corrective surgery in many patients, the medical board charged.

title: Wilander Is Upset In Australia
description: Ramesh Krishnan of India defeated Mats Wilander, 6-3, 6-2, 7-6, in the second round of the Australian Open today, leaving the top-ranked player in the world contemplating a complete break from the sport.

title: King Accuses Cayton
description: Don King castigated Bill Cayton for a second day yesterday as he gave his deposition in the suit that Mike Tyson has brought against Cayton, his manager, to void their contract, which runs until February 1992. During six hours of questioning by Thomas Puccio, Cayton's attorney, King accused Cayton of ''double-dipping'' on foreign sales for Tyson's championship fights against Larry Holmes, Tony Tubbs and Michael Spinks. He testified that Cayton took 20 percent off the top of the sales and deposited the rest into the general gross pool of which he and Lorraine Jacobs, widow of Jimmy Jacobs, who died last March, shared 20 percent. Jimmy Jacobs and Cayton were Tyson's co-managers. Puccio, responding to King's deposition, said: ''We don't accept any of these charges. Bill Cayton will be deposed on Feb. 16-17 and at that time all these questions will be raised and answered.'' . . . Tyson, who was training in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday, said he may reunite with the trainer Kevin Rooney after his fight against Frank Bruno. Tyson met with reporters after boxing six rounds with sparring partners in a tiny gym where he is working out for the Feb. 25 fight.

title: Joys of the Bank That Stays Together
description: YOU hear it immediately: the crystalline blend of the instruments, the effortless elegance of the musicians, the subtle shadings of the beat that are acknowledged on the bandstand by a sideways glance and a smile. It's the sound of musical empathy, the sound of a band that plays together regularly -one that's more than willing to produce extraordinary music on any bandstand at any time. Jazz's miracle, spontaneous invention, works best with people familiar with each other. This weekend, the foremost exponents of the band-as-surrogate-family - the Modern Jazz Quartet, the Mingus Dynasty band and a new addition to the circle, the Harper Brothers band - are working their magic across town.

title: Reviews/Music; Blues and Country Sounds From Cowboy Junkies
description: In great blues and country performances, there's usually a moment where the music drops to a hush and the singer quietly confesses stark, primal terrors. Cowboy Junkies, a Canadian band that sold out the Bottom Line on Tuesday, want to extend that moment through its entire repertory.

title: Reviews/Music; Christopher Young Plays Varied Works
description: Christopher Young, the organist who won the American Guild of Organist's National Young Artist Competition last year, offered a stylistically varied recital program on Wednesday evening at Park Avenue Christian Church. In works ranging from a 17th-century Bruhns Praeludium through a recent William Albright piece, Mr. Young proved a distinguished interpreter with a firm, commanding technique.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: A.L. Laboratories, Inc., Fort Lee, N.J., a maker of generic pharmaceuticals and animal health micronutrients, named John T. Janssen to the newly created post of chief financial officer of its subsidiary Barre-National Inc., Baltimore.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Walliser Wins Again: Maria Walliser of Switzerland won her second World Cup race of the season, defeating Carole Merle of France yesterday in a women's downhill in Tignes, France. Walliser was timed in 1 minute 19.16 seconds. Merle, who moved to second place in the overall standing, was clocked in 1:19.57. Michaela Gerg of West Germany was third in 1:19.63. Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, who did not compete in the downhill, retained commanding hold on first place in the overall standing. (AP) FIGURE SKATING Leistner in Lead: Claudia Leistner of West Germany took the lead after the women's compulsory figures yesterday at the European championships in Birmingham, England, and Soviet skaters led in two other events. Leistner was ranked first in both figures, which count for 20 percent of the total score. Marina Klimova and Sergei Ponomarenko led a Soviet sweep of the top places in the dance after the original set pattern presentation. The dance ends tomorrow. The British champion, Joanne Conway, was second in the women's event, with Natalya Gorbenko of the Soviet Union third. Aleksandr Fadeyev of the Soviet Union, seeking his fourth European title, was the leader in the men's singles. (AP) N.B.A. Bulls 112, Heat 108: Michael Jordan scored 34 points at Miami last night as the Bulls took their sixth consecutive victory and ninth in 11 games. Rory Sparrow of Miami scored 11 points and Kelvin Upshaw 10 in the fourth quarter and Rony Seikaly made his first 3-point goal of the year with 35 seconds left to cut the margin to 110-108. Craig Hodges of Chicago hit two free throws with 10 seconds left. Sparrow led Miami with 27 points. (AP) Bullets 115, Spurs 112: Jeff Malone scored 29 points, and Bernard King had 22 and a key steal in the closing seconds for the Bullets at Landover, Md. San Antonio has lost seven straight, five on the road, and has not beaten the Bullets in the last five meetings. Alvin Robertson led the Spurs with 30 points. (AP) Suns 126, Hornets 112: Jeff Hornacek had a career-high 28 points and Eddie Johnson had 8 during a 10-1 third-quarter run for the Suns at Charlotte, N.C. Hornacek, whose previous high was 24 points, made 11 of 15 shots. Tom Chambers had 31 points and 13 rebounds for the Suns. Kelly Tripucka scored 27 points for Charlotte. (AP) Cavaliers 113, Pacers 106: Mark Price scored 29 points and Brad Daugherty added 25 as the Cavaliers handed Indiana its fourth consecutive loss. Cleveland, with the best league record at 28-7, won its third straight game.(AP) HOCKEY Flames 7, Bruins 2: Mark Hunter had four goals for the Flames last night in Boston. He had just 7 goals in 36 previous games this year.(AP) Maple Leafs 3, North Stars 3: Daniel Marois scored with 1 minute 20 seconds left in regulation to give the host Maple Leafs the tie. Bob Brooke's goal at 14:12 of the second period had given the North Stars a 3-2 lead. (AP) Whalers 6, Canadiens 4: Jody Hull's power-play goal midway through the third period capped a four-goal flurry in a 5-minute-43-second span as the Whalers overcame a four-goal deficit at Hartford. (AP)

title: Borman's to Fight Stockholders' Suit
description: Borman's Inc. said it would contest a lawsuit by shareholders who say they sold their stock at artificially low prices at a time company officials were holding secret acquisition talks with the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

title: Marcos's Health Takes Bad Turn, Court Told
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos's health took a turn for the worse yesterday, his doctors said, while a court in New York was holding a hearing on whether the former Philippine President is too ill to stand trial.

title: Ohio State Upsets Cold Iowa by 102-91
description: Jay Burson scored 26 points and No. 16 Ohio State ran away from No. 7 Iowa tonight, defeating the Hawkeyes, 102-91, in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: Edgar P. Mannix, 75, a Thoracic Surgeon
description: Dr. Edgar P. Mannix Jr., a thoracic surgeon and former director of surgery at the St. Francis Hospital Heart Center in Roslyn, L.I., died Jan. 9 at his home in Escondido, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: Selection of Baker Wins Endorsement Of Senate Committee
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to recommend confirmation by the full Senate of James A. Baker 3d as the Bush Administration's Secretary of State.

title: U.S. to Let Oil Companies Operate Again in Libya
description: President Reagan announced today that he was modifying trade restrictions against Libya to allow American oil companies to resume operations there and avoid a Libyan takeover of their assets.

title: Dr. Hubert Beck, 81, A Retired Professor
description: Dr. Hubert Park Beck, a psychologist and retired professor of educational psychology, died of cardiac arrest Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pentagon, Not Social Security, Made the Deficit; Double Tax Jeopardy
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonnell Shares Up on Order Report
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation's stock climbed today after it was reported that the aircraft company was close to obtaining an order of up to $7.4 billion from the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines Inc. McDonnell Douglas closed $1.50 higher today, at $82.50 a share on the Big Board.

title: Hitachi Sued By Motorola
description: Motorola Inc. filed a lawsuit Wednesday charging that Hitachi Ltd. had infringed on several of its patents and was engaging in unfair competition in the sale of microprocessors. In the lawsuit filed in United

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 In Poland, leaders published the text of the Communist Party resolution calling for talks leading to legalization of new trade unions, including Solidarity, which was banned more than six years ago. Page A1

title: From George Washington to George Bush, Speeches and Parades, Dances and Tradition
description: Of the 50 formal inaugural ceremonies that have installed American Presidents from George Washington to Ronald Reagan, only a handful remain memorable.

title: Consumer Prices Increase 0.3%; Year's Rise Matches 4.4% of '87
description: Retail prices rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Jokers and Leaders Keep Teams Together
description: They have talked enough about the blitz to make them blue and plenty more about who will shuffle last and who will slip first, who has the edge and who has the heart in Super Bowl XXIII. They have played the game 100 times in practices and several times more in their sleep.

title: Residents Assail Plan for A-Waste Dump
description: The anger was audible here Wednesday night as 500 people filled a high school auditorium to hear state officials explain why an 86-square-mile parcel in Washington County is being considered for a low-level radioactive waste dump.

title: Aldo DeDominicis, Broadcaster, 85
description: Aldo DeDominicis, who founded the first television station in New England, died Tuesday at Hartford Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Cheshire, Mr. DeDominicis and a partner, Patrick Goode, financed and built what is now WTNH-TV in New Haven in 1948. Earlier in the 40's, Mr. DeDominicis was a co-founder of WNHC-AM in New Haven and bought stations in New Britain that he renamed WRCH-AM and FM. He was a native of Italy. Surviving are a brother who lives in Italy and six nephews.

title: Gene Combination Tied to Higher Risk of Multiple Sclerosis
description: Scientists said yesterday that they had found that two genes, when inherited together, heightened the risk of developing multiple sclerosis, a severe and mysterious disease of the central nervous system.

title: Gooden and Darling File for Big Pay Increases
description: The high price of success was spelled out yesterday when more than 100 baseball players and their teams exchanged salary arbitration numbers and Dwight Gooden joined Orel Hershiser, Roger Clemens and Kirby Puckett in asking for salaries of more than $2 million.

title: Barron and Mitchell
description: The duo of Kenny Barron on piano and Red Mitchell on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:30 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.

title:
LAW;
Computers Assuming New Roles at Law Firms
description: LEAD: Computers are changing the practice of law, performing a widening variety of legal tasks and even imitating the lawyer's stock-in-trade: the ability to ''think like a lawyer.''

title: Review/Theater; Evoking Bohemian Memories
description: In her quest for novel ''site specific'' locations for environmental theater, Anne Hamburger has taken intrepid audiences into abandoned storefronts, converted warehouses and city streets, from which we watched a play enacted on and around the facade of a high-rise apartment building. The latest excursion of Ms. Hamburger's En Garde Arts company is to the Chelsea Hotel, with a series of performance-art events featuring downtown artists and evoking the hotel's bohemian past.

title: Power for a Friend
description: President Reagan's power is dwindling fast, but he can still do a few favors for friends.

title: Review/Art; 'Museum-cum-Semnar': The Janis Gallery at 40
description: Long before he opened a gallery, Sidney Janis bought works, by Picasso and Leger and Brancusi, and he purchased a painting from Mondrian in 1930 for $70, which even at the time seemed an awfully good deal. Mr. Janis was a shrewd businessman, having made a fortune selling shirts (this, following a stint dancing the hesitation waltz and the one-step on the Gus Sun Time vaudeville circuit). When he decided, in 1948, at the age of 52, that it was time to open his own gallery, Mr. Janis believed with certainty in what he liked, had established friendships with leading School of Paris artists, and had amassed for himself a private collection of 20th-century art virtually unmatched in this country.

title: Confessed Rapist Fails to Surrender
description: A man who said he was the rapist who has attacked seven women in the subway called the police yesterday and arranged to surrender, but then failed to show up, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said.

title: Croatian Official Chosen to Be Yugoslav Premier
description: Ante Markovic, a member of the collective presidency of Croatia who is regarded as a supporter of economic change, was chosen as Yugoslavia's Prime Minister today.

title: Steinbrenner Pardoned by Reagan For '72 Election Law Violations
description: President Reagan has pardoned George M. Steinbrenner 3d, owner of the New York Yankees, for convictions connected with illegal contributions to the 1972 campaign of Richard M. Nixon, a White House official disclosed today.

title: The All-Purpose Inaugural Address
description: Presidents' inaugural addresses from George Washington onward have dwelled on similar themes. Turn them upside-down, shake them out, and one can excerpt and assemble the parts into a single all-purpose speech, like the following. (The authors are footnoted below.)

title: Koch Clarifies Comment on S.R.O. Law
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he had not meant to suggest last week that city officials and City Council members had publicly discussed a change in a city law that benefited the developer Harry Macklowe.

title: Zimbabwe Reads of Officials' Secrets
description: One of the scarcest commodities in Zimbabwe these days is a spunky newspaper that has been attracting national attention with tales of wrongdoing in high places.

title: Pennsylvania Light Mortgage Bonds
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company is offering $125 million in 10 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2019 at a price of 99.35, to yield 10.7 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: The Fullback Is a Throwback
description: From September to January he's a flattop kind of guy. Tom Rathman could not explain why his hair, which grows out when the football season ends, becomes a flattop again each year when it's time to return to work. ''It's just something I do,'' he said. Rathman is 6 feet 1 inch and 232 pounds, and his appearance reflects a role that is functional and basic. Rathman's picture will not sell T-shirts, not even with the help of a playoff goatee that will soon disappear. His touchdowns do not lead to dance steps.

title: Economic Scene; The Daunting Job Confronting Bush
description: AFTER an initial burst of anxiety immediately after his election, the financial markets have greeted the ascendancy of George Bush to the White House with a joy bordering on euphoria. What explains it? Mr. Bush's camp says the markets are cheering because they like the policies they see ahead. And many outsiders say they like the choices Mr. Bush has made for his key officers and, after the bitterness of the campaign, his conciliatory, take-charge style. They want somebody there ''watching the store.''

title: Who's Who at 1600
description: The seasoned but little-known people who will staff the White House know that the important word in a title like assistant to the President is assistant, not President. The last of five articles on the players in George Bush's Washington. Page A10.

title: Mexico's President Gets Tough
description: The Rambo-style assault by Mexican troops last week against the home of Joaquin Hernandez Galicia, boss of the powerful oil workers' union, can be seen as evidence that Mexico remains, behind its democratic facade, a virtual presidential dicatorship. Legal niceties lost out in the raid and in Mr. Hernandez's swift imprisonment on charges of amassing a private arsenal.

title: Review/Cabaret; 'Ad Hock,' Sellouts In Song
description: The world of advertising, as scores of novels and movies have insisted over the years, is populated with sensitive artists prostituting their creative talents in order to live well. For those who make it big in the business, the cliche has it, success and self-flagellation often go hand in hand.

title: 'Sex Club' Found at Mental Unit
description: Children at a New York State psychiatric center near Buffalo operated a ''sex club'' in which younger patients were intimidated into performing sex acts, an investigation by a state watchdog agency has found. Several staff members at the center also engaged in sex with children, the agency said.

title: U.S. Revokes Privileges on Thai Goods
description: On the last full day of the Reagan Administration, the United States today revoked special trading privileges for $165 million worth of products from Thailand in retaliation against that country's refusal to grant copyright protection for American pharmaceuticals and software.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Reviews/Art; Kinetic Sculpture Using Toys, Fire and Water
description: Dennis Oppenheim's two SoHo exhibitions, one at the John Gibson Gallery, the other at the newly opened Willoughby Sharp Gallery, mark something of a comeback for an artist who has kept a low profile in New York for the last five years.
