Mr. Oppenheim emerged in the late 1960's as a combination earth artist and body artist who came to specialize in indoor and outdoor installation works.

title: Bristol, Pfizer Raise Profits
description: The Bristol-Myers Company yesterday reported a 12.3 percent earnings gain in the fourth quarter of 1988, while a rival health care company, Pfizer Inc., reported an increase of just 3.7 percent.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WOOLF'S WOMEN

title: Uninspired Goaltending Is Key Factor in Devil Loss
description: The Devils' goaltending was so poor tonight that Coach Jim Schoenfeld covered his eyes in their 5-4 loss to the Quebec Nordiques.

title: Pentagon, Not Social Security, Made the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Limited Practice Session for Rice
description: Jerry Rice, the San Francisco 49ers' dangerous pass receiver, did limited work today in a 90-minute practice session at the University of Miami field. Coach Bill Walsh said he expected Rice to take part in practice Friday and continued to give him a 75 percent chance to play against the Cincinnati Bengals on Sunday in Super Bowl XXIII.

title: Dali's Health Declines; Condition Called Critical
description: The condition of Salvador Dali worsened today after he developed pneumonia and an inflamed lung, the Spanish radio reported the artist's doctor as saying.

title: U.S. Acts to Aid the Oil Industry On Leases and Use of Arctic Land
description: The Interior Department, in the last hours of the Reagan Administration, took two actions tonight to benefit the oil industry.

title: Plan to Bid For G.E.C. Is Shelved
description: A consortium formed to make a multibillion-dollar takeover bid for the General Electric Company, Britain's largest manufacturing enterprise, said today that it was shelving its attempt.

title: 'Romance' Closes
description: ''Romance Romance,'' a musical with book, lyrics and direction by Barry Harman and music by Keith Herrmann, closed Sunday after the matinee at the Helen Hayes Theater. The production ran for 297 regular performances and 10 previews.

title: Trout & Ries Moving
description: A year after announcing that it was leaving the agency business, Trout & Ries is leaving New York City as well. Jack Trout and Al Ries are packing up some of their remaining employees and establishing their marketing-strategy consulting operation in Greenwich, Conn. With their books and articles, the partners had established themselves as doyens of positioning when they lost the United Jersey Banks account in late 1987, an event that hastened their move out of advertising. At one point the agency - formerly Ries Capiello Colwell -boasted $35 million in billings. The repositioning becomes effective March 1.

title: Pentagon, Not Social Security, Made the Deficit; Growing Old's Reward
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Shoots Two Officers And Escapes
description: Two New York City police officers were shot and wounded yesterday morning - one of them critically - as a murder suspect with a history of violence against police officers burst through the door of a Brooklyn apartment and, the police said, opened fire.

title: Society for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $387,000 for the quarter and $1,395,000 for the year. The company said the sale of three branch offices in the fourth quarter resulted in a pre-tax gain of $2.4 million.

title: Police Capture Suspect Freed By Forged Papers
description: A murder suspect who walked out of Rikers Island last month because of falsified records was returned to custody yesterday after investigators tracked him to the Brooklyn home of a former sister-in-law.

title: Guerrillas Attack Police Center in Salvador
description: Guerrillas attacked the Treasury Police headquarters today with mortars launched from the backs of pickup trucks, killing 2 people and wounding up to 10 others, the authorities said.

title: Muller Scores With 35 Seconds Left in Overtime
description: The way things have been going for the Devils lately, with only a victory in five games, a tie against one of the league's elite teams would have sufficed. But the Devils had victory on their minds when they went into overtime against the Capitals here tonight.

title: Anxiety Rises as New York Limits Tranquilizer Prescriptions
description: The New York State Department of Health has increased the anxiety and possibly the expenses for some people who use tranquilizers.

title: Dynatronics Laser reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $14,933 and $29,866 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $35,750 for the quarter and $67,750 for the 6 months.

title: Quake Rescue Shows Need for Esperanto
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stryker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Federal Savings & Loan South Carolina reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Preserving Organs for Transplant
description: A surgeon and a biochemist at the University of Wisconsin Medical School in Madison won patent approval this week for a chemical solution that preserves human organs several times longer than present compounds, improving the chances of successful transplants.

title: Dover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter included a gain of $15.1 million from the sale of a manufacturing facility, a charge of $4.5 million for costs incurred in the restructuring of a Swedish subsidiary and provisions for excess costs in connection with a missile contract, and a reserve of about $7.9 million for plant reorganization and other expenses planned for 1989. Latest fourth quarter benefited from a lower tax rate. The company said in accordance with FAS 94, the 1988 financial statements included the consolidation of two finance subidiaries, and the 1987 financials have been restated on a comparable basis. This increased sales by $2,597 in 1988 and $2,699 in 1987 but had no impact on earnings.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Saturday about Advanced Micro Devices Inc. misstated the company's revenues for the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Georgia Gulf Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $9,885,000 from retirement of debt for both the quarter and year.

title: Hey Guys, Let's Keep Bowling Low-Tech
description: LEAD: As a blue-collar-league bowler, I'll concede that mid-tech innovations aren't all bad. Without pinsetting machines, I'd have to sit through another hour of Eddie W.'s gripes and Vinnie D.'s bad jokes. The ''scientifically'' balanced vinyl balls and all that prosthetic equipment to keep the wrist straight are O.K., although they add some quackery to the sport.

title: Review/Ice Show; Adding the Frosting to Romance
description: The Ice Capades has returned to Madison Square Garden in a new edition, , a show that is brilliant in color, fast on the ice and imaginative in decor. It is not, to be sure, Harold Pinter, and rather than judge it for its significant silences and inner meaning, neither of which were in attendance, it lends itself very nicely to a gee-whiz rating.

title: Clippers' New Coach Puts Team on Notice
description: Don Casey says he is somewhat uncomfortable about taking over as coach of the Los Angeles Clippers because the man he replaces, Gene Shue, is his friend. But he wasted no time in putting his young, injury-prone and lackluster team on notice.

title: Offer to Buy Braves
description: Chuck Tanner, dismissed last season as manager of the Atlanta Braves, said he has offered to buy the team and would make himself manager. Tanner said a group of investors, including himself, offered Ted Turner, the team's owner, $80 million for the franchise, but the offer was turned down.

title: Lord Harding, Field Marshal, 92
description: Lord Harding, a commander of Britain's forces in North Africa during World War II, died today at his home in Nether Compton in southwestern England after a long illness, his family said. He was 92 years old.

title: Wardair Delays Aircraft Orders
description: Wardair Inc., a Canadian passenger airline that agreed this week to a buyout by a rival domestic carrier, said it was putting on hold a $600 million (Canadian) order for 14 aircraft until the two companies determined a future business strategy.

title: Haley's No Longer Just a Lineman

title: Insuring Less-Expensive Treasures
description: There is an increasingly popular way to insure treasured items like jewelry, cameras and great-grandmother's crystal that are usually valued at about $500 to $5,000 each. It is called blanket insurance, and it is for entire categories of possessions.

Her dark eyes and soft dimples make her a standout in a book full of attractive faces. A cheerleader, a choir member, a scholar, she was someone, her 15-year-old sister said, bound to be famous.

That may be. The Marcoses have, of course, already been convicted in the public mind on those and many other charges.

title: The Checkered Past of Commodity Markets
description: The Government's investigation into trading at two leading commodity exchanges follows a number of celebrated cases: Marc Rich: During 1980 and 1981, Mr. Rich, one of the world's most successful commodity traders, conducted sham transactions in oil contracts to evade Federal regulations limiting the amount of profits permitted in selling crude oil during the energy crisis. Mr. Rich sold oil that was in effect under price controls at free-market prices and shifted millions of dollars in illegal profits overseas. In 1983 Mr. Rich, who had fled to Switzerland, was charged with evading $48 million in income taxes. A year later two companies he controls pleaded guilty to criminal tax charges and agreed to pay $150 million to the Government. While the companies are free to do business in the United States, Mr. Rich and his partner, Pincus Green, face arrest on tax charges if they return. Efforts to extradite Mr. Rich have been unsuccessful. The Silver Crisis: In 1979 two of the Hunt brothers - Nelson Bunker and William Herbert - set out to control the world silver market.The buying spree pushed prices up and brought much old silver into the market. Prices collapsed in late March 1980. The collapse, which shook the foundations of a number of major financial institutions, cost the Hunts well over $1 billion. Federal charges of manipulation against the Hunts , in addition to damage claims, are outstanding. The Con Man's Game: James A. Carr, and the firm he headed, Lloyd, Carr & Company, sold fraudulent London commodity options to investors in the United States in 1977.Federal investigators discovered that Mr. Carr was Alan Abrahams, an escaped felon. As Mr. Carr, Mr. Abrahams bilked customers of $28 million. The ''Salad Oil Scandal'': Through an elaborate scheme of forging warehouse receipts and listing hundreds of thousands of gallons of fictitious salad oil as assets, Anthony DeAngelis, head of the Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Corporation, borrowed millions of dollars from banks and investment houses in an attempt to corner the soybean oil market in 1963. Panic hit when investors learned there was nothing to support the loans. Sixteen companies and two brokerage houses were forced into bankruptcy.Mr. DeAngelis spent seven years in prison and was released in 1972. The ''Onion Scandal'': Bowing to pressure from farmers and the National Onion Growers Association, onion trading at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was banned in 1958 by Congress as a result of wild speculation. It was the only time that Congress banned trading in a commodity.

The other performers are Annette Bik, a violinist; Tabea Zimmermann, a violist; Thomas Demenga, a cellist, and Alois Posch, a bassist. Tickets are $38 to $15. Information: 247-7800.

title: DOWN COMFORTERS
description: Chilly nights and winter white sales mean the time is right to shop for a down comforter. The cost of a queen-size comforter can range from $89 to $900, depending on the quality of the down, the ratio of down to feathers, the quality of the fabric shell and the intricacy of the stitching. Here are the main indicators of quality; all should be listed on the literature provided with the comforter, or available on request. Filling Power: Reflects the contents' ability to provide warmth and spring back when compressed. Manufacturers consider 500 the minimum and 700 extremely high quality. Weight: Minimum weights suggested by manufacturers are 20 ounces for a twin size; 24 ounces, full; 29 ounces, queen, and 34 ounces, king. Blend: The higher the percentage of down, the warmer the comforter. If the down has been blended, the manufacturer must indicate the percentage and type of feathers and down. Thread Count And Stitching: The higher the thread count of the fabric shell, the less down will escape; avoid shells with a count of less than 220. Baffled stitching, which uses an interior fabric wall, is the most effective and costly. (Sources: Scandia Down Corporation, Seattle, and the American Down Association, 3830 Watt Avenue, Suite 10, Sacramento, Calif. 95821.)

They will be delivered to Air Canada between December 1990 and May 1991, the airline said.

Review/Pop; A Mixture of Two Esthetics
description: On a formal level, the composer Michael Gordon's music, which he performed at the opening of the Kitchen's music series on Wednesday night, had moments of real promise. On a social level, it did as well, but both aspects of his music had the sort of stillborn quality that indicated a composer with ideas, but not the technique to develop them.

title: Gabor Sues Delta Over Dogs
description: Zsa Zsa Gabor has filed a lawsuit against Delta Air Lines, saying she ''was not treated in a first-class manner'' by the airline's ''servants and employees'' when she was escorted off a flight Jan. 6 for refusing to cage her two dogs. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in Palm Beach County, Fla., where Ms. Gabor lives, seeks at least $10 million in damages from the Atlanta-based airline. Delta officials said the actress was belligerent and used offensive language.

title: Review/Music
description: For some time now, it has been apparent that Susan Dunn's is a potentially major talent. The large-voiced soprano, filling in on short notice Thursday evening as soloist with the New York Philharmonic for Julia Varady (who dropped out owing to illness), gave fresh evidence of her promise and progress. Rather than the expected couple of sure-fire arias drawn from her operatic repertory, Miss Dunn offered Strauss's ''Four Last Songs,'' the melancholy but painfully beautiful pieces that he set down in 1948, a year before his death.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Otto George Obermaier; Defender Who Would Be Prosecutor
description: Early in his career, Otto G. Obermaier prosecuted Mafia dons, drug kingpins and nefarious Wall Street schemers. Later, he defended people accused of insider-trading, tax evasion and other white-collar crimes. In the lawyer's parlance, he has walked both sides of the street.

title: THE 41st PRESIDENT; BUSH TAKES OFFICE ASKING BIPARTISAN HELP IN FIGHTING SOCIAL ILLS DESPITE THE DEFICIT
description: George Herbert Walker Bush of Texas, promising new efforts to heal social wounds and to end two decades of divisiveness between the White House and Congress, was inaugurated today as the 41st President of the United States.

title: Microsoft Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-5, 28 The Sandinistas tried to improve ties with the new Bush Administration by announcing that they were lifting a freeze on new visas for American diplomats. No American response was forthcoming. Page 5 Parts of a Soviet hero's memoirs that criticize Stalin's World War II leadership and blame him for the deaths of Soviet citizens were made public for the first time. The war hero is the late Marshal Georgi Zhukov. 3 Andrei Sakharov was nominated for a seat in the new national Congress of Deputies, but after he was spurned by the scientific establishment. His platform: human rights, disarmament and environmental protection. 3 Soviet bombing of Afghan guerrillas has taken a new turn with Soviet forces using a new, heavier bomb for the first time in the Afghan war, Washington officials say. 3 Lech Walesa said he is ready to talk with Poland's leaders about restoring the legal status of the outlawed union. It was the first sign that he accepts a Communist Party resolution passed Wednesday. 3 Israel closed schools in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, saying gatherings of students had contributed to a rise in demonstrations. And the Defense Minister unvieled his plan to end the uprising. 4 Yasir Arafat disputed a U.S. charge that he had threatened Arabs who tried to halt the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank. Other senior P.L.O. officials also countered the charge. 4 U.S. Jewish groups say they will urge Bush to deny Arafat a visa 4 Lima Journal: starting over, the Ex-Peruvian way 4 South India election will test political strength of Gandhi 5 Burma refuses to say when it will hold elections 28 National 6-12 George Bush became 41st President of the United States. He promised an end to divisiveness between the White House and Congress and vowed a new effort to heal social wounds. 1 World leaders congratulate Bush, bid Reagan farewell 9 News analysis: Mr. Bush called for subtle yet significant corrections in the nation's course: away from bickering between the White House and Congress, insensitivity to the poor and greed. 1 Peggy Noonan: the writer behind the speech 10 The inauguration marked a passage Mr. Bush has made in the last ten weeks with an ease that has amazed all but those closest to him: from faithful and sometimes fumbling lieutenant to self-assured leader. 1 The Reagans left the Bushes notes as they finished packing, with Ronald Reagan wistful, Nancy Reagan worried. At the ceremonies, Vice President Quayle was animated, President Bush excited. 1 ''Carry on,'' Ronald Reagan said in Washington when he was asked for final thoughts. Then he left on the first leg of his trip to California. 7 Bittersweet day in the White House as Reagan staff departs 7 The inaugural balls are the highpoint to the week's festivities, but, generally, these affairs - big, dense and anonymous - are not the places to seek out the rich or the powerful. 8 Commodity traders in Chicago are being pressed by fraud investigators to name others who may have engaged in illegal activiites, lawyers and others said. 1 Chicago's commodity exchanges begin fruad inquiries 39 Workers at a Colorado weapon plant, where plutonium is formed into triggers for nuclear warheads, took the first steps to reopen a processing building shut down since October for emergency repairs. 11 A Boeing 737 jet engine broke away during takeoff from Chicago's O'Hare Airport, but the jet returned safely to the runway, scattering debris that delayed other flights at the nation's busiest airport. 11 Whether to build a domed stadium in San Antonio is a question on the city's ballot today that has become much more: a debate over the city's future course and over its troubled Mayor's legacy. 11 A former head of the Ku Klux Klan is running in a special Louisiana primary election held today to fill a seat in the state House of Representatives. Though he trails in the polls, some say he may score an upset. 11 A large trade deficit in November has signaled that the downward course achieved last year after a long and agonizing battle may be ending. 37 Exxon's Canadian subsidiary, Imperial Oil Ltd., agreed to pay Texaco Inc. $3.24 billion for its 78 percent interest in Texaco Canada, Canada's fourth-largest oil and gas enterprise. 37 Regional 29-33 A boy accused of selling crack from a bike will remain in police custody, a Suffolk County judge ordered after finding reasonable likelihood that a crime had been committed. 1 News analysis: Child protection by New York City became a target for criticism again for the city's handling of a Bronx family whose 10 month-old boy suffocated last week. 29 Two policemen were shot, one critically, as a murder suspect they had gone to arrest burst through the door of a Brooklyn apartment and, the police said, opened fire with a .25-caliber automatic gun. 29 Joel Steinberg was portrayed by prosecutors as a repulsive killer of Lisa Steinberg and an evasive defendant who tried to conceal murder with lies and deceit and then, failing that, blamed Hedda Nussbaum. 29 Man in the news: Otto Obermaier, who was recommended for United States Attorney in Manhattan, is known by his friends as a person of diverse experience and fierce independence. 31 State mental-health officials have ordered management changes at a children's psychiatric center where a state inquiry uncovered a patients' ''sex club'' and four instances of sex between staff members and patients. 30 A bite to eat, a gunshot, and a young woman's life is wasted 29 Women says she will stay put, park or no 30 Neediest Cases 33

Rare Wares Dazzle at Antiques Show
description: A series of elegant back-to-back parties opened the 1989 Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan yesterday. Seventy-four dealers presented their prize wares - rare and often eccentric museum-quality pieces that dazzled even the most sophisticated collectors.

title: Girl Killed in Drug Shooting
description: A 12-year-old Brooklyn girl was shot and killed last night and a 14-year-old boy was seriously injured by machine-gun fire that erupted during a drug transaction in their neighborhood, the police said. The girl, Kashaine Green, of 2225 Ditmars Avenue, was hit in the neck by bullets fired about 7:20 P.M. outside a house at 531 East 22d Street in the Flatbush section, a police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said. She died at 10 P.M. at Kings County Hospital. The boy, whose name was withheld, was shot in the mouth. He was in serious but stable condition at the hospital. Both were innocent bystanders, the police said. An Uzi machine gun and drugs were recovered.

title: Israelis Close All Schools in West Bank and Gaza
description: The Israeli Government closed all schools in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip indefinitely again today, saying gatherings of students had contributed to the recent rise in violent demonstrations.

title: President Bush's Breeze of Decency
description: The scene at the Capitol yesterday contrasted strikingly with January 1961, the last time a vastly popular Republican President left office after eight years. John Kennedy fired public imagination then with his urgent summons to a New Frontier. Yesterday George Bush spoke, in measured tones, about a new breeze and the age of the offered hand. Why so measured, so modest?

Bridge; Youthful schooling in the classics leads to an elite post interpreting tournament play.
description: the British establishment used to make the comfortable assumption that anyone who could master classical languages in youth could do anything else later in life. One of the few contemporary examples of this thesis is a 30-year-old Londoner named Barry Rigal, who studied Latin, Greek and classical Hebrew at Oxford and is now an accountant by day and a bridge player the rest of the time.

title: More Ado About Abortion
description: The Missouri abortion case the Supreme Court has accepted for review doesn't warrant the commotion it has evoked on all sides. As abortion cases go, it's no legal landmark. But Missouri, at the Justice Department's urging, has asked the Court to use the case as a vehicle for overturning the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision. The Court has rejected such invitations before and ought to do so again.

title: Olga Averino, Soprano, 93
description: Olga Averino, a former lyric soprano and a voice teacher for more than 50 years, died in her sleep Tuesday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 93 years old.

description: In a staff change that may signal a shift in its attitude toward the collecting of paintings, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., has announced the resignation of its paintings curator, Myron Laskin, and his replacement by George Goldner.

title: Piedmont Jet Loses Engine in Chicago
description: The right engine of a Piedmont Airlines Boeing 737 fell off in a takeoff from Chicago's O'Hare Airport today, scattering debris on the runway that delayed flights for hours at the nation's busiest airport. The plane landed safely on its second engine and no one was injured.

description: The Bass family came into the Greenwich House on Saturday night and settled in without a moment's hesitation. Martha Bass, the gospel singer and matriarch of the clan, brought her daughter, Fontella Bass, and her son, David Peaston, in for a rocking, friendly show that moved easily from rhythm-and-blues to prim gospel numbers to black pop.

title: Shad to Leave As Envoy
description: John S. R. Shad, the United States Ambassador to the Netherlands, will leave his post next month, the American Embassy said today. His departure comes amid speculation that he might be named chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

description: The company said the latest quarter increase in sales and net income is a result of the recently acquired Morton House line of food products.

title: London Broker Layoffs
description: Two London stockbrokers announced today that they were curtailing trading activities and eliminating 43 jobs in the latest cutbacks since the 1987 stock market crash. Warburg Securities, the stockbroking arm of the big London merchant bank Warburgs, said it was withdrawing from some Eurobond market-making, or wholesale dealing, activities and cutting 15 jobs. County NatWest Woodmac, the securities arm of National Westminster Bank P.L.C., said it would lay off 28 equity market makers. County said it would review its coverage of the unlisted securities markets. The dismissals follow a review of staff levels and a decision to refocus business in the shares of small companies, it said.

title: Chiefs Make Choice?
description: A Cleveland television station reported yesterday that Marty Schottenheimer, former coach of the Cleveland Browns, would be named head coach of the Kansas City Chiefs on Tuesday.

description: The New Yorkers who have descended upon Washington for the inauguration ''like to party hearty,'' says Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, and when New Yorkers party they, well, they work.

title: Cambridge Players
description: The Cambridge Chamber Players - D'Anna Fortunato, mezzo-soprano; Carmit Zori, violinist; Richard Sher, cellist; John Gibbons, harpsichordist, and Robert Stallman, flutist - are to play a program of Baroque music at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Lafayette Avenue and Oxford Street South, Brooklyn, at 3:30 P.M. today. The program includes vocal works by Telemann and Handel, and sonatas by Scarlatti, Corelli and Bach. Tickets are $12. Information: 246-1429.

title: As Tarzan Knew, Jungle Nice
description: Here is another story about an armed lunatic gunning down small children. It reminds us of how perilous life can be in a heavily armed nation where insanity is commonplace. Death by armed maniac is always an American possibility. If you are a worrier you take precautions.

title: THE 41st PRESIDENT: Fashion; Following a Tough Act With Impeccable Taste
description: Nancy Reagan is a tough fashion act to follow, but Barbara Bush has already shown that she has star quality. The clothes she wears as she takes center stage for the inaugural festivities demonstrate that she has excellent taste and an understanding of what is both appropriate and flattering to a woman of her age and size.

title: 50th Goal for Lemieux
description: Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins became only the second player in National Hockey League history to score 50 goals in less than 50 games in the first period of tonight's 7-3 loss to the Winnipeg Jets. Pat Elynuik, a rookie, had two goals and three assists for the Jets.

title: Water Metering Penalizes New York Landlords
description: To the Editor:

title: Bengals' 'Anchor' Keeps His Balance
description: In a formal style that sounded as if it had been learned in Public Speaking 101, Reggie Williams declared: ''I am being used as the anchor of the Bengals' defense. Our coaching staff has to depend on Reggie Williams so that his job is done at right outside linebacker.'' Indeed. title: 4 Down, 104 to Go
description: Kirk McCaskill and Jose Guzman, pitchers, and Geno Petralli and Steve Lake, catchers, settled their arbitration cases yesterday. McCaskill, 8-6 last season with a 4.31 earned-run average, settled with the California Angels at $400,000, a raise of $138,000. Guzman, 11-13 with a 3.70 e.r.a., settled with the Texas Rangers at $425,000, a raise of $255,000. Petralli, who batted .282 with 7 home runs and 36 runs batted in, settled with Texas at $325,000, a $185,000 raise.

RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 117, 76ers 109: Dennis Johnson hit three long jump shots down the stretch and Boston withstood Philadelphia's fourth-quarter comeback last night at Boston Garden. (AP) Lakers 115, Mavericks 99: Magic Johnson scored 30 points to lead Los Angeles to its 17th victory at home this season without a loss..(AP) Pistons 132, Pacers 99: Bill Laimbeer scored a season-high 27 points and Adrian Dantley added 25 as Detroit won its third straight and Indiana lost its fifth straight. (AP) Jazz 98, Bucks 96: Karl Malone's jumper with two seconds remaining helped Utah hand Milwukee its first loss in nine games against Western Conference teams. (AP) N.H.L. Blackhawks 3, Red Wings 2: Dirk Graham scored as time expired in regulation. Alain Chevrier turned aside 24 shots in his Chicago debut.(AP) SKIING Girardelli Sets Record: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg broke an eight-year-old record on the circuit's longest downhill course yesterday in Wengen, Switzerland. Girardelli streaked down the icy 4,185-meter Lauberhorn run in 2 minutes 26.54 seconds, bettering by more than a second the record set in 1981 by Toni Buergler of Switzerland..(AP) FIGURE SKATING Leistner Near Title: Claudia Leistner of West Germany took a commanding lead yesterday after the original program at the European championships in Birmingham, England. Leistner would have to finish fourth or worse in the freestyle program today in order not to succeed Katarina Witt as European champion. Soviet skaters have won three titleses. Larisa Selezneva and Oleg Makarov won the pairs event, Aleksandr Fadeyev took the men's singles and Limova and Sergei Ponomarenko took the ice-dancing event.(AP) Indoor Lacrosse Thunder 10, Saints 9: Indoor lacrosse came to Long Island for the first time last night as the Major Indoor Lacrosse League started its third season. The New York Saints, who were the New Jersey Saints last year, were beaten, 10-9, by the Baltimore Thunder before a crowd of 8,662 at Nassau Coliseum. TRACK Kingdom Edges Foster: Roger Kingdom edged Greg Foster at the tape to win the 55-meter high hurdles in 6.98 seconds last night at the 30th annual Sunkist Invitational in Los Angeles. Foster was timed in 7.02. Kingdom, the two-time Olympic gold medalist in the 110-meter high hurdles, avenged a photo-finish loss to Foster a week ago in Dallas. Emmit King won the 60-meter dash in 6.15. Houston McTear, attempting a comeback after a cocaine addiction left him homeless for three years, finished fifth in 6.49. It was his first race in four years. (AP)

description: A hearing into whether Ferdinand E. Marcos is too ill to be arraigned in New York on racketeering charges was adjourned yesterday until next month. More medical testimony on Mr. Marcos's health is expected to be heard Feb. 9 by Judge John F. Keenan in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The former Philippine leader, who was indicted last October, is in a hospital in Honolulu, where, his lawyers say, he is being treated for pneumonia, asthmatic bronchitis and a heart ailment.

title: Italy's Economy Grows
description: Italy's economic expansion, driven by booming consumer demand and strong industrial investment, is continuing to gather pace, according to official data issued today. The National Statistics Institute said Italy's gross domestic product, the measure of economic performance excluding foreign trade, grew 3.9 percent year-to-year in the third quarter of 1988, up from 3.3 percent growth in the second quarter. Growth in the third quarter alone was a strong 1.5 percent, well above the second quarter's eight-tenths of 1 percent growth level.

title: 2 Are Killed in a Queens Fire
description: A 30-year-old woman and an unidentified man died early yesterday in a three-alarm fire that heavily damaged a three-story house in Maspeth, Queens, the authorities said. A Police Department spokesman said the fire, which was declared not suspicious, broke out at about 6:30 A.M. in a kitchen at 59-30 57th Drive and ''consumed most of the house.'' The Fire Department identified the dead woman as Joyce Vella, a resident of the building.

title: For Data Base Buyers, a Choice
description: Philippe Kahn, the chief executive of Borland International Inc., has set himself an unusual task, considering that he holds the French equivalent of a doctorate in mathematics. His mission, he says, is to prove that 3.0 is greater than IV. Yet a growing number of data base users are convinced of the validity of his thesis, which is, specifically, that Borland's Paradox 3.0 can outperform Ashton-Tate's new dBASE IV.

DANCE;
Dorfman Work to Have Premiere
description: LEAD: ON a physical level, ''The Master'' is a kneepad work in which dancers - two men and five women - hurtle across the floor like express trains through a tunnel. Thematically, Carolyn Dorfman's newest work, premiering Saturday at the Morris Museum in Morristown, grapples with the human forces of desire and power and reaches unexpected conclusions about man and society.

title: The Tough Job Of Teaching Ethics
description: At the Harvard Business School earlier this semester, a group of students gathered around a table on the spacious patio of Gallatin Hall to drink some Harpoon Ale (itself both soothing and a prod, since it is a successful product of two recent graduates), and talk cases.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Back to Square 1 For Riverfront
description: LEAD: DESPITE the withdrawal of the developer of Penn's Landing, city officials say they are confident that plans for the 37-acre site along the Delaware River will go forward.

title: FOUR COLORS AND NO INHIBITIONS
description: LEAD: THE ART OF GRAPHIC DESIGN By Bradbury Thompson. Illustrated. 218 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $65.

title: Perfect Stews to Warm a Winter Day
description: STEWS are the most inviting and practical of winter food. They can be made in one pot, cooked a day or more in advance and are economical, since cheaper cuts of meat are used. They are also warming and filling on a cold day. Here are some hints for making perfect stews: Use cheaper cuts of meat. They will have less fat and more flavor. Gristle dissolves during long cooking and gives a syrupy texture to the sauce. Before cooking meat, trim away as much fat as possible. Make sure the meat is at room temperature before you brown it. Always heat the oil in the pan before you brown the meat. Brown the meat thoroughly, a few pieces at a time, without crowding the pan. A little sugar sprinkled over the meat helps it brown more.

title: Troubled Hempstead Debates Its Renewal
description: WITH its central location, rich commercial history and seemingly unsurpassed access to major transportation, downtown Hempstead offers perhaps the greatest potential for redevelopment of any business district on Long Island.

title: CONSUMER RATES
What the World Expects From George Bush: Western Europe
description: IT has been a long time since Western Europe was so reassured by the transition from one American President to another. In the hand-over from Ronald Reagan to George Bush, there is something almost European in the respect for continuity.

title: The New Climate
description: Just as Angola brought the breakdown of detente in the mid-1970's, it is an early beneficiary of the ''new climate'' in East-West relations. But it is also a prime example of how much more is involved than decisions in Moscow and Washington. The superpowers may command, but they are caught in local tides that run their course.

title: Queens Democratic Chief Flexes Political Muscle
description: Three years after Donald R. Manes first attempted suicide and threw the Queens Democratic organization into turmoil and investigations that overturned its leadership, a new leader is presiding over a tranquil Queens Democratic Party that is trying to reassert itself politically.

title: U.S. Using Exchanges' Disciplinary Records in Commodity Inquiry
description: Government prosecutors investigating possible fraud on the nation's two largest commodities exchanges are using documents from disciplinary proceedings conducted by the exchanges against traders to help build the criminal inquiry, people involved in the case said today.

title: The Waterfront Heart of the City
description: AS the sun rises along a deep and smooth bend in the Huangpu River, where the boats known as sampans tie up at the mouth of the Suzhou Creek, the river bank already shows signs of bustle. On the main street, Doric columns, Gothic windows and plaster friezes adorn the grand buildings towering above the rest of the city's low, flat-roofed houses and hint at the past presence of European brokers in the opium trade. But now the street overflows with Chinese workers - officials, bankers, shippers, dumpling vendors and cart pullers.

title: What the World Expects From George Bush: Soviet Union
description: LEAD: THE hope and expectation in the Soviet Union is that the Bush Administration will produce new meetings with Soviet leaders and more agreements on a par with those signed by Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Such agreements could help Mr. Gorbachev as he seeks to turn around his troubled economy.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Steinberg Live; Courtroom TV Is A Fixture, Even as New York Is Deciding
description: THIRTEEN months have passed since New York State first allowed cameras a front-row seat at criminal trials. So far at least, the only clear casualties of the experiment, a test of the effect of television on the judicial process, are courtroom artists who have been automated out of their jobs.

title: AGAINST FATALISM
description: AIDS AND ITS METAPHORS By Susan Sontag. 95 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: REGATTA: A Celebration of Oarsmanship. By Benjamin Ivry. (Simon & Schuster, $29.95) Benjamin Ivry has extensively researched his subject and, reflecting his poetic and literary background, has embellished his text with well-chosen quotes from previous writings on rowing. What Mr. Ivry is not able to bring to his subject is a personal knowledge of the competitive nature of an oarsman, which may explain his propensity for aggrandizing the personalities he writes about.

title: Short Grows The List
description: HOW COME,'' A LADY asks her husband in a James Stevenson cartoon in The New Yorker, ''you're never on anybody's >short list?''

title: Coda for Nick's
description: To the Editor:

title: Marilyn Silverman Engaged
description: Marilyn Silverman and Paul Feiner, a Westchester County Legislator, plan to marry next month. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Silverman of Brooklyn, who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Alan Feiner of Scarsdale, N.Y. Ms. Silverman is a freelance book editor. Her fiance, a Democrat, is completing his third term in the 12th Legislative District of Westchester County.

title: Mr. Bush's Hand
description: President Bush's Inaugural Address contained no specific battle plan, no detailed agenda for the next Hundred Days. But it offered something at least as important: a conciliatory and practical strategy for governing.

title: Wende Sawyer To Marry in May
description: Wende Ellen Sawyer and George Thompson Hutton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hutton of Greenwich, Conn., and Seattle, plan to marry in May. The engagement has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Sawyer of San Mateo, Calif.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CAJUN NIGHTS. By D. J. Donaldson. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) Intriguing as the title of D. J. Donaldson's first novel may be, one of its problems is that it is only marginally about New Orleans and Louisiana's Cajun culture, and it has virtually nothing to do with the night. However, Dr. Donaldson, who teaches in the department of anatomy and neurobiology at the University of Tennessee in

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CHIEFTAINS IN MONTCLAIR The Chieftains - the Dublin-based ambassadors of traditional Irish music whose repertory of reels, jigs, airs and ballads are the product of centuries - will appear Thursday evening in Montclair.

title: Inescapable Super Stress
description: Idaho State Penitentiary inmates are talking about a possible disturbance.

title: Reviews/Music; The Louisville Plays Works It Ordered
description: For the last 40 years, the Louisville Orchestra has been giving American composers a specific reason to write symphonic music. A decision in 1948 to commission works, and subsequent support by the Rockefeller Foundation, set in place a program that has put a little optimism in composers' hearts and some money in their pockets. Judging by its concert under Lawrence Leighton Smith at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, the Louisville is still not an orchestra as smoothly accomplished as, say, the Philadelphia and the Boston or even the Pittsburgh and St. Louis, but in this case let us measure value according to purpose and not so much by technique.

title: Drug Wars Don't Pause To Spare the Innocent
description: The killing of innocent bystanders, particularly in the crossfires of this nation's drug wars, has suddenly become a phenomenon that greatly troubles experts on crime. And the death of three young people in the first three weeks of this year in Brooklyn - including a 12-year-old girl on Friday - has focused attention on the severity of the situation in New York City.

title: Painting and Sculpture at the Michener
description: James Michener is a novelist whose biography reads like the invention of a novelist. Itr begins with Mr. Michener, an adopted child, growing up poor in Doylestown, Pa., continues with his obtaining, by dint of hard work and a scholarship to Swarthmore College, a good education and jobs as a school teacher and then an editor.

title: Brazilians Tell Of the Forest And the Fears
description: In a stifling hall in the heart of the Amazon, a group of American legislators sat listening to the people of the rain forest -Indians and rubber tappers, who appealed for help from abroad to save their jungle habitat.

title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute
description: A 12-year-old girl who was talking with a group of friends less than a block from her home was shot and killed Friday evening when she inadvertently walked into a drug-related dispute on a sidewalk in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Spanish Boom Fuels Fight on Sharing Wealth
description: A booming economy in Spain has proved to be an embarrassment of riches that is feeding tension and jeopardizing the parliamentary majority of the Socialist Party.

title: Outdoors; Spawning Run Restored
description: Pleased with the results of its just-completed five-year plan aimed at restoring optimum spawning runs of Atlantic salmon in its rivers, the province of Quebec expects few changes in its sport-fishing regulations for the species in 1989.

title: Divorce, Wall Street Style
description: This is yet another story of Wall Street in the 1980's - of four men in their 30's and 40's who came out of nowhere, secured a grubstake and used it to become big-time deal makers worth hundreds of millions of dollars and who rather than living happily ever after, have been fighting each other ever since.

title: Dreams - And Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A WORD ON TREES A free talk about ''Historic Trees of Westchester'' will be given at 2 P.M. today by Ted Kozlowski, the county forester with the Department of Parks, at Washington's Headquarters Museum in North White Plains. Mr. Kozlowski is in charge of the Westchester County Big Tree Register, on which some 40 of the largest trees of a particular species are listed.

title: Child Abuse: Education Is Key
description: The problem of child abuse and neglect is unfortunately ''more common and complex'' than the public realizes. While solving the problem will undoubtedly require complex and creative approaches, there is one currently recognized remedy that is fairly simple, that of educating people in the art of parenting.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FIVE HOURS WITH MARIO. By Miguel Delibes. Translated by Frances M. Lopez-Morillas. (Columbia University, $25.) The year is 1966. Mario Diez Collado, a schoolteacher and writer, dies suddenly at age 49 in the small Spanish city where he has made his home. As ''Five Hours With Mario'' begins, friends and relatives gather to offer condolences to Carmen, his wife of 24 years.

title: Gilgo Beach: Don't Interfere
description: Sharon Monahan's article ''Army Acts to Save Eroded Gilgo Beach in Babylon'' [ Dec. 25 ] might well have been written by the Public Relations Department of the Army Corps of Engineers. It ignores the wealth of geological and oceanic knowledge regarding our barrier island.

title: CHARITY TO FOCUS ON UNDERCLASS
description: The Rockefeller Foundation, known for its role in the fight against disease and hunger around the world, is turning more of its attention and resources to persistently poor Americans who have become the country's underclass.

title: Arabs and Jews In a Peace Process
description: LEAD: IT was, to be sure, only a moment, but a glorious moment. Thirty-five Jewish men and women sat at tables in a synagogue here on a recent Wednesday noon, peering at the dining room entrance. Five Arabs entered, to a profound silence. Then Alan D. Nemlich of Scarsdale, office furniture, leaned out of his seat, smiled and thrust out his hand.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Putting Some Zip in Those Shopping Strips
description: LEAD: COME spring, masses of tulips will be blooming at the Country Glen Center in Carle Place and the fountain will have been turned back on at the entrance plaza.

title: Richard Broomer and Kathleen Kelly, Historic Preservation Consultant, Wed
description: Kathleen Anne Kelly and Richard Jeffrey Broomer were married last evening at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Joseph Kelly, in Scarsdale, N.Y. Mr. Broomer is a son of Fay Broomer of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Cyril J. Broomer. Msgr. Edward M. Connors, who presided at the marriage of the bride's parents 27 years ago, and Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner officiated.

title: Lisa K. Schmitt to Marry Kenneth Buenker in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Schmitt Jr. of Seaford, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Karen Schmitt, to Kenneth Arnold Buenker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Buenker, also of Seaford. A May wedding is planned.

title: A DISSOLVING MONOLITH: Arunas Zebriunas, 58, Soviet Union Filmmaker
description: Arunas Zebriunas, chairman of the Filmmakers Union of Lithuania, is one of the leaders of Sajudis, the Lithuanian Movement for Perestroika, a grass-roots nationalist movement. Now 58, he joined the Soviet Communist Party three years ago

title: North Korean Group Arrives On First Official Japan Visit
description: A North Korean delegation arrived in Tokyo today on the first visit by Pyongyang officials, a spokesman for the Japan Socialist Party said.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Housing the Homeless; The '100 Percent' Buildings Come on Line
description: TUCKED away in corners of New York City, a new form of potentially troublesome low-income housing is being created in vacant city-owned buildings as part of the response to the problem of finding permanent apartments for the homeless.

title: Bush Starts the Job Briskly, and With an Open House
description: An energetic George Bush completed his first full day as President today with a flourish of symbolic gestures and conciliatory statements, including a renewed plea for the assistance of other countries in winning the release of American hostages in Lebanon.

title: How the City Council Changed the Law Behind Its Own Back
description: HOW could the New York City Council have changed a municipal law without knowing that it had done so? The question reverberated around City Hall last week, as members of the Council and the Koch administration, alternately perplexed, embarrassed, defiant and defensive, tried to determine how the city had let the developer Harry Macklowe off the hook.

title: TWO STEPS FORWARD, ONE STEP BACK
description: WAITING FOR PRIME TIME The Women of Television News. By Marlene Sanders and Marcia Rock. Illustrated. 214 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $19.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Variations on a Theme
description: WHAT becomes of a legend lost? Bygone film stars slip into obscurity, obsolete fashions fade away, but antique flowers never die. Although gardenias no longer adorn gentlemen's buttonholes, gardeners struggle to keep them living happily ever after on their windowsills.

title: 2 San Jose Policemen Slain, as Is Their Killer
description: A homeless man chased down and shot a policeman to death Friday, then mortally wounded another before being killed by other officers in a noontime gun battle on the street.

title: When Your Luggage Includes a Bicycle
description: IF you are a biking enthusiast you are probably already thinking about taking some extended trips come warmer weather. Even though spring is still three months away, it is not too soon to start planning, especially if you intend to use a bicycle while vacationing abroad.

title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility
description: AIDS has come to Long Island. It's been here since nearly the beginning, of course, but much like the early turn of autumn leaves, few took notice. Indeed, the first Long Islanders who developed the disease had the good taste to be diagnosed in the pernicious anonymity of the Big City, only to return home for the family support most never received.

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Only Men Need Apply

title: NONFICTION
description: CENTURIES OF FEMALE DAYS: Englishwomen's Private Diaries. By Harriet Blodgett. (Rutgers University, $29.95.) On Oct. 23, 1848, Caroline Fox, the 29-year-old daughter of the eminent English scientist Robert Were Fox, noted succinctly in her diary, ''A wet day and all its luxuries.'' The following day she recorded as, ''A fine day and all its liabilities.'' Thus were one woman's days characterized for posterity. Women's diaries, writes Harriet Blodgett in ''Centuries of Female Days,'' ''provide invaluable testimonials to individual female lives and reveal patterns of female existence.'' They also ''constitute a literary tradition of female serial writing.'' Quoting from the diaries of 69 English or Welsh women whose private thoughts were written between 1599 and 1939, Ms. Blodgett offers illuminating examples of her subjects ''in process of being in a particular world.'' Some of these diarists were obscure housewives, while others were mothers, wives or daughters of men well known to history. Many were accomplished in their own right, among them Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Beatrix Potter, Katherine Mansfield, Beatrice Webb and Virginia Woolf. Ironically, all the diaries quoted in this volume were intended as private and personal (this was one of the author's criteria for inclusion in her study), yet all have been published in some form (another of the author's requirements). There is is a tantalizing clamor of voices, unfortunately dominated by Ms. Blodgett's. Readers will be left wishing that this book heralded a plan by some publisher to issue obscure diaries, which, read in sustained form, are far more intriguing than the muted tidbits scattered in this compendium.

title: NAVY SEES LESSONS FROM PERSIAN GULF
description: If there is a word to describe the United States Navy's operations now winding down in the Persian Gulf, it has to be ''improvise.'' Captains and crews had to adapt high-tech ships to what military people call a low-intensity conflict.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SPARTA;
This Neighborhood'Feels Like Family'
description: LEAD: IN the historic Sparta neighborhood here, the intersection of Liberty Street, Spring Street and Rockledge Avenue is a busy one - busy, that is, with people. ''Everyone comes out on that corner - we all talk,'' said Lisbe Elwyn, a retired social worker and 18-year resident of Sparta. ''I look out my window and wonder what's happening.

title: DISGUST WITH TYRANTS: Erik M. Ametistov, Lawyer, Soviet Union
description: Erik M. Ametistov, 54, a Moscow lawyer specializing in international law at a Government research institute, is a member of the Gorbachev generation. He has recently been working on reforms of the legal code, and has been active in some unofficial political groups .

title: THE INDIAN MUSEUM'S LAST STAND
description: I have followed with interest and concern the plight of the Museum of the Amerian Indian. Those negotiating its fate should look for a solution that will insure the museum's ability to preserve its collection and maximize the accessibility of the collection to the widest audience. I believe there should be two facilities: a larger building in New York City, such as the Custom House, and another in Washington. These cities attract museumgoers. The collection is large enough to be split up, and portions could be rotated on a periodic basis. DONALD M. SPECTOR Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: THE INDIAN MUSEUM'S LAST STAND
description: I object to the implication that the collection at the Museum of the American Indian melted away in vast numbers during my tenure as director (''The Indian Museum's Last Stand,'' by William Grimes, Nov. 27). George Gustav Heye freely disposed of objects by exchange and sale; indeed, three major museums were largely created from the Heye collection by this practice. In addition, normal breakage, thefts and deterioration took their toll; plus the attrition suffered when the collection was moved from its original home in Philadelphia.

title: Which Way Does the New Breeze Blow?
description: GEORGE BUSH assumed the Presidency as one of the best known and least understood figures in American politics, a many-sided man who can simultaneously embrace rugged individualism and self-denial, praising in his Inaugural Address both ''the exercise of free will unhampered by the state'' and the virtues of ''duty, sacrifice, commitment.''

title: School Breakfast Plans Grow
description: LEAD: JEFF BALIFF, a sophomore at East Brunswick High School, leaves his home and heads for school without having had breakfast - not an unusual occurrence for a high school student.

title: Handicapped Skaters Train for Olympics
description: LEAD: ON a frigid night at the Edward J. Murray Memorial Skating Center on Tuckahoe Road, the seventh-fastest female skater in the world kneeled on the ice to thread the laces for a young man.

title: Yale Alumni Recruiting
description: LEAD: THE Yale Westchester Alumni Association, which counts among its members 2,500 graduates of the college and some of their parents, is trying to increase its active membership.

title: Rights Parley - Or Sham?
description: LEAD: A few years ago, the Soviet proposal to hold an international conference on human rights in Moscow seemed like the height of chutzpah - like a conference on racism sponsored by the South African Government. But the Western decision to hold such a conference in Moscow in 1991 has caused hardly a ripple.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FALLEN ANGELS By Walter Dean Myers. 309 pp. New York: Scholastic. $12.95. (Ages 14 and up)

title:
MUSIC;
Pianist to Play in Princeton
description: LEAD: THE internationally renowned pianist Bella Davidovich, who will perform in Princeton tomorrow night, has just returned from four triumphant concerts in Moscow. Miss Davidovich, and her son, the violinist Dmitri Sitkovetsky, were among the first Soviet emigres ever invited back to perform in the Soviet

title: Thelonious Monk Memorial Will Help Jazz Live
description: The Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz introduced itself to Durham on Jan. 14with a high-voltage handshake at the Page Auditorium of Duke University: a concert by some of jazz's most noted musicians and appearances by Steve Allen; his wife, Jayne Meadows, and Clint Eastwood, who directed the movie ''Bird.''

title: Kaunda Urges Bush to Drop Angola Rebels
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda has urged the Bush Administration to recognize Angola and end United States support for the rebels led by Jonas Savimbi.

title: A July Wedding For Miss Muranyi
description: Adrienne Carol Muranyi and Daniel Nathan Fuss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Fuss of Delray Beach, Fla., plan to marry in July, the future bride's parents, Donna K. Muranyi and Joseph Muranyi, both of New York, have announced.

title: Between Some Bookends
description: LEAD: THE visitor had been near, or had driven past, the Oceanside Free Library on Davison Avenue many times in the decades he had spent in neighboring Baldwin, but he had never been inside. Indeed, he thought now, as the library's program coordinator led him into the private study area, he had never known the library existed.

title: Noisy Crowds Lack Manners
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Norma Varden, 90, TV and Film Actress
description: Norma Varden, whose acting career in films, television and on the state included such roles as Jack Benny's mother and the housekeeper in ''The Sound of Music,'' has died at age 90.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I slept out at Shea Stadium once for the Who, and this is the President of the United States.'' - Mitchell Jaspan of Oceanside, L.I., at the White House. [ 20:5. ]

title: BURNING LEAVES AND APPLE PIE
description: BORDERLAND Origins of the American Suburb, 1820-1939. By John R. Stilgoe. Illustrated. 353 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: The Case of the Curious 'Corner'
description: The stock ''corner'' flourished in the age when it was every man for himself, and when insider trading was accepted as a normal practice. Corners grew rarer and less profitable in the 1920's, and were supposed to have disappeared entirely until a series of transactions made it appear that a corner is now in the works.

title: Success of Vista Hotel Draws Developers Downtown
description: WHEN Hilton International announced a decade ago that it intended to build the financial district's first new hotel in over a century, many people in the hospitality industry smiled knowingly. Hotels in Manhattan were equated with midtown and that's the way it would remain, ran the conventional wisdom.

title: Ban on Bow Hunting Is Without Logic
description: I'd like to rebut Edwin Ritchie's letter of Jan. 8 in which he calls for a ban on bow hunting. Mr. Ritchie's request carries no supporting logic. Instead I see a bitter diatribe of personal emotions laced together with his own opinions of what constitutes psychiatric behavior.

title: Question Of the Week; Can Winfield and Steinbrenner Find Peace?
description: Absolutely not.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Hospital Fund Ailing

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HEAVENLY MUSIC For some musical tastes, the only thing better than one harp is two harps. This truism is something that Eva Jaslar and Margery Fitts figured out in 1981, when they formed the New York Harp Duo.

title: St. John's Rallies to Beat B.C.
description: Jayson Williams scored 22 points, including 7 in a key second-half rally, to lead St. John's to a 74-66 victory over Boston College tonight in a Big East Conference game.

title: Church and Builder Scale Back Plan
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL by a historic church and a major developer to put up two high-rise office buildings and a public plaza in the heart of the city has been scaled down as a result of officials' misgivings over the proposed height, density and provisions for public amenities.

title: CLEESE FOR CHRISTMAS
description: Thank you for the Christmas present - Bill Bryson's article on John Cleese (''Cleese Up Close,'' Dec. 25).

description: LEAD: PUBLIC attitudes about race relations and housing will be explored Wednesday in an innovative survey at the County Center here.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TV Commentators Rely on Inside Information
description: Merlin Olsen isn't saying, but he knows what the first play of Super Bowl XXIII will be. In fact, he probably knows what the first half-dozen plays run by the Bengals and the 49ers will be.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: VICTORIA D. SCHMIDT;
Increasing State's Share of Conventions
description: LEAD: Two years ago, as part of a program to stimulate business growth, Gov. Thomas H. Kean created the Office of Business Tourism Development here and named Victoria D. Schmidt its director.
