title: School Sues Over a Ban on Pools
description: LEAD: THE 98-year-old Lawrence Country Day School, a private institution that serves 156 students from nursery through the ninth grade, is suing the affluent village of Hewlett Bay Park over the revocation of building permits to construct two outdoor swimming pools on its 10-acre site.

title: What the World Expects From George Bush: Japan
description: WHEN President Bush turns his attention to Japan, he will find problems that center on trade and defense and, lurking in the background, increasing American technological dependence on Japan.

title: Leisure College
description: As an all-America cornerback with a bright professional future, Deion Sanders has apparently not put too much store in the academic side of things at Florida State. Indeed, according to rumors circulating in Tallahassee, after a stint at summer school to meet eligibility requirements for the fall season, Sanders, a fourth-year player, virtually dropped out of school during the football season and even skipped his final exams before playing against Auburn in the Sugar Bowl Jan. 2.

title: Nana Smith Wed To James Milliken
description: At the Judson Memorial Church in New York, Nana Graves Hilliard Smith, the daughter of Dr. Gilbert Graves Smith of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Sherry Griffing Hatch, was married yesterday to James Bennett Milliken, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Milliken of Fremont, Neb. The Rev. Howard Moody, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony. Janet E. Mitchell and Steve Farris attended the couple as maid of honor and best man.

title: The People in Thousands, Get a Look at Their House
description: George and Barbara Bush had a few thousand folks over this morning to show off their new house.

title: Exile in Limbo
description: In recent years, the name of Idi Amin has cropped up mainly as a symbol of a tyranny nearly as bizarre as it was brutal. Once the self-proclaimed President-for-Life of Uganda, whose whim meant death to thousands and exile to hundreds of thousands, he fled in 1979 and was given sanctuary in Saudi Arabia - on condition that he stay out of the public eye. This month, though, the 61-year-old Mr. Amin, who has talked of recapturing power, turned up in Zaire on a false passport. The Saudis made it clear they did not want him back. Anxious lest his presence damage relations with neighboring Uganda, Zaire began looking last week for another home for Mr. Amin.

title: Michelle Gail Kaplan Weds Dr. Michael Sicklick
description: Michelle Gail Kaplan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kaplan of Marlboro, N.J., and Dr. Michael Douglas Sicklick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sicklick of Hackensack, N.J. were married last evening in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi David Feldman performed the ceremony at the Short Hills.

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Suddenly, Youth Service Comes Closer
description: National youth service, sidetracked for eight years by the Reagan Administration's resistance, suddenly is on the fast track. The new Bush Administration is readying YES to America, a youth service foundation. The Democratic Leadership Council, meanwhile, offers a plan to make service a prerequisite for Federal education aid. Both ideas merit careful consideration by Congress.

title: Splat!
description: THE BLOB Starring Shawnee Smith (in photo), Donovan Leitch, Kevin Dillon, Jeffrey DeMunn, Candy Clark, Del Close. Directed by Chuck Russell. 1988. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Entertainment. 95 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. Rated R.

title: A Love of Children
description: In ''Failing in Teaching'' the author makes the point that teachers have a great opportunity to develop children's hopes for themselves. They also have the opportunity to make an impact on their lives. The writer is correct in these statements, but then continues with the most bitter condemnation of teachers that I have seen in my many years as a teacher.

title: Of Fraud, Markets, and the Future
description: On Thursday it was disclosed that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had posed as commodities traders as part of a two-year investigation of the commodity futures markets. Typical of the violations they reportedly discovered was ''bucket trading'' - where brokers and traders arrange deals in secret to purchase commodities for clients at prices that are too high. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which normally polices the futures markets, was apparently kept in the dark about the U.S. Attorney's investigation.

title: Opening Shoreham Is No Solution
description: Paul Townsend, editor of Long Island Business News (Jan. 1, ''Shoreham Impasse: Suggested Solutions'') said Shoreham should open, and called it ''nonpolluting as compared to fossil fuels''!

title: Elizabeth Smith Becomes Bride Of D. H. Bartram
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ann Smith to David Hunt Bartram took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien, Conn. The Rev. William Donovan performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. James Whittemore, an Episcopal priest.

title: Ryder Golf on USA Cable
description: For the first time, the USA Cable network will televise the Ryder Cup matches back to the United States, Sept. 22-24, according to a source close to television negotiations for the biennial professional golf match between the United States and European teams.

title:
ART;
Heart of the Matter: The Figure as Motif
description: LEAD: IN their search for ways to express and interpret human emotion, many artists use abstraction and distortion to get beyond superficial appearance.

title: A NORMAL LIFE, WITH OVEN MITTS
description: LEAD: OWNING JOLENE By Shelby Hearon. 210 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Islanders Survive a Wild Shootout
description: The game was one-dimensional, the goaltenders were besieged and the scoring came at breakneck speed. So far as Coach Al Arbour was concerned, the game was a monstrosity, but he couldn't control the hint of a smile as he made that observation.

title: The Case in Favor of Proposition 42
description: In attempting to understand the controversy over Proposition 42, it is necessary to look to the reason behind it. Students who enter college without basic academic skills will not have the opportunity to succeed without assistance in acquiring those skills.

title: Specs Toporcer Had Keen Eye
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have cabinets of ash wood in my kitchen. Food and dirt stains have accumulated around the handles and knobs on the cabinet doors. Is it possible to clean off this dirt without also removing or damaging the finish, or must the cabinets be revarnished?

title: Maria del Carmel Valdivieso Is Married
description: Maria del Carmel Valdivieso, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos Valdivieso Salazar of Lima, Peru, was married there yesterday to Adam Matthew Shub, the son of Joyce Lasky Reed and Anatole Shub, both of Washington. The Rev. Antonino Hernando performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of Santa Maria Reina in San Isidro.

title: Stylishness That Never Goes Out of Style
description: THINGS that are genuine tend to last, to hold up over the years. Fads come and go, styles change. But stylishness, if one really has it, and more importantly, a quiet gracefulness, tend to be constants, as impervious to whim as a skillful sailor is to slight variations in the wind.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Blending the Old With the New; Developers Working Around Remnants of the Past in Towers
description: IN their push to erect new towers, developers today are feeling pressure to work around pieces of history. Projects are rising over, behind and around relics of the past.

title: Orchestre de Paris On Public Radio Series
description: A weekly series of taped concerts by the Orchestre de Paris is being carried on more than 100 public radio stations in the United States and Canada until April, in conjunction with the orchestra's United States tour, which starts next month, and in celebration of the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution.

title: Shoreham Deadlines Come and Go
description: LEAD: ANOTHER crucial period in the complex fight over the Shoreham nuclear-power plant will begin tomorrow with another missed deadline.

title: Max Laemmle, 82, Theater Chain Owner
description: Max Laemmle, whose chain of art theaters exposed Los Angeles moviegoers to such international film-makers as Ingmar Bergman, Costa-Gavras and Francois Truffaut, died of pulmonary congestion Friday night at his home. He was 82 years old and lived Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: A New Bill Threatens Greek Private Schools
description: Greek education is in turmoil. Many private schools and universities have come to a near standstill as staff, students and even parents have taken to the streets this week in a dispute over funding, educational change and politics.

title: Vermont Official Is Sentenced
description: George Sleeman, the former superintendent of Bennington schools who was convicted of embezzlement, was sentenced Wednesday to a minimum of two years in jail.

title: ARMS AND MEN: WHO'S IN CONTROL?
description: WAR AND PEACE IN THE NUCLEAR AGE By John Newhouse. Illustrated. 486 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: THE CHICKEN AND THE EGG, TOGETHER AT LAST
description: LEAD: TOPOBIOLOGY An Introduction to Molecular Embryology. By Gerald M. Edelman. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95.

title: SUPER BOWL XXIII QUARTERBACKS: While Esiason Emerges, Montana Survives; BENGALS' LEADER FINDS SUCCESS AFTER TRAVELING 'HARD ROADS'
description: The little blond kid who used to threaten to climb the glass at Madison Square Garden hockey games to get at the bad guys can take things into his own hands now.

title: Assemblyman Challenges O'Rourke
description: A 42-year-old State Assemblyman, Richard L. Brodsky, became the first official challenger today in a major effort by Westchester Democrats to unseat County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a popular Republican who has held the county's top political post for seven years.

title: OPENNESS ABOUT CYNICISM: ANONYMOUS, POET, CHINA
description: A poet and assistant professor from Shanghai, he agreed to speak candidly only if his name was not used. He joined the party in 1985, when he was asked to apply during his third year in college. He said cynicism and disillusionment are widespread among younger party members, particularly among intellectuals.

title: A DOCTRINE UNDER ATTACK: Nina A. Andreyeva, Teacher, Soviet Union
description: A Soviet newspaper panicked the nation's liberals last March with an article signed by Nina A. Andreyeva, a 50-year-old Leningrad chemistry teacher, complaining that liberals were using glasnost to sow ideological confusion and blacken Soviet history. Three weeks later, Pravda denounced the letter as an anti-perestroika manifesto; nonetheless, she said she has received many letters supporting her views. In October, in her first interview with a Western reporter, she gave 32 typewritten pages of answers to questions submitted in advance, then answered questions for 90 minutes.

title: DEBUNKING OF MAO: Li Shuxian, Professor, China
description: Granddaughter of a wealthy landlord and daughter of a doctor who died when she was 5 years old, Li Shuxian, now 53, spent her youth in poverty. She welcomed the revolution and joined the party in 1954, only to be expelled three years later in an ''anti-rightist'' campaign and then, finally, reinstated automatically along with other purge victims in 1979. In the Cultural Revolution, she spent more than two years planting rice, wading hipdeep in water infested with liver flukes, parasites that bore into the skin. A Beijing physics professor, she is the wife of Fang Lizhi, who was expelled from the party in 1987 for his unorthodox views.

title: It's Time to Play Final 'Jeopardy!'
description: LEAD: As a successful contestant on the television quiz show ''Jeopardy!'' I have heard three questions repeatedly:

title: Slighted by Trend Watchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Christine Henderson Wed To Stephen H. Beach 3d
description: Christine Diane Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Thomas Henderson of Wellesley, Mass., was married there yesterday to Stephen Holbrook Beach 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Beach Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Vincent Warner performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The former coach of the Cleveland Browns, Marty Schottenheimer, has taken himself out of the running to become head coach of the San Diego Chargers and is now considered a candidate to take over the Kansas City Chiefs. . . . Rob Castagna, an Iona College running back, has won the national Woody Hayes Scholar Athlete Award for Division III. . . . Gennadi Avdeyenko, the Olympic high jump champion, has entered the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Feb. 3 along with two other Soviet athletes, Grigori Yegorov, who placed third in the pole vault, and Ludmila Kondratyeva, who won the women's 100 meters at the 1980 Games. . . . Mary Slaney has become the first athlete hired to wear the L'eggs pantyhose logo when she competes.(AP)

title: France Offers to Hold Cambodia Conference
description: France said today that it was prepared to be the host of an international peace conference on Cambodia this year and planned to step up diplomatic contacts with all parties to the conflict.

title: SCHEME AND VARIATIONS
description: LISTENING OUT LOUD Becoming a Composer. By Elizabeth Swados. 208 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: FROM ALPHA TO OMEGA
description: CIVILIZATION OF THE ANCIENT MEDITERRANEAN: Greece and Rome. Edited by Michael Grant and Rachel Kitzinger. (Scribners, $225.) That price is not a typographical error. What you get here is 1,980 double-column pages in three volumes containing 97 chapters by 88 authorities on everything from farming and cooking to taxes, warfare and divinities in Greece and Rome. Michael Grant, who in a long life of scholarship has written many volumes on the ancient world, and Rachel Kitzinger, who teaches classics at Vassar College, have assembled the articles in groups that generally proceed from geography and history to government, from individual and family life to social life and ideas. But it is obvious they have not supplied their writers with outlines; there are some delightful departures and surprises tucked away in these pages, and it is not hard to detect not only different attitudes, but disagreements among the contributors. All the articles are written for the general reader, but some of the writers are much sprightlier than others. On the whole the essays on technical subjects like farming, building, engineering and mining are more energetic and revealing than those on government, society and intellectual and spiritual life, although the one on Greek philosophy and another on divinities in general are more elegant and penetrating than one expects in a small encyclopedia. The bibliographies following each chapter are current and comprehensive, the photographs and illustrations are as instructive as they are delightful and the maps are easy to read (however, it is difficult to guess why the editors chose to illustrate the provinces of the Roman Empire at the end of the reign of Augustus rather than a century later when it had reached its greatest extent).

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Alexandria, Va.;
Fairfax Getting 443 Rentals
description: LEAD: THE Hardaway Group of Nashville, Tenn., has started pouring footings for Huntington Gateway, a major residential rental project in Fairfax County, just a half-mile from here.

title: Annella M. White Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Annella Marie Tuolumne White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Brooke White of New York, was married there yesterday to Roy Christopher Dignes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyder Dignes of Mountain Lakes, N.J. The ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Susan C. Harriss.

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AMERICAN IN BRUSSELS
description: LEAD: THE VAST, AIRY REHEARSAL studios that the choreographer Mark Morris and his troupe have inherited are tucked away in a converted warehouse behind the Gare du Midi, a Brussels train station. On this particular day, the building is permeated by a cloying odor of chocolate emanating from a neighboring factory.

title: FICTION
description: SAFE PASSAGE. By Ellyn Bache. (Crown, $16.95.) Ellyn Bache's first novel begins with a mother's premonition of disaster: ''At four-thirty on Sunday morning Mag came up from sleep with her heart thumping and sweat pouring from her.'' Mag Singer's premonition rapidly proves true as she and her husband, Patrick, learn from an early-morning newscast that the Beirut airport, where one of their seven sons is stationed as a marine, has been destroyed by Lebanese terrorists. All communication with the base has been cut off and they have no way of finding out if he is dead or alive. As the news spreads over the next three days, the Singers gather to hold what they all fear is a death watch, leaping when the telephone rings and hoping for the young man's safe return. Mag buries herself in music, racked with guilt over earlier resentments (''I never wanted children. . . . This is the punishment'') as Patrick goes intermittently blind from a mysterious malady no one has been able to treat; meanwhile, their other sons nervously express their own fear through imagined paralysis and bargain-filled prayers. The problem with ''Safe Passage'' is that Ms. Bache has chosen an event as genuine as a newspaper story and imbued it with an ultimately belittling inauthenticity. The family members are all light sketches with unconvincing emotional lives. And the events that are supposed to be compelling - Patrick's inexplicable blindness, Mag's climactic battle with a neighborhood foe - seem strenuous attempts to rouse emotion where none is really felt. Mag, in particular, is a character who is clearly intended to embody the contradictions of motherhood, and as such is more of an idea than a person. Basing a novel on actual headlines can be a dangerous enterprise. Unfortunately, Ms. Bache has not avoided its pitfalls.

title: Stacey Cozzens Is Wed To Brian Boyle on L.I.
description: Stacey Lynn Cozzens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart G. Cozzens of Manhasset, L.I., and Brian Owen Boyle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Boyle of Manhasset, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L.I. Canon Rodney Michel performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Dennison, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Shoreham Impasse: Legislative View
description: Your Jan. 1 story ''Shoreham Impasse: Suggested Solutions'' noticeably lacked a view from the Suffolk County Legislature. This 18-member body has consistently served as Long Island's most effective defense against the safety and economic hazards posed by the Shoreham plant and will undoubtably be a leader and partner in any settlement of the Shoreham issue.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: JULIA PARADISE, by Rod Jones. (King Penguin, $6.95.) A Shanghai psychoanalyst cures a missionary's wife of tormenting fantasies by making love to her while she practices free association; in return, she helps him overcome a debilitating case of ennui. In 1987, our reviewer, Wray Herbert, said this ''haunting first novel [ is ] a remarkable accomplishment.'' THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS: Economic Change and Military Conflict From 1500 to 2000, by Paul Kennedy. (Vintage, $12.95.) Time and again, a Yale historian argues, mighty empires have hastened their own demise by spending too much money on the military. ''In a work of almost Toynbeean sweep he describes a pattern of past development that is not only directly relevant to our times but is clearly intended to be read by policy makers, particularly American policy makers,'' Michael Howard said in The Book Review last year. ''There are lessons to be learned from the past at a profounder level than those of Munich or Sarajevo, and the American leadership would do well to heed them.'' BROKEN GROUND, by John Keeble. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) An engineer from Portland is recruited by a sinister multinational corporation to help build a prison in the Oregon desert. ''Skillfully blending elements from regional writing, adventure thrillers and magical realism, Mr. Keeble weaves a tale made up of many finely observed scenes,'' Tom Nolan said here last year. FIGHTING FAITHS: The Abrams Case, the Supreme Court, and Free Speech, by Richard Polenberg. (Penguin, $9.95.) In 1919 the Supreme Court upheld the conviction of four Russian anarchists charged with sedition for advocating a munitions workers strike. But in the long run, the dissenting opinion by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. has been the most influential aspect of the case, helping establish that the First Amendment protects all political speech that does not pose a ''clear and present danger'' to the country. Last year, our reviewer, Carol E. Rinzler, called this ''a lively [ and ] meticulous history.'' In UNTENDED GATES: The Mismanaged Press (Columbia University, $14.50), Norman E. Isaacs argues that newspaper editors often abuse their constitutional privilege, arrogantly dismissing complaining readers as kooks. The author, who was chairman of an ill-fated group of journalistic ombudsmen called the National News Council, ''makes a number of telling points,'' Kathleen J. Turner said here in 1986. THE SILVER DESOTO, by Patty Lou Floyd. (Washington Square/Pocket, $5.95.) These short stories about growing up in the days of the Oklahoma dust bowl are ''strong and memorable,'' Jill McCorkle said here in 1988. ''Patty Lou Floyd creates an unforgettable journey into adulthood.'' TIME AND THE ART OF LIVING, by Robert Grudin. (Ticknor & Fields, $8.95.) In a melancholic series of vignettes and philosophical observations, a Shakespeare scholar reflects on life, death and the nature of time. In 1983, one commentator said the book ''could be enormously valuable to anyone trying to restructure a life.'' THE STRANGE NATION OF RAFAEL MENDES, by Moacyr Scliar. Translated by Eloah F. Giacomelli. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A Brazilian financier inherits two notebooks that trace his ancestry to the prophet Jonah, the philosopher Maimonides and the ancient cult of the Essenes. Last year, our reviewer, Herbert Gold, said this ''contemporary story of financial and sexual skulduggery . . . sings with a fado wail,'' a kind of Portugese folk song. THE RECORDING ANGEL: The Experience of Music from Aristotle to Zappa, by Evan Eisenberg. (Penguin, $7.95.) By reshaping the way musicians think of their craft, the invention of the phonograph led to a new art form, Evan Eisenberg writes. This ''seems to be the first full-length book on the implications and effects of recording on music,'' Jon Pareles said in The Times in 1987. ''It's bursting with ideas, taking up topics from the ties between ritual and music to the compression that 78-rpm records brought to the classic blues.'' HER OWN TERMS, by Judith Grossman. (Ivy, $3.95) Having escaped dreary South London for the literary life in Oxford, Irene Tanner can hardly believe that she still must overcome the obstacle of being a woman. This novel ''replicates for the reader the confusion, the sense of dislocation from self, the inability to recognize what is demeaning, self-denying, that many women experienced who grew up and were educated in the 50's and early 60's,'' Sue Miller said in The Book Review in 1988. ''Its achievement is that it does this without cant, without dogma, without a grain of self-pity.'' EUROPE: A Tapestry of Nations, by Flora Lewis. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) Drawing on years of experience as a foreign correspondent, a New York Times columnist reflects on the personalities of the countries of Europe. Writing in The Times in 1987, Anthony Sampson said that ''for many American visitors to Europe, [ the book ] will provide an invaluable introductory guide, to remind them just how different these countries are from each other and from America, and how complex are their varied histories and formations.'' A CUP OF DEATH, by Gene Thompson. (Ballantine, $3.50.) After a classics professor is murdered, a piece of missing jewelry points to a conspiracy that seems to have roots in ancient Greece. ''It's a very complicated plot, and Mr. Thompson has many strands to weave together,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. He does so ''neatly and artistically.''

title: Suzanne Patnode Is Wed To Thomas Edward Dean
description: At the Old West Church in Boston, Suzanne Patnode, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Patnode of South Natick, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Edward Dean, the son of Mrs. George A. Dean Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., and the late Mr. Dean. The Rev. Charles McCracken performed the Methodist ceremony.

title: From Heads to Tails to Placing Tidbits? You Bet!
description: Going strictly by the book, more citizens become lawbreakers on Super Bowl Sunday than any day of the year. Unless, that is, they spend the day in Nevada.

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Snowboarding

title: Unveiling the Unsung Heroes
description: Nearly all eyes will be on Joe Montana and Boomer Esiason, Ickey Woods and Roger Craig, Jerry Rice and Eddie Brown, the prime players in Super Bowl XXIII. They are the favorites to win the most valuable player award of the game.

title: NONFICTION
description: MEMBERS OF THE TRIBE: On the Road in Jewish America. By Ze'ev Chafets. (Bantam, $18.95.) While the question ''Who is a Jew?'' has been raging in Israel, the answer in the United States is simple enough. As a leader of the Jewish community of Waco, Tex., says: ''If somebody says he's Jewish, that's good enough.'' In ''Members of the Tribe,'' a richly detailed, perceptive and often funny book of vignettes gathered during a six-month tour of 30 states, Ze'ev Chafets - an Israeli writer who was raised in Pontiac, Mich. - recounts the many ways Americans define their Jewishness. There are, for example, the houses of worship, like the All People's Synagogue in Miami, where a renegade rabbi converts people to Judaism in a one-day crash course; the black synagogue in New York, where the rabbi prays for ''Israel, Africa and America;'' and the Gay Synagogue in San Francisco, where every one is invited to the ''lesbian Havdalah [ prayer ] hot tub'' service to mark the end of the Sabbath. For some Jews, all this worship is too much and so they have found a new religious shrine - the health club at the Jewish community center where, Mr. Chafets tells us, ''cigarettes have replaced pork as the forbidden substance of choice.''

title: Martha C. Little To Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Little of Charlottesville, Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter Martha Cortelyou Little to Raoul Louis Rosenberg, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Roy A. Rosenberg of New York. The wedding is planned for May. Miss Little, a cum laude graduate of Mount Holyoke College, was until recently the director of public affairs at the Committee for National Security in Washington. She is a Ford Foundation fellow at the University of Southern California, studying for a master's degree in international security. Her father is the Jennings Randolph Distinguished Fellow at the United States Institute for Peace in Washington and a professor of religious studies at the University of Virginia. Her mother, Priscilla C. Little, is the founder of the Ash Lawn Opera Festival in Charlottesville and a program associate at the Virginia Foundation for the Humanities in Charlottesville.

title: CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
description: AS RECENTLY as the 1970's, when the American divorce rate began to soar, divorce was thought to be a brief crisis that soon resolved itself. Young children might have difficulty falling asleep and older children might have trouble at school. Men and women might become depressed or frenetic, throwing themselves into sexual affairs or immersing themselves in work.

title: Amelia R. Hamill To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Axel Litchfield of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Litchfield's daughter, Amelia Richardson Hamill, to Timothy Balch Hopkins, a son of Elizabeth Balch Hopkins of Westport, Conn., and the late Dwight Douglas Hopkins of Buffalo. The future bride is also the daughter of the late James Lyon Hamill of Downingtown, Pa.

title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'
description: CAPT. JAMES M. MOONEY of the State Police, has headed the Statewide Narcotics Task Force, a cooperative effort between state and local police officers, for the last five of its 11 years. In that time he has seen some dramatic changes in drug use in Connecticut.

title: Dr. Lainie Friedman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Friedman of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Lainie Sue Friedman, to John Louis Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ross, also of Jericho. Dr. Friedman, a third-year pediatric resident at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, graduated from the Woodrow Wilson School of Public Affairs at Princeton University and the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine. Her fiance, a risk arbitrageur at Great Pacific Capital Inc. in New York, graduated cum laude from the Engineering School at Princeton. They plan to marry in August.

title: MAKEUP MOVES
description: Remember the advertisement for Popeil's Veg-O-Matic? It diced, it sliced, it shredded, it chopped. That marketing spirit is at work for makeup today. It isn't enough for makeup to provide color; now, it has to deliver treatment benefits as well.

title: One-Liners and One-Acters
description: WITH Larry Shue's ''Nerd,'' a standard situation comedy on their main stage, and a pair of Christopher Durang's howlingly funny offbeat comic one-acts on its second stage, Port Jefferson's Theater Three is offering something for everyone.

title: Haggis, a Scottish Tradition
description: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin'-race! Aboon them a' ye tak your place. Painch, tripe or thairm: Weel are ye wordy o' a grace As lang's my arm.

title: STILL THE GREATEST
description: THE RISE OF THE GREEKS By Michael Grant. Illustrated. 391 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $27.50.

title: Robert M. Weitman, 83, Former Producer
description: Robert M. Weitman, a former film, stage and television producer, died Friday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 83 years old.

title: An Ancient Call From a Gifted People
description: The world of the ancient Nazca civilization of South America comes alive in a killer whale rendered in a whiplash of clay and in boldly painted images on bottles and jars, depicting whiskered cougars, fierce-eyed condors and hummingbirds soaring.

title: A Rabbi, a Slain Arab and an Inquiry
description: Two days before Israel opened schools in the occupied West Bank last fall, Ibrahim Bali was buying new shoes for his young daughters at the downtown Hebron store of his friend, Khayed Salah, when both men were startled by the sound of gunfire.

title: The New Guard's Military Look
description: PINNED to downtown denim and uptown designs, cloisonne French military insignia sold by a sidewalk vendor are a hot costume jewelry item in Manhattan. The colorful pins have become especially popular since appearing in fashion magazines, said the vendor, James Kusnir, who sells them for $20 to $50 in SoHo and on Columbus Avenue.

title: People's Choice: 49ers
description: Just as they were in 1982, when they defeated the Cincinnati Bengals, 26-21, the San Francisco 49ers are the team the American public wants to see win the Super Bowl.

title: Victoria Post Marries John Risko, a Banker
description: Victoria Anne Post, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Post of Beachwood, Ohio, and John F. Risko, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Risko of Portsmouth, R.I., were married yesterday at the Beverly Hills (Calif.) Hotel. The Rev. Robert H. Stucky, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. E. J. Dionne Jr. was best man.

title: Those Knobs in The Back
description: Among all the knobs and switches on stereo equipment, perhaps the most mystifying are the controls often found at the rear of the loudspeakers. Most listeners have only a vague idea of their purpose - or none at all.

title: 'AIDS and Its Metaphors'
description: Susan Sontag's purpose in ''AIDS and Its Metaphors'' is to show how the way we talk and think about AIDS makes the disease even worse than it actually is. The metaphorical packaging of AIDS, she argues, increases the suffering of the afflicted while creating unneeded anxiety among the population at large. Readers familiar with Ms. Sontag's ''Illness as Metaphor'' (1978) will recognize a familiar intellectual tactic. In that work she directed her critical skills at the metaphorical uses of tuberculosis in the 19th century and cancer in the 20th, revealing how language distorted the reality of both diseases and, in the case of cancer at least, kept patients from pursuing the most rational course of treatment.

title: No Might in Sight
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Basil Harris, 70, Hospital Administrator
description: Dr. Basil Harris, former director of health services at Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan, died of lung cancer yesterday in Rutland Memorial Hospital in Rutland, Vt. He was 70 years old and lived in Manchester Center, Vt.

title: A Mother's Advice Brings Success
description: LEAD: NEIL FELDMAN was a college dropout and had held a series of uninteresting jobs when, in frustration, he asked his mother for advice.

title: Rightists Blamed in Killing of 12 in Colombia
description: The slayings this week of 12 members of a judicial commission that had apparently uncovered evidence on previous massacres has focused outrage on violent right-wing paramilitary groups and prompted a two-day protest strike by the nation's judges and court workers.

title: Quayle, on a Bush Mission, To Meet Foes of Abortion
description: In one of his first official acts, Vice President Dan Quayle will meet with anti-abortion leaders Monday at the request of President Bush, Administration officials said today.

title: And So to Bed
description: THE top-floor aerie in San Francisco's Westin St. Francis Hotel was everything a weary traveler from the East could fantasize. Suite 3178 came with a wet bar in the foyer, sumptuous Biedermeier furniture, a marble bath with gold fixtures, a panoramic view. I parted the drapes and gazed at hills aglitter with pinpoints of light that limned the contours of America's most romantic of cities.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Pewaukee, Wis.;
A Study Sires Adult Complex
description: LEAD: A STUDY by the University of Illinois on retirement housing has led to the construction of Avondale, a $100 million adult housing community in this rural Milwaukee suburb.

title: FIRST-RATE FINDS
description: Spending a few days in Biarritz, we'd been loafing at the Hotel du Palais, sampling the bustling open-air fish restaurants under the cliff, poking around the shops down at St. Jean-de-Luz and, one night, enjoying a great dinner at the old and still-grand Cafe de Paris.

title: Martha Bumsted Becomes Fiancee Of D. P. O'Hearn
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Bumsted of Vero Beach, Fla., and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Cleaver Bumsted, to Dennis Patrick O'Hearn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Charles O'Hearn Jr. of Fripp Island, S.C. A June wedding is planned.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Montreal
description: Winter in Montreal can be as old-fashioned as a horse-drawn sleigh on Le Mont-Royal, the 500-acre park at the city's center, or as futuristic as the Olympic Stadium, built for the 1976 Summer Games and crowned a year ago with a 556-foot tower to hold up its retractable, seasonal roof. It's this blend of the Old World and New France that makes Montreal intriguing. Only an hour's flight from New York, Montreal looks and sounds like Europe - without jet lag. Imagine Paris at reasonable prices, with the added advantage of the United States dollar being worth approximately $1.20 in Canada. (Prices given throughout in United States dollars.) Though the almost three million residents of Montreal cope with snow from October to April and temperatures as low as 20 degrees below zero in January, winter sports abound and commerce thrives in a weatherproof second city below street level. Within the past year alone, two architecturally distinctive office towers, Maison de Cooperants and Place Montreal Trust, and a condominium development, Les Cours Mont-Royal, have been built downtown atop underground promenades. While changing the skyline, they have also expanded to about 10 miles the network of 1,250 shops, 200 restaurants and 25 theaters linked below icy sidewalks to eight hotels, 10 million square feet of office space and a train station. Events

title: Paris Art Thefts Meant Just as Spectator Sport
description: A West German art student suspected of stealing works of art worth about $3.2 million told the French police that he took them only because he wanted to ''admire them quietly at home,'' the authorities report.

title: Game of Week Link to Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Masked Revels of a Belgian Mardi Gras
description: IN the freezing predawn darkness of Mardi gras in the Belgian town of Binche, a drummer and two costumed men dance along a lamp-lighted alley to round up fellow celebrants for the day's procession. The Binchois call this precarnival dawn ''the best moment.''

title: Dillusion in Victory: Tran Bach Dang, Writer, Vietnam
description: Tran Bach Dang joined the Vietnamese Communist Party at 17; two years later, in 1945, he was a leader of the uprising that briefly seized Saigon. When Saigon fell again in 1975, Mr. Dang had run the party for a decade in the enemy's capital. A 62-year-old pensioner, he now lives in the city renamed for Ho Chi Minh. A novelist, journalist and friend of the party leader, Nguyen Van Linh, he spoke in a garden as his grandson, Thien Son, clamored for attention.

title: SUPER BOWL XXIII
description: The 49ers play the Bengals today. Some of the highlights of the coverage are:

title: Buick Open Purse Raised to Million
description: The purse for the 1989 Buick Open will be $1 million, up from $700,000 last year. The 25-year-old tournament becomes the 15th on the PGA Tour with a purse of at least $1 million.

title: FICTION: A USER'S MANUAL
description: THE COMPANY WE KEEP An Ethics of Fiction. By Wayne C. Booth. 557 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $29.95.

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Exploring the Human Need for Help
description: Terry Creach and Stephen Koester both create dances for themselves and commission works from guest choreographers. What the resultant pieces have in common is their all-male casts. Mr. Creach and Mr. Koester wish to explore all the possibilities of male dancing.

title: The Medium Is the Master: Video Creates Its Own Reality
description: MARRIAGES are not made in heaven any more, they are made on the cutting-room floor. This may not be news to those who have attended avant-garde wedding ceremonies in recent years, but there may be many like me who have not undergone this latest shock to the battered modern psyche. My cautionary tale may serve to limit the trauma to the innocent among us.

title: Vietnam in Art and Words
description: THE Vietnam War killed thousands of Americans, left others with painful memories and changed the way many people saw their country and themselves. Many Americans wanted to forget the war and put it behind them. But today, people are looking back and looking carefully at the war.

title: Burma Tries to Avoid Slips of the Authoritarian Lip
description: It was a moment of high drama that severely tested the Burmese military Government's lurching, awkward efforts to open up a bit to the world.

title: Composers Who Pay Their Way
description: Think of New York's concert life and one thinks first of the big, glamorous events: first nights at the Metropolitan Opera, famous recitalists and singers at Lincoln Center, glittering visiting orchestras at Carnegie Hall.

title: Iraq Called Willing to Soften Stand in Its Talks With Iran
description: A United Nations official left for the Persian Gulf today to hold new talks with Iran and Iraq as a report circulated that Iraq may be easing its stand.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 22, 1989
'PLAY THE MAN AND NOT THE BOARD'
description: HENCE By Brad Leithauser. 320 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Regents Decide Rural Librarians Won't Need Master's
description: The Board of Regents has declined to approve mandating professional degrees for directors of small libraries.

title: RICO Redux
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL: WARREN GROVE;
Towers for Pine Barrens Opposed
description: LEAD: Mary Henry does not consider herself a political person. But last fall, when she heard that the United States Air Force planned to construct high-frequency towers just up the road from her home in Warren Grove, she knew she had to act.

title: A Debate Over Putting Nuclear Power in Orbit
description: WHERE does a satellite get the electricity it needs as it orbits the earth? The Soviet space program uses small nuclear reactors aboard some of its most important space vehicles, while American spacecraft tend to generate electricity from the sun.

title: Positive Expectations
description: ''Failing in Teaching'' by Karon Cooney is one of the saddest statements I've ever read about education, although my first reaction to it was why such a negative, unforgiving article would be printed at all.

title: Auto Insurance Pool to Be Scrutinized
description: LEAD: AN ad hoc Assembly committee has called hearings to investigate accusations that failures by the Kean administration to enforce a law creating an automobile insurance pool for motorists that private insurers refused to cover have contributed to an estimated $2.7 billion deficit since it began operating in 1984.

title: Fighting for a Place on Crowded Newsstands
description: Magazine publishers seem undaunted by the fact that only two out of 10 new magazines survive beyond their fourth year. Indeed, in 1987, 477 new consumer magazines appeared on the newsstands, a 28 percent increase over new launches in 1986.

title: Get Ready for Longer Gasoline Lines
description: Fifteen years ago, during a few days in mid-October, the Arab oil-producing nations shut the global oil valve and plunged the free world into energy panic. The 1973 oil embargo in the wake of the Yom Kippur War, coupled with American regulatory overreaction, led to the first gasoline lines at the pumps since World War II and brought on our own kind of domestic energy warfare.

title: Paying Cash For School Grades
description: PUBLIC school pupils in Cleveland can get more than a diploma when they graduate. Each can collect up to $4,800 toward a college education.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about WZFM, the FM radio station in Pleasantville, gave an incorrect name for its weekly program of old rock-and-roll. It is the ''Saturday Night Special.'' A co-host of the show was also misidentified. He is Kerin McCue, not Kevin.

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Back to Square 1 For Riverfront
description: LEAD: DESPITE the withdrawal of the developer of Penn's Landing, city officials say they are confident that plans for the 37-acre site along the Delaware River will go forward.

title: BOOM TOWN ON THE DANUBE
description: BUDAPEST 1900 A Historical Portrait of a City and Its Culture. By John Lukacs. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson.

title: CRIME
description: If the Italy of Magdalen Nabb's five earlier mysteries remains an unknown country, THE MARSHAL AND THE MADWOMAN (Scribners, $16.95) should correct that loss. Although no less pristine in style than its series predecessors - provocative procedural cases solved, and occasionally forgiven, by the paternalistic Marshal Salvatore Guarnaccia of the Florence Carabinieri - the English author's new crime novel examines the human components of a murder case on a level of perception that surpasses mere mastery of form.

title: Where Picasso Crafted His Ceramics
description: IT doesn't take much more than a cursory glance to realize that Vallauris, a town in the Maritime Alps of France, is a pottery center of consequence. Avenue Georges-Clemenceau, the main street, is lined with shops spilling their wares out onto the sidewalk. Individual artisans and artists have studios and shops on the avenue and on adjoining side streets.

title: The Videodisk Comeback
description: Staging a comeback - even a modest one - often suggests vindication and moral triumph. There is a sense of an earlier injustice being righted, of wrongly withheld recognition bestowed at last, and true deserts finally enjoyed.

title: It's Time to Put a Tax on Imported Oil
description: Something curious happened in early January. With little more than two weeks of his term remaining, President Reagan endorsed a Commerce Department finding that rising petroleum imports threaten to impair national security, leaving the West dependent on potentially insecure sources. Then, just a few hours after President Reagan's announcement, American Navy jets shot down two Libyan MIG's over the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Estate Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Poe Be Shunned Again? Quoth Admirers, 'Nevermore'
description: LEAD: These are heady days for the ghost of Edgar Allan Poe, but Norman George says he does not feel a bit tired.

title:
FOCUS: Mortgages;
'Designer' Loans for Almost Every Purse
description: LEAD: WHEN Tony Basinski found a four-bedroom house last July in Upper St. Clair, Pa., a suburb 15 miles south of Pittsburgh, he was worried that rising interest rates would price him out and keep him from closing on the $235,000 home on schedule on Nov. 30.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: The Man Who Looked Like Howard Cosell By John Bartholomew Tucker St. Martin's Press. 250 pages. $16.95. Catchy title, eh? Immediate name recognition. Everyone knows Howard Cosell, and everyone seems to have an opinion about him. The ingenious dustjacket shows a smiling-eyed Mr. Cosell from the ears up. That is Howard Cosell, isn't it? Perhaps not. Let's go back to 1983 and have a drink in the Oak Room Bar at the Plaza Hotel, where the book opens. Harry Baker, an agent for television celebrities, and his friend Alice - ''wearing that smile of hers that silently says, I-know-exactly-what-you-are-and-I-find-it-all-amusing-stimulating -and-exciting'' - see a man at the bar wearing an ABC sports jacket. ''My God, look over at the bar,'' Alice says. ''The resemblance is uncanny.'' Harry, who knows Howard, approaches the man. ''It was his eyes that were different,'' Harry, the first-person narrator says. ''That's what made him look so eerie. Howard has friendly eyes. This man's eyes were hard.''

title: The Supermarket Amaryllis
description: For millions of Americans, today is the day the San Francisco 49ers and the Cincinnati Bengals meet in the Superbowl. For some of them it is also the day that their supermarket amaryllis should bloom. Finally.

title: Miss Christ Wed on L.I.
description: At St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., Geraldine Payne Christ, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. M. Hallsted Christ of Oyster Bay, was married yesterday to Harold B. Cooper 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooper Jr. of Waverly, Pa. The Rev. Steven Babos performed the ceremony.

title: Now You See Her . . .
description: VANISHING ACT Starring Mike Farrell (in photo), Elliott Gould, Fred Gwynne, Margot Kidder (in photo). Directed by David Greene. 1986. Vidmark Entertainment. 93 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG.

title: Carl Furillo, 66, Outfielder for Brooklyn Dodgers
description: Carl Furillo, the right fielder for the Brooklyn Dodgers during their glory years in the late 1940's and 50's, died yesterday at his home at Stony Creek Mills, Pa. He was 66 years old.

title: The Good in Others
description: Pilfering, substance abuse, profound ennui, malingering and uninspiring: Karon Cooney's list of sweeping accusations against her teaching companions is, indeed, frightfully all encompassing.

title: Veteran Teachers Tutor New Ones
description: LEAD: WHEN Enid Lipeles was a fledgling teacher, she would have loved to have had someone advise her on such matters as tests, grading, resource materials and school politics.

title: Police Provide Details on Shooting of Officers, but Questions Linger
description: The few minutes it took to make a telephone call about a search warrant was all the time it took for two New York City police officers to be shot Friday morning as they tried to arrest a murder suspect.

title: Varieties of Sandpaper
description: CHOOSING sandpaper from among the many varieties stocked by hardware stores often perplexes amateurs, and not surprisingly.

title: TALKING: Booklets; A Sampling Of Sources For Advice
description: SPECIALIZED advice is usually quite costly, but not always. For example, an excellent way to learn about buying, managing, maintaining or selling a piece of property from a variety of experts without spending more than a handful of dollars is to write for the many books and pamphlets available from government and private agencies.

title: Baker's Five Points On Global Politics
description: As he began testifying at his confirmation hearing last week before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, James A. Baker 3d, who will be President Bush's Secretary of State, outlined five ''very significant transformations'' taking place around the world. They are: Gains for democracy

title: Botha Is Expected to Be Discharged Soon
description: South Africa's President, P. W. Botha, who suffered a mild stroke on Wednesday, will probably be discharged from the hospital early next week but will then require a six-week period of recuperation, Health Minister Willem A. van Niekerk said today.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: J. Henry Weber;
60 Years of Watching the Weather
description: LEAD: VIRTUALLY everyone has an opinion on the weather, particularly when it is very hot or cold or snowy. But when J. Henry Weber, an 84-year-old resident of Dobbs Ferry, talks about the weather he knows what he's talking about. For more than 60 years Mr. Weber has been a meteorologist, although he is quick to point out that these professionals were called scientists in his early days of weather-watching.

title: KISSING CUSTOMS
description: Michael T. Kaufman's article about hand-kissing delighted me (About Men: ''Kissing Customs,'' Dec. 11). Indeed, my mother always said that a communist government could take all material things away from you, but it could not deprive you of your education or your manners.

title: DATA BANK: January 22, 1989
Prospects; The Trade Gap Widens
description: The trade figures for November showed a sharp and unexpected widening of the trade deficit to $12.5 billion, from $10.3 billion in October. The cause of the increase was a surge in imports and a decrease in exports. The question for the analysts is whether the growth in the deficit is an aberration or a trend. Four economists give their views. Shiniji Sasaki General manager and senior economist, Yamaichi Research Institute, Tokyo.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ...And See Who Salutes IVIA question of the year: What can East Hamptonites put on a flagpole? The query began last year in the village when Morgan Rank put more than a flag on his flagpole. An ''American primitive art'' dealer, Mr. Rank decided to add some ''American primitive art'' to the landscape. In front of his building, he had constructed a 20-foot-high flagpole, on the top of which is perched a 6-foot-tall ''life size'' wooden lumberjack.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: WINTER CARNIVAL

title: 3 Honored by Black Charities
description: Associated Black Charities, a federation of 59 human service agencies in New York City, has named three winners of its annual Black History Maker awards for ''extraordinary achievement.'' The 1989 awards went to Franklin Thomas, president of the Ford Foundation, Rachel Robinson, chairwoman of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, and Arthur Mitchell, president of the Dance Theatre of Harlem. The federation will honor the winners at a Carnegie Hall concert on Feb. 1, the start of Black History Month.

title: COASTAL LEGACY
description: To understand the food of the Carolina Low Country, you have to know first a little geography and then a little history. The Low Country is that narrow stretch of South Carolina coastline that runs from Pawleys Island in the north, southwest into Georgia, and inland 80 miles or so to the Fall Line, as Carolinians call the dramatic divide where the Sand Hills rise abruptly from the coastal plain. It is an area of palm trees and Spanish moss, of water moccasins, alligators and ghostly old rice plantations - the kind of landscape the rest of the country pictures as the heart of the Old South.

title: A Spot of Paint Won't Hurt This Lily
description: It is almost 24 years since the publication of an eccentric, brilliant, and eerily prescient advertisement for the Plaza Hotel. The ad had no picture of the Plaza or of anything inside it; it was simply a parable, and it was called ''The Day New York Almost Vanished.''

title: Cuba Has Come Far Since Days of the Casinos
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION: Cuomo Concedes; A Gap in the Drug War
description: THE plague of drugs ''is the single most ominous phenomenon of our times,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in his State of the State address early in the month. ''Every day more children surrender their bodies and souls to crack, driven to madness, robbed of their childhood, left desperate and broken and dangerous.''

title: Schools Suing for Tax Money
description: ALL 14 school districts in the Towns of Huntington and Smithtown and 5 of 11 in the Town of Islip are suing their respective towns, accusing the towns of violating the Suffolk County Tax Act by failing to forward tax-receipt money to them promptly.

title: Beth Otten Wed To Bruce Hood
description: Barbara Ethel Otten, a daughter of Robert P. Otten of South Salem, N.Y., and the late Loisclaire S. Otten, and Bruce Edward Hood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ramon R. Hood of Wilmington, Del., were married last evening at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. The Rev. Dr. William Weisenbach, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by Walfred W. Scofield, an ordained elder of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), who is an uncle of the bride.

title:
GARDENING;
Maintaining Color in Flower Borders
description: LEAD: GARDENERS strive for continuous color in their flower borders, yet there seems to be at least one period when a paucity of flowers results in a dowdy, unkempt appearance.

title:
GARDENING;
Maintaining Color in Flower Borders
description: LEAD: GARDENERS strive for continuous color in their flower borders, yet there seems to be at least one period when a paucity of flowers results in a dowdy, unkempt appearance.

title: Reviews/Dance; Sleekness in 'Waltz' and 'Symphony'
description: Take a newcomer to the kind of program the New York City Ballet presented on Friday night and you will see preconceptions about classical ballet break into shards.

title: American Graffiti
description: George Bush has the best handwriting of all the Republicans who vied for the Presidency last year, according to the National Coalition to Stamp Out Chicken Scratching. The ''coalition'' is the creation of a ball-point pen manufacturer, whose not-so-hidden agenda is to promote them. But, commerce apart, the stamper-outers have a legitimate cause: in the age of word processors, penmanship is getting sloppier.

title: Barbet Schroeder: From Bukowski To von Bulow
description: Charles Bukowski and Claus von Bulow may seem like polar opposites of American society. Nevertheless, the free-spirited writer who has chronicled Los Angeles's Skid Row and the New York socialite who stood trial and was acquitted of the attempted murder of his wife have at least one thing in common: Their stories come to the screen via the director Barbet Schroeder.

title: Question Of the Week; Can Winfield and Steinbrenner Find Peace?
description: Steinbrenner's battles with Winfield are merely a result of his understandable frustration and boredom after years with a losing team. The obvious cure is for the compassionate city of New York to take up a collection and send Our George to Los Angeles, where he can once again pursue his favorite pastime: destroying a winning team. That should bring peace to all of us - at least for a while. DIANE COFFIELD Great Neck, L.I.

title: Campaign Flawed, Dukakis Aide Agrees
description: In a strikingly blunt post-mortem, the chief strategist for Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign has tacitly accepted many of the criticisms directed at that organization, saying that it should have been more inclusive, that it lacked a central and unifying message and that it should have been more open about its disagreements with the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The assessment was made Thursday in a speech by the Dukakis aide, John Sasso, who had high praise for Mr. Jackson as a leader of the Democratic Party. ''I have never in 20 years of politics encountered a more original mind and gifted motivator of people, especially the young,'' Mr. Sasso said.

title: Hands Across The Table
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGHER EDUCATION: THE REAL CRISIS
description: ON THE AFTERNOON OF MAY 18, 1988, COMMENCEMENT Day at Columbia University, more than 25,000 people - including 7,000 degree candidates and their families - sat outdoors beneath a driving rain, wondering what would happen to the graduation exercises.

title: STREETSCAPES: Readers' Questions; Three Rats, and a Cocktail Lounge Atop a Bridge
description: This is another in a series of columns answering questions about New York's changing streetscapes.

title: Bigger Role for Air Agency Is Urged
description: Three former chiefs of the Federal Aviation Administration and other experts are calling for more autonomy for the agency and a new push for technological solutions to a host of problems facing aviation.

title: Deaf People As Court Jurors
description: SHOULD a deaf person be barred from serving on a trial jury?

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Is the Big East The Best Conference?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Masterpieces
description: To the Editor: When in the past I went to pieces over masterpieces (Travel, Nov. 6) it was called art poisoning or art indigestion. Now I can use a much more sophisticated name: Stendahl's Syndrome. Thank you, Louis Inturrisi, for lifting me out of a country hick status. FRANK MEISSNER Bethesda, Md.

title:
DINING OUT;
Unusual Mix of French and American
description: LEAD: When a good restaurant closes, there is always the fear that a mediocre one will take its place. Fortunately, Margaux, the restaurant that replaced the Fox and Hounds in Colts Neck, is even better than its predessor.

title: Exile of Apartheid
description: Two years ago, when a one-man judicial commission appointed by President P. W. Botha of South Africa castigated a prominent commercial banker, Christopher J. W. Ball, for his anti-apartheid activities, his business colleagues said the action was a politically manipulated bid to destroy his career. Last week, Mr. Ball, the managing director of the First National Bank in Johannesburg, made a career decision of his own. He will leave to take an unspecified post in Europe, joining a growing group of liberal executives who have left South Africa since the Government imposed a state of emergency in 1987.

title: Strains Emerge in the Partnership Of 2 Who Lead New York Schools
description: Signs of strain and even suspicion have begun to surface in the relationship between Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green and the man largely responsible for bringing him to New York City, the Board of Education President, Robert F. Wagner Jr. Underlying the wary relationship is uncertainty about their respective roles as well as conflicting styles. But aides to both men say they have had few major disagreements and continue, on many occasions, to cooperate.

title: An Encore for the Cleveland
description: THE Hartford and Waterbury Symphonies started the new season yesterday evening, and you can catch the repeat of the Waterbury Symphony's Gershwin program at the Kennedy High School today at 3. At least eight other orchestral programs hop on the musical bandwagon this week, beginning with tomorrow's annual visit of the Cleveland Orchestra to Bushnell Hall in Hartford.

title: Larger Than Life
description: THEY CALL ME MR. MARDI Gras,'' Blaine Kern says, with some justification. The float-and-prop design firm he founded 41 years ago, Blaine Kern Artists, is now responsible for much of the mobile decoration that parades through New Orleans during the notorious, pre-Lent carnival every year. (This year's celebration runs from mid-January through Feb. 7, which is the day known as Mardi Gras.) Stored in 28 huge warehouses Kern refers to as ''dens,'' the population of papier-mache figures he's created over the years by now amounts to a purgatory for replicas of the famous and fantastic. ''I've got practically every President,'' Kern says. ''Every god and goddess. And all sorts of creatures - witches, goblins, Prince Charmings.''

title: TV VIEW
description: If something appalling goes on long enough, people become inured to it. Witness the state of American television, where, due to the peculiar exigencies of commercial network economics, we do not even blink when a scene of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. being assassinated is followed by a commercial for an underarm deodorant. It no longer strikes us as disconcerting - much less upsetting or unworkable - that the emotional thread of a drama (''Hamlet,'' ''Oedipus,'' ''Lassie''?) should be interrupted by an advertisement for a product.

title: CASH OF CAMPAIGNS CAN GO ELSEWHERE
description: Nearly 200 House members have stockpiled $39.2 million in campaign funds that they could use as retirement cushions because of a provision of the Federal election law, a new study reports.

title: Goal in Overtime Boosts Rangers
description: If it wasn't beyond the call of duty, it certainly exceeded his job description. Mark Hardy, who is not even a stylish defenseman, tonight performed a good imitation of a gifted left wing. The odd change in role consequently preserved a familiar theme for the Rangers.

title: Now, Kohl Has to Plod His Way Out of the Libya Mess
description: CRISES by definition never break at opportune times.

title: Flying Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: That's Entertainment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paradox, Ambiguity And Ferruccio Busoni Photos of Ferruccio Busoni (Bettmann Archive); conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi confering with the soloist, Garrick Ohlsson (Jack Van Antwerp)
description: It is the destiny of Ferruccio Busoni's music to be perpetually revived and re-examined, never established in the repertory yet not forgotten, either. The composer guaranteed such a state of affairs; whatever cravings he had for popular success were more than gratified by his long career as a piano virtuoso, and he composed his music for a self-selecting audience of the curious and intelligent. ''The public neither knows nor wants to know,'' he wrote, ''that in order to receive a work of art, half the work must be done by the recipient.''

title: Peter Brook Conjures 'The Mahabharata' for TV
description: Peter Brook, the magician who makes theater in unlikely places, is transforming his epic ''Mahabharata'' into a six-hour film for television, and a theatrical movie of about half that length. Filming has just been completed in a formerly abandoned studio at Joinville, outside Paris.

title: POSTINGS: Moving Market; Westward, Ho!
description: Gambling on the future of the commercial real estate market in central New Jersey, two developers in the area will start construction in Bridgewater next month on two three-story office buildings with 325,000 square feet of rental space. Named the Grande Commons at Bridgewater, the $60 million project on a 24-acre site on Route 22 near the junction of Route 28 is a joint venture of the Bellemead Development Corporation of Roseland and Claremont Properties of Bridgewater.

title: A CONTESTED ELECTION: Dr. Anatoly N. Solovyev, Doctor, Soviet Union
description: Anatoly N. Solovyev, 45, is chief doctor at a big hospital in the center of Moscow. Neither his wife, who is also a doctor, nor his son, who is studying to be a doctor, is a party member. He joined the party in 1970 and recently defeated two other candidates in an election for the Moscow City Council.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TURNED FUNNY. By Celestine Sibley. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) This memoir by the longtime Atlanta Journal-Constitution reporter and columnist Celestine Sibley is a delight. In ''Turned Funny,'' Ms. Sibley chronicles her more than 40 years in journalism, her Depression-era childhood in the Deep South and her family's roots in rural Georgia and Florida.

title: A Typical Day in the Life of a Village Manager
description: LEAD: THE telephone buzzed again. ''You gotta take them all,'' Village Manager Joseph P. Fraioli said apologetically as he snatched up the receiver.

title: Cuba Has Come Far Since Days of the Casinos; The War on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dedicated People
description: Castigation of any profession in its entirety is both arrogant and inaccurate. When Karon Cooney has no good words to say for the teaching profession, she must be wrong.

title: SUPER BOWL XXIII QUARTERBACKS: While Esiason Emerges, Montana Survives; QUARTERBACK FOR 49ERS OVERCOMES INJURIES, DOUBTS
description: To hear Joe Montana's perception of the perceptions of him, he will foolishly drag what is left of his 60-year-old body onto the field at Joe Robbie Stadium late this afternoon as the quarterback of the San Francisco 49ers in his latest attempt to succeed in a line of work designed for younger, sturdier people.

title: Rutgers Stops Slide
description: Tom Savage scored 23 of his season-high 33 points in the second half, when Rutgers shot 80 percent from the field, and the Scarlet Knights defeated Duquesne by 102-87 today in an Atlantic 10 Conference game.

title: Dust and Dreams From the Lone Star State
description: Three score years ago, Larry L. King sprouted from the jackrabbit plains of West Texas, a barren space where the air stinks of crude oil somebody else owns, the dust burns in your nostrils like needles and the sky seems boundless principally because there are no trees. Broadway, Harvard and Elaine's might as well have been on Jupiter.

title: A June Wedding For Ms. Penney
description: The engagement of Celeste Penney to Tyler Preston Benson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Benson of North Haven, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. and Mrs. John S. Penney Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Order Restored After Violence At Capital Jail
description: Heavily armed guards restored order early today to the District of Columbia prison complex after a night of disturbances by inmates left one prisoner dead, another injured and two buildings badly damaged by fire.

title: Leah Goldfarb Marries
description: At Temple Beth El in Portland, Me., Leah Beth Goldfarb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew S. Goldfarb of Portland, was married last evening to Michael Lubin Byer, a son of Hope L. Byer of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., and Charles H. Byer of Philadelphia. Rabbi Harry Z. Sky and Cantor Kurt Messerschmidt performed the ceremony. Mrs. Byer, who is studying for a master's degree in elementary education at George Washington University, graduated from Wellesley College. The bridegroom, a partner at Comvest Properties, a development company in Washington, graduated from George Washington.

title: THE WORLD: Armenians vs. Azerbaijanis; How Moscow Hopes to Defuse an Ancient Ethnic Conflict
description: IT is a little like watching someone try to slip the pin back into a live grenade. Slowly and with a caution learned the hard way, Moscow has begun a new campaign to pacify the ethnic tensions in Armenia and Azerbaijan. If the exercise is successful, it will bode better for the orderly resolution of ethnic discontents in other republics with restive non-Russian majorities. If not, Mikhail S. Gorbachev may come to look at this region as his Ulster, his Beirut.

title:
GARDENING;
Maintaining Color in Flower Borders
description: LEAD: GARDENERS strive for continuous color in their flower borders, yet there seems to be at least one period when a paucity of flowers results in a dowdy, unkempt appearance.

title: Votes for Hall Are Taken
description: Terry Bradshaw, Bob Griese, Art Shell, Mel Blount, Ted Hendricks and Willie Wood attained the final yes-or-no vote today at the annual meeting of the Pro Football Hall of Fame selectors.

title: Constitution Takes It on the Chin in North Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Transforming Downtown Brooklyn
description: GEORGE BUGLIARELLO, the president of Polytechnic University in downtown Brooklyn, seems happy now to tell the story of being offered his job in 1973 and turning it down at first, not because of the school's faculty, finances or academic standing, but because of the urban blight surrounding its campus.

title: Removing the Duds
description: I am in general agreement with Karon Cooney's many criticisms of teachers.

title: KEY MATCHUPS
description: Randy Cross, 49ers' center, vs. Tim Krumrie, Bengals' nose tackle: Krumrie stays low, and he moves so quickly and so well laterally that he can take away the cutback by a running back. Bill Walsh, the 49ers' coach, said it would take two men to block him. ''Krumrie is the foundation of our defense,'' said Dick LeBeau, the Bengals' defensive coordinator. Cross is a wise old head with bad knees and reduced quickness. He is in his 13th pro season and says it will be his last. Michael Carter, 49ers' nose tackle, vs. Bruce Kozerski, Bengals' center: Though Carter is explosive and quick, he sometimes tries so hard to make plays that he overruns them. ''If we're going to run the ball effectively,'' said Kozerski, ''we've got to stay on him, but we're not going to be driving him back 10 yards because no one does it.'' Carter responded, ''Once Kozerski gets the edge on you, he can cut you off the play, but as long as I stay low I'll be fine.'' Jerry Rice, 49ers' wide receiver, vs. Eric Thomas and Lewis Billups, Bengals' cornerbacks: In the regular season, Rice averaged 20.4 yards a catch, and in two playoff games he has caught five touchdown passes, including three against the Bears in the N.F.C. championship game. Sprained ankle or not, he is still the 49ers' game-breaker, and Thomas said he had to be controlled at the line of scrimmage. LeBeau said he would not flop cornerbacks, so Thomas and Billups will share the coverage. Roger Craig, 49ers' running back, vs. Bengals' front seven: This season's lighter Craig is the premier all-round running back in the league, with 1,502 yards rushing and 534 yards in receptions. If he gains 100 yards rushing or near that in receptions the Bengals will be in trouble. ''If he finds the seam and breaks into the secondary,'' said LeBeau, ''he's very difficult to bring down one on one. And you can't give him the wide seam.'' Bill Walsh, 49ers' coach, vs. Sam Wyche, Bengals' coach: These are two old friends who worked together as quarterback coach and quarterback and later as coach and assistant coach. They are smart and innovative and not afraid to be different. Walsh scripts his first 25 plays to avoid stereotyped play calling and to allow his players to prepare better. Wyche often uses no huddle or a quick huddle to create chaos and uncertainty in the opposing defense.

title: Give Attention to Teachers Who Care
description: Karon Cooney's article, ''Failing in Teaching'' (Opinion page, Jan. 1), speaks of passionless teachers, but I expect it will arouse the passion of all effective teachers who read it. Ms. Cooney lifts the burden of guilt for our children's ills from parents' shoulders and drops it on the most popular scapegoat of the 80's - our nation's teachers.
