title: Some Applause for A Generous Gesture
description: THE annual award that used to be presented for the best sportsmanship in a given year would have had an obvious nominee in 1988. It would surely have gone to the Swedish team that won the bronze medals at the world team championships in Venice in October.

title: Familiar Comforts in a Cozy Setting
description: WHAT was formerly the Quarterdeck in Stamford has evolved into a new restaurant called Crispin's. In a freestanding house on Long Ridge Road, it is about one-quarter mile north of Lord & Taylor's on the right hand side of the road.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson's Core Curriculum Appraised
description: LEAD: IN a classroom on the campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University here, Dr. Walter Cummins challenges his students to compare the philosophy of Martin Buber with the ideas of other authors they have studied during the last two years. What would Buber have thought of Freud? Would he have agreed with the Romantic perceptions of

title:
FOCUS: MORTGAGES;
Mortgages for Every - Well, Almost Every - Purse
description: LEAD: When Tony Basinski found a four-bedroom house last July in Upper St. Clair, Pa., a suburb 15 miles south of Pittsburgh, he was worried that rising interest rates would price him out and keep him from closing on the $235,000 home on schedule on Nov. 30.

title: The Environment as Local Jurisdiction
description: AS part of the legacy of the Reagan Administration's New Federalism, states and local communities are taking on many responsibilities for protecting the environment that were once largely the province of the Federal Government. While many state officials are glad to have more power, they complain that the Government is not giving them enough money or guidance.

title: A ''Catch-22'' On Health Care in the Home
description: Americans now spend more than $1 out of every $10 on health care. How we put this money to the most cost-effective use is one of the most important questions facing individuals and political leaders today.

title: A Better Way to the Beach in Puerto Rico
description: THE best road to the best beach in Puerto Rico - and one of the best in the world - isn't the main one. The car rental agency in San Juan may tell you that Route 3 east from San Juan is the best way to reach Luquillo Beach - and they'd be half-right. Route 3 is two-lane highway, and if a bit more beat-up than the average Interstate, it's fast and direct.

title: ART VIEW
description: With the presence of ''German Art in the Late 80's'' here, the other shoe of the ''Binationale,'' an unusual German-American exhibition exchange, has dropped. This survey of the work of 27 West German artists, reorganized by curators from three Dusseldorf museums, is on view at the Institute of Contemporary Art and the Museum of Fine Arts through next Sunday.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: BREATHES there anyone who doesn't get a kick out of saving money, who doesn't love a bargain, who wouldn't take advantage of a discount that requires no coupon, no stamp and no effort? Probably not - depending. . . .

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Artist as Beast

title: When Music Runs in the Family
description: LEAD: NAVAH PERLMAN, the young pianist who is pursuing a growing - and, critics say, promising - career on the concert scene, is the first to admit that bearing a famous musical name has its advantages.

title: The Salt Alarm
description: EVERY TIME SHE SEES ME SALTING THE spaghetti water, my daughter sucks in her breath with a slight, righteous whistle. She eats the spaghetti (and the lightly salted sauce), but with a shrug of self-sacrifice, contemplating what this dietary indiscretion will do, sooner or later, to her blood pressure.

title: Elmhurst's Pride: Winner of U.S. Literacy Contest
description: Two years ago, Annie Goolabia, a 59-year-old mother of six, could not read this sentence. Today she could probably write it herself.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: After 14 years, ''The Papers of William Livingston'' a major publishing project that was edited by Carl E. Prince, was completed last month when its fifth and final volume was issued by the Rutgers University Press.

title: THE HAND THAT ROCKS THE CRADLE WRITES THE BOOK
description: LEAD: This essay has been given as a lecture six or seven times. I rewrote it each time, guided by responses, questions, letters after the lecture. I look on it, gratefully, as a collaboration with my listeners, my editors and all the writers whose works and words I pieced together in it - ancestors, strangers and friends.

title: Miami Officer Disputed On Shot That Led to Riot
description: Witnesses to the fatal shooting that led to widespread racial violence here have given an account sharply at odds with that given by the lawyer for the police officer who fired the shot.

title: 'The Collar City' Is Loosening Its Ties to the Past
description: Back in 1820, Orlando Montague, a blacksmith, complained to his wife, Hannah, that he did not have a clean white shirt in the evening when he came home from work. Mrs. Montague solved the problem by cutting collars off her husband's shirts, providing a clean one for him to wear whenever he wanted.

title: A Few Problems Are Solved
description: DO not delay mailing orders for seeds and plants to be sure of getting first choices. Check mulches on flower borders, new shrubs and young trees; be sure trunks of new trees are protected with commercial tree wrap to prevent scald from winter sun. Indoors plant seed of petunias and snapdragons. Carry On

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Kill 2 Arabs in Protests in West Bank
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a 14-year-old youth and another Palestinian today in scattered demonstrations throughout the occupied West Bank.

title: Melissa Ann Brown to Wed Sean McCrary Moore in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren Archibald Hoadley Brown of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Boston, have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Ann Brown to Sean McCrary Moore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Moore of Montrose, Colo. A June wedding is planned.

title: FICTION
description: THE CARPATHIANS. By Janet Frame. (Braziller, $17.50.) Janet Frame's 11th novel, her first in nine years, is an unconventional fantasy. Told for the most part from the viewpoint of a wealthy, compulsive globe-trotter, a middle-aged New Yorker named Mattina Brecon, it describes her two-month stay in the fictional New Zealand town of Puamahara. The book takes as its starting point the discovery of a strange celestial phenomenon: a galaxy that, paradoxically, appears at the same time ''both relatively close and seven billion light years away'' as a result of light's passage through intervening gravitational forces. ''The Carpathians'' examines what might happen if this so-called Gravity Star phenomenon suddenly affected our own world - starting in the street in Puamahara where Mattina takes up residence - and ''destroyed the concept of nearness and distance as opposites.'' Fascinating, frustrating, obscure, complex, with a deceptively haphazard plot and confoundingly shifting points of view, ''The Carpathians'' is not a fast, entertaining read. But it is a small masterpiece of literary craftsmanship, the work of an original thinker with a poet's ear for the sound and cadence of language. The catastrophic effects of the Gravity Star paradox on one New Zealand neighborhood prefigure Ms. Frame's vision of the worldwide destruction ''of the old ways when distance is near and the eastern mountains of Puamahara could be the Carpathians; and weight becomes lightness; and the trees . . . have their roots in the sky.'' In just under 200 pages, Ms. Frame conveys volumes: her book yields new facets of meaning with each rereading.

title: The Yugoslav Republic That Roared
description: In weather and politics, the capital of Montenegro, Yugoslavia's smallest republic, is basking in a precocious springtime.

title: Argentinian Presence Is Here at Last
description: OLE! Argentina has come to Long Island. Nassau-Suffolk's first Argentinian restaurant is La Estancia in Elmont. This authentic, convivial South American storefront is muy bueno.

title: Tenants and Pets and Best Friends
description: I applaud the informative article on the legislative battle for tenants' rights to keep pets (Jan.l). As a single musician with two cats, I can testify to the emotional necessity of the companionship they provide.

title: Emergency Landing in Britain
description: A British Airways Boeing 757 carrying 82 people made an emergency landing at Heathrow Airport today after one of its two engines developed problems in flight, the airline said. The airline first reported that the left engine had been shut off, but later it said the engine had just been slowed down after developing problems.

title: POP VIEW
description: On Jan. 12, The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced the nominations for this year's Grammy Awards, to be presented on Feb. 22 at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. In the three decades since Domenico Modugno's ''Nel Blu Dipinto Di Blu (Volare)'' was voted both record and song of the year and Henry Mancini's ''Music From Peter Gunn'' was chosen best album, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has grown from a small group of musicians and executives centered in Los Angeles and New York into a 6,000-member organization with chapters in seven cities.

title: POSTINGS: A Proposal for Putnam; 139 Homes for a 388-Acre, 1860 Estate
description: A half century ago, George and Ira Gershwin, Cole Porter and Jerome Kern were frequent visitors to the 388-acre Dreyfus estate in southeastern Putnam County, now the subject of a proposal before the Town Board of Southeast to divide it into 139 home sites. The property features a three-story castle that evolved from an Italianate villa built in 1860 by Daniel Drew, the financier for whom Drew University, in Madison, N.J., is named. In 1930, the estate and its sculpture gardens were bought as a summer home by the late music publisher Max Dreyfus, which explains the Broadway visitors.

title: Shaw and Christmas
description: To the Editor:

title: On Irish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Can't Sustain A Powerful Start
description: For one half tonight, the Nets looked better than ever. They were outplaying the team with the best record in the National Basketball Association. They were functioning as a poised, cohesive unit. And if they had been able to upset the Cleveland Cavaliers, it could have done wonders for New Jersey's confidence.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Saco, Me.; Old Textile Mill Gets New Role
description: A CONVERSION of a group of buildings that once were part of a textile mill is bringing a year-round residential population to an island near the mouth of the Saco River.

title: Making the Grade
description: 'People frequently misuse the word ''exploit,'' but to admit an athlete to an institution and then put him in basket-weaving courses, then drop them or push them through for four years without them being able to read is an abomination and it should not happen in higher education.' - Dr. Frederick P. Whiddon, President of the University of South Alabama, defending the National Collegiate Athletic Association's recently adopted Proposition 42, which makes it harder for freshman athletes to qualify for scholarships.

title: Tough Guys in Black and White
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Going Home To Commack
description: S. Dianne Moritz's article ''Going Home Again: But Where Is 'Home'?'' [ Opinion, Jan. 1 ] brought to mind Commack as I knew it in 1953 to 1959; lovely suburban community with one general store.

title: Who Needs Punctuation?
description: To the Editor:

title: KNOWING WHICH READERS GROW WHEAT AND WHICH GROW CORN
description: Driven by fierce competition, magazine publishers are finding innovative ways to compete for advertisers. Consider a computerized process known as selective binding, which at least a handful of publishers are using to create custom editions for small clusters of subscribers who share similar characteristics.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: Disappointed over the urbanization and industrialization of Italy and the high prices, we decided to follow Boccaccio's lead to the southern west coast towns that he described as perhaps the most beautiful part of Italy.

title: Taking No Chances With Romance
description: The embrace that is also a stranglehold, the caress that becomes a blow: Images of this sort have emerged with surprising ferocity in new choreography. These obsessive love-hate motifs are often criticized when they surface in the ballet world, but they are accepted and admired when explored in modern dance.

title: Monastery in the Himalayas Reported Burned to Ground
description: The main part of Thyangboche monastery, a landmark for hikers near Mount Everest, has burned to the ground, a Buddhist priest said today.

title: A Proposition 48 Success Story at Pitt
description: It is a success story in the making, although Brian Shorter cannot be faulted if he doesn't always feel that way. Sitting in the bleachers overlooking the basketball court that was off limits to him last year, Shorter fielded questions that are as familiar to him now as the terms grade-point average and Scholastic Aptitude Test became two years ago, when both were obstacles to his college education.

title: Health Care Plan Renewed
description: LEAD: HOSPITALS in New Jersey are continuing to provide free treatment to uninsured poor patients under an agreement, forged in the final days of 1988, to renew the statewide trust fund that pays for such care.

title: Calcavecchia Takes Charge
description: Mark Calcavecchia, a husky, free-swinging long hitter,shot 6-under par over the stretch from No. 13 through 17 today to take a three-stroke lead in the $700,000 Phoenix Open.

title: Up From the Ruins
description: On a dusty plain above the harbor hundreds of men and women sit at rickety stands, shielded from the sun by battered sheets of metal. Spread in front of them are their wares: shoes and Coca-Cola, eggs, tomatoes, steel wool, whisky, vitamin B tablets . . .

title: Mario Vargas Llosa Is Unhurt After Ambush, Paper Reports
description: Two men waiting to throw dynamite at a plane carrying Mario Vargas Llosa, the author and politician, shot four people on Thursday after their attack was foiled, a newspaper said today.

title: ALL THE TALL YOUNG MEN
description: A SEASON INSIDE One Year in College Basketball. By John Feinstein. 464 pp. New York: Villard Books. $18.95.

title: Exile of the Opera
description: What a grand operatic plan it was. As artistic director of the new Bastille Opera of Paris, Daniel Barenboim, the Israeli conductor and pianist, assembled an international team of conductors, singers, directors and designers for three seasons to begin in 1990. A $350 million theater for the opera is scheduled to open with a concert on July 14. But there was much uncertainty last week after Mr. Barenboim was dismissed by Pierre Berge, the Yves Saint Laurent executive who is head of the opera's board.

title: Last Bonn Envoys Leave Afghan Capital
description: West Germany's diplomatic staff left Kabul today on orders from Bonn, and the Soviet press agency Tass reported that Moscow had begun an airlift of emergency food supplies to this beleaguered capital.

title: Giuliani, Uncertain on Run for Mayor, Talks Tough on Drugs and Defense
description: After Rudolph W. Giuliani brought a few prosecutions that made waves around the world, critics and admirers both said he was the only prosecutor in the country with a foreign policy.

title: For Bill Walsh, Two Doors Are Ajar
description: His 49er players talk about Bill Walsh's ability to identify and exploit an opposing team's weakness on defense. And when Super Bowl XXIII begins, the whispers are that the 49ers will try to exploit Reggie Williams, the Bengals' 34-year-old right outside linebacker.

title: Ms. Dorsey Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin H. Dorsey of Chevy Chase, Md., of the engagement of their daughter Melanie Graham Dorsey to Daniel James Standish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Standish of Englewood, Colo. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: TV Documentary On Rodino Career
description: PETER W. RODINO Jr. returned from World War II with a battlefield commission and a desire to enter politics. Focusing on issues that were important to returning veterans, like housing, and supported by a growing Italian-American population in the 10th Congressional District, he unseated Fred A. Hartley, a Republican, in 1948 and began a 40-year career in Congress.

title: Families' Apartment-Lease Rights Upheld
description: The right of family members to remain in their rent-stabilized apartments in New York City after the tenant named on the lease has died or moved out was upheld last week by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Taylor Keeps Title; Bout Halted After 7
description: Meldrick Taylor beat John Meekins to retain his International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title today when Referee Steve Smoger, acting on the advice of the ringside physician, stopped the bout after the seventh round of a scheduled 12-rounder.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: On-Time Tally For Amtrak Is Still Eroding

title: O'Rourke Maintains Cuomo's Budget is County's ''Bad News''
description: AN angry County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's ''bad news budget'' was a ''blatant attempt by the state'' to maintain a four-year income tax cut, at enormous cost to counties and municipalities.

title: Pointed Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynthia Louise Donahue Is Engaged To Wed Andrew Hamilton Richards
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm M. Donahue of Westwood, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Louise Donahue to Andrew Hamilton Richards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben F. Richards of Far Hills, N.J. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Miss Broadus, Law Firm Aide, Becomes Bride
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Margaret Carlisle Broadus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Broadus of New York, was married yesterday to Carl Albert Saling Jr., the son of Madeline A. Hickman of Penn Valley, Pa., and the late Mr. Saling. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS. By Peter Quennell. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) With dilettantish relish, Peter Quennell examines how ''being happy'' has ''perplexed and fascinated imaginative artists for the last two thousand years'' (3,000, in fact, since Mr. Quennell intermittently includes Homer, along with Horace and Epicurus).

title: Muttontown Zoning Opposed
description: MUTTONTOWN's 3,900 acres have long been among the most exclusive on the North Shore, with its large open spaces preserved through the years by private individuals and municipal actions of the village. However, a rapid increase in development in recent years has generated concern within the village. As the old estates are being divided and a growing number of homes constructed, the open space in Muttontown is beginning to diminish.

title: Building a World Within a World
description: IT has been called a hedge against the extinction of life on earth and a step toward colonization of the moon and Mars: Biosphere II, an enclosed, airtight, 2.25-acre ecosystem in which plants, animals and humans could survive indefinitely in harmony.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Wicker Man Starring Edward Woodward, Christopher Lee, Diane Cilento, Britt Ekland, Ingrid Pitt. Directed by Robin Hardy. 1974. Magnum Entertainment. 102 minutes. $59.98. Rated R.

title: HOMELESS GAINING WIDER VISIBILITY
description: The visibility of the homeless has risen dramatically over the past three years, with a majority of Americans now saying they see the homeless problem at first hand and not just through the news media, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Umpire's 2d Chance
description: After 12 years as a minor league umpire, Pam Postema, is getting a second chance to become the first woman to work behind a major league plate. As it did last year, the National League has invited her to umpire during spring training.

title: REVIVAL FROM WITHIN: Huang Gang, Writer, China
description: Huang Gang, a Chinese literary critic, writer and party member in his late 60's, is a member of a party wing that holds that Communism's basic principles are being forgotten. He acknowledged that past crises, particularly the cultural revolution, challenged the party's integrity. But, he argued, those ''mistakes'' have been recognized.

title: Library's Stock Is Books on Family
description: Colonial women in the Gloucester area depended on Isabel Babson, a midwife, to help deliver their babies. Three hundred years later, parents and children can rely on a library devoted entirely to family topics that was inspired by the midwife's work.

title: Diana Dorfman Engaged to Wed James Deutsch
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Dorfman of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter Diana Brooke Dorfman to Dr. James Alan Deutsch, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Deutsch of Brooklyn. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Reviews/Music; Composer Adds Links to Neo-Classic Chain
description: Three long pieces in short sections made up the concert of Lawrence Axelrod's compositions Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The young composer has at least one enviable ability: It is not easy, in a time when convention no longer provides formal structures, to write persuasive and coherent half-hour spans. ''To Be Danced,'' for piano trio, and ''Moonsongs'' a cycle of seven songs to various poets, last that long; the ''Serenata'' for 12 instruments is a healthy 18 minutes, and each seemed of a piece.

title: An Old Eli Performs As Kung Fu Star in China
description: On the banks of the West Lake, an enchanted region of islands and temples shrouded by mist and magic in this city 100 miles southwest of Shanghai, a love story has been unfolding before the cameras. It is a Chinese love story, in which the leading actress is both chased and - after a fleeting temptation - chaste. But it is also a Western love story, both unlikely and true, of a young American devoted to Chinese martial arts.

title: Bush Seen as Opposing Iran Arms
description: At two White House meetings on the sale of American arms to Iran, in December 1985 and May 1986, George Bush supported Robert C. McFarlane's advice to Ronald Reagan that the operation should not proceed, according to a published interview with Mr. McFarlane.

title: Kicking the Lottery Habit
description: I HAVE stopped playing the lottery. I thought it would be difficult to kick the habit, because I viewed those bits of paper as my tickets to the good life.

title: Dr. Jodi Singer Engaged
description: Dr. Jodi Sue Singer, a resident physician in pathology at the New York Hospital, and Dr. Albert Sassoon, an obstetrician and gynecologist in New York, plan to marry in April. The future bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Singer of Moorestown, N.J., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mrs. Neville Sassoon of White Plains and the late Mr. Sassoon.

title:
BASEBALL;
Exploring Baseball's Mystery
description: LEAD: How can you learn to throw a split-fingered fastball? Why use a tire hanging from a rope to work on hitting technique or a wooden glove for fielding fundamentals? Did you know if you were right-handed, with a dominant right eye and right foot, you'd probably have trouble playing third base, but a leg up on swinging a bat from the left side?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LOVE SONG. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $18.95.) In Chicago, a beauteous young Irish-Italian lawyer, Diana Marie Lyons, hopes to avenge her father's ruined career by putting a playboy poet called Conor Clement Clarke behind bars. Con, you see, is the son of the financial pirate who did her Daddy wrong.

title: Former Representatives And Their Leftover Campaign Funds
description: U.S. Representatives who left office in 1988 who were in office on or before Jan. 8, 1980. Legally, they may keep leftover campaign funds for their personal use. In some cases, it is not known how the money will be spent. Robert E. Badham (R-Calif.) Retired.

title: Views on Abortion Are Sharply Split 16 Years After Supreme Court Ruling
description: On the 16th anniversary of the Supreme Court's landmark decision legalizing abortion, polls show that Americans remain sharply divided about their stands on abortion.

title: In Hope and Dismay, Lenin's Heirs Speak
description: In the Communist world, the underground joke is often the best index of conditions. ''What is Communism?'' asks one that has recently been making the rounds.

title: Benefits Around Town
description: A Night at the Ballet

title: No. 1 Duke Falls To Wake Forest
description: Derrick McQueen shrugged off foul trouble in the second half and scored a career-high 20 points today as Wake Forest defeated No. 1 Duke by 75-71 in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Burnout From Caring
description: I hope this is one of many letters of outrage you receive from administrators, teachers, parents and students in response to Karon Cooney's diatribe against teachers. I cannot imagine what her experience has been to engender such hatred and bitterness, but I can vouch for mine. I have been a teacher and guidance counselor in some of the most difficult schools in New York City for 24 years.

title: Time Lapse
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Hearty Peasant Fare in Larchmont
description: LEAD: THIS charming and relaxing neighborhood brasserie just south of the movie theater distinguishes itself from other places serving French food by devoting a large portion of its menu to the full-flavored, peasant cooking of France's Languedoc district.

title: Bach Versus Computer
description: ACCORDING to the famous ballad, John Henry pitted his steel-driving speed against that of the steam drill (and beat the newfangled contraption), but that historic confrontation may pale alongside the man-versus-machine competition coming up this Saturday at the State University of New York campus at Purchase.

title: Should Every Emigre Really Be Equal Under the Law?
description: CONGRESS did away with quotas based on national origin when it overhauled the immigration law in 1965. And in 1980 it abolished the presumption that anyone fleeing Communism was a refugee. But experience in the last few months shows that it is much easier to write an evenhanded law than to carry it out in the face of political pressures reflecting special concern for particular groups of emigres.

title: A.T.&T.'s New Call to Arms
description: Five years after the breakup of the Bell system changed its world forever, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company finally seems willing to do what it takes to thrive in a fiercely competitive marketplace.

title: Banks and Bonds: A Barrier Falls
description: New powers for banks were granted by the Federal Reserve, which approved giving them limited authority to underwrite corporate bonds. The action is the most significant yet in breaking the barriers that the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 put between banking and the securities business. Bankers have long complained that the law restrictsed them as securities firms encroached on the banks' traditional businesses. The Fed imposed tight restrictions on the new powers, including forbidding banks to use depositor money to finance bond operations. As some members of Congress protested that the Fed had exceeded its authority, the securities industry, which has filed suits in the past challenging new powers for banks, was expressing objections. But the Fed said that next year it might go even further and allow banks to deal in stocks. *

title: Post-Hirohito, Japan Debates His War Role
description: Slowly, tentatively, Japan is beginning to confront a once-taboo subject - whether Emperor Hirohito bears any responsibility for World War II.

title: Q and A
description: Eviction-Co-op Rules

title: The Mall, A Member of the Family
description: The shopping mall has long been villified as a pockmark on the face of suburbia. Its detractors have faulted it for everything from the spread of mediocrity to the corruption of youth. It's my belief, however, that these hostile critics are not the mothers of preschool children stuck inside on a slushy Monday.

title: Question Of the Week; Can Winfield and Steinbrenner Find Peace?
description: If Martin and Steinbrenner can fall apart (and then make up) so many times, why not Winfield and Steinbrenner?

title: Reviews/Dance; Post-Modernist Work by Three Choreographers By JENNIFER DUNNING
description: The three choreographers presented by Dance Chance on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater of Dance Theater Workshop have different styles, histories and choreographic interests. But the new and recent works on the second program of a two-part series were recognizably of 1980's post-modernist dance, with its emphasis on sheer energy and physicality.

title: Questions and Fear Follow 2 Larchmont Slayings
description: Investigators say they have yet to find a suspect, motive or murder weapon in the stabbing deaths of an Indian-American couple here, and Indian-Americans in the region are becoming increasingly worried that the slayings may have been ethnically motivated.

title: BUD MCFARLANE: SEMPER FI
description: ROBERT C. (BUD) MCFARLANE SOMETIMES has trouble with the truth, even when he is telling it. Take the time in 1982 when he was deputy national security adviser, and an intelligence leak reached The New York Times. McFarlane proposed that National Security Council staff members in the know be given lie-detector tests to find the leak, and he volunteered to go first. He flunked.

title: INTRODUCING 'VIDEOZINES' - THEY ARE WATCHED, NOT READ
description: Because of the stiff competition among traditional print magazines, some publishers are delivering magazines on video cassettes. Of the handful of magazines now on video in this country, most are about sports.

title: A Lesson About Age
description: HAVING broken off a relationship with a woman after 10 years, I find myself where I was 14 years ago when I was separated from my wife and subsequently divorced. I remember going to my first singles dance and wine-tasting party in 1974 with a male friend also divorced but already into the scene.

title: Shipping Out From Shanghai
description: AT the Shanghai Hai Xing Shipping Company dock, just down river from the steel skeleton of the Waibaidu Bridge, the summer holiday crush was on: Western backpackers, like the overburdened camels that once traveled the Silk Road, lumbered toward the inconceivably small immigration gate, while hundreds of old Chinese men and women flooded around them, pushing, pulling, shoving trunks and suitcases and well-wrapped baskets of vegetables, roots and assorted exotica.

title: 17 Are Reported Hurt as Racists March in Atlanta
description: At least 17 people were reported injured and 42 were arrested today as several hundred people broke through police barricades in an attempt to attack seven avowed racists parading in downtown Atlanta.

title: WINGING IT
description: The fin is back. Call it a bit of madness or simply a return to 1950's kitsch, but this angular, wing-like shape is cropping up as a design element in everything from vases to chairs. Some 30 years ago, the fin became a symbol of modern efficiency and power. Most notable was its appearance on cars like the 1957 Cadillac shown here. Originally inspired by an airplane - a Lockheed P-38 Lightning - the tail fin was described by its designer, Harley Earl, as a kind of ''graceful bulk'' that gave people ''an extra receipt for their money in the form of visible prestige marking for an expensive car,'' and thus won its wild popularity.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
In Monroe, a $550 Million Mixed-Use Project
description: LEAD: A $550 MILLION mixed-use project is now rising in Monroe Township - at 42 square miles the largest of Middlesex County's 25 municipalities and a magnet for growth in the last decade.

title: Review/Jazz; 4 Artists Find Niche In Church
description: Acoustically there is no space in New York more ideal for the delectation of acoustic jazz than St. Clement's Church (423 West 46th Street). Last season, when Lyn Austin's Music Theater group presented ''Prison-Made Tuxedos,'' an ambitious music-theater piece featuring the great alto saxophonist Frank Morgan, a muddled concept was redeemed by thrilling music perfectly projected. This year the company has broadened its commitment to jazz by opening its 18th winter season with ''Short Takes '89,'' in which four jazz artists of widely varying styles perform new original work.

title: Another View Of the Fog Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: And That's Why They Say 'Vive la France'
description: To the Editor:

title: What the World Expects From George Bush: Latin America
description: LATIN AMERICANS routinely shrug when new United States administrations pledge special interest in their region. The record shows that other parts of the world invariably gain precedence. But this time may be different. Latin America's multifaceted crisis is so acute that its main problems - debt, drugs and democracy - may be difficult to ignore.

title: Harlem of the 20's Echoes in America Today
description: Nine-tenths of the way through this century, reverberations from one of its earliest eras still hold powerful sway over our collective imagination. That era, depicted in ''Black and Blue'' (which opens Thursday at the Minskoff Theater), saw an explosion of black American culture, one that radically changed the nature of American and world entertainment.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: THE INDIAN MUSEUM'S LAST STAND
description: The founder of the Museum of the American Indian, George Heye, started the collection literally by taking the shirt off the back of a Native American. I say, give every object in the museum back to its rightful owners, the Native Americans themselves. Let them decide what they want to share and what they need for the spiritual nourishment of their nations. ELIZABETH K. DORAN Member of the All Peoples Congress Boston

title: Both Coaches Promising a Lively Game
description: Did you hear that? Promises, promises from Bill Walsh and Sam Wyche, the Super Bowl XXIII coaches, pals offering predictions. Both guarantee that this will be one of the most exciting Super Bowls ever, a close, high-scoring affair full of twists.

title: Sweet Talk, Tough Tactics
description: My day always becomes wonderful/when I see your/pretty face smiling so sweetly. . . . Such free-verse sentiment, printed against a background of pastel artwork, is a kind of signature for Blue Mountain Arts, a greeting-card company founded here in 1971.

title: From Obscurity To Stardom! - Then What?
description: LEAD: ''All the characters in this film are authentic'' are the words that open Luis Bunuel's epic ''Los Olvidados,'' a film about street kids in a rough part of Mexico City, circa 1950. Based on actual events observed by Bunuel, the drama features real street children.

title: MAGAZINES FOR SOUTHERN BRIDES AND HISPANIC ENTREPRENEURS
description: Earlier in the century, publishers sought the lowest common denominator in editorial content, attempting to appeal to the widest spectrum of Americans and advertisers. Look, Life and Reader's Digest were born.

title: Modern Color Films Enter the Field
description: POOR Agfa. When we think of films in this country, we think first of Kodak, then of Fuji, and finally, maybe, of Agfa. Few of us remember that Agfa was a pioneer of color films, back before World War II.

title: Question Of the Week; Can Winfield and Steinbrenner Find Peace?
description: Steinbrenner and Winfield possess two totally incompatible personalities. Their never-ending squabbles have left the Yankee organization in ruins and the national media laughing. Soon, the integrity of every Yankee fan will be threatened. Peace can only be achieved if: 1) the Yankees win the World Series; 2) Winfield resigns; 3) Steinbrenner resigns; 4) both Winfield and Steinbrenner resign, or 5) Donald Trump takes over the Yankees and dumps Steinbrenner.

title: A Warning Signal Is Flashing
description: Since the first week of December some short-term interest rates have moved up so sharply that they now exceed the rates on long-term securities. In the past, such an occurrence, known on Wall Street as an ''inverted yield curve,'' has often been followed by a recession and falling stock and bond markets.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Summation From Womanworks
description: The Womanworks festival, devoted to female modern-dance choreographers, presented the last of its new programs Thursday night with works by Anna Sokolow and Bebe Miller.

title: Knicks' Problem: How to Stop Ellis
description: One minute Dale Ellis would pop a shot from the wing or put up a 3-pointer. Then he would drive the lane or crash the boards for a rebound. Just when the Clippers thought they had the 6-foot-7-inch Seattle SuperSonic guard covered, he would pass the ball inside.

title: What of '48 Refugees?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pollution War: The Penalties Are Growing
description: A CRACKDOWN on polluters netted the state more than $1 million in fines last year, more than twice as much as in 1987, Environmental Protection Department officials said.

title: POSTINGS: Restoration Fund; Friend of Friends
description: The New York Landmarks Conservancy has donated $5,000 from its Sacred Sites and Properties Fund to help restore the front of the Fifteenth Street Monthly Meeting building, a two-story Greek Revival structure more commonly called the Friends Meeting House, on the west side of Stuyvesant Square. The funds will help defray the cost - estimated at $45,000 - of restoring the wood on the entrance doors and their portico. Clara Garcia, business administrator of the New York Quarterly Meeting, the Quaker group that owns the property and the adjoining Friends School in the area east of Third Avenue, said the renovation efforts are due to start next month. Two years ago, renovation was completed on the windows of the building at 15 Rutherford Place, which was designed by Charles T. Bunting in 1860 and completed in 1864. The Conservancy also donated $5,000 to help repair the roof of the Brooklyn Monthly Meeting, 110 Schermerhorn Street, another building owned by the local Religious Society of Friends.

title: What the World Expects From George Bush: Middle East
description: WITH the Persian Gulf war stilled, the Arab world is looking to the new Administration to focus on an older and far more persistent priority - a settlement of the Palestinian dispute with Israel.

title: Player Pay Asked In Nebraska Bill
description: Sen. Ernie Chambers has reintroduced a proposal in the Legislature calling for University of Nebraska football players to be paid by the state. The same bill was passed by the Legislature last year, but vetoed by Gov. Kay Orr.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Mamaroneck, N.Y. $262,500 188 Mount Pleasant Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1887 Victorian; eat-in kitchen, full basement, walk to schools and transportation; taxes $3,188. Rye Brook, N.Y. $430,000 19 Meadowlark Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; fireplace, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $4,960. Valhalla, N.Y. $525,000 81 Eastview 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old ranch; fenced yard, dining room, family room, 1 acre; taxes $5,102. Branford, Conn. $190,000 21 Mill Creek Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car attached garage, bordering park, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,248. East Windsor, Conn. $125,000 33 Woolam Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; rustic site, recreation room with wood stove in partially finished basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,015. Guilford, Conn. $155,500 279 Old Whitfield Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1871 Federal Colonial; needs work, near village green, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,128. OTHER AREAS Bloomingdale, N.J. $145,900 10 Sunrise Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 51-year-old ranch; family room, full basement; taxes $2,875. Butler, N.J. $149,900 84 Boonton Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, century-old colonial; stone fireplace, patio, enclosed porch; taxes $2,320. Bayport, L.I. $118,000 365 McConnell Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,500.

title: Once Again, a Kiss Is Just a Kiss As Sanity Returns in Social Mores
description: IS it possible that the days of kissy-kissy are over? That instant intimacy, like transcendental meditation, break dancing and all the other fads that spew from the tube, has run its course?

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title: Cuba Has Come Far Since Days of the Casinos; No Capital of Vice
description: To the Editor:

title: A Turn-of-the-Century Tale Resonates Through a Lifetime
description: MY father-in-law died recently at the age of 96, and of all the memories I have of him, his telling of one small happening in his early years, which he kept in his memory for all of his life, has stayed with me for all of mine. Perhaps that is because in the telling he revealed some part of himself that was not apparent, that told me something about the little boy who later became the ''Pater Familias'' whom I so loved and admired.

title: Czech Police Block Protest Pilgrimage to Village
description: The police prevented human rights protesters from making a pilgrimage today to the village that was the home of Jan Palach, who burned himself to death 20 years ago to protest the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

title: Coach Bridges Basketball and Art
description: LEAD: Armond Hill has spent many years sizing up opponents on the basketball court first as an outstanding player and more recently as a preparatory school coach. But over the last four years, Mr. Hill, a basketball star at Princeton in the mid-1970's, who went on to play in the National Basketball Association, has been sizing up art as well.

title: Through the Palestinian Labyrinth
description: THE Palestine Liberation Organization has recently been talking a more moderate line, and that has thrust its older leaders into the spotlight and brought new prominence to some younger voices. Radical P.L.O. groups have gone along with the avowals of moderation but have warned that if the peace process does not produce results, they will return to harsher tactics. Who are these leaders, what are their backgrounds, and how do their factions differ?

title: THE CRACK IN WOLF'S MIRROR
description: NO MAN'S LAND By Martin Walser. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 160 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: 21 Injured in Nebraska Bus
description: A bus carrying a high school basketball team went out of control on a steep road and overturned Friday night, injuring 21 people, the authorities said. The bus crashed while coming down a hill in a canyon area and came to rest in a ditch about seven miles south of this western Nebraska village. A 16-year-old boy was hospitalized in serious condition with a head injury.

title: Some 'Small' Movies Can Be Very Big
description: Movies are too easy to make. When you come down to it, all it takes is money, which buys access to writers, directors and actors. It buys long shooting schedules, location trips, special effects and stretch limos. It also buys technicians who are so talented that they can make even a frivolous orangutan look like a serious orangutan, if not a movie maker of substance.

title: Proposals to Avoid Insolvency in Medicare Trust Fund Bring Sharp Debate
description: The fund that pays all Government reimbursement for hospital care of Medicare patients is projected to become insolvent in the next decade or so, but the proposed remedies hold little political appeal.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: AFRICAN MADNESS. By Alex Shoumatoff. (Knopf, $18.95.) The Africa of Alex Shoumatoff, a staff writer for The New Yorker, is the meat of travel journalism but hardly the stuff of the travel pages. He leads no safaris, paints no portraits of dignified tribesmen, drinks no tea at dawn in a tent on the African plain.

title: Unsportsmanlike Conduct
description: AS OUR 9-YEAR-OLD son stretched to turn off the television during the halftime show of the football game, my wife stopped him. ''That's the only part Daddy likes,'' she said. We all laughed at the role turnabout in our household: My wife, an otherwise appealing woman, loves to watch football on television, and I do not. But the laughter covered a malady that has afflicted me since age 17. For almost 30 years, I have not followed sports, and I have not tried very hard to hide it.

title: Museum Theft: An Artist's Loss
description: A story ''Museums Seek to Halt Thefts,'' Jan. 1 addressed a problem that I as a creative artist was confronted with in June: the theft of a piece of my artwork from a prestigious gallery on Long Island.

title: East Timor Bishop Assails Indonesia on Rights
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of East Timor, saying claims that human rights abuses had ended were ''lying propaganda,'' has accused the Indonesian Government of continuing to practice torture in the region.

title: Winterfest Plays Are ''Back to Basics''
description: THE influences on the playwrights in this year's Winterfest series of the Yale Repertory Theater are eclectic, to say the least, and range from Euripides to Pat Boone.

title: Eileen O'Shaughnessy Weds Patrick Grasso
description: The wedding of Eileen O'Shaughnessy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. O'Shaughnessy of Westfield, N.J., to Patrick Andrew Grasso, a son of Mr. and Mrs. P. A. Grasso of New Rochelle, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Thomas J. Joyce performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Fairfield University who received an M.B.A. from Fordham University, is a marketing manager for the L'Oreal Haircare division of Cosmair in New York. Her father is a retired chemical engineer for N.L. Industries. Her mother, Ethel O'Shaughnessy, founded the Monterssori School of Cranford, N.J.

title: Musical: Hollywood In the 30's
description: FROM a work in progress, ''Tales of Tinseltown'' has devolved into a musical in regress.

title: The Coaches Speak Out
description: Sam Wyche On meeting Bill Walsh for the first time: ''I was a Cincinnati Bengals rookie. I don't remember the first 'Hello' or 'How do you do?' I was a rookie walk-on trying to find out where Cincinnati was.'' On what he has learned from Walsh about being a head coach: ''He's an integral part of my style. You'll see some of the same mannerisms. Sometimes, he flips his hand and he puts his hand to his teeth. I'll do that. I think I'm trying to figure out how he wins.'' On the Bengals' role as underdogs: ''We plan to show up for all four quarters. Our guys took a vote.'' On his love of gimmick plays: ''We have 12 gimmicks in this game, but I don't know how many we're going to use. We try to go into a game with 10 or 12. We think of them not as gimmicks, but as sound plays.'' On reports that he will quit his job because of the pressure: ''Some days, I say I'm not too sure this job is worth what it puts you through. A lot of people feel that way about their jobs. I'm not leaning toward getting out of football or leaving the Bengals.'' On his memories of Super Bowl XVI, when he was the 49ers' quarterback coach: ''I remember the snow and the ice driving to the Silverdome. I was sitting on the second bus with Bill Walsh, and the road was blocked. He got up and said: 'Don't worry, men. The score is only 3-0 and we're hanging in.' That got a big laugh and helped relax the players.'' On his reputation as a players' coach: ''When I started, I was older than some players, and I played the game. Well, I was on rosters for nine years. I showered with a lot of the fellows.'' Bill Walsh On his feelings about Wyche, who played and coached under him: ''It's sort of a love-hate thing. I care so much about him, what he's done and all his accomplishments. But you have to deal with them. On one hand, it's great to see him. On the other hand, I'd prefer to see someone else.'' On the time when he was the Bengals' quarterback coach and Wyche was a rookie free agent: ''We liked him. He was big and strong. We made a quarterback out of him. I coached him four years and developed him to the upper reaches of mediocrity.'' On whether Walsh, the teacher, can beat Wyche, the student, in the Super Bowl: ''Not if I'm still teaching Magellan and Columbus. Not if I'm outdated. I'm just concerned we can stay with him.'' On the importance of scoring first in the Super Bowl: ''I don't know if it's important to score first. Now if you score first, second and third, that's another thing.'' On the success of the Bengals' no-huddle offense: ''It's very creative, very interesting. It took time to refine it. I think it's the wave of the future in football. But one problem with it is that the team using it fatigues quickly.'' On whether other teams will adopt the no-huddle offense: ''We've seen the nickel defense developed by George Allen and the 46 defense by Buddy Ryan. We've seen the one-back offense from Joe Gibbs and the Redskins. People emulate those things, and they often fail.'' On his offensive plans for the game: ''We hope to throw in the neighborhood of 30 passes. We hope we can complete 20. It's up to Joe Montana to sustain the offense on those third-and-4, third-and-5 situations.'' On the one-sided Super Bowls in recent years: ''It's like a heavyweight fight, a championship fight. Both people come in really armed, but it ends very quickly. That can happen in football. One team gets a lead and the other begins to take more and more calculated risks. The odds get higher with everything they do, and they're unable to change the course of the game and the score gets out of hand.''

title: More Feed, More Line, More Wood: Down (And Out) On the Farm
description: SOMEONE described a boat as ''a hole in the water into which you throw money.'' A small farm is like that.

title: 'HOW MANY PEOPLE DID YOU KILL OVE RTHERE?'
description: LEAD: HOMECOMING When the Soldiers Returned From Vietnam. By Bob Greene. 269 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Westerly, R.I.;
Vacation Homes Off the Beach
description: LEAD: A NEW residential condominium project is attracting vacation-home buyers even though it is set apart from this shoreline town's beach communities. Eleven of the 16 completed units at Captain's Watch, a Victorian-style project on Watch Hill Road, have been sold and three are occupied.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MULBERRY AND PEACH: Two Women of China. By Hualing Nieh. Translated by Jane Parish Yang with Linda Lappin. (Beacon, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95.) This novel, which is the first of the Chinese writer Hualing Nieh's fiction to be published in the United States, recounts the political and psychological events that cause the schizophrenia of an Asian immigrant.

title: Railroad a Peril for Moose
description: Railroad locomotives have killed 61 moose in Alaska so far this winter, as against 329 from November to April a year ago. The Alaska Railroad keeps moose kill figures in that five-month period because it is then that deep snow drives the moose from their summer range in the mountains down toward firm footing on or near the cleared railroad tracks.

title: Iraqi Denies Libya Plant Role
description: The owner of a company under criminal investigation for its role in the supply and construction of a suspected chemical weapons plant in Libya has denied the assertions.

title: Becker Eliminates Canadian in a Flash
description: Boris Becker did a good imitation of another famous West German tennis player tonight when he routed Chris Pridham of Canada in 70 minutes at the Australian Open.

title: POSTINGS: 3 Years of Planning; Revitalizing Stamford
description: The Stamford Urban Redevelopment Commission has chosen the Lincoln Property Company of Dallas to build an $87 million mixed-use downtown project as one of the major pieces of Stamford's urban renewal plan. Stamford Court, as the project is called, will have 365 rental apartments, 35 town houses, medical office space, a 1,020-car garage and a recreation center that will include movie houses and restaurants.

title: Getting Back on a Bicycle After 48 Years
description: THERE I was, at 65, as close as I had ever been to serving on a jury. One woman among eight men, the first to be questioned by the two lawyers. Skipping from man to man, the lawyer for the defendant asked, ''Do you ride a bicycle?'' If the answer was yes, he wanted to know if it was a 10-speed. Eventually, the questioner stood in front of me. ''Do you ride a bicycle?'' My answer of yes led him to ask, ''A stationary bike?''

title: Reviews/Music; Some Newcomers to Cast Of Met Opera 'Fledermaus'
description: Five newcomers have joined the cast of the Met's ''Fledermaus'' since it opened in late December. But the principal reasons to see this production - Hakan Hagegard's fine singing as Eisenstein and Sid Caesar's comic turns as Frosch, the jailer -have been there from the start.

title: Florida Resort Offers a Slice Of Fantasy
description: AT a small sign posted on a fence halfway between Miami and Miami Beach we turned off MacArthur Causeway and drove to the water's edge where a private ferry was waiting. The ferry was called the Eagle. (Two others are available at all times, the Flamingo, and the Pelican.) A security guard in full regalia stopped us and requested identification. He radioed the information on a walkie-talkie and waited for clearance.

title: Amnesty International Appeal
description: Amnesty International released a report today urging the Brazilian Government to investigate ''the widespread killing of community leaders.'' The request came a month after the murder of Francisco Mendes Filho, an environmental campaigner for Amazon rain forests.

title: An Eclectic Lineup, Fit for The Kronos
description: Some years back, before the Kronos Quartet was the media darling it is today and before it had the large, hip following it now enjoys, the ensemble sometimes programmed an encore that proved deeply disturbing to many of its listeners, more upsetting than the new music it played or the wild costumes the players wore. The encore, ''TV Madness,'' was a humorous medley of 1950's television themes (''I Love Lucy,'' ''Peter Gunn,'' among others), and on its own it was amusing. However, the Kronos liked to play ''TV Madness'' as a follow-up to Berg's ''Lyric'' Suite, with its transcendental ending that seems to trail off into infinity.

title: Albany Notes; Cuomo Finds All Work and No Play Lacks Efficiency
description: One thing the Cuomo administration had never been known for is its frivolity. Indeed, one of the favored pastimes on the second floor of the State Capitol, where the top officials work, is to see who can stay even later than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo himself, a famed workaholic.

title: Question Of the Week; Can Winfield and Steinbrenner Find Peace?
description: Winfield and Steinbrenner will never find peace.

title: 3 Bobsledders Banned
description: Three bobsledders have been suspended from the United States team after testing positive for the use of steroids, and five others have been reprimanded for inadvertantly using over-the-counter medications banned by the International Olympic Committee. According to reports in The Lake Placid News and The Watertown Times, the one-year suspensions and the reprimands stemmed from tests administered at the world team trials in November. The suspended competitors were identified as Rick Calcutt of Treasure Island, Fla.; Steve Maiorica of Rockford, Md., and Joe Schulze of Chrisman, Ill. The names of those receiving reprimands were not disclosed.

title: Trip Planning
description: To the Editor: I noted with interest Stanley Carr's answer to the question on how those using frequent-flier credits to fly overseas can find on their own the kind of inexpensive hotels and tours offered in package deals (Q & A, Nov. 27).

title: EXCESSIVE, EVEN IN LEGEND
description: CATHERINE THE GREAT Life and Legend. By John T. Alexander. Illustrated. 418 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: Don't Implicate All Germans in What a Few Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Killer, Facing Death, Is Confessing Many Slayings
description: Theodore Bundy, linked by the authorities to about three dozen killings, confessed to at least nine additional murders today, while his lawyers maneuvered to block his execution scheduled for Tuesday, officials from two Western states said.

title: A Freudian Spoof Is Slipped Past Many Scholars
description: In a case more reminiscent of Pirandello than of Freud, scholars of psychoanalysis are in a furor over an article by an eminent historian.

title: Images of New York, in Anger and in Sorrow
description: When commentators insisted that election year 1988 was one of ''peace and prosperity,'' some New Yorkers could only gape and snarl in disbelief. In their neighborhoods, they saw homeless people begging outside luxury co-ops, friends dying of AIDS, teen-agers smoking crack; the nightly news intercut abused children, racist demagogues and poisoned beaches with voracious deal makers and free-spending consumers. Lou Reed was one of the snarlers, and his new ''New York'' (Sire 25829; LP, cassette and CD) assaults 1980's happytalk and yuppie complacency. It's his best, most hardheaded album in a decade.

title: THE REGION: A Tight State Budget; Albany Needs $800 Million, but Who's Going to Raise Taxes?
description: IN New York's capital, as in the nation's, taxes are out; revenues are in. To prove it, the budget that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed last week calls for $800 million in new revenues, but no increase in the state's primary taxes on corporate and personal income and on sales.

title: Deena Holliday Weds Stephen Howard Wolff
description: The marriage of Deena Lynn Holliday, the daughter of Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Floral Park, Queens, and Morton Holliday of New York, to Stephen Howard Wolff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Wolff of Essex, Conn., took place last evening at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Gramercy Park
description: SUCH is its allure that on a recent wintry day, when the melting detritus of a snowstorm was keeping most New Yorkers off the streets, Gramercy Park was zinging with activity.

title: Jamie Broussard Wed To John D. Tierney 2d
description: Jamie Ann Broussard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Broussard of Tulsa, Okla., and John Donald Tierney 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donald Tierney of Morristown, N.J., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., by the Rev. Patrick Brown.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 22, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 10 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 2 25 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent in the Soviet Union. 3 4 18 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 4 3 12 ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A man and his wife find themselves in a fantasy world where the possibilities of their pasts still exist. 5 5 14 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and ''The Vampire Lestat.'' 6 11 35 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 7 * 9 30 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 8 * 7 5 SPY HOOK, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $18.95.) The agent Bernard Samson on the trail of a financial scam within the British secret service. 9 1 A SEASON IN HELL, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A young widow's quest for her stepson's killers leads to horrendous adventures across Europe. 10 1 RIVALS, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) Two women, descendants of long-feuding families, find themselves competitors in business and romance. 11 * 10 14 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer from Philadelphia. 12 12 2 THE LYRE OF ORPHEUS, by Robertson Davies. (Viking, $19.95.) The staging of an unfinished Hoffmann opera causes its participants to relive the legend of King Arthur. 13 1 WILDERNESS, by Jim Morrison. (Villard, $12.95.) Poems by the songwriter and rock star of the 1960's. 14 14 15 FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Colonel Qazi, an ''international terrorist,'' plots to steal American nuclear weapons. 15 * 8 10 DEAR MILI, by Wilhelm Grimm. (di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) A recently discovered tale by the 19th-century folklorist, illustrated by Maurice Sendak. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 12 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 2 40 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 3 3 10 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 4 4 11 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 5 6 13 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 6 5 14 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 7 7 10 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 8 10 7 CHRISTMAS IN AMERICA, edited by David Cohen. (Collins Publishers, $35.) An album of pictures taken by 100 photographers. 9 11 5 ''WHAT DO YOU> CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. 10 9 15 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 11 5 THE HOME PLANET, edited by Kevin W. Kelley. (Addison-Wesley, $39.95.) How the earth looks from outer space, shown in 150 photographs. 12 12 13 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican Presidential nominee. 13 13 2 PARTING THE WATERS, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The rise of the American civil rights movement under the leadership of Martin Luther King Jr. 14 16 THE RAGMAN'S SON, by Kirk Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The actor recalls his life as poor immigrant's son, waiter, steel mill worker, haberdashery salesman, film star, father and man. 15 15 29 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 81 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 2 1 10 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 3 3 39 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 4 13 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 5 4 26 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THIS BOY'S LIFE: A Memoir, by Tobias Wolff. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) Mr. Wolff's account of his youthful experiences with downward mobility, a rat stepfather and a street education is literate, entertaining and up to snuff with his published fiction. LOST IN TRANSLATION: A Life in a New Language, by Eva Hoffman. (Dutton, $18.95.) An adolescent girl is uprooted from Poland to grow up in the New World in this honest, remorseful but ultimately good-humored memoir of exile, relocation and renewal by an editor of The New York Times Book Review. UTZ, by Bruce Chatwin. (Viking, $16.95.) An elegant, even lapidary novel, presenting the life and world of Kaspar Joachim Utz, a victim and survivor (thanks to good taste, equanimity and a certain want of scruple) of World War II in Czechoslovakia. INNUMERACY: Mathematical Illiteracy and Its Consequences, by John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) An entertaining and cautionary demonstration that simple common sense can clear a lot of fog from quantitative propositions in everyday life. EDWARD R. MURROW: An American Original, by Joseph E. Persico. (McGraw-Hill, $24.95.) The life of a modern American hero who made journalism better than he found it, told with insight, perceptiveness and dramatic but faithful anecdote. THE NOTEBOOK, by Agota Kristof. (Grove, $15.95.) This grim, disquieting first novel by a Hungarian living in Switzerland concerns a pair of twins who study to become unfeeling and merciless, since that is the price of life in the world they inhabit. BULLWHIP DAYS: The Slaves Remember, edited by James Mellon. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $27.50.) A moving and shocking chronicle, extracted from some 2,000 interviews with former slaves conducted by the Federal Writers' Project in the 1930's.

title: Thompson, Hoyas Come Back to Win
description: One week after walking away to protest a new rule on freshman eligibility, John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown, returned to the bench in triumph this afternoon.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION
description: MANY of my best friends are gone. I knew them well, admired their strengths and enjoyed their jokes, and in no time they were dead.

title: Adventure On a First Blind Date
description: SEATED on the Scarsdale train to New York, I was concentrating on what I was going to say, repeating phrases over and over again. Ask him about himself, his interests, his children - all advice my friends had given me. I also wondered what on earth I was doing in my good red coat, best black wool dress, being propelled by public transportation to a rendezvous in the same week that my third grandchild was born.

title: Private Enclaves For London Epicures
description: LONDON is the very mecca of clubland. It contains clubs for every conceivable purpose, but one of the most universal is the consumption of food. The dining club has long been a congenial place to gather with like-minded friends, and London offers two types, the traditional members' club, where food is only one of the home-away-from-home facilities, and the private dining club, sometimes sniffily called the checkbook club, but an option for Americans who are in London for frequent or lengthy stays.

title: Anne R. Kurz Married To Jeffrey Alan Zenn
description: Anne Robin Kurz, a daughter of Ruth Kurz of Clifton, N.J. and the late Nathan Kurz, was married in Summit, N.J., last evening to Jeffrey Alan Zenn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zenn of Millburn, N.J. Rabbi Steven Shaw performed the ceremony at the Summit Hotel. Mrs. Zenn is the associate director of resource development at the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopedic Institute in New York. She graduated from Ithaca College and received a master's degree from New York University in public administration and health services management. Her father owned Kurz Jewelers in Passaic, N.J.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have cabinets of ash wood in my kitchen. Food and dirt stains have accumulated around the handles and knobs on the cabinet doors. Is it possible to clean off this dirt without also removing or damaging the finish, or must the cabinets be revarnished?

title: Barnes Sets Mark In Indoor Shot-Put
description: Randy Barnes may quickly outgrow the indoor shot-put. Barnes's final attempt nearly hit the barrier at the back of the shot-put sector on the floor of the Sports Arena Friday night at the Sunskist Invitational.

title: PERSONAL FINANCE
description: One-stop shopping for money management? That's the idea behind an investment product increasingly being marketed by the big brokerage firms - the so-called wrap account.

title: 4 Musicians Scheduled For Off Stage Series
description: Keith Jarrett, James Levine, Steve Reich and Wynton Marsalis will take part in the Lincoln Center Off Stage series of snacks and discussion beginning in March. Each program begins with a wine-and-cheese reception at 5:30 P.M. and is followed by a talk and a question-answer session with the guest.

title: Cynthia C. Scully Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Scully of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Crowell Scully, to Todd Hodges Doolan, the son of Mrs. James A. Gobes of West Hartford, Conn., and Dwight M. Doolan of New York. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Documenting an Outbreak of Self-Presentation
description: No subject has held the attention of more types of photographers during the last 25 years than the self-portrait. A list of those artists who have looked at themselves seriously - not just glancingly -would include such disparate stylists as Andy Warhol, Lee Friedlander, Anselm Kiefer, Eleanor Antin, Lucas Samaras, William Wegman, John Coplans, Judy Dater, Robert Mapplethorpe, Arnulf Rainer, Cindy Sherman, Chuck Close, Duane Michals, Adrian Piper, Bruce Charlesworth, Christian Boltanski and Ann Noggle. It cuts across gender, age, race, and nationality. Rare but important in the history of Western painting, the self-portrait seems to have interested photographers since the announced invention of the medium, never more so than now.

title: Suffolk Seeks to Level Crack Houses
description: LEAD: IN an effort to deny habitat to crack dealers and users, Suffolk County is trying a new approach: demolishing buildings identified as crack houses.

title: Coins From the Siege
description: SEIGE coins are representative of tumultuous eras and such is the case with the shekel of the First Revolt (A.D. 66-70) This shekel is one of only three examples of ancient silver Jewish coinage. The other two being a miniscule coin from earliest times and the shekel of the Second Revolt (A.D. 132-135).

title: Preservationists Praise Tarrytown Ruling
description: A JUDGE'S order that a Tarrytown man tear down a major addition to his home in a historic district will be felt far beyond Westchester County's borders, historic preservationists believe.

title: Why Defend a Defenseless Defense?
description: WHEN one of your favorite defensive systems runs into trouble, the solution is quite simple: Don't play it. Yet it is just amazing how player after player can look down at the floor when the handwriting is on the wall.

title: Owners Contend Rozelle Is Slowing
description: As the Super Bowl today closes another National Football League season, Pete Rozelle ends his 29th year as commissioner, a period in which the league has grown from a mom-and-pop operation of a dozen teams to a cultural institution of 28 franchises worth as much as $80 million each.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Football Gary Leads South in Senior Bowl: Cleveland Gary of the University of Miami was voted the outstanding player in the Senior Bowl after he rushed for 97 yards to spark the South in a 13-12 victory over the North yesterday in Mobile, Ala. Gary caught 5 passes for 42 yards, including a 10-yard catch on a fourth-and-2 at the North 41 to keep the game-winning drive going on the opening play of the fourth quarter.(AP) Skiing Schneider Ties Cup Record: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, trailing after the first run, rallied to win the women's giant slalom yesterday and tied a World Cup record with her 11th victory of the season at Tignes, France. With victories in all five races so far this season, Schneider clinched the 1988-89 giant slalom title. She also extended her lead in the overall cup standing to 286-206 over Carole Merle of France.(AP) Girardelli Wins 3d Downhill in Row: Marc Girardelli, who was born in Austria and but skis for Luxembourg, won his third straight downhill yesterday, capturing the race on the World Cup's longest circuit, the 4,185-meter Lauberhorn at Wengen, Switzerland. Girardelli, bidding for his third World Cup title in a 10-year career, finished in 2 minutes 25.76 seconds. Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, the defending World Cup champion, was second, 1.92 seconds behind. (AP) Golf Palmer Wins $70,000 in Senior Skins: Arnold Palmer rolled in two dramatic putts yesterday to win two holes and earn $70,000 on the opening day of the Senior Skins Game. Gary Player won one hole to earn $50,000. The final nine holes, with a total of $240,000 at stake, of the $360,000 tournament will be played today. (AP) Speed Skating Flaim of U.S. Wins Sprint: Eric Flaim of the United States won a 500-meter sprint and finished second in the 1,500 meters in an international meet yesterday at Davos, Switzerland. Flaim captured the 500 meters in 38.11 seconds. Andre Hoffman of East Germany won the 1,500 meters in 1 minute 55.80 seconds, and Flaim was second in 1:57.66. In another 500-meter sprint, Uwe-Jens Mey of East Germany finished first in 36.81. Dan Jansen of the United States was second in 37.05. Michael Spielmann of East Germany won the 3,000 meters in 4:03.91. (AP) Figure Skating Leistner Captures European Title: Claudia Leistner of West Germany stepped into the void left by Katarina Witt of East Germany to win the women's gold medal yesterday at the European championships in Birmingham, England. Leistner, who won the silver medal at the 1983 world championships and is a two-time European bronze medalist, finally struck gold with a flowing, self-assurred free-skating program that earned top marks from the judges. The 23-year-old, who also won the school figures and original program, was her country's first woman titleholder since Gundi Busch in 1954. Natalya Lebedeva of the Soviet Union took the silver. (AP) Boxing Coggi Stops Brazier to Keep Title: Juan Martin Coggi of Argentina knocked down the American challenger, Harold Brazier, in the 10th round last night in Basto, Italy, and went on to win a unanimous 12-round decision to retain his World Boxing Association junior welterweight title. A left hook by Coggi caught Brazier on the jaw and sent the 33-year-old challenger from South Bend, Ind., to the canvas.(AP) N.B.A. Suns 116, Bulls 107: The Bulls' Michael Jordan scored a season-high 53 points last night, but Phoenix overcame a 19-point first-quarter deficit at Chicago. Jordan also had 14 rebounds and 8 assists. (AP) Bullets 107, 76ers 105: Steve Colter scored 8 of his 10 points in the fourth quarter, and John Williams blocked Charles Barkley's last-second shot to insure the victory in Landover, Md. Jeff Malone led the Bullets with 23 points. Hersey Hawkins had 25 points for the 76ers.(AP) Hawks 137, Hornets 113: Moses Malone and Dominique Wilkins scored 21 points each forthe Hawks at home. Wilkins had 17 points in the first quarter. The Hornets were without their leading scorer, Kelly Tripucka, who was home with the flu. Robert Reid scored 26 points to lead the Hornets.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 6, Bruins 5: Pierre Turgeon scored his second goal of the game on a power play at 3:58 of overtime last night as Buffalo rallied from a 4-0 deficit at Boston. (AP) Penguins 7, Oilers 4: Mario Lemieux had two goals and five assists for the Pittsburgh. Paul Coffey, traded by the Oilers to Pittsburgh last season, added a goal and two assists as the Penguins won for only the second time in 16 career visits to Edmonton.(AP) Blues 4, Blackhawks 2: Steve Tuttle converted Herb Raglan's centering pass for his 10th goal at 3:23 of the third period and Peter Zezel added the winning goal three and a half minutes later.(AP) Canadiens 4, Maple Leafs 3: Montreal's Guy Carbonneau scored twice, including a short-handed goal, and Mats Naslund was credited with a goal that Toronto steered into its net. (AP) Gretzky Second in Scoring: Wayne Gretzky of the Los Angeles Kings moved into second place on the career National Hockey League scoring list, passing Marcel Dionne of the Rangers with his fourth point of the game, an assist on Luc Robitaille's goal at 14:47 of the second period of the 5-4 loss at Hartford. Gretzky, playing in his 743d game, has 616 goals and a league-record 1,155 assists for 1,771 points. Dionne has 1,770 points in 18 seasons. Gordie Howe is the career leader with 1,850 points.(AP) Nordiques 4, Flames 3: Robert Picard broke a tie with a shorthanded goal in the second period and Peter Stastny added a power-play goal in the third for Quebec at home.(AP) Flyers 7, Jets 3: Ron Hextall blocked 37 shots and assisted on Tim Kerr's third goal of the game for the Flyers.(AP) High School Basketball Molloy Upset: Terrance Bethel made a 15-foot jumper with 5 seconds left to give St. Nicholas of Tolentine a 73-72 upset of Archbishop Molloy, the 12th-ranked team in the country. Kenny Anderson led Molloy (14-2) with 33 points. Tolentine is 11-6. College Basketball Columbia Woman Sets Mark: Charlene Williams, a forward, had a school-record 35 points in a 83-71 Ivy League victory over Cornell at Columbia. Williams made 10 of 14 field goals and all 15 of her free throws.

title: AT REST IN GOOD COMPANY
description: Cemeteries are, perhaps paradoxically, living catalogues of history, and when it comes to name-dropping there are few that can match Woodlawn Cemetery's roster of illustrious interments.
