From the first burial there in 1865, Woodlawn's 400 splendidly landscaped acres have grown increasingly crowded; today there are almost 300,000 occupants. Among them are six New York mayors (including Fiorello LaGuardia), the diplomat Ralph Bunche, the dancers Irene and Vernon Castle, Duke Ellington, Joseph Pulitzer, F. W. Woolworth, Robert Moses, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, Herman Melville, Fritz Kreisler, the feminist crusader Carrie Chapman Catt, George M. Cohan, Damon Runyon, the nation's first admiral, David Farragut, the financier Jay Gould and one of his nemeses, the cartoonist Thomas Nast. Woodlawn, in the Bronx, grew as an alternative to Brooklyn's no less beautiful Green-Wood, also a cemetery filled with notables and marked by similar extraordinary statuary. The route from Manhattan to Green-Wood became, it seems, too vulgarly populated to hold a somber procession and some gentry sought a new site out of town and accessible by train or boat. In WOODLAWN REMEMBERS: Cemetery of American History (North Country Books, Paper, $24.95), Edward F. Bergman, chairman of the department of geology and geography at Lehman College, approaches with historical perspective and gentle humor a topic that in other hands might have been dulled by palliative pieties. He writes of cemeteries and their role in spurring public parks to match their own charm. He provides a list of the famous architects whose handiwork memorializes the wealthy departed in a style suitable to the manner they knew when they were alive. Each of his entries contains an illustration dealing with the notable in life, along with a photograph of the tomb, grave or mausoleum in Woodlawn and a tidy biography. Mr. Bergman understands that a cemetery is less a story about how one died than it is an account of how one lived.

title: Madelon Rosen to Wed Lawrence M. Solomon
description: Madelon Joyce Rosen and Lawrence Michael Solomon plan to be married in April. The future bride, a senior account executive and theatrical publicity agent with the public relations company of Max Eisen in New York, is the daughter of Helen Beck Rosen of the Bronx, and the late Samuel Rosen. Her fiance, the director of marketing and communications for MedComp Technologies in Armonk, N.Y., is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Solomon of Brooklyn.

title:
GARDENING;
Maintaining Color in Flower Borders
description: LEAD: GARDENERS strive for continuous color in their flower borders, yet there seems to be at least one period when a paucity of flowers results in a dowdy, unkempt appearance.

title: He's a New Man Now, Thanks to the Press
description: AMERICANS depend on newspapers and television for an image of their President. But their impression of George Bush depends substantially on whether they remember what they read and heard about him before he was elected President or since.

title: Question Of the Week; Can Winfield and Steinbrenner Find Peace?
description: Why not? Charity begins at home.

title: Tough Year for 'Market Timers'
description: Last year was a tough one for the so-called ''market timers'' - money managers who frequently move back and forth from stocks to cash, depending upon their reading of economic or technical indicators. Their approach, which some academics have questioned, is designed to take advantage of rallies while missing market downturns.

title: What's Hot, What's Not
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
County Housing Bill Gaining in Albany
description: LEAD: FOR the last five years, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, has sought an amendment to the New York State Constitution that would give counties the authority to create housing. Each time his efforts have failed. Now, however, prospects of the bill to implement the amendment are looking better in Albany because the ubiquitous problems of the homeless and the lack of affordable housing are making many legislators feel its time has come.

title: EVEN THE PALM TREES HAVE HAIRSTYLES
description: LOS ANGELES WITHOUT A MAP By Richard Rayner. 186 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $16.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have cabinets of ash wood in my kitchen. Food and dirt stains have accumulated around the handles and knobs on the cabinet doors. Is it possible to clean off this dirt without also removing or damaging the finish, or must the cabinets be revarnished?

title: Stamford's Old Town Hall May Have a Future in Art
description: FOR the last quarter-century, the Old Town Hall, a designated national landmark in downtown Stamford, has stood virtually empty and very much out of place, a Beaux Arts anachronism in the midst of what has become a business district of modern corporate towers. Now there are plans afoot to turn the hall into a museum of borrowed glories and local exhibits.

title: England
description: To the Editor: You mentioned (Travel, Nov. 27), ''Christmas is still a bit more secular and lighthearted for the English . . .'' Having spent several Christmases in England, it is fair to say the English Christmas today is one of religious services, family reunions and general merrymaking and carol singing. Although churches and cathedrals are bulging on Christmas Eve, unlike America, it is on Christmas Day that most people attend church in Britain. It is on Christmas that the annual Christmas message of the Queen is broadcast. Christmas dinner is usually a family affair and is served in early afternoon. England does, indeed, close down for the tourist except for religious services, hotel and restaurant celebrations. KAREN F. ZUMBRUNN Princeton, N.J.

title: Marvin Klein, Neurologist, 52
description: Dr. Marvin Klein, a pediatric neurologist, died of cancer yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 52 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Jozef Cyrankiewicz Is Dead at 77; Polish Premier in 1970 Food Riots
description: Jozef Cyrankiewicz, the Polish Prime Minister who was toppled by the violent food-price riots of 1970, died Friday, official Polish newspapers said today. He was 77 years old.

title: Hospital Leads Patients to Where All Bets Are Off
description: Twenty-eight years after his first two-bit bet at the race track, the double life of lies and deception caught up with an insurance executive whose gambling debts had climbed into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. The business he had built went bankrupt. His marriage ended in bitter divorce. Often, he considered killing himself. The former executive does not look like an addict, a liar, a manipulator or someone who would ignore his two young daughters, but he admits to having been all of these.

title: Correction
description: An article on drug-testing technology in The Week in Review on Nov. 20 included an erroneous reference to ibuprofen, a drug used in some over-the-counter pain remedies. Manufacturers of drug testing equipment say that there is no indication that the drug can cause a false positive reading for marijuana.

title: Contributors to the Neediest Cases Reach Beyond Boundaries
description: The whole Schoenberger family - 17 people in all - spent the year-end holidays in Israel and had a wonderful time, but before they left they remembered The New York Times Neediest Cases.

title: NORTH AND SOUTH OF THE MAYONNAISE LINE
description: THE CLUSTERING OF AMERICA By Michael J. Weiss. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Tilden Press/Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Victoria A. Chave Becomes a Bride
description: At the Battell Chapel at Yale University in New Haven, Victoria Anne Chave, the daughter of Mrs. Charles T. Chave of Madison, Conn., and the late Mr. Chave, was married yesterday to Peter Wickham Clement, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Clement of Buffalo. The Rev. John G. Macort Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Downwardly Mobile
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Foresee Budget Deficit of $162 Billion
description: The Soviet budget deficit could reach $162 billion by 1990, according to figures published today in a Soviet newspaper.

title: Coping With the Met's Casting Headaches
description: When it comes to casting leading roles in opera - and particularly in ''bread-and-butter'' works that are or used to be at the center of the repertory - people in the opera world repeatedly stress the sometimes insane conditions under which this complex and exotic art operates today, singers' vagaries being only one aspect, and not even the most difficult.

title: Midwives Gaining L.I. Role
description: LEAD: JANICE MERCEP of Sound Beach went into labor at about 2:30 A.M. By 5 o'clock, she knew it was time to call the hospital. Mary Seravalli, nurse-midwife, got the call from the hospital in Smithtown a few minutes later. She had been sound asleep, but she is accustomed to being awakened at all hours.

title: College President is Honored
description: LEAD: SISTER Dorothy Ann Kelly, president of the College of New Rochelle, will receive the fifth annual Westchester County/Avon Women's Hall of Fame award on March 2 at the Rye Town Hilton. The prize medallion is given to a woman who has made a ''significant and measurable contribution'' to the progress of other women.

title: Holding Down Fort for Bush's Team
description: In the hiatus from Inauguration Day to the confirmation of President Bush's nominees, midlevel officials and career civil servants have inherited legal authority to run the show at many Government agencies.

title: How to Tell Pilgrims From the Puritans
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Mugged on Subway; 11 Youths Are Arrested
description: Eleven teen-aged youths were arrested early yesterday as they stepped off a downtown N train at the 14th Street station in Manhattan and were charged with beating and robbing three subway passengers, the police said.

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; Transormation of the Classes: Daniele Billitteri, Editor, Italy
description: An editor at Giornale di Sicilia, Sicily's largest newspaper, Daniele Billitteri, 36, joined the Communist Youth Federation in 1966 but left the party in 1976 after it sought an alliance with the Christian Democrats. Then, he said, ''It did not make sense to maintain a militant commitment to the party under those circumstances.'' He almost always votes Communist. I AM NOT A REPENTANT COMMUNIST, or an ex-Communist, maybe not even a Communist at all anymore. The problem is to decide what kind of yardstick to use to measure this word. It is difficult to say what a Communist is today. . . .

title: European Delay Seen in Meat Fight
description: European foreign ministers will likely delay putting into effect tough duties on some American imports in an effort to defuse tensions over a ban on hormone-treated meat from the United States, officials said Friday.

title: Reagans Settle In at 668 Saint Cloud
description: It was an ordinary Sunday in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles, warm and slow and pleasant. Jeff Hyland, a real estate broker, sat by his pool reading the paper and then went for a drive in his black Mercedes with his fiancee, Lori Wynn-Ferber, and her poodle, Jasmine. Sandy and Teryn Wayne watched the Super Bowl with friends. Zsa Zsa Gabor was back home with her dogs on Bel Air Road.

title: Review/Music; A Male Gospel Sextet
description: Just when it seemed that the stylistic possibilities of group harmony singing had been carried into the furthest nooks and crannies of pop and jazz by groups like Manhattan Transfer and Jon Hendricks's family ensembles, along comes Take 6.

title: Police in South Korea Halt March by 10,000 Protesters
description: The police clashed with thousands of demonstrators here today in a protest called by a coalition of dissident groups.

title: For Scribners, Bookstore Closing Is Put Off but Not for Long
description: Quietly, slowly, almost graciously, the Scribner Book Store in mid-Manhattan approached the twilight of business yesterday, with the question still unanswered as to what comes next for the glass-fronted, Beaux-Arts jewel case on Fifth Avenue.

title: Christopher D. Landsberg Marries Debra W. Nahum
description: Debra Wendy Nahum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Nahum of Paramus, N.J., and Christopher David Landsberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. John Landsberg of Bronxville, N.Y., were married yesterday in Livingston, N.J. Mayor Samuel A. Spina of West Orange, N.J., officiated at the Livingston Country Club.

title: Aiming for Average
description: Bowling one's average right on the nose may not be as difficult as rolling a perfect game, but it's probably a close second. Yet, John Frampton of Lake Elsinore, Calif., did it three times in a row (in his case a 165) to qualify for the final in a somewhat unusual amateur bowling competition in Las Vegas recently.

title: Bridge
description: Tournaments, almost by definition, are held in one location. But the Club Sectional in New York City last week was an exception. The players competed in their own clubs but were scored across the whole field.

title: TV Notes
description: Pat Sajak's Ratings

title: Markets Chief Is Named In Freddie Mac Revamping
description: Mark J. Latimer has been named to head a new capital markets group as a vice president of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the Government-chartered organization known as Freddie Mac that provides a flow of funds to mortgage lenders.

title: Don't Let Salvador Become Lebanon
description: Is the Bush Administration kidding itself, or the American people, about El Salvador? James Baker, at his confirmation hearings, said that ''despite guerrilla violence the democratic political process has been established in El Salvador.'' But in recent weeks American diplomats and knowledgeable Salvadorans have been telling a very different story.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day on Wednesday about Apple Computer Inc.'s earnings misidentified the microprocessor used in the Macintosh SE computer. It is the Motorola 68000; the 68020 is used in the Macintosh II.

title: Book Theft Traced to Woman
description: Thirty boxes of stolen books that turned up on a library doorstep Jan. 3 have been traced to a woman who died last year. The boxes returned to the Thornhill Branch County Library yielded 4,369 books and magazines worth about $28,000, a library spokeswoman, Jo Ann Rogers, said Friday. The mystery was solved when a lawyer for the woman's estate called and asked the library to pick up the remaining books, Ms. Rogers said. She refused to identify the woman.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 22, 1989: MONDAY Archer Daniels Midland Mercury Svgs & Ln Assn Kennametal Inc Meredith Corp Lubrizol Corp TUESDAY Amoco Corp Glenfed Inc Ball Corp Great Westn Finl Corp Black Hills Corp Jostens Inc Cilcorp Inc Rorer Group Inc Consolidated Edison Co NY USLife Corp EDO Corp WEDNESDAY American Elec Pwr Inc NCNB Corp AMP Inc Oneida Ltd Baker Hughes Inc Phelps Dodge Corp Coast Svgs & Loan L.A. Pilgrims Pride Corp Columbia Svgs & Ln Shaw Inds Inc Downey Svgs & Ln Assn SmithKline Beckman Corp Du Pont E I De Nemours Standex Intl Corp Equifax Inc TW SVCS Inc Grainger W W Inc Union Carbide Corp Hercules Inc Westinghouse Elec Corp Lukens Inc Zero Corp Minnesota Pwr & Lt Co THURSDAY American Home Prods Iowa Ill Gas & Elec Co Anadarko Pete Corp Morton Thiokol Inc AVEMCO Corp Olin Corp CRS Sirrine Inc Parker Hannifin Corp Cameron Iron Wks Inc Potlatch Corp Carson Pirie Scott Potomac Elec Pwr Co Delta Air Lines Inc Quaker St Corp Donnelley R R & Sons Co Quantum Chem Corp Edison Bros Stores Inc RLC Corp Empire Dist Elec Co Sara Lee Corp Ethyl Corp Trinova Corp Handy & Harman Universal Foods Corp FRIDAY Acme Elec Corp Kysor Indl Corp Ferro Corp McDonnell Douglas Corp First Wachovia Corp National Med Enterprises Indiana Energy Inc Rodman & Renshaw Cap Kaufman & Broad Home Scottys Inc Kaufman & Broad Inc SATURDAY Wackenhut

title: Letter: On U.S. Fiscal Policy; Deficit Levers Work World Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: >Review/Television; Tributes to 8, Serious and Comic
description: ''Television Academy Hall of Fame'' gets another annual broadcast tonight, at 8 on Channel 5 on Fox Broadcasting, and for the fifth consecutive year the distinguished producers Gary Smith and Dwight Hemion have put on the smooth and amiable awards ceremony.

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; Endurance of the Party: Georges Marchais, Party leader, France
description: Georges Marchais, 68, has been general secretary of the French Communist Party since 1972. He was drawn to the party through trade-union activity after World War II. IN MY LIFE AS AN ACTIVIST, I went through many difficult periods but also many fairly exulting ones. Let's say that in the period during which I was a member of the party, and just a member of the party, after 1947, I think the Communist Party -and this is how I felt it - can be very proud of the role it played in our country to end colonialism.

title: Let Washington Honor Treaties With Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: Kaydon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; Contempt for American Values: Jean-Pierre Quilgars, Factory worker, France
description: Jean-Pierre Quilgars, 33, was dismissed from his job at the Renault factory in Boulogne-Billancourt, a Paris suburb, two years ago. He said he was one of 10 party members and unionists dismissed for organizing protests against layoffs. Renault also prosecuted them for various crimes, like theft. All 10 were acquitted and are fighting to be rehired; three have won reinstatement.

title: Soviet General Talks of Failure in Afghanistan
description: A Soviet military commander acknowledged today that his country's forces are leaving Afghanistan with something of a sense of failure. He also denied that the Soviets have resumed their pullout but said they still plan to be out of the country by Feb. 15.

title: Let Washington Honor Treaties With Indians; Dependent Too Long
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., a hospital owner and operator, elected Richard A. Gilleland, the company's new chief executive, to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Royce Diener.

title: Ex-Official Says Bush Urged End to Iran Arms Shipments
description: George Bush advised President Reagan at White House meetings in December 1985 and in the spring of 1986 to end American arms shipments to Iran, Mr. Reagan's former national security adviser said today.

title: Reviews/Dance; Learning To Hate Oneself
description: David Rousseve has created a bold piece in ''Pull Your Head to the Moon. . . . Tales of Creole Women,'' presented on Friday evening at Performance Space 122. The second section in a three-part work, it makes use of text, movement and popular, operatic and religious music sung by black female performers to tell a story based on the experiences of two old residents of a small town in Louisiana, which was called Coonville.

title: GAF Stock Trial Is Halted
description: A Supreme Court justice yesterday evening halted jury selection in the GAF Corporation's criminal stock-manipulation trial after the defendants complained that the trial would violate the double-jeopardy clause of the Constitution.

title: A Strange Sentencing Reform Survives
description: Despite misgivings about the ''peculiar institution'' Congress created in the name of penal reform, the Supreme Court has upheld the constitutionality of the United States Sentencing Commission.

title: Adventure Time on the Rocks
description: TO imagine what it is like to be an ice climber, think of yourself perched along the face of a frozen waterfall. Picture the waterfall as a cascade of glass chandeliers overhanging a rock wall. You are picking your way up slowly. In your hand is an ice hammer, and a piton or ice screw for securing a belay rope to the top. A line is fed through the metal screws, embedded every 15 feet or so in the ice. There is no stopping a fall on ice, even on fairly flat surfaces.

title: Rocky Mountain Medical Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Revenue represented net revenue.

title: ESPN's Baseball-Rights Purchase: Game-Saving Catch
description: FOR all the homers and stolen bases and knock-down pitches that will be shown, there will probably not be any money made for a while, if at all. That, however, may be beside the point.

title: How to Tell Pilgrims From the Puritans
description: To the Editor:

title: Aurora Environmental Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents service revenue.

title: Celebrity Prisoners Share a Spartan Space
description: It is a small place: only 13 beds, a picnic table and a television set. The men who live there watch ''Good Morning America'' or the ''Today'' show in the morning and the 6 o'clock news in the evening. The way officials describe it, it is almost like living in a fraternity house.

title: In Area Shattered by Unrest, a Pause for Cheering
description: Under the orange-streaked clouds of dusk, shouts were heard again in Overtown this evening. Small groups congregated. Smoke curled from a fire on a street corner. But unlike last week, none of this had anything to do with racial violence, and everything to do with touchdowns.

title: Let Washington Honor Treaties With Indians; American Apartheid
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Trade Surplus Up
description: Brazil posted a record $19.09 billion trade surplus in 1988 amid large export drives by steel and soybean producers, according to official figures released Thursday. The country's exports rose 22 percent, to $33.78 billion, while imports dipped 2 percent, to $14.70 billion, from 1987 levels.

title: Wyche Offers No Apologies for Bengals
description: A defiant Sam Wyche, who expected to be dismissed after the Cincinnati Bengals' 4-11 season in 1987, made no apologies to or for his team after it lost Super Bowl XXIII today.

title: Washington Talk: Economic Cycles; How Presidents Ride Recession to Re-election
description: There is at least one widespread assumption in the capital that turns out to be valid when closely examined, perhaps more valid than the assumers realize: a well-performing economy is about the biggest asset a President can have.

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Persistent Idealism: Ivan T. Berend, Economist, Hungary
description: A respected intellectual, Ivan T. Berend, 58, is an economic theorist and a member of the Central Committee of Hungary's Communist Party. He is a former rector of Karl Marx University in Budapest and president of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences. He has traveled widely in the West and studied at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington. A Jew, he was deported to Dachau during World War II.

title: 'Point of No Return'; Eastern Airlines' Prolonged Union Battle May Have Driven Fliers Away for Keeps
description: As Eastern Airlines and the machinists' union continue their bitter fight over wages and working conditions, some airline industry analysts and executives are beginning to ask whether the carrier has reached a point from which it cannot emerge in a financially sound condition -even if labor peace is eventually achieved.

title: Is the Deficit Still Dangerous? Maybe Not, Some Start to Say
description: President Bush's pledge Friday to bring down the Federal budget deficit embraced a central orthodoxy of the 1980's, that large deficits are harmful. But gaining credence are opposing views, that the deficit is not such a problem after all and is certainly not an agent of imminent doom.

title: Central Pennsylvania Finanial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $80,000 and $247,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Dreams and Despair Collide As Miami Searches for Itself
description: Carl (Moon) Mullins, a black man who came here 40 years ago from rural Georgia, found success and owns a string of shops. But he said he also found blacks being treated as second-class citizens, and that he discourages his 12 children from building their lives in Miami. ''I just don't see a future for them here, not here,'' he said.

title: Stop Blaming the Victims in Campus Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Josephine Baker Films
description: Two films starring Josephine Baker, the American music-hall entertainer who became a superstar in France in the 1930's, will be presented at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street, from Feb. 10 to 23. The films, ''Zou Zou'' (1934) and ''Princess Tam Tam'' (1935), are subtitled in English. Information: 431-1592.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Detective and Suspect Shot at L.I. Shopping Mall
description: LEAD: A Suffolk County detective and a Medford, L.I., man he was trying to arrest for murder were shot and wounded Saturday in a confrontation outside a Long Island shopping mall, a Suffolk County Police spokesman said yesterday.

title: Russo Won't Join Race For Governor in Jersey
description: John F. Russo, president of the New Jersey Senate, has announced his withdrawal from the Democratic primary race for governor, strengthening the lead of State Representative James J. Florio, the front-runner in the June primary.

title: Gas Concern To Talk With Other Suitors
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation, trying to fend off an unwanted $2.6 billion takeover bid from the Coastal Corporation, said yesterday that it was preparing to talk with other potential buyers.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; I'll See You Again
description: True to his word, Charles Z. Wick, the departing director of the United States Information Agency, is moving back to California, where he will be close to his friend, former President Ronald Reagan. But Mr. Wick is not turning his back on the capital completely. Last week Mr. Reagan appointed him to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts's board.The board meets three or four times a year.

title: Corvus Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income c-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $1,504,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and tax credits of $1,267,000 for the quarter and $1,443,000 for the 6 months.

title: Outdoors: Ice Fishing From All Angles
description: MOST anglers in the Northeast accept winter's interruption of their sport with equanimity, but others leave hearthside, study or workshop to dally on desolate frozen expanses of lakes and ponds across which fierce winds often howl.

title: 'Strong' Quake Hits Soviet Central Asia
description: A strong earthquake shook Tadzhikistan in Soviet Central Asia early today, destroying buildings and causing some deaths, the official news agency, Tass, reported.

title: Digilog Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cutting Mileage Will Keep You Fit
description: IF you've been running for five years or more, can't shake the injury syndrome, feel mentally stale or find your racing times at a plateau, the answer to your problems may be a revolutionary training system that is gaining acceptance among competitive runners across the country. Cut your running to a mere 20 miles a week.

title: Mortgage & Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter included additional interest income resulting from the payoff of participating loans equal to 6 cents a share.

title: Business and the Law; Shift in Applying Antitrust Rules
description: A RECENT decision by a Federal appeals court about a proposed merger of the two biggest herbal tea companies is being seen as a signal by antitrust lawyers that times could be changing.

title: One for the Early Birds
description: When Coach Al Arbour was told to prepare the Islanders for an 11 o'clock game in Philadelphia this Saturday, he was worried about his players being too tired so late in the evening. Then he found out the game was scheduled for 11 A.M., not 11 P.M.

title: A Prosecutor on a Roll: Anton Ronald Valukas
description: To some lawyers here, Anton Ronald Valukas, the United States Attorney in Chicago, is the Rudolph Giuliani of the Midwest. But others, including some people who work on his staff, scoff at the notion. Mr. Valukas, they say, has been even more aggressive than his counterpart in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS The F.B.I. inquiry into commodity trading reportedly began after a large agricultural company, Archer-Daniels-Midland, complained of possible cheating. Prosecutors are said to be using documents from the Chicago exchanges' disciplinary proceedings to help build their cases. [ D1. ] The U.S. Attorney in Chicago, Anton R. Valukas, is at center stage in a high-profile investigation. [ D5. ] Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said enforcement of trading laws would be ''beefed up.'' But industry officials and observers expressed concern that regulators and lawmakers would overreact and introduce unneeded rules. [ D5. ] COMPANIES Texas Eastern is set to talk with potential buyers other than Coastal, which made an unwanted $2.6 billion offer. Wall Street rumors have put British Gas among the potential bidders. [ D1. ] A second trial of GAF was temporarily halted by Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court. [ D3. ] The Boston Company's president was removed after a review showed that after-tax earnings for three quarters were overstated by $30 million. Two other top executives resigned. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The economy is likely to be jolted next year if short-term interest rates continue to rise and consumers shift spending to make higher payments on adjustable-rate mortgages, home builders were told at a convention in Atlanta. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT In numerous ways, Argentines escape efforts to tax them and re-order their economic behavior. One research institute has estimated that one of three items manufactured in Argentina does not officially exist. [ D1. ] A confidential report was sent to France's President, Francois Mitterrand, suggesting that one of his closest friends had engaged in insider trading, a Paris newspaper reported. [ D4. ] Local and international investors in Hong Kong are battling over proposed rules aimed at curbing freewheeling practices on its stock exchange and bringing the ''cowboy'' market more in line with those in other financial centers. [ D4. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Turner Broadcasting is coming out of the woods after two difficult years. Although still losing money, the company's purchase of MGM/UA is providing some rewards and two properties, the WTBS ''superstation'' and Cable News Network, are doing well. [ D1. ] ESPN's $400 million purchase of rights to baseball games was a defensive move that caught what could have been a rival's grand slam just before it cleared the wall. Television. [ D8. ] Walt Disney has taken control of its first TV station. Viewers in Los Angeles have front-row seats for a battle among entertainment-industry leaders. [ D9. ] Five new Betty Crocker cookbooks are on the way. Prentice Hall is working to sustain and expand the line's popularity. [ D8. ] K Mart and Bruno Inc. are beginning an extensive campaign for American Fare, their new hypermarket. Advertising. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS In a sign of the growing acceptance of ''junk bonds,'' a rating agency has concluded that a mutual fund invested in the high-yield bonds can itself be rated investment grade. Market Place. [ D6. ] Times may be changing in antitrust law. A court decision to allow R. C. Bigelow to challenge Lipton's purchase of a rival tea company indicates a sharp shift in the interpretation of antitrust rules. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Interest rates should remain in a narrow range for the next week or so, analysts say. They believe the next real test will come in mid-February. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Df Southeastern reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings for the latest year, year-ago quarter and prior year are not applicable; the company went public Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Consultant to Head Graphic Scanning
description: The Graphic Scanning Corporation of Englewood, N.J., has picked an outside management consulting expert, Robert J. Cymbala, to fill its recently vacated chief executive post and also to assume the position of president. The appointments are effective Feb. 6. Mr. Cymbala, who is 51 years old, is a partner in the consulting firm of Booz Allen & Hamilton.

title: Company's Aid to F.B.I. Reported
description: The Government began its two-year undercover investigation of the nation's two largest commodities exchanges after a major agricultural company said it believed there was cheating by traders at the exchanges, people involved in the case said today.

title: John Duka, 39, Former Times Writer On Fashion and Art
description: John Duka, a journalist who wrote with humor and grace about fashion, art and society, died Saturday morning at his Manhattan home. He was 39 years old.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Among the 28 National Football League teams, which one has gone the longest time without winning a playoff game?

title: Held in $4.5 Million Holdup, 2 Cadets Resign From V.M.I.
description: Two Virginia Military Institute cadets charged with robbing an armored car in New Jersey, resigned from the school Saturday.

title: Last-Place Islanders Keeping the Faith
description: While the Islanders were on their losing streak and seemed doomed to interminable failures, they were never quite able to believe they were a last-place team and the league's most resounding failure.

title: Bills and Two-Year Notes to Be Auctioned
description: Treasury financings this week begin with today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. On Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction a new two-year note.

title: Rates Expected to Remain Steady
description: Barring sudden weakness in the dollar, credit market analysts predicted that interest rates should remain in a fairly narrow range for the next week or so. The next real test, they believe, will not come until mid-February, when the Treasury will hold its quarterly refunding auctions.

title: 'I'm Not Reagan'
description: Remember the hit show, ''I'm Not Rappoport''? The show now being directed by George Bush in Washington is ''I'm Not Reagan.''

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; Bankruptcy of the Doctrinaire: Martin Jacques, Editor, Britain
description: Martin Jacques's journal, Marxism Today, is a lively forum for criticism and discussion of Marxism and its relevance to British society. It has an important influence on the British Labor Party, which is floundering after losing three general elections to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and the Conservatives. Mr. Jacques, 43, lives in London. He joined the Communist Party at 18.

title: Times Machinists Vote to Ratify Contract
description: Machinists employed by The New York Times voted yesterday to ratify a six-year extension of a labor contract that expired nearly two years ago, thus becoming the last of 14 unions to approve agreements with the newspaper through March 1993.

title: Review/Television; Nuclear Arms and the Superpowers
description: A 13-hour documentary is public television's equivalent of a nuclear explosion. Although no program can live up to the blast of a title like ''War and Peace in the Nuclear Age,'' the series that begins tonight at 10 P.M. on Channels 13 and 21 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 49 makes a considerable impact. Intelligently conceived and fastidiously balanced, it probes the effects of nuclear weapons on Soviet-American relations since World War II. A companion book of the same title by John Newhouse has just been published Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Designatronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for retroactive effect of 5 percent common stock dividends in September 1988 and September 1987.

title: Lawyer Is Picked for High State Department Post
description: Secretary of State-designate James A. Baker 3d will name Robert M. Kimmett, a Washington lawyer who directed the search for President Bush's running mate, as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Some Promising Signs For Turner's Empire
description: Ted Turner has always had a knack for making headlines, but for the past three years most of the news has been bad. The trouble began with his $1.5 billion purchase of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company in 1986, which submerged his relatively small company in what threatened to be overwhelming debt. Many analysts said he paid far too much for the company.

title: CZECH DISSIDENTS CITE 400 ARRESTS
description: The police arrested at least 400 people who tried to attend a vigil at the grave of a student who burned himself to death to protest the 1968 Soviet-led invasion, dissidents said today.

title: Compromising on Solid Waste
description: In his State of the State Message, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York emphasized the urgency of reducing waste volume and recycling re-usable components, but added pointedly that incineration and landfill would also be necessary ''for the foreseeable future.'' Then he argued that decisions on solid waste facilities were best made by local governments. The disclaimer of state responsibility is regrettable, but the emphasis on combining recycling with incineration and landfill makes sense.

title: New Account Of Shooting Of 2 Officers
description: The police officers involved in a shootout with a murder suspect in a Brooklyn row house on Friday had not planned to arrest him, but to establish that he was staying there so a larger team of officers could apprehend him later, New York City's Chief of Detectives said yesterday.

title: Buckley Byers, 72, Republican Official
description: Buckley M. Byers, the deputy chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee since 1976, died of a stroke Friday in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, where he lived. He was 72 years old.

title: Checkpoint Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bush Plans Tough Ethics Message In First Working Day as President
description: In his first week in office, President Bush plans to focus on the importance of ethics for Government officials, begin talks with Congressional leaders on the budget deficit and speak to allied leaders, Administration officials said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Second Time Around
description: In a sense, this is Corneliu Bogdan's second tour in Washington. He was the Rumanian Ambassador from 1967 to 1978 and was widely credited at the time with being instrumental in improving his country's relations with the United States. He later served in senior posts in the Rumanian Foreign Ministry.

title: 49ers Win Super Bowl On Last-Minute Score
description: The San Francisco 49ers drove 92 yards in the final minutes and scored a touchdown with 34 seconds left to defeat the Cincinnati Bengals, 20-16, yesterday in Super Bowl XXIII.

title: Defenses Were in Control for Most of the Game
description: Until the closing minutes of the Super Bowl game, the minutes that saw the San Francisco 49ers drive 92 yards for the winning touchdown, the defenses of both sides were the controlling factors.

title: Ndola Journal; Zambia's on Its Uppers (Just Try Buying Shoes)
description: Five shop assistants and a cashier, all at loose ends, welcomed a customer into a shoe store in this industrial town that is the heart of Zambia's copper belt.

title: Rabin Defends Moves to Quell Unrest
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin seems unyielding at the center of a national storm caused by his new directive that permits soldiers to use harsher tactics in the suppression of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions of the Business People column on Friday misidentified the new chief executive of Fuqua Industries. He is Lawrence P. Klamon.

title: How to Tell Pilgrims From the Puritans
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Edgerly Is Married
description: Linda Edgerly, the daughter of Ruth H. Edgerly of Layton, N.J., and the late O. Chester Edgerly, and Loyd C. Moore, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore of Bellevue, Wash., were married yesterday at Evermay-on-the-Delaware, an inn in Erwinna, Pa. The Rev. Robb Shoaf, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. The bride is a director and consulting archivist in New York for the Winthrop Group, business consultants in Boston. The bridegroom is the founder and the principal of Technology Design, an industrial design firm in Bellevue.

title: L.I. Medical Center Rebounding After Slip in Patient Care
description: Six months ago public confidence in the Nassau County Medical Center, the largest hospital on Long Island, was badly shaken.

title: ATC Environmental Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents service revenue.

title: Birtcher Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Hardy Helps Rangers Prevail
description: In the chaotic elation of the Rangers' locker room Saturday night in Vancouver, a young boy walked up to Mark Hardy and shyly asked him to sign a hockey bubble gum card.

title: Coach's Schooling Laid Groundwork For His Protest
description: Shortly after his team had welcomed him back with a 59-55 victory over Connecticut Saturday, John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown University, wiped his brow and said that it certainly felt good to be on the bench again.

title: Lilco Talks Adjourn With Little Progress Reported on Accord
description: After a daylong meeting in Federal court in Brooklyn, the mediator in talks to settle a racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company yesterday adjourned discussions without moving much closer to a final accord, participants in the talks said.

title: Report Details Cheaper Source For Bomb Fuel
description: The chronic difficulties in producing a critical gas for the nation's nuclear weapons could be solved for about a third the cost of the proposal being backed by the Energy Department, according to an executive report prepared for the department.

title: Argentina's Bustling Underground
description: A woman recently bought an apartment in a pleasant Buenos Aires neighborhood for $33,000, paying for it in what the Argentines call ''greens'' -stacks of hundred-dollar bills.

title: Review/Music; Atwater's Other Hat: Stealing an Inaugural Show
description: It was a night for boogying and head-scratching, as the Republicans ended their entertainment-filled inaugural weekend with a stirring, nearly four-hour rhythm-and-blues show Saturday at the Washington Convention Center.

title: Errors Cost Becker Trip to Quarterfinal
description: Jonas Svensson upset error-prone Boris Becker, 7-6, 6-4, 6-3, today to advance to the quarterfinal round of the Australian Open.

title: Poor and Rich Children Join in a Day-Care Center
description: At the sunny, seven-story school building among the glittering high-rises of one of the nation's most affluent neighborhoods, 2-year-old Ruben Torres and 4-year-old Nancy Raymond stretch their minds and their Play-Doh.

title: New Turn In French Insider Case
description: A Paris newspaper reported today that a report was sent to President Francois Mitterrand suggesting that one of his closest friends, Roger-Patrice Pelat, a businessman, bought 50,000 shares of Triangle Industries' stock just before Pechiney S.A. of France announced plans to acquire Triangle.

title: The Sun Shines On Miami and Game
description: POOR Miami finally caught a break.

title: Reviews/Music; The Romberg Habit
description: Sigmund Romberg is less an acquired taste then an old habit hard to break. The sentiments are paper-thin, the characters bogus, the timeliness long since expired; but Romberg offers at least fractional redemption with melodic turns that are often quite beautiful. Almost as an act of archeology, the Light Opera of Manhattan is presenting his ''Student Prince'' at Playhouse 91 through Feb. 19.

title: A Big Store Gets a Big Ad Campaign
description: THROUGHOUT much of the expansion splurge of the 1980's, retailers have agonized over how to market yet another new store. The similarity in the looks and concepts of many new stores has presented the biggest marketing hurdle.

title: Heart Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1988 results reflected the effects of the changes in accounting for loan fees as a result of the implementation of FASB No. 91. It said because it chose not to restate loan fees and resulting earnings of prior periods, the figures shown for 1988 are not entirely comparable with such prior periods.

title: A Slow but Sure Way to Get in Shape
description: SO you are sedentary and the doctor has scared you with talk of heart disease and a lecture about your weight. Or a significant other has delivered an ultimatum. Or you have caught a glimpse of yourself in the bathroom mirror and been unhappy with what you saw. It's time to get fit. But how do you begin?

title: Rover Group Chairman Taking Cadbury Post
description: After 14 years as chairman of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., Sir Adrian Cadbury is stepping down. Sir Adrian, who will be 60 in April, the normal retirement age for directors, will formally take his leave after the annual meeting in May. He will be succeeded by Sir Graham Day, chairman of Rover Group P.L.C.

title: Reviews/Music; Kremer and Friends
description: The violinist Gidon Kremer has built a bankable reputation on an ability to deliver performances that lead listeners off the beaten path, whether by including unusual cadenzas in war-horse concertos, or by programming new and provocative works. He took the second approach on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall, when he presided over a chamber-music concert with Annette Bik, a violinist; Tabea Zimmermann, a violist; Thomas Demenga, a cellist, and Alois Posch, a bassist.

title: President Is Removed at Boston Company
description: The Boston Company announced Friday that it had removed its president, James N. von Germeten, after having concluded that its after-tax earnings for the first three quarters of 1988 were overstated by $30 million - more than twice as much as a preliminary estimate.

title: Al's Formal Wear reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
South Bronx Rallies for a Firehouse
description: Martin Rogers said he remembers Superbowl Sunday in 1988 well. Not because of the game, he said yesterday, but because of what he called the ''sneaky'' way that New York City closed a Brooklyn firehouse.

title: CXR Telcom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Builders Are Warned of Rising Loan Rates
description: With nearly a third of the nation's home mortgage debt now tied to short-term interest rates, the economy is likely to be jolted by cutbacks in consumer spending next year if those rates continue to rise as expected.

title: Carl Furillo, 66, the Right Fielder With 'Boys of Summer,' Is Dead
description: Carl Furillo, the right fielder for the Brooklyn Dodgers during their glory years in the late 1940's and 50's, died Saturday at his home in Stony Creek Mills, Pa. He was 66 years old.

title: U.S. Foreign Aid Program Hasn't Paid for Abortions Since 1974
description: To the Editor:

title: Will the Vietnam War End?
description: LEAD: On Jan. 27, 1973, the United States signed the Paris Peace Accords, formally ending its part in the Vietnam War.

title: Rice's Subtle Touch Shows
description: After her son had accepted a most valuable player trophy he said he did not deserve, Jerry Rice's mother said she had been worried.

title: Accounts
description: * Sands Hotel & Casino, San Juan, Puerto Rico, to Kaufman & Maraffi Advertising, with a $1 million budget.

title: First Capitol Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $600,000 from an accounting change. c-Included a loss of $1,468,000 on the extinguishment of debt.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council FOURTH U.N. REGIONAL CARTOGRAPHIC CONFERENCE FOR THE AMERICAS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. Reported to Be Sending Agents to Peru in Drug Fight
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration will send more than two dozen agents to Peru to augment a campaign against drug traffickers in an area of the country that has been the scene of civil unrest, according to a published report.

title: Police Embody Racism To My People
description: LEAD: The talk of the country today is about how I, a black police sergeant, was picked up and attacked by white police officers in Long Beach, Calif. Some people wonder how I have the audacity to challenge the police. I have the audacity because I know who I am and I know what the police have represented to my people.

title: INSIDE
description: All-Star Ballot in Moscow Andrei Sakharov, Boris Yeltsin and a Politburo member are seeking the same congressional seat. Page A3. Commodity Complaints An agricultural company's suspicions apparently started the fraud inquiry in Chicago. Page D1. Mixing In the Homeless A day-care program in Manhattan brings children from affluent and homeless families together.Page B1. A Reprieve for Scribners The Scribner Book Store, which was due to close forever yesterday, may be preserved. Page B3. A Setback for Gandhi The ruling Congress Party appeared to have suffered a defeat in a state election that could bode ill for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in national elections to be held later this year.

title: Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $456,402 charge to close unprofitable stores. c-Net income

title: Market Place; New Acceptance For Junk Bonds
description: THE ''junk bond'' business is booming, with prices high and worries low. And, in what may be the ultimate in acceptance of junk bonds, a bond-rating agency has found a way to conclude that a mutual fund invested only in junk bonds can itself be rated investment grade.

title: Reviews/Music; Dressed Up for Guitar
description: Transcriptions might be described as the dressing of naked bodies in different clothes. Powerful fashion statements drastically alter the wearer, but strong personalities have a way of surviving cosmetics and ornament.

title: Riding Tandem in Style
description: It may be time to erase those romantic notions of a bicycle built for two. Think instead of a stretched-out mountain bike and all the high-tech that goes with it. It is today's newest version of the tandem, a bicycle that will take you to more places than picnics in the park.

title: Britain's Inflation Rises
description: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to 6.8 percent in December, from 6.4 percent in November, the Government said Friday. The Department of Employment said its retail price index was up three-tenths of 1 percent in December from the previous month. Market expectations had been for an annual rate of 6.7 percent to 7 percent and a monthly rate of three-tenths of 1 percent to one-half of 1 percent. In November, the retail price index rose one-half of 1 percent from October.

title: Executive Shift At Leo Burnett
description: Leo Burnett International, Chicago, has named 49-year-old Sergio Suarez vice chairman. Mr. Suarez will be relocating from Chicago to the agency's Miami headquarters. Replacing him as director of

title: Gandhi Party Seems Headed For Big Defeat in State Vote
description: The party of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi appeared tonight to have been defeated decisively in a legislative election in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu.

title: Hong Kong Battle Over Market Plan
description: The Hong Kong stock market - with trading volume running only about half of what it was before the October 1987 crash - is beginning to emerge from the darkness.

title: Transit Account Seen For Ephron, Raboy
description: After a month-long review, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has reportedly called on Ephron, Raboy & Tsao Advertising to handle its advertising. The budget is expected to be in the $5 million range.

title: Drought in Midwest Persists, Imperiling Crucial Wheat Crop
description: The drought of 1988 has now reached into 1989.

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Conversion to Pragmatism: Hans-Alfred Rosenthal, Virologist, East Germany
description: Hans-Alfred Rosenthal, 64, is the director of the Institute of Virology at Humboldt University in East Berlin and a frequent visitor to the West. During World War II, he worked at forced labor, was arrested by the Gestapo and later freed,and spent some time in hiding. He joined the party in 1946, a year after he was liberated by Soviet soldiers. WITHOUT AN IDEA there can be no Communism. There has to be an idea, a thought. I myself was in Germany illegally in 1943 and became convinced that the only power in the world which could defeat Hitler was Communism, because Communists were the only people through the Nazi period who were intensively and effectively opposed to Hitler. So I viewed Communism as freedom.

title: Peru Optimistic After Big Oil Find
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has made a major oil discovery estimated at 600 million barrels that should convert Peru into a net exporter and guarantee supplies for 15 years, President Alan Garcia said.

title: A Sakharov vs. Yeltsin Ballot? Maybe
description: When citizens of Moscow vote in March to fill the city's only at-large seat in a new national congress, they may be handed ballots with the following surreal choice: a full member of the ruling Communist Party Politburo, a world-renowned dissident or a popular rogue Communist.

title: Knape & Vogt Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wilson Suspended For Substance Use
description: Stanley Wilson, a Cincinnati Bengal running back with a history of drug problems and two prior suspensions from the National Football League, was suspended again today for substance abuse. His coach, Sam Wyche, said after the Super Bowl that Wilson's career was over.

title: When Disney Buys a TV Station
description: Viewers in Los Angeles have front-row seats for a battle among entertainment-industry leaders for the most competitive television market in the nation.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * West German inflation can be held at around 2 percent in 1989, Helmut Haussmann, the Economics Minister, predicted in a radio interview. The Government's economic report for 1989, scheduled to be published Tuesday, is expected to include a forecast that the inflation rate will be 2.5 percent. Figures for December put year-on-year inflation for 1988 at 1.6 percent. Mr. Haussmann also repeated official forecasts of 2.5 percent economic growth for the year, against 3.4 percent for 1988. This would help create 150,000 jobs in 1989, Mr. Haussmann said.

title: Review/Dance; Delicate World Described
description: Sanghi Wagner is a performer with a strong, quiet presence that quickly draws the viewer into the delicately fashioned world she establishes onstage. And she presented two memorable pieces on Saturday evening at St. Mark's Church in a program of new and recent dances shared with Linda Austin and presented by Danspace.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Jan. 14 showing a model of a condominium, hotel and shopping complex planned for First Avenue and 60th Street was provided in error by the developers' press office. It showed the original proposal for the project. As approved by the City Planning Commission, the building was changed significantly, and its height was reduced by 189 feet.

title: Forest Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Plessey Talks On Deal Seen
description: Plessey P.L.C., facing a hostile British-German takeover bid, is close to signing a technology exchange deal in anti-submarine warfare with Thomson-CSF, The Financial Times said on Saturday.

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A New Outspokenness: Matjaz Kmecl, Politician, Yugoslavia
description: Matjaz Kmecl, 54, a former professor of literature, switched careers to become the chief of culture and education for the Slovenian Communist Party, and he rose to the presidency of the Yugoslav republic.

title: Private Agency Facing Shortfall In Homeless Aid
description: Because of a cut in Federal aid and a dropoff in private contributions, the largest private network for the homeless in New York City is struggling to keep its shelters and soup kitchens open.

title: Diceon Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Place for Profits: Waldemar Zaprzaluk, Plant manager, Poland
description: One of the new breed of Polish managers, Waldemar Zaprzaluk, 40, has been a member of the party since he was 20. He appears to have no Marxist idols, and is proud to be running his pencil factory - which was nationalized in 1946 when the Communists took power - the way its capitalist owner ran it before the war. TALKING ABOUT WAGES, I have to tell you that I employ different principles than the ones that used to be used in dealing with prospective employees. It used to be regarded as embarrassing if the first thing someone asked was, ''How much?'' I'm a kind of mischievous guy, so if they don't ask that question, but tell me they've come for sentimental reasons, or because the mood, the conditions, in factory are good - I get rid of such people as fast as I can.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Durable Goods Dec. Friday G.N.P. 4th Qtr.

title: POLISH UNION SAYS YES TO DISCUSSING ITS LEGAL STATUS
description: Solidarity, banned since 1982, accepted a Government offer today to discuss the restoration of its legal status as a union.

title: Onetime Walk-On Walks Off a Hero
description: Jerry Rice had caught 11 passes for 215 yards. John Taylor had dropped the only ball thrown to him.

title: Drexel Hired by Southmark
description: The Southmark Corporation, whose two top officers resigned under pressure from dissident creditors last week, said Friday that its directors had hired Drexel Burnam Lambert Inc. to advise the company on the sale of all or part of its assets.

title: Besieged San Salvador Feels Realities of War
description: After eight years, the civil war has returned to the capital and this seeming oasis is beginning to feel like a city under siege.

title: People
description: * Charles E. Claggett Jr. has been named deputy managing director and chief creative officer and David W. Henke has been named group creative director at D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles/St. Louis. Mr. Henke already is a senior vice president.

title: First Federal Savings & Loan Chattaooga reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the second quarter and 6 months 1987 figures included a $2,335,000 loss on loan sale.

title: Bench Helps Knicks Defeat Trail Blazers
description: The Knicks finally got their first victory of this road trip, and it was an improbable one at that.

title: Needle Exchange for Addicts Wins Foothold Against AIDS in Tacoma
description: On a rain-swept street corner in this grimy mill town, just steps from a heroin shooting gallery, David Purchase gives out clean syringes in exchange for dirty ones - 13,000 needles in all since he set up his folding table five months ago.

title: Dataproducts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: b-Net loss

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Trade Move Due
description: The State Department's Bureau of European and Canadian Affairs is pressing for a major relaxation of East-West trade controls if the Soviets complete their withdrawal from Afghanistan by Feb. 15 as scheduled under the Geneva accords.

title: Big Bengal Play Not Big Enough
description: On the second play of the fourth quarter of Super Bowl XXIII, the San Francisco 49ers had a first down on the Cincinnati Bengals' 14-yard line. The official scoring summary described the play this way: ''Montana pass for Taylor in end zone broken up by Billups.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about bank earnings described Citicorp inaccurately. Citicorp, the parent company of Citibank,is the largest banking company in the United States, not the largest bank.

title: Illinois Makes Bid For Top Ranking
description: Kenny Battle scored 25 points as Illinois rallied for a 103-92 double-overtime victory over Georgia Tech today to reinforce its claim to the No. 1 spot in the college basketball ranking by The Associated Press.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the shooting of two New York City police officers in Brooklyn Friday misstated the circumstances under which they tried to arrest a murder suspect. They arrived at 82 Hancock Street, where the suspect was hiding in a friend's apartment, with a warrant issued for the man's previous address, where they had earlier searched in vain.

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Flourishing of the Arts: Henryk Kliszko, Party adviser, Poland
description: Henryk Kliszko, 39, is an adviser to various Polish party groups, including the official labor unions. A Marxist theoretician, he joined the party as a student in 1962 because he believed that membership was the most effective way to change the system. If just a few years ago Polish youth was very unwilling, very cynical about anything called socialism or Marxism, well at the moment of Gorbachev coming to power this changed, especially with the youth of the intelligentsia, who were very frustrated. Parents were unable to buy them expensive clothing.

title: Reviews/Dance; From Shanghai, Opera And Mirth of Qi Shufang
description: A mixture of song, dance, declamation and acrobatics, the traditional Chinese theatrical form known as Beijing opera is not confined to one Chinese city. Wherever it may thrive, it can offer great entertainment. That was evident Saturday night when the Qi Shufang Beijing Opera Troupe of Shanghai came to Symphony Space with a program of comedy, fairy tales and acrobatics.

title: Close Competition
description: Imitation may be the sincerest form of flattery, but when Miles Wolff heard about plans to establish a minor league baseball team in Raleigh, N.C., he felt neither flattered nor amused.

title: As Bush Rides In, Is Capital Big Enough for Texans?
description: Last time, it was the Californians; the time before that, it was the Georgians. Now, with the advent of the Bush Administration, it is the Texans' turn to shine, which they did Saturday night at gala events all over the capital.

title: Calcavecchia's 64 Seals Easy Victory
description: Mark Calcavecchia, one of the most aggressive and longest hitters on the PGA Tour, never let up after the first nine holes of Saturday's third round of the 49th Phoenix Open, and ran away today with a seven-shot victory.

title: Metro Matters; Exploring Laws and the Legacy Of the Goetz Case
description: The trial of Bernhard H. Goetz is history, but what has society learned from his crime of self-defense?

title: Scenes of Poverty and Despair Prompt Gifts to the Neediest
description: For the 37 people seen sleeping the other day on the uptown platform of the Astor Place subway station in Manhattan, John Foster sent $37 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: House Beautiful
description: Laura Riordan has been named publisher of House Beautiful. She succeeds Marcia Miller, who resigned from the Hearst magazine in November over policy differences. For the last six years, Ms. Riordan has run her own company, Marketing Concepts, where her clients included Conde Nast's Vogue and Vanity Fair.

title: KLA Instruments Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are answering, we are stretching out our hand, because there is an outstretched hand on the other side, too.'' - Lech Walesa. [ A1:6. ]

title: Where G.I.'s Died, a Beach Is Brimming With Life
description: Nero, who was born here and might be considered somewhat biased, liked this town so much that he would come back in the summer, living in a villa that he had built on a sheer cliff overlooking the Tyrrhenian Sea. Caligula was also born here. There are people who wonder how it is that Antium, as it used to be called, managed to produce two Roman emperors of such enduring infamy. In any event, Caligula, too, was known to spend holidays on the Anzio shore. A Flock of Romans

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Sense of Rectitude: Mario Benedetti, Auto mechanic, Italy
description: An auto mechanic for more than 30 years, Mario Benedetti, 54, has a garage next to a big gas station where he employs his son and one other mechanic. He is a painter and an avid reader, and he has been active in Italy's Communist Party since his youth. No one else in his family has joined the party - proof, he says, of the freedom of choice that Communists allow. They say now that the Communist Party is in a state of crisis, but I don't feel at all crisis-ridden. My belief is firm. I have never had a moment of crisis in this sense. . . . They are talking a lot now about renewal. As far as I'm concerned, the Italian Communist Party has never been old.

title: Intellicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $4,000 for the quarter and $152,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; New Judgements on Stalin: Enrique Lister, Retired general, Spain
description: A major figure in the Spanish Communist Party since before the Civil War, Enrique Lister, 81, survived two world wars and 40 years of Francoism. A deeply committed party man, he is a member of the party's Central Committee and part of the faction of Spanish Communism that defeated and survived Santiago Carrillo, who pursued Stalinist methods.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Cliffie Triumphs: Cliffie, ridden by Richard Migliore, won by a head in the $89,100 Broadway Handicap for New York State-bred fillies and mares 3 years old and up yesterday at Aqueduct. Beru finished fast but had to settle for second place in the field of 10, 1 1/2 lengths ahead of Joe's Tammie. Cliffie went the mile and 70 yards on the fast track in 1:43 1/5 and earned $53,460 for her owner, N.Y. Edition Farm.(AP) Golf Casper Wins Playoff: Chi Chi Rodriguez won only one hole but earned $120,000 and Billy Casper increased his winnings to $80,000 yesterday with a playoff victory over Arnold Palmer in the Senior Skins Game in La Quinta, Calif. Rodriguez, 53 years old, who collected $300,000 of the $360,000 purse at the first Senior Skins a year ago, was shut out for all but one hole this year. But that hole, the 16th, was worth $120,000. Casper, playing in the Skins competition for the first time, won $60,000 on the second playoff hole, No. 18, when he rolled in a 25-foot birdie putt, and Palmer missed his birdie attempt from 12 feet. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 112, Pistons 99: Robert Parish scored 12 points and Danny Ainge 10 during a 39-point third period yesterday as Boston, playing at home, broke open a close game. Kevin McHale and Reggie Lewis had 6 points each and Dennis Johnson 5 in the decisive burst that ended Detroit's three-game winning streak while handing the Pistons a sixth consecutive road defeat.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Capitals 3: Joe Kocur scored an unassisted goal with 57 seconds remaining to lift Detroit over Washington yesterday at the Capital Centre. Kocur picked up a loose puck near the Washington blue line, jumped over a check by the Capitals' Grant Ledyard, and put a wrist shot from the left face-off circle just inside the right goal post. (AP) Sabres 6, Bruins 4: Rick Vaive scored twice, including the game-winner midway through the third period, as Buffalo swept a weekend series from Boston. Skiing Austrian Edges Tomba: Rudolf Nierlich of Austria edged Alberto Tomba in winning a World Cup slalom race for the first time yesterday, while Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg virtually clinched his third overall title. Nierlich was timed in 1 minute 35.90 seconds, for two runs down the tricky, steep slope in Wengen, Switzerland, to beat Tomba by .02 of a second. Another Austrian, Hubert Strolz, was third, in 1:37.60. The Austrian-born Girardelli finished fourth in 1:37.75 with a brilliant second-heat performance. The fourth place, together with a downhill victory Saturday, gave Girardelli the combined title, based on the results in both.(AP) Road Racing Records Set in Central Park: Mike Keohane of Livingston, N.J., and Cindi Girard of Red Bank, N.J., each set meet records in winning the New York Road Runners Club's 10-mile run yesterday at Central Park. The 23-year-old Keohane covered the course in 49 minutes 34 seconds, breaking the old mark of 50:27 set in 1983 by Luis Ostolozaga of the New York Fire Department. Girard topped her own meet record of 57:09 set two years ago by crossing the finish line in 56:19.

title: San Antonio Stadium Is Voted
description: San Antonio area voters have approved a proposal to build a 65,000-seat stadium that has been unofficially called the Alamodome.

title: Rough Ending For 49ers' Cross
description: For 13 seasons, Randy Cross had played guard and then center for the San Francisco 49ers. He announced last week that Super Bowl XXIII would be the last game of his career, and for most of the game it was a nightmare.

title: Polish Union Issues a Text Of Its Reply
description: Following is the text, as translated by The Associated Press, of a statement released today by Solidarity's leadership in response to a Communist Party offer to legalize the banned trade union federation: Point 1

title: Plane That Lost Engine Needed Safety Changes
description: A Piedmont Airlines jet whose engine fell off just after takeoff had not yet undergone safety modifications ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration, a Federal official said Saturday.

title: Motorola, LSI Post Profits
description: Belying reports of an electronics industry slowdown, Motorola Inc. reported on Friday record results for the fourth quarter and the year that ended on Dec. 31. The LSI Logic Corporation, meanwhile, reported lower earnings for the quarter but higher profits for the year.

title: For the Bastille, Very French Fireworks
description: In a season of juicy scandals in France, politics, personal ambition and clashing visions of culture lurk at the heart of the angriest and nastiest scandal of all: the battle for control of the brand-new $350 million Bastille Opera.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Kathryn Hinnant, the Bellevue pathologist, and Steven Smith, the man charged with her murder and rape, were both in Columbia, S.C., last April. It was only coincidence. They did not meet, nor is there any sign that they were ever aware of each other until their lives converged in violence two weeks ago.

title: For Publishing Giant, 55 Million Betty Crocker Cookbooks Is Just a Start
description: For Prentice Hall, which next year will become the sole publisher of the Betty Crocker cookbooks, the challenge is a large one: to make a line that is already successful even more popular, at a time when there is a glut of cookbooks on the shelves.

title: Minneapolis Journal; Ah, for a Bone-Chilling, Icy Winter
description: William C. Rogers has an idea whose time has come.

title: Action Staffing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $56,536 for the latest quarter and $98,551 for the year- earlier period.

title: IPCO Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest periods' results included tax benefits of $990,000 for the quarter and $1,694,000 for the 6 months.

title: Books of The Times; Dangers of Being a Nation of Number Numbskulls
description: Innumeracy Mathematical Illiteracy and Its Consequences By John Allen Paulos 135 pages. Hill & Wang. $16.95.

title: Chicago Case Spurs Tough Stance
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that enforcement of securities and commodity trading laws would be ''beefed up'' after reports of a widespread Federal inquiry into the Chicago commodity markets.

title: Across a Divided Europe, An Ideology Under Siege
description: For a diminishing band of Communist believers in Europe, Mikhail S. Gorbachev - a riveting prophet, a Russian Jeremiah - holds out the promise of revitalizing a decaying system of belief. But the scattered Communist faithful no longer share a single set of beliefs.

title: 49ers Snatch Victory With Last-Minute Score
description: For all of the newfangled big-play offense the San Francisco 49ers and the Cincinnati Bengals were to provide in Super Bowl XXIII today, the first half ended in a 3-3 tie. With 50 seconds remaining in the third quarter, the game was tied at 6-6. Ho-hum. Sure, there were stirring defensive hits and timely offensive trips, but this Super Bowl looked as if it might be a dud as so many others were.

title: Glamour to Ahern
description: After a 12-agency review, Glamour magazine has awarded its account to Ahern & Heussner, a two-year-old shop. The budget is about $500,000. David Deutsch Associates previously handed the Glamour account. Advertising for the magazine, which will celebrate its 50th anniversary this spring, is expected to be ready by March. Glamour's circulation is two million, the highest of any publication in the Conde Nast group.

title: Ex-Klan Chief Places First in Louisiana Primary
description: David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, placed first Saturday in a special primary election to fill a vacancy in the Louisiana House of Representatives. He will compete in a runoff election Feb. 18 against a mainstream Republican, John Treen.

title: Critic's Notebook; Dance Versatility: Is It Virtue or Vice?
description: Versatility is often applauded in the arts, and many theatrical troupes are celebrated for their eclectic repertories. Yet a strange thing has happened in ballet. Versatility is now slightly suspect in some quarters.

title: A Super Party Under The Sky
description: Thousands of 49er fans staged a noisy celebration this evening moments after San Francisco's Super Bowl victory.

title: 'He Was Typical Joe Cool'
description: FOR nearly a quarter of a century, the Super Bowl had been searching for this scenario: pro football's best quarterback taking pro football's best team the length of the field for the winning touchdown in the final minutes. And now, at last, Joe Montana has played the part.

title: Advanced Magnetics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Two for the Road
description: Robert A. Farmer, a key figure in the campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, is planning to divide his time between his home in Boston and his new one in Washington.

title: Where the Scientists Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Matlack Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a credit of $875,000, representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. Matlack will be spun off by RLC Corp. on Jan. 25 by the distribution of one Matlack share for each 3 1/2 RLC shares held of record Jan. 17.

title: Review/Music; A Flute and Harp Recital
description: Sharon Levin, a flutist, and Karen Stern, a harpist, have been performing together as the Levin-Stern Duo since 1984, when they were both students at the Manhattan School of Music. On Saturday afternoon, they made their New York debut at Weill Recital Hall, with a program that showed a temperamental affinity for the French repertory, if not quite the suppleness of sound that Gallic music demands.

title: Review/Music; For Gunter Wand, an American Debut at Age 77
description: A conductor of rare eloquence and dignity made his American debut here last week at the age of 77. All of musical Chicago was talking about Gunter Wand after he led the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in two familiar symphonies Thursday night; the reports were sufficiently glowing to convince a visitor who came Friday for ''Aida'' at the Lyric Opera that it would be wiser to head for Orchestra Hall and Mr. Wand's second performance instead.

title: Hospitals Get Orders To Reduce Crowding In Emergency Rooms
description: The New York State Health Commissioner yesterday took four actions to reduce overcrowding in emergency rooms in New York City, including the installation of a citywide data bank to keep track of how many emergency room beds are available from moment to moment.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Trading Carefully
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer of New York has a tale with a twist similar - sort of - to those medieval fables about the man who does a favor for the wizard and is in turn rewarded.

title: Robert G. Eoff, War Pilot, 93
description: Robert Grimshaw Eoff, one of the last survivors of the Lafayette Escadrille, died of pneumonia Friday at his home here. He was 93 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the selection of a Washington lawyer as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs misidentified him. He is Robert M. Kimmitt.

title: Rorkesdrift Journal; On an Old Battlefield, Zulus Are Given Their Due
description: Only a fierce wind breaking across the rock buttress rising Gibraltar-like from the rolling sea of green hills disturbs the silence of Isandhlwana. Shafts of sunlight break through the afternoon's gathering clouds to bathe a distant ridge.

description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, saw its stock fall by $1.375, to $58.50, after announcing last week that it might be forced to delay deliveries of the latest version of its 747 aircraft.

description: Airplanes can trigger lightning bolts when lightning is not occurring naturally, suggesting that airplanes have a greater chance of being struck by lightning than previously believed, new studies show.
