title: William Como Memorial
description: A memorial service for William Como, the editor in chief of Dance Magazine, is to be held on Feb. 3 at 4 P.M. at City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street. Dancers from national and international companies are to participate in the tribute.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Soviet use of a new bomb against guerrillas in Afghanistan misstated the frequency of takeoffs and landings of Soviet IL-76 transport planes reported at the Kabul airport the previous week. Eight to 12 was the number per day, not the weekly total.

title: Choosing a College
description: MUCH of the excitement in the personal computer industry revolves around the introduction of new or upgraded major software and hardware: a new word-processing or database program, a faster computer or modem, a bigger hard disk. For many users, especially in large companies, a slight improvement in speed or convenience may mean a large improvement in productivity or training speed.

title: Excerpts From Court Opinions in Voiding of Richmond's Contracting Plan
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor today as the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional a Richmond plan for awarding 30 percent of public works funds to minority-owned contractors. Justice O'Connor's opinion was joined in most respects by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Anthony M. Kennedy and John Paul Stevens. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote a separate opinion. Justices Thurgood Marshall, William J. Brennan Jr. and Harry A. Blackmun dissented. Ellipses within quotations are the Court's own. FROM THE OPINION By Justice O'Connor

title: Cuba's Enduring Example: Patrica Hales, Architect, Chile
description: Patricio Hales, 42, is a Santiago architect who has been in Chile for the 15 years since the military coup in 1973 that overthrew the Government of Salvador Allende Gossens, in which the Communists and Socialists were partners. He has been detained several times, once on charges of aiding guerrilla groups. He was absolved of that charge by the Supreme Court. The Chilean Communist Party functions in a state of illegality. Nevertheless, all political and social realities have nuances, fine points. . . .

title: Ciprico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Theater; Sadness as Life Slips By in Chekhov
description: When Stanislavsky first read Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' written especially for the Moscow Art Theater, he was disappointed. There were no real characters, the director complained, only hints of them. Yet nearly a century later the characters who inhabit Chekhov's drawing rooms and gardens in provinical Russia speak more clearly to the eternal yearnings and frustrations of the human condition than those in a hundred contemporary plays.

title: Kemper Plans Restructuring
description: In a significant restructuring move, the Kemper Corporation said today that it would divide its Kemper Group into two units to improve its performance and to raise the company's stock price. The transaction was valued at between $280 million and $300 million. Joseph E. Luecke, the

title: Persistence of Class Conflict: Saifuddin Chowdhury, Politician, India
description: Saifuddin Chowdhury, 36, a member of the Communist Party of India - Marxist, says he was 15 or 16 when he decided to join the party. He said he was a fugitive from the police and the Congress Party in Bengal from 1972 to 1977, when the Congress Party tried to destroy the Communist movement in the state. On Hungary, Czechoslovakia and other military actions: If a socialist country says, ''Let us stop this kind of military activities,'' I have no objection. But we must remember that the interventions by Socialist or Communist countries have been necessitated by interventions by imperialists. . . .

title: C.F.T.C. Insists It Had Role All Along
description: Asserting that it has not been asleep as a regulator, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had been participating in the Government's investigation of trading at two Chicago commodity exchanges for more than two years.

description: Prof. Sydney Goldstein, an authority on aerodynamics, died of heart failure Sunday at Cardinal Cushing Hospital, Brockton, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Randolph, Mass.

description: A jury today sentenced Richard Biegenwald to death for the slaying of 19-year-old Anna Olesiewicz in Asbury Park more than five years ago.

title: Catholic Churches Move to Embrace Blacks
description: For generations, St. Rocco's, St. Stanislaus and other sturdy Roman Catholic churches were the heart of Irish, Italian and Eastern European communities here. But now the neighborhoods are predominantly black. Few residents, and few children in the churches' schools, are Catholic.

Fines for Tesoro
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation of San Antonio has been ordered to pay more than $56 million to the Energy Department for regulatory violations between 1973 and 1981, the company said today. According to the agency's final order, Tesoro has 30 days to make an initial payment of $25 million, after which six annual payments of $5.2 million will be due. The Energy Department had sought a total of $144 million in fines and repayment for the energy company's reported abuse of price and allocation regulations during the eight-year period.

title: Lyondell Petrochemical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: In 1988, Lyondell was a wholly owned subsidiary of Atlantic Richfield Co. Trading of Lyondell shares on the New York Stock Exchange began on Jan. 19, pursuant to an initial public offering scheduled to close Jan. 25.

description: Merrill Lynch & Company, led by record earnings in its investment banking and trading divisions, yesterday reported sharp increases in earnings and revenues for the fourth quarter and the full year.

title: Liechtenstein Political Crisis
description: The 15-member Parliament of this tiny Central European principality was dissolved today after a dispute between the two coalition parties.

description: The Republican National Committee today made public the names of about 250 donors who gave at least $100,000 to the party last year, in effect protecting Robert A. Mosbacher Sr., the Commerce Secretary designate, from pointed questions about the list at his Senate confirmation hearing Tuesday.

description: Names and numbers have changed, but the intensity that has characterized the St. John's-Georgetown rivalry remains intact.

title: Rice's Career Is Moving At a Most Incredible Pace
description: When Jerry Rice was attending Mississippi Valley State, a college without rich playboys, he drove a Datsun 300ZX, a car popular with playboys on other campuses. He said he earned much of his money as a summertime hod carrier, handling bricks for his father for $200 a week.

title: A Sense of Pointless Sacrifice: Govinda Pillai, Party Intellectual, India
description: Govinda Pillai, 62, is a a member of the board of the Kerala State Film Development Corporation. He is formerly editor of a Communist newspaper. We don't oppose the opening of Soviet society. They have to stop this process of people leaving the scene only when they die. . . . But what I don't like is the sense of the messianic: The Great Gorbachev has come to give the movement a human face! I spent all this time in jail to give Communism an animal face? . . .

description: The imprisoned former president of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc. today pleaded guilty to perjury charges for denying his involvement in the fraud that led to the securities firm's collapse in 1985.

Morley Drury, Ex-Football Star, 85
description: Morley Drury, an all-America running back at Southern California in 1927, when he became the first Trojan to rush for 1,000 yards in a season, died Sunday at the age of 85.

title: Corning Glass Works reports earnings for 12wks to Jan 1
description: b-Included tax benefits of $200,000 and $2,200,000 for the 12 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively. c-Included tax benefits of $2,400,000 for the 12 weeks and $4,200,000 for the 52 weeks, and the 52 weeks also included a gain of $14,200,000 from a cumulative effect on prior years (to Dec. 28, 1986) of change in method of accounting for certain manufacturing costs, net of applicable income taxes, and a gain of $83,900,000 for the cumulative effect on prior years (to Jan. 3, 1988) of change in method of accounting for postemployment medical benefits net of applicable income taxes. The ''unusual events'' reduced final net income for 1988 by $6.2 million. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 17, 1989. The company said in the year-ago periods certain amounts have been reclassified for comparative purposes. The company also said the major events in 1988 were a charge of $83.9 million to reflect an accounting change related to future health-care benefits for current retirees, a charge of $19.1 million to previously established restructuring reserves, a gain of $58 million related to an initial public offering of shares of Iwaki Glass Co. in Japan, a gain of $6.1 million related to the formation of Corning Asahi Video Products Co., and a $12.1 million gain from the sale of shares in International Clinical Laboratories.

title: David Monroe Collins, Frick Administrator, 51
description: David Monroe Collins, administrator and assistant secretary of the Frick Collection, died in his sleep Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 51 years old.

title: Losing Streak Ends
description: The trainer Oscar Barrera broke a personal losing streak extending back to last May 16 when Home by Nine won Aqueduct's ninth race yesterday with Richard Castillo aboard. Barrera had not had a winner among 130 consecutive horses he saddled going into yesterday's last race. Jose Martinez, aboard the runner-up, Poster Run, alleged interference by Home by Nine but the claim was disallowed. Home By Nine paid $49 for $2 to win and combined with Poster Run and Absolute Authority to produce a triple payoff of $16,004. (AP)

title: Merrill Lynch & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $254.7 million resulting from the previously announced termination of the corporation's defined benefit plan which covered substantially all U.S. employees. It also includes a charge of $44.4 million relating to a provision for the costs of merging or downsizing certain foreign and domestic branch offices and operating facilities. c-Included a $36,838,000 cumulative effect of the adoption for all periods prior to 1987. The year-ago quarter earnings were reduced by $2 million and prior year earnings by $55.4 million to reflect adoption of an accounting change. The restated 1987 earnings included after-tax gains of $110 million related to the sale of a portion of the corporation's leasing business, $52.9 million related to the sale of Master Limited Partnership units in the corporation's residential real estate operations, and $87 million related to the sale of the corporation's right to acquire a partnership interest in the south tower of the corporate headquarters. The latest year had 53 weeks, compared with 52 weeks for year-earlier period.

Recounting the story of Genesis, ''Songs of Paradise,'' now playing at the Public Theater, is witty, tuneful, contemporary and traditional.

title: A Moral Claim in Africa: Mzala, Writer, South Africa
description: Mzala, 33, goes only by one name, and says his first name ''got lost'' when he was growing up. A member of the South African Communist Party, he writes for journals of the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party. Mzala, who has lived in exile in Britain since 1987 and is studying at Essex University for a doctorate in sociology, was detained several times by the South African authorities, the first time when he was 15. He left South Africa in 1976. MY INSTINCTIVE FEELING was grounded, I think, to a large extent on my admiration then, at that time, of the classless society as I perceived it in the context of the old African communal village, where there was no exploitation of one person by the other and where the main means of life was by people as a whole, even though they might have been under the custodianship of a king.

title: A Search for Clues to 'Dark Ages' of the Cosmos
description: SCIENTISTS believe they are on the verge of major discoveries about the ''dark ages'' of the universe, the critical period from three minutes after the explosive moment of creation until the appearance of enormous galaxies. They hope to answer one of the most perplexing questions in cosmology: how primeval particles, hurtling apart from the Big Bang, managed to combine into atoms, which then clumped together to eventually form stars, galaxies and clusters of galaxies in the evolving universe.

title: Accord for Henke
description: Tom Henke settled with the Toronto Blue Jays on a one-year contract for $975,000 yesterday, avoiding a second successive arbitration hearing. Greg Gagne of the Minnesota Twins also settled his case, agreeing to a one-year contract for about $550,000. Last year, Henke asked for $1.025 million and Toronto offered $725,000, the figure picked by the arbitrator, Raymond Goetz. This year, Henke asked for $1.05 million and the Blue Jays offered $900,000. Henke, a 31-year-old right-hander, was 4-4 last season with 25 saves and a 2.91 earned run average in 55 appearances. He has 99 career saves in four seasons. Gagne batted .236 in 1988 with 14 homers and 48 runs batted in. He had asked for $595,000 and the Twins had offered $535,000. There are 102 players remaining in arbitration. Hearings will take place from Feb. 1-20.(AP)

title: Cynicism About the Free Market: Gustavo Espinoza Montesinos
description: Gustavo Espinoza Montesinos, 47, has been a member of the Central Committee of the Peruvian Communist Party since 1966. A former teacher, he is part of the United Left bloc in Peru's congress, the second-largest bloc after that of the Government party. He has not been arrested since 1979, but has often been beaten in protests. On his desk rest a bust of Lenin and half a dozen used tear gas shells - made by Federal Laboratories in Saltsburg, Pa. - that he said were fired at him and other demonstrators. It was a Communist home. From the age of 9, I was aware of politics, because in 1950 there was a popular uprising . . . and my family took part. There was street fighting, but after four days the army attacked.

title: The (900) Numbers to the Stars

title: Temptation for the Freethinker: Roberto Freire, Politician, Brazil
description: Roberto Freire, 46, is on the 12-member Executive Committee and the 63-member Central Committee of Brazil's Communist Party. He holds one of three Communist seats in Congress. Mr. Freire, who comes from Recife, in Brazil's poor northeast, turned to politics in 1961. ''What finally led me to Communism was my disbelief in religion,'' he said. I think the socialist countries of what is called Eastern Europe are socialist, some more developed than others, some still underdeveloped.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Meteorite Umbrella
description: Edward Teller has a new idea for those jaded by ''Star Wars'': a space-based defense against large meteorites. Speaking recently at George Washington University, Dr. Teller, the physicist who led the nation's hydrogen bomb team, said an international project could in effect render meteorites - called meteoroids before they enter Earth's atmosphere - impotent and obsolete at a cost of just $100 million or so. He said researchers at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory estimate the worldwide cost of meteorite strikes at $10 million to $100 million a year. A meteorite the size of the one that hit remote Siberia in 1908, not to mention the bigger ones that struck Earth millions of years ago, would do immense damage to a populated region, he warned.

title: Tim Cohane, 76, Sports Editor at Look
description: Tim Cohane, who was the sports editor of Look magazine from 1944 until it ceased publication in 1965, died Sunday at a health care center in Nashua, N.H., after a lengthy illness. Mr. Cohane, who lived in Derry, N.H., was 76 years old.

title: FASHION: By Design; All That Glitters
description: In the last few months silver has surged into the forefront as a favorite metal for jewelry and fashionable bits of trimming. (Yes, gold-toned Chanel-style jewelry is still the rage, too.) Silver first became chic in the mid-1970's when Tiffany & Company started selling Elsa Peretti's bold, original bracelets and belt buckles. Her extraordinary designs set a new style standard for silver. Tiffany then began offering a wider variety of silver ornaments, everything from sedate circle pins and button earrings to smart modern designs, including zigzaggy pins and ear clips by Paloma Picasso. The other day, to their mild surprise, Tiffany's executives realized that silver jewelry had become their second-biggest jewelry seller, just after diamonds.

title: Howard Savings Bank of New Jersey reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Super Bowl Ratings Rise
description: The A. C. Nielsen Company said yesterday that overnight reports from 17 markets showed that the NBC broadcast of the Super Bowl Sunday had a slight increase in ratings over last year's audience for the Washington-Denver game broadcast by ABC. The complete national ratings are expected to be available today. A spokesman for NBC, John Prenty, estimated that 120 million people watched some portion of the telecast.

title: Business and Health; Key Labor Issue: Retaining Benefits
description: PREPARING for bargaining with the telephone companies this spring, the Communications Workers of America recently drew up a statement outlining six broad objectives. Among them, wage increases received one paragraph. Health care was given more than two pages.

title: New Project Will Renovate The Garden
description: A $1.3-billion plan to replace Madison Square Garden with an office complex and build a new arena west of the present site on the West Side of Manhattan has been abandoned in favor of a $100-million renovation of the Garden, public officials and real-estate executives said yesterday.

title: Our Towns; At Youth Center, Need and Crack Are the Enemies
description: William Collins has a picture of Mario Cuomo hanging in his office, but to tell the truth, lately he's been disappointed with the man. The Governor doesn't want to raise income taxes (the Governor doesn't want to deter business) and Mr. Collins could use some more tax dollars. He runs the Wyandanch Youth Center, a tidy speck of purposefulness in a suburban ghetto.

title: Alza Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Horizon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grove Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Music; The Opera That Made Rossini's Reputation
description: The bel canto revival - the restoration of operas by Rossini, Donizetti, Bellini and the young Verdi - has been one of the three or four most influential postwar operatic movements. The Lyric Opera's current production of Rossini's ''Tancredi'' is arguably a state-of-the-art specimen - critical edition, uncut score, first-choice cast -and so Saturday evening's performance prompted as many thoughts about the bel canto scene in general as about the particular merits of ''Tancredi.''

title: Foreign Policy; Rightist Conservatives Keep Eye on Kissinger
description: For most of the Reagan era Henry A. Kissinger's profile in Washington was low, except sporadically in 1983 when the former Secretary of State headed a Presidential commission on Central America. Seven years ago his New York-based consulting firm, Kissinger Associates, opened offices here.

title: Civilian Band Seizes Argentine Barracks
description: Fifty heavily armed men and women took over an army base in Argentina today and waged a daylong battle with soldiers and policemen trying to retake it.

title: Old Spaghetti Warehouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Neediest Are Helped By Families
description: Peter Janssen, age 12, is worried about homeless children and wanted to do something to help out. He decided his family should make a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''It must feel really horrible to be really poor or have parents who don't have jobs or not enough food or clothes,'' Peter said in a note with his own donation of $5.

title: Greenspan Pleased With Long-Term Rates
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, expressed satisfaction today that the financial markets appeared to be impressed with the central bank's commitment to prevent any significant increase in inflation.

title: For 25 Cents, Every Moviegoer Was Royalty
description: In 1922, a young actress named Margaret Buckley swallowed five bichloride of mercury tablets, then calmly strolled to the opulent Capitol Theatre on Broadway in New York City. There, succumbing while the theater orchestra played ''Espagna'' before the feature, she moaned, ''I had high ideals, but I couldn't live up to them.''

description: Whatever the decision of the jury in the Joel B. Steinberg murder trial, in which deliberations began yesterday, one question will remain unresolved: how culpable is Hedda Nussbaum?

title: Fraser Wilkins Is Dead; Ex-U.S. Envoy Was 80
description: Fraser Wilkins, who was the first United States Ambassador to the Republic of Cyprus, died of a stroke Saturday at Sibley Memorial Hospital here. He was 80 years old.

16.97 Dow Fall Second Biggest This Month
description: LEAD: Stock prices fell sharply in late trading yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped by 16.97 points to close at 2,218.39.

title: Gotti Is Seized In '86 Shooting Of Union Chief
description: John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino organized-crime family, and two associates were arrested last night and charged with ordering the murder of a union leader who was shot but not killed in May 1986.

description: Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it was discussing the purchase of the Rose & Company Investment Brokerage, a unit of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: East Germany to Cut Its Armed Forces by 10,000
description: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, announced today that his country would reduce its armed forces by 10,000 and also cut military spending by 10 percent.

title: Chang Yu-Yi Is Dead; Bank Official Was 88
description: Chang Yu-Yi, vice president of the first women's bank in China from 1927 to 1937, died Saturday of cardiac arrest in her sleep at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old. Miss Chang was a member of a family that was influential in China before the Communist takeover in 1949. She was the sister of Chang Chia-ao, who became chairman of the Bank of China, and Carsun Chang, a philosopher who became a high official in the Nationalist Government of Chiang Kai-shek.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the police do not need a search warrant to conduct low-altitude helicopter searches of private property.

Film-Color Panel Seeks Meaning of 'American'
description: The National Film Preservation Board, which was set up to help select movies to be protected as leading examples of American culture, met for the first time today and became mired in a discussion over just what an American film was.

description: b-Included an aftertax charge of $768,000 from early extinguishment of debt and pretax charges totaling $11,004,000 in connection with the company's strategic restructuring and redirection for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 6-month also included pretax provisions of $18,933,000 and $33,910,000, respectively, for contractual adjustments and doubtful accounts, compared with provisions of $9,920,000 and $21,142,000 for the year- ago quarter and 6-month, respectively.

description: Texaco Inc., which may face another proxy fight with Carl C. Icahn this spring, said yesterday that it would elect to its board John Brademas, the president of New York University, and Charles H. Price, the departing Ambassador to Britain.

description: A Federal mediator's proposal to settle the racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company has moved negotiations ahead, but the participants remain sharply divided over what the utility can afford to pay to end the dispute, officials said yesterday.

title: In Peshawar, Everyone Awaits the Fall of Kabul
description: ''In Afghanistan behind every mountain there is a king,'' an Afghan guerrilla commander said.

title: Sister Ann Heintz, 58, Journalism Teacher
description: Sister Ann Christine Heintz, a Roman Catholic nun who founded a national student-written news service, died of cancer here Friday. She was 58 years old.

description: On his first working day in office, President Bush moved quickly today to establish a personal dialogue with his foreign counterparts, including making a telephone call to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

Wobbling of the Party Line: Safdar Hashmi, Theater Director, India
description: Safdar Hashmi, 35, a founder of the pro-Marxist Students Federation of India at Delhi University in 1970, was a playwright, actor, director and leading figure in Indian street theater. He was beaten to death by a street gang early this month after refusing to stop production of a street play. The play supported a candidate running against a member of the Congress Party. Mr. Hashmi was one of the most sought-after film and video narrators in India. He told an interviewer that he had earned enough at documentary work to ''spend 11 months doing anything that the party wants me to do.'' On perestroika and glasnost: The two things are quite separate. The Communist Party of India-Marxist has broadly supported perestroika. But glasnost and perestroika are two different cups of tea. We do not put them together. . . . The interpretation of the West is that the reforms and Gorbachev's admissions are an expression of failure. We can see from the breakneck speed of the changes that only a society that is in control of itself can do this sort of thing. . . .

title: Patterns
description: June in January

title: Seat Prices and Trading Slip in Chicago
description: Trading volume and seat prices have fallen sharply at the nation's largest commodity exchanges, and exchange officials are trying to allay the fears of traders and restore the confidence of the public.

title: Rebel-Held Areas of Sudan to Get U.S. Food Aid
description: In a move that reflects growing frustration with the Sudanese Government, the United States Agency for International Development plans to provide food to rebel-held areas in famine-stricken southern Sudan.

title: Savings Crisis Estimate Due
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board indicated today that the agency was likely to increase its estimate next week on the size of the savings and loan crisis.

title: An Off-Duty Officer Kills Unarmed Man In a Traffic Dispute
description: A 60-year-old unarmed man was fatally shot in the stomach by an off-duty police officer during a traffic dispute in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Neighbors Opposing Reagan Drug Center
description: Probably few people in the Beverly Hills dinner crowd who paid $1,000 each Jan. 4 for a new drug rehabilitation center to be named after Nancy Reagan have ever visited the neighborhood where it would operate.

description: The guerrillas in El Salvador have offered to take part in new presidential elections and abide by the results if the voting is postponed by six months and the rebels receive security guarantees.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Racial classifications are suspect, and that means that simple legislative assurances of good intention cannot suffice.'' - Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, in opinion striking down a quota for minority contractors in Richmond, Va. [ A18:2 ]

title: Garlic and Cancer
description: Garlic and onions, food items that have often received mixed reviews in this country, have been credited in China with a benefit that has nothing to do with taste or odor. A new study shows that they reduce the risk of stomach cancer.

title: Commodity Case Seen Expanding
description: At least a dozen more subpoenas were delivered today in the Government's widening investigation of trading abuses on Chicago's huge commodity exchanges, a Federal official who has held discussions with the investigators said.

title: Closing the Book on Career
description: While his teammates on the San Francisco 49ers leaped at the sight of a last-minute Super Bowl victory, Randy Cross lingered for one last look around Joe Robbie Stadium. He could not recall any specific memory or vision, just the need to take one last mental snapshot.

title: Computerland In Settlement
description: Settling a five-year-old class action, the Computerland Corporation agreed today to cut its franchisees' royalty rates to 5 percent of sales, from 8 percent.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Tumi Luggage, Middlesex, N.J., to Janklow Bender, with a budget of more than $1 million.

description: b-Net loss The 1987 results included a net charge of $3,262,000 from a restructuring program.

title: Hubbell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Bridge
description: The strongest event scheduled for this year in Europe, and perhaps in the world, ended Sunday in the Hague. It was the third Unisys Staten Bank World Top tournament, which included 16 outstanding partnerships from four continents.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 142, Warriors 109: Larry Nance took advantage of a considerable height edge and scored 22 points last night as Cleveland, playing at home, ended Golden State's eight-game winning streak. The Cavaliers had seven players in double figures, and the 142 points represented their best output of the season. They won their fifth game in a row and their 12th straight at home to improve their league-leading record to 30-7. The 6-foot-11-inch Nance, going against such defenders as 6-8 Larry Smith and 6-5 Mitch Richmond, took control of the game early, scoring 16 first-half points to help Cleveland to a 72-52 halftime lead. Richmond's 3-point shot at the start of the second half got the Warriors within 17, but they got no closer. Chris Mullin led Golden State with 27.(AP) Pacers 117, Nuggets 102: Herb Williams had a team-record 29 rebounds as Indiana defeated Denver at home to end a five-game losing streak. Reggie Miller led the Pacers with 27 points. Alex English had 25 for the Nuggets.(AP) Spurs 119, Heat 101: Willie Anderson scored 26 points and San Antonio ended a seven-game losing streak by beating Miami at home. Anderson also had nine assists and six steals, both season highs. The Spurs used a 22-6 third-quarter run to blow open what had been a tight game. Miami finished with 34 turnovers, one shy of its season high. San Antonio had a team-record 22 steals.(AP) HORSE RACING Las Manitas Wins Sugar Loaf: Las Manitas, guided along the rail by Julie Krone, carried 112 pounds to a 1 1/2-length victory in the $36,000 Sugar Loaf Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday. Avie's Gal, carrying 122 pounds and ridden by Frank Lovato Jr., was second in the field of seven, 3 1/2 lengths ahead of Bodacious Tatas. Las Manitas went six furlongs in 1:10 1/5 for her second victory in two starts this year. She earned $21,600 for Peter M. Brant and returned $11.40 for $2 to win.(AP) N.H.L. Flames 3, Canadiens 1: Joe Mullen snapped a 1-1 tie with eight seconds left in the second period and Joe Nieuwendyk scored Calgary's other two goals as the Canadiens' 18-game home-ice unbeaten streak was snapped. The Canadiens, who hold a 3-point edge over Calgary in the overall league standing, had won 16 and tied 2 at the Forum since Oct. 29. Mullen beat the Montreal goaltender, Brian Hayward, just seconds after Calgary won a face-off in the Canadiens' zone. Mullen, positioned at the top of the right face-off circle, used the Montreal defenseman Chris Chelios as a screen while unleashing a shot that caught the corner to Hayward's left. It was Mullen's 31st goal of the season. (AP) Whalers 5, Nordiques 0: The Hartford goaltender, Peter Sidorkiewicz, stopped 27 shots for the second shutout of his league career and Kevin Dineen scored twice to lead the Whalers at Quebec. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN L.S.U. 78, South Alabama 64: Patricia Woods scored 16 points to lead five Louisiana State players in double figures last night as the 14th-ranked Ben-Gals defeated South Alabama in Mobile, Ala. Woods also grabbed 12 rebounds for L.S.U. (9-4). Adrian Vickers scored 17 points for South Alabama (11-7).(AP) Auburn 85, Austin Peay 37: Evelyn Thompson and Linda Godby both scored 13 points as the No. 1 Lady Tigers beat Austin Peay in Auburn, Ala. Auburn (17-0) allowed the first basket to the Lady Govs' Tracie Mason before scoring the next 13 points. Mason scored 10 points to lead Austin Peay (0-16). The victory was Auburn's 33d in a row at home. (AP)

title: Microscopes Reveal Sea Hitchhikers
description: MARINE biologists in California have found evidence that the decomposing organic matter that constantly sinks to the ocean depths is colonized by a surprising variety of microscopic animals that appear to hitchhike rides part of the way down.

title: Review/Television; On 'Schoolbreak,' 60's Civil Rights
description: ''My Past Is My Own,'' being presented as a ''Schoolbreak Special'' on CBS at 4 P.M. today, is one powerful scene surrounded by not very convincing contrivances.

title: Salvador Dali, Pioneer Surrealist, Dies at 84
description: Salvador Dali, pioneer of European Surrealism and for more than half a century one of the best-known and most bitterly contested figures in the international art world, died yesterday at Figueras Hospital in Figueras, Spain. He was 84 years old.

title: China Will Launch U.S.-Built Satellite
description: A Hong Kong company signed a $30 million contract today to fire an American-built satellite into space on a Chinese rocket - the first time China will launch a foreign-built satellite.

title: Social Security Fails in Effort to Use Own Lawyers to Judge Appeals
description: The Government has rejected a request by the Social Security Administration to relax requirements for appointing administrative law judges so that the agency's attorneys would qualify for the positions.

title: Shelling From Cambodia Empties a Khmer Rouge Refugee Camp
description: Heavy shelling from inside Cambodia has forced the complete evacuation of a refugee camp run by the Khmer Rouge and caused its 4,350 inhabitants to flee further into Thailand, relief officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Reassessment of the Soviet Model, Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, Artist, Mexico
description: Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, 63, was general secretary of the Mexican Communist Party from 1963 until 1981, when the party became part of the Unified Socialist Party of Mexico. An artist and former presidential candidate, he has twice been elected to the Chamber of Deputies. In 1982, he was the Unified Socialist Party's presidential candidate, winning less than 1 percent of the vote. I began working at the age of 15, when I left my village in Sinaloa to go and work in Sonora in a tomato packing plant, while there was a boom in tomato production to be able to export to the United States. I spent three years at that, and from there I joined the workers building the first big dam in northwestern Mexico, where I found a class consciousness that influenced me greatly.

title: Candidate Drops Out of Race

Jesse Jackson's manager at the Democratic convention, the candidates are former Representatives James Stanton of Ohio and Jim Jones of Oklahoma and Richard Wiener, the chairman of the Michigan Democratic Party.

The telegram promised that ''operations would create no environmental, toxic or radiological hazards.''

description: The company said prior 12 months included a gain of $16,847,000 from an accounting change and a writeoff of $91 million for a portion of the Zimmer generating station. Revenue represent total revenue.

title: Stalemate Over Kinsey Institute's Director
description: The Kinsey Institute and Indiana University, where the institute is based, are at a stalemate over the future of June Reinisch, the institute's director.

title: Acme-Cleveland Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $310,000 tax credit. c-Net loss Year-ago quarter included a $500,000 gain from the sale of a product line. Year-ago quarter results are restated for an accounting change.

title: Regional Federal Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comshare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $337,700 on the disposal of discontinued operations. The company said during the three months ended Sept. 30, 1987, it made provisions totaling about $600,000 in connection with reductions of certain facilities and staff of its European operations.

title: Tickets, Anyone?
description: There are few images as genteel as those of strawberries and cream and manicured grass at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club's annual Wimbledon fortnight. But its ticket scalping makes America's Super Bowl look dainty.

title: Standard Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $5 million gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-After an extraordinary gain of $10.6 million.

title: Handling Past Wrongs: Bayardo Arce, Politician, Nicaragua
description: Bayardo Arce's responsibility in Nicaragua's ruling Sandinista National Directorate is to tend to the party structure. He is sometimes classed among the country's more radical leaders. A 39-year-old former journalist, he used his newspaper job before the Sandinistas took power as a cover for revolutionary activities. In Nicaragua there was very little knowledge of Marxism. No Marxist literature circulated here. My own father, who was self-educated to the point that he taught himself to speak five languages, didn't have a single book about Marxism in his library when he died. The first appearance of the Communist Manifesto in Nicaragua was in 1970, when I and a group of other students printed 10,000 copies and distributed them. . . .

title: Chemical Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been restated for the 1988 acquisition of First National Bank & Trust of Big Rapids, Mich., and the 10 percent stock dividend declared last month.

title: Michael Lepiner, 46, President of Telecom
description: Michael Lepiner, president of Telecom Entertainment, producers of programs for commercial television, died of pancreatic cancer Sunday at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Indiana Wins 13th In a Row
description: Indiana ran its winning streak to 13 games, 6 in the Big Ten Conference, as Jay Edwards scored 20 second-half points to lead the 16th-ranked Hoosiers to a 71-70 victory over No. 10 Michigan tonight.

title: 2 Josephine Baker Films
description: Two films starring Josephine Baker, the American music-hall entertainer who became a superstar in France in the 1930's, will be presented at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street, from Feb. 10 to 23. The films, ''Zou Zou'' (1934) and ''Princess Tam Tam'' (1935), are subtitled in English. Information: 431-1592.

title: Oldtimers Key As Rangers' Road Streak Continues
description: Guy Lafleur, John Ogrodnick, Lucien DeBlois. They are a strange collection of goal scorers. The three, who are humble enough to admit their primes are past, are also astute enough to understand that a very special year is unfolding in front of them. And they are each in their own way determined to play a part in it.

title: South Jersey Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $113,000 and $308,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Judge Instructs Jurors On Steinberg Charges
description: The jury in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg began deliberating yesterday after Acting Justice Harold J. Rothwax had said it could consider four homicide charges against the defendant in Lisa Steinberg's death.

title: Susquehanna Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $450,000.

title: Intergraph Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Finding the Founder Fallible: Luis Sanchez Sancho, Politician, Nicaragua
description: Luis Sanchez Sancho, 46, is a leader of the Nicaraguan Socialist Party, the first in Nicaragua to proclaim Marxist ideals. For years the Socialist Party maintained direct ties to the Soviet Communist Party. The Socialist Party sees itself as an opposition group, as does Nicaragua's Communist Party. The Socialists recently issued a lengthy paper in which they said it was time to develop a new strategy for socialism in Nicaragua. Mr. Sanchez was sent to the Soviet Union for political training as a young man. There he developed his first misgivings about Soviet Marxism. From my own perspective in Nicaragua, I have believed for a long time that socialism in the Soviet Union is not functioning as it really should . . . Socialism is now in a global and universal crisis. I am convinced that in practice, much of the original thought of Marx has been lost.

title: Too Many Hurdles for the Bengals
description: In the end, the Cincinnati Bengals had too much to overcome.

title: Murdoch to Introduce Sports Travel in June
description: In June Murdoch Magazines will introduce Sports Travel, a trade magazine catering to sports-minded travel planners, athletic directors, promoters and travel agents.

title: Officials in New York Region Assess Effects of Bias Ruling
description: While acknowledging the uncertainty raised by a United States Supreme Court decision issued Monday, Connecticut and New Jersey officials, vowed yesterday to continue with state programs that set aside a percentage of government contracts for minority-owned businesses.

title: In Paris, Seductive Ungaro And Streamlined Lagerfeld
description: Few designers ever lost caste by overestimating the demand for sexy clothes. As the spring and summer couture openings continue here, Emanuel Ungaro, no stranger to the genre, achieved the apogee of seductive dressing this season. He did it with flower prints, flaring skirts, open necklines, petticoats and tiny waistlines: all the classic appurtenances of appealing femininity.

title: Newton Goes Home
description: C. M. Newton, basketball coach at Vanderbilt since 1981 and a member of Kentucky's top-ranked team in 1951, yesterday was named athletic director at Kentucky. He will begin his duties on April 1, succeeding Cliff Hagan, a former Kentucky basketball star who resigned Nov. 15, after 13 years as athletic director, amid an investigation of the Wildcats' basketball program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. David Roselle, the president of the university, said the contract for Newton, 58, is for five years with an annual salary of slightly more than $100,000. Newton recently coached the 500th victory of his career, which includes jobs at Transylvania (1956-68) and Alabama (1969-80). (AP)

title: Willie Wells, 82, Dies; Star in Negro Leagues
description: Willie Wells, a shortstop who batted .358 over his career in the Negro leagues from 1924-45 but never played in the major leagues, died last Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: Salvador Balks at Rebels' Voting Plan
description: After the Salvadoran rebels presented a proposal that they said would lead to their participation in elections for the first time in a decade, senior officials in the Government and ruling party today tentatively rejected the key point.

title: 6.2% Yield Is Set For Iowa Notes
description: Iowa yesterday tentatively priced $100 million of tax and revenue anticipation notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.

title: Independence Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Adaptec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 23
One More Time, Islanders Find the Devils Too Much to Handle
description: The Islanders harbor an avid dislike of the Devils, the team that soured their first-place divisional finish last spring by shoving them into a first-round playoff exit. The Islanders believe the Devils stole their confidence back in April, and all the while they sank into last place in the league this season, they held a special grudge.

title: 3 Rescued From Mine That Collapsed in Peru
description: Rescuers found three buried miners alive today and heard faint tapping inside a dilapidated gold mine where as many as 200 men were trapped in a cave-in, officials said.

title: Corning Glass Works reports earnings for 12wks to Jan 1
description: b-Included tax benefits of $200,000 and $2,200,000 for the 12 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively, and the 52 weeks also included a charge of $83,900,000. c-Included tax benefits of $2,400,000 for the 12 weeks and $4,200,000 for the 53 weeks, and the 53 weeks also included a credit of $14,200,000 for an accounting adjustment. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 17, 1989. The company said in the year-ago periods certain amounts have been reclassified for comparative purposes. The company also said the major events in 1988 were a charge of $83.9 million to reflect an accounting change related to future health-care benefits for current retirees, a charge of $19.1 million to previously established restructuring reserves, a gain of $58 million related to an initial public offering of shares of Iwaki Glass Co. in Japan, a gain of $6.1 million related to the formation of Corning Asahi Video Products Co., and a $12.1 million gain from the sale of shares in International Clinical Laboratories. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Cilcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: The Pop Life
description: Music and Movies It wasn't so long ago that the movies ''Fame,'' ''Flashdance'' and ''Footloose'' were being touted as harbingers of a revival of the movie musical built around peppy pop-rock music and music videos. Since the genre still has not fully established itself, a lot is riding on the reception given to ''Sing,'' a contemporary movie musical set in Brooklyn that is to open in theaters on March 3.

title: George Knudson, Pro Golfer, 51
description: George Knudson, whom Ben Hogan once described as having the sweetest swing in professional golf, died of cancer today. He was 51 years old. Knudson, Canada's outstanding pro golfer of the 1960's and 70's, had been undergoing treatment for lung cancer since June 1987.

title: New Con Ed President In Line to Run Utility
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York yesterday named Eugene R. McGrath president and chief operating officer, putting him in position to become the utility's next chief executive.

title: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $5,032,000 from the repurchase of debentures. c-Included an extraordinary gain of $4,357,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Rohm & Haas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trading Black Tie and Tray For White Tie and Spotlight
description: Peter Stewart put on a white jacket and black tie last Thursday to serve lunch for 150 guests in the Seventh Regiment Armory. On Sunday, he will get into white tie and tails to make his New York recital debut, singing works by Debussy, Tchaikovsky and Stephen Foster at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Beans, Old or New, Win Fans Among Chefs and Nutritionists
description: ALTHOUGH people don't usually rhapsodize at cocktail parties about great bean dishes they have enjoyed lately, that is beginning to change. As new varieties of dried beans arrive on the market, and research unveils ever greater nutritional properties, beans are finding passionate advocates among culinarians.

title: Review/Music; Anniversary Flute Recital
description: John Solum's flute-playing, teaching, concert-organizing and recording have spanned more than three decades, and to celebrate the 30th anniversary of his New York recital debut, he came to Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: Schottenheimer Named Coach of Chiefs
description: Marty Schottenheimer, whose Cleveland Browns teams compiled an impressive record of 46 victories and 31 defeats with four trips to the playoffs in four and a half seasons, was named yesterday to succeed Frank Gansz as coach of the Kansas City Chiefs. Gansz, who was dismissed Jan. 5, won only four games in each of his two seasons with the Chiefs. Schottenheimer, 45, resigned earlier this month rather than replace himself with an offensive coordinator.(AP)

title: Jury Questions Capital Mayor
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. appeared today for the second time before a Federal grand jury investigating his ties to a drug suspect, but his lawyer stressed again that Mr. Barry was not a target of the inquiry. Federal officials refused to comment on Mr. Barry's appearances, but have said before that they are trying to determine if the Mayor thwarted a police drug investigation last month.

title: Trump to Close a 'Tacky' Trader Vic's
description: Trader Vic's, the Polynesian bar in the Plaza that has played host to generations of moneyed gadabouts, prep school students on R&R and fans of its Samoan Fog Cutters, has ''gotten tacky'' and will be closed, the hotel's owner, Donald J. Trump, said yesterday.

title: Five-Year Drive Raises $60 Million for Culver
description: Culver Military Academy and Culver Girls Academy have raised a record $60 million in a five-year campaign, academy officials in Culver, Ind., have announced.

title: Knicks Hand Lakers Their First Home Loss
description: Patrick Ewing walked around the hotel today telling everyone, ''I want to return the Lakers the favor.''

title: Short-Story Readings
description: ''Selected Shorts: A Celebration of the Short Story'' is to begin its fifth season at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, at 6:30 P.M. tonight. The program features Irene Worth, Estelle Parsons and Charles Keating reading stories by Chekhov, Flannery O'Connor and Robertson Davies. Information: 864-1414.

title: Shell Canada Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its record 1988 earnings were largely due to the performance of its chemicals segment which had earnings of $237 million for 1988, compared to $107 million in 1987. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Formula One to Phoenix
description: Phoenix's first Formula One Grand Prix auto race will be run June 2-4 through the downtown area, officials announced today.

title: EASE SOVIET TRADE, SHULTZ ADVOCATED IN THE FINAL DAYS
description: In one of his final acts as Secretary of State, George P. Shultz argued that the United States should in effect reward the Soviet Union for a timely withdrawal from Afghanistan by easing trade controls imposed when Soviet forces swept into the country, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Deposit-Fee Option Studied
description: To resolve the crisis in the savings industry, the Treasury Department is considering charging a fee on deposits at insured institutions, a Congressional aide said today.

title: Kidnapping Victim Found Slain in Jersey
description: A 58-year-old warehouse supervisor was kidnapped while driving to work Monday morning and later slain, even though his wife left $25,000 in ransom in the parking lot of a diner here as demanded, the authorities said.

title: Books of The Times; Exploring the South, or Rednecks Reconsidered
description: A Turn in the South By V. S. Naipaul 307 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Washington Trust Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
James F. Collins, Is Dead at 85; General Headed Red Cross in War
description: James F. Collins, a four-star general in the United States Army who in retirement served as president of the American Red Cross in the Vietnam War, died of prostate cancer on Sunday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 83 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: First Financial Management Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Greenspan's Inflation Stance Spurs a Rally in the Dollar
description: The dollar rose yesterday, spurred by strong anti-inflation comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and the absence of dollar-selling by central banks.

title: Syracuse Beats Boston College, 72-60
description: Sherman Douglas scored 19 points as 14th-ranked Syracuse snapped a three-game Big East Conference Closing streak tonight by defeating Boston College, 72-60.

title: KEY RATES
HBO & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $5,884,000 net pretax gain on the disposition and writedown of investments for both the quarter and year, and the company said $3.7 million of the year pretax gain of $5,884,000 was contributed the company's reported net income for the year.

title: Gallagher, Arthur J & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Woman Wins Approval To Be Episcopal Bishop
description: The last barrier to the consecration of a woman as a bishop in the Episcopal Church fell yesterday when the Diocese of Massachusetts announced that its choice of the Rev. Barbara C. Harris had been approved by a majority of the 118 bishops heading dioceses around the country.

title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $12,715,000 for the quarter and $79,751,000 for the year. c-Net loss and included pre-tax restructuring charges of $46,721,000 for the quarter and $48,607,000 for the year; the quarter also included an extraordinary charge of $8,747,000 and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $31,847,000 and a loss of $149.7 million from cumulative effect of accounting change. The latest fourth quarter and year results included an investment tax credit refund of $14,026,000.

title: Europe Unity By '92 Doubted
description: A leading American accounting firm said today that it was doubtful the European Community could achieve a single capital market by 1992.

title: Audiovox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Franklin Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago revenue restated to reflect consolidation of previously unconsolidated subsidiaries.

title: Borden Chemicals & Plastics LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent units. The company began operations on Nov. 30, 1987.

title: A Victorian Relic, Flogging, Arouses New Distaste
description: Eight times last year, petty criminals were led into a bare room in the old Lai Chi Kok Prison where, stripped naked from the waist down, their hands and feet bound, they were forced to bend over a thick leather bar as they were beaten by a prison guard using a long rattan cane.

title: GREENSPAN CALLS INFLATION TOO HIGH AND VOWS ACTION
description: In an unusually direct statement, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the nation's inflation rate was unacceptably high and that he would seek to reduce it.

title: Congress Would Vote Funds for More Refugees; They Needn't Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: From a California Lab, a French Delicacy
description: LEAD: FOR what is believed to be the first time, one of the most coveted delicacies in the world - the Perigord black truffle - has been successfully grown in a laboratory. Two former University of California professors, Dr. Moshe Shifrine and Dr. Randy Dorian, have used their backgrounds in microbiology and cell biology to reproduce the elusive fungus also known as

title: Western Digital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from a tax credit of $103,000 and $263,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A World I Never Made
description: LEAD: Since I'm 95 years old, it may be that ''you can't teach an old dog new tricks,'' but I'm just not comfortable with new appliances. They make me nervous and seem to know I'm a square. They never work for me.

title: Sonoco Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Contraceptives Crucial in Fighting Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: CRS Sirrine Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net in the year- ago 6 months included a gain of $6,924,000, or $1.10 a share, on termination of a retirement plan.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: STATE park rangers here are adding grist to the mill. Real grist. Real mill.

title: Sun Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest and year-ago quarters are after after-tax charges of $17 million and $15 million, respectively, related to provisions for employee terminations and other matters. Sun Co. said the 1988 fourth-quarter results outside North America included a $6 million one-time after-tax benefit relating to Sun's interest in the Balmoral Field located in the United Kingdom sector of the North Sea. In the 1988 second quarter, Sun recognized a $297 million after-tax charge for the writedown of assets intended for sale and the cost of anticipated employee terminations, office closings and other matters.

title: Correction
description: A recipe with the Eating Well column in The Living Section last Wednesday, for halibut and turnips, misstated the amount of lemon juice. The correct amount is the juice of half a lemon.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Much-Deserved Honor
description: In an unusual mark of bipartisan esteem, Connie Gerrard, one of the capital's political long-distance runners who worked as a press assistant in the White House for 25 years, serving five Presidents, will be honored at a party at the Ritz Carlton Hotel Friday night by the 12 White House press secretaries for whom she worked. She turned in her White House pass on Friday, the last day of the Reagan Presidency. ''I think it's time I took a rest,'' said Miss Gerrard, who has had a number of job offers but first plans to do some traveling.

title: Review/Television; A Comedy Special Without the Bile
description: There is something different about a comedy special currently on the schedule of Showtime, the pay-cable service. ''The Comedy and Magic Club's 10th Anniversary Special'' is downright affable. While audiences might still be reeling from the poisonous spleen of Sam Kinison or the hate rallies of Andrew Dice Clay, along comes a batch of stand-up comics who seem quite willing to be amiable. The hourlong program can be seen on Showtime at 8 P.M. today.

title: Leaving Miami, Wilson Gets in Touch With the Bengals
description: Stanley Wilson, the Cincinnati Bengal running back who had been missing since Saturday when he was discovered having just used cocaine, phoned the Bengals at 10:30 this morning from a hotel here. He said he was with his parents and was leaving for the Miami Airport, said John Murdough, a Bengal business consultant.

title: Loral Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Surprise for Mullen
description: The phone in Brian Mullen's Edmonton hotel room rang at 9 A.M. yesterday, which struck the left wing for the Rangers as curious. Michel Bergeron, his coach, was on the other end asking him whether he had heard the news, which struck Mullen as downright ominous. ''He thought he'd been traded,'' Bergeron said of Mullen. However, the coach was there to tell Mullen that he was to plan on returning to Edmonton for next month's National Hockey League All-Star Game. Mullen, who has 22 goals this season, was named to the Wales Conference team by Terry O'Reilly, the coach of the Boston Bruins. O'Reilly also selected John MacLean of the Devils (28 goals) as a right wing and Pat LaFontaine (27 goals) of the Islanders as a center for the Feb. 7 game.

title: Mutual Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Profits Off At 3 Big Oil Companies
description: Three major oil companies yesterday reported lower fourth-quarter profits, principally because of lower crude oil prices, the companies said.

title: Officer Is Suspended From Force In Off-Duty Killing of a Motorist
description: A New York City police officer was suspended without pay yesterday after he shot and killed a 62-year-old Brooklyn man Monday evening during a traffic dispute while he was off duty.

title: Raleigh Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bush Will Stand By Nominee To Health Post, Officials Say
description: White House officials and leading Republican lawmakers expressed confidence today that Dr. Louis W. Sullivan would remain President Bush's choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services and would be confirmed by the Senate, despite his latest collision with the President's views on abortion policy.

title: First Federal Savings Bank of Alabama reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $8,000 from the sale of mortgage- backed securities and a $53,000 after- tax charge relating to an accounting change. c-Included an after-tax gain of about $180,000 on the sale of mortgage-backed securities.

title: Brady Voices Concern Over Takeover Debts
description: Saying that he and President Bush had a ''gnawing feeling'' about the surge of corporate takeovers, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that he was studying ways to curb the use of high-yield ''junk bonds'' to finance such deals.

title: Domestic Vehicle Sales Decline 11.5%
description: Sales of new domestic cars and light trucks fell 11.5 percent in mid-January from a year earlier, the seven domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Bundy Is Put to Death in Florida After Admitting Trail of Killings
description: Theodore Bundy, among the most notorious killers in recent times, was electrocuted today, and about 200 people gathered outside the entrance of the Florida State Prison cheered when they heard the news.

title: Roosevelt Financial Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $42,000 for the quarter and $4,940,000 for the year.

title: California Financial Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
At the Nation's Table
description: LOW in fiber and high in saturated fat, the chef's special each Thursday night at the Wayside Restaurant here is an old-timer's dream and a nutritionist's nightmare. The special, salt pork and milk gravy, is a traditional New England supper that fans say can be found at no other restaurant in the area.

title: Goldin Requests Inquiry on Shift In S.R.O. Law
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, called yesterday for an independent investigation to determine how a city law was changed to allow the developer Harry Macklowe to start building a midtown hotel two years early.

title: Northern Telecom Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Japanese Cabinet Approves Budget Rise for Foreign Aid
description: Japan's Cabinet approved a budget today that increases spending on foreign aid even more than a draft made public last week.

title: '89 Milk Output Forecast
description: Last year's drought is still having a lingering effect on the nation's dairy farmers, but an Agriculture Department report said on Monday that 1989 milk output could still set another record. Production rose to a record 145.3 billion pounds in 1988 because of an increase of almost 3 percent in milk output per cow. The number of cows declined by 1 percent, to an average of 10.2 million head.

title: Heritage Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The fourth quarter results included a full write-down of $3.7 million investment in Cosine, a company formed to develop computer software to meet the data-processing needs of Heritage and other financial institutions.

title: Bridge
description: On most bridge deals, a good player can inspect a 52-card diagram and decide with reasonable assurance whether a given contract will succeed with the best play by both sides. But his verdict may be wrong. How would you rate South's chances of success in five clubs doubled?

title: In China, Black Isn't Beautiful
description: LEAD: The attack on African students in Nanjing, one in a series of such incidents on China's campuses in recent years, makes me feel ashamed of my countrymen. After the brawl, thousands of demonstrators chanted, ''Beat the blacks!'' The incident triggered racial confrontations in several other cities.

title: American Savings Financial of Washington reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' losses included $2.4 million writedown of its only residual interest of a collateralized mortgage obligation security investment and a $687,000 addition to Amercian Savings' loan loss reserve.

title: City Mark for Anderson
description: Kenny Anderson, considered the nation's best high school player, scored 40 points yesterday and became New York City's top-scoring schoolboy player ever. In leading Archbishop Molloy to a 73-61 victory over Xaverian in Brooklyn, Anderson raised his career point total to 2,377. Anderson, a 6-foot-2-inch guard who will attend Georgia Tech next season, entered the game needing 15 points to break the record of 2,351 set by Duane Ivory of Our Savior Lutheran in the Bronx from 1982 through '86.

title: Review/Dance; Adding a Theater Role
description: Michele Elliman combined acting with dancing in two examples of dance-theater on Sunday night at the Vital Arts Center.

title: Freeport McMoran Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ball Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $17,800,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter is after a pretax provision of $30 million ($18.6 million, or 80 cents a share after taxes), largely representing the company's previously announced decision to exit the blow molded portion of the plastic container business and from the writeoff of certain packaging products equipment removed from service as part of plant modernization programs. Before this provision, net from operations for the latest quarter was $7.2 million, or 31 cents a share. Prior year results have been restated as required by the SEC to restate the 1987 gain recognized from the sale of the company's Commercial Glass business to Ball-Incon Glass Packaging Corp. The company said the restated results recognize half the gain in 1987, with the remaining half of the gain initially deferred and amortized over the period benefitted.

title: Vermont U. Surplus Yields a Deficit
description: The University of Vermont is facing an unusual financial problem this year, a deficit caused by a surfeit of Vermont students.

title: Detroit Edison Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After write-offs of $558,746,000 and $624,335,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, of certain of the company's Fermi-2 plant costs disallowed by the Michigan Public Service Commission, and the year also included a charge of $344,147,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for disallowed costs, a gain of $61,367,000 from a change in accounting for unbilled revenue, and a gain of $139,288,000 from a change in accounting for property taxes combined. c-Net income

title: Traders Goading the Policy Makers
description: The fact that the dollar rally this year has been so persistent - and the fact that central bank intervention is finally quelling it - reflects an important change in the $400 billion foreign exchange market.

title: British Troupe Is Bringing Its Plays and Pointers
description: On a gray London afternoon four actors from the Royal National Theater took their places under the cold fluorescent lights of a church auditorium and delivered the opening lines of ''Apart From George,'' one of the two plays they are taking to theaters and college campuses in the United States.

title: Lessons
description: With the exception of entertainment, it is hard to think of a field in which the United States dominates the world market more than it does in higher education. Yet the system is fraught with contradictions.

title: S.E.C. Proposal To Congress
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sent to Congress a legislative package that would expand the Federal agency's enforcement powers.

title: Winfield, Steinbrenner Agree to an Arbitrator
description: Michael Armstrong, a prominent New York attorney and baseball fan, said yesterday that he had agreed to arbitrate the dispute between Dave Winfield, the Yankee outfielder, and George Steinbrenner over the Winfield Foundation.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Toshiba Unit Starts Making Telephones
description: The Toshiba Corporation said it had begun assembling cellular car telephones in the United States. A Toshiba spokesman said that the company's Toshiba America Inc. subsidiary began production last week at its plant in Irvine, Calif., which assembles 10,000 to 12,000 mobile telephones a month, using Japanese components. Toshiba makes the telephones for the Audiovox Corporation of Hauppauge, L.I. Audiovox markets the telephones, which retail for about $1,000 each, under its name. Toshiba had shipped the telephones fully assembled from Japan.

title: Business May Cut Back, but Not on Its Private Jets
description: Despite the focus on belt tightening at many companies, the business jet is becoming more popular than ever.

title: Cliburn Plans Concert, His First in 10 Years
description: Van Cliburn plans to perform with the Philadelphia Orchestra on June 19 in his first major concert in more than a decade.

title: Commerce Choice Vows To Work With Industry
description: Robert A. Mosbacher, President Bush's nominee to become Commerce Secretary, said today that he would seek closer cooperation between government and industry, possibly through the relaxation of antitrust laws, to help American manufacturers compete more effectively in the global market for high technology.

title: Employee Is Said to Detail German Link to Plant

Under an agreement with the N.J. Transit board of directors, the board will not seek any court action against Mr. Premo. The assistant commissioner of N.J. Transit, Roger E. Nutt, has been appointed acting executive director. Mr. Premo was fined $16,250 seven months ago for improperly charging more than $12,000 in personal expenses on a transit authority credit card.

RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals 4, Kings 4: Scott Stevens and Dave Christian scored in the final 49 seconds of regulation last night as Washington overcame a three-goal deficit in the final 13 minutes 22 seconds for the tie at Landover, Md. With Washington behind by 4-3, Larry Murphy stopped a clearing pass by the Kings' goalie, Glenn Healy, behind the Los Angeles goal and centered the puck to Christian, who put a wrist shot just inside the right post with five seconds remaining for the tie. Washington had pulled to within a goal on a power-play goal by Stevens, who fired a slapshot past Healy. The puck rolled into the corner of the net with 49 seconds remaining. The Capitals, who trailed, 4-1, after two periods, began their comeback with a power-play goal by Mike Millar at 6:38 of the final period. Washington had two shots in the extra period, but the best scoring chance came when the Kings' Luc Robitaille hit the post with a slapshot with 40 seconds left. Los Angeles had taken a 4-1 lead on goals by Mike Krushelnyski, Robitaille and John Tonelli in a 2:46 span in the second. Wayne Gretzky assisted on the Kings' second and fourth goals. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Maryland 86, Virginia 73: Maryland won its sixth consecutive game as Christy Winters scored 25 points last night to lead the seventh-ranked Terrapins over No. 15 Virginia in an Atlantic Coast Conference game. Deanna Tate scored 24 points and had 12 assists, and Vicky Bullett added another 16 points for Maryland, which shot 55 percent from the field playing at home. The victory improved the Terrapins' record to 14-2 over all and 5-1 in the conference. Virginia, 13-5 and 3-3, had a 41-38 lead at halftime, but the Terrapins began the second half by scoring 6 straight points to go ahead, 44-41. They never relinquished the lead. Virginia led by 11 at the 2:23 mark in the first half. Maryland closed the gap to 9 by halftime. Virginia's Tonya Cardoza and Dawn Staley scored 20 points apiece.(AP) North Carolina St. 86, North Carolina 69Andrea Stinson scored 27 points to lead No. 13 North Carolina State to the Atlantic Coast Conference victory at North Carolina last night. The Wolfpack, who shot 53.6 percent from the field, improved to 14-2 and 7-0 in the A.C.C. North Carolina (9-9, 1-4) was without Coach Sylvia Hatchell, who missed the game because she gave birth to a 10-pound, 8-ounce boy yesterday afternoon. With the score tied at 25, Stinson sparked an 8-0 run with an assist to Krista Kilburn and three consecutive field goals. Merlaine Oden led North Carolina with 18 points and 13 rebounds.(AP)

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Inflation is unacceptably high, Alan Greenspan said, raising the possibility of higher short-term rates. The markets responded favorably to his anti-inflation stance. [ Page A1. ] Criminal charges against Drexel Burnham Lambert were filed by the Government. The details indicate a broader range of illegal activities than had been disclosed. [ A1. ] Treasury Secretary Brady said he was studying ways to curb the use of high-yield ''junk bonds.'' [ D1. ] Currency traders usually anticipate market moves by watching economic indicators. Now they want to know what policy makers hope for. News Analysis. [ D1. ] The dollar rose, helped by the absence of dollar-selling by central banks. [ D15. ] The Big Three auto makers urged the U.S. to impose a 25 percent tariff on imported sport-utility vehicles and mini-vans. [ D4. ] Car and light-truck sales fell 11.5 percent in mid-January. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S. should reward Moscow by easing controls on trade, George Shultz has argued. [ A1. ] The head of Japan's Economic Planning Agency resigned after admitting that he accepted a large political donation from the company at the heart of a scandal over stock dealings. [ A3. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average regained all the ground it lost in the October 1987 market crash. The Dow soared 38.04 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at 2,256.43. [ D1. ] Treasury notes and bond prices rose again, as market participants reacted positively to comments by Alan Greenspan. [ D17. ] Subpoenas were served on more than 100 clearing firms on Chicago's commodity exchanges. [ D1. ] Coffee futures prices fell sharply in anticipation of a greater supply from Brazil. Soybeans and corn rose. [ D15. ] COMPANIES Exxon reported an 11.3 percent drop in earnings for the fourth quarter, Mobil reported a 1.1 percent decline and Chevron a 25.2 percent decline. [ D1. ] Morgan Stanley's earnings soared for the quarter, to $108.3 million. Shearson Lehman Hutton lost $13.5 million. [ D2. ] Pacific Telesis's earnings rose 66 percent in the fourth quarter. Southwestern Bell and BellSouth also reported gains. [ D5. ] Porsche's income fell 27.2 percent in 1987-88, as U.S. sales plunged 51 percent. Fiat reported strong gains. [ D4. ] A Federal appeals board denied Honeywell's protest of the Air Force's award of a $4.5 billion contract to A.T.&T. [ D1. ] American Healthcare Management's board endorsed a buyout offer of about $311 million in cash and securities. [ D4. ] Ransburg agreed to be acquired by Illinois Tool Works, in a deal valued at $163 million. [ D4 ] TECHNOLOGY A use has finally been found for the world's brightest light, developed in 1980. It can be a heat source for manufacturing. [ D7. ] An electronic kazoo has emerged from - where else? - Silicon Valley. It can simulate blues guitar or classical violin. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Why does altruism coexist with selfishness? A Cornell economist offers an explanation. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Another closed-end fund has come under the gun. An investor group owns 10.82 percent of Cypress Fund. Market Place. [ D8. ] Mother Jones magazine has gone post-revolutionary and has been redesigned. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: 'Enduring Love'
description: The beginning is simple to mark. We were in sunlight under a turkey oak, partly protected from a strong, gusty wind. I was kneeling on the grass with a corkscrew in my hand, and Clarissa was passing me the bottle--a 1987 Daumas Gassac. This was the moment, this was the pinprick on the time map: I was stretching out my hand, and as the cool neck and the black foil touched my palm, we heard a man's shout. We turned to look across the field and saw the danger. Next thing, I was running toward it. The transformation was absolute: I don't recall dropping the corkscrew, or getting to my feet, or making a decision, or hearing the caution Clarissa called after me. What idiocy, to be racing into this story and its labyrinths, sprinting away from our happiness among the fresh spring grasses by the oak. There was the shout again, and a child's cry, enfeebled by the wind that roared in the tall trees along the hedgerows. I ran faster. And there, suddenly, from different points around the field, four other men were converging on the scene, running like me.

Art Shell, an offensive tackle for the Oakland and Los Angeles Raiders, and Willie Wood, a defensive back and punt-return specialist for the Green Bay Packers during the 1960's, were also selected.

title: Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $33,400,000 for the quarter, and the year included a loss of $193,200,000 from discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $32,700,000 and $133,600,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income The company said the combined effect of the pipeline gain and an 11 percent increase in operating income in the latest quarter more than offset an increase of $114,900,000 in interest expense which was related primarily to the company's restructuring.

title: Radionics Agrees To Be Acquired
description: Radionics Inc. reached an agreement with Expamet International P.L.C. under which the London-based company will begin a tender offer of $20 a share, or about $88 million, for the security equipment maker. Radionics' shares rose $6.125 today, to $19.625, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Agreement on Drug Testing
description: Olympic officials of East Germany and the United States have agreed to develop a joint anti-drug program, similar to the one being put together by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Curtice-Burns Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 23
Hahn's Ex-Boss Pleads Guilty
