description: A Long Island minister, facing the prospect of damaging testimony from Jessica Hahn, his secretary who became embroiled in the downfall of Jim Bakker, the television evangelist, pleaded guilty today to reduced charges before his tax-evasion trial could begin. The Rev. Eugene Profeta's plea to two of 18 state charges came before Miss Hahn was to testify in a pretrial hearing. Mr. Profeta admitted asking Miss Hahn to lie to grand jurors investigating his financial dealings. He is to be sentenced to six months in jail, fined $5,000 and forced to pay $13,000 in back taxes.

title: Amerada Hess Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $30,314,000 for both the quarter and year for capitalized exploration expenses related to certain properties for which the company has no current development plans. c-Net loss d-Included non-recurring income of $73,017,000 for both the quarter and year resulting primarily from reductions in foreign taxes. The company said latest quarter refining and marketing earnings were $90,800,000, compared with a loss of $195,800,000 in the fourth quarter of 1987. That loss primarily reflects writedowns of crude oil and refined product inventory values. Revenue represent total revenue.

title: Koch Imposes 2-Month Hiring Freeze
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it will impose a two-month partial hiring freeze and warned that New York City would face its toughest budget in this decade if the state spending plan proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is adopted.

title: Airport Staff Makes a Gift To Neediest
description: The plight of men and women who use the terminals at Kennedy International Airport as their homes has deeply troubled a group of airline employees.

title: Lake Sunapee Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tougher Airline Security Steps Debated
description: One month after a bomb destroyed a Pan American jetliner flying to New York from London, international aviation agencies and airlines are debating how broadly to apply new security measures aimed at preventing criminal attacks against passenger planes.

title: Earnings Up 32% at Merck
description: Merck & Company, the nation's leading pharmaceutical concern, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings increased 32 percent, to $307.3 million.

title: 38.04 Surge Puts Dow At 2,256.43
description: LEAD: The stock market stormed higher yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average finally regained all the ground it lost in the October 1987 market crash.

title: Illinois Central Transportation Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $61.3 million from a change in accounting. All figures are for the company as a subsidiary of Whitman Corp. because the company went public in a spinoff on Jan. 3.

title: Statoil Plans Job Cuts
description: Norway's state-owned oil company, Statoil S.A., the nation's largest concern, said today that it planned to shed jobs over three years to cut costs. Statoil has been hit hard by lower crude prices and by cost overruns at a refinery project in western Norway.

title: Siberia-to-Alaska Ski Trip Planned by U.S.-Soviet Team
description: In one of the more unusual sidelights to the improvement in Soviet-American relations, Eskimos and explorers from the two countries plan a trek across the ice in the Bering Strait from Siberia to Alaska this year, the first time such a trip is known to have been attempted on skis since 1914.

title: Big East Suspensions
description: When Jayson Williams, the high-scoring center for St. John's, and John Turner, Georgetown's rugged forward, were ejected for fighting in a game Monday night, Connecticut and Seton Hall got the best of it. Under Big East rules, each player will be suspended for his team's next conference game. That means Williams will miss the St. John's game with Connecticut Saturday and Turner will be absent from the Georgetown-Seton Hall game next Wednesday.

title: Helicopter Crash Kills Two
description: A helicopter clipped power lines and crashed in flame Sunday in a remote area near former President Ronald Reagan's ranch, killing the two people aboard, the authorities said. The crashed occurred about eight miles from Mr. Reagan's ranch, said Deputy Don Friedley of the Santa Barbara County Sheriff's Department.

title: Imperial Oil Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $29 million on the sale of a subsidiary for the quarter and year. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.N. Chief Offers Proposal for Namibia Force
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar proposed cuts today in the size and cost of the peacekeeping force that the United Nations will send to Namibia this year to oversee its independence from South Africa.

title: Secret Magnet Sweeps Top 40 Science Prizes
description: PROJECT TITLE

title: Carl F. Jellinghaus, Editor, 71
description: Carl F. Jellinghaus, a retired executive editor of The Record newspaper in Hackensack, N.J., died of congestive heart failure yesterday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Ahmanson, H F & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains from sales of loans and mortgage-backed securities of $2.4 million, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and $20.9 million, or 21 cents a share for the year. c-Included gains from sales of loans and mortgage-backed securities of $13.7 million, or 14 cents a share for the quarter and the year included $85.8 million, or 87 cents a share. Effective Jan. 1, the company prospectively adopted FASB 96 accounting for income taxes. The cumulative effect of this change reduced 1988 net earnings by $857,000, or 1 cent a share. Restatement of the prior quarter and year earnings for FASB 91 accounting change increased 1987 earnings by $1.03 million, or 1 cent per share and $13.1 million, or 13 cents per share, respectively. Earnings for 1987 reduced by $16.5 million, or 17 cents per share, from write-off of company's $24 million investment in FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Mobil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $21,000,000 and $56,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $82,000,000 and $130,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said changes in U.S. and significant foreign income tax rates benefited income by $37,000,000, compared with a negative impace of $15,000,000 in the fourth quarter of 1987. It said the latest quarter benefit resulted from a reduction in Japanese income tax rates.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apogee Enterprises Inc., Minneapolis, a maker of windows and other glass products, named Gerald K. Anderson president, succeeding Donald W. Goldfus, who continues as chairman and chief executive.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Was Quayle President?
description: Was Dan Quayle Acting President of the United States for three and a half minutes last Friday afternoon? Authorities who believe he was, including officials of the Senate Rules Committee, cite Article II, Section 1 of the Constitution, which provides, regarding the President, that ''before he enter on the execution of his office, he shall take the following oath or affirmation.'' On the Capitol steps, Mr. Quayle had taken his oath as Vice President and automatically assumed that office when Vice President George Bush's term expired at noon on Jan. 20, pursuant to the 20th Amendment.

title: Mid Maine Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the decrease in earnings is primarily due to net securities losses of $475,864 in 1988, compared with net securities gains of $872,745 in 1987.

title: Polaroid Board Spurns Offer
description: The Polaroid Corporation today rejected a sweetened $3.2 billion bid from Roy E. Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc., calling it inadequate and not in the best interests of shareholders, but Shamrock immediately said it would pursue its offer for the instant-camera company.

title: U.S. Said to Back Bonn Curbs On Chemical Trade to Libya
description: A top Administration official told Congress today that the United States was satisfied with Bonn's recent efforts to stop West German companies from providing Libya with the equipment and expertise to make chemical weapons.

title: Court Doesn't Bar Affirmative Action, But Holds Plans to a Stringent Test
description: In declaring unconstitutional the effort by Richmond to increase opportunities for blacks in the construction industry, the Supreme Court did not declare an end to government-sponsored affirmative action programs.

title: Jennifer Convertibles reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The results included the operations of two New York stores acquired in August 1988, as if these stores had been acquired in August 1987.

title: BMC Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: The caption of a picture from The Associated Press on Dec. 12 showing Benazir Bhutto as she voted in the Pakistani election misidentified the woman with her. The woman was the first wife of Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, not Ms. Bhutto's mother.

title: INSIDE
description: New Resignation in Japan

title: Hometown Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $7,000 for the quarter and $72,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $11,000 for the quarter and $49,000 for the year.

title: Credit Cards Back $1 Billion Issue
description: National Credit Card Trust 1989-1 is offering $1 billion of credit-card-backed securities, due in 1994, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Lincoln Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Report Finds Need for Action To Close Gaps Between Races
description: Asserting that the greatness of a nation is measured by its treatment of ''the least among us,'' the National Urban League today implored President Bush to narrow gaps between blacks and whites in poverty, employment, housing and education.

title: Tandy Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,657,000 and $1,876,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included a tax credit of $591,000 and $768,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Jerrico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After a credit of $5,684,000 from an accounting change. The operating net for the ye-a-a 6 6 monthincluded a $1 million charge for litigation settlement.

title: Ransburg Signs Accord
description: The Ransburg Corporation, which makes industrial equipment, said today that it had signed an agreement to be acquired by Illinois Tool Works Inc. in a transaction valued at nearly $163 million.

title: Freeport McMoran Resources Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Browning-Ferris Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Porsche's Income Falls 27.2% As U.S. Sales Drop by Half
description: LEAD: Porsche A.G. today reported a 27.2 percent drop in income in the year ended July 31. The sports car maker said American sales were particularly weak, plunging 51 percent in terms of units sold.

title: New Chairman for Landmarks Panel; David Fenton Michie Todd
description: At the age of 73, David F. M. Todd is about to take a long journey across a short space - from one side of the table at which he has been sitting for four years, as a flintily independent member of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, into the chairman's post.

title: The Macklowe Mess: Still a Mess
description: The Macklowe case reveals a disturbing failure of New York City's government to do its job. The more City Hall attempts to explain how it let Harry Macklowe start building his new midtown hotel two years early, the more embarrassing the matter becomes.

title: At Last, Food for the Starving in Sudan
description: Thousands face death by starvation in the southern Sudan. The Khartoum regime of Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi won't let relief agencies fly in food lest it feed non-Islamic rebels. Until now, Washington scarcely uttered a peep for fear of pushing the Khartoum Government further into Libya's orbit. But even as the United States withholds public criticism, it is finally preparing to move food - indeed may already have done so -from Kenya into Sudanese towns near the border, whatever Khartoum may think. That's welcome progress.

title: Even So, Affirmative Action Lives
description: The Supreme Court has made it harder for states and cities to give minorities an edge in competing for public works contracts that long went only to whites. Harder, yes, but not impossible, for the Court once again has struck down one affirmative action plan while announcing rules by which others may survive.

title: NO VOTE ON RAISE, HOUSE WHIP SAYS
description: A Democratic House leader said today that the House would not vote to halt a proposed 50 percent Congressional pay increase set to take effect automatically at 12:01 A.M. Feb. 8.

title: FHP International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings per share for the latest quarter and 6-month periods were positively affected by the repurchase of 2.5 million shares of common stock in January 1988.

title: Shelton Jones 76er Pact
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have signed Shelton Jones, the former St. John's star, to a contract for the rest of the season. Jones, a rookie forward, had played out two 10-day contracts as the replacement for Cliff Robinson, who may miss the remainder of the season with a knee injury. Jones played in seven games for the 76ers and has scored 22 points.(AP)

title: Bush Confers on the Budget, Suggesting Weekly Meetings
description: President Bush told Congressional leaders from both parties today that he would specify his budget priorities when he addresses Congress on Feb. 9. He suggested weekly bipartisan budget negotiations between the two branches to work out a quick compromise.

title: Citizens Savings Bank of Maryland reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income for 1987 included an after-tax gain of $491,000, or 25 cents a share, on termination of the company's former pension plan and an after- tax expense of $368,000 on the writeoff of the company's FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: AGFA Photo Division Uses McCann-Erickson
description: The photo retail division of AGFA Leverkusen, a unit of Bayer G.m.b.H., based near Dusseldorf, West Germany, has retained McCann-Erickson Worldwide to create its advertising for Western Europe. Several agencies formerly did the ads, which have about a $16 million budget.

title: Choice Near for Pentagon Job
description: Paul D. Wolfowitz, a former senior official in the State Department who is now Ambassador to Indonesia, is expected to be named to a high policy position in the Defense Department, Administration officials said Monday.

title: A Peripatetic President: Election Over, He Runs
description: At 1:30 P.M., the announcement came over the loudspeaker in the White House press room: ''The travel pool should assemble in 10 minutes for a 1:50 movement.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Lacking Garbage, a Jersey Incinerator Is Losing Money
description: Mechanically, Warren County's incinerator has worked just fine since opening here last July. Financially, it has stumbled. Amid a waste-disposal crisis across much of New Jersey, the state's first county incinerator doesn't have enough garbage.

title: Freeport McMoran Copper Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Book Notes
description: Awaiting the Other Shoe

title: Kinark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $5,120,000 for the quarter and $5,348,000 for the year.

title: How to Gain Credibility On Eligibility
description: Sports fans are generally uncomfortable when the real world intrudes on their games, so imagine how they squirmed last week when journalists and talk-show hosts were confronted with the disturbances in Miami, Proposition 42 and the suspension of Stanley Wilson, the Bengal fullback who was found using cocaine in his hotel room on the night before the biggest game of his career.

title: Court Ruling Is a Bitter Irony for Richmond Blacks
description: All things considered, a case might be made that this city no longer qualifies as the capital of the Confederacy, at least not in the old sense.

title: Nets Edge Nuggets To Stop Slide By CLIFTON BROWN
description: The Nets are sick of losing leads and tired of losing games.

title: Fireman's Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $11,659,000 from debt extinguishment costs. c-Included a gain of $61,596,000 from a pension plan termination. The company said the 1987 quarter and year share earnings and average shares outstanding were restated to reflect common stock equivalents.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: ''OFTEN imitated, never duplicated'' boasts the sign at the shop where Irving and Edith Gorsky have been selling pepperoni rolls, a Youngstown favorite, for 18 years. The sandwich is baked daily at the West Gate Deli & Food Carry Out, the Gorskys' small storefront bakery-delicatessen on this city's west side.

title: Martin Marietta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a reserve of $90 million reflecting prospective revenues, costs and demands for launch vehicles relating to the commercial Titan launch program.

title: Lendl Eliminates McEnroe to Reach Semifinal
description: Ivan Lendl, playing almost perfect tennis, beat John McEnroe, 7-6, 6-2, 7-6, today to reach the Australian Open semifinals for the fourth straight time.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose again yesterday as market participants reacted positively to what essentially was a pessimistic outlook from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: South Carolina Federal reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock of $875,000 and is after a tax benefit of $116,000. c-After a tax credit of $84,000. The year-ago quarter's net from operations included a gain on the sale of a branceh office location of $783,000. The per share earnings reflected 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 20, 1989.

title: Union Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its net from discontinued operations in the latest fourth quarter was $31.4 million and $21.4 million in the year-ago fourth quarter. Net from discontinued opertions was $85.2 million for 1988 and $88.1 million for 1987. All 1987 figures were restated for the discontinued operations and to reflect full consolidation of Overnite Transportation Co.

title: John Davidson, 80, Naval Academy Chief
description: John Frederick Davidson, a retired rear admiral who was superintendent of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md., from 1960 to 1962, died Saturday at his home in Annapolis after suffering a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

title: A Ford Chair at Michigan U.
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would endow a professorial chair for the University of Michigan's new program that unites the study of engineering, manufacturing and business.

title: Capital Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: It Takes a Stiff Upper Lip To Love Fish and Chips
description: Fish and chips are to the British what hamburgers and fries are to Americans. So every American who wants to go native will try fish and chips at least once on a visit.

title: RAIDERS SURRENDER AT ARGENTINE BASE
description: Armed civilians holding out at an Argentine infantry barracks surrendered to the army today after a daylong assault in which at least 36 people were killed and scores wounded, the Government said.

title: CNB Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arts Figures in New York Protest Arrest of Czechoslovak Dramatist
description: Responding to the arrest of the Czechoslovak playwright Vaclav Havel, a group of influential figures in the arts in New York staged a program of protest on Monday night.

title: Sunwest Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year net reflected the assimilation costs of two banks in Texas acquired early in the year, as well as a $7.7 million one-time securities gain taken during 1987.

title: Jackson Backs Mayor In the Chicago Primary
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today endorsed Mayor Eugene Sawyer for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: Congress Would Vote Funds for More Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: City Officials Sign Foster-Care Contract
description: New York City said yesterday that it had signed a new contract with private groups that provide foster care for some 20,000 children. The contract is intended to improve placement and assure that the agencies abide by a Federal court decision requiring ''meaningful access'' to birth control.

title: Food Notes
description: Elegant Carryout

title: House in '88 Rated Most Liberal in 40 Years
description: Americans for Democratic Action, the liberal advocacy group, said Monday that the House of Representatives last year had the most liberal record since the organization began rating Congressional voting records in 1947.

title: Acquittal in Slaying of Sergeant
description: A 23-year-old woman has been cleared in the killing of a police sergeant during a raid at her apartment in which a fellow officer fired the fatal shot.

title: A&W Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year included results from Vernors Inc., which was acquired in October 1987.

title: Lloyd Gets Go-Ahead
description: Commissioner Jay Ramsdell reversed an earlier decision yesterday and gave Lewis Lloyd permission to play for Cedar Rapids in the Continental Basketball Association immediately. Ramsdell had refused to admit Lloyd to the league last November, saying that the former Drake guard had not shown over a long period that he had overcome the cocaine problem that brought his ban from the National Basketball Association two years ago. Ramsdell says he is convinced that Lloyd is drug-free and should be given a chance to play professional basketball again. (AP)

title: Germans See 2.5% Growth
description: The West German economy is expected to grow at an inflation-adjusted rate of 2.5 percent this year after rising 3.4 percent in 1988, according to the Government's annual economic report, which was approved by the Cabinet today.

title: Review/Theater; An Aching to Be Hank Williams
description: As ''The Night Hank Williams Died'' moves to its conclusion, a theatergoer may ponder the question of how a play can be so amusing and ultimately so poignant. For the answer, look back at the inspiration: those country music songs that encouraged so many singers and songwriters to fantasize about conquering Nashville.

title: 36,000 Farmers Fail to Seek Restructuring of Debt With U.S.
description: More than 36,000 farmers have failed to meet a deadline for declaring an interest in restructuring overdue debts to the Government, an Agriculture Department official said today.

title: San Diego Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 year results include the effect of a change in accounting to record unbilled revenues.

title: Indonesia Patent Law
description: Indonesia proposed legislation today to protect foreign patents after Washington announced trade sanctions on Thailand last week for refusing to do so. The State Secretary, Major General Moerdiono, said Indonesia's first patent law would include protection of pharmaceutical brand names, one of the more widely pirated items in developing countries.

title: Landmark Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bond Yields at 7.2% to 7.75% For Carolina Power Agency
description: The North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency tentatively priced yesterday $429.55 million of power system revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.75 percent for an issue due in 2012.

title: Corrections
description: A bank earnings listing in Business Day yesterday bore an erroneous company name. The earnings, listed between those of New England Bancorp and Neworld Bancorp, were those of NBB Bancorp of New Bedford, Mass., not NBD Bancorp of Detroit. A corrected version appears in the listing today.

title: About New York; Autism: Illness That Can Steal A Child's Sparkle
description: ''People used to say to me they hoped they had a baby just like mine,'' Sarah said of Eric, her 3-year-old. But a year ago, Eric was found to be autistic. Layers and layers of a barrier that medical science little understands now separate the child from the world, and the world from the child.

title: MAI Basic Move
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. asked a Federal District Court judge to lift an order blocking its $20-a-share bid for Prime Computer Inc. In court documents responding to a judge's concerns, MAI Basic said Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was confident it could raise $875 million to finance the takeover. Prime, based in Natick, Mass., said it would fight to keep the court order in place.

title: Ameron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included non-recurring expenses of about $1.3 million, or 33 cents a share for the quarter and $3 million, or 70 cents a share for the year because of accruals relating to tax adjustments. c-Included a non-recurring expense of about $2.4 million, or 49 cents a share related to restructuring and environmental cleanup costs. d-Included a one-time gain of $4.6 million, or 95 cents a share from the sale of property.

title: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $165 million of pretax, non-recurring merger-related expenses associated with the company's acquisition of E.F. Hutton Group Inc. in January 1988 and a $100 million pretax writedown of MCorp.securities held by the firm. Partially offsetting these charges was the $33 million pretax gain from the sale of Shearson's interest in McLeod Young Weir. Latest-quarter results included $21 million of pretax non-recurring, merger-related costs, primarily for additional bonus compensation being paid to Hutton financial consultants based on commissionable revenue and a $70 million pretax charge from the reduction in the carrying value of MCorp. securities. The year-ago fourth quarter results included the previously disclosed $21 million pretax charge at Balcor Co., a wholly-owned subsidiary, primarily for a revaluation of residual property values; a $30 million pretax addition to Shearson's legal reserves; and a $77 million pretax charge relatd to the underwriting of a British petroleum equity issue. Share earnings assumed full conversion of certain options into common stock when dilutive. The assumed conversion of the preferred stock was not dilutive and therefore not included.

title: Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of about $16 million to reserve for restructuring and costs associated with disposing of discontinued operations in Pactel Communications Cos. c-Included one-time charges for an early retirement program and the restructuring of Pactel Communications. Annual results for 1987 also included the 1986 retroactive effect of the California Public Utilities Commission's December 1987 ruling on Pacific Bell's 1986 rate case. Pacific Telesis said that about 5 cents of the 1987 CPUC reduction of 11 cents was an out-of-period adjustment to reduce 1986 earnings per share. In addition, 1987 balances have been restated to reflect the consolidation of majority-owned subsidiaries previously accounted for under the equity method.

title: American Healthcare Backs $311 Million Bid
description: American Healthcare Management Inc., a hospital company that has been in bankruptcy for nearly two years, said today that its board had endorsed an buyout offer of about $311 million from Bain Capital and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Florida City Offers Revenue Bonds
description: Gainesville, Fla., is tentatively offering $100 million of tax-exempt subordinated utility system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.4 percent for an issue due in 2013, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Harris Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included a gain of $35,085,000 from an accounting change.

title: Louisiana-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the results for both years have been restated to reflect the spinoff of Fibreboard Corp. in June 1988.

title: NBB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 year's per share figure was not applicable; the company went public in March 1987. The year-ago periods' results were restated to reflect an accounting change. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: American Bionetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Kaisertech's Chairman Is Replaced by Maxxam
description: In a surprise move, Kaisertech Ltd.'s new owner, Maxxam Inc., has ousted James S. Pasman as chairman and chief executive.

title: SURVIVORS LEAVING SOVIET QUAKE AREA
description: The authorities began evacuating women and children today from villages in a Soviet Central Asian republic where a mudslide after an earthquake buried parts of three settlements. There was still uncertainty about how many people had died.

title: First American Savings FA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cenvest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Consolidated Edison Co of New York Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rayonier Timberlands LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Jazz at the Y
description: The jazz pianist and composer Dick Hyman is to present Jazz Piano at the Y, two lectures and performances on jazz history and improvisational techniques, at 4 P.M. on Feb. 26 and March 12 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Mr. Hyman, whose compositions include movie scores, piano, chamber and orchestral works, is to be assisted by Derek Smith, a pianist. Tickets for both events are $20; single tickets, $15. Information: 996-1100.

title: Bright Chicago Students Lured to Teaching
description: Fifteen of Chicago's best and brightest high school seniors are being enticed into the teaching profession in a scholarship program under corporate sponsorship.

title: Keith Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Scorecard for the G.O.P. Money Team
description: Though it finally acted mostly to avoid embarrassing President Bush's Commerce Secretary-designate, Robert Mosbacher, the Republican National Committee deserves credit for coming forward with a list of big money donors to the fall campaign. Nonetheless Mr. Mosbacher, who served as Mr. Bush's chief fund-raiser, needs to make fuller disclosure before he is confirmed.

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; Tough Words to Translate: 'Kinder and Gentler'
description: Even as George Bush begins to define his Presidency, a vigorous debate has unfolded around what he meant when he promised a ''kinder, gentler nation.''

title: Midwest Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,863,000 from an accounting change. c-Included a tax credit of $906,000 and $3,746,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Psychiatric Nurse Wins British Literary Prize
description: The first novel by a psychiatric nurse who began writing as a hobby won Britain's biggest literary prize on Tuesday, the Whitbread Book of the Year Award.

title: Valley National Bancorp of New Jersey reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings have been adjusted retroactively to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split distributed to shareholders of record at June 13, 1988. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $250,000 on repayment of indebtedness at a discount for both periods; the quarter also included a loss of $1,855,151 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,100,000 from reversal of a tax credit; the year also included a gain from discontinued operations of $15,260,676. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,006,379 for the quarter; the year included a gain of $4,150,778 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Rebuffs Honeywell On Contract
description: A Federal appeals board yesterday denied a protest by Honeywell Federal Systems Inc. of the Air Force's decision to award a $4.5 billion computer contract to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Cannon Express Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
International Microelectronic Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Improper Test at Savannah River Causes New Accident in Reactor
description: An accident resulted from an improper testing procedure at the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina last weekend, causing several large valves to rupture in the cooling system of a nuclear reactor there, the Department of Energy said today.

title: Mother Jones Settles It: 60's Are Over
description: IN the style of the television show ''Jeopardy,'' today the answer will come first. It is: Susan Sarandon.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our strategy continues to be centered on moving toward, and ultimately reaching, stable prices - that is, price levels sufficiently stable so that expectations of change do not become major factors in key economic decisions. Current inflation rates, by that criterion, clearly are too high and must be brought down.'' - Alan Greenspan. [ A1:6. ]

title: Byelorussia Plans to Build Memorial to Stalin's Victims
description: Authorities in the Soviet republic of Byelorussia have agreed to build a monument to thousands of people shot by Stalin's police in the Kuropaty Forest near Minsk in the 1930's, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: Armor All Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter included results of the rain dance and rally car wash lines acquired from Borden Inc. The impact on earnings of integrating the brands into its product line were slightly dilutive.

title: Market Place; Closed-End Fund Draws a Suitor
description: ANOTHER closed-end fund came under the gun yesterday as an investor group disclosed it had 10.82 percent of the shares in the Cypress Fund and demanded that the fund convert to open-end status. Such a move would immediately raise the value of shares in the fund.

title: Chief Executive Named At Amalgamated Bank
description: Nicholas J. Palermo, a senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has been named president and chief executive of the Amalgamated Bank of New York, a $1.6 billion institution owned by the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union.

title: Gotti Free on Bail After Plea In Shooting of Union Leader
description: After spending a night in jail, John Gotti, the reputed chief of the nation's largest organized-crime group, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he ordered the shooting of an official of a carpenters' union in Manhattan in 1986.

title: Stein Attacked on Campaign-Finance Refusal
description: Representatives of four civic groups criticized City Council President Andrew J. Stein yesterday for declining to participate in a new campaign-financing program that restricts contributions and spending.

title: Gradco Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $216,000 and $660,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $95,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 9 mohths.

title: Scandal Fells Another Japanese Official
description: The head of the Economic Planning Agency resigned today after admitting that he had received a large political donation from the company at the heart of a scandal over insider stock dealings.

title: Amity Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, approved a 2-for-1 split of its common stock.

title: Greek Jurists Protest Attacks
description: Greece's courts came to a standstill today as judicial officials and lawyers began a 10-day strike in protest over recent terrorist attacks against their colleagues.

title: East, West And Design All Mingle
description: THE growing influence of Eastern design on the West and Western design on the East is the subject of an exhibition, ''The Archeology of the Present: East Meets West in Design,'' on view from Sunday through Feb. 3 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Pro-Life? Or Pro-Death?
description: On the President's first day in office, he lost no time in congratulating foes of safe, legal abortion for their extraordinary valor on the part of fetal - if not human - life. In a phone call to anti-abortion demonstrators, President Bush made it absolutely clear that his vision of a gentler America does not include any gentleness for women of childbearing age.

title: Savings Unit Rescue Plan
description: The nation's largest savings and loan trade association proposed a plan on Tuesday that would call on taxpayers to rescue hundreds of insolvent savings institutions. The plan would reduce the long-term cost of the rescue to the healthy segment of the industry.

title: Child Care, as Seen by Children
description: PARENTS often talk about the stress of juggling work and children, of searching for child care that is of high quality but affordable, consistent rather than erratic. But what about the children who are living through the social upheavals taking place? What do they think of the arrangements being made for them?

title: Bush Cautious on Anti-Inflation Steps
description: President Bush cautioned the Federal Reserve Board today against overreacting to the threat of inflation, saying the central bank should not risk curtailing the nation's long economic expansion.

title: Reagan Agrees to Write Memoirs
description: Simon & Schuster announced yesterday that it would publish Ronald Reagan's memoirs and a collection of speeches selected by the former President.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shift at DDB Unit
description: Bernard Rochand, 50 years old, previously chief executive at Eurocom, has been chosen president of DDB Needham International, a Paris-based operation of the DDB Needham Worldwide network. He will replace John Bradstock, 55, who will become corporate executive vice president in charge of global accounts. Alan Pikington, 46, president of DDB Needham's Asia-Pacific region, will add the job of director of corporate planning.

title: Review/Recital; A Piano Prizewinner, 40 Years Later
description: Seymour Lipkin played his way into the forefront of America's young pianists more than 40 years ago when he won the Rachmaninoff Competition, but he subsequently dropped out of the keyboard spotlight to pursue a conducting career and teach. That he has not lost his interest in the piano or his command of the instrument was clear on Tuesday evening at the Juilliard Theater, where he performed in the school's Faculty Recital Series. For all we hear nowadays about the glut of virtuosos, pianism of this quality is by no means common.

title: Dana Agrees to Buy Champion Spark Plug
description: The Dana Corporation, a giant auto parts company, agreed to buy the 82-year-old Champion Spark Plug Company for about $600 million in cash and stock, the companies said today.

title: LFC May Raise Bid for Ransburg
description: One day after the Ransburg Corporation signed an agreement to be acquired by Illinois Tool Works Inc. for $20 a share, or about $163 million, the LFC Financial Corporation said it would consider submitting a higher bid for Ransburg. Frank P. Slattery Jr., president of LFC, described the bidding process for the Indianapolis-based Ransburg as a ''skewed auction'' in a letter to the Ransburg board today. LFC, based in Radnor, Pa., said it had been denied private financial information provided to Illinois Tool that might have been the basis of the $20-a-share bid. LFC offered $18 a share for Ransburg Monday. The Chicago-based Eagle Industries, which bid $18 a share Friday, also did not have access to this information.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Meineke Assignment To Lintas Detroit
description: Meineke Discount Mufflers, known for its ''I'm not gonna pay a lot for this muffler'' campaign, has assigned its $20 million account to Lintas: Campbell-Ewald, Detroit, a unit of Lintas:USA. The agency search began three months ago, initially with some 100 agencies.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Revlon's Mitchum and Lady Mitchum line of anti-perspirants to Sudler & Hennessey, with a seven-figure budget.

title: S.E.C. Sues 2 Brokers Over 'Corner'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused two brokers for Moore & Schley, Cameron & Company yesterday of trying to corner the stock of Chase Medical Group Inc.

title: Steel, Velvet And a Wall In Brooklyn
description: As a young pitcher, Carl Erskine was called little Carl by his Brooklyn Dodger teammates because Carl Furillo was already established in right field. Now little Carl, white-haired and wearing a black tie, stood up by the sprays of flowers near the open casket to give the eulogy at Carl Furillo's funeral service.

title: Economist's Deficit Figure Is Triple Kremlin's
description: A leading official economic adviser said tonight that the real Soviet budget deficit is the equivalent of $165 billion, nearly three times the official estimate, and called the colossal deficit the most important economic problem facing the country.

title: Nathan Jacobs, 83, an Ex-Justice Of the New Jersey Supreme Court
description: Nathan L. Jacobs, a retired associate justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court and an influential figure in court reform in the state, died yesterday at his home in Livingston, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Energy Dept. Says A-Bomb Plant's Safeguards for Workers Are Lax
description: Procedures intended to protect the 15,000 workers who deal with radioactive material at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina are deficient in dozens of areas, the Energy Department said today. The department said weak management and complacent attitudes at Savannah River, which is operated for the agency by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, had resulted in safeguards against radiation exposure that are lax in comparison with those in effect at commercial nuclear power plants, overseen by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Tar Heels Roll Over Wake Forest
description: Kevin Madden and J. R. Reid sparked North Carolina in the opening nine minutes as the seventh-ranked Tar Heels rolled past Wake Forest, 88-74, tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Drexel Expected to Dismiss Milken as Part of a Plea Deal
description: Michael R. Milken, the head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s ''junk bond'' operations, is expected to be dismissed within the next two weeks as part of an agreement between the Government and the firm that was disclosed yesterday.

title: Metro Matters; A Closer Look At the Gorillas Of G.O.P. Finance
description: When you're looking for a job in the Bush Administration or if you're a Republican thinking of running for mayor or governor, it couldn't hurt to have contributed $100,000 or more to the Bush campaign for President.

title: Kean Urges Spending Cuts In Budget Plan
description: Marking the end of six flush years for New Jersey government, Gov. Thomas H. Kean today released a proposed $12.09 billion budget for the next fiscal year that he described as ''tight,'' ''frugal'' and ''bordering on the austere.''

title: HEALTH: Medical Training; A New Specialty in Emergency Care Causing Fierce Debate in Hospitals
description: In a major change over the past 10 years, emergency rooms in many American hospitals have begun to rely on a corps of doctors trained in an entirely new medical speciality: emergency room medicine.

title: CHICAGO EXCHANGE APPOINTS A PANEL TO PRESS CHANGES
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it had appointed a special panel to recommend some of the most extensive changes in its 115 years of trading.

title:
Market Place;
Sluggish Quarter For Bank Funds
description: LEAD: COMMON stock funds administered by banks had a lackluster fourth quarter over all, but for all of 1988 they ran virtually neck and neck with the broad stock market.

title: Rebels Disrupting the Eradication of Coca in Peru
description: A surge of leftist guerrilla activity is bringing new difficulties to a United States-backed campaign to eradicate coca production and break up drug trafficking gangs in Peru's main coca-growing region.

title: Income Flat at Unisys; Apollo, Prime Do Poorly
description: The Unisys Corporation, the nation's third-largest computer maker, said yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter were essentially flat in the face of a year the company called unexpectedly difficult.

title: Texaco Profit Rises Sharply
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had posted a fourth-quarter profit of $296 million, or $1.21 a share, in contrast to a year ago, when the company lost more than $4.6 billion because of the settlement of its lawsuit with the Pennzoil Company and write-offs from a restructuring.

title: Iran Experts Foresee New Policy Stressing Economy
description: The Islamic regime of Iran will end its first decade in power next month with its revolutionary aims severely trimmed, its armed forces spent and its economy in urgent need of revival, according to experts on Iran.

title: Charles C. Hornbostel, Former Track Star, 77
description: Charles C. Hornbostel, a former holder of the world-best time for the 600-yard run indoors and the first full-time president of Financial Executives Institute, died of Parkinson's disease Jan. 13 in New London, N.H. He was 77 years old.

title: Personal Health
description: A child starts learning about sexuality from the first day of life, and parents are the primary source of this education. Each touch, caress, hug, smile and coo tells the infant that he or she is lovable and attractive, knowledge that is the precursor to a healthy ego and normal sexual functioning.

title: Clarence Norris, The Last Survivor of 'Scottsboro Boys', Dies at 76
description: Clarence Norris, the last survivor of the ''Scottsboro Boys'' rape case, which became a symbol of racial injustice in the Deep South in the 1930's, died Monday at Bronx Community Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: SmithKline President Quits Over Differences With Chief
description: The president and chief operating officer of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation abruptly resigned yesterday because of policy differences with the company's chief executive, both men said.

title: Talking Deals; Is Europe Ready for Big Takeovers?
description: Even though the move to put together a consortium bid of up to $14 billion for Britain's General Electric Company collapsed last week, the effort showed that Europe appears ready to follow the United States in making mammoth bids for major corporations previously thought invulnerable.

title: Catchers Are Swapped
description: The San Francisco Giants and the Baltimore Orioles traded starting catchers on Tuesday with the Giants acquiring 32-year-old Terry Kennedy, a left-handed batter with a $850,000 salary in exchange for Bob Melvin, 27, a right-handed batter whose salary last season was $145,000. Yesterday, the Orioles signed Melvin for one year at a salary of about $215,000. Kennedy is a four-time All-Star selection. Melvin split last season between San Francisco and Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League. (AP)

title: Cross-Country Skiing to the Inn
description: Cross-country skiing usually involves traversing trails that go in loops that eventually take skiers back to their starting point. Cross-country skiing can, however, lead to a destination and, even better, to a cozy, country inn that offers a warm fire, a comfortable bed for the night and home-cooked meals.

title: Koch, Citing Rising Burdens, Lays Out Goals
description: In a speech that seemed to herald his campaign for another term, Mayor Edward I. Koch unveiled ambitious responses yesterday to drug addiction, homelessness and other urban ills, although he left doubt about how and when some of them would be put into effect.

title: U.S. Surgical Admits Spying on Animal-Rights Groups
description: The president of a Connecticut surgical-supplies manufacturer, who was the target of a bombing attempt by an animal-rights advocate last November, said yesterday that his company has used paid informers to infiltrate animal-rights organizations since the early 1980's.

title: Brazil Stirred By a Manhunt In the Jungle
description: As dawn filtered into the forest around this jungle village, policemen once again fanned out along rutted roads and trails, trying to solve a murder that has mesmerized Brazil.

title: Review/Dance; Zeromoving's German Expressionism
description: The Zeromoving Dance Company has come a long way. Although, to speak literally, it has come from Philadelphia - which may not seem far at all - the company has covered great distance artistically. Sporadic previous visits to New York have always given dancegoers much to think about. But, on Tuesday night when Zeromoving opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, the troupe revealed that it has gained an authoritative stage presence, making Zeromoving equally good to look at and think about.

title: Joseph B. Ridder, 68, Publisher in San Jose
description: Joseph B. Ridder, the retired publisher and president of The San Jose Mercury News, died of complications from emphysema Monday at Queens Hospital in Honolulu, where he lived. He was 68 years old and also had a home in Saratoga, Calif.

title: President of Lyphomed Seeks to Stop Red Ink
description: Gary E. Nei's job is to restore a once high-flying pharmaceutical company that has been battered by a traumatic year in which everything that could go wrong seems to have done so.

title: Lord Basnett, Union Leader, 64
description: Lord Basnett, a former union leader often blamed by his fellow members of the Labor Party for helping to put Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in power, died today. He was 64 years old.

title: Warren H. Reed, Ex-Executive, Dies at 62
description: Warren H. Reed, a specialist in management training and a retired vice president of Paine Webber, died of AIDS on Sunday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 62 years old and lived in Cherry Grove, L.I.

title: Lilco Rate-Increase Request: Topic for Yet Another Day
description: Avoiding an increasingly volatile question once again, a divided State Public Service Commission voted today to postpone action on a $98 million rate increase request by the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Why Not Sanction Political Killings?
description: LEAD: With the advent of a new Administration, with the memory of the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 still vivid and with our ever present fear of the spread of terrorism, it is time for a reassessment of the current prohibition on political assassination.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Clearing the Air
description: There was a meeting on the Clean Air Act of the House-Senate Environmental and Energy Study Conference yesterday morning in an unventilated room of the Capitol building called E.F. 100. According to a participant, the room was packed and the air became increasingly fetid. Two people fainted.

title: Pilot Unaware Engine Fell Off Until After Landing
description: An airline pilot misunderstood an air traffic controller who told him ''you've lost the engine,'' not realizing it had actually fallen off the plane until he landed safely, a transcript of cockpit conversations shows.

title: Tyson Bid Studied
description: The Holly Farms Corporation indicated it would consider endorsing a sweetened $63.50-a-share offer from Tyson Foods Inc., but it left room for Conagra Inc., a rival bidder, to raise its offer. It was the first indication that Holly's board would consider a deal with Tyson. Tyson's latest offer values the poultry company at about $1.1 billion. Holly Farms stock fell 25 cents a share, to $62, on the New York Stock Exchange. Tyson closed at $15.50 a share, up 37.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Review/Jazz; A New Spin on the Old Sounds of Swing
description: In the late 1930's and early 40's when the big swing bands dominated popular music, the John Kirby Sextet provided a novel contrast to the bands' heavy drives. With its light-voiced front line of alto saxophone, clarinet and trumpet, the Kirby group had a crisp, brisk, tightly arranged approach to swing. It bridged the gap between the boisterous little jazz clubs on 52d Street (the sextet's home base was the Onyx Club) and the hushed mood that was then customary for Sunday-afternoon radio when, joined by Mr. Kirby's wife, Maxine Sullivan, the group broadcast a weekly network program.

title: Appointment in Samarra
description: A democratic nation, like a person with free will, has some control over its destiny. If it denies wrongdoing and flees from moral responsibility, that nation surrenders to Fate's retribution; but if its people are moved to root out corruption, that nation can overcome its past and shape its future.

title: A Place for Children Helps Parents, Too
description: THE story of Kids Place is a story of a community that took on a big-city-style problem, delivering social services to poor families, and solved it in a small-town way, with money raised through piano-bench races and flea markets.

title: Makarova Plans to Dance in Leningrad
description: The ballerina Natalia Makarova, who is making her first visit to the Soviet Union since her defection in 1970, is to perform with her old company, the Kirov Ballet, in Leningrad on Wednesday. The ballerina's first performance with the company since she defected was last Aug. 6 in London. In Leningrad, Miss Makarova is to dance two pas de deux from John Cranko's ''Onegin'' at the Kirov Theater and is expected to dance them again next Thursday.

title: Bush Weighs User Fee on Savings Deposits
description: President Bush said today that his Administration was considering imposing a user fee on depositors at savings and loan associations, commercial banks and credit unions in an effort to raise billions of dollars to solve the nation's savings crisis.

title: Profits at Philip Morris Fell By 28.5% in Fourth Quarter
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter fell 28.5 percent, to $342 million, or $1.48 a share, from $478 million in 1987, or $2.02 a share, as a result of a $348 million pretax charge to cover a restructuring of its General Foods subsidiary.

title: EXPERTS ON BUDGET VOICING OPTIMISM ON GOAL ON DEFICIT
description: Many budget specialists in both parties have concluded that the deficit limit can be met this year without raising taxes, meaning that it is possible for President Bush to maintain his central campaign pledge of ''no new taxes'' for the first year of his term.

title: Koch Proposes Police Academy For South Bronx
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch's plan for a new police academy and a major middle-income housing complex in the South Bronx would be a boon for that beleaguered neighborhood and its Hispanic political constituency, whose support the Mayor wants to retain.

title: Agreement Reached on Indian Museum Shift
description: Negotiators from New York City and the Museum of the American Indian in upper Manhattan said tonight that an agreement had been reached to shift the museum's holdings to the Smithsonian Institution. The Smithsonian would build a new museum on the Mall in Washington and also operate a large adjunct museum at the United States Custom House in lower Manhattan.

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; Bush Begins Perhaps His Toughest Job: Taming Press Corps
description: For the last eight years White House reporters dealt with a President, Ronald Reagan, who spoke to them mostly in two ways: responding to shouted questions, with a grin and a shrug, at picture-taking events, or craning his ear over the sound of a helicopter on the White House lawn.

title: San Antonio Mayor Stands By Decision To Stay Out of Race
description: Mayor Henry Cisneros on Tuesday reaffirmed his decision not to seek a fifth term after key supporters said they would back the campaign of his opponent even if he sought re-election.

title: INSIDE
description: Party Race Appears Over Ronald H. Brown has enough votes to become the first black chairman of the Democratic Party, he and other Democrats said. Page A12. Radiation Efforts Faulted Procedures to protect workers dealing with radioactive material at the Savannah River Plant are deficient, a U.S. report says. Page A18. Reagan Memoirs Ronald Reagan is to write his memoirs, and Simon & Schuster has agreed to publish them and a collection of his speeches. Page C21. China-Vietnam Accord China and Vietnam were reported to have agreed on the outlines for the withdrawal of Hanoi's troops from Cambodia. Page A5.

title: Christmas Trees That Live On
description: In January, Christmas trees are a sad sight, naked and brittle, piled up on curbs, waiting to be hauled away. But for the Green Guerillas, a nonprofit horticultural group, these holiday leftovers can help spruce up New York's asphalt jungle.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Deal for Stone & Adler Creates New HDM Unit
description: HDM, a joint venture of Young & Rubicam, Dentsu and Eurocom, has acquired Stone & Adler, a direct-response firm, for an undisclosed amount from Young & Rubicam. A new entity called HDM Direct Marketing Group will be looking after Stone & Adler and HDM Worldwide Direct, which will have combined billings of $50 million, The client list of HDM Worldwide Direct, which was formed 18 months ago, includes Nintendo, Suzuki and Hertz. Stone & Adler, which has been around since 1966, does work for, among others, Navistar, Sears, Roebuck and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois.

title: Review/Theater; In Pursuit Of Giggles And Gasps
description: The theme music from ''Superman'' is a prelude to Stephen Gregg's ''Sex Lives of Superheroes,'' a tale of craven cowardice. A hero-worshiping young man (Barry Miller) allows his former girlfriend (Andrea Weber) to strip their apartment, item by item, of all its furnishings. Finally all that remains is a poster of Superman. Deep in despondency, the antihero fantasizes that he is giving lectures on the title subject, with Ms. Weber as his heckler.

title: Dow Up by 9.46; Institutional Buying Cited
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average once again reached a post-crash high.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The answer to the problem of drugs lies more on solving the demand side of the equation than it does on the supply side - than it does on interdiction or sealing the borders or something of that nature. And so it is going to have to be a major educational effort, and the private sector and the schools are all going to have to be involved in this.'' - President Bush. [ A1:4. ]

title: King Glorious Will Miss Derby Because of Injury
description: King Glorious, the undefeated California colt who had been rated the early second choice for the Kentucky Derby May 6, is no longer being pointed for the race because of a minor knee injury, his trainer said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Campeau Corp., Toronto, a Canadian retailer, said its 1988 sales were better than the flat results projected last April.

title: Poaching Operation Found Killing Bears For Aphrodisiac Use
description: Ten people have been arrested in an undercover operation against poaching in the Northeast that turned up the slaughter of more than 400 black bears for their gall bladders, which are prized as aphrodisiacs in the Far East.

title: TV Notes
description: Cambodian Doctor

title: In China, Only Foreign Students Know Comfort; Advice to Africans
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the reaction in Richmond to the Supreme Court decision striking down that city's program to aid minority contractors misstated the race of the Mayor, Geline B. Williams, in some editions. She is white. In some copies a picture caption with the article misidentified Henry L. Marsh. He is a City Council member and former Mayor, not the current Mayor.

title: A Kinder, Smarter Mayor Koch
description: Mayor Edward Koch of New York proved again yesterday that no matter how beleaguered he may be, he has not lost his political touch. His State of the City address was a masterful election year performance and an example of politics at its best. Mr. Koch responded to the growing number of New Yorkers worried about quality of life in their city, while keeping the opposition off balance; in the process he offered rational, humanitarian priorities and programs that merit support.

title: Postcard Reprints Peep Into the American Past
description: SCENIC postcards have been an evocative record of the changing American landscape. The Curt Teich Postcard Collection at the Lake County Museum in Wauconda, Ill., is one of the best. For those unable to get to Wauconda, the Preservation Press has put out two books, ''Picture Palaces'' and ''Ducks & Diners,'' each consisting of 24 ready-to-mail postcards reproduced from the Teich Collection.

title: Making Things Easier May Not Mean Better
description: AS the days lengthen and thinking about spring becomes less and less a silly notion, I would like to put in a word for the high virtue of inconvenience in a gardener's life. Or maybe say a few grouchy things about convenience.

title: Honduran Who Promoted U.S. Aid to Contras Is Slain
description: The former armed forces chief who closely cooperated with Washington in supporting the Nicaraguan rebel movement in Honduras was assassinated today by six men who riddled his car with gunfire, officials said.

title: Carlos Alfredo Yorio, Linguistics Teacher, 48
description: Dr. Carlos Alfredo Yorio, a professor of linguistics at Lehman College and at the City University Graduate Center, died Monday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Genentech Posts a Net Loss
description: Genentech Inc. today reported a net loss of $15.4 million for the fourth quarter of 1988, after a special charge relating to an excess inventory of its leading drug, tissue plasminogen activator.

title: Notes and Bonds Post Declines
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds retreated in fairly light trading yesterday, pushed lower by softness in the dollar, a rise in oil prices and profit taking by dealers following Tuesday's rally.

title: Note Offering By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, also known as Sallie Mae, is offering $250 million worth of fixed-rate notes due in 1994 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Yugo Importer Has Layoffs
description: Global Motors Inc., the company that imports and markets Yugo cars in the United States, acknowledged today that several dozen employees, including some top officers, were laid off Monday night in a move to conserve its limited finances.

title: Ex-Jackson Aide Confident Of Winning Top Party Post
description: Ronald H. Brown, a former aide to both Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, has lined up the votes to become the new chairman of the Democratic Party, Mr. Brown and other Democrats said today.

title: Hitachi Files Suit
description: Hitachi Ltd. filed a Federal lawsuit accusing Motorola Inc. of patent infringment on a microprocessor. The lawsuit follows a similar suit filed last week by Motorola against Hitachi. The dispute centers on Motorola's 68HC11 and Hitachi's H-8 microprocessors, digital electronic devices that perform the control and arithmetic functions of televisions, watches, videorecorders and other products.

title: Big Sofa, Little Space
description: YOU'VE tried everything: squeezing it into the elevator, coaxing it up the back stairs. You've even considered hoisting it through a window. But no matter what you try, you can't get your new sofa into your apartment. It's a city dweller's nightmare. Luckily, there are skilled people who can cut and reassemble furniture in your apartment.

title: Calcavecchia on Mission
description: Ever since Tony Jacklin, the European Ryder Cup captain, said last July that the European golf pros were better than their American rivals, Mark Calcavecchia has set his sights on revenge. The long-hitting Florida pro, who easily won the Phoenix Open last Sunday, sounds like a man on a crusade to bring the Ryder Cup back to the United States.

title: Air Force Move Against Official
description: The Air Force said today that it had begun legal proceedings to suspend a top contracting official who has been implicated in the Pentagon fraud investigation.

title: P.L.O. Goes Back to Debating How to Create Its Exile State
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has resumed its divisive debate over the declaration of a provisional government in the Israeli-occupied territories, according to senior P.L.O. officials here.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Gilbert L. Voss, 70, a Conservationist, Dies
description: Gilbert L. Voss, professor emeritus of biological oceanography at the University of Miami, died of liver cancer Monday at his home in Miami. He was 70 years old.

title: Two Who Fell Far Land in Same Place
description: On the synthesizer keyboard, Denny McLain played the Motown tune ''Stop! In the Name of Love,'' which was made popular by the Supremes more than two decades ago, when McLain was one of baseball's best pitchers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Whalers 3, Blues 3: Paul MacDermid of Hartford scored with 11 minutes 9 seconds left as the Whalers battled the St. Louis Blues to a tie in Hartford last night. MacDermid broke in free from the blue line off a pass from Dean Evason and converted a backhander to give the Whalers the tying goal with his 10th of the season. Jody Hull and Ron Francis also scored for Hartford, which is 3-0-1 in its last four games.(AP) Sabres 6, Red Wings 3: Phil Housley, a defenseman, scored one goal and set up another as Buffalo ran its unbeaten streak to eight games at Detroit last night. Housley set up Dave Andreychuk's goal late in the first period to tie the score 1-1. He then scored the second of three straight Buffalo goals at 4:44 of the second period to give the Sabres a 3-1 lead. After tying on Andreychuk's late goal, the Sabres broke the game open with three goals in a 4:54 span early in the second.(AP) Penguins 5, Jets 4: Rob Brown scored his second goal of the game at 12:38 of the third period last night as the Penguins came back after losing a three-goal lead in Pittsburgh last night. Mario Lemieux, who scored his 53d goal, also assisted on three goals to raise his league-leading point total to 133. The Jets came back from a 4-1 first-period deficit to get a 4-4 tie early in the third period.(AP) Bruins 2, Maple Leafs 1: Andy Brickley deflected Greg Hawgood's long shot at the Toronto crease 1:57 into overtime to give Boston the victory in Toronto. Brickley's 11th goal of the season ended a three-game Boston losing streak. Hawgood had sent the game into overtime with a goal with nine minutes remaining in the third period.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Auburn 65, New Orleans 47: Patrena Scruggs scored 15 points and top-ranked Auburn shook off a sluggish first half to post the victory on its home court last night. The Lady Tigers (18-0) scored the game's first 10 points and held New Orleans without a basket until Carvie Upshaw connected on a field goal eight minutes into the game. Missy Lynn scored 15 points to lead New Orleans (8-8). (AP) Mississippi 78, Mississippi State 65: Jackie Martin scored 16 points as Mississippi won at home last night and stopped a three-game losing streak. The eighth-ranked Lady Rebels had only seven turnovers in the game and led at the half, 39-25. Teena Bender who had missed Mississippi's last four games with a knee injury, grabbed 10 rebounds and had 8 points. The Lady Rebels improved to 14-3 and 2-3 in the Southeastern Conference, while Mississippi State is 9-10 and 1-3.(AP)

title: Du Pont Plans Stock Buyback
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it would buy and retire up to 20 million of its own shares, or about 8 percent of the stock outstanding, to enhance the price of the stock.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A YEAR ago Pam Faulds, whose mother had died of breast cancer when Ms. Faulds was 6 years old, told her own three children that she had developed the disease. Since that time, her children have tried to make sense of their mother's cancer and to manage the stress of living with a seriously ill parent.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Our dry walls were originally covered with a rough-texture paint. Over the years there has been scraping, patching and repainting so that some of the roughness has been smoothed out in places, but the walls still do not have the uniformly flat look we prefer. Can you suggest how to achieve that look, short of replacing the walls? A.The look can be achieved by extensive power sanding and patching with spackling compound, but this would be very time-consuming and is very likely to damage the dry-wall facing in places. It can also be done by simply installing new dry-wall panels on top of the existing material with construction adhesive, but you would have to level off most of the bad bumps first.

title: Sam Halper, Journalist, 72
description: Sam Halper, a journalist who was with Time magazine for many years, died of Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at the Wilton Meadows Health Care Facility in Wilton, Conn. He was 72 years old and lived in Wilton.

title: Michael Lland, Dancer And Ballet Master, 64
description: Michael Lland, a dancer and ballet master at the American Ballet Theater, died last Friday at Tuomey Hospital in Sumter, S.C. He was 64 years old.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: SINCE the summer of 1976, when I was convalescing from an illness, my younger daughter and I have watched a soap opera. I had never seen one before that July: turning on ''Days of Our Lives'' was a way to break an otherwise shapeless day into segments. The other ways were a) to talk on the phone in the morning, b) nap from 2 to 3, c) wobble outside to view the filming of ''Kojak'' episodes on my street. This was the pleasantest summer of my life. At first, ''Days'' seemed as mysterious as Kabuki. It appeared, for instance, that Julie, who was married to Doug, was the daughter of his first wife and half-sister to his daughter to whom she was also stepmother. Was this possible? Julie also had grandparents who looked scarcely old enough to be her parents, and an uncle who had to deliver his wife's baby in a howling blizzard while handicapped by a paralyzed right arm. I cackled, and was caught.

title: HEALTH: Geriatrics; Juggling Family, Job and Aged Dependent
description: A substantial number of working mothers are finding that they must juggle another responsibility: providing unpaid personal care in the homes of elderly relatives and friends.

title: 2 Rival Shiite Armies Declare A New Cease-Fire in Lebanon
description: Rival Shiite Muslim militias announced a cease-fire today in their monthlong gun battles here and in southern Lebanon but failed to resolve political differences that provoked the violence.

title: Youth Admits Burning Synagogue; Term of Weekends in Jail Planned
description: In an emotionally charged hearing in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, a 16-year-old boy pleaded guilty yesterday to the burning and desecration of a synagogue in which five Torah scrolls were destroyed. The judge said he would sentence the youth to weekends in jail, community service and probation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * A series of radio spots featuring the entertainer Steve Allen urging people to be tested regularly for colon cancer has been developed for the Advertising Council by Calet, Hirsch & Spector.

title: Steinberg Jury Notes: Reading of Tea Leaves
description: Every time the jury in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg sends a note to the judge, everyone involved in the trial rushes to the 11th floor courtroom in the Manhattan Criminal Court Building on the chance that the panel has reached a verdict.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Susan M. Machtiger has been named senior vice president at Young & Rubicam New York.

title: Blueprints For the Disabled
description: Since 1976, the Eastern chapter of the Paralyzed Veterans Association, an advocacy and support group for veterans with spinal cord injuries or diseases, has prepared blueprints for improved wheelchair accessibility in the homes of paralyzed veterans. The organization has just made available a booklet of the blueprints titled 'Wheelchair House Designs.'

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about telephone companies' earnings, and a listing in the Company Earnings table, misstated the earnings per share for the BellSouth Corporation. The company earned $3.51 a share in 1988 and $3.45 a share in 1987.

title: Chairman Is Retiring At American Standard
description: American Standard Inc., known for its plumbing fixtures and which has gone private through a leveraged buyout, said yesterday that William B. Boyd was retiring as chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Mullen Brothers Go From Roller Hockey to the Elite on Ice
description: The temperature didn't have to sink to any specific number. There simply had to be a touch of cool air in the summer night on the West Side of Manhattan and the sticks and roller skates would disappear from Marion Mullen's hallway.

title: Independent Oil Nations May Back OPEC Pact
description: Oil traders were closely watching developments in London today for signs that oil-producing countries that are not OPEC members may join in an effort to keep prices high.

title: Increase Is Sought In Foremost Stake
description: Two Texas investors said they would seek clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to increase their stake in the Foremost Corporation of America to 24.9 percent from 14.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, David Bonderman and W. Robert Cotham, associates of the Bass family of Fort Worth, said they would file their request with the Federal Trade Commission by the end of this month.

title: Salvadoran Leader Rejects Rebel Plan on Election
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte tonight dismissed a proposal by the Salvadoran guerrillas laying out conditions for their participation in presidential elections, saying it amounted to a ''proposal of war.''

title: American Express Reports $231 Million Net in Quarter
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it earned $231 million, or 54 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of $104 million, or 24 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1987.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; One-Stop Shopping To Reach Alumni
description: Students at the Wharton School, the University of Pennsylvania's graduate school of business, have assembled the alumni magazines of seven top business schools into a unified advertising network called the Management Network.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Interview on Issues Ranging From Taxes to Drugs
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Bush by Gerald M. Boyd of The New York Times and Katherine Lewis of The Houston Post, as transcribed by the White House. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, was present.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Review/Television A History Of Spying In America
description: A clip of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testifying at the 1987 Iran-contra hearings sets the cautionary theme of ''Secret Intelligence,'' a four-hour history of the development of American espionage that begins tonight at 9 on Channel 13 and continues in three weekly chapters. At issue is the secrecy treasured by spies versus the openness required by democracy.

title: Timepieces, From Sundial to Swatch
description: IN the age of the digital watch, the public timepiece has become a lost communal art. The famous Biltmore Hotel clock in New York is now tucked away in the atrium of a bank building, only five of New York City's historic clocks have landmark status and few new public spaces post the time.

title: New Delhi Journal; Now at Least, the Customer Is Sometimes Right
description: In a country abounding with complaints about shoddy manufactured goods, corrupt public services and adulterated food and drink, a small band of public and private citizens is taking on the monumental task of making consumer protection a national issue.

title: Probert Suspended
description: Bob Probert, the Detroit Red Wings' forward, was suspended for the second time this season when he arrived 25 minutes late for the team's game last night against the Buffalo Sabres. ''He showed up at 6:10 P.M. and he was supposed to be here at 5:45 P.M.,'' said Bill Jamieson, director of public relations for the Red Wings. ''He's suspended for one day - today - without pay. That's over $1,000.'' The suspension is the latest trouble for the 23-year-old who was one of six Red Wings caught drinking after hours before the fifth game of the Detroit's Campbell Conference Final in Edmonton last spring. Probert was suspended Sept. 23 during training camp for disciplinary reasons.(AP)

title: Homeless Organize to Fight for Themselves
description: Like thousands of other New York gadflies, Ruth Young and Jean Chappell organize and agitate, register voters, denounce City Hall, speak out at meetings of the P.T.A. and the Board of Estimate and mass-produce news releases on everything from the crack crisis to the need for better housing for poor people.

title: From the Man Who Drew Mobil With a Red 'O'
description: Accidents and fear, he will gladly tell you, pervade the artistic life of Ivan Chermayeff. Best known as the founding partner in the design firm of Chermayeff & Geismar Associates, creators of corporate images for powerful and prestigious clients, Mr. Chermayeff is also a painter, illustrator and collagist. The fine-arts side of his career is on view in a new show of his work at the Cooper Union in Manhattan.

title: Federal Farm Credit Banks In $2.4 Billion Offerings
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday announced the interest rates on three consolidated systemwide bond issues totaling $2.4 billion, which were offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers and dealer banks.
