title: New Light for the Salvador Tunnel
description: El Salvador's Marxist guerrillas welcomed Ronald Reagan's Administration with an unsuccessful but bloody ''final offensive.'' Now they greet George Bush by proposing to take part in democratic elections this year. It's an abrupt change, subject to many questions. Yet Washington, which has long declared guerrilla rejectionism to be El Salvador's central political problem, can only welcome this apparent opening toward a settlement.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS -10:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council REGIONAL CARTOGRAPHIC CONFERENCE FOR THE AMERICAS - 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Green Seeks 11% Rise In His Schools Budget
description: Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green proposed a $6.4 billion budget yesterday for New York City's schools, the first move in what is expected to be months of negotiations with the state and city governments.

title: In New Era, Banks May Avoid Blue-Chip Bonds
description: As banking companies expand into the corporate bond market for the first time in more than 50 years, they are expected to avoid some low-profit sectors like bonds of blue-chip companies and concentrate on more lucrative financings involving lower-quality companies and new sectors of the market.

title: Morgan Stanley Post
description: The Morgan Stanley Group said Tuesday that Robert F. Greenhill had been named to the newly created position of vice chairman. Mr. Greenhill, who joined Morgan in 1962, will remain director of the firm's investment banking division. The announcement was made by S. Parker Gilbert, chairman, and Richard B. Fisher, president.

title: 3 CONCERNS RAIDED BY BONN IN INQUIRY
description: West German customs officials today raided 3 companies and 12 private homes in search of evidence that Libya received aid in building what is said to be a poison-gas plant.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 'Hi, Governor'
description: In Washington some titles have a way of sticking, as Charles S. Robb, the former Democratic Governor of Virginia and newly elected Senator, has discovered. ''When I telephone my office, they answer: 'Senator Robb's office,' but the moment they realize who is calling, they say, 'Oh, Hi Governor, what can we do for you?' ''

title: Is What Bon Jovi Plays Chamber Music? Maybe
description: Can performances by the Miles Davis Quintet, the Art Ensemble of Chicago or Bon Jovi be considered chamber music? That was one of the questions raised this week during a panel discussion called ''Chamber Music in the 20th Century,'' part of Chamber Music America's 11th national conference. And it was a notion that did not seem to raise any hackles among the conference's participants, representatives of a field normally regarded as conservative.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Madonna Joins Pepsi Lineup
description: Madonna, the rock star, has signed a one-year contract with the Pepsi-Cola Company, joining Michael Jackson, Tina Turner, David Bowie, Lionel Richie and the Miami Sound Machine as spokesmen for the soft drink.

title: Car Output Up in Japan
description: Japanese auto makers built a record 12.7 million cars, trucks and buses in 1988, an increase of 3.7 percent from the previous year, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the acquittal of a woman in the death of a New York City police officer misstated the charges in some editions. She was charged with second-degree manslaughter, not first-degree.

title:
Metro Datelines;
Man Is Convicted In Officer's Slaying
description: LEAD: A 25-year-old man with a history of felony convictions was found guilty of second-degree murder yesterday in the shooting death of a transit police officer two years ago.

title: Justice Allows 2d GAF Trial
description: A Supreme Court Justice cleared the way today for a second trial of the GAF Corporation on charges of stock manipulation. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall lifted his order that blocked a new trial on possible grounds of ''double jeopardy.''

title: For Subaru, Luxury Is a Necessity
description: Subaru of America Inc. is counting on a powerful and luxurious new compact vehicle and high-tech gadgetry to pull it out of a two-year sales slump.

title: Calender: Unearthing Manhattan History
description: The Past Unearthed, South Street Seaport Museum Gallery, 213 Water Street, off Beekman Street; 212-669-9430.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 High-level Chilean officials, in conversations in 1978, acknowledged the responsibility of the head of the intelligence police for two killings in Washington in 1976, a retired Chilean diplomat has asserted. Page A1

title: U.S. Plans a Ditch in California To Stem the Flow of Illegal Aliens
description: The Government announced plans today to build a four-mile long ditch along the United States border with Mexico to deter illegal immigration and drug smuggling, while a private group here detailed its own proposal for a 50-mile metal fence along the border.

title: T.B.A.: Two Rooms By Graves
description: THE Brooklyn Museum is known for its period rooms from the 17th to the 20th centuries. But tucked away in storage is a pair of rooms from recent post-modern history: the library, right, and child's bedroom Michael Graves designed for Susan and John Reinhold's apartment on Central Park West.

title: Books of The Times; Scoops and Scuttlebutt of a British Correspondent
description: Special Relationships A Foreign Correspondent's Memoirs From Roosevelt to Reagan By Henry Brandon Illustrated. 436 pages. Atheneum. $24.95.

title: Bush, Citing Cost, Says Drug War Will Focus Largely on Education
description: President Bush said today that the all-out war on drugs he promised in his Inaugural Address would be mainly an educational effort rather than a law-enforcement crackdown.

title: 2 Democrats in House Subpoenaed by North
description: Lawyers for Oliver L. North have subpoenaed two Democratic members of the House of Representatives, Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma and Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, to testify in Mr. North's defense in his criminal trial, officials in the House said today.

title: Pitt, in Big-Game Mode, Registers Another Upset
description: Early in the second half tonight, P. J. Carlesimo shed his suit jacket and knelt in front of Seton Hall's bench with a worried look on his face. The Pirates' coach sensed his team was in trouble.

title: MITCHELL DETAILS DEMOCRATIC GOALS
description: George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, today set bipartisanship in foreign policy and the establishment of a ''new social contract'' between the Government and its citizens as the major objectives of Senate Democrats in the 101st Congress.

title: Susan Sontag, as Image and as Herself
description: The first exhibit - as Susan Sontag might begin if she were writing an essay about herself - is a thin volume entitled ''AIDS and Its Metaphors,'' which adds itself to a growing collection of volumes sharing a widely recognized characteristic. They all strive to be on the cusp of cultural discovery.

title: Soviet Quake Area A Vast Sea of Mud; Death Toll Reduced
description: When Saifuo Khodzhaya was found on Monday, after an earthquake shook this tiny village and a landslide buried it in mud and clay, he was dead, crushed when the roof of his house fell. His arms were stretched through a window, and in them lay his 6-day-old daughter, alive and crying.

title: Bridge
description: Every player in North America, barring a handful clinging to Ely Culbertson's honor-trick method, uses the 4-3-2-1 point-count introduced early in the century by Milton Work. He was a decisive loser to Culbertson in the battle of systems in the 30's, but he has had the last laugh in the area of valuation.

title: Consolidated Gas Debenture Sale
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company in Pittsburgh tapped the debt market yesterday through the competitive sale of $100 million in debentures due in 1997.

title: As New York Watches for Drought, Suburbs Take Heed
description: The water shortages that prompted the declaration of a drought watch last week in New York City and Westchester County do not extend to most of Connecticut, New Jersey and Long Island. But mindful of rising demand and climatic fickleness, governments throughout the region are encouraging conservation.

title: Dividend Tax Cut Is Favored
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that he favored the elimination of double taxation on dividends.

title: Bundy Toll May Be 50, Prosecutor in Case Says
description: The prosecutor who sent Ted Bundy to the electric chair said today that the killer might have slain 50 young women, a toll that investigators have sought to prove for years.

title: KEY RATES
Chilean Official Links a General, Long Suspect, to Letelier Killing
description: A retired Chilean diplomat has asserted that high-level Chilean officials, in conversations in 1978, acknowledged the responsibility of the head of the intelligence police for two killings in Washington in 1976.

title: Boston Journal; Waiting for the Snow to Fall and Wondering Why
description: What would Henry James have had to write about this winter? What would John Singer Sargent have had to paint? The artists who captured this city's temperament using scenes of the snow-touched Boston Common might have been frustrated this January, the first in recent memory with no real snowfall.

title: Graf Overwhelms Sabatini
description: Steffi Graf, the defending champion, turned on her awesome power after a shaky start today and overwhelmed Gabriela Sabatini, 6-3, 6-0, in the Australian Open to reach her eighth straight Grand Slam final.

title: Home Resales Up by 11.4%
description: Sales of existing single-family homes shot up 11.4 percent in December, as sales for all of 1988 reached the highest level in nine years, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Police Killings Highest in Death-Penalty States
description: To the Editor:

title: Have Drill, Will Travel: Dentists Visit Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Portrait Power: The Warhol Look
description: JUDGING by two current movies the power accessory women prefer is multiportraits in the style of Andy Warhol. In ''Beaches,'' Bette Midler's hang in a Mae West-style apartment; Sigourney Weaver's, in ''Working Girl,'' hang amid rare woods and flouncy chintz a la Mario Buatta. Forget gilded mirrors. Vanity, thy name is Warhol.

title: Molson, Carling
description: The Molson Companies and the Carling O'Keefe Breweries, a unit of the Australian-based conglomerate Elders IXL Ltd., said they would close seven of 16 breweries across Canada in the next three years after completing the proposed merger of their North American beer operations. The companies would eliminate 500 full-time jobs and slash their payrolls by another 900 employees through attrition and early retirement incentives. The Toronto-based companies also announced that they would invest $220 million (Canadian), or $186 million (United States), to improve production efficiency and packaging capacity.

title: In China, Only Foreign Students Know Comfort
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Voices His Strong Support For Beleaguered Health Nominee
description: President Bush today expressed strong support for Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, his nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services. Then he dispatched Dr. Sullivan to Capitol Hill to soothe the fears of conservative Republican Senators who have voiced concern over Dr. Sullivan's position on abortion.

title: Review/Opera; 'Postman' in Washington
description: The Washington Opera has revived ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' the 1982 operatic adaptation of James M. Cain's famous and twice-filmed novel of ruthlessness, frustration and violence in Depression-era California.

title: Senator Proposes Simultaneous Poll Closing
description: Legislation to set a uniform nationwide time for closing the polls in Presidential elections was introduced today by Senator Brock Adams, a Washington Democrat.

title: New Japanese Car Out
description: A little car named Lettuce, aimed to appeal basically to women, went on sale at supermarkets in Japan this week. Sold exclusively through supermarkets, the Lettuce costs $4,700. The mini-car is made by Mitsubishi and is being offered in red, white or black.

title: Weirton Steel Sets Plan to Sell Stock
description: Settling a longstanding debate with the Independent Steelworkers Union, the management of the Weirton Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 15 percent of its shares to the public as part of a $600 million modernization plan.

title: Net Up at Bell Atlantic and U S West
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and U S West Inc., two regional Bell telephone companies, yesterday reported higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1988 and for the year. Analysts said the results were in line with projections.

title: Soviets Limit Their Quick-Strike Ability
description: New details about Moscow's plan to withdraw some military forces from Eastern Europe suggest that the withdrawal will substantially blunt Moscow's ability to mount an attack on short notice against Western Europe, according to American experts inside and outside the Government.

title: CHINA AND VIETNAM REPORTED IN PACT
description: China and Vietnam have agreed on a broad outline for a Vietnamese troop withdrawal from Cambodia by the end of September, a Vietnamese diplomat here said today.

title: Parceling Things Out
description: The white minority Government that used to rule Rhodesia and its black successor in Zimbabwe have one attitude ironically in common. Both like to run a dirigiste economy, effectively deciding who can do what kind of business.

title: DISARMING OF 5 MX'S IN '88 IS REPORTED
description: An MX missile came loose from its support and fell as much as a foot inside its underground silo last year, causing the Air Force to remove that missile's 10-warhead payload and those of four other MX's found to be defective, according to an article published today.

title: Bethlehem Steel's Profit Off; Increase Posted at Lukens
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel producer, said yesterday that its net income fell by 8.1 percent in the fourth quarter. It attributed the decline to higher operating costs and special charges.

title: Metro Datelines; Smoke Injures 25 In Fire at Kennedy
description: A smoky three-alarm fire that began in a storage area behind a restaurant forced the evacuation of one wing of the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy International Airport last night, officials said. Eighteen firefighters and seven Port Authority police officers were treated for smoke inhalation.

title: Texas Audits Are Faulted
description: The General Accounting Office will soon release a study showing that some of the nation's largest accounting firms failed to detect and report problems at ailing Texas savings and loan associations just before they failed, Government officials said tonight.

title: Tower Tells Hearing Panel He'll Accept Military Cuts
description: John G. Tower, President Bush's choice to be Secretary of Defense, sought today to dispel concern about his consulting work for military contractors and past support for huge military budget increases.

title: Interest in Guidry
description: Ron Guidry, spurned by the Yankees when they refused to offer him a contract for the coming season, is close to reaching a deal with one of three teams, according to his agent, Reggie Ringuet. The Los Angeles Dodgers, the Toronto Blue Jays and the Minnesota Twins all have contacted Ringuet about a one-year contract for the 38-year-old Guidry. ''There's no question that he's going to be working again in February somewhere,'' Ringuet said.

title: Transco to Sell Assets of Unit
description: The Transco Exploration Company, a subsidiary of the Transco Energy Corporation, said today that it intended to sell all the oil and gas assets of its Transco Exploration Partners L.P. and to liquidate the partnership. Transco owns 74 percent of the partnership, which is publicly traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Dollar's Advance Is Halted After Intervention by Fed
description: The dollar fell yesterday after the Federal Reserve once again entered the market to sell dollars, traders said.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Donald Jesse Atwood; Manager for Pentagon
description: Donald J. Atwood, a General Motors executive named today to the No. 2 job in the Defense Department, is a seasoned manager whose biggest task may be to run the department's daily operations while contending with a tighter budget.

title: People Who Love New York Give to Neediest
description: Expressing his ''thanks to your great city for the many pleasures it's provided me this year,'' Jonathan Ballard of New Haven sent $2,500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Newsweek Losing President
description: Christopher M. Little, the president of Newsweek Inc. since 1986, will step down March 1 to become president of Cowles Magazines Inc., Cowles and the Washington Post Company said yesterday.

title: New Design Head at Arts Endowment
description: RANDOLPH McAUSLAND, the president of Design Publications Inc., which publishes Industrial Design magazine in New York, has been named director of the design arts program of the National Endowment for the Arts. He succeeds Adele Chatfield-Taylor, who recently became president of the American Academy in Rome.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Coleman Sanctioned
description: Derrick Coleman, a junior basketball player who was named to several preseason all-America teams, was one of five students at Syracuse University who have been sanctioned by a university judicial board in connection with a fight and series of apartment break-ins last month. Coleman, who still faces charges of fourth-degree criminal mischief (a misdemeanor) and harassment (a violation) stemming from the incident on Dec. 11, will not be forced to sit out any basketball games, according to Robert Hill, a vice president for public relations at the university.(AP)

title: Americans Happy in the Water, or on It
description: The manager of a Manhattan fishing-tackle store is looking forward to a winner of a season, with the new President providing free publicity and public opinion already on his side.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; English Role In Hispanic Marketing
description: VISTA magazine, an English-language Sunday newspaper supplement whose material is intended for Hispanic audiences, is expected to turn its first profit this year, a success it owes to the increasing use of English marketing by advertisers trying to reach Hispanic consumers.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Making His Day
description: With obvious relish, the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Carlisle A. H. Trost, told students at the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., a sea story the other day about Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, the former chief of staff of the Soviet Union's armed forces.

title: A Custody Case With Extra Tangles
description: In January 1985, Norma Lee Stotsky of Pataskala, Ohio, gave her day-old baby girl to Beverly Seymour and Richard Reams, a married couple for whom she had agreed to bear the child in return for $10,000 and expenses.

title: Woman Who Will Be Bishop Acts to Avoid a Radical Image
description: The Rev. Barbara C. Harris sought yesterday to soften her image as a political and theological radical as she prepared to become the first female bishop of the Episcopal Church.

title: Saint Laurant Deals His Strong Suit: Easy Separates
description: Yves Saint Laurent says that his message for spring is ''easy dressing'' and that it is best expressed in his suits.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ACOUSTICAL tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used to cover new and replacement ceilings. Although they are excellent for absorbing sound, they are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean. Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced.

title: Corrections
description: The Favorite Stocks chart in some copies of Business Day yesterday, with the article about the stock market, carried outdated prices. Rather than Monday's closing prices, it should have used Tuesday's, which appeared in the stock market tables.

title: Man Wanted in Officers' Shooting Kills Himself After a Crime Spree
description: A man wanted in the shooting last week of two New York City police officers was found dead early yesterday in a stolen car after shooting himself, the police said.

title: Restored Housing and Rent Control Don't Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Women Killed as Sailboat Explodes off the Florida Keys
description: Two women were killed and two male companions sailed to safety today when their 38-foot sailboat exploded off Adams Key in Biscayne National Park, the authorities said.

title: Doctor Loses Practice Over Genital Surgery
description: A gynecologist who had performed surgery to alter women's genitals can no longer practice medicine in the United States, the Ohio Medical Board said today.

title: Please Face the Rear of the Airplane
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan Hits 10,000 But Bulls Fall to 76ers
description: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls scored the 10,000th point of his career tonight, but the Bulls lost to the Philadelphia 76ers, 120-108.

title: HOCKEY: Notebook; At Long Last, East Beats West
description: Hockey East, a league with high expectations that have not been realized, had an ego-building weekend against the mighty Western Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Hazy Sight Tied to Some Colored Contact Lenses
description: Wearing some contact lenses that change the color of the iris may cause some haziness of peripheral vision, researchers at the Louisiana State University Eye Center in New Orleans have concluded.

title: Farewell, Samoan Fog Cutter
description: A superannuated Ivy Leaguer complains that New York City developers keep slamming doors on his past. First it was the lobby under the clock at the old Biltmore Hotel, once a watering hole for generations of students returning to school in the Northeast. Now Donald Trump is closing Trader Vic's, which for 25 years has occupied the basement of his latest acquisition, the Plaza.

title: New Contract Rewards Wyche, Bengals Coach
description: Sam Wyche said yesterday that he has agreed to remain as coach of the Cincinnati Bengals under terms of a new five-year contract. Wyche's team had one of the most dramatic turnarounds in N.F.L. history this past season. After going 4-11 in 1987, the Bengals won the 1988 American Conference championship before losing to the San Francisco 49ers in the Super Bowl. Wyche's previous five-year contract expired at the end of the 1988 season. Wyche received $250,000 a year under the previous contract, but refused to discuss his new salary or other terms.(AP)

title: The Budget Conspirators
description: A skeptical world awaits President Bush's showing that he can balance the Federal books with a ''flexible freeze'' on spending. But well before his Feb. 9 presentation to Congress, the word is already out that he's likely to embrace the Reagan Administration's ''rosy scenario'' tactic for forecasting tax revenue and interest costs. And there's something else that makes this game even more damaging to trust in Government: Congress plays it, too.

title: Too Much Truffle?
description: Once in a while something comes along that makes one feel lucky to be alive at the end of the 20th century.

title: College Hall Adds 11
description: Six backs and five linemen who won all-America acclaim during their playing days have been selected for induction into the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame on Dec. 5 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The honorees are Donnie Anderson, Texas Tech, halfback, 1963-65; Paul Cleary, Southern California, end, 1946-47; Larry Csonka, Syracuse, fullback, 1965-67; Chalmers (Bump) Elliott, halfback, Purdue, 1944, Michigan, 1946-47; Roman Gabriel, North Carolina State, quarterback, 1959-61; Bob Johnson, Tennessee, center, 1965-67; Ted Kwalick, Penn State, end, 1966-68; Archie Manning, Mississippi, quarterback, 1968-70; Ed Manske, Northwestern, end, 1931-33; Bob Schloredt, Washington, quarterback, 1958-60; Aurelius Thomas, Ohio State, guard, 1955-57.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Contel Corp., Atlanta, a telephone holding company, named Alan B. Salisbury president of the Contel Technology Center. It is part of Contel Federal Systems, Fairfax, Va., a provider of telecommunications and information to government agencies.

title: U.S. Data Since 1895 Fail To Show Warming Trend
description: After examining climate data extending back nearly 100 years, a team of Government scientists has concluded that there has been no significant change in average temperatures or rainfall in the United States over that entire period.

title: Service for Lekachman
description: A service for Robert Lekachman, professor of economics at Herbert H. Lehman College and the City University Graduate School, will be held Wednesday at 3:30 P.M. at the Theater of the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue in the Bedford Park area of the Bronx. Professor Lekachman died Jan. 14.

title: Twins Sign Puckett
description: Kirby Puckett avoided salary arbitration by signing a one-year deal with the Minnesota Twins yesterday. Puckett, the All-Star center fielder, had asked for $2.15 million, while the Twins had offered $1.9 million. General Manager Andy MacPhail and Puckett's agent, Ron Shapiro, said the two sides met in the middle. Neither would give the figure. With 4 years 147 days of major league service, Puckett becomes the player with the shortest service to reach the $2 million mark. Don Mattingly is the other.(AP)

title: Records, of Course, At the '88 Auctions
description: IN 1988, auction fever reigned at antiques and collectibles sales everywhere, defying earlier predictions of a market collapse. It was a year when objects of quality and rarity with a pedigree - whether they were Andy Warhol's cookie jars or Marie Antoinette's console table - caused buying frenzies.

title: Funny Thing Happens At the Forum
description: Magic Johnson calls it ''winning time.''

title: A Visit to Thailand
description: The diplomatic assumptions of the last decade in Southeast Asia shifted more than a little today, as the Thai Government welcomed Hun Sen, Prime Minister in the Vietnamese-backed Government in Phnom Penh.

title: Cuban Envoy Defects to U.S.
description: A veteran Cuban diplomat secretly defected to the United States three months ago after becoming disillusioned with widespread official corruption and with Cuban support for Marxist rebels in at least three Latin American countries.

title: Small Rise In Yields
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, but the increases were smaller than those of the previous week.

title: Reviews/Music; Balalaikas, Piccolo to Octobass
description: The Osipov Balalaika Orchestra arrived in New York this week from the Soviet Union to begin a 40-city tour of the United States, its first visit to this country since 1977. At Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, the orchestra and its guests, the Babinka Folk Ensemble, offered vibrant, finely polished and timbrally variegated performances of Russian folk music, along with a few classics.

title: The New Medicare: No Catastrophe
description: Older Americans cheered last year when Congress broadened Medicare health insurance. Now that they have examined it closely, some of the cheers have turned to harsh complaint. Payments for Medicare coverage under the new catastrophic-illness plan seem to be increasing more than the added benefits are worth.

title: FPS Computing reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Du Pont, E I de Nemours & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $24 million for a writedown of businesses for the quarter and the year included net gains of $77 million, or 32 cents a share, from the settlement of litigation, sale of businesses and technology and writedowns. c-Included gains of $16 million, or 6 cents a share, and $95 million, or 39 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, both from settlement of litigation, sale of businesses and technology and writedowns.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Netsuke and Lacquers

title: One Good Quarter Not Enough for Nets
description: An optimist would say the Nets almost pulled off a great comeback tonight. A realist would say the Nets had no business falling 12 points behind the Sacramento Kings in the first place.

title: Contel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,408,000 for the quarter and $35,514,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $36,220,000 and $43,095,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Con Brio's Schubert
description: The Con Brio Ensemble - Joyce Hammann-Feibel, violinist; Bruce Wang, cellist; Victor Battipaglia, clarinetist, and Diana Mittler, pianist - is to play the Schubert Trio in B flat major, Dvorak's ''Dumky'' Trio, and William Ryden's ''Rags for Tomorrow'' at 3 P.M. Sunday at the Community House of the Church in the Gardens, 15 Borage Place, Forest Hills, Queens. Tickets are $5. Information: (718) 459-1277.

title: Free Shave For Bush
description: Even Richard M. Nixon, probably the most divisive figure to have attained the Presidency in this century, was granted a Presidential honeymoon.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lexus Unit at Toyota Picks General Manager
description: LEAD: J. Davis Illingworth was appointed general manager of Lexus, the new luxury car division now being established in this country by Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. He succeeds Jim C. Perkins, who last week returned to the General Motors Corporation, which he had left for Toyota in 1984.

title: I.B.M. Enters Journalism Experiment
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has donated more than $2 million to the University of Missouri School of Journalism to ''explore new uses in journalism of the latest microcomputer technology.''

title: McDonald's Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $47.4 million, or 25 cents a share, from a change in accounting. Systemwide sales for the latest periods totaled $4,138,184,000 for the quarter and $16,063,639,000 for the year. This compared with year-ago quarter of $3,677,752,000 and $14,330,386,000 for the year.

title: Polish Priest Buried; Many Suspect Murder
description: Thousands of Poles today attended a funeral service for a popular priest who was found dead in his rectory over the weekend, apparently a murder victim.

title: On Early Instruments
description: La Stravaganza, an early-instruments chamber orchestra directed by Dongsok Shin, is to perform music by Boyce, Arne and Handel at 5 P.M. Sunday at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street. Among the works on the program are Arne's Harpsichord Concerto No. 5, in which Mr. Shin will be the soloist; a Handel Organ Concerto (Op. 4, No. 1), with Mary Jane Newman as the soloist, and Boyce's Symphony No. 3. Tickets are $8. Information: 289-4100.

title: F.T.C. Charges Campbell Soup
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged the Campbell Soup Company yesterday with deceptive advertising that contended its soups could reduce ''the risk of heart disease'' while not disclosing what the commission considers a high sodium content in the products.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's testimony on corporate takeovers misidentified the man with Mr. Brady. He was Assistant Treasury Secretary John K. Meagher.

title: Review/Art; Introducing Swiss Sculptors to U.S. and Vice Versa
description: Although ''Sculpture: Material and Abstraction'' was presented in museum spaces in Aarau and Lausanne, Switzerland, it is not a museum show. Its approach to its subject, post-Minimalism in Switzerland and the United States, is schematic and vague. Any show partly conceived to introduce five American sculptors to Switzerland and five Swiss sculptors to the United States is not going to make much of a statement about anything.

title: American Television & Comunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time pre-tax charge of $19.9 million taken in the third quarter for certain reorganization and relocation expenses. American Television & Communications Corp. is an 82-percent owned subsidiary of Time Inc.

title: Tiger International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $14,400,000. Share earnings are fully diluted. Year-ago results ae restated for an accounting change.

title: Surging Islanders Frustrate the Jets
description: Time was when it was an Islander coach, either the departed Terry Simpson or the incumbent Al Arbour, who made his mute comment on the club's performances this season with a weary hand pressed in frustration to his brow.

title: Interlake Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net gains of $11 million for the quarter and $17 million for the year from exceptional charges and unusual items. The unusual items and exceptional charges in the fourth quarter included the completion of the necessary actions to record the settlemtn of certain over-funded pension plans, which added $87.5 million to pre-tax earnings. In addition, provisions were made in the fourth quarter for restructuring adjustments which lowered pre-tax income by $31.2 million. The year-ago quarter also included exceptional charges of $12.5 million against continuing operations for costs related to a re-evaluation of all operating business areas. In 1988, the liquidation of LIFO inventories benefited income before taxes by $1.9 million in the fourth quarter and $2.4 million for the year. Similar LIFO inventory reduction benefits in 1987 amounted to $2.6 million for the quarter and $3.7 million for the year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anchor Savings Bank FSB, Hewlett, L.I., appointed David W. Beal executive vice president-mortgages.

title: BUSH PUTS STRESS ON PUBLIC SERVICE
description: President Bush today called Government ''an opportunity for public service, not private gain,'' and urged senior career Federal officials ''to simply know right from wrong to avoid even the appearance of wrong.''

title: Some Film Series Around Town
description: A number of film series are playing this weekend, some with personal appearances by the filmmakers. The following programs are among them: 'Early Kurosawa'

title: Georgia-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1987 included a pre-tax gain of $66 million from the liquidation of investments.

title: Oboe Quartet
description: The Odyssey Chamber Players are to perform the world premiere of Thomas Flaherty's Oboe Quartet at 8 tonight at the Brooklyn Music School, 126 Felix Street, Fort Greene section. The program also includes a Haydn Flute Trio (Hob. XV:15), and the Brahms Piano Quartet No. 1 in G minor (Op. 25). The Odyssey Chamber Players are Wendy Rolfe, flutist; Mark Hill, oboist; Miriam Lockhart, clarinetist; Mowry Pearson, violinist; Lois Martin, violist, and Jeffrey Szabo, cellist. Tickets are $9. Information: 718-678-0793.

title: U.S. Lifts Sundstrand Suspension
description: The Defense Department ended the suspension of the Sundstrand Corporation today, permitting the supplier of aeropsace components to bid for Government business again, but only after the company agreed to repay the Government $62.5 million in excess charges.

title: Restaurants
description: Mitsukoshi

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To begin with, I don't believe that we can devise an umbrella that can protect the entire American population from nuclear incineration. I think that's unrealistic.'' - John G. Tower. [ A1:6. ]

title: Paine Webber Net Plummets
description: Paine Webber Group Inc., the brokerage house, yesterday reported net earnings of $512,000 in the fourth quarter, a decline of 92.9 percent from $7 million, or 16 cents a share, in the 1987 period.

title: Delta Air Lines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax gains on sale of aircraft of $7,700,000 and $12,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included a pre-tax gain of $644,000.

title: Quantum Chemcial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $5,900,000, or 25 cents a share, and $22,600,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations; the quarter also included a charge of $22,600,000 for costs and expenses related to a $50 a share special dividend paid Jan. 10. c-Included a loss of $3,400,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter; the year included $120,400,000 in income from discontinued operations.

title: Donnelley, R R & Sons Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said full year 1987 results included the sale of Rockford/ Park Cablevision assets in the third quarter 1987, which contributed $39.9 million to net income and 51 cents per share to the 1987 full-year results.

title: Review/Theater; Black Blues and Jazz
description: ''Black and Blue,'' the new revue at the Minskoff, is a festive tribute to great black American jazz and blues artists as only a madcap pair of Argentine set and costume designers could have imagined it.

title: Officer Did Not Realize Gunman Was Fugitive
description: Several hours had passed before Police Officer Jannet Caban realized she had been in a shootout with one of New York City's most wanted fugitives during a robbery Tuesday night, she said yesterday.

title: No More 'Steak' for The Post
description: THE agency that added meat to The New York Post's sizzling image has been banished from the kitchen.

title: Greenspan Shuns Curb On Buyouts
description: The recent wave of leveraged buyouts and other forms of corporate restructuring has probably crested, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today. He urged Congress to shun legislation to restrict such transactions.

title: Toyota Reportedly Plans Europe Plant
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation is reportedly close to announcing plans for a $1.2 billion European car plant. Toyota officials confirmed that the Japanese company had narrowed the list of possible sites and partners for European passenger car production.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Telephone & Teleraph Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time charge which reduced net income by $3,935,000,000 from the write-off of older network equipment and other related charges as a result of accelerating the modernization as a result of its long distance network for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said 1987 earnings have been restated for a change in an accounting standard.

title: WILDER TO LAUNCH RUN FOR GOVERNOR
description: Lieut. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, a black who confounded political experts in 1985 by winning statewide office in the conservative South, opened a campaign for Governor today.

title: Managua Journal; It's a Mad, Mad City. But Bienvenido, Anyway
description: Foreigners who visit Managua these days are often pleased to learn that they can safely drink the water.

title: BCE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for 1988 reflect its share of provisions by two BCE companies- $242 million established by Northern Telecom Ltd. to cover restructuring costs, and $72 million by Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. following a reduction in the carrying value of certain of its assets. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: INSIDE
description: Math Education Criticized

title: The Chip Industry Is Sliding Again
description: After a boom that lasted less than two years, the nation's semiconductor industry appears to be headed back into a slump.

title: Michael Gilbert, Pediatrician, 69
description: Dr. Michael Gilbert, a pediatrician and one of the founding physicians at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 69 years old. Dr. Gilbert was born in Brooklyn and graduated from Washington & Lee University and New York University Medical School. He was in private practice in Manhasset for 40 years.

title: Field of Democrats Narrows
description: Democrats today began rallying around the man who seems certain to be their new national chairman, although conservatives were still worried the party was again placing itself too far to the left of the political mainstream.

title: Cabot Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $816,000 from refinancing of debt.

title: Alexander & Baldwin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an $18,269,000 gain for an accounting change. Prior year net included effect of a change in the method of accounting for voyage revenue and variable expenses.

title: Army Takes Offensive Against Contract Fraud
description: Ever since the first gusts of Operation Ill Wind, the Department of Justice's investigation into possible fraud in the Pentagon's procurement of arms and equipment, the Army's officers and civilian officials have been watching warily.

title: Health Officials Face Fears Created by Meningitis Cases
description: Hundreds of anxious telephone calls are coming into the offices of Long Island health officials in the wake of three unrelated deaths from meningitis caused by the meningococcus bacterium, but officials say there is no cause for alarm.

title: UAL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $24,549,000 for the quarter; the year included net from discontinued operations of $524,386,000. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $290,381,000 and $339,311,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said that because of the substantial reduction in the number of shares outstanding as a result of a self-tender offer in the first quarter of 1988, net earnings per share comparisons year-to-date are not meaningful for the quarter or for the year.

title: Jordan Tops All-Star Vote
description: Michael Jordan and Magic Johnson finished 1-2 in fan balloting for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, and Atlanta placed two players in the starting lineup announced yesterday. The game will be played Feb. 12 at the Houston Astrodome.

title: The Stamps of Incumbency
description: Congressional leaders voice concern about the steady decline in real competition for House and Senate seats. Yet they now propose to add to incumbents' overwhelming advantage by fattening next year's Congressional mailing budget.

title: Review/Film; Soviet Eye Examines Atom War
description: What do you look for in a Soviet film that, like the American television series ''The Day After'' in 1983, depicts the ultimate human drama -death and survival after the nuclear holocaust? There are those in the West who have long suspected that the Soviet Government, always carefully controlling its own peace movement, wanted to encourage greater fear of the nuclear catastrophe among other people than among its own citizens. But ''Letters From a Dead Man,'' which, after the Chernobyl disaster, drew long lines of viewers in the Soviet Union, shows no marks of the political censor, no effort to lighten the vision of suffering. If there is any optimism in this film, directed by Konstantin Lopushansky and on view at the Public Theater through Feb. 2, it comes only at the end, in offering some faint albeit ambiguous hope that even after the war there might yet be a human future.

title: Reviews/Film; Burt Reynolds Up a Creek With Many Red Herrings
description: The fact that the weary, red-herring-strewn thriller ''Physical Evidence'' has been advertised as being ''from the producer of 'Jagged Edge' '' may give some idea of what the film's other selling points are worth. Actually, the presence of Burt Reynolds ought to help, since Mr. Reynolds looks great here and manages to seem smarter and more substantial than anyone else in the cast. But Mr. Reynolds has a less than show-stopping role. He plays a hard-living policeman who, while temporarily suspended from the force, finds himself accused of murder. He also finds himself constantly upstaged by his lawyer.

title: Malaise Among Maryland Lawyers
description: The work can be interesting, the pay spectacular and the perquisites extravagant, yet the mood in the legal profession is oddly grim. While job dissatisfaction has been detected by lawyers and discussed in the legal press, there have been few efforts to measure it.

title: REBEL PLAN SPLITS U.S. AND SALVADOR
description: The State Department reacted positively today to a proposal by guerrillas in El Salvador despite President Jose Napoleon Duarte's statement that it amounted to a ''proposal of war.''

title: Independent Oil Producers And OPEC in Loose Accord
description: Represententatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and independent oil producers ended a two-day meeting in London with an agreement to work together on pushing oil prices higher.

title: Sara Lee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a nonrecurring gain equal to 10 cents a share, reflecting the gain on the sale of several businesses, net of restructuring charges.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Gain
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in fairly active trading yesterday, erasing what had been an early selloff.

title: Hype And Reality
description: After many soppy eulogies on the air and in print, as Ronald Reagan's eight years in the Presidency finally came to a close, the Supreme Court has given the nation a hard look at the real Reagan legacy.

title: Prelate Says Convent at Auschwitz Will Move
description: A Carmelite convent that Jewish groups have protested because it is at the site of the Auschwitz death camp will soon be moved to another site, France's Roman Catholic Primate has announced.

title: Paris Coiffures Recall the 30's
description: Coiffures, many of them revivals, have attracted attention at the round of couture fashion shows for spring and summer this week. In recent seasons, simple French knots and buns have prevailed, giving the models a well-groomed look that did not distract from the clothes. This time the hairdo is part of the atmosphere, recalling the grand days of the couture in the 1930's.

title: Illinois Central
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company plans to increase its stake in the Illinois Central Transportation Company to at least 15 percent, Illinois Central said.

title: Capitals and Flames To Head Overseas
description: Although the official announcement will not be made until next month, it appears certain that the Washington Capitals and the Calgary Flames will be the two National Hockey League teams that tour the Soviet Union and Scandinavia in the fall.

title: Paine Webber Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $8,000,000 and $20,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectivley, from a Washington Public Power Supply system settlement, and about $5 million and $20 million for the same periods, respecitvely, relocation fees. Latest-quarter net did not cover preferred stock requirements.

title: Stockton Takes Lead With a 65 in Pro-Am
description: Dave Stockton was the best there was around the greens during the height of his career, when he won the PGA Championship in 1970 and 1976. But the 47-year-old former wizard of the wedge and putter has only occassionally played in PGA Tour events in recent years.

title: The Greenhouse Effect Is for Real
description: A team of Government scientists report no sign of a warming trend in the average temperatures in the United States over the last century. Does that mean the greenhouse effect, the feared heating of the earth's atmosphere by burning coal and oil, is just another false alarm? The answer, unfortunately, is an emphatic no.

title: Bruno's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $949,000 from the write-off of deferred debt acquisition costs and the premium paid on bond redemption for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months also included a gain of $3,577,000 from an accounting change. Figures for the latest 6 months included 26 weeks of results from Piggly Wiggly operations, compared with 28 weeks in the year-ago period.

title: People
description: * Joseph Dell'Aquila has been appointed executive vice president on the M&M/Mars confectionery business at Backer Spielvogel Bates, the U.S. company of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide.

title: Khomeini Is Well, Daughter Says
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the 88-year-old Iranian leader, is ''in good health,'' works hard and sometimes performs marriage ceremonies, his daughter says.

title: Acme Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,010,000. c-Included tax credits of $1,875,000 and $6,041,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Abortion for Injured Wife Sought
description: A Long Island man whose pregnant wife is in a coma said today that he wanted to be appointed her guardian so he could authorize an abortion in an attempt to help her recover.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Germain Leads: Dot Germain, who last won a tournament in 1980, birdied the last two holes yesterday to finish with a 4-under-par 68 and a one-shot lead after the opening round of the LPGA Oldsmobile Classic in Boca Raton, Fla. Germain sank a 15-foot putt on her 17th hole to pull even with Jody Rosenthal, Dottie Mochrie and Beth Daniel and made a 10-footer on the final hole to take the lead.(AP) BOXING Foreman WinsThe former heavyweight champion George Foreman stopped Mark Young at 1:47 of the seventh round last night in Rochester to earn the 15th consecutive victory in his comeback following a 10-year retirement. Foreman, 60-2 with 57 knockouts, floored Young (10-12) with a left and right to the head. After Young took a mandatory eight count, the 40-year-old Foreman hit him with another combination and Young's corner stopped the fight. Foreman weighed 253 and Young 231. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 1, Flyers 0: Clint Malarchuk made Geoff Courtnall's early goal stand up by turning back 42 shots as the Capitals broke a four-game winless streak in Philadelphia last night. It was the 100th victory and 10th shutout of Malarchuk's career, but his first since last Feb. 27.(AP) Bruins 4, Blues 2 Glen Wesley scored the first of Boston's three power-play goals. The Bruins, with eight players already on their injury list, lost Ray Neufeld with a torn ligament in his right knee when he was taken into the boards by Paul Cavallini in the opening period. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN Georgia 102, S. Carolina State 31: Sharon Baldwin and Kim Berry scored 14 points each, leading fifth-ranked Georgia (17-2). The 71-point margin bettered the school record set eight nights earlier in a 102-32 triumph over Tennessee State. (AP) South Carolina 64, Clemson 62: Beth Hunt, who led No. 16 South Carolina with 20 points, hit a one-and-one with 18 seconds remaining for the victory last night.(AP) AUTO RACING Biasion Wins Monte Carlo: Massimo Biasion of Italy won the 57th Monte Carlo Rally, leading a sweep yesterday of the first three places by Lancia Integrales. Biasion, who took the lead last Sunday, was timed in 7 hours 13 minutes 27 seconds. He had a lead of 6:27 over his teammate Didier Auriol of France.(AP)

title: Honda Develops Traction System
description: The Honda Motor Company has developed what it said was the first automatic traction-control system for front-wheel-drive cars. The company said it had solved the problem of maximizing traction during acceleration on slippery surfaces while retaining enough of the tires' lateral force to turn sharp corners. The product has not been announced on any particular model.

title: To Cut Local Taxes, Kean Urges Shifting Some Costs to State
description: In response to growing outrage over rising property taxes in New Jersey, Gov. Thomas H. Kean proposed today that the state take over from the counties the costs of the welfare and state court systems to save those who pay property taxes more than $320 million.

title: Scott Undergoes Test
description: Byron Scott of the Los Angeles Lakers, who has been suffering from internal bleeding, underwent urological tests yesterday and will miss tonight's home game against Charlotte. Team doctors recommended that the 27-year-old guard not play until the condition clears. Scott, in his sixth National Basketball Association season is the club's third-leading scorer with an average of 19.4 points. (AP)

title: Educational Mediocrity Hurts Our Economy; Protect Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Square D Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Allegheny Plan Under Attack
description: A plan of reorganization that the board of Allegheny International had recently endorsed came under attack in Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh yesterday from two suitors, creditors and a competitor.

title: Death Forms in 2 States Ask About Tobacco Use
description: Oregon and Utah have become the first states to ask doctors to specify on death certificates whether tobacco use contributed to death, a change that the American Medical Association has urged other areas to imitate.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary on Sunday about George Cassidy, the official starter at New York Racing Association tracks, omitted a survivor. She is a daughter, Sheila Cassidy Outcault.

title: Sonat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting method of $13,130,000. c-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $320,000 and $25,945,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a gain of $14.4 million from the sale of Timerlands. Latest year results included gains of $14.9 million and $10.6 million, respectively, from the reversal of reserves related to a regulatory matter and income tax refunds and adjustments. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of FAS 96.

title: Deals Said to Be Offered In Commodities Scandal
description: Prosecutors investigating the commodities-trading scandal here have begun telling people they question that if they cooperate they will face no jail time or at least a reduced sentence under new Federal sentencing guidelines, lawyers involved in the case said today.

title: Market Place; Behind Advance In the Blue Chips
description: IT is an institutional party, but small investors have joined the merrymaking as the stock market relentlessly moves to new highs.

title: ON L.I. , SOME QUIET PLACES TO UNWIND
description: The word ''inn'' appears in the name of many dining and lodging establishments on Long Island, but don't be misled. If you are looking for a peaceful abode with character and interesting food, you may have to make some compromises. Only a handful of places on Long Island's suburban and rural 110-mile peninsula merit a recommendation. Here are four choice spots: Three Village Inn

title: Barnes Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. to Allow Hanoi Official To Attend Capitol Reception
description: The United States has allowed a Vietnamese official to visit Washington, the State Department said today.

title: Addenda
description: * Duome & Associates, a financial public relations firm, and Mannensha International, a Japan-based ad agency, have formed Duome/Manneninter, which will specialize in public relations and advertising in the U.S., Europe and East Asia.

title: Remember Those Killed on the Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Bush's Hopes, Greenspan's Fear,
description: THE American economy is moving too fast for the comfort of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. In Congressional testimony this week, he made clear his intention of slowing it down rather than risk an acceleration of inflation, saying that the Fed would rather ''err more on the side of restrictiveness than stimulus.''

title: Elizabeth Knowlton Is Dead at 93; Pioneer of Himalayas in the 30's
description: Elizabeth Knowlton, a mountain climber who in 1932 became the first woman to climb as high as 20,000 feet in the Himalayas, died of heart disease Sunday at the Ocean Manor Nursing Home in Scituate, Mass., where she lived for the last four years. She was 93 years old and a longtime resident of Cambridge, Mass.

title: TOWER DECLARES 'STAR WARS' SHIELD CAN'T BE COMPLETE
description: Moving away from Ronald Reagan's vision of an impregnable shield against missiles, the Secretary of Defense-designate said today that the Bush Administration did not consider it possible to ''devise an umbrella that can protect the entire American population from nuclear incineration.''

title: MCA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter excluded earnings for Cineplex Odeon.

title: Way to Hasten Tax Refunds
description: Taxpayers who are due a refund will be able to get it within three to five days if they use an electronic filing service announced yesterday by the Dollar Dry Dock Bank.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about computer makers' earnings misstated the stock price of Prime Computer Inc. in some editions. Its shares closed Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange at $19.375, up 25 cents.

title: After 40 Years Making the Law, Rodino Now Teaches It
description: His silver hair swept back, his glasses perched imperially on the bridge of his nose, Peter W. Rodino Jr. was doing what he has done for the last 40 years: instructing on the Constitution and the rule of law.

title: Race Forums In Westchester Turn Unruly
description: It was supposed to be an exercise in reason, an effort to use electronic gadgetry to rise above the angry rhetoric of the past and examine issues of racism and housing in Westchester County.

title: Computer Sciences Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Amdahl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $9,500,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Included a tax credit of $4,000,000 for both the quarter and year. Year-ago share earnings results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in 1988.

title: Papers Show 1962 U.S. Plan Against Castro
description: More than a year after an American-backed invasion of Cuba failed at the Bay of Pigs in April 1961, the United States actively pursued another clandestine plan to overthrow Fidel Castro, according to newly declassified American documents made available here today.

title: Deluxe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago fourth quarter and year included non- recurring gains of $8,350,000 and $16,000,000, respectively, from the sale of investments in Data Card Corp.

title: Emerson Radio Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $381,000 and $580,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $415,000 for the quarter and $1,828,000 for the 9 months.

title: Prague Rock In a Benefit For Prisoner
description: In Czechoslovakia, rock music can be played for high stakes: cracked heads, jail sentences, exile. All have been a part of life for the Plastic People of the Universe, which got started in 1968 as a progressive-rock band and became, in the 1970's, the target of Government prosecution and a rallying point for Czechoslovak artists, intellectuals and human-rights activists. Band members were jailed; the rural farmhouses where they performed were sometimes burned down, sometimes seized by the Government.

title: Accounts
description: * Christian Dior Perfumes to HDM New York for United States advertising of its entire line of fragrances, cosmetics and treatment products. HDM is a joint venture of Young & Rubicam, Dentsu of Japan and Havas-Conseil of France.

title: Sihanouk Says He Is Withdrawing From Cambodia Settlement Talks
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leader of the Cambodian opposition and a key figure in the resolution of Cambodia's future, announced today that he would withdraw from talks about his country next month.

title: Robert Rienow, 79, Author and a Professor
description: Dr. Robert Rienow, a retired professor of political science at the State University of New York at Albany and an author and environmentalist who had warned about the depletion of natural resources, died on Sunday in a fire that destroyed his farmhouse in Selkirk, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Oakland to Pay Raider Legal Fee
description: The city of Oakland and the Los Angeles Raiders reached an out-of-court settlement today in which the city will pay $3 million for the team's legal fees over a four-year period.

title: Experts Say North's Use of Selected Data in Trial Poses No Threat
description: Government experts have tentatively decided that Oliver L. North may use selected secret documents as evidence in his criminal trial without posing major security problems, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Soviets Admit Double Afghan Defeat: Najibullah's and Their Own
description: Soviet officials and Government news accounts now all but openly say there is little question that the Afghan Government will collapse after the Soviets finish withdrawing their troops next month.

title: Arafat, in Reversal, Refuses An Invitation to Talk in U.S.
description: An aide to Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman had decided not to ask the United States for a visa to let him address an Arab-American group.

title: Liggett Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A.T.& T. Says Annual Loss, Its First, Was $1.67 Billion
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported, as expected, the first annual loss in its 104 years in business.

title: Bugged Embassy in Moscow Gets Chance for a New Life
description: An American trade group has offered to buy the unfinished United States Embassy building in Moscow as office space, State Department officials said today. Washington halted construction on the building last year after concluding that it had been embedded with enough eavesdropping devices to turn it into an eight-story microphone.

title: THE EAST VILLAGE'S ART GALLERIES ARE ALIVE IN SOHO
description: The East Village art scene may be defunct, but its legacy lives on deep in the complicated heart of SoHo, where art and money, glamour and real estate continue to mingle in evermore varied combinations. The move of galleries out of the East Village, which started in earnest last season, still continues and is in its second and probably final phase.

title: Jefferson Smurfit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Northern States Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Souvenirs of Justice
description: The Supreme Court probably does not leap to mind as the place to shop for souvenirs. But for years, a tiny kiosk on the Court's ground floor did a brisk business in pocket-size Constitutions and key rings decorated with the scales of justice.

title: Wetterau Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Edwards Charts a Course On More Familiar Turf
description: There is no pretending that these are the good old days, when her world revolved around going to classes, basketball practice and the games. Teresa Edwards is 24 years old now, back at the University of Georgia to complete some unfinished business, too far removed from college life to envy the Lady Dawgs working out on the Coliseum court.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Dec. 13 about a Federal bankruptcy proceeding reported that a Canadian businessman, Stephen J. Mernick, was the high bidder for the PTL television ministry. The article described Mr. Mernick as an Orthodox Jew.

title: Farley Extends Bid
description: Farley Inc. said it was extending for the ninth time its $1.4 billion hostile takeover bid for West Point-Pepperell Inc. The new deadline is next Wednesday, a week later than the previous deadline. About 15.7 million shares of West Point-Pepperell common stock had been tendered by shareholders, which gives Farley about 62 percent of Pepperell common stock. Farley, maker of Fruit of the Loom underwear, first made its $48-a-share cash offer on Oct. 25 to Pepperell, the Georgia-based textile company.

title: Teen-Age Gunman Wounds 4 Students At School in Capital
description: A teen-age gunman with a nine-millimeter automatic pistol wounded four students today as they were leaving Woodrow Wilson High School in the Northwest section of the city.

title: Review/Dance; A Menu of Ballet to Baked Alaska
description: Baked Alaska was last on the menu at the New York City Ballet's dinner dance and performance to raise money for its affiliated School of American Ballet. The problem apparently was what to do for starters on the entertainment side.

title: SOJOURNING IN JERSEY BY RIVER AND SEA
description: New Jersey may be America's most densely populated state, but it has an abundance of tranquil small towns and countryside with a more than ample stock of country inns. The historic seaside resort of Cape May is a trove of Victorian inns, the scenic Delaware River region in the northwestern region has many intimate and charming accommodations and small inns can be found throughout the state. Here is a selection: Delaware River Area

title: Integrated-I.C.H. Deal Is Challenged
description: Frederick A. Moran, president of Moran Asset Management Inc., an investment advisory firm in Greenwich, Conn., said he would oppose the merger agreement between Integrated Resources Inc. and the I.C.H. Corporation. Mr. Moran holds a 4.97 percent in Integrated.

title: FRIDAY
description: SHALL WE DANCE? Ballroom dancing has enjoyed a recent resurgence of popularity as countless competitions, classes and clubs have been created for people seeking the romance of waltzing and fox trotting. A photographic chronicle of contemporary ballroom dancers of all ages in the United States, Canada and England is on view at the Midtown Y Photographic Gallery, 344 East 14th Street. This free exhibition of 80 black-and-white photographs by Ken Graves, a photography professor at Pennsylvania State University, and Eva Lipman, a New York freelance photographer, continues through Feb. 12. Hours are noon to 4 P.M. Fridays and Sundays and noon to 8 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays. Information: 674-7200. UNORTHODOX AND SHORT

title: Our Towns; For Drug Addict, Spot Awaits Him, Probably in a Jail
description: If a drug addict says, 'Yes, I'll take residential treatment,'' counselors want to grab him and throw him in a program, pronto. ''The addict will say yes today - he'll say no tomorrow,'' said Kevin Frawley, who knows.

title: Cherokee Colony Back in Stride
description: The most unexpected and welcome comeback of the new racing season has been Cherokee Colony, who has returned from obscurity to become the early favorite for the $500,000 Strub Stakes at Santa Anita Feb. 5.

title: Room With a View
description: There is a spacious room on the second floor of the Old Executive Office Building with a splendid view of the White House. One of its first occupants, if not the first, was Redfield Proctor, the Secretary of War under President Benjamin Harrison a century ago.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council FOURTH REGIONAL CARTOGRAPHIC CONFERENCE FOR THE AMERICAS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Fairies' Godmother
description: If ever a memory deserved the masks of comedy and tragedy, surely remembrance of Bea Lillie does. Beatrice Lillie, who died last week at her home at Henley-on-Thames at the age of 94, embodied the comic spirit on stage while suffering tragedy in her private life as Lady Peel.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 7 about the opening of the Ottoman archives on the mass killing of Armenians referred incorrectly to the World War I alliance that included the Ottoman Empire. It was the Central Powers, not the Axis.

title: New York Is First State To Try to Curb Caesareans
description: The New York State Health Department has begun the first statewide program in the nation to reduce the rate of Caesarean births.

title: Death Penalty Likely to Gain, Miller Predicts
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller has warned Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of the ''distinct possibility'' that the Legislature will reinstate the death penalty in New York this year.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $737.2 million, to $285.34 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 137 institutional funds increased by $1.05 billion, to $74.99 billion. Those of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $240.8 million, to $89.92 billion. The 91 broker-dealer funds decreased by $73.7 million, to $120.43 billion, the institute said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about President Bush's relationship with the press rendered two quotations incorrectly in some editions. Jody Powell, a former White House press secretary, said of an experiment in which President Carter was interviewed by a few reporters, ''In the end I backed off and I regret I did.'' Michael K. Deaver, a White House official in the Reagan Administration, said: ''As for formal news conferences, they were a necessary evil. I don't think a great deal of news came out of them. It was more a format for the media than anything else.''

title: MIM-Southdown
description: MIM Ltd., the British investment firm, said it held a 6.9 percent stake in Southdown Inc., a oil and gas development company in Houston. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, MIM said it had acquired 473,200 Southdown preferred shares and 35,500 Southdown common shares for investment purposes only. The British group said it might buy additional Southdown shares on the open market, or sell its holdings, depending upon future economic developments.

title: At the Movies
description: Anatomy of a Movie

title: Dokes in Title Defense Against Holyfield
description: Michael Dokes, former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, had to fight back tears yesterday as he looked back on a career that was nearly destroyed by a cocaine habit. At a news conference in Manhattan to announce his defense of the Continental Americas heavyweight title against Evander Holyfield on March 11 in Las Vegas, Nev., the 30-year-old Dokes conceded: ''It took changes to bring me to the point I'm at now. I want to thank Pops, who I love very dearly.'' Pops is Dokes's manager, 91-year-old Marty Cohen, who took a chance on Dokes after the fighter was out of boxing from March 1985 to December 1987. During that period, Dokes served time for possession of cocaine and spent time in a rehabilitation center. With seven straight victories in his comeback, Dokes's record is 37-1-2 with 23 knockouts. Holyfield is undefeated in 20 bouts, with 16 knockouts.

title: Durable Orders Up Brisk 6.4% in December
description: New orders for durable goods rose by 6.4 percent in December, a much stronger gain than had been expected. Analysts said yesterday that the report was a sign that the economy was entering 1989 with plenty of momentum for continued growth.

title: Calfed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the decline in 1988 earnings primarily resulted from a loss of $9.3 million in the company's life insurance operations due to the previously reported sale of three product lines and a general strengthening of reserves.

title: Biggest British Privatization
description: Shares in Britain's electricity industry will be sold off in four stages to avoid overloading the stock market with London's largest privatization to date, the Energy Secretary, Cecil Parkinson, said on Wednesday.

title: Credit Rating Cut On Du Pont Debt
description: The credit ratings have been reduced on $3.7 billion of the debt of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the debt of its Du Pont Overseas Capital N.V. unit, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.

title: Policeman Shoots Man In Dispute at Hospital
description: An off-duty police officer seeking treatment for his wife in a Brooklyn hospital following a car accident last night, shot and critically wounded a man who had been involved in the accident during a dispute in the hospital emergency room, the police said.

title: Dow Climbs Another 25.18; Nears 2,300
description: LEAD: Wall Street's 1989 rally continued unabated yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 25.18 points to close at 2,291.07, another post-crash high.

title: Affirmative Action Booms in Atlanta
description: Before 1973, when this city started its first affirmative action program, less than 1 percent of city-financed construction went to minority contractors. Today minority contractors win 37 percent of city contracts, a dizzying demonstration of affirmative action progress that has spilled over to the private market as well.

title: A Dance Troupe Lands, and Takes Off
description: Philadelphia is a choreographic crossroads, thanks to the Zeromoving Dance Company. That group - now at the Joyce Theater through Sunday - has made the city stand at an intersection between German Expressionism and American modern and postmodern dance.

title: Unheralded, Apartments Are Reborn For Homeless
description: The apartment is completely bare, except for a table and chairs in the middle of the living room and beds covered by green blankets in the bedrooms. But when Clarence Rollocks Jr. is asked what he thinks of his new apartment, he lights up in a smile and his answer is brief. ''Heaven,'' he says.

title: Mcorp to Be Reviewed By Federal Examiners
description: More than 100 Federal examiners are assembling in Dallas to begin reviewing loans throughout the 25 banks owned by Mcorp, the second-largest bank-holding company in Texas, regulatory officials in Washington said today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Park Bistro

title: On Stage
description: Let the Musicals Begin

title: 2 'Tabloid' Programs Gain As TV Officials' Parley Ends
description: The convention of the National Association of Television Program Executives ended today with Fox Television's ''A Current Affair'' and ''Tabloid,'' a new program by the Paramount Pictures Corporation, making large gains in sales to program buyers from local stations across the country.

title: Interior Nominee Pledges Development With Care
description: Manuel Lujan Jr., President Bush's choice to be Interior Secretary, pledged today to be a careful steward of the nation's lands but said that environmentally sound development of public resources was possible and desirable.

title: No Time to Change U.S. Defense Policy
description: Transition is the key word these days in Washington - and, according to many observers, in international affairs as well. There is a widespread sense that 1988 was a watershed year in international affairs - a year that marked the beginning of a ''new era,'' requiring a radically new approach to relationships with our allies as well as our adversaries. To those who hold this view, the time has come for American perestroika - restructuring -in national security policy.

title: Ocean Drilling & Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Latest fourth quarter and year results included gains on the disposition of assets of $9,123,000, or 18 cents a share. Year-ago fourth quarter and year included loss provisions of $100 million on an agreement with banks which issued letters of credit on behalf of an insurance subsidiary. Results include gains resulting from amendments and adjustments to certain gas sales contracts of $4,297,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year ended Dec. 31, 1988; $18,366,000, or 35 cents a share, for the year ended Dec. 31, 1987; and $2,888,000, or 5 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Foundations, Citing Homeless, Aid Neediest
description: Departing from usual practice, the James A. Macdonald Foundation of White Plains asked that this year's gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund be directed particularly to solving the problems of housing the homeless and the elderly.

title: Review/Art; An Architect's Dreams And What He Built
description: Frederick Kiesler was nearly 75 years old and his death was only a few months away when his first major building, the Shrine of the Book in Jerusalem, was finally completed in 1965. Until then, he had designed shop windows at Saks Fifth Avenue, stage sets for the Juilliard School's opera program, a movie house in Greenwich Village and a handful of contemporary art galleries. But it was as much for what he dreamed as for what he built that Mr. Kiesler became known.

title: Oliver H. Durrell, Book Publisher, 81
description: Oliver H. Durrell, retired chairman of Durrell Publications, a publisher of books on New England and the Bahamas, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at New Hanover Memorial Hospital in Wilmington, N.C., where he lived. He was 81 years old.

title: Clarksville Journal; Hailing the Return of the Eagles (They Hope)
description: If most of the swallows spurned Capistrano some year, it might give a clue to what it's like to be here in Clarksville on the brink of Eagle Days with hardly a dark wing to be seen skimming over the Mississippi River.

title: Law Degree Wanes as Passport to Business Job
description: Lawyers, once marketable commodities as business executives, have been devalued in the corporate marketplace. Personnel executives and business school administrators say a job seeker's legal training is as likely to be seen now as a liability as an asset, and lawyers trying to switch careers say they are often typecast as narrow-minded, confrontational and unimaginative.

title: 5 in Bronx Indicted in First Cases In Inquiry on City's School Boards
description: In the first criminal charges since the investigation of New York City's community school boards began last year, four school board members and a former district superintendent from the Bronx were indicted yesterday on charges ranging from theft of school property to bribe-taking.

title: KEY RATES
Cominco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
