description: b-Included special gains of $26,800,000 and $28,500,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included speical gains of $25,300,000 for the quarter and $91,300,000 for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars. Year-ago earnings have been restated.

title: About Real Estate; Condo Project Sells Well in the Bronx
description: Within six months of going on the market, the largest low-rise development of middle-income condominiums to be built in the Bronx is selling so well that the developers have raised their prices and are planning another increase in the spring.

title: Only Two Ways to Free College Sport
description: When Dale Brown was asked why he was trying to recruit a 7-foot-4-inch, 285-pound basketball player from Lithuania named Arvidas Sabonis to attend Louisiana State University, the coach said it was for humanitarian reasons.

title: France Trade Gap Wider
description: France recorded a trade deficit of 33 billion francs ($5.3 billion) in 1988, its largest annual trade deficit in five years, the nation's customs office reported today. The 1988 performance was slightly wider than the gap of 31.5 billion francs in 1987, but less than the deficit of 48.9 billion francs reported in 1983. Economists said the French merchandise trade balance had been hurt by heavy imports of manufactured goods and capital equipment. Domestic consumers also bought more imported goods last year.

title: A.C.L.U., Though Buoyed by Surge of Recruits, Still Frets Over Presidential Campaign Fallout
description: Precariousness is a way of life for the American Civil Liberties Union, but even by that standard 1988 seemed like a disaster. Through Labor Day only 15,000 new members had enlisted, which did not even cover attrition. The stock market crash, the defeat of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court and the end of the Reagan era all made for malaise. To make matters worse, it was an election year, a time when people were thinking of other things.

title: Pryor Bout Canceled
description: The former junior welterweight champion Aaron Pryor, scheduled to continue his comeback attempt, was taken off the card in Rochester yesterday after doctors determined that his left eye was too badly damaged to allow him to fight. ''The final decision was mine,'' said Randy Gordon, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission. ''I waited until I could get all the doctors together. They all agreed.'' Dr. Robert Vanderlinde of Rochester said Pryor has a dense cataract and maybe a detached retina. Vanderlinde said Pryor would undergo surgery Tuesday. Pryor, whose record is 37-1 with 33 knockouts, was to fight a 10-round bout with Rick Kaiser of Spearfish, S.D. (AP)

title: Broadcast News Awards
description: CBS won two of broadcast journalism's highest awards yesterday when ''60 Minutes'' received the Alfred I. du Pont-Columbia University Gold Baton and the ''CBS Evening News'' received a Silver Baton for its coverage of the Persian Gulf in the final weeks of the Iran-Iraq War.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.M.E. Inc., Burbank, Calif., said it had extended the date, originally Jan. 13, for concluding a buyout agreement with ADAG Inc. and that a third party had expressed an interest in proposing an alternative to ADAG's proposal.

title: U.S. TO WITHDRAW STAFF OF EMBASSY IN AFGHAN CAPITAL
description: In his first major decision as Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d has decided to close the American Embassy in Afghanistan because of increasing instability during the final stages of a Soviet troop withdrawal, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Leaders in the House Set a Tentative Pact On Salary Increase
description: Leaders in the House of Representatives have tentatively worked out a package that would impose significant financial restrictions on House members in return for a 50 percent pay increase, leadership sources said today.

title: U.S. Orders More Inspections Of Engine Mountings on Jets
description: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended today that airlines increase their inspections of bolts holding engines to Boeing 737 jets to prevent recurrences of the episode Friday in which an engine fell off a plane taking off in Chicago.

title: Vladimir Feltsman
description: The pianist Vladimir Feltsman is to play Beethoven's first and last Sonatas and Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' at 3 P.M. Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $12 to $23. Information: 874-6770.

title: Review/Film; Chocolate As Capital
description: All those aspects of adolescence that are best forgotten - the sullenness, the self-importance, the taste for self-dramatization and the tendency to be insufferably smug - are lovingly enshrined in ''The Chocolate War,'' a film about schoolboys that has its own unmistakably schoolboy point of view. The setting is St. Trinity's, where the overzealous Brother Leon (John Glover) goads his students into turning the selling of chocolates, an annual fund-raising event, into a metaphor for commerce and corruption. A metaphor can be a dangerous thing.

title: Robert Burmester, 58, Accounting Executive
description: Robert W. Burmester, national director of accounting and auditing for the Arthur Young accounting firm, died of a heart attack Monday night at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 58 years old.

title: Clark Triples Salary
description: Will Clark tripled his salary yesterday, agreeing to a one-year contract for $1.125 million with the San Francisco Giants. Clark, eligible for arbitration for the first time, made $345,000 in 1988, when he batted .282 with 29 home runs and a league-leading 109 runs batted in. The first baseman had asked for $1.2 million in arbitration and the Giants had offered $900,000. Clark would earn a $200,000 bonus if he is the league's most valuable player. Seven others agreed to one-year contracts, reducing those remaining in arbitration to 85.(AP)

title: Top Bush Economist Sees Growth As Slower Than Reagan Projected
description: The man chosen by President Bush as his chief economist, Michael J. Boskin, disassociated himself today from President Reagan's final forecast for the economy and predicted somewhat slower growth this year.

title: Lendl Eliminates Muster, Will Face Mecir in Final
description: Ivan Lendl, closing in on a Grand Slam title he has never won, outplayed 11th-seeded Thomas Muster of Austria, 6-2, 6-4, 5-7, 7-5, in a grueling baseline duel today to reach his second Australian Open final.

title: Review/Film; That's 1, 2, 3, 4 and Dip!
description: ''Tango Bar'' is a combination dance lesson and history lecture, describing the evolution of the tango and its important role in the culture of Argentina. The dance is described as a sexy, gritty, vital expression of street values, which places it in unfortunately sharp contrast with the film itself.

title: UAL Posts A Profit; Delta Down
description: The UAL Corporation yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $45.4 million, or $2.11 a share, in contrast to a loss of $80.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1987 from continuing operations.

title: American Income Life Insurnce Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $1,333,000 and $3,144,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After capital losses of $1,846,000 for the quarter and $1,682,000 for the year.

title: HAWK IS BACK AGAIN, AND SO IS RINGO STARR
description: Two new weekly series are making their debuts this weekend. On commercial television, ABC is offering ''A Man Called Hawk'' on Saturdays at 9 P.M. This is a spinoff from the canceled ''Spenser: For Hire,'' and is based on a character created by Robert B. Parker, author of the ''Spenser'' detective novels.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Russian Politics: It's Pandemonium
description: The late arrivals had already toppled a fence, surged past the police and cracked one window, and now they were pressing their collective weight against the glass front doors of the Moscow Council of Trade Unions Hall.

title: Dining Out Guide: Country Fireplaces
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings - poor, satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary -are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Randall's Ordinary Good (Sept. 18, 1988) Route 2, North Stonington, Conn. (203-599-4540) -Dining by firelight is one of winter's pleasures, and cooking in the fireplace, as practiced at Randall's Ordinary, provides an unusual dining adventure. Crackling fires dominate the three low-ceilinged colonial dining rooms of the 18th-century farmhouse. A system of fireplace cranes is used to prepare soups, breads, vegetables and entrees in the hearth according to 18th- and 19th-century recipes. The menu changes daily and includes three entrees (red meat, poultry and fish) served with hearth-roasted winter vegetables. Dinner can start with carrot soup and ''spider'' corn bread; entrees might be turkey, leg of lamb and tuna or salmon steak. Lunch is $4.50 to $7.50 and is served from noon to 2 P.M. Friday to Sunday. Dinner is prix fixe at $25, and there is one seating, at 7 P.M. Friday to Sunday. Barney's Excellent (Oct. 25, 1987), 315 Buckram Road, Locust Valley, L.I. (516-671-6300) - A Nassau County fire chief remembered for his girth opened Barney's as a bar-hotel in 1893. The restaurant is in a simple wooden house with a wide front porch (the better to accommodate 647-pound Barney). A stone fireplace is the centerpiece of the largest dining room, decorated with Shaker pieces, wainscoting and charming memorabilia. Appetizers include oysters (grilled, fried or on the half shell) and sashimi pizza, a baked pizza crust topped with creme fraiche and tuna. Duck breast with glazed pears, rack of lamb, and seared tuna with peppercorns over yellow pepper puree are a few of the entrees. Appetizers are $5.50 to $11, entrees $16 to $25. Hours are 4 P.M. to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Old Inlet Inn Excellent (Feb. 7, 1988), 108 South Country Road, Bellport, L.I. (516-286-2650) - Each candlelit dining room in this landmark house on the South Shore has its own brick fireplace. Built in the 19th century, the house is listed in the National Register of Historic Places. One of the best appetizers, a special, is warm lamb salad (smoked lamb, wild rice, goat cheese and endive). Another is the distinctive house salad with sesame vinaigrette. The main courses include filet mignon with glazed shallots, chicken breast with cranberry-apple relish and grilled salmon or trout. Hot apple tart is a fine dessert. Appetizers are $5.75 to $8.95, entrees $17.95 to $21.95. Hours are 6 to 10:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 4:30 to 9 P.M. Sunday. Le Chateau Very Good (March 16, 1986), Route 35, at the junction of Route 123, South Salem, N.Y. (914-533-6631) - Built by J. P. Morgan in 1907 for his minister, this imposing Tudor home sits on 30 acres overlooking the Hudson Valley. In the style of that era, most rooms have large brick fireplaces. Original hand-hewn woodwork and paneling embellish the grand-scale decor. The restaurant's French menu features appetizers of duck salad with walnut oil and escargots Paul Bocuse. Among the entrees are rack of lamb with basil and Pommerey mustard, parchment-baked salmon with julienne of vegetables, and poached scallops and lobster with dill, tarragon and pink peppercorns. Entrees are $14.50 to $19.50 at lunch, $17.50 to $27 at dinner. Lunch noon to 2 P.M. Friday; dinner 6 to 10 P.M. Friday, seatings at 6:30 and 9 P.M. Saturday, 2 to 9 P.M. Sunday. with Saturday seatings at 6:30 and 9 P.M; Sunday 2 to 9 P.M. Van Blarcom Inn Very Good (Nov. 2, 1986), 834 Franklin Lakes Road, Franklin Lakes, N.J. (201-848-0650) - Van Blarcom Inn's two genteel dining rooms are housed in a 1780 Dutch colonial farmhouse in Bergen County. Patrons have the choice of dining in the glassed-in porch draped with antique lace curtains, or in the forest green and rose-colored room with a green marble fireplace. On the appetizer menu are crab cakes, house-smoked salmon with shallots and balsamic vinegar, and duck confit with ginger-citrus sauce. Main courses include rack of lamb and poached salmon with orange-hazelnut sauce. Appetizers from $6.95 to $8.95; entrees, $16.95 to $22.95. Hours are Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 10 P.M. Sunday brunch from 11 to 3 P.M. Closed Sundays for dinner until March.

title: J. Floyd Andrews, 69; Founded an Airline
description: J. Floyd Andrews, the retired president of Pacific Southwest Airlines, died of lung cancer Tuesday at Sharp Memorial Hospital in San Diego. He was 69 years old and lived in San Diego.

title: Chauncey Stillman, 81, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Chauncey Devereux Stillman, an investor and philanthropist, died Tuesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Wicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sister Helen M. Ingraham, Educator, 101
description: Sister Helen Madeline Ingraham, who in 1919 founded Emmanuel College, the first Roman Catholic college for women in New England, died Tuesday. She was 101 years old.

title: Franklin's Birthday
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Fugitives, Ne Fugitifs
description: ''Three Fugitives,'' which opens today at the Sutton and other theaters, demonstrates that there's all the difference in the world between what is actually funny and what merely appears to be. This comedy has the earmarks of humor and even a few genuine laughs, but it also has a prefabricated, automatic-pilot feeling. In fact it is prefabricated, being an American remake of a French film (''Les Fugitifs''), by the same director (Francis Veber), that has not yet been released here. Something else ''Three Fugitives'' demonstrates is that humor does not necessarily speak in an international language.

title: Stone Agrees To Acquire Paper Maker
description: In the first of what could be several friendly takeover deals outside the country, the Stone Container Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy Consolidated-Bathurst Inc., a big Canadian paper and packaging company, for $2.6 billion in cash.

title: Message From Kabul
description: Among the world leaders who sent congratulatory messages to President Bush was Najibullah, the President of Afghanistan. The Afghan Embassy was so eager to get his message out that it took the unusual step of reprinting it in a four-page press release.

title: Procter & Gamble Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Flames Show Rangers Why They're Top Team
description: There wasn't much the Rangers could do all night, and so there wasn't much they could find to say about the game after it was over. Quiet resignation to the obvious had characterized their play against the Flames, and thus it dominated their muted conversation afterward.

title: Wilson's Agent Reacts
description: The agent for Stanley Wilson of the Cincinnati Bengals, the running back suspended before the Super Bowl last Sunday because of drug use, said yesterday that the Bengals might have contributed to Wilson's relapse into cocaine use by not closely monitoring his nonfootball activities in Miami. ''I can't say they're totally to blame, but there are things you have to do under the simplest form of rehabilitation that weren't done,'' said Reginald Turner of Los Angeles, the agent. ''When we all put our heads together, we might be able to find out just where we all slipped up with Stanley. Not taking any shots at Miami, because cocaine is everywhere, but it is probably more prevalent there than anywhere else in America. It was an obvious fact we couldn't overlook. We had some extra concerns about Stanley, but we didn't expect a relapse.'' Coach Sam Wyche took exception to Turner's observations. ''That bothers me, especially after the extra hundred miles we've walked with Stanley this year,'' he said. ''Stanley's an adult. Our responsibility was fulfilled. We can't baby-sit him for the rest of his life.''(AP)

title: Books of The Times; A Simple Miracle to Start, Then High Complexity
description: The Satanic Verses By Salman Rushdie 547 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Educational Mediocrity Hurts Our Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes Asked in 24 A-Plants
description: The protective containment vessels on nearly one-quarter of the nation's commercial nuclear reactors should be modified to reduce the risk of rupture in a major accident, the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: Givenchy: Romance You Can Count On
description: Couture designers are not obligated to create a brave new world of fashion with every collection. Making clothes that help women look pretty and feel secure is also an accomplishment. Because he is so skilled at designing clothes that are flattering and familiar without looking strange, Hubert de Givenchy received a standing ovation this morning from an international audience of retailers and customers. A woman who is not sure about her taste could hardly go wrong by picking almost any of his designs.

title: Cooper Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kean Chooses Nominee For Attorney General
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean today said he will nominate Peter Perretti Jr., a partner in a Newark law firm, as state Attorney General. Mr. Perretti, 57 years old, would succeed W. Cary Edwards, who resigned last week to consider a possible run for governor.

title: Account Review Is Set By Shearson Lehman
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton has placed its $25 million advertising account, which has been at McCann-Erickson in one form or another for more than five years, into review, a McCann spokeswoman said yesterday. Last fall the agency created a sober, straightforward ad campaign in which former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was interviewed by Richard Valeriani, the former television news reporter.

title: Educational Mediocrity Hurts Our Economy; Find Bright Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Chester Hammond, 77, A Retired Industrialist
description: Chester Hammond, a retired industrialist who served as a millitary aide to Franklin D. Roosevelt, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at the Maplewood Manse Rest Home in Peterborough, N.H. He was 77 years old and lived in Peterborough.

title: Mead Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $11.4 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary loss of $1.5 million for the both periods.

title: American President Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Dallas Office for DDB
description: DDB Needham Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, said it would open a Dallas office, exclusively to service the $20 million American Airlines international account that the agency retained after a six-week competition with Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Dallas. Bozell will continue to handle the $120 million domestic account.

title: Dow Jones & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings in 1988 included after-tax gains of $68,034,000, or 71 cents a share, largely from the February sale of the company's book- publishing unit, Richard D. Irwin Inc. In the first quarter of 1987, the company recorded a non-recurring after- tax gain of $29,364,000, or 30 cents a share. Excluding these transactions, Dow Jones' 1988 earnings were $160,144,000, or $1.65 share, compared with $173,654,000, or $1.80. The company also said it has consolidated Telerate's results with its own since Oct. 1, 1987. Thus, 100 percent of Telerate's revenue, expenses and operating income are included in the operating results of Dow Jones. Earnings of the minority interests in Telerate not owned by Dow Jones are deducted in calculating net income. Prior to the 1987 fourth quarter, Telerate's contribution was reflected through the equity method of accounting and was not shown in Dow Jones' operating results. This change accounts for the large increase in revenue in 1988.

title: How Albany Can Keep Libraries Open When Schools Are Closed
description: To the Editor:

title: Colgate to Rename a Toothpaste
description: After more than three years of pressure from shareholders, religious groups and blacks, the Colgate-Palmolive Company announced yesterday that it would rename Darkie, a popular toothpaste that it sells in Asia, and redesign its logotype, a minstrel in blackface.

title: Brush Wellman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lafarge Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rustic Havens: Inns So Near, Yet So Far From, Big-City Bustle
description: Just a few hours from the nerve-jangling heart of New York City, there exists an almost unrecognizably idyllic world where secluded country inns offer an escape into another, more peaceful time and place.

title: Walsh Resigns as Coach And Seifert Replaces Him
description: Bill Walsh, the offensive specialist who led the San Francisco 49ers to three Super Bowl championships in 10 seasons, stepped aside as head coach today and was named the team's executive vice president for football operations. He was replaced by George Seifert, the team's highly respected defensive coordinator.

title: Will This Scourge End?
description: President Bush, in his first post-Inaugural comment on fighting drugs, said education was very important.

title: Nynex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jury Rehears a Doctor's Testimony on Nussbaum
description: The jury in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg asked yesterday for a re-reading of testimony by a doctor who had said that on the night Lisa Steinberg was fatally beaten, Hedda Nussbaum was ''wasted'' and at risk of death from the beatings she said she received from Mr. Steinberg.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Educational Mediocrity Hurts Our Economy; Study Japanese
description: To the Editor:

title: Harland, John H Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Opera; 'Barber' in Washington
description: A performance of ''The Barber of Seville'' that had the whole audience beaming with pleasure - most of all those who know and love the score best - was given Wednesday evening at the Eisenhower Theater by the Washington Opera Company. A consistently excellent cast, a stage director who did certain important things right, a conductor with the imagination to give the score some rethinking, an intimate theater in which details could tell: With all these ingredients in place, Rossini's wonderful music could do its work.

title: Bush Plans China Visit After Hirohito Funeral
description: The White House announced today that President Bush plans to visit China next month after attending the funeral of Emperor Hirohito in Tokyo.

title: U.S. Considers Relaxing Rules At Its Reactors
description: The Department of Energy is considering reducing its safety requirements so it can speed the reopening of the troubled reactors at its Savannah River Plant, the chairman of a safety advisory panel said today.

title: Board Votes Homeless Center on E. 77th St.
description: The Board of Estimate, ending months of controversy, voted last night to finance a 24-hour drop-in center for 75 homeless men and women on the Upper East Side.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Sounds of Ghana

title: Report Says Math Teaching In U.S. Needs an Overhaul
description: The way mathematics is taught and perceived in the United States needs a major overhaul because most students leave school without enough skills to meet job demands or to continue their education effectively, prominent mathematicians, scientists and engineers said in a report today.

title: Review/Music; Playing With Ideas, in Different Voices
description: There was a bit of esthetic tension onstage at the Blue Note on Monday night. The saxophonist Kenny Garrett and the pianist Geri Allen, who have known each other since they were children in Detroit, play with different musical voices. Mr. Garrett is an old-fashioned blistering soloist whose playing is infused with soul and blues ideas that often reach exultant climaxes, fervent as a gospel performance.

title: France Vows No Cover-Up
description: The French Finance Minister promised a parliamentary committee today that there would be no cover-up of an insider trading scandal involving a close friend of President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Liberal? Conservative? What's in a Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: At Weill Hall
description: Mary Ann Hart, the mezzo-soprano who won third prize in the 1987 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition, is to sing Dominick Argento's ''Diary of Virginia Woolf,'' Ravel's ''Chansons Madecasses'' and music by George Gershwin and Irving Berlin at 8 tonight at Weill Recital Hall. Tickets are $12. Information: 247-7800.

title: BRIEFS
description: Preferred Stock

title: Hershel Cohen, 89, Retired Rabbi in Jersey
description: Rabbi Hershel Cohen, a Talmudic scholar and the spiritual leader of Ahawas Achim B'nai Jacob synagogue in Newark for several decades, died of congestive heart failure last Friday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 89 years old and a resident of Livingston.

title: 'User Fee' on Savings: What It Means
description: When Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady casually mentioned on Tuesday that his staff was considering imposing a ''user fee'' on customers at banks and savings institutions, a storm of protest arose.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Blythe's Mood at Indigo

title: Review/Music; The Not-So-Serious Strauss
description: The Johann Strauss family and its immediate predecessors wrote music the Viennese public vastly preferred to Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, Bruckner and Mahler. We should not forget that a repertory so delicious to us was, in its way, painful to them.

title: Prague Releases 6 Protesters
description: Communist authorities in Czechoslovakia have released six human-rights advocates arrested 10 days ago at a rally in central Prague, an emigre source reported today. But the banned playwright Vaclav Havel and two other dissidents remain in custody and, like the six who were released Wednesday in Prague, face trial on charges of disturbing the peace and hooliganism.

title: Squibb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales represent net sales. The company said average shares used to compute the per share amounts were 98,955,000 in 1988 and 104,740,000 in 1987.

title: Telerate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 With Classics
description: Sue Ann Kahn, a flutist, and Andrew Willis, a fortepianist, are to play ''Classical Variations,'' a program of works by J. C. Bach, Mozart, Hummel, Beethoven and E. A. Finckel at 5:30 P.M. Sunday at CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street. Tickets are $5. Information: 799-5783

title: U.S.-PANAMA TIES FACE 3 KEY TESTS
description: The Bush Administration will soon face three critical tests in the political and economic campaign to oust the Noriega Government, Panamanian political leaders and foreign diplomats say.

title: Garden to Close The Felt Forum For Two Years
description: The Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden will be closed for two years as part of a $100 million renovation of the sports and entertainment complex, its president said yesterday.

title: Death of 3 Georgia Quadruplets Is a Mystery
description: After more than 200 hours of medical investigation, the police and medical examiners said today they had been unable to solve the mystery of the deaths of three infants from a set of quadruplets.

title: SOME OTHER INNS IN NEW YORK AND CONNECTICUT
description: Dozens of additional country inns can be found surprisingly close to New York City. Here are some of the others in upstate New York and western Connecticut, within about 125 miles of Manhattan. (All rates are per night double occupancy during the winter off-season, unless indicated otherwise. Spring, summer and fall rates are higher at some inns.) New York State

title: Muncie Jailed
description: Chuck Muncie, 35 years old, a former running back with the New Orleans Saints, the San Diego Chargers and the Minnesota Vikings, was jailed in San Diego Wednesday after testing positive for drug use while awaiting sentencing on a Federal cocaine charge. Muncie had been free on $20,000 bond since pleading guilty last Dec. 12 to intending to sell two ounces of cocaine to a friend. His sentencing is scheduled for Feb. 13.(AP)

title: Dun & Bradstreet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $625,000. Year-ago quarter excluded a net loss of $2,635,000 and 1987 year excluded a net gain of $12,458,000, or 7 cents a share, from disposal of discontinued operations by its IMS International unit. Latest quarter and year reflected the sale of official airline guides and other actions to restructure certain operations and businesses, as well as to increase operating efficiencies. Dun & Bradstreet said pre-tax costs associated with the restructuring actions exceeded the pre-tax gain from the OAG sale and resulted in a net restructuring charge of $32,052,000.

title: Total Petroleum North Amerca Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included most of an aftertax gain of about $16 million on the sale of all oil and gas producing assets in the U.S. c-Net loss

title: Ms. Pearson, Designer, Weds Aaron N. Heine
description: The wedding of Randi Ellen Pearson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Peck of New York, to Aaron Noah Heine, a son of Aaron Heine of Philadelphia and Miriam Shindler of Miami Beach, Fla., took place yesterday in New York. Rabbi Stanley M. Davids performed the ceremony in his study at the Central Synagogue.

title: Time Inc. Profits Rise by 11.5% in Quarter
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 11.5 percent, to $58 million, or $1.01 a share, from $52 million, or 88 cents a share, in the 1987 quarter. The increase came despite a $35 million charge for writing down the value of a satellite venture.

title: Budget Deficit Falls Briefly
description: A temporary shift in the payment of Social Security benefits held last month's budget deficit to less than half the level of a year earlier, but economists still expect the shortfall for the 1989 fiscal year to exceed last year's level.

title: Nicaragua Devalues
description: In a move to salvage Nicaragua's war-ravaged economy, the Government devalued its currency Wednesday for the second time in a month. Managua has increased the official cordoba exchange rate 13 percent, to 2,300 cordobas to the dollar from 2,000, the official daily Barricada said. The currency was devalued from 920 cordobas to the dollar on Jan. 4.

title: Review/Film; Dubious Housekeeping In Balaban's 'Parents'
description: Sometimes it seems that beneath every mild, low-budget comedy there's a slasher film waiting to jump out. In ''Parents,'' that happens to be true. Except for the few seconds of teasing horror-movie music and the close-up of an eyeball at the very start, the first half could be a television send-up of shows like ''Leave it to Beaver.'' While we hear a tinny version of ''Cherry Pink and Apple Blossom White,'' Michael moves into his new suburban home with his all-American, 1950's Mom and Dad.

title: Portland, Ore., Passes a Ban On Polystyrene Foam Items
description: The City Council has banned polystyrene foam, joining a growing number of communities in which the substance, commonly used in fast-food packaging, is unwelcome.

title: Avnet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Time Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter a pretax charge of $35 million to reduce the carrying value of Ku-Band satellite investment and related costs; the year included a $19.9 million pretax charge for the reorganization and relocation of American Television & Communications Corp., a $1.5 million pretax gain from the sale of creative ideas for Living Magazine, and the $35 million pretax charge taken in the fourth quarter which resulted in a total aftertax loss from these special items equal to 58 cents a share. c-Included for the quarter a loss from the sale of Sami-Burke Inc. that lowered income before taxes by $8 million. The loss, as well as related tax expenses, resulted in a reduction of earnings per share of 22 cents. The year included a pretax gain of $15 million from the sale of Discover Magazine, a $32 million pretax gain from the sale of the company's interest in USA Network, a $17 million charge from refinancing long-term debt, and the loss from the sale of Sami-Burke that was taken in the 1987 fourth quarter which resulted in a total aftertax gain from these non-recurring items of 8 cents a share.

title: Carson Meets With Browns Again About Coaching Job
description: Bud Carson, the Jets' defensive coordinator, met again last night with Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns' owner, who wants to name his new head coach today.

title: No. 1 Illinois Shocked by Minnesota
description: Minnesota upset top-ranked Illinois, 69-62, tonight as Willie Burton scored 20 points and grabbed 13 rebounds to spark a first-half spurt that sent the Illini to their first loss of the season.

title: Maytag Merger Is Completed
description: The Maytag Corporation, a leading appliance maker, and the Chicago Pacific Company, the manufacturer of Hoover vacuum cleaners, announced the completion of their $1 billion merger. The combination was approved by stockholders of both companies and became effective with the filing of legal documents in Delaware, where Maytag is incorporated.

title: Cleveland at Carnegie
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi is to lead the Cleveland Orchestra in Mozart's Symphony No. 39 (K. 543) and the Busoni Piano Concerto (Op. 39) at 8 tonight at Carnegie Hall. Garrick Ohlsson is to be the soloist in the Busoni piece. The orchestra is to play another program at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Carnegie Hall, with the soprano Kathleen Battle as the soloist in Villa-Lobos's '' Bachiana Brasileira'' No. 5 and Bach's ''Wedding'' Cantata. Also on tomorrow's program are Bartok's ''Miraculous Mandarin'' Suite and Varese's ''Ameriques.'' Tickets are $15 to $38. Information: 247-7800.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 The U.S. Embassy in Afghanistan will close, James Baker 3d has decided in his first major decision as Secretary of State, because of mounting instability during the final stages of a Soviet troop withdrawal. Page A1

title: Gatx Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Brooklyn
description: The tenor Carlo Bergonzi is to be the soloist with the Brooklyn Philharmonic and Il Piccolo Teatro del Opera chorus in arias by Verdi, Puccini and Donizetti at 8 tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section. Lukas Foss is to conduct the program, which also includes Verdi's rarely heard ''Hymn of the Nations'' and Tchaikovsky's ''Francesca da Rimini'' Overture. The concert is to be repeated at 8 P.M. tomorrow and 2 P.M. Sunday. Tickets are $10 to $22. Information: (718) 622-1000.

title: Perlman in Sibelius
description: Itzhak Perlman is to perform the Sibelius Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic at 8 tonight at Avery Fisher Hall. The all-Sibelius program, which is to be conducted by Zubin Mehta, also includes the Symphony No. 1 and ''The Swan of Tuonela.'' The concert is to be repeated at 8 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $7.50 to $40. Information: 580-8700.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about the proposed Congressional pay raise misstated the position of Common Cause on the proposal. The group favors the proposal and accompanying legislation to ban honorariums and related payments by private groups.

title: South African Official Quits After Reports on Help to Son
description: A Cabinet minister has resigned following newspaper reports that he had abused his position to further his son's business interests.

title: Asarco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time pre-tax gains of $212.8 million from the sale of shares of M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an associated company in Australia, and $9.4 million from the sale of newly issued shares of Asarco Australia Ltd., a gold mining company. The year-ago fourth quarter included pre-tax gains of $17.4 million from the recovery of excess funds from Asarco's pension plans and $3.6 million from the sale of LIFO valued inventory. Earnings for the year-ago fourth quarter and year have been restated to reflect an accounting change. The company said share earnings in the latest quarter and year benefited from the retirement of all Asarco preferred stock in late 1987 and early 1988. Full year 1988 earnings also benefited from lower interest costs resulting from the repayment of all bank debt in 1987 and from elimination of equity accounting for M.I.M. when Asarco reduced its investment in the company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Three big accounting firms are being sued by Federal regulators who contend the firms failed to detect problems that led to insolvencies at savings and loan associations, the industry's chief regulator told Congress. He said most Big Eight accounting firms would face similar suits. [ Page A1. ] The talk of a ''user fee'' on savings deposits has raised controversy and questions. [ D3. ] A disagreement with a Reagan economic forecast was expressed by the man President Bush has chosen as his chief economist. Michael J. Boskin told Congress he foresees growth this year of slightly more than 3 percent. The Reagan Administration had estimated 3.5 percent. [ A1. ] The wave of leveraged buyouts has probably crested, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, said. He urged Congress to shun legislation to restrict such transactions. [ D1. ] New orders for durable goods rose by 6.4 percent in December, much more than had been expected. Analysts said the report indicated the economy had retained its momentum in 1989. [ D1. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average rose to near 2,300, gaining 25.18 points, to close at 2,291.07. The 2,300 level was first reached on March 20, 1987, and last seen on Oct. 15 of that year, just before the stock market crashed. [ D1. ] People questioned in the commodities-trading investigation are reportedly being told that if they cooperate they will get leniency on any jail sentence. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in fairly active trading, erasing an early sell-off. [ D12. ] Foreign exchange traders pushed the dollar slightly higher. Gold fell to $403 an ounce, off $3, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. [ D13. ] OPEC representatives and independent oil producers agreed to work together on pushing oil prices higher as they ended a two-day meeting in London. [ D13. ] COMPANIES Colgate-Palmolive is changing the name of a toothpaste that is a top seller in Asia. The product's name, Darkie, had drawn protests from blacks and religious groups. [ D1. ] Stone Container agreed to pay $2.2 billion for Consolidated Bathurst, a big Canadian paper and packaging company. Stone is the world's largest producer of cardboard and cardboard boxes. [ D2. ] The U.S. lifted its suspension of Sundstrand, permitting the supplier of aeropsace components to bid for Government business again after agreeing to repay $62.5 million in excess charges. [ D3. ] A.T.& T. posted the first annual loss in its history. A previously announced $6.7 billion write-off was responsible. [ D1. ] UAL earned $45.4 million in the quarter, in contrast to a loss of $80.4 million in the 1987 period. Delta Air Lines' quarterly profit was down 3.5 percent. [ D4. ] Time Inc. had a quarterly gain of 11.5 percent. Profits at Dow Jones were down 14.5 percent. [ D5. ] Shows from Fox Television and Paramount sold well at a national convention of program buyers. [ D5. ] Mcorp's condition will be examined by Federal examiners as part of a plan to recapitalize its insolvent subsidiary banks. [ D4. ] A reorganization backed by Allegheny International was attacked in court by suitors, creditors and a competitor. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The New York Post has replaced the ad agency that created its ''sizzle and steak'' campaign. Advertising. [ D5. ] The Fed and the White House are back in their normal state of muffled conflict over fiscal and monetary policy. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The stock market in 1989 has been a blue-chip bonanza, as institutional money managers leap in. They rarely take the time to study and buy smaller stocks gradually. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: McDonald's Profit Rises
description: The McDonald's Corporation said today that its earnings rose 16.8 percent, to $151.5 million, in the fourth quarter and that it planned to open 600 restaurants this year.

title: For Children; Shows, Nature, Museums
description: ''THE GIRL WITH THE ENAMEL EYES (The Coppelia Suite),'' a ballet show by the Children's Ballet Theater and the Neubert Ballet Company, 3:30 P.M. Sundays through March 12, at the Neubert Ballet Theater, Carnegie Hall, Suite 819, 881 Seventh Avenue. Tickets: $10. Information: 246-3166. ''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' a show by Nicolas Coppola's Puppetworks, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays through Feb. 26 at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: children, $3.75; adults, $4. Reservations: (718) 834-1828. ''SILLY BILLY THE CLOWN,'' magic show, storytelling hour and book fair, 1:30 P.M. Saturday at Olmstead Hall, St. George's Church, 209 East 16th Street, to benefit the Jack and Jill School. Admission: $3. Information: 475-0855. ''NO PROBLEM,'' #10 new vignettes by the Paper Bag Players, set to the music of Donald Ashwander, with Judith Martin, who also wrote the material, directing, 2 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays through Feb. 26 at Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway. Admission: $10. Reservations: 864-5400. ''FOLK TALES FROM AROUND THE WORLD,'' show by the Big Apple Puppets based on five stories, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday at the Puppet Playhouse at the Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' musical comedy presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sunday at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180.

title: Western Company of North America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for the latest quarter included $700,000 of reversal of allowance for doubtful accounts receivable. The quarter also primarily included costs associated with the company's financial restructuring, partially offset by a state franchise tax refund. Although the company reported net income for the quarter, a credit for income taxes was recorded, reflecting the partial elimination of deferred foreign income taxes commensurate with losses incurred in the United Kingdom. Results for the year-ago quarter included $1.1 million of reserve for mobilization costs associated with an offshore drilling rig. The quarter also included approximately $4 million of penalty interest associated with outstanding debt in default. The quarter primarily included approximately $4 million of pension expense relating to a transition charge recorded pursuant to implementation of new pension accounting requirements, $3.5 million of expense associated with additional contractual deficiencies resulting from the return of a leased offshore driling rig in the 1987 second quarter and approximately $2 million of exchange losses related to certain foreign deferred income taxes payable. Fourth-quarter 1987 results included nonrecurring noncash charges totaling approximately $15 million. Results for 1987 included significant nonrecurring noncash charges, including a write-down of onshore petroleum services equipment and facilities and valuation reserves totaling approximately $90 million.

title: New York State Electric & Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago fourth quarter loss was after certain charges, but the company did not list them. The loss for 1987 is after a charge of $230 million representing cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: U.S. and Angola Discuss Forging Diplomatic Ties
description: The United States and Angola have been discussing the possibility of establishing low-level diplomatic representation in each other's capitals, American officials said today.

title: Selfish, Sanctimonious Anti-Smokers
description: Recently, I boarded a flight from Boston to New York. As I sat down, the attendant announced that the flight was scheduled to take less than two hours (it actually took four hours) and consequently ''in accord with Federal Aviation Association regulations this is a nonsmoking flight.'' A large number of the passengers cheered and applauded.

title: U.S. AGENCY SUING ACCOUNTING FIRMS ON SAVINGS AUDITS
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board disclosed today that his agency had lawsuits pending against three of the nation's largest accounting firms for failing to detect fraud and mismanagement that contributed to insolvencies at various savings and loan associations. Insolvencies at savings institutions are costing the Government billions of dollars.

title: Rorer Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hornets Beat Jazz At Buzzer
description: Kurt Rambis grabbed a loose ball under the Charlotte basket and banked it in at the buzzer tonight to give the Hornets an 89-88 victory over the Utah Jazz.

title: Legislature May Reject Lilco Pact, Leaders Say
description: As Federal court negotiations over the future of the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear power plant intensify, legislative leaders are warning that any accord requiring the Legislature's approval will face a doubtful future.

title: President's Successor Is Chosen at Raytheon
description: The Raytheon Company, the electronics company that had $8.2 billion in sales last year, has named Dennis J. Picard, 56 years old, as its next president.

title: German Inflation 2.5%
description: West Germany's average annual inflation rate rose sharply in January, to 2.5 percent, its highest level in three and a half years, preliminary figures showed today.

title: Rough Road Out of Kabul for Soviets
description: Less than three weeks remain for thousands of Soviet troops still in Afghanistan to withdraw through mountain passes dotted with hundreds of potential ambush sites, many of them occupied by thousands of Afghan guerrillas.

title: Harvey Bristol Move
description: John Harvey & Sons Ltd. will keep Bristol in the brand name of its sherry, but the company said today that it was moving most of its operations to Spain and Portugal. Nearly 300 jobs, or about two-thirds of the company's British work force, will be lost when the factories that blend, bottle and distribute sherry and port are closed in June. The company will keep its headquarters in Bristol, the city in southwestern England where it began business in 1792.

title: Truck Crash Kills 50 Haitians
description: Fifty people, including three children, were killed today and 46 injured when a military truck loaded with Haitian workers on their way to Dominican sugar fields flipped over. The truck was bound for the Jaina refinery. ''The driver was speeding and it looked like he fell asleep,'' said a survivor, Louis Raphael. The truck, driven by a soldier, went off the highway 20 miles north of Santo Domingo, the police said. Forty men, six woman, three children and a Dominican soldier were killed, he said.

title: Biogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Media General Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results included after-tax charges of $33.5 million from the divestiture of broadcast services, a $4.1 million writeoff of unamortized goodwill, and a $2.8 million writedown on the Jacksonville, Fla., television operation.

title: Roadway Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the quarter results reflect improved profitability by Roadway Package System, the company's small package transportation division. Results were also helped by the acquisition of Viking Freight Inc., a western regional carrier.

title: Kansas Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Angola Gives Hints of Willingness To Seek Political Solution to War
description: In a sharp break with past policy, Angolan officials now indicate that they will seek a political solution to their nation's long-running civil war.

title: Determining Suicide: Fugitive's End Is Traced
description: When Ralph Richardson was found dead in a stolen car in Brooklyn Wednesday morning, New York City authorities, using a synthesis of physical evidence and experience, determined that he had committed suicide.

title: Knicks Fall With :03 Left; Jackson Signs 5-Year Pact
description: Tom Chambers rebounded a missed free throw and hit a five-foot hook shot with three seconds remaining to lift the Phoenix Suns over the Knicks, 132-130, last night.

title: Claude Hudson, 102, N.A.A.C.P. Director
description: Dr. H. Claude Hudson, a national director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a longtime civil rights advocate, died of pneumonia Thursday. He was 102 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Robert W. Burmester, an accounting executive who died on Monday, misstated his age and misidentified his wife. He was 55 years old; his wife was the former Barbara Hosek.

title: Visiting Hanoi Officials Seek Indian Aid in Cambodia Crisis
description: Nearing the end of a weeklong visit to India, Vietnamese officials said today that they they wanted New Delhi to play a major role in supervising a political solution to the decade-old war in Cambodia.

title: TV Satellite Merger
description: Two television satellite transmission companies, Bonneville Satellite Communications and Wold Communications Inc., have agreed to merge, the companies announced today. The privately held concerns declined to disclose financial terms other than to say that Salt Lake City-based Bonneville would own 60 percent of the new entity and Wold, of Los Angeles, would hold 40 percent. The companies said they had sought approval for the combination from the Federal Communications Commission and would continue to operate separately pending a decision, expected in 60 days.

title: Drugs Found on Jet in Miami
description: About 47 pounds of cocaine was discovered Tuesday on an Eastern Airlines jet that had stopped at Miami International Airport on the way from Colombia to New York, officials said. United States Customs officials are considering whether to impose fines against the airline, which was fined $1 million last fall after cocaine was discovered on two flights in a two-week span.

title: Devils Lose 3-0 Lead And Game
description: The Devils relinquished a three-goal lead and suffered an 8-6 defeat to the Hartford Whalers tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Editors' Note
description: A report in the TV Notes column on Thursday described a dispute over a Channel 13 program, ''The 11th Hour,'' about proposals for the old Penn Central rail yards on the West Side of Manhattan. John Young, an architect who gave the producers information about red tape in such projects, appeared on the program but did not speak.

title: Boole & Babbage reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Excluded a gain of $3,256,000, or 99 cents a share, from sale of a product family.

title: Judge in Iran-Contra Case Asserts He Can Order President to Testify
description: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell said today that he had the authority to order President Bush and former President Ronald Reagan to testify at the criminal trial of Oliver L. North, who has subpoenaed them as defense witnesses, but that he would do so only ''as a last resort.''

title: About New York; Shall We Dance? A Day to Party For the Ailing
description: The 504 patients at Beth Abraham Hospital in the Bronx are very, very sick. So sick that each year half of them die. The ones who linger on suffer from chronic ailments like strokes, Parkinson's disease and multiple sclerosis.

title: Wyse Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income The company also said inventory valuation adjustments of about $10 million (pretax) were provided in the latest quarter primarily to adjust raw materials and work in process inventories to net realizable values in light of reduced production volumes. The restructuring costs of $4.5 million included costs associated with the layoffs announced in early January when the company reduced its total workforce by 15 percent and costs associated with the consolidation of several domestic facilities.

title: President's News Conference: Affirmative Action and Tax on Capital Gains
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: The Ramones
description: The Ramones, a rock band, are to perform tonight at 12:30 A.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), on a bill that also includes Circus of Power at 11 P.M. Tickets are $14.50.

title: Time Marches On, to a Band's Beat
description: The Inaugural Parade last week was many things: a patriotic effusion, a stirring spectacle, a sometimes campy pageant, ambulatory choreography and, not least, a heady succession of musical performances that echoed Charles Ives in its ebullient cacophony. But the parade was something more, a marching history lesson in the evolution of the American band.

title: Ryan, Beck & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Carson Signs to Coach Browns
description: As expected, Bud Carson, the Jets' innovative defensive coordinator, was officially named coach of the Browns in Cleveland yesterday. Afterward, Coach Joe Walton of the Jets conceded that the loss of his assistant was a setback for the team.

title: D. William Violi, 74; Issued Rare Recordings
description: D. William Violi, a dealer in historical opera and vocal recordings, died of heart disease on Thursday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 74 years old.

title: Carroll Sidelined
description: Joe Barry Carroll, the Nets' starting center, will miss the game against Philadelphia tonight because of an acute lower back strain. Carroll suffered the injury during a 112-109 loss to Sacramento Thursday night. Roy Hinson will start. Carroll, averaging 15.2 points and 8.8 rebounds, will be re-examined on a day-to-day basis.

title: Seamen's Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $234,000 and $355,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively. The company said the latest fourth quarter results were after an extraordinary credit of $337,000 and a tax credit of $1.4 million. The company also said the full-year 1988 and fourth-quarter results were adversely affected by the narrowing of the net interest margin.

title: Diversified Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $58,000 for the quarter and a gain of $2,240,000 for the year both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $529,000 and $995,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also included a tax credit of $253,000.

title: Soviets Buy U.S. Grain
description: The Soviet Union has bought another 25,000 metric tons of United Sates wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said today. The wheat was part of an authorization of more than two million tons under the Export Enhancement Program. Counting some left over from a previous arrangement and a newly authorized two million tons this week, the Soviets have more than 2.01 million tons still available under the program.

title: American and Delta Discuss Venture
description: American Airlines said that it was talking with Delta Air Lines about establishing a computer reservation system that would combine the resources of the system now being used by each airline. American's move to join with Delta was considered unusual, since American's Sabre reservation system is the largest in the nation.

title: Customary Law of Sea Allows a 12-Mile Limit; A Call for Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. WITHHOLDS AID IN SOMALIA DISPUTE
description: United Nations officials are withholding food aid from Ethiopian refugees in Somalia because of what they say is Somalia's use of refugees for military activities.

title: Betz Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Subway Restrictions Will Be Debated
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to open a three-month period of public discussion on rules that would restrict musicians, speakers, pamphleteers, solicitors for charity and other people involved in nontransit activities in the New York City subways.

title: United Saver's Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter loss is after a pre- tax addition of $4.1 million to the company's loan loss provisions. The year-ago quarter is after a pre- tax charge of $15.5 million from the writedown of the company's equities portfolio.

title: Senate Panel Moves Swiftly To Approve Trade Nominee
description: The nomination of Carla A. Hills as the United States trade representative sailed through the Senate Finance Committee today after a confirmation hearing in which she said she would not hesitate to impose sanctions on countries that do not ''show results'' in reducing trade barriers that Washington deems unfair.

title: Steinberg Jury Hears Testimony a 3d Time
description: The jury in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg indicated yesterday that it was still divided on whether the defendant struck the blows that killed Lisa Steinberg.

title: Atlantic Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $29.4 million special loan loss provision and an after-tax extraordinary gain of $647,000. c-Net income and included a tax benefit of $4,285,000 and an extraordinary gain of $519,000.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Thursday with an article about plans for a new Police Academy and new housing in the Bronx showed the locations incorrectly. A corrected version appears today on page 31.

title: Schuller Wins Prize
description: Gunther Schuller, the 63-year-old American composer, has been named the winner of Columbia University's William Schuman Award. The prize of $50,000, for lifetime achievement in American musical composition, was presented Thursday evening in a ceremony at the university. The award, named for the American composer, was established in 1981 through a gift to Columbia from the Bydale Foundation. Previous recipients have been Mr. Schuman himself, in 1981, and David Diamond, in 1985.

title: Review/Theater; People Joined Together, Marriages Torn Asunder
description: When J. B. Priestley's ''When We Are Married'' was revived in London in 1986, the production was a tribute to the eloquent art of English character acting. Enlisting such expert farceurs as Prunella Scales and Bill Fraser, the director Ronald Eyre turned a period comedy into a blithe evening of turnabout fair play. To the sound of laughter, timid souls became emboldened to talk back and stuffed shirts lost their starch.

title: Slain Father's Six Sons Reuniting in Grief
description: LEAD: Although he called them ''my boys,'' Stephen Kelley wanted his six husky sons to cope with life's pain as brave men and to keep each other strong in times of crisis. This week, they set out to make him proud. On Jan. 23, Mr. Kelley was killed by Radames Ortiz, an off-duty New York City police officer, in an argument over Mr.

title: And Now a Question for the Press
description: In his first full-fledged news conference as President, George Bush today turned the tables on the White House press corps, questioning the reporters about the convention of the follow-up question. The results were blurred.

title: BRIDGE
description: All bridge players eat, and some cook so that others may eat. Good food and a good social bridge game complement each other, providing an evening of pleasure that would be incomplete if either element were missing.

title: Bush Endorses Pay Rise, Heartening House
description: President Bush endorsed the 50 percent Congressional pay increase today, which came as welcome news on Capitol Hill. House leaders there are hustling to contain the political damage as the clock ticks closer to Feb. 8, when the raise automatically takes effect.

title: American Steel & Wire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $3,878,000 on the sale of assets for both the quarter and 6 months, and losses of $481,000 and $523,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: Dollar Spurts And Gold Plummets
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, passing through the 1.85 level against the West German mark despite dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve and European central banks.

title: Imperial Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,294,000 for the quarter and $4,148,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After extraordinary credits of $1,007,000 for the quarter and $877,000 for the year. Imperial said the latest fourth quarter loss reflected loan loss provisions of $52.6 million which represent the effects of fraud by a third party seller- service of certain automobile contracts, the writeoff of a corporate loan, and an extensive regulatory and accounting review of Imperial's asset portfolios. The 1987 net included a $10.2 million after-tax writeoff of the FSLIC secondary reserve. Imperial said pre-tax gains on the sale of mortgage securities and loan servicing contracts totaled $12.3 million in 1988, compared with $55.8 million in 1987. It said that in 1987, it also benefited from gains on the sale of several of its subsidiaries which contributed $21.7 million to pre-tax income. Offsetting these 1988 declines, Imperial said, were pre-tax profits of $23 million from the sale of Federal Home Mortgage Corp. preferred stock.

title: Trilling Medical Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $58,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The savings and loan deposits are backed by the full faith and credit of the Government, and they are sound, dollar-good.'' - President Bush. [ 6:1. ]

title: Study Notes Fare Rises at Hub Airports
description: Airlines that dominate schedules at airports serving as hubs for connecting flights have in recent years raised their fares at those locations considerably faster than the national average, the Transportation Department said today.

title: Wheeling Chief Quits And Sells 34% Stake
description: The chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation sold his 34 percent stake yesterday and resigned from the company, it said. Wheeling, one of the nation's largest steelmakers, said that the chairman, Lloyd C. Lubensky, had given no reason for the actions.

title: Measures Suggested For Reducing Risks At 24 Atomic Plants
description: The protective containment vessels on nearly one-quarter of the nation's commercial nuclear reactors should be modified to reduce the risk of rupture in a major accident, the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Thursday.

title: Fabricland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Allied Security Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net charge of $180,023 to reflect an accounting change.

title: Krueger W A Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $4.4 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: No More Killing Fields in Cambodia
description: Americans agree on two goals in Cambodia: First, Vietnam should end its occupation and let Cambodians choose their own government. Second, no solution is morally tolerable if it permits a return to power by Pol Pot and the mass murderers of the Khmer Rouge. Now a whirl of diplomacy has brought the first goal in sight. There's no worthier challenge for the new Bush Administration than to make sure the Khmer Rouge gets no chance to wreak new horrors on a shattered nation.

title: Pasteurizing Cheese
description: To the Editor:

title: Gander Mountain Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
William A. Ott, Newspaper Publisher, 61
description: William A. Ott, president and publisher of The San Jose Mercury News, died of cancer Thursday, He was 61 years old.

title: Patents; Speeding the Process Of Making Jelly
description: The General Foods Corporation won patent approval this week for a new form of pectin, the additive that puts the gel in jellies and jams.

title: Giuliani Running Out of Time
description: If Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to secure an indictment of Michael R. Milken, the head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s ''junk bond'' operations, it will have to come on Monday.

title: Fair Compromise on the Indian Museum
description: The collapse of last year's agreement on the Museum of the American Indian means that instead of a New York museum with a Washington satellite, it will become a Washington museum with a New York satellite. That's a blow to New York pride. But the collection finally will have a decent home and the proposed satellite will give New Yorkers access to twice as much of the museum's huge collection as they have now. That's reason enough to approve.

title: Continental Information Sysems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income As reported, the company and 11 of its subsidiaries have filed voluntary petitions for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code.

title: Universal Security reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quaker State Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $5.7 million related to additional pension costs and a gain of $9 million from the sale of certain production and related land and mineral rights assets. c-Net loss and included a $122 million writedown of certain refining and production assets.

ICO Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The company said the 1987 revenue included $5.2 million from the company's Denver radio stations, which were sold in August of the year.

title: Patents; A Crawling Machine, For Exercise
description: Because of the interest in fitness, exercise buffs already have a wide range of machines that simulate running, rowing, bicycle riding and step-climbing.

title: Homeowners Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Albany Takes 20 Drugstores Off Medicaid
description: The New York State Department of Social Services expelled 25 physicians and 20 pharmacies from Medicaid yesterday, saying the doctors had routinely prescribed and the pharmacies routinely dispensed unnecessary prescription drugs to addicts and then billed the Government for them.
