Medical Dynamics reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Louisville Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sprague Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Included in the latest fourth quarter and year are the results of the company's ceramic capacitor operations which were placed into continuing operations in July 1988.

title: E-Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Texas Instruments Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $17 million related to cost reduction actions.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Air Group Inc., Seattle, said its Alaska Airlines unit would purchase six additional MD-80 aircraft from McDonnell Douglas Corp. in addition to a previous order for seven other MD-80 aircraft. The two orders represent a commitment of approximately $390 million.

title: Guilford Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
WCI Holdings
description: The WCI Holdings Corporation, formerly the Wickes Companies, has sold four apparel businesses to Taren Holdings, a corporation formed by Odyssey Partners and James I. Spiegel. The price was not disclosed. The companies acquired are Catalina, Cole of California and Colonial Apparel - all of which were part of Wickes's Kayser-Roth Corporation subsidiary - and the Mode O'Day women's apparel retail chain with 350 stores. Odyssey is a privately held New York-based investment group. Mr. Spiegel, who will be chief executive of Taren Holdings, was previously a senior executive of Gulf and Western Inc. and formerly president of the Kayser-Roth, which Gulf and Western sold to Wickes.

title: Anadarko Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Imtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: INSIDE
description: New Approach in Angola?

title: Valentino Takes Paris by Storm, Softly
description: Valentino, Rome's leading designer, showed his couture collection here for the first time on Thursday evening, and won the city over. With his elegant, feminine clothes, he proved that the best Italian fashion can rival in sophistication the best of the French.

title: L.I. Businesses Feel the Toll Of Lilco's Uncertain Future
description: The continuing uncertainty over Long Island's future electricity costs and supplies is taking a rising toll on businesses on the Island, economists and business leaders say.

title: International Container Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Indemnity Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $111,254 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $1,688,746 for the year.

title: Kemp Vows Effort on 'Appalling' Homelessness
description: Jack F. Kemp, President's Bush's nominee to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, today called homelessness a ''national tragedy of appalling proportions'' and promised a Senate committee he would make it his top priority.

title: Great American
description: Great American Management and Investment Inc. said it had filed suit in Federal court in Indianapolis seeking to void the $163 million merger agreement between the Ransburg Corporation and Illinois Tool Works Inc. Great American, a Chicago-based manufacturing and financial services concern, accused Ransburg's directors of violating their fiducicary responsibiliteis. Great American's Eagle Industries last week offered $18 a share for Ransburg.

title: Patents; Carving a Line With an Electron Beam
description: Alvin Marks, the founder of Phototherm Inc., in Amherst, N.H., has obtained patent approval for a new sub-micron beam writer, a device that carves lines far smaller than those in the circuitry of state-of-the-art computer chips.

title: Ladd Furniture Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Word From Wilson
description: Gary Burley, a former Cincinnati Bengals defensive lineman who has befriended Stanley Wilson, the suspended Bengals running back, said yesterday that Wilson was feeling better and was talking with Burley daily by telephone from his family home in Carson, Calif. Wilson was declared ineligible for the Super Bowl after suffering a drug relapse in Miami. ''He's aware of what he did,'' Burley said. ''He's accepted his responsibility. He's accepted that his football career is over.'' Burley said he had found out how Wilson had gotten the drugs, but would not disclose what he says he knows. ''He told me who gave it to him; how it happened,'' Burley said. ''He told me he didn't remember what happened from the time he got it to the time they found him.'' (AP)

title: Review/Theater; Lessons of Love and Despair by the Sea
description: With its distilled oracular diction, repetitious imagery, and use of narrative indirection to grasp at the profound, the prose of Marguerite Duras strikes one as simultaneously poetic and pretentious. Such self-conscious writing would also seem to resist dramatization. But in ''The Malady of Death,'' one of two new theater pieces by the Talking Band, the experimental company founded by veterans of Joseph Chaikin's Open Theater in 1974, the author's dreamy erotic novella has been turned into an allusive, visually striking tone poem for the stage.

title: Alliance Capital Management reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent units. The partnership's inception was on April 21; therefore, comparable quarter and 36 weeks results are not applicable.

title: Louisiana Land & Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $36.9 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income The latest periods' results excluded those from properties designated for sale. The year-ago periods' results included a pre-tax gain of $4 million from the sale of Hawaii Real Estate.

title: Apple, in Shift, Sees A Decline in Quarter
description: In a striking reversal from what it said only last week, Apple Computer Inc. announced today that it would experience an unexpected drop in earnings in the current quarter.

title: Thomas Sopwith, Aircraft Pioneer In 2 World Wars, Is Dead at 101
description: Sir Thomas Sopwith, whose companies built the British Sopwith Camel plane of World War I fame, died yesterday at his manor house outside Winchester in southern England. He was 101 years old. His son, Thomas, said he died of old age after a ''marvelous life.'' He was an aircraft designer, yachtsman and aviator as well as an airplane manufacturing executive.

title: Teacher Held in Sexual Abuse
description: A New York City public school teacher was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually molested two of his students, the police said.

title: Hawaiian Concern Begins Buyback
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc. repurchased 4.4 million of its shares for $38 a share, or $168 million, from the Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation Inc. The foundation also entered into a standstill agreement that stipulates that Mr. Weinberg's companies refrain for seven years from buying more A.&B. stock, beginning a proxy contest or making any proposals to shareholders.

title: Scott's Tests Negative
description: Kidney tests performed on Byron Scott, a Los Angeles Lakers guard, were negative, but Scott will probably be sidelined until late next week. Scott, 27 years old, underwent tests at Centinela Hospital Medical Center Thursday after experiencing blood in his urine for a few days. (AP)

title: A Decent, but Incomplete, Homeless Plan
description: In his State of the City address this week, Mayor Edward Koch recognized that New York's ''quality of life suffers a serious decline'' because of the homeless camped out in public. His commitment is encouraging. But the program he proposes won't address the most serious part of the problem - the homeless who are mentally ill.

title: IFR Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cenvill Development reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Fiscal 1987 results included net income of $5.5 million, or 39 cents a share, and revenue of $8.9 million from the sale of a subsidiary and the sale of certain management agreements.

title: Corrections
description: A report yesterday about the marriage of Randi Ellen Pearson misidentified the bridegroom. He is Andrew Noah Heine.

title: The Dorming of New York City
description: LEAD: New Yorkers live in daily contact with Manhattan's never ending construction projects, taking for granted the incredible energy of our city and its ever changing face. We blithely skirt detours, excavations, cranes, girders and hardhats. Amid all the recent construction, there has been a significant but hardly noticed development.

title: Timken Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
When Health Care Comes to the Home
description: With more people getting health care at home, instead of or in addition to hospital and nursing-home care, licensing of the agencies providing this service is expanding.

title: Vault Mark in Doubt
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation is awaiting documents from the Soviet Union to begin the process of officially recognizing a pole vault of 19 feet 8 1/4 inches by Rodion Gataullin, which would be a world indoor record. Gataullin, a silver medalist at the Seoul Olympics last year, cleared the height at a meet in Leningrad, according to a report by Tass, the Soviet press agency, on Monday. The previous record of 19-7 was set in 1987 by Sergei Bubka, also of the Soviet Union and the gold medalist at Seoul. (AP)

title: Sherwin-Williams Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a fourth quarter gain from the sale of a unit and other adjustments of $14,195,000, or 32 cents a share. c-Included for both periods a gain from year-end inventory adjustments and the sale of certain fixed assets of $11,641,000, or 26 cents a share; the year also included a gain from discontinued operations of $2,772,000.

title: Merger of Detroit Papers Is Upheld
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit yesterday approved the proposed merger of the business operations of The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News. The ruling by a three-judge panel rejected an appeal from a group of readers, advertisers and elected officials that had sought to preserve two independent newspaper companies in Detroit.

title: KEY RATES
Customary Law of Sea Allows a 12-Mile Limit; Objections to Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Bush Should Learn About Mrs. Roosevelt
description: To the Editor:

title: Fracas on Saul Place: Is One-Way the Way?
description: Is tiny Saul Place about to become a one-way street to neighborhood ruin?

title: Essef Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the first quarter loss resulted from a sales decline of 65 percent in the contract manufacturing business machine and computer segment and from costs of an acquisition and start-up costs of a new west coast manufacturing facility.

title: Crawford & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jury Chosen for Trial Of Murder Suspect
description: The jury has been selected in the murder trial of Joseph Pikul, a Wall Street analyst who is charged with killing his wife and dumping her body along the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Orange County.

title: Lieut. Christopher M. Long And Susan Mosmiller Wed
description: Susan Marie Mosmiller, an assistant account executive at the Reeves advertising agency in Baltimore, and Second Lieut. Christopher Matthew Long, an instructor pilot at Reese Air Force Base in Texas, were married yesterday at St. Mark Chapel in Baltimore. The Rev. Michael Carrion performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph William Mosmiller of Baltimore, and her husband is a son of Godfrey M. Long Jr. of Cincinnati and Catherine Burkett of Stony Brook, L.I. The couple graduated from the University of Virginia in 1987. Her father is the chief executive officer and chairman of the Loyola Federal Savings and Loan Association in Baltimore. His father is the president of Blum Data Graphics in Cincinnati.

title: Thon Sent to Phillies
description: The San Diego Padres sold the contract of the shortstop Dickie Thon to the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday for an undisclosed amount of cash. Thon, 30 years old, was signed by the Padres as a free agent last February and played in 95 games, hitting .264. He would have become a free agent if the Padres had not completed a deal by March 15.(AP)

title: Insurance Company Will Pay For Experimental AIDS Drug
description: One of the nation's biggest private health insurers will offer coverage for an experimental drug treatment that is thought to prevent a deadly form of pneumonia in AIDS patients.

title: Oakwood Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gain of about $980,000 related to the sale of one of the company's manufacturing housing communities.

title: Liberte, Oui. Egalite? Fraternite?
description: LEAD: The drumbeat of the ''Marseillaise'' will reverberate through much of this year's rhetoric, together with echoes of Liberte, Egalite, Fraternite.

title:
Your Money;
Ways to Save When Investing
description: LEAD: The stock market's recent surge, while still fueled mainly by big institutions, is beginning to pique the interest of smaller investors, some of whom swore off stocks forever after the October 1987 market crash. But ''forever'' in the stock market often lasts only to the next big rally.

title: Tyler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,413,000. c-Included a charge of $4,831,000 from retirement of debt for the quarter; the year included a loss from discontinued operations of $6,659,000 and an extraordinary charge of $4,831,000.

title: For Aged, Night Falls Are Most Common
description: To the Editor:

title: Kean Proposes Attorney General
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean has decided to nominate Peter Perretti Jr., a partner in a leading Newark law firm, as state attorney general.

title: McDonnell Douglas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago periods' results included a charge of $14 million to cover the estimated costs of modification of an aircraft. It also said a voluntary retirement plan decreased 1987 pre-tax earnings by $65 million.

title: Faberge Exhibit for Soviets
description: The first major exhibition in the Soviet Union of the work of Peter Carl Faberge, jeweler to the czars, is to open Feb. 8 at the Museum of Applied Arts in Elagin Palace in Leningrad.

title: Emanuel A. Salma, Educator, 81
description: Emanuel A. Salma, former associate dean of the College of Engineering and Science at New York University, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Dolli Holland Weds
description: Dolli Holland and Jerome Coe were married yesterday at the Plaza Athenee by Judge Carol H. Arber of the New York City Civil Court. Mrs. Coe is a consultant with Travel Horizons Unlimited, which specializes in travel for people with physical impairments. Mr. Coe is a vice president in the institutional-trading division of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's.

title: Jerry Blatt, 47, Dies; Composer Worked With Bette Midler
description: Jerry Blatt, a composer and lyricist who had collaborated with Bette Midler since 1975, died Jan. 19 in Amsterdam. He was 47 years old.

title: Texaco Is Silent On Holder Funds
description: Texaco Inc. held a regularly scheduled board meeting yesterday but gave no word after a five-hour session how it would distribute $1.7 billion to be paid shareholders out of an estimated $6.8 billion that is being raised on the sale of company assets. Speculation continued that Texaco would soon announce plans to buy back a substantial block of its stock or declare a special dividend.

title: W.A. Krueger Receives Offer
description: The W. A. Krueger Company, a commercial printing concern based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said yesterday that it had received an offer of $10 a share, or a total of about $321 million, in cash from Ringier A.G. of Zurich. The Swiss concern, which is also a printing company, has been involved in a joint venture with Krueger.

title: 2 Admit Illicit Political Donations In Military Procurement Inquiry
description: Two representatives of the Unisys Corporation pleaded guilty today to charges of providing illegal campaign contributions to members of Congress.

title: Bond Prices Climb on G.N.P. Data
description: Bond prices rallied yesterday on news that growth in the gross national product had slowed in the fourth quarter, a development that could reduce any pressures for an increase in interest rates to slow the economy.

title: Caci International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bush Isn't Entitled to a Honeymoon
description: Every President, conventional wisdom holds, is entitled to a ''honeymoon'' period during which it is socially unacceptable to unsheathe one's knife, word processor or fax machine. George Bush has been enjoying the fruits of a smiling opposition and a blunt-edged press for more than two months now.

title: BRAND OR GENERIC?
description: Brand-name prescription drugs can cost nearly twice as much as their equivalents, and about half of all brand-named drugs have generic equivalents. Once a pharmaceutical company's patent for a drug has run out, competitors may seek approval for their own versions from the Food and Drug Administration. The makers of brand-name drugs maintain that variations in the speed and amount of absorption of generic drugs can be dangerous, but an F.D.A study finds no such variations. Let your doctor be your guide. Here is a sampling of some of the more dramtic price differences for some well-known drugs. Generic Name Dosage Retail Price (per 100 units) (Brand Name) Generic Brand allpourinol 300 mg $11.99 $26.78 (Zyloprim) Amitriptyline HCL 25 mg 6.99 23.68 (Elavil) chlorpropamide 250 mg 8.59 34.62 (Diabinese) doxycycline-hyclate 100 mg 39.58 200.34 (Vibramycin) indomethacin 25 mg 12.79 34.71 (Indocin) propranolol HCL 20 mg 7.49 16.81 (Inderal) Source: Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Associatin.

title: U.S. Study Links Severity of Armenia Quake to Soil Condition
description: An American team's survey of damage from the Armenian earthquake last month has found virtually none in a village only three miles from Leninakan, where the damage was catastrophic and as many as 25,000 may have died.

title: No Headline
description: When Harold E. Ballard suffered a heart attack a year ago, shares in Maple Leaf Gardens Ltd., the company that owns the Toronto Maple Leafs hockey team and the arena where they play, jumped $3.50 (Canadian) on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Six months later, when Mr. Ballard entered the hospital for a quintuple heart-bypass operation, the stock rose again, by $2.75 a share.

description: This is Seton Hall's season in the sun. Much to the surprise of just about everyone, the Catholic university's basketball team has a 17-2 record, second place in the Big East conference and a national ranking.

description: The retirement question has been raised every year since she turned 30. Although Chris Evert has admitted that it was becoming more difficult to keep up with players half her age, she has invariably wrinkled her nose, squinted across the net, grunted for all she was worth and given another tennis prodigy a spanking.

Silver Burdett is a publishing company, and its comment is reported today on page 31.

description: As turmoil grows and security conditions worsen in Afghanistan, President Bush said today that the United States would try to help bring stability to that country after the Soviets complete their troop withdrawal.

description: Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria today joined other East bloc countries in announcing military cuts.

title: 60's Jazz Innovator Returns From End of an Era
description: The pianist Andrew Hill, who is playing tonight and tomorrow at the Knitting Factory, is an expert at vanishing.

title: Youth Held in School Shooting
description: The police today arrested a teen-age suspect in the shooting of four students outside a high school here Thursday. The suspect, Rodney Reardon, 18 years old, of Washington, was charged with assault with attempt to murder. It was initially believed that the shooting, in which the victims were only slightly wounded, had been the work of one young gunman, accompanied by another youth. But an affidavit presented at Mr. Reardon's arraignment in Distict of Columbia Superior Court today said he was one of two gunmen who had been among a a group of ''at least four males.'' The police are still searching for the others.

description: In ''Ivesiana,'' a quicksand of a ballet whose choreographic texture shifts as trickily as its music, George Balanchine made his sharpest comment on alienation.

description: Some people are born with silver spoons in their mouths; if nothing else that helps them stir things up a bit. Not enough, perhaps, to properly mix the likes of protein, diet or nutritional drinks - and yes, why not, cocktails for one.

Carlisle Humelsine, 73, Who Led Board of Colonial Williamsburg
description: Carlisle H. Humelsine, former chairman of the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, died of heart disease Wednesday at Williamsburg (Va.) Community Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Williamsburg.

Rabbi Search Goes On; Abduction Is Ruled Out
description: Almost two weeks after the disappearance of a Manhattan Hasidic rabbi, his family, friends and neighbors are continuing a citywide search for him, visiting shelters for the homeless, hospitals and Jewish neighborhoods where he may have gravitated.

title: ARX Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a $298,000 loss from early redemption of debentures. The latest quarter and 6 months included writedowns of stock inventory totaling $2,176,000 and a writedown of deferred product line enhancement and modification costs to net realizable value of $3,337,000. The latest 6 months also included a $298,000 charge relating to the early redemption of the company's 9 3/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures. The company said the writedowns were a result of the continued decline and stretchout in military contract procurement.

title: John Holden, 77, Dies; Founder of a School
description: John S. Holden, founder of the Colorado Rocky Mountain School in Carbondale, Colo., died of cancer Sunday in Glenwood Springs, Colo. He was 77 years old and lived in Carbondale.

title: DUTCH FREE 2 NAZIS IN PRISON 43 YEARS
description: The Dutch Parliament today pardoned two Nazi war criminals who spent 43 years in prison and sent them home to their families in West Germany.

title: Skoonj, We'll Miss You (And Your Rifle Arm)
description: LEAD: Carl Furillo - ''Skoonj'' (short for scungilli) -died in his sleep last week, perhaps with visions of injustice dancing in his head, compounded by bitter memories. We Dodger fans will miss him.

title: Patronage Takes On Personal Touches as Parties Wane
description: The City Hall job-dispensing that came under an unaccustomed and unflattering spotlight before a state investigating commission recently was as much a case of personal as political patronage.

title: Coping: With Film Processing
description: Getting film developed and printed used to be a simple matter. You took your exposed rolls to the neighborhood drugstore, where they were put in envelopes and sent off. Two weeks or so later, you picked up the printed and developed negatives.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year results included a $179 million after-tax writedown that resulted from a rate settlement taken in the second quarter. The prior year results are restated to reflect a change in the company's method of accounting for property losses. The restatement increased previously reported after-tax net income by about $600,000 for the year- ago quarter and about $2.4 million for the year.

title: Community Psychiatric Ceners reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Caray Named Winner Of Ford Frick Award
description: Harry Caray, the broadcaster for the Chicago Cubs who has been describing major league baseball games since 1944, when he did his first play-by-play for the St. Louis Cardinals, was named yesterday as the winner of the Ford Frick Award, presented annually by the Baseball Hall of Fame. Caray, 68 years old, will be honored in July at the annual induction ceremonies at Cooperstown, N.Y., joining a dozen other broadcasters, including Mel Allen, Red Barber, Vin Scully and Curt Gowdy. Caray, who has been with the Cubs for the last seven seasons, spent his first 25 years as a broadcaster with the Cardinals, leaving in 1970 for one year with the Oakland Athletics and then 11 years with the White Sox before joining the Cubs in 1982. He suffered a stroke in February 1987, which left him temporarily unable to speak. He returned to the microphone on May 20 of that year. (AP)

title: Historical Society Opens Two Conservation Labs
description: The New-York Historical Society, which was shaken last summer by disclosures that many of its paintings, manuscripts and other works had deteriorated in storage, has opened two laboratories for book and paper conservation.

title: Saving Up Nickels and Dimes To Assist the Neediest Cases
description: For over 10 years, the Roth family of Manhattan accumulated nickels and pennies, which grew to amount to $200. Agreeing that their hoard should go to charity, they first thought about the earthquake victims in Armenia or about an international aid organization.

title: G.N.P. Increases by 2%
description: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 2 percent in fourth quarter of 1988, reduced 1.1 percent by the summer's drought. Page 35.

title: Robert B. Kelly, 75, Naval Officer Prominent in Storied PT Boat Unit
description: Robert B. Kelly, a Navy PT boat commander whose exploits in World War II were chronicled in the best-selling book ''They Were Expendable'' and the film of the same name, died of pneumonia Monday at Howard County General Hospital in Columbia, Md. He was 75 years old and lived in Columbia.

title: Jill Burns Is Married To Frederick Kemper
description: Jill Burns and Frederick William Kemper, 1988 graduates of Brigham Young University, were married yesterday at the Washington Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Bishop Morgan Bates performed the ceremony.

title: Albert Hofstadter, Philosopher, 78
description: Professor Albert Hofstadter, professor emeritus of philosophy at Columbia University and the University of California at Santa Cruz, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Santa Cruz. He was 78 years old.

title: Arafat Meets Formally With European Community
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, held his first official talks with the European Community today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls 117, Bullets 106: Michael Jordan, held to 5 points in the first quarter, scored 16 of his 33 points during a six-minute second-period burst last night, leading Chicago over Washington in Chicago. The victory, which ended the Bullets' three-game winning streak, was the eighth in 10 games for the Bulls.(AP) Cavaliers 80, Pistons 79: Mark Price scored 22 points for Cleveland at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich. Price hit two free throws with 51 seconds left to put the Cavaliers ahead, 80-77. Isiah Thomas scored Detroit's last 5 points but missed a shot at the buzzer. Brad Daugherty and Bill Laimbeer were ejected with 9:42 left in the third quarter after they exchanged punches.(AP) 76ers 113, Warriors 112: Hersey Hawkins's 3-point shot with five seconds left lifted Philadelphia at the Spectrum. Golden State hasn't won in Philadelphia since the 1978-79 season. Manute Bol of Golden State blocked 11 shots to break the Spectrum record of 10 set by Harvey Catchings of Philadelphia in 1975 and equaled by Larry Nance of Cleveland in 1988.(AP) Celtics 128, Kings 116: Robert Parish scored 26 points and Reggie Lewis added 24 to lead Boston's second-half comeback. The victory was the Celtics' 10th in a row at Boston Garden over the Kings.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 8, Maple Leafs 1: Steve Yzerman reached the 100-point level for the second time in his career as Detroit, playing at home, handed Toronto its third consecutive defeat. With the 3 points, including his 45th goal, Yzerman became the first player in Red Wing history to reach the 100-point level twice. (AP) Sabres 4, Canadiens 2: Rick Vaive's sixth goal in his last five games helped Buffalo, playing at home, extend its unbeaten streak to nine games.(AP) College Basketball Princeton 61, Brown 55: Kit Mueller scored 23 points, including 5 in overtime to lift Princeton.(AP) Penn 62, Yale 58:Walt Frazier 3d scored 25 points and Hassan Duncombe added 23 for Penn.(AP) GOLF Daniel Leads: Beth Daniel, thriving on a course she normally finds difficult, shot four-under-par 68 yesterday to open a two-stroke lead over Chris Johnson midway through the L.P.G.A. Oldsmobile Classic in Boca Raton, Fla. Daniel had six birdies and two bogeys on the par-72 Stonebridge Golf and Country Club course and finished with a 36-hole total of seven-under 137. Johnson shot a 69, with four birdies and a bogey. That left her at 139. Five other players trailed Daniel by three strokes, including the defending champion, Nancy Lopez, and the first-round leader, Dot Germain.(AP) Track and Field Kingdom Upset: The two-time Olympic champion Roger Kingdom was upset last night for the second time this season by his 1988 Olympic teammate Arthur Blake in the men's 55-meter high hurdles. The competition was held at the Kodak Invitational indoor meet in Johnson City, Tenn. Kingdom, the 1984 and 1988 Olympic 110-meter high hurdles gold medalist, suffered a slight muscle pull early in the race but didn't use that as an excuse for getting nipped at the tape by Blake. Blake's time of 7.06 seconds was a meet record. Kingdom was second in 7.07.(AP)

title: Tower's Military Work Still at Issue
description: Although John G. Tower sailed through the start of his confirmation hearing this week, several Senators expressed concern that his work as a military consultant could appear to be a conflict of interest, and the Secretary of Defense-designate is likely to face more questions on that score next week.

title: Drug Fight at Source Is Also Important, Bush Says
description: President Bush said today that although he thought education was one of the best ways to fight America's drug problem, it would also be necessary to work at eliminating drugs at their source and stopping them at the nation's borders.

title: Ruddick Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Review/Music; 3d Hearing for Tippett Work
description: It is an axiom of music criticism, amounting to a cliche, that firm assessment of a new work is impossible at first hearing. A common alternative approach of reviewers is bland approbation of everything new, since in that way they can be confident of not making a mistake that might reverberate down through the ages. That cautious attitude, however, though justified in certain historical instances, is mostly useful as a shield and buckler for the timid reviewer, who thereby avoids ending up in the next edition of Nicolas Slonimsky's ''Lexicon of Musical Invective.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 28 Bringing stability to Afghanistan after the Soviets complete their troop withdrawal will be an aim of United States, President Bush said. Page 1 Possible collapse of the Afghan Army is a danger to Soviet troops in the last three weeks of their withdrawal through mountain passes that hold hundreds of ambush sites and thousands of Afghan guerrillas. 1 A U.S. survey of damage in Armenia after an earthquake last month has found an almost unscathed village only three miles from catastrophic damage. Soil conditions may have made the difference. 5 Angolan officials say they will seek a political solution to their nation's long-running civil war, amid reports that the Government has had contacts with the Unita rebels. 4 A decision by a South African judge that let a white avoid jail after he killed a black has been condemned by Johannesburg's legal association. A Member of Parliament said she would seek impeachment. 28 The U.N. is withholding food aid from Ethiopian refugees in Somalia because of what they say is Somalia's use of refugees in the military. Somalia has accused the United Nations of endangering 400,000 refugees. 4 Yasir Arafat held official talks with the European Community for the first time. Afterward, West European officials said they backed his call for an international conference on the Arab-Israeli conflict. 3 At a Solidarity church meeting, an official of the trade union was greeted with suspicion over the Polish Goverment's intentions for talks that Solidarity agreed to last Sunday. 3 Two Nazi war criminals got pardons from the Dutch Parliament after spending 43 years in prison. They were convicted for their parts in the deaths of more than 10,000 Dutch Jews in World War II. 3 Taipei journal: When Greeks ask Trojans to step into the horse 4 National 6-9, 32 Savings and loan deposits are safe and all guarantees would be honored by the Government, President Bush said as he sought to calm depositor fears over industry troubles and a over plan for account fees. 1 Two representatives of Unisys pleaded guilty to charges of making illegal campaign contributions, and a Pentagon supervisor pleaded guilty to taking bribes, in developments of the Pentagon fraud inquiry. 1 Questions on John G. Tower's work as a military consultant continue. And the Secretary of Defense-designate is likely to face more questions on that score next week. 8 Lyndon LaRouche was sentenced to 15 years in prison for scheming to defraud the I.R.S. and deliberately defaulting on more than $30 million in loans from his supporters. 1 Stock prices surged again as foreign buying intensified and the Dow Jones industrial average completed its best week in eight months. A stronger dollar and reports of a slightly weaker economy helped push up prices. 1 A ban on the sale of assault rifles has become much more likely after a gunman's rampage on a schoolyard in Stockton, Calif., and a wave of gang violence. 1 The political role of a Chicago area is larger than its size would suggest. In a city where most citizens vote along racial lines, affluent ''lakefront liberals'' are the only white voters likely to support a black. 9 President Bush endorsed a pay rise to increase Congressional salaries by 50 percent, bringing sighs of relief to Capitol Hill. But he said parts of the proposal ''bother people, including me.'' 8 Bush grapples with the press's follow-up questions 6 Bush says interdiction is also important in drug fight 7 President Bush can be ordered to testify at the criminal trial of Oliver North along with former President Reagan, a Federal judge said; he said that he would do so only ''as a last resort.'' 8 Jack Kemp said his top priority as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development would be to deal with homelessness, which he told a Senate panel is ''a national tragedy of appalling proportions.'' 7 Senate panel moves swiftly to approve trade nominee 7 The economy grew at an annual rate of 2 percent during 1988's fourth quarter, after 1.1 percentage points were subtracted to account for the summer's drought. 35 A $434 million takeover offer was made by the Prospect Group, an acquisitions company, for the Illinois Central Transportation Company, which operates the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad. 35 Apple Computer earnings will drop in the current quarter, the company said, in a dramatic reversal from a statement last week. 35 Regional 29-32, 50 Uncertainty over electricity costs and future supplies on Long Island is taking a rising toll on businesses on the Island, economists and business leaders say. Many companies are frustrated by the Lilco stalemate. 1 The six sons of Stephen Kelley, who was killed by an off-duty New York City police officer, say they feel adrift and lonely without their father but are keeping busy and bracing for an agonizing reunion. 29 Twenty-five doctors were expelled along with 20 pharmacies from the Medicaid program by New York State, which said they prescribed and dispensed unnecessary drugs to addicts and billed the Government. 29 The City Hall job-dispensing that recently came under an unflattering spotlight of a state investigation was as much a case of personal as political patronage, with officials finding jobs for relatives and friends. 29 Seton Hall's student base is changing from working class to affluent while the Catholic university watches its basketball team rack up a remarkable 17-2 record and second place in the Big East conference. 29 When the New York City authorities determined that Ralph Richardson had committed suicide, they combined physical evidence with the event's circumstances and a dash of common sense, officials said. 31 A college student and a bank teller were arrested in connection with the attempted bombing at a surgical supply company that uses dogs for research. 30 The search for a Hasidic rabbi continues 31 Neediest Cases 10
