John McCallum Jr., Musician, 36
description: John McCallum Jr., a pianist and musical director for Off Off Broadway and touring theatrical productions, died of a heart attack Monday at his home. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patents; Computer Recognizes 5,000 Spoken Words
description: Kurzweil Applied Intelligence Inc. of Waltham, Mass., won patent approval for a computer program that allows a desktop computer to recognize as many as 5,000 spoken words. The computer can also be trained to recognize the pronunciation of a particular speaker.

title: The Drive for a Fire-Safe Cigarette
description: The Surgeon General has estimated that smoking-related diseases kill 390,000 Americans a year. But there is another way that cigarettes can kill - through the fires they start. While overshadowed by the health issue, fire abatement is gaining new momentum, partly because of new findings that it is feasible to create a less fire-prone cigarette.

title: Widespread Jazz
description: The Widespread Jazz Orchestra is to play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society tomorrow at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090). The doors open at 7 P.M. and music begins at 8; tickets are $8, $4 for the elderly.

title: Johannesburg Lawyers Condemn a Judge's Ruling
description: The Johannesburg Bar has taken the rare step of formally condemning a judge's decision that let a white farmer avoid jail after he killed a black laborer who ran over his dogs.

title: Bancorp of Mississippi reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Correction
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch has proposed a new Police Academy and housing to help revitalize the South Bronx. A map on Thursday gave an incorrect location for the academy and incorrect boundaries for the housing.

title: Article 971789 -- No Title
description: The Prospect Group, a Manhattan-based buyout company, made a $434 million bid yesterday for the company that operates the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad.

title: Seashells And Straw
description: Patrick Kelly, an American ready-to-wear designer, staged an exhibition of his couture styles in his workroom at 6 rue du Parc-Royal in the Marais district here Thursday afternoon. The theme was jungle prints, and the exhibit was a precursor, the designer explained, of his full-fledged entry into the couture.

title: BKW Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.N.P. Rate Up 2% in 4th Quarter
description: The economy grew at an annual rate of 2 percent during the fourth quarter of 1988, held in check by the impact of the summer's drought, Commerce Department figures showed today.

title: Hughes Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soo Line Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said a pre-tax credit of $4,900,000 and $6,960,000 for adjustments to employee reduction and equipment restructuring charges are included in the results of the latest fourth quarter and year, respectively. Prior-year results included a charge of $24 million related to the company's sale of its Lake States Transportation division.

title: Concurrent Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a tax credit of $100,000. The company said the present company was formed Sept. 27 through the combination of Concurrent Computer and Massachusetts Computer Corp. Results of the year-ago periods do not include operations of the former Concurrent Computer. The company attributed the losses in the latest periods to non-cash charges related to the allocation of the purchase price to the acquired assets of the former Concurrent. The charges reduced net income by about $15.5 million.

title: Customary Law of Sea Allows a 12-Mile Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: Graf Overcomes Sukova To Win Australian Open
description: Steffi Graf, overcoming her toughest test of this tournament, beat fifth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-4, at the Australian Open today to capture her fifth straight Grand Slam title.

title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston
description: Twenty-eight Federal prosecutors in Massachusetts urged the resignation or removal of their boss, United States Attorney Frank L. McNamara Jr., today in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh.

title: Washington Court to Inquire Into Grand Jury Disclosures
description: A Federal appeals court here today ordered an investigation into whether prosecutors had disclosed details of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s appearance in 1984 before a Federal grand jury looking into city corruption.

title: Effort to Ban Assault Rifles Gains Momentum
description: A gunman's rampage in a schoolyard in Stockton, Calif., and a wave of gang killings have dramatically improved the chances for laws banning the sale of military assault guns to the public.

title: American Business Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $604,000 for the quarter and $1,785,000 for the year.

title: Kaufman & Broad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,428,000 for the quarter and $3,222,000 for the year. The company said its after-tax income was impacted by $26.8 million of charges and increased taxes resulting from the divestiture of certain life insurance operations and its recently announced corporate restructuring plan. It also said 1988 after-tax results reflected a $30.9 million, or 99 cents a share, decrease in net realized investment gains, compared with the prior year.

title: Anderson Sets State Mark
description: Kenny Anderson, who broke the New York City schoolboy career scoring record Tuesday night, scored a game-high 32 points last night to set a state record, leading Archbishop Molloy to a 77-62 victory over Holy Cross High School in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Pepperell Says It's Studying 3 Options
description: In the latest development in a three-month-long battle, West Point-Pepperell Inc. said it was considering a restructuring, a sale of the company or a leveraged buyout as alternatives to the hostile $1.4 billion offer from Farley Industries. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, West Point said that it had already entered into preliminary negotiations with various third parties and commercial banks.

title: A. William Salomone, A History Professor, 73
description: A. William Salomone, professor emeritus of history at the University of Rochester, died of cancer Tuesday at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 73 years old and lived in Ardmore, Pa.

title: 'Speed-the-Plow' Gets Mixed London Reviews
description: ''Speed-the-Plow,'' David Mamet's acerbic comedy about the mores of Hollywood, opened at the National Theater Wednesday night to mixed reviews from London's theater critics.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about the Army's effort to eliminate contract fraud described an out-of-court settlement with the N. W. Ayer advertising agency incorrectly. In paying $700,000 to cover what the Army considered excessive labor costs, the agency admitted no wrongdoing.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Question are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: O'Meara Leads Pro-Am by a Shot
description: Mark O'Meara won the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am in 1985, the last year the tournament was officially known by that name.

title: At a Solidarity Meeting, The Call Is for Strength
description: Andrzej Milczanowski took Solidarity's case for talks with the Government to the grass roots this week, and ran into a wall of suspicion and disbelief of the Government's intentions.

title: Cedar Income Fund I Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $13,575 from the sale of securities.

title: Silver Burdett Reports It Refused Bribe Offer
description: Silver Burdett & Ginn Inc., one of the largest publishers of elementary school textbooks in the country, said yesterday that it was solicited for a bribe last year, but refused to pay it.

title: Ex-Beatle in Phone-In With Soviet Rock Fans
description: Paul McCartney, the former Beatle, told young Soviet rock fans that he loved them ''madly'' and answered phone calls for 55 minutes from all parts of the Soviet Union in a live phone-in radio show Thursday on the BBC.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 28, 1989
description: The Economy

title: National-Standard Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $45,000 for the latest first quarter and $2,845,000 for the year-ago period. The year-ago quarter also included a net gain of $4.7 million on settlement of pension liabilities associated with the termination of the company's pension plan for domestic salaried employees.

title: Otter Tail Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on June 15, 1988.

title: Dr. John French, 77, Neurosurgeon, Is Dead
description: Dr. John Douglas French, a neurosurgeon who helped found and for 20 years directed the U.C.L.A. Brain Research Institute, died of Alzheimer's disease Wednesday. He was 77 years old.

title: Transactions
description: THURSDAY Baseball

title: STRONGER DOLLAR HELPS STOCKS RISE
description: Capping its best week in eight months, the stock market surged ahead yesterday on buying by American and foreign institutional investors. Traders said buying was encouraged by a stronger dollar and by renewed indications that the Federal Reserve would not push up interest rates.

title: Ambiguity Between Best Girlfriends
description: Cat's Eye By Margaret Atwood 446 pages. Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Brintec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $5,702,000 for the quarter and $7,047,000 for the year. The company said the year-ago quarter loss from continuing operations included a pre-tax restructuring charge of $4 million. The prior year included a pre-tax restructuring charge of $4 million and is after a one-time litigation gain of $1.8 million.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Two Charged in Plot To Murder Giuliani
description: Two brothers were charged yesterday with participating in a racketeering conspiracy that prosecutors said included a plot to kill the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: SAVERS ARE GIVEN BUSH'S ASSURANCE ON DEPOSIT SAFETY
description: Concerned that people were withdrawing deposits from savings institutions after reports earlier this week that the Administration might impose fees on accounts, President Bush sought today to assure the public that savings deposits are safe.

title: Taiwan Goes Fishing for Its Notion of Lost Souls
description: For nearly 40 years, defecting in a fighter plane was almost the only way for a citizen of China to visit Taiwan. These days Taiwan is cooling its invitation to pilots and instead is admitting private individuals from the mainland for the first time.

title: There'll Always Be Bolsheviks
description: It's hard being a czar in America. A few days ago President Bush shook William Bennett's hand and said congratulations, you are the new drug czar. A day or two later Bennett learned the country can't afford a czar right now.

title: The Issue Of Wilson's Baby Sitter
description: Stanley Wilson's agent, an objective soul who regularly takes his bite out of the running back's checks, says that the Bengals may have contributed to his client's drug relapse on the night before the Super Bowl.

title: Review/Music; The Yearning in Early Sibelius
description: All-Sibelius programs are not a bad idea, for perhaps it takes the length of an entire evening to let the dark elements of this music settle fully around us. Music cannot describe places, but knowing of the composer's Finnish origins and then hearing the New York Philharmonic with Itzhak Perlman play the ''Swan of Tuonela,'' the First Symphony and the Violin Concerto Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, it took little effort to associate their sounds with the bleak northern light under which they were written.

title: On the Privilege of Using Signatures
description: BUYERS who get used to using credit cards also get used to just signing for their purchases. Then the bills come.

title: Movie Theaters Finding There is Safety in Numbers
description: A FEW old-timers in Stamford have fond memories of the night of June 2, 1927, when the Palace Theater on Atlantic Street opened with ''Rookies'' starring Karl Dane, George K. Arthur and Marceline Day. There was also a vaudeville show that included Dave Kramer and Jack Boyle, the ''Happy Go Lucky Boys,'' and the ''acrobatic sensations'' Janowski & Company. A capacity audience of 2,000 viewed the premiere, paying 80 cents to sit in the orchestra, 75 cents for loge and balcony and 50 cents for the rear balcony.

title: Tito's Retreat Goes Public
description: ONE shouldn't really blame Comrade Tito too much. Brioni, the cluster of small and verdant islands off the coast of Istria at the head of the Adriatic, is irresistibly beautiful. And he was deserving of the Yugoslav nation's gratitude for having led its gallant struggle to throw off German occupation and Soviet dominance. And anyway, Brioni had a long history of being privately owned. So, in 1949, flushed with genuine popularity, he declared the archipelago his residence. (The year before his government had made the 14 islands a ''protected area,'' which restricted access to them.) Thereafter, the only persons, Yugoslav or foreign, to set foot on Brioni did so as President Tito's aides or invited guests or because they were needed to care for, feed, protect or otherwise serve him and his favorites.

title: Reviews/Music; 20th-Century Piano Music
description: Tuija Hakkila, a pianist from Finland, offered a well-chosen and persuasively played program of 20th-century music in her New York debut recital Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Big East The Best Conference?
description: Ever since the Big East put three of four teams in the Final Four, the conference has been the class of all conferences. The competition level from top to bottom is pure entertainment, evidenced this year with unranked teams now in the Top 20 - Seton Hall and Providence - while the other powers are among the best. Outside the conference, the Big East wins a majority of games. Most of their losses are to each other, therefore, explaining why six teams go to the N.C.A.A. tournament each year. TOM ZIMMERMAN New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Martin Popper, 79, Lawyer in Leftist Causes
description: Martin Popper, a lawyer who was active in left-wing causes in the years after World War II and who was executive secretary of the National Lawyers Guild, died of cancer of the prostate Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: New Curb on Ozone Pollution
description: The Department of Environmental Protection today lowered the limit on vapor-producing ingredients in gasoline sold in New Jersey between May 1 and Sept. 15 to control worsening ozone pollution. The new order limits volatility - a measure of gasoline's polluting potency - to nine pounds per square inch, compared to the 11.5 the state has averaged in recent summers, the department said. It said that last summer, ozone pollution reached unhealthful levels at various places in New Jersey one out of every three days.

title: Directions
description: To the Editor: Mr. Kunstler's article will invite diverse interpretation, as we discovered while driving south from Fort Collins to Stapelton International Airport in Denver. With more than three hours to spare, we hastily calculated what we thought would be an easy detour west, promising much local color and scenery. The three-dimensional reality, however, was a corkscrew traverse of mountain after mountain after mountain, extending into dusky visibility and depleted petrol. Plainsmen, beware. ELLA BURKE Avon-by-the-Sea, N.J.

title: Another Opinion On Dining Out
description: Re: Anne Semmes's harsh review of the Newarker, at the Vista Hotel near Newark Airport (Dec. 18): My wife and I recently dined at the Newarker on three consecutive Wednesday evenings and found total satisfaction each time; excellent menu and preparation, superb service, an ambiance of subdued elegance. There were touches rare in New Jersey restaurants: exquisite presentation of food, unsalted butter, fish knives and forks, petits fours with coffee, Baroque music softly in the background. Altogether, ''a class act!''

title: The High Cost Of Scorecards
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Anne L. Taylor Wed To Robert S. Hendry
description: At Morningside Presbyterian Church in Atlanta, Anne Lucile Taylor, the daughter of Virginia Smith Taylor and Thomas E. Taylor, both of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Robert Steven Hendry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Hendry of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Elinor Daniel performed the ceremony.

title: Powerful Quake in Aleutians
description: A powerful earthquake, measured at 6.3 on the Richter scale, shook the remote Komandorsky Islands west of Alaska on Friday, the National Earthquake Information Center here reported.

title: Computer Offers Car-Repair Information
description: ''WHEN will my car be ready?'' is one of the most plaintive queries in the English language. Trying to get information on the progress of an automobile repair has been known to send car owners around the bend and car dealers diving for cover.

title: THE WORLD: Moscow Revisited; Back in the U.S.S.R., the New Ideas Are Visionary, but Not Very Visible
description: THE Soviet Union is not the same place it was when I left in 1980.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This isn't the first thing I've done that was previously for whites only.'' - Ronald H. Brown, on his prospects to become chairman of the Democratic Party. [ 24:1. ]

title: Planned For Flowers
description: WHAT could be simpler than a planting plan for a flower garden that can be grown from seed? Planting diagrams for two of them are shown here.

title: POSTINGS: Go West, Bargain Hunter; Discount District
description: The success of warehouse outlet stores in the New Jersey Meadowlands about a mile west of the Lincoln Tunnel is leading to yet another one, on a three-acre site at the intersection of County Avenue and Metro Way in Secaucus. The proposed warehouse would adjoin the Hartz Mountain Industries Harmon Cove development, one of several that together house more than 100 retail outlets selling clothing and housewares at better than bargain-basement discounts (60 percent below ordinary retail prices is not unusual).

title: 22 Assists for Douglas
description: Sherman Douglas tied a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I record with 22 assists and Stephen Thompson scored a career-high 29 points tonight as 14th-ranked Syracuse rallied to beat No. 20 Providence, 100-96, in a Big East Conference game.

title: Paris Again Embraces Mediocrity
description: WHAT IS IT ABOUT PARIS AND MUSIC? The apparent collapse - or at best crippling - of Daniel Barenboim's ambitious plan for the new Bastille Opera seems one more instance of the city's unwillingness to deal with musical performance on the highest level. For a metropolis whose pedigree stretches back to Caesar and that for centuries has been regarded as the cultural capital of Europe, the ''City of Light'' remains remarkably content with the second-rate.

title: Inquiries Conclude 'Sex Club' at Children's Center Was Aberration
description: The existence of a ''sex club'' among children at a New York State psychiatric center near Buffalo, a group that operated with the knowledge of the center's management, appears to have been an ''aberration'' limited to that institution.

title: Jill A. Siskind Is Married
description: Jill Allison Siskind, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Siskind of Roslyn, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last night to Jeffrey Alan Marks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Marks of Searingtown, L.I., and Wilmington, Vt. Rabbi Arnold Marans, assisted by Cantor Richard Berman, officiated at the Sephardic Temple of Cedarhurst, L.I. Mrs. Marks is a sales manager for Airline Stationery Company, a New York retail office-supply company. Mr. Marks is in the sales division of Garden Bolt Industries, an importer of nuts and bolts in Sayreville, N.J.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: PAT BUCKLEY, one of the major players in Manhattan's social swim and charity benefit circuit, is photographed constantly, with varying results. She has now reached the point where she couldn't care less if the picture is unflattering. With one exception.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE RITES OF AUTUMN: A Falconer's Journey Across the American West. By Dan O'Brien. (Atlantic Monthly, $17.95.) Man's relationship with the natural world is a labyrinth of perplexing ironies, among them the fact that the faster modern man drifts from his lingering connections with nature, the greater is his yearning to reaffirm his love for the natural world and his need to somehow reclaim his rightful place in it.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SPORTING SCENE The first of what is expected to be a yearly Sportsmen's Exposition is to be held at the County Center in White Plains Thursday through next Sunday. More than 175 booths will display fishing tackle, hunting gear and guns, all-terrain vehicles, trailers, four-wheel-drive vehicles, camping equipment, white-water rafting boats and other types of recreational craft and log homes. Exhibitors have been selected from throughout the United States and Canada.

title: Ground Broken for Memorial For '70 Kent State Shooting
description: Officials at Kent State University have broken ground for a scaled-down memorial to the four students killed by Ohio National Guardsmen in 1970.

title: MAGICAL MYSTERY PILRIMAGE
description: THE SATANIC VERSES By Salman Rushdie. 547 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: About Cars; A Multi-purpose Way to Harmony
description: ''Here is the multi-faceted versatility of a van. The seven-passenger room of a station wagon. But here also are sporty handling and performance that come as a surprise in a vehicle as practical as this . . . If you feel a special kind of harmony between man and machine at the wheel - it's no coincidence.''

title: For Big Crowd, a Big Upset By L.S.U.
description: Before Louisiana State's game with Georgetown today, there were suspicions that Chris Jackson, the Tigers' outstanding freshman guard, was a regional phenomenon at best, more hype than substance.

title: David C. Hutton Wed To Amanda T. Erskine
description: The marriage of Amanda Tompkins Erskine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Erskine of New York, to David Charles Hutton, a son of William Hutton of Dallas and the late Sandra Van Buskirk Hutton, took place yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Israeli Army Lawyer Defends Use of Plastic Bullets
description: The Israeli Army's chief attorney said today that the new orders for opening fire against Palestinians were not only ''manifestly legal'' but under the circumstances just and fair as well.

title: Suspected Mugger Is Beaten by Crowd of Hasidim
description: A group of Hasidic Jews last week severely beat a homeless man suspected of robbing a Hasidic man in a Brooklyn housing project, the police said yesterday.

title: MONSTER OF ALL HE SURVEYED
description: SECRET AND SACRED The Diaries of James Henry Hammond, a Southern Slaveholder. Edited by Carol Bleser. 342 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

title: Whipping Post Is Proposed for Drug Dealing
description: A bill introduced in the State Senate on Thursday would bring back public whipping as punishment for people convicted of dealing in hard drugs.

title: E.M.S. Sees Computer Easing Crisis
description: In the low light of the Emergency Medical Service headquarters in Maspeth, Queens, a score of uniformed technicians labor over the computer terminals that screen the city's 2,300 calls each day for emergency medical assistance.

title: Police Officers' Own Rights Are Not So Easy to Define
description: THE question of whether the public weal outweighs the rights of public workers has been aboil for some years, drawing fresh fuel from the Reagan Administration's recurrent proposals to require polygraphs and random drug tests for Federal employees.

title: VINTAGE VOWS
description: Say you plan to marry this year and are 28 years old. Count your blessings, because you were born in one of the great vintage years of the century, 1961, and you might want to consider serving some 1961 wines at the reception. Of course, it would help considerably if one of you comes to the union rather well-heeled; a case of 1961 Chateau Lafite-Rothschild sells for at least $4,000.

title: Anti-Semitic Incidents in 1988 Put at 5-Year High
description: Anti-Semitic incidents in the United States rose to a five-year high in 1988, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reports.

title: BUSH IS BEGINNING TO SET OWN COURSE
description: President Bush is publicly and quite consciously distancing his week-old Administration from that of his predecessor, senior politicians of both parties have concluded, even though Ronald Reagan left town with his remarkable popularity intact after eight years in office.

title: A Fire Unit Counsels Troubled Young Arsonists
description: Rupert Callender leaned over a small table in his makeshift trailer home, explaining to a visiting fire marshal why he thought his 8-year-old son Danny had burned down their ramshackle house in Little Neck, Queens, last month.

title: >Comforting Young Victims Of AIDS
description: A 14-month-old baby who looks half his age plays with a toy in a hospital bed while a nurse, Bessie Bryant, strokes his head. The child's physical development has been impaired by the AIDS virus.

title: A Salvaged Coin From the Colonies
description: ON Feb. 7, Christie's will auction a New England shilling, one of the many coins from the salvaged ship H.M.S. Feversham lost in 1711. One of the rarest coins of the auction, the plain New England shilling is also one of the first coins minted in the English American colonies.

title: Florida Condos
description: To the Editor: Carol Cott Gross must have been in shock when she saw the response (Letters on Travel, Nov. 20) to her light article on condo living in Florida (Travel, Oct. 16). She should be reassured that there are lots of Florida folks who do have a sense of humor. I immediately clipped the piece to show to my dad. He'll get a kick out of it, and my mother, if she were still alive, would love it. She was more scared of the Commando on Pool Duty than my kids ever were - and more devilishly creative at imitating him behind his back.

title: A CHINOPHILE AMID THE LEISURE SLACKS
description: HOLIDAYS IN HELL By P. J. O'Rourke. 257 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/ The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
description: Eleanor Bergholz's grim story of psychological despair while ''under the shadow of cancer'' describes in detail her unusual, one-year siege of toxicity from the relatively mild CMF regimen for breast cancer. Less than 20 percent of patients receiving CMF suffer the intense toxicity she describes. Her negative attitude is evident in the use of the term ''poisons'' for chemicals that are, indeed, lifesaving. The association of more positive attitudes with better drug tolerance (psychological feedback mechanisms) has been scientifically documented.

title: No Utopia, but to Workers It's a Job
description: In the four years since a shuttered General Motors Corporation factory here re-opened as a joint venture with the Toyota Motors Corporation, the resurrected assembly plant has been hailed as proof that a labor and management utopia could be created in American heavy industry.

title: Cancer: Trying to Get An Honest Answer
description: A FEW months ago I had a mastectomy, but three weeks after that I celebrated. ''No chemotherapy needed,'' said my doctor, the department head of breast surgery at one of New York's major hospitals. ''No lymph nodes were involved, according to pathology, so you're home free on that score.''

title: Illinois Rallies in Second Half To Turn Back Indiana, 75-65
description: Kenny Battle scored 22 points and led a second-half rally tonight as top-ranked Illinois beat No. 16 Indiana, 75-65, in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: IRAN IS EXPANDING CHEMICAL STOCKS USED IN POISON GAS
description: Working through its embassy in West Germany, Iran has secretly enlisted companies from Germany, Asia and the United States to expand its limited stockpile of the chemicals needed to make poison gas, according to Federal court records and American officials.

title: Buying Cable Does Not Pay
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Barbara Ethel Otten and Bruce Edward Hood misstated the bridegroom's occupation. He is a partner, not an associate, in the New York law firm of Sann & Howe.

title: Sports of The Times; Three Cheers for the 3-Point Rule
description: It was only a few years ago that the world fretted because professional basketball seemed to have gotten too big - not too big for its britches but too big for the court.

title: Only the Profile Is High
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bush View on AIDS: Money Will Tell Much
description: AS he prepares his own battle plan for the war on AIDS, President Bush will be pulled in opposite directions. Advocates for victims of the epidemic see a larger AIDS budget as a logical extension of the President's recent signals that he will pursue a gentler brand of Reaganism. At the same time, some conservatives argue that the epidemic is being used to promote a liberal agenda that includes sex education, contraception, free needles for addicts and more rights for homosexuals.

title: A SEASON OF INCONSISTENCY
description: There is a large bulletin board in the rear of the Nets' locker room. The coaching staff uses it to keep track of the National Basketball Association standing.

title: Conservationist's View on Ducks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ron Brown Declares Independence
description: Ronald H. Brown, the Washington lawyer who will soon be elected chairman of the Democratic Party, professes not to think much about the history being made as his party begins to rally around him even here in the South.

title: Lucinda Jenney, Actress in 'Rain Man,' Is Married to John Henry Swanger 3d
description: Lucinda Kingsbury Jenney, the daughter of Judy Atterbury-Jenney of New Canaan, Conn., and La Madera, N.M., and Ralph Royal Jenney of McLean, Va., and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to John Henry Swanger 3d, a son of Julianne Clarke of Chester Springs, Pa., and Mr. Swanger Jr. of Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill 2d performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Corrections
description: Two captions on page 27 of of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about movie music, are reversed in some copies. The performer shown in dark glasses is Brian Eno; John Lurie is shown without glasses. The caption on the same page about ''La Boheme'' misidentifies the male singer. He is James Busterud.

title: Ms. Rommelsbacher to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rommelsbacher of North Bellmore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Gerette Rommelsbacher, to Timothy Joseph Frost, a son of Duaine Frost of Portland, Ore., and the late Vickie Frost. Ms. Rommelsbacher is the manager of mortgage-backed securities for DRI/McGraw Hill in New York.. Her fiance is an associate at the management consulting firm of Booz, Allen & Hamilton in New York. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Outdoors; New Edition of Book on Tuna
description: Whether you are a big-game angler, a student of fishes or simply one who is curious about the natural world, the recently published fourth edition of ''Tuna And Billfish'' by James Joseph, Witold Klawe and Pat Murphy will both delight and inform you.

title: Walesa Wants Talks to End Power Monopoly
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, took the offensive against the Government today, pledging that his goal in coming talks with the authorities would be to dismantle their monopoly of economic and political power in Poland.

title: How Madeline Kahn Works for Laughs
description: ANGEL-FACED MADELINE KAHN frowns. ''Laughter is a strange response,'' she says. ''I mean, what is it? It's a spasm of some kind! Is that always joy? It's very often discomfort. It's some sort of explosive reaction.'' She flashes a devilish smile and then adds musically: ''It's very complex.'' And you laugh.

title: German Concern Said to Aid Pakistan A-Weapons
description: Pakistan has acquired from a West German company a plant for purifying a gas than can be used in nuclear weapons, a German prosecutor says.

title: TWO TEACHERS, TWO WORLDS, A COMMON MISSION
description: LEAD: ''EVERY single child has an internal standard of excellence. It is the job of the teacher to find out where that standard is, and move it higher.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Los Angeles TV station KCET gives an outdated identification for Bruce L. Christensen; he is president of the Public Broadcasting Service. The article and a caption give an incorrect day for the American Playhouse presentation of ''A Raisin in the Sun''; it will be shown at 9 P.M. on Wednesday. The caption also misidentifies the actress pictured with Esther Rolle; she is Starletta DuPois.

title:
DINING OUT;
Where Updated Italian Cuisine Is In
description: LEAD: UPDATED Italian food is in, and so is grazing through several light courses. Yet wickedly rich desserts are also the rage. Restaurant Associates obviously had its research and development finger on the pulse of today's diner when it opened Panevino in November because this lively trattoria offers all these temptations, and it seems to have been busy from day one.

title: Museums That Span Mexico's History
description: WHEN Mexico City had money, about a century ago under the brief rule of Maximilian and later under President Porfirio Diaz, it was spent on luxurious parks, vast esplanades and a grand avenue designed to rival the Champs-Elysees. Today these remnants of elegance remain in the city's center, and it is here that three museums of exceptional quality - the Templo Mayor (Great Temple) Museum, the Franz Mayer Museum and the Centro Cultural - have recently opened. More inviting still is that these museums, though separately administered and financed, together span Mexico's cultural history. TEMPLO MAYOR MUSEUM

title: 5 Indicted in Mustang Killings
description: Five ranch workers have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges of killing more than 40 wild horses and burros. The indictments, handed up Tuesday, resulted from an investigation by the Bureau of Land Management into the killing of more than 500 mustangs since last August, most of them in Landeer and Pershing Counties.

title: Even Without Barkley, 76ers Overpower Nets
description: When the Nets arrived at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, they couldn't have asked for a better situation.

title: Called Shot Is Not a Myth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Don't Blame Professors if Adjuncts Are Serfs; Administrations at Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Max Ernst's Adventures in Collage
description: THE PERFECT COLLAGE, LIKE the perfect crime, is the one that goes undetected. Almost anyone who takes a little trouble can put two unrelated images together with an effect that is amusing or disturbing (or both). It is the privilege of genius to suggest - as Max Ernst was able to do over a period of more than 50 years - that the wildest of incongruities can bespeak both a higher logic and a successful reordering of the experiences of every day.

title: Vail Attracts World Meet
description: For the first time since 1950, the world Alpine ski championships, the ski-racing equivalent of the Super Bowl, will be held in the United States.

title: Price Marks Birthday By Gaining Tie for First
description: Nick Price, who said he was ''confused'' over his failure to win in recent years, celebrated his 32d birthday today by charging from six shots behind to tie Mark O'Meara for the lead going into the final round of the A.T.&.T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

title: Once More, the Old South in All Its Glory
description: IN 1939, IT WAS THE MOST TECHNICALLY sophisticated color film ever made, but by 1987 ''Gone With the Wind'' looked more like ''Confederates From Mars.'' Scarlett and Rhett had grown green and blue, a result of unstable film stocks and generations of badly duplicated prints. Hair styles and costumes, once marvels of spectral subtlety, looked as though captured in Crayola, not Technicolor.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Clone It
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Openness Brings Poverty Out of the Shadows
description: Valeriya Ionava struggles privately in her Moscow apartment to live on a monthly pension of less than $60. Yelena Smolnikova has to skip meals so that her meager income can be stretched to buy warm clothes for her children.

title:
GARDENING;
Let There Be Light for Indoor Plants
description: LEAD: THIS is the most difficult time of year for indoor plants. It will be another month before the daylight hours are sufficient to encourage thrifty plant growth. To make matters worse, cloudy periods tend to last for several days at a time.

title: C.I.A. Investigating Contras' Use of Money
description: In a move that appears to have been prompted by internal friction among Nicaraguan contra leaders, the Central Intelligence Agency has begun an audit of the rebels' use of money provided by the agency, Government officials said today.

title: Art Brut
description: To the Editor: When reading Allen S. Weiss's article ''In Europe, Tracing the Art of the Outsider'' (Travel, Nov. 20), I was reminded of an example of U.S. Art Brut (Raw Art) - the Watts Towers in Los Angeles.

title: An Inspired Lead Defeats a Slam
description: IN the past decade computers have taken over the scoring procedures in virtually all American tournaments and in many clubs. The result is an improvement in speed and accuracy, and one useful bonus: Organizers can offer a type of event that is tedious without the calculating prowess of the computer chip.

title: DIPLOMATS AND BUREAUCRATS: A PROPOSAL
description: PREVENTING WORLD WAR III A Realistic Grand Strategy. By David M. Abshire. 331 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Getting a Handle on the New Mac
description: When Apple Computer Inc. introduced a powerful version of the Mac II last year, it simply added an ''x'' to the name. Hence the Mac IIx. When Apple introduced a powerful version of the Mac SE at the Macworld exposition in San Francisco last week, it decided not to call it the SEx and settled on SE/30.

title: For American Technology, It's a Job Just to Keep Within Sight of the Japanese
description: IF someone picked a single spot on the globe to mark the retreat of American high technology, it might be near this town on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu, amid some flooded rice paddies.

title: Sculptural Links in the Chain of Urban Events
description: FEW THINGS ARE AS DESIRABLE to integrate with cities as sculpture, and as difficult. All too often public sculpture seems an afterthought, a punctuation mark added, like an exclamation point, at the last minute for extra pizazz. Who could not say this of even the best of Alexander Calder's stabiles, like the one in Chicago that sits in front of the great Federal Center by Mies van der Rohe, or of works like Dubuffet's ''Four Trees'' in front of 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza in lower Manhattan?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Diego;
New Tower for Golden Triangle
description: LEAD: WHEN the 15-story La Jolla Executive Tower is completed next July, it will represent an act of faith in the busy Golden Triangle office market, where there is a 27.4 percent vacancy rate.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: My wife and I were recently in Venice, and although we had been forewarned, we found the high prices staggering. After spending over $100 each for a few dinners and even lunches, we discovered Do Mori, a charming restaurant on the Giudecca owned and operated by two ex-waiters from Harry's Bar. The pastas were wonderful and reasonable. The pizzas were of a high quality, and the homemade desserts were some of the best in Venice. It is well worth the vaporetto ride to reach Do Mori, a restaurant where tourists can dine with Venetians for a reasonable price. EWARD ADLER New York, N.Y.

title: Summer Wedding For Patricia Dovi
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sebastian F. Dovi Jr. of Moorestown, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Patricia Anne Dovi to Harlan McBrier Kent, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kent of Redrock, Pa., and Washington. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Water Suppliers Fighting Cap Edict
description: LEAD: THREE of the nine Nassau County water suppliers that formally objected two years ago, when the state's Department of Environmental Conservation announced its annual pumpage caps, have taken their cases a step further.

title: WHICH HOSPITAL?
description: Melvin Konner writes that in a teaching hospital the hand that performs the surgery may belong, not to the famed senior physician, but to the young surgeon standing on the other side of the table (Body and Mind: ''Which Hospital?'' by Melvin Konner, Dec. 18). And that's O.K., says Dr. Konner, because ''it is not the hands, in most surgery, but the mind that matters.''

title: New Life for an Ice Cream Parlor
description: LEAD: AN Art Deco restaurant might seem an incongruous setting for an establishment that serves American dishes at lunch, then switches gears and chefs for the evening, when it features authentic Chinese home-style cooking, innovative salads and American desserts. But somehow, Steve Wu and James O'Shea have taken disparate ingredients and made them work at the renovated Baumgart's Restaurant in downtown

title: STRETCHING THE RULES
description: Not too long ago, a young man slipped an engagement ring on a young woman's finger, and in an instant she was poring over a guide to proper wedding etiquette. She dutifully followed the book. She wore a white wedding dress with a ''conservative neckline, and sleeves preferably long'' (''The Amy Vanderbilt Complete Book of Etiquette,'' revised and expanded by Letitia Baldrige). She married in a religious ceremony, greeted her guests at a reception, waltzed with her father, cut into a snow-white tiered cake and whisked off to her honeymoon.

title: Running in Place?
description: If the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. mounts a fourth campaign for the Presidency in 1992, it will probably involve very little travel. Mr. LaRouche was sentenced last week to 15 years in prison for his conviction last month on charges of scheming to defraud the Internal Revenue Service and deliberately defaulting on more than $30 million in loans from his supporters. Mr. LaRouche said his prosecution was part of a Government campaign ''to eliminate me from the political scene.'' Not so, said Federal District Court Judge Albert V. Bryan, ''This was a case of theft.'' Prosecutors said that Mr. LaRouche, who was convicted along with six aides, will be eligible for parole in five years.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CHICAGO IN PERSPECTIVE;
Market Pressure Makes Markets Honest
description: LEAD: After a two-year undercover sting operation the Federal Bureau of Investigation has alleged that some members of the two largest futures exchanges in the United States - the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade - cheated customers by improperly executing their orders on the exchange floor.

title: A Skewering of Reagan In a Surprising Forum
description: Bucknell University is the kind of place that would put a twinkle in Ronald Reagan's eye.

title: POSTINGS: Facelift on Lex; Gold That Faded
description: The ugly duckling of Lexington Avenue, the 36-story office tower with the esthetics that everyone on the East Side loves to hate, is going to be given an $18 million facelift. The building, at 575 Lexington at 51st Street, was erected in 1958 by Sam Minskoff & Sons and faced with gold-colored aluminum to commemorate the company's 50th anniversary in the building business. But the gold color did not weather as planned. The finish blotched in places, while the color faded to an unpleasant yellow. Koeppel & Koeppel, the real estate investment firm that bought the building in 1965, will renovate it by having the 100,000 square feet of exterior reclad.

title: UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
description: Eleanor Bergholz's article ''Under the Shadow of Cancer'' (Dec. 11), said so much so well. To a person who has been there, it all struck home. I want to tell Ms. Bergholz that some of the pain, the sensitivities about and toward others, will fade -though no feelings ever leave completely.

title: Improvisatitonal Games And Skills in New Haven
description: AN improvisational revue, the theatrical equivalent of potluck, usually appears more useful as an exercise for actors than as an entertainment for audiences. On the evidence of last Saturday night's performance, ''TBA: On Demand,'' the Ensemble Theater Company's evening of games and on-the-spot skits and scenarios, is no exception.

title: A Debt to Pay at Fort Corchaug
description: ON the afternoon of a chilly but pristine fall day, our caravan of government and private cars pulled up alongside a wide, peaceful creek on the North Fork. We climbed out of our modern, climate-controlled cocoons for a moment to gaze through the almost golden vegetation, across the water to the place, ''the principal place'' as its people knew it hundreds of years ago.

title: Florida Condos
description: To the Editor: As a former year-round condo resident in south Florida (for nine years), I found many chuckles in Carol Cott Gross's article and the cartoons accompanying it.

title: Q and A
description: Oxygen Aloft

title: PERSPECTIVES: Midtown Development; No Man's Land Breached on 45th Street
description: THE past and the future are colliding on Broadway this year, and nowhere so dramatically as on West 45th Street. As the construction of hotels, office buildings and retail space sets the stage for the new Times Square that will greet the 21st century, a close-up look at the projects in construction along a single street shows how the crosscurrents of law, business and public policy shape the growth of the city.

title: Review/Opera; 'Il Trovatore' Cast Changes
description: The Metropolitan Opera has packed up the immense pillars and omnipresent steps of its ''Trovatore,'' and sent it safely into storage. At the final performance of the season, on Tuesday evening, there were three newcomers to the cast.

title: Commuter Car Areas Due to Rise
description: LEAD: NEARLY three years ago, Nassau County bought a narrow strip of land that runs from one end of the county to the other. It lies adjacent to the Long Island Rail Road tracks on the northern side of Sunrise Highway.

title: Map Said to Show 1777 Encampment
description: HARRY KELS SWAN delicately removed a brown paper bag from a vault in the visitors' center at Washington Crossing State Park. He put the bag on his desk and extracted an acetate-covered parchment from within. ''I've been looking at these things since I was a kid,'' the 60-year-old historian said, ''but I never actually held one in my hands before.''

title: A Revived Hispanic Helpline
description: LEAD: IN its first incarnation, the Hispanic Helpline at Port Chester High School was a phone service provided by bilingual students and intended to help members of the Hispanic community learn about community resources. Now it has changed its focus and is helping new students adjust to the school.

title: POSTINGS: Land for Wildlife; Friends in Deed
description: Before Roy and Marjorie Parsell died two years ago within a few months of each other, the couple - both were in their 90's and childless - wanted to make a donation to their adopted town of Madison, Conn. They had moved there in 1972 after Mr. Parsell retired as a patent attorney at the old Winchester Arms plant in New Haven.

title: Back on Stage, Challenges for Mr. Guinness
description: It WAS 90 MINUTES TO CURTAIN TIME the other evening in the stately 104-year-old Comedy Theater on Panton Street, where Lee Blessing's two-character drama, ''A Walk in the Woods,'' has been playing since the first week in November. Here, the cast is Anglo-American. Early last year the play had modest success with an all-American cast on Broadway at the Booth Theater.

title: 'The Romantic'
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Ethics Panel Sought
description: A man who fought in court successfully to let his comatose wife die proposed legislation today to create a state medical ethics commission to make such judgments. In November, the man, H. Glenn Gray, obtained a Federal court order to remove the feeding tube of his wife, Marcia V. Gray, 49 years old, who went into a coma in January 1986 after a blood vessel burst in her brain.

title: Many Memorial Gifts Sent to Neediest Cases
description: On the national day marking the Rev. Martin Luther King's 60th birthday earlier this month, Margaret Lalor of Glens Falls, N.Y., sent her first gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases.

title: Yanks List Tryouts
description: As a result of the Yankees' determination to enter the 1989 season with the best possible pitching staff, seven pitchers, including some whose careers had seemed all but over, are getting a new chance to make their mark on the majors. They have been invited to try out at the Yankees' major league training camp even though the team has 17 pitchers on the roster.

title: New York's Planned Parenthood Chief Is to Retire
description: When the United States Supreme Court issued its landmark 1973 ruling that women have a Constitutional right to abortion, Alfred F. Moran, executive director of Planned Parenthood of New York City, concluded that the battle had been won - for good.

title: Honed Hyperbole
description: 'Higher income taxes are a razor guillotine, poised to descend on the bare neck of prosperity.' - Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, proposing a budget that he described as ''bordering on the austere.''

title: Kathleen T. Milton Married To Lyndon Abell in Capital
description: The marriage of Kathleen Therese Milton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Milton of Cheshire, Conn., to Lyndon Abell took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Tyler Abell of Washington. The Rev. Sanford Garner Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Biggest Diplomatic Openings for Baker
description: THE late President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was fond of saying that the United States didn't hold just 90 percent of the cards in international affairs, it held 99 percent. Mr. Sadat's statement was an exaggeration, but it reflects a perception still widely shared around the globe. So James A. Baker 3d began his first week as Secretary of State looking out on a world that is scrutinizing his every wink and nod for signs of how he intends to play his opening hand.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/ANIMALS
description: TAIL TOES EYES EARS NOSE Written and illustrated by Marilee Robin Burton. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: Opera as an Adventure
description: FOR NEW YORK - A CITY notably more conservative in operatic matters than comparable musical capitals around the world - Thursday night will represent a triple-barreled opera adventure. The always adventurous Brooklyn Academy of Music opens its first BAM Opera season with the Welsh National Opera, one of the most advenTurous repertory opera companies in the world, in its new production of Verdi's ''Falstaff'' overseen by one of Europe's leading directors, Peter Stein, who until a few years ago headed one of Europe's foremost experimental theaters.

title:
GARDENING;
Let There Be Light for Indoor Plants
description: LEAD: THIS is the most difficult time of year for indoor plants. It will be another month before the daylight hours are sufficient to encourage thrifty plant growth. To make matters worse, cloudy periods tend to last for several days at a time.

title: TWO TEACHERS, TWO WORLDS, A COMMON MISSION
description: LEAD: SARA MITCHELL, 39 years old, teaches preschoolers at the Fairfield Elementary School here. Her ties to the surrounding area are strong; she grew up in Newport, 12 miles to the south. She says that back then, migrant families predominated in that tiny Cumberland County fishing village tucked beside Delaware

title: New Year's to May Day to Christmas, Clothes Make the Season
description: LEAD: TO celebrate its centennial, only the best would do. The New Canaan Historical Society, which seasonally changes its costume exhibit, combed its storage rooms for its most compelling creme de la creme costumes to be placed in an anniversary show called ''Seasonal Celebrations.''

title: Correction
description: The Personal Finance column on Jan. 8 described decreasing term life insurance incorrectly. Benefits payable under this type of policy shrink each year; premiums remain the same.

title: FICTION
description: ALL OUR GAMES. By Erika Mitterer. (Camden House, $24.95.) In the Austria of the Anschluss, 16-year-old Helga Wegscheider zealously embraces Hitler's message, convinced of the justice of his design for Europe. Like her fiance, an SS soldier, she devotes herself passionately to the Nazi cause. But at home something else is taking shape, outside the scope of Helga's bedazzled vision: her brothers hold secretive Bible-group meetings, her parents' conversation is sprinkled with cryptic remarks. Only years later do the pieces fall into place, revealing to Helga her family's involvement in the Viennese resistance. ''All Our Games'' is a forceful American debut for Erika Mitterer, one of Austria's most eminent poets, whose fiction has never before appeared in an English translation. Complex and multilayered, it tackles head on the agonizing question of collective guilt for World War II, without rationalization but with burrowing introspection. Ms. Mitterer spares few truths. ''We enjoyed the war,'' her narrator writes. ''I was one of them, one of these shabby cowards who only shout with joy for the rich and mighty and despise the loser.'' It's hard at first to like Helga, who tells the story in the form of a memoir for her 15-year-old son, whose paternity is the book's central, page-turning mystery; but we readily respect her for surmounting her own ignobleness. The translation by Catherine Hutter is stilted and literal rather than lyrical, but it can't affect the potent, poetic witness this novel bears to what it was like to live the war from the other side - and survive as a human being.

title: Daring On Great Lakes
description: LAST summer, Thomas Mazuzan became the first man to cross Lake Ontario and Lake Erie alone in a canoe. Now he is mapping out plans for solo crossings of Lake Michigan and Lake Huron this summer and Lake Superior in 1990.

title: NONFICTION
description: WALT FRAZIER: One Magic Season and a Basketball Life. By Walt Frazier with Neil Offen. (Times Books, $17.95.) Although there have been memorable basketball teams led by greater individuals, there may have been no more remarkable combination of players than the 1970 National Basketball Association champions, the New York Knicks, led by their buttery-smooth point guard, Walt Frazier. ''We weren't the tallest, fastest, or best jumpers,'' Mr. Frazier writes. ''We were just the most intelligent team I've ever seen.'' Unfortunately, ''Walt Frazier: One Magic Season,'' an autobiography that focuses on the 1970 season, is thin on background and context: his childhood in Atlanta in the 1950's whizzes by with the speed of a breakaway layup. Disappointingly, Mr. Frazier and his co-author, Neil Offen, a former New York Post sportswriter, do not lavish much more attenton on any other topic: the Knicks' coach, Red Holtzman, and Mr. Frazier's teammates - including Bill Bradley, Dave DeBusschere, Dick Barnett and Willis Reed - appear as mere sketches. An account of the record-setting 18-game winning streak early in the season is so much wood to be chopped, and the rest of Mr. Frazier's career is an afterthought (the Knicks won another title three years later but ''the funny thing is, I can barely remember that second championship''). Even the description of the climactic seventh game of the 1970 championship against Wilt Chamberlain's Lakers, enlivened by the undeniable drama of Mr. Reed's wounded glory, is more perfunctory than moving. The book, which suffers from the cautious, steady style that made Mr. Frazier successful as a player and television commentator, is forgotten as quickly as it is read. What remains is what existed before: the memory of an ineffably wonderful basketball team.

title: Value of Foreign Disaster Relief Is Questioned
description: Despite worldwide eagerness to provide medical aid to victims of natural catastrophes, assistance flown in from far away has generally proved of little value, according to reports presented this week to a workshop at the United Nations.

title: Truth - And Its Consequences
description: To the Editor:

title: By the Bay, by the Beautiful Bay
description: THROUGH the four-foot-high porthole windows of Port Washington's Bayview Restaurant, diners can see Manhasset Bay, dull and gray under lowering late-January skies. But inside, it's springtime.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CALDECOTT & CO.: Notes on Books & Pictures. By Maurice Sendak. (Michael di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) Though culled from such varied forms as essays, speeches, and reviews from a period of 33 years, the 32 pieces in ''Caldecott & Co.,'' this first collection of critical writings by the author and illustrator Maurice Sendak, offer a remarkably clear and consistent vision of excellence in both children's picture books and popular culture.

title: Minority Works Challenge Boundaries
description: THE setting is Snug Harbor's Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, on Staten Island; the action is provided by the 14 artists contributing to ''Bridges and Boundaries.''

title: Bush Finds Social Issues Can Shorten A Honeymoon
description: PRESIDENT BUSH's first week in office was supposed to highlight ethics in government, good will in Congress, congratulations from abroad and a feeling of national cheerfulness. But a shower of social and economic debates dampened the careful programming, demonstrating that deep disagreements over domestic priorities can be set aside only briefly for initiation rituals like the Democratic leaders' bearing gifts of pork rinds and hot sauce to the new President.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Jersey, Two Weeks of Woe Hound Russo
description: Things might have gone worse for the President of the New Jersey Senate over the past two weeks, but it's hard to imagine how.

title: A Bit of Slinky
description: Sling-back pumps by Valentino establish the delicate, sexy look of his spring-summer couture collection, shown in Paris this week.

GARDENING;

description: LEAD: THIS is the most difficult time of year for indoor plants. It will be another month before the daylight hours are sufficient to encourage thrifty plant growth. To make matters worse, cloudy periods tend to last for several days at a time.

title: Amy Rappeport, Publisher, Weds Thomas Teicholz
description: Amy Louise Rappeport, the publisher of New York Woman magazine, and Thomas David Teicholz, a writer and lawyer, were married yesterday at the Loft in New York by Rabbi Rolando Matalon.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bozeman, Mont.;
Resurrecting A Railway Inn
description: LEAD: BILL KESHISHIAN and his mother, Catherine Wrather, spent $500,000 in 1985 to buy the 24,000-square-foot, 26-room Gallatin Gateway Inn, with its 15-acre tract and several out buildings.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Downhill on Skis and a Prayer
description: LEAD: WHEN my husband prepares for trips to ski resorts, he tries on his ski jacket, checks his boots and sharpens his skis. I wax my American Express card.

title: Prospects; Affirmative Action's Future
description: Last Monday the Supreme Court made a ruling that invalidated a law in Richmond setting aside 30 percent of all municipal contracts for minority-owned companies. The ruling by the Court cast doubt on other minority set-aside programs in more than 200 municipalities around the country. Four experts look at the implications of the Court's decision for minority-owned businesses. Eva Clayton President, Technical Resources International Ltd.

title: Plaza Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Designs on A Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: The Legacy Of Nikos
description: EARLY IN MY 20-YEAR CAREER at the Williamstown Theater Festival, I was taking notes at a rehearsal of the balcony scene from ''Cyrano de Bergerac.'' The director turned away briefly from a spirited dialogue with Cyrano, Christian and Roxanne, steered me into a corner and whispered: ''O.K., Stephen - get rid of that person.''

title: Records Awe Molloy Star
description: When the season began it was reasonable to expect that Kenny Anderson would break the New York City and State high school career scoring records if he had a good year.

description: A couple and their 14-year-old son have been charged in a series of sexual crimes involving the couple's 11-year-old daughter, the police said today.

description: Boston College provided little resistance against Seton Hall this afternoon.

title: Abortion, Intolerance and Mr. Bush
description: George Bush once said that he wanted to be President of ''all the people'' of the United States. Since this is a country with a remarkably, and often unnervingly, diverse citizenry, that's a tall order but an indispensable duty.

title: Blacks Battle Fellow Blacks in Natal
description: The danger peaks around midnight, Xakile Duma said, when vigilantes stalk the streets of the black township of Imbali.

title: Few Show Up For Workfare Jobs
description: THREE weeks after introducing a ''workfare'' program that links welfare benefits to supervised work, county officials are finding that relatively few recipients are showing up for the program, despite the risk of losing their assistance.

title: In a Burmese Town, a Voice of Fear
description: The civil servant, surprised and tentative, invited his visitors to come in. He said he would not speak of politics, because as a Government employee he was not supposed to take part in political activities.

title: Israel Reviews Military Tactics, and Sees Only Defiance
description: AFTER 408 days, 6,000 arrests, at least 361 deaths and many thousands of injuries, the Palestinian uprising still rumbles steadily along, barely deterred by Israel's ever-changing tactics for suppressing it. But now for the first time, Israeli Army officers as well as other leading officials are acknowledging with frustration and despair that nothing they can do will end it.

title: Contemporary American Works and Salvador Dali
description: IN 1963, Larry Aldrich put up for auction paintings and drawings that he had been amassing since 1937. Most were European - Picassos, Miros, Vuillards, Dubuffets, a Monet ''Water Lillies'' and an early Matisse landscape - but there were exceptions, like the circa 1949 de Kooning of two women.

title: Marilyn Forman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Forman of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marilyn Forman to Glenn R. Jacobowitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Jacobowitz of Convent Station, N.J. Ms. Forman and her fiance, both fourth-year medical students at New York University, plan to marry in June.

title: Plant's Opponents Widen Their Goals
description: SINCE a 28-inch-wide pipeline burst, spewing toxic substances into a residential neighborhood here in April 1984, residents' opposition to the Ciba-Geigy Corporation, which manufactures chemicals and plastics, has been unrelenting.

title: Truth - And Packaging
description: To the Editor:

title: Joy C. Schaefer and Gregory Teal Wed
description: The marriage of Joy Challenor Schaefer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Moran Schaefer of Loudonville, N.Y., New York City, Vero Beach, Fla., and Nantucket, Mass., to Gregory Edward Teal, a son of Mrs. Carl Ernst of Menands, N.Y., and Edward A. Teal of Fremont, Calif., took place yesterday in Albany. The Rev. Robert E. Eggenschiller and the Rev. Dr. Laman H. Bruner Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Gimme a D-U-F and an F-E-L!
description: NO one would ever mistake Fifth Avenue for the quad at old Ivy U., but a lot of people strolling up and down the avenue recently have had a certain collegiate air about them. Could it be the words of the Great Philosophers one often hears quoted in passing conversations outside Trump Tower, Bergdorf Goodman and Tiffany's? No, more likely it's that so many people seem to be wearing duffel coats and looking as if they're on their way to a field hockey game between Middlebury and Bowdoin.

title: Review of Bush's Opening Week: a Few 'Ripples' but No Bursting Bubbles
description: George Bush ended his first week as President by having some friends over to the family quarters of the White House on Friday night for beef pie and a screening of the movie ''Working Girl.'' He warned his guests, a mix of prominent Democrats and Republicans, that he had heard that the film about a Wall Street Cinderella had some ''dirty parts,'' so they had better watch out.

title: >New Jersey Q & A: Keith Ferris; Putting the Brush to Air History
description: SOME artists believe in painting what they see, but that isn't good enough for Keith Ferris. Mr. Ferris, a 59-year-old aviation artist, seeks out an experience as well, and admirers say it is that attitude that helps to distinguish him from others in the field.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CANDLELIGHT CONCERT

title: Group Honoring Stalin Victims Seeks Legal Status
description: A group dedicated to exposing Stalin's crimes, honoring his victims and eradicating lingering Stalinist practices moved today to legalize its standing and establish itself as a significant political force.

title: Panel Will Examine Land Use in Adirondack Park
description: The president of the National Audubon Society, Peter A. A. Berle, will head a new state commission to plan the future of the Adirondack Park, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced today.

title: 'We Have Tremendous Brain Power'
description: THE Governor's choice to be the state's new Economic Development Commissioner is Stephen Heintz. The Commissioner is responsible for attracting and retaining business in the state, and he and and a staff of 100 employees also coordinate business education and development programs. The department has a budget of $8.5 million.

title: Guess Who'll Bail Out the Thrifts?
description: Who is going to pay for the savings and loan fiasco - taxpayers or the banking industry?

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots. Can you explain why this mildew occurred?

title: Steinberg Jury Asks Judge to Define Lesser Charge
description: The jury in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg asked the presiding judge yesterday to define the elements of first-degree manslaughter, one of the lesser charges Mr. Steinberg faces in the death of Lisa Steinberg.

title: State Cautions Diners On Menu Half-Truths
description: WHEN the State Department of Consumer Protection tells Connecticut restaurants ''no substitutions, please,'' it means no fake crabmeat, no jumbo shrimp that is not really jumbo shrimp, and no other half-truths on the menu.

title: Sherrill Paid Player
description: A university investigation has confirmed that Jackie Sherrill, who resigned as the Texas A&M football coach last month, gave $1,500 to a former player, but the investigators said they found no evidence that the payments had been hush money.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Nutley
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Nutley is just 12 miles from Manhattan and eight from the heart of Newark, it has steadfastly set its own course for 300 years. Today its quiet neighborhoods with stately old homes and verdant parks make it a 3.5-square-mile suburban oasis in the urbanized northeastern corner of Essex County.

title: FICTION
description: BLUE HEAVEN. By Joe Keenan. (Penguin, Paper, $7.95.) Gilbert Selwyn is a broke, gay author with a heart of gold who is too lazy even to have writer's block. Moira Finch is a broke, straight social climber with a heart of unalloyed steel who has a penchant for disastrous investments. ''Blue Heaven'' is their nuptial adventure story, following them as they embark on a marriage designed to swindle their rich but parsimonious families out of a fortune in wedding gifts. Greed, lust, blackmail, petty jealousy - they're all here, described with glib alacrity by Gilbert's best friend (and sometime lover) Philip Cavanaugh, a struggling songwriter who is in for a cut. As Gilbert and Moira try to outfox their families, their friends and each other, they confront the wrath of both his Mafia stepfamily and an affected SoHo designer who speaks ''as if it were midnight and she was standing on a railway platform in Zurich, fingering the blueprints under her trenchcoat while waiting for the Belgian with the carnation'' - not to mention the ire of assorted muscular, jilted ex-lovers. By the time the plot escalates to a scene in which a drug-addled transvestite bank officer impersonates Moira's dear Mummy, the Duchess, for the benefit of Gilbert's family, it's clear that Joe Keenan has put the high back in high jinks. His sendups of trendy poseurs and criminal nouveaux riches are biting and dead on. Mr. Keenan, a playwright and lyricist, has a good ear for a gag (''I soon learned,'' his narrator reports, ''that though mafiosi are heinous sorts with no respect for law or the sanctity of human life, they do, as a class, tip well'') and his dialogue is refreshingly effervescent. This novel will be thoroughly enjoyed whenever there's a little time to kill - on the beach, in transit or while bedridden with a lingering cold. ''Blue Heaven'' may not be ethereal literature, but it certainly has the gift of gab.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NORWICH;
A City Becomes a Haven for the Poor
description: LEAD: BEVERLY GOULET remembers Saturday shopping trips to downtown Norwich when she was a little girl. The downtown area was bustling with people who came to shop and stroll. Now, many of those shops are closed, and downtown Norwich has increasingly become a haven for the poor.

title: No Big Changes in '89 Federal Arts Budget
description: Government officials and lobbyists expect the Bush Administration's forthcoming culture budget to be virtually identical to the levels of arts and humanities spending proposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: Congress Says: A Commission Made Us Do It
description: IT may not be the noblest form of democracy, but government by commission does offer certain advantages. In the last month, independent commissions, set up by Congress or at its direction, have taken care of several thorny tasks that seemed impervious to conventional politics.

title: When Big-City Politics Shakes Up the Suburbs
description: THE Democrats who became Republicans after they moved from New York City to the suburbs have found that their havens are suffering from many of the same problems they thought they had left behind.

title: Brightening Spirits and Releving Headaches With Light
description: Last year, when the Quaker Oats Company moved its headquarters of 30 years from Chicago's Merchandise Mart to a new steel and glass building, it was determined to distribute natural light more equitably to its 2,000 employees.

title: The Perfect Baby?
description: SHAKESPEARE, ALLOWING RICHARD III to explain the origins of his villainy, had him announce that he had been ''Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time/ Into this breathing world scarce half made up'' (Act I, Scene 1). What could be worse than a birth defect, what tragedy greater than a baby born abnormal?

title: GIVING IT THE OLD COLLEGE TRY
description: The college game has come to pro basketball. It arrived in New York by way of Providence College when Rick Pitino became the Knicks' coach July 13, 1987. And it came with all the trimmings: the 3-point basket, an uptempo offense, the full-court trap, and pressure defenses that slice seconds off a team's ability to run their offense.

title: Party of the First
description: Ronald H. Brown, a former aide of Senator Edward M. Kennedy and, briefly, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, says he has enough votes to be elected chairman of the Democratic Party when it meets Feb. 10. If so, the 47-year-old partner in a major Washington law firm will be the first black to lead a major American political party. ''He has the opportunity, on a smaller scale, to be like Nixon to China or Reagan to Russia,'' said Robert Strauss, a former Democratic chairman. More conservative Democrats said they feared the selection of Mr. Brown would reinforce the party's image as a bastion of liberalism, although the Harlem-born Mr. Brown has repeatedly asserted that he would reach out to all Democrats.

title: Support Groups Are Offering Embrace to Cocaine's Victims
description: The tale that Martha told tumbled out in pieces, bits of a life breaking under an unbearable strain. Her 31-year-old daughter, a crack user and a dropout from a local drug rehabilitation program, had moved her four children into Martha's apartment and resumed her old ways - sudden disappearances, long absences, stealing clothes, appliances, even her own children's pocket money.

title: Thrown for a Loss by Gift
description: The man who gave the University of Notre Dame a sweater worn by the football legend George Gipp says he is stunned the university gave it away - even to Ronald Reagan.

title: Shh! Can You Hear The Crackle?
description: WHEN Kellogg's created its hugely successful ad campaign that turned a whole generation of breakfast eaters on to the ''Snap, Crackle and Pop'' of Rice Krispies, it must have been a quieter time. Morning munchers had to be able to hear not only one another talking, but also their cereal. I think things have changed, and I don't think for the better. As a freelance writer, I have the privilege of working in the ''peace and quiet of my own home.'' A wonderful privilege.

title: SMALL TOTS, BIG BIZ
description: IN MAPLE HEIGHTS, OHIO, JUST OFF THE highway that leads to downtown Cleveland, at the building with the big red bell tower in front, a steady stream of traffic comes through every weekday morning from 6:30 to 9. Mothers and fathers drive up, unbuckle the baby seats, lift their children out and take them inside to one or another of the long, open, bright rooms.

title: Pas de Deux
description: To the Editor: Nothing reminds me more of the old Alphonse and Gaston routine than the Whitney's duo of Breuer and Graves [ ''The Whitney Paradox: To Add Is To Subtract,'' Jan. 8 ] . The two Frenchmen of old, simultaneously gesturing grandly in order to allow the other to pass first, always wound up slamming into one another as they both conveyed false gestures of yielding while truly feeling entitled to enter a room before the other.

title: A MURDER THAT DIDN'T ADD UP
description: BLIND FAITH By Joe McGinniss. Illustrated. 381 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

title: UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
description: Eleanor Bergholz's article on breast cancer was honest and moving, but the story is incomplete.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $110,000 405 Middle Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old ranch; dining area, sun porch, partial basement; taxes $2,700. Massapequa $385,000 10 Canal Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old waterfront brick ranch; fireplace, 110 feet of bulkheading, 2-car garage; taxes $8,500. Uniondale $195,000 332 Leslie Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, finished basement, l-car garage; taxes $3,100. Sayville $120,000 5 Alfred Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; den, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, basement; taxes $3,300. Westbury $185,000 112 Morningside Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, brick construction; taxes $2,400. West Hempstead $240,000 599 Mohawk Drive West 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, attic; taxes $5,000. OTHER AREAS Livingston, N.J. $360,000 6 Hamilton Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; patio, den, stone fireplace; taxes $4,384. Branford, Conn. $225,000 99 Windmill Hill Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; skylights, family room in basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,728. White Plains, N.Y. $190,000 16 Osborne Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fenced yard, eat-in kitchen, unfinished basement; taxes $1,150.

title: Undercover in Corporate America
description: At his last four jobs, the 27-year-old blue-collar worker quickly made friends with a crowd that liked to snort cocaine or smoke marijuana on lunch hours and coffee breaks.

title: Incident on a Train
description: THE TRIAL OF BERNHARD GOETZ Starring Peter Crombie (in photo), Larry B. Scott, Richard Libertini, Andrew Robinson. Directed by Harry Moses. 1988. Today Home Entertainment. 135 minutes. $59.95. Not rated.

title: Tower Is Initiated Into NATO Wrangling
description: John G. Tower, the Secretary of Defense-designate, got a taste today of what his new job entails as defense experts and officials from across NATO wrangled at a seminar here over the future of an alliance increasingly at odds over the peace signals from the Eastern bloc.

title: Jean Alice Brashear Is Wed in Pittsburgh
description: Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jean Alice Brashear, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Oscar Brashear of Glenshaw, Pa., to Christopher Donald Bayer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Bayer of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Mark Glasko, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Celebrating Black History Month
description: BLACKS of the past and present, famous and everyday, will be the focus in February at Connecticut libraries, colleges and cultural centers - as well as on television - as the state celebrates Black History Month.

title: SIGMUND AND MINNA? THE BIOGRAPHER AS VOYEUR
