description: As every biographer of Freud must ruefully acknowledge, that great unriddler of mysteries left behind some tantalizing private mysteries of his own. Probably the most titillating of these, which has been generating gossip for perhaps 75 years, is his relationship with his sister-in-law, Minna Bernays. Did he have a love affair with her, or did he not?

title: Chinese to Eat In or Take Out
description: THE trend toward ethnic take-out food continues unabated, attesting to our national hunger for dining diversity and for decent food that is reasonably priced and quickly prepared - by someone else.

title: Asbestos
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DEBBIE: My Life. By Debbie Reynolds with David Patrick Columbia. (Morrow, $18.95.) Things happen to Debbie Reynolds - bad things - with shocking frequency. She marries Eddie Fisher, an amphetamine-addicted singer who gives her two children and grief (Mr. Fisher leaves her for Elizabeth Taylor). Ms.

title: L.I. Power Authority To Weigh Lilco Bankruptcy
description: The nine directors of the Long Island Power Authority agreed today to investigate the effect of a possible Lilco bankruptcy on the company's one million customers.

title: High Jinks and Low Bogeys
description: BOGEYS,'' CRIED A United States fighter pilot facing fast-closing Libyan jets, ''have jinked back at me again for the fifth time. . . . Fox One!''

title: Joy and Pain
description: In a church where bishops are considered the successors to the apostles of Christ, and where some members are still unreconciled to the 1976 decision to ordain women as priests, naming a woman as bishop was not done lightly. But last week, after months of debate that sometimes verged on schism, the Episcopal Church approved the consecration of the Rev. Barbara C. Harris, 58 years old. Ms. Harris, whose critics have said that her positions on social issues were radical, said she would concentrate on pastoral duties and not be an ''Anglican gadfly.'' Presiding Bishop Edmond L. Brown said her consecration would be ''a time of great joy.'' But he added, ''Growth does not come without pain.''

title: Graf Captures Title In Australian Open
description: Can Steffi Graf sweep the Grand Slam events again?

title: TROUBLE IN THE FORM OF A REDHEAD
description: HOW I GOT HIM BACK Or, Under the Cold Moon's Shine. By Valerie Sayers. 300 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

title: The Bold are Stuided For Alcoholism Risk
description: SO far, none of his subjects have tried rappelling down the building when they leave or taken any other similarly bizarre risks, but Victor M. Hesselbrock admits he has his hands full with his latest research project.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE EIFFEL TOWER AT PLAY
description: LEAD: As the ominous green golfer on the cover of this collection of cartoons, illustrations and paintings by Devis Grebu prepares to putt the world into a starry void, a reader tumbles head over heels into a surrealistic world more startling than Alice ever dreamed of. Filled with symbols and elements drawn from his exile in foreign lands, DEVIS GREBU: Through an Artist's Eye (Rizzoli, $37.50) is a graphic mix of folklore from his native Rumania, subtle colors drawn from the landscape of Israel and a refinement of line learned in France, driven by the energy generated in America.

title: Los Angeles Mayor, Once Challenged, Regains Stride
description: As New York and Chicago enter heated and racially charged mayoral campaigns, a tall, mild-mannered man who just turned 71 is headed for easy re-election to a fifth term as Mayor of Los Angeles. A black man who leads a city that is less than 20 percent black, he has no significant opposition in the April 11 election.

title: For Blacks, Slavery Cut the Branches of the Family Tree
description: MY grandfather died several weeks ago in Mississippi. When he was laid to rest, there were no heads of states or 21-gun salutes, for he was not a great man in the ubiquitous sense in which we judge greatness.

title: Laurels Reward Innovative Loudspeakers
description: ONCE AGAIN, AS IN NINE previous years, the Grands Prix for audio have been announced. Under the aegis of Audio-Video International, a leading trade journal, a jury of technical experts chose outstanding audio components of 1988 from a list of nominations submitted through a nationwide poll of audio dealers.

title: THE DEATH OF THE SIX-HOUR DAY
description: WORK WITHOUT END Abandoning Shorter Hours for the Right to Work. By Benjamin Kline Hunnicutt. Illustrated. 404 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press.

title: Barbara Scanlan Wed To James B. Stevenson
description: Barbara Leslie Scanlan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Scanlan of Fair Haven, N.J., was married in Rumson, N.J., yesterday to James Buery Stevenson, a son of Mrs. Kenneth H. Stevenson of Rumson and the late Mr. Stevenson. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church.

title: Bill to Arm Guards at Malls Is Debated
description: CRIME is on the rise at shopping malls throughout the state, law-enforcement officials say. But they say that coping with the increase can be better accomplished by improved training of security guards, not by arming them.

title: Do You Need More Space? Try Shrinking the Furniture
description: With real estate prices soaring, many companies with bulging work forces are renovating their offices rather than relocating. In squeezing more workers into a given amount of space, companies ''are packing more punch per square foot,'' said Paul Cornell, the psychologist at Steelcase, which is spending $10 million on a new research and develpment center expected to open in May.

title: Basketball and Model Airplanes Compete for County Center
description: LEAD: IN a case reminiscent of a movie judge who had to decide on the existence of Santa Claus, a court was asked last week to choose between model airplanes and basketballs.

title: Rangers Unhappy With Tie
description: It was difficult to tell whether the Rangers were too exhausted to celebrate or too ambivalent about all that had just taken place. But at least one thing was certain: The road trip was over - not gloriously, not painlessly, but not embarrassingly either.

title: Making Pianistic History With Prokofiev
description: AT FIRST IT SOUNDS slightly peculiar to hear Barbara Nissman proselytize for Prokofiev's piano music as if the Russian composer were a new discovery. Prokofiev is hardly unknown - ''Peter and Wolf,'' the ''Classical'' Symphony and ''Lieutenant Kije'' Suite are among the most often played of all 20th-century classics. Balletomanes certainly know him, as do symphony goers. And so, too, do pianists - the dazzlingly kinetic Seventh Sonata, in particular, has long been a favorite coming-out piece for young pianistic showmen; the Third Piano Concerto is a repertory staple.

title: Wide Graft Reported in Indian Programs
description: A special Senate investigating committee has uncovered evidence of widespread corruption among some American Indian leaders and Federal officials who oversee Government programs on Indian reservations, lawmakers say.

title: 2 Brothers, One With a Gun, Held in a Queens School Assault
description: Two brothers have been charged with invading a Queens schoolyard, one wielding a loaded semiautomatic gun that had been modified to resemble an Uzi, the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, said Friday.

title: An Office With All the Comforts of Home - Even a Fireplace
description: Some offices today are becoming homier. Credenzas are replacing metal filing cabinets, round meeting tables are replacing square ones, and sofas and coffee tables are preferred to clusters of chairs. Some offices even have fireplaces.

title: U Yan Naing, Burmese Dissident, 71
description: U Yan Naing, one of Burma's ''Thirty Comrades'' who rebelled against British rule in World War II and led the country to independence, died today of a heart ailment. He was 71 years old.

title: Review/Dance; The Very Essence of Divertissement
description: The New York City Ballet presented an evening of mostly happy, giddy fare on Tuesday at the New York State Theater. There was Balanchine's delectably mad ''Donizetti Variations'' to begin and ''The Concert,'' Jerome Robbins's comic view of a concert audience's fantasies and manners, to bring the program to a spirited close.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Big East The Best Conference?
description: Last year the Big East sent six teams to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, two others, UConn and Boston College, played in the National Invitation Tournament final, and only Providence (a Final Four team in 1987) sat home. This year is no different. All nine teams have overall winning records, and nationally ranked Syracuse already has three conference losses. No conference game is a gimmee. GABE JACOBSON Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: POST-MORTEM POSSIBILITIES
description: FIVE SEASONS By A. B. Yehoshua. Translated by Hillel Halkin. 359 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/ANIMALS
description: LEAD: THE HAWK'S TALE By John Balaban. Illustrated by David Delamare. 148 pp. San Diego: Gulliver Books/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Adult Braces for the Future
description: AS a child, nothing caused me to tremble more than the pronouncement that it was time for my regular visit to the family dentist.

title: Miss Schafer Engaged To Todd M. Foreman
description: The engagement of Tracy Ellen Schafer to Todd Matthew Foreman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Spencer Foreman of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour J. Schafer of Pittsburgh. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Music for Movies: Trickier Than It Looks
description: COMPOSERS HAVE LONG ENJOYED an uneasy, if lucrative, relationship with film. From such early idealists as Sergei Prokofiev to the populist experiments of the 1930's (Aaron Copland, Virgil Thomson et al.), serious composers have been attracted to the film medium.

title: Rights Group Reports Continued Abuses in Cuba
description: A human rights organization based in New York said today that while Cuba has improved its prisons and permitted some dissident groups to form, it continues to commit ''serious violations of human rights that victimize the whole Cuban population.''

title: Adapting an Opening to Meet the Player's Needs
description: WHICH counts for more, the player or the opening?

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Big East The Best Conference?
description: Yes.

title: Fending Off The Bats
description: WHEN bats moved into Lorraine Disburger's house in New London, N.Y., last summer, she moved out. The normally nocturnal bats were everywhere, even at midday: between the walls, beneath the floorboards, behind the curtains, scratching and wheezing and squeaking and swarming. ''It was like that movie 'The Birds,' '' she said at the time. ''Only it was 'The Bats.' ''

title: Hands Pose for Their Portraits
description: THE HUMAN HAND HAS BEEN A recurring subject in photography - in part because, in an esthetic sense, photography renders the idea of ''the hand'' vestigial. Unlike other methods of representation, including drawing and painting, photography cannot claim to be an art of line, stroke or touch. To take a picture, all the hand need do is press the shutter button.

title: THE NATION: Justices' Ruling; Why Minority Contractors See 'a Giant Step Backward'
description: WHILE affirmative action programs in education and employment have been subject to frequent, sometimes heated debate in recent years, another kind of race-based remedy for discrimination - public spending set-asides - have operated with relatively little dispute over the last 20 years.

title: DATABANK: January 29, 1989
Robert Duvall: The Actor As Chameleon
description: ''MYSTERY - THAT'S THE key word about Bobby. One thing he never talks about is his craft. He never does - that one area is a closed door.'' That is the director Simon Wincer, speaking by phone from his cattle ranch in Mooroolbark, Australia, half a world away, about the American actor Robert Duvall. For four months, the two men worked and lived together under excruciating conditions, and yet, Mr. Wincer repeats, ''He was a mystery then, and he's a mystery now.''

title: California Bill Would Curb Cutting of Redwoods
description: Citing accelerated cutting of redwoods by a lumber company, State Assemblyman Byron Sher says he will introduce legislation Monday to outlaw the practice of cutting down entire stands of ancient redwoods and impose civil fines of up to $50,000 for violations.

title: Africa Must Control Population Explosion
description: To the Editor:

title: BROWN-BAGGING IT TO BUCKINGHAM
description: Russell Baker's article ''Brown-Bagging It to Buckingham'' (Jan. 1), prodded my memory to relive the jubilation of Coronation Day, 1953.

title: Suffolk Police Study Flexible Responses to Crimes of Bias
description: LEAD: TWO black men are sitting in a car in an affluent white neighborhood. A police car drives by, circles the block a few times and stops. The officer gets out, questions the men, asks to see a driver's license and then sends them on their way.

title: Soviets Say Nuclear Warheads Were Deployed in Cuba in '62
description: Soviet officials disclosed today for the first time that in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, Soviet nuclear warheads had already been deployed in Cuba and could have been launched at American cities within a few hours.

title: Medicare Act: Expand Access
description: Pat Costello Smith's article (''New Medicare Act Benefits the Aged, but They'll Foot the Bill,'' Jan. 15) was an excellent presentation of a complex and disturbing phenomenon.

title: Eleanor B. Smith To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Smith of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Eleanor Batterman Smith to Kenneth Alden Southworth 4th, the son of Mrs. Morgan Kiker Jr. of Andover, Mass., and Mr. Southworth 3d of Edgartown, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Mixed Verdict Is Given In S. Carolina Slaying
description: Noah Robinson, a Chicago millionaire, was sentenced to the maximum 10 years in prison today after being found guilty of a felony in connection with the attempted murder of a woman who witnessed a killing.

title: Smoked Foods Offer a 'Haunting Edge'
description: SMOKING as a habit may be on the decline but as a flavoring it is more popular than ever. Restaurant chefs are using smoked foods - meats, poultry, seafood, vegetables and cheeses - in a variety of dishes. Many of the chefs are doing their own smoking with simple, improvised equipment.

title: From Cabinet To Disbarment
description: ROBERT B. ANDERSON, Treasury Secretary in the second Eisenhower Administration, pleaded guilty in 1987 in Federal District Court in Manhattan to evading income taxes and operating an illegal offshore bank in the British West Indies. Judge Edmund Palmieri sentenced Mr. Anderson to a month in prison, five months' house arrest and five years on probation.

title: Carnegie Hall to Chinatown
description: Mixed Concert

title: Approaching Kennan
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MINISTRY OF GREED: The Inside Story of the Televangelists and Their Holy Wars. By Larry Martz with Ginny Carroll. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $18.95.) Larry Martz and Ginny Carroll, two staff members of Newsweek magazine, promise new information in ''Ministry of Greed'' on Tammy and Jim Bakker and the still toasty carcass of their PTL ministry, but for those of us who followed each installment of the days following Jim's downfall at the hands of Jessica Hahn, there are no big surprises.

title: Tit for Tat
description: Things have a way of happening to people who offend John Gotti, who is reputed to be head of the nation's largest organized crime group. So when a restaurant run by a colleague of Mr. Gotti's was vandalized in 1986 after the owner declined to pay a bribe demanded, authorities said, by an official of the carpenters' union, there was immediate speculation that the labor leader, John F. O'Connor, was in for a bout of ill health. Sure enough Mr. O'Connor soon came down with a bad case of bullet wounds.

title: LET THE WORLD SAY 'AMEN'
description: MANY MANSIONS A Christian's Encounter With Other Faiths. By Harvey Cox. 216 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $18.95.

title: The Pyramids of New York
description: It's a stunning sight up here atop an abandoned brick apartment house in the Bronx, a sight that offers a glimpse into one of the great construction projects in the history of cities.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Literary Impact When Malcolm Cowley impulsively punched a Parisian cafe owner in the jaw, the effect on his French acquaintances was surprising. He describes this in ''Exile's Return: A Literary Odyssey of the 1920s'' (Penguin).

title: The Emperor's Umbrella
description: John Tower, the Defense Secretary-designate, acknowledges what most strategic and scientific experts have long understood: President Reagan's Star Wars scheme for defending the American population from a nuclear attack cannot work. Mr. Tower, who as a Senator was a proponent of just such a defense, last week told a Senate committee, ''I think that's just unrealistic.''

title: Chinese Films Offer New Perspective
description: LEAD: LIKE most Westerners visiting China for the first time, E. Ann Kaplan had little idea of what went on behind the Bamboo Curtain.

title: 25 Anti-Abortion Protestors Arrested at a Clinic in Jersey
description: Eight anti-abortion protestors who were chained together by their necks and legs inside a women's clinic today resisted efforts by local authorities to remove them for nearly 12 hours, before they were dragged from the building by the police, who brought special equipment to break the shackles. At least 17 other protestors who were without chains inside the Medical Care Center were arrested and were to be charged with defiant trespassing for not obeying an order to leave the grounds, said Lieut. John Demarest of the Woodbridge Police Department.

title: At a Posh Club, Privilege of Membership Is Weighed Against the Real Life
description: THE ball sailed slowly through the air on a high arc as it passed over 150 yards of water on its way to the green. When I first hit the ball I simply wished it success in traversing the hazard. However, as the shot unfolded my expectations soared as I realized that this single effort had the possibility of immortal greatness.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Speed Skating Jansen Takes 500-Meter Race: Dan Jansen of the United States won the 500-meter World Cup race yesterday and finished second to Uwe Jens Mey of East Germany in the 1,000-meter event at Miola di Pine, Italy.

title: Jane Billington Wed To Johnson Flucker
description: Jane Billington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Billington of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Johnson Flucker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Flucker of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Edward Prevost performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Princeton University Chapel.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: COE HALL CONCERTS After some time off for holidaying, Friends of the Arts today continues Concerts at Coe Hall, its Sunday chamber-music series. On hand to do the honors at 2:30 P.M. is Music Amici, an ensemble of strings, winds and piano.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Troupe's German Roots
description: The Zeromoving Dance Company from Philadelphia is a group with a difference. The second program of its New York engagement, which ends tonight, explained why the troupe attracts the curious and viewers interested in plain good dancing.

title: Panel Seeking Accountability in Koch Talent Bank
description: The New York State commission that spotlighted City Hall patronage two weeks ago is now trying to determine who was responsible for turning an agency with the announced purpose of providing jobs for women and minority-group members into a political job-placement operation.

title: Lobby Extends a Hand To Children in Trouble
description: When an 11-year-old boy was charged with killing his baby sitter by setting his house ablaze here in early January, some Maine residents decided it was time to stop studying the problems of seriously troubled children and start helping them.

title: Don't Blame Professors if Adjuncts Are Serfs; Cry Out Against It
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots. Can you explain why this mildew occurred?

title: Reduction in Force: The Plight of Island Defense Workers
description: LEAD: PETER was using the telephone of his Pentagon client to call his office on Long Island to retrieve messages left by other clients.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Lease Feuds; Renovation Often Leads to Tenant-Owner Disputes
description: WHEN a commercial tenant watches his landlord disregard the spirit or the letter of their lease agreement, rancor builds quickly. And any landlord becomes equally upset when a tenant tries to withhold rent or sidestep restrictions incorporated into a lease.

title: Wave of Immigrant Children Strains Schools and Housing
description: The latest wave of Latin American immigrants now flooding Texas, California and Florida includes an increasing proportion of women and children, a phenomenon that is already beginning to strain housing, education and social services in some cities.

title: Mementos to Preserve The Record of Anguish
description: The threadbare woolen jacket that William Luksenburg wore as a prisoner in a Nazi concentration camp has been hanging in the back of a closet in his home for 40 years. This month, Mr. Luksenburg took the jacket out and brought it to the new Holocaust museum being built here on the National Mall.

title: Linda Black Is Married
description: Linda Cabot Black, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dudley Cabot of Weston, Mass., and Roger E. Clapp, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Furbush Clapp of Cleveland, were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. The Revs. Max Gaebler and Carl Scovel, Unitarian ministers, performed the ceremony at Cabot House at Harvard University.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CORPORATE PERESTROIKA;
Why Owner-Workers Are Winners
description: LEAD: In 1967, five hooded robbers in Miami, Fla., relieved William M. du Pont and his wife of their $1.5 million Russian coin collection at gunpoint. One of the robbers paused long enough to ask Mr. du Pont: ''Why don't you make your living like a normal person?'' When Mr. du Pont asked what was normal, the gunman replied: ''Working to earn a living like everyone else.

title: Evidence Fails to Show Psychological Harm From Abortions; History Misread Again
description: To the Editor:

title: THEIR CHEATIN' HEARTS
description: LEAD: ADULTERY An Analysis of Love and Betrayal. By Annette Lawson. 440 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Crunch Time
description: ON SEPT. 20, 1985, AGENTS FROM the United States Customs Service and the Secret Service seized more than 25,000 imported, counterfeit watches from illicit distributors in South Florida. Twenty-six people were subsequently arrested and convicted of trafficking in counterfeit merchandise. However, it was more than three years before the case, known as Operation Stopwatch, wound down. Finally, the watches, officially forfeited to the Federal Government, were marked for destruction. Last Nov. 10, as part of the ongoing effort to seize and dispose of illicit goods, 17,000 of them were steamrolled. The Customs Service captures hundreds of millions of dollars of general merchandise every year. Of the $483 million worth seized in 1988, counterfeit goods accounted for more than $28 million. (The rest included abandoned and unclaimed merchandise, and products that violate import laws.) Counterfeits cost legitimate manufacturers and importers billions of dollars annually.

title: Carey Schach Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William O. Schach of Pittsburgh of the engagement of their daughter, Carrington Coburn Schach, to Daniel Covington North, a son of Judge and Mrs. John C. North 2d of St. Michaels, Md. The couple plan to marry in May.

title:
INVESTING;
Making Hay From the Drought INVESTING
description: LEAD: In what securities analysts expect to be a boon for agriculture suppliers, farmers are expected to try to make up for the crops lost to last year's drought by planting more acreage this spring.

title: The Budget Law Does Its Work, Too
description: BUSH Administration officials and Congressional leaders are not counting on the National Economic Commission to grease the way to a compromise on reducing the Federal budget deficit. Rather, they are banking on the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law to bludgeon them into an agreement.

title: EXTREMIST GAINS SEEN IN SALVADOR
description: Eight years after the United States began to pour money into El Salvador to fight Marxist-led guerrillas, American officials say that the war is deadlocked, that extremist forces are gaining strength and that the issue is coming back to the forefront of political debate in this country.

title: UConn Ends Jinx Against St. John's
description: For the Huskies of Connecticut, the frustration of eight years of losses to St. John's was reduced to a footnote today.

title:
MUSIC;
Royal Philharmonic Starting U.S. Tour
description: LEAD: THE Royal Philharmonic Orchestra of London, which will play a 16-concert American tour in the next few weeks, will make the first of its appearances in the New York metropolitan area on Thursday evening at 8 at the State Theater in New Brunswick.

title: THE GIFTED
description: When my closest friend from college got married, the basement of her parents' home looked like Tiffany's storeroom the day after Christmas. Long folding tables were piled with open pastel boxes of china, crystal and silver carefully nestled in wrinkled tissue paper and bubble wrap. A neat row of file boxes sat at the head of the first table, containing a master guest list with notations and gift cards stapled next to each name. Only by such fastidious organization, her mother informed me, could accurate thank-you notes be written.

title: Kirk A. Ruebenson Is Wed To Dr. Elizabeth A. Rudey
description: Dr. Elizabeth Ann Rudey, a professor of ceramic arts at Long Island University, and Kirk Arthur Ruebenson, a graphic arts cameraman for Quad Rite in New York, were married yesterday at the Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated.

title: A Union Split Over Givebacks
description: LEAD: From the time he was a teen-ager shoveling manure in the stockyards in Sioux City, Iowa, Lewie Anderson believed in protecting his union from the enemy: the company. As a striking beef butcher and as an official for the last 18 years of the meatpackers' union, the United Food and Commercial Workers, Mr.

title: OF GODS, RICE AND WOODY ALLEN
description: OTHER PEOPLES' MYTHS The Cave of Echoes. By Wendy Doniger O'Flaherty. 225 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95

title: Newcommers' Club Meets New Needs
description: LEAD: WHEN the Newcomers' Club of Pound Ridge began 30 years ago, members took cakes to new neighbors and gathered to chat over embroidery. Now the group sponsors book discussions, dinners featuring recipes from sophisticated restaurants, a cooking contest for men and a variety of theme parties.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 1 with an article about Egypt identified a tomb incompletely and misstated its location. It is that of Sennedjem, a necropolis worker, and is near the Valley of the Kings. A map of Cairo with the article omitted the site of the newly opened opera house. It is on the island of Gezira. In addition, a listing of hotels misstated the room rates charged by Leading Hotels of the World for the Mena House Oberoi in Giza, Egypt. A double room starts at $89.

title: St. James Enhances Its Series
description: ST. JAMES Episcopal Church, a small (capacity 150), steepled white frame building in North Salem, carries with it some 125 years of history; the parish it serves is one of the oldest in the country, predating the American Revolution by nearly a decade. Two years ago, the church installed a 100-year-old pipe organ and decided to celebrate the new acquisition by beginning an annual chamber series.

title: FOCUS: Montreal; Old City Being Revitalized for Anniversary
description: THE district known as Vieux Montreal (Old Montreal or Old City) is being targeted for a major revitalization in time for the city's 350th anniversary in 1992.

title: FICTION
description: HEART SONGS: And Other Stories. By E. Annie Proulx. (Scribners, $16.95.) The men in E. Annie Proulx's nine stories, who have come to northern New England to seek self-renewal by grouse hunting, trout fishing or folk singing, are as harried by misery as the people who live there. Cut off from their spouses or harassed by their mothers and sisters, they are shy, battered, depleted men. In ''The Wer-Trout,'' for example, two neighbors named Rivers and Sauvage go north to fish the swamps known as the Yellow Bogs. Sauvage's wife has been carted off by her doctor for putting a mouse in her mouth. Rivers's wife has intuited her husband's itch of interest in this wire-haired woman, who's plowed across their lawn in a Jeep, ravaging their young apple tree and garden. Enraged, Mrs. Rivers leaves for the city with her tapestry designs, sewing box and vitamins, declaring her husband ''a fishing alky'' who can't make a living or secure decent neighbors. At the bog, Rivers drinks whisky, fishes naked and treads on his precious bamboo rod, while Sauvage, with discount-store gear, catches large lunkers that he fries and eats ''as he would a slice of watermelon.'' Through the contrast between Rivers and Sauvage, Ms. Proulx explores both the cultural and sexual conflicts of her characters. Similar concerns are at play in ''Bedrock,'' a story in which Bobhot Mackie (one of the many odd regional names that appear in Ms. Proulx's fiction) installs his sister Maureen as housekeeper - and then new wife - to a mournful widower named Perley in order to seize control of the older man's farm. As this convoluted relationship deteriorates, Perley has a surprising revelation as he recalls a hazy incident from his past, thus confronting his own moral culpability. Ms. Proulx's stories are most compelling when they're rooted in a coarse rural sexuality. At these times, their sometimes enigmatic, often lyrical images seem to complement New England's lavish but barren beauty.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Big East The Best Conference?
description: An argument could be made that the Big East is not only the best conference teamwise, but also coachwise. Every season, Jim Boeheim, John Thompson, Rollie Massimino, and Lou Carnesecca field teams that have the potential to do anything. With the emergence of Seton Hall, it seems that P. J. Carlesimo will soon join the elite. The only comparable basketball conference would be the Big Ten, in which Bob Knight of Indiana is already a legend. Although teams in the Big Ten are excellent this year, they don't always have the consistency and dominance of the Big East.

title: LEVERAGED BUYOUTS: AMERICAN PAYS THE PRICE
description: When the capital development of a country becomes a byproduct of the activities of a casino, the job is likely to be ill-done. The measure of success attained by Wall Street . . . cannot be claimed as one of the outstanding triumphs of laissez-faire capitalism. - John Maynard Keynes, ''The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money'' (1936)

title: Evidence Fails to Show Psychological Harm From Abortions
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Blame Professors if Adjuncts Are Serfs
description: To the Editor:

title: Tap-Dancing Teachers Are People Too
description: Regarding Nora Polinsky's letter ''Tap-Dancing Teachers: This Is Education?'' (Jan. 8).

title:
Jersey City Journal;
Historic Designation Divides Bergen Hill Residents
description: LEAD: A TIDY neighborhood of brownstones, brick row houses and old frame homes whose architecture has remained virtually unchanged for 100 years has become the prize in a tug-of-war between blacks and whites over gentrification.

title: 'Lawrence' Seen Whole
description: FIRST LOVE BETWEEN A PERSON and a film can be as intoxicating as first love between two people. It can mean just as much crazy behavior, just as many sleepless nights. As a young adolescent, I became so desperately obsessed with a certain film that I saw it over and over, spent years studying the life of its hero, regarded him as a kind of role model and even dragged my family on a long, dusty pilgrimage to a place where he had lived. If one measure of a film's greatness is its power to affect the lives of those who see it, then ''Lawrence of Arabia'' must be the best film I know.

title: Colleges Widen Their Job Choices
description: FOR thousands of people, college does not mean four or more years of classroom study to obtain a bachelor's degree in English or a master's in engineering. It means investing six months, a year or, tops, two years to learn a trade.

title: THE REGION: Promises, Promises; When Koch Campaigns, The Possibilities Are Elastic
description: THIS year's campaign for Mayor of New York may well turn on issues at once daunting and inescapable: drugs, homelessness, the sorry state of the schools and, perhaps foremost, the persona of the three-term incumbent, Edward I. Koch.

title:
ART;
'Stopping Time,' at the Katonah Gallery, Seeks to Stop Motion
description: LEAD: LIKE all exhibitions at the Katonah Gallery, ''Stopping Time'' is didactic. But the gallery always makes its teaching palatable: What we are taught seems directly proportional to how much our imagination and senses are stimulated. The subject of ''Stopping Time'' is photography and it appeals both to those who have an aptitude for science and to those who are comfortable with photography sharing the status of fine art along with painting and sculpture.

title: Don't Let City Garbage Go Up in Smoke
description: LEAD: Two recent developments should serve as timely warnings that, in turning to incineration to solve their trash disposal problems, New York City and many other municipalities throughout the country are heading in the wrong direction. Properly handled, recycling could dispose of most of the trash and eliminate the need for incineration.

title: Review/Opera; At the Met, 'Don Carlo,' Verdi's Study of Conflict
description: ''Don Carlo,'' in many ways the most dramatically challenging of Verdi's operas, can also be the most rewarding when everything meshes. The work, a dark study in insoluble conflicts - church versus state, friendship versus duty, love versus jealousy - returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory on Friday evening in John Dexter's still-handsome 10-year-old production.

title: Polly Egan Wroe To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Patricia Pettigrew Wroe of Weston, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Polly Egan Wroe, to John H. Knowles Jr., the son of Edith LaCroix Dabney of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Knowles. The couple plan to marry June 3.

title: Recasting The Mold In Theater
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 - As a boy, Daniel Kim dreamed of becoming an actor but was afraid his Asian background would bar him from many of the parts to which he aspired.

title: Vermonters Fight to Save Battlefields
description: They would seem to have nothing in common. Pvt. Elba Jillson fought for the Union in the Civil War. Richard Henry Brooks, a Virginia slave, briefly served a Confederate officer in the field.

title: R. S. Auchincloss Jr. Wed to Mary Rogers
description: Mary Rogers and Richard Saltonstall Auchincloss Jr. were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Sharline Fulton performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Rudolph Moore.

title:
INVESTING;
A Passion That Could Soon Cool
description: LEAD: Before the recent revelation that the Government was investigating possible fraud in the Chicago futures markets, commodity funds were enjoying a surge in growth. Last year, investors poured a record $1.2 billion into them, up from $650 million in 1987, according to the Managed Futures Trade Association.

title: Islanders Are Taken Out of It Early
description: It wasn't the early hour, nor was it the inhospitality the Flyers routinely extend toward their opponents, particularly division rivals intent on taking away their playoff spot.

title: WHY CAN'T A ROBOT BE MORE LIKE A MAN?
description: James Gleick's article ''Why Can't a Robot Be More Like a Man?'' (Dec.11), exhibited a fine touch of realism, technological insight and humor.

title: Don't Report On Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Frederick City, Md.;
From Barns To Bedrooms
description: LEAD: WITH 11 projects that will provide more than 1,500 single-family houses now under way, Frederick County's largest builder is helping to transform this thriving farmland into yet another bedroom suburb for the Baltimore-Washington metropolitan area.

title: The Homeless at the Heart Of Poverty and Policy
description: IN the 1930's, ''poverty'' was the unemployment line, it was a nation down on its luck. In the 1960's and 1970's it was the crumbling ghetto, a separate place that a Great Society thought it could reach out and repair. Now, homelessness has crossed one of those invisible lines of American politics. The homeless are everywhere.

title: Bank Board Sues The Accountants
description: Accountants faced lawsuits and heavy criticism as the savings and loan industry's dire condition received considerable attention in Washington. M. Danny Wall, head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said his agency was suing three accounting firms and expected to eventually sue most of the profession's Big Eight firms. He said auditors' failures to detect and report fraud and mismanagement had contributed to the failure of a number of savings institutions. Most of the accounting firms had no comment, but one that was sued, Deloitte, Haskins & Sells, said the accusations had no basis. Mr. Wall also said his agency, which dealt with more than 200 failed institutions last year, is nearly out of money to continue bailouts; 350 institutions remain in need of rescue.

title: White House Says Option of Fee For Savings Accounts Is Still Alive
description: The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that imposing a fee on savings accounts is still an option to help resolve a crisis in the nation's savings and loan institutions.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Jan. 1 with an article about the paradors of Spain mislocated one establishment. The Reyes Catolicos parador mentioned is in Santiago de Compostela, in northwest Spain, not the one on the Mediterranean coast.

title: SECURITY BEGINS AT HOME
description: THE FATE OF NATIONS The Search for National Security in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries. By Michael Mandelbaum. 416 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $39.50. Paper, $13.95.

title: At National Steel
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'NORMAL' ACT OF GENOCIDE?
description: LEAD: THE UNMASTERABLE PASTHistory, Holocaust, and German National Identity. By Charles S. Maier. 227 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.50.

title: The Case for Takeovers
description: THE TAKEOVER BOOM IS A treatment for a disease that is destroying American productivity: gross and widespread incompetent management. Takeovers are part of a free-market response, working to unseat corporate bureaucracies, control runaway costs and make America competitive again.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CELEBRATING JOYCE James Joyce's 107th birthday on Thursday will be celebrated at Paperback Alley in South Windsor with the showing of two Joycean films and the serving of Irish tea, soda bread and a large birthday cake with the first page of Joyce's ''Ulysses'' written in chocolate icing.

title: Remaking Kidder in G.E.'s Image
description: The halls at Kidder, Peabody & Company, one of Wall Street's oldest and most prestigious firms, are quiet. Rows of darkened offices overlook New York Harbor and cardboard boxes are stacked on desks where secretaries once worked. Where there was once the chaotic bustle of young men and women rushing around with papers in hand, there is now eerie stillness. The 124-year-old firm seems populated not by employees but by survivors.

title: Filling a Void
description: When Clemson takes on Duke in Durham, N.C., today, don't be surprised if Dennis Hopf is wearing the cleanest Tiger uniform. Until yesterday, the 6-foot sophomore was the Clemson manager. He was pressed into service for today's game to help fill the void created by the surprise suspension of seven Clemson players, including two starters, apparently for skipping study hall.

title: Trooper Is Held in Rape Case
description: A state trooper will face a Saratoga County grand jury Tuesday after he was arrested on seven counts stemming from the rape and sodomy of a 29-year-old woman last fall, the police said today. Robert O. Bennett Jr., 35 years old, of Clifton Park, was arrested Friday, a state police spokesman said. Mr. Bennett was charged with first-degree rape, two counts of first-degree sodomy, first-degree sexual abuse, first-degree coercion, second-degree unlawful imprisonment and official misconduct, he said. Mr. Bennett has been suspended pending the outcome of the case, the spokesman said. Mr. Bennett was arraigned Friday and released on $25,000 bond.

title: Jewish Institute to Aid South African Blacks
description: A Jewish institute devoted to strengthening ties between black and Jewish Americans plans to present Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu with a $100,000 grant for training black South African medical workers.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots. Can you explain why this mildew occurred?

title: Packer Misses With Statistics
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shoreham Mediator Strives for a Deal
description: LEAD: WITH a potentially fateful court date set for Thursday, a mediator appointed by Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein labored last week to remove obstacles to a settlement of a Federal racketeering suit in which the Long Island Lighting Company faces $4 billion in damages.

title: 'Broadway Bound'
description: ''BROADWAY BOUND'' is about a young comedy writer who gets the first big break that puts him on the road to becoming Neil Simon. It is also about his restrictive family in Brighton Beach in the late 1940's, but mostly it turns out to be about his repressed mother who, in a revelatory mid-second-act monologue, recounts her moment in the spotlight: the night she danced with George Raft.

title: Carousel to Be Auctioned
description: LEAD: THE sign in the window of the Palace Amusements arcade at Lake Avenue and Kingsley Street here said, ''Video Games for Sale.'' Inside the 100-year-old building, stuffed animals in cotton-candy colors dangled from the prize booth, waiting for summer and to be traded for points won at Skilo and Big Bertha.

title: DIPLOMATS AND BUREAUCRATS: ... AND A FAREWELL
description: WAR AND PEACE IN CENTRAL AMERICA By Frank McNeil. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: IMPERIAL PURPLE. By Gillian Bradshaw. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Setting a historical romance in the early Christian era would seem to promise the excitement of a chariot race - or some juicy glimpses of feasting, orgies and decadent monarchs. But ''Imperial Purple'' is likely to leave readers as dissatisfied as its heroine appears to be when the novel begins.

title: REVERBERATIONS OF DALLAS
description: FINAL DISCLOSURE The Full Truth About the Assassination of President Kennedy. By David W. Belin. Illustrated. 249 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95. MAFIA KINGFISH Carlos Marcello and the Assassination of John F. Kennedy. By John H. Davis. Illustrated. 580 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $19.95. ON THE TRAIL OF THE ASSASSINS My Investigation and Prosecution of the Murder of President Kennedy. By Jim Garrison. Illustrated. 342 pp. New York: Sheridan Square Press. $19.95.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Boonton $425,000 259 Rockaway Street 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 87-year-old Victorian; new kitchen, fireplace, patio, greenhouse; taxes $4,599. Hawthorne $214,900 32 North 19 Street 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old ranch; finished basement, hardwood floors, family room; taxes $2,652. Livingston $360,000 6 Hamilton Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; patio, den, stone fireplace; taxes $4,384. Millburn $274,950 79 Linden Street 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, fireplace, den, porch; taxes $2,972. South Orange $267,000 309 Franklin Place 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old colonial; full basement, den, 2-car garage, pool; taxes $4,679. Wayne $180,000 31 Dubel Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; w/w carpeting, dining room, fenced yard; taxes $1,921. OTHER AREAS Sayville, L.I. $120,000 5 Alfred Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; den, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, basement; taxes $3,300. Branford, Conn. $225,000 99 Windmill Hill Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; skylights, family room in basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,728. White Plains, N.Y. $190,000 16 Osborne Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fenced yard, eat-in kitchen, unfinished basement; taxes $1,150.

title: Christina Fiore Plans to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fiore of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Christina Barbara Fiore, to Philip Van Munching, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Van Munching Jr. of Darien, Conn. The couple plan to marry in October.

title: Miss Somers Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emannuel M. Somers of Sands Point, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Angela Jennifer Somers to Thomas Lawrence DiGaloma, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. DiGaloma of San Francisco. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: 'Home Fires Burning': Integrity Amid Substance
description: ''HALLMARK HALL OF FAME'' comes up with its 160th presentation tonight at 9 on CBS. Starring Barnard Hughes, Sada Thompson and Robert Prosky, ''Home Fires Burning'' is one more example of why American television should cherish this distinguished series. ''Home Fires Burning'' is not great drama. In fact, it has some nagging flaws. But, like the bulk of productions broadcast under the Hallmark banner, this latest effort has substance and an underlying integrity. ''Home Fires Burning'' will not induce despair about the general state of popular culture.

title: Picking the Right Guide for Tax Time
description: The flurry of W-2 forms arriving in the mail ushers in that time of year when tax guides start to supplant other, more pleasurable, forms of leisure reading. While nothing can make brushing up on the fine points of the tax law exactly fun, some guides can make it easier than others to wend your way through the maze of legislation, Internal Revenue Service rulings and court decisions. Below are thumbnail descriptions of some current choices.

title: Soviet Minister Ends Kabul Talks
description: Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov of the Soviet Union ended two days of talks with President Najibullah today as convoys carrying food and other vital supplies arrived in the Afghan capital.

title: Research Looks Away From Laboratory Animals
description: BENETTON, the Italian clothing chain, announces that it will no longer perform safety tests for new cosmetics and toiletries on animals. A Cornell Medical College researcher gives up a $600,000 Federal grant for a study of barbiturate addiction that uses cats. Noxell Corporation, the maker of Noxzema skin products and Cover Girl cosmetics, says it will rely on mouse tissue cultures in laboratory dishes instead of tests on rabbits to determine whether its products can damage the human eye.

title: Africa Must Control Population Explosion Reaction to Slavers
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Condos
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article ''Condo Spoken Here'' and the subsequent letters:

title:
DANCE;
Taylor Troupe Leads a Parade
description: LEAD: A PARADE of performances winds across the February dance calendar, packing the month with a broad spectrum of concerts. Leading the procession, with a performance Saturday sponsored by the Friday Evening Club, is the Paul Taylor Dance Company, one of the most distinguished modern-dance companies in the world of dance.

title: THE NOBEL PAIR
description: GERTRUDE BELLE Elion was the only female recipient on the stage at last month's Nobel Prize ceremonies in Stockholm. Dressed in royal blue chiffon, she was a flash of brilliance among the starched white evening shirts and formal black suits of the others. George Herbert Hitchings, too, stood apart, at 83 the oldest new recipient by a good many years.

title: Daughter Follows Mother's Footsteps
description: I MISSED the sexual revolution. I missed the feminist movement. I was too busy diapering babies. I missed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s sit-ins. I never got to march for anything. I was too busy keeping the pace with carriages.

title: Shoreham Evacuation: Like the Blizzard of '86?
description: REMEMBER the first snowstorm of 1986? The recent Shoreham news returns it poignantly to mind. As recently as last week, many Long Islanders thought that Shoreham could be written off. But with the distinct possibility that the monster could be resurrected (when did it ever go away?) and the reality that Lilco will push for an operating license (when did they ever stop trying?), a tremor of fear again ripples across our weary island.

title: SALMAN RUSHDIE: FICTION'S EMBATTLED INFIDEL
description: BRICK LANE, IN LONDON'S EAST END, IS A neighborhood peopled by those whom the city never expected to accommodate. It is a neighborhood of Asians - as they are called by the English, who are comfortable still with the old colonial term that did not distinguish among the many peoples east of Europe. There are thought to be 40,000 Asians in Brick Lane, mostly Muslims from Bengal, a region cleaved in 1947 when India was partitioned and East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) created. They have come for many reasons - exiles, refugees, schemers - and they have not always been welcomed. ''Asian'' suggests not only the distance the immigrants have traveled but also the distance at which they remain. And something more troubling, a sense of unease and estrangement, is suggested by newer, post-colonial terms: quotas, fourth world, National Front, Paki-bashing.

title: Japan Joins the Superconductor Fray
description: Near rusting railroad yards and blackened smokestacks in this industrial town, Dr. Akinobu Kasami and a team of 50 researchers are working to transform the theory of high-temperature superconductivity into the business of practical electronic products.

title: Review/Jazz; A Patchwork On the Piano
description: Compositions seem to crumble under Andrew Hill's hands. His piano style is a patchwork of approaches -ringing chords and quick jabs and stride piano oom-pahs, skittering runs and skewed be-bop lines, melodies fractured by pauses and asides - cobbled together in asymmetrical fits and starts. His own themes are just as eccentric, barely announcing themselves as ballads or hard-bop before veering away.

title: Abuse on TV: Enough Is Enough
description: COME on. Now it's getting silly. Early on, it really was educational. People who grew up with the dirty secret of abusive or alcoholic parents found out there were others like them. Women who were raped by dates and who always felt it must be their own fault, found out it wasn't their fault, and they were not alone.

title: Marjorie Schein To Marry in June
description: Marjorie Laura Schein and Brian Alexander Weston, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Vaughan H. Weston of West Lafayette, Ind., plan to marry in June. Their engagement has been made known by the future bride's parents, Carol S. Gill of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and David S. Schein of West Nyack, N.Y.

title: Egypt
description: To the Editor: I had an interesting experience discovering the Temple of Ptah at Karnak, mentioned by Paula Weideger (''Coping With Egypt on Your Own,'' Travel, Jan. 1). After exploring Karnak for hours, long after the early morning throngs of guided tours had departed the heat of an October day, I was sitting in the cool shadows of the gigantic columns. A young Egyptian in white robes approached and asked if I would like to see something that ''no tourist has seen.'' Since tourism has been Egypt's major industry since the time of ancient Greece, this sounded unlikely, but this is a good way to see out-of-the-way spots.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Passaic Pressing Plans for a Recovery
description: LEAD: DERELICT buildings still line many of the streets of Passaic, reminders of the flight in the 1950's of residents and industry from its 3.2 square miles. But after decades of economic decline and biting setbacks, this old manufacturing city along the Passaic River is slowly rebounding.

title: FICTION
description: LUCID STARS. By Andrea Barrett. (Delta, Paper, $7.95.) In her first novel, Andrea Barrett enlists the whole empyrean - Orion through Libra through Pegasus - to serve as a backdrop for and sad commentary on a dissolving family. Her story opens on a Vermont mountaintop in 1955 when 19-year-old Penny Webb succumbs to the charms of a ski bum named Benjamin Day. In rapid succession, Penny becomes pregnant, married and miserable. While her new husband carves Cape Cod into housing developments and chases other women, she withdraws into twin solaces: her children, Cass and Webb, and her study of the stars. But after 11 years of marriage even these fail her. The family breaks apart, its ''elements joining and separating and recombining into changing patterns.'' Penny divorces Benjamin, who marries a younger woman, Diane, who gives birth to a third child; Cass and Webb carry on continuous domestic warfare against their stepmother; Benjamin wearies of Diane, too, and divorces her to marry yet another younger woman, Jill. By the time ''Lucid Stars'' concludes, in 1977, these characters have settled into a sprawling familial constellation - ''as if,'' Diane notes, ''their loose-linked family hangs in the sky, joined for a few minutes by the wandering moon.'' Initially the prose in this sidereal drama suffers from a certain slackness, but as the novel gains momentum it deepens, and Ms. Barrett's language adeptly rises, or falls, to portray occasions of considerable unhappiness. She also possesses the gift of forgiving her characters more readily than they do one another - which is neither more nor less than they deserve. In doing so, she has made a spacious and sympathetic debut.

title: Diagnosing Electrical Woes
description: A VOLT-OHM meter is a battery-powered measuring device that is used to diagnose a wide range of household electrical problems. With one, you can test batteries and switches, pinpoint causes of trouble in appliances and measure voltages at outlets.

title: Yes, There Is No Free Lunch
description: I HAD heard all the stories: A friend whose purse was grabbed in Paris, a man who lost his wallet in London, another who had paid an exorbitant fare for a dizzying ride around the Etoile. Thus alerted, I determined that none of the above would happen to me on my first trip abroad.

title: Mayflower Replica Repaired
description: After a month of refurbishing, the Mayflower II is back in its berth at Plimoth Plantation. ''It came back yesterday, and it looks absolutely gorgeous,'' Troy Creane, a spokeswoman for the plantation, said Wednesday. The replica of the Pilgrims' ship, visited by about 300,000 people a year, undergoes major repairs about every two years. The latest repairs cost about $25,000.

title:
wESTCHESTER Q&A;: ANDREW M. CUOMO;
Working Out Answers on the Homeless
description: LEAD: THE county government expects to spend about $64.5 million this year on emergency help for the county's ever-increasing homeless population. The lion's share of this money is to be spent on temporary housing for the projected 1,000 homeless families and 1,325 homeless individuals.

title: Teamsters Said to Reject Offer in Takeover Suit
description: Leaders of the teamsters union today rejected a Government proposal to settle a racketeering suit that contends there is mob-sponsored corruption in the nation's largest union and that seeks to oust its top officials, union sources said.

title: Sound Cleanup Cost: Billions, Not Millions
description: It will not cost ''millions'' of dollars to clean up Long Island Sound, as Elex Ingersoll says in an appeal for public support for the task [ Opinion, ''Resolutions: For 1989, Clean Up Long Island Sound,'' Jan. 15 ] . According to Congressman George J. Hochbrueckner, the total cost, including upgrading old sewage plants and building new ones on both sides of the Sound, will be 10 to 15 billion dollars. The cost will keep rising with inflation and the worsening condition of the Sound, which is why marine biology scientists told Congress early in 1988 that the work needs to start as soon as possible. If it doesn't, the cost could become prohibitive and the Sound as well as all the other rich fish and shellfish waters along the coast will die in 20 years.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall. This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall. I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots. Can you explain why this mildew occurred?

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WIDOWS, by Ariel Dorfman. Translated by Stephen Kessler. (Penguin, $7.95.) In a land resembling both contemporary Chile and ancient Greece, the unrecognizable bodies of the ''disappeared'' begin washing ashore, tormenting the living with memories of the terror of the secret police. ''The plot resounds with the moral thunder of classic drama, specifically that of 'Antigone' and 'The Trojan Women,' '' Alan Cheuse said here in 1983. SECRETS OF THE TEMPLE: How the Federal Reserve Runs the Country, by William Greider. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) With its almost magical ability to create money out of thin air, the powerful and mysterious Federal Reserve has probably been the focus of as many conspiracy theories as the freemasons and the Trilateral Commission. William Greider ''has set out not just to demystify the Fed, but to place it in context, especially in the last decade,'' Adam Smith said here last year. ''He has done this with breathtaking energy and research. . . . After this book, the Fed can scarcely be called secret and mysterious. Even experienced professionals can find something to learn.'' THE RABBI OF LUD, by Stanley Elkin. (Scribners, $8.95.) As the rabbi of Lud, a vast burial ground on the New Jersey flats, Jerry Goldkorn presides over a congregation of the dead, administering last rites to people he never knew. In 1987 our reviewer, William Pritchard, praised the book for its ''brilliant, ruthless writing,'' though he found Lud ''an oddly airless fictional world.'' THE WORLD OF MATHEMATICS: A Small Library of the Literature of Mathematics From A'h-mose the Scribe to Albert Einstein, edited by James R. Newman. (Tempus, $50.) Why is geometry so intimately connected to music? Is mathematics something people discover or create?

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Former First Lady Stymied on Dunes

title: A Return to Pakistan
description: WHEN British India shuddered on the faultline of religion and split apart at independence in 1947, a new nation for Muslims, which they called Pakistan, was born.

title: Midlife Exhilaration
description: IN TRADITIONAL CULTURES, some women benefit from aging. According to the anthropologist Judith K. Brown, they acquire the authority and control and freedom they haven't had before. But just when I was launching into my own cross-cultural comparisons, wondering, ''Us, too?'' Dr. Brown goes on to say in her book, ''In Her Prime,'' that ''Although American women (in their middle years) are not as sinister or pitiable as they have been portrayed, they do not share all the advantages enjoyed by matrons in nonindustrialized societies.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Builders See a Gradual Market Upswing
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH many builders agree that the new-home market on Long Island will continue to show weakness this year, they also are optimistic that buyers will start trickling back now that memories of the 1987 stock market crash have faded and national elections are over. ''The election ended an uncertainty and resulted in a perception that present policies would continue and that the economy would remain stable,'' said Calvin Rafuse, president of the Long Island Builders Institute.

title: Anita A. Wager To Have a Bridal
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James B. Wager of Pittsburgh of the engagement of their daughter, Anita Andrews Wager, to George Oliver Richardson 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Jr. of Darien, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Katherine L. Knowles To Wed C. A. Sadler
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Knowles of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Lunt Knowles, to Christopher A. Sadler, a son of Anne Forrest of Featherston, New Zealand, and Alan Sadler of Masterton, New Zealand. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Eighth Avenue Goes From Grit to Glitter
description: ''WHENEVER someone asks me about success in real estate, I tell them to plan to live a long time,'' said Ian Woodner, a builder of office and residential projects in New York and Washington. ''If you live long enough, everything you own will end up being worth something to you.''

title:
MUSIC;
Guitarist's Passion for Gypsy Jazz
description: LEAD: FOR some reason that he is not able to explain fully, jazz was Frank Vignola's all-consuming passion when he was growing up in Islip.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Branford, Conn. $225,000 99 Windmill Hill Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; skylights, family room in basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,728. East Hartford, Conn. $128,000 63 Salem Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 46-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, enclosed porch, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,266. Old Greenwich, Conn. $635,000 27 Innis Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; on cul-de-sac, new kitchen, 0.33 acre; taxes $2,583. Armonk, N.Y. $536,000 3 Hidden Oak Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old ranch; basement, fireplace, playroom, workshop, pool and cabana, 2 acres; taxes $5,693. Bedford, N.Y. $477,500 Seminary Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old colonial; family room with w/b stove, Jacuzzi, deck, 1 acre; taxes $5,324. White Plains, N.Y. $190,000 16 Osborne Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fenced yard, eat-in kitchen, unfinished basement; taxes $1,150. OTHER AREAS Uniondale, L.I. $195,000 332 Leslie Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, finished basement, l-car garage; taxes $3,100. Sayville, L.I. $120,000 5 Alfred Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; den, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, basement; taxes $3,300. Livingston, N.J. $360,000 6 Hamilton Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; patio, den, stone fireplace; taxes $4,384.

title: Even Now, Hong Kong Is Unpracticed In Democracy
description: ON almost every distant rock of empire - in India, in Africa, in the Caribbean - Britain tried as it withdrew from its possessions to leave a democratic system as its legacy. But in Hong Kong, which is to be handed over to China in 1997, the British Government is critical of a democratic movement that has sprung up on its own, and it seems determined not to introduce a fully democratic system in the remaining years of its rule.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Vienna
description: In front of the 840-year-old Cathedral of St. Stephen, Vienna's geographic and historic center, a bulging structure of concrete, glass and bright metal is nearing completion amid a fierce debate. Designed by the leading architect Hans Hollein, the new eight-story building, in bold contrast to the ancient church's Gothic lacework, will house 16 ground-floor stores, a gourmet market, offices and - what else ? - a top-floor cafe with a view.

title: Chamber and Orchestral at Yale
description: YALE UNIVERSITY will provide a bountiful array this week, starting Tuesday at 8 P.M. The trio of David Golub, pianist; Mark Kaplan, violinist, and Colin Carr, cellist, will play Beethoven, Brahms and Schubert at Sprague Hall (432-4158). On Wednesday at 12:30 P.M., the Essex String Quartet, who hold fellowships, will give a short and free lunchtime concert at the Center for British Art. Information is at 432-2850. Carlo Bergonzi's master class last year was such a success that the Italian tenor has been invited to preside at two open coaching sessions with graduate music students Wednesday and Thursday at 7 P.M. in Sprague Hall. Details are at 432-2690.

title: Cambodian War Seen Through Cambodian Eyes
description: JUST 30 FEET AWAY, IN THE SUN-FLECKED shadows of the Cambodian jungle, was the sight that locals and visitors most dread: crouched, aiming his rifle, a teen-ager in dirty black pajamas and a red-checked scarf; nearby were four other Khmer Rouge guerrillas, in black with checked scarves, darting and dodging behind trees, guns pointed. Within minutes, the battle erupted. Through the noise and smoke of gunfire, exploding mines and burning leaves, two men seemed to be hit. Then, bizarrely, above the pandemonium came the sound of children laughing. Someone shouted ''Coupez!'' And the cameras stopped rolling. The feature film being shot in Kompong Speu Province last month isn't the first movie about the Khmer Rouge. In addition to the American ''Killing Fields'' (1984) and a recent Czechoslovak feature, ''Nine Circles of Hell,'' several documentaries have tried to show the genocidal Communist regime that ruled Cambodia from 1975 through early 1979, leaving the country in ruins and a sixth of its population dead. But this is the first film about the Khmer Rouge made by Cambodians in Cambodia - in fact, the first film of any kind made there since the Khmer Rouge dismantled the society in 1975.

title: Hungary, in Turnabout, Declares '56 Rebellion a Popular Uprising
description: Contradicting the official view of history held for more than 30 years, a member of the ruling Politburo has declared that Hungary's 1956 rebellion was a popular uprising rather than a foreign-instigated attempt at counterrevolution.

title: An April Bridal For Julia Forbes
description: The engagement of Julia Barrington Forbes and Matthew Scott Burnett has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mrs. Eric K. Lindquist of Sarasota, Fla., and John B. Forbes of New York. Mr. Burnett is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bradley Burnett, also of Sarasota. An April wedding is planned.

title: Ruling Against T.W.A. In Suit by Ex-Workers
description: Trans World Airlines is liable for civil damages to 3,000 former flight attendants who were replaced when they went on strike in 1986, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: The Legacy of Revolution
description: The French have launched a yearlong celebration of their Revolution's bicentennial. It comes when the worth of revolution was never more in question. In 1789 and after, they gave at least as many examples of the lasting damage and distress it causes as of the flowering of ideals it can release.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; At 25 Stories, It's the Tallest
description: ATER being vacant for four years, one of Wilmington's premier pieces of commercial real estate is about to be developed with a $70 million high-rise thrift headquarters.

title: When Parrents Suffer the Adult Children
description: RECENTLY, I read an article discussing how adolescence takes longer to go through these days. According to the researchers, not until children reach their mid-20's are they able to properly separate from their parents and accept them as human beings. Since our children range in age from 25 to 33, we know something about this phenomenon. Our experience suggests modern adolescence extends beyond the researchers' theory.

title: Lahore as Kipling Knew It
description: THOUGH Rudyard Kipling lived only five of his 70 years in Lahore, they were the most crucial years of his development as a writer. This rich confection of a city, whose great Mogul buildings and street life evoke the deep hues and sensuality of a miniature painting, was where the teen-aged Kipling cut his teeth as a newspaperman. Lahore provided the setting for some of Kipling's greatest stories, as well as the raw material for his somewhat misunderstood view of East and West.

title: The Sweet Prosciutto Of San Danieli, Italy
description: AL VECIO MULIN (the old mill) in Gradisca d'Isonzo, about six miles from the Italian-Yugoslav border, is always crowded with local residents who stop in to share a bottle of wine and some typical Friuli fare. The owner, Bruno Spessot, who turned the 200-year-old mill into an informal inn 25 years ago, offers top-quality hams, sausages and other cold cuts along with the local Montasio cheese and, from the nearby Collio wine region, tocai, pinot grigio and merlot. His lightly smoked prosciutto cotto, baked in a crust of bread to retain its moisture before being sliced, is delicious. But the real star here is prosciutto di San Daniele, a raw-cured ham from San Daniele del Friuli.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Travel to Burma And North Korea Now Permitted

title: Ms. McCormick Becomes a Bride
description: At the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, Conn., Kathleen Ellen McCormick, the daughter of Nancy McCormick Rance of Huntsville, Ala., and the late Cyrus Ross McCormick of Albany, Ore., was married yesterday to John Franklin Rhodes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Rhodes of Westport. The Rev. Mark Pitton performed the ceremony.

title: Besides Blood, Hospitals Test the Patience of Patients
description: THE young nurse had just finished taking my blood pressure - the only steady numbers my body gives off - and she turned her attention to my pulse. Her tiny fingers gently pinched my wrist searching for the radial artery. I remained quietly seated on the hospital bed as she stared at the simple gold chain bracelet on her otherwise naked wrist. ''Where's your watch?'' I asked. ''It's in the shop for repairs,'' she said. ''How can you take my pulse without a watch?'' I asked. ''If your pulse seems to be running unusually fast or slow, I borrow a watch. I'll get one.'' Under the circumstances, could there be any doubt that my pulse had just taken a quick run for the record?

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JERSEY CITY JAZZ Noel Pointer, that charming master of the electronic violin, will join Lonnie Liston Smith, a keyboard musician, Saturday evening for a jazz concert at Jersey City State College.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: New Hope, Pa.;
New Edition for A Paper Mill
description: LEAD: A GROUP of 62 condominiums called the Waterworks is under construction within the remaining walls of the 1820's Union Paper Mill on the edge of this southern Bucks County community.

title: Megabuck Jackpots For Slots Considered
description: SOME casinos here may band together soon in a program that would make millionaires of some slot-machine players.

title: Workshops That Lift Self-Esteem
description: LEAD: A VISITOR passing Room 101 at North Shore Junior High School in Glen Head could easily have thought that some kind of mystical ritual was taking place.

title: Woman Unharmed In Subway Attack, But Suspect Escapes
description: A 38-year-old woman escaped yesterday morning from the grasp of a man who had grabbed her and exposed himself on a lonely subway platform in lower Manhattan. She hit the man with a tote bag and was able to break free, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; Tearing Up Canton's Sidetrack
description: Even before Terry Bradshaw, Mel Blount, Art Shell and Willie Wood were announced as this year's inductees into the Pro Football Hall of Fame, some historians asked a valid question: why didn't Al Davis and Bud Grant, two of the candidates up for discussion, at least qualify for the final vote in the selection committee meeting?

title: Stockton Assists In Rise Of Jazz
description: The last time the Utah Jazz saw the Knicks was on Dec. 15 at Madison Square Garden.

title: UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
description: Cancer treatment is not in what Eleanor Bergholz calls ''a sorry state.'' It saves the lives of about 40 percent of those who have the disease.

title: Richmond
description: To the Editor: In Joe Mysak's story on the Richmond building that served as the Confederate States' executive mansion (''Where Davis Led the Confederacy,'' Travel, Dec. 4) a guide explained that one of two Confederate banners decorating a mantel included so much white that it was redesigned so as not to be taken as a flag of surrender. So far so good. But the guide is quoted as adding, ''The familiar stars and bars flag was actually a battle flag.'' There are two errors in the statement, for the Confederate Battle Flag is not the Stars and Bars, nor is the actual Stars and Bars flag familiar to anyone but vexillologists and the most careful viewers of ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: CATERING TO THE BRIDE AND GROOM
description: When a chef asks his sous chef for her hand in marriage, wedding plans become menus and grocery lists and recipes. That's what happened when Ali Barker, then chef at the Union Square Cafe in New York, became engaged to Marcie Smith, his sous chef. Of course, they would make all the food for the reception, not to mention the rehearsal dinner. ''That was going to be our personal touch,'' says Ali.

title: Alaska Cold Wave Is Endangering Life and Limbs
description: For more than two weeks, Alaska has been gripped by a cold wave that has turned a shared adventure into a test of endurance.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It may very well be that the net effect of L.B.O.'s is a financial snipe hunt, where all the long-term investors, flashlight in hand, are left holding the bag.'' - Nicholas F. Brady, Treasury Secretary, on leveraged buyouts.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 29, 1989

IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GLAMOROUS POWERS. By Susan Howatch. (Knopf, $18.95.) Susan Howatch's 13th novel, the second in a projected series that began with ''Glittering Images,'' weaves an intriguing and wholly involving story out of the otherwise sober subject of Christian mysticism in the 20th-century Church of England.

title: In County's Music World, Two Siblings Stand Out
description: ''GET the Brookses!'' people used to say, when it was music recital time in Port Chester. Norman Brooks and his little sister, Lorraine - known then and now as ''Rainie'' - could always be counted on to perform for their school or community: he to play the piano, she to play the piano or sing.

title: Stone Carver's Magnificent Obsession
description: In a cathedral with shrines to such eclectic groups as New York City firefighters and AIDS victims, a memorial exhibit has been opened to honor a homegrown artisan whose fluid stone carvings of demons, lion heads and African masks adorn the building's unfinished bell tower.

title: Carl Furillo, 1922-1989
description: Gil Hodges was the first to go. Then Jackie Robinson. Next after our brief remission from death, Billy Cox. And suddenly there stood a journalist asking Pee Wee Reese, ''How does it feel to be the last person alive from the great Brooklyn Dodger infield?''

title: AN ARDOR TO MATCH DIXIE'S
description: ''A PEOPLE'S CONTEST'' The Union and Civil War, 1861-1865. By Phillip Shaw Paludan. Illustrated. 486 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.95.

title: Celebrating Black History
description: LEAD: IN recognition of the achievements that black Americans have made and of their contributions to America, various events have been scheduled in Westchester throughout February - Black History Month.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/ANIMALS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A New 'Boheme' Puts Spotlight On Americans
description: DEUTSCHE GRAMMOPHON'S RECENT ''Boheme'' (423 601), recorded by Leonard Bernstein in Rome with a cast of young Americans, comes introduced in the program booklet by one of its producers with an oddly faint vote of confidence in the singers. ''Why an American cast for an Italian opera set in Paris?'' asks Hanno Rinke in an essay titled ''Bernstein's 'Boheme.' '' By way of answer, he explains how important it was to Mr. Bernstein to have dramatic credibility in the casting, to have his singers ''really become the characters they were singing.'' And so, it turns out, ''for purely practical reasons this was easier to achieve with an American cast, who had left their New York homes weeks before the first rehearsal in Italy to come over to Bernstein's apartment in the Dakota on Central Park.''

title: Reliable Sources For Quality Seeds
description: THIS is a good month to schedule commercial tree work: arborists can prune to shape overgrown trees or cut down unwanted specimens that are crowding the landscape; use deciduous tree logs for firewood, but caution on using conifer logs in the fireplace or woodstove. Indoors start seed of impatiens, snapdragons, petunias, fibrous begonias, calendula and geraniums. Study seed and nursery catalogues and mail orders promptly. Seed Sources

title: School Teaches Future Wrestlers
description: LEAD: LARRY SHARPE knows that monsters are made, not born. In a modest stucco building across from Paulsboro High School, where he had been a varsity wrestler, the 6-foot 260-pound (Pretty Boy) Sharpe teaches the basics of professional wrestling to a group of would-be monsters at his Monster Factory.

title: Scottish Treasures: Antique Buckles From Gilt to Glass
