description: A FLORIDLY engraved Victorian silver buckle, large in size and mounted as a brooch, originally belonging to my mother's mother and passed on to me when I was in college, began my fascination with British buckles. Among my most treasured possessions, a symmetrical pair of delicate Art Nouveau traceries, from the days when Liberty of London engaged England's leading designers for their silver, now clasps a suede belt. Although buckles are by no means unique to Britain, the decorative arts in general and metalwork in particular flowered in England and Scotland in the Arts and Crafts style nurtured by William Morris and in distinctively British forms of Art Nouveau fostered by Liberty's silver designers, Charles Horner and others in England, and the artists surrounding Charles Rennie Macintosh and the Glasgow Art School in Scotland.

title: Claire Noumair, A Schoolteacher, To Wed in July
description: The engagement of Claire Margaret Noumair to Gerald D. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Smith of San Jose, Calif., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George J. Noumair of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Deal, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: Hurricane-Damaged Y's in Jamaica Receive Help
description: LEAD: THE Y.M.C.A. of Kingston, Jamaica, which was badly damaged by Hurricane Gilbert last fall, and the Y.M.C.A. of Spanishtown, Jamaica, which needs different kinds of assistance with daily operations, will benefit Saturday night when the Y.M.C.A. of Central and Northern Westchester holds a fund-raising dinner-dance at the Rye Town

title: Cynthia R. Stone To Wed in March
description: Cynthia Rogers Stone and John Joseph Phelan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Phelan of Southbury, Conn., plan to marry in March, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wadsworth S. Stone of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced.

title: John Tower and The Revolving Door
description: In hearings last week on his confirmation as Secretary of Defense, John G. Tower provided a glimpse of the lucrative world of consulting which many Government officials enter when they leave public life. Mr. Tower, who retired from the Senate in 1984, founded Tower & Associates in 1986 and has since earned more than $750,000 in consulting fees from military contractors. On the whole, he was treated gently by the Senate Armed Forces Committee. But at one point, the committee's Democratic chairman, Sam Nunn of Georgia, reminded Mr. Tower of his recent assertion that he would not take part in Pentagon decisions affecting his former clients. ''If you were to recuse yourself on all of them, you couldn't be Secretary of Defense,'' Mr. Nunn said. Here are the six military contractors that employed Mr. Tower in his two-year consulting career, and the amounts they paid him. LTV Aerospace and Defense Company . . . . $246,860. Rockwell International Corporation . . . . $166,750. Hicks and Associates Inc. . . . . . . . . $154,167. Martin Marietta Information Systems . . . $116,000. Textron Inc. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $70,000. Jeford-McManus International Inc. . . . . . $10,000.

title: Cooperate? Co-opt?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cuckoos: The Bards of Avians
description: THEIR repertory is musically varied but subject specific. Their audiences are few but select. Their name says all. They are the Six Cuckoos.

title: With Concert Disks, Is It Live or Memories?
description: IT WAS A BRIGHT, MUGGY day on July 12, 1987 when 71,597 other people and I crowded into Giants Stadium to hear Bob Dylan and the Grateful Dead. There were clean-cut teen-agers in simulated 1960's tie-dyed shirts next to balding, long-term Dead Heads; from the first song, flailing dancers made the aisles impassible. While everyone seemed a little dazed and out-of-synch - from heat, beer and other substances - the audience was gleeful.

title: Many Say It's All but Certain: Dinkins Will Run
description: Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins will almost certainly run for mayor, say aides, politicians close to him and even potential opponents who have met with him.

title: A Death at Sea Brings Disbelief Vast as an Ocean
description: ''THE ship's gone down,'' he muttered with the icy calm of stupefied disbelief. ''Vinnie is among the missing - lost at sea.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-15 Iran has secretly enlisted companies from Germany, Asia and the United States to expand its limited stockpile of the chemicals needed to make poison gas, Federal court records and officials say. Page 1

title: Allison Shemitz Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan R. Shemitz of Woodbridge, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Allison Kate Shemitz to David Rounds Schieffelin, a son of G. Richard Schieffelin of New Haven and Billings, Mont., and the late Anne Rounds. A September wedding is planned.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Die Hard Starring Bruce Willis, Bonnie Bedelia, Clarence Gilyard Jr., Alexander Godunov, Alan Rickman. Directed by John McTiernan. 1988. CBS/Fox Video. 131 minutes. $89.98. Closed captioned. Rated R.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 29, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 9 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 6 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) Three performers in tinselly southern California. 3 16 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $4.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
In Special Education, State Is Making Progress
description: LEAD: THE 1975 landmark Federal legislation - Public Law 94-142 - guaranteed all school-age handicapped children a ''free and appropriate'' educational experience in the ''least restrictive environment.'' The State of New Jersey has obeyed this mandate and even expanded it to include all children up to the age of 21.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Frederick City, Md.;
From Barns To Bedrooms
description: LEAD: WITH 11 projects that will provide more than 1,500 single-family houses now under way, Frederick County's largest builder is helping to transform this thriving farmland into yet another bedroom suburb for the Baltimore-Washington metropolitan area.

title: Which Hospital?
description: The public might be less concerned over the participation of interns and resident physicians in their care if Dr. Konner had mentioned that morbidity and mortality rates have been shown to be significantly lower in teaching hospitals. This is underscored by the mortality rates for Medicare patients in New York-area hospitals, which were published in The New York Times in December. JOSEPH M. O'CONNELL, M.D. Southport, Conn.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Sneezing Beauty in a Raccoon Coat
description: LEAD: A MONTH before our 10th wedding anniversary, my husband announced that he wanted to buy me a fur coat to mark our first decade together.

title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth
description: LEAD: JANET W., who is pregnant and has a history of drug abuse, is typical of many young women in their late teens or early 20's showing up in increasing numbers at the Island's major hospitals.

title: Back to Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Bedford Tradeoff; Higher Density for Affordable Rents
description: An age-restricted garden apartment-town house complex is rising in Westchester's Bedford Hills as a result of a cooperative effort between officials of the Town of Bedford and a private developer. Named Bedford Lake, the 140 units include 112 one- and two-bedroom condominiums ranging in price from $138,500 to $200,000 to be sold to people 62 years of age or older.

title: Lyres, Lions and Things Neo-Classical
description: OVER THE CENTURIES, the Americans, French, English, Russians and even the Chinese have borrowed freely from the ancient Greeks and Romans in devising variations on classical themes, all of which have gained in popularity over the last decade. The Neo-Classical vocabulary of ornament - lyres, swans, columns, urns, eagles, griffins, lions, mythological creatures, gods and goddesses - dominates the imagery seen throughout the Winter Antiques Show, which ends its nine-day run today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.

title: MURDER IN BELLEVUE
description: PRIMAL SCENE By Yale Kramer. 381 pp. New York: Arbor House/ William Morrow.

title: Why Trade Remains a Jumble
description: Early this month the Customs Service issued a ruling to increase tariffs tenfold on imported vans and sports-utility vehicles. The decision, which would give added protection to American manufacturers, was chiefly designed to end a tariff classification ambiguity and harmonize American procedures with those of other countries.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/ANIMALS
description: A CARIBOU ALPHABET Written and illustrated by Mary Beth Owens. With a compendium by Mark McCollough. Unpaged. Brunswick, Me.: The Dog Ear Press. $13.95. (All ages) WILD ANIMALS OF AMERICA ABC Written and with photographs by Hope Ryden. Unpaged. New York: Lodestar Books/ E.P. Dutton. $12.95. (All ages) ONE CROW A Counting Rhyme. By Jim Aylesworth. Illustrated by Ruth Young. Unpaged. New York: J.B. Lippincott. $12.95. (Ages 2 to 6) HOW MANY SNAILS? A Counting Book. By Paul Giganti Jr. Illustrated by Donald Crews. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.95. (Ages 3 and up)

title: >IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: NOT counting the lights of Easton, Pa. (or Venus), I could count precisely 10 lights from my vantage point. Ten. That's not many, and there aren't many locations in New Jersey where a person can stand and make that boast.

title: A Public-TV Station Spins a Comeback Story
description: FOR A PUBLIC-TELEVISION station that was almost bankrupt seven years ago, KCET is celebrating its 25th anniversary in style. From ''Secret Intelligence'' - its current four-hour series on the underbelly of American espionage that documents United States attempts to assassinate Cuban leader Fidel Castro - to a new production of ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' KCET is flaunting its resurrection.

title: Review/Dance; Modern Works Inspired by the Past
description: Mark Franko has often choreographed in Renaissance and Baroque styles. But on Thursday night at the Washington Square Methodist Church, his company, Novantiqua, performed works by him to recorded music by Webern and Messiaen as well as Bach and Vivaldi and the program was essentially a modern-dance concert.

title: Directions
description: To the Editor: While I couldn't find my way around upstate New York from the position of the sun, as James Howard Kunstler claims he can (''Finding Your Routes,'' Travel, Jan. 8), I can find my way around a stage. Stage right and left are not, as he maintains, referred to from the audience's point of view but from the actor's.

title:
DINING OUT;
High Visibility in Scarsdale
description: LEAD: THIS unusual half-timbered Tudor-style structure has been here so long that it may be entitled to landmark status. Situated on one of the prominent corners - where Heathcote Road, Wilmot Road, Weaver Street and Palmer Avenue meet - visibility has never been a problem for any of the string of restaurant occupants in this building.

title: 'Billy Bishop' Musical: The Reality of Heroism
description: IN June 1915, a 21-year-old Canadian named Billy Bishop set sail for England and for war. He carried with him every young man's fantasy of romance and adventure.

title: Low-Fare Hunt Via London
description: IF you want to do some traveling in Europe - for warmth or for more intense winter - and can move fast, you can get some excellent air-fare buys right now. Early in January, Pan American started selling a deeply discounted ticket to London from New York for $298 round trip. British Airways and Trans World Airlines matched it, and Delta, flying out of Atlanta, did the same.

title: Two Initiatives Under Way on Drugs and Alcohol
description: THE concept of selling is so pervasive today - from toothpaste to political candidates - that it seems natural that the idea would be among the first things the leaders of two new alcohol- and drug-abuse prevention groups in Pleasantville would think of when considering programs to help them reach their objectives.

title: Exhibition of Puppets Is Coming to Columbia
description: An exhibition of puppets and masks from the Brander Matthews Dramatic Museum is to be on display in the Low Library Rotunda at Columbia University, 116th Street and Broadway, from Wednesday through Feb. 21. The show, sponsored by the Oscar Hammerstein 2d Center for Theater Studies, includes Noh masks, dance masks from Java and Thailand, carnival masks from Latin America, French marionettes and shadow figures from several countries. Admission is free. Hours are 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., Monday through Friday. Information: 854-3408.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TUTELARY TALES. By Villy Sorensen. Translated by Paula Hostrup-Jessen. (University of Nebraska, $21.) When an old optician makes glasses through which all that is bad appears good, and everyone can then see as ''only God had been able to see in the beginning,'' the blind have true vision and the interpretive role of the artist becomes obsolete.

title: Pound Ridge Dispute Puts Focus on Zen Group
description: LEAD: AS an image of peaceful meditation fostered by a Zen Buddhist monastery here dissolves into one of discord, the Town Board has scheduled a hearing on the widening dispute between the religious community and a neighboring homeowner.

title: CRIME ON THEIR HANDS
description: LEAD: GENERAL MURDERS By Loren D. Estleman. 232 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. MERMAIDS ON THE GOLF COURSE By Patricia Highsmith. 233 pp. New York: Penzler Books. $17.95.

title: A Progress Report on Rental Complex
description: LEAD: ONE of three rose and burgundy stone buildings in the Westchester Financial Center, rising from the urban-renewal area of this city's downtown, is Plaza 25, the only luxury rental apartment complex built in the county in at least 15 years.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY;
Testing the Limits, Making Demands
description: LEAD: THE question of how far photography can be pushed is central to Guild Hall's lively, provocative exhibition, ''Out of Bounds: Contemporary Long Island Photographers.''

title: 66 Appointed to Pulitzer Prize Journalism Jury
description: Columbia University has named 66 newspaper editors, executives and others for the jury to nominate entries for the 1989 Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

title: Alysheba Is Voted Top Horse of 1988
description: Alysheba, who won major races from coast to coast last year and become the richest race horse ever, today was named thoroughbred racing's Horse of the Year for 1988.

title: Call for Inquiry
description: The president of the North Carolina university system has asked four prominent citizens to investigate charges of wrongdoing in the North Carolina State basketball program.

title: The End of Ideology
description: Nearly 30 years ago, in ''The End of Ideology,'' Daniel Bell wrote that the universalist political ideas of the 19th century were exhausted. Marxism in particular. Its premises about the crisis of capitalism and the superiority of socialist organization had simply not squared with reality.

title: Some Sarcasm For Thompson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/ANIMALS
description: MOON-DARK By Patricia Wrightson. Illustrated by Noela Young. 169 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $13.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: Tipping
description: To the Editor: Regarding the response to a question on tipping (Q & A, Jan. 1):

title:
The View From: Mountain Lakes Camp;
By the Light of the Silvery Moon, Wintertime Life Goes On
description: LEAD: UNDER the full moon, the people walked through Mountain Lakes Camp. Over a dirt trail, down a steep slope, onto a lake frozen thick with smooth white ice, they went, talking softly. The silver rays bathed them in light that at times seemed almost as bright as the sun's, but the five humans appeared small, dwarfed by the forest, the 500-million-year-old rocks, the star-studded sky.

title: A Barber's View On Licensing
description: I enjoyed the Jan. 8 article ''Barbers Say 1984 Law Makes It Difficult to Do Their Business.'' I believe there are facets of this issue that should be brought to light.

title: Reviews/Music; Night of the Fortepianos
description: Malcolm Bilson's ''On Original Instruments'' series at Merkin Concert Hall has normally offered recital or chamber fare. Wednesday night, it worked itself up to chamber-orchestra proportions, mustering 22 musicians in all for an evening of Haydn and Mozart.

title: Of Art, Commerce And Mayors
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Trolley Barn Switches to Another Track
description: IN 1866, the Norwalk Horse Railway Company was established in a new downtown brick terminal and storage barn. Through its arched bays passed a fleet of red plush-seated trolley cars and the horses that drew them.

title: THE 99-YEAR ITCH
description: HONG KONG By Jan Morris. Illustrated. 359 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Debate on Officer's Statuette
description: A nine-inch statuette of the Virgin Mary that a police official put on his desk led to a dispute that has spiraled into a debate on the division between church and state. The debate is being waged in an arbitration case.

title: No Headline
description: Members of the staff of the United States Embassy in Beirut locked Ambassador John McCarthy in his office for three hours today to press their demands for higher salaries. A State Department spokeswoman, Nancy Beck, said Lebanese guards had carried out a ''work action,'' but declined to give details. ''The issues are economic and are being dealt with,'' she said.

title: Diamonds Are Forever
description: BULL DURHAM Starring Kevin Costner and Susan Sarandon (in photo), Tim Robbins, Trey Wilson, Robert Wuhl. Directed by Ron Shelton. 1988. Orion Home Video. 108 minutes. $89.98. Closed captioned. Rated R.

title: Elderly Are Offered Reverse Mortgages
description: LEAD: THE County Executive's Office for the Aging has introduced a reverse mortgage program to help the elderly create income through the equity in their homes.

title: Cooperate? Co-opt?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Custom Dance Company With Genuine Swiss Parts
description: FROZEN UNDER A BLANKET OF fresh snow, with its old town of pastel 16th-century houses nestled along the Rhine, Basel seems more like a sleepy Swiss town of Advent cards, where each window reveals a warm domestic scene, than a city where the arts are knit together in a powerful coalition that has made it a creative force in Europe.

title: Montreal Revitalizing Old City for 350th Anniversary
description: The district known as Vieux Montreal (Old Montreal or Old City) is being targeted for a major revitalization in time for the city's 350th anniversary in 1992.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: ANNA CURTENIUS ROOSEVELT;
In Search of Lost Civilizations in the Amazon Basin
description: LEAD: THEODORE ROOSEVELT surely would not agree with much of what his great-granddaughter, the archeologist Anna Curtenius Roosevelt, has to say. Ms. Roosevelt, a native of Oyster Bay, is rewriting a piece of history, and insisting that we cast off some well-worn ideas about the way native cultures interact with the rest of the world.

title: Redecorating for the Computer Generation
description: Companies are sparing no expense to dress up their offices. This year, factory sales of office furniture are expected to rise to $8.4 billion, double the $4.1 billion in revenues posted in 1982, the Business and Institutional Furniture Manufacturing Association, an industry trade group, reported.

title: Discovering Old Germany In Bamberg
description: A MEANDERING river, lined with old houses; a tall, four-towered cathedral on the hill, and next to it a great Baroque palace: today Bamberg still looks like a late 18th-century engraving of one of those little German towns that time had apparently forgotten. The texture of life - except for the inconveniently numerous cars - still belongs to an easier, sleepier time; from the dark, wood-paneled taverns serving the local white wine, beer and sausages to the impressive antique shops, all here speaks of the past.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What Do The Mets Need to Add For 1989?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: College's Aims Are Misguided
description: To the Sports Editor:

Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 13 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 2 41 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 3 3 11 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 4 4 12 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) The former actress's autobiography. 5 6 15 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 6 5 14 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 7 13 3 PARTING THE WATERS, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The rise of the American civil rights movement under the leadership of Martin Luther King Jr. 8 1 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 9 10 16 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 10 9 6 ''WHAT DO YOU> CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. 11 * 12 14 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican Presidential nominee. 12 7 11 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 13 15 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications/Prentice Hall, $49.95.) A profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 14 20 THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, by Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The life of the woman who married King Edward VIII. 15 14 17 THE RAGMAN'S SON, by Kirk Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The actor recalls his life as poor immigrant's son, waiter, film star, father and man. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 82 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 2 2 11 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 3 1 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 4 3 40 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 5 4 14 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) HENCE, by Brad Leithauser. (Knopf, $18.95.) At the heart of Mr. Leithauser's provocative and smartly written novel, set in 1993, is a man-versus-machine chess game in which the computer's approximations to humanity surpass those of the human player. THE COMPANY WE KEEP: An Ethics of Fiction, by Wayne C. Booth. (University of California, $29.95.) Forty years of reading, writing and teaching are summed up in Mr. Booth's examination of the strategies of writers and the counterstrategies of readers. WAR AND PEACE IN THE NUCLEAR AGE, by John Newhouse. (Knopf, $22.95.) Mr. Newhouse, a former Government arms control expert, offers a sober, responsible account of the nuclear-driven revolution in the issues of international relations (without, in his view, suitable changes in conducting them). BORDERLAND: Origins of the American Suburb, 1820-1939, by John R. Stilgoe. (Yale University, $35.) A scholar's presentation of contemporary detail characterizing the origin of the zone created by the American urge to commute from somewhere countryish. NO MAN'S LAND, by Martin Walser. (Holt, $18.95.) Economical and intense as theater, this powerful novel is really a dramatic monologue inside the head of its protagonist, Wolf, a divided man in a divided Germany whose reunion can't even be conceived. OWNING JOLENE, by Shelby Hearon. (Knopf, $17.95.) Fraudulent characters are the principal presences in this tale of a Texas girl, a chronic kidnap victim and poseur by necessity who is, off and on, hidden by her mother and stolen by her father. AIDS AND ITS METAPHORS, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) An ingenious and generous effort, directed against fatalism and obscurantism, to show how the way AIDS is talked about makes the disease even worse than it inherently is.

title: DIPLOMATS AND BUREAUCRATS: ... A PROTEST ...
description: INSIDE THE NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL The True Story of the Making and Unmaking of Reagan's Foreign Policy. By Constantine C. Menges. 418 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Kabul's Long, Suspenseful Goodbye
description: When night falls over this capital, Afghan soldiers, shabbily dressed, but armed with Russian-made Kalashnikov rifles, stop automobiles at every city block.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Union Square Theater; The Ghost Behind a Huge Sign
description: NOW covered by a huge McDonald's sign, the old Union Square Theater at 58 East 14th Street - usually described as the oldest such surviving structure in New York City - apparently had an intact Victorian theater interior walled off in 1936, when stores were inserted in the ground floor. Now the owner, Philips International Realty, says the building will be demolished this year.

title: Help Wanted: Male Dancers From America
description: LOOK AT THE PHOTOGRAPH ON THIS page and you might muse upon the fact that all three men, still in their 20's, were trained in Europe, while the women are American. Yet, all eight dancers are performing in an American company, the New York City Ballet.

title: Banned for Fighting
description: The Detroit Pistons' Bill Laimbeer and Brad Daugherty of the Cleveland Cavaliers were each suspended without pay for one game by the National Basketball Association yesterday.

title: Some Basic Facts On the Use of Flash
description: THOSE of us who watched the Super Bowl on television last Sunday were witness to several special photographic effects. For starters, thousands of fans in the stands fired their flashes into the air at the opening kickoff. I presume this was pre-arranged by the broadcasting powers-that-be to provide a nice glitter around the players, since none of the exposures has a chance of turning out.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Dentist With a Heart SOME give candy for Valentine's Day, others flowers. Fred Danziger, a dentist practicing in Long Beach, believes in giving a more substantial gift. ''I like to give health,'' he said. And so on Valentine's Day, as on the past two Valentine's Days, Dr. Danziger will offer free dentistry.

title: Q and A
description: Renting in a Co-op

title: TALKING: Tie-In Mortgages; Broker Conflict At Issue
description: A long-brewing controversy over whether brokers should place mortgages for home buyers may now be up to the incoming Congress to resolve. Earlier this month, the Department of Housing and Urban Development decided not to issue new regulations to govern the practice and left the problem to be settled by legislation.

title: Caveat Emptor
description: To the Editor:

title: Perceptions of the Problem
description: Do you personally see homeless people around your community or on your way to work, or is the problem only something you have seen on television or have read about?

title: INSIDE
description: Breaking Barriers Again

title: UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
description: As the spouse of a cancer victim, I found Eleanor Bergholz's article very informative. I had many questions about what my wife was experiencing. She withdrew from me, keeping her pain and depression to herself, just as Ms. Bergholz did. I believe she thought she was saving me from suffering. After reading this article, I was better able to understand what my wife was going through. BARRY GELBER Mahopac, N.Y.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: 'Speciesism' Explored; But Are Some More Equal Than Others?
description: FOR months, supporters of animal rights picketed, telephoned and wrote letters excoriating the experiments of Dr. Michiko Okamoto, a scientist at Cornell Medical College. When she gave up the experiments, which used cats to study drug addiction, the protests stopped.

title: The End of RICO
description: Back in 1969, when law 'n' order was a sexy issue, we all had this great idea: Congress would pass and the President would sign a law making it a crime for mobsters to take over legitimate businesses. That new legal weapon would make it possible, we told each other, for crusading prosecutors to break the back of organized crime.

title: Review/Television; Right and Wrong, in Our Time
description: The talking head has received its share of knocks over the years from television producers and reviewers who hold that programs relying on people talking to the audience or to other people on screen are not making the most of the medium's potential. For these critics, the pictures are the thing; lectures, debates, conversations are throwbacks to radio.

title: Sports World Specials; Fighting the Yips
description: In an era when performance-enhancing drugs are used by too many athletes, golf has come out almost squeaky clean compared with football and track. But golf has not been completely free of experimentation with such drugs, according to a study reported in the February issue of Neurology, the publication of the American Academy of Neurology. The drugs were found to be of little or no use for bettering performances and therefore dropped by the handful of golfers who admitted using them.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's like saying that a patient who died on the operating table is expected to fully recover.'' - Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, on Administration proposal for a fee on savings and loan deposits. [ A1:6. ]

title: Hydrogen Fuel Line Repaired On Space Shuttle Discovery
description: Engineers have fixed a leak in a hydrogen fuel line on the space shuttle Discovery.

title: Review/Dance; With Humor, a World From Ghana
description: The thicket of microphones was off-putting at first, and the gold-and-silver costumes looked a little garish. The atmosphere on stage seemed placid to the point of noninvolvement with the audience and the material. But Odadaa, a company of 11 musicians, dancers and singers from Ghana, soon proved irresistible and its performance on Saturday night at Symphony Space was far too short a visit to New York City.

title: Suspect Held in 5 L.I. Sniper Attacks That Left One Man Dead
description: A 20-year-old man was charged today in five sniper attacks on eastern Long Island that left one man dead and three other people wounded, and created fear among residents of two towns, the Suffolk County police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: British Lawyers Jolted by Thatcher Plan
description: In the last decade, occupations ranging from steelworker to stockbroker have been transformed by the relentless application of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-market principles. But few of the changes have been so sweeping or created such an uproar as the Government's proposals last week to overhaul the legal profession.

title: Rangers' Travels Prove Prosperous
description: Tony Granato awoke this morning in a hospital room, his head throbbing mildly, his recollection of the events that landed him here rather incomplete.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 20 about racial discrimination in the Navy erroneously characterized, in some copies, the jobs open 30 years ago to minority sailors. They served in a variety of jobs, not solely as mess stewards.

title: Goodbye, Dali - It's Been Surreal
description: LEAD: In 1960, Mafalda Davis, once a lady-in-waiting to the Queen of Egypt, asked me to deliver an 18th century Russian enamel spoon to Salvador Dali at the St. Regis Hotel. The moment the flamboyant master of surrealist painting and I exchanged glances, we were certain we were destined for each other.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Veteran Campaign
description: Remember the 38th parallel? The New York Korean Veterans Memorial Commission has decided not too many people do, so it is releasing a jolting ad campaign, created as a pro bono gesture by Burkhardt & Christy Advertising. Included will be two television spots and six newspaper ads. The commission plans to build a memorial in Battery Park City to the 53,000 Americans killed in the war.

title: Being Senior Judge Pays For Former Chief Justice
description: Warren E. Burger, who stepped down as Chief Justice of the United States in 1986 and has not heard a case since, stands to receive a $60,000-a-year raise because he chose to become a senior judge when he retired.

title: Remember, Carnivores, One Man's Meat Is Another Man's Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Texaco Feud Resolved Texaco and Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, reached a compromise in a bitter struggle over the company's future that had lasted for more than a year. Page D1. For Sale: Spy Photos American experts think close-up photographs of the earth now being marketed commercially by the Soviet Union were taken by Soviet reconnaissance satellites. Page A12. Environmental Collision Oil companies are excited and environmentalists worried by the prospect of huge natural gas reserves off the North Carolina coast. Page A10. On to the Courtroom Oliver L. North, who helped finance a guerrilla war in Nicaragua through arms sales to Iran, is to go on trial tomorrow. Page A14. Banks Closing Branches Obtaining banking services in middle- and low-income minority communities in the New York region is becoming harder. Page B1. More Lesbian Mothers Thousands of lesbians around the country are becoming mothers for the first time, usually by artificial insemination. Page A13. Man Charged as L.I. Sniper Yusef Abdullah Rahman was accused of five attacks on Long Island. Police said he also confessed to three murders in Kansas City, Mo. Page B1.

title: Medicare Pay Questioned for Mechanized Chairs
description: Medicare is paying an average of about $60 million a year for mechanized lounge chairs that have questionable medical value, a draft report by the Department of Health and Human Services says.

title: Publisher of Classes Looks to Masses
description: In the search for new ideas in publishing, Burke's Peerage Ltd., the 163-year-old chronicler of British nobility, with its hoary gaze on a gilded past, would appear to be the last place to look. But try this one from Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's: books peppered with advertisements.

title: Time Inc.'s Grand Plan Leaves Room for Books
description: As Time Inc. positions itself to compete in the 1990's with communications empires like those of Rupert Murdoch and Robert Maxwell, books are playing an increasingly important role.

title: Books of The Times; 10 Heeders of the Call to Make It New
description: The Modern World Ten Great Writers By Malcolm Bradbury Illustrated. 294 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about beans described their cholesterol-lowering properties incorrectly. It is the soluble fiber, not the insoluble fiber, that reduces cholesterol in the blood.

title: Legality and Morality of Patronage Are Both Open to Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Driven to Kill Are Shown More Mercy
description: LEAD: Two convicted murderers walked out of prison in Springfield, Ill., last month, their sentences commuted to the time they had already served.

title: Soviet Craft Orbits Mars on Way to Moon Phobos
description: The Soviet spacecraft Phobos 2 today entered into orbit around Mars, bringing it closer to landing on the Martian moon Phobos. The mission is the first in the Soviet Union's program to land a man on Mars in the next 25 years.

title: Lebanon's Multiplying Rivalries Move Nation Closer to Breakup
description: Lebanon is sinking ever closer to disintegration in the worst crisis of its 14 years of civil war.

title: Justice Dept. Will Drop Suit Against Two Who Quit Union
description: Two teamsters' union leaders who resigned this weekend will be dropped as defendants in a Government suit charging racketeering, a spokeswoman for the United States Attorney in New York said today.

title: Optimism Abounds in Calgary
description: LAST spring, a melancholy feeling swept over this city like an unexpected, stubborn chinook. The Olympics had packed up and gone, leaving a lot of suddenly vacant hotels and a generally empty atmosphere of anticlimax. Worse, the Flames had been routed from the National Hockey League playoffs by their deeply resented rivals to the north, the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about an exhibition of art by the designer Ivan Chermayeff at Cooper Union in New York misattributed the design of corporate logos for Mobil, Chase Manhattan Bank and Lincoln Center. They were produced by the firm of Chermayeff & Geismar Associates and were designed by Mr. Chermayeff's associate, Thomas H. Geismar.

title: Bank Closings Discriminate, Report Asserts
description: Commercial bank-branch closings in the New York metropolitan region over the last three years have made it more difficult for blacks and other minorities to gain access to banking services, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Old Hand on Capitol Hill Is Creating a New Voice in Cabinet
description: Back on the South Side of Chicago, where Edward J. Derwinski's political career first flourished, veterans' organizations were threaded through the community fabric.

title: Bhutto's Party Suffers Blow in Key Elections
description: The political opposition in Pakistan made a strong showing this weekend in the first test of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's leadership since national elections in November.

title: Guard and Cleaner Are Suspended In Sexual Assault Case at Hospital
description: A security guard and a cleaning aide at the Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan were suspended without pay last week after a psychiatric patient there said they had sexually assaulted her, a spokeswoman for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday.

title: Weary Knicks Return Home
description: When their jet touched down at Kennedy International Airport late yesterday afternoon, most of the Knicks, who had experienced the rigors of a long National Basketball Association road trip for the first time this season, felt relief.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 The political forces in Chile that led the successful campaign against Gen. Augusto Pinochet are feuding over whom to nominate for President, with the main opposition party torn in factions. Page A1

title: '62 MISSILE CRISIS YIELDS NEW PUZZLE
description: Leading figures in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis ended an unusual meeting here this weekend having resolved some of the mysteries about that autumn of nuclear brinksmanship, but having added at least one puzzle: Did Fidel Castro urge Nikita S. Khrushchev to fire nuclear weapons at the United States?

title: New York City Ballet To Offer Seminar Series
description: The New York City Ballet is presenting ''The N.Y.C.B. at 40,'' a series of seminars this month and in February, on aspects of the creative process. Robert Gottlieb, editor of The New Yorker, will serve as moderator this evening for ''Muscles and Memory.''

title: Outdoors: Finding Solitude on Snowshoes in the Woods
description: ALTHOUGH they are far outnumbered by cross-country skiers, there are many who favor snowshoes for wandering in the winter woods.

title: Modest Insider-Trading Stir Is a Huge Scandal in France
description: The insider-trading accusations surrounding Pechiney's acquisition of Triangle Industries are modest by American standards, but in France they have ballooned into a huge scandal that is shaking the Government and that is likely to lead to significant changes in how France regulates its financial markets.

title: Reviews/Music; Enveloped in Busoni
description: Liszt taught us that virtuosity could be a purely musical tool. To its virtues, Busoni added excess. As a compositional device, excess upends our musical values, and indeed Busoni's music leaves us unprepared and threatened, like passengers who have unwittingly chosen a rowboat in which to face a tidal wave.

title: In Radio, an Expensive Battle at Sunrise
description: Radio station owners are increasingly turning to well-paid personalities to host shows in the morning in a growing recognition of the time slot's importance to overall ratings.

title: Tax Watch; C.P.A. Calculates 13 Brackets Now
description: WHEN the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was still on the Congressional drawing boards, proponents discussed simplification of individual returns as a major goal. But as soon as it was passed, tax professionals were quick to contend that it was really tax complication. Now, Joel S. Isaacson, a certified public accountant who is in charge of personal financial planning for Weber, Lipshie & Company, has provided evidence of the complications.

title: California Dreams Of a Derby Prospect
description: In each of the last three years, Californians swore that they did not have a potential Kentucky Derby winner wintering in their midst. Most Eastern handicappers agreed with them. Then, of course, Ferdinand, Alysheba and Winning Colors all came out of California to win the last three Derbies.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Inquiry on Film And Cigarettes
description: Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio, who has helped lead the legislative battle against cigarette advertising, has announced an investigation of tobacco product placements in Hollywood movies.

title: Moscow Journal; The Stalin Generation, Where Nostalgia Dies Hard
description: He was 3 years old when his family was driven from its village near Kursk in 1929, during Stalin's campaign against the more prosperous peasants known as kulaks. His infant brother died in the exile.

title: Metro Matters; The Homeless: A Problem Koch Wants to Lose
description: Among the many applause lines in Mayor Edward I. Koch's State of the City Message last week was this: ''No one should turn away from the plight of the homeless. But neither should the homeless turn public streets, parks and buildings into de facto shelters. Under such a system no one is helped, nothing improves.''

title: F.B.I. Commodities 'Sting': Fast Money, Secret Lives
description: Few people at the Chicago Board of Trade took notice in December 1986 when a stocky man, who combed strands of hair over his head to conceal a bald spot, began working on the trading floor as a telephone clerk.

title: A Departing Envoy's Grim Afghan View
description: The United States cannot prevent the Afghan rebels from accelerating their onslaught against the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul once Moscow completes its expected troop withdrawal next month, says Richard W. Murphy, the State Department's senior Middle East policy maker during much of the Reagan Administration.

title: 'Art of Passover'
description: An exhibition titled ''From Seder to Stella: The Art of Passover in the Collections of the Jewish Museum'' is to open next Monday at the museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street. The exhibition, which is to run through Oct. 19, includes ceremonial objects used in the observance of Passover and examples of work by 20th-century artists that was inspired by the Passover theme. Admission is $4 for adults, $2 for children and the elderly. Information: 860-1888.

title: BUSH IS CRITICIZED FOR NOT DROPPING SAVINGS-FEE PLAN
description: Bankers and members of Congress criticized the Bush Administration today for insisting that a fee on deposits remains an option to rescue the savings and loan industry.

title: Discussion Closed
description: There are more than 100 choice parking places in the quadrangle bounded by Pennsylvania Avenue, Constitution Avenue, 15th Street and 17th Street, and most of them are reserved for people who work at the White House and the Old Executive Office Building. The parking places are divided into categories: choice spots within the White House gates, less choice spots in the immediate vicinity on State Place and spots around the Ellipse for executive branch underlings.

title: Study Says Toxic Waste Plan Uses Private Sector Too Much
description: The Government program to clean up toxic wastes relies too much on outside contractors, many of whom are making hefty profits while Government supervisors remain underpaid, understaffed and underqualified, a Congressional study says.

title: For Insider Dinner, Bush, Well Done
description: It is an elite Washington club open to men only and with a number of political heavyweights as members, a tradition of tongue-in-cheek humor and a motto that in Latin translates roughly, ''He who picks up the check is blessed.''

title: Man Is Charged In Wife's Slaying
description: A 33-year-old man has been charged with murder in the stabbing death of his wife, the New Britain police said yesterday.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

title: Reviews/Music; For the Cleveland, Audience Divided
description: There seemed to be two partisan groups at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, when the Cleveland Orchestra played the last of its three concerts there. One group came to hear the soprano Kathleen Battle sing, after which they cheered long and loud, then left the hall in order to avoid hearing the work the second group came for, Edgar Varese's ''Ameriques.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about President Bush's endorsement of a Congressional pay raise misattributed a remark defending the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright. It was another Democratic leadership aide, not Mr. Wright's press secretary, who said it was unfair that ''people have been laying it all at the foot of the Speaker.''

title: Tokyo Stocks Set Record; Dollar Rises
description: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen in morning trading today, while share prices reached a new high on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: Big Victory for a Little Horse
description: After a two-year fight to evict Ragtime, a 27-inch-high miniature horse that has the run of its owner's home here, the City Council of this Los Angeles suburb has voted to give up. ''From New York to Nova Scotia, people are telling us to stop picking on the horse,'' Mayor Larry Horner said Wednesday. ''It's time to just bow out of it.'' Ragtime's owner, Patty Fairchild, contended all along that he was clearly a pet and therefore should not be subject to an ordinance barring farm animals from residential neighborhoods.

title: Louisville Loses In Bid for Top Spot
description: Jay Burson scored 29 points and 17th-ranked Ohio State rallied today for an 85-79 victory over No. 3 Louisville.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the headquarters city of the Irwin Company, a consulting concern. It is Los Angeles.

title: Whales on Tape
description: The Smithsonian Institution, which has spread learning through books, records and television, has now gone into videotape production. Its first effort is a one-hour video, ''The Magnificent Whales,'' which features dolphins, seals, sea lions and sea otters as well as the top-billed species.

title: Steinberg Jury Asks Judge to Define 'Intent'
description: The judge in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg redefined the main element of one of the charges against the defendant yesterday as the jury deliberated for the seventh day.

title: Woman and Boy Die In a Fire at a House
description: An 11-year-old boy and a 24-year-old woman died of smoke inhalation yesterday morning in a small fire at their house in Brooklyn, the police said, but they were not discovered until family members went upstairs to awaken them for church.

title: Third Parties in U.S. Have Fared Poorly
description: To the Editor:

title: Networks Plan More Series Efforts
description: ''Moonlighting,'' the ABC television show, has always tried to be a little different from other television shows by combining action, mystery, romance and comedy.

title: Miss Miller Is Married To Robert Zalaznick
description: Kathryn Ann Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis A. Miller of Darien, Conn., and Robert Samuel Zalaznick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Zalaznick of Great Neck, L.I., were married yesterday at the Landmark Club in Stamford, Conn., by Rabbi Deborah Hirsch.

title: Co-presidents Named At Foxmoor Specialty
description: The Foxmoor Specialty Stores Corporation, which operates 603 young women's apparel stores in the United States, will have two presidents starting Wednesday.

title: Sports World Specials; Hidden Talent
description: When National Basketball Association scouts scour college campuses in search of a center or power forward, their stops usually include Chapel Hill, N.C., Ann Arbor, Mich., and Lexington, Ky.

title: Concern on Canada's Merger Wave
description: The last two weeks have been unsettling for the millions of Canadians who fly on the country's airlines or buy beer, paper products or gasoline. A spate of billion-dollar takeovers and mergers has swept these four important industries, threatening thousands of jobs and reviving concerns about the concentration of economic power.

title: Remeber, Carnivores, One Man's Meat Is Another Man's Poison; Low-Cholesterol Tips
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Bush Wants for Drug War Is Less Than Sought by Congress
description: President Bush will seek only a small increase in money for drug enforcement over Ronald Reagan's final budget, a rise that would fall short of the amount being sought in Congress, Administration officials said today.

title: Two Officers Killed In Thruway Crash
description: Two auxiliary police sergeants were killed yesterday on the New England Thruway in the Bronx when a motorist crashed into an abandoned car they were inspecting, the police said.

title: King's 38 Lead Bullets
description: Bernard King scored 38 points, his highest total since a serious knee injury nearly four years ago, as the Washington Bullets overcame a 20-point deficit to beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 122-117, in overtime today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON THE DRAFTING OF AN INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION AGAINST RECRUITMENT, USE FINANCING AND TRAINING OF MERCENARIES - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NON-GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Jay Rosenblum, Painter, 55
description: Jay Rosenblum, an abstract painter, died Friday in St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering massive injuries in an accident with a bus while he was bicycling. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Art; Early Cezanne: Toward His Own Vision
description: Finally we have arrived at the beginning of Cezanne. For years his restlessly still Midi landscapes from the 1870's and 80's have been celebrated for their serenity and resolution. In 1977 the Museum of Modern Art in New York devoted a landmark exhibition exclusively to the late Cezanne, whose broken, translucent planes seemed to open directly into Cubism, perhaps the main link in the museum's great modernist chain of being.

title: U.S. Rules on Japanese 'Dumping'
description: The Commerce Department ruled on Thursday that Japanese all-terrain vehicles were being sold in the United States at less than their fair value and proposed that anti-dumping duties be imposed to eliminate the price advantage.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Cincinati's Super Bowl
description: GEORGE BLAKE, the editor of The Cincinnati Enquirer, does not usually count himself among the bettors on major sporting events, but recently he wagered $3,740 that the Cincinnati Bengals would make the Super Bowl in Miami.

title: Review/Theater; Right-Thinking Ingenuousness Cleans Up a Nation
description: Theatergoers who were born yesterday can only speculate about why Garson Kanin's ''Born Yesterday'' caused a sensation on Broadway in 1946. The play's flat new revival at the 46th Street Theater, enlivened solely by Madeline Kahn's game stab at the heroine, Billie Dawn, refuses to yield many clues. Nor can the ritualistic explanation for the comedy's initial runaway success - the emergence of Judy Holliday, the original Billie, as a star - be the entire story. If one eliminates musicals, ''Born Yesterday'' is the seventh-longest running play in Broadway history, eclipsing even Neil Simon's most popular works in the record books. Mr. Kanin didn't merely write a hit; he created a phenomenon.

title: Bonn Vows Inquiry on Charges Involving Iran Gas
description: A West German Foreign Ministry official said today that the Government would thoroughly investigate assertions that Iran had used its embassy in Bonn to arrange supplies for the production of poison gas.

title: Bush Urged to Appoint Judge As Lawyer to Supreme Court
description: The Justice Department has asked President Bush to name a Federal appeals court judge as the agency's solicitor general, the Government's main legal representative before the Supreme Court, an Administration official said tonight.

title: Owners Set on Free Agency
description: Unless United States District Judge David Doty grants an injunction to stop them, the National Football League's owners plan to institute a new policy on free agency Wednesday.

title: Market Place; Replacing Shares In Index Funds
description: RUNNING an index fund would seem to be a dull way to make a living. But appearances can be deceiving, and last week index fund managers made big decisions that may have played a significant role in sending blue-chip stock prices up sharply.

title: RICO: Assault With a Deadly Weapon?
description: Wall Street is not a racketeering enterprise, say brokers and financiers; then why are they being treated like mobsters? Prosecutors and civil litigants who once were content to file stock fraud charges now invoke the law known as RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act passed by Congress in 1970. Nice people are accused, not just scurvy hoodlums.

title: O'Meara Wins With Birdie at 18
description: Mark O'Meara, who had not won on the PGA Tour since having consecutive triumphs at the 1985 Bing Crosby Pro-Am and Hawaiian Open, rolled a 10-foot birdie putt right into the center of the 18th cup today to beat Tom Kite by a stroke in the current version of the old Bing Crosby: the $1 million A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

title: Texas Eastern Rejects Offer From Coastal
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said today that its board had rejected the Coastal Corporation's $42-a-share tender offer as inadequate and recommended that Texas Eastern shareholders not tender their shares.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cable Guide Magazine On Video
description: THE CABLE GUIDE, the monthly road map offered to cable-television subscribers by their cable operators, is going on the air - or more accurately, on the cable.

title: Needle Plan Fails to Attract Drug Addicts, So It's Revised
description: Confined to a former X-ray clinic hardly larger than a one-car garage, New York City drug counselors wait, sometimes all day, for intravenous drug addicts who come to get clean needles.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With Tommy John released by the Yankees and seemingly out of baseball, is Nolan Ryan the last player in the major leagues who played in the 1960's and has a chance to play in the 1990's?

title: R. L. Knudsen Dies; Photographer Was 61
description: Robert LeRoy Knudsen, a White House photographer from 1946 until 1974, died of a heart attack Friday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 61 years old and lived in Annandale, Va.

title: Auto Racing; Grand Prix Moves to Phoenix
description: The United States Grand Prixfollowed the St. Louis Cardinals football team last week and moved from the Midwest to Phoenix.

title: A Novelist Focuses On a Common Fact of Life: Its Ending
description: A. B. Yehoshua's new novel, ''Five Seasons,'' begins at 4 o'clock one autumn morning in the bedroom of an apartment in Haifa, Israel, as a middle-aged Israeli named Molkho watches his wife die after a seven-year struggle with cancer. The book, which has been a best seller in Israel and has recently been published to critical praise in the United States, follows Molkho through the next five seasons, as he thinks back over the seven years of suffering, begins to cope with the reality of his wife's death and takes his first tentative steps toward a new life.

title: Separate Shootings Claim Two Victims
description: The police yesterday said they were investigating two unrelated murders in the borough.

title: A Mugging and a Mob Evoke Debate in Brooklyn
description: There is a tradition in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a tradition almost as old as the sidecurls, beards and broad-brimmed hats that the Hasidic men who live there wear. The tradition is that when someone cries ''Chaptzum'' - the Yiddish equivalent of ''Grab him!'' - everyone obeys.

title: 4 Bronx Slayings Called Drug-Related
description: A Lehman College freshman and three other people were shot and their throats were slit in a quadruple murder in a grocery store in the northeastern section of the Bronx early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Delaware Adds to Court
description: A rising tide of corporate takeover battles has prompted Delaware to enlarge its Chancery Court, one of the nation's most important arbiters of corporate takeovers.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 29, 1989: MONDAY Boeing Co Consol Freightways Foster Wheeler Kentucky Utils Co TUESDAY Airborne Fght Corp Duke Pwr Co McDonald & Co Invts Inc Philadelphia Subn Cor UGI Corp USX Corp Weis Mkts Inc WEDNESDAY not available THURSDAY n.a. FRIDAY n.a. SATURDAY n.a.

title: A New Ski Binding
description: rrA new ski binding designed with a sliding heel is in the wings for the downhill ski market next season.

title: Texaco And Icahn End Feud
description: Texaco Inc. and Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, ended a feud yesterday that had left the company's future uncertain for more than a year.

title: Lesbian Partners Find The Means to Be Parents
description: In a baby boom of unusual complexity, thousands of lesbians around the country are having children.

title: Clemson Comes Up Short
description: Clemson, without six players who had been suspended, gave Duke trouble for much of the first half today before crumbling. Danny Ferry and Quin Snyder led a 32-5 spurt as the eighth-ranked Blue Devils broke a three-game losing streak with a 92-62 victory.

title: After Months of Legal Skirmishing, Trial of North Is Only a Day Away
description: After 10 months of pretrial legal battles, Oliver L. North, the former marine who helped finance a guerrilla war in Nicaragua through arms sales to Iran, is scheduled to go on trial Tuesday on 12 criminal charges stemming from his activities.

title: Incinerators Creating New Landfill Woes
description: Fifteen years ago, with empty land for garbage dumps disappearing, Connecticut became one of the first states to look to large incinerators as a way to dispose of trash. Today, the state is struggling to deal with the consequences of its own foresight.

title: Spanish Banks Are Bracing for 1992
description: A year ago executives at Spain's top seven banks had one concern: that merger fever could make them all takeover targets.

title: COALITION PARTIES SET BACK IN BERLIN
description: Municipal elections in West Berlin today dealt a blow to the governing center-right coalition, while a small extreme-right party led by a former SS officer made an unexpectedly strong showing to gain its first parliamentary seats.

title: Dead Children and Civic Duty
description: In New York City last year, 127 children died of abuse or neglect, the second-highest total in the 80's. Mayor Edward Koch insists that the city cannot prevent all child abuse deaths. But what about the recent deaths of Jessica Cortez and Michael Anthony Baker?

title: Urge to Help Neediest Cases Spans Several Generations
description: Following in her father's footsteps, a daughter of the actor Paul Newman, who did not want to be named, sent a contribution of $2,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A similar gift of $2,000 came from Timothy Hotchner, 17 years old, son of A. E. Hotchner, the writer and a neighbor of the Newmans in Westport, Conn.

title: U.S. Seeks Compromise For Development Bank
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is trying to resolve a two-year-old dispute between the United States and one of the largest suppliers of capital to Latin America as part of a Bush Administration strategy for tackling the debt crisis.

title: Old Rail Line To Be Turned Into Parkland
description: An abandoned rail line here in the Harlem Valley will be converted into a public park under a complicated plan approved this week by New York State, Dutchess County and the private owner of the railroad right of way.

title: Soviet Photos of U.S. Were for Spying
description: Government and private experts who analyzed close-up photographs of the earth sold by the Soviet Union have concluded they were taken by satellites placed in orbit for military spying rather than scientific research.

title: Bridge
description: One of the last great players to survive from the early days of the game is Lee Hazen of Manhattan. At age 83, he continues to pursue a busy legal practice, and he was recently named an Honor Member of the International Bridge Press Association, in recognition of his many services to the game. His latest brainstorm is the establishment of a Bridge Hall of Fame.

title: Jail for Denying Medical Aid
description: A member of a small Amish community who has refused to allow his 6-year-old son to be treated for cancer was sent to jail Friday on a contempt of court charge. The man, Danny Mast, argued that chemotherapy was not helping his son, Amos, who has abdominal cancer, and that the boy has done much better on the ''natural medicine'' like herbs and vitamins that the father learned at a clinic in Mexico.

title: Tennis; Lendl Takes Title and No. 1
description: Ivan Lendl had two New Year's resolutions: to win the Australian Open and to win Wimbledon. Now he has one. Lendl beat ninth-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-2, 6-2, today for his first Australian Open title and regained the No. 1 ranking in men's tennis.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness
description: GOING for a walk is an easy way for a sedentary person to start a fitness routine, but sooner or later it will be raining or snowing, or it will be too hot or too cold, or there will be too much traffic. Any excuse not to go out will suffice.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
McDonnell Douglas Names Head of Jet Unit
description: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said on Friday that it had named Robert H. Hood Jr. president of the Douglas Aircraft Company, effective May 1. He succeeds James E. Worsham, who the company said may continue in some other position after he turns 65 years old in April.

title: Rod Serling's Hometown Likes to Bask in His 'Twilight'
description: You're traveling through another dimension, a dimension not only of sight and sound but of mind. Next stop, the town where Rod Serling grew up.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * Everex, Fremont, Calif., a maker of personal computers and peripherals, to Tycer Fultz Bellack, Palo Alto, Calif., with a budget of roughly $5 million.

title: Robert William Haymes, Composer, 65
description: Robert William Haymes, a composer and broadcast producer, died of Lou Gehrig's disease Saturday at his home in Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 65 years old and also had a home in Greenville, S.C.

title: Natural Gas May Hold Key in Global-Warming Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Narrows Trade Gap
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed in December to $:1.66 billion, or about $2.92 billion, the Government said Friday.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Make Winter Golf a Foul-Weather Friend
description: LEAD: SEVERAL golfers at an Air Force base in Greenland once held a golf tournament atop Mount Dundas, 800 miles from the North Pole. They each carried a piece of carpet that served as a teeing ground and putting green. History does not record the winner.

title: Moran in Pact With Moore
description: J. T. Moran & Company said Friday that it had reached a tentative agreement to buy control of Moore & Schley, Cameron & Company.

title: Rising Stocks May Bolster Bonds
description: The stock market, which has tended to take its cue from interest rates since the 1987 crash, may now be a major source of strength for the credit markets, some analysts contend.

title: Results Plus
description: N.F.L. N.F.C. 34, A.F.C. 3: Herschel Walker ran for a pair of touchdowns and Randall Cunningham directed three scoring drives yesterday, leading the National Football Conference to a 34-3 victory over the American Conference in the Pro Bowl at Honolulu. Walker, the Dallas Cowboys' running back, scored on runs of 4 yards and 7 yards as the N.F.C. beat the A.F.C. All-Stars for the first time in three years. Cunningham, the Philadelphia Eagles' quarterback, who was making his first Pro Bowl appearance, completed 10 of 14 passes for 63 yards and rushed twice for 49 yards while playing about half the game. He was voted the game's most valuable player. The Saints' Morten Andersen added two field goals, including a Pro Bowl record 51-yarder. The N.F.C. led by 14-3 at halftime, then took command with 10 points in both the third and the fourth quarters. The Bears' Neal Anderson rushed 13 times for 85 yards. (AP) Skiing Schneider Catches McKinney: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland charged from more than a full second off the pace to overtake Tamara McKinney of the United States and win the women's combined slalom yesterday at the world Alpine championships in Beaver Creek, Colo. Results of the race - the opening event of the championships - will be paired with the results of a downhill race on Thursday to determine the combined medalists. Schneider is a heavy favorite for the gold medal. Her aggregate time for two runs was 1 minute 18.58 seconds. McKinney was second in 1:18.70. (AP) Horse Racing A. M. Swinger Takes Count Fleet: A. M. Swinger, ridden by Chris Antley, came from just off the pace to score a 3 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $70,900 Count Fleet Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. The winning time of 1:42 1/5 for one mile 70 yards equaled the stakes record posted by Delightful Doctor last year. Militron, the favorite in the field of nine, finished second, a neck in front of Color War, who raced coupled with White Bridle as the D. Wayne Lukas-trained entry. The victory was the fourth in seven career starts for A. M. Swinger, who earned $42,540 for John H. Peace and returned $10, $4.80 and $2.60 for $2 across the board. (AP) Speed Skating East German Wins 500 and 1,000: Uwe Jens Mey of East Germany won both the 500- and the 1,000-meter races yesterday at a World Cup meet in Miola di Pine, Italy, and strengthened his lead in the overall cup standing. Mey, who leads the standing with 192 points, won the 500-meter race with a rink-record time of 36.99 seconds. Dan Jansen of the United States, who won at the same distance on Saturday, finished second with a time of 37.71. Ki Tae Bae of South Korea, second in the overall standing with 163 points, finished third at 37.94. Mey won the 1,000 in a time of 1:15.63, outdistancing Nick Thometz of the United States, who was second in 1:16.16.(AP) Track and Field Record Set in 500 Meters: Brian McAlpin, a senior at Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, ran the fastest indoor 500 meters ever by a New York City schoolboy when he won the event in 1 minute 4.31 seconds yesterday at the West Point Track and Field meet in the Army field house. The previous best by a city schoolboy was the 1:04.8 posted by Alfonso Averhart of Bishop Loughlin in 1982. McAlpin's time is the 12th fastest ever in the country.

title: Sports of The Times; The Scoop On Embry's Hands
description: I HAVEN'T checked it out completely, but if the Cleveland Cavaliers, who currently sport the best record in the National Basketball Association, go on to win the league title, then Wayne Embry will hold a singular distinction.

title: Don't Humiliate Gorbachev
description: As President Bush's aides begin their study of East-West policy options, they can safely dismiss two scenarios for the Soviet side of Europe in this century.

title: Jill H. Pace Is the Bride Of Dr. Albert Harris Teich
description: At the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Washington, Jill H. Pace, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Pace of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Albert Harris Teich, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Teich of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Gerald Serotta officiated.

title: Israel Releases a Major Palestinian From Detention in the West Bank
description: The army released a leading Palestine Liberation Organization figure from prison today in an apparent attempt to promote the growth of a local Palestinian leadership that might one day enter negotiations with Israel.

title: Agency to Vote on Capping A.T.&T. Rates
description: The Federal Communications Commission is expected to vote today on a proposal that would place a cap on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance rates but would allow A.T.&T. to earn greater profits if it can cut its operating costs.

title: From Bad to Worse on S & L's
description: The Bush Administration, barely a week old, has already managed to throw more confusion into the savings and loan crisis. Incredibly, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady has floated the notion of a ''user fee'' on bank and savings accounts to pay for insolvent savings and loan institutions. Predictably, he scared anxious S & L depositors, who started pulling their money out, and angered depositors everywhere. An already bad situation has now become worse.

title: Chicago Journal; For Men Who Do Time, Eternal Love Is Message
description: Just before lockup at the Cook County Jail, the 54 men in Cell Block J2 - convicted murderers, rapists, drug dealers and thieves - got down on their knees, huddled around a tiny woman in minister's robes and repeated after her: ''Our Father who art in heaven . . . . ''

title: Serb-Croat Rivalry Is Again Shaking Yugoslavia
description: Yugoslavia's oldest and most divisive problem, almost dormant for nearly two decades, is vibrating once again. Croats are expressing fears about Serbian strivings for dominance.

title: Koch's Preliminary Plan Envisions 1,200 Layoffs
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that his preliminary spending plan for the coming fiscal year calls for the layoff of 1,200 municipal employees and significant attrition in New York City's uniform services.

title: 9 Canadians Die in Plane Crash
description: A military transport carrying 18 Canadian Forces soldiers to the United States Army's ''Brim Frost'' exercises crashed late today at Fort Wainwright, killing at least nine aboard, the authorities said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: 48 on Bus Die in Ivory Coast
description: A bus packed with schoolchildren toppled into a culvert during a thunderstorm on Saturday, and news reports said today that 48 passengers were killed and 75 injured. The storm had filled the culvert with water and many of the victims drowned, reports said.

title: Rights Group Reports 1,000 Iran Executions
description: Amnesty International said today that more than 1,000 political prisoners had been shot or hanged in Iran over the past six months in the biggest wave of executions there since the early 1980's.

title: Howard R. Silberthau And Dr. Mandel Wed
description: The wedding of Dr. Susan Jennifer Mandel, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Mandel of Tenafly, N.J., to Howard Robert Silberthau, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Silberthau of Tenafly, took place yesterday in Hackensack, N.J. Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Cantor Kurt Silbermann performed the ceremony at the Stony Hill Inn.

title: School Basketball; Anderson Scores 39 but Molloy Loses
description: Christ the King won the King of Bluegrass tournament in Louisville, Ky., over the Christmas Holidays and the Tournament of Champions in Springfield, Mo., earlier this month. But the team scored one of its biggest victories of the season yesterday by routing Archbishop Molloy, 79-61, in a game carried nationally over the SportsChannel America cable network.

title: U.S. to Press Monitoring of Cuba
description: At the annual meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission opening in Geneva on Monday, the Bush Administration will urge the panel to continue public monitoring of Cuba's human rights record for another year, American officials say.

title: Sports world Specials; Air Apparent
description: For someone who has set 79 ballooning records, Julian Nott is having a hard time securing No. 80. That's because the 44-year-old British adventurer has an ambitious goal. He wants to become the first person to fly a balloon nonstop around the world.

title: 'Working Girl' Receives 4 Golden Globe Awards
description: ''Working Girl,'' a corporate Cinderella story, won four Golden Globe awards including the one for best comedy film, and ''Rain Man'' won two, including best dramatic film, to emerge as favorites in the race for Oscar nominations.

title: Tool Orders Rose 13.4% In December
description: Orders for American-made machine tools, bolstered by continuing strength in foreign demand, rose 13.4 percent in December, to $316.4 million, according to a report to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: The Panchen Lama Is Dead at 50; Key Figure in China's Tibet Policy
description: The Panchen Lama, Tibet's most important spiritual leader after the Dalai Lama and a crucial figure in China's policy toward the region, died Saturday night during a visit to Tibet, China announced today. He was 50 years old. The official news organizations reported that he had died of a heart attack in his residence in Shigatse, now usually spelled Xigaze, the largest city in Tibet outside the capital, Lhasa. It attributed the heart attack to fatigue resulting from the strains of presiding over the opening of an important new Buddhist shrine a week ago.

title: Carlucci Takes Job at Carlyle Group
description: Gradually the former top officials of the Reagan Administration are taking jobs elsewhere. Late last week the Carlyle Group, a merchant bank based in Washington, said the former Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci, had been named a vice chairman.

title: Black History Month
description: In observance of Black History Month, the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, is to present in February a series of programs on the cultural diversity of Africans and their descendants in the United States and the Caribbean. The series is to begin with ''Jazz Celebration,'' a concert by the Composers Workshop Ensemble, on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. Suggested admission is $3.50 for adults, $1.50 for children. Information: 769-5315.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, a provider of local telephone service, elected John T. Dunbar senior vice president, nonregulated operations.

title: FOES OF PINOCHET FEUDING OVER VOTE
description: Four months after Gen. Augusto Pinochet lost a bid to extend his presidency by eight years, the political forces that led the campaign against him are themselves divided and feuding over whom to nominate for president.

title: Energy vs. Environment: Clash on Carolina Coast
description: For 150 years, visitors have been drawn to the turbulent ocean waters and alluring beaches of the Outer Banks, the slivers of land along the North Carolina coast.

title: The News From Liberated Grenada Looks Grim
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the earnings of regional telephone companies misidentified the one that provides local service in Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas. It is the Southwestern Bell Corporation.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Machines Counter Lack of Real Snow
description: LEAD: TEN years ago, with a snow drought like the one the Northeast has had this winter, most of the ski areas could not operate. This year, almost all ski areas in the region are open.

title: TV Notes
description: Classroom Commercials

title: In Test of Talent, L.S.U. Freshman Has Right Answers
description: ABOUT 20 minutes after his team defeated Georgetown, 82-80, in the Superdome, Chris Jackson sat in a crowded room answering questions about his 26-point performance and L.S.U.'s exhilarating upset victory.
