title: Remeber, Carnivores, One Man's Meat Is Another Man's Poison; Plenty Is All Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Ballet; Multifaceted 'Interplay'
description: By JACK ANDERSON

title: Heartland Express reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Abercrombie & Fitch Chief Sees Growth Opportunities
description: Sally Frame-Kasaks yesterday was named the president and chief executive of Abercrombie & Fitch, the fashion and sports apparel chain owned by the Limited Inc. Mrs. Kasaks, 44, was previously the president of Talbots Inc., the classic New England apparel retailer, and before that the president of the Ann Taylor Inc. fashion chain.

title: Terminal Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included a $144,000 tax benefit.

title: Kaman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ancient Irish Tomb Found Aligned With Sun
description: AN Irish tomb, built centuries before Stonehenge or the Pyramids of Egypt, appears to be the oldest known structure with an astronomical function, according to an analysis published last week in the British journal Nature.

title: Boeing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Farley May Seek A Loan Change
description: Farley Industries said it might try to refinance or modify its bank credit agreements so that it would not have to sell some assets of West Point-Pepperell Inc. if it acquired the company.

title: New Theater League Head
description: Cy Feuer has been named president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, the trade association of Broadway producers, theater owners and presenters. Mr. Feuer, who has been the league's executive vice president, succeeds Richard Barr, who died Jan. 8.

title: Afghan Factions Squabble in Rebel-Held City
description: In the main square of this town of about 10,000, the shopkeepers hawk oranges, old clothes and Russian-printed cloth. Afghan men sit in an open-air tea shop, their Kalashnikovs at their sides.

title: Consolidated Freightways reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lectec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Scientific-Atlanta Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Music; By Opera Ebony
description: Opera Ebony offered slightly more than a double bill on Sunday afternoon in Aaron Davis Hall at the City College of New York. The principal draw, for listeners interested in unusual music, was the American premiere of ''The Misunderstood Policeman,'' a one-act play by Jean Cocteau with an incidental score by Francis Poulenc. The other half of the bill was Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Medium.'' And as a prelude to the afternoon, there was a five-minute version of a Darius Milhaud miniature, ''Caramel Mou.''

title: U.S. Companies Tied to Chemical Sales
description: American and foreign businessmen shipped large quantities of chemicals needed to make poison gas to Jordan, Federal officials said today, broadening an investigation into the illegal shipment of chemicals to the Middle East. The officials said they believed that the chemicals were ultimately delivered to Iraq.

title: Greenwich Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago first quarter per share figure was not applicable because the company went public in April 1988.

title: Leslie Halliwell, 59; Wrote Guides to Film
description: Leslie Halliwell, the author of several encyclopedic guides to film, died of cancer on Jan. 21 at the Princess Alice Hospice in Surrey, England. He was 59 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This jury has overcome incredible odds. We were almost hopelessly divided. It was clear from the beginning that the only way to arrive at a verdict was to keep talking. It's not always easy to do. In the final analysis, everything we accomplished was due to a sense of humor and willingness to work together. Despite our different backgrounds, we became a family. There was an awful lot of affection in there.'' - Jeremiah Cole, jury foreman in the Joel B. Steinberg trial. [ B5:1. ]

title: Vision Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trustcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the fourth quarter loss was due to pre-tax charges of $30.4 million associated with four Toledo, Ohio, commercial real estate projects and $10.3 million for an increase in the loan loss reserve.

title: First Ohio Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $2.4 million, or 54 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for federal income taxes.

title: F.C.C. Delays New Rules For A.T.&T.
description: Bowing to Congressional pressure, the Federal Communications Commission today postponed a decision on a proposal to overhaul its regulation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance business.

title: Brown's Path Clear For Leader of Party As Contender Quits
description: Former Representative James Jones withdrew today from the race for chairman of the Democratic National Committee, leaving Ronald H. Brown the only candidate and a certain winner.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Ease By KENNETH N. GILPIN
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell in very sluggish trading yesterday, as market participants took profits following last week's strong rally and assumed a defensive stance in advance of a slew of upcoming economic and political developments later in the week.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about the sentencing of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist, characterized the charges incorrectly. They included conspiracy to commit mail fraud involving more than $30 million in defaulted loans, and 11 counts of actual mail fraud involving $294,000 in defaulted loans. He was not convicted of deliberately defaulting on more than $30 million in loans.

title: Financial Corp of Santa Barara reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,031,000 for the quarter and $2,686,000 for the year, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,740,000 and an extraordinary loss of $2,428,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and included a losses from discontinued operations of $623,000 and $1,442,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest fourth quarter and year included a gain of $9.1 million from the sale of Freddie Mac preferred stock.

title: Great Lakes Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Phillips Petroleum Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for both periods of 1987 included a $50 million pre-tax charge, or $30 million after taxes, for special employee separation program. Results have also been restated for the adoption of an accounting change. The company said the adoption of FASB Statement 95 reflected a restatement of the company's capital expenditures but has no effect on the company's net income.

title: Atwood Oceanics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Richard D. Crinkley Dies at 49; Former Beaumont Theater Chief
description: Richmond Crinkley, who became the focus of intense controversy during his five years as executive director of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center in the early 1980's, died of cancer Sunday at the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, Va. He was 49 years old.

title: Sandwich Chef reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Defiance Precision Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $350,000 and $671,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Soup Stir
description: The Campbell Soup Company boasts in an ad that its soups could ''reduce the risk of heart disease.'' It neglects to mention that the soups' high sodium content could also increase that same risk. Last week, the Federal Trade Commission rightly cited Campbell's for making misleading health claims.

title: Ortega Unveils Austerity Plan For Nicaragua
description: Taking dramatic steps to shore up Nicaragua's rapidly deteriorating economy, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced a tough austerity program today. Officials said the program would slash the national budget by nearly half, requiring the discharge of up to 35,000 public employees and military personnel.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday about the news agency Wordservice International characterized it incorrectly.

title: Volunteer Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hartford Court Upholds Removal of Life Support
description: Connecticut's highest court, taking up the first major challenge to the state's right-to-die law, ruled today that the family of a comatose accident victim may legally remove the feeding tube keeping her alive.

title: Telxon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Agency Seeks Wide Changes In Zoning Plan
description: The City Planning Department yesterday proposed sweeping zoning changes intended to preserve the shape, size and nature of housing in that half of New York City where one- and two-family homes, two or three stories high, now predominate.

title: Pope Urges Catholics To Be More Active In and Out of Church
description: Pope John Paul II appealed today to Roman Catholics to become more active participants in church and social matters, but he urged greater caution in allowing lay people to perform duties that have generally been carried out by priests.

title: Florida Progress Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Andover Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAY Packaging Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Lexington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RJR Nabisco Stock Surges On U.S. Move
description: The stock of RJR Nabisco Inc. rose sharply yesterday after Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company announced an agreement with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission on the buyout firm's acquisition of RJR.

title: Hickam, Dow B Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Another Hershiser Shutout
description: Holding a microphone in front of the dais at the New York Baseball Writers dinner, Pat Cooper was working the room. With a glance at Dallas Green, the comedian wondered how long the Yankees' new manager would last in the dugout.

title: Germania Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Permian Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Comparable prior-year results were not applicable. The partnership went public in June 1987 and said its earnings turnaround was the result of higher prices for crude oil. Share earnings are in units.

title: Gibson Greetings Head Will Retire on Feb. 28
description: Thomas M. Cooney, who built Gibson Greetings Inc. into a major player and kept his job through several changes of ownership, plans to retire as chairman on Feb. 28.

title: CSC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said results for 1987 and for the first three quarters of 1988 have been restated for an accounting change.

title: Guardsman Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Full-year share earnings were restated for a 10 percent stock dividend issued in December 1988.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Maize-Products Co., Stamford, Conn., appointed Edmond G. Herve controller. He succeeds Edward P. Norris, who continues as chief financial officer.

title: McClatchy Newspapers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $14,346,000 for the quarter and $14,150,000 for the year.

title: Bush Likely to Ask Lower Capital Gains Tax
description: President Bush will almost certainly ask Congress next week to adopt a lower capital gains tax rate and a variety of other tax incentives he advocated during his election campaign, Administration officials said today.

title: University National Bank & Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Powerful New Ataris
description: NEIL Harris, for years an executive of the Atari Corporation, likes to say that the Atari and the Amiga live in the ''ghetto'' of personal computing. Users in the mainstream - that is, users of I.B.M.-compatible and Macintosh computers - prefer to pretend that Atari and Amiga do not exist, even though the machines are better in some ways, and are more cost-effective for many users.

title: Cityfed May Face A Proxy Fight
description: The Lehigh Financial Corporation, a Union, N.J., mortgage company, said it might start a proxy fight for a seat on the board of the Cityfed Financial Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Lehigh said it ''has become unsatisfied with the performance of Cityfed'' since it bought its 7.3 percent stake in the Palm Beach, Fla., banking company.

title: Perkins Family Restaurants LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: RJR Nabisco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $208,000,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $80,000,000 from early retirement of debt. Results for the latest fourth quarter included an after-tax gain of $104 million from the sale of its cereal and confectionary businesses in U.K. The company said the fourth-quarter results were adversely affected by tax provisions for the repatriation of certain foreign earnings, advisory fees and certain other expenses that were incurred in anticipation of the pending purchase of the company by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. The prior-year results included a gain on the sale of Heublein Inc. which was subtantially offset by expenses related to restructuring activities and the early retirement of high interest debt.

title: United New Mexico Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Black & Decker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: Latest quarter included a tax credit of $6.3 million, or 11 cents a share. Year-ago quarter included a tax credit of $6 million, or 10 cents a share. The company said its latest first quarter results included a provision for the voluntary recall of its spacemaker plus thermal carafe coffeemakers but it did not give a dollar amount of the provision.

title: Koch Warns of Sharp Reductions In Workers if Cuomo Plan Stands
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch, pursuing a strategy to place the blame for New York City's budget troubles on Albany, said yesterday that he would have to cut 12,000 jobs from the municipal payroll, severely affecting many city agencies, if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed state budget was not changed.

title: Three Elected To Football Hall
description: Matt Hazeltine, once a star linebacker for the San Francisco 49ers; Jack Green, the captain of Army's 1945 team, and Joe Aillet, a longtime coach at Louisiana Tech, were elected posthumously yesterday to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame.

title: Newell Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISI Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Friday, about the Grumman Corporation, misstated the size of its work force reduction. The company will cut 3,100 jobs.

title: Mylan Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Koch's Plan for Staff Cuts Is Assailed
description: Officials said yesterday that New Yorkers would see fewer police officers and firefighters on the city's streets - streets that would be dirtier - if the city imposed the stringent financial plan envisioned by Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: 57th St. Loc., 2 TVs/Rm., $400 a Night
description: Reflecting the voracious appetite of foreign investors for Manhattan real estate, developers backed by $300 million from Japan are planning a new East 57th Street hotel that will vie for the distinction of being New York's most luxurious, and will charge more than $400 a night for a single room.

title: Italy Embarks on Bold Effort To Save Fabled City of Venice From Threatening Tides
description: IN the Bible, Moses parted the waters. In Venice, Moses intends to stop them cold.

title: INSIDE
description: Combating Global Warming Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d urged an international effort to counter the threat of global warming caused by pollution. Page C7. Prison for Ex-Olympian Bruce Kimball, an Olympic silver medalist in diving in 1984, was sentenced to 17 years for drunken driving that killed two teen-agers and injured three others. Page B7. House Survey on Raise Speaker Jim Wright is surveying House members to determine whether to vote on the 50 percent Congressional pay increase. Page A19.

title: First Federal Savings of Monana reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wesbanco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WRIGHT ASKS VIEWS OF HOUSE ON RAISE
description: The fate of the 50 percent Congressional pay increase may be decided in an anonymous survey of the 435 members of the House of Representatives.

title: In New York, School Deficits Called Routine
description: An increasing number of New York City's local school districts have regularly overspent their budgets and the central Board of Education has shown a ''disturbing lack of effectiveness'' in curbing the excessive spending, said a report by the State Comptroller's office.

title: American Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $900,000 loss for the quarter and income of $39,200,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $24,300,000 and $20,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest quarter and year reflected restructuring charges of $44,000,000 and $52,000,000, respectively. The company said prior year results are restated for an accounting change. The comany said the latest quarter earnings benefited by a $2,000,000, or 2 cents a share, by higher exchange rates for foreign currencies; for the year, the benefit was $22,000,000, or 23 cents a share. The company said in 1987, Taylor Food Products Inc. and certain components of Pumps and Valves (subsidiaries of Gallaher Ltd.) were sold and the company announced plans to discontinue operations and dispose of Sunshine Biscuits Inc., Pinkerton's Inc. and the Andrew Jergens Company. Accordingly, results of these operations were separately classified. The estimated net gain on the disposition of these companies was deferred at Dec. 31, 1987, until the sales were completed. During 1988, the company sold Sunshine Biscuits, Pinkerton's, and Andrew Jergens, the remaining components of Pumps and Valves and W. R. Case & Sons Cutlery Company. Proceeds from the sale of these companies approximated $648 million and resulted in a net gain of approximately $58 million. This gain, partly offset by losses from operations of discontinued subsidiaries, resulted in income of $39 million for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1988. The latest and year-ago periods all included results of operations since dates of acquisition of the distilled spirits business of National Distillers and Chemical Corporation (acquired May 1987) and ACCO World Corporation (acquired August 1987) as well as certain subsidiaries purchased from E-II Holdings Inc. (acquired February 1988).

title: Seahawks Lose General Manager
description: Mike McCormack, the Seattle Seahawks' president and general manager for the past six years, is leaving the team, the new owner, Ken Behring, announced tonight.

title: Centerbank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY President Bush will be urged to approve an increase in Federal deposit insurance premiums paid by banks and other lending institutions as a means to rescue troubled savings and loan institutions, Administration officials said. They backed away from a proposal for a fee on deposits. [ Page A1. ] President Bush will almost certainly ask Congress to adopt a lower capital gains tax rate and a variety of other tax incentives, Administration officials said. [ A17. ] Top officials of the Justice Department and the F.B.I. knew of the huge undercover investigation of the commodities markets from the start and approved of the investigators' techniques, Federal officials said. [ D2. ] Americans' after-tax incomes increased 3.8 percent last year, with some of the extra money going to raise the nation's personal savings rate from the 40-year low of a year before. [ D7. ] The F.C.C. bowed to Congressional pressure and postponed its overhaul of the regulation of A.T.& T.'s long-distance business. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Polaroid will buy back $1.1 billion of its stock, financing the move in part by selling a block of stock to a private investor group. The plans are part of Polaroid's anti-takeover defense. [ D1. ] Salomon Brothers suffered another round of defections, as four members of its ''junk bond'' department, including the head trader, resigned to join Wasserstein, Perella. [ D1. ] Global Motors, the Yugo importer, filed for bankruptcy protection. The Yugoslav manufacturer asked the court for permission to operate Global while it is being reorganized. [ D1. ] The family that controls 90 percent of U-Haul is feuding, even as the truck-rental company enjoys a turnaround. Some members of the Shoen family are suing the family-led management. [ D1. ] A combative car dealer became president of the National Automobile Dealers Association. [ D6. ] United Cable and United Artists Communications ended their merger agreement but said they would try again. [ D21. ] Detroit's two daily newspapers will merge their business operations on Monday, their owners said. [ D21. ] American Brands' Franklin Life Insurance will sell one unit to GeorgiaUS for about $440 million in cash. [ D5. ] Archer-Daniels-Midland agreed to buy a million additional shares of Illinois Central's stock for $13.50 a share. [ D4. ] New World Entertainment has hired investment bankers to find a backer for its troubled motion picture business. [ D4. ] MARKETS Stock prices rose, and for a change the broad market did better than the Dow Jones industrial average, which closed up 1.25 points, at 2,324.11. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell in very sluggish trading, as market participants took profits following last week's strong rally. [ D17. ] The dollar slipped, giving up part of the gains achieved on Friday. Gold prices edged down. [ D15. ] Fear of frost in Florida helped touch off a rally of futures prices for frozen concentrated orange juice on the Cotton Exchange in New York. [ D15. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S., West Germany and Japan will have to act to reduce trade imbalances, Treasury Under Secretary Mulford said. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Publishers Clearing House will announce tonight the winner of its yearly sweepstakes. Advertising. [ D1. ] Jewelry retailing is undergoing a round of restructuring and consolidation. David Cornstein, president and chief executive of Finlay, discusses the changes. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Texaco Inc.'s settlement with Carl C. Icahn does little for many individual or institutional investors. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Bush, but Not Reagan, Is Out of North Trial
description: President Bush will not testify at the criminal trial of Oliver L. North, but former President Reagan may be asked to appear and parts of his personal diary could be used as evidence, the Federal judge in the case ruled today.

title: Xicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New World Seeks a Backer
description: New World Entertainment Ltd., one of a number of Hollywood studios to encounter financial difficulties in recent years, said today that it had hired investment bankers to find a backer for its troubled motion picture business.

title: Heritage Financial Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People: BASKETBALL; Smith Out 6 Days
description: The Sacramento guard Derek Smith was suspended for six days yesterday following what Kings officials described as a ''verbal confrontation'' with Coach Jerry Reynolds. Bill Stevens, the Kings' assistant director of publicity, said that Smith's confrontation with Reynolds took place during a team meeting yesterday in Milwaukee. The Kings are scheduled to play the Bucks tonight. Stevens said he didn't know what was said by the two men. He said Smith was suspended with pay and would be returning to Sacramento. Smith will miss four games. Smith, in his seventh season, has been bothered by a bad left knee and has missed 11 games this season. He was dropped from the Kings' starting lineup after 20 games. (AP)

title: President to Succeed Roderick in USX Job
description: The USX Corporation said yesterday that Charles A. Corry, its president, would succeed David M. Roderick as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Roderick retires on May 31 at age 65.

title: Let Magnetic Levitation Trains Help Cure U.S. Economic Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Northwest Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,195,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Aristotle, Tolstoy, Donald Duck, Beast Literature
description: A debate now raging in our colleges and universities concerns the kind of general education that all students, no matter what their specific interests, ought to receive in college. On one side are demands for a coherent ''core'' program, centered on a canon of great books and required courses in the traditions of the West. On the other side are arguments that deny that a canon exists or can be formed.

title: BUSH STAFF BACKS RISE IN PREMIUMS PAID BY BANKERS
description: Senior Administration officials said today that they would urge President Bush to approve an increase in Federal deposit insurance premiums paid by banks and other lending institutions to rescue troubled savings and loan institutions and to back away from a proposal for a fee on savings deposits.

title: Curt George Segeler, Scoutmaster, 88
description: Curt George Segeler, a retired chemical engineer and a Boy Scout leader for almost 66 years, died of cancer on Jan. 22. He was 88 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Hanna, M A Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-recurring charges of $8,400,000. The company said share earnings have been restated to reflect the 3-for- 2 stock split effective Oct. 17, 1988.

title: Cytogen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax writeoffs of $2,885,000 for the quarter and $3,452,000 for the year.

title: Ponce Federal Bank FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A graph on Thursday depicting rainfall trends in the United States, with an article about climate trends over the last century, appeared with a section omitted and a repetition in its place. A correct version of the graph is printed today on page C4.

title: Indian Leader Charges 'Rampant Graft'
description: One of the nation's best-known Indian leaders, Russell C. Means, told Congress today that there was ''rampant graft and corruption'' among tribal governments and in Federal programs intended to assist American Indians.

title: Cuomo Might Waive Lilco Pact Condition
description: In a move that could clear the way for a Shoreham settlement, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is considering dropping his insistence that the State Legislature ratify a key provision of the plan.

title: Cape Cod Bank & Trust Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included a gain of $436,946, or 18 cents a share, on the termination of the bank's pension plan.

title: New Technology From Du Pont
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it had developed proprietary technology for compounds that in some cases can replace fully halogenated chlorofluorocarbons, which are used to service refrigeration and air-conditioning equipment. Du Pont said the three-component blends have an ozone-depletion potential about 97 percent less than that of chlorofluorocarbon-12, one of the products suspected of depleting the earth's ozone layer.

title: Great Lakes Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dawson Geophysical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: A. M. E. Inc., Burbank, Calif., said its employee stock ownership plan was considering making an offer to buy the company, which earlier agreed to be acquired for $13.75 a share by AOAG Inc.

title: 200 Tickets for a Broadway Show Sell for a Song
description: ''Don Giovanni'' came to Broadway yesterday -and so did''Aida,'' ''La Boheme,'' ''Faust,'' ''Tosca,'' ''Rigoletto,'' ''Tannhauser'' and ''Gianni Schicchi.'' And so did ''Gilligan's Island.''

title: Mosinee Paper Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Jan. 18 misidentified the organization with which David Goldstein is affiliated. He studied the energy efficiency of large appliances for the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: Commonwealth Energy Sysem reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago fourth quarter included a writeoff of $702,000 from a federal energy regulatory commission settlement. Fiscal 1988 included a writeoff of $3.7 million from a federal energy regulatory commission settlement.

title: F.C.C. Licensing Plan
description: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed putting into place a lottery system to award licenses for new AM and FM radio stations and for television stations. The system would replace its comparative hearings, in which applicants argue their qualifications. The commission said that the hearing process was too long, complex and expensive and that it had been a drain on the agency's administrative resources. It said a lottery would lower entry barriers and encourage newcomers to enter the field.

title: Adding Tools to the Kit
description: ONE of the most intriguing products at the recent Macworld exposition in San Francisco was Supercard, a prototype program from Silicon Beach Software that allows Apple Macintosh users to construct customized software. The company calls it a second-generation personal software tool kit.

title: Japanese Dancers Are Dominant In Prix de Lausanne
description: Young Japanese dancers dominated the Prix de Lausanne ballet competition that ended here Sunday, taking more than a third of the prizes in the contest, which was held in Asia for the first time in its 17-year history.

title: A 2d Polish Priest Is Found Dead
description: A pro-Solidarity priest in northeast Poland was found dead today, evidently of asphyxiation after a fire broke out in his room.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday about the pianist Barbara Nissman named the concert hall incorrectly for her recital tomorrow at 8 P.M. She is to perform at Alice Tully Hall, not Merkin Hall.

title: Fulton Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $4,800,000 gain on sales of loans and mortgage-backed securities, property and equipment, and investment securities, as well as $2,400,000 in gains from the sale of an interest rate swap in conjunction with the refinancing of certain short-term borrowings into five-year, fixed-rate borrowings. c-Included $4,900,000 gains on sales of loans and mortgage-back securities, property and equipment, and investment securities. The company said 1988 also included $3,000,000 reduction of net due to implementation of new accounting rules that required deferral of mortgage loan origination fee income and certain loan orgination costs, and the amortization of such fees and costs over the estimated lives of the related loans.

title: V.A. Penalties In Gift Inquiry
description: The Veterans Administration said it had disciplined 32 employees for conflicts of interest in accepting gifts and fees from drug companies.

title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry
description: Faced with a Federal investigation of his conduct and overt hostility from his staff, the United States Attorney in Massachusetts, Frank L. McNamara Jr., resigned today, saying, ''The work of this office is far too important to be sidetracked by any controversy.''

title: Great American First Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included pre-tax gains of $77.7 million for the quarter and $99 million for the year from the sale of Great American's holdings in Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: Auto Dealers' President Sets Stage for Change
description: Big Three automobile executives are bracing for what may well be a year of discord with the influential organization that represents their franchise dealers.

title: Cameras in the Courts: A Test in Steinberg Case
description: Whatever disagreements remain about the trial of Joel B. Steinberg, on one point there seems to be general accord: Once Hedda Nussbaum's mashed-in face appeared on the screen during her days of testimony in December, viewers could not turn away.

title: Whittaker Sees Criminal Charges
description: The Whittaker Corporation, a specialty chemical and technology concern, said it expected a Justice Department investigation to result in criminal charges against the company or one of its susidiaries. Whittaker said Justice Department lawyers had presented it with evidence suggesting that employees of a Whittaker unit had illegally paid money to a Government employee in connection with certain contracts.

title: London Journal; 'Pygmalion' Updated: Henry Higgins Was Right
description: John Honey is a kind of real-life, latter-day Henry Higgins, urging his countrymen to acknowledge that speech accents are lethal weapons in the English class war and to strike a blow for social equality by teaching everyone to speak the Queen's English.

title: Many Donors to Neediest Cases Earmark Gifts
description: To help an older person remain at home, June Bruce of Great Neck, L.I., sent $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She requested, as she has for the last 24 years, that her contribution be directed to the Community Service Society of New York.

title: Unocal and Phillips Nets Up
description: Two large oil companies, the Unocal Corporation and the Phillips Petroleum Corporation, yesterday reported strong increases in fourth-quarter earnings.

title: Iran Petrochemical Unit
description: Iran is determined to complete the petrochemical plant at Bandar Khomeini despite the disruption of construction during the Persian Gulf war. Ahmad Rahgozar, managing director of Iran's National Petrochemical Company, quoted by the Iranian press agency, said the plant could be completed for a fraction of the cost of building a new one. The plant, designed to produce 150,000 tons a year of polyvinyl chloride, was 80 percent complete when the war with Iraq forced a halt in construction.

title: Steinberg Is Guilty of First-Degree Manslaughter
description: Joel B. Steinberg was convicted of first-degree manslaughter last night in the death of Lisa Steinberg, the 6-year-old child he and Hedda Nussbaum raised in their Greenwich Village apartment.

title: Family Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 earnings were enhanced by a gain of $533,000 in the fourth quarter on a joint venture investment.

title: Brandywine Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $336,170 from petitions for refunds filed with the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

title: Salomon Suffers 'Junk Bond' Defections
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. suffered another round of defections yesterday when four members of the ''junk bond'' department, including the head trader, resigned from the firm.

title: Let Magnetic Levitation Trains Help Cure U.S. Economic Blues; Technically Practical
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA to Begin Drug Tests
description: Random drug testing for key personnel, including astronauts, will start in March at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the chief of the agency has announced.

title: To Treat the Attack of Acid Rain, Add Limestone to Water and Wait
description: IN a nascent counterattack on the effects of acid rain, American scientists and wildlife experts are increasingly bringing dead lakes and streams back to life by using the simple technique of adding limestone to the water.

title: Olympic Champion Finds Races Yet to Be Won
description: ''She just hates my airport workouts,'' Bob Kersee said yesterday, nodding toward his wife, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, whose wince seemed to prove her husband right. Once, at San Francisco International with time to kill before a flight, Bob set up five garbage cans for a hurdle drill. He wanted Jackie to practice getting her trail leg higher. ''She didn't go for that one,'' he said, and they both laughed.

title: A Correction
description: Following is a corrected version of a graph that appeared incorrectly on Thursday, Jan. 26, with an article on climate in the United States.

title: People
description: * Gavin Scotti has been appointed president of Klemtner Advertising.

title: New Robot Holds Key To Repair Of Reactors
description: IN an exacting applications of remote-control technology, engineers at the Government's Savannah River nuclear weapons plant have fabricated a computer-guided robot to detect cracks in the walls of nuclear reactors.

title: The Times Names 3 Senior Editors
description: The New York Times announced three appointments yesterday to newly created positions as senior editor and also named a group of newsroom department heads. The appointments, effective in the coming weeks, were announced by Max Frankel, the executive editor.

title: Trans Financial Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings are fully diluted and adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split payable Feb. 13.

title: Marsh & McLennan Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Devon Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that a change to the FIFO method of valuing inventories at its black dot subsidiary increased its year-ago 9 months results by $272,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: New York City Needs a Drug Czar of Its Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Excel Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Backing Seen For Globex
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which polices futures exchanges, is expected to vote Thursday to approve a proposal by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to begin the first computerized network available to futures traders around the world.

title: Hytek Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a tax credit of $154,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Sizeler Property Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ruin vs. Renewal: When $56,000 Houses Go Begging
description: Thomas and Paula Pilkington won a lottery. Their prize was their dream: the chance to buy a new, three-bedroom house for $56,000, one-third the average price of a house on Long Island. They turned it down.

title: Mutual Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in April 1988.

title: Bank of East Tennessee reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Baseball; Mets Sign Darling To Contract For 3 Years
description: The Mets resolved one of their thorny negotiating problems yesterday by reaching agreement with Ron Darling on a three-year, $5.3 million contract.

title: Altus Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $659,000. c-Net income and after a tax credit of $682,000.

title: U.S. Would Limit Doctor 'Kickbacks'
description: The Government has called for public comment on regulations intended to crack down on physicians who make large profits by referring patients to laboratories or clinics in which the doctors have a financial stake.

title: Pegeen Fitzgerald, 78, Radio Host Of Family-Style Talk Show, Dies
description: Pegeen Fitzgerald, who, with her husband, Edward, conducted a radio talk show for 42 years and pioneered the at-home radio format, died of breast cancer Monday at her Manhattan home. She stated her age as 78 and also had a home in Kent, Conn.

title: New Hampshire Savings Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter and year included an after-tax charge of $3,960,000 from an addition to loan loss reserves; the year also included an after-tax charge of $3,011,000 from merger and reorganization expenses.

title: Beatrice B. Gould, Ex-Editor, Is Dead at 90
description: Beatrice Blackmar Gould, co-editor with her husband, Bruce, of the Ladies' Home Journal from 1935 until their retirement in 1967, died of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at their home in Hopewell, N.J. She was 90 years old.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: The company said it reduced pretax earnings for the year by about $96,000,000 as a result of increases in LIFO inventory valuation reserves. LIFO reserves in 1987 were $19,000,000.

title: United Water Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
How Japanese Respond To a Cancer Diagnosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolina Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said latest fourth quarter earnings were reduced by $18.6 million as the result of a charge required by the December 1988 wholesale rate order and by a charge associated with its early retirement program. The company also said the 1988 earnings decline was due to regulatory treatment of a portion of its investment in the Harris nuclear plant and a charge of $133.7 million from retail rate orders in August. The company said the charge to its latest year earnings are one-time events and will not affect the company's dividend.

title: Firm to Acquire Crosby Associates
description: Alexander Proudfoot P.L.C., a British management-consulting firm, said it would acquire an American counterpart, Philip Crosby Associates Inc., for $9.50 a share, or $67 million. Crosby's shares soared $1.75 today, to $9.375, on the American Stock Exchange, where its 23 percent gain was the second largest of the day.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-12 A severe Nicaraguan austerity plan that cuts the national budget by almost half, was announced by President Ortega in an dramatic move to shore up the nation's rapidly deteriorating economy. Page A1

title: New G.M. Van
description: The General Motors Corporation is developing an extended version of its Chevrolet passenger van that could be used for commercial hauling, an executive vice president, Lloyd Reuss, said. But Mr. Reuss refused to comment on a report that the longer van would be introduced in the fall. Metalworking News also reported that the van would seat 17 people -two more than can be seated by the longest Ford van on the market.

title: Review/Music; Pianist's Cage and Ives
description: Stephen Drury's piano recital last Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall led off with thunderous virtuoso showpieces and then turned after the intermission to rarer American experimental music by two of this country's best-known composers, Charles Ives and John Cage.

title: For the 15th Year, Ballet in the Hands And Heart of Eliot Feld
description: Eliot Feld was ballet's favorite young upstart in 1969 when he founded his first dance company - a troupe of mostly gawky yet gifted youngsters who had gone from advanced ballet training straight into what one critic likened to the children's crusades.

title: Redmen Squander a 2d Chance
description: For nearly 30 minutes last night, St. John's seemed on the verge of pulling out of a two-game tailspin that had broken the team's momentum.

title: Finally, a Sound Plan for the Schools
description: Despite the extraordinary good will that surrounded his arrival last March, New York City's Schools Chancellor, Richard Green, has yet to mobilize widespread discontent with the school system into a force for bold reform. But after nearly a full year in office, he at last offers New Yorkers a clear picture of his hopes and dreams for the nation's largest school system.

title: Sports People: FOOTBALL; Rice Seeks Attention But Softens Remarks
description: Jerry Rice, voted the most valuable player in the Super Bowl after his 11 pass receptions for 215 yards and one touchdown helped the San Francisco 49ers to a 20-16 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals, yesterday received the booty that goes with the award, a 1989 Subaru XT6 and the m.v.p. trophy. Then the wide receiver protested at a news conference that his complaints last week about not receiving proper recognition from the news media were ''blown out of proportion.'' Rice stressed that charges of racism had been in no way implied in his critical remarks. ''I was the most valuable player,'' he said at a ceremony at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. ''I thought I deserved more coverage, but between Bill Walsh retiring as coach and stories about Joe Montana, I got lost in the shuffle. I'm a real modest guy, but I went out and played my best ball that day. It's not that I wanted all the attention. I just wanted respect for what I achieved. It surprised me that I had to say something to get attention. But it was something that had to be said.'' ''What I said won't hurt the 49ers,'' he said. ''Joe Montana and I have a good understanding, good chemistry. My complaints were not against Joe. But if he had won the m.v.p., it would have meant headlines all over the country.''

title: Sports People: FOOTBALL; Wilson Is Sentenced
description: Stanley Wilson, the Cincinnati Bengals running back who was banned from playing in the Super Bowl for violating the National Football League's substance abuse policy, appeared in court in Newport, Ky., yesterday and received an unspecified sentence on an unrelated charge of disorderly conduct. The charge related to his urinating on the sidewalk outside a northern Kentucky nightclub Jan. 5. District Judge Daniel Guidugli of Campbell County placed Wilson in a diversion program. Justin Verst, the assistant prosecutor, agreed to the defense's request for the program because the charge against Wilson involved a first-time, nonviolent offense. Verst said Wilson would probably be required to go through a counseling program and attend sessions of a drug rehabilitation program. The charge against Wilson would be dismissed upon successful completion of the diversion program, Verst said. Asked whether he thought his client would play in the N.F.L. again, Wilson's lawyer, James Kidney, replied, ''That's something that Pete Rozelle will have to decide.'' (AP)

title: Barenboim to Follow Solti At Chicago Symphony
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra yesterday announced the appointment of Daniel Barenboim as the orchestra's next music director. Mr. Barenboim, who has often appeared as a guest conductor in Chicago, will succeed Sir Georg Solti beginning with the 1991-92 season. Sir Georg has led the orchestra since 1969; he will become conductor laureate when Mr. Barenboim takes over.

title: Sports People: FIGURE SKATING; Kadavy Still Injured
description: Caryn Kadavy, who dropped out of the 1988 Olympic figure skating competition because of the flu, has withdrawn from the national championships, scheduled to begin next week in Baltimore. Kadavy, who was regarded as a co-favorite with Jill Trenary, has been suffering from a stress fracture in one ankle and a pinched nerve in the other. Kadavy's coach, Charlene Guarino, said the injuries developed after she tried to come back too soon from an operation in December to remove a cyst on an ovary.(AP)

Results for 1988 included a charge of $63.8 million recorded in the third quarter to reflect additional defueling and decommissioning costs associated with the Fort St. Vrain Nuclear Plant. In addition, earnings for the full year were decreased by an equivalent of about 39 cents a share because the plant did not generate electricity in the last half of 1988. Our Towns; After Therapy, Child of Privilege Spurns Drugs

His grandfather, Ralph Bunche, the United Nations leader, was the first black to win the Nobel Prize. His father, Burton, held a high-ranking job in the Lindsay administration. His uncle, Samuel, just finished eight years running the Department of Housing and Urban Development for President Reagan.

Schering-Plough Drug Is Approved
description: The Food and Drug Administration said it had approved the use of a hormone-blocking drug made by the Schering-Plough Corporation to help slow the progress of prostate cancer. The drug, flutamide, is to be sold under the name Eulexin. The F.D.A. said a National Cancer Institute study found that patients taking flutamide in combination with leuprolide - a drug already on the United States market - survived an average of 34.9 months, or nearly 25 percent longer than patients taking leuprolide alone.

title: L.I. Suspect Sought in Five Midwest Shootings
description: People here who know Yusef Abdullah Rahman, the 20-year-old man charged Sunday in five sniper attacks in two eastern Long Island towns, describe him as a quiet, playful man who was devoutly religious. But to the police in the Middle West, Mr. Rahman was known as a devious, methodical killer.

title: Sports People: BASKETBALL; Ellison Recovering
description: An examination of Pervis Ellison's injured left knee yesterday revealed that the University of Louisville basketball star had suffered no serious damage. Dr. Rudy Ellis, the team's physician, said a special X-ray machine that can see through the knee confirmed that Ellison sprained the medial collateral ligament. Ellison is expected to be sidelined about 10 days, which would mean that he would miss four games. ''The ligament is not torn, nor is any cartilage,'' Ellis said. Ellison, the team's leading scorer and rebounder, hurt his knee after stealing a pass just before halftime Sunday in his team's 85-79 loss to Ohio State.(AP)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Mochrie Wins Playoff: Dottie Moch-rie sank a 2-foot putt for par on the fifth extra hole of the L.P.G.A. Oldsmobile Classic yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla., ending a sudden-death playoff with Beth Daniel, whose last shot lipped the cup and failed to fall. Mochrie and Daniel, both former Furman University students who starred at the school in different decades, played four holes of the playoff before officials suspended play because of darkness Sunday night at Stonebridge Golf and Country Club. They resumed play this morning on the 18th hole.(AP) SKIING Norwegian Is Winner: Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway claimed a narrow victory in the men's combined slalom yesterday but admitted he faced overwhelming odds in holding off Marc Girardelli for the gold medal at the world Alpine championships at Beaver Creek, Colo. The slalom results will be paired with Friday's downhill to determine the combined medalists, with heavier emphasis given to the downhill in computing the final standing. (AP) HORSE RACING Cordero Rides Launching to Victory: Launching, with Angel Cordero aboard, opened an early lead and then held on for a one-length victory in the $41,000 Smart Knave Handicap for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Big Mukora, the outsider in the field of six, was runner-up. The victory was the second in two starts this year for Launching, who went a mile and a sixteenth on the muddy track in 1:45 3/5 to earn $24,600 for I'll Wait Stable. Launching returned $6.60 for $2 to win.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Indiana 104, Iowa 89: Todd Jadlow made his first 18 foul shots and scored a career-high 32 points to lead No. 17 Indiana past No. 9 Iowa last night in the Big Ten Conference game at Bloomington, Ind. Jadlow, who had made just 38.5 percent of his free throws in conference play this season, finished 18 for 20 from the foul line. Iowa cut a 13-point deficit to 2 in the second half, then went more than four minutes without a field goal as Indiana pulled away. Indiana's 12th straight home victory kept the Hoosiers in first place in the Big Ten at 7-1. They are 17-5 over all. Iowa slipped to 15-4 and 3-3.(AP) UConn 104, Massachusetts 75: Cliff Robinson scored 29 points, grabbed 14 rebounds and had five steals to lead the Huskies at home. UConn (12-5) led by as many as 30 points in the second half and Massachusetts (8-11) never was able to catch up. Jim McCoy, a freshman guard, scored 27 points for Massachusetts.(AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 4, Red Wings 3: Iiro Jarvi and Walt Poddubny scored 1 minute 34 seconds apart midway through the second period last night to ignite a four-goal outburst for visiting Quebec. Glen Hanlon, the Detroit goaltender, turned aside Quebec's first 15 shots and Detroit led by 1-0 on Gerard Gallant's first-period power-play goal. But Quebec connected on four of their last seven shots in the second period to take a 4-1 lead.(AP) Blackhawks 7, Maple Lea

Here he played Beethoven's first and last Sonatas and Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition.''

Well, Stuart Millar, producer, director and co-writer with Victor Levin of ''Dream Breakers,'' seems to have remembered - but not well enough. The two-hour television movie that occupies CBS from 9 to 11 tonight is their with-it remodeling job.

The budget is in the $10 million to $12 million range. After a monthlong competition, the agency bested two other New York-based agencies, Wells, Rich, Greene and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, the incumbent, which had handled the account for four years. Saatchi's slogan for the brewer was ''Molson is Canadian beer.''

description: James A. Baker 3d will make his first solo trip abroad as Secretary of State to meet with his fellow foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in mid-February, a Bush Administration official said yesterday.

title: Robinson Nugent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $160,000 from an accounting change.

title: Rabin Alters Demand on Halt To Uprising in the Territories
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that he no longer demands an end to the Palestinian uprising as a condition for peace talks with residents of the occupied territories.

title: Looking at America
description: To go upstairs to a smallish room in the Museum of Modern Art in New York City is to see America hanging on the walls.

title: One Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $251,000. c-Net income and after a tax benefit of $508,000. d-After a gain of $1,983,000 from the early retirement of debt and a tax credit. One Bancorp said its lower earnings in 1988 were mainly due to an increase in its provision for loan losses to $23.2 million from $2.9 million in 1987. It said it also had writedowns of $11.3 million in 1988 on certain loans and a real estate development project.

title: Aceto Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First National Bank of Michigan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Group Sues to Block Gene-Transfer Study
description: A group critical of genetic research filed suit today to block the first federally approved attempt to transfer foreign genes into humans.

title: Base Ten Systems reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included a provision of $2,524,000 to cover expected losses during the disposal period of BT Telecom Inc. c-Net income

title: Article 433989 -- No Title
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, is offering through various securities dealers $900 million of indexed sinking-fund debentures due in 1999, with about $200 million of the issue reserved for foreign investors and with a significant share being bought by the Japanese. It is the first time the agency has set aside a specific portion of one of its debt financings for overseas investors.

title: Four Charges Considered
description: In convicting Joel B. Steinberg of first-degree manslaughter in the death of his adopted daughter, Lisa Steinberg, the jury in State Supreme Court last night found him guilty of the second most serious of four homicide charges they had considered.

title: Tolland Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Armstrong World Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $3.3 million from the use of lower cost LIFO inventories in the floor-coverings segment. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year included the results of American Olean Tile Co.

title: Stocks Move Ahead Again; Dow Up 1.25
description: LEAD: Stock prices rose in active trading yesterday, and for a change the broad market did better than the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Metro Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures were not applicable; bank converted to stock form on Nov. 10, 1988.

title: KEY RATES
Grenada Sunburst System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pricor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S.A.S. Increases Texas Air Holdings
description: Scandinavian Airlines System has increased its stake in the Texas Air Corporation to 7.9 percent from 6.33 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Stockholm-based airline said that it had bought an additional 624,500 Texas Air shares on the open market for prices ranging from $13.87 to $14.87 a share. Texas Air's stock slipped 12.5 cents today, to $14.875, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Wyoming National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Regional Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jefferson National Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Warring Shiite Muslim Militias Sign Truce Agreement in Lebanon
description: Leaders of Lebanon's rival Shiite Muslim militias signed a peace agreement today that they said would end a year of bitter fighting.

title: Banks of Iowa Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Idaho Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The earnings for 1987 have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Scourge of Stalinism
description: Ordinarily, there might be little to remark about the 65th birthday of a valued anti-Communist publication, The New Leader. But the anniversary fell last week as party faithful all over the world were arguing about truths revealed in the magazine's pages decades ago - that one-party power corrupts, that Stalin's purges claimed millions of innocent victims, that the fruit of Soviet central planning is stagnation.

title: After 8 Soldiers Die in Crash, Canada Pulls Out of Exercises
description: Canada pulled out of joint cold-weather military exercises with the United States today, the morning after eight of its soldiers were killed in the crash of a Canadian transport plane trying to land in icy fog at 50 degrees below zero.

title: Cuts at Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc., which said Friday that its profits had risen 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter, announced a voluntary program to trim its payroll.

title: Technology Research reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Latest 9-month share net was less than one cent.

title: Mexico Is Said to Seek Drug-Corruption Data
description: Mexico has asked Washington for files linking top Mexican law-enforcement officials to the narcotics trade, and former Secretary of State George P. Shultz responded by asking other Government departments to cooperate with the request, American officials said today.

title: Congress Still Purring as Bush Applies the Right Strokes
description: He returns their phone calls. He drops by their offices. He tells them to just call him ''George.'' He does not bash them in his speeches, as Ronald Reagan did for eight whole years and Jimmy Carter did before that. He remembers their names. He even remembers their jokes.

title: Detroit Papers' Merger Set; Opponents to Continue Fight
description: The owners of Detroit's two daily newspapers said yesterday that they would merge the business operations of their publications Monday as a result of a court decision last week that approved a waiver of antitrust law.

title: Northland Cranberries Inc reports earnings for
description: The comparable 1987 full year results are unavailable as the company began operations on Aug. 17, 1987.

title: L. H. Chamberlain, 82, Columbia Dean and Vice President
description: Dr. Lawrence Henry Chamberlain, a former dean of Columbia College and a retired vice president of Columbia University, died of a stroke Sunday at the Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula in Monterey, Calif. He was 82 years old and lived in Pacific Grove.

title: Amoskeag Bank Shares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $20 million after-tax writedown of the company's equity portfolio. The latest quarter's net is after a $4.2 million provision for an allowance for loan and lease losses. The year-ago figures are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: 2 Savings Units Closed
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today closed two insolvent savings institutions: Carver Savings and Loan Association of Escondido, Calif., and First Financial Savings and Loan Association of New Albany, Miss. The board said Calfed Inc. had acquired the deposits from Carver's Escondido office and New West Federal Savings and Loan Association had acquired Carver's San Diego deposits. It said the cost of the Carver transaction to the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation was about $57.3 million and the cost of the First Financial action would be about $4.7 million after the liquidation of assets.

title: Cable Plan For Merger Is Called Off
description: The United Cable Television Corporation and United Artists Communications Inc. said yesterday that they had called off their merger but would seek to negotiate a new deal.

title: Chess
description: After Game 6 of the quarterfinal world championship candidates match in Quebec between the Canadian grandmaster Kevin Spraggett and the Soviet grandmaster Artur Yusupov was drawn in Quebec on Sunday, the series was deadlocked at 3-3. The players will now commence two tiebreak games with Yusupov having White today and Spraggett Thursday.

title: Bond Industry Trade Group To Study Widening Access
description: The Public Securities Association, a bond industry trade group, yesterday announced the formation of a study group to consider expanding access to price information in the secondary market for Government securities.

title: Empire of America Federal Savngs Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income A sharp increase in the provision for possible loan losses ($78.6 million in 1988, compared with $30.8 million in 1987) was the principal reason for the reversal of the bank's earnings.

title: John N. Gentry, 58, a Labor Aide to Carter
description: John Newton Gentry, a lawyer and labor arbitrator who served as Under Secretary of Labor in the Carter Administration, died of cancer Friday at Washington Hospital Center in Washington. He was 58 years old and lived in Reston, Va.

title: Britain to Gradually Remove One-Third of Gibraltar Force
description: Britain will withdraw most or all of the infantry battalion stationed in Gibraltar ''in due course,'' Defense Secretary George Younger told Parliament today, reducing the 1,800-member garrison there by as many as 600 soldiers.

title: Morton Da Costa, 74, Director
description: Morton Da Costa, a director who had four Broadway hits in three years during the mid-1950's, died Sunday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in West Redding, Conn.

title: Central Louisiana Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Music; Baroque by Stravaganza
description: La Stravaganza, a Baroque chamber orchestra led by Dongsok Shin, a harpsichordist, devoted its Sunday afternoon concert at Holy Trinity Church to music of the English Baroque. The program was dominated, as was the era in question, by a transplanted German, George Frideric Handel. There was also music by William Boyce and Thomas Arne.

title: First Bank System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses on investment security transactions of $501.9 million for the quarter and $497.4 million for the year. c-Net income and included a gain of $2.2 million for the quarter and a loss of $8.8 million for the year.

title: Review/Recital; Diverse Array of Songs
description: It was toward the end of Mary Ann Hart's program of songs Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall that one began to see clearly what makes Ms. Hart a special singer. In two groups of American songs - several comic, some sentimental, some bold and nostalgic, one new and Manhattan-in-the-80's neurotic - she proved herself a master of timing, diction and interplay with the audience. In a word, she knows how to sell a song.

title: Santa Fe Energy Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $14,500,000 special charges from the scheduled sale of marginal properties and a $1,900,000 charge relating to the relocation of administrative activities from Amarillo, Texas, to Houston.

title: Careers: An Unusual Technology Program
description: COURSES in telecommunications and computer science are readily available, but master's programs that combine the two often-overlapping areas are few, says Dr. Ivan T. Frisch of the Center for Advanced Technology in Telecommunications at Polytechnic University.

title: EAST BLOC GIVES FIRST ARMS TALLY
description: The Warsaw Pact today published its first detailed breakdown of troops and weapons in Europe, intending to show that while each side has its advantages, East and West are about evenly matched in overall military strength.

title: LCS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $24,000.

title: Yugoslav Military Warns Feuding Politicians
description: The military issued a stern warning today to politicians who ''are pushing our Yugoslav ship toward the rocks of catastrophe.''

title: Bridge
description: Diplomats must have determination and stamina. Exemplifying this in the World Team Olympiad last October in Venice was Alberto Calvo, Panama's Ambassador to Japan. He played every one of the 540 deals in the qualifying stage, at a steady rate of 60 a day. Two of his teammates, Jeff Hand and John Maduro, were put to the same test, and a fourth, Gerry Cooklin, played 520. They must have been very tired at the end. Most of the teams they opposed had three pairs, making a 40-deals-a-day schedule possible.

title: Andal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.M. Saturn Dealers
description: A group of 26 men Sunday became the first franchised dealers for the General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary. The 26 dealers, based in large automobile-selling markets in 11 states, are the first of about 90 dealers who will begin selling Saturn cars in the fall of 1990, said Donald Hudler, Saturn's vice president for sales, service and marketing. Mr. Hudler estimated that each of the dealers invested $2 million to $4 million to establish a new franchise.

title: Inquiry on Commodities Is Defended by Officials
description: Federal officials said today that top officials of the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation knew of the huge undercover investigation of the commodities markets from the start and had approved of the investigators' techniques.

title: Unocal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter a $98,000,000 after-tax gain on the sale of the company's downtown Los Angeles headquarters property; the year included a $456,000,000 gain from an accounting change. Latest-year results included a $341,000,000 charge from writedown of certain company assets, a $33,000,000 aftertax refund for overpayment of windfall profit tax, and a $13,000,000 gain from the settlement of certain pension obligations.

title: Chinese-Soviet Detente: Not to Be Feared
description: The visit of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to Beijing this Thursday will mark another milestone in a Chinese-Soviet rapprochement that is unfolding with little fanfare and insufficient scrutiny - even as it redraws the political landscape of Asia.

title: Importer of Yugo Seeks Protection
description: Global Motors Inc., the American importer of the Yugo, filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy law yesterday, and the car's Yugoslav manufacturer petitioned the court for permission to operate Global while it is being reorganized.

title: Jackson's Half Brother Is Guilty in a Stabbing
description: A mistrial was declared Saturday on murder and conspiracy charges against Noah Robinson, a Chicago businessman and a half brother of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, after a jury convicted him of being an accessory in the stabbing of a gangland murder witness.

title: Article 492589 -- No Title
description: Moving to protect itself against an unwanted takeover, the Polaroid Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back $1.1 billion worth of its own stock, and that it would finance the move in part by selling a large block of stock to a private investor group.
